10136-8{_}514{_}The still-room was formerly much more in vogue than at present;     for in days of "auld lang syne," the still was in constant     requisition for the supply of sweet-flavoured waters for the     purposes of cookery, scents and aromatic substances used in the     preparation of the toilet, and cordials in cases of accidents     and illness.
10136-8{_}515{_}There are some establishments, however, in which     distillation is still carried on, and in these, the still-room     maid has her old duties to perform.
10136-8{_}516{_}In a general way, however,     this domestic is immediately concerned with the housekeeper.
10136-8{_}517{_}For     the latter she lights the fire, dusts her room, prepares the     breakfast-table, and waits at the different meals taken in the     housekeeper's room (_see_ 58).
10136-8{_}518{_}A still-room maid may learn a     very great deal of useful knowledge from her intimate connection     with the housekeeper, and if she be active and intelligent, may     soon fit herself for a better position in the household.
10136-8{_}519{_}60.
10136-8{_}520{_}IN THE EVENING, the housekeeper will often busy herself with the necessary preparations for the next day's duties.
10136-8{_}521{_}Numberless small, but still important arrangements, will have to be made, so that everything may move smoothly.
10136-8{_}522{_}At times, perhaps, attention will have to be paid to the breaking of lump-sugar, the stoning of raisins, the washing, cleansing, and drying of currants, &c. The evening, too, is the best time for setting right her account of the expenditure, and duly writing a statement of moneys received and paid, and also for making memoranda of any articles she may require for her storeroom or other departments.
10136-8{_}523{_}Periodically, at some convenient time,--for instance, quarterly     or half-yearly, it is a good plan for the housekeeper to make an     inventory of everything she has under her care, and compare this     with the lists of a former period; she will then be able to     furnish a statement, if necessary, of the articles which, on     account of time, breakage, loss, or other causes, it has been     necessary to replace or replenish.
10136-8{_}524{_}61.
10136-8{_}525{_}IN CONCLUDING THESE REMARKS on the duties of the housekeeper, we will briefly refer to the very great responsibility which attaches to her position.
10136-8{_}526{_}Like "Caesar's wife," she should be "above suspicion," and her honesty and sobriety unquestionable; for there are many temptations to which she is exposed.
10136-8{_}527{_}In a physical point of view, a housekeeper should be healthy and strong, and be particularly clean in her person, and her hands, although they may show a degree of roughness, from the nature of some of her employments, yet should have a nice inviting appearance.
10136-8{_}528{_}In her dealings with the various tradesmen, and in her behaviour to the domestics under her, the demeanour and conduct of the housekeeper should be such as, in neither case, to diminish, by an undue familiarity, her authority or influence.
10136-8{_}529{_}_Note_.--It will be useful for the mistress and housekeeper to know the best seasons for various occupations connected with Household Management; and we, accordingly, subjoin a few hints which we think will prove valuable.
10136-8{_}530{_}As, in the winter months, servants have much more to do, in consequence of the necessity there is to attend to the number of fires throughout the household, not much more than the ordinary every-day work can be attempted.
10136-8{_}531{_}In the summer, and when the absence of fires gives the domestics more leisure, then any extra work that is required, can be more easily performed.
10136-8{_}532{_}The spring is the usual period set apart for house-cleaning, and removing all the dust and dirt, which will necessarily, with the best of housewives, accumulate during the winter months, from the smoke of the coal, oil, gas, &c. This season is also well adapted for washing and bleaching linen, &c., as, the weather, not being then too hot for the exertions necessary in washing counterpanes, blankets, and heavy things in general, the work is better and more easily done than in the intense heats of July, which month some recommend for these purposes.
10136-8{_}533{_}Winter curtains should be taken down, and replaced by the summer white ones; and furs and woollen cloths also carefully laid by.
10136-8{_}534{_}The former should be well shaken and brushed, and then pinned upon paper or linen, with camphor to preserve them from the moths.
10136-8{_}535{_}Furs, &c., will be preserved in the same way.
10136-8{_}536{_}Included, under the general description of house-cleaning, must be understood, turning out all the nooks and corners of drawers, cupboards, lumber-rooms, lofts, &c., with a view of getting rid of all unnecessary articles, which only create dirt and attract vermin; sweeping of chimneys, taking up carpets, painting and whitewashing the kitchen and offices, papering rooms, when needed, and, generally speaking, the house putting on, with the approaching summer, a bright appearance, and a new face, in unison with nature.
10136-8{_}537{_}Oranges now should be preserved, and orange wine made.
10136-8{_}538{_}The summer will be found, as we have mentioned above, in consequence of the diminution of labour for the domestics, the best period for examining and repairing household linen, and for "putting to rights" all those articles which have received a large share of wear and tear during the dark winter days.
10136-8{_}539{_}In direct reference to this matter, we may here remark, that sheets should be turned "sides to middle" before they are allowed to get very thin.
10136-8{_}540{_}Otherwise, patching, which is uneconomical from the time it consumes, and is unsightly in point of appearance, will have to be resorted to.
10136-8{_}541{_}In June and July, gooseberries, currants, raspberries, strawberries, and other summer fruits, should be preserved, and jams and jellies made.
10136-8{_}542{_}In July, too, the making of walnut ketchup should be attended to, as the green walnuts will be approaching perfection for this purpose.
10136-8{_}543{_}Mixed pickles may also be now made, and it will be found a good plan to have ready a jar of pickle-juice (for the making of which all information will be given in future pages), into which to put occasionally some young French beans, cauliflowers, &c.  In the early autumn, plums of various kinds are to be bottled and preserved, and jams and jellies made.
10136-8{_}544{_}A little later, tomato sauce, a most useful article to have by you, may be prepared; a supply of apples laid in, if you have a place to keep them, as also a few keeping pears and filberts.
10136-8{_}545{_}Endeavour to keep also a large vegetable marrow,--it will be found delicious in the winter.
10136-8{_}546{_}In October and November, it will be necessary to prepare for the cold weather, and get ready the winter clothing for the various members of the family.
10136-8{_}547{_}The white summer curtains will now be carefully put away, the fireplaces, grates, and chimneys looked to, and the House put in a thorough state of repair, so that no "loose tile" may, at a future day, interfere with your comfort, and extract something considerable from your pocket.
10136-8{_}548{_}In December, the principal household duty lies in preparing for the creature comforts of those near and dear to us, so as to meet old Christmas with a happy face, a contented mind, and a full larder; and in stoning the plums, washing the currants, cutting the citron, beating the eggs, and MIXING THE PUDDING, a housewife is not unworthily greeting the genial season of all good things.
10136-8{_}549{_}[Illustration]     CHAPTER III.
10136-8{_}550{_}ARRANGEMENT AND ECONOMY OF THE KITCHEN.
10136-8{_}551{_}62.
10136-8{_}552{_}"THE DISTRIBUTION OF A KITCHEN," says Count Rumford, the celebrated philosopher and physician, who wrote so learnedly on all subjects connected with domestic economy and architecture, "must always depend so much on local circumstances, that general rules can hardly be given respecting it; the principles, however, on which this distribution ought, in all cases, to be made, are simple and easy to be understood," and, in his estimation, these resolve themselves into symmetry of proportion in the building and convenience to the cook.
10136-8{_}553{_}The requisites of a good kitchen, however, demand something more special than is here pointed out.
10136-8{_}554{_}It must be remembered that it is the great laboratory of every household, and that much of the "weal or woe," as far as regards bodily health, depends upon the nature of the preparations concocted within its walls.
10136-8{_}555{_}A good kitchen, therefore, should be erected with a view to the following particulars.
10136-8{_}556{_}1.
10136-8{_}557{_}Convenience of distribution in its parts, with largeness of dimension.
10136-8{_}558{_}2.
10136-8{_}559{_}Excellence of light, height of ceiling, and good ventilation.
10136-8{_}560{_}3.
10136-8{_}561{_}Easiness of access, without passing through the house.
10136-8{_}562{_}4.
10136-8{_}563{_}Sufficiently remote from the principal apartments of the house, that the members, visitors, or guests of the family, may not perceive the odour incident to cooking, or hear the noise of culinary operations.
10136-8{_}564{_}5.
10136-8{_}565{_}Plenty of fuel and water, which, with the scullery, pantry, and storeroom, should be so near it, as to offer the smallest possible trouble in reaching them.
10136-8{_}566{_}[Illustration: _Fig_.
10136-8{_}567{_}1.]
10136-8{_}568{_}The kitchens of the Middle Ages, in England, are said to have     been constructed after the fashion of those of the Romans.
10136-8{_}569{_}They     were generally octagonal, with several fireplaces, but no     chimneys; neither was there any wood admitted into the building.
10136-8{_}570{_}The accompanying cut, fig.
10136-8{_}571{_}1, represents the turret which was     erected on the top of the conical roof of the kitchen at     Glastonbury Abbey, and which was perforated with holes to allow     the smoke of the fire, as well as the steam from cooking, to     escape.
10136-8{_}572{_}Some kitchens had funnels or vents below the eaves to     let out the steam, which was sometimes considerable, as the     Anglo-Saxons used their meat chiefly in a boiled state.
10136-8{_}573{_}From     this circumstance, some of their large kitchens had four ranges,     comprising a boiling-place for small boiled meats, and a     boiling-house for the great boiler.
10136-8{_}574{_}In private houses the     culinary arrangements were no doubt different; for Du Cange     mentions a little kitchen with a chamber, even in a solarium, or     upper floor.
10136-8{_}575{_}63.
10136-8{_}576{_}THE SIMPLICITY OF THE PRIMITIVE AGES has frequently been an object of poetical admiration, and it delights the imagination to picture men living upon such fruits as spring spontaneously from the earth, and desiring no other beverages to slake their thirst, but such as fountains and rivers supply.
10136-8{_}577{_}Thus we are told, that the ancient inhabitants of Argos lived principally on pears; that the Arcadians revelled in acorns, and the Athenians in figs.
10136-8{_}578{_}This, of course, was in the golden age, before ploughing began, and when mankind enjoyed all kinds of plenty without having to earn their bread "by the sweat of their brow."
10136-8{_}579{_}This delightful period, however, could not last for ever, and the earth became barren, and continued unfruitful till Ceres came and taught the art of sowing, with several other useful inventions.
10136-8{_}580{_}The first whom she taught to till the ground was Triptolemus, who communicated his instructions to his countrymen the Athenians.
10136-8{_}581{_}Thence the art was carried into Achaia, and thence into Arcadia.
10136-8{_}582{_}Barley was the first grain that was used, and the invention of bread-making is ascribed to Pan.
10136-8{_}583{_}The use of fire, as an instrument of cookery, must have been     coeval with this invention of bread, which, being the most     necessary of all kinds of food, was frequently used in a sense     so comprehensive as to include both meat and drink.
10136-8{_}584{_}It was, by     the Greeks, baked under the ashes.
10136-8{_}585{_}64.
10136-8{_}586{_}IN THE PRIMARY AGES it was deemed unlawful to eat flesh, and when mankind began to depart from their primitive habits, the flesh of swine was the first that was eaten.
10136-8{_}587{_}For several ages, it was pronounced unlawful to slaughter oxen, from an estimate of their great value in assisting men to cultivate the ground; nor was it usual to kill young animals, from a sentiment which considered it cruel to take away the life of those that had scarcely tasted the joys of existence.
10136-8{_}588{_}At this period no cooks were kept, and we know from Homer that     his ancient heroes prepared and dressed their victuals with     their own hands.
10136-8{_}589{_}Ulysses, for example, we are told, like a     modern charwoman, excelled at lighting a fire, whilst Achilles     was an adept at turning a spit.
10136-8{_}590{_}Subsequently, heralds, employed     in civil and military affairs, filled the office of cooks, and     managed marriage feasts; but this, no doubt, was after mankind     had advanced in the art of living, a step further than     _roasting_, which, in all places, was the ancient manner of     dressing meat.
10136-8{_}591{_}65.
10136-8{_}592{_}THE AGE OF ROASTING we may consider as that in which the use of the metals would be introduced as adjuncts to the culinary art; and amongst these, iron, the most useful of them all, would necessarily take a prominent place.
10136-8{_}593{_}This metal is easily oxidized, but to bring it to a state of fusibility, it requires a most intense heat.
10136-8{_}594{_}Of all the metals, it is the widest diffused and most abundant; and few stones or mineral bodies are without an admixture of it.
10136-8{_}595{_}It possesses the valuable property of being welded by hammering; and hence its adaptation to the numerous purposes of civilized life.
10136-8{_}596{_}Metallic grains of iron have been found in strawberries, and a     twelfth of the weight of the wood of dried oak is said to     consist of this metal.
10136-8{_}597{_}Blood owes its colour of redness to the     quantity of iron it contains, and rain and snow are seldom     perfectly free from it.
10136-8{_}598{_}In the arts it is employed in three     states,--as _cast_ iron, _wrought_ iron, and _steel_.
10136-8{_}599{_}In each of     these it largely enters into the domestic economy, and stoves,     grates, and the general implements of cookery, are usually     composed of it.
10136-8{_}600{_}In antiquity, its employment was, comparatively     speaking, equally universal.
10136-8{_}601{_}The excavations made at Pompeii     have proved this.
10136-8{_}602{_}The accompanying cuts present us with     specimens of stoves, both ancient and modern.
10136-8{_}603{_}Fig.
10136-8{_}604{_}2 is the     remains of a kitchen stove found in the house of Pansa, at     Pompeii, and would seem, in its perfect state, not to have been     materially different from such as are in use at the present day.
10136-8{_}605{_}Fig.
10136-8{_}606{_}3 is a self-acting, simple open range in modern use, and     may be had of two qualities, ranging, according to their     dimensions, from £3.
10136-8{_}607{_}10s.
10136-8{_}608{_}and £3.
10136-8{_}609{_}18s.
10136-8{_}610{_}respectively, up to £4.
10136-8{_}611{_}10s.
10136-8{_}612{_}and £7.
10136-8{_}613{_}5s.
10136-8{_}614{_}They are completely fitted up with oven,     boiler, sliding cheek, wrought-iron bars, revolving shelves, and     brass tap.
10136-8{_}615{_}Fig.
10136-8{_}616{_}4, is called the Improved Leamington Kitchener,     and is said to surpass any other range in use, for easy cooking     by one fire.
10136-8{_}617{_}It has a hot plate, which is well calculated for an     ironing-stove, and on which as many vessels as will stand upon     it, may be kept boiling, without being either soiled or injured.
10136-8{_}618{_}Besides, it has a perfectly ventilated and spacious wrought-iron     roaster, with movable shelves, draw-out stand, double     dripping-pan, and meat-stand.
10136-8{_}619{_}The roaster can be converted into     an oven by closing the valves, when bread and pastry can be     baked in it in a superior manner.
10136-8{_}620{_}It also has a large iron     boiler with brass tap and steam-pipe, round and square gridirons     for chops and steaks, ash-pan, open fire for roasting, and a set     of ornamental covings with plate-warmer attached.
10136-8{_}621{_}It took a     first-class prize and medal in the Great Exhibition of 1851, and     was also exhibited, with all the recent improvements, at the     Dublin Exhibition in 1853.
10136-8{_}622{_}Fig.
10136-8{_}623{_}5 is another kitchener, adapted     for large families.
10136-8{_}624{_}It has on the one side, a large ventilated     oven; and on the other, the fire and roaster.
10136-8{_}625{_}The hot plate is     over all, and there is a back boiler, made of wrought iron, with     brass tap and steam-pipe.
10136-8{_}626{_}In other respects it resembles Fig.
10136-8{_}627{_}4,     with which it possesses similar advantages of construction.
10136-8{_}628{_}Either maybe had at varying prices, according to size, from £5.

10136-8{_}642{_}FROM KITCHEN RANGES to the implements used in cookery is but a step.
10136-8{_}643{_}With these, every kitchen should be well supplied, otherwise the cook must not be expected to "perform her office" in a satisfactory manner.
10136-8{_}644{_}Of the culinary utensils of the ancients, our knowledge is very limited; but as the art of living, in every civilized country, is pretty much the same, the instruments for cooking must, in a great degree, bear a striking resemblance to each other.
10136-8{_}645{_}On referring to classical antiquities, we find mentioned, among household utensils, leather bags, baskets constructed of twigs, reeds, and rushes; boxes, basins, and bellows; bread-moulds, brooms, and brushes; caldrons, colanders, cisterns, and chafing-dishes; cheese-rasps, knives, and ovens of the Dutch kind; funnels and frying-pans; handmills, soup-ladles, milk-pails, and oil-jars; presses, scales, and sieves; spits of different sizes, but some of them large enough to roast an ox; spoons, fire-tongs, trays, trenchers, and drinking-vessels; with others for carrying food, preserving milk, and holding cheese.
10136-8{_}646{_}This enumeration, if it does nothing else, will, to some extent, indicate the state of the simpler kinds of mechanical arts among the ancients.
10136-8{_}647{_}[Illustration: _Fig_.
10136-8{_}648{_}6.]
10136-8{_}649{_}[Illustration: _Fig_.
10136-8{_}650{_}7.]
10136-8{_}651{_}[Illustration: _Fig_.
10136-8{_}652{_}8.]
10136-8{_}653{_}In so far as regards the shape and construction of many of the     kitchen utensils enumerated above, they bore a great resemblance     to our own.
10136-8{_}654{_}This will be seen by the accompanying cuts.
10136-8{_}655{_}Fig.
10136-8{_}656{_}6     is an ancient stock-pot in bronze, which seems to have been made     to hang over the fire, and was found in the buried city of     Pompeii.
10136-8{_}657{_}Fig.
10136-8{_}658{_}7 is one of modern make, and may be obtained     either of copper or wrought iron, tinned inside.
10136-8{_}659{_}Fig.
10136-8{_}660{_}8 is     another of antiquity, with a large ladle and colander, with     holes attached.
10136-8{_}661{_}It is taken from the column of Trajan.
10136-8{_}662{_}The     modern ones can be obtained at all prices, according to size,     from 13s.
10136-8{_}663{_}6d.
10136-8{_}664{_}up to £1.
10136-8{_}665{_}1s.
10136-8{_}666{_}67.
10136-8{_}667{_}IN THE MANUFACTURE OF THESE UTENSILS, bronze metal seems to have been much in favour with the ancients.
10136-8{_}668{_}It was chosen not only for their domestic vessels, but it was also much used for their public sculptures and medals.
10136-8{_}669{_}It is a compound, composed of from six to twelve parts of tin to one hundred of copper.
10136-8{_}670{_}It gives its name to figures and all pieces of sculpture made of it.
10136-8{_}671{_}Brass was another favourite metal, which is composed of copper and zinc.
10136-8{_}672{_}It is more fusible than copper, and not so apt to tarnish.
10136-8{_}673{_}In a pure state it is not malleable, unless when hot, and after it has been melted twice it will not bear the hammer.
10136-8{_}674{_}To render it capable of being wrought, it requires 7 lb.
10136-8{_}675{_}of lead to be put to 1 cwt.
10136-8{_}676{_}of its own material.
10136-8{_}677{_}The Corinthian brass of antiquity was a mixture of silver, gold,     and copper.
10136-8{_}678{_}A fine kind of brass, supposed to be made by the     cementation of copper plates with calamine, is, in Germany,     hammered out into leaves, and is called Dutch metal in this     country.
10136-8{_}679{_}It is employed in the same way as gold leaf.
10136-8{_}680{_}Brass is     much used for watchworks, as well as for wire.
10136-8{_}681{_}68.
10136-8{_}682{_}The braziers, ladles, stewpans, saucepans, gridirons, and colanders of antiquity might generally pass for those of the English manufacture of the present day, in so far as shape is concerned.
10136-8{_}683{_}In proof of this we have placed together the following similar articles of ancient and modern pattern, in order that the reader may, at a single view, see wherein any difference that is between them, consists.

10136-8{_}714{_}_Figs_.
10136-8{_}715{_}9 and 10 are flat sauce or _sauté_ pans, the ancient one     being fluted in the handle, and having at the end a ram's head.
10136-8{_}716{_}Figs.
10136-8{_}717{_}11 and 12 are colanders, the handle of the ancient one     being adorned, in the original, with carved representations of a     cornucopia, a satyr, a goat, pigs, and other animals.
10136-8{_}718{_}Any     display of taste in the adornment of such utensils, might seem     to be useless; but when we remember how much more natural it is     for us all to be careful of the beautiful and costly, than of     the plain and cheap, it may even become a question in the     economy of a kitchen, whether it would not, in the long run, be     cheaper to have articles which displayed some tasteful ingenuity     in their manufacture, than such as are so perfectly plain as to     have no attractions whatever beyond their mere suitableness to     the purposes for which they are made.
10136-8{_}719{_}Figs.
10136-8{_}720{_}13 and 14 are     saucepans, the ancient one being of bronze, originally copied     from the cabinet of M. l'Abbé Charlet, and engraved in the     Antiquities of Montfaucon.
10136-8{_}721{_}Figs.
10136-8{_}722{_}15 and 17 are gridirons, and 16     and 18 dripping-pans.
10136-8{_}723{_}In all these utensils the resemblance     between such as were in use 2,000 years ago, and those in use at     the present day, is strikingly manifest.
10136-8{_}724{_}69.
10136-8{_}725{_}SOME OF THE ANCIENT UTENSILS represented in the above cuts, are copied from those found amid the ruins of Herculaneum and Pompeii.
10136-8{_}726{_}These Roman cities were, in the first century, buried beneath the lava of an eruption of Vesuvius, and continued to be lost to the world till the beginning of the last century, when a peasant, in digging for a well, gradually discovered a small temple with some statues.
10136-8{_}727{_}Little notice, however, was taken of this circumstance till 1736, when the king of Naples, desiring to erect a palace at Portici, caused extensive excavations to be made, when the city of Herculaneum was slowly unfolded to view.
10136-8{_}728{_}Pompeii was discovered about 1750, and being easier cleared from the lava in which it had so long been entombed, disclosed itself as it existed immediately before the catastrophe which overwhelmed it, nearly two thousand years ago.
10136-8{_}729{_}It presented, to the modern world, the perfect picture of the form and structure of an ancient Roman city.
10136-8{_}730{_}The interior of its habitations, shops, baths, theatres, and temples, were all disclosed, with many of the implements used by the workmen in their various trades, and the materials on which they were employed, when the doomed city was covered with the lavian stream.
10136-8{_}731{_}70.
10136-8{_}732{_}AMONGST THE MOST ESSENTIAL REQUIREMENTS of the kitchen are scales or weighing-machines for family use.
10136-8{_}733{_}These are found to have existed among the ancients, and must, at a very early age, have been both publicly and privately employed for the regulation of quantities.
10136-8{_}734{_}The modern English weights were adjusted by the 27th chapter of Magna Charta, or the great charter forced, by the barons, from King John at Runnymede, in Surrey.
10136-8{_}735{_}Therein it is declared that the weights, all over England, shall be the same, although for different commodities there were two different kinds, Troy and Avoirdupois.
10136-8{_}736{_}The origin of both is taken from a grain of wheat gathered in the middle of an ear.
10136-8{_}737{_}The standard of measures was originally kept at Winchester, and by a law of King Edgar was ordained to be observed throughout the kingdom.
10136-8{_}738{_}[Illustration: _Fig_.
10136-8{_}739{_}19.]
10136-8{_}740{_}[Illustration: _Fig_.
10136-8{_}741{_}20.]
10136-8{_}742{_}Fig.
10136-8{_}743{_}19 is an ancient pair of common scales, with two basins and     a movable weight, which is made in the form of a head, covered     with the pileus, because Mercury had the weights and measures     under his superintendence.
10136-8{_}744{_}It is engraved on a stone in the     gallery of Florence.
10136-8{_}745{_}Fig.
10136-8{_}746{_}20 represents a modern     weighing-machine, of great convenience, and generally in use in     those establishments where a great deal of cooking is carried     on.
10136-8{_}747{_}71.
10136-8{_}748{_}ACCOMPANYING THE SCALES, or weighing-machines, there should be spice-boxes, and sugar and biscuit-canisters of either white or japanned tin.
10136-8{_}749{_}The covers of these should fit tightly, in order to exclude the air, and if necessary, be lettered in front, to distinguish them.
10136-8{_}750{_}The white metal of which they are usually composed, loses its colour when exposed to the air, but undergoes no further change.
10136-8{_}751{_}It enters largely into the composition of culinary utensils, many of them being entirely composed of tinned sheet-iron; the inside of copper and iron vessels also, being usually what is called _tinned_.
10136-8{_}752{_}This art consists of covering any metal with a thin coating of tin; and it requires the metal to be covered, to be perfectly clean and free from rust, and also that the tin, itself, be purely metallic, and entirely cleared from all ashes or refuse.
10136-8{_}753{_}Copper boilers, saucepans, and other kitchen utensils, are tinned after they are manufactured, by being first made hot and the tin rubbed on with resin.
10136-8{_}754{_}In this process, nothing ought to be used but pure grain-tin.
10136-8{_}755{_}Lead, however, is sometimes mixed with that metal, not only to make it lie more easily, but to adulterate it--a pernicious practice, which in every article connected with the cooking and preparation of food, cannot be too severely reprobated.--The following list, supplied by Messrs. Richard & John Slack, 336, Strand, will show the articles required for the kitchen of a family in the middle class of life, although it does not contain all the things that may be deemed necessary for some families, and may contain more than are required for others.
10136-8{_}756{_}As Messrs.
10136-8{_}757{_}Slack themselves, however, publish a useful illustrated catalogue, which may be had at their establishment _gratis_, and which it will be found advantageous to consult by those about to furnish, it supersedes the necessity of our enlarging that which we give:--                                   s.  d.    1 Tea-kettle                   6   6   1 Toasting-fork                1   0   1 Bread-grater                 1   0   1 Pair of Brass Candlesticks   3   6   1 Teapot and Tray              6   6   1 Bottle-jack                  9   6   6 Spoons                       1   6   2 Candlesticks                 2   6   1 Candle-box                   1   4   6 Knives and Forks             5   3   2 Sets of Skewers              1   0   1 Meat-chopper                 1   9   1 Cinder-sifter                1   3   1 Coffee-pot                   2   3   1 Colander                     1   6   3 Block-tin Saucepans          5   9   5 Iron Saucepans              12   0   1 Ditto and Steamer            6   6   1 Large Boiling-pot           10   0   4 Iron Stewpans                8   9   1 Dripping-pan and Stand       6   6   1 Dustpan                      1   0   1 Fish and Egg-slice           1   9   2 Fish-kettles                10   0   1 Flour-box                    1   0   3 Flat-irons                   3   6   2 Frying-pans                  4   0   1 Gridiron                     2   0   1 Mustard-pot                  1   0   1 Salt-cellar                  0   8   1 Pepper-box                   0   6   1 Pair of Bellows              2   0   3 Jelly-moulds                 8   0   1 Plate-basket                 5   6   1 Cheese-toaster               1  10   1 Coal-shovel                  2   6   1 Wood Meat-screen            30   0    The Set                  £8   11   1   72.
10136-8{_}758{_}AS NOT ONLY HEALTH BUT LIFE may be said to depend on the cleanliness of culinary utensils, great attention must be paid to their condition generally, but more especially to that of the saucepans, stewpans, and boilers.
10136-8{_}759{_}Inside they should be kept perfectly clean, and where an open fire is used, the outside as clean as possible.
10136-8{_}760{_}With a Leamington range, saucepans, stewpans, &c., can be kept entirely free from smoke and soot on the outside, which is an immense saving of labour to the cook or scullery-maid.
10136-8{_}761{_}Care should be taken that the lids fit tight and close, so that soups or gravies may not be suffered to waste by evaporation.
10136-8{_}762{_}They should be made to keep the steam in and the smoke out, and should always be bright on the upper rim, where they do not immediately come in contact with the fire.
10136-8{_}763{_}Soup-pots and kettles should be washed immediately After being used, and dried before the fire, and they should be kept in a dry place, in order that they may escape the deteriorating influence of rust, and, thereby, be destroyed.
10136-8{_}764{_}Copper utensils should never be used in the kitchen unless tinned, and the utmost care should be taken, not to let the tin be rubbed off.
10136-8{_}765{_}If by chance this should occur, have it replaced before the vessel is again brought into use.
10136-8{_}766{_}Neither soup nor gravy should, at any time, be suffered to remain in them longer than is absolutely necessary, as any fat or acid that is in them, may affect the metal, so as to impregnate with poison what is intended to be eaten.
10136-8{_}767{_}Stone and earthenware vessels should be provided for soups and gravies not intended for immediate use, and, also, plenty of common dishes for the larder, that the table-set may not be used for such purposes.
10136-8{_}768{_}It is the nature of vegetables soon to turn sour, when they are apt to corrode glazed red-ware, and even metals, and frequently, thereby, to become impregnated with poisonous particles.
10136-8{_}769{_}The vinegar also in pickles, by its acidity, does the same.
10136-8{_}770{_}Consideration, therefore, should be given to these facts, and great care also taken that all _sieves, jelly-bags,_ and tapes for collared articles, be well scalded and kept dry, or they will impart an unpleasant flavour when next used.
10136-8{_}771{_}To all these directions the cook should pay great attention, nor should they, by any means, be neglected by the _mistress of the household_, who ought to remember that cleanliness in the kitchen gives health and happiness to home, whilst economy will immeasurably assist in preserving them.
10136-8{_}772{_}73.
10136-8{_}773{_}WITHOUT FUEL, A KITCHEN might be pronounced to be of little use; therefore, to discover and invent materials for supplying us with the means of domestic heat and comfort, has exercised the ingenuity of man.
10136-8{_}774{_}Those now known have been divided into five classes; the first comprehending the fluid inflammable bodies; the second, peat or turf; the third, charcoal of wood; the fourth, pit-coal charred; and the fifth, wood or pit-coal in a crude state, with the capacity of yielding a copious and bright flame.
10136-8{_}775{_}The first may be said seldom to be employed for the purposes of cookery; but _peat_, especially amongst rural populations, has, in all ages, been regarded as an excellent fuel.
10136-8{_}776{_}It is one of the most important productions of an alluvial soil, and belongs to the vegetable rather than the mineral kingdom.
10136-8{_}777{_}It may be described as composed of wet, spongy black earth, held together by decayed vegetables.
10136-8{_}778{_}Formerly it covered extensive tracts in England, but has greatly disappeared before the genius of agricultural improvement.
10136-8{_}779{_}_Charcoal_ is a kind of artificial coal, used principally where a strong and clear fire is desired.
10136-8{_}780{_}It is a black, brittle, insoluble, inodorous, tasteless substance, and, when newly-made, possesses the remarkable property of absorbing certain quantities of the different gases.
10136-8{_}781{_}Its dust, when used as a polishing powder, gives great brilliancy to metals.
10136-8{_}782{_}It consists of wood half-burned, and is manufactured by cutting pieces of timber into nearly the same size, then disposing them in heaps, and covering them with earth, so as to prevent communication with the air, except when necessary to make them burn.
10136-8{_}783{_}When they have been sufficiently charred, the fire is extinguished by stopping the vents through which the air is admitted.
10136-8{_}784{_}Of _coal_ there are various species; as, pit, culm, slate, cannel, Kilkenny, sulphurous, bovey, jet, &c. These have all their specific differences, and are employed for various purposes; but are all, more or less, used as fuel.
10136-8{_}785{_}The use of coal for burning purposes was not known to the     Romans.
10136-8{_}786{_}In Britain it was discovered about fifty years before     the birth of Christ, in Lancashire, not tar from where     Manchester now stands; but for ages after its discovery, so long     as forests abounded, wood continued to be the fuel used for     firing.
10136-8{_}787{_}The first public notice of coal is in the reign of Henry     III., who, in 1272, granted a charter to the town of Newcastle,     permitting the inhabitants to dig for coal.
10136-8{_}788{_}It took some     centuries more, however, to bring it into common use, as this     did not take place till about the first quarter of the     seventeenth century, in the time of Charles I.
10136-8{_}789{_}A few years after     the Restoration, we find that about 200,000 chaldrons were     consumed in London.
10136-8{_}790{_}Although several countries possess mines of     coal, the quality of their mineral is, in general, greatly     inferior to that of Great Britain, where it is found mostly in     undulating districts abounding with valleys, and interspersed     with plains of considerable extent.
10136-8{_}791{_}It lies usually between the     _strata_ of other substances, and rarely in an horizontal     position, but with a _dip_ or inclination to one side.
10136-8{_}792{_}Our cut,     Fig.
10136-8{_}793{_}21, represents a section of coal as it is found in the     stratum.
10136-8{_}794{_}[Illustration: _Fig_.
10136-8{_}795{_}21.]
10136-8{_}796{_}74.
10136-8{_}797{_}TO BE ACQUAINTED WITH THE PERIODS when things are in season, is one of the most essential pieces of knowledge which enter into the "Art of Cookery."
10136-8{_}798{_}We have, therefore, compiled the following list, which will serve to show for every month in the year the   TIMES WHEN THINGS ARE IN SEASON.
10136-8{_}799{_}JANUARY.
10136-8{_}800{_}FISH.--Barbel, brill, carp, cod, crabs, crayfish, dace, eels, flounders, haddocks, herrings, lampreys, lobsters, mussels, oysters, perch, pike, plaice, prawns, shrimps, skate, smelts, soles, sprats, sturgeon, tench, thornback, turbot, whitings.
10136-8{_}801{_}MEAT.--Beef, house lamb, mutton, pork, veal, venison.
10136-8{_}802{_}POULTRY.--Capons, fowls, tame pigeons, pullets, rabbits, turkeys.
10136-8{_}803{_}GAME.--Grouse, hares, partridges, pheasants, snipe, wild-fowl, woodcock.
10136-8{_}804{_}VEGETABLES.--Beetroot, broccoli, cabbages, carrots, celery, chervil, cresses, cucumbers (forced), endive, lettuces, parsnips, potatoes, savoys, spinach, turnips,--various herbs.
10136-8{_}805{_}FRUIT.--Apples, grapes, medlars, nuts, oranges, pears, walnuts, crystallized preserves (foreign), dried fruits, such as almonds and raisins; French and Spanish plums; prunes, figs, dates.
10136-8{_}806{_}FEBRUARY.
10136-8{_}807{_}FISH.--Barbel, brill, carp, cod may be bought, but is not so good as in January, crabs, crayfish, dace, eels, flounders, haddocks, herrings, lampreys, lobsters, mussels, oysters, perch, pike, plaice, prawns, shrimps, skate, smelts, soles, sprats, sturgeon, tench, thornback, turbot, whiting.
10136-8{_}808{_}MEAT.--Beef, house lamb, mutton, pork, veal.
10136-8{_}809{_}POULTRY.--Capons, chickens, ducklings, tame and wild pigeons, pullets with eggs, turkeys, wild-fowl, though now not in full season.
10136-8{_}810{_}GAME.--Grouse, hares, partridges, pheasants, snipes, woodcock.
10136-8{_}811{_}VEGETABLES.--Beetroot, broccoli (purple and white), Brussels sprouts, cabbages, carrots, celery, chervil, cresses, cucumbers (forced), endive, kidney-beans, lettuces, parsnips, potatoes, savoys, spinach, turnips,--various herbs.
10136-8{_}812{_}FRUIT.--Apples (golden and Dutch pippins), grapes, medlars, nuts, oranges, pears (Bon Chrétien), walnuts, dried fruits (foreign), such as almonds and raisins; French and Spanish plums; prunes, figs, dates, crystallized preserves.
10136-8{_}813{_}MARCH.
10136-8{_}814{_}FISH.--Barbel, brill, carp, crabs, crayfish, dace, eels, flounders, haddocks, herrings, lampreys, lobsters, mussels, oysters, perch, pike, plaice, prawns, shrimps, skate, smelts, soles, sprats, sturgeon, tench, thornback, turbot, whiting.
10136-8{_}815{_}MEAT.--Beef, house lamb, mutton, pork, veal.
10136-8{_}816{_}POULTRY.--Capons, chickens, ducklings, tame and wild pigeons, pullets with eggs, turkeys, wild-fowl, though now not in full season.
10136-8{_}817{_}GAME.--Grouse, hares, partridges, pheasants, snipes, woodcock.
10136-8{_}818{_}VEGETABLES.--Beetroot, broccoli (purple and white), Brussels sprouts, cabbages, carrots, celery, chervil, cresses, cucumbers (forced), endive, kidney-beans, lettuces, parsnips, potatoes, savoys, sea-kale, spinach, turnips,--various herbs.
10136-8{_}819{_}FRUIT.--Apples (golden and Dutch pippins), grapes, medlars, nuts, oranges, pears (Bon Chrétien), walnuts, dried fruits (foreign), such as almonds and raisins; French and Spanish plums; prunes, figs, dates, crystallized preserves.
10136-8{_}820{_}APRIL.

10136-8{_}845{_}AUGUST.

10136-8{_}853{_}FISH.--Brill, carp, cod, eels, flounders, lobsters, mullet, oysters, plaice, prawns, skate, soles, turbot, whiting, whitebait.

10136-8{_}866{_}NOVEMBER.

10136-8{_}873{_}DECEMBER.

10136-8{_}875{_}MEAT.--Beef, house lamb, mutton, pork, venison.
10136-8{_}876{_}POULTRY.--Capons, chickens, fowls, geese, pigeons, pullets, rabbits, teal, turkeys, widgeons, wild ducks.
10136-8{_}877{_}GAME.--Hares, partridges, pheasants, snipes, woodcocks.
10136-8{_}878{_}VEGETABLES.--Broccoli, cabbages, carrots, celery, leeks, onions, potatoes, parsnips, Scotch kale, turnips, winter spinach.
10136-8{_}879{_}FRUIT.--Apples, chestnuts, filberts, grapes, medlars, oranges, pears, walnuts, dried fruits, such as almonds and raisins, figs, dates, &c.,--crystallized preserves.
10136-8{_}880{_}75.
10136-8{_}881{_}WHEN FUEL AND FOOD ARE PROCURED, the next consideration is, how the latter may be best preserved, with a view to its being suitably dressed.
10136-8{_}882{_}More waste is often occasioned by the want of judgment, or of necessary care in this particular, than by any other cause.
10136-8{_}883{_}In the absence of proper places for keeping provisions, a hanging safe, suspended in an airy situation, is the best substitute.
10136-8{_}884{_}A well-ventilated larder, dry and shady, is better for meat and poultry, which require to be kept for some time; and the utmost skill in the culinary art will not compensate for the want of proper attention to this particular.
10136-8{_}885{_}Though it is advisable that annual food should be hung up in the open air till its fibres have lost some degree of their toughness, yet, if it is kept till it loses its natural sweetness, its flavour has become deteriorated, and, as a wholesome comestible, it has lost many of its qualities conducive to health.
10136-8{_}886{_}As soon, therefore, as the slightest trace of putrescence is detected, it has reached its highest degree of tenderness, and should be dressed immediately.
10136-8{_}887{_}During the sultry summer months, it is difficult to procure meat that is not either tough or tainted.
10136-8{_}888{_}It should, therefore, be well examined when it comes in, and if flies have touched it, the part must be cut off, and the remainder well washed.
10136-8{_}889{_}In very cold weather, meat and vegetables touched by the frost, should be brought into the kitchen early in the morning, and soaked in cold water.
10136-8{_}890{_}In loins of meat, the long pipe that runs by the bone should be taken out, as it is apt to taint; as also the kernels of beef.
10136-8{_}891{_}Rumps and edgebones of beef, when bruised, should not be purchased.
10136-8{_}892{_}All these things ought to enter into the consideration of every household manager, and great care should be taken that nothing is thrown away, or suffered to be wasted in the kitchen, which might, by proper management, be turned to a good account.
10136-8{_}893{_}The shank-bones of mutton, so little esteemed in general, give richness to soups or gravies, if well soaked and brushed before they are added to the boiling.
10136-8{_}894{_}They are also particularly nourishing for sick persons.
10136-8{_}895{_}Roast-beef bones, or shank-bones of ham, make excellent stock for pea-soup.--When the whites of eggs are used for jelly, confectionary, or other purposes, a pudding or a custard should be made, that the yolks may be used.
10136-8{_}896{_}All things likely to be wanted should be in readiness: sugars of different sorts; currants washed, picked, and perfectly dry; spices pounded, and kept in very small bottles closely corked, or in canisters, as we have already directed (72).
10136-8{_}897{_}Not more of these should be purchased at a time than are likely to be used in the course of a month.
10136-8{_}898{_}Much waste is always prevented by keeping every article in the place best suited to it.
10136-8{_}899{_}Vegetables keep best on a stone floor, if the air be excluded; meat, in a cold dry place; as also salt, sugar, sweet-meats, candles, dried meats, and hams.
10136-8{_}900{_}Rice, and all sorts of seed for puddings, should be closely covered to preserve them from insects; but even this will not prevent them from being affected by these destroyers, if they are long and carelessly kept.
10136-8{_}901{_}[Illustration]     CHAPTER IV.
10136-8{_}902{_}INTRODUCTION TO COOKERY.
10136-8{_}903{_}76.
10136-8{_}904{_}AS IN THE FINE ARTS, the progress of mankind from barbarism to civilization is marked by a gradual succession of triumphs over the rude materialities of nature, so in the art of cookery is the progress gradual from the earliest and simplest modes, to those of the most complicated and refined.
10136-8{_}905{_}Plain or rudely-carved stones, tumuli, or mounds of earth, are the monuments by which barbarous tribes denote the events of their history, to be succeeded, only in the long course of a series of ages, by beautifully-proportioned columns, gracefully-sculptured statues, triumphal arches, coins, medals, and the higher efforts of the pencil and the pen, as man advances by culture and observation to the perfection of his facilities.
10136-8{_}906{_}So is it with the art of cookery.
10136-8{_}907{_}Man, in his primitive state, lives upon roots and the fruits of the earth, until, by degrees, he is driven to seek for new means, by which his wants may be supplied and enlarged.
10136-8{_}908{_}He then becomes a hunter and a fisher.
10136-8{_}909{_}As his species increases, greater necessities come upon him, when he gradually abandons the roving life of the savage for the more stationary pursuits of the herdsman.
10136-8{_}910{_}These beget still more settled habits, when he begins the practice of agriculture, forms ideas of the rights of property, and has his own, both defined and secured.
10136-8{_}911{_}The forest, the stream, and the sea are now no longer his only resources for food.
10136-8{_}912{_}He sows and he reaps, pastures and breeds cattle, lives on the cultivated produce of his fields, and revels in the luxuries of the dairy; raises flocks for clothing, and assumes, to all intents and purposes, the habits of permanent life and the comfortable condition of a farmer.
10136-8{_}913{_}This is the fourth stage of social progress, up to which the useful or mechanical arts have been incidentally developing themselves, when trade and commerce begin.
10136-8{_}914{_}Through these various phases, _only to live_ has been the great object of mankind; but, by-and-by, comforts are multiplied, and accumulating riches create new wants.
10136-8{_}915{_}The object, then, is not only to _live_, but to live economically, agreeably, tastefully, and well.
10136-8{_}916{_}Accordingly, the art of cookery commences; and although the fruits of the earth, the fowls of the air, the beasts of the field, and the fish of the sea, are still the only food of mankind, yet these are so prepared, improved, and dressed by skill and ingenuity, that they are the means of immeasurably extending the boundaries of human enjoyments.
10136-8{_}917{_}Everything that is edible, and passes under the hands of the cook, is more or less changed, and assumes new forms.
10136-8{_}918{_}Hence the influence of that functionary is immense upon the happiness of a household.
10136-8{_}919{_}77.
10136-8{_}920{_}In order that the duties of the Cook may be properly performed, and that he may be able to reproduce esteemed dishes with certainty, all terms of indecision should be banished from his art.
10136-8{_}921{_}Accordingly, what is known only to him, will, in these pages, be made known to others.
10136-8{_}922{_}In them all those indecisive terms expressed by a bit of this, some of that, a small piece of that, and a handful of the other, shall never be made use of, but all quantities be precisely and explicitly stated.
10136-8{_}923{_}With a desire, also, that all ignorance on this most essential part of the culinary art should disappear, and that a uniform system of weights and measures should be adopted, we give an account of the weights which answer to certain measures.
10136-8{_}924{_}A TABLE-SPOONFUL is frequently mentioned in a recipe, in the prescriptions of medical men, and also in medical, chemical, and gastronomical works.
10136-8{_}925{_}By it is generally meant and understood a measure or bulk equal to that which would be produced by _half an ounce_ of water.
10136-8{_}926{_}A DESSERT-SPOONFUL is the half of a table-spoonful; that is to say, by it is meant a measure or bulk equal to a _quarter of an ounce_ of water.
10136-8{_}927{_}A TEA-SPOONFUL is equal in quantity to a _drachm_ of water.
10136-8{_}928{_}A DROP.--This is the name of a vague kind of measure, and is so called on account of the liquid being _dropped_ from the mouth of a bottle.
10136-8{_}929{_}Its quantity, however, will vary, either from the consistency of the liquid or the size and shape of the mouth of the bottle.
10136-8{_}930{_}The College of Physicians determined the quantity of a drop to be _one grain_, 60 drops making one fluid drachm.
10136-8{_}931{_}Their drop, or sixtieth part of a fluid drachm, is called a _minim_.
10136-8{_}932{_}[Illustration: _Fig_.
10136-8{_}933{_}22.]
10136-8{_}934{_}Graduated class measures can be obtained at any chemist's, and     they save much trouble.
10136-8{_}935{_}One of these, containing a wine pint, is     divided into 16 oz., and the oz, into 8 drachms of water; by     which, any certain weight mentioned in a recipe can be     accurately measured out.
10136-8{_}936{_}Home-made measures of this kind can     readily be formed by weighing the water contained in any given     measure, and marking on any tall glass the space it occupies.
10136-8{_}937{_}This mark can easily be made with a file.
10136-8{_}938{_}It will be interesting     to many readers to know the basis on which the French found     their system of weights and measures, for it certainly possesses     the grandeur of simplicity.
10136-8{_}939{_}The metre, which is the basis of the     whole system of French weights and measures, is the exact     measurement of one forty-millionth part of a meridian of the     earth.
10136-8{_}940{_}78.
10136-8{_}941{_}EXCELLENCE IN THE ART OF COOKERY, as in all other things, is only attainable by practice and experience.
10136-8{_}942{_}In proportion, therefore, to the opportunities which a cook has had of these, so will be his excellence in the art.
10136-8{_}943{_}It is in the large establishments of princes, noblemen, and very affluent families alone, that the man cook is found in this country.
10136-8{_}944{_}He, also, superintends the kitchens of large hotels, clubs, and public institutions, where he, usually, makes out the bills of fare, which are generally submitted to the principal for approval.
10136-8{_}945{_}To be able to do this, therefore, it is absolutely necessary that he should be a judge of the season of every dish, as well as know perfectly the state of every article he undertakes to prepare.
10136-8{_}946{_}He must also be a judge of every article he buys; for no skill, however great it may be, will enable him to, make that good which is really bad.
10136-8{_}947{_}On him rests the responsibility of the cooking generally, whilst a speciality of his department, is to prepare the rich soups, stews, ragouts, and such dishes as enter into the more refined and complicated portions of his art, and such as are not usually understood by ordinary professors.
10136-8{_}948{_}He, therefore, holds a high position in a household, being inferior in rank, as already shown (21), only to the house steward, the valet, and the butler.
10136-8{_}949{_}In the luxurious ages of Grecian antiquity, Sicilian cooks were     the most esteemed, and received high rewards for their services.
10136-8{_}950{_}Among them, one called Trimalcio was such an adept in his art,     that he could impart to common fish both the form and flavour of     the most esteemed of the piscatory tribes.
10136-8{_}951{_}A chief cook in the     palmy days of Roman voluptuousness had about £800 a year, and     Antony rewarded the one that cooked the supper which pleased     Cleopatra, with the present of a city.
10136-8{_}952{_}With the fall of the     empire, the culinary art sank into less consideration.
10136-8{_}953{_}In the     middle ages, cooks laboured to acquire a reputation for their     sauces, which they composed of strange combinations, for the     sake of novelty, as well as singularity.
10136-8{_}954{_}79.
10136-8{_}955{_}THE DUTIES OF THE COOK, THE KITCHEN AND THE SCULLERY MAIDS, are so intimately associated, that they can hardly be treated of separately.
10136-8{_}956{_}The cook, however, is at the head of the kitchen; and in proportion to her possession of the qualities of cleanliness, neatness, order, regularity, and celerity of action, so will her influence appear in the conduct of those who are under her; as it is upon her that the whole responsibility of the business of the kitchen rests, whilst the others must lend her, both a ready and a willing assistance, and be especially tidy in their appearance, and active, in their movements.
10136-8{_}957{_}In the larger establishments of the middle ages, cooks, with the     authority of feudal chiefs, gave their orders from a high chair     in which they ensconced themselves, and commanded a view of all     that was going on throughout their several domains.
10136-8{_}958{_}Each held a     long wooden spoon, with which he tasted, without leaving his     seat, the various comestibles that were cooking on the stoves,     and which he frequently used as a rod of punishment on the backs     of those whose idleness and gluttony too largely predominated     over their diligence and temperance.
10136-8{_}959{_}80.
10136-8{_}960{_}IF, AS WE HAVE SAID (3), THE QUALITY OF EARLY RISING be of the first importance to the mistress, what must it be to the servant!
10136-8{_}961{_}Let it, therefore, be taken as a long-proved truism, that without it, in every domestic, the effect of all things else, so far as _work_ is concerned, may, in a great measure, be neutralized.
10136-8{_}962{_}In a cook, this quality is most essential; for an hour lost in the morning, will keep her toiling, absolutely toiling, all day, to overtake that which might otherwise have been achieved with ease.
10136-8{_}963{_}In large establishments, six is a good hour to rise in the summer, and seven in the winter.
10136-8{_}964{_}81.
10136-8{_}965{_}HER FIRST DUTY, in large establishments and where it is requisite, should be to set her dough for the breakfast rolls, provided this has not been done on the previous night, and then to engage herself with those numerous little preliminary occupations which may not inappropriately be termed laying out her duties for the day.
10136-8{_}966{_}This will bring in the breakfast hour of eight, after which, directions must be given, and preparations made, for the different dinners of the household and family.
10136-8{_}967{_}82.
10136-8{_}968{_}IN THOSE NUMEROUS HOUSEHOLDS where a cook and housemaid are only kept, the general custom is, that the cook should have the charge of the dining-room.
10136-8{_}969{_}The hall, the lamps and the doorstep are also committed to her care, and any other work there may be on the outside of the house.
10136-8{_}970{_}In establishments of this kind, the cook will, after having lighted her kitchen fire, carefully brushed the range, and cleaned the hearth, proceed to prepare for breakfast.
10136-8{_}971{_}She will thoroughly rinse the kettle, and, filling it with fresh water, will put it on the fire to boil.
10136-8{_}972{_}She will then go to the breakfast-room, or parlour, and there make all things ready for the breakfast of the family.
10136-8{_}973{_}Her attention will next be directed to the hall, which she will sweep and wipe; the kitchen stairs, if there be any, will now be swept; and the hall mats, which have been removed and shaken, will be again put in their places.
10136-8{_}974{_}The cleaning of the kitchen, pantry, passages, and kitchen     stairs must always be over before breakfast, so that it may not     interfere with the other business of the day.
10136-8{_}975{_}Everything should     be ready, and the whole house should wear a comfortable aspect     when the heads of the house and members of the family make their     appearance.
10136-8{_}976{_}Nothing, it may be depended on, will so please the     mistress of an establishment, as to notice that, although she     has not been present to see that the work was done, attention to     smaller matters has been carefully paid, with a view to giving     her satisfaction and increasing her comfort.
10136-8{_}977{_}83.
10136-8{_}978{_}BY THE TIME THAT THE COOK has performed the duties mentioned above, and well swept, brushed, and dusted her kitchen, the breakfast-bell will most likely summon her to the parlour, to "bring in" the breakfast.
10136-8{_}979{_}It is the cook's department, generally, in the smaller establishments, to wait at breakfast, as the housemaid, by this time, has gone up-stairs into the bedrooms, and has there applied herself to her various duties.
10136-8{_}980{_}The cook usually answers the bells and single knocks at the door in the early part of the morning, as the tradesmen, with whom it is her more special business to speak, call at these hours.
10136-8{_}981{_}84.
10136-8{_}982{_}IT IS IN HER PREPARATION OF THE DINNER that the cook begins to feel the weight and responsibility of her situation, as she must take upon herself all the dressing and the serving of the principal dishes, which her skill and ingenuity have mostly prepared.
10136-8{_}983{_}Whilst these, however, are cooking, she must be busy with her pastry, soups, gravies, ragouts, &c. Stock, or what the French call _consommé_, being the basis of most made dishes, must be always at hand, in conjunction with her sweet herbs and spices for seasoning.
10136-8{_}984{_}"A place for everything, and everything in its place," must be her rule, in order that time may not be wasted in looking for things when they are wanted, and in order that the whole apparatus of cooking may move with the regularity and precision of a well-adjusted machine;--all must go on simultaneously.
10136-8{_}985{_}The vegetables and sauces must be ready with the dishes they are to accompany, and in order that they may be suitable, the smallest oversight must not be made in their preparation.
10136-8{_}986{_}When the dinner-hour has arrived, it is the duty of the cook to dish-up such dishes as may, without injury, stand, for some time, covered on the hot plate or in the hot closet; but such as are of a more important or _recherché_ kind, must be delayed until the order "to serve" is given from the drawing-room.
10136-8{_}987{_}Then comes haste; but there must be no hurry,--all must work with order.
10136-8{_}988{_}The cook takes charge of the fish, soups, and poultry; and the kitchen-maid of the vegetables, sauces, and gravies.
10136-8{_}989{_}These she puts into their appropriate dishes, whilst the scullery-maid waits on and assists the cook.
10136-8{_}990{_}Everything must be timed so as to prevent its getting cold, whilst great care should be taken, that, between the first and second courses, no more time is allowed to elapse than is necessary, for fear that the company in the dining-room lose all relish for what has yet to come of the dinner.
10136-8{_}991{_}When the dinner has been served, the most important feature in the daily life of the cook is at an end.
10136-8{_}992{_}She must, however, now begin to look to the contents of her larder, taking care to keep everything sweet and clean, so that no disagreeable smells may arise from the gravies, milk, or meat that may be there.
10136-8{_}993{_}These are the principal duties of a cook in a first-rate establishment.
10136-8{_}994{_}In smaller establishments, the housekeeper often conducts the higher department of cooking (_see_ 58, 59, 60), and the cook, with the assistance of a scullery-maid, performs some of the subordinate duties of the kitchen-maid.
10136-8{_}995{_}When circumstances render it necessary, the cook engages to perform the whole of the work of the kitchen, and, in some places, a portion of the house-work also.
10136-8{_}996{_}85.
10136-8{_}997{_}WHILST THE COOK IS ENGAGED WITH HER MORNING DUTIES, the kitchen-maid is also occupied with hers.
10136-8{_}998{_}Her first duty, after the fire is lighted, is to sweep and clean the kitchen, and the various offices belonging to it.
10136-8{_}999{_}This she does every morning, besides cleaning the stone steps at the entrance of the house, the halls, the passages, and the stairs which lead to the kitchen.
10136-8{_}1000{_}Her general duties, besides these, are to wash and scour all these places twice a week, with the tables, shelves, and cupboards.
10136-8{_}1001{_}She has also to dress the nursery and servants'-hall dinners, to prepare all fish, poultry, and vegetables, trim meat joints and cutlets, and do all such duties as may be considered to enter into the cook's department in a subordinate degree.
10136-8{_}1002{_}86.
10136-8{_}1003{_}THE DUTIES OF THE SCULLERY-MAID are to assist the cook; to keep the scullery clean, and all the metallic as well as earthenware kitchen utensils.
10136-8{_}1004{_}The position of scullery-maid is not, of course, one of high     rank, nor is the payment for her services large.
10136-8{_}1005{_}But if she be     fortunate enough to have over her a good kitchen-maid and clever     cook, she may very soon learn to perform various little duties     connected with cooking operations, which may be of considerable     service in fitting her for a more responsible place.
10136-8{_}1006{_}Now, it     will be doubtless thought by the majority of our readers, that     the fascinations connected with the position of the     scullery-maid, are not so great as to induce many people to     leave a comfortable home in order to work in a scullery.
10136-8{_}1007{_}But we     are acquainted with one instance in which the desire, on the     part of a young girl, was so strong to become connected with the     kitchen and cookery, that she absolutely left her parents, and     engaged herself as a scullery-maid in a gentleman's house.
10136-8{_}1008{_}Here     she showed herself so active and intelligent, that she very     quickly rose to the rank of kitchen-maid; and from this, so     great was her gastronomical genius, she became, in a short space     of time, one of the best women-cooks in England.
10136-8{_}1009{_}After this, we     think, it must be allowed, that a cook, like a poet, _nascitur,     non fit_.
10136-8{_}1010{_}87.
10136-8{_}1011{_}MODERN COOKERY stands so greatly indebted to the gastronomic propensities of our French neighbours, that many of their terms are adopted and applied by English artists to the same as well as similar preparations of their own.
10136-8{_}1012{_}A vocabulary of these is, therefore, indispensable in a work of this kind.
10136-8{_}1013{_}Accordingly, the following will be found sufficiently complete for all ordinary purposes:--   EXPLANATION OF FRENCH TERMS USED IN MODERN HOUSEHOLD COOKERY.
10136-8{_}1014{_}ASPIC.--A savoury jelly, used as an exterior moulding for cold game, poultry, fish, &c. This, being of a transparent nature, allows the bird which it covers to be seen through it.
10136-8{_}1015{_}This may also be used for decorating or garnishing.
10136-8{_}1016{_}ASSIETTE (plate).--_Assiettes_ are the small _entrées_ and _hors-d'oeuvres_, the quantity of which does not exceed what a plate will hold.
10136-8{_}1017{_}At dessert, fruits, cheese, chestnuts, biscuits, &c., if served upon a plate, are termed _assiettes_.--ASSIETTE VOLANTE is a dish which a servant hands round to the guests, but is not placed upon the table.
10136-8{_}1018{_}Small cheese soufflés and different dishes, which ought to be served very hot, are frequently made _assielles volantes_.
10136-8{_}1019{_}AU-BLEU.--Fish dressed in such a manner as to have a _bluish_ appearance.
10136-8{_}1020{_}BAIN-MARIE.--An open saucepan or kettle of nearly boiling water, in which a smaller vessel can be set for cooking and warming.
10136-8{_}1021{_}This is very useful for keeping articles hot, without altering their quantity or quality.
10136-8{_}1022{_}If you keep sauce, broth, or soup by the fireside, the soup reduces and becomes too strong, and the sauce thickens as well as reduces; but this is prevented by using the _bain-marie_, in which the water should be very hot, but not boiling.
10136-8{_}1023{_}BÉCHAMEL.--French white sauce, now frequently used in English cookery.
10136-8{_}1024{_}BLANCH.--To whiten poultry, vegetables, fruit, &c., by plunging them into boiling water for a short time, and afterwards plunging them into cold water, there to remain until they are cold.
10136-8{_}1025{_}BLANQUETTE.--A sort of fricassee.
10136-8{_}1026{_}BOUILLI.--Beef or other meat boiled; but, generally speaking, boiled beef is understood by the term.
10136-8{_}1027{_}BOUILLIE.--A French dish resembling hasty-pudding.
10136-8{_}1028{_}BOUILLON.--A thin broth or soup.
10136-8{_}1029{_}BRAISE.--To stew meat with fat bacon until it is tender, it having previously been blanched.
10136-8{_}1030{_}BRAISIÈRE.--A saucepan having a lid with ledges, to put fire on the top.
10136-8{_}1031{_}BRIDER.--To pass a packthread through poultry, game, &c., to keep together their members.
10136-8{_}1032{_}CARAMEL (burnt sugar).--This is made with a piece of sugar, of the size of a nut, browned in the bottom of a saucepan; upon which a cupful of stock is gradually poured, stirring all the time a glass of broth, little by little.
10136-8{_}1033{_}It may be used with the feather of a quill, to colour meats, such as the upper part of fricandeaux; and to impart colour to sauces.
10136-8{_}1034{_}Caramel made with water instead of stock may be used to colour _compôtes_ and other _entremets_.
10136-8{_}1035{_}CASSEROLE.--A crust of rice, which, after having been moulded into the form of a pie, is baked, and then filled with a fricassee of white meat or a purée of game.
10136-8{_}1036{_}COMPOTE.--A stew, as of fruit or pigeons.
10136-8{_}1037{_}CONSOMMÉ.--Rich stock, or gravy.
10136-8{_}1038{_}CROQUETTE.--Ball of fried rice or potatoes.
10136-8{_}1039{_}CROUTONS.--Sippets of bread.
10136-8{_}1040{_}DAUBIÈRE.--An oval stewpan, in which _daubes_ are cooked; _daubes_ being meat or fowl stewed in sauce.
10136-8{_}1041{_}DÉSOSSER.--To _bone_, or take out the bones from poultry, game, or fish.
10136-8{_}1042{_}This is an operation requiring considerable experience.
10136-8{_}1043{_}ENTRÉES.--Small side or corner dishes, served with the first course.
10136-8{_}1044{_}ENTREMETS.--Small side or corner dishes, served with the second course.
10136-8{_}1045{_}ESCALOPES.--Collops; small, round, thin pieces of tender meat, or of fish, beaten with the handle of a strong knife to make them tender.
10136-8{_}1046{_}FEUILLETAGE.--Puff-paste.
10136-8{_}1047{_}FLAMBER.--To singe fowl or game, after they have been picked.
10136-8{_}1048{_}FONCER.--To put in the bottom of a saucepan slices of ham, veal, or thin broad slices of bacon.
10136-8{_}1049{_}GALETTE.--A broad thin cake.
10136-8{_}1050{_}GÂTEAU.--A cake, correctly speaking; but used sometimes to denote a pudding and a kind of tart.
10136-8{_}1051{_}GLACER.--To glaze, or spread upon hot meats, or larded fowl, a thick and rich sauce or gravy, called _glaze_.
10136-8{_}1052{_}This is laid on with a feather or brush, and in confectionary the term means to ice fruits and pastry with sugar, which glistens on hardening.
10136-8{_}1053{_}HORS-D'OEUVRES.--Small dishes, or _assiettes volantes_ of sardines, anchovies, and other relishes of this kind, served to the guests during the first course.
10136-8{_}1054{_}(_See_ ASSIETTES VOLANTES.)
10136-8{_}1055{_}LIT.--A bed or layer; articles in thin slices are placed in layers, other articles, or seasoning, being laid between them.
10136-8{_}1056{_}MAIGRE.--Broth, soup, or gravy, made without meat.
10136-8{_}1057{_}MATELOTE.--A rich fish-stew, which is generally composed of carp, eels, trout, or barbel.
10136-8{_}1058{_}It is made with wine.
10136-8{_}1059{_}MAYONNAISE.--Cold sauce, or salad dressing.
10136-8{_}1060{_}MENU.--The bill of fare.
10136-8{_}1061{_}MERINGUE.--A kind of icing, made of whites of eggs and sugar, well beaten.
10136-8{_}1062{_}MIROTON.--Larger slices of meat than collops; such as slices of beef for a vinaigrette, or ragout or stew of onions.
10136-8{_}1063{_}MOUILLER.--To add water, broth, or other liquid, during the cooking.
10136-8{_}1064{_}PANER.--To cover over with very fine crumbs of bread, meats, or any other articles to be cooked on the gridiron, in the oven, or frying-pan.
10136-8{_}1065{_}PIQUER.--To lard with strips of fat bacon, poultry, game, meat, &c. This should always be done according to the vein of the meat, so that in carving you slice the bacon across as well as the meat.
10136-8{_}1066{_}POÊLÉE.--Stock used instead of water for boiling turkeys, sweetbreads, fowls, and vegetables, to render them less insipid.
10136-8{_}1067{_}This is rather an expensive preparation.
10136-8{_}1068{_}PURÉE.--Vegetables, or meat reduced to a very smooth pulp, which is afterwards mixed with enough liquid to make it of the consistency of very thick soup.
10136-8{_}1069{_}RAGOUT.--Stew or hash.
10136-8{_}1070{_}REMOULADE.--Salad dressing.
10136-8{_}1071{_}RISSOLES.--Pastry, made of light puff-paste, and cut into various forms, and fried.
10136-8{_}1072{_}They may be filled with fish, meat, or sweets.
10136-8{_}1073{_}ROUX.--Brown and white; French thickening.
10136-8{_}1074{_}SALMI.--Ragout of game previously roasted.
10136-8{_}1075{_}SAUCE PIQUANTE.--A sharp sauce, in which somewhat of a vinegar flavour predominates.
10136-8{_}1076{_}SAUTER.--To dress with sauce in a saucepan, repeatedly moving it about.
10136-8{_}1077{_}TAMIS.--Tammy, a sort of open cloth or sieve through which to strain broth and sauces, so as to rid them of small bones, froth, &c.
10136-8{_}1078{_}TOURTE.--Tart.
10136-8{_}1079{_}Fruit pie.
10136-8{_}1080{_}TROUSSER.--To truss a bird; to put together the body and tie the wings and thighs, in order to round it for roasting or boiling, each being tied then with packthread, to keep it in the required form.
10136-8{_}1081{_}VOL-AU-VENT.--A rich crust of very fine puff-paste, which may be filled with various delicate ragouts or fricassees, of fish, flesh, or fowl.
10136-8{_}1082{_}Fruit may also be inclosed in a _vol-au-vent_.
10136-8{_}1083{_}[Illustration]  SOUPS.
10136-8{_}1084{_}CHAPTER V.   GENERAL DIRECTIONS FOR MAKING SOUPS.
10136-8{_}1085{_}88.
10136-8{_}1086{_}LEAN, JUICY BEEF, MUTTON, AND VEAL, form the basis of all good soups; therefore it is advisable to procure those pieces which afford the richest succulence, and such as are fresh-killed.
10136-8{_}1087{_}Stale meat renders them bad, and fat is not so well adapted for making them.
10136-8{_}1088{_}The principal art in composing good rich soup, is so to proportion the several ingredients that the flavour of one shall not predominate over another, and that all the articles of which it is composed, shall form an agreeable whole.
10136-8{_}1089{_}To accomplish this, care must be taken that the roots and herbs are perfectly well cleaned, and that the water is proportioned to the quantity of meat and other ingredients.
10136-8{_}1090{_}Generally a quart of water may be allowed to a pound of meat for soups, and half the quantity for gravies.
10136-8{_}1091{_}In making soups or gravies, gentle stewing or simmering is incomparably the best.
10136-8{_}1092{_}It may be remarked, however, that a really good soup can never be made but in a well-closed vessel, although, perhaps, greater wholesomeness is obtained by an occasional exposure to the air.
10136-8{_}1093{_}Soups will, in general, take from three to six hours doing, and are much better prepared the day before they are wanted.
10136-8{_}1094{_}When the soup is cold, the fat may be much more easily and completely removed; and when it is poured off, care must be taken not to disturb the settlings at the bottom of the vessel, which are so fine that they will escape through a sieve.
10136-8{_}1095{_}A tamis is the best strainer, and if the soup is strained while it is hot, let the tamis or cloth be previously soaked in cold water.
10136-8{_}1096{_}Clear soups must be perfectly transparent, and thickened soups about the consistence of cream.
10136-8{_}1097{_}To thicken and give body to soups and gravies, potato-mucilage, arrow-root, bread-raspings, isinglass, flour and butter, barley, rice, or oatmeal, in a little water rubbed well together, are used.
10136-8{_}1098{_}A piece of boiled beef pounded to a pulp, with a bit of butter and flour, and rubbed through a sieve, and gradually incorporated with the soup, will be found an excellent addition.
10136-8{_}1099{_}When the soup appears to be _too thin_ or _too weak_, the cover of the boiler should be taken off, and the contents allowed to boil till some of the watery parts have evaporated; or some of the thickening materials, above mentioned, should be added.
10136-8{_}1100{_}When soups and gravies are kept from day to day in hot weather, they should be warmed up every day, and put into fresh scalded pans or tureens, and placed in a cool cellar.
10136-8{_}1101{_}In temperate weather, every other day may be sufficient.
10136-8{_}1102{_}89.
10136-8{_}1103{_}VARIOUS HERBS AND VEGETABLES are required for the purpose of making soups and gravies.
10136-8{_}1104{_}Of these the principal are,--Scotch barley, pearl barley, wheat flour, oatmeal, bread-raspings, pease, beans, rice, vermicelli, macaroni, isinglass, potato-mucilage, mushroom or mushroom ketchup, champignons, parsnips, carrots, beetroot, turnips, garlic, shalots, and onions.
10136-8{_}1105{_}Sliced onions, fried with butter and flour till they are browned, and then rubbed through a sieve, are excellent to heighten the colour and flavour of brown soups and sauces, and form the basis of many of the fine relishes furnished by the cook.
10136-8{_}1106{_}The older and drier the onion, the stronger will be its flavour.
10136-8{_}1107{_}Leeks, cucumber, or burnet vinegar; celery or celery-seed pounded.
10136-8{_}1108{_}The latter, though equally strong, does not impart the delicate sweetness of the fresh vegetable; and when used as a substitute, its flavour should be corrected by the addition of a bit of sugar.
10136-8{_}1109{_}Cress-seed, parsley, common thyme, lemon thyme, orange thyme, knotted marjoram, sage, mint, winter savoury, and basil.
10136-8{_}1110{_}As fresh green basil is seldom to be procured, and its fine flavour is soon lost, the best way of preserving the extract is by pouring wine on the fresh leaves.
10136-8{_}1111{_}90.
10136-8{_}1112{_}FOR THE SEASONING OF SOUPS, bay-leaves, tomato, tarragon, chervil, burnet, allspice, cinnamon, ginger, nutmeg, clove, mace, black and white pepper, essence of anchovy, lemon-peel, and juice, and Seville orange-juice, are all taken.
10136-8{_}1113{_}The latter imparts a finer flavour than the lemon, and the acid is much milder.
10136-8{_}1114{_}These materials, with wine, mushroom ketchup, Harvey's sauce, tomato sauce, combined in various proportions, are, with other ingredients, manipulated into an almost endless variety of excellent soups and gravies.
10136-8{_}1115{_}Soups, which are intended to constitute the principal part of a meal, certainly ought not to be flavoured like sauces, which are only designed to give a relish to some particular dish.
10136-8{_}1116{_}SOUP, BROTH AND BOUILLON.
10136-8{_}1117{_}91.
10136-8{_}1118{_}IT HAS BEEN ASSERTED, that English cookery is, nationally speaking, far from being the best in the world.
10136-8{_}1119{_}More than this, we have been frequently told by brilliant foreign writers, half philosophers, half _chefs_, that we are the _worst_ cooks on the face of the earth, and that the proverb which alludes to the divine origin of food, and the precisely opposite origin of its preparers, is peculiarly applicable to us islanders.
10136-8{_}1120{_}Not, however, to the inhabitants of the whole island; for, it is stated in a work which treats of culinary operations, north of the Tweed, that the "broth" of Scotland claims, for excellence and wholesomeness, a very close second place to the _bouillon_, or common soup of France.
10136-8{_}1121{_}"_Three_ hot meals of broth and meat, for about the price of ONE roasting joint," our Scottish brothers and sisters get, they say; and we hasten to assent to what we think is now a very well-ascertained fact.
10136-8{_}1122{_}We are glad to note, however, that soups of vegetables, fish, meat, and game, are now very frequently found in the homes of the English middle classes, as well as in the mansions of the wealthier and more aristocratic; and we take this to be one evidence, that we are on the right road to an improvement in our system of cookery.
10136-8{_}1123{_}One great cause of many of the spoilt dishes and badly-cooked meats which are brought to our tables, arises, we think, and most will agree with us, from a non-acquaintance with "common, every-day things."
10136-8{_}1124{_}Entertaining this view, we intend to preface the chapters of this work with a simple scientific _résumé_ of all those causes and circumstances which relate to the food we have to prepare, and the theory and chemistry of the various culinary operations.
10136-8{_}1125{_}Accordingly, this is the proper place to treat of the quality of the flesh of animals, and describe some of the circumstances which influence it for good or bad.
10136-8{_}1126{_}We will, therefore, commence with the circumstance of _age_, and examine how far this affects the quality of meat.
10136-8{_}1127{_}92.
10136-8{_}1128{_}DURING THE PERIOD BETWEEN THE BIRTH AND MATURITY OF ANIMALS, their flesh undergoes very considerable changes.
10136-8{_}1129{_}For instance, when the animal is young, the fluids which the tissues of the muscles contain, possess a large proportion of what is called _albumen_.
10136-8{_}1130{_}This albumen, which is also the chief component of the white of eggs, possesses the peculiarity of coagulating or hardening at a certain temperature, like the white of a boiled egg, into a soft, white fluid, no longer soluble, or capable of being dissolved in water.
10136-8{_}1131{_}As animals grow older, this peculiar animal matter gradually decreases, in proportion to the other constituents of the juice of the flesh.
10136-8{_}1132{_}Thus, the reason why veal, lamb, and young pork are _white, and without gravy_ when cooked, is, that the large quantity of albumen they contain hardens, or becomes coagulated.
10136-8{_}1133{_}On the other hand, the reason why beef and mutton are _brown, and have gravy_, is, that the proportion of albumen they contain, is small, in comparison with their greater quantity of fluid which is soluble, and not coagulable.
10136-8{_}1134{_}93.
10136-8{_}1135{_}THE QUALITY OF THE FLESH OF AN ANIMAL is considerably influenced by the nature of the _food on which it has been fed_; for the food supplies the material which produces the flesh.
10136-8{_}1136{_}If the food be not suitable and good, the meat cannot be good either; just as the paper on which these words are printed, could not be good, if the rags from which it is made, were not of a fine quality.
10136-8{_}1137{_}To the experienced in this matter, it is well known that the flesh of animals fed on farinaceous produce, such as corn, pulse, &c., is firm, well-flavoured, and also economical in the cooking; that the flesh of those fed on succulent and pulpy substances, such as roots, possesses these qualities in a somewhat less degree; whilst the flesh of those whose food contains fixed oil, as linseed, is greasy, high coloured, and gross in the fat, and if the food has been used in large quantities, possessed of a rank flavour.
10136-8{_}1138{_}94.
10136-8{_}1139{_}IT IS INDISPENSABLE TO THE GOOD QUALITY OF MEAT, that the animal should be _perfectly healthy_ at the time of its slaughter.
