10136-8{_}1140{_}However slight the disease in an animal may be, inferiority in the quality of its flesh, as food, is certain to be produced.
10136-8{_}1141{_}In most cases, indeed, as the flesh of diseased animals has a tendency to very rapid putrefaction, it becomes not only unwholesome, but absolutely poisonous, on account of the absorption of the _virus_ of the unsound meat into the systems of those who partake of it.
10136-8{_}1142{_}The external indications of good and bad meat will be described under its own particular head, but we may here premise that the layer of all wholesome meat, when freshly killed, adheres firmly to the bone.
10136-8{_}1143{_}95.
10136-8{_}1144{_}ANOTHER CIRCUMSTANCE GREATLY AFFECTING THE QUALITY OF MEAT, is the animal's treatment _before it is slaughtered_.
10136-8{_}1145{_}This influences its value and wholesomeness in no inconsiderable degree.
10136-8{_}1146{_}It will be easy to understand this, when we reflect on those leading principles by which the life of an animal is supported and maintained.
10136-8{_}1147{_}These are, the digestion of its food, and the assimilation of that food into its substance.
10136-8{_}1148{_}Nature, in effecting this process, first reduces the food in the stomach to a state of pulp, under the name of chyme, which passes into the intestines, and is there divided into two principles, each distinct from the other.
10136-8{_}1149{_}One, a milk-white fluid,--the nutritive portion,--is absorbed by innumerable vessels which open upon the mucous membrane, or inner coat of the intestines.
10136-8{_}1150{_}These vessels, or absorbents, discharge the fluid into a common duct, or road, along which it is conveyed to the large veins in the neighbourhood of the heart.
10136-8{_}1151{_}Here it is mixed with the venous blood (which is black and impure) returning from every part of the body, and then it supplies the waste which is occasioned in the circulating stream by the arterial (or pure) blood having furnished matter for the substance of the animal.
10136-8{_}1152{_}The blood of the animal having completed its course through all parts, and having had its waste recruited by the digested food, is now received into the heart, and by the action of that organ it is urged through the lungs, there to receive its purification from the air which the animal inhales.
10136-8{_}1153{_}Again returning to the heart, it is forced through the arteries, and thence distributed, by innumerable ramifications, called capillaries, bestowing to every part of the animal, life and nutriment.
10136-8{_}1154{_}The other principle--the innutritive portion--passes from the intestines, and is thus got rid of.
10136-8{_}1155{_}It will now be readily understood how flesh is affected for bad, if an animal is slaughtered when the circulation of its blood has been increased by over-driving, ill-usage, or other causes of excitement, to such a degree of rapidity as to be too great for the capillaries to perform their functions, and causing the blood to be congealed in its minuter vessels.
10136-8{_}1156{_}Where this has been the case, the meat will be dark-coloured, and become rapidly putrid; so that self-interest and humanity alike dictate kind and gentle treatment of all animals destined to serve as food for man.
10136-8{_}1157{_}THE CHEMISTRY AND ECONOMY OF SOUP-MAKING.
10136-8{_}1158{_}96.
10136-8{_}1159{_}STOCK BEING THE BASIS of all meat soups, and, also, of all the principal sauces, it is essential to the success of these culinary operations, to know the most complete and economical method of extracting, from a certain quantity of meat, the best possible stock or broth.
10136-8{_}1160{_}The theory and philosophy of this process we will, therefore, explain, and then proceed to show the practical course to be adopted.
10136-8{_}1161{_}97.
10136-8{_}1162{_}AS ALL MEAT is principally composed of fibres, fat, gelatine, osmazome, and albumen, it is requisite to know that the FIBRES are inseparable, constituting almost all that remains of the meat after it has undergone a long boiling.
10136-8{_}1163{_}98.
10136-8{_}1164{_}FAT is dissolved by boiling; but as it is contained in cells covered by a very fine membrane, which never dissolves, a portion of it always adheres to the fibres.
10136-8{_}1165{_}The other portion rises to the surface of the stock, and is that which has escaped from the cells which were not whole, or which have burst by boiling.
10136-8{_}1166{_}99.
10136-8{_}1167{_}GELATINE is soluble: it is the basis and the nutritious portion of the stock.
10136-8{_}1168{_}When there is an abundance of it, it causes the stock, when cold, to become a jelly.
10136-8{_}1169{_}100.
10136-8{_}1170{_}OSMAZOME is soluble even when cold, and is that part of the meat which gives flavour and perfume to the stock.
10136-8{_}1171{_}The flesh of old animals contains more _osmazome_ than that of young ones.
10136-8{_}1172{_}Brown meats contain more than white, and the former make the stock more fragrant.
10136-8{_}1173{_}By roasting meat, the osmazome appears to acquire higher properties; so, by putting the remains of roast meats into your stock-pot, you obtain a better flavour.
10136-8{_}1174{_}101.
10136-8{_}1175{_}ALBUMEN is of the nature of the white of eggs; it can be dissolved in cold or tepid water, but coagulates when it is put into water not quite at the boiling-point.
10136-8{_}1176{_}From this property in albumen, it is evident that if the meat is put into the stock-pot when the water boils, or after this is made to boil up quickly, the albumen, in both cases, hardens.
10136-8{_}1177{_}In the first it rises to the surface, in the second it remains in the meat, but in both it prevents the gelatine and osmazome from dissolving; and hence a thin and tasteless stock will be obtained.
10136-8{_}1178{_}It ought to be known, too, that the coagulation of the albumen in the meat, always takes place, more or less, according to the size of the piece, as the parts farthest from the surface always acquire _that degree_ of heat which congeals it before entirely dissolving it.
10136-8{_}1179{_}102.
10136-8{_}1180{_}BONES ought always to form a component part of the stock-pot.
10136-8{_}1181{_}They are composed of an earthy substance,--to which they owe their solidity,--of gelatine, and a fatty fluid, something like marrow.
10136-8{_}1182{_}_Two ounces_ of them contain as much gelatine as _one pound_ of meat; but in them, this is so incased in the earthy substance, that boiling water can dissolve only the surface of whole bones.
10136-8{_}1183{_}By breaking them, however, you can dissolve more, because you multiply their surfaces; and by reducing them to powder or paste, you can dissolve them entirely; but you must not grind them dry.
10136-8{_}1184{_}We have said (99) that gelatine forms the basis of stock; but this, though very nourishing, is entirely without taste; and to make the stock savoury, it must contain _osmazome_.
10136-8{_}1185{_}Of this, bones do not contain a particle; and that is the reason why stock made entirely of them, is not liked; but when you add meat to the broken or pulverized bones, the osmazome contained in it makes the stock sufficiently savoury.
10136-8{_}1186{_}103.
10136-8{_}1187{_}In concluding this part of our subject, the following condensed hints and directions should be attended to in the economy of soup-making:--  I.
10136-8{_}1188{_}BEEF MAKES THE BEST STOCK; veal stock has less colour and taste; whilst mutton sometimes gives it a tallowy smell, far from agreeable, unless the meat has been previously roasted or broiled.
10136-8{_}1189{_}Fowls add very little to the flavour of stock, unless they be old and fat.
10136-8{_}1190{_}Pigeons, when they are old, add the most flavour to it; and a rabbit or partridge is also a great improvement.
10136-8{_}1191{_}From the freshest meat the best stock is obtained.
10136-8{_}1192{_}II.
10136-8{_}1193{_}IF THE MEAT BE BOILED solely to make stock, it must be cut up into the smallest possible pieces; but, generally speaking, if it is desired to have good stock and a piece of savoury meat as well, it is necessary to put a rather large piece into the stock-pot, say sufficient for two or three days, during which time the stock will keep well in all weathers.
10136-8{_}1194{_}Choose the freshest meat, and have it cut as thick as possible; for if it is a thin, flat piece, it will not look well, and will be very soon spoiled by the boiling.
10136-8{_}1195{_}III.
10136-8{_}1196{_}NEVER WASH MEAT, as it deprives its surface of all its juices; separate it from the bones, and tie it round with tape, so that its shape may be preserved, then put it into the stock-pot, and for each pound of meat, let there be one pint of water; press it down with the hand, to allow the air, which it contains, to escape, and which often raises it to the top of the water.
10136-8{_}1197{_}IV.
10136-8{_}1198{_}PUT THE STOCK-POT ON A GENTLE FIRE, so that it may heat gradually.
10136-8{_}1199{_}The albumen will first dissolve, afterwards coagulate; and as it is in this state lighter than the liquid, it will rise to the surface; bringing with it all its impurities.
10136-8{_}1200{_}It is this which makes _the scum_.
10136-8{_}1201{_}The rising of the hardened albumen has the same effect in clarifying stock as the white of eggs; and, as a rule, it may be said that the more scum there is, the clearer will be the stock.
10136-8{_}1202{_}Always take care that the fire is very regular.
10136-8{_}1203{_}V. REMOVE THE SCUM when it rises thickly, and do not let the stock boil, because then one portion of the scum will be dissolved, and the other go to the bottom of the pot; thus rendering it very difficult to obtain a clear broth.
10136-8{_}1204{_}If the fire is regular, it will not be necessary to add cold water in order to make the scum rise; but if the fire is too large at first, it will then be necessary to do so.
10136-8{_}1205{_}VI.
10136-8{_}1206{_}WHEN THE STOCK IS WELL SKIMMED, and begins to boil, put in salt and vegetables, which may be two or three carrots, two turnips, one parsnip, a bunch of leeks and celery tied together.
10136-8{_}1207{_}You can add, according to taste, a piece of cabbage, two or three cloves stuck in an onion, and a tomato.
10136-8{_}1208{_}The latter gives a very agreeable flavour to the stock.
10136-8{_}1209{_}If fried onion be added, it ought, according to the advice of a famous French _chef_, to be tied in a little bag: without this precaution, the colour of the stock is liable to be clouded.
10136-8{_}1210{_}VII.
10136-8{_}1211{_}BY THIS TIME we will now suppose that you have chopped the bones which were separated from the meat, and those which were left from the roast meat of the day before.
10136-8{_}1212{_}Remember, as was before pointed out, that the more these are broken, the more gelatine you will have.
10136-8{_}1213{_}The best way to break them up is to pound them roughly in an iron mortar, adding, from time to time, a little water, to prevent them getting heated.
10136-8{_}1214{_}It is a great saving thus to make use of the bones of meat, which, in too many English families, we fear, are entirely wasted; for it is certain, as previously stated (No.
10136-8{_}1215{_}102), that two ounces of bone contain as much gelatine (which is the nutritive portion of stock) as one pound of meat.
10136-8{_}1216{_}In their broken state tie them up in a bag, and put them in the stock-pot; adding the gristly parts of cold meat, and trimmings, which can be used for no other purpose.
10136-8{_}1217{_}If, to make up the weight, you have received from the butcher a piece of mutton or veal, broil it slightly over a clear fire before putting it in the stock-pot, and be very careful that it does not contract the least taste of being smoked or burnt.
10136-8{_}1218{_}VIII.
10136-8{_}1219{_}ADD NOW THE VEGETABLES, which, to a certain extent, will stop the boiling of the stock.
10136-8{_}1220{_}Wait, therefore, till it simmers well up again, then draw it to the side of the fire, and keep it gently simmering till it is served, preserving, as before said, your fire always the same.
10136-8{_}1221{_}Cover the stock-pot well, to prevent evaporation; do not fill it up, even if you take out a little stock, unless the meat is exposed; in which case a little boiling water may be added, but only enough to cover it.
10136-8{_}1222{_}After six hours' slow and gentle simmering, the stock is done; and it should not be continued on the fire, longer than is necessary, or it will tend to insipidity.
10136-8{_}1223{_}_Note_.--It is on a good stock, or first good broth and sauce, that excellence in cookery depends.
10136-8{_}1224{_}If the preparation of this basis of the culinary art is intrusted to negligent or ignorant persons, and the stock is not well skimmed, but indifferent results will be obtained.
10136-8{_}1225{_}The stock will never be clear; and when it is obliged to be clarified, it is deteriorated both in quality and flavour.
10136-8{_}1226{_}In the proper management of the stock-pot an immense deal of trouble is saved, inasmuch as one stock, in a small dinner, serves for all purposes.
10136-8{_}1227{_}Above all things, the greatest economy, consistent with excellence, should be practised, and the price of everything which enters the kitchen correctly ascertained.
10136-8{_}1228{_}The _theory_ of this part of Household Management may appear trifling; but its practice is extensive, and therefore it requires the best attention.
10136-8{_}1229{_}[Illustration]     RECIPES.
10136-8{_}1230{_}CHAPTER VI.
10136-8{_}1231{_}FRUIT AND VEGETABLE SOUPS.
10136-8{_}1232{_}[_It will be seen, by reference to the following Recipes, that an entirely original and most intelligible system has been pursued in explaining the preparation of each dish.
10136-8{_}1233{_}We would recommend the young housekeeper, cook, or whoever may be engaged in the important task of "getting ready" the dinner, or other meal, to follow precisely the order in which the recipes are given.
10136-8{_}1234{_}Thus, let them first place on their table all the INGREDIENTS necessary; then the modus operandi, or MODE of preparation, will be easily managed.
10136-8{_}1235{_}By a careful reading, too, of the recipes, there will not be the slightest difficulty in arranging a repast for any number of persons, and an accurate notion will be gained of the TIME the cooling of each dish will occupy, of the periods at which it is SEASONABLE, as also of its_ AVERAGE COST.
10136-8{_}1236{_}_The addition of the natural history, and the description of the various properties of the edible articles in common use in every family, will be serviceable both in a practical and an educational point of view._  _Speaking specially of the Recipes for Soups, it may be added, that by the employment of the_ BEST, MEDIUM, _or_ COMMON STOCK, _the quality of the Soups and their cost may be proportionately increased or lessened._]   STOCKS FOR ALL KINDS OF SOUPS.
10136-8{_}1237{_}RICH STRONG STOCK.
10136-8{_}1238{_}104.
10136-8{_}1239{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 lbs.
10136-8{_}1240{_}of shin of beef, 4 lbs.
10136-8{_}1241{_}of knuckle of veal, 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}1242{_}of good lean ham; any poultry trimmings; 3 small onions, 3 small carrots, 3 turnips (the latter should be omitted in summer, lest they ferment), 1 head of celery, a few chopped mushrooms, when obtainable; 1 tomato, a bunch of savoury herbs, not forgetting parsley; 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}1243{_}of salt, 12 white peppercorns, 6 cloves, 3 small blades of mace, 4 quarts of water.
10136-8{_}1244{_}_Mode_.--Line a delicately clean stewpan with the ham cut in thin broad slices, carefully trimming off all its rusty fat; cut up the beef and veal in pieces about 3 inches square, and lay them on the ham; set it on the stove, and draw it down, and stir frequently.
10136-8{_}1245{_}When the meat is equally browned, put in the beef and veal bones, the poultry trimmings, and pour in the cold water.
10136-8{_}1246{_}Skim well, and occasionally add a little cold water, to stop its boiling, until it becomes quite clear; then put in all the other ingredients, and simmer very slowly for 5 hours.
10136-8{_}1247{_}Do not let it come to a brisk boil, that the stock be not wasted, and that its colour may be preserved.
10136-8{_}1248{_}Strain through a very fine hair sieve, or tammy, and it will be fit for use.
10136-8{_}1249{_}_Time_.--5 hours.
10136-8{_}1250{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}1251{_}3d.
10136-8{_}1252{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}1253{_}MEDIUM STOCK.
10136-8{_}1254{_}105.
10136-8{_}1255{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 lbs.
10136-8{_}1256{_}of shin of beef, or 4 lbs.
10136-8{_}1257{_}of knuckle of veal, or 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}1258{_}of each; any bones, trimmings of poultry, or fresh meat, 1/2 a lb.
10136-8{_}1259{_}of lean bacon or ham, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}1260{_}of butter, 2 large onions, each stuck with 3 cloves; 1 turnip, 3 carrots, 1/2 a leek, 1 head of celery, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}1261{_}of salt, 1/2 a teaspoonful of whole pepper, 1 large blade of mace, 1 small bunch of savoury herbs, 4 quarts and 1/2 pint of cold water.
10136-8{_}1262{_}_Mode_.--Cut up the meat and bacon or ham into pieces about 3 inches square; rub the butter on the bottom of the stewpan; put in 1/2 a pint of water, the meat, and all the other ingredients.
10136-8{_}1263{_}Cover the stewpan, and place it on a sharp fire, occasionally stirring its contents.
10136-8{_}1264{_}When the bottom of the pan becomes covered with a pale, jelly-like substance, add 4 quarts of cold water, and simmer very gently for 5 hours.
10136-8{_}1265{_}As we have said before, do not let it boil quickly.
10136-8{_}1266{_}Skim off every particle of grease whilst it is doing, and strain it through a fine hair sieve.
10136-8{_}1267{_}This is the basis of many of the soups afterwards mentioned, and will be found quite strong enough for ordinary purposes.
10136-8{_}1268{_}_Time_.--5-1/2 hours.
10136-8{_}1269{_}_Average cost_, 9d.
10136-8{_}1270{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}1271{_}ECONOMICAL STOCK.
10136-8{_}1272{_}106.
10136-8{_}1273{_}INGREDIENTS.--The liquor in which a joint of meat has been boiled, say 4 quarts; trimmings of fresh meat or poultry, shank-bones, &c., roast-beef bones, any pieces the larder may furnish; vegetables, spices, and the same seasoning as in the foregoing recipe.
10136-8{_}1274{_}_Mode_.--Let all the ingredients simmer gently for 6 hours, taking care to skim carefully at first.
10136-8{_}1275{_}Strain it off, and put by for use.
10136-8{_}1276{_}_Time_.--6 hours.
10136-8{_}1277{_}_Average cost_, 3d.
10136-8{_}1278{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}1279{_}WHITE STOCK.
10136-8{_}1280{_}(_To be Used in the Preparation of White Soups_.)
10136-8{_}1281{_}107.
10136-8{_}1282{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 lbs.
10136-8{_}1283{_}of knuckle of veal, any poultry trimmings, 4 slices of lean ham, 1 carrot, 2 onions, 1 head of celery, 12 white peppercorns, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}1284{_}of salt, 1 blade of mace, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}1285{_}butter, 4 quarts of water.
10136-8{_}1286{_}_Mode_.--Cut up the veal, and put it with the bones and trimmings of poultry, and the ham, into the stewpan, which has been rubbed with the butter.
10136-8{_}1287{_}Moisten with 1/2 a pint of water, and simmer till the gravy begins to flow.
10136-8{_}1288{_}Then add the 4 quarts of water and the remainder of the ingredients; simmer for 5 hours.
10136-8{_}1289{_}After skimming and straining it carefully through a very fine hair sieve, it will be ready for use.
10136-8{_}1290{_}_Time_.--5-1/2 hours.
10136-8{_}1291{_}_Average cost_, 9d.
10136-8{_}1292{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}1293{_}_Note_.--When stronger stock is desired, double the quantity of veal, or put in an old fowl.
10136-8{_}1294{_}The liquor in which a young turkey has been boiled, is an excellent addition to all white stock or soups.
10136-8{_}1295{_}BROWNING FOR STOCK.
10136-8{_}1296{_}108.
10136-8{_}1297{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 oz.
10136-8{_}1298{_}of powdered sugar, and 1/2 a pint of water.
10136-8{_}1299{_}_Mode_.--Place the sugar in a stewpan over a slow fire until it begins to melt, keeping it stirred with a wooden spoon until it becomes black, then add the water, and let it dissolve.
10136-8{_}1300{_}Cork closely, and use a few drops when required.
10136-8{_}1301{_}_Note_.--In France, burnt onions are made use of for the purpose of browning.
10136-8{_}1302{_}As a general rule, the process of browning is to be discouraged, as apt to impart a slightly unpleasant flavour to the stock, and, consequently, all soups made from it.
10136-8{_}1303{_}TO CLARIFY STOCK.
10136-8{_}1304{_}109.
10136-8{_}1305{_}INGREDIENTS.--The whites of 2 eggs, 1/2 pint of water, 2 quarts of stock.
10136-8{_}1306{_}_Mode_.--Supposing that by some accident the soup is not quite clear, and that its quantity is 2 quarts, take the whites of 2 eggs, carefully separated from their yolks, whisk them well together with the water, and add gradually the 2 quarts of boiling stock, still whisking.
10136-8{_}1307{_}Place the soup on the fire, and when boiling and well skimmed, whisk the eggs with it till nearly boiling again; then draw it from the fire, and let it settle, until the whites of the eggs become separated.
10136-8{_}1308{_}Pass through a fine cloth, and the soup should be clear.
10136-8{_}1309{_}_Note_.--The rule is, that all clear soups should be of a light straw colour, and should not savour too strongly of the meat; and that all white or brown thick soups should have no more consistency than will enable them to adhere slightly to the spoon when hot.
10136-8{_}1310{_}All _purées_ should be somewhat thicker.
10136-8{_}1311{_}ALMOND SOUP.
10136-8{_}1312{_}110.
10136-8{_}1313{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 lbs.
10136-8{_}1314{_}of lean beef or veal, 1/2 a scrag of mutton, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}1315{_}of vermicelli, 4 blades of mace, 6 cloves, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}1316{_}of sweet almonds, the yolks of 6 eggs, 1 gill of thick cream, rather more than 2 quarts of water.
10136-8{_}1317{_}_Mode_.--Boil the beef, or veal, and the mutton, gently in water that will cover them, till the gravy is very strong, and the meat very tender; then strain off the gravy, and set it on the fire with the specified quantities of vermicelli, mace, and cloves, to 2 quarts.
10136-8{_}1318{_}Let it boil till it has the flavour of the spices.
10136-8{_}1319{_}Have ready the almonds, blanched and pounded very fine; the yolks of the eggs boiled hard; mixing the almonds, whilst pounding, with a little of the soup, lest the latter should grow oily.
10136-8{_}1320{_}Pound them till they are a mere pulp, and keep adding to them, by degrees, a little soup until they are thoroughly mixed together.
10136-8{_}1321{_}Let the soup be cool when mixing, and do it perfectly smooth.
10136-8{_}1322{_}Strain it through a sieve, set it on the fire, stir frequently, and serve hot.
10136-8{_}1323{_}Just before taking it up, add the cream.
10136-8{_}1324{_}_Time_.--3 hours.
10136-8{_}1325{_}_Average cost_ per quart, 2s.
10136-8{_}1326{_}3d.
10136-8{_}1327{_}_Seasonable_ all the year.
10136-8{_}1328{_}_Sufficient_ for 8 persons.
10136-8{_}1329{_}[Illustration: ALMOND & BLOSSOM.]
10136-8{_}1330{_}THE ALMOND-TREE.--This tree is indigenous to the northern parts     of Asia and Africa, but it is now cultivated in Europe,     especially in the south of France, Italy, and Spain.
10136-8{_}1331{_}It flowers     in spring, and produces its fruit in August.
10136-8{_}1332{_}Although there are     two kinds of almonds, the _sweet_ and the _bitter,_ they are     considered as only varieties of the same species.
10136-8{_}1333{_}The best sweet     almonds brought to England, are called the Syrian or Jordan, and     come from Malaga; the inferior qualities are brought from     Valentia and Italy.
10136-8{_}1334{_}_Bitter_ almonds come principally from     Magadore.
10136-8{_}1335{_}Anciently, the almond was much esteemed by the nations     of the East.
10136-8{_}1336{_}Jacob included it among the presents which he     designed for Joseph.
10136-8{_}1337{_}The Greeks called it the Greek or Thasian     nut, and the Romans believed that by eating half a dozen of     them, they were secured against drunkenness, however deeply they     might imbibe.
10136-8{_}1338{_}Almonds, however, are considered as very     indigestible.
10136-8{_}1339{_}The _bitter_ contain, too, principles which     produce two violent poisons,--prussic acid and a kind of     volatile oil.
10136-8{_}1340{_}It is consequently dangerous to eat them in large     quantities.
10136-8{_}1341{_}Almonds pounded together with a little sugar and     water, however, produce a milk similar to that which is yielded     by animals.
10136-8{_}1342{_}Their oil is used for making fine soap, and their     cake as a cosmetic.
10136-8{_}1343{_}APPLE SOUP.
10136-8{_}1344{_}111.
10136-8{_}1345{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 lbs.
10136-8{_}1346{_}of good boiling apples, 3/4 teaspoonful of white pepper, 6 cloves, cayenne or ginger to taste, 3 quarts of medium stock.
10136-8{_}1347{_}_Mode_.--Peel and quarter the apples, taking out their cores; put them into the stock, stew them gently till tender.
10136-8{_}1348{_}Rub the whole through a strainer, add the seasoning, give it one boil up, and serve.
10136-8{_}1349{_}_Time_.--1 hour.
10136-8{_}1350{_}_Average cost_ per quart, 1s.
10136-8{_}1351{_}_Seasonable_ from September to December.
10136-8{_}1352{_}_Sufficient_ for 10 persons.
10136-8{_}1353{_}[Illustration: APPLE AND BLOSSOM.]
10136-8{_}1354{_}THE APPLE.--This useful fruit is mentioned in Holy Writ; and     Homer describes it as valuable in his time.
10136-8{_}1355{_}It was brought from     the East by the Romans, who held it in the highest estimation.
10136-8{_}1356{_}Indeed, some of the citizens of the "Eternal city" distinguished     certain favourite apples by their names.
10136-8{_}1357{_}Thus the Manlians were     called after Manlius, the Claudians after Claudius, and the     Appians after Appius.
10136-8{_}1358{_}Others were designated after the country     whence they were brought; as the Sidonians, the Epirotes, and     the Greeks.
10136-8{_}1359{_}The best varieties are natives of Asia, and have, by     grafting them upon others, been introduced into Europe.
10136-8{_}1360{_}The     crab, found in our hedges, is the only variety indigenous to     Britain; therefore, for the introduction of other kinds we are,     no doubt, indebted to the Romans.
10136-8{_}1361{_}In the time of the Saxon     heptarchy, both Devon and Somerset were distinguished as _the     apple country_; and there are still existing in Herefordshire     some trees said to have been planted in the time of William the     Conqueror.
10136-8{_}1362{_}From that time to this, the varieties of this     precious fruit have gone on increasing, and are now said to     number upwards of 1,500.
10136-8{_}1363{_}It is peculiar to the temperate zone,     being found neither in Lapland, nor within the tropics.
10136-8{_}1364{_}The best     baking apples for early use are the Colvilles; the best for     autumn are the rennets and pearmains; and the best for winter     and spring are russets.
10136-8{_}1365{_}The best table, or eating apples, are     the Margarets for early use; the Kentish codlin and summer     pearmain for summer; and for autumn, winter, or spring, the     Dowton, golden and other pippins, as the ribstone, with small     russets.
10136-8{_}1366{_}As a food, the apple cannot be considered to rank high,     as more than the half of it consists of water, and the rest of     its properties are not the most nourishing.
10136-8{_}1367{_}It is, however, a     useful adjunct to other kinds of food, and, when cooked, is     esteemed as slightly laxative.
10136-8{_}1368{_}ARTICHOKE (JERUSALEM) SOUP.
10136-8{_}1369{_}(_A White Soup_.)
10136-8{_}1370{_}112.
10136-8{_}1371{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 slices of lean bacon or ham, 1/2 a head of celery, 1 turnip, 1 onion, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}1372{_}of butter, 4 lbs.
10136-8{_}1373{_}of artichokes, 1 pint of boiling milk, or 1/2 pint of boiling cream, salt and cayenne to taste, 2 lumps of sugar, 2-1/2 quarts of white stock.
10136-8{_}1374{_}_Mode_.--Put the bacon and vegetables, which should be cut into thin slices, into the stewpan with the butter.
10136-8{_}1375{_}Braise these for 1/4 of an hour, keeping them well stirred.
10136-8{_}1376{_}Wash and pare the artichokes, and after cutting them into thin slices, add them, with a pint of stock, to the other ingredients.
10136-8{_}1377{_}When these have gently stewed down to a smooth pulp, put in the remainder of the stock.
10136-8{_}1378{_}Stir it well, adding the seasoning, and when it has simmered for five minutes, pass it through a strainer.
10136-8{_}1379{_}Now pour it back into the stewpan, let it again simmer five minutes, taking care to skim it well, and stir it to the boiling milk or cream.
10136-8{_}1380{_}Serve with small sippets of bread fried in butter.
10136-8{_}1381{_}_Time_.--1 hour.
10136-8{_}1382{_}_Average cost_ per quart, 1s.
10136-8{_}1383{_}2d.
10136-8{_}1384{_}_Seasonable_ from June to October.
10136-8{_}1385{_}_Sufficient_ for 8 persons.
10136-8{_}1386{_}ASPARAGUS SOUP.
10136-8{_}1387{_}I.
10136-8{_}1388{_}113.
10136-8{_}1389{_}INGREDIENTS.--5 lbs.
10136-8{_}1390{_}of lean beef, 3 slices of bacon, 1/2 pint of pale ale, a few leaves of white beet, spinach, 1 cabbage lettuce, a little mint, sorrel, and marjoram, a pint of asparagus-tops cut small, the crust of 1 French roll, seasoning to taste, 2 quarts of water.
10136-8{_}1391{_}_Mode_.--Put the beef, cut in pieces and rolled in flour, into a stewpan, with the bacon at the bottom; cover it close, and set it on a slow fire, stirring it now and then till the gravy is drawn.
10136-8{_}1392{_}Put in the water and ale, and season to taste with pepper and salt, and let it stew gently for 2 hours; then strain the liquor, and take off the fat, and add the white beet, spinach, cabbage lettuce, and mint, sorrel, and sweet marjoram, pounded.
10136-8{_}1393{_}Let these boil up in the liquor, then put in the asparagus-tops cut small, and allow them to boil till all is tender.
10136-8{_}1394{_}Serve hot, with the French roll in the dish.
10136-8{_}1395{_}_Time_.--Altogether 3 hours.
10136-8{_}1396{_}_Average cost_ per quart, 1s.
10136-8{_}1397{_}9d.
10136-8{_}1398{_}_Seasonable_ from May to August.
10136-8{_}1399{_}_Sufficient_ for 8 persons.
10136-8{_}1400{_}II.
10136-8{_}1401{_}114.
10136-8{_}1402{_}INGREDIENTS.--1-1/2 pint of split peas, a teacupful of gravy, 4 young onions, 1 lettuce cut small, 1/2 a head of celery, 1/2 a pint of asparagus cut small, 1/2 a pint of cream, 3 quarts of water: colour the soup with spinach juice.
10136-8{_}1403{_}_Mode_.--Boil the peas, and rub them through a sieve; add the gravy, and then stew by themselves the celery, onions, lettuce, and asparagus, with the water.
10136-8{_}1404{_}After this, stew altogether, and add the colouring and cream, and serve.
10136-8{_}1405{_}_Time_.--Peas 2-1/2 hours, vegetables 1 hour; altogether 4 hours.
10136-8{_}1406{_}_Average cost_ per quart, 1s.
10136-8{_}1407{_}[Illustration: ASPARAGUS.]
10136-8{_}1408{_}ASPARAGUS.--The ancients called all the sprouts of young     vegetables asparagus, whence the name, which is now limited to a     particular species, embracing artichoke, alisander, asparagus,     cardoon, rampion, and sea-kale.
10136-8{_}1409{_}They are originally mostly wild     seacoast plants; and, in this state, asparagus may still be     found on the northern as well as southern shores of Britain.
10136-8{_}1410{_}It     is often vulgarly called, in London, _sparrowgrass_; and, in     it's cultivated form, hardly bears any resemblance to the     original plant.
10136-8{_}1411{_}Immense quantities of it are raised for the     London market, at Mortlake and Deptford; but it belongs rather     to the classes of luxurious than necessary food.
10136-8{_}1412{_}It is light and     easily digested, but is not very nutritious.
10136-8{_}1413{_}BAKED SOUP.
10136-8{_}1414{_}115.
10136-8{_}1415{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}1416{_}of any kind of meat, any trimmings or odd pieces; 2 onions, 2 carrots, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}1417{_}of rice, 1 pint of split peas, pepper and salt to taste, 4 quarts of water.
10136-8{_}1418{_}_Mode_.--Cut the meat and vegetables in slices, add to them the rice and peas, season with pepper and salt.
10136-8{_}1419{_}Put the whole in a jar, fill up with the water, cover very closely, and bake for 4 hours.
10136-8{_}1420{_}_Time_.--4 hours.
10136-8{_}1421{_}_Average cost_, 2-1/2d.
10136-8{_}1422{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}1423{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}1424{_}_Sufficient_ for 10 or 12 persons.
10136-8{_}1425{_}_Note_.--This will be found a very cheap and wholesome soup, and will be convenient in those cases where baking is more easily performed than boiling.
10136-8{_}1426{_}BARLEY SOUP.
10136-8{_}1427{_}116.
10136-8{_}1428{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 lbs.
10136-8{_}1429{_}of shin of beef, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}1430{_}of pearl barley, a large bunch of parsley, 4 onions, 6 potatoes, salt and pepper, 4 quarts of water.
10136-8{_}1431{_}_Mode_.--Put in all the ingredients, and simmer gently for 3 hours.
10136-8{_}1432{_}_Time_.--3 hours.
10136-8{_}1433{_}_Average cost_, 2-1/2d.
10136-8{_}1434{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}1435{_}_Seasonable_ all the year, but more suitable for winter.
10136-8{_}1436{_}[Illustration: BARLEY.]
10136-8{_}1437{_}BARLEY.--This, in the order of cereal grasses, is, in Britain,     the next plant to wheat in point of value, and exhibits several     species and varieties.
10136-8{_}1438{_}From what country it comes originally, is     not known, but it was cultivated in the earliest ages of     antiquity, as the Egyptians were afflicted with the loss of it     in the ear, in the time of Moses.
10136-8{_}1439{_}It was a favourite grain with     the Athenians, but it was esteemed as an ignominious food by the     Romans.
10136-8{_}1440{_}Notwithstanding this, however, it was much used by them,     as it was in former times by the English, and still is, in the     Border counties, in Cornwall, and also in Wales.
10136-8{_}1441{_}In other parts     of England, it is used mostly for malting purposes.
10136-8{_}1442{_}It is less     nutritive than wheat; and in 100 parts, has of starch 79, gluten     6, saccharine matter 7, husk 8.
10136-8{_}1443{_}It is, however, a lighter and     less stimulating food than wheat, which renders a decoction of     it well adapted for invalids whose digestion is weak.
10136-8{_}1444{_}BREAD SOUP.
10136-8{_}1445{_}(_Economical_.)
10136-8{_}1446{_}117.
10136-8{_}1447{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}1448{_}of bread crusts, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}1449{_}butter, 1 quart of common stock.
10136-8{_}1450{_}_Mode_.--Boil the bread crusts in the stock with the butter; beat the whole with a spoon, and keep it boiling till the bread and stock are well mixed.
10136-8{_}1451{_}Season with a little salt.
10136-8{_}1452{_}_Time_.--Half an hour.
10136-8{_}1453{_}_Average cost_ per quart, 4d.
10136-8{_}1454{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}1455{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}1456{_}_Note_.--This is a cheap recipe, and will be found useful where extreme economy is an object.
10136-8{_}1457{_}[Illustration: QUERN, or GRINDING-MILL.]
10136-8{_}1458{_}BREAD.--The origin of bread is involved in the obscurity of     distant ages.
10136-8{_}1459{_}The Greeks attributed its invention to Pan; but     before they, themselves, had an existence, it was, no doubt, in     use among the primitive nations of mankind.
10136-8{_}1460{_}The Chaldeans and     the Egyptians were acquainted with it, and Sarah, the companion     of Abraham, mixed flour and water together, kneaded it, and     covered it with ashes on the hearth.
10136-8{_}1461{_}The Scriptures inform us     that leavened bread was known to the Israelites, but it is not     known when the art of fermenting it was discovered.
10136-8{_}1462{_}It is said     that the Romans learnt it during their wars with Perseus, king     of Macedon, and that it was introduced to the "imperial city"     about 200 years before the birth of Christ.
10136-8{_}1463{_}With them it no     doubt found its way into Britain; but after their departure from     the island, it probably ceased to be used.
10136-8{_}1464{_}We know that King     Alfred allowed the unfermented cakes to burn in the neatherd's     cottage; and that, even in the sixteenth century, unfermented     cakes, kneaded by the women, were the only kind of bread known     to the inhabitants of Norway and Sweden.
10136-8{_}1465{_}The Italians of this     day consume the greater portion of their flour in the form of     _polenta_, or soft pudding, vermicelli, and macaroni; and, in     the remoter districts of Scotland, much unfermented bread is     still used.
10136-8{_}1466{_}We give a cut of the _quern_ grinding-mill, which,     towards the end of the last century, was in use in that country,     and which is thus described by Dr. Johnson in his "Journey to     the Hebrides:"--"It consists of two stones about a foot and half     in diameter; the lower is a little convex, to which the     concavity of the upper must be fitted.
10136-8{_}1467{_}In the middle of the     upper stone is a round hole, and on one side is a long handle.
10136-8{_}1468{_}The grinder sheds the corn gradually into the hole with one     hand, and works the handle round with the other.
10136-8{_}1469{_}The corn slides     down the convexity of the lower stone, and by the motion of the     upper, is ground in its passage."
10136-8{_}1470{_}Such a primitive piece of     machinery, it may safely be said, has entirely disappeared from     this country.--In other parts of this work, we shall have     opportunities of speaking of bread and bread-making, which, from     its great and general use in the nourishment of mankind, has     emphatically been called the "staff of life."
10136-8{_}1471{_}The necessity,     therefore, of having it both pure and good is of the first     importance.
10136-8{_}1472{_}CABBAGE SOUP.
10136-8{_}1473{_}118.
10136-8{_}1474{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 large cabbage, 3 carrots, 2 onions, 4 or 5 slices of lean bacon, salt and pepper to taste, 2 quarts of medium stock No.
10136-8{_}1475{_}105.
10136-8{_}1476{_}_Mode_.--Scald the cabbage, exit it up and drain it.
10136-8{_}1477{_}Line the stewpan with the bacon, put in the cabbage, carrots, and onions; moisten with skimmings from the stock, and simmer very gently, till the cabbage is tender; add the stock, stew softly for half an hour, and carefully skim off every particle of fat.
10136-8{_}1478{_}Season and serve.
10136-8{_}1479{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}1480{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}1481{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}1482{_}_Seasonable_ in winter.
10136-8{_}1483{_}_Sufficient_ for 8 persons.
10136-8{_}1484{_}[Illustration: CABBAGE SEEDING.]
10136-8{_}1485{_}THE CABBAGE.--It is remarkable, that although there is no     country in the world now more plentifully supplied with fruits     and vegetables than Great Britain, yet the greater number of     these had no existence in it before the time of Henry VIII.
10136-8{_}1486{_}Anderson, writing under the date of 1548, says, "The English     cultivated scarcely any vegetables before the last two     centuries.
10136-8{_}1487{_}At the commencement of the reign, of Henry VIII.
10136-8{_}1488{_}neither salad, nor carrots, nor cabbages, nor radishes, nor any     other comestibles of a like nature, were grown in any part of     the kingdom; they came from Holland and Flanders."
10136-8{_}1489{_}The original     of all the cabbage tribe is the wild plant _sea-colewort_, which     is to be found _wasting_ whatever sweetness it may have on the     desert air, on many of the cliffs of the south coast of England.
10136-8{_}1490{_}In this state, it scarcely weighs more than half an ounce, yet,     in a cultivated state, to what dimensions can it be made to     grow!
10136-8{_}1491{_}However greatly the whole of the tribe is esteemed among     the moderns, by the ancients they were held in yet higher     estimation.
10136-8{_}1492{_}The Egyptians adored and raised altars to them, and     the Greeks and Romans ascribed many of the most exalted virtues     to them.
10136-8{_}1493{_}Cato affirmed, that the cabbage cured all diseases, and     declared, that it was to its use that the Romans were enabled to     live in health and without the assistance of physicians for 600     years.
10136-8{_}1494{_}It was introduced by that people into Germany, Gaul, and,     no doubt, Britain; although, in this last, it may have been     suffered to pass into desuetude for some centuries.
10136-8{_}1495{_}The whole     tribe is in general wholesome and nutritive, and forms a     valuable adjunct to animal food.
10136-8{_}1496{_}SOUP A LA CANTATRICE.
10136-8{_}1497{_}(_An Excellent Soup, very Beneficial for the Voice_.)
10136-8{_}1498{_}119.
10136-8{_}1499{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 oz.
10136-8{_}1500{_}of sago, 1/2 pint of cream, the yolks of 3 eggs, 1 lump of sugar, and seasoning to taste, 1 bay-leaf (if liked), 2 quarts of medium stock No.
10136-8{_}1501{_}105.
10136-8{_}1502{_}_Mode_.--Having washed the sago in boiling water, let it be gradually added to the nearly boiling stock.
10136-8{_}1503{_}Simmer for 1/2 an hour, when it should be well dissolved.
10136-8{_}1504{_}Beat up the yolks of the eggs, add to them the boiling cream; stir these quickly in the soup, and serve immediately.
10136-8{_}1505{_}Do not let the soup boil, or the eggs will curdle.
10136-8{_}1506{_}_Time_.--40 minutes.
10136-8{_}1507{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}1508{_}6d.
10136-8{_}1509{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}1510{_}_Seasonable_ all the year.
10136-8{_}1511{_}_Sufficient_ for 8 persons.
10136-8{_}1512{_}_Note_.--This is a soup, the principal ingredients of which, sago and eggs, have always been deemed very beneficial to the chest and throat.
10136-8{_}1513{_}In various quantities, and in different preparations, these have been partaken of by the principal singers of the day, including the celebrated Swedish Nightingale, Jenny Lind, and, as they have always avowed, with considerable advantage to the voice, in singing.
10136-8{_}1514{_}CARROT SOUP.
10136-8{_}1515{_}I.
10136-8{_}1516{_}120.
10136-8{_}1517{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 quarts of liquor in which a leg of mutton or beef has been boiled, a few beef-bones, 6 large carrots, 2 large onions, 1 turnip; seasoning of salt and pepper to taste; cayenne.
10136-8{_}1518{_}_Mode_.--Put the liquor, bones, onions, turnip, pepper, and salt, into a stewpan, and simmer for 3 hours.
10136-8{_}1519{_}Scrape and cut the carrots thin, strain the soup on them, and stew them till soft enough to pulp through a hair sieve or coarse cloth; then boil the pulp with the soup, which should be of the consistency of pea-soup.
10136-8{_}1520{_}Add cayenne.
10136-8{_}1521{_}Pulp only the red part of the carrot, and make this soup the day before it is wanted.
10136-8{_}1522{_}_Time_.--4-1/2 hours.
10136-8{_}1523{_}_Average cost_ per quart, 1-1/2d.
10136-8{_}1524{_}_Seasonable_ from October to March.
10136-8{_}1525{_}_Sufficient_ for 10 persons.
10136-8{_}1526{_}II.
10136-8{_}1527{_}121.
10136-8{_}1528{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 lbs.
10136-8{_}1529{_}of carrots, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}1530{_}of butter, seasoning to taste of salt and cayenne, 2 quarts of stock or gravy soup.
10136-8{_}1531{_}_Mode_.--Scrape and cut out all specks from the carrots, wash, and wipe them dry, and then reduce them into quarter-inch slices.
10136-8{_}1532{_}Put the butter into a large stewpan, and when it is melted, add 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}1533{_}of the sliced carrots, and let them stew gently for an hour without browning.
10136-8{_}1534{_}Add to them the soup, and allow them to simmer till tender,--say for nearly an hour.
10136-8{_}1535{_}Press them through a strainer with the soup, and add salt and cayenne if required.
10136-8{_}1536{_}Boil the whole gently for 5 minutes, skim well, and serve as hot as possible.
10136-8{_}1537{_}_Time_.--1-1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}1538{_}_Average cost_ per quart, 1s.
10136-8{_}1539{_}1d.
10136-8{_}1540{_}[Illustration: TAZZA AND CARROT LEAVES.]
10136-8{_}1541{_}THE CARROT.--There is a wild carrot which grows in England; but     it is white and small, and not much esteemed.
10136-8{_}1542{_}The garden carrot     in general use, was introduced in the reign of Queen Elizabeth,     and was, at first, so highly esteemed, that the ladies wore     leaves of it in their head-dresses.
10136-8{_}1543{_}It is of great value in the     culinary art, especially for soups and stews.
10136-8{_}1544{_}It can be used     also for beer instead of malt, and, in distillation, it yields a     large quantity of spirit.
10136-8{_}1545{_}The carrot is proportionably valuable     as it has more of the red than the yellow part.
10136-8{_}1546{_}There is a large     red variety much used by the farmers for colouring butter.
10136-8{_}1547{_}As a     garden vegetable, it is what is called the orange-carrot that is     usually cultivated.
10136-8{_}1548{_}As a fattening food for cattle, it is     excellent; but for man it is indigestible, on account of its     fibrous matter.
10136-8{_}1549{_}Of 1,000 parts, 95 consist of sugar, and 3 of     starch.--The accompanying cut represents a pretty winter     ornament, obtained by placing a cut from the top of the     carrot-root in a shallow vessel of water, when the young leaves     spring forth with a charming freshness and fullness.
10136-8{_}1550{_}CELERY SOUP.
10136-8{_}1551{_}122.
10136-8{_}1552{_}INGREDIENTS.--9 heads of celery, 1 teaspoonful of salt, nutmeg to taste, 1 lump of sugar, 1/2 pint of strong stock, a pint of cream, and 2 quarts of boiling water.
10136-8{_}1553{_}_Mode_.--Cut the celery into small pieces; throw it into the water, seasoned with the nutmeg, salt, and sugar.
10136-8{_}1554{_}Boil it till sufficiently tender; pass it through a sieve, add the stock, and simmer it for half an hour.
10136-8{_}1555{_}Now put in the cream, bring it to the boiling point, and serve immediately.
10136-8{_}1556{_}_Time_.--1 hour.
10136-8{_}1557{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}1558{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}1559{_}_Seasonable_ from September to March.
10136-8{_}1560{_}_Sufficient_ for 10 persons.
10136-8{_}1561{_}_Note_.--This soup can be made brown, instead of white, by omitting the cream, and colouring it a little.
10136-8{_}1562{_}When celery cannot be procured, half a drachm of the seed, finely pounded, will give a flavour to the soup, if put in a quarter of an hour before it is done.
10136-8{_}1563{_}A little of the essence of celery will answer the same purpose.
10136-8{_}1564{_}CELERY.--This plant is indigenous to Britain, and, in its wild     state, grows by the side of ditches and along some parts of the     seacoast.
10136-8{_}1565{_}In this state it is called _smallaqe_, and, to some     extent, is a dangerous narcotic.
10136-8{_}1566{_}By cultivation, however, it has     been brought to the fine flavour which the garden plant     possesses.
10136-8{_}1567{_}In the vicinity of Manchester it is raised to an     enormous size.
10136-8{_}1568{_}When our natural observation is assisted by the     accurate results ascertained by the light of science, how     infinitely does it enhance our delight in contemplating the     products of nature!
10136-8{_}1569{_}To know, for example, that the endless     variety of colour which we see in plants is developed only by     the rays of the sun, is to know a truism sublime by its very     comprehensiveness.
10136-8{_}1570{_}The cause of the whiteness of celery is     nothing more than the want of light in its vegetation, and in     order that this effect may be produced, the plant is almost     wholly covered with earth; the tops of the leaves alone being     suffered to appear above the ground.
10136-8{_}1571{_}CHANTILLY SOUP.
10136-8{_}1572{_}123.
10136-8{_}1573{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 quart of young green peas, a small bunch of parsley, 2 young onions, 2 quarts of medium stock No.
10136-8{_}1574{_}105.
10136-8{_}1575{_}_Mode_.--Boil the peas till quite tender, with the parsley and onions; then rub them through a sieve, and pour the stock to them.
10136-8{_}1576{_}Do not let it boil after the peas are added, or you will spoil the colour.
10136-8{_}1577{_}Serve very hot.
10136-8{_}1578{_}_Time_.--Half an hour.
10136-8{_}1579{_}_Average_ cost, 1s.
10136-8{_}1580{_}6d.
10136-8{_}1581{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}1582{_}_Seasonable_ from June to the end of August.
10136-8{_}1583{_}_Sufficient_ for 8 persons.
10136-8{_}1584{_}_Note_.--Cold peas pounded in a mortar, with a little stock added to them, make a very good soup in haste.
10136-8{_}1585{_}Parsley.--Among the Greeks, in the classic ages, a crown of     parsley was awarded, both in the Nemaean and Isthmian games, and     the voluptuous Anacreon pronounces this beautiful herb the     emblem of joy and festivity.
10136-8{_}1586{_}It has an elegant leaf, and is     extensively used in the culinary art.
10136-8{_}1587{_}When it was introduced to     Britain is not known.
10136-8{_}1588{_}There are several varieties,--the     _plain_-leaved and the _curled_-leaved, _celery_-parsley,     _Hamburg_ parsley, and _purslane_.
10136-8{_}1589{_}The curled is the best, and,     from the form of its leaf, has a beautiful appearance on a dish     as a garnish.
10136-8{_}1590{_}Its flavour is, to many, very agreeable in soups;     and although to rabbits, hares, and sheep it is a luxury, to     parrots it is a poison.
10136-8{_}1591{_}The celery-parsley is used as a celery,     and the Hamburg is cultivated only for its roots, which are used     as parsnips or carrots, to eat with meat.
10136-8{_}1592{_}The purslane is a     native of South America, and is not now much in use.
10136-8{_}1593{_}CHESTNUT (SPANISH) SOUP.
10136-8{_}1594{_}124.
10136-8{_}1595{_}INGREDIENTS.--3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}1596{_}of Spanish chestnuts, 1/4 pint of cream; seasoning to taste of salt, cayenne, and mace; 1 quart of stock No.
10136-8{_}1597{_}105.
10136-8{_}1598{_}_Mode_.--Take the outer rind from the chestnuts, and put them into a large pan of warm water.
10136-8{_}1599{_}As soon as this becomes too hot for the fingers to remain in it, take out the chestnuts, peel them quickly, and immerse them in cold water, and wipe and weigh them.
10136-8{_}1600{_}Now cover them with good stock, and stew them gently for rather more than 3/4 of an hour, or until they break when touched with a fork; then drain, pound, and rub them through a fine sieve reversed; add sufficient stock, mace, cayenne, and salt, and stir it often until it boils, and put in the cream.
10136-8{_}1601{_}The stock in which the chestnuts are boiled can be used for the soup, when its sweetness is not objected to, or it may, in part, be added to it; and the rule is, that 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}1602{_}of chestnuts should be given to each quart of soup.
10136-8{_}1603{_}_Time_.--rather more than 1 hour.
10136-8{_}1604{_}_Average cost_ per quart, 1s.
10136-8{_}1605{_}6d.
10136-8{_}1606{_}_Seasonable_ from October to February.
10136-8{_}1607{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}1608{_}[Illustration: CHESTNUT.]
10136-8{_}1609{_}THE CHESTNUT.--This fruit is said, by some, to have originally     come from Sardis, in Lydia; and by others, from Castanea, a city     of Thessaly, from which it takes its name.
10136-8{_}1610{_}By the ancients it     was much used as a food, and is still common in France and     Italy, to which countries it is, by some, considered indigenous.
10136-8{_}1611{_}In the southern part of the European continent, it is eaten both     raw and roasted.
10136-8{_}1612{_}The tree was introduced into Britain by the     Romans; but it only flourishes in the warmer parts of the     island, the fruit rarely arriving at maturity in Scotland.
10136-8{_}1613{_}It     attains a great age, as well as an immense size.
10136-8{_}1614{_}As a food, it     is the least oily and most farinaceous of all the nuts, and,     therefore, the easiest of digestion.
10136-8{_}1615{_}The tree called the _horse     chestnut_ is very different, although its fruit very much     resembles that of the other.
10136-8{_}1616{_}Its "nuts," though eaten by horses     and some other animals, are unsuitable for human food.
10136-8{_}1617{_}COCOA-NUT SOUP.
10136-8{_}1618{_}125.
10136-8{_}1619{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 oz.
10136-8{_}1620{_}of grated cocoa-nut, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}1621{_}of rice flour, 1/2 a teaspoonful of mace; seasoning to taste of cayenne and salt; 1/4 of a pint of boiling cream, 3 quarts of medium stock No.
10136-8{_}1622{_}105.
10136-8{_}1623{_}_Mode_.--Take the dark rind from the cocoa-nut, and grate it down small on a clean grater; weigh it, and allow, for each quart of stock, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}1624{_}of the cocoa-nut.
10136-8{_}1625{_}Simmer it gently for 1 hour in the stock, which should then be strained closely from it, and thickened for table.
10136-8{_}1626{_}_Time_.--2-1/4 hours.
10136-8{_}1627{_}_Average cost_ per quart, 1s.
10136-8{_}1628{_}3d.
10136-8{_}1629{_}_Seasonable_ in Autumn.
10136-8{_}1630{_}_Sufficient_ for 10 persons.
10136-8{_}1631{_}[Illustration: COCOA-NUT PALM.]
10136-8{_}1632{_}[Illustration: NUT & BLOSSOM.]
10136-8{_}1633{_}THE COCOA-NUT.--This is the fruit of one of the palms, than     which it is questionable if there is any other species of tree     marking, in itself, so abundantly the goodness of Providence, in     making provision for the wants of man.
10136-8{_}1634{_}It grows wild in the     Indian seas, and in the eastern parts of Asia; and thence it has     been introduced into every part of the tropical regions.
10136-8{_}1635{_}To the     natives of those climates, its bark supplies the material for     creating their dwellings; its leaves, the means of roofing them;     and the leaf-stalks, a kind of gauze for covering their windows,     or protecting the baby in the cradle.
10136-8{_}1636{_}It is also made into     lanterns, masks to screen the face from the heat of the sun,     baskets, wicker-work, and even a kind of paper for writing on.
10136-8{_}1637{_}Combs, brooms, torches, ropes, matting, and sailcloth are made     of its fibers.
10136-8{_}1638{_}With these, too, beds are made and cushions     stuffed.
10136-8{_}1639{_}Oars are supplied by the leaves; drinking-cups, spoons,     and other domestic utensils by the shells of the nuts; milk by     its juice, of which, also, a kind of honey and sugar are     prepared.
10136-8{_}1640{_}When fermented, it furnishes the means of     intoxication; and when the fibres are burned, their ashes supply     an alkali for making soap.
10136-8{_}1641{_}The buds of the tree bear a striking     resemblance to cabbage when boiled; but when they are cropped,     the tree dies.
10136-8{_}1642{_}In a fresh state, the kernel is eaten raw, and     its juice is a most agreeable and refreshing beverage.
10136-8{_}1643{_}When the     nut is imported to this country, its fruit is, in general,     comparatively dry, and is considered indigestible.
10136-8{_}1644{_}The tree is     one of the least productive of the palm tribe.
10136-8{_}1645{_}SOUP A LA CRECY.
10136-8{_}1646{_}126.
10136-8{_}1647{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 carrots, 2 sliced onions, 1 cut lettuce, and chervil; 2 oz.
10136-8{_}1648{_}butter, 1 pint of lentils, the crumbs of 2 French rolls, half a teacupful of rice, 2 quarts of medium stock No.
10136-8{_}1649{_}105.
10136-8{_}1650{_}_Mode_.--Put the vegetables with the butter in the stewpan, and let them simmer 5 minutes; then add the lentils and 1 pint of the stock, and stew gently for half an hour.
10136-8{_}1651{_}Now fill it up with the remainder of the stock, let it boil another hour, and put in the crumb of the rolls.
10136-8{_}1652{_}When well soaked, rub all through a tammy.
10136-8{_}1653{_}Have ready the rice boiled; pour the soup over this, and serve.
10136-8{_}1654{_}_Time_.--1-3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}1655{_}_Average cost_,1s.
10136-8{_}1656{_}2d.
10136-8{_}1657{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}1658{_}_Seasonable_ all the year.
10136-8{_}1659{_}_Sufficient_ for 8 persons.
10136-8{_}1660{_}[Illustration: THE LENTIL.]
10136-8{_}1661{_}THE LENTIL.--This belongs to the legumious or _pulse_ kind of     vegetables, which rank next to the corn plants in their     nutritive properties.
10136-8{_}1662{_}The lentil is a variety of the bean tribe,     but in England is not used as human food, although considered     the best of all kinds for pigeons.
10136-8{_}1663{_}On the Continent it is     cultivated for soups, as well as for other preparations for the     table; and among the presents which David received from Shobi,     as recounted in the Scriptures, were beans, lentils, and parched     pulse.
10136-8{_}1664{_}Among the Egyptians it was extensively used, and among     the Greeks, the Stoics had a maxim, which declared, that "a wise     man acts always with reason, and prepares his own lentils."
10136-8{_}1665{_}Among the Romans it was not much esteemed, and from them the     English may have inherited a prejudice against it, on account,     it is said, of its rendering men indolent.
10136-8{_}1666{_}It takes its name     from _lentus_ 'slow,' and, according to Pliny, produces mildness     and moderation of temper.
10136-8{_}1667{_}CUCUMBER SOUP (French Recipe).
10136-8{_}1668{_}127.
10136-8{_}1669{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 large cucumber, a piece of butter the size of a walnut, a little chervil and sorrel cut in large pieces, salt and pepper to taste, the yolks of 2 eggs, 1 gill of cream, 1 quart of medium stock No.
10136-8{_}1670{_}105.
10136-8{_}1671{_}_Mode_.--Pare the cucumber, quarter it, and take out the seeds; cut it in thin slices, put these on a plate with a little salt, to draw the water from them; drain, and put them in your stewpan, with the butter.
10136-8{_}1672{_}When they are warmed through, without being browned, pour the stock on them.
10136-8{_}1673{_}Add the sorrel, chervil, and seasoning, and boil for 40 minutes.
10136-8{_}1674{_}Mix the well-beaten yolks of the eggs with the cream, which add at the moment of serving.
10136-8{_}1675{_}_Time_.--1 hour.
10136-8{_}1676{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}1677{_}2d.
10136-8{_}1678{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}1679{_}_Seasonable_ from June to September.
10136-8{_}1680{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}1681{_}THE CUCUMBER.--The antiquity of this fruit is very great.
10136-8{_}1682{_}In the     sacred writings we find that the people of Israel regretted it,     whilst sojourning in the desert; and at the present time, the     cucumber, and other fruits of its class, form a large portion of     the food of the Egyptian people.
10136-8{_}1683{_}By the Eastern nations     generally, as well as by the Greeks and Romans, it was greatly     esteemed.
10136-8{_}1684{_}Like the melon, it was originally brought from Asia by     the Romans, and in the 14th century it was common in England,     although, in the time of the wars of "the Roses," it seems no     longer to have been cultivated.
10136-8{_}1685{_}It is a cold food, and of     difficult digestion when eaten raw.
10136-8{_}1686{_}As a preserved sweetmeat,     however, it is esteemed one of the most agreeable.
10136-8{_}1687{_}EGG SOUP.
10136-8{_}1688{_}128.
10136-8{_}1689{_}INGREDIENTS.--A tablespoonful of flour, 4 eggs, 2 small blades of finely-pounded mace, 2 quarts of stock No.
10136-8{_}1690{_}105.
10136-8{_}1691{_}_Mode_.--Beat up the flour smoothly in a teaspoonful of cold stock, and put in the eggs; throw them into boiling stock, stirring all the time.
10136-8{_}1692{_}Simmer for 1/4 of an hour.
10136-8{_}1693{_}Season and serve with a French roll in the tureen, or fried sippets of bread.
10136-8{_}1694{_}_Time_.
10136-8{_}1695{_}1/2 an hour.
10136-8{_}1696{_}_Average cost_,11d.
10136-8{_}1697{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}1698{_}_Seasonable_ all the year.
10136-8{_}1699{_}_Sufficient_ for 8 persons.
10136-8{_}1700{_}SOUP A LA FLAMANDE (Flemish).
10136-8{_}1701{_}I.
10136-8{_}1702{_}129.
10136-8{_}1703{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 turnip, 1 small carrot, 1/2 head of celery, 6 green onions shred very fine, 1 lettuce cut small, chervil, 1/4 pint of asparagus cut small, 1/4 pint of peas, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}1704{_}butter, the yolks of 4 eggs, 1/2 pint of cream, salt to taste, 1 lump of sugar, 2 quarts of stock No.
10136-8{_}1705{_}105.
10136-8{_}1706{_}_Mode_.--Put the vegetables in the butter to stew gently for an hour with a teacupful of stock; then add the remainder of the stock, and simmer for another hour.
10136-8{_}1707{_}Now beat the yolks of the eggs well, mix with the cream (previously boiled), and strain through a hair sieve.
10136-8{_}1708{_}Take the soup off the fire, put the eggs, &c. to it, and keep stirring it well.
10136-8{_}1709{_}Bring it to a boil, but do not leave off stirring, or the eggs will curdle.
10136-8{_}1710{_}Season with salt, and add the sugar.
10136-8{_}1711{_}_Time_.--24 hours.
10136-8{_}1712{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}1713{_}9d.
10136-8{_}1714{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}1715{_}_Seasonable_ from May to August.
10136-8{_}1716{_}_Sufficient_ for 8 persons.
10136-8{_}1717{_}CHERVIL.--Although the roots of this plant are poisonous, its     leaves are tender, and are used in salads.
10136-8{_}1718{_}In antiquity it made     a relishing dish, when prepared with oil, wine, and gravy.
10136-8{_}1719{_}It is     a native of various parts of Europe; and the species cultivated     in the gardens of Paris, has beautifully frizzled leaves.
10136-8{_}1720{_}II.
10136-8{_}1721{_}130.
10136-8{_}1722{_}INGREDIENTS.--5 onions, 5 heads of celery, 10 moderate-sized potatoes, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}1723{_}butter, 1/2 pint of water, 1/2 pint of cream, 2 quarts of stock No.
10136-8{_}1724{_}105.
10136-8{_}1725{_}_Mode_.--Slice the onions, celery, and potatoes, and put them with the butter and water into a stewpan, and simmer for an hour.
10136-8{_}1726{_}Then fill up the stewpan with stock, and boil gently till the potatoes are done, which will be in about an hour.
10136-8{_}1727{_}Rub all through a tammy, and add the cream (previously boiled).
10136-8{_}1728{_}Do not let it boil after the cream is put in.
10136-8{_}1729{_}_Time_.--2-1/2 hours.
10136-8{_}1730{_}__Average cost_,1s.
10136-8{_}1731{_}4d.
10136-8{_}1732{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}1733{_}_Seasonable_ from September to May.
10136-8{_}1734{_}_Sufficient_ for 8 persons.
10136-8{_}1735{_}_Note_.--This soup can be made with water instead of stock.
10136-8{_}1736{_}SOUP A LA JULIENNE.
10136-8{_}1737{_}[Illustration: STRIPS OF VEGETABLE.]
10136-8{_}1738{_}131.
10136-8{_}1739{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of carrots, 1/2 pint of turnips, 1/4 pint of onions, 2 or 3 leeks, 1/2 head of celery, 1 lettuce, a little sorrel and chervil, if liked, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}1740{_}of butter, 2 quarts of stock No.
10136-8{_}1741{_}105.
10136-8{_}1742{_}_Mode_.--Cut the vegetables into strips of about 1-1/4 inch long, and be particular they are all the same size, or some will be hard whilst the others will be done to a pulp.
10136-8{_}1743{_}Cut the lettuce, sorrel, and chervil into larger pieces; fry the carrots in the butter, and pour the stock boiling to them.
10136-8{_}1744{_}When this is done, add all the other vegetables, and herbs, and stew gently for at least an hour.
10136-8{_}1745{_}Skim off all the fat, pour the soup over thin slices of bread, cut round about the size of a shilling, and serve.
10136-8{_}1746{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}1747{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}1748{_}3d.
10136-8{_}1749{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}1750{_}_Seasonable_ all the year.
10136-8{_}1751{_}_Sufficient_ for 8 persons.
10136-8{_}1752{_}_Note_.--In summer, green peas, asparagus-tops, French beans, &c. can be added.
10136-8{_}1753{_}When the vegetables are very strong, instead of frying them in butter at first, they should be blanched, and afterwards simmered in the stock.
10136-8{_}1754{_}SORREL.--This is one of the _spinaceous_ plants, which take     their name from spinach, which is the chief among them.
10136-8{_}1755{_}It is     little used in English cookery, but a great deal in French, in     which it is employed for soups, sauces, and salads.
10136-8{_}1756{_}In English     meadows it is usually left to grow wild; but in France, where it     is cultivated, its flavour is greatly improved.
10136-8{_}1757{_}KALE BROSE (a Scotch Recipe).
10136-8{_}1758{_}132.
10136-8{_}1759{_}INGREDIENTS.--Half an ox-head or cow-heel, a teacupful of toasted oatmeal, salt to taste, 2 handfuls of greens, 3 quarts of water.
10136-8{_}1760{_}_Mode_.--Make a broth of the ox-head or cow-heel, and boil it till oil floats on the top of the liquor, then boil the greens, shred, in it.
10136-8{_}1761{_}Put the oatmeal, with a little salt, into a basin, and mix with it quickly a teacupful of the fat broth: it should not run into one doughy mass, but form knots.
10136-8{_}1762{_}Stir it into the whole, give one boil, and serve very hot.
10136-8{_}1763{_}_Time_.--4 hours.
10136-8{_}1764{_}_Average cost_, 8d.
10136-8{_}1765{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}1766{_}_Seasonable_ all the year, but more suitable in winter.
10136-8{_}1767{_}_Sufficient_ for 10 persons.
10136-8{_}1768{_}LEEK SOUP.
10136-8{_}1769{_}I.
10136-8{_}1770{_}133.
10136-8{_}1771{_}INGREDIENTS.--A sheep's head, 3 quarts of water, 12 leeks cut small, pepper and salt to taste, oatmeal to thicken.
10136-8{_}1772{_}_Mode_.--Prepare the head, either by skinning or cleaning the skin very nicely; split it in two; take out the brains, and put it into boiling water; add the leeks and seasoning, and simmer very gently for 4 hours.
10136-8{_}1773{_}Mix smoothly, with cold water, as much oatmeal as will make the soup tolerably thick; pour it into the soup; continue stirring till the whole is blended and well done, and serve.
10136-8{_}1774{_}_Time_.--4-1/2 hours.
10136-8{_}1775{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}1776{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}1777{_}_Seasonable_ in winter.
10136-8{_}1778{_}_Sufficient_ for 10 persons.
10136-8{_}1779{_}II.
10136-8{_}1780{_}COMMONLY CALLED COCK-A-LEEKIE.
10136-8{_}1781{_}134.
10136-8{_}1782{_}INGREDIENTS.--A capon or large fowl (sometimes an old cock, from which the recipe takes its name, is used), which should be trussed as for boiling; 2 or 3 bunches of fine leeks, 5 quarts of stock No.
10136-8{_}1783{_}105, pepper and salt to taste.
10136-8{_}1784{_}_Mode_.--Well wash the leeks (and, if old, scald them in boiling water for a few minutes), taking off the roots and part of the heads, and cut them into lengths of about an inch.
10136-8{_}1785{_}Put the fowl into the stock, with, at first, one half of the leeks, and allow it to simmer gently.
10136-8{_}1786{_}In half an hour add the remaining leeks, and then it may simmer for 3 or 4 hours longer.
10136-8{_}1787{_}It should be carefully skimmed, and can be seasoned to taste.
10136-8{_}1788{_}In serving, take out the fowl, and carve it neatly, placing the pieces in a tureen, and pouring over them the soup, which should be very thick of leeks (a _purée_ of leeks the French would call it).
10136-8{_}1789{_}_Time_.--4 hours.
10136-8{_}1790{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}1791{_}6d.
10136-8{_}1792{_}per quart; or, with stock No.
10136-8{_}1793{_}106, 1s.
10136-8{_}1794{_}_Seasonable_ in winter.
10136-8{_}1795{_}_Sufficient_ for 10 persons.
10136-8{_}1796{_}_Note_.--Without the fowl, the above, which would then be merely called leek soup, is very good, and also economical.
10136-8{_}1797{_}Cock-a-leekie was largely consumed at the Burns Centenary Festival at the Crystal Palace, Sydenham, in 1859.
10136-8{_}1798{_}[Illustration: LEEKS.]
10136-8{_}1799{_}THE LEEK.--As in the case of the cucumber, this vegetable was     bewailed by the Israelites in their journey through the desert.
10136-8{_}1800{_}It is one of the alliaceous tribe, which consists of the onion,     garlic, chive, shallot, and leek.
10136-8{_}1801{_}These, as articles of food,     are perhaps more widely diffused over the face of the earth than     any other _genus_ of edible plants.
10136-8{_}1802{_}It is the national badge of     the Welsh, and tradition ascribes to St. David its introduction     to that part of Britain.
10136-8{_}1803{_}The origin of the wearing of the leek     on St. David's day, among that people, is thus given in     "BEETON'S DICTIONARY of UNIVERSAL INFORMATION:"--"It probably     originated from the custom of _Cymhortha_, or the friendly aid,     practised among farmers.
10136-8{_}1804{_}In some districts of South Wales, all     the neighbours of a small farmer were wont to appoint a day when     they attended to plough his land, and the like; and, at such     time, it was the custom for each to bring his portion of leeks     with him for making the broth or soup."
10136-8{_}1805{_}(_See_ ST.
10136-8{_}1806{_}DAVID.)
10136-8{_}1807{_}Others derive the origin of the custom from the battle of     Cressy.
10136-8{_}1808{_}The plant, when grown in Wales and Scotland, is sharper     than it is in England, and its flavour is preferred by many to     that of the onion in broth.
10136-8{_}1809{_}It is very wholesome, and, to     prevent its tainting the breath, should be well boiled.
10136-8{_}1810{_}MACARONI SOUP.
10136-8{_}1811{_}135.
10136-8{_}1812{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 oz.
10136-8{_}1813{_}of macaroni, a piece of butter the size of a walnut, salt to taste, 2 quarts of clear stock No.
10136-8{_}1814{_}105.
10136-8{_}1815{_}_Mode_.--Throw the macaroni and butter into boiling water, with a pinch of salt, and simmer for 1/2 an hour.
10136-8{_}1816{_}When it is tender, drain and cut it into thin rings or lengths, and drop it into the boiling stock.
10136-8{_}1817{_}Stew gently for 15 minutes, and serve grated Parmesan cheese with it.
10136-8{_}1818{_}_Time_.--3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}1819{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}1820{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}1821{_}_Seasonable_ all the year.
10136-8{_}1822{_}_Sufficient_ for 8 persons.
10136-8{_}1823{_}[Illustration: MACARONI.]
10136-8{_}1824{_}MACARONI.--This is the favourite food of Italy, where,     especially among the Neapolitans, it may be regarded as the     staff of life.
10136-8{_}1825{_}"The crowd of London," says Mr. Forsyth, "is a     double line in quick motion; it is the crowd of business.
10136-8{_}1826{_}The     crowd of Naples consists in a general tide rolling up and down,     and in the middle of this tide, a hundred eddies of men.
10136-8{_}1827{_}You are     stopped by a carpenter's bench, you are lost among shoemakers'     stalls, and you dash among the _pots of a macaroni stall_."
10136-8{_}1828{_}This     article of food is nothing more than a thick paste, made of the     best wheaten flour, with a small quantity of water.
10136-8{_}1829{_}When it has     been well worked, it is put into a hollow cylindrical vessel,     pierced with holes of the size of tobacco-pipes at the bottom.
10136-8{_}1830{_}Through these holes the mass is forced by a powerful screw     bearing on a piece of wood made exactly to fit the inside of the     cylinder.
10136-8{_}1831{_}Whilst issuing from the holes, it is partially baked     by a fire placed below the cylinder, and is, at the same time,     drawn away and hung over rods placed about the room, in order to     dry.
10136-8{_}1832{_}In a few days it is fit for use.
10136-8{_}1833{_}As it is both wholesome     and nutritious, it ought to be much more used by all classes in     England than it is.
10136-8{_}1834{_}It generally accompanies Parmesan cheese to     the tables of the rich, but is also used for thickening soups     and making puddings.
10136-8{_}1835{_}SOUP MAIGRE (i.e.
10136-8{_}1836{_}without Meat).
10136-8{_}1837{_}136.
10136-8{_}1838{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 oz.
10136-8{_}1839{_}butter, 6 onions sliced, 4 heads of celery, 2 lettuces, a small bunch of parsley, 2 handfuls of spinach, 3 pieces of bread-crust, 2 blades of mace, salt and pepper to taste, the yolks of 2 eggs, 3 teaspoonfuls of vinegar, 2 quarts of water.
10136-8{_}1840{_}_Mode_.--Melt the butter in a stewpan, and put in the onions to stew gently for 3 or 4 minutes; then add the celery, spinach, lettuces, and parsley, cut small.
10136-8{_}1841{_}Stir the ingredients well for 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}1842{_}Now put in the water, bread, seasoning, and mace.
10136-8{_}1843{_}Boil gently for 1-1/2 hour, and, at the moment of serving, beat in the yolks of the eggs and the vinegar, but do not let it boil, or the eggs will curdle.
10136-8{_}1844{_}_Time_.--2 hours.
10136-8{_}1845{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}1846{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}1847{_}_Seasonable_ all the year.
10136-8{_}1848{_}_Sufficient_ for 8 persons.
10136-8{_}1849{_}[Illustration: LETTUCE.]
10136-8{_}1850{_}THE LETTUCE.--This is one of the acetarious vegetables, which     comprise a large class, chiefly used as pickles, salads, and     other condiments.
10136-8{_}1851{_}The lettuce has in all antiquity been     distinguished as a kitchen-garden plant.
10136-8{_}1852{_}It was, without     preparation, eaten by the Hebrews with the Paschal lamb; the     Greeks delighted in it, and the Romans, in the time of Domitian,     had it prepared with eggs, and served in the first course at     their tables, merely to excite their appetites.
10136-8{_}1853{_}Its botanical     name is _Lactuca_, so called from the milky juice it exudes when     its stalks are cut.
10136-8{_}1854{_}It possesses a narcotic virtue, noticed by     ancient physicians; and even in our day a lettuce supper is     deemed conducive to repose.
10136-8{_}1855{_}Its proper character, however, is     that of a cooling summer vegetable, not very nutritive, but     serving as a corrective, or diluent of animal food.
10136-8{_}1856{_}MILK SOUP (a Nice Dish for Children).
10136-8{_}1857{_}137.
10136-8{_}1858{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 quarts of milk, 1 saltspoonful of salt, 1 teaspoonful of powdered cinnamon, 3 teaspoonfuls of pounded sugar, or more if liked, 4 thin slices of bread, the yolks of 6 eggs.
10136-8{_}1859{_}_Mode_.--Boil the milk with the salt, cinnamon, and sugar; lay the bread in a deep dish, pour over it a little of the milk, and keep it hot over a stove, without burning.
10136-8{_}1860{_}Beat up the yolks of the eggs, add them to the milk, and stir it over the fire till it thickens.
10136-8{_}1861{_}Do not let it curdle.
10136-8{_}1862{_}Pour it upon the bread, and serve.
10136-8{_}1863{_}_Time_.--3/4 of an hour.
10136-8{_}1864{_}_Average cost_, 8d.
10136-8{_}1865{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}1866{_}_Seasonable_ all the year.
10136-8{_}1867{_}_Sufficient_ for 10 children.
10136-8{_}1868{_}ONION SOUP.
10136-8{_}1869{_}138.
10136-8{_}1870{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 large onions, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}1871{_}of butter, salt and pepper to taste, 1/4 pint of cream, 1 quart of stock No.
10136-8{_}1872{_}105.
10136-8{_}1873{_}_Mode_.--Chop the onions, put them in the butter, stir them occasionally, but do not let them brown.
10136-8{_}1874{_}When tender, put the stock to them, and season; strain the soup, and add the boiling cream.
10136-8{_}1875{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}1876{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}1877{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}1878{_}_Seasonable_ in winter.
10136-8{_}1879{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}1880{_}CHEAP ONION SOUP.
10136-8{_}1881{_}139.
10136-8{_}1882{_}INGREDIENTS.--8 middling-sized onions, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}1883{_}of butter, a tablespoonful of rice-flour, salt and pepper to taste, 1 teaspoonful of powdered sugar, thickening of butter and flour, 2 quarts of water.
10136-8{_}1884{_}_Mode_.--Cut the onions small, put them in the stewpan with the butter, and fry them well; mix the rice-flour smoothly with the water, add the onions, seasoning, and sugar, and simmer till tender.
10136-8{_}1885{_}Thicken with butter and flour, and serve.
10136-8{_}1886{_}_Time_.--2 hours.
10136-8{_}1887{_}_Average cost_,4d.
10136-8{_}1888{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}1889{_}_Seasonable_ in winter.
10136-8{_}1890{_}_Sufficient_ for 8 persons.
10136-8{_}1891{_}[Illustration: ONION.]
10136-8{_}1892{_}THE ONION.--Like the cabbage, this plant was erected into an     object of worship by the idolatrous Egyptians 2,000 years before     the Christian era, and it still forms a favourite food in the     country of these people, as well as in other parts of Africa.
10136-8{_}1893{_}When it was first introduced to England, has not been     ascertained; but it has long been in use, and esteemed as a     favourite seasoning plant to various dishes.
10136-8{_}1894{_}In warmer climates     it is much milder in its flavour; and such as are grown in Spain     and Portugal, are, comparatively speaking, very large, and are     often eaten both in a boiled and roasted state.
10136-8{_}1895{_}The Strasburg is     the most esteemed; and, although all the species have highly     nutritive properties, they impart such a disagreeable odour to     the breath, that they are often rejected even where they are     liked.
10136-8{_}1896{_}Chewing a little raw parsley is said to remove this     odour.
10136-8{_}1897{_}PAN KAIL.
10136-8{_}1898{_}140.
10136-8{_}1899{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 lbs.
10136-8{_}1900{_}of cabbage, or Savoy greens; 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}1901{_}of butter or dripping, salt and pepper to taste, oatmeal for thickening, 2 quarts of water.
10136-8{_}1902{_}_Mode_.--Chop the cabbage very fine, thicken the water with oatmeal, put in the cabbage and butter, or dripping; season and simmer for 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}1903{_}It can be made sooner by blanching and mashing the greens, adding any good liquor that a joint has been boiled in, and then further thicken with bread or pounded biscuit.
10136-8{_}1904{_}_Time_--1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}1905{_}_Average cost_, 1-1/2d.
10136-8{_}1906{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}1907{_}_Seasonable_ all the year, but more suitable in winter.
10136-8{_}1908{_}_Sufficient_ for 8 persons.
10136-8{_}1909{_}THE SAVOY.--This is a close-hearted wrinkle-leaved cabbage,     sweet and tender, especially the middle leaves, and in season     from November to spring.
10136-8{_}1910{_}The yellow species bears hard weather     without injury, whilst the _dwarf_ kind are improved and     rendered more tender by frost.
10136-8{_}1911{_}PARSNIP SOUP.
10136-8{_}1912{_}141.
10136-8{_}1913{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}1914{_}of sliced parsnips, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}1915{_}of butter, salt and cayenne to taste, 1 quart of stock No.
10136-8{_}1916{_}106.
10136-8{_}1917{_}_Mode_.--Put the parsnips into the stewpan with the butter, which has been previously melted, and simmer them till quite tender.
10136-8{_}1918{_}Then add nearly a pint of stock, and boil together for half an hour.
10136-8{_}1919{_}Pass all through a fine strainer, and put to it the remainder of the stock.
10136-8{_}1920{_}Season, boil, and serve immediately.
10136-8{_}1921{_}_Time_.--2 hours.
10136-8{_}1922{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}1923{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}1924{_}_Seasonable_ from October to April.
10136-8{_}1925{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}1926{_}THE PARSNIP.--This is a biennial plant, with a root like a     carrot, which, in nutritive and saccharine matter, it nearly     equals.
10136-8{_}1927{_}It is a native of Britain, and, in its wild state, may     be found, in many parts, growing by the road-sides.
10136-8{_}1928{_}It is also     to be found, generally distributed over Europe; and, in Catholic     countries, is mostly used with salt fish, in Lent.
10136-8{_}1929{_}In Scotland     it forms an excellent dish, when beat up with butter and     potatoes; it is, also, excellent when fried.
10136-8{_}1930{_}In Ireland it is     found to yield, in conjunction with the hop, a pleasant     beverage; and it contains as much spirit as the carrot, and     makes an excellent wine.
10136-8{_}1931{_}Its proportion of nutritive matter is     99 parts in 1,000; 9 being mucilage and 90 sugar.
10136-8{_}1932{_}PEA SOUP (GREEN).
10136-8{_}1933{_}142.
10136-8{_}1934{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 pints of green peas, 1/4 lb.
