10136-8{_}2805{_}The green turtle is highly prized on     account of the delicious quality of its flesh, the fat of the     upper and lower shields of the animal being esteemed the richest     and most delicate parts.
10136-8{_}2806{_}The soup, however, is apt to disagree     with weak stomachs.
10136-8{_}2807{_}As an article of luxury, the turtle has only     come into fashion within the last 100 years, and some hundreds     of tureens of turtle soup are served annually at the lord     mayor's dinner in Guildhall.
10136-8{_}2808{_}A GOOD FAMILY SOUP.
10136-8{_}2809{_}190.
10136-8{_}2810{_}INGREDIENTS.--Remains of a cold tongue, 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}2811{_}of shin of beef, any cold pieces of meat or beef-bones, 2 turnips, 2 carrots, 2 onions, 1 parsnip, 1 head of celery, 4 quarts of water, 1/2 teacupful of rice; salt and pepper to taste.
10136-8{_}2812{_}_Mode_.--Put all the ingredients in a stewpan, and simmer gently for 4 hours, or until all the goodness is drawn from the meat.
10136-8{_}2813{_}Strain off the soup, and let it stand to get cold.
10136-8{_}2814{_}The kernels and soft parts of the tongue must be saved.
10136-8{_}2815{_}When the soup is wanted for use, skim off all the fat, put in the kernels and soft parts of the tongue, slice in a small quantity of fresh carrot, turnip, and onion; stew till the vegetables are tender, and serve with toasted bread.
10136-8{_}2816{_}_Time_.--5 hours.
10136-8{_}2817{_}__Average cost_,3d.
10136-8{_}2818{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}2819{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}2820{_}_Sufficient_ for 12 persons.
10136-8{_}2821{_}HODGE-PODGE.
10136-8{_}2822{_}191.
10136-8{_}2823{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 lbs.
10136-8{_}2824{_}of shin of beef, 3 quarts of water, 1 pint of table-beer, 2 onions, 2 carrots, 2 turnips, 1 head of celery; pepper and salt to taste; thickening of butter and flour.
10136-8{_}2825{_}_Mode_.--Put the meat, beer, and water in a stewpan; simmer for a few minutes, and skim carefully.
10136-8{_}2826{_}Add the vegetables and seasoning; stew gently till the meat is tender.
10136-8{_}2827{_}Thicken with the butter and flour, and serve with turnips and carrots, or spinach and celery.
10136-8{_}2828{_}_Time_.--3 hours, or rather more.
10136-8{_}2829{_}_Average cost_, 3d.
10136-8{_}2830{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}2831{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}2832{_}_Sufficient_ for 12 persons.
10136-8{_}2833{_}TABLE BEER.--This is nothing more than a weak ale, and is not     made so much with a view to strength, as to transparency of     colour and an agreeable bitterness of taste.
10136-8{_}2834{_}It is, or ought to     be, manufactured by the London professional brewers, from the     best pale malt, or amber and malt.
10136-8{_}2835{_}Six barrels are usually drawn     from one quarter of malt, with which are mixed 4 or 5 lbs.
10136-8{_}2836{_}of     hops.
10136-8{_}2837{_}As a beverage, it is agreeable when fresh; but it is not     adapted to keep long.
10136-8{_}2838{_}FISH SOUPS.
10136-8{_}2839{_}FISH STOCK.
10136-8{_}2840{_}192.
10136-8{_}2841{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 lbs.
10136-8{_}2842{_}of beef or veal (these can be omitted), any kind of white fish trimmings, of fish which are to be dressed for table, 2 onions, the rind of 1/2 a lemon, a bunch of sweet herbs, 2 carrots, 2 quarts of water.
10136-8{_}2843{_}_Mode_.--Cut up the fish, and put it, with the other ingredients, into the water.
10136-8{_}2844{_}Simmer for 2 hours; skim the liquor carefully, and strain it.
10136-8{_}2845{_}When a richer stock is wanted, fry the vegetables and fish before adding the water.
10136-8{_}2846{_}_Time_.--2 hours.
10136-8{_}2847{_}_Average cost_, with meat, 10d.
10136-8{_}2848{_}per quart; without, 3d.
10136-8{_}2849{_}_Note_.--Do not make fish stock long before it is wanted, as it soon turns sour.
10136-8{_}2850{_}CRAYFISH SOUP.
10136-8{_}2851{_}193.
10136-8{_}2852{_}INGREDIENTS.--50 crayfish, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}2853{_}of butter, 6 anchovies, the crumb of 1 French roll, a little lobster-spawn, seasoning to taste, 2 quarts of medium stock, No.
10136-8{_}2854{_}105, or fish stock, No.
10136-8{_}2855{_}192.
10136-8{_}2856{_}_Mode_.--Shell the crayfish, and put the fish between two plates until they are wanted; pound the shells in a mortar, with the butter and anchovies; when well beaten, add a pint of stock, and simmer for 3/4 of an hour.
10136-8{_}2857{_}Strain it through a hair sieve, put the remainder of the stock to it, with the crumb of the rolls; give it one boil, and rub it through a tammy, with the lobster-spawn.
10136-8{_}2858{_}Put in the fish, but do not let the soup boil, after it has been rubbed through the tammy.
10136-8{_}2859{_}If necessary, add seasoning.
10136-8{_}2860{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}2861{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}2862{_}3d.
10136-8{_}2863{_}or 1s.
10136-8{_}2864{_}9d.
10136-8{_}2865{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}2866{_}_Seasonable_ from January to July.
10136-8{_}2867{_}_Sufficient_ for 8 persons.
10136-8{_}2868{_}[Illustration: CRAYFISH.]
10136-8{_}2869{_}THE CRAYFISH.--This is one of those fishes that were highly     esteemed by the ancients.
10136-8{_}2870{_}The Greeks preferred it when brought     from Alexandria, and the Romans ate it boiled with cumin, and     seasoned with pepper and other condiments.
10136-8{_}2871{_}A recipe tells us,     that crayfish can be preserved several days in baskets with     fresh grass, such as the nettle, or in a bucket with about     three-eighths of an inch of water.
10136-8{_}2872{_}More water would kill them,     because the large quantity of air they require necessitates the     water in which they are kept, to be continually renewed.
10136-8{_}2873{_}EEL SOUP.
10136-8{_}2874{_}194.
10136-8{_}2875{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 lbs.
10136-8{_}2876{_}of eels, 1 onion, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}2877{_}of butter, 3 blades of mace, 1 bunch of sweet herbs, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}2878{_}of peppercorns, salt to taste, 2 tablespoonfuls of flour, 1/4 pint of cream, 2 quarts of water.
10136-8{_}2879{_}_Mode_.--Wash the eels, cut them into thin slices, and put them in the stewpan with the butter; let them simmer for a few minutes, then pour the water to them, and add the onion, cut in thin slices, the herbs, mace, and seasoning.
10136-8{_}2880{_}Simmer till the eels are tender, but do not break the fish.
10136-8{_}2881{_}Take them out carefully, mix the flour smoothly to a batter with the cream, bring it to a boil, pour over the eels, and serve.
10136-8{_}2882{_}_Time_.--1 hour, or rather more.
10136-8{_}2883{_}_Average cost_, 10d.
10136-8{_}2884{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}2885{_}_Seasonable_ from June to March.
10136-8{_}2886{_}_Sufficient_ for 8 persons.
10136-8{_}2887{_}_Note_.--This soup may be flavoured differently by omitting the cream, and adding a little ketchup or Harvey's sauce.
10136-8{_}2888{_}LOBSTER SOUP.
10136-8{_}2889{_}195.
10136-8{_}2890{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 large lobsters, or 6 small ones; the crumb of a French roll, 2 anchovies, 1 onion, 1 small bunch of sweet herbs, 1 strip of lemon-peel, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}2891{_}of butter, a little nutmeg, 1 teaspoonful of flour, 1 pint of cream, 1 pint of milk; forcemeat balls, mace, salt and pepper to taste, bread crumbs, 1 egg, 2 quarts of water.
10136-8{_}2892{_}_Mode_.--Pick the meat from the lobsters, and beat the fins, chine, and small claws in a mortar, previously taking away the brown fin and the bag in the head.
10136-8{_}2893{_}Put it in a stewpan, with the crumb of the roll, anchovies, onions, herbs, lemon-peel, and the water; simmer gently till all the goodness is extracted, and strain it off.
10136-8{_}2894{_}Pound the spawn in a mortar, with the butter, nutmeg, and flour, and mix with it the cream and milk.
10136-8{_}2895{_}Give one boil up, at the same time adding the tails cut in pieces.
10136-8{_}2896{_}Make the forcemeat balls with the remainder of the lobster, seasoned with mace, pepper, and salt, adding a little flour, and a few bread crumbs; moisten them with the egg, heat them in the soup, and serve.
10136-8{_}2897{_}_Time_.--2 hours, or rather more.
10136-8{_}2898{_}_Average cost_, 3s 6d per quart.
10136-8{_}2899{_}_Seasonable_ from April to October.
10136-8{_}2900{_}_Sufficient_ for 8 persons.
10136-8{_}2901{_}OYSTER SOUP.
10136-8{_}2902{_}I.
10136-8{_}2903{_}196.
10136-8{_}2904{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 dozen of oysters, 2 quarts of white stock, 1/2 pint of cream, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}2905{_}of butter, 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}2906{_}of flour; salt, cayenne, and mace to taste.
10136-8{_}2907{_}_Mode_.--Scald the oysters in their own liquor; take them out, beard them, and put them in a tureen.
10136-8{_}2908{_}Take a pint of the stock, put in the beards and the liquor, which must be carefully strained, and simmer for 1/2 an hour.
10136-8{_}2909{_}Take it off the fire, strain it again, and add the remainder of the stock with the seasoning and mace.
10136-8{_}2910{_}Bring it to a boil, add the thickening of butter and flour, simmer for 5 minutes, stir in the boiling cream, pour it over the oysters, and serve.
10136-8{_}2911{_}_Time_.--1 hour.
10136-8{_}2912{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}2913{_}8d.
10136-8{_}2914{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}2915{_}_Seasonable_ from September to April.
10136-8{_}2916{_}_Sufficient_ for 8 persons.
10136-8{_}2917{_}_Note_.--This soup can be made less rich by using milk instead of cream, and thickening with arrowroot instead of butter and flour.
10136-8{_}2918{_}II.
10136-8{_}2919{_}197.
10136-8{_}2920{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 quarts of good mutton broth, 6 dozen oysters, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}2921{_}butter, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}2922{_}of flour.
10136-8{_}2923{_}_Mode_.--Beard the oysters, and scald them in their own liquor; then add it, well strained, to the broth; thicken with the butter and flour, and simmer for 1/4 of an hour.
10136-8{_}2924{_}Put in the oysters, stir well, but do not let it boil, and serve very hot.
10136-8{_}2925{_}_Time_.--3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}2926{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}2927{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}2928{_}_Seasonable_ from September to April.
10136-8{_}2929{_}_Sufficient_ for 8 persons.
10136-8{_}2930{_}SEASON OF OYSTERS.--From April and May to the end of July,     oysters are said to be sick; but by the end of August they     become healthy, having recovered from the effects of spawning.
10136-8{_}2931{_}When they are not in season, the males have a black, and the     females a milky substance in the gill.
10136-8{_}2932{_}From some lines of     Oppian, it would appear that the ancients were ignorant that the     oyster is generally found adhering to rocks.
10136-8{_}2933{_}The starfish is one     of the most deadly enemies of these bivalves.
10136-8{_}2934{_}The poet says:--        The prickly star creeps on with full deceit       To force the oyster from his close retreat.
10136-8{_}2935{_}When gaping lids their widen'd void display,       The watchful star thrusts in a pointed ray,       Of all its treasures spoils the rifled case,       And empty shells the sandy hillock grace.
10136-8{_}2936{_}PRAWN SOUP.
10136-8{_}2937{_}198.
10136-8{_}2938{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 quarts of fish stock or water, 2 pints of prawns, the crumbs of a French roll, anchovy sauce or mushroom ketchup to taste, 1 blade of mace, 1 pint of vinegar, a little lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}2939{_}_Mode_.--Pick out the tails of the prawns, put the bodies in a stewpan with 1 blade of mace, 1/2 pint of vinegar, and the same quantity of water; stew them for 1/4 hour, and strain off the liquor.
10136-8{_}2940{_}Put the fish stock or water into a stewpan; add the strained liquor, pound the prawns with the crumb of a roll moistened with a little of the soup, rub them through a tammy, and mix them by degrees with the soup; add ketchup or anchovy sauce to taste, with a little lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}2941{_}When it is well cooked, put in a few picked prawns; let them get thoroughly hot, and serve.
10136-8{_}2942{_}If not thick enough, put in a little butter and flour.
10136-8{_}2943{_}_Time_.--hour.
10136-8{_}2944{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}2945{_}1d.
10136-8{_}2946{_}per quart, if made with water.
10136-8{_}2947{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}2948{_}_Sufficient_ for 8 persons.
10136-8{_}2949{_}_Note_.--This can be thickened with tomatoes, and vermicelli served in it, which makes it a very tasteful soup.
10136-8{_}2950{_}[Illustration: THE PRAWN.]
10136-8{_}2951{_}THE PRAWN.--This little fish bears a striking resemblance to the     shrimp, but is neither so common nor so small.
10136-8{_}2952{_}It is to be found     on most of the sandy shores of Europe.
10136-8{_}2953{_}The Isle of Wight is     famous for shrimps, where they are potted; but both the prawns     and the shrimps vended in London, are too much salted for the     excellence of their natural flavour to be preserved.
10136-8{_}2954{_}They are     extremely lively little animals, as seen in their native     retreats.
10136-8{_}2955{_}[Illustration]  FISH.
10136-8{_}2956{_}CHAPTER VII.
10136-8{_}2957{_}THE NATURAL HISTORY OF FISHES.
10136-8{_}2958{_}199.
10136-8{_}2959{_}IN NATURAL HISTORY, FISHES form the fourth class in the system of Linnaeus, and are described as having long under-jaws, eggs without white, organs of sense, fins for supporters, bodies covered with concave scales, gills to supply the place of lungs for respiration, and water for the natural element of their existence.
10136-8{_}2960{_}Had mankind no other knowledge of animals than of such as inhabit the land and breathe their own atmosphere, they would listen with incredulous wonder, if told that there were other kinds of beings which existed only in the waters, and which would die almost as soon as they were taken from them.
10136-8{_}2961{_}However strongly these facts might be attested, they would hardly believe them, without the operation of their own senses, as they would recollect the effect produced on their own bodies when immersed in water, and the impossibility of their sustaining life in it for any lengthened period of time.
10136-8{_}2962{_}Experience, however, has taught them, that the "great deep" is crowded with inhabitants of various sizes, and of vastly different constructions, with modes of life entirely distinct from those which belong to the animals of the land, and with peculiarities of design, equally wonderful with those of any other works which have come from the hand of the Creator.
10136-8{_}2963{_}The history of these races, however, must remain for ever, more or less, in a state of darkness, since the depths in which they live, are beyond the power of human exploration, and since the illimitable expansion of their domain places them almost entirely out of the reach of human accessibility.
10136-8{_}2964{_}200.
10136-8{_}2965{_}IN STUDYING THE CONFORMATION OF FISHES, we naturally conclude that they are, in every respect, well adapted to the element in which they have their existence.
10136-8{_}2966{_}Their shape has a striking resemblance to the lower part of a ship; and there is no doubt that the form of the fish originally suggested the form of the ship.
10136-8{_}2967{_}The body is in general slender, gradually diminishing towards each of its extremities, and flattened on each of its sides.
10136-8{_}2968{_}This is precisely the form of the lower part of the hull of a ship; and it enables both the animal and the vessel, with comparative ease, to penetrate and divide the resisting medium for which they have been adapted.
10136-8{_}2969{_}The velocity of a ship, however, in sailing before the wind, is by no means to be compared to that of a fish.
10136-8{_}2970{_}It is well known that the largest fishes will, with the greatest ease, overtake a ship in full sail, play round it without effort, and shoot ahead of it at pleasure.
10136-8{_}2971{_}This arises from their great flexibility, which, to compete with mocks the labours of art, and enables them to migrate thousands of miles in a season, without the slightest indications of languor or fatigue.
10136-8{_}2972{_}201.
10136-8{_}2973{_}THE PRINCIPAL INSTRUMENTS EMPLOYED BY FISHES to accelerate their motion, are their air-bladder, fins, and tail.
10136-8{_}2974{_}By means of the air-bladder they enlarge or diminish the specific gravity of their bodies.
10136-8{_}2975{_}When they wish to sink, they compress the muscles of the abdomen, and eject the air contained in it; by which, their weight, compared with that of the water, is increased, and they consequently descend.
10136-8{_}2976{_}On the other hand, when they wish to rise, they relax the compression of the abdominal muscles, when the air-bladder fills and distends, and the body immediately ascends to the surface.
10136-8{_}2977{_}How simply, yet how wonderfully, has the Supreme Being adapted certain means to the attainment of certain ends!
10136-8{_}2978{_}Those fishes which are destitute of the air-bladder are heavy in the water, and have no great "alacrity" in rising.
10136-8{_}2979{_}The larger proportion of them remain at the bottom, unless they are so formed as to be able to strike their native element downwards with sufficient force to enable them to ascend.
10136-8{_}2980{_}When the air-bladder of a fish is burst, its power of ascending to the surface has for ever passed away.
10136-8{_}2981{_}From a knowledge of this fact, the fishermen of cod are enabled to preserve them alive for a considerable time in their well-boats.
10136-8{_}2982{_}The means they adopt to accomplish this, is to perforate the sound, or air-bladder, with a needle, which disengages the air, when the fishes immediately descend to the bottom of the well, into which they are thrown.
10136-8{_}2983{_}Without this operation, it would be impossible to keep the cod under water whilst they had life.
10136-8{_}2984{_}In swimming, the _fins_ enable fishes to preserve their upright position, especially those of the belly, which act like two feet.
10136-8{_}2985{_}Without those, they would swim with their bellies upward, as it is in their backs that the centre of gravity lies.
10136-8{_}2986{_}In ascending and descending, these are likewise of great assistance, as they contract and expand accordingly.
10136-8{_}2987{_}The _tail_ is an instrument of great muscular force, and largely assists the fish in all its motions.
10136-8{_}2988{_}In some instances it acts like the rudder of a ship, and enables it to turn sideways; and when moved from side to side with a quick vibratory motion, fishes are made, in the same manner as the "screw" propeller makes a steamship, to dart forward with a celerity proportioned to the muscular force with which it is employed.
10136-8{_}2989{_}202.
10136-8{_}2990{_}THE BODIES OF FISHES are mostly covered with a kind of horny scales; but some are almost entirely without them, or have them so minute as to be almost invisible; as is the case with the eel.
10136-8{_}2991{_}The object of these is to preserve them from injury by the pressure of the water, or the sudden contact with pebbles, rocks, or sea-weeds.
10136-8{_}2992{_}Others, again, are enveloped in a fatty, oleaginous substance, also intended as a defence against the friction of the water; and those in which the scales are small, are supplied with a larger quantity of slimy matter.
10136-8{_}2993{_}203.
10136-8{_}2994{_}THE RESPIRATION OF FISHES is effected by means of those comb-like organs which are placed on each side of the neck, and which are called gills.
10136-8{_}2995{_}It is curious to watch the process of breathing as it is performed by the finny tribes.
10136-8{_}2996{_}It seems to be so continuous, that it might almost pass for an illustration of the vexed problem which conceals the secret of perpetual motion.
10136-8{_}2997{_}In performing it, they fill their mouths with water, which they drive backwards with a force so great as to open the large flap, to allow it to escape behind.
10136-8{_}2998{_}In this operation all, or a great portion, of the air contained in the water, is left among the feather-like processes of the gills, and is carried into the body, there to perform its part in the animal economy.
10136-8{_}2999{_}In proof of this, it has been ascertained that, if the water in which fishes are put, is, by any means, denuded of its air, they immediately seek the surface, and begin to gasp for it.
10136-8{_}3000{_}Hence, distilled water is to them what a vacuum made by an air-pump, is to most other animals.
10136-8{_}3001{_}For this reason, when a fishpond, or other aqueous receptacle in which fishes are kept, is entirely frozen over, it is necessary to make holes in the ice, not so especially for the purpose of feeding them, as for that of giving them air to breathe.
10136-8{_}3002{_}204.
10136-8{_}3003{_}THE POSITIONS OF THE TEETH OF FISHES are well calculated to excite our amazement; for, in some cases, these are situated in the jaws, sometimes on the tongue or palate, and sometimes even in the throat.
10136-8{_}3004{_}They are in general sharp-pointed and immovable; but in the carp they are obtuse, and in the pike so easily moved as to seem to have no deeper hold than such as the mere skin can afford.
10136-8{_}3005{_}In the herring, the tongue is set with teeth, to enable it the better, it is supposed, to retain its food.
10136-8{_}3006{_}205.
10136-8{_}3007{_}ALTHOUGH NATURALISTS HAVE DIVIDED FISHES into two great tribes, the _osseous_ and the _cartilaginous_, yet the distinction is not very precise; for the first have a great deal of cartilage, and the second, at any rate, a portion of calcareous matter in their bones.
10136-8{_}3008{_}It may, therefore, be said that the bones of fishes form a kind of intermediate substance between true bones and cartilages.
10136-8{_}3009{_}The backbone extends through the whole length of the body, and consists of vertebrae, strong and thick towards the head, but weaker and more slender as it approaches the tail.
10136-8{_}3010{_}Each species has a determinate number of vertebrae, which are increased in size in proportion with the body.
10136-8{_}3011{_}The ribs are attached to the processes of the vertebrae, and inclose the breast and abdomen.
10136-8{_}3012{_}Some kinds, as the rays, have no ribs; whilst others, as the sturgeon and eel, have very short ones.
10136-8{_}3013{_}Between the pointed processes of the vertebrae are situated the bones which support the dorsal (back) and the anal (below the tail) fins, which are connected with the processes by a ligament.
10136-8{_}3014{_}At the breast are the sternum or breastbone, clavicles or collar-bones, and the scapulae or shoulder-blades, on which the pectoral or breast fins are placed.
10136-8{_}3015{_}The bones which support the ventral or belly fins are called the _ossa pelvis_.
10136-8{_}3016{_}Besides these principal bones, there are often other smaller ones, placed between the muscles to assist their motion.
10136-8{_}3017{_}206.
10136-8{_}3018{_}SOME OF THE ORGANS OF SENSE IN FISHES are supposed to be possessed by them in a high degree, and others much more imperfectly.
10136-8{_}3019{_}Of the latter kind are the senses of touch and taste, which are believed to be very slightly developed.
10136-8{_}3020{_}On the other hand, those of hearing, seeing, and smelling, are ascertained to be acute, but the first in a lesser degree than both the second and third.
10136-8{_}3021{_}Their possession of an auditory organ was long doubted, and even denied by some physiologists; but it has been found placed on the sides of the skull, or in the cavity which contains the brain.
10136-8{_}3022{_}It occupies a position entirely distinct and detached from the skull, and, in this respect, differs in the local disposition of the same sense in birds and quadrupeds.
10136-8{_}3023{_}In some fishes, as in those of the ray kind, the organ is wholly encompassed by those parts which contain the cavity of the skull; whilst in the cod and salmon kind it is in the part within the skull.
10136-8{_}3024{_}Its structure is, in every way, much more simple than that of the same sense in those animals which live entirely in the air; but there is no doubt that they have the adaptation suitable to their condition.
10136-8{_}3025{_}In some genera, as in the rays, the external orifice or ear is very small, and is placed in the upper surface of the head; whilst in others there is no visible external orifice whatever.
10136-8{_}3026{_}However perfect the _sight_ of fishes may be, experience has shown that this sense is of much less use to them than that of smelling, in searching for their food.
10136-8{_}3027{_}The optic nerves in fishes have this peculiarity,--that they are not confounded with one another in their middle progress between their origin and their orbit.
10136-8{_}3028{_}The one passes over the other without any communication; so that the nerve which comes from the left side of the brain goes distinctly to the right eye, and that which comes from the right goes distinctly to the left.
10136-8{_}3029{_}In the greater part of them, the eye is covered with the same transparent skin that covers the rest of the head.
10136-8{_}3030{_}The object of this arrangement, perhaps, is to defend it from the action of the water, as there are no eyelids.
10136-8{_}3031{_}The globe in front is somewhat depressed, and is furnished behind with a muscle, which serves to lengthen or flatten it, according to the necessities of the animal.
10136-8{_}3032{_}The crystalline humour, which in quadrupeds is flattened, is, in fishes, nearly globular.
10136-8{_}3033{_}The organ of _smelling_ in fishes is large, and is endued, at its entry, with a dilating and contracting power, which is employed as the wants of the animal may require.
10136-8{_}3034{_}It is mostly by the acuteness of their smell that fishes are enabled to discover their food; for their tongue is not designed for nice sensation, being of too firm a cartilaginous substance for this purpose.
10136-8{_}3035{_}207.
10136-8{_}3036{_}WITH RESPECT TO THE FOOD OF FISHES, this is almost universally found in their own element.
10136-8{_}3037{_}They are mostly carnivorous, though they seize upon almost anything that comes in their way: they even devour their own offspring, and manifest a particular predilection for all living creatures.
10136-8{_}3038{_}Those, to which Nature has meted out mouths of the greatest capacity, would seem to pursue everything with life, and frequently engage in fierce conflicts with their prey.
10136-8{_}3039{_}The animal with the largest mouth is usually the victor; and he has no sooner conquered his foe than he devours him.
10136-8{_}3040{_}Innumerable shoals of one species pursue those of another, with a ferocity which draws them from the pole to the equator, through all the varying temperatures and depths of their boundless domain.
10136-8{_}3041{_}In these pursuits a scene of universal violence is the result; and many species must have become extinct, had not Nature accurately proportioned the means of escape, the production, and the numbers, to the extent and variety of the danger to which they are exposed.
10136-8{_}3042{_}Hence the smaller species are not only more numerous, but more productive than the larger; whilst their instinct leads them in search of food and safety near the shores, where, from the shallowness of the waters, many of their foes are unable to follow them.
10136-8{_}3043{_}208.
10136-8{_}3044{_}THE FECUNDITY OF FISHES has been the wonder of every natural philosopher whose attention has been attracted to the subject.
10136-8{_}3045{_}They are in general oviparous, or egg-producing; but there are a few, such as the eel and the blenny, which are viviparous, or produce their young alive.
10136-8{_}3046{_}The males have the _milt_ and the females the _roe_; but some individuals, as the sturgeon and the cod tribes, are said to contain both.
10136-8{_}3047{_}The greater number deposit their spawn in the sand or gravel; but some of those which dwell in the depths of the ocean attach their eggs to sea-weeds.
10136-8{_}3048{_}In every instance, however, their fruitfulness far surpasses that of any other race of animals.
10136-8{_}3049{_}According to Lewenhoeck, the cod annually spawns upwards of nine millions of eggs, contained in a single roe.
10136-8{_}3050{_}The flounder produces one million; the mackerel above five hundred thousand; a herring of a moderate size at least ten thousand; a carp fourteen inches in length, according to Petit, contained two hundred and sixty-two thousand two hundred and twenty-four; a perch deposited three hundred and eighty thousand six hundred and forty; and a female sturgeon seven millions six hundred and fifty-three thousand two hundred.
10136-8{_}3051{_}The viviparous species are by no means so prolific; yet the blenny brings forth two or three hundred at a time, which commence sporting together round their parent the moment they have come into existence.
10136-8{_}3052{_}209.
10136-8{_}3053{_}IN REFERENCE TO THE LONGEVITY OF FISHES, it is affirmed to surpass that of all other created beings; and it is supposed they are, to a great extent, exempted from the diseases to which the flesh of other animals is heir.
10136-8{_}3054{_}In place of suffering from the rigidity of age, which is the cause of the natural decay of those that "live and move and have their being" on the land, their bodies continue to grow with each succeeding supply of food, and the conduits of life to perform their functions unimpaired.
10136-8{_}3055{_}The age of fishes has not been properly ascertained, although it is believed that the most minute of the species has a longer lease of life than man.
10136-8{_}3056{_}The mode in which they die has been noted by the Rev.
10136-8{_}3057{_}Mr. White, the eminent naturalist of Selbourne.
10136-8{_}3058{_}As soon as the fish sickens, the head sinks lower and lower, till the animal, as it were, stands upon it.
10136-8{_}3059{_}After this, as it becomes weaker, it loses its poise, till the tail turns over, when it comes to the surface, and floats with its belly upwards.
10136-8{_}3060{_}The reason for its floating in this manner is on account of the body being no longer balanced by the fins of the belly, and the broad muscular back preponderating, by its own gravity, over the belly, from this latter being a cavity, and consequently lighter.
10136-8{_}3061{_}210.
10136-8{_}3062{_}FISHES ARE EITHER SOLITARY OR GREGARIOUS, and some of them migrate to great distances, and into certain rivers, to deposit their spawn.
10136-8{_}3063{_}Of sea-fishes, the cod, herring, mackerel, and many others, assemble in immense shoals, and migrate through different tracts of the ocean; but, whether considered in their solitary or gregarious capacity, they are alike wonderful to all who look through Nature up to Nature's God, and consider, with due humility, yet exalted admiration, the sublime variety, beauty, power, and grandeur of His productions, as manifested in the Creation.
10136-8{_}3064{_}FISH AS AN ARTICLE OF HUMAN FOOD.
10136-8{_}3065{_}211.
10136-8{_}3066{_}AS THE NUTRITIVE PROPERTIES OF FISH are deemed inferior to those of what is called butchers' meat, it would appear, from all we can learn, that, in all ages, it has held only a secondary place in the estimation of those who have considered the science of gastronomy as a large element in the happiness of mankind.
10136-8{_}3067{_}Among the Jews of old it was very little used, although it seems not to have been entirely interdicted, as Moses prohibited only the use of such as had neither scales nor fins.
10136-8{_}3068{_}The Egyptians, however, made fish an article of diet, notwithstanding that it was rejected by their priests.
10136-8{_}3069{_}Egypt, however, is not a country favourable to the production of fish, although we read of the people, when hungry, eating it raw; of epicures among them having dried it in the sun; and of its being salted and preserved, to serve as a repast on days of great solemnity.
10136-8{_}3070{_}The modern Egyptians are, in general, extremely temperate in     regard to food.
10136-8{_}3071{_}Even the richest among them take little pride,     and, perhaps, experience as little delight, in the luxuries of     the table.
10136-8{_}3072{_}Their dishes mostly consist of pilaus, soups, and     stews, prepared principally of onions, cucumbers, and other cold     vegetables, mixed with a little meat cut into small pieces.
10136-8{_}3073{_}On     special occasions, however, a whole sheep is placed on the     festive board; but during several of the hottest months of the     year, the richest restrict themselves entirely to a vegetable     diet.
10136-8{_}3074{_}The poor are contented with a little oil or sour milk, in     which they may dip their bread.
10136-8{_}3075{_}212.
10136-8{_}3076{_}PASSING FROM AFRICA TO EUROPE, we come amongst a people who have, almost from time immemorial, occupied a high place in the estimation of every civilized country; yet the Greeks, in their earlier ages, made very little use of fish as an article of diet.
10136-8{_}3077{_}In the eyes of the heroes of Homer it had little favour; for Menelaus complained that "hunger pressed their digestive organs," and they had been obliged to live upon fish.
10136-8{_}3078{_}Subsequently, however, fish became one of the principal articles of diet amongst the Hellenes; and both Aristophanes and Athenaeus allude to it, and even satirize their countrymen for their excessive partiality to the turbot and mullet.
10136-8{_}3079{_}So infatuated were many of the Greek gastronomes with the love     of fish, that some of them would have preferred death from     indigestion to the relinquishment of the precious dainties with     which a few of the species supplied them.
10136-8{_}3080{_}Philoxenes of Cythera     was one of these.
10136-8{_}3081{_}On being informed by his physician that he was     going to die of indigestion, on account of the quantity he was     consuming of a delicious fish, "Be it so," he calmly observed;     "but before I die, let me finish the remainder."
10136-8{_}3082{_}213.
10136-8{_}3083{_}THE GEOGRAPHICAL SITUATION OF GREECE was highly favourable for the development of a taste for the piscatory tribes; and the skill of the Greek cooks was so great, that they could impart every variety of relish to the dish they were called upon to prepare.
10136-8{_}3084{_}Athenaeus has transmitted to posterity some very important precepts upon their ingenuity in seasoning with salt, oil, and aromatics.
10136-8{_}3085{_}At the present day the food of the Greeks, through the combined     influence of poverty and the long fasts which their religion     imposes upon them, is, to a large extent, composed of fish,     accompanied with vegetables and fruit.
10136-8{_}3086{_}Caviare, prepared from     the roes of sturgeons, is the national ragout, which, like all     other fish dishes, they season with aromatic herbs.
10136-8{_}3087{_}Snails     dressed in garlic are also a favourite dish.
10136-8{_}3088{_}214.
10136-8{_}3089{_}AS THE ROMANS, in a great measure, took their taste in the fine arts from the Greeks, so did they, in some measure, their piscine appetites.
10136-8{_}3090{_}The eel-pout and the lotas's liver were the favourite fish dishes of the Roman epicures; whilst the red mullet was esteemed as one of the most delicate fishes that could be brought to the table.
10136-8{_}3091{_}With all the elegance, taste, and refinement of Roman luxury, it     was sometimes promoted or accompanied by acts of great     barbarity.
10136-8{_}3092{_}In proof of this, the mention of the red mullet     suggests the mode in which it was sometimes treated for the, to     us, _horrible_ entertainment of the _fashionable_ in Roman     circles.
10136-8{_}3093{_}It may be premised, that as England has, Rome, in her     palmy days, had, her fops, who had, no doubt, through the medium     of their cooks, discovered that when the scales of the red     mullet were removed, the flesh presented a fine pink-colour.
10136-8{_}3094{_}Having discovered this, it was further observed that at the     death of the animal, this colour passed through a succession of     beautiful shades, and, in order that these might be witnessed     and enjoyed in their fullest perfection, the poor mullet was     served alive in a glass vessel.
10136-8{_}3095{_}215.
10136-8{_}3096{_}THE LOVE OF FISH among the ancient Romans rose to a real mania.
10136-8{_}3097{_}Apicius offered a prize to any one who could invent a new brine compounded of the liver of red mullets; and Lucullus had a canal cut through a mountain, in the neighbourhood of Naples, that fish might be the more easily transported to the gardens of his villa.
10136-8{_}3098{_}Hortensius, the orator, wept over the death of a turbot which he had fed with his own hands; and the daughter of Druses adorned one that she had, with rings of gold.
10136-8{_}3099{_}These were, surely, instances of misplaced affection; but there is no accounting for tastes.
10136-8{_}3100{_}It was but the other day that we read in the "_Times_" of a wealthy _living_ English hermit, who delights in the companionship of rats!
10136-8{_}3101{_}The modern Romans are merged in the general name of Italians,     who, with the exception of macaroni, have no specially     characteristic article of food.
10136-8{_}3102{_}216.
10136-8{_}3103{_}FROM ROME TO GAUL is, considering the means of modern locomotion, no great way; but the ancient sumptuary laws of that kingdom give us little information regarding the ichthyophagous propensities of its inhabitants.
10136-8{_}3104{_}Louis XII.
10136-8{_}3105{_}engaged six fishmongers to furnish his board with fresh-water animals, and Francis I. had twenty-two, whilst Henry the Great extended his requirements a little further, and had twenty-four.
10136-8{_}3106{_}In the time of Louis XIV.
10136-8{_}3107{_}the cooks had attained to such a degree of perfection in their art, that they could convert the form and flesh of the trout, pike, or carp, into the very shape and flavour of the most delicious game.
10136-8{_}3108{_}The French long enjoyed a European reputation for their skill     and refinement in the preparing of food.
10136-8{_}3109{_}In place of plain     joints, French cookery delights in the marvels of what are     called made dishes, ragouts, stews, and fricassees, in which no     trace of the original materials of which they are compounded is     to be found.
10136-8{_}3110{_}217.
10136-8{_}3111{_}FROM GAUL WE CROSS TO BRITAIN, where it has been asserted, by, at least, one authority, that the ancient inhabitants ate no fish.
10136-8{_}3112{_}However this may be, we know that the British shores, particularly those of the North Sea, have always been well supplied with the best kinds of fish, which we may reasonably infer was not unknown to the inhabitants, or likely to be lost upon them for the lack of knowledge as to how they tasted.
10136-8{_}3113{_}By the time of Edward II., fish had, in England, become a dainty, especially the sturgeon, which was permitted to appear on no table but that of the king.
10136-8{_}3114{_}In the fourteenth century, a decree of King John informs us that the people ate both seals and porpoises; whilst in the days of the Troubadours, whales were fished for and caught in the Mediterranean Sea, for the purpose of being used as human food.
10136-8{_}3115{_}Whatever checks the ancient British may have had upon their     piscatory appetites, there are happily none of any great     consequence upon the modern, who delight in wholesome food of     every kind.
10136-8{_}3116{_}Their taste is, perhaps, too much inclined to that     which is accounted solid and substantial; but they really eat     more moderately, even of animal food, than either the French or     the Germans.
10136-8{_}3117{_}Roast beef, or other viands cooked in the plainest     manner, are, with them, a sufficient luxury; yet they delight in     living _well_, whilst it is easy to prove how largely their     affections are developed by even the prospect of a substantial     cheer.
10136-8{_}3118{_}In proof of this we will just observe, that if a great     dinner is to be celebrated, it is not uncommon for the appointed     stewards and committee to meet and have a preliminary dinner     among themselves, in order to arrange the great one, and after     that, to have another dinner to discharge the bill which the     great one cost.
10136-8{_}3119{_}This enjoyable disposition we take to form a     very large item in the aggregate happiness of the nation.
10136-8{_}3120{_}218.
10136-8{_}3121{_}THE GENERAL USE OF FISH, as an article of human food among civilized nations, we have thus sufficiently shown, and will conclude this portion of our subject with the following hints, which ought to be remembered by all those who are fond of occasionally varying their dietary with a piscine dish:--  I.
10136-8{_}3122{_}Fish shortly before they spawn are, in general, best in condition.
10136-8{_}3123{_}When the spawning is just over, they are out of season, and unfit for human food.
10136-8{_}3124{_}II.
10136-8{_}3125{_}When fish is out of season, it has a transparent, bluish tinge, however much it may be boiled; when it is in season, its muscles are firm, and boil white and curdy.
10136-8{_}3126{_}III.
10136-8{_}3127{_}As food for invalids, white fish, such as the ling, cod, haddock, coal-fish, and whiting, are the best; flat fish, as soles, skate, turbot, and flounders, are also good.
10136-8{_}3128{_}IV.
10136-8{_}3129{_}Salmon, mackerel, herrings, and trout soon spoil or decompose after they are killed; therefore, to be in perfection, they should be prepared for the table on the day they are caught.
10136-8{_}3130{_}With flat fish, this is not of such consequence, as they will keep longer.
10136-8{_}3131{_}The turbot, for example, is improved by being kept a day or two.
10136-8{_}3132{_}GENERAL DIRECTIONS FOR DRESSING FISH.
10136-8{_}3133{_}219.
10136-8{_}3134{_}IN DRESSING FISH, of any kind, the first point to be attended to, is to see that it be perfectly clean.
10136-8{_}3135{_}It is a common error to wash it too much; as by doing so the flavour is diminished.
10136-8{_}3136{_}If the fish is to be boiled, a little salt and vinegar should be put into the water, to give it firmness, after it is cleaned.
10136-8{_}3137{_}Cod-fish, whiting, and haddock, are far better if a little salted, and kept a day; and if the weather be not very hot, they will be good for two days.
10136-8{_}3138{_}220.
10136-8{_}3139{_}WHEN FISH IS CHEAP AND PLENTIFUL, and a larger quantity is purchased than is immediately wanted, the overplus of such as will bear it should be potted, or pickled, or salted, and hung up; or it may be fried, that it may serve for stewing the next day.
10136-8{_}3140{_}Fresh-water fish, having frequently a muddy smell and taste, should be soaked in strong salt and water, after it has been well cleaned.
10136-8{_}3141{_}If of a sufficient size, it may be scalded in salt and water, and afterwards dried and dressed.
10136-8{_}3142{_}221.
10136-8{_}3143{_}FISH SHOULD BE PUT INTO COLD WATER, and set on the fire to do very gently, or the outside will break before the inner part is done.
10136-8{_}3144{_}Unless the fishes are small, they should never be put into warm water; nor should water, either hot or cold, be poured _on_ to the fish, as it is liable to break the skin: if it should be necessary to add a little water whilst the fish is cooking, it ought to be poured in gently at the side of the vessel.
10136-8{_}3145{_}The fish-plate may be drawn up, to see if the fish be ready, which may be known by its easily separating from the bone.
10136-8{_}3146{_}It should then be immediately taken out of the water, or it will become woolly.
10136-8{_}3147{_}The fish-plate should be set crossways over the kettle, to keep hot for serving, and a clean cloth over the fish, to prevent its losing its colour.
10136-8{_}3148{_}222.
10136-8{_}3149{_}IN GARNISHING FISH, great attention is required, and plenty of parsley, horseradish, and lemon should be used.
10136-8{_}3150{_}If fried parsley be used, it must be washed and picked, and thrown into fresh water.
10136-8{_}3151{_}When the lard or dripping boils, throw the parsley into it immediately from the water, and instantly it will be green and crisp, and must be taken up with a slice.
10136-8{_}3152{_}When well done, and with very good sauce, fish is more appreciated than almost any other dish.
10136-8{_}3153{_}The liver and roe, in some instances, should be placed on the dish, in order that they may be distributed in the course of serving; but to each recipe will be appended the proper mode of serving and garnishing.
10136-8{_}3154{_}223.
10136-8{_}3155{_}IF FISH IS TO BE FRIED OR BROILED, it must be dried in a nice soft cloth, after it is well cleaned and washed.
10136-8{_}3156{_}If for frying, brush it over with egg, and sprinkle it with some fine crumbs of bread.
10136-8{_}3157{_}If done a second time with the egg and bread, the fish will look so much the better.
10136-8{_}3158{_}If required to be very nice, a sheet of white blotting-paper must be placed to receive it, that it may be free from all grease.
10136-8{_}3159{_}It must also be of a beautiful colour, and all the crumbs appear distinct.
10136-8{_}3160{_}Butter gives a bad colour; lard and clarified dripping are most frequently used; but oil is the best, if the expense be no objection.
10136-8{_}3161{_}The fish should be put into the lard when boiling, and there should be a sufficiency of this to cover it.
10136-8{_}3162{_}224.
10136-8{_}3163{_}WHEN FISH IS BROILED, it must be seasoned, floured, and laid on a very clean gridiron, which, when hot, should be rubbed with a bit of suet, to prevent the fish from sticking.
10136-8{_}3164{_}It must be broiled over a very clear fire, that it may not taste smoky; and not too near, that it may not be scorched.
10136-8{_}3165{_}225.
10136-8{_}3166{_}IN CHOOSING FISH, it is well to remember that it is possible it may be _fresh_, and yet not _good_.
10136-8{_}3167{_}Under the head of each particular fish in this work, are appended rules for its choice and the months when it is in season.
10136-8{_}3168{_}Nothing can be of greater consequence to a cook than to have the fish good; as if this important course in a dinner does not give satisfaction, it is rarely that the repast goes off well.
10136-8{_}3169{_}RECIPES.
10136-8{_}3170{_}CHAPTER VIII.
10136-8{_}3171{_}FISH.
10136-8{_}3172{_}[_Nothing is more difficult than to give the average prices of Fish, inasmuch as a few hours of bad weather at sea will, in the space of one day, cause such a difference in its supply, that the same fish--a turbot for instance--which may be bought to-day for six or seven shillings, will, to-morrow, be, in the London markets, worth, perhaps, almost as many pounds.
10136-8{_}3173{_}The average costs, therefore, which will be found appended to each recipe, must be understood as about the average price for the different kinds of fish, when the market is supplied upon an average, and when the various sorts are of an average size and quality._  GENERAL RULE IN CHOOSING FISH.--_A proof of freshness and goodness in most fishes, is their being covered with scales; for, if deficient in this respect, it is a sign of their being stale, or having been ill-used._]  FRIED ANCHOVIES.
10136-8{_}3174{_}226.
10136-8{_}3175{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 tablespoonful of oil, 1/2 a glass of white wine, sufficient flour to thicken; 12 anchovies.
10136-8{_}3176{_}_Mode_.--Mix the oil and wine together, with sufficient flour to make them into a thickish paste; cleanse the anchovies, wipe them, dip them in the paste, and fry of a nice brown colour.
10136-8{_}3177{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}3178{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 9d.
10136-8{_}3179{_}_Seasonable_ all the year.
10136-8{_}3180{_}_Sufficient_ for 2 persons.
10136-8{_}3181{_}[Illustration: THE ANCHOVY.]
10136-8{_}3182{_}THE ANCHOVY.--In his book of "British Fishes," Mr. Yarrell     states that "the anchovy is a common fish in the Mediterranean,     from Greece to Gibraltar, and was well known to the Greeks and     Romans, by whom the liquor prepared from it, called _garum_, was     in great estimation.
10136-8{_}3183{_}Its extreme range is extended into the     Black Sea.
10136-8{_}3184{_}The fishing for them is carried on during the night,     and lights are used with the nets.
10136-8{_}3185{_}The anchovy is common on the     coasts of Portugal, Spain, and France.
10136-8{_}3186{_}It occurs, I have no     doubt, at the Channel Islands, and has been taken on the     Hampshire coast, and in the Bristol Channel."
10136-8{_}3187{_}Other fish, of     inferior quality, but resembling the real Gorgona anchovy, are     frequently sold for it, and passed off as genuine.
10136-8{_}3188{_}ANCHOVY BUTTER OR PASTE.
10136-8{_}3189{_}227.
10136-8{_}3190{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 dozen anchovies, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}3191{_}of fresh butter.
10136-8{_}3192{_}_Mode_.--Wash the anchovies thoroughly; bone and dry them, and pound them in a mortar to a paste.
10136-8{_}3193{_}Mix the butter gradually with them, and rub the whole through a sieve.
10136-8{_}3194{_}Put it by in small pots for use, and carefully exclude the air with a bladder, as it soon changes the colour of anchovies, besides spoiling them.
10136-8{_}3195{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 2s.
10136-8{_}3196{_}POTTED ANCHOVIES.
10136-8{_}3197{_}POTTED ANCHOVIES are made in the same way, by adding pounded mace, cayenne, and nutmeg to taste.
10136-8{_}3198{_}ANCHOVY TOAST.
10136-8{_}3199{_}228.
10136-8{_}3200{_}INGREDIENTS.--Toast 2 or 3 slices of bread, or, if wanted very savoury, fry them in clarified butter, and spread on them the paste, No.
10136-8{_}3201{_}227.
10136-8{_}3202{_}Made mustard, or a few grains of cayenne, may be added to the paste before laying it on the toast.
10136-8{_}3203{_}ANCHOVY PASTE.--"When some delicate zest," says a work just     issued on the adulterations of trade, "is required to make the     plain English breakfast more palatable, many people are in the     habit of indulging in what they imagine to be anchovies.
10136-8{_}3204{_}These     fish are preserved in a kind of pickling-bottle, carefully     corked down, and surrounded by a red-looking liquor, resembling     in appearance diluted clay.
10136-8{_}3205{_}The price is moderate, one shilling     only being demanded for the luxury.
10136-8{_}3206{_}When these anchovies are     what is termed potted, it implies that the fish have been     pounded into the consistency of a paste, and then placed in flat     pots, somewhat similar in shape to those used for pomatum.
10136-8{_}3207{_}This     paste is usually eaten spread upon toast, and is said to form an     excellent _bonne bouche_, which enables gentlemen at     wine-parties to enjoy their port with redoubled gusto.
10136-8{_}3208{_}Unfortunately, in six cases out of ten, the only portion of     these preserved delicacies, that contains anything indicative of     anchovies, is the paper label pasted on the bottle or pot, on     which the word itself is printed.... All the samples of anchovy     paste, analyzed by different medical men, have been found to be     highly and vividly coloured with very large quantities of bole     Armenian."
10136-8{_}3209{_}The anchovy itself, when imported, is of a dark dead     colour, and it is to make it a bright "handsome-looking sauce"     that this red earth is used.
10136-8{_}3210{_}BARBEL.
10136-8{_}3211{_}229.
10136-8{_}3212{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of port wine, a saltspoonful of salt, 2 tablespoonfuls of vinegar, 2 sliced onions, a faggot of sweet herbs, nutmeg and mace to taste, the juice of a lemon, 2 anchovies; 1 or 2 barbels, according to size.
10136-8{_}3213{_}_Mode_--Boil the barbels in salt and water till done; pour off some of the water, and, to the remainder, put the ingredients mentioned above.
10136-8{_}3214{_}Simmer gently for 1/2 hour, or rather more, and strain.
10136-8{_}3215{_}Put in the fish; heat it gradually; but do not let it boil, or it will be broken.
10136-8{_}3216{_}_Time_.--Altogether 1 hour.
10136-8{_}3217{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}3218{_}_Seasonable_ from September to November.
10136-8{_}3219{_}[Illustration: THE BARBEL.]
10136-8{_}3220{_}THE BARBEL,--This fish takes its name from the barbs or wattels     at its mouth; and, in England, is esteemed as one of the worst     of the fresh-water fish.
10136-8{_}3221{_}It was, however, formerly, if not now,     a favourite with the Jews, excellent cookers of fish.
10136-8{_}3222{_}Others     would boil with it a piece of bacon, that it might have a     relish.
10136-8{_}3223{_}It is to be met with from two to three or four feet     long, and is said to live to a great age.
10136-8{_}3224{_}From Putney upwards,     in the Thames, some are found of large size; but they are valued     only as affording sport to the brethren of the angle.
10136-8{_}3225{_}BRILL.
10136-8{_}3226{_}230.
10136-8{_}3227{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}3228{_}of salt to each gallon of water; a little vinegar.
10136-8{_}3229{_}_Mode_.--Clean the brill, cut off the fins, and rub it over with a little lemon-juice, to preserve its whiteness.
10136-8{_}3230{_}Set the fish in sufficient cold water to cover it; throw in salt, in the above proportions, and a little vinegar, and bring it gradually to boil; simmer very gently till the fish is done, which will be in about 10 minutes; but the time for boiling, of course, depends entirely on the size of the fish.
10136-8{_}3231{_}Serve it on a hot napkin, and garnish with cut lemon, parsley, horseradish, and a little lobster coral sprinkled over the fish.
10136-8{_}3232{_}Send lobster or shrimp sauce and plain melted butter to table with it.
10136-8{_}3233{_}_Time_.--After the water boils, a small brill, 10 minutes; a large brill, 15 to 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}3234{_}_Average cost_, from 4s.
10136-8{_}3235{_}to 8s.
10136-8{_}3236{_}_Seasonable_ from August to April.
10136-8{_}3237{_}[Illustration: THE BRILL.]
10136-8{_}3238{_}THE BRILL.--This fish resembles the sole, but is broader, and     when large, is esteemed by many in a scarcely less degree than     the turbot, whilst it is much cheaper.
10136-8{_}3239{_}It is a fine fish, and is     abundant in the London market.
10136-8{_}3240{_}TO CHOOSE BRILL.--The flesh of this fish, like that of turbot, should be of a yellowish tint, and should be chosen on account of its thickness.
10136-8{_}3241{_}If the flesh has a bluish tint, it is not good.
10136-8{_}3242{_}CODFISH.
10136-8{_}3243{_}231.
10136-8{_}3244{_}Cod may be boiled whole; but a large head and shoulders are quite sufficient for a dish, and contain all that is usually helped, because, when the thick part is done, the tail is insipid and overdone.
10136-8{_}3245{_}The latter, cut in slices, makes a very good dish for frying; or it may be salted down and served with egg sauce and parsnips.
10136-8{_}3246{_}Cod, when boiled quite fresh, is watery; salting a little, renders it firmer.
10136-8{_}3247{_}[Illustration: THE COD.]
10136-8{_}3248{_}THE COD TRIBE.--The Jugular, characterized by bony gills, and     ventral fins before the pectoral ones, commences the second of     the Linnaean orders of fishes, and is a numerous tribe,     inhabiting only the depths of the ocean, and seldom visiting the     fresh waters.
10136-8{_}3249{_}They have a smooth head, and the gill membrane has     seven rays.
10136-8{_}3250{_}The body is oblong, and covered with deciduous     scales.
10136-8{_}3251{_}The fins are all inclosed in skin, whilst their rays are     unarmed.
10136-8{_}3252{_}The ventral fins are slender, and terminate in a point.
10136-8{_}3253{_}Their habits are gregarious, and they feed on smaller fish and     other marine animals.
10136-8{_}3254{_}COD'S HEAD AND SHOULDERS.
10136-8{_}3255{_}232.
10136-8{_}3256{_}INGREDIENTS.--Sufficient water to cover the fish; 5 oz.
10136-8{_}3257{_}of salt to each gallon of water.
10136-8{_}3258{_}_Mode_.--Cleanse the fish thoroughly, and rub a little salt over the thick part and inside of the fish, 1 or 2 hours before dressing it, as this very much improves the flavour.
10136-8{_}3259{_}Lay it in the fish-kettle, with sufficient cold water to cover it.
10136-8{_}3260{_}Be very particular not to pour the water on the fish, as it is liable to break it, and only keep it just simmering.
10136-8{_}3261{_}If the water should boil away, add a little by pouring it in at the side of the kettle, and not on the fish.
10136-8{_}3262{_}Add salt in the above proportion, and bring it gradually to a boil.
10136-8{_}3263{_}Skim very carefully, draw it to the side of the fire, and let it gently simmer till done.
10136-8{_}3264{_}Take it out and drain it; serve on a hot napkin, and garnish with cut lemon, horseradish, the roe and liver.
10136-8{_}3265{_}(_See_ Coloured Plate C.)  _Time_.--According to size, 1/2 an hour, more or less.
10136-8{_}3266{_}_Average cost_, from 3s.
10136-8{_}3267{_}to 6s.
10136-8{_}3268{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 or 8 persons.
10136-8{_}3269{_}_Seasonable_ from November to March.
10136-8{_}3270{_}_Note_.--Oyster sauce and plain melted butter should be served with this.
10136-8{_}3271{_}TO CHOOSE COD.--The cod should be chosen for the table when it is plump and round near the tail, when the hollow behind the head is deep, and when the sides are undulated as if they were ribbed.
10136-8{_}3272{_}The glutinous parts about the head lose their delicate flavour, after the fish has been twenty-four hours out of the water.
10136-8{_}3273{_}The great point by which the cod should be judged is the firmness of its flesh; and, although the cod is not firm when it is alive, its quality may be arrived at by pressing the finger into the flesh.
10136-8{_}3274{_}If this rises immediately, the fish is good; if not, it is stale.
10136-8{_}3275{_}Another sign of its goodness is, if the fish, when it is cut, exhibits a bronze appearance, like the silver side of a round of beef.
10136-8{_}3276{_}When this is the case, the flesh will be firm when cooked.
10136-8{_}3277{_}Stiffness in a cod, or in any other fish, is a sure sign of freshness, though not always of quality.
10136-8{_}3278{_}Sometimes, codfish, though exhibiting signs of rough usage, will eat much better than those with red gills, so strongly recommended by many cookery-books.
10136-8{_}3279{_}This appearance is generally caused by the fish having been knocked about at sea, in the well-boats, in which they are conveyed from the fishing-grounds to market.
10136-8{_}3280{_}SALT COD, COMMONLY CALLED "SALT-FISH."
10136-8{_}3281{_}233.
10136-8{_}3282{_}INGREDIENTS.--Sufficient water to cover the fish.
10136-8{_}3283{_}_Mode_.--Wash the fish, and lay it all night in water, with a 1/4 pint of vinegar.
10136-8{_}3284{_}When thoroughly soaked, take it out, see that it is perfectly clean, and put it in the fish-kettle with sufficient cold water to cover it.
10136-8{_}3285{_}Heat it gradually, but do not let it boil much, or the fish will be hard.
10136-8{_}3286{_}Skim well, and when done, drain the fish and put it on a napkin garnished with hard-boiled eggs cut in rings.
10136-8{_}3287{_}_Time_.--About 1 hour.
10136-8{_}3288{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}3289{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}3290{_}_Seasonable_ in the spring.
10136-8{_}3291{_}_Sufficient_ for each person, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}3292{_}_Note_.--Serve with egg sauce and parsnips.
10136-8{_}3293{_}This is an especial dish on Ash Wednesday.
10136-8{_}3294{_}PRESERVING COD.--Immediately as the cod are caught, their heads     are cut off.
10136-8{_}3295{_}They are then opened, cleaned, and salted, when     they are stowed away in the hold of the vessel, in beds of five     or six yards square, head to tail, with a layer of salt to each     layer of fish.
10136-8{_}3296{_}When they have lain in this state three or four     days, in order that the water may drain from them, they are     shifted into a different part of the vessel, and again salted.
10136-8{_}3297{_}Here they remain till the vessel is loaded, when they are     sometimes cut into thick pieces and packed in barrels for the     greater convenience of carriage.
10136-8{_}3298{_}COD SOUNDS.
10136-8{_}3299{_}Should be well soaked in salt and water, and thoroughly washed before dressing them.
10136-8{_}3300{_}They are considered a great delicacy, and may either be broiled, fried, or boiled: if they are boiled, mix a little milk with the water.
10136-8{_}3301{_}COD SOUNDS, EN POULE.
10136-8{_}3302{_}234.
10136-8{_}3303{_}INGREDIENTS.--For forcemeat, 12 chopped oysters, 3 chopped anchovies, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}3304{_}of bread crumbs, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}3305{_}of butter, 2 eggs; seasoning of salt, pepper, nutmeg, and mace to taste; 4 cod sounds.
10136-8{_}3306{_}_Mode_.--Make the forcemeat by mixing the ingredients well together.
10136-8{_}3307{_}Wash the sounds, and boil them in milk and water for 1/2 an hour; take them out and let them cool.
10136-8{_}3308{_}Cover each with a layer of forcemeat, roll them up in a nice form, and skewer them.
10136-8{_}3309{_}Rub over with lard, dredge with flour, and cook them gently before the fire in a Dutch oven.
10136-8{_}3310{_}_Time_.--1 hour.
10136-8{_}3311{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}3312{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}3313{_}_Seasonable_ from November to March.
10136-8{_}3314{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}3315{_}THE SOUNDS IN CODFISH.--These are the air or swimming bladders,     by means of which the fishes are enabled to ascend or descend in     the water.
10136-8{_}3316{_}In the Newfoundland fishery they are taken out     previous to incipient putrefaction, washed from their slime and     salted for exportation.
10136-8{_}3317{_}The tongues are also cured and packed up     in barrels; whilst, from the livers, considerable quantities of     oil are extracted, this oil having been found possessed of the     most nourishing properties, and particularly beneficial in cases     of pulmonary affections.
10136-8{_}3318{_}COD PIE.
10136-8{_}3319{_}(_Economical_.)
10136-8{_}3320{_}I.
10136-8{_}3321{_}235.
10136-8{_}3322{_}INGREDIENTS.--Any remains of cold cod, 12 oysters, sufficient melted butter to moisten it; mashed potatoes enough to fill up the dish.
10136-8{_}3323{_}_Mode_.--Flake the fish from the bone, and carefully take away all the skin.
10136-8{_}3324{_}Lay it in a pie-dish, pour over the melted butter and oysters (or oyster sauce, if there is any left), and cover with mashed potatoes.
10136-8{_}3325{_}Bake for 1/2 an hour, and send to table of a nice brown colour.
10136-8{_}3326{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}3327{_}_Seasonable_ from November to March.
10136-8{_}3328{_}II.
10136-8{_}3329{_}236.
10136-8{_}3330{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 slices of cod; pepper and salt to taste; 1/2 a teaspoonful of grated nutmeg, 1 large blade of pounded mace, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}3331{_}of butter, 1/2 pint of stock No.
10136-8{_}3332{_}107, a paste crust (_see_ Pastry).
10136-8{_}3333{_}For sauce, 1 tablespoonful of stock, 1/4 pint of cream or milk, thickening of flour or butter; lemon-peel chopped very fine to taste; 12 oysters.
10136-8{_}3334{_}_Mode_.--Lay the cod in salt for 4 hours, then wash it and place it in a dish; season, and add the butter and stock; cover with the crust, and bake for 1 hour, or rather more.
10136-8{_}3335{_}Now make the sauce, by mixing the ingredients named above; give it one boil, and pour it into the pie by a hole made at the top of the crust, which can easily be covered by a small piece of pastry cut and baked in any fanciful shape--such as a leaf, or otherwise.
10136-8{_}3336{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}3337{_}_Average cost_, with fresh fish, 2s.
10136-8{_}3338{_}6d.
10136-8{_}3339{_}_Seasonable_ from November to March.
10136-8{_}3340{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 persons.
10136-8{_}3341{_}_Note_.--The remains of cold fish may be used for this pie.
10136-8{_}3342{_}CURRIED COD.
10136-8{_}3343{_}237.
10136-8{_}3344{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 slices of large cod, or the remains of any cold fish; 3 oz.
10136-8{_}3345{_}of butter, 1 onion sliced, a teacupful of white stock, thickening of butter and flour, 1 small teaspoonful of curry-powder, 1/4 pint of cream, salt and cayenne to taste.
10136-8{_}3346{_}_Mode_.--Flake the fish, and fry it of a nice brown colour with the butter and onions; put this in a stewpan, add the stock and thickening, and simmer for 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}3347{_}Stir the curry-powder into the cream; put it, with the seasoning, to the other ingredients; give one boil, and serve.
10136-8{_}3348{_}_Time_.--3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}3349{_}_Average cost_, with fresh fish, 3s.
10136-8{_}3350{_}_Seasonable_ from November to March.
10136-8{_}3351{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}3352{_}THE FOOD OF THE COD.--This chiefly consists of the smaller     species of the scaly tribes, shell-fish, crabs, and worms.
10136-8{_}3353{_}Their     voracity is very great, and they will bite at any small body     they see moved by the water, even stones and pebbles, which are     frequently found in their stomachs.
10136-8{_}3354{_}They sometimes attain a     great size, but their usual weight is from 14 to 40 lbs.
10136-8{_}3355{_}COD A LA CREME.
10136-8{_}3356{_}238.
10136-8{_}3357{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 large slice of cod, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}3358{_}of butter, 1 chopped shalot, a little minced parsley, 1/4 teacupful of white stock, 1/4 pint of milk or cream, flour to thicken, cayenne and lemon-juice to taste, 1/4 teaspoonful of powdered sugar.
10136-8{_}3359{_}_Mode_.--Boil the cod, and while hot, break it into flakes; put the butter, shalot, parsley, and stock into a stewpan, and let them boil for 5 minutes.
10136-8{_}3360{_}Stir in sufficient flour to thicken, and pour to it the milk or cream.
10136-8{_}3361{_}Simmer for 10 minutes, add the cayenne and sugar, and, when liked, a little lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}3362{_}Put the fish in the sauce to warm gradually, but do not let it boil.
10136-8{_}3363{_}Serve in a dish garnished with croûtons.
10136-8{_}3364{_}_Time_.--Rather more than 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}3365{_}_Average cost_, with cream, 2s.
10136-8{_}3366{_}_Seasonable_ from November to March.
10136-8{_}3367{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 persons.
10136-8{_}3368{_}_Note_.--The remains of fish from the preceding day answer very well for this dish.
10136-8{_}3369{_}COD A LA BECHAMEL.
10136-8{_}3370{_}239.
10136-8{_}3371{_}INGREDIENTS.--Any remains of cold cod, 4 tablespoonfuls of béchamel (_see_ Sauces), 2 oz.
10136-8{_}3372{_}butter; seasoning to taste of pepper and salt; fried bread, a few bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}3373{_}_Mode_.--Flake the cod carefully, leaving out all skin and bone; put the béchamel in a stewpan with the butter, and stir it over the fire till the latter is melted; add seasoning, put in the fish, and mix it well with the sauce.
10136-8{_}3374{_}Make a border of fried bread round the dish, lay in the fish, sprinkle over with bread crumbs, and baste with butter.
10136-8{_}3375{_}Brown either before the fire or with a salamander, and garnish with toasted bread cut in fanciful shapes.
10136-8{_}3376{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}3377{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the fish, 6d.
10136-8{_}3378{_}THE HABITAT OF THE COD.--This fish is found only in the seas of     the northern parts of the world, between the latitudes of 45°     and 66°.
10136-8{_}3379{_}Its great rendezvous are the sandbanks of Newfoundland,     Nova Scotia, Cape Breton, and New England.
10136-8{_}3380{_}These places are its     favourite resorts; for there it is able to obtain great     quantities of worms, a food peculiarly grateful to it.
10136-8{_}3381{_}Another     cause of its attachment to these places has been said to be on     account of the vicinity to the Polar seas, where it returns to     spawn.
10136-8{_}3382{_}Few are taken north of Iceland, and the shoals never     reach so far south as the Straits of Gibraltar.
10136-8{_}3383{_}Many are taken     on the coasts of Norway, in the Baltic, and off the Orkneys,     which, prior to the discovery of Newfoundland, formed one of the     principal fisheries.
10136-8{_}3384{_}The London market is supplied by those     taken between the Dogger Bank, the Well Bank, and Cromer, on the     east coast of England.
10136-8{_}3385{_}COD A LA MAITRE D'HOTEL.
10136-8{_}3386{_}240.
10136-8{_}3387{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 slices of cod, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}3388{_}of butter, a little chopped shalot and parsley; pepper to taste, 1/4 teaspoonful of grated nutmeg, or rather less, when the flavour is not liked; the juice of 1/4 lemon.
10136-8{_}3389{_}_Mode_.--Boil the cod, and either leave it whole, or, what is still better, flake it from the bone, and take off the skin.
10136-8{_}3390{_}Put it into a stewpan with the butter, parsley, shalot, pepper, and nutmeg.
10136-8{_}3391{_}Melt the butter gradually, and be very careful that it does not become like oil.
10136-8{_}3392{_}When all is well mixed and thoroughly hot, add the lemon-juice, and serve.
10136-8{_}3393{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}3394{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}3395{_}6d.
10136-8{_}3396{_}; with remains of cold fish, 5d.
10136-8{_}3397{_}_Seasonable_ from November to March.
10136-8{_}3398{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}3399{_}_Note_.--Cod that has been left will do for this.
10136-8{_}3400{_}THE SEASON FOR FISHING COD.--The best season for catching cod is     from the beginning of February to the end of April; and although     each fisherman engaged in taking them, catches no more than one     at a time, an expert hand will sometimes take four hundred in a     day.
10136-8{_}3401{_}The employment is excessively fatiguing, from the weight of     the fish as well as from the coldness of the climate.
10136-8{_}3402{_}COD A L'ITALIENNE.
10136-8{_}3403{_}241.
10136-8{_}3404{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 slices of crimped cod, 1 shalot, 1 slice of ham minced very fine, 1/2 pint of white stock, No.
10136-8{_}3405{_}107; when liked, 1/2 teacupful of cream; salt to taste; a few drops of garlic vinegar, a little lemon-juice, 1/2 teaspoonful of powdered sugar.
10136-8{_}3406{_}_Mode_.--Chop the shalots, mince the ham very fine, pour on the stock, and simmer for 15 minutes.
10136-8{_}3407{_}If the colour should not be good, add cream in the above proportion, and strain it through a fine sieve; season it, and put in the vinegar, lemon-juice, and sugar.
10136-8{_}3408{_}Now boil the cod, take out the middle bone, and skin it; put it on the dish without breaking, and pour the sauce over it.
10136-8{_}3409{_}_Time_.--3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}3410{_}_Average cost_, 3s.
10136-8{_}3411{_}6d., with fresh fish.
10136-8{_}3412{_}_Seasonable_ from November to March.
10136-8{_}3413{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}3414{_}THE FECUNDITY OF THE COD.--In our preceding remarks on the     natural history of fishes, we have spoken of the amazing     fruitfulness of this fish; but in this we see one more instance     of the wise provision which Nature has made for supplying the     wants of man.
10136-8{_}3415{_}So extensive has been the consumption of this     fish, that it is surprising that it has not long ago become     extinct; which would certainly have been the case, had it not     been for its wonderful powers of reproduction.
10136-8{_}3416{_}"So early as     1368," says Dr. Cloquet, "the inhabitants of Amsterdam had     dispatched fishermen to the coast of Sweden; and in the first     quarter of 1792, from the ports of France only, 210 vessels went     out to the cod-fisheries.
10136-8{_}3417{_}Every year, however, upwards of 10,000     vessels, of all nations, are employed in this trade, and bring     into the commercial world more than 40,000,000 of salted and     dried cod.
10136-8{_}3418{_}If we add to this immense number, the havoc made     among the legions of cod by the larger scaly tribes of the great     deep, and take into account the destruction to which the young     are exposed by sea-fowls and other inhabitants of the seas,     besides the myriads of their eggs destroyed by accident, it     becomes a miracle to find that such mighty multitudes of them     are still in existence, and ready to continue the exhaustless     supply.
10136-8{_}3419{_}Yet it ceases to excite our wonder when we remember that     the female can every year give birth to more than 9,000,000 at a     time."
10136-8{_}3420{_}BAKED CARP.
10136-8{_}3421{_}242.
10136-8{_}3422{_}INGREDIENTS--1 carp, forcemeat, bread crumbs, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}3423{_}butter, 1/2 pint of stock No.
10136-8{_}3424{_}105, 1/2 pint of port wine, 6 anchovies, 2 onions sliced, 1 bay-leaf, a faggot of sweet herbs, flour to thicken, the juice of 1 lemon; cayenne and salt to taste; 1/2 teaspoonful of powdered sugar.
10136-8{_}3425{_}_Mode_.--Stuff the carp with a delicate forcemeat, after thoroughly cleansing it, and sew it up to prevent the stuffing from falling out.
10136-8{_}3426{_}Rub it over with an egg, and sprinkle it with bread crumbs, lay it in a deep earthen dish, and drop the butter, oiled, over the bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}3427{_}Add the stock, onions, bay-leaf, herbs, wine, and anchovies, and bake for 1 hour.
10136-8{_}3428{_}Put 1 oz.
10136-8{_}3429{_}of butter into a stewpan, melt it, and dredge in sufficient flour to dry it up; put in the strained liquor from the carp, stir frequently, and when it has boiled, add the lemon-juice and seasoning.
10136-8{_}3430{_}Serve the carp on a dish garnished with parsley and cut lemon, and the sauce in a boat.
10136-8{_}3431{_}_Time_.--1-1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}3432{_}_Average cost_.
10136-8{_}3433{_}Seldom bought.
10136-8{_}3434{_}_Seasonable_ from March to October.
10136-8{_}3435{_}_Sufficient_ for 1 or 2 persons.
10136-8{_}3436{_}[Illustration: THE CARP.]
10136-8{_}3437{_}THE CARP.--This species of fish inhabit the fresh waters, where     they feed on worms, insects, aquatic plants, small fish, clay,     or mould.
10136-8{_}3438{_}Some of them are migratory.
10136-8{_}3439{_}They have very small     mouths and no teeth, and the gill membrane has three rays.
10136-8{_}3440{_}The     body is smooth, and generally whitish.
10136-8{_}3441{_}The carp both grows and     increases very fast, and is accounted the most valuable of all     fish for the stocking of ponds.
10136-8{_}3442{_}It has been pronounced the queen     of river-fish, and was first introduced to this country about     three hundred years ago.
10136-8{_}3443{_}Of its sound, or air-bladder, a kind of     glue is made, and a green paint of its gall.
10136-8{_}3444{_}STEWED CARP.
10136-8{_}3445{_}243.
10136-8{_}3446{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 carp, salt, stock No.
10136-8{_}3447{_}105, 2 onions, 6 cloves, 12 peppercorns, 1 blade of mace, 1/4 pint of port wine, the juice of 1/2 lemon, cayenne and salt to taste, a faggot of savoury herbs.
10136-8{_}3448{_}_Mode_.--Scale the fish, clean it nicely, and, if very large, divide it; lay it in the stewpan, after having rubbed a little salt on it, and put in sufficient stock to cover it; add the herbs, onions, and spices, and stew gently for 1 hour, or rather more, should it be very large.
10136-8{_}3449{_}Dish up the fish with great care, strain the liquor, and add to it the port wine, lemon-juice, and cayenne; give one boil, pour it over the fish, and serve.
10136-8{_}3450{_}_Time_.--1-1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}3451{_}_Average cost_.
10136-8{_}3452{_}Seldom bought.
10136-8{_}3453{_}_Seasonable_ from March to October.
10136-8{_}3454{_}_Sufficient_ for 1 or 2 persons.
10136-8{_}3455{_}_Note_.--This fish can be boiled plain, and served with parsley and butter.
10136-8{_}3456{_}Chub and Char may be cooked in the same manner as the above, as also Dace and Roach.
10136-8{_}3457{_}THE AGE OF CARP.--This fish has been found to live 150 years.
10136-8{_}3458{_}The pond in the garden of Emmanuel College, Cambridge, contained     one that had lived there 70 years, and Gesner mentions an     instance of one 100 years old.
10136-8{_}3459{_}They are, besides, capable of     being tamed.
10136-8{_}3460{_}Dr. Smith, in his "Tour on the Continent," says, in     reference to the prince of Condé's seat at Chantilly, "The most     pleasing things about it were the immense shoals of very large     carp, silvered over with age, like silver-fish, and perfectly     tame; so that, when any passengers approached their watery     habitation, they used to come to the shore in such numbers as to     heave each other out of the water, begging for bread, of which a     quantity was always kept at hand, on purpose to feed them.
10136-8{_}3461{_}They     would even allow themselves to be handled."
10136-8{_}3462{_}[Illustration: THE CHUB.]
10136-8{_}3463{_}[Illustration: THE CHAR.]
10136-8{_}3464{_}THE CHUB.--This fish takes its name from its head, not only in     England, but in other countries.
10136-8{_}3465{_}It is a river-fish, and     resembles the carp, but is somewhat longer.
10136-8{_}3466{_}Its flesh is not in     much esteem, being coarse, and, when out of season, full of     small hairy bones.
10136-8{_}3467{_}The head and throat are the best parts.
10136-8{_}3468{_}The     roe is also good.
10136-8{_}3469{_}THE CHAR.--This is one of the most delicious of fish, being     esteemed by some superior to the salmon.
10136-8{_}3470{_}It is an inhabitant of     the deep lakes of mountainous countries.
10136-8{_}3471{_}Its flesh is rich and     red, and full of fat.
10136-8{_}3472{_}The largest and best kind is found in the     lakes of Westmoreland, and, as it is considered a rarity, it is     often potted and preserved.
10136-8{_}3473{_}THE DACE, OR DARE.--This fish is gregarious, and is seldom above     ten inches long; although, according to Linnaeus, it grows a     foot and a half in length.
10136-8{_}3474{_}Its haunts are in deep water, near     piles of bridges, where the stream is gentle, over gravelly,     sandy, or clayey bottoms; deep holes that are shaded, water-lily     leaves, and under the foam caused by an eddy.
10136-8{_}3475{_}In the warm months     they are to be found in shoals on the shallows near to streams.
10136-8{_}3476{_}They are in season about the end of April, and gradually improve     till February, when they attain their highest condition.
10136-8{_}3477{_}In that     month, when just taken, scotched (crimped), and broiled, they     are said to be more palatable than a fresh herring.
10136-8{_}3478{_}THE ROACH.--This fish is found throughout Europe, and the     western parts of Asia, in deep still rivers, of which it is an     inhabitant.
10136-8{_}3479{_}It is rarely more than a pound and a half in weight,     and is in season from September till March.
10136-8{_}3480{_}It is plentiful in     England, and the finest are caught in the Thames.
10136-8{_}3481{_}The proverb,     "as sound as a roach," is derived from the French name of this     fish being _roche_, which also means rock.
10136-8{_}3482{_}[Illustration: THE DACE.]
10136-8{_}3483{_}[Illustration: THE ROACH.]
10136-8{_}3484{_}TO DRESS CRAB.
10136-8{_}3485{_}244.
10136-8{_}3486{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 crab, 2 tablespoonfuls of vinegar, 1 ditto of oil; salt, white pepper, and cayenne, to taste.
10136-8{_}3487{_}_Mode_.--Empty the shells, and thoroughly mix the meat with the above ingredients, and put it in the large shell.
10136-8{_}3488{_}Garnish with slices of cut lemon and parsley.
10136-8{_}3489{_}The quantity of oil may be increased when it is much liked.
10136-8{_}3490{_}(See Coloured Plate I.)
10136-8{_}3491{_}_Average cost_, from 10d.
10136-8{_}3492{_}to 2s.
10136-8{_}3493{_}_Seasonable_ all the year; but not so good in May, June, and July.
10136-8{_}3494{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 persons.
10136-8{_}3495{_}TO CHOOSE CRAB.--The middle-sized crab is the best; and the crab, like the lobster, should be judged by its weight; for if light, it is watery.
10136-8{_}3496{_}HOT CRAB.
10136-8{_}3497{_}245.
10136-8{_}3498{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 crab, nutmeg, salt and pepper to taste, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}3499{_}of butter, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}3500{_}of bread crumbs, 3 tablespoonfuls of vinegar.
