10136-8{_}3501{_}_Mode_.--After having boiled the crab, pick the meat out from the shells, and mix with it the nutmeg and seasoning.
10136-8{_}3502{_}Cut up the butter in small pieces, and add the bread crumbs and vinegar.
10136-8{_}3503{_}Mix altogether, put the whole in the large shell, and brown before the fire or with a salamander.
10136-8{_}3504{_}_Time_.--1 hour.
10136-8{_}3505{_}_Average cost_, from 10d.
10136-8{_}3506{_}to 2s.
10136-8{_}3507{_}_Seasonable_ all the year; but not so good in May, June, and July.
10136-8{_}3508{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 persons.
10136-8{_}3509{_}[Illustration: THE CRAB.]
10136-8{_}3510{_}THE CRAB TRIBE.--The whole of this tribe of animals have the     body covered with a hard and strong shell, and they live chiefly     in the sea.
10136-8{_}3511{_}Some, however, inhabit fresh waters, and a few live     upon land.
10136-8{_}3512{_}They feed variously, on aquatic or marine plants,     small fish, molluscae, or dead bodies.
10136-8{_}3513{_}The _black-clawed_     species is found on the rocky coasts of both Europe and India,     and is the same that is introduced to our tables, being much     more highly esteemed as a food than many others of the tribe.
10136-8{_}3514{_}The most remarkable feature in their history, is the changing of     their shells, and the reproduction of their broken claws.
10136-8{_}3515{_}The     former occurs once a year, usually between Christmas and Easter,     when the crabs retire to cavities in the rocks, or conceal     themselves under great stones.
10136-8{_}3516{_}Fishermen say that they will live     confined in a pot or basket for several months together, without     any other food than what is collected from the sea-water; and     that, even in this situation, they will not decrease in weight.
10136-8{_}3517{_}The _hermit_ crab is another of the species, and has the     peculiarity of taking possession of the deserted shell of some     other animal, as it has none of its own.
10136-8{_}3518{_}This circumstance was     known to the ancients, and is alluded to in the following lines     from Oppian:--       The hermit fish, unarm'd by Nature, left       Helpless and weak, grow strong by harmless theft.
10136-8{_}3519{_}Fearful they stroll, and look with panting wish       For the cast crust of some new-cover'd fish;       Or such as empty lie, and deck the shore,       Whose first and rightful owners are no more.
10136-8{_}3520{_}They make glad seizure of the vacant room,       And count the borrow'd shell their native home;       Screw their soft limbs to fit the winding case,       And boldly herd with the crustaceous race.
10136-8{_}3521{_}CRAYFISH.
10136-8{_}3522{_}246.
10136-8{_}3523{_}Crayfish should be thrown into boiling water, to which has been added a good seasoning of salt and a little vinegar.
10136-8{_}3524{_}When done, which will be in 1/4 hour, take them out and drain them.
10136-8{_}3525{_}Let them cool, arrange them on a napkin, and garnish with plenty of double parsley.
10136-8{_}3526{_}_Note_.--This fish is frequently used for garnishing boiled turkey, boiled fowl, calf's head, turbot, and all kinds of boiled fish.
10136-8{_}3527{_}POTTED CRAYFISH.
10136-8{_}3528{_}247.
10136-8{_}3529{_}INGREDIENTS.--100 crayfish; pounded mace, pepper and salt to taste, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}3530{_}butter.
10136-8{_}3531{_}_Mode_.--Boil the fish in salt and water; pick out all the meat and pound it in a mortar to a paste.
10136-8{_}3532{_}Whilst pounding, add the butter gradually, and mix in the spice and seasoning.
10136-8{_}3533{_}Put it in small pots, and pour over it clarified butter, carefully excluding the air.
10136-8{_}3534{_}_Time_.--15 minutes to boil the crayfish.
10136-8{_}3535{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}3536{_}9d.
10136-8{_}3537{_}_Seasonable_ all the year.
10136-8{_}3538{_}JOHN DORY.
10136-8{_}3539{_}248.
10136-8{_}3540{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}3541{_}of salt to each gallon of water.
10136-8{_}3542{_}_Mode_.--This fish, which is esteemed by most people a great delicacy, is dressed in the same way as a turbot, which it resembles in firmness, but not in richness.
10136-8{_}3543{_}Cleanse it thoroughly and cut off the fins; lay it in a fish-kettle, cover with cold water, and add salt in the above proportion.
10136-8{_}3544{_}Bring it gradually to a boil, and simmer gently for 1/4 hour, or rather longer, should the fish be very large.
10136-8{_}3545{_}Serve on a hot napkin, and garnish with cut lemon and parsley.
10136-8{_}3546{_}Lobster, anchovy, or shrimp sauce, and plain melted butter, should be sent to table with it.
10136-8{_}3547{_}_Time_.--After the water boils, 1/4 to 1/2 hour, according to size.
10136-8{_}3548{_}_Average cost_, 3s.
10136-8{_}3549{_}to 5s.
10136-8{_}3550{_}_Seasonable_ all the year, but best from September to January.
10136-8{_}3551{_}_Note_.--Small John Dorie are very good, baked.
10136-8{_}3552{_}[Illustration: THE JOHN DORY.]
10136-8{_}3553{_}THE DORU, or JOHN DORY.--This fish is of a yellowish golden     colour, and is, in general, rare, although it is sometimes taken     in abundance on the Devon and Cornish coasts.
10136-8{_}3554{_}It is highly     esteemed for the table, and its flesh, when dressed, is of a     beautiful clear white.
10136-8{_}3555{_}When fresh caught, it is tough, and,     being a ground fish, it is not the worse for being kept two, or     even three days before it is cooked.
10136-8{_}3556{_}BOILED EELS.
10136-8{_}3557{_}249.
10136-8{_}3558{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 small eels, sufficient water to cover them; a large bunch of parsley.
10136-8{_}3559{_}_Mode_.--Choose small eels for boiling; put them in a stewpan with the parsley, and just sufficient water to cover them; simmer till tender.
10136-8{_}3560{_}Take them out, pour a little parsley and butter over them, and serve some in a tureen.
10136-8{_}3561{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}3562{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}3563{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}3564{_}_Seasonable_ from June to March.
10136-8{_}3565{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}3566{_}[Illustration: THE EEL.]
10136-8{_}3567{_}THE EEL TRIBE.--The Apodal, or bony-gilled and ventral-finned     fish, of which the eel forms the first Linnaean tribe, in their     general aspect and manners, approach, in some instances, very     nearly to serpents.
10136-8{_}3568{_}They have a smooth head and slippery skin,     are in general naked, or covered with such small, soft, and     distant scales, as are scarcely visible.
10136-8{_}3569{_}Their bodies are long     and slender, and they are supposed to subsist entirely on animal     substances.
10136-8{_}3570{_}There are about nine species of them, mostly found     in the seas.
10136-8{_}3571{_}One of them frequents our fresh waters, and three     of the others occasionally pay a visit to our shores.
10136-8{_}3572{_}STEWED EELS.
10136-8{_}3573{_}I.
10136-8{_}3574{_}250.
10136-8{_}3575{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 lbs.
10136-8{_}3576{_}of eels, 1 pint of rich strong stock, No.
10136-8{_}3577{_}104, 1 onion, 3 cloves, a piece of lemon-peel, 1 glass of port or Madeira, 3 tablespoonfuls of cream; thickening of flour; cayenne and lemon-juice to taste.
10136-8{_}3578{_}_Mode_.--Wash and skin the eels, and cut them into pieces about 3 inches long; pepper and salt them, and lay them in a stewpan; pour over the stock, add the onion stuck with cloves, the lemon-peel, and the wine.
10136-8{_}3579{_}Stew gently for 1/2 hour, or rather more, and lift them carefully on a dish, which keep hot.
10136-8{_}3580{_}Strain the gravy, stir to the cream sufficient flour to thicken; mix altogether, boil for 2 minutes, and add the cayenne and lemon-juice; pour over the eels and serve.
10136-8{_}3581{_}_Time_.--3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}3582{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 2s.
10136-8{_}3583{_}3d.
10136-8{_}3584{_}_Seasonable_ from June to March.
10136-8{_}3585{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}3586{_}THE COMMON EEL.--This fish is known frequently to quit its     native element, and to set off on a wandering expedition in the     night, or just about the close of clay, over the meadows, in     search of snails and other prey.
10136-8{_}3587{_}It also, sometimes, betakes     itself to isolated ponds, apparently for no other pleasure than     that which may be supposed to be found in a change of     habitation.
10136-8{_}3588{_}This, of course, accounts for eels being found in     waters which were never suspected to contain them.
10136-8{_}3589{_}This rambling     disposition in the eel has been long known to naturalists, and,     from the following lines, it seems to have been known to the     ancients:--        "Thus the mail'd tortoise, and the wand'ring; eel,       Oft to the neighbouring beach will silent steal."
10136-8{_}3590{_}II.
10136-8{_}3591{_}251.
10136-8{_}3592{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 lbs.
10136-8{_}3593{_}of middling-sized eels, 1 pint of medium stock, No.
10136-8{_}3594{_}105, 1/4 pint of port wine; salt, cayenne, and mace to taste; 1 teaspoonful of essence of anchovy, the juice of 1/2 a lemon.
10136-8{_}3595{_}_Mode_.--Skin, wash, and clean the eels thoroughly; cut them into pieces 3 inches long, and put them into strong salt and water for 1 hour; dry them well with a cloth, and fry them brown.
10136-8{_}3596{_}Put the stock on with the heads and tails of the eels, and simmer for 1/2 hour; strain it, and add all the other ingredients.
10136-8{_}3597{_}Put in the eels, and stew gently for 1/2 hour, when serve.
10136-8{_}3598{_}_Time_.--2 hours.
10136-8{_}3599{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}3600{_}9d.
10136-8{_}3601{_}_Seasonable_ from June to March.
10136-8{_}3602{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}3603{_}FRIED EELS.
10136-8{_}3604{_}252.
10136-8{_}3605{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}3606{_}of eels, 1 egg, a few bread crumbs, hot lard.
10136-8{_}3607{_}_Mode_.--Wash the eels, cut them into pieces 3 inches long, trim and wipe them very dry; dredge with flour, rub them over with egg, and cover with bread crumbs; fry of a nice brown in hot lard.
10136-8{_}3608{_}If the eels are small, curl them round, instead of cutting them up.
10136-8{_}3609{_}Garnish with fried parsley.
10136-8{_}3610{_}_Time_.--20 minutes, or rather less.
10136-8{_}3611{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}3612{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}3613{_}_Seasonable_ from June to March.
10136-8{_}3614{_}_Note_.--Garfish may be dressed like eels, and either broiled or baked.
10136-8{_}3615{_}THE PRODUCTIVENESS OF THE EEL.--"Having occasion," says Dr.     Anderson, in the _Bee_, "to be once on a visit to a friend's     house on Dee-side, in Aberdeenshire, I frequently delighted to     walk by the banks of the river.
10136-8{_}3616{_}I, one day, observed something     like a black string moving along the edge of the water where it     was quite shallow.
10136-8{_}3617{_}Upon closer inspection, I discovered that     this was a shoal of young eels, so closely joined together as to     appear, on a superficial view, on continued body, moving briskly     up against the stream.
10136-8{_}3618{_}To avoid the retardment they experienced     from the force of the current, they kept close along the water's     edge the whole of the way, following all the bendings and     sinuosities of the river.
10136-8{_}3619{_}Where they were embayed, and in still     water, the shoal dilated in breadth, so as to be sometimes     nearly a foot broad; but when they turned a cape, where the     current was strong, they were forced to occupy less space and     press close to the shore, struggling very hard till they passed     it.
10136-8{_}3620{_}This shoal continued to move on, night and day without     interruption for several weeks.
10136-8{_}3621{_}Their progress might be at the     rate of about a mile an hour.
10136-8{_}3622{_}It was easy to catch the animals,     though they were very active and nimble.
10136-8{_}3623{_}They were eels     perfectly well formed in every respect, but not exceeding two     inches in length.
10136-8{_}3624{_}I conceive that the shoal did not contain, on     an average, less than from twelve to twenty in breadth; so that     the number that passed, on the whole, must have been very great.
10136-8{_}3625{_}Whence they came or whither they went, I know not; but the place     where I saw this, was six miles from the sea."
10136-8{_}3626{_}EEL PIE.
10136-8{_}3627{_}253.
10136-8{_}3628{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}3629{_}of eels, a little chopped parsley, 1 shalot; grated nutmeg; pepper and salt to taste; the juice of 1/2 a lemon, small quantity of forcemeat, 1/4 pint of béchamel (see Sauces); puff paste.
10136-8{_}3630{_}_Mode_.--Skin and wash the eels, cut them into pieces 2 inches long, and line the bottom of the pie-dish with forcemeat.
10136-8{_}3631{_}Put in the eels, and sprinkle them with the parsley, shalots, nutmeg, seasoning, and lemon-juice, and cover with puff-paste.
10136-8{_}3632{_}Bake for 1 hour, or rather more; make the béchamel hot, and pour it into the pie.
10136-8{_}3633{_}_Time_.--Rather more than 1 hour.
10136-8{_}3634{_}_Seasonable_ from August to March.
10136-8{_}3635{_}COLLARED EEL.
10136-8{_}3636{_}254.
10136-8{_}3637{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 large eel; pepper and salt to taste; 2 blades of mace, 2 cloves, a little allspice very finely pounded, 6 leaves of sage, and a small bunch of herbs minced very small.
10136-8{_}3638{_}_Mode_.--Bone the eel and skin it; split it, and sprinkle it over with the ingredients, taking care that the spices are very finely pounded, and the herbs chopped very small.
10136-8{_}3639{_}Roll it up and bind with a broad piece of tape, and boil it in water, mixed with a little salt and vinegar, till tender.
10136-8{_}3640{_}It may either be served whole or cut in slices; and when cold, the eel should be kept in the liquor it was boiled in, but with a little more vinegar put to it.
10136-8{_}3641{_}_Time_.--2 hours.
10136-8{_}3642{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}3643{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}3644{_}_Seasonable_ from August to March.
10136-8{_}3645{_}HAUNTS OF THE EEL.--These are usually in mud, among weeds, under     roots or stumps of trees, or in holes in the banks or the     bottoms of rivers.
10136-8{_}3646{_}Here they often grow to an enormous size,     sometimes weighing as much as fifteen or sixteen pounds.
10136-8{_}3647{_}They     seldom come forth from their hiding-places except in the night;     and, in winter, bury themselves deep in the mud, on account of     their great susceptibility of cold.
10136-8{_}3648{_}EELS A LA TARTARE.
10136-8{_}3649{_}255.
10136-8{_}3650{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 lbs.
10136-8{_}3651{_}of eels, 1 carrot, 1 onion, a little flour, 1 glass of sherry; salt, pepper, and nutmeg to taste; bread crumbs, 1 egg, 2 tablespoonfuls of vinegar.
10136-8{_}3652{_}_Mode_.--Rub the butter on the bottom of the stewpan; cut up the carrot and onion, and stir them over the fire for 5 minutes; dredge in a little flour, add the wine and seasoning, and boil for 1/2 an hour.
10136-8{_}3653{_}Skin and wash the eels, cut them into pieces, put them to the other ingredients, and simmer till tender.
10136-8{_}3654{_}When they are done, take them out, let them get cold, cover them with egg and bread crumbs, and fry them of a nice brown.
10136-8{_}3655{_}Put them on a dish, pour sauce piquante over, and serve them hot.
10136-8{_}3656{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}3657{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}3658{_}8d., exclusive of the sauce piquante.
10136-8{_}3659{_}_Seasonable_ from August to March.
10136-8{_}3660{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}3661{_}VORACITY OF THE EEL.--We find in a note upon Isaac Walton, by     Sir John Hawkins, that he knew of eels, when kept in ponds,     frequently destroying ducks.
10136-8{_}3662{_}From a canal near his house at     Twickenham he himself missed many young ducks; and on draining,     in order to clean it, great numbers of large eels were caught in     the mud.
10136-8{_}3663{_}When some of these were opened, there were found in     their stomachs the undigested heads of the quacking tribe which     had become their victims.
10136-8{_}3664{_}EELS EN MATELOTE.
10136-8{_}3665{_}256.
10136-8{_}3666{_}INGREDIENTS.--5 or 6 young onions, a few mushrooms, when obtainable; salt, pepper, and nutmeg to taste; 1 laurel-leaf, 1/2 pint of port wine, 1/2 pint of medium stock, No.
10136-8{_}3667{_}105; butter and flour to thicken; 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}3668{_}of eels.
10136-8{_}3669{_}_Mode_.--Rub the stewpan with butter, dredge in a little flour, add the onions cut very small, slightly brown them, and put in all the other ingredients.
10136-8{_}3670{_}Wash, and cut up the eels into pieces 3 inches long; put them in the stewpan, and simmer for 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}3671{_}Make round the dish, a border of croutons, or pieces of toasted bread; arrange the eels in a pyramid in the centre, and pour over the sauce.
10136-8{_}3672{_}Serve very hot.
10136-8{_}3673{_}_Time_.--3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}3674{_}Average cost, 1s.
10136-8{_}3675{_}9d.
10136-8{_}3676{_}for this quantity.
10136-8{_}3677{_}_Seasonable_ from August to March.
10136-8{_}3678{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}3679{_}TENACITY OF LIFE IN THE EEL.--There is no fish so tenacious of     life as this.
10136-8{_}3680{_}After it is skinned and cut in pieces, the parts     will continue to move for a considerable time, and no fish will     live so long out of water.
10136-8{_}3681{_}[Illustration: THE LAMPREY.]
10136-8{_}3682{_}THE LAMPREY.--With the Romans, this fish occupied a respectable     rank among the piscine tribes, and in Britain it has at various     periods stood high in public favour.
10136-8{_}3683{_}It was the cause of the     death of Henry I. of England, who ate so much of them, that it     brought on an attack of indigestion, which carried him off.
10136-8{_}3684{_}It     is an inhabitant of the sea, ascending rivers, principally about     the end of winter, and, after passing a few months in fresh     water, returning again to its oceanic residence.
10136-8{_}3685{_}It is most in     season in March, April, and May, but is, by some, regarded as an     unwholesome food, although looked on by others as a great     delicacy.
10136-8{_}3686{_}They are dressed as eels.
10136-8{_}3687{_}FISH AND OYSTER PIE.
10136-8{_}3688{_}257.
10136-8{_}3689{_}INGREDIENTS.--Any remains of cold fish, such as cod or haddock; 2 dozen oysters, pepper and salt to taste, bread crumbs sufficient for the quantity of fish; 1/2 teaspoonful of grated nutmeg, 1 teaspoonful of finely-chopped parsley.
10136-8{_}3690{_}_Mode_.--Clear the fish from the bones, and put a layer of it in a pie-dish, which sprinkle with pepper and salt; then a layer of bread crumbs, oysters, nutmeg, and chopped parsley.
10136-8{_}3691{_}Repeat this till the dish is quite full.
10136-8{_}3692{_}You may form a covering either of bread crumbs, which should be browned, or puff-paste, which should be cut into long strips, and laid in cross-bars over the fish, with a line of the paste first laid round the edge.
10136-8{_}3693{_}Before putting on the top, pour in some made melted butter, or a little thin white sauce, and the oyster-liquor, and bake.
10136-8{_}3694{_}_Time_.--If made of cooked fish, 1/4 hour; if made of fresh fish and puff-paste, 3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}3695{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}3696{_}6d.
10136-8{_}3697{_}_Seasonable_ from September to April.
10136-8{_}3698{_}_Note_.--A nice little dish may be made by flaking any cold fish, adding a few oysters, seasoning with pepper and salt, and covering with mashed potatoes; 1/4 hour will bake it.
10136-8{_}3699{_}FISH CAKE.
10136-8{_}3700{_}258.
10136-8{_}3701{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of any cold fish, 1 onion, 1 faggot of sweet herbs; salt and pepper to taste, 1 pint of water, equal quantities of bread crumbs and cold potatoes, 1/2 teaspoonful of parsley, 1 egg, bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}3702{_}_Mode_.--Pick the meat from the bones of the fish, which latter put, with the head and fins, into a stewpan with the water; add pepper and salt, the onion and herbs, and stew slowly for gravy about 2 hours; chop the fish fine, and mix it well with bread crumbs and cold potatoes, adding the parsley and seasoning; make the whole into a cake with the white of an egg, brush it over with egg, cover with bread crumbs, and fry of a light brown; strain the gravy, pour it over, and stew gently for 1/4 hour, stirring it carefully once or twice.
10136-8{_}3703{_}Serve hot, and garnish with slices of lemon and parsley.
10136-8{_}3704{_}_Time_--1/2 hour, after the gravy is made.
10136-8{_}3705{_}BOILED FLOUNDERS.
10136-8{_}3706{_}259.
10136-8{_}3707{_}INGREDIENTS.--Sufficient water to cover the flounders, salt in the proportion of 6 oz.
10136-8{_}3708{_}to each gallon, a little vinegar.
10136-8{_}3709{_}_Mode_.--Pat on a kettle with enough water to cover the flounders, lay in the fish, add salt and vinegar in the above proportions, and when it boils, simmer very gently for 5 minutes.
10136-8{_}3710{_}They must not boil fast, or they will break.
10136-8{_}3711{_}Serve with plain melted butter, or parsley and butter.
10136-8{_}3712{_}_Time_.--After the water boils, 5 minutes.
10136-8{_}3713{_}_Average cost_, 3d.
10136-8{_}3714{_}each.
10136-8{_}3715{_}_Seasonable_ from August to November.
10136-8{_}3716{_}[Illustration: FLOUNDERS.]
10136-8{_}3717{_}THE FLOUNDER.--This comes under the tribe usually denominated     Flat-fish, and is generally held in the smallest estimation of     any among them.
10136-8{_}3718{_}It is an inhabitant of both the seas and the     rivers, while it thrives in ponds.
10136-8{_}3719{_}On the English coasts it is     very abundant, and the London market consumes it in large     quantities.
10136-8{_}3720{_}It is considered easy of digestion, and the Thames     flounder is esteemed a delicate fish.
10136-8{_}3721{_}FRIED FLOUNDERS.
10136-8{_}3722{_}260.
10136-8{_}3723{_}INGREDIENTS.--Flounders, egg, and bread crumbs; boiling lard.
10136-8{_}3724{_}_Mode_.--Cleanse the fish, and, two hours before they are wanted, rub them inside and out with salt, to render them firm; wash and wipe them very dry, dip them into egg, and sprinkle over with bread crumbs; fry them in boiling lard, dish on a hot napkin, and garnish with crisped parsley.
10136-8{_}3725{_}_Time_.--From 5 to 10 minutes, according to size.
10136-8{_}3726{_}_Average cost_, 3d.
10136-8{_}3727{_}each.
10136-8{_}3728{_}_Seasonable_ from August to November.
10136-8{_}3729{_}_Sufficient_, 1 for each person.
10136-8{_}3730{_}GUDGEONS.
10136-8{_}3731{_}261.
10136-8{_}3732{_}INGREDIENTS.--Egg and bread crumbs sufficient for the quantity of fish; hot lard.
10136-8{_}3733{_}_Mode_.--Do not scrape off the scales, but take out the gills and inside, and cleanse thoroughly; wipe them dry, flour and dip them into egg, and sprinkle over with bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}3734{_}Fry of a nice brown.
10136-8{_}3735{_}_Time_.--3 or 4 minutes.
10136-8{_}3736{_}_Average cost_.
10136-8{_}3737{_}Seldom bought.
10136-8{_}3738{_}_Seasonable_ from March to July.
10136-8{_}3739{_}_Sufficient_, 3 for each person.
10136-8{_}3740{_}[Illustration: THE GUDGEON.]
10136-8{_}3741{_}THE GUDGEON.--This is a fresh-water fish, belonging to the carp     genus, and is found in placid streams and lakes.
10136-8{_}3742{_}It was highly     esteemed by the Greeks, and was, at the beginning of supper,     served fried at Rome.
10136-8{_}3743{_}It abounds both in France and Germany; and     is both excellent and numerous in some of the rivers of England.
10136-8{_}3744{_}Its flesh is firm, well-flavoured, and easily digested.
10136-8{_}3745{_}GURNET, or GURNARD.
10136-8{_}3746{_}262.
10136-8{_}3747{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 gurnet, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}3748{_}of salt to each gallon of water.
10136-8{_}3749{_}_Mode_.--Cleanse the fish thoroughly, and cut off the fins; have ready some boiling water, with salt in the above proportion; put the fish in, and simmer very gently for 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}3750{_}Parsley and butter, or anchovy sauce, should be served with it.
10136-8{_}3751{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}3752{_}_Average cost_.
10136-8{_}3753{_}Seldom bought.
10136-8{_}3754{_}_Seasonable_ from October to March, but in perfection in October.
10136-8{_}3755{_}_Sufficient_, a middling sized one for 2 persons.
10136-8{_}3756{_}_Note_.--This fish is frequently stuffed with forcemeat and baked.
10136-8{_}3757{_}[Illustration: THE GURNET.]
10136-8{_}3758{_}THE GURNET.-"If I be not ashamed of my soldiers, I am a souced     gurnet," says Falstaff; which shows that this fish has been long     known in England.
10136-8{_}3759{_}It is very common on the British coasts, and     is an excellent fish as food.
10136-8{_}3760{_}BAKED HADDOCKS.
10136-8{_}3761{_}263.
10136-8{_}3762{_}INGREDIENTS.--A nice forcemeat (_see_ Forcemeats), butter to taste, egg and bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}3763{_}_Mode_.--Scale and clean the fish, without cutting it open much; put in a nice delicate forcemeat, and sew up the slit.
10136-8{_}3764{_}Brush it over with egg, sprinkle over bread crumbs, and baste frequently with butter.
10136-8{_}3765{_}Garnish with parsley and cut lemon, and serve with a nice brown gravy, plain melted butter, or anchovy sauce.
10136-8{_}3766{_}The egg and bread crumbs can be omitted, and pieces of butter placed over the fish.
10136-8{_}3767{_}_Time_.--Large haddock, 3/4 hour; moderate size, 1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}3768{_}_Seasonable_ from August to February.
10136-8{_}3769{_}_Average cost_, from 9d.
10136-8{_}3770{_}upwards.
10136-8{_}3771{_}_Note_.--Haddocks may be filleted, rubbed over with egg and bread crumbs, and fried a nice brown; garnish with crisped parsley.
10136-8{_}3772{_}[Illustration: THE HADDOCK.]
10136-8{_}3773{_}THE HADDOCK.--This fish migrates in immense shoals, and arrives     on the Yorkshire coast about the middle of winter.
10136-8{_}3774{_}It is an     inhabitant of the northern seas of Europe, but does not enter     the Baltic, and is not known in the Mediterranean.
10136-8{_}3775{_}On each side     of the body, just beyond the gills, it has a dark spot, which     superstition asserts to be the impressions of the finger and     thumb of St. Peter, when taking the tribute money out of a fish     of this species.
10136-8{_}3776{_}BOILED HADDOCK.
10136-8{_}3777{_}264.
10136-8{_}3778{_}INGREDIENTS.--Sufficient water to cover the fish; 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}3779{_}of salt to each gallon of water.
10136-8{_}3780{_}_Mode_.--Scrape the fish, take out the inside, wash it thoroughly, and lay it in a kettle, with enough water to cover it and salt in the above proportion.
10136-8{_}3781{_}Simmer gently from 15 to 20 minutes, or rather more, should the fish be very large.
10136-8{_}3782{_}For small haddocks, fasten the tails in their mouths, and put them into boiling water.
10136-8{_}3783{_}10 to 15 minutes will cook them.
10136-8{_}3784{_}Serve with plain melted butter, or anchovy sauce.
10136-8{_}3785{_}_Time_.--Large haddock, 1/2 hour; small, 1/4 hour, or rather less.
10136-8{_}3786{_}_Average cost_, from 9d.
10136-8{_}3787{_}upwards.
10136-8{_}3788{_}_Seasonable_ from August to February.
10136-8{_}3789{_}WEIGHT OF THE HADDOCK.--The haddock seldom grows to any great     size.
10136-8{_}3790{_}In general, they do not weigh more than two or three     pounds, or exceed ten or twelve inches in size.
10136-8{_}3791{_}Such are     esteemed very delicate eating; but they have been caught three     feet long, when their flesh is coarse.
10136-8{_}3792{_}DRIED HADDOCK.
10136-8{_}3793{_}I.
10136-8{_}3794{_}265.
10136-8{_}3795{_}Dried haddock should be gradually warmed through, either before or over a nice clear fire.
10136-8{_}3796{_}Hub a little piece of butter over, just before sending it to table.
10136-8{_}3797{_}II.
10136-8{_}3798{_}266.
10136-8{_}3799{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 large thick haddock, 2 bay-leaves, 1 small bunch of savoury herbs, not forgetting parsley, a little butter and pepper; boiling water.
10136-8{_}3800{_}_Mode_.--Cut up the haddock into square pieces, make a basin hot by means of hot water, which pour out.
10136-8{_}3801{_}Lay in the fish, with the bay-leaves and herbs; cover with boiling water; put a plate over to keep in the steam, and let it remain for 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}3802{_}Take out the slices, put them in a hot dish, rub over with butter and pepper, and serve.
10136-8{_}3803{_}_Time_.--10 minutes.
10136-8{_}3804{_}_Seasonable_ at any time, but best in winter.
10136-8{_}3805{_}THE FINNAN HADDOCK.--This is the common haddock cured and dried,     and takes its name from the fishing-village of Findhorn, near     Aberdeen, in Scotland, where the art has long attained to     perfection.
10136-8{_}3806{_}The haddocks are there hung up for a day or two in     the smoke of peat, when they are ready for cooking, and are     esteemed, by the Scotch, a great delicacy.
10136-8{_}3807{_}In London, an     imitation of them is made by washing the fish over with     pyroligneous acid, and hanging it up in a dry place for a few     days.
10136-8{_}3808{_}RED HERRINGS, or YARMOUTH BLOATERS.
10136-8{_}3809{_}267.
10136-8{_}3810{_}The best way to cook these is to make incisions in the skin across the fish, because they do not then require to be so long on the fire, and will be far better than when cut open.
10136-8{_}3811{_}The hard roe makes a nice relish by pounding it in a mortar, with a little anchovy, and spreading it on toast.
10136-8{_}3812{_}If very dry, soak in warm water 1 hour before dressing.
10136-8{_}3813{_}THE RED HERRING.--_Red_ herrings lie twenty-four hours in the     brine, when they are taken out and hung up in a smoking-house     formed to receive them.
10136-8{_}3814{_}A brushwood fire is then kindled beneath     them, and when they are sufficiently smoked and dried, they are     put into barrels for carriage.
10136-8{_}3815{_}BAKED WHITE HERRINGS.
10136-8{_}3816{_}268.
10136-8{_}3817{_}INGREDIENTS.--12 herrings, 4 bay-leaves, 12 cloves, 12 allspice, 2 small blades of mace, cayenne pepper and salt to taste, sufficient vinegar to fill up the dish.
10136-8{_}3818{_}_Mode_.--Take the herrings, cut off the heads, and gut them.
10136-8{_}3819{_}Put them in a pie-dish, heads and tails alternately, and, between each layer, sprinkle over the above ingredients.
10136-8{_}3820{_}Cover the fish with the vinegar, and bake for 1/2 hour, but do not use it till quite cold.
10136-8{_}3821{_}The herrings may be cut down the front, the backbone taken out, and closed again.
10136-8{_}3822{_}Sprats done in this way are very delicious.
10136-8{_}3823{_}_Time_.--1/2 an hour.
10136-8{_}3824{_}_Average cost_, 1d.
10136-8{_}3825{_}each.
10136-8{_}3826{_}TO CHOOSE THE HERRING.--The more scales this fish has, the surer the sign of its freshness.
10136-8{_}3827{_}It should also have a bright and silvery look; but if red about the head, it is a sign that it has been dead for some time.
10136-8{_}3828{_}[Illustration: THE HERRING.]
10136-8{_}3829{_}THE HERRING.--The herring tribe are found in the greatest     abundance in the highest northern latitudes, where they find a     quiet retreat, and security from their numerous enemies.
10136-8{_}3830{_}Here     they multiply beyond expression, and, in shoals, come forth from     their icy region to visit other portions of the great deep.
10136-8{_}3831{_}In     June they are found about Shetland, whence they proceed down to     the Orkneys, where they divide, and surround the islands of     Great Britain and Ireland.
10136-8{_}3832{_}The principal British     herring-fisheries are off the Scotch and Norfolk coasts; and the     fishing is always carried on by means of nets, which are usually     laid at night; for, if stretched by day, they are supposed to     frighten the fish away.
10136-8{_}3833{_}The moment the herring is taken out of     the water it dies.
10136-8{_}3834{_}Hence the origin of the common saying, "dead     as a herring."
10136-8{_}3835{_}KEGEREE.
10136-8{_}3836{_}269.
10136-8{_}3837{_}INGREDIENTS.--Any cold fish, 1 teacupful of boiled rice, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}3838{_}of butter, 1 teaspoonful of mustard, 2 soft-boiled eggs, salt and cayenne to taste.
10136-8{_}3839{_}_Mode_.--Pick the fish carefully from the bones, mix with the other ingredients, and serve very hot.
10136-8{_}3840{_}The quantities may be varied according to the amount of fish used.
10136-8{_}3841{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour after the rice is boiled.
10136-8{_}3842{_}_Average cost_, 5d., exclusive of the fish.
10136-8{_}3843{_}TO BOIL LOBSTERS.
10136-8{_}3844{_}270.
10136-8{_}3845{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}3846{_}of salt to each gallon of water.
10136-8{_}3847{_}_Mode_.--Buy the lobsters alive, and choose those that are heavy and full of motion, which is an indication of their freshness.
10136-8{_}3848{_}When the shell is incrusted, it is a sign they are old: medium-sized lobsters are the best.
10136-8{_}3849{_}Have ready a stewpan of boiling water, salted in the above proportion; put in the lobster, and keep it boiling quickly from 20 minutes to 3/4 hour, according to its size, and do not forget to skim well.
10136-8{_}3850{_}If it boils too long, the meat becomes thready, and if not done enough, the spawn is not red: this must be obviated by great attention.
10136-8{_}3851{_}Hub the shell over with a little butter or sweet oil, which wipe off again.
10136-8{_}3852{_}_Time_.--Small lobster, 20 minutes to 1/2 hour; large ditto, 1/2 to 1/3 hour.
10136-8{_}3853{_}_Average cost_, medium size, 1s.
10136-8{_}3854{_}6d.
10136-8{_}3855{_}to 2s.
10136-8{_}3856{_}6d.
10136-8{_}3857{_}_Seasonable_ all the year, but best from March to October.
10136-8{_}3858{_}TO CHOOSE LOBSTERS.--This shell-fish, if it has been cooked alive, as it ought to have been, will have a stiffness in the tail, which, if gently raised, will return with a spring.
10136-8{_}3859{_}Care, however, must be taken in thus proving it; for if the tail is pulled straight out, it will not return; when the fish might be pronounced inferior, which, in reality, may not be the case.
10136-8{_}3860{_}In order to be good, lobsters should be weighty for their bulk; if light, they will be watery; and those of the medium size, are always the best.
10136-8{_}3861{_}Small-sized lobsters are cheapest, and answer very well for sauce.
10136-8{_}3862{_}In boiling lobsters, the appearance of the shell will be much improved by rubbing over it a little butter or salad-oil on being immediately taken from the pot.
10136-8{_}3863{_}[Illustration: THE LOBSTER.]
10136-8{_}3864{_}THE LOBSTER.--This is one of the crab tribe, and is found on     most of the rocky coasts of Great Britain.
10136-8{_}3865{_}Some are caught with     the hand, but the larger number in pots, which serve all the     purposes of a trap, being made of osiers, and baited with     garbage.
10136-8{_}3866{_}They are shaped like a wire mousetrap; so that when the     lobsters once enter them, they cannot get out again.
10136-8{_}3867{_}They are     fastened to a cord and sunk in the sea, and their place marked     by a buoy.
10136-8{_}3868{_}The fish is very prolific, and deposits of its eggs     in the sand, where they are soon hatched.
10136-8{_}3869{_}On the coast of     Norway, they are very abundant, and it is from there that the     English metropolis is mostly supplied.
10136-8{_}3870{_}They are rather     indigestible, and, as a food, not so nurtritive as they are     generally supposed to be.
10136-8{_}3871{_}HOT LOBSTER.
10136-8{_}3872{_}271.
10136-8{_}3873{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lobster, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}3874{_}of butter, grated nutmeg; salt, pepper, and pounded mace, to taste; bread crumbs, 2 eggs.
10136-8{_}3875{_}_Mode_.--Pound the meat of the lobster to a smooth paste with the butter and seasoning, and add a few bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}3876{_}Beat the eggs, and make the whole mixture into the form of a lobster; pound the spawn, and sprinkle over it.
10136-8{_}3877{_}Bake 1/4 hour, and just before serving, lay over it the tail and body shell, with the small claws underneath, to resemble a lobster.
10136-8{_}3878{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}3879{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}3880{_}6d.
10136-8{_}3881{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}3882{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}3883{_}LOBSTER SALAD.
10136-8{_}3884{_}272.
10136-8{_}3885{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 hen lobster, lettuces, endive, small salad (whatever is in season), a little chopped beetroot, 2 hard-boiled eggs, a few slices of cucumber.
10136-8{_}3886{_}For dressing, equal quantities of oil and vinegar, 1 teaspoonful of made mustard, the yolks of 2 eggs; cayenne and salt to taste; 3 teaspoonful of anchovy sauce.
10136-8{_}3887{_}These ingredients should be mixed perfectly smooth, and form a creamy-looking sauce.
10136-8{_}3888{_}_Mode_.--Wash the salad, and thoroughly dry it by shaking it in a cloth.
10136-8{_}3889{_}Cut up the lettuces and endive, pour the dressing on them, and lightly throw in the small salad.
10136-8{_}3890{_}Mix all well together with the pickings from the body of the lobster; pick the meat from the shell, cut it up into nice square pieces, put half in the salad, the other half reserve for garnishing.
10136-8{_}3891{_}Separate the yolks from the whites of 2 hard-boiled eggs; chop the whites very fine, and rub the yolks through a sieve, and afterwards the coral from the inside.
10136-8{_}3892{_}Arrange the salad lightly on a glass dish, and garnish, first with a row of sliced cucumber, then with the pieces of lobster, the yolks and whites of the eggs, coral, and beetroot placed alternately, and arranged in small separate bunches, so that the colours contrast nicely.
10136-8{_}3893{_}_Average cost_, 3s.
10136-8{_}3894{_}6d.
10136-8{_}3895{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}3896{_}_Seasonable_ from April to October; may be had all the year, but salad is scarce and expensive in winter.
10136-8{_}3897{_}_Note_.--A few crayfish make a pretty garnishing to lobster salad.
10136-8{_}3898{_}THE SHELL OF THE LOBSTER.--Like the others of its tribe, the     lobster annually casts its shell.
10136-8{_}3899{_}Previously to its throwing off     the old one, it appears sick, languid, and restless, but in the     course of a few days it is entirely invested in its new coat of     armour.
10136-8{_}3900{_}Whilst it is in a defenceless state, however, it seeks     some lonely place, where it may lie undisturbed, and escape the     horrid fate of being devoured by some of its own species who     have the advantage of still being encased in their mail.
10136-8{_}3901{_}LOBSTER (a la Mode Francaise).
10136-8{_}3902{_}273.
10136-8{_}3903{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lobster, 4 tablespoonfuls of white stock, 2 tablespoonfuls of cream, pounded mace, and cayenne to taste; bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}3904{_}_Mode_.--Pick the meat from the shell, and cut it up into small square pieces; put the stock, cream, and seasoning into a stewpan, add the lobster, and let it simmer gently for 6 minutes.
10136-8{_}3905{_}Serve it in the shell, which must be nicely cleaned, and have a border of puff-paste; cover it with bread crumbs, place small pieces of butter over, and brown before the fire, or with a salamander.
10136-8{_}3906{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}3907{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}3908{_}6d.
10136-8{_}3909{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}3910{_}CELERITY OF THE LOBSTER.--In its element, the lobster is able to     run with great speed upon its legs, or small claws, and, if     alarmed, to spring, tail foremost, to a considerable distance,     "even," it is said, "with the swiftness of a bird flying."
10136-8{_}3911{_}Fishermen have seen some of them pass about thirty feet with a     wonderful degree of swiftness.
10136-8{_}3912{_}When frightened, they will take     their spring, and, like a chamois of the Alps, plant themselves     upon the very spot upon which they designed to hold themselves.
10136-8{_}3913{_}LOBSTER CURRY (an Entree).
10136-8{_}3914{_}274.
10136-8{_}3915{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lobster, 2 onions, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}3916{_}butter, 1 tablespoonful of curry-powder, 1/2 pint of medium stock, No.
10136-8{_}3917{_}105, the juice of 1/2 lemon.
10136-8{_}3918{_}_Mode_.--Pick the meat from the shell, and cut it into nice square pieces; fry the onions of a pale brown in the butter, stir in the curry-powder and stock, and simmer till it thickens, when put in the lobster; stew the whole slowly for 1/2 hour, and stir occasionally; and just before sending to table, put in the lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}3919{_}Serve boiled rice with it, the same as for other curries.
10136-8{_}3920{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}3921{_}_Average cost_, 3s.
10136-8{_}3922{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}3923{_}LOBSTER CUTLETS (an Entree).
10136-8{_}3924{_}275.
10136-8{_}3925{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 large hen lobster, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}3926{_}fresh butter, 1/2 saltspoonful of salt, pounded mace, grated nutmeg, cayenne and white pepper to taste, egg, and bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}3927{_}_Mode_.--Pick the meat from the shell, and pound it in a mortar with the butter, and gradually add the mace and seasoning, well mixing the ingredients; beat all to a smooth paste, and add a little of the spawn; divide the mixture into pieces of an equal size, and shape them like cutlets.
10136-8{_}3928{_}They should not be very thick.
10136-8{_}3929{_}Brush them over with egg, and sprinkle with bread crumbs, and stick a short piece of the small claw in the top of each; fry them of a nice brown in boiling lard, and drain them before the fire, on a sieve reversed; arrange them nicely on a dish, and pour béchamel in the middle, but not over the cutlets.
10136-8{_}3930{_}_Time_.--About 8 minutes after the cutlets are made.
10136-8{_}3931{_}_Average cost_ for this dish, 2s.
10136-8{_}3932{_}9d.
10136-8{_}3933{_}_Seasonable_ all the year.
10136-8{_}3934{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}3935{_}ANCIENT MODE OF COOKING THE LOBSTER.--When this fish was to be     served for the table, among the ancients, it was opened     lengthwise, and filled with a gravy composed of coriander and     pepper.
10136-8{_}3936{_}It was then put on the gridiron and slowly cooked,     whilst it was being basted with the same kind of gravy with     which the flesh had become impregnated.
10136-8{_}3937{_}TO DRESS LOBSTERS.
10136-8{_}3938{_}276.
10136-8{_}3939{_}When the lobster is boiled, rub it over with a little salad-oil, which wipe off again; separate the body from the tail, break off the great claws, and crack them at the joints, without injuring the meat; split the tail in halves, and arrange all neatly in a dish, with the body upright in the middle, and garnish with parsley.
10136-8{_}3940{_}(_See_ Coloured Plate, H.)   LOBSTER PATTIES (an Entree).
10136-8{_}3941{_}277.
10136-8{_}3942{_}INGREDIENTS.--Minced lobster, 4 tablespoonfuls of béchamel, 6 drops of anchovy sauce, lemon-juice, cayenne to taste.
10136-8{_}3943{_}_Mode_.--Line the patty-pans with puff-paste, and put into each a small piece of bread: cover with paste, brush over with egg, and bake of a light colour.
10136-8{_}3944{_}Take as much lobster as is required, mince the meat very fine, and add the above ingredients; stir it over the fire for 6 minutes; remove the lids of the patty-cases, take out the bread, fill with the mixture, and replace the covers.
10136-8{_}3945{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}3946{_}LOCAL ATTACHMENT OF THE LOBSTER.--It is said that the attachment     of this animal is strong to some particular parts of the sea, a     circumstance celebrated in the following lines:--        "Nought like their home the constant lobsters prize,       And foreign shores and seas unknown despise.
10136-8{_}3947{_}Though cruel hands the banish'd wretch expel,       And force the captive from his native cell,       He will, if freed, return with anxious care,       Find the known rock, and to his home repair;       No novel customs learns in different seas,       But wonted food and home-taught manners please."
10136-8{_}3948{_}POTTED LOBSTER.
10136-8{_}3949{_}278.
10136-8{_}3950{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 lobsters; seasoning to taste, of nutmeg, pounded mace, white pepper, and salt; 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}3951{_}of butter, 3 or 4 bay-leaves.
10136-8{_}3952{_}_Mode_.--Take out the meat carefully from the shell, but do not cut it up.
10136-8{_}3953{_}Put some butter at the bottom of a dish, lay in the lobster as evenly as possible, with the bay-leaves and seasoning between.
10136-8{_}3954{_}Cover with butter, and bake for 3/4 hour in a gentle oven.
10136-8{_}3955{_}When done, drain the whole on a sieve, and lay the pieces in potting-jars, with the seasoning about them.
10136-8{_}3956{_}When cold, pour over it clarified butter, and, if very highly seasoned, it will keep some time.
10136-8{_}3957{_}_Time_.--3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}3958{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 4s.
10136-8{_}3959{_}4d.
10136-8{_}3960{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}3961{_}_Note_.--Potted lobster may be used cold, or as _fricassee_ with cream sauce.
10136-8{_}3962{_}How the Lobster Feeds.--The pincers of the lobster's large claws     are furnished with nobs, and those of the other, are always     serrated.
10136-8{_}3963{_}With the former, it keeps firm hold of the stalks of     submarine plants, and with the latter, it cuts and minces its     food with great dexterity.
10136-8{_}3964{_}The knobbed, or numb claw, as it is     called by fishermen, is sometimes on the right and sometimes on     the left, indifferently.
10136-8{_}3965{_}BAKED MACKEREL.
10136-8{_}3966{_}279.
10136-8{_}3967{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 middling-sized mackerel, a nice delicate forcemeat (_see_ Forcemeats), 3 oz.
10136-8{_}3968{_}of butter; pepper and salt to taste.
10136-8{_}3969{_}_Mode_.--Clean the fish, take out the roes, and fill up with forcemeat, and sew up the slit.
10136-8{_}3970{_}Flour, and put them in a dish, heads and tails alternately, with the roes; and, between each layer, put some little pieces of butter, and pepper and salt.
10136-8{_}3971{_}Bake for 1/2 an hour, and either serve with plain melted butter or a _maître d'hôtel_ sauce.
10136-8{_}3972{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}3973{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 1s.
10136-8{_}3974{_}10d.
10136-8{_}3975{_}_Seasonable_ from April to July.
10136-8{_}3976{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 persons.
10136-8{_}3977{_}_Note_.--Baked mackerel may be dressed in the same way as baked herrings (_see_ No.
10136-8{_}3978{_}268), and may also be stewed in wine.
10136-8{_}3979{_}WEIGHT OF THE MACKEREL.--The greatest weight of this fish seldom     exceeds 2 lbs., whilst their ordinary length runs between 14 and     20 inches.
10136-8{_}3980{_}They die almost immediately after they are taken from     their element, and, for a short time, exhibit a phosphoric     light.
10136-8{_}3981{_}BOILED MACKEREL.
10136-8{_}3982{_}280.
10136-8{_}3983{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}3984{_}of salt to each gallon of water.
10136-8{_}3985{_}_Mode_.--Cleanse the inside of the fish thoroughly, and lay it in the kettle with sufficient water to cover it with salt as above; bring it gradually to boil, skim well, and simmer gently till done; dish them on a hot napkin, heads and tails alternately, and garnish with fennel.
10136-8{_}3986{_}Fennel sauce and plain melted butter are the usual accompaniments to boiled mackerel; but caper or anchovy sauce is sometimes served with it.
10136-8{_}3987{_}(_See_ Coloured Plate, F.)  _Time_.--After the water boils, 10 minutes; for large mackerel, allow more time.
10136-8{_}3988{_}_Average cost_, from 4d.
10136-8{_}3989{_}_Seasonable_ from April to July.
10136-8{_}3990{_}_Note_.--When variety is desired, fillet the mackerel, boil it, and pour over parsley and butter; send some of this, besides, in a tureen.
10136-8{_}3991{_}BROILED MACKEREL.
10136-8{_}3992{_}281.
10136-8{_}3993{_}INGREDIENTS.--Pepper and salt to taste, a small quantity of oil.
10136-8{_}3994{_}_Mode_.--Mackerel should never be washed when intended to be broiled, but merely wiped very clean and dry, after taking out the gills and insides.
10136-8{_}3995{_}Open the back, and put in a little pepper, salt, and oil; broil it over a clear fire, turn it over on both sides, and also on the back.
10136-8{_}3996{_}When sufficiently cooked, the flesh can be detached from the bone, which will be in about 15 minutes for a small mackerel.
10136-8{_}3997{_}Chop a little parsley, work it up in the butter, with pepper and salt to taste, and a squeeze of lemon-juice, and put it in the back.
10136-8{_}3998{_}Serve before the butter is quite melted, with a _maître d'hôtel_ sauce in a tureen.
10136-8{_}3999{_}_Time_.--Small mackerel 15 minutes.
10136-8{_}4000{_}_Average cost_, from 4d.
10136-8{_}4001{_}_Seasonable_ from April to July.
10136-8{_}4002{_}[Illustration: THE MACKEREL.]
10136-8{_}4003{_}THE MACKEREL.--This is not only one of the most     elegantly-formed, but one of the most beautifully-coloured     fishes, when taken out of the sea, that we have.
10136-8{_}4004{_}Death, in some     degree, impairs the vivid splendour of its colours; but it does     not entirely obliterate them.
10136-8{_}4005{_}It visits the shores of Great     Britain in countless shoals, appearing about March, off the     Land's End; in the bays of Devonshire, about April; off Brighton     in the beginning of May; and on the coast of Suffolk about the     beginning of June.
10136-8{_}4006{_}In the Orkneys they are seen till August; but     the greatest fishery is on the west coasts of England.
10136-8{_}4007{_}TO CHOOSE MACKEREL.--In choosing this fish, purchasers should, to a great extent, be regulated by the brightness of its appearance.
10136-8{_}4008{_}If it have a transparent, silvery hue, the flesh is good; but if it be red about the head, it is stale.
10136-8{_}4009{_}FILLETS OF MACKEREL.
10136-8{_}4010{_}282.
10136-8{_}4011{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 large mackerel, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}4012{_}butter, 1 small bunch of chopped herbs, 3 tablespoonfuls of medium stock, No.
10136-8{_}4013{_}105, 3 tablespoonfuls of béchamel (_see_ Sauces); salt, cayenne, and lemon-juice to taste.
10136-8{_}4014{_}_Mode_.--Clean the fish, and fillet it; scald the herbs, chop them fine, and put them with the butter and stock into a stewpan.
10136-8{_}4015{_}Lay in the mackerel, and simmer very gently for 10 minutes; take them out, and put them on a hot dish.
10136-8{_}4016{_}Dredge in a little flour, add the other ingredients, give one boil, and pour it over the mackerel.
10136-8{_}4017{_}_Time_.--20 minutes.
10136-8{_}4018{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 1s.
10136-8{_}4019{_}6d.
10136-8{_}4020{_}_Seasonable_ from April to July.
10136-8{_}4021{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}4022{_}_Note_.--Fillets of mackerel may be covered with egg and bread crumbs, and fried of a nice brown.
10136-8{_}4023{_}Serve with _maître d'hôtel_ sauce and plain melted butter.
10136-8{_}4024{_}THE VORACITY OF THE MACKEREL.--The voracity of this fish is very     great, and, from their immense numbers, they are bold in     attacking objects of which they might, otherwise, be expected to     have a wholesome dread.
10136-8{_}4025{_}Pontoppidan relates an anecdote of a     sailor belonging to a ship lying in one of the harbours on the     coast of Norway, who, having gone into the sea to bathe, was     suddenly missed by his companions; in the course of a few     minutes, however, he was seen on the surface, with great numbers     of mackerel clinging to him by their mouths.
10136-8{_}4026{_}His comrades     hastened in a boat to his assistance; but when they had struck     the fishes from him and got him up, they found he was so     severely bitten, that he shortly afterward expired.
10136-8{_}4027{_}PICKLED MACKEREL.
10136-8{_}4028{_}283.
10136-8{_}4029{_}INGREDIENTS.--12 peppercorns, 2 bay-leaves, 1/2 pint of vinegar, 4 mackerel.
10136-8{_}4030{_}_Mode_.--Boil the mackerel as in the recipe No.
10136-8{_}4031{_}282, and lay them in a dish; take half the liquor they were boiled in; add as much vinegar, peppercorns, and bay-leaves; boil for 10 minutes, and when cold, pour over the fish.
10136-8{_}4032{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}4033{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}4034{_}6d.
10136-8{_}4035{_}MACKEREL GARUM.--This brine, so greatly esteemed by the     ancients, was manufactured from various kinds of fishes.
10136-8{_}4036{_}When     mackerel was employed, a few of them were placed in a small     vase, with a large quantity of salt, which was well stirred, and     then left to settle for some hours.
10136-8{_}4037{_}On the following day, this     was put into an earthen pot, which was uncovered, and placed in     a situation to get the rays of the sun.
10136-8{_}4038{_}At the end of two or     three months, it was hermetically sealed, after having had added     to it a quantity of old wine, equal to one third of the mixture.
10136-8{_}4039{_}GREY MULLET.
10136-8{_}4040{_}284.
10136-8{_}4041{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}4042{_}of salt to each gallon of water.
10136-8{_}4043{_}_Mode_.--If the fish be very large, it should be laid in cold water, and gradually brought to a boil; if small, put it in boiling water, salted in the above proportion.
10136-8{_}4044{_}Serve with anchovy sauce and plain melted butter.
10136-8{_}4045{_}_Time_.--According to size, 1/4 to 3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}4046{_}_Average cost_, 8d.
10136-8{_}4047{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}4048{_}_Seasonable_ from July to October.
10136-8{_}4049{_}[Illustration: THE GREY MULLET.]
10136-8{_}4050{_}THE GREY MULLET.--This is quite a different fish from the red     mullet, is abundant on the sandy coasts of Great Britain, and     ascends rivers for miles.
10136-8{_}4051{_}On the south coast it is very     plentiful, and is considered a fine fish.
10136-8{_}4052{_}It improves more than     any other salt-water fish when kept in ponds.
10136-8{_}4053{_}RED MULLET.
10136-8{_}4054{_}285.
10136-8{_}4055{_}INGREDIENTS.--Oiled paper, thickening of butter and flour, 1/2 teaspoonful of anchovy sauce, 1 glass of sherry; cayenne and salt to taste.
10136-8{_}4056{_}_Mode_.--Clean the fish, take out the gills, but leave the inside, fold in oiled paper, and bake them gently.
10136-8{_}4057{_}When done, take the liquor that flows from the fish, add a thickening of butter kneaded with flour; put in the other ingredients, and let it boil for 2 minutes.
10136-8{_}4058{_}Serve the sauce in a tureen, and the fish, either with or without the paper cases.
10136-8{_}4059{_}_Time_.--About 25 minutes.
10136-8{_}4060{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}4061{_}each.
10136-8{_}4062{_}_Seasonable_ at any time, but more plentiful in summer.
10136-8{_}4063{_}_Note_.--Red mullet may be broiled, and should be folded in oiled paper, the same as in the preceding recipe, and seasoned with pepper and salt.
10136-8{_}4064{_}They may be served without sauce; but if any is required, use melted _butter_, Italian or anchovy sauce.
10136-8{_}4065{_}They should never be plain boiled.
10136-8{_}4066{_}[Illustration: THE STRIPED RED MULLET.]
10136-8{_}4067{_}THE STRIPED RED MULLET.--This fish was very highly esteemed by     the ancients, especially by the Romans, who gave the most     extravagant prices for it.
10136-8{_}4068{_}Those of 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}4069{_}weight were valued at     about £15 each; those of 4 lbs.
10136-8{_}4070{_}at £60, and, in the reign of     Tiberius, three of them were sold for £209.
10136-8{_}4071{_}To witness the     changing loveliness of their colour during their dying agonies,     was one of the principal reasons that such a high price was paid     for one of these fishes.
10136-8{_}4072{_}It frequents our Cornish and Sussex     coasts, and is in high request, the flesh being firm, white, and     well flavoured.
10136-8{_}4073{_}FRIED OYSTERS.
10136-8{_}4074{_}286.
10136-8{_}4075{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 dozen oysters, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}4076{_}butter, 1 tablespoonful of ketchup, a little chopped lemon-peel, 1/2 teaspoonful of chopped parsley.
10136-8{_}4077{_}_Mode_.--Boil the oysters for 1 minute in their own liquor, and drain them; fry them with the butter, ketchup, lemon-peel, and parsley; lay them on a dish, and garnish with fried potatoes, toasted sippets, and parsley.
10136-8{_}4078{_}This is a delicious delicacy, and is a favourite Italian dish.
10136-8{_}4079{_}_Time_.--5 minutes.
10136-8{_}4080{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 1s.
10136-8{_}4081{_}9d.
10136-8{_}4082{_}_Seasonable_ from September to April.
10136-8{_}4083{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}4084{_}[Illustration: THE EDIBLE OYSTER.]
10136-8{_}4085{_}THE EDIBLE OYSTER:--This shell-fish is almost universally     distributed near the shores of seas in all latitudes, and they     especially abound on the coasts of France and Britain.
10136-8{_}4086{_}The     coasts most celebrated, in England, for them, are those of Essex     and Suffolk.
10136-8{_}4087{_}Here they are dredged up by means of a net with an     iron scraper at the mouth, that is dragged by a rope from a boat     over the beds.
10136-8{_}4088{_}As soon as taken from their native beds, they are     stored in pits, formed for the purpose, furnished with sluices,     through which, at the spring tides, the water is suffered to     flow.
10136-8{_}4089{_}This water, being stagnant, soon becomes green in warm     weather; and, in a few days afterwards, the oysters acquire the     same tinge, which increases their value in the market.
10136-8{_}4090{_}They do     not, however, attain their perfection and become fit for sale     till the end of six or eight weeks.
10136-8{_}4091{_}Oysters are not considered     proper for the table till they are about a year and a half old;     so that the brood of one spring are not to be taken for sale,     till, at least, the September twelvemonth afterwards.
10136-8{_}4092{_}SCALLOPED OYSTERS.
10136-8{_}4093{_}I.
10136-8{_}4094{_}287.
10136-8{_}4095{_}INGREDIENTS.--Oysters, say 1 pint, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}4096{_}butter, flour, 2 tablespoonfuls of white stock, 2 tablespoonfuls of cream; pepper and salt to taste; bread crumbs, oiled butter.
10136-8{_}4097{_}_Mode_.--Scald the oysters in their own liquor, take them out, beard them, and strain the liquor free from grit.
10136-8{_}4098{_}Put 1 oz.
10136-8{_}4099{_}of batter into a stewpan; when melted, dredge in sufficient flour to dry it up; add the stock, cream, and strained liquor, and give one boil.
10136-8{_}4100{_}Put in the oysters and seasoning; let them gradually heat through, but not boil.
10136-8{_}4101{_}Have ready the scallop-shells buttered; lay in the oysters, and as much of the liquid as they will hold; cover them over with bread crumbs, over which drop a little oiled butter.
10136-8{_}4102{_}Brown them in the oven, or before the fire, and serve quickly, and very hot.
10136-8{_}4103{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}4104{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 3s.
10136-8{_}4105{_}6d.
10136-8{_}4106{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}4107{_}II.
10136-8{_}4108{_}Prepare the oysters as in the preceding recipe, and put them in a scallop-shell or saucer, and between each layer sprinkle over a few bread crumbs, pepper, salt, and grated nutmeg; place small pieces of butter over, and bake before the fire in a Dutch oven.
10136-8{_}4109{_}Put sufficient bread crumbs on the top to make a smooth surface, as the oysters should not be seen.
10136-8{_}4110{_}_Time_.--About 1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}4111{_}_Average cost_, 3s.
10136-8{_}4112{_}2d.
10136-8{_}4113{_}_Seasonable_ from September to April.
10136-8{_}4114{_}STEWED OYSTERS.
10136-8{_}4115{_}288.
10136-8{_}4116{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint of oysters, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}4117{_}of butter, flour, 1/3 pint of cream; cayenne and salt to taste; 1 blade of pounded mace.
10136-8{_}4118{_}_Mode_.--Scald the oysters in their own liquor, take them out, beard them, and strain the liquor; put the butter into a stewpan, dredge in sufficient flour to dry it up, add the oyster-liquor and mace, and stir it over a sharp fire with a wooden spoon; when it comes to a boil, add the cream, oysters, and seasoning.
10136-8{_}4119{_}Let all simmer for 1 or 2 minutes, but not longer, or the oysters would harden.
10136-8{_}4120{_}Serve on a hot dish, and garnish with croutons, or toasted sippets of bread.
10136-8{_}4121{_}A small piece of lemon-peel boiled with the oyster-liquor, and taken out before the cream is added, will be found an improvement.
10136-8{_}4122{_}_Time_.--Altogether 15 minutes.
10136-8{_}4123{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 3s.
10136-8{_}4124{_}6d.
10136-8{_}4125{_}_Seasonable_ from September to April.
10136-8{_}4126{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 persons.
10136-8{_}4127{_}THE OYSTER AND THE SCALLOP.--The oyster is described as a     bivalve shell-fish, having the valves generally unequal.
10136-8{_}4128{_}The     hinge is without teeth, but furnished with a somewhat oval     cavity, and mostly with lateral transverse grooves.
10136-8{_}4129{_}From a     similarity in the structure of the hinge, oysters and scallops     have been classified as one tribe; but they differ very     essentially both in their external appearance and their habits.
10136-8{_}4130{_}Oysters adhere to rocks, or, as in two or three species, to     roots of trees on the shore; while the scallops are always     detached, and usually lurk in the sand.
10136-8{_}4131{_}OYSTER PATTIES (an Entree).
10136-8{_}4132{_}289.
10136-8{_}4133{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 dozen oysters, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}4134{_}butter, 3 tablespoonfuls of cream, a little lemon-juice, 1 blade of pounded mace; cayenne to taste.
10136-8{_}4135{_}_Mode_.--Scald the oysters in their own liquor, beard them, and cut each one into 3 pieces.
10136-8{_}4136{_}Put the butter into a stewpan, dredge in sufficient flour to dry it up; add the strained oyster-liquor with the other ingredients; put in the oysters, and let them heat gradually, but not boil fast.
10136-8{_}4137{_}Make the patty-cases as directed for lobster patties, No.
10136-8{_}4138{_}277: fill with the oyster mixture, and replace the covers.
10136-8{_}4139{_}_Time_.--2 minutes for the oysters to simmer in the mixture.
10136-8{_}4140{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the patty-cases, 1s.
10136-8{_}4141{_}1d.
10136-8{_}4142{_}_Seasonable_ from September to April.
10136-8{_}4143{_}THE OYSTER FISHERY.--The oyster fishery in Britain is esteemed     of so much importance, that it is regulated by a Court of     Admiralty.
10136-8{_}4144{_}In the month of May, the fishermen are allowed to     take the oysters, in order to separate the spawn from the     cultch, the latter of which is thrown in again, to preserve the     bed for the future.
10136-8{_}4145{_}After this month, it is felony to carry away     the cultch, and otherwise punishable to take any oyster, between     the shells of which, when closed, a shilling will rattle.
10136-8{_}4146{_}TO KEEP OYSTERS.
10136-8{_}4147{_}290.
10136-8{_}4148{_}Put them in a tub, and cover them with salt and water.
10136-8{_}4149{_}Let them remain for 12 hours, when they are to be taken out, and allowed to stand for another 12 hours without water.
10136-8{_}4150{_}If left without water every alternate 12 hours, they will be much better than if constantly kept in it.
10136-8{_}4151{_}Never put the same water twice to them.
10136-8{_}4152{_}OYSTERS FRIED IN BATTER.
10136-8{_}4153{_}291.
10136-8{_}4154{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of oysters, 2 eggs, 1/2 pint of milk, sufficient flour to make the batter; pepper and salt to taste; when liked, a little nutmeg; hot lard.
10136-8{_}4155{_}_Mode_.--Scald the oysters in their own liquor, beard them, and lay them on a cloth, to drain thoroughly.
10136-8{_}4156{_}Break the eggs into a basin, mix the flour with them, add the milk gradually, with nutmeg and seasoning, and put the oysters in the batter.
10136-8{_}4157{_}Make some lard hot in a deep frying-pan, put in the oysters, one at a time; when done, take them up with a sharp-pointed skewer, and dish them on a napkin.
10136-8{_}4158{_}Fried oysters are frequently used for garnishing boiled fish, and then a few bread crumbs should be added to the flour.
10136-8{_}4159{_}_Time_.--5 or 6 minutes.
10136-8{_}4160{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 1s.
10136-8{_}4161{_}10d.
10136-8{_}4162{_}_Seasonable_ from September to April.
10136-8{_}4163{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 persons.
10136-8{_}4164{_}EXCELLENCE OF THE ENGLISH OYSTER.--The French assert that the     English oysters, which are esteemed the best in Europe, were     originally procured from Cancalle Bay, near St. Malo; but they     assign no proof for this.
10136-8{_}4165{_}It is a fact, however, that the     oysters eaten in ancient Rome were nourished in the channel     which then parted the Isle of Thanet from England, and which has     since been filled up, and converted into meadows.
10136-8{_}4166{_}BOILED PERCH.
10136-8{_}4167{_}292.
10136-8{_}4168{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}4169{_}of salt to each gallon of water.
10136-8{_}4170{_}_Mode_.--Scale the fish, take out the gills and clean it thoroughly; lay it in boiling water, salted as above, and simmer gently for 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}4171{_}If the fish is very large, longer time must be allowed.
10136-8{_}4172{_}Garnish with parsley, and serve with plain melted butter, or Dutch sauce.
10136-8{_}4173{_}Perch do not preserve so good a flavour when stewed as when dressed in any other way.
10136-8{_}4174{_}_Time_.--Middling-sized perch, 1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}4175{_}_Seasonable_ from September to November.
10136-8{_}4176{_}_Note_.--Tench may be boiled the same way, and served with the same sauces.
10136-8{_}4177{_}[Illustration: THE PERCH.]
10136-8{_}4178{_}THE PERCH.--This is one of the best, as it is one of the most     common, of our fresh-water fishes, and is found in nearly all     the lakes and rivers in Britain and Ireland, as well as through     the whole of Europe within the temperate zone.
10136-8{_}4179{_}It is extremely     voracious, and it has the peculiarity of being gregarious, which     is contrary to the nature of all fresh-water fishes of prey.
10136-8{_}4180{_}The     best season to angle for it is from the beginning of May to the     middle of July.
10136-8{_}4181{_}Large numbers of this fish are bred in the     Hampton Court and Bushy Park ponds, all of which are well     supplied with running water and with plenty of food; yet they     rarely attain a large size.
10136-8{_}4182{_}In the Regent's Park they are also     very numerous; but are seldom heavier than three quarters of a     pound.
10136-8{_}4183{_}FRIED PERCH.
10136-8{_}4184{_}293.
10136-8{_}4185{_}INGREDIENTS.--Egg and bread crumbs, hot lard.
10136-8{_}4186{_}_Mode_.--Scale and clean the fish, brush it over with egg, and cover with bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}4187{_}Have ready some boiling lard; put the fish in, and fry a nice brown.
10136-8{_}4188{_}Serve with plain melted butter or anchovy sauce.
10136-8{_}4189{_}_Time_.--10 minutes.
10136-8{_}4190{_}_Seasonable_ from September to November.
10136-8{_}4191{_}_Note_.--Fry tench in the same way.
10136-8{_}4192{_}PERCH STEWED WITH WINE.
10136-8{_}4193{_}294.
10136-8{_}4194{_}INGREDIENTS.--Equal quantities of stock No.
10136-8{_}4195{_}105 and sherry, 1 bay-leaf, 1 clove of garlic, a small bunch of parsley, 2 cloves, salt to taste; thickening of butter and flour, pepper, grated nutmeg, 1/2 teaspoonful of anchovy sauce.
10136-8{_}4196{_}_Mode_.--Scale the fish and take out the gills, and clean them thoroughly; lay them in a stewpan with sufficient stock and sherry just to cover them.
10136-8{_}4197{_}Put in the bay-leaf, garlic, parsley, cloves, and salt, and simmer till tender.
10136-8{_}4198{_}When done, take out the fish, strain the liquor, add a thickening of butter and flour, the pepper, nutmeg, and the anchovy sauce, and stir it over the fire until somewhat reduced, when pour over the fish, and serve.
10136-8{_}4199{_}_Time_.--About 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}4200{_}_Seasonable_ from September to November.
10136-8{_}4201{_}BOILED PIKE.
10136-8{_}4202{_}295.
10136-8{_}4203{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}4204{_}of salt to each gallon of water; a little vinegar.
10136-8{_}4205{_}_Mode_.--Scale and clean the pike, and fasten the tail in its mouth by means of a skewer.
10136-8{_}4206{_}Lay it in cold water, and when it boils, throw in the salt and vinegar.
10136-8{_}4207{_}The time for boiling depends, of course, on the size of the fish; but a middling-sized pike will take about 1/2 an hour.
10136-8{_}4208{_}Serve with Dutch or anchovy sauce, and plain melted butter.
10136-8{_}4209{_}_Time_.--According to size, 1/2 to 1 hour.--_Average cost_.
10136-8{_}4210{_}Seldom bought.
10136-8{_}4211{_}_Seasonable_ from September to March.
10136-8{_}4212{_}[Illustration: THE PIKE.]
10136-8{_}4213{_}THE PIKE.--This fish is, on account of its voracity, termed the     freshwater shark, and is abundant in most of the European lakes,     especially those of the northern parts.
10136-8{_}4214{_}It grows to an immense     size, some attaining to the measure of eight feet, in Lapland     and Russia.
10136-8{_}4215{_}The smaller lakes, of this country and Ireland, vary     in the kinds of fish they produce; some affording trout, others     pike; and so on.
10136-8{_}4216{_}Where these happen to be together, however, the     trout soon becomes extinct.
10136-8{_}4217{_}"Within a short distance of     Castlebar," says a writer on sports, "there is a small bog-lake     called Derreens.
10136-8{_}4218{_}Ten years ago it was celebrated for its     numerous well-sized trouts.
10136-8{_}4219{_}Accidentally pike effected a passage     into the lake from the Minola river, and now the trouts are     extinct, or, at least, none of them are caught or seen.
10136-8{_}4220{_}Previous     to the intrusion of the pikes, half a dozen trouts would be     killed in an evening in Derreens, whose collective weight often     amounted to twenty pounds."
10136-8{_}4221{_}As an eating fish, the pike is in     general dry.
10136-8{_}4222{_}BAKED PIKE.
10136-8{_}4223{_}296.
10136-8{_}4224{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 or 2 pike, a nice delicate stuffing (_see_ Forcemeats), 1 egg, bread crumbs, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}4225{_}butter.
10136-8{_}4226{_}_Mode_.--Scale the fish, take out the gills, wash, and wipe it thoroughly dry; stuff it with forcemeat, sew it up, and fasten the tail in the mouth by means of a skewer; brush it over with egg, sprinkle with bread crumbs, and baste with butter, before putting it in the oven, which must be well heated.
10136-8{_}4227{_}When the pike is of a nice brown colour, cover it with buttered paper, as the outside would become too dry.
10136-8{_}4228{_}If 2 are dressed, a little variety may be made by making one of them green with a little chopped parsley mixed with the bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}4229{_}Serve anchovy or Dutch sauce, and plain melted butter with it.
10136-8{_}4230{_}_Time_.--According to size, 1 hour, more or less.
10136-8{_}4231{_}_Average cost_.--Seldom bought.
10136-8{_}4232{_}_Seasonable_ from September to March.
10136-8{_}4233{_}_Note_.--Pike _à la génévese_ may be stewed in the same manner as salmon _à la génévese_.
10136-8{_}4234{_}FRIED PLAICE.
10136-8{_}4235{_}297.--INGREDIENTS.--Hot lard, or clarified dripping; egg and bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}4236{_}_Mode_.--This fish is fried in the same manner as soles.
10136-8{_}4237{_}Wash and wipe them thoroughly dry, and let them remain in a cloth until it is time to dress them.
10136-8{_}4238{_}Brush them over with egg, and cover with bread crumbs mixed with a little flour.
10136-8{_}4239{_}Fry of a nice brown in hot dripping or lard, and garnish with fried parsley and cut lemon.
10136-8{_}4240{_}Send them to table with shrimp-sauce and plain melted butter.
10136-8{_}4241{_}_Time_.--About 5 minutes.
10136-8{_}4242{_}_Average cost_, 3d.
10136-8{_}4243{_}each.
10136-8{_}4244{_}_Seasonable_ from May to November.
10136-8{_}4245{_}_Sufficient_, 4 plaice for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}4246{_}_Note_.--Plaice may be boiled plain, and served with melted butter.
10136-8{_}4247{_}Garnish with parsley and cut lemon.
10136-8{_}4248{_}STEWED PLAICE.
10136-8{_}4249{_}298.
10136-8{_}4250{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 or 5 plaice, 2 onions, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}4251{_}ground ginger, 1 pint of lemon-juice, 1/4 pint water, 6 eggs; cayenne to taste.
10136-8{_}4252{_}_Mode_.--Cut the fish into pieces about 2 inches wide, salt them, and let them remain 1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}4253{_}Slice and fry the onions a light brown; put them in a stewpan, on the top of which put the fish without washing, and add the ginger, lemon-juice, and water.
10136-8{_}4254{_}Cook slowly for 1/2 hour, and do not let the fish boil, or it will break.
10136-8{_}4255{_}Take it out, and when the liquor is cool, add 6 well-beaten eggs; simmer till it thickens, when pour over the fish, and serve.
10136-8{_}4256{_}_Time_.--3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}4257{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 1s.
10136-8{_}4258{_}9d.
10136-8{_}4259{_}_Seasonable_ from May to November.
10136-8{_}4260{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons; according to size.
10136-8{_}4261{_}[Illustration: THE PLAICE.]
10136-8{_}4262{_}THE PLAICE.--This fish is found both in the Baltic and the     Mediterranean, and is also abundant on the coast of England.
10136-8{_}4263{_}It     keeps well, and, like all ground-fish, is very tenacious of     life.
10136-8{_}4264{_}Its flesh is inferior to that of the sole, and, as it is a     low-priced fish, it is generally bought by the poor.
10136-8{_}4265{_}The best     brought to the London market are called _Dowers plaice_, from     their being caught in the Dowers, or flats, between Hastings and     Folkstone.
10136-8{_}4266{_}TO BOIL PRAWNS OR SHRIMPS.
10136-8{_}4267{_}299.
10136-8{_}4268{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}4269{_}salt to each gallon of water.
10136-8{_}4270{_}_Mode_.--Prawns should be very red, and have no spawn under the tail; much depends on their freshness and the way in which they are cooked.
10136-8{_}4271{_}Throw them into boiling water, salted as above, and keep them boiling for about 7 or 8 minutes.
10136-8{_}4272{_}Shrimps should be done in the same way; but less time must be allowed.
10136-8{_}4273{_}It may easily be known when they are done by their changing colour.
10136-8{_}4274{_}Care should be taken that they are not over-boiled, as they then become tasteless and indigestible.
10136-8{_}4275{_}_Time_.--Prawns, about 8 minutes; shrimps, about 5 minutes.
10136-8{_}4276{_}_Average cost_, prawns, 2s.
10136-8{_}4277{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}4278{_}; shrimps, 6d.
10136-8{_}4279{_}per pint.
10136-8{_}4280{_}_Seasonable_ all the year.
10136-8{_}4281{_}TO DRESS PRAWNS.
10136-8{_}4282{_}300.
10136-8{_}4283{_}Cover a dish with a large cup reversed, and over that lay a small white napkin.
10136-8{_}4284{_}Arrange the prawns on it in the form of a pyramid, and garnish with plenty of parsley.
10136-8{_}4285{_}BOILED SALMON.
10136-8{_}4286{_}301.
10136-8{_}4287{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 oz.
10136-8{_}4288{_}of salt to each gallon of water,--sufficient water to cover the fish.
10136-8{_}4289{_}_Mode_.--Scale and clean the fish, and be particular that no blood is left inside; lay it in the fish-kettle with sufficient cold water to cover it, adding salt in the above proportion.
10136-8{_}4290{_}Bring it quickly to a boil, take off all the scum, and let it simmer gently till the fish is done, which will be when the meat separates easily from the bone.
10136-8{_}4291{_}Experience alone can teach the cook to fix the time for boiling fish; but it is especially to be remembered, that it should never be underdressed, as then nothing is more unwholesome.
10136-8{_}4292{_}Neither let it remain in the kettle after it is sufficiently cooked, as that would render it insipid, watery, and colourless.
10136-8{_}4293{_}Drain it, and if not wanted for a few minutes, keep it warm by means of warm cloths laid over it.
10136-8{_}4294{_}Serve on a hot napkin, garnish with cut lemon and parsley, and send lobster or shrimp sauce, and plain melted butter to table with it.
10136-8{_}4295{_}A dish of dressed cucumber usually accompanies this fish.
10136-8{_}4296{_}_Time_.--8 minutes to each lb.
10136-8{_}4297{_}for large thick salmon; 6 minutes for thin fish.
10136-8{_}4298{_}_Average cost_, in full season, 1s.
10136-8{_}4299{_}3d.
10136-8{_}4300{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}4301{_}_Seasonable_ from April to August.
10136-8{_}4302{_}_Sufficient_, 1/2 lb., or rather less, for each person.
10136-8{_}4303{_}_Note_.--Cut lemon should be put on the table with this fish; and a little of the juice squeezed over it is considered by many persons a most agreeable addition.
10136-8{_}4304{_}Boiled peas are also, by some connoisseurs, considered especially adapted to be served with salmon.
10136-8{_}4305{_}TO CHOOSE SALMON.--To be good, the belly should be firm and thick, which may readily be ascertained by feeling it with the thumb and finger.
10136-8{_}4306{_}The circumstance of this fish having red gills, though given as a standing rule in most cookery-books, as a sign of its goodness, is not at all to be relied on, as this quality can be easily given them by art.
10136-8{_}4307{_}SALMON AND CAPER SAUCE.
10136-8{_}4308{_}302.
10136-8{_}4309{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 slices of salmon, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}4310{_}batter, 1/2 teaspoonful of chopped parsley, 1 shalot; salt, pepper, and grated nutmeg to taste.
10136-8{_}4311{_}_Mode_.--Lay the salmon in a baking-dish, place pieces of butter over it, and add the other ingredients, rubbing a little of the seasoning into the fish; baste it frequently; when done, take it out and drain for a minute or two; lay it in a dish, pour caper sauce over it, and serve.
10136-8{_}4312{_}Salmon dressed in this way, with tomato sauce, is very delicious.
10136-8{_}4313{_}_Time_.--About 3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}4314{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}4315{_}3d.
10136-8{_}4316{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}4317{_}_Seasonable_ from April to August.
10136-8{_}4318{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}4319{_}THE MIGRATORY HABITS OF THE SALMON.--The instinct with which the     salmon revisits its native river, is one of the most curious     circumstances in its natural history.
10136-8{_}4320{_}As the swallow returns     annually to its nest, so it returns to the same spot to deposit     its ova.
10136-8{_}4321{_}This fact would seem to have been repeatedly proved.
10136-8{_}4322{_}M.     De Lande fastened a copper ring round a salmon's tail, and found     that, for three successive seasons, it returned to the same     place.
10136-8{_}4323{_}Dr. Bloch states that gold and silver rings have been     attached by eastern princes to salmon, to prove that a     communication existed between the Persian Gulf and the Caspian     and Northern Seas, and that the experiment succeeded.
10136-8{_}4324{_}COLLARED SALMON.
10136-8{_}4325{_}303.
10136-8{_}4326{_}INGREDIENTS.--A piece of salmon, say 3 lbs., a high seasoning of salt, pounded mace, and pepper; water and vinegar, 3 bay-leaves.
10136-8{_}4327{_}_Mode_.--Split the fish; scale, bone, and wash it thoroughly clean; wipe it, and rub in the seasoning inside and out; roll it up, and bind firmly; lay it in a kettle, cover it with vinegar and water (1/3 vinegar, in proportion to the water); add the bay-leaves and a good seasoning of salt and whole pepper, and simmer till done.
10136-8{_}4328{_}Do not remove the lid.
10136-8{_}4329{_}Serve with melted butter or anchovy sauce.
10136-8{_}4330{_}For preserving the collared fish, boil up the liquor in which it was cooked, and add a little more vinegar.
10136-8{_}4331{_}Pour over when cold.
10136-8{_}4332{_}_Time_.--3/4 hour, or rather more.
10136-8{_}4333{_}HABITAT OF THE SALMON.--The salmon is styled by Walton the "king     of fresh-water fish," and is found distributed over the north of     Europe and Asia, from Britain to Kamschatka, but is never found     in warm latitudes, nor has it ever been caught even so far south     as the Mediterranean.
