10136-8{_}4334{_}It lives in fresh as well as in salt     waters, depositing its spawn in the former, hundreds of miles     from the mouths of some of those rivers to which it has been     known to resort.
10136-8{_}4335{_}In 1859, great efforts were made to introduce     this fish into the Australian colonies; and it is believed that     the attempt, after many difficulties, which were very skilfully     overcome, has been successful.
10136-8{_}4336{_}CRIMPED SALMON.
10136-8{_}4337{_}304.
10136-8{_}4338{_}Salmon is frequently dressed in this way at many fashionable tables, but must be very fresh, and cut into slices 2 or 3 inches thick.
10136-8{_}4339{_}Lay these in cold salt and water for 1 hour; have ready some boiling water, salted, as in recipe No.
10136-8{_}4340{_}301, and well skimmed; put in the fish, and simmer gently for 1/4 hour, or rather more; should it be very thick, garnish the same as boiled salmon, and serve with the same sauces.
10136-8{_}4341{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour, more or less, according to size.
10136-8{_}4342{_}_Note_.--Never use vinegar with salmon, as it spoils the taste and colour of the fish.
10136-8{_}4343{_}[Illustration: THE SALMON.]
10136-8{_}4344{_}THE SALMON TRIBE.--This is the Abdominal fish, forming the     fourth of the orders of Linnaeus.
10136-8{_}4345{_}They are distinguished from     the other fishes by having two dorsal fins, of which the     hindmost is fleshy and without rays.
10136-8{_}4346{_}They have teeth both on the     tongue and in the jaws, whilst the body is covered with round     and minutely striated scales.
10136-8{_}4347{_}CURRIED SALMON.
10136-8{_}4348{_}305.
10136-8{_}4349{_}INGREDIENTS.--Any remains of boiled salmon, 3/4 pint of strong or medium stock (No.
10136-8{_}4350{_}105), 1 onion, 1 tablespoonful of curry-powder, 1 teaspoonful of Harvey's sauce, 1 teaspoonful of anchovy sauce, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}4351{_}of butter, the juice of 1/2 lemon, cayenne and salt to taste.
10136-8{_}4352{_}_Mode_.--Cut up the onions into small pieces, and fry them of a pale brown in the butter; add all the ingredients but the salmon, and simmer gently till the onion is tender, occasionally stirring the contents; cut the salmon into small square pieces, carefully take away all skin and bone, lay it in the stewpan, and let it gradually heat through; but do not allow it to boil long.
10136-8{_}4353{_}_Time_.--3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}4354{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the cold fish, 9d.
10136-8{_}4355{_}GROWTH OF THE SALMON.--At the latter end of the year--some as     soon as November--salmon begin to press up the rivers as far as     they can reach, in order to deposit their spawn, which they do     in the sand or gravel, about eighteen inches deep.
10136-8{_}4356{_}Here it lies     buried till the spring, when, about the latter end of March, it     begins to exclude the young, which gradually increase to four or     five inches in length, and are then termed smelts or smouts.
10136-8{_}4357{_}About the beginning of May, the river seems to be alive with     them, and there is no forming an idea of their numbers without     having seen them.
10136-8{_}4358{_}A seasonable flood, however, comes, and     hurries them to the "great deep;" whence, about the middle of     June, they commence their return to the river again.
10136-8{_}4359{_}By this     time they are twelve or sixteen inches long, and progressively     increase, both in number and size, till about the end of July,     when they have become large enough to be denominated _grilse_.
10136-8{_}4360{_}Early in August they become fewer in numbers, but of greater     size, haying advanced to a weight of from six to nine pounds.
10136-8{_}4361{_}This rapidity of growth appears surprising, and realizes the     remark of Walton, that "the salmlet becomes a salmon in as short     a time as a gosling becomes a goose."
10136-8{_}4362{_}Recent writers have,     however, thrown considerable doubts on this quick growth of the     salmon.
10136-8{_}4363{_}SALMON CUTLETS.
10136-8{_}4364{_}306.
10136-8{_}4365{_}Cut the slices 1 inch thick, and season them with pepper and salt; butter a sheet of white paper, lay each slice on a separate piece, with their ends twisted; broil gently over a clear fire, and serve with anchovy or caper sauce.
10136-8{_}4366{_}When higher seasoning is required, add a few chopped herbs and a little spice.
10136-8{_}4367{_}_Time_.--5 to 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}4368{_}SALMON A LA GENEVESE.
10136-8{_}4369{_}307.
10136-8{_}4370{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 slices of salmon, 2 chopped shalots, a little parsley, a small bunch of herbs, 2 bay-leaves, 2 carrots, pounded mace, pepper and salt to taste, 4 tablespoonfuls of Madeira, 1/2 pint of white stock (No.
10136-8{_}4371{_}107), thickening of butter and flour, 1 teaspoonful of essence of anchovies, the juice of 1 lemon, cayenne and salt to taste.
10136-8{_}4372{_}_Mode_.--Rub the bottom of a stewpan over with butter, and put in the shalots, herbs, bay-leaves, carrots, mace, and seasoning; stir them for 10 minutes over a clear fire, and add the Madeira or sherry; simmer gently for 1/2 hour, and strain through a sieve over the fish, which stew in this gravy.
10136-8{_}4373{_}As soon as the fish is sufficiently cooked, take away all the liquor, except a little to keep the salmon moist, and put it into another stewpan; add the stock, thicken with butter and flour, and put in the anchovies, lemon-juice, cayenne, and salt; lay the salmon on a hot dish, pour over it part of the sauce, and serve the remainder in a tureen.
10136-8{_}4374{_}_Time_.--1-1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}4375{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 3s.
10136-8{_}4376{_}6d.
10136-8{_}4377{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}4378{_}PICKLED SALMON.
10136-8{_}4379{_}308.
10136-8{_}4380{_}INGREDIENTS.--Salmon, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}4381{_}of whole pepper, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}4382{_}of whole allspice, 1 teaspoonful of salt, 2 bay-leaves, equal quantities of vinegar and the liquor in which the fish was boiled.
10136-8{_}4383{_}_Mode_.--After the fish comes from table, lay it in a nice dish with a cover to it, as it should be excluded from the air, and take away the bone; boil the liquor and vinegar with the other ingredients for 10 minutes, and let it stand to get cold; pour it over the salmon, and in 12 hours this will be fit for the table.
10136-8{_}4384{_}_Time_.--10 minutes.
10136-8{_}4385{_}TO CURE SALMON.--This process consists in splitting the fish,     rubbing it with salt, and then putting it into pickle in tubs     provided for the purpose.
10136-8{_}4386{_}Here it is kept for about six weeks,     when it is taken out, pressed and packed in casks, with layers     of salt.
10136-8{_}4387{_}POTTED SALMON.
10136-8{_}4388{_}309.
10136-8{_}4389{_}INGREDIENTS.--Salmon; pounded mace, cloves, and pepper to taste; 3 bay-leaves, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}4390{_}butter.
10136-8{_}4391{_}_Mode_.--Skin the salmon, and clean it thoroughly by wiping with a cloth (water would spoil it); cut it into square pieces, which rub with salt; let them remain till thoroughly drained, then lay them in a dish with the other ingredients, and bake.
10136-8{_}4392{_}When quite done, drain them from the gravy, press into pots for use, and, when cold, pour over it clarified butter.
10136-8{_}4393{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}4394{_}AN AVERSION IN THE SALMON.--The salmon is said to have an     aversion to anything red; hence, fishermen engaged in catching     it do not wear jackets or caps of that colour.
10136-8{_}4395{_}Pontoppidan also     says, that it has an abhorrence of carrion, and if any happens     to be thrown into the places it haunts, it immediately forsakes     them.
10136-8{_}4396{_}The remedy adopted for this in Norway, is to throw into     the polluted water a lighted torch.
10136-8{_}4397{_}As food, salmon, when in     perfection, is one of the most delicious and nutritive of our     fish.
10136-8{_}4398{_}BAKED SEA-BREAM.
10136-8{_}4399{_}310.
10136-8{_}4400{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 bream.
10136-8{_}4401{_}Seasoning to taste of salt, pepper, and cayenne; 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}4402{_}of butter.
10136-8{_}4403{_}_Mode_.--Well wash the bream, but do not remove the scales, and wipe away all moisture with a nice dry cloth.
10136-8{_}4404{_}Season it inside and out with salt, pepper, and cayenne, and lay it in a baking-dish.
10136-8{_}4405{_}Place the butter, in small pieces, upon the fish, and bake for rather more than 1/2 an hour.
10136-8{_}4406{_}To stuff this fish before baking, will be found a great improvement.
10136-8{_}4407{_}_Time_.--Rather more than 1/2 an hour.
10136-8{_}4408{_}_Seasonable_ in summer.
10136-8{_}4409{_}[Illustration: THE SEA-BREAM.]
10136-8{_}4410{_}_Note_.--This fish may be broiled over a nice clear fire, and served with a good brown gravy or white sauce, or it may be stewed in wine.
10136-8{_}4411{_}THE SEA-BREAM.--This is an abundant fish in Cornwall, and it is     frequently found in the fish-market of Hastings during the     summer months, but it is not in much esteem.
10136-8{_}4412{_}MR. YARRELL'S RECIPE.
10136-8{_}4413{_}"When thoroughly cleansed, the fish should be wiped dry, but     none of the scales should be taken off.
10136-8{_}4414{_}In this state it should     be broiled, turning it often, and if the skin cracks, flour it a     little to keep the outer case entire.
10136-8{_}4415{_}When on table, the whole     skin and scales turn off without difficulty, and the muscle     beneath, saturated in its own natural juices, which the outside     covering has retained, will be of good flavour."
10136-8{_}4416{_}TO DRESS SHAD.
10136-8{_}4417{_}311.
10136-8{_}4418{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 shad, oil, pepper, and salt.
10136-8{_}4419{_}_Mode_.--Scale, empty and wash the fish carefully, and make two or three incisions across the back.
10136-8{_}4420{_}Season it with pepper and salt, and let it remain in oil for 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}4421{_}Broil it on both sides over a clear fire, and serve with caper sauce.
10136-8{_}4422{_}This fish is much esteemed by the French, and by them is considered excellent.
10136-8{_}4423{_}_Time_.--Nearly 1 hour.
10136-8{_}4424{_}_Average cost_.--Seldom bought.
10136-8{_}4425{_}_Seasonable_ from April to June.
10136-8{_}4426{_}[Illustration: THE SHAD.]
10136-8{_}4427{_}THE SHAD.--This is a salt-water fish, but is held in little     esteem.
10136-8{_}4428{_}It enters our rivers to spawn in May, and great numbers     of them are taken opposite the Isle of Dogs, in the Thames.
10136-8{_}4429{_}POTTED SHRIMPS.
10136-8{_}4430{_}312.
10136-8{_}4431{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint of shelled shrimps, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}4432{_}of fresh butter, 1 blade of pounded mace, cayenne to taste; when liked, a little nutmeg.
10136-8{_}4433{_}_Mode_.--Have ready a pint of picked shrimps, and put them, with the other ingredients, into a stewpan; let them heat gradually in the butter, but do not let it boil.
10136-8{_}4434{_}Pour into small pots, and when cold, cover with melted butter, and carefully exclude the air.
10136-8{_}4435{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour to soak in the butter.
10136-8{_}4436{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 1s.
10136-8{_}4437{_}3d.
10136-8{_}4438{_}BUTTERED PRAWNS OR SHRIMPS.
10136-8{_}4439{_}313.
10136-8{_}4440{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint of picked prawns or shrimps, 3/4 pint of stock No.
10136-8{_}4441{_}104, thickening of butter and flour; salt, cayenne, and nutmeg to taste.
10136-8{_}4442{_}_Mode_.--Pick the prawns or shrimps, and put them in a stewpan with the stock; add a thickening of butter and flour; season, and simmer gently for 3 minutes.
10136-8{_}4443{_}Serve on a dish garnished with fried bread or toasted sippets.
10136-8{_}4444{_}Cream sauce may be substituted for the gravy.
10136-8{_}4445{_}_Time_.--3 minutes.
10136-8{_}4446{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 1s.
10136-8{_}4447{_}4d.
10136-8{_}4448{_}[Illustration: THE SHRIMP.]
10136-8{_}4449{_}THE SHRIMP.--This shell-fish is smaller than the prawn, and is     greatly relished in London as a delicacy.
10136-8{_}4450{_}It inhabits most of     the sandy shores of Europe, and the Isle of Wight is especially     famous for them.
10136-8{_}4451{_}BOILED SKATE.
10136-8{_}4452{_}314.
10136-8{_}4453{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}4454{_}of salt to each gallon of water.
10136-8{_}4455{_}_Mode_.--Cleanse and skin the skate, lay it in a fish-kettle, with sufficient water to cover it, salted in the above proportion.
10136-8{_}4456{_}Let it simmer very gently till done; then dish it on a hot napkin, and serve with shrimp, lobster, or caper sauce.
10136-8{_}4457{_}_Time_.--According to size, from 1/2 to 1 hour.
10136-8{_}4458{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}4459{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}4460{_}_Seasonable_ from August to April.
10136-8{_}4461{_}CRIMPED SKATE.
10136-8{_}4462{_}315.
10136-8{_}4463{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/8 lb.
10136-8{_}4464{_}of salt to each gallon of water.
10136-8{_}4465{_}_Mode_.--Clean, skin, and cut the fish into slices, which roll and tie round with string.
10136-8{_}4466{_}Have ready some water highly salted, put in the fish, and boil till it is done.
10136-8{_}4467{_}Drain well, remove the string, dish on a hot napkin, and serve with the same sauces as above.
10136-8{_}4468{_}Skate should never be eaten out of season, as it is liable to produce diarrhoea and other diseases.
10136-8{_}4469{_}It may be dished without a napkin, and the sauce poured over.
10136-8{_}4470{_}_Time_.--About 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}4471{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}4472{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}4473{_}_Seasonable_ from August to April.
10136-8{_}4474{_}TO CHOOSE SKATE.--This fish should be chosen for its firmness, breadth, and thickness, and should have a creamy appearance.
10136-8{_}4475{_}When crimped, it should not be kept longer than a day or two, as all kinds of crimped fish soon become sour.
10136-8{_}4476{_}[Illustration: THORNBACK SKATE.]
10136-8{_}4477{_}THE SKATE.--This is one of the ray tribe, and is extremely     abundant and cheap in the fishing towns of England.
10136-8{_}4478{_}The flesh is     white, thick, and nourishing; but, we suppose, from its being so     plentiful, it is esteemed less than it ought to be on account of     its nutritive properties, and the ease with which it is     digested.
10136-8{_}4479{_}It is much improved by crimping; in which state it is     usually sold in London.
10136-8{_}4480{_}The THORNBACK differs from the true     skate by having large spines in its back, of which the other is     destitute.
10136-8{_}4481{_}It is taken in great abundance during the spring and     summer months, but its flesh is not so good as it is in     November.
10136-8{_}4482{_}It is, in regard to quality, inferior to that of the     true skate.
10136-8{_}4483{_}SKATE WITH CAPER SAUCE (a la Francaise)  316.
10136-8{_}4484{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 or 3 slices of skate, 1/2 pint of vinegar, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}4485{_}of salt, 1/2 teaspoonful of pepper, 1 sliced onion, a small bunch of parsley, 2 bay-leaves, 2 or 3 sprigs of thyme, sufficient water to cover the fish.
10136-8{_}4486{_}_Mode_.--Put in a fish-kettle all the above ingredients, and simmer the skate in them till tender.
10136-8{_}4487{_}When it is done, skin it neatly, and pour over it some of the liquor in which it has been boiling.
10136-8{_}4488{_}Drain it, put it on a hot dish, pour over it caper sauce, and send some of the latter to table in a tureen.
10136-8{_}4489{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}4490{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}4491{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}4492{_}_Seasonable_ from August to April.
10136-8{_}4493{_}_Note_.--Skate may also be served with onion sauce, or parsley and butter.
10136-8{_}4494{_}SMALL SKATE FRIED.
10136-8{_}4495{_}317.
10136-8{_}4496{_}INGREDIENTS.--Skate, sufficient vinegar to cover them, salt and pepper to taste, 1 sliced onion, a small bunch of parsley, the juice of 1/2 lemon, hot dripping.
10136-8{_}4497{_}_Mode_.--Cleanse the skate, lay them in a dish, with sufficient vinegar to cover them; add the salt, pepper, onion, parsley, and lemon-juice, and let the fish remain in this pickle for 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}4498{_}Then drain them well, flour them, and fry of a nice brown, in hot dripping.
10136-8{_}4499{_}They may be served either with or without sauce.
10136-8{_}4500{_}Skate is not good if dressed too fresh, unless it is crimped; it should, therefore, be kept for a day, but not long enough to produce a disagreeable smell.
10136-8{_}4501{_}_Time_.--10 minutes.
10136-8{_}4502{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}4503{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}4504{_}_Seasonable_ from August to April.
10136-8{_}4505{_}OTHER SPECIES OF SKATE.--Besides the true skate, there are     several other species found in our seas.
10136-8{_}4506{_}These are known as the     _white_ skate, the long-nosed skate, and the Homelyn ray, which     are of inferior quality, though often crimped, and sold for true     skate.
10136-8{_}4507{_}TO BAKE SMELTS.
10136-8{_}4508{_}318.
10136-8{_}4509{_}INGREDIENTS.--12 smelts, bread crumbs, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}4510{_}of fresh butter, 2 blades of pounded mace; salt and cayenne to taste.
10136-8{_}4511{_}_Mode_.--Wash, and dry the fish thoroughly in a cloth, and arrange them nicely in a flat baking-dish.
10136-8{_}4512{_}Cover them with fine bread crumbs, and place little pieces of butter all over them.
10136-8{_}4513{_}Season and bake for 15 minutes.
10136-8{_}4514{_}Just before serving, add a squeeze of lemon-juice, and garnish with fried parsley and cut lemon.
10136-8{_}4515{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}4516{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}4517{_}per dozen.
10136-8{_}4518{_}_Seasonable_ from October to May.
10136-8{_}4519{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 persons.
10136-8{_}4520{_}TO CHOOSE SMELTS.--When good, this fish is of a fine silvery appearance, and when alive, their backs are of a dark brown shade, which, after death, fades to a light fawn.
10136-8{_}4521{_}They ought to have a refreshing fragrance, resembling that of a cucumber.
10136-8{_}4522{_}THE ODOUR OF THE SMELT.--This peculiarity in the smelt has been     compared, by some, to the fragrance of a cucumber, and by     others, to that of a violet.
10136-8{_}4523{_}It is a very elegant fish, and     formerly abounded in the Thames.
10136-8{_}4524{_}The _Atharine_, or sand smelt,     is sometimes sold for the true one; but it is an inferior fish,     being drier in the quality of its flesh.
10136-8{_}4525{_}On the south coast of     England, where the true smelt is rare, it is plentiful.
10136-8{_}4526{_}TO FRY SMELTS.
10136-8{_}4527{_}319.
10136-8{_}4528{_}INGREDIENTS.--Egg and bread crumbs, a little flour; boiling lard.
10136-8{_}4529{_}_Mode_.--Smelts should be very fresh, and not washed more than is necessary to clean them.
10136-8{_}4530{_}Dry them in a cloth, lightly flour, dip them in egg, and sprinkle over with very fine bread crumbs, and put them into boiling lard.
10136-8{_}4531{_}Fry of a nice pale brown, and be careful not to take off the light roughness of the crumbs, or their beauty will be spoiled.
10136-8{_}4532{_}Dry them before the fire on a drainer, and servo with plain melted butter.
10136-8{_}4533{_}This fish is often used as a garnishing.
10136-8{_}4534{_}_Time_.--5 minutes.
10136-8{_}4535{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}4536{_}per dozen.
10136-8{_}4537{_}_Seasonable_ from October to May.
10136-8{_}4538{_}[Illustration: THE SMELT.]
10136-8{_}4539{_}THE SMELT.--This is a delicate little fish, and is in high     esteem.
10136-8{_}4540{_}Mr. Yarrell asserts that the true smelt is entirety     confined to the western and eastern coasts of Britain.
10136-8{_}4541{_}It very     rarely ventures far from the shore, and is plentiful in     November, December, and January.
10136-8{_}4542{_}BAKED SOLES.
10136-8{_}4543{_}320.
10136-8{_}4544{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 soles, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}4545{_}of butter, egg, and bread crumbs, minced parsley, 1 glass of sherry, lemon-juice; cayenne and salt to taste.
10136-8{_}4546{_}_Mode_.--Clean, skin, and well wash the fish, and dry them thoroughly in a cloth.
10136-8{_}4547{_}Brush them over with egg, sprinkle with bread crumbs mixed with a little minced parsley, lay them in a large flat baking-dish, white side uppermost; or if it will not hold the two soles, they may each be laid on a dish by itself; but they must not be put one on the top of the other.
10136-8{_}4548{_}Melt the butter, and pour it over the whole, and bake for 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}4549{_}Take a portion of the gravy that flows from the fish, add the wine, lemon-juice, and seasoning, give it one boil, skim, pour it _under_ the fish, and serve.
10136-8{_}4550{_}_Time_.--20 minutes.
10136-8{_}4551{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}4552{_}to 2s.
10136-8{_}4553{_}per pair.
10136-8{_}4554{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}4555{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}4556{_}TO CHOOSE SOLES.--This fish should be both thick and firm.
10136-8{_}4557{_}If the skin is difficult to be taken off, and the flesh looks grey, it is good.
10136-8{_}4558{_}[Illustration: THE SOLE.]
10136-8{_}4559{_}THE SOLE.--This ranks next to the turbot in point of excellence     among our flat fish.
10136-8{_}4560{_}It is abundant on the British coasts, but     those of the western shores are much superior in size to those     taken on the northern.
10136-8{_}4561{_}The finest are caught in Torbay, and     frequently weigh 8 or 10 lbs.
10136-8{_}4562{_}per pair.
10136-8{_}4563{_}Its flesh being firm,     white, and delicate, is greatly esteemed.
10136-8{_}4564{_}BOILED SOLES.
10136-8{_}4565{_}321.
10136-8{_}4566{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}4567{_}salt to each gallon of water.
10136-8{_}4568{_}_Mode_.--Cleanse and wash the fish carefully, cut off the fins, but do not skin it.
10136-8{_}4569{_}Lay it in a fish-kettle, with sufficient cold water to cover it, salted in the above proportion.
10136-8{_}4570{_}Let it gradually come to a boil, and keep it simmering for a few minutes, according to the size of the fish.
10136-8{_}4571{_}Dish it on a hot napkin after well draining it, and garnish with parsley and cut lemon.
10136-8{_}4572{_}Shrimp, or lobster sauce, and plain melted butter, are usually sent to table with this dish.
10136-8{_}4573{_}_Time_.--After the water boils, 7 minutes for a middling-sized sole.
10136-8{_}4574{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}4575{_}to 2s.
10136-8{_}4576{_}per pair.
10136-8{_}4577{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}4578{_}_Sufficient_,--1 middling-sized sole for 2 persons.
10136-8{_}4579{_}SOLE OR COD PIE.
10136-8{_}4580{_}322.
10136-8{_}4581{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold boiled sole or cod, seasoning to taste of pepper, salt, and pounded mace, 1 dozen oysters to each lb.
10136-8{_}4582{_}of fish, 3 tablespoonfuls of white stock, 1 teacupful of cream thickened with flour, puff paste.
10136-8{_}4583{_}_Mode_.--Clear the fish from the bones, lay it in a pie-dish, and between each layer put a few oysters and a little seasoning; add the stock, and, when liked, a small quantity of butter; cover with puff paste, and bake for 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}4584{_}Boil the cream with sufficient flour to thicken it; pour in the pie, and serve.
10136-8{_}4585{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}4586{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 10d.
10136-8{_}4587{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}4588{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}4589{_}SOLES WITH CREAM SAUCE.
10136-8{_}4590{_}323.
10136-8{_}4591{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 soles; salt, cayenne, and pounded mace to taste; the juice of 1/2 lemon, salt and water, 1/2 pint of cream.
10136-8{_}4592{_}_Mode_.--Skin, wash, and fillet the soles, and divide each fillet in 2 pieces; lay them in cold salt and water, which bring gradually to a boil.
10136-8{_}4593{_}When the water boils, take out the fish, lay it in a delicately clean stewpan, and cover with the cream.
10136-8{_}4594{_}Add the seasoning, simmer very gently for ten minutes, and, just before serving, put in the lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}4595{_}The fillets may be rolled, and secured by means of a skewer; but this is not so economical a way of dressing them, as double the quantity of cream is required.
10136-8{_}4596{_}_Time_.--10 minutes in the cream.
10136-8{_}4597{_}_Average cost_, from 1s.
10136-8{_}4598{_}to 2s.
10136-8{_}4599{_}per pair.
10136-8{_}4600{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}4601{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}4602{_}This will be found a most delicate and delicious dish.
10136-8{_}4603{_}THE SOLE A FAVOURITE WITH THE ANCIENT GREEKS.--This fish was     much sought after by the ancient Greeks on account of its light     and nourishing qualities.
10136-8{_}4604{_}The brill, the flounder, the diamond     and Dutch plaice, which, with the sole, were known under the     general name of _passeres_, were all equally esteemed, and had     generally the same qualities attributed to them.
10136-8{_}4605{_}FILLETED SOLES A L'ITALIENNE.
10136-8{_}4606{_}324.
10136-8{_}4607{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 soles; salt, pepper, and grated nutmeg to taste; egg and bread crumbs, butter, the juice of 1 lemon.
10136-8{_}4608{_}_Mode_.--Skin, and carefully wash the soles, separate the meat from the bone, and divide each fillet in two pieces.
10136-8{_}4609{_}Brush them over with white of egg, sprinkle with bread crumbs and seasoning, and put them in a baking-dish.
10136-8{_}4610{_}Place small pieces of butter over the whole, and bake for 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}4611{_}When they are nearly done, squeeze the juice of a lemon over them, and serve on a dish, with Italian sauce (see Sauces) poured over.
10136-8{_}4612{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}4613{_}_Average cost_, from 1s.
10136-8{_}4614{_}to 2s.
10136-8{_}4615{_}per pair.
10136-8{_}4616{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}4617{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}4618{_}WHITING may be dressed in the same manner, and will be found very delicious.
10136-8{_}4619{_}THE FLAVOUR OF THE SOLE.--This, as a matter of course, greatly     depends on the nature of the ground and bait upon which the     animal feeds.
10136-8{_}4620{_}Its natural food are small crabs and shell-fish.
10136-8{_}4621{_}Its colour also depends on the colour of the ground where it     feeds; for if this be white, then the sole is called the white,     or lemon sole; but if the bottom be muddy, then it is called the     black sole.
10136-8{_}4622{_}Small-sized soles, caught in shallow water on the     coasts, are the best in flavour.
10136-8{_}4623{_}FRICASSEED SOLES.
10136-8{_}4624{_}325.
10136-8{_}4625{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 middling-sized soles, 1 small one, 1/2 teaspoonful of chopped lemon-peel, 1 teaspoonful of chopped parsley, a little grated bread; salt, pepper, and nutmeg to taste; 1 egg, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}4626{_}butter, 1/2 pint of good gravy, 2 tablespoonfuls of port wine, cayenne and lemon-juice to taste.
10136-8{_}4627{_}_Mode_.--Fry the soles of a nice brown, as directed in recipe No.
10136-8{_}4628{_}327, and drain them well from fat.
10136-8{_}4629{_}Take all the meat from the small sole, chop it fine, and mix with it the lemon-peel, parsley, bread, and seasoning; work altogether, with the yolk of an egg and the butter; make this into small balls, and fry them.
10136-8{_}4630{_}Thicken the gravy with a dessert-spoonful of flour, add the port wine, cayenne, and lemon-juice; lay in the 2 soles and balls; let them simmer gently for 6 minutes; serve hot, and garnish with cut lemon.
10136-8{_}4631{_}_Time_.--10 minutes to fry the soles.
10136-8{_}4632{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 3s.
10136-8{_}4633{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}4634{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}4635{_}HOW SOLES ARE CAUGHT.--The instrument usually employed is a     trawl net, which is shaped like a pocket, of from sixty to     eighty feet long, and open at the mouth from thirty-two to forty     feet, and three deep.
10136-8{_}4636{_}This is dragged along the ground by the     vessel, and on the art of the fisherman in its employment, in a     great measure depends the quality of the fish he catches.
10136-8{_}4637{_}If,     for example, he drags the net too quickly, all that are caught     are swept rapidly to the end of the net, where they are     smothered, and sometimes destroyed.
10136-8{_}4638{_}A medium has to be observed,     in order that as few as possible escape being caught in the net,     and as many as possible preserved alive in it.
10136-8{_}4639{_}FRIED FILLETED SOLES.
10136-8{_}4640{_}326.
10136-8{_}4641{_}Soles for filleting should be large, as the flesh can be more easily separated from the bones, and there is less waste.
10136-8{_}4642{_}Skin and wash the fish, and raise the meat carefully from the bones, and divide it into nice handsome pieces.
10136-8{_}4643{_}The more usual way is to roll the fillets, after dividing each one in two pieces, and either bind them round with twine, or run a small skewer through them.
10136-8{_}4644{_}Brush over with egg, and cover with bread crumbs; fry them as directed in the foregoing recipe, and garnish with fried parsley and cut lemon.
10136-8{_}4645{_}When a pretty dish is desired, this is by far the most elegant mode of dressing soles, as they look much better than when fried whole.
10136-8{_}4646{_}(_See_ Coloured Plate A.)
10136-8{_}4647{_}Instead of rolling the fillets, they may be cut into square pieces, and arranged in the shape of a pyramid on the dish.
10136-8{_}4648{_}_Time_.--About 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}4649{_}_Average cost_, from 1s.
10136-8{_}4650{_}to 2s.
10136-8{_}4651{_}per pair.
10136-8{_}4652{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}4653{_}_Sufficient_,--2 large soles for 6 persons.
10136-8{_}4654{_}FRIED SOLES.
10136-8{_}4655{_}327.
10136-8{_}4656{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 middling-sized soles, hot lard or clarified dripping, egg, and bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}4657{_}_Mode_.--Skin and carefully wash the soles, and cut off the fins, wipe them very dry, and let them remain in the cloth until it is time to dress them.
10136-8{_}4658{_}Have ready some fine bread crumbs and beaten egg; dredge the soles with a little flour, brush them over with egg, and cover with bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}4659{_}Put them in a deep pan, with plenty of clarified dripping or lard (when the expense is not objected to, oil is still better) heated, so that it may neither scorch the fish nor make them sodden.
10136-8{_}4660{_}When they are sufficiently cooked on one side, turn them carefully, and brown them on the other: they may be considered ready when a thick smoke rises.
10136-8{_}4661{_}Lift them out carefully, and lay them before the fire on a reversed sieve and soft paper, to absorb the fat.
10136-8{_}4662{_}Particular attention should be paid to this, as nothing is more disagreeable than greasy fish: this may be always avoided by dressing them in good time, and allowing a few minutes for them to get thoroughly crisp, and free from greasy moisture.
10136-8{_}4663{_}Dish them on a hot napkin, garnish with cut lemon and fried parsley, and send them to table with shrimp sauce and plain melted butter.
10136-8{_}4664{_}_Time_.--10 minutes for large soles; less time for small ones.
10136-8{_}4665{_}_Average cost_, from 1s.
10136-8{_}4666{_}to 2s.
10136-8{_}4667{_}per pair.
10136-8{_}4668{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}4669{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}4670{_}SOLES WITH MUSHROOMS.
10136-8{_}4671{_}328.
10136-8{_}4672{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint of milk, 1 pint of water, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}4673{_}butter, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}4674{_}salt, a little lemon-juice, 2 middling-sized soles.
10136-8{_}4675{_}_Mode_.--Cleanse the soles, but do not skin them, and lay them in a fish-kettle, with the milk, water, butter, salt, and lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}4676{_}Bring them gradually to boil, and let them simmer very gently till done, which will be in about 7 minutes.
10136-8{_}4677{_}Take them up, drain them well on a cloth, put them on a hot dish, and pour over them a good mushroom sauce.
10136-8{_}4678{_}(_See_ Sauces.)
10136-8{_}4679{_}_Time_.--After the water boils, 7 minutes.
10136-8{_}4680{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}4681{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}4682{_}SPRATS.
10136-8{_}4683{_}329.
10136-8{_}4684{_}Sprats should be cooked very fresh, which can be ascertained by their bright and sparkling eyes.
10136-8{_}4685{_}Wipe them dry; fasten them in rows by a skewer run through the eyes; dredge with flour, and broil them on a gridiron over a nice clear fire.
10136-8{_}4686{_}The gridiron should be rubbed with suet.
10136-8{_}4687{_}Serve very hot.
10136-8{_}4688{_}_Time_,--3 or 4 minutes.
10136-8{_}4689{_}_Average cost_, 1d.
10136-8{_}4690{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}4691{_}_Seasonable_ from November to March.
10136-8{_}4692{_}TO CHOOSE SPRATS.--Choose these from their silvery appearance, as the brighter they are, so are they the fresher.
10136-8{_}4693{_}SPRATS FRIED IN BATTER.
10136-8{_}4694{_}330.
10136-8{_}4695{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 eggs, flour, bread crumbs; seasoning of salt and pepper to taste.
10136-8{_}4696{_}_Mode_.--Wipe the sprats, and dip them in a batter made of the above ingredients.
10136-8{_}4697{_}Fry of a nice brown, serve very hot, and garnish with fried parsley.
10136-8{_}4698{_}Sprats may be baked like herrings.
10136-8{_}4699{_}(_See_ No.
10136-8{_}4700{_}268.)
10136-8{_}4701{_}DRIED SPRATS.
10136-8{_}4702{_}331.
10136-8{_}4703{_}Dried sprats should be put into a basin, and boiling water poured over them; they may then be skinned and served, and this will be found a much better way than boiling them.
10136-8{_}4704{_}[Illustration: THE SPRAT.]
10136-8{_}4705{_}THE SPRAT.--This migratory fish, is rarely found longer than     four or five inches, and visits the shores of Britain after the     herring and other kinds of fish have taken their departure from     them.
10136-8{_}4706{_}On the coasts of Suffolk, Essex, and Kent, they are very     abundant, and from 400 to 500 boats are employed in catching     them during the winter season.
10136-8{_}4707{_}Besides plentifully supplying the     London market, they are frequently sold at sixpence a bushel to     farmers for manuring purposes.
10136-8{_}4708{_}They enter the Thames about the     beginning of November, and leave it in March.
10136-8{_}4709{_}At Yarmouth and     Gravesend they are cured like red herrings.
10136-8{_}4710{_}BAKED STURGEON.
10136-8{_}4711{_}332.
10136-8{_}4712{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 small sturgeon, salt and pepper to taste, 1 small bunch of herbs, the juice of 1/2 lemon, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}4713{_}of butter, 1 pint of white wine.
10136-8{_}4714{_}_Mode_,--Cleanse the fish thoroughly, skin it, and split it along the belly without separating it; have ready a large baking-dish, in which lay the fish, sprinkle over the seasoning and herbs very finely minced, and moisten it with the lemon-juice and wine.
10136-8{_}4715{_}Place the butter in small pieces over the whole of the fish, put it in the oven, and baste frequently; brown it nicely, and serve with its own gravy.
10136-8{_}4716{_}_Time_.--Nearly 1 hour.
10136-8{_}4717{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}4718{_}to 1s.
10136-8{_}4719{_}6d.
10136-8{_}4720{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}4721{_}_Seasonable_ from August to March.
10136-8{_}4722{_}[Illustration: THE STURGEON.]
10136-8{_}4723{_}THE STURGEON.--This fish commences the sixth of Linnaean order,     and all the species are large, seldom measuring, when     full-grown, less than three or four feet in length.
10136-8{_}4724{_}Its flesh is     reckoned extremely delicious, and, in the time of the emperor     Severus, was so highly valued by the ancients, that it was     brought to table by servants crowned with coronets, and preceded     by a band of music.
10136-8{_}4725{_}It is an inhabitant of the Baltic, the     Mediterranean, the Caspian, and the Black Sea, and of the     Danube, the Volga, the Don, and other large rivers.
10136-8{_}4726{_}It is     abundant in the rivers of North America, and is occasionally     taken in the Thames, as well as in the Eske and the Eden.
10136-8{_}4727{_}It is     one of those fishes considered as royal property.
10136-8{_}4728{_}It is from its     _roe_ that _caviare_, a favourite food of the Russians, is     prepared.
10136-8{_}4729{_}Its flesh is delicate, firm, and white, but is rare in     the London market, where it sells for 1s.
10136-8{_}4730{_}or 1s.
10136-8{_}4731{_}6d.
10136-8{_}4732{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}4733{_}THE STERLET is a smaller species of sturgeon, found in the     Caspian Sea and some Russian rivers.
10136-8{_}4734{_}It also is greatly prized     on account of the delicacy of its flesh.
10136-8{_}4735{_}ROAST STURGEON.
10136-8{_}4736{_}333.
10136-8{_}4737{_}INGREDIENTS.--Veal stuffing, buttered paper, the tail-end of a sturgeon.
10136-8{_}4738{_}_Mode_.--Cleanse the fish, bone and skin it; make a nice veal stuffing (see Forcemeats), and fill it with the part where the bones came from; roll it in buttered paper, bind it up firmly with tape, like a fillet of veal, and roast it in a Dutch oven before a clear fire.
10136-8{_}4739{_}Serve with good brown gravy, or plain melted butter.
10136-8{_}4740{_}_Time_.--About 1 hour.
10136-8{_}4741{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}4742{_}to 1s.
10136-8{_}4743{_}6d.
10136-8{_}4744{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}4745{_}_Seasonable_ from August to March.
10136-8{_}4746{_}_Note_.--Sturgeon may be plain-boiled, and served with Dutch sauce.
10136-8{_}4747{_}The fish is very firm, and requires long boiling.
10136-8{_}4748{_}ESTIMATE OF THE STURGEON BY THE ANCIENTS.--By the ancients, the     flesh of this fish was compared to the ambrosia of the     immortals.
10136-8{_}4749{_}The poet Martial passes a high eulogium upon it, and     assigns it a place on the luxurious tables of the Palatine     Mount.
10136-8{_}4750{_}If we may credit a modern traveller in China, the people     of that country generally entirely abstain from it, and the     sovereign of the Celestial Empire confines it to his own     kitchen, or dispenses it to only a few of his greatest     favourites.
10136-8{_}4751{_}MATELOT OF TENCH.
10136-8{_}4752{_}334.
10136-8{_}4753{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of stock No.
10136-8{_}4754{_}105, 1/2 pint of port wine, 1 dozen button onions, a few mushrooms, a faggot of herbs, 2 blades of mace, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}4755{_}of butter, 1 teaspoonful of minced parsley, thyme, 1 shalot, 2 anchovies, 1 teacupful of stock No.
10136-8{_}4756{_}105, flour, 1 dozen oysters, the juice of 1/2 lemon; the number of tench, according to size.
10136-8{_}4757{_}_Mode_.--Scale and clean the tench, cut them into pieces, and lay them in a stewpan; add the stock, wine, onions, mushrooms, herbs, and mace, and simmer gently for 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}4758{_}Put into another stewpan all the remaining ingredients but the oysters and lemon-juice, and boil slowly for 10 minutes, when add the strained liquor from the tench, and keep stirring it over the fire until somewhat reduced.
10136-8{_}4759{_}Rub it through a sieve, pour it over the tench with the oysters, which must be previously scalded in their own liquor, squeeze in the lemon-juice, and serve.
10136-8{_}4760{_}Garnish with croutons.
10136-8{_}4761{_}_Time_.
10136-8{_}4762{_}3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}4763{_}_Seasonable_ from October to June.
10136-8{_}4764{_}[Illustration: THE TENCH.]
10136-8{_}4765{_}THE TENCH.--This fish is generally found in foul and weedy     waters, and in such places as are well supplied with rushes.
10136-8{_}4766{_}They thrive best in standing waters, and are more numerous in     pools and ponds than in rivers.
10136-8{_}4767{_}Those taken in the latter,     however, are preferable for the table.
10136-8{_}4768{_}It does not often exceed     four or five pounds in weight, and is in England esteemed as a     delicious and wholesome food.
10136-8{_}4769{_}As, however, they are sometimes     found in waters where the mud is excessively fetid, their     flavour, if cooked immediately on being caught, is often very     unpleasant; but if they are transferred into clear water, they     soon recover from the obnoxious taint.
10136-8{_}4770{_}TENCH STEWED WITH WINE.
10136-8{_}4771{_}335.
10136-8{_}4772{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of stock No.
10136-8{_}4773{_}105, 1/2 pint of Madeira or sherry, salt and pepper to taste, 1 bay-leaf, thickening of butter and flour.
10136-8{_}4774{_}_Mode_.--Clean and crimp the tench; carefully lay it in a stewpan with the stock, wine, salt and pepper, and bay-leaf; let it stew gently for 1/2 hour; then take it out, put it on a dish, and keep hot.
10136-8{_}4775{_}Strain the liquor, and thicken it with butter and flour kneaded together, and stew for 5 minutes.
10136-8{_}4776{_}If not perfectly smooth, squeeze it through a tammy, add a very little cayenne, and pour over the fish.
10136-8{_}4777{_}Garnish with balls of veal forcemeat.
10136-8{_}4778{_}_Time_.--Rather more than 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}4779{_}_Seasonable_ from October to June.
10136-8{_}4780{_}A SINGULAR QUALITY IN THE TENCH.--It is said that the tench is     possessed of such healing properties among the finny tribes,     that even the voracious pike spares it on this account.
10136-8{_}4781{_}The pike, fell tyrant of the liquid plain,       With ravenous waste devours his fellow train;       Yet howsoe'er with raging famine pined,       The tench he spares, a medicinal kind;       For when by wounds distress'd, or sore disease,       He courts the salutary fish for ease;       Close to his scales the kind physician glides,       And sweats a healing balsam from his sides.
10136-8{_}4782{_}In our estimation, however, this self-denial in the pike may be     attributed to a less poetical cause; namely, from the mud-loving     disposition of the tench, it is enabled to keep itself so     completely concealed at the bottom of its aqueous haunts, that     it remains secure from the attacks of its predatory neighbour.
10136-8{_}4783{_}STEWED TROUT.
10136-8{_}4784{_}336.
10136-8{_}4785{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 middling-sized trout, 1/2 onion cut in thin slices, a little parsley, 2 cloves, 1 blade of mace, 2 bay-leaves, a little thyme, salt and pepper to taste, 1 pint of medium stock No.
10136-8{_}4786{_}105, 1 glass of port wine, thickening of butter and flour.
10136-8{_}4787{_}_Mode_.--Wash the fish very clean, and wipe it quite dry.
10136-8{_}4788{_}Lay it in a stewpan, with all the ingredients but the butter and flour, and simmer gently for 1/2 hour, or rather more, should not the fish be quite done.
10136-8{_}4789{_}Take it out, strain the gravy, add the thickening, and stir it over a sharp fire for 5 minutes; pour it over the trout, and serve.
10136-8{_}4790{_}_Time_.--According to size, 1/2 hour or more.
10136-8{_}4791{_}_Average cost_.--Seldom bought.
10136-8{_}4792{_}_Seasonable_ from May to September, and fatter from the middle to the end of August than at any other time.
10136-8{_}4793{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}4794{_}Trout may be served with anchovy or caper sauce, baked in buttered paper, or fried whole like smelts.
10136-8{_}4795{_}Trout dressed a la Génévese is extremely delicate; for this proceed the same as with salmon, No.
10136-8{_}4796{_}307.
10136-8{_}4797{_}[Illustration: THE TROUT.]
10136-8{_}4798{_}THE TROUT.--This fish, though esteemed by the moderns for its     delicacy, was little regarded by the ancients.
10136-8{_}4799{_}Although it     abounded in the lakes of the Roman empire, it is generally     mentioned by writers only on account of the beauty of its     colours.
10136-8{_}4800{_}About the end of September, they quit the deep water to     which they had retired during the hot weather, for the purpose     of spawning.
10136-8{_}4801{_}This they always do on a gravelly bottom, or where     gravel and sand are mixed among stones, towards the end or by     the sides of streams.
10136-8{_}4802{_}At this period they become black about the     head and body, and become soft and unwholesome.
10136-8{_}4803{_}They are never     good when they are large with roe; but there are in all trout     rivers some barren female fish, which continue good throughout     the winter.
10136-8{_}4804{_}In the common trout, the stomach is uncommonly     strong and muscular, shell-fish forming a portion of the food of     the animal; and it takes into its stomach gravel or small stones     in order to assist in comminuting it.
10136-8{_}4805{_}BOILED TURBOT.
10136-8{_}4806{_}337.
10136-8{_}4807{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 oz.
10136-8{_}4808{_}of salt to each gallon of water.
10136-8{_}4809{_}_Mode_--Choose a middling-sized turbot; for they are invariably the most valuable: if very large, the meat will be tough and thready.
10136-8{_}4810{_}Three or four hours before dressing, soak the fish in salt and water to take off the slime; then thoroughly cleanse it, and with a knife make an incision down the middle of the back, to prevent the skin of the belly from cracking.
10136-8{_}4811{_}Rub it over with lemon, and be particular not to cut off the fins.
10136-8{_}4812{_}Lay the fish in a very clean turbot-kettle, with sufficient cold water to cover it, and salt in the above proportion.
10136-8{_}4813{_}Let it gradually come to a boil, and skim very carefully; keep it gently simmering, and on no account let it boil fast, as the fish would have a very unsightly appearance.
10136-8{_}4814{_}When the meat separates easily from the bone, it is done; then take it out, let it drain well, and dish it on a hot napkin.
10136-8{_}4815{_}Rub a little lobster spawn through a sieve, sprinkle it over the fish, and garnish with tufts of parsley and cut lemon.
10136-8{_}4816{_}Lobster or shrimp sauce, and plain melted butter, should be sent to table with it.
10136-8{_}4817{_}(See Coloured Plate E.)  _Time_.--After the water boils, about 1/2 hour for a large turbot; middling size, about 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}4818{_}_Average cost_,--large turbot, from 10s.
10136-8{_}4819{_}to 12s.
10136-8{_}4820{_}; middling size, from 12s.
10136-8{_}4821{_}to 15s.
10136-8{_}4822{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}4823{_}_Sufficient_, 1 middling-sized turbot for 8 persons.
10136-8{_}4824{_}_Note_.--An amusing anecdote is related, by Miss Edgeworth, of a bishop, who, descending to his kitchen to superintend the dressing of a turbot, and discovering that his cook had stupidly cut off the fins, immediately commenced sewing them on again with his own episcopal fingers.
10136-8{_}4825{_}This dignitary knew the value of a turbot's gelatinous appendages.
10136-8{_}4826{_}GARNISH FOR TURBOT OR OTHER LARGE FISH.
10136-8{_}4827{_}338.
10136-8{_}4828{_}Take the crumb of a stale loaf, cut it into small pyramids with flat tops, and on the top of each pyramid, put rather more than a tablespoonful of white of egg beaten to a stiff froth.
10136-8{_}4829{_}Over this, sprinkle finely-chopped parsley and fine raspings of a dark colour.
10136-8{_}4830{_}Arrange these on the napkin round the fish, one green and one brown alternately.
10136-8{_}4831{_}TO CHOOSE TURBOT.--See that it is thick, and of a yellowish white; for if of a bluish tint, it is not good.
10136-8{_}4832{_}[Illustration: THE TURBOT.]
10136-8{_}4833{_}THE TURBOT.--This is the most esteemed of all our flat fish.
10136-8{_}4834{_}The     northern parts of the English coast, and some places off the     coast of Holland, produce turbot in great abundance, and in     greater excellence than any other parts of the world.
10136-8{_}4835{_}The London     market is chiefly supplied by Dutch fishermen, who bring to it     nearly 90,000 a year.
10136-8{_}4836{_}The flesh is firm, white, rich, and     gelatinous, and is the better for being kept a day or two     previous to cooking it.
10136-8{_}4837{_}In many parts of the country, turbot and     halibut are indiscriminately sold for each other.
10136-8{_}4838{_}They are,     however, perfectly distinct; the upper parts of the former being     marked with large, unequal, and obtuse tubercles, while those of     the other are quite smooth, and covered with oblong soft scales,     which firmly adhere to the body.
10136-8{_}4839{_}[Illustration: TURBOT-KETTLE.]
10136-8{_}4840{_}FISH-KETTLES are made in an oblong form, and have two handles,     with a movable bottom, pierced full of holes, on which the fish     is laid, and on which it may be lifted from the water, by means     of two long handles attached to each side of the movable bottom.
10136-8{_}4841{_}This is to prevent the liability of breaking the fish, as it     would necessarily be if it were cooked in a common saucepan.
10136-8{_}4842{_}In     the list of Messrs. Richard and John Slack (see 71), the price     of two of these is set down at 10s.
10136-8{_}4843{_}The turbot-kettle, as will     be seen by our cut, is made differently from ordinary     fish-kettles, it being less deep, whilst it is wider, and more     pointed at the sides; thus exactly answering to the shape of the     fish which it is intended should be boiled in it.
10136-8{_}4844{_}It may be     obtained from the same manufacturers, and its price is £1.
10136-8{_}4845{_}BAKED FILLETS OF TURBOT.
10136-8{_}4846{_}339.
10136-8{_}4847{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold turbot, lobster sauce left from the preceding day, egg, and bread crumbs; cayenne and salt to taste; minced parsley, nutmeg, lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}4848{_}_Mode_.--After having cleared the fish from all skin and bone, divide it into square pieces of an equal size; brush them over with egg, sprinkle with bread crumbs mixed with a little minced parsley and seasoning.
10136-8{_}4849{_}Lay the fillets in a baking-dish, with sufficient butter to baste with.
10136-8{_}4850{_}Bake for 1/4 hour, and do not forget to keep them well moistened with the butter.
10136-8{_}4851{_}Put a little lemon-juice and grated nutmeg to the cold lobster sauce; make it hot, and pour over the fish, which must be well drained from the butter.
10136-8{_}4852{_}Garnish with parsley and cut lemon.
10136-8{_}4853{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}4854{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}4855{_}_Note_.--Cold turbot thus warmed in the remains of lobster sauce will be found much nicer than putting the fish again in water.
10136-8{_}4856{_}FILLETS OF TURBOT A L'ITALIENNE.
10136-8{_}4857{_}340.
10136-8{_}4858{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold turbot, Italian sauce.
10136-8{_}4859{_}(See Sauces.)
10136-8{_}4860{_}_Mode_.--Clear the fish carefully from the bone, and take away all skin, which gives an unpleasant flavour to the sauce.
10136-8{_}4861{_}Make the sauce hot, lay in the fish to warm through, but do not let it boil.
10136-8{_}4862{_}Garnish with croutons.
10136-8{_}4863{_}_Time_.--5 minutes.
10136-8{_}4864{_}_Seasonable_ all the year.
10136-8{_}4865{_}THE ANCIENT ROMANS' ESTIMATE OF TURBOT.--As this luxurious     people compared soles to partridges, and sturgeons to peacocks,     so they found a resemblance to the turbot in the pheasant.
10136-8{_}4866{_}In     the time of Domitian, it is said one was taken of such     dimensions as to require, in the imperial kitchen, a new stove     to be erected, and a new dish to be made for it, in order that     it might be cooked and served whole: not even imperial Rome     could furnish a stove or a dish large enough for the monstrous     animal.
10136-8{_}4867{_}Where it was caught, we are not aware; but the turbot of     the Adriatic Sea held a high rank in the "Eternal City."
10136-8{_}4868{_}TURBOT A LA CREME.
10136-8{_}4869{_}341.
10136-8{_}4870{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold turbot.
10136-8{_}4871{_}For sauce, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}4872{_}of butter, 4 tablespoonfuls of cream; salt, cayenne, and pounded mace to taste.
10136-8{_}4873{_}_Mode_.--Clear away all skin and bone from the flesh of the turbot, which should be done when it comes from table, as it causes less waste when trimmed hot.
10136-8{_}4874{_}Cut the flesh into nice square pieces, as equally as possible; put into a stewpan the butter, let it melt, and add the cream and seasoning; let it just simmer for one minute, but not boil.
10136-8{_}4875{_}Lay in the fish to warm, and serve it garnished with croutons or a paste border.
10136-8{_}4876{_}_Time_.--10 minutes.
10136-8{_}4877{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}4878{_}_Note_.--The remains of cold salmon may be dressed in this way, and the above mixture may be served in a _vol-au-vent_.
10136-8{_}4879{_}TURBOT AU GRATIN.
10136-8{_}4880{_}342.
10136-8{_}4881{_}INGREDIENTS.--Remains of cold turbot, béchamel (_see_ Sauces), bread crumbs, butter.
10136-8{_}4882{_}_Mode_.--Cut the flesh of the turbot into small dice, carefully freeing it from all skin and bone.
10136-8{_}4883{_}Put them into a stewpan, and moisten with 4 or 5 tablespoonfuls of béchamel.
10136-8{_}4884{_}Let it get thoroughly hot, but do not allow it to boil.
10136-8{_}4885{_}Spread the mixture on a dish, cover with finely-grated bread crumbs, and place small pieces of butter over the top.
10136-8{_}4886{_}Brown it in the oven, or with a salamander.
10136-8{_}4887{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}4888{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}4889{_}BOILED WHITING.
10136-8{_}4890{_}343.
10136-8{_}4891{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}4892{_}of salt to each gallon of water.
10136-8{_}4893{_}_Mode_.--Cleanse the fish, but do not skin them; lay them in a fish-kettle, with sufficient cold water to cover them, and salt in the above proportion.
10136-8{_}4894{_}Bring them gradually to a boil, and simmer gently for about 5 minutes, or rather more should the fish be very large.
10136-8{_}4895{_}Dish them on a hot napkin, and garnish with tufts of parsley.
10136-8{_}4896{_}Serve with anchovy or caper sauce, and plain melted butter.
10136-8{_}4897{_}_Time_.--After the water boils, 5 minutes.
10136-8{_}4898{_}_Average cost_ for small whitings, 4d.
10136-8{_}4899{_}each.
10136-8{_}4900{_}_Seasonable_ all the year, but best from October to March.
10136-8{_}4901{_}_Sufficient_, 1 small whiting for each person.
10136-8{_}4902{_}To CHOOSE WHITING.--Choose for the firmness of its flesh and the silvery hue of its appearance.
10136-8{_}4903{_}[Illustration: THE WHITING.]
10136-8{_}4904{_}The Whiting.--This fish forms a light, tender, and delicate     food, easy of digestion.
10136-8{_}4905{_}It appears in our seas in the spring,     within three miles of the shores, where it arrives in large     shoals to deposit its spawn.
10136-8{_}4906{_}It is caught by line, and is     usually between ten and twelve inches long, and seldom exceeding     a pound and a half in weight.
10136-8{_}4907{_}On the edge of the Dogger Bank,     however, it has been caught so heavy as to weigh from three to     seven or eight pounds.
10136-8{_}4908{_}When less than six inches long, it is not     allowed to be caught.
10136-8{_}4909{_}BROILED WHITING.
10136-8{_}4910{_}344.
10136-8{_}4911{_}INGREDIENTS.--Salt and water, flour.
10136-8{_}4912{_}_Mode_.--Wash the whiting in salt and water, wipe them thoroughly, and let them remain in the cloth to absorb all moisture.
10136-8{_}4913{_}Flour them well, and broil over a very clear fire.
10136-8{_}4914{_}Serve with _maître d'hôtel_ sauce, or plain melted butter (_see_ Sauces).
10136-8{_}4915{_}Be careful to preserve the liver, as by some it is considered very delicate.
10136-8{_}4916{_}_Time_.--5 minutes for a small whiting.
10136-8{_}4917{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}4918{_}each.
10136-8{_}4919{_}_Seasonable_ all the year, but best from October to March.
10136-8{_}4920{_}_Sufficient_, 1 small whiting for each person.
10136-8{_}4921{_}Buckhorn.--Whitings caught in Cornwall are salted and dried, and in winter taken to the markets, and sold under the singular name of "Buckhorn."
10136-8{_}4922{_}FRIED WHITING.
10136-8{_}4923{_}345.
10136-8{_}4924{_}INGREDIENTS.--Egg and bread crumbs, a little flour, hot lard or clarified dripping.
10136-8{_}4925{_}_Mode_.--Take off the skin, clean, and thoroughly wipe the fish free from all moisture, as this is most essential, in order that the egg and bread crumbs may properly adhere.
10136-8{_}4926{_}Fasten the tail in the mouth by means of a small skewer, brush the fish over with egg, dredge with a little flour, and cover with bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}4927{_}Fry them in hot lard or clarified dripping of a nice colour, and serve them on a napkin, garnished with fried parsley.
10136-8{_}4928{_}(See Coloured Plate D.) Send them to table with shrimp sauce and plain melted butter.
10136-8{_}4929{_}_Time_.--About 6 minutes.
10136-8{_}4930{_}Average cost, 4d.
10136-8{_}4931{_}each.
10136-8{_}4932{_}_Seasonable_ all the year, but best from October to March.
10136-8{_}4933{_}_Sufficient_, 1 small whiting for each person.
10136-8{_}4934{_}_Note_.--Large whitings may be filleted, rolled, and served as fried filleted soles (_see_ Coloured Plato A).
10136-8{_}4935{_}Small fried whitings are frequently used for garnishing large boiled fish, such as turbot, cod, etc.
10136-8{_}4936{_}WHITING AU GRATIN, or BAKED WHITING.
10136-8{_}4937{_}346.
10136-8{_}4938{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 whiting, butter, 1 tablespoonful of minced parsley, a few chopped mushrooms when obtainable; pepper, salt, and grated nutmeg to taste; butter, 2 glasses of sherry or Madeira, bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}4939{_}_Mode_.--Grease the bottom of a baking-dish with butter, and over it, strew some minced parsley and mushrooms.
10136-8{_}4940{_}Scale, empty, and wash the whitings, and wipe them thoroughly dry, carefully preserving the livers.
10136-8{_}4941{_}Lay them in the dish, sprinkle them with bread crumbs and seasoning, adding a little grated nutmeg, and also a little more minced parsley and mushrooms.
10136-8{_}4942{_}Place small pieces of butter over the whiting, moisten with the wine, and bake for 20 minutes in a hot oven.
10136-8{_}4943{_}If there should be too much sauce, reduce it by boiling over a sharp fire for a few minutes, and pour under the fish.
10136-8{_}4944{_}Serve with a cut lemon, and no other sauce.
10136-8{_}4945{_}_Time_.---20 minutes.
10136-8{_}4946{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}4947{_}each.
10136-8{_}4948{_}_Seasonable_ all the year, but best from October to March.
10136-8{_}4949{_}_Sufficient_.--This quantity for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}4950{_}WHITING AUX FINE HERBES.
10136-8{_}4951{_}347.
10136-8{_}4952{_}INGREDIENTS.-1 bunch of sweet herbs chopped very fine; butter.
10136-8{_}4953{_}_Mode_.--Clean and skin the fish, fasten the tails in the mouths; and lay them in a baking-dish.
10136-8{_}4954{_}Mince the herbs very fine, strew them over the fish, and place small pieces of butter over; cover with another dish, and let them simmer in a Dutch oven for 1/4 hour or 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}4955{_}Turn the fish once or twice, and serve with the sauce poured over.
10136-8{_}4956{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour or 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}4957{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}4958{_}each.
10136-8{_}4959{_}_Seasonable_ all the year, but best from October to March.
10136-8{_}4960{_}_Sufficient_, 1 small whiting for each person.
10136-8{_}4961{_}THE WHITING POUT, AND POLLACK.--About the mouth of the Thames,     and generally all round the English coasts, as well as in the     northern seas, the pout is plentiful.
10136-8{_}4962{_}It bears a striking     resemblance to the whiting, and is esteemed as an excellent     fish.--The _pollack_ is also taken all round our coasts, and     likewise bears a striking resemblance to the whiting; indeed, it     is sometimes mistaken by the inexperienced for that fish; its     flesh being considered by many equally delicate.
10136-8{_}4963{_}TO DRESS WHITEBAIT.
10136-8{_}4964{_}348.
10136-8{_}4965{_}INGREDIENTS.--A little flour, hot lard, seasoning of salt.
10136-8{_}4966{_}_Mode_.--This fish should be put into iced water as soon as bought, unless they are cooked immediately.
10136-8{_}4967{_}Drain them from the water in a colander, and have ready a nice clean dry cloth, over which put 2 good handfuls of flour.
10136-8{_}4968{_}Toss in the whitebait, shake them lightly in the cloth, and put them in a wicker sieve to take away the superfluous flour.
10136-8{_}4969{_}Throw them into a pan of boiling lard, very few at a time, and let them fry till of a whitey-brown colour.
10136-8{_}4970{_}Directly they are done, they must he taken out, and laid before the fire for a minute or two on a sieve reversed, covered with blotting-paper to absorb the fat.
10136-8{_}4971{_}Dish them on a hot napkin, arrange the fish very high in the centre, and sprinkle a little salt over the whole.
10136-8{_}4972{_}_Time_.--3 minutes.
10136-8{_}4973{_}_Seasonable _from April to August.
10136-8{_}4974{_}[Illustration: WHITEBAIT.]
10136-8{_}4975{_}WHITEBAIT.--This highly-esteemed little fish appears in     innumerable multitudes in the river Thames, near Greenwich and     Blackwall, during the month of July, when it forms, served with     lemon and brown bread and butter, a tempting dish to vast     numbers of Londoners, who flock to the various taverns of these     places, in order to gratify their appetites.
10136-8{_}4976{_}The fish has been     supposed be the fry of the shad, the sprat, the smelt, or the     bleak.
10136-8{_}4977{_}Mr. Yarrell, however, maintains that it is a species in     itself, distinct from every other fish.
10136-8{_}4978{_}When fried with flour,     it is esteemed a great delicacy.
10136-8{_}4979{_}The ministers of the Crown have     had a custom, for many years, of having a "whitebait dinner"     just before the close of the session.
10136-8{_}4980{_}It is invariably the     precursor of the prorogation of Parliament, and the repast is     provided by the proprietor of the "Trafalgar," Greenwich.
10136-8{_}4981{_}FISH PIE, WITH TENCH AND EELS.
10136-8{_}4982{_}349.
10136-8{_}4983{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 tench, 2 eels, 2 onions, a faggot of herbs, 4 blades of mace, 3 anchovies, 1 pint of water, pepper and salt to taste, 1 teaspoonful of chopped parsley, the yolks of 6 hard-boiled eggs, puff paste.
10136-8{_}4984{_}_Mode_.--Clean and bone the tench, skin and bone the eels, and cut them into pieces 2 inches long, and leave the sides of the tench whole.
10136-8{_}4985{_}Put the bones into a stewpan with the onions, herbs, mace, anchovies, water, and seasoning, and let them simmer gently for 1 hour.
10136-8{_}4986{_}Strain it off, put it to cool, and skim off all the fat.
10136-8{_}4987{_}Lay the tench and eels in a pie-dish, and between each layer put seasoning, chopped parsley, and hard-boiled eggs; pour in part of the strained liquor, cover in with puff paste, and bake for 1/2 hour or rather more.
10136-8{_}4988{_}The oven should be rather quick, and when done, heat the remainder of the liquor, which pour into the pie.
10136-8{_}4989{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour to bake, or rather more if the oven is slow.
10136-8{_}4990{_}FISH SCALLOP.
10136-8{_}4991{_}I.
10136-8{_}4992{_}350.
10136-8{_}4993{_}INGREDIENTS.--Remains of cold fish of any sort, 1/2 pint of cream, 1/2 tablespoonful of anchovy sauce, 1/2 teaspoonful of made mustard, ditto of walnut ketchup, pepper and salt to taste (the above quantities are for 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}4994{_}of fish when picked); bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}4995{_}_Mode_.--Put all the ingredients into a stewpan, carefully picking the fish from the bones; set it on the fire, let it remain till nearly hot, occasionally stir the contents, but do not allow it to boil.
10136-8{_}4996{_}When done, put the fish into a deep dish or scallop shell, with a good quantity of bread crumbs; place small pieces of butter on the top, set in a Dutch oven before the fire to brown, or use a salamander.
10136-8{_}4997{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}4998{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the cold fish, 10d.
10136-8{_}4999{_}II.
10136-8{_}5000{_}351.
10136-8{_}5001{_}INGREDIENTS.--Any cold fish, 1 egg, milk, 1 large blade of pounded mace, 1 tablespoonful of flour, 1 teaspoonful of anchovy sauce, pepper and salt to taste, bread crumbs, butter.
10136-8{_}5002{_}_Mode_.--Pick the fish carefully from the bones, and moisten with milk and the egg; add the other ingredients, and place in a deep dish or scallop shells; cover with bread crumbs, butter the top, and brown before the fire; when quite hot, serve.
10136-8{_}5003{_}_Time_.--20 minutes.
10136-8{_}5004{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the cold fish, 4d.
10136-8{_}5005{_}WATER SOUCHY.
10136-8{_}5006{_}352.
10136-8{_}5007{_}Perch, tench, soles, eels, and flounders are considered the best fish for this dish.
10136-8{_}5008{_}For the souchy, put some water into a stewpan with a bunch of chopped parsley, some roots, and sufficient salt to make it brackish.
10136-8{_}5009{_}Let these simmer for 1 hour, and then stew the fish in this water.
10136-8{_}5010{_}When they are done, take them out to drain, have ready some finely-chopped parsley, and a few roots cut into slices of about one inch thick and an inch in length.
10136-8{_}5011{_}Put the fish in a tureen or deep dish, strain the liquor over them, and add the minced parsley and roots.
10136-8{_}5012{_}Serve with brown bread and butter.
10136-8{_}5013{_}353.
