10136-8{_}5026{_}ADDENDUM AND ANECDOTE.
10136-8{_}5027{_}It will be seen, from the number and variety of the recipes which we have been enabled to give under the head of FISH, that there exists in the salt ocean, and fresh-water rivers, an abundance of aliment, which the present state of gastronomic art enables the cook to introduce to the table in the most agreeable forms, and oftentimes at a very moderate cost.
10136-8{_}5028{_}Less nutritious as a food than the flesh of animals, more succulent than vegetables, fish may be termed a middle dish, suited to all temperaments and constitutions; and one which those who are recovering from illness may partake of with safety and advantage.
10136-8{_}5029{_}As to which is the best fish, there has been much discussion.
10136-8{_}5030{_}The old Latin proverb, however, _de gustibus non disputandum_, and the more modern Spanish one, _sobre los gustos no hai disputa_, declare, with equal force, that where _taste_ is concerned, no decision can be arrived at.
10136-8{_}5031{_}Each person's palate may be differently affected--pleased or displeased; and there is no standard by which to judge why a red mullet, a sole, or a turbot, should be better or worse than a salmon, trout, pike, or a tiny tench.
10136-8{_}5032{_}Fish, as we have explained, is less nourishing than meat; for it is lighter in weight, size for size, and contains no ozmazome (_see_ No.
10136-8{_}5033{_}100).
10136-8{_}5034{_}Shell-fish, oysters particularly, furnish but little nutriment; and this is the reason why so many of the latter can be eaten without injury to the system.
10136-8{_}5035{_}In Brillat Savarin's [Footnote: Brillat Savarin was a French lawyer and judge of considerable eminence and great talents, and wrote, under the above title, a book on gastronomy, full of instructive information, enlivened with a fund of pleasantly-told anecdote.]
10136-8{_}5036{_}clever and amusing volume, "The Physiology of Taste," he says, that towards the end of the eighteenth century it was a most common thing for a well-arranged entertainment in Paris to commence with oysters, and that many guests were not contented without swallowing twelve dozen.
10136-8{_}5037{_}Being anxious to know the weight of this advanced-guard, he ascertained that a dozen oysters, fluid included, weighed 4 ounces,--thus, the twelve dozen would weigh about 3 lbs.
10136-8{_}5038{_}; and there can be no doubt, that the same persons who made no worse a dinner on account of having partaken of the oysters, would have been completely satisfied if they had eaten the same weight of chicken or mutton.
10136-8{_}5039{_}An anecdote, perfectly well authenticated, is narrated of a French gentleman (M. Laperte), residing at Versailles, who was extravagantly fond of oysters, declaring he never had enough.
10136-8{_}5040{_}Savarin resolved to procure him the satisfaction, and gave him an invitation to dinner, which was duly accepted.
10136-8{_}5041{_}The guest arrived, and his host kept company with him in swallowing the delicious bivalves up to the tenth dozen, when, exhausted, he gave up, and let M. Laperte go on alone.
10136-8{_}5042{_}This gentleman managed to eat thirty-two dozen within an hour, and would doubtless have got through more, but the person who opened them is described as not being very skilful.
10136-8{_}5043{_}In the interim Savarin was idle, and at length, tired with his painful state of inaction, he said to Laperte, whilst the latter was still in full career, "Mon cher, you will not eat as many oysters to-day as you meant; let us dine."
10136-8{_}5044{_}They dined, and the insatiable oyster-eater acted at the repast as if he had fasted for a week.
10136-8{_}5045{_}FISH CARVING.
10136-8{_}5046{_}GENERAL DIRECTIONS FOR CARVING FISH.
10136-8{_}5047{_}In carving fish, care should be taken to help it in perfect flakes, as, if these are broken, the beauty of the fish is lost.
10136-8{_}5048{_}The carver should be acquainted, too, with the choicest parts and morsels; and to give each guest an equal share of these _titbits_ should be his maxim.
10136-8{_}5049{_}Steel knives and forks should on no account be used in helping fish, as these are liable to impart to it a very disagreeable flavour.
10136-8{_}5050{_}Where silver fish-carvers are considered too dear to be bought, good electro-plated ones answer very well, and are inexpensive.
10136-8{_}5051{_}The prices set down for them by Messrs.
10136-8{_}5052{_}Slack, of the Strand, are from a guinea upwards.
10136-8{_}5053{_}COD'S HEAD AND SHOULDERS.
10136-8{_}5054{_}(For recipe, see No.
10136-8{_}5055{_}232; and for mode of serving, Coloured Plate C.)  [Illustration]  First run the knife along the centre of the side of the fish, namely, from _d_ to _b_, down to the bone; then carve it in unbroken slices downwards from _d_ to _e_, or upwards from _d_ to _c_, as shown in the engraving.
10136-8{_}5056{_}The carver should ask the guests if they would like a portion of the roe and liver.
10136-8{_}5057{_}_Note_.--Of this fish, the parts about the backbone and shoulders are the firmest, and most esteemed by connoisseurs.
10136-8{_}5058{_}The sound, which lines the fish beneath the backbone, is considered a delicacy, as are also the gelatinous parts about the head and neck.
10136-8{_}5059{_}SALMON.
10136-8{_}5060{_}(For recipe, see No.
10136-8{_}5061{_}301; and for mode of dressing, Coloured Plate B.)
10136-8{_}5062{_}[Illustration]  First run the knife quite down to the bone, along the side of the fish, from _a_ to _b_, and also from _c_ to _d_.
10136-8{_}5063{_}Then help the thick part lengthwise, that is, in the direction of the lines from _a_ to _b_; and the thin part breadthwise, that is, in the direction of the lines from _e_ to _f_, as shown in the engraving.
10136-8{_}5064{_}A slice of the thick part should always be accompanied by a smaller piece of the thin from the belly, where lies the fat of the fish.
10136-8{_}5065{_}_Note_.--Many persons, in carving salmon, make the mistake of slicing the thick part of this fish in the opposite direction to that we have stated; and thus, by the breaking of the flakes, the beauty of its appearance is destroyed.
10136-8{_}5066{_}BOILED OR FRIED SOLE.
10136-8{_}5067{_}(For recipes, see Nos.
10136-8{_}5068{_}321 and 327.)
10136-8{_}5069{_}The usual way of helping this fish is to cut it quite through, bone and all, distributing it in nice and not too large pieces.
10136-8{_}5070{_}A moderately-sized sole will be sufficient for three slices; namely, the head, middle, and tail.
10136-8{_}5071{_}The guests should be asked which of these they prefer.
10136-8{_}5072{_}A small one will only give two slices.
10136-8{_}5073{_}If the sole is very large, the upper side may be raised from the bone, and then divided into pieces; and the under side afterwards served in the same way.
10136-8{_}5074{_}In helping FILLETED SOLES, one fillet is given to each person.
10136-8{_}5075{_}(For mode of serving, see Coloured Plate A.)
10136-8{_}5076{_}TURBOT.
10136-8{_}5077{_}(For recipe, see No.
10136-8{_}5078{_}337; and for mode of serving, Coloured Plate E.)  First run the fish-slice down the thickest part of the fish, quite through to the bone, from _a_ to _b_, and then cut handsome and regular slices in the direction of the lines downwards, from _c_ to _e_, and upwards from _c_ to _d_, as shown in the engraving.
10136-8{_}5079{_}When the carver has removed all the meat from the upper side of the fish, the backbone should be raised, put on one side of the dish, and the under side helped as the upper.
10136-8{_}5080{_}A BRILL and JOHN DORY are carved in the same manner as a Turbot.
10136-8{_}5081{_}[Illustration]  _Note_.--The thick parts of the middle of the back are the best slices in a turbot; and the rich gelatinous skin covering the fish, as well as a little of the thick part of the fins, are dainty morsels, and should be placed on each plate.
10136-8{_}5082{_}WHITING, &c.  Whiting, pike, haddock, and other fish, when of a sufficiently large size, may be carved in the same manner as salmon.
10136-8{_}5083{_}When small, they may be cut through, bone and all, and helped in nice pieces, a middling-sized whiting serving for two slices.
10136-8{_}5084{_}_Note_.--The THICK part of the EEL is reckoned the best; and this holds good of all flat fish.
10136-8{_}5085{_}The TAIL of the LOBSTER is the prime part, and next to that the CLAWS.
10136-8{_}5086{_}[Illustration: FISH CARVERS.]
10136-8{_}5087{_}[Illustration]  SAUCES, PICKLES, GRAVIES, AND FORCEMEATS.
10136-8{_}5088{_}CHAPTER IX.
10136-8{_}5089{_}GENERAL REMARKS.
10136-8{_}5090{_}354.
10136-8{_}5091{_}AN ANECDOTE IS TOLD of the prince de Soubise, who, intending to give an entertainment, asked for the bill of fare.
10136-8{_}5092{_}His _chef_ came, presenting a list adorned with vignettes, and the first article of which, that met the prince's eye, was "fifty hams."
10136-8{_}5093{_}"Bertrand," said the prince, "I think you must be extravagant; Fifty hams!
10136-8{_}5094{_}do you intend to feast my whole regiment?"
10136-8{_}5095{_}"No, Prince, there will be but one on the table, and the surplus I need for my Espagnole, blondes, garnitures, &c." "Bertrand, you are robbing me: this item will not do."
10136-8{_}5096{_}"Monseigneur," said the _artiste_, "you do not appreciate me.
10136-8{_}5097{_}Give me the order, and I will put those fifty hams in a crystal flask no longer than my thumb."
10136-8{_}5098{_}The prince smiled, and the hams were passed.
10136-8{_}5099{_}This was all very well for the prince de Soubise; but as we do not write for princes and nobles alone, but that our British sisters may make the best dishes out of the least expensive ingredients, we will also pass the hams, and give a few general directions concerning Sauces, &c.  355.
10136-8{_}5100{_}THE PREPARATION AND APPEARANCE OF SAUCES AND GRAVIES are of the highest consequence, and in nothing does the talent and taste of the cook more display itself.
10136-8{_}5101{_}Their special adaptability to the various viands they are to accompany cannot be too much studied, in order that they may harmonize and blend with them as perfectly, so to speak, as does a pianoforte accompaniment with the voice of the singer.
10136-8{_}5102{_}356.
10136-8{_}5103{_}THE GENERAL BASIS OF MOST GRAVIES and some sauces is the same stock as that used for soups (_see_ Nos.
10136-8{_}5104{_}104, 105, 106, and 107); and, by the employment of these, with, perhaps, an additional slice of ham, a little spice, a few herbs, and a slight flavouring from some cold sauce or ketchup, very nice gravies may be made for a very small expenditure.
10136-8{_}5105{_}A milt (either of a bullock or sheep), the shank-end of mutton that has already been dressed, and the necks and feet of poultry, may all be advantageously used for gravy, where much is not required.
10136-8{_}5106{_}It may, then, be established as a rule, that there exists no necessity for good gravies to be expensive, and that there is no occasion, as many would have the world believe, to buy ever so many pounds of fresh meat, in order to furnish an ever so little quantity of gravy.
10136-8{_}5107{_}357.
10136-8{_}5108{_}BROWN SAUCES, generally speaking, should scarcely be so thick as white sauces; and it is well to bear in mind, that all those which are intended to mask the various dishes of poultry or meat, should be of a sufficient consistency to slightly adhere to the fowls or joints over which they are poured.
10136-8{_}5109{_}For browning and thickening sauces, &c., browned flour may be properly employed.
10136-8{_}5110{_}358.
10136-8{_}5111{_}SAUCES SHOULD POSSESS A DECIDED CHARACTER; and whether sharp or sweet, savoury or plain, they should carry out their names in a distinct manner, although, of course, not so much flavoured as to make them too piquant on the one hand, or too mawkish on the other.
10136-8{_}5112{_}359.
10136-8{_}5113{_}GRAVIES AND SAUCES SHOULD BE SENT TO TABLE VERY HOT; and there is all the more necessity for the cook to see to this point, as, from their being usually served in small quantities, they are more liable to cool quickly than if they were in a larger body.
10136-8{_}5114{_}Those sauces, of which cream or eggs form a component part, should be well stirred, as soon as these ingredients are added to them, and must never be allowed to boil; as, in that case, they would instantly curdle.
10136-8{_}5115{_}360.
10136-8{_}5116{_}ALTHOUGH PICKLES MAY BE PURCHASED at shops at as low a rate as they can usually be made for at home, or perhaps even for less, yet we would advise all housewives, who have sufficient time and convenience, to prepare their own.
10136-8{_}5117{_}The only general rules, perhaps, worth stating here,--as in the recipes all necessary details will be explained, are, that the vegetables and fruits used should be sound, and not over ripe, and that the very best vinegar should be employed.
10136-8{_}5118{_}361.
10136-8{_}5119{_}FOR FORCEMEATS, SPECIAL ATTENTION IS NECESSARY.
10136-8{_}5120{_}The points which cooks should, in this branch of cookery, more particularly observe, are the thorough chopping of the suet, the complete mincing of the herbs, the careful grating of the bread-crumbs, and the perfect mixing of the whole.
10136-8{_}5121{_}These are the three principal ingredients of forcemeats, and they can scarcely be cut too small, as nothing like a lump or fibre should be anywhere perceptible.
10136-8{_}5122{_}To conclude, the flavour of no one spice or herb should be permitted to predominate.
10136-8{_}5123{_}RECIPES.
10136-8{_}5124{_}CHAPTER X.   SAUCES, PICKLES, GRAVIES, AND FORCEMEATS.
10136-8{_}5125{_}ANCHOVY SAUCE FOR FISH.
10136-8{_}5126{_}362.
10136-8{_}5127{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 anchovies, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}5128{_}of butter, 1/2 pint of melted butter, cayenne to taste.
10136-8{_}5129{_}_Mode_.--Bone the anchovies, and pound them in a mortar to a paste, with 1 oz.
10136-8{_}5130{_}of butter.
10136-8{_}5131{_}Make the melted butter hot, stir in the pounded anchovies and cayenne; simmer for 3 or 4 minutes; and if liked, add a squeeze of lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}5132{_}A more general and expeditious way of making this sauce is to stir in 1-1/2 tablespoonfuls of anchovy essence to 1/2 pint of melted butter, and to add seasoning to taste.
10136-8{_}5133{_}Boil the whole up for 1 minute, and serve hot.
10136-8{_}5134{_}_Time_.--5 minutes.
10136-8{_}5135{_}_Average cost_, 5d.
10136-8{_}5136{_}for 1/2 pint.
10136-8{_}5137{_}_Sufficient_, this quantity, for a brill, small turbot, 3 or 4 soles, &c.  ANCHOVY BUTTER (_see_ No.
10136-8{_}5138{_}227).
10136-8{_}5139{_}[Illustration: THE CAPISCUM.]
10136-8{_}5140{_}CAYENNE.--This is the most acrid and stimulating spice with     which we are acquainted.
10136-8{_}5141{_}It is a powder prepared from several     varieties of the capsicum annual East-India plants, of which     there are three so far naturalized in this country as to be able     to grow in the open air: these are the Guinea, the Cherry, and     the Bell pepper.
10136-8{_}5142{_}All the pods of these are extremely pungent to     the taste, and in the green state are used by us as a pickle.
10136-8{_}5143{_}When ripe, they are ground into cayenne pepper, and sold as a     condiment.
10136-8{_}5144{_}The best of this, however, is made in the West     Indies, from what is called the _Bird_ pepper, on account of     hens and turkeys being extremely partial to it.
10136-8{_}5145{_}It is imported     ready for use.
10136-8{_}5146{_}Of the capiscum species of plants there are five;     but the principal are,--1.
10136-8{_}5147{_}_Capsicum annuum_, the common     long-podded capsicum, which is cultivated in our gardens, and of     which there are two varieties, one with red, and another with     yellow fruit.
10136-8{_}5148{_}2.
10136-8{_}5149{_}_Capsicum baccatum_, or bird pepper, which     rises with a shrubby stalk four or five feet high, with its     berries growing at the division of the branches: this is small,     oval-shaped, and of a bright-red colour, from which, as we have     said, the best cayenne is made.
10136-8{_}5150{_}3.
10136-8{_}5151{_}_Capsicum grossum_, the     bell-pepper: the fruit of this is red, and is the only kind fit     for pickling.
10136-8{_}5152{_}APPLE SAUCE FOR GEESE, PORK, &c.  363.
10136-8{_}5153{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 good-sized apples, sifted sugar to taste, a piece of butter the size of a walnut, water.
10136-8{_}5154{_}_Mode_.--Pare, core, and quarter the apples, and throw them into cold water to preserve their whiteness.
10136-8{_}5155{_}Put them in a saucepan, with sufficient water to moisten them, and boil till soft enough to pulp.
10136-8{_}5156{_}Beat them up, adding sugar to taste, and a small piece of butter This quantity is sufficient for a good-sized tureen.
10136-8{_}5157{_}_Time_.--According to the apples, about 3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}5158{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}5159{_}_Sufficient_, this quantity, for a goose or couple of ducks.
10136-8{_}5160{_}BROWN APPLE SAUCE.
10136-8{_}5161{_}364.
10136-8{_}5162{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 good-sized apples, 1/2 pint of brown gravy, cayenne to taste.
10136-8{_}5163{_}_Mode_.
10136-8{_}5164{_}Put the gravy in a stewpan, and add the apples, after having pared, cored, and quartered them.
10136-8{_}5165{_}Let them simmer gently till tender; beat them to a pulp, and season with cayenne.
10136-8{_}5166{_}This sauce is preferred by many to the preceding.
10136-8{_}5167{_}_Time_.--According to the apples, about 3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}5168{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}5169{_}ASPARAGUS SAUCE.
10136-8{_}5170{_}365.
10136-8{_}5171{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 bunch of green asparagus, salt, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}5172{_}of fresh butter, 1 small bunch of parsley, 3 or 4 green onions, 1 large lump of sugar, 4 tablespoonfuls of sauce tournée.
10136-8{_}5173{_}_Mode_.--Break the asparagus in the tender part, wash well, and put them into boiling salt and water to render them green.
10136-8{_}5174{_}When they are tender, take them out, and put them into cold water; drain them on a cloth till all moisture is absorbed from them.
10136-8{_}5175{_}Put the butter in a stewpan, with the parsley and onions; lay in the asparagus, and fry the whole over a sharp fire for 5 minutes.
10136-8{_}5176{_}Add salt, the sugar and sauce tournée, and simmer for another 5 minutes.
10136-8{_}5177{_}Rub all through a tammy, and if not a very good colour, use a little spinach green.
10136-8{_}5178{_}This sauce should be rather sweet.
10136-8{_}5179{_}_Time_.--Altogether 40 minutes.
10136-8{_}5180{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 1s.
10136-8{_}5181{_}4d.
10136-8{_}5182{_}ASPIC, or ORNAMENTAL SAVOURY JELLY.
10136-8{_}5183{_}366.
10136-8{_}5184{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 lbs.
10136-8{_}5185{_}of knuckle of veal, 1 cow-heel, 3 or 4 slices of ham, any poultry trimmings, 2 carrots, 1 onion, 1 faggot of savoury herbs, 1 glass of sherry, 3 quarts of water; seasoning to taste of salt and whole white pepper; 3 eggs.
10136-8{_}5186{_}_Mode_.--Lay the ham on the bottom of a stewpan, cut up the veal and cow-heel into small pieces, and lay them on the ham; add the poultry trimmings, vegetables, herbs, sherry, and water, and let the whole simmer very gently for 4 hours, carefully taking away all scum that may rise to the surface; strain through a fine sieve, and pour into an earthen pan to get cold.
10136-8{_}5187{_}Have ready a clean stewpan, put in the jelly, and be particular to leave the sediment behind, or it will not be clear.
10136-8{_}5188{_}Add the whites of 3 eggs, with salt and pepper, to clarify; keep stirring over the fire, till the whole becomes very white; then draw it to the side, and let it stand till clear.
10136-8{_}5189{_}When this is the case, strain it through a cloth or jelly-bag, and use it for moulding poultry, etc.
10136-8{_}5190{_}(See Explanation of French Terms, page 44.)
10136-8{_}5191{_}Tarragon vinegar may be added to give an additional flavour.
10136-8{_}5192{_}_Time_.--Altogether 4-1/2 hours.
10136-8{_}5193{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 4s.
10136-8{_}5194{_}WHITE PEPPER.--This is the produce of the same plant as that     which produces the black pepper, from which it is manufactured     by steeping this in lime and water, and rubbing it between the     hands till the coats come off.
10136-8{_}5195{_}The best berries only will bear     this operation; hence the superior qualities of white pepper     fetch a higher price than those of the other.
10136-8{_}5196{_}It is less acrid     than the black, and is much prized among the Chinese.
10136-8{_}5197{_}It is     sometimes adulterated with rice-flour, as the black is with     burnt bread.
10136-8{_}5198{_}The berries of the pepper-plant grow in spikes of     from twenty to thirty, and are, when ripe, of a bright-red     colour.
10136-8{_}5199{_}After being gathered, which is done when they are green,     they are spread out in the sun, where they dry and become black     and shrivelled, when they are ready for being prepared for the     market.
10136-8{_}5200{_}BECHAMEL, or FRENCH WHITE SAUCE.
10136-8{_}5201{_}367.
10136-8{_}5202{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 small bunch of parsley, 2 cloves, 1/2 bay-leaf, 1 small faggot of savoury herbs, salt to taste; 3 or 4 mushrooms, when obtainable; 2 pints of white stock, 1 pint of cream, 1 tablespoonful of arrowroot.
10136-8{_}5203{_}_Mode_.--Put the stock into a stewpan, with the parsley, cloves, bay-leaf, herbs, and mushrooms; add a seasoning of salt, but no pepper, as that would give the sauce a dusty appearance, and should be avoided.
10136-8{_}5204{_}When it has boiled long enough to extract the flavour of the herbs, etc., strain it, and boil it up quickly again, until it is nearly half-reduced.
10136-8{_}5205{_}Now mix the arrowroot smoothly with the cream, and let it simmer very gently for 5 minutes over a slow fire; pour to it the reduced stock, and continue to simmer slowly for 10 minutes, if the sauce be thick.
10136-8{_}5206{_}If, on the contrary, it be too thin, it must be stirred over a sharp fire till it thickens.
10136-8{_}5207{_}This is the foundation of many kinds of sauces, especially white sauces.
10136-8{_}5208{_}Always make it thick, as you can easily thin it with cream, milk, or white stock.
10136-8{_}5209{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 2 hours.
10136-8{_}5210{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}5211{_}per pint.
10136-8{_}5212{_}[Illustration: THE CLOVE.]
10136-8{_}5213{_}THE CLOVE.--The clove-tree is a native of the Molucca Islands,     particularly Amboyna, and attains the height of a laurel-tree,     and no verdure is ever seen under it.
10136-8{_}5214{_}From the extremities of     the branches quantities of flowers grow, first white; then they     become green, and next red and hard, when they have arrived at     their clove state.
10136-8{_}5215{_}When they become dry, they assume a yellowish     hue, which subsequently changes into a dark brown.
10136-8{_}5216{_}As an     aromatic, the clove is highly stimulating, and yields an     abundance of oil.
10136-8{_}5217{_}There are several varieties of the clove; the     best is called the _royal clove_, which is scarce, and which is     blacker and smaller than the other kinds.
10136-8{_}5218{_}It is a curious fact,     that the flowers, when fully developed, are quite inodorous, and     that the real fruit is not in the least aromatic.
10136-8{_}5219{_}The form is     that of a nail, having a globular head, formed of the four     petals of the corolla, and four leaves of the calyx not     expanded, with a nearly cylindrical germen, scarcely an inch in     length, situate below.
10136-8{_}5220{_}BECHAMEL MAIGRE, or WITHOUT MEAT.
10136-8{_}5221{_}368.
10136-8{_}5222{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 onions, 1 blade of mace, mushroom trimmings, a small bunch of parsley, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}5223{_}of butter, flour, 1/2 pint of water, 1 pint of milk, salt, the juice of 1 lemon, 2 eggs.
10136-8{_}5224{_}_Mode_.--Put in a stewpan the milk, and 1/2 pint of water, with the onions, mace, mushrooms, parsley, and salt.
10136-8{_}5225{_}Let these simmer gently for 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}5226{_}In the mean time, rub on a plate 1 oz.
10136-8{_}5227{_}of flour and butter; put it to the liquor, and stir it well till it boils up; then place it by the side of the fire, and continue stirring until it is perfectly smooth.
10136-8{_}5228{_}Now strain it through a sieve into a basin, after which put it back in the stewpan, and add the lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}5229{_}Beat up the yolks of the eggs with about 4 dessertspoonfuls of milk; strain this to the sauce, keep stirring it over the fire, but do not let it boil, lest it curdle.
10136-8{_}5230{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}5231{_}_Average cost_, 5d.
10136-8{_}5232{_}per pint.
10136-8{_}5233{_}This is a good sauce to pour over boiled fowls when they are a bad colour.
10136-8{_}5234{_}PICKLED BEETROOT.
10136-8{_}5235{_}369.
10136-8{_}5236{_}INGREDIENTS.--Sufficient vinegar to cover the beets, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}5237{_}of whole pepper, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}5238{_}of allspice to each gallon of vinegar.
10136-8{_}5239{_}_Mode_.--Wash the beets free from dirt, and be very careful not to prick the outside skin, or they would lose their beautiful colour.
10136-8{_}5240{_}Put them into boiling water, let them simmer gently, and when about three parts done, which will be in 1-1/2 hour, take them out and let them cool.
10136-8{_}5241{_}Boil the vinegar with pepper and allspice, in the above proportion, for ten minutes, and when cold, pour it on the beets, which must be peeled and cut into slices about 1/2 inch thick.
10136-8{_}5242{_}Cover with bladder to exclude the air, and in a week they will be fit for use.
10136-8{_}5243{_}_Average cost_, 3s.
10136-8{_}5244{_}per gallon.
10136-8{_}5245{_}[Illustration: BLACK PEPPER.]
10136-8{_}5246{_}BLACK PEPPER.--This well-known aromatic spice is the fruit of a     species of climbing vine, and is a native of the East Indies,     and is extensively cultivated in Malabar and the eastern islands     of Borneo, Sumatra, and Java, and others in the same latitude.
10136-8{_}5247{_}It was formerly confined to these countries, but it has now been     introduced to Cayenne.
10136-8{_}5248{_}It is generally employed as a condiment;     but it should never be forgotten, that, even in small     quantities, it produces detrimental effects on inflammatory     constitutions.
10136-8{_}5249{_}Dr. Paris, in his work on Diet, says, "Foreign     spices were not intended by Nature for the inhabitants of     temperate climes; they are heating, and highly stimulant.
10136-8{_}5250{_}I am,     however, not anxious to give more weight to this objection than     it deserves.
10136-8{_}5251{_}Man is no longer the child of Nature, nor the     passive inhabitant of any particular region.
10136-8{_}5252{_}He ranges over     every part of the globe, and elicits nourishment from the     productions of every climate.
10136-8{_}5253{_}Nature is very kind in favouring     the growth of those productions which are most likely to answer     our local wants.
10136-8{_}5254{_}Those climates, for instance, which engender     endemic diseases, are, in general, congenial to the growth of     plants that operate as antidotes to them.
10136-8{_}5255{_}But if we go to the     East for tea, there is no reason why we should not go to the     West for sugar.
10136-8{_}5256{_}The dyspeptic invalid, however, should be     cautious in their use; they may afford temporary benefit, at the     expense of permanent mischief.
10136-8{_}5257{_}It has been well said, that the     best quality of spices is to stimulate the appetite, and their     worst to destroy, by insensible degrees, the tone of the     stomach.
10136-8{_}5258{_}The intrinsic goodness of meats should always be     suspected when they require spicy seasonings to compensate for     their natural want of sapidity."
10136-8{_}5259{_}The quality of pepper is known     by rubbing it between the hands: that which withstands this     operation is good, that which is reduced to powder by it is bad.
10136-8{_}5260{_}The quantity of pepper imported into Europe is very great.
10136-8{_}5261{_}BENTON SAUCE (to serve with Hot or Cold Roast Beef).
10136-8{_}5262{_}370.
10136-8{_}5263{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 tablespoonful of scraped horseradish, 1 teaspoonful of made mustard, 1 teaspoonful of pounded sugar, 4 tablespoonfuls of vinegar.
10136-8{_}5264{_}_Mode_.--Grate or scrape the horseradish very fine, and mix it with the other ingredients, which must be all well blended together; serve in a tureen.
10136-8{_}5265{_}With cold meat, this sauce is a very good substitute for pickles.
10136-8{_}5266{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 2d.
10136-8{_}5267{_}BREAD SAUCE (to serve with Roast Turkey, Fowl, Game, &c.).
10136-8{_}5268{_}I.
10136-8{_}5269{_}371.
10136-8{_}5270{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint of milk, 3/4 of the crumb of a stale loaf, 1 onion; pounded mace, cayenne, and salt to taste; 1 oz.
10136-8{_}5271{_}of butter.
10136-8{_}5272{_}_Mode_.--Peel and quarter the onion, and simmer it in the milk till perfectly tender.
10136-8{_}5273{_}Break the bread, which should be stale, into small pieces, carefully picking out any hard outside pieces; put it in a very clean saucepan, strain the milk over it, cover it up, and let it remain for an hour to soak.
10136-8{_}5274{_}Now beat it up with a fork very smoothly, add a seasoning of pounded mace, cayenne, and salt, with 1 oz.
10136-8{_}5275{_}of butter; give the whole one boil, and serve.
10136-8{_}5276{_}To enrich this sauce, a small quantity of cream may be added just before sending it to table.
10136-8{_}5277{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 1-3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}5278{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 4d.
10136-8{_}5279{_}_Sufficient_ to serve with a turkey, pair of fowls, or brace of partridges.
10136-8{_}5280{_}[Illustration: MACE.]
10136-8{_}5281{_}MACE.--This is the membrane which surrounds the shell of the     nutmeg.
10136-8{_}5282{_}Its general qualities are the same as those of the     nutmeg, producing an agreeable aromatic odour, with a hot and     acrid taste.
10136-8{_}5283{_}It is of an oleaginous nature, is yellowish in its     hue, and is used largely as a condiment.
10136-8{_}5284{_}In "Beeton's     Dictionary" we find that the four largest of the Banda Islands     produce 150,000 lbs.
10136-8{_}5285{_}of it annually, which, with nutmegs, are     their principal articles of export.
10136-8{_}5286{_}II.
10136-8{_}5287{_}372.
10136-8{_}5288{_}INGREDIENTS.--Giblets of poultry, 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}5289{_}of the crumb of a stale loaf, 1 onion, 12 whole peppers, 1 blade of mace, salt to taste, 2 tablespoonfuls of cream or melted butter, 1 pint of water.
10136-8{_}5290{_}_Mode_.--Put the giblets, with the head, neck, legs, &c., into a stewpan; add the onion, pepper, mace, salt, and rather more than 1 pint of water.
10136-8{_}5291{_}Let this simmer for an hour, when strain the liquor over the bread, which should be previously grated or broken into small pieces.
10136-8{_}5292{_}Cover up the saucepan, and leave it for an hour by the side of the fire; then beat the sauce up with a fork until no lumps remain, and the whole is nice and smooth.
10136-8{_}5293{_}Let it boil for 3 or 4 minutes; keep stirring it until it is rather thick; when add 3 tablespoonfuls of good melted butter or cream, and serve very hot.
10136-8{_}5294{_}_Time_.--2-1/4 hours.
10136-8{_}5295{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}5296{_}BROWNING FOR GRAVIES AND SAUCES.
10136-8{_}5297{_}373.
10136-8{_}5298{_}The browning for soups (_see_ No.
10136-8{_}5299{_}108) answers equally well for sauces and gravies, when it is absolutely necessary to colour them in this manner; but where they can be made to look brown by using ketchup, wine, browned flour, tomatoes, or any colour sauce, it is far preferable.
10136-8{_}5300{_}As, however, in cooking, so much depends on appearance, perhaps it would be as well for the inexperienced cook to use the artificial means (No.
10136-8{_}5301{_}108).
10136-8{_}5302{_}When no browning is at hand, and you wish to heighten the colour of your gravy, dissolve a lump of sugar in an iron spoon over a sharp fire; when it is in a liquid state, drop it into the sauce or gravy quite hot.
10136-8{_}5303{_}Care, however, must be taken not to put in too much, as it would impart a very disagreeable flavour.
10136-8{_}5304{_}BEURRE NOIR, or BROWNED BUTTER (a French Sauce).
10136-8{_}5305{_}374.
10136-8{_}5306{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}5307{_}of butter, 1 tablespoonful of minced parsley, 3 tablespoonfuls of vinegar, salt and pepper to taste.
10136-8{_}5308{_}_Mode_.--Put the butter into a fryingpan over a nice clear fire, and when it smokes, throw in the parsley, and add the vinegar and seasoning.
10136-8{_}5309{_}Let the whole simmer for a minute or two, when it is ready to serve.
10136-8{_}5310{_}This is a very good sauce for skate.
10136-8{_}5311{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}5312{_}CLARIFIED BUTTER.
10136-8{_}5313{_}375.
10136-8{_}5314{_}Put the butter in a basin before the fire, and when it melts, stir it round once or twice, and let it settle.
10136-8{_}5315{_}Do not strain it unless absolutely necessary, as it causes so much waste.
10136-8{_}5316{_}Pour it gently off into a clean dry jar, carefully leaving all sediment behind.
10136-8{_}5317{_}Let it cool, and carefully exclude the air by means of a bladder, or piece of wash-leather, tied over.
10136-8{_}5318{_}If the butter is salt, it may be washed before melting, when it is to be used for sweet dishes.
10136-8{_}5319{_}MELTED BUTTER.
10136-8{_}5320{_}I.
10136-8{_}5321{_}376.
10136-8{_}5322{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}5323{_}of butter, a dessertspoonful of flour, 1 wineglassful of water, salt to taste.
10136-8{_}5324{_}_Mode_.--Cut the butter up into small pieces, put it in a saucepan, dredge over the flour, and add the water and a seasoning of salt; stir it _one way_ constantly till the whole of the ingredients are melted and thoroughly blended.
10136-8{_}5325{_}Let it just boil, when it is ready to serve.
10136-8{_}5326{_}If the butter is to be melted with cream, use the same quantity as of water, but omit the flour; keep stirring it, but do not allow it to boil.
10136-8{_}5327{_}_Time_.--1 minute to simmer.
10136-8{_}5328{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 4d.
10136-8{_}5329{_}II.
10136-8{_}5330{_}_(More Economical.
10136-8{_}5331{_})_  377.
10136-8{_}5332{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 oz.
10136-8{_}5333{_}of butter, 1 dessertspoonful of flour, salt to taste, 1/2 pint of water.
10136-8{_}5334{_}_Mode_.--Mix the flour and water to a smooth batter, which put into a saucepan.
10136-8{_}5335{_}Add the butter and a seasoning of salt, keep stirring _one way_ till all the ingredients are melted and perfectly smooth; let the whole boil for a minute or two, and serve.
10136-8{_}5336{_}_Time_.--2 minutes to simmer.
10136-8{_}5337{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 2d.
10136-8{_}5338{_}MELTED BUTTER (the French Sauce Blanche).
10136-8{_}5339{_}378.
10136-8{_}5340{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}5341{_}of fresh butter, 1 tablespoonful of flour, salt to taste, 1/2 gill of water, 1/2 spoonful of white vinegar, a very little grated nutmeg.
10136-8{_}5342{_}_Mode_.--Mix the flour and water to a smooth batter, carefully rubbing down with the back of a spoon any lumps that may appear.
10136-8{_}5343{_}Put it in a saucepan with all the other ingredients, and let it thicken on the fire, but do not allow it to boil, lest it should taste of the flour.
10136-8{_}5344{_}_Time_.--1 minute to simmer.
10136-8{_}5345{_}_Average cost_, 5d.
10136-8{_}5346{_}for this quantity.
10136-8{_}5347{_}[Illustration: THE NUTMEG.]
10136-8{_}5348{_}NUTMEG.--This is a native of the Moluccas, and was long kept     from being spread in other places by the monopolizing spirit of     the Dutch, who endeavoured to keep it wholly to themselves by     eradicating it from every other island.
10136-8{_}5349{_}We find it stated in     "Beeton's Dictionary of Universal Information," under the     article "Banda Islands," that the four largest are appropriated     to the cultivation of nutmegs, of which about 500,000 lbs.
10136-8{_}5350{_}are     annually produced.
10136-8{_}5351{_}The plant, through the enterprise of the     British, has now found its way into Penang and Bencooleu, where     it flourishes and produces well.
10136-8{_}5352{_}It has also been tried to be     naturalized in the West Indies, and it bears fruit all the year     round.
10136-8{_}5353{_}There are two kinds of nutmeg,--one wild, and long and     oval-shaped, the other cultivated, and nearly round.
10136-8{_}5354{_}The best is     firm and hard, and has a strong aromatic odour, with a hot and     acrid taste.
10136-8{_}5355{_}It ought to be used with caution by those who are     of paralytic or apoplectic habits.
10136-8{_}5356{_}THICKENED BUTTER.
10136-8{_}5357{_}379.--INGREDIENTS.--1/4 pint of melted butter, No.
10136-8{_}5358{_}376, the yolks of 2 eggs, a little lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}5359{_}_Mode_.--Make the butter quite hot, and be careful not to colour it.
10136-8{_}5360{_}Well whisk the yolks of the eggs, pour them to the butter, beating them all the while.
10136-8{_}5361{_}Make the sauce hot over the fire, but do not let it boil; add a squeeze of lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}5362{_}MELTED BUTTER MADE WITH MILK.
10136-8{_}5363{_}380.
10136-8{_}5364{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 teaspoonful of flour, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}5365{_}butter, 1/3 pint of milk, a few grains of salt.
10136-8{_}5366{_}_Mode_.--Mix the butter and flour smoothly together on a plate, put it into a lined saucepan, and pour in the milk.
10136-8{_}5367{_}Keep stirring it _one way_ over a sharp fire; let it boil quickly for a minute or two, and it is ready to serve.
10136-8{_}5368{_}This is a very good foundation for onion, lobster, or oyster sauce: using milk instead of water makes it look so much whiter and more delicate.
10136-8{_}5369{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}5370{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 3d.
10136-8{_}5371{_}CAMP VINEGAR.
10136-8{_}5372{_}381.
10136-8{_}5373{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 head of garlic, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}5374{_}cayenne, 2 teaspoonfuls of soy, 2 ditto walnut ketchup, 1 pint of vinegar, cochineal to colour.
10136-8{_}5375{_}_Mode_.--Slice the garlic, and put it, with all the above ingredients, into a clean bottle.
10136-8{_}5376{_}Let it stand to infuse for a month, when strain it off quite clear, and it will be fit for use.
10136-8{_}5377{_}Keep it in small bottles well sealed, to exclude the air.
10136-8{_}5378{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 8d.
10136-8{_}5379{_}CAPER SAUCE FOR BOILED MUTTON.
10136-8{_}5380{_}382.
10136-8{_}5381{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of melted butter (No.
10136-8{_}5382{_}376), 3 tablespoonfuls of capers or nasturtiums, 1 tablespoonful of their liquor.
10136-8{_}5383{_}_Mode_.--Chop the capers twice or thrice, and add them, with their liquor, to 1/2 pint of melted butter, made very smoothly; keep stirring well; let the sauce just simmer, and serve in a tureen.
10136-8{_}5384{_}Pickled nasturtium-pods are fine-flavoured, and by many are eaten in preference to capers.
10136-8{_}5385{_}They make an excellent sauce.
10136-8{_}5386{_}_Time_.--2 minutes to simmer.
10136-8{_}5387{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 8d.
10136-8{_}5388{_}_Sufficient_ to serve with a leg of mutton.
10136-8{_}5389{_}CAPER SAUCE FOR FISH.
10136-8{_}5390{_}383.
10136-8{_}5391{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of melted butter No.
10136-8{_}5392{_}376, 3 dessertspoonfuls of capers, 1 dessertspoonful of their liquor, a small piece of glaze, if at hand (this may be dispensed with), 1/4 teaspoonful of salt, ditto of pepper, 1 tablespoonful of anchovy essence.
10136-8{_}5393{_}_Mode_.--Cut the capers across once or twice, but do not chop them fine; put them in a saucepan with 1/2 pint of good melted butter, and add all the other ingredients.
10136-8{_}5394{_}Keep stirring the whole until it just simmers, when it is ready to serve.
10136-8{_}5395{_}_Time_.--1 minute to simmer.
10136-8{_}5396{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 5d.
10136-8{_}5397{_}_Sufficient_ to serve with a skate, or 2 or 3 slices of salmon.
10136-8{_}5398{_}[Illustration: THE CAPER.]
10136-8{_}5399{_}CAPERS.--These are the unopened buds of a low trailing shrub,     which grows wild among the crevices of the rocks of Greece, as     well as in northern Africa: the plant, however, has come to be     cultivated in the south of Europe.
10136-8{_}5400{_}After being pickled in     vinegar and salt, they are imported from Sicily, Italy, and the     south of France.
10136-8{_}5401{_}The best are from Toulon.
10136-8{_}5402{_}A SUBSTITUTE FOR CAPER SAUCE.
10136-8{_}5403{_}384.
10136-8{_}5404{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of melted butter, No.
10136-8{_}5405{_}376, 2 tablespoonfuls of cut parsley, 1/2 teaspoonful of salt, 1 tablespoonful of vinegar.
10136-8{_}5406{_}_Mode_.--Boil the parsley slowly to let it become a bad colour; cut, but do not chop it fine.
10136-8{_}5407{_}Add it to 1/2 pint of smoothly-made melted butter, with salt and vinegar in the above proportions.
10136-8{_}5408{_}Boil up and serve.
10136-8{_}5409{_}_Time_.--2 minutes to simmer.
10136-8{_}5410{_}Average cost for this quantity, 3d.
10136-8{_}5411{_}PICKLED CAPSICUMS.
10136-8{_}5412{_}385.
10136-8{_}5413{_}INGREDIENTS.--Vinegar, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}5414{_}of pounded mace, and 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}5415{_}of grated nutmeg, to each quart; brine.
10136-8{_}5416{_}_Mode_.--Gather the pods with the stalks on, before they turn red; slit them down the side with a small-pointed knife, and remove the seeds only; put them in a strong brine for 3 days, changing it every morning; then take them out, lay them on a cloth, with another one over them, until they are perfectly free from moisture.
10136-8{_}5417{_}Boil sufficient vinegar to cover them, with mace and nutmeg in the above proportions; put the pods in a jar, pour over the vinegar when cold, and exclude them from the air by means of a wet bladder tied over.
10136-8{_}5418{_}CAYENNE VINEGAR, or ESSENCE OF CAYENNE.
10136-8{_}5419{_}386.
10136-8{_}5420{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}5421{_}of cayenne pepper, 1/2 pint of strong spirit, or 1 pint of vinegar.
10136-8{_}5422{_}_Mode_.--Put the vinegar, or spirit, into a bottle, with the above proportion of cayenne, and let it steep for a month, when strain off and bottle for use.
10136-8{_}5423{_}This is excellent seasoning for soups or sauces, but must be used very sparingly.
10136-8{_}5424{_}CELERY SAUCE, FOR BOILED TURKEY, POULTRY, &c.  387.
10136-8{_}5425{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 heads of celery, 1 pint of white stock, No.
10136-8{_}5426{_}107, 2 blades of mace, 1 small bunch of savoury herbs; thickening of butter and flour, or arrowroot, 1/2 pint of cream, lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}5427{_}_Mode_.--Boil the celery in salt and water, until tender, and cut it into pieces 2 inches long.
10136-8{_}5428{_}Put the stock into a stewpan with the mace and herbs, and let it simmer for 1/2 hour to extract their flavour.
10136-8{_}5429{_}Then strain the liquor, add the celery and a thickening of butter kneaded with flour, or, what is still better, with arrowroot; just before serving, put in the cream, boil it up and squeeze in a little lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}5430{_}If necessary, add a seasoning of salt and white pepper.
10136-8{_}5431{_}_Time_.--25 minutes to boil the celery.
10136-8{_}5432{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}5433{_}3d.
10136-8{_}5434{_}_Sufficient_, this quantity, for a boiled turkey.
10136-8{_}5435{_}This sauce may be made brown by using gravy instead of white stock, and flavouring it with mushroom ketchup or Harvey's sauce.
10136-8{_}5436{_}[Illustration: ARROWROOT.]
10136-8{_}5437{_}ARROWROOT.--This nutritious fecula is obtained from the roots of     a plant which is cultivated in both the East and West Indies.
10136-8{_}5438{_}When the roots are about a year old, they are dug up, and, after     being well washed, are beaten to a pulp, which is afterwards, by     means of water, separated from the fibrous part.
10136-8{_}5439{_}After being     passed through a sieve, once more washed, and then suffered to     settle, the sediment is dried in the sun, when it has become     arrowroot.
10136-8{_}5440{_}The best is obtained from the West Indies, but a     large quantity of what is sold in London is adulterated with     potato-starch.
10136-8{_}5441{_}As a means of knowing arrowroot when it is good,     it may be as well to state, that the genuine article, when     formed into a jelly, will remain firm for three or four days,     whilst the adulterated will become as thin as milk in the course     of twelve hours.
10136-8{_}5442{_}CELERY SAUCE (a More Simple Recipe).
10136-8{_}5443{_}388.
10136-8{_}5444{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 heads of celery, 1/2 pint of melted butter, made with milk (No.
10136-8{_}5445{_}380), 1 blade of pounded mace; salt and white pepper to taste.
10136-8{_}5446{_}_Mode_.--Wash the celery, boil it in salt and water till tender, and cut it into pieces 2 inches long; make 1/2 pint melted butter by recipe No.
10136-8{_}5447{_}380; put in the celery, pounded mace, and seasoning; simmer for three minutes, when the sauce will be ready to serve.
10136-8{_}5448{_}_Time_.--25 minutes to boil the celery.
10136-8{_}5449{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}5450{_}_Sufficient_, this quantity, for a boiled fowl.
10136-8{_}5451{_}CELERY VINEGAR.
10136-8{_}5452{_}389.
10136-8{_}5453{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}5454{_}of celery-seed, 1 pint of vinegar.
10136-8{_}5455{_}_Mode_.--Crush the seed by pounding it in a mortar; boil the vinegar, and when cold, pour it to the seed; let it infuse for a fortnight, when strain and bottle off for use.
10136-8{_}5456{_}This is frequently used in salads.
10136-8{_}5457{_}CHESTNUT SAUCE FOR FOWLS OR TURKEY.
10136-8{_}5458{_}390.
10136-8{_}5459{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}5460{_}of chestnuts, 1/2 pint of white stock, 2 strips of lemon-peel, cayenne to taste, 1/4 pint of cream or milk.
10136-8{_}5461{_}_Mode_.--Peel off the outside skin of the chestnuts, and put them into boiling water for a few minutes; take off the thin inside peel, and put them into a saucepan, with the white stock and lemon-peel, and let them simmer for 1-1/2 hour, or until the chestnuts are quite tender.
10136-8{_}5462{_}Rub the whole through a hair-sieve with a wooden spoon; add seasoning and the cream; let it just simmer, but not boil, and keep stirring all the time.
10136-8{_}5463{_}Serve very hot; and quickly.
10136-8{_}5464{_}If milk is used instead of cream, a very small quantity of thickening may be required: that, of course, the cook will determine.
10136-8{_}5465{_}_Time_.--Altogether nearly two hours.
10136-8{_}5466{_}_Average cost_, 8d.
10136-8{_}5467{_}_Sufficient_, this quantity, for a turkey.
10136-8{_}5468{_}BROWN CHESTNUT SAUCE.
10136-8{_}5469{_}391.
10136-8{_}5470{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}5471{_}of chestnuts, 1/2 pint of stock No.
10136-8{_}5472{_}105, 2 lumps of sugar, 4 tablespoonfuls of Spanish sauce (_see_ Sauces).
10136-8{_}5473{_}_Mode_.--Prepare the chestnuts as in the foregoing recipe, by scalding and peeling them; put them in a stewpan with the stock and sugar, and simmer them till tender.
10136-8{_}5474{_}When done, add Spanish sauce in the above proportion, and rub the whole through a tammy.
10136-8{_}5475{_}Keep this sauce rather liquid, as it is liable to thicken.
10136-8{_}5476{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 hour to simmer the chestnuts.
10136-8{_}5477{_}_Average cost_, 8d.
10136-8{_}5478{_}BENGAL RECIPE FOR MAKING MANGO CHETNEY.
10136-8{_}5479{_}392.
10136-8{_}5480{_}INGREDIENTS.--1-1/2 lbs.
10136-8{_}5481{_}of moist sugar, 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}5482{_}of salt, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}5483{_}of garlic, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}5484{_}of onions, 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}5485{_}of powdered ginger, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}5486{_}of dried chilies, 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}5487{_}of mustard-seed, 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}5488{_}of stoned raisins, 2 bottles of best vinegar, 30 large unripe sour apples.
10136-8{_}5489{_}_Mode_.--The sugar must be made into syrup; the garlic, onions, and ginger be finely pounded in a mortar; the mustard-seed be washed in cold vinegar, and dried in the sun; the apples be peeled, cored, and sliced, and boiled in a bottle and a half of the vinegar.
10136-8{_}5490{_}When all this is done, and the apples are quite cold, put them into a large pan, and gradually mix the whole of the rest of the ingredients, including the remaining half-bottle of vinegar.
10136-8{_}5491{_}It must be well stirred until the whole is thoroughly blended, and then put into bottles for use.
10136-8{_}5492{_}Tie a piece of wet bladder over the mouths of the bottles, after they are well corked.
10136-8{_}5493{_}This chetney is very superior to any which can be bought, and one trial will prove it to be delicious.
10136-8{_}5494{_}_Note_.--This recipe was given by a native to an English lady, who had long been a resident in India, and who, since her return to her native country, has become quite celebrated amongst her friends for the excellence of this Eastern relish.
10136-8{_}5495{_}[Illustration: GARLIC.]
10136-8{_}5496{_}GARLIC.--The smell of this plant is generally considered     offensive, and it is the most acrimonious in its taste of the     whole of the alliaceous tribe.
10136-8{_}5497{_}In 1548 it was introduced to     England from the shores of the Mediterranean, where it is     abundant, and in Sicily it grows naturally.
10136-8{_}5498{_}It was in greater     repute with our ancestors than it is with ourselves, although it     is still used as a seasoning herb.
10136-8{_}5499{_}On the continent, especially     in Italy, it is much used, and the French consider it an     essential in many made dishes.
10136-8{_}5500{_}CHILI VINEGAR.
10136-8{_}5501{_}393.
10136-8{_}5502{_}INGREDIENTS.--50 fresh red English chilies, 1 pint of vinegar.
10136-8{_}5503{_}_Mode_.--Pound or cut the chilies in half, and infuse them in the vinegar for a fortnight, when it will be fit for use.
10136-8{_}5504{_}This will be found an agreeable relish to fish, as many people cannot eat it without the addition of an acid and cayenne pepper.
10136-8{_}5505{_}CHRISTOPHER NORTH'S SAUCE FOR MEAT OR GAME.
10136-8{_}5506{_}394.
10136-8{_}5507{_}INGREDIENTS.-1 glass of port wine, 2 tablespoonfuls of Harvey's sauce, 1 dessertspoonful of mushroom ketchup, ditto of pounded white sugar, 1 tablespoonful of lemon-juice, 1/4 teaspoonful of cayenne pepper, ditto of salt.
10136-8{_}5508{_}_Mode_.--Mix all the ingredients thoroughly together, and heat the sauce gradually, by placing the vessel in which it is made in a saucepan of boiling water.
10136-8{_}5509{_}Do not allow it to boil, and serve directly it is ready.
10136-8{_}5510{_}This sauce, if bottled immediately, will keep good for a fortnight, and will be found excellent.
10136-8{_}5511{_}CONSOMME, or WHITE STOCK FOR MANY SAUCES.
10136-8{_}5512{_}395.
10136-8{_}5513{_}Consommé is made precisely in the same manner as stock No.
10136-8{_}5514{_}107, and, for ordinary purposes, will be found quite good enough.
10136-8{_}5515{_}When, however, a stronger stock is desired, either put in half the quantity of water, or double that of the meat.
10136-8{_}5516{_}This is a very good foundation for all white sauces.
10136-8{_}5517{_}CRAB SAUCE FOR FISH (equal to Lobster Sauce).
10136-8{_}5518{_}396.

10136-8{_}5520{_}380).
10136-8{_}5521{_}_Mode_.--Choose a nice fresh crab, pick all the meat away from the shell, and cut it into small square pieces.
10136-8{_}5522{_}Make 1/2 pint of melted butter by recipe No.
10136-8{_}5523{_}380, put in the fish and seasoning; let it gradually warm through, and simmer for 2 minutes.
10136-8{_}5524{_}It should not boil.
10136-8{_}5525{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}5526{_}2d.
10136-8{_}5527{_}CREAM SAUCE FOR FISH OR WHITE DISHES.
10136-8{_}5528{_}397.
10136-8{_}5529{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/3 pint of cream, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}5530{_}of butter, 1 teaspoonful of flour, salt and cayenne to taste; when liked, a small quantity of pounded mace or lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}5531{_}_Mode_.--Put the butter in a very clean saucepan, dredge in the flour, and keep shaking round till the butter is melted.
10136-8{_}5532{_}Add the seasoning and cream, and stir the whole till it boils; let it just simmer for 5 minutes, when add either pounded mace or lemon-juice to taste, to give it a flavour.

10136-8{_}5536{_}CUCUMBER SAUCE.
10136-8{_}5537{_}398.
10136-8{_}5538{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 or 4 cucumbers, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}5539{_}of butter, 6 tablespoonfuls of brown gravy.
10136-8{_}5540{_}_Mode_.--Peel the cucumbers, quarter them, and take out the seeds; cut them into small pieces; put them in a cloth, and rub them well, to take out the water which hangs about them.
10136-8{_}5541{_}Put the butter in a saucepan, add the cucumbers, and shake them over a sharp fire until they are of a good colour.
10136-8{_}5542{_}Then pour over it the gravy, mix this with the cucumbers, and simmer gently for 10 minutes, when it will be ready to serve.
10136-8{_}5543{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}5544{_}PICKLED CUCUMBERS.
10136-8{_}5545{_}399.
10136-8{_}5546{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 oz.
10136-8{_}5547{_}of whole pepper, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}5548{_}of bruised ginger; sufficient vinegar to cover the cucumbers.
10136-8{_}5549{_}_Mode_.--Cut the cucumbers in thick slices, sprinkle salt over them, and let them remain for 24 hours.
10136-8{_}5550{_}The next day, drain them well for 6 hours, put them into a jar, pour boiling vinegar over them, and keep them in a warm place.
10136-8{_}5551{_}In a short time, boil up the vinegar again, add pepper and ginger in the above proportion, and instantly cover them up.
10136-8{_}5552{_}Tie them down with bladder, and in a few days they will be fit for use.
10136-8{_}5553{_}[Illustration: LONG PEPPER.]
10136-8{_}5554{_}LONG PEPPER.--This is the produce of a different plant from that     which produces the black, it consisting of the half-ripe     flower-heads of what naturalists call _Piper longum_ and     _chaba_.
10136-8{_}5555{_}It is the growth, however, of the same countries;     indeed, all the spices are the produce of tropical climates     only.
10136-8{_}5556{_}Originally, the most valuable of these were found in the     Spice Islands, or Moluccas, of the Indian Ocean, and were highly     prized by the nations of antiquity.
10136-8{_}5557{_}The Romans indulged in them     to a most extravagant degree.
10136-8{_}5558{_}The long pepper is less aromatic     than the black, but its oil is more pungent.
10136-8{_}5559{_}CUCUMBER SAUCE, WHITE.
10136-8{_}5560{_}400.
10136-8{_}5561{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 or four cucumbers, 1/2 pint of white stock, No.
10136-8{_}5562{_}107, cayenne and salt to taste, the yolks of 3 eggs.
10136-8{_}5563{_}_Mode_.--Cut the cucumbers into small pieces, after peeling them and taking out the seeds.
10136-8{_}5564{_}Put them in a stewpan with the white stock and seasoning; simmer gently till the cucumbers are tender, which will be in about 1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}5565{_}Then add the yolks of the eggs well beaten; stir them to the sauce, but do not allow it to boil, and serve very hot.
10136-8{_}5566{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}5567{_}CUCUMBER VINEGAR (a very nice Addition to Salads).
10136-8{_}5568{_}401.
10136-8{_}5569{_}INGREDIENTS.--10 large cucumbers, or 12 smaller ones, 1 quart of vinegar, 2 onions, 2 shalots, 1 tablespoonful of salt, 2 tablespoonfuls of pepper, 1/4 teaspoonful of cayenne.
10136-8{_}5570{_}_Mode_.--Pare and slice the cucumbers, put them in a stone jar or wide-mouthed bottle, with the vinegar; slice the onions and shalots, and add them, with all the other ingredients, to the cucumbers.
10136-8{_}5571{_}Let it stand 4 or 5 days, boil it all up, and when cold, strain the liquor through a piece of muslin, and store it away in small bottles well sealed.
10136-8{_}5572{_}This vinegar is a very nice addition to gravies, hashes, &e., as well as a great improvement to salads, or to eat with cold meat.
10136-8{_}5573{_}GERMAN METHOD OF KEEPING CUCUMBERS FOR WINTER USE.
10136-8{_}5574{_}402.
10136-8{_}5575{_}INGREDIENTS.--Cucumbers, salt.
10136-8{_}5576{_}_Mode_.--Pare and slice the cucumbers (as for the table), sprinkle well with salt, and let them remain for 24 hours; strain off the liquor, pack in jars, a thick layer of cucumbers and salt alternately; tie down closely, and, when wanted for use, take out the quantity required.
10136-8{_}5577{_}Now wash them well in fresh water, and dress as usual with pepper, vinegar, and oil.
10136-8{_}5578{_}[Illustration: THE CUCUMBER.]
10136-8{_}5579{_}THE CUCUMBER.--Though the melon is far superior in point of     flavour to this fruit, yet it is allied to the cucumber, which     is known to naturalists as _Cucumia sativus_.
10136-8{_}5580{_}The modern     Egyptians, as did their forefathers, still eat it, and others of     its class.
10136-8{_}5581{_}Cucumbers were observed, too, by Bishop Heber,     beyond the Ganges, in India; and Burckhardt noticed them in     Palestine.
10136-8{_}5582{_}(See No.
10136-8{_}5583{_}127.)
10136-8{_}5584{_}AN EXCELLENT WAY OF PRESERVING CUCUMBERS.
10136-8{_}5585{_}403.
10136-8{_}5586{_}INGREDIENTS.--Salt and water; 1 lb.
10136-8{_}5587{_}of lump sugar, the rind of 1 lemon, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}5588{_}of ginger, cucumbers.
10136-8{_}5589{_}_Mode_.--Choose the greenest cucumbers, and those that are most free from seeds; put them in strong salt and water, with a cabbage-leaf to keep them down; tie a paper over them, and put them in a warm place till they are yellow; then wash them and set them over the fire in fresh water, with a very little salt, and another cabbage-leaf over them; cover very closely, but take care they do not boil.
10136-8{_}5590{_}If they are not a fine green, change the water again, cover them as before, and make them hot.
10136-8{_}5591{_}When they are a good colour, take them off the fire and let them cool; cut them in quarters, take out the seeds and pulp, and put them into cold water.
10136-8{_}5592{_}Let them remain for 2 days, changing the water twice each day, to draw out the salt.
10136-8{_}5593{_}Put the sugar, with 1/4 pint of water, in a saucepan over the fire; remove the scum as it rises, and add the lemon-peel and ginger with the outside scraped off; when the syrup is tolerably thick, take it off the fire, and when _cold_, wipe the cucumbers _dry_, and put them in.
10136-8{_}5594{_}Boil the syrup once in 2 or 3 days for 3 weeks; strengthen it if required, and let it be quite cold before the cucumbers are put in.
10136-8{_}5595{_}Great attention must be paid to the directions in the commencement of this recipe, as, if these are not properly carried out, the result will be far from satisfactory.
10136-8{_}5596{_}_Seasonable_.--This recipe should be used in June, July, or August.
10136-8{_}5597{_}[Illustration: SALT-MINE AT NORTHWICH.]
10136-8{_}5598{_}COMMON SALT.--By this we mean salt used for cooking purposes,     which is found in great abundance both on land and in the waters     of the ocean.
10136-8{_}5599{_}Sea or salt water, as it is often called,     contains, it has been discovered, about three per cent, of salt     on an average.
10136-8{_}5600{_}Solid rocks of salt are also found in various     parts of the world, and the county of Chester contains many of     these mines, and it is from there that much of our salt comes.
10136-8{_}5601{_}Some springs are so highly impregnated with salt, as to have     received the name of "brine" springs, and are supposed to have     become so by passing through the salt rocks below ground, and     thus dissolving a portion of this mineral substance.
10136-8{_}5602{_}We here     give an engraving of a salt-mine at Northwich, Cheshire, where     both salt-mines and brine-springs are exceedingly productive,     and are believed to have been wrought so far back as during the     occupation of Britain by the Romans.
10136-8{_}5603{_}CUSTARD SAUCE FOR SWEET PUDDINGS OR TARTS.
10136-8{_}5604{_}404.
10136-8{_}5605{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint of milk, 2 eggs, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}5606{_}of pounded sugar, 1 tablespoonful of brandy.
10136-8{_}5607{_}_Mode_.--Put the milk in a very clean saucepan, and let it boil.
10136-8{_}5608{_}Beat the eggs, stir to them the milk and pounded sugar, and put the mixture into a jug.
10136-8{_}5609{_}Place the jug in a saucepan of boiling water; keep stirring well until it thickens, but do not allow it to boil, or it will curdle.
10136-8{_}5610{_}Serve the sauce in a tureen, stir in the brandy, and grate a little nutmeg over the top.
10136-8{_}5611{_}This sauce may be made very much nicer by using cream instead of milk; but the above recipe will be found quite good enough for ordinary purposes.
10136-8{_}5612{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}5613{_}per pint.
10136-8{_}5614{_}_Sufficient_, this quantity, for 2 fruit tarts, or 1 pudding.
10136-8{_}5615{_}DUTCH SAUCE FOR FISH.
10136-8{_}5616{_}405.
10136-8{_}5617{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 teaspoonful of flour, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}5618{_}of butter, 4 tablespoonfuls of vinegar, the yolks of 2 eggs, the juice of 1/2 lemon; salt to taste.
10136-8{_}5619{_}_Mode_.--Put all the ingredients, except the lemon-juice, into a stew-pan; set it over the fire, and keep continually stirring.
10136-8{_}5620{_}When it is sufficiently thick, take it off, as it should not boil.
10136-8{_}5621{_}If, however, it happens to curdle, strain the sauce through a tammy, add the lemon-juice, and serve.
10136-8{_}5622{_}Tarragon vinegar may be used instead of plain, and, by many, is considered far preferable.
10136-8{_}5623{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}5624{_}Note.--This sauce may be poured hot over salad, and left to get quite cold, when it should be thick, smooth, and somewhat stiff.
10136-8{_}5625{_}Excellent salads may be made of hard eggs, or the remains of salt fish flaked nicely from the bone, by pouring over a little of the above mixture when hot, and allowing it to cool.
10136-8{_}5626{_}[Illustration: THE LEMON.]
10136-8{_}5627{_}THE LEMON.--This fruit is a native of Asia, and is mentioned by     Virgil as an antidote to poison.
10136-8{_}5628{_}It is hardier than the orange,     and, as one of the citron tribe, was brought into Europe by the     Arabians.
10136-8{_}5629{_}The lemon was first cultivated in England in the     beginning of the 17th century, and is now often to be found in     our green-houses.
10136-8{_}5630{_}The kind commonly sold, however, is imported     from Portugal, Spain, and the Azores.
10136-8{_}5631{_}Some also come from St.     Helena; but those from Spain are esteemed the best.
10136-8{_}5632{_}Its juice is     now an essential for culinary purposes; but as an antiscorbutic     its value is still greater.
10136-8{_}5633{_}This juice, which is called _citric     acid_, may be preserved in bottles for a considerable time, by     covering it with a thin stratum of oil.
10136-8{_}5634{_}_Shrub_ is made from it     with rum and sugar.
10136-8{_}5635{_}GREEN DUTCH SAUCE, or HOLLANDAISE VERTE.
10136-8{_}5636{_}406.
10136-8{_}5637{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 tablespoonfuls of Béchamel, No.
10136-8{_}5638{_}367, seasoning to taste of salt and cayenne, a little parsley-green to colour, the juice of 1/2 a lemon.
10136-8{_}5639{_}_Mode_.--Put the Béchamel into a saucepan with the seasoning, and bring it to a boil.
10136-8{_}5640{_}Make a green colouring by pounding some parsley in a mortar, and squeezing all the juice from it.
10136-8{_}5641{_}Let this just simmer, when add it to the sauce.
10136-8{_}5642{_}A moment before serving, put in the lemon-juice, but not before; for otherwise the sauce would turn yellow, and its appearance be thus spoiled.
10136-8{_}5643{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}5644{_}BÉCHAMEL SAUCE--This sauce takes its name from a Monsieur     Béchamel, a rich French financier, who, according to Borne     authorities, invented it; whilst others affirm he only     patronized it.
10136-8{_}5645{_}Be this as it may, it is one of the most pleasant     sauces which come to table, and should be most carefully and     intelligently prepared.
10136-8{_}5646{_}It is frequently used, as in the above     recipe, as a principal ingredient and basis for other sauces.
10136-8{_}5647{_}TO PICKLE EGGS.
10136-8{_}5648{_}407.
10136-8{_}5649{_}INGREDIENTS.--16 eggs, 1 quart of vinegar, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}5650{_}of Black pepper, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}5651{_}of Jamaica pepper, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}5652{_}of ginger.
10136-8{_}5653{_}_Mode_.--Boil the eggs for 12 minutes, then dip them into cold water, and take off the shells.
10136-8{_}5654{_}Put the vinegar, with the pepper and ginger, into a stewpan, and let it simmer for 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}5655{_}Now place the eggs in a jar, pour over them the vinegar, &c., boiling hot, and, when cold, tie them down with bladder to exclude the air.
10136-8{_}5656{_}This pickle will be ready for use in a month.
10136-8{_}5657{_}_Average cost_, for this quantity, 1s.
10136-8{_}5658{_}9d.
10136-8{_}5659{_}_Seasonable_.--This should be made about Easter, as at this time eggs are plentiful and cheap.
10136-8{_}5660{_}A store of pickled eggs will be found very useful and ornamental in serving with many first and second course dishes.
10136-8{_}5661{_}[Illustration: GINGER.]
10136-8{_}5662{_}The ginger-plant, known to naturalists as _Zingiber officinale_,     is a native, of the East and West Indies.
10136-8{_}5663{_}It grows somewhat like     the lily of the valley, but its height is about three feet.
10136-8{_}5664{_}In     Jamaica it flowers about August or September, fading about the     end of the year.
10136-8{_}5665{_}The fleshy creeping roots, which form the     ginger of commerce, are in a proper state to be dug when the     stalks are entirely withered.
10136-8{_}5666{_}This operation is usually     performed in January and February; and when the roots are taken     out of the earth, each one is picked, scraped, separately     washed, and afterwards very carefully dried.
10136-8{_}5667{_}Ginger is generally     considered as less pungent and heating to the system than might     he expected from its effects on the organs of taste, and it is     frequently used, with considerable effect, as an anti-spasmodic     and carminative.
10136-8{_}5668{_}EGG BALLS FOR SOUPS AND MADE DISHES.
10136-8{_}5669{_}408.
10136-8{_}5670{_}INGREDIENTS.--8 eggs, a little flour; seasoning to taste of salt.
10136-8{_}5671{_}_Mode_.--Boil 6 eggs for 20 minutes, strip off the shells, take the yolks and pound them in a mortar.
10136-8{_}5672{_}Beat the yolks of the other 2 eggs; add them, with a little flour and salt, to those pounded; mix all well together, and roll into balls.
10136-8{_}5673{_}Boil them before they are put into the soup or other dish they may be intended for.
10136-8{_}5674{_}_Time_.--20 minutes to boil the eggs.
10136-8{_}5675{_}_Average cost_, for this quantity, 8d.
10136-8{_}5676{_}_Sufficient_, 2 dozen balls for 1 tureen of soup.
10136-8{_}5677{_}EGG SAUCE FOR SALT FISH.
10136-8{_}5678{_}409.
10136-8{_}5679{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 eggs, 1/2 pint of melted butter, No.
10136-8{_}5680{_}376; when liked, a very little lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}5681{_}_Mode_.--Boil the eggs until quite hard, which will be in about 20 minutes, and put them into cold water for 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}5682{_}Strip off the shells, chop the eggs into small pieces, not, however, too fine.
10136-8{_}5683{_}Make the melted butter very smoothly, by recipe No.
10136-8{_}5684{_}376, and, when boiling, stir in the eggs, and serve very hot.
10136-8{_}5685{_}Lemon-juice may be added at pleasure.
10136-8{_}5686{_}_Time_.--20 minutes to boil the eggs.
10136-8{_}5687{_}_Average cost_, 8d.
10136-8{_}5688{_}_Sufficient_.--This quantity for 3 or 4 lbs.
10136-8{_}5689{_}of fish.
10136-8{_}5690{_}_Note_.--When a thicker sauce is required, use one or two more eggs to the same quantity of melted butter.
10136-8{_}5691{_}EPICUREAN SAUCE FOR STEAKS, CHOPS, GRAVIES, OR FISH.
10136-8{_}5692{_}410.
10136-8{_}5693{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 pint of walnut ketchup, 1/4 pint of mushroom ditto, 2 tablespoonfuls of Indian soy, 2 tablespoonfuls of port wine; 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}5694{_}of white pepper, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}5695{_}of shalots, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}5696{_}of cayenne, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}5697{_}of cloves, 3/4 pint of vinegar.
10136-8{_}5698{_}_Mode_.--Put the whole of the ingredients into a bottle, and let it remain for a fortnight in a warm place, occasionally shaking up the contents.
10136-8{_}5699{_}Strain, and bottle off for use.
10136-8{_}5700{_}This sauce will be found an agreeable addition to gravies, hashes, stews, &c.  _Average cost_, for this quantity, 1s.
10136-8{_}5701{_}6d.
10136-8{_}5702{_}[Illustration: SHALOT.]
10136-8{_}5703{_}SHALOT, OR ESCHALOT.--This plant is supposed to have been     introduced to England by the Crusaders, who found it growing     wild in the vicinity of Ascalon.
10136-8{_}5704{_}It is a bulbous root, and when     full grown, its leaves wither in July.
10136-8{_}5705{_}They ought to be taken up     in the autumn, and when dried in the house, will keep till     spring.
10136-8{_}5706{_}It is called by old authors the "barren onion," and is     used in sauces and pickles, soups and made dishes, and as an     accompaniment to chops and steaks.
10136-8{_}5707{_}ESPAGNOLE, OR BROWN SPANISH SAUCE.
10136-8{_}5708{_}411.
10136-8{_}5709{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 slices of lean ham, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}5710{_}of veal, 1-1/2 pint of white stock, No.
10136-8{_}5711{_}107; 2 or 3 sprigs of parsley, 1/2 a bay-leaf, 2 or 3 sprigs of savoury herbs, 6 green onions, 3 shalots, 2 cloves, 1 blade of mace, 2 glasses of sherry or Madeira, thickening of butter and flour.
10136-8{_}5712{_}_Mode_.--Cut up the ham and veal into small square pieces, and put them into a stewpan.
10136-8{_}5713{_}Moisten these with 1/2 pint of the stock No.
10136-8{_}5714{_}107, and simmer till the bottom of the stewpan is covered with a nicely-coloured glaze, when put in a few more spoonfuls to detach it.
10136-8{_}5715{_}Add the remainder of the stock, with the spices, herbs, shalots, and onions, and simmer very gently for 1 hour.
10136-8{_}5716{_}Strain and skim off every particle of fat, and when required for use, thicken with butter and flour, or with a little roux.
10136-8{_}5717{_}Add the wine, and, if necessary, a seasoning of cayenne; when it will be ready to serve.
10136-8{_}5718{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}5719{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}5720{_}per pint.
10136-8{_}5721{_}_Note_.--The wine in this sauce may be omitted, and an onion sliced and fried of a nice brown substituted for it.
10136-8{_}5722{_}This sauce or gravy is used for many dishes, and with most people is a general favourite.
10136-8{_}5723{_}FENNEL SAUCE FOR MACKEREL.
10136-8{_}5724{_}412.
10136-8{_}5725{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of melted butter, No.
10136-8{_}5726{_}376, rather more than 1 tablespoonful of chopped fennel.
10136-8{_}5727{_}_Mode_.--Make the melted butter very smoothly, by recipe No.
10136-8{_}5728{_}376; chop the fennel rather small, carefully cleansing it from any grit or dirt, and put it to the butter when this is on the point of boiling.
10136-8{_}5729{_}Simmer for a minute or two, and serve in a tureen.
10136-8{_}5730{_}_Time_.--2 minutes.
10136-8{_}5731{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}5732{_}_Sufficient_ to serve with 5 or 6 mackerel.
10136-8{_}5733{_}[Illustration: FENNEL.]
10136-8{_}5734{_}FENNEL.--This elegantly-growing plant, of which the Latin name     is _Anethum foeniculum_, grows best in chalky soils, where,     indeed, it is often found wild.
10136-8{_}5735{_}It is very generally cultivated     in gardens, and has much improved on its original form.
10136-8{_}5736{_}Various     dishes are frequently ornamented and garnished with its graceful     leaves, and these are sometimes boiled in soups, although it is     more usually confined, in English cookery, to the mackerel sauce     as here given.
10136-8{_}5737{_}FISH SAUCE.
10136-8{_}5738{_}413.
