10136-8{_}5740{_}of cayenne, 2 tablespoonfuls of walnut ketchup, 2 tablespoonfuls of soy, a few shreds of garlic and shalot, 1 quart of vinegar.
10136-8{_}5741{_}_Mode_.--Put all the ingredients into a large bottle, and shake well every day for a fortnight.
10136-8{_}5742{_}Keep it in small bottles well sealed, and in a few days it will be fit for use.
10136-8{_}5743{_}_Average cost_, for this quantity, 1s.
10136-8{_}5744{_}FORCEMEAT BALLS FOR FISH SOUPS.
10136-8{_}5745{_}414.
10136-8{_}5746{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 middling-sized lobster, 1/2 an anchovy, 1 head of boiled celery, the yolk of a hard-boiled egg; salt, cayenne, and mace to taste; 4 tablespoonfuls of bread crumbs, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}5747{_}of butter, 2 eggs.
10136-8{_}5748{_}_Mode_.--Pick the meat from the shell of the lobster, and pound it, with the soft parts, in a mortar; add the celery, the yolk of the hard-boiled egg, seasoning, and bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}5749{_}Continue pounding till the whole is nicely amalgamated.
10136-8{_}5750{_}Warm the butter till it is in a liquid state; well whisk the eggs, and work these up with the pounded lobster-meat.
10136-8{_}5751{_}Make into balls of about an inch in diameter, and fry of a nice pale brown.
10136-8{_}5752{_}_Sufficient_, from 18 to 20 balls for 1 tureen of soup.
10136-8{_}5753{_}FORCEMEAT FOR COLD SAVOURY PIES.
10136-8{_}5754{_}415.
10136-8{_}5755{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}5756{_}of veal, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}5757{_}of fat bacon; salt, cayenne, pepper, and pounded mace to taste; a very little nutmeg, the same of chopped lemon-peel, 1/2 teaspoonful of chopped parsley, 1/2 teaspoonful of minced savoury herbs, 1 or 2 eggs.
10136-8{_}5758{_}_Mode_.--Chop the veal and bacon together, and put them in a mortar with the other ingredients mentioned above.
10136-8{_}5759{_}Pound well, and bind with 1 or 2 eggs which have been previously beaten and strained.
10136-8{_}5760{_}Work the whole well together, and the forcemeat will be ready for use.
10136-8{_}5761{_}If the pie is not to be eaten immediately, omit the herbs and parsley, as these would prevent it from keeping.
10136-8{_}5762{_}Mushrooms or truffles may be added.
10136-8{_}5763{_}_Sufficient_ for 2 small pies.
10136-8{_}5764{_}[Illustration: MARJORAM.]
10136-8{_}5765{_}MARJORAM.--Although there are several species of marjoram, that     which is known as the sweet or knotted marjoram, is the one     usually preferred in cookery.
10136-8{_}5766{_}It is a native of Portugal, and     when its leaves are used as a seasoning herb, they have an     agreeable aromatic flavour.
10136-8{_}5767{_}The winter sweet marjoram used for     the same purposes, is a native of Greece, and the pot-marjoram     is another variety brought from Sicily.
10136-8{_}5768{_}All of them are     favourite ingredients in soups, stuffings, &c.  FORCEMEAT FOR PIKE, CARP, HADDOCK, AND VARIOUS KINDS OF FISH.
10136-8{_}5769{_}416.
10136-8{_}5770{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 oz.
10136-8{_}5771{_}of fresh butter, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}5772{_}of suet, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}5773{_}of fat bacon, 1 small teaspoonful of minced savoury herbs, including parsley; a little onion, when liked, shredded very fine; salt, nutmeg, and cayenne to taste; 4 oz.
10136-8{_}5774{_}of bread crumbs, 1 egg.
10136-8{_}5775{_}_Mode_.--Mix all the ingredients well together, carefully mincing them very finely; beat up the egg, moisten with it, and work the whole very smoothly together.
10136-8{_}5776{_}Oysters or anchovies may be added to this forcemeat, and will be found a great improvement.
10136-8{_}5777{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}5778{_}_Sufficient_ for a moderate-sized haddock or pike.
10136-8{_}5779{_}FORCEMEAT FOR VEAL, TURKEYS, FOWLS, HARE, &c.  417.
10136-8{_}5780{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 oz.
10136-8{_}5781{_}of ham or lean bacon, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}5782{_}of suet, the rind of half a lemon, 1 teaspoonful of minced parsley, 1 teaspoonful of minced sweet herbs; salt, cayenne, and pounded mace to taste; 6 oz.
10136-8{_}5783{_}of bread crumbs, 2 eggs.
10136-8{_}5784{_}_Mode_.--Shred the ham or bacon, chop the suet, lemon-peel, and herbs, taking particular care that all be very finely minced; add a seasoning to taste, of salt, cayenne, and mace, and blend all thoroughly together with the bread crumbs, before wetting.
10136-8{_}5785{_}Now beat and strain the eggs, work these up with the other ingredients, and the forcemeat will be ready for use.
10136-8{_}5786{_}When it is made into balls, fry of a nice brown, in boiling lard, or put them on a tin and bake for 1/2 hour in a moderate oven.
10136-8{_}5787{_}As we have stated before, no one flavour should predominate greatly, and the forcemeat should be of sufficient body to cut with a knife, and yet not dry and heavy.
10136-8{_}5788{_}For very delicate forcemeat, it is advisable to pound the ingredients together before binding with the egg; but for ordinary cooking, mincing very finely answers the purpose.
10136-8{_}5789{_}_Average cost_, 8d.
10136-8{_}5790{_}_Sufficient_ for a turkey, a moderate-sized fillet of veal, or a hare.
10136-8{_}5791{_}_Note_.--In forcemeat for HARE, the liver of the animal is sometimes added.
10136-8{_}5792{_}Boil for 5 minutes, mince it very small, and mix it with the other ingredients.
10136-8{_}5793{_}If it should be in an unsound state, it must be on no account made use of.
10136-8{_}5794{_}[Illustration: BASIL.]
10136-8{_}5795{_}SWEET HERBS.--Those most usually employed for purposes of     cooking, such as the flavouring of soups, sauces, forcemeats,     &c., are thyme, sage, mint, marjoram, savory, and basil.
10136-8{_}5796{_}Other     sweet herbs are cultivated for purposes of medicine and     perfumery: they are most grateful both to the organs of taste     and smelling; and to the aroma derived from them is due, in a     great measure, the sweet and exhilarating fragrance of our     "flowery meads."
10136-8{_}5797{_}In town, sweet herbs have to be procured at the     greengrocers' or herbalists', whilst, in the country, the garden     should furnish all that are wanted, the cook taking great care     to have some dried in the autumn for her use throughout the     winter months.
10136-8{_}5798{_}FORCEMEAT FOR BAKED PIKE.
10136-8{_}5799{_}418.
10136-8{_}5800{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 oz.
10136-8{_}5801{_}of bread crumbs, 1 teaspoonful of minced savoury herbs, 8 oysters, 2 anchovies (these may be dispensed with), 2 oz.
10136-8{_}5802{_}of suet; salt, pepper, and pounded mace to taste; 6 tablespoonfuls of cream or milk, the yolks of 2 eggs.
10136-8{_}5803{_}_Mode_.--Beard and mince the oysters, prepare and mix the other ingredients by recipe No.
10136-8{_}5804{_}416, and blend the whole thoroughly together.
10136-8{_}5805{_}Moisten with the cream and eggs, put all into a stewpan, and stir it over the fire till it thickens, when put it into the fish, which should have previously been cut open, and sew it up.
10136-8{_}5806{_}_Time_.--4 or 6 minutes to thicken.
10136-8{_}5807{_}_Average cost_, 10d.
10136-8{_}5808{_}_Sufficient_ for a moderate-sized pike.
10136-8{_}5809{_}FRENCH FORCEMEAT.
10136-8{_}5810{_}419.
10136-8{_}5811{_}It will be well to state, in the beginning of this recipe, that French forcemeat, or quenelles, consist of the blending of three separate processes; namely, panada, udder, and whatever meat you intend using.
10136-8{_}5812{_}PANADA.
10136-8{_}5813{_}420.
10136-8{_}5814{_}INGREDIENTS.--The crumb of 2 penny rolls, 4 tablespoonfuls of white stock, No.
10136-8{_}5815{_}107, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}5816{_}of butter, 1 slice of ham, 1 bay-leaf, a little minced parsley, 2 shalots, 1 clove, 2 blades of mace, a few mushrooms (when obtainable), butter, the yolks of 2 eggs.
10136-8{_}5817{_}_Mode_.--Soak the crumb of the rolls in milk for about 1/2 hour, then take it out, and squeeze so as to press the milk from it; put the soaked bread into a stewpan with the above quantity of white stock, and set it on one side; then put into a separate stewpan 1 oz.
10136-8{_}5818{_}of butter, a slice of lean ham cut small, with a bay-leaf, herbs, mushrooms, spices, &c., in the above proportions, and fry them gently over a slow fire.
10136-8{_}5819{_}When done, moisten with 2 teacupfuls of white stock, boil for 20 minutes, and strain the whole through a sieve over the panada in the other stewpan.
10136-8{_}5820{_}Place it over the fire, keep constantly stirring, to prevent its burning, and when quite dry, put in a small piece of butter.
10136-8{_}5821{_}Let this again dry up by stirring over the fire; then add the yolks of 2 eggs, mix well, put the panada to cool on a clean plate, and use it when required.
10136-8{_}5822{_}Panada should always be well flavoured, as the forcemeat receives no taste from any of the other ingredients used in its preparation.
10136-8{_}5823{_}Boiled Calf's Udder for French Forcemeats.
10136-8{_}5824{_}421.
10136-8{_}5825{_}Put the udder into a stewpan with sufficient water to cover it; let it stew gently till quite done, when take it out to cool.
10136-8{_}5826{_}Trim all the upper parts, cut it into small pieces, and pound well in a mortar, till it can be rubbed through a sieve.
10136-8{_}5827{_}That portion which passes through the strainer is one of the three ingredients of which French forcemeats are generally composed; but many cooks substitute butter for this, being a less troublesome and more expeditious mode of preparation.
10136-8{_}5828{_}[Illustration: PESTLE AND MORTAR.]
10136-8{_}5829{_}PESTLE AND MORTAR.--No cookery can be perfectly performed     without the aid of the useful instruments shown in the     engraving.
10136-8{_}5830{_}For pounding things sufficiently fine, they are     invaluable, and the use of them will save a good deal of time,     besides increasing the excellence of the preparations.
10136-8{_}5831{_}They are     made of iron, and, in that material, can be bought cheap; but as     these are not available, for all purposes, we should recommend,     as more economical in the end, those made of Wedgwood, although     these are considerably more expensive than the former.
10136-8{_}5832{_}Veal Quenelles.
10136-8{_}5833{_}422.
10136-8{_}5834{_}INGREDIENTS.--Equal quantities of veal, panada (No.
10136-8{_}5835{_}420), and calf's udder (No.
10136-8{_}5836{_}421), 2 eggs; seasoning to taste of pepper, salt, and pounded mace, or grated nutmeg; a little flour.
10136-8{_}5837{_}_Mode_.--Take the fleshy part of veal, scrape it with a knife, till all the meat is separated from the sinews, and allow about 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}5838{_}for an entrée.
10136-8{_}5839{_}Chop the meat, and pound it in a mortar till reduced to a paste; then roll it into a ball; make another of panada (No.
10136-8{_}5840{_}420), the same size, and another of udder (No.
10136-8{_}5841{_}421), taking care that these three balls be of the same _size_.
10136-8{_}5842{_}It is to be remembered, that equality of _size_, and not of weight, is here necessary.
10136-8{_}5843{_}When the three ingredients are properly prepared, pound them altogether in a mortar for some time; for the more quenelles are pounded, the more delicate they are.
10136-8{_}5844{_}Now moisten with the eggs, whites and yolks, and continue pounding, adding a seasoning of pepper, spices, &c. When the whole is well blended together, mould it into balls, or whatever shape is intended, roll them in flour, and poach in boiling water, to which a little salt should have been added.
10136-8{_}5845{_}If the quenelles are not firm enough, add the yolk of another egg, but omit the white, which only makes them hollow and puffy inside.
10136-8{_}5846{_}In the preparation of this recipe, it would be well to bear in mind that the ingredients are to be well pounded and seasoned, and must be made hard or soft according to the dishes they are intended for.
10136-8{_}5847{_}For brown or white ragoûts they should be firm, and when the quenelles are used very small, extreme delicacy will be necessary in their preparation.
10136-8{_}5848{_}Their flavour may be varied by using the flesh of rabbit, fowl, hare, pheasant, grouse, or an extra quantity of mushroom, parsley, &c.  _Time_,--About 1/4 hour to poach in boiling water.
10136-8{_}5849{_}_Sufficient_, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}5850{_}of veal or other meat, with other ingredients in proportion, for 1 entrée.
10136-8{_}5851{_}_Note_.--The French are noted for their skill in making forcemeats; one of the principal causes of their superiority in this respect being, that they pound all the ingredients so diligently and thoroughly.
10136-8{_}5852{_}Any one with the slightest pretensions to refined cookery, must, in this particular, implicitly follow the example of our friends across the Channel.
10136-8{_}5853{_}FORCEMEAT, or QUENELLES, FOR TURTLE SOUP.
10136-8{_}5854{_}(_See No_.
10136-8{_}5855{_}189.)
10136-8{_}5856{_}423.
10136-8{_}5857{_}SOYER'S RECIPE FOR FORCEMEATS.--Take a pound and a half of lean veal from the fillet, and cut it in long thin slices; scrape with a knife till nothing but the fibre remains; put it in a mortar, pound it 10 minutes, or until in a purée; pass it through a wire sieve (use the remainder in stock); then take 1 pound of good fresh beef suet, which skin, shred, and chop very fine; put it in a mortar and pound it; then add 6 oz.
10136-8{_}5858{_}of panada (that is, bread soaked in milk and boiled till nearly dry) with the suet; pound them well together, and add the veal; season with a teaspoonful of salt, a quarter one of pepper, half that of nutmeg; work all well together; then add four eggs by degrees, continually pounding the contents of the mortar.
10136-8{_}5859{_}When well mixed, take a small piece in a spoon, and poach it in some boiling water; and if it is delicate, firm, and of a good flavour, it is ready for use.
10136-8{_}5860{_}FRIED BREAD CRUMBS.
10136-8{_}5861{_}424.
10136-8{_}5862{_}Cut the bread into thin slices, place them in a cool oven overnight, and when thoroughly dry and crisp, roll them down into fine crumbs.
10136-8{_}5863{_}Put some lard, or clarified dripping, into a frying-pan; bring it to the boiling-point, throw in the crumbs, and fry them very quickly.
10136-8{_}5864{_}Directly they are done, lift them out with a slice, and drain them before the fire from all greasy moisture.
10136-8{_}5865{_}When quite crisp, they are ready for use.
10136-8{_}5866{_}The fat they are fried in should be clear, and the crumbs should not have the slightest appearance or taste of having been, in the least degree, burnt.
10136-8{_}5867{_}FRIED SIPPETS OF BREAD (for Garnishing many Dishes).
10136-8{_}5868{_}425.
10136-8{_}5869{_}Cut the bread into thin slices, and stamp them out in whatever shape you like,--rings, crosses, diamonds, &c. &c. Fry them in the same manner as the bread crumbs, in clear boiling lard, or clarified dripping, and drain them until thoroughly crisp before the fire.
10136-8{_}5870{_}When variety is desired, fry some of a pale colour, and others of a darker hue.
10136-8{_}5871{_}FRIED BREAD FOR BORDERS.
10136-8{_}5872{_}426.
10136-8{_}5873{_}Proceed as above, by frying some slices of bread cut in any fanciful shape.
10136-8{_}5874{_}When quite crisp, dip one side of the sippet into the beaten white of an egg mixed with a little flour, and place it on the edge of the dish.
10136-8{_}5875{_}Continue in this manner till the border is completed, arranging the sippets a pale and a dark one alternately.
10136-8{_}5876{_}GENEVESE SAUCE FOR SALMON, TROUT, &c.  427.
10136-8{_}5877{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 small carrot, a small faggot of sweet herbs, including parsley, 1 onion, 5 or 6 mushrooms (when obtainable), 1 bay-leaf, 6 cloves, 1 blade of mace, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}5878{_}of butter, 1 glass of sherry, 1-1/2 pint of white stock, No.
10136-8{_}5879{_}107, thickening of butter and flour, the juice of half a lemon.
10136-8{_}5880{_}_Mode_.--Cut up the onion and carrot into small rings, and put them into a stewpan with the herbs, mushrooms, bay-leaf, cloves, and mace; add the butter, and simmer the whole very gently over a slow fire until the onion is quite tender.
10136-8{_}5881{_}Pour in the stock and sherry, and stew slowly for 1 hour, when strain it off into a clean saucepan.
10136-8{_}5882{_}Now make a thickening of butter and flour, put it to the sauce, stir it over the fire until perfectly smooth and mellow, add the lemon-juice, give one boil, when it will be ready for table.
10136-8{_}5883{_}_Time_.--Altogether 2 hours.
10136-8{_}5884{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}5885{_}3d per pint.
10136-8{_}5886{_}_Sufficient_, half this quantity for two slices of salmon.
10136-8{_}5887{_}[Illustration: SAGE.]
10136-8{_}5888{_}SAGE.--This was originally a native of the south of Europe, but     it has long been cultivated in the English garden.
10136-8{_}5889{_}There are     several kinds of it, known as the green, the red, the     small-leaved, and the broad-leaved balsamic.
10136-8{_}5890{_}In cookery, its     principal use is for stuffings and sauces, for which purpose the     red is the most agreeable, and the green the next.
10136-8{_}5891{_}The others     are used for medical purposes.
10136-8{_}5892{_}PICKLED GHERKINS.
10136-8{_}5893{_}428.
10136-8{_}5894{_}INGREDIENTS.--Salt and water, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}5895{_}of bruised ginger, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}5896{_}of whole black pepper, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}5897{_}of whole allspice, 4 cloves, 2 blades of mace, a little horseradish.
10136-8{_}5898{_}This proportion of pepper, spices, &c., for 1 quart of vinegar.
10136-8{_}5899{_}_Mode_.--Let the gherkins remain in salt and water for 3 or 4 days, when take them out, wipe perfectly dry, and put them into a stone jar.
10136-8{_}5900{_}Boil sufficient vinegar to cover them, with spices and pepper, &c., in the above proportion, for 10 minutes; pour it, quite boiling, over the gherkins, cover the jar with vine-leaves, and put over them a plate, setting them near the fire, where they must remain all night.
10136-8{_}5901{_}Next day drain off the vinegar, boil it up again, and pour it hot over them.
10136-8{_}5902{_}Cover up with fresh leaves, and let the whole remain till quite cold.
10136-8{_}5903{_}Now tie down closely with bladder to exclude the air, and in a month or two, they will be fit for use.
10136-8{_}5904{_}_Time_.--4 days.
10136-8{_}5905{_}_Seasonable_ from the middle of July to the end of August.
10136-8{_}5906{_}[Illustration: GHERKINS.]
10136-8{_}5907{_}GHERKINS.--Gherkins are young cucumbers; and the only way in     which they are used for cooking purposes is pickling them, as by     the recipe here given.
10136-8{_}5908{_}Not having arrived at maturity, they have     not, of course, so strongly a developed flavour as cucumbers,     and, as a pickle, they are very general favourites.
10136-8{_}5909{_}GOOSEBERRY SAUCE FOR BOILED MACKEREL.
10136-8{_}5910{_}429.
10136-8{_}5911{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint of green gooseberries, 3 tablespoonfuls of Béchamel, No.
10136-8{_}5912{_}367 (veal gravy may be substituted for this), 2 oz.
10136-8{_}5913{_}of fresh butter; seasoning to taste of salt, pepper, and grated nutmeg.
10136-8{_}5914{_}_Mode_.--Boil the gooseberries in water until quite tender; strain them, and rub them through a sieve.
10136-8{_}5915{_}Put into a saucepan the Béchamel or gravy, with the butter and seasoning; add the pulp from the gooseberries, mix all well together, and heat gradually through.
10136-8{_}5916{_}A little pounded sugar added to this sauce is by many persons considered an improvement, as the saccharine matter takes off the extreme acidity of the unripe fruit.
10136-8{_}5917{_}_Time_.--Boil the gooseberries from 20 minutes to 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}5918{_}_Sufficient_, this quantity, for a large dish of mackerel.
10136-8{_}5919{_}_Seasonable_ from May to July.
10136-8{_}5920{_}[Illustration: THE GOOSEBERRY.]
10136-8{_}5921{_}THE GOOSEBERRY.--This useful and wholesome fruit (_Ribes     grossularia_) is thought to be indigenous to the British Isles,     and may be occasionally found in a wild state in some of the     eastern counties, although, when uncultivated, it is but a very     small and inferior berry.
10136-8{_}5922{_}The high state of perfection to which     it has been here brought, is due to the skill of the English     gardeners; for in no other country does it attain the same size     and flavour.
10136-8{_}5923{_}The humidity of the British climate, however, has     doubtless something to do with the result; and it is said that     gooseberries produced in Scotland as far north as Inverness, are     of a very superior character.
10136-8{_}5924{_}Malic and citric acid blended with     sugar, produce the pleasant flavour of the gooseberry; and upon     the proper development of these properties depends the success     of all cooking operations with which they are connected.
10136-8{_}5925{_}GLAZE FOR COVERING COLD HAMS, TONGUES, &c.  430.
10136-8{_}5926{_}INGREDIENTS.--Stock No.
10136-8{_}5927{_}104 or 107, doubling the quantity of meat in each.
10136-8{_}5928{_}_Mode_.--We may remark at the outset, that unless glaze is wanted in very large quantities, it is seldom made expressly.
10136-8{_}5929{_}Either of the stocks mentioned above, boiled down and reduced very considerably, will be found to produce a very good glaze.
10136-8{_}5930{_}Put the stock into a stewpan, over a nice clear fire; let it boil till it becomes somewhat stiff, when keep stirring, to prevent its burning.
10136-8{_}5931{_}The moment it is sufficiently reduced, and comes to a glaze, turn it out into the glaze-pot, of which we have here given an engraving.
10136-8{_}5932{_}As, however, this is not to be found in every establishment, a white earthenware jar would answer the purpose; and this may be placed in a vessel of boiling water, to melt the glaze when required.
10136-8{_}5933{_}It should never be warmed in a saucepan, except on the principle of the bain marie, lest it should reduce too much, and become black and bitter.
10136-8{_}5934{_}If the glaze is wanted of a pale colour, more veal than beef should be used in making the stock; and it is as well to omit turnips and celery, as these impart a disagreeable bitter flavour.
10136-8{_}5935{_}TO GLAZE COLD JOINTS, &c.--Melt the glaze by placing the vessel which contains it, into the bain marie or saucepan of boiling water; brush it over the meat with a paste-brush, and if in places it is not quite covered, repeat the operation.
10136-8{_}5936{_}The glaze should not be too dark a colour.
10136-8{_}5937{_}(_See_ Coloured Cut of Glazed Ham, P.)  [Illustration: GLAZE-KETTLE.]
10136-8{_}5938{_}[Illustration: THE BAIN MARIE.]
10136-8{_}5939{_}GLAZE-KETTLE.--This is a kettle used for keeping the strong     stock boiled down to a jelly, which is known by the name of     glaze.
10136-8{_}5940{_}It is composed of two tin vessels, as shown in the cut,     one of which, the upper,--containing the glaze, is inserted into     one of larger diameter and containing boiling water.
10136-8{_}5941{_}A brush is     put in the small hole at the top of the lid, and is employed for     putting the glaze on anything that may require it.
10136-8{_}5942{_}THE BAIN MARIE.--So long ago as the time when emperors ruled in     Rome, and the yellow Tiber passed through a populous and wealthy     city, this utensil was extensively employed; and it is     frequently mentioned by that profound culinary chemist of the     ancients, Apicius.
10136-8{_}5943{_}It is an open kind of vessel (as shown in the     engraving and explained in our paragraph No.
10136-8{_}5944{_}87, on the French     terms used in modern cookery), filled with boiling or nearly     boiling water; and into this water should be put all the     stewpans containing those ingredients which it is desired to     keep hot.
10136-8{_}5945{_}The quantity and quality of the contents of these     vessels are not at all affected; and if the hour of dinner is     uncertain in any establishment, by reason of the nature of the     master's business, nothing is so certain a means of preserving     the flavour of all dishes as the employment of the bain marie.
10136-8{_}5946{_}GREEN SAUCE FOR GREEN GEESE OR DUCKLINGS.
10136-8{_}5947{_}431.
10136-8{_}5948{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 pint of sorrel-juice, 1 glass of sherry, 1/2 pint of green gooseberries, 1 teaspoonful of pounded sugar, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}5949{_}of fresh butter.
10136-8{_}5950{_}_Mode_.--Boil the gooseberries in water until they are quite tender; mash them and press them through a sieve; put the pulp into a saucepan with the above ingredients; simmer for 3 or 4 minutes, and serve very hot.
10136-8{_}5951{_}_Time_.--3 or 4 minutes.
10136-8{_}5952{_}_Note_.--We have given this recipe as a sauce for green geese, thinking that some of our readers might sometimes require it; but, at the generality of fashionable tables, it is now seldom or never served.
10136-8{_}5953{_}[Illustration: SORREL.]
10136-8{_}5954{_}SORREL.--We gather from the pages of Pliny and Apicius, that     sorrel was cultivated by the Romans in order to give it more     strength and flavour, and that they also partook of it sometimes     stewed with mustard, being seasoned with a little oil and     vinegar.
10136-8{_}5955{_}At the present day, English cookery is not much     indebted to this plant (_Rumex Acetosa_), although the French     make use of it to a considerable extent.
10136-8{_}5956{_}It is found in most     parts of Great Britain, and also on the continent, growing wild     in the grass meadows, and, in a few gardens, it is cultivated.
10136-8{_}5957{_}The acid of sorrel is very _prononcé_, and is what chemists term     a binoxalate of potash; that is, a combination of oxalic acid     with potash.
10136-8{_}5958{_}GENERAL STOCK FOR GRAVIES.
10136-8{_}5959{_}432.
10136-8{_}5960{_}Either of the stocks, Nos.
10136-8{_}5961{_}104, 105, or 107, will be found to answer very well for the basis of many gravies, unless these are wanted very rich indeed.
10136-8{_}5962{_}By the addition of various store sauces, thickening and flavouring, the stocks here referred to may be converted into very good gravies.
10136-8{_}5963{_}It should be borne in mind, however, that the goodness and strength of spices, wines, flavourings, &c., evaporate, and that they lose a great deal of their fragrance, if added to the gravy a long time before they are wanted.
10136-8{_}5964{_}If this point is attended to, a saving of one half the quantity of these ingredients will be effected, as, with long boiling, the flavour almost entirely passes away.
10136-8{_}5965{_}The shank-bones of mutton, previously well soaked, will be found a great assistance in enriching gravies; a kidney or melt, beef skirt, trimmings of meat, &c. &c., answer very well when only a small quantity is wanted, and, as we have before observed, a good gravy need not necessarily be so very expensive; for economically-prepared dishes are oftentimes found as savoury and wholesome as dearer ones.
10136-8{_}5966{_}The cook should also remember that the fragrance of gravies should not be overpowered by too much spice, or any strong essences, and that they should always be warmed in a _bain marie_, after they are flavoured, or else in a jar or jug placed in a saucepan full of boiling water.
10136-8{_}5967{_}The remains of roast-meat gravy should always be saved; as, when no meat is at hand, a very nice gravy in haste may be made from it, and when added to hashes, ragoûts, &c., is a great improvement.
10136-8{_}5968{_}[Illustration: GRAVY-KETTLE.]
10136-8{_}5969{_}GRAVY-KETTLE.--This is a utensil which will not be found in     every kitchen; but it is a useful one where it is necessary to     keep gravies hot for the purpose of pouring over various dishes     as they are cooking.
10136-8{_}5970{_}It is made of copper, and should,     consequently, be heated over the hot plate, if there be one, or     a charcoal stove.
10136-8{_}5971{_}The price at which it can be purchased is set     down by Messrs.
10136-8{_}5972{_}Slack at 14s.
10136-8{_}5973{_}GRAVY FOR ROAST MEAT.
10136-8{_}5974{_}433.
10136-8{_}5975{_}INGREDIENTS.--Gravy, salt.
10136-8{_}5976{_}_Mode_.--Put a common dish with a small quantity of salt in it under the meat, about a quarter of an hour before it is removed from the fire.
10136-8{_}5977{_}When the dish is full, take it away, baste the meat, and pour the gravy into the dish on which the joint is to be served.
10136-8{_}5978{_}SAUCES AND GRAVIES IN THE MIDDLE AGES.--Neither poultry,     butcher's meat, nor roast game were eaten dry in the middle     ages, any more than fried fish is now.
10136-8{_}5979{_}Different sauces, each     having its own peculiar flavour, were served with all these     dishes, and even with the various _parts_ of each animal.
10136-8{_}5980{_}Strange and grotesque sauces, as, for example, "eggs cooked on     the spit," "butter fried and roasted," were invented by the     cooks of those days; but these preparations had hardly any other     merit than that of being surprising and difficult to make.
10136-8{_}5981{_}A QUICKLY-MADE GRAVY.
10136-8{_}5982{_}434.
10136-8{_}5983{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}5984{_}of shin of beef, 1/2 onion, 1/4 carrot, 2 or 3 sprigs of parsley and savoury herbs, a piece of butter about the size of a walnut; cayenne and mace to taste, 3/4 pint of water.
10136-8{_}5985{_}_Mode_.--Cut up the meat into very small pieces, slice the onion and carrot, and put them into a small saucepan with the butter.
10136-8{_}5986{_}Keep stirring over a sharp fire until they have taken a little colour, when add the water and the remaining ingredients.
10136-8{_}5987{_}Simmer for 1/2 hour, skim well, strain, and flavour, when it will be ready for use.
10136-8{_}5988{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}5989{_}_Average cost_, for this quantity, 5d.
10136-8{_}5990{_}A HUNDRED DIFFERENT DISHES.--Modern housewives know pretty well     how much care, and attention, and foresight are necessary in     order to serve well a little dinner for six or eight persons,--a     dinner which will give credit to the _ménage_, and satisfaction     and pleasure to the guests.
10136-8{_}5991{_}A quickly-made gravy, under some     circumstances that we have known occur, will be useful to many     housekeepers when they have not much time for preparation.
10136-8{_}5992{_}But,     talking of speed, and time, and preparation, what a combination     of all these must have been necessary for the feast at the     wedding of Charles VI.
10136-8{_}5993{_}of France.
10136-8{_}5994{_}On that occasion, as Froissart     the chronicler tells us, the art of cooking, with its     innumerable paraphernalia of sauces, with gravy, pepper,     cinnamon, garlic, scallion, brains, gravy soups, milk _potage_,     and ragoûts, had a signal triumph.
10136-8{_}5995{_}The skilful _chef-de-cuisine_     of the royal household covered the great marble table of the     regal palace with no less than a hundred different dishes,     prepared in a hundred different ways.
10136-8{_}5996{_}A GOOD BEEF GRAVY FOR POULTRY, GAME, &c.  435.
10136-8{_}5997{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}5998{_}of lean beef, 1/2 pint of cold water, 1 shalot or small onion, 1/2 a teaspoonful of salt, a little pepper, 1 tablespoonful of Harvey's sauce or mushroom ketchup, 1/2 a teaspoonful of arrowroot.
10136-8{_}5999{_}_Mode_.--Cut up the beef into small pieces, and put it, with the water, into a stewpan.
10136-8{_}6000{_}Add the shalot and seasoning, and simmer gently for 3 hours, taking care that it does not boil fast.
10136-8{_}6001{_}A short time before it is required, take the arrowroot, and having mixed it with a little cold water, pour it into the gravy, which keep stirring, adding the Harvey's sauce, and just letting it boil.
10136-8{_}6002{_}Strain off the gravy in a tureen, and serve very hot.
10136-8{_}6003{_}_Time_.--3 hours.
10136-8{_}6004{_}_Average cost_, 8d.
10136-8{_}6005{_}per pint.
10136-8{_}6006{_}BROWN GRAVY.
10136-8{_}6007{_}436.
10136-8{_}6008{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 oz.
10136-8{_}6009{_}of butter, 2 large onions, 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}6010{_}of shin of beef, 2 small slices of lean bacon (if at hand), salt and whole pepper to taste, 3 cloves, 2 quarts of water.
10136-8{_}6011{_}For thickening, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}6012{_}of butter, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}6013{_}of flour.
10136-8{_}6014{_}_Mode_.--Put the butter into a stewpan; set this on the fire, throw in the onions cut in rings, and fry them a light brown; then add the beef and bacon, which should be cut into small square pieces; season, and pour in a teacupful of water; let it boil for about ten minutes, or until it is of a nice brown colour, occasionally stirring the contents.
10136-8{_}6015{_}Now fill up with water in the above proportion; let it boil up, when draw it to the side of the fire to simmer very gently for 1-1/2 hour; strain, and when cold, take off all the fat.
10136-8{_}6016{_}In thickening this gravy, melt 3 oz.
10136-8{_}6017{_}of butter in a stewpan, add 2 oz.
10136-8{_}6018{_}of flour, and stir till of a light-brown colour; when cold, add it to the strained gravy, and boil it up quickly.
10136-8{_}6019{_}This thickening may be made in larger quantities, and kept in a stone jar for use when wanted.
10136-8{_}6020{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 2 hours.
10136-8{_}6021{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}6022{_}per pint.
10136-8{_}6023{_}CLOVES.--This very agreeable spice is the unexpanded flower-buds     of the _Caryophyllus aromaticus_, a handsome, branching tree, a     native of the Malacca Islands.
10136-8{_}6024{_}They take their name from the     Latin word _clavus_, or the French _clou_, both meaning a nail,     and to which the clove has a considerable resemblance.
10136-8{_}6025{_}Cloves     were but little known to the ancients, and Pliny appears to be     the only writer who mentions them; and he says, vaguely enough,     that some were brought to Rome, very similar to grains of     pepper, but somewhat longer; that they were only to be found in     India, in a wood consecrated to the gods; and that they served     in the manufacture of perfumes.
10136-8{_}6026{_}The Dutch, as in the case of the     nutmeg (_see_ 378), endeavoured, when they gained possession of     the Spice Islands, to secure a monopoly of cloves, and, so that     the cultivation of the tree might be confined to Amboyna, their     chief island, bribed the surrounding chiefs to cut down all     trees found elsewhere.
10136-8{_}6027{_}The Amboyna, or royal clove, is said to     be the best, and is rare; but other kinds, nearly equally good,     are produced in other parts of the world, and they come to     Europe from Mauritius, Bourbon, Cayenne, and Martinique, as also     from St. Kitts, St. Vincent's, and Trinidad.
10136-8{_}6028{_}The clove contains     about 20 per cent.
10136-8{_}6029{_}of volatile aromatic oil, to which it owes     its peculiar pungent flavour, its other parts being composed of     woody fibre, water, gum, and resin.
10136-8{_}6030{_}BROWN GRAVY WITHOUT MEAT.
10136-8{_}6031{_}437.
10136-8{_}6032{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 large onions, 1 large carrot, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}6033{_}of butter, 3 pints of boiling water, 1 bunch of savoury herbs, a wineglassful of good beer; salt and pepper to taste.
10136-8{_}6034{_}_Mode_.--Slice, flour, and fry the onions and carrots in the butter until of a nice light-brown colour; then add the boiling water and the remaining ingredients; let the whole stew gently for about an hour; then strain, and when cold, skim off all the fat.
10136-8{_}6035{_}Thicken it in the same manner as recipe No.
10136-8{_}6036{_}436, and, if thought necessary, add a few drops of colouring No.
10136-8{_}6037{_}108.
10136-8{_}6038{_}_Time_.--1 hour.
10136-8{_}6039{_}Average cost, 2d.
10136-8{_}6040{_}per pint.
10136-8{_}6041{_}_Note_.--The addition of a small quantity of mushroom ketchup or Harvey's sauce very much improves the flavour of this gravy.
10136-8{_}6042{_}RICH GRAVY FOR HASHES, RAGOUTS, &c.  438.
10136-8{_}6043{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 lbs.
10136-8{_}6044{_}of shin of beef, 1 large onion or a few shalots, a little flour, a bunch of savoury herbs, 2 blades of mace, 2 or 3 cloves, 4 whole allspice, 1/4 teaspoonful of whole pepper, 1 slice of lean ham or bacon, 1/2 a head of celery (when at hand), 2 pints of boiling water; salt and cayenne to taste.
10136-8{_}6045{_}_Mode_.--Cut the beef into thin slices, as also the onions, dredge them with flour, and fry of a pale brown, but do not allow them to get black; pour in the boiling water, let it boil up; and skim.
10136-8{_}6046{_}Add the remaining ingredients, and simmer the whole very gently for 2 hours, or until all the juices are extracted from the meat; put it by to get cold, when take off all the fat.
10136-8{_}6047{_}This gravy may be flavoured with ketchup, store sauces, wine, or, in fact, anything that may give additional and suitable relish to the dish it is intended for.
10136-8{_}6048{_}_Time_.--Rather more than 2 hours.
10136-8{_}6049{_}_Average cost_, 8d.
10136-8{_}6050{_}per pint.
10136-8{_}6051{_}[Illustration: PIMENTO.]
10136-8{_}6052{_}ALLSPICE.--This is the popular name given to pimento, or Jamaica     pepper, known to naturalists as _Eugenia pimenta_, and belonging     to the order of Myrtaceae.
10136-8{_}6053{_}It is the berry of a fine tree in the     West Indies and South America, which attains a height of from     fifteen to twenty feet: the berries are not allowed to ripen,     but, being gathered green, are then dried in the sun, and then     become black.
10136-8{_}6054{_}It is an inexpensive spice, and is considered more     mild and innocent than most other spices; consequently, it is     much used for domestic purposes, combining a very agreeable     variety of flavours.
10136-8{_}6055{_}GRAVY MADE WITHOUT MEAT FOR FOWLS.
10136-8{_}6056{_}439.
10136-8{_}6057{_}INGREDIENTS.--The necks, feet, livers, and gizzards of the fowls, 1 slice of toasted bread, 1/2 onion, 1 faggot of savoury herbs, salt and pepper to taste, 1/2 pint of water, thickening of butter and flour, 1 dessertspoonful of ketchup.
10136-8{_}6058{_}_Mode_.--Wash the feet of the fowls thoroughly clean, and cut them and the neck into small pieces.
10136-8{_}6059{_}Put these into a stewpan with the bread, onion, herbs, seasoning, livers, and gizzards; pour the water over them and simmer gently for 1 hour.
10136-8{_}6060{_}Now take out the liver, pound it, and strain the liquor to it.
10136-8{_}6061{_}Add a thickening of butter and flour, and a flavouring of mushroom ketchup; boil it up and serve.
10136-8{_}6062{_}_Time_.--1 hour.
10136-8{_}6063{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}6064{_}per pint.
10136-8{_}6065{_}A CHEAP GRAVY FOR HASHES, &c.  440.
10136-8{_}6066{_}INGREDIENTS.--Bones and trimmings of the cooked joint intended for hashing, 1/4 teaspoonful of salt, 1/4 teaspoonful of whole pepper, 1/4 teaspoonful of whole allspice, a small faggot of savoury herbs, 1/2 head of celery, 1 onion, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}6067{_}of butter, thickening, sufficient boiling water to cover the bones.
10136-8{_}6068{_}_Mode_.--Chop the bones in small pieces, and put them in a stewpan, with the trimmings, salt, pepper, spice, herbs, and celery.
10136-8{_}6069{_}Cover with boiling water, and let the whole simmer gently for 1-1/2 or 2 hours.
10136-8{_}6070{_}Slice and fry the onion in the butter till it is of a pale brown, and mix it gradually with the gravy made from the bones; boil for  1/4 hour, and strain into a basin; now put it back into the stewpan; flavour with walnut pickle or ketchup, pickled-onion liquor, or any store sauce that may be preferred.
10136-8{_}6071{_}Thicken with a little butter and flour, kneaded together on a plate, and the gravy will be ready for use.
10136-8{_}6072{_}After the thickening is added, the gravy should just boil, to take off the rawness of the flour.
10136-8{_}6073{_}_Time_.--2 hours, or rather more.
10136-8{_}6074{_}_Average cost_, 4d., exclusive of the bones and trimmings.
10136-8{_}6075{_}JUGGED GRAVY (Excellent).
10136-8{_}6076{_}441.
10136-8{_}6077{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 lbs.
10136-8{_}6078{_}of shin of beef, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}6079{_}of lean ham, 1 onion or a few shalots, 2 pints of water, salt and whole pepper to taste, 1 blade of mace, a faggot of savoury herbs, 1/2 a large carrot, 1/2 a head of celery.
10136-8{_}6080{_}_Mode_.--Cut up the beef and ham into small pieces, and slice the vegetables; take a jar, capable of holding two pints of water, and arrange therein, in layers, the ham, meat, vegetables, and seasoning, alternately, filling up with the above quantity of water; tie down the jar, or put a plate over the top, so that the steam may not escape; place it in the oven, and let it remain there from 6 to 8 hours; should, however, the oven be very hot, less time will be required.
10136-8{_}6081{_}When sufficiently cooked, strain the gravy, and when cold, remove the fat.
10136-8{_}6082{_}It may be flavoured with ketchup, wines, or any other store sauce that may be preferred.
10136-8{_}6083{_}It is a good plan to put the jar in a cool oven over-night, to draw the gravy; and then it will not require so long baking the following day.
10136-8{_}6084{_}_Time_.--From 6 to 8 hours, according to the oven.
10136-8{_}6085{_}_Average cost_, 7d.
10136-8{_}6086{_}per pint.
10136-8{_}6087{_}[Illustration: CELERY.]
10136-8{_}6088{_}CELERY.--As in the above recipe, the roots of celery are     principally used in England for flavouring soups, sauces, and     gravies, and for serving with cheese at the termination of a     dinner, and as an ingredient for salad.
10136-8{_}6089{_}In Italy, however, the     green leaves and stems are also employed for stews and soups,     and the seeds are also more frequently made use of on the     continent than in our own islands.
10136-8{_}6090{_}In Germany, celery is very     highly esteemed; and it is there boiled and served up as a dish     by itself, as well as used in the composition of mixed dishes.
10136-8{_}6091{_}We ourselves think that this mild aromatic plant might oftener     be cooked than it is; for there are very few nicer vegetable     preparations brought to table than a well-dressed plate of     stewed celery.
10136-8{_}6092{_}VEAL GRAVY FOR WHITE SAUCES, FRICASSEES, &c.  442.
10136-8{_}6093{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 slices of nicely flavoured lean ham, any poultry trimmings, 3 lbs.
10136-8{_}6094{_}of lean veal, a faggot of savoury herbs, including parsley, a few green onions (or 1 large onion may be substituted for these), a few mushrooms, when obtainable; 1 blade of mace, salt to taste, 3 pints of water.
10136-8{_}6095{_}_Mode_.--Cut up the ham and veal into small square pieces, put these in a stewpan, moistening them with a small quantity of water; place them over the fire to draw down.
10136-8{_}6096{_}When the bottom of the stewpan becomes covered with a white glaze, fill up with water in the above proportion; add the remaining ingredients, stew very slowly for 3 or 4 hours, and do not forget to skim well the moment it boils.
10136-8{_}6097{_}Put it by, and, when cold, take off all the fat.
10136-8{_}6098{_}This may be used for Béchamel, sauce tournée, and many other white sauces.
10136-8{_}6099{_}_Time_.--3 or 4 hours.
10136-8{_}6100{_}_Average cost_, 9d.
10136-8{_}6101{_}per pint.
10136-8{_}6102{_}CHEAP GRAVY FOR MINCED VEAL.
10136-8{_}6103{_}443.
10136-8{_}6104{_}INGREDIENTS.--Bones and trimmings of cold roast or boiled veal, 1-1/2 pint of water, 1 onion, 1/4 teaspoonful of minced lemon-peel, 1/4 teaspoonful of salt, 1 blade of pounded mace, the juice of 1/4 lemon; thickening of butter and flour.
10136-8{_}6105{_}_Mode_.--Put all the ingredients into a stewpan, except the thickening and lemon-juice, and let them simmer very gently for rather more than 1 hour, or until the liquor is reduced to a pint, when strain through a hair-sieve.
10136-8{_}6106{_}Add a thickening of butter and flour, and the lemon-juice; set it on the fire, and let it just boil up, when it will be ready for use.
10136-8{_}6107{_}It may be flavoured with a little tomato sauce, and, where a rather dark-coloured gravy is not objected to, ketchup, or Harvey's sauce, may be added at pleasure.
10136-8{_}6108{_}_Time_.--Rather more than 1 hour.
10136-8{_}6109{_}_Average cost_, 3d.
10136-8{_}6110{_}GRAVY FOR VENISON.
10136-8{_}6111{_}444.
10136-8{_}6112{_}INGREDIENTS.--Trimmings of venison, 3 or 4 mutton shank-bones, salt to taste, 1 pint of water, 2 teaspoonfuls of walnut ketchup.
10136-8{_}6113{_}_Mode_.--Brown the trimmings over a nice clear fire, and put them in a stewpan with the shank-bones and water; simmer gently for 2 hours, strain and skim, and add the walnut ketchup and a seasoning of salt.
10136-8{_}6114{_}Let it just boil, when it is ready to serve.
10136-8{_}6115{_}_Time_.--2 hours.
10136-8{_}6116{_}[Illustration: THE DEER.]
10136-8{_}6117{_}VENISON.--Far, far away in ages past, our fathers loved the     chase, and what it brought; and it is usually imagined that when     Isaac ordered his son Esau to go out with his weapons, his     quiver and his bow, and to prepare for him savoury meat, such as     he loved, that it was venison he desired.
10136-8{_}6118{_}The wise Solomon, too,     delighted in this kind of fare; for we learn that, at his table,     every day were served the wild ox, the roebuck, and the stag.
10136-8{_}6119{_}Xenophon informs us, in his History, that Cyrus, king of Persia,     ordered that venison should never be wanting at his repasts; and     of the effeminate Greeks it was the delight.
10136-8{_}6120{_}The Romans, also,     were devoted admirers of the flesh of the deer; and our own     kings and princes, from the Great Alfred down to the Prince     Consort, have hunted, although, it must be confessed, under     vastly different circumstances, the swift buck, and relished     their "haunch" all the more keenly, that they had borne     themselves bravely in the pursuit of the animal.
10136-8{_}6121{_}TO DRY HERBS FOR WINTER USE.
10136-8{_}6122{_}445.
10136-8{_}6123{_}On a very dry day, gather the herbs, just before they begin to flower.
10136-8{_}6124{_}If this is done when the weather is damp, the herbs will not be so good a colour.
10136-8{_}6125{_}(It is very necessary to be particular in little matters like this, for trifles constitute perfection, and herbs nicely dried will be found very acceptable when frost and snow are on the ground.
10136-8{_}6126{_}It is hardly necessary, however, to state that the flavour and fragrance of fresh herbs are incomparably finer.)
10136-8{_}6127{_}They should be perfectly freed from dirt and dust, and be divided into small bunches, with their roots cut off.
10136-8{_}6128{_}Dry them quickly in a very hot oven, or before the fire, as by this means most of their flavour will be preserved, and be careful not to burn them; tie them up in paper bags, and keep in a dry place.
10136-8{_}6129{_}This is a very general way of preserving dried herbs; but we would recommend the plan described in a former recipe.
10136-8{_}6130{_}_Seasonable_.--From the month of July to the end of September is the proper time for storing herbs for winter use.
10136-8{_}6131{_}HERB POWDER FOR FLAVOURING, when Fresh Herbs are not obtainable.
10136-8{_}6132{_}446.
10136-8{_}6133{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 oz.
10136-8{_}6134{_}of dried lemon-thyme, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}6135{_}of dried winter savory, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}6136{_}of dried sweet marjoram and basil, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}6137{_}of dried parsley, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}6138{_}of dried lemon-peel.
10136-8{_}6139{_}_Mode_.--Prepare and dry the herbs by recipe No.
10136-8{_}6140{_}445; pick the leaves from the stalks, pound them, and sift them through a hair-sieve; mix in the above proportions, and keep in glass bottles, carefully excluding the air.
10136-8{_}6141{_}This, we think, a far better method of keeping herbs, as the flavour and fragrance do not evaporate so much as when they are merely put in paper bags.
10136-8{_}6142{_}Preparing them in this way, you have them ready for use at a moment's notice.
10136-8{_}6143{_}Mint, sage, parsley, &c., dried, pounded, and each put into separate bottles, will be found very useful in winter.
10136-8{_}6144{_}[Illustration: CORK WITH WOODEN TOP.]
10136-8{_}6145{_}CORKS WITH WOODEN TOPS.--These are the best corks to use when it     is indispensable that the air should not be admitted to the     ingredients contained in bottles which are in constant use.
10136-8{_}6146{_}The     top, which, as will be seen by the accompanying little cut, is     larger than the cork, is made of wood; and, besides effectually     covering the whole top of the bottle, can be easily removed and     again used, as no corkscrew is necessary to pull it out.
10136-8{_}6147{_}SAVORY.--This we find described by Columella, a voluminous Roman     writer on agriculture, as an odoriferous herb, which, "in the     brave days of old," entered into the seasoning of nearly every     dish.
10136-8{_}6148{_}Verily, there are but few new things under the sun, and we     don't find that we have made many discoveries in gastronomy, at     least beyond what was known to the ancient inhabitants of Italy.
10136-8{_}6149{_}We possess two varieties of this aromatic herb, known to     naturalists as _Satureja_.
10136-8{_}6150{_}They are called summer and winter     savory, according to the time of the year when they are fit for     gathering.
10136-8{_}6151{_}Both sorts are in general cultivation throughout     England.
10136-8{_}6152{_}HORSERADISH SAUCE, to serve with Roast Beef.
10136-8{_}6153{_}447.
10136-8{_}6154{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 tablespoonfuls of grated horseradish, 1 teaspoonful of pounded sugar, 1 teaspoonful of salt, 1/2 teaspoonful of pepper, 2 teaspoonfuls of made mustard; vinegar.
10136-8{_}6155{_}_Mode_.--Grate the horseradish, and mix it well with the sugar, salt, pepper, and mustard; moisten it with sufficient vinegar to give it the consistency of cream, and serve in a tureen: 3 or 4 tablespoonfuls of cream added to the above, very much improve the appearance and flavour of this sauce.
10136-8{_}6156{_}To heat it to serve with hot roast beef, put it in a bain marie or a jar, which place in a saucepan of boiling water; make it hot, but do not allow it to boil, or it will curdle.
10136-8{_}6157{_}_Note_.--This sauce is a great improvement on the old-fashioned way of serving cold-scraped horseradish with hot roast beef.
10136-8{_}6158{_}The mixing of the cold vinegar with the warm gravy cools and spoils everything on the plate.
10136-8{_}6159{_}Of course, with cold meat, the sauce should be served cold.
10136-8{_}6160{_}[Illustration: THE HORSERADISH.]
10136-8{_}6161{_}THE HORSERADISH.--This has been, for many years, a favourite     accompaniment of roast beef, and is a native of England.
10136-8{_}6162{_}It     grows wild in wet ground, but has long been cultivated in the     garden, and is, occasionally, used in winter salads and in     sauces.
10136-8{_}6163{_}On account of the great volatility of its oil, it should     never be preserved by drying, but should be kept moist by being     buried in sand.
10136-8{_}6164{_}So rapidly does its volatile oil evaporate, that     even when scraped for the table, it almost immediately spoils by     exposure to the air.
10136-8{_}6165{_}HORSERADISH VINEGAR.
10136-8{_}6166{_}448.
10136-8{_}6167{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}6168{_}of scraped horseradish, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}6169{_}of minced shalot, 1 drachm of cayenne, 1 quart of vinegar.
10136-8{_}6170{_}_Mode_.--Put all the ingredients into a bottle, which shake well every day for a fortnight.
10136-8{_}6171{_}When it is thoroughly steeped, strain and bottle, and it will be fit for use immediately.
10136-8{_}6172{_}This will be found an agreeable relish to cold beef, &c.
10136-8{_}6173{_}_Seasonable_.--This vinegar should be made either in October or November, as horseradish is then in its highest perfection.
10136-8{_}6174{_}INDIAN CURRY-POWDER, founded on Dr. Kitchener's Recipe.
10136-8{_}6175{_}449.
10136-8{_}6176{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}6177{_}of coriander-seed, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}6178{_}of turmeric, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}6179{_}of cinnamon-seed, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}6180{_}of cayenne, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}6181{_}of mustard, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}6182{_}of ground ginger, 1/2 ounce of allspice, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}6183{_}of fenugreek-seed.
10136-8{_}6184{_}_Mode_.--Put all the ingredients in a cool oven, where they should remain one night; then pound them in a mortar, rub them through a sieve, and mix thoroughly together; keep the powder in a bottle, from which the air should be completely excluded.
10136-8{_}6185{_}_Note_.--We have given this recipe for curry-powder, as some persons prefer to make it at home; but that purchased at any respectable shop is, generally speaking, far superior, and, taking all things into consideration, very frequently more economical.
10136-8{_}6186{_}INDIAN MUSTARD, an excellent Relish to Bread and Butter, or any cold Meat.
10136-8{_}6187{_}450.
10136-8{_}6188{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}6189{_}of the best mustard, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}6190{_}of flour, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}6191{_}of salt, 4 shalots, 4 tablespoonfuls of vinegar, 4 tablespoonfuls of ketchup, 1/4 bottle of anchovy sauce.
10136-8{_}6192{_}_Mode_.--Put the mustard, flour, and salt into a basin, and make them into a stiff paste with boiling water.
10136-8{_}6193{_}Boil the shalots with the vinegar, ketchup, and anchovy sauce, for 10 minutes, and pour the whole, _boiling_, over the mixture in the basin; stir well, and reduce it to a proper thickness; put it into a bottle, with a bruised shalot at the bottom, and store away for use.
10136-8{_}6194{_}This makes an excellent relish, and if properly prepared will keep for years.
10136-8{_}6195{_}[Illustration: MUSTARD.]
10136-8{_}6196{_}MUSTARD.--Before the year 1729, mustard was not known at English     tables.
10136-8{_}6197{_}About that time an old woman, of the name of Clements,     residing in Durham, began to grind the seed in a mill, and to     pass the flour through several processes necessary to free the     seed from its husks.
10136-8{_}6198{_}She kept her secret for many years to     herself, during which she sold large quantities of mustard     throughout the country, but especially in London.
10136-8{_}6199{_}Here it was     introduced to the royal table, when it received the approval of     George I.
10136-8{_}6200{_}From the circumstance of Mrs. Clements being a     resident at Durham, it obtained the name of Durham mustard.
10136-8{_}6201{_}In     the county of that name it is still principally cultivated, and     the plant is remarkable for the rapidity of its growth.
10136-8{_}6202{_}It is     the best stimulant employed to impart strength to the digestive     organs, and even in its previously coarsely-pounded state, had a     high reputation with our ancestors.
10136-8{_}6203{_}INDIAN PICKLE (very Superior).
10136-8{_}6204{_}451.
10136-8{_}6205{_}INGREDIENTS.--To each gallon of vinegar allow 6 cloves of garlic, 12 shalots, 2 sticks of sliced horseradish, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}6206{_}of bruised ginger, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}6207{_}of whole black pepper, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}6208{_}of long pepper, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}6209{_}of allspice, 12 cloves, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}6210{_}of cayenne, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}6211{_}of mustard-seed, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}6212{_}of mustard, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}6213{_}of turmeric; a white cabbage, cauliflowers, radish-pods, French beans, gherkins, small round pickling-onions, nasturtiums, capsicums, chilies, &c.
10136-8{_}6214{_}_Mode_.--Cut the cabbage, which must be hard and white, into slices, and the cauliflowers into small branches; sprinkle salt over them in a large dish, and let them remain two days; then dry them, and put them into a very large jar, with garlic, shalots, horseradish, ginger, pepper, allspice, and cloves, in the above proportions.
10136-8{_}6215{_}Boil sufficient vinegar to cover them, which pour over, and, when cold, cover up to keep them free from dust.
10136-8{_}6216{_}As the other things for the pickle ripen at different times, they may be added as they are ready: these will be radish-pods, French beans, gherkins, small onions, nasturtiums, capsicums, chilies, &c. &c. As these are procured, they must, first of all, be washed in a little cold vinegar, wiped, and then simply added to the other ingredients in the large jar, only taking care that they are _covered_ by the vinegar.
10136-8{_}6217{_}If more vinegar should be wanted to add to the pickle, do not omit first to boil it before adding it to the rest.
10136-8{_}6218{_}When you have collected all the things you require, turn all out in a large pan, and thoroughly mix them.
10136-8{_}6219{_}Now put the mixed vegetables into smaller jars, without any of the vinegar; then boil the vinegar again, adding as much more as will be required to fill the different jars, and also cayenne, mustard-seed, turmeric, and mustard, which must be well mixed with a little cold vinegar, allowing the quantities named above to each gallon of vinegar.
10136-8{_}6220{_}Pour the vinegar, boiling hot, over the pickle, and when cold, tie down with a bladder.
10136-8{_}6221{_}If the pickle is wanted for immediate use, the vinegar should be boiled twice more, but the better way is to make it during one season for use during the next.
10136-8{_}6222{_}It will keep for years, if care is taken that the vegetables are quite covered by the vinegar.
10136-8{_}6223{_}This recipe was taken from the directions of a lady whose pickle was always pronounced excellent by all who tasted it, and who has, for many years, exactly followed the recipe given above.
10136-8{_}6224{_}__Note_.--For small families, perhaps the above quantity of pickle will be considered too large; but this may be decreased at pleasure, taking care to properly proportion the various ingredients.
10136-8{_}6225{_}[Illustration: INDIA PICKLE.]
10136-8{_}6226{_}KEEPING PICKLES.--Nothing shows more, perhaps, the difference     between a tidy thrifty housewife and a lady to whom these     desirable epithets may not honestly be applied, than the     appearance of their respective store-closets.
10136-8{_}6227{_}The former is     able, the moment anything; is wanted, to put her hand on it at     once; no time is lost, no vexation incurred, no dish spoilt for     the want of "just little something,"--the latter, on the     contrary, hunts all over her cupboard for the ketchup the cook     requires, or the pickle the husband thinks he should like a     little of with his cold roast beef or mutton-chop, and vainly     seeks for the Embden groats, or arrowroot, to make one of her     little boys some gruel.
10136-8{_}6228{_}One plan, then, we strenuously advise     all who do not follow, to begin at once, and that is, to label     all their various pickles and store sauces, in the same way as     the cut here shows.
10136-8{_}6229{_}It will occupy a little time at first, but     there will be economy of it in the long run.
10136-8{_}6230{_}VINEGAR.--This term is derived from the two French words _vin     aigre_, 'sour wine,' and should, therefore, be strictly applied     to that which is made only from wine.
10136-8{_}6231{_}As the acid is the same,     however it is procured, that made from ale also takes the same     name.
10136-8{_}6232{_}Nearly all ancient nations were acquainted with the use of     vinegar.
10136-8{_}6233{_}We learn in _Ruth_, that the reapers in the East soaked     their bread in it to freshen it.
10136-8{_}6234{_}The Romans kept large     quantities of it in their cellars, using it, to a great extent,     in their seasonings and sauces.
10136-8{_}6235{_}This people attributed very     beneficial qualities to it, as it was supposed to be digestive,     antibilious, and antiscorbutic, as well as refreshing.
10136-8{_}6236{_}Spartianus, a Latin historian, tells us that, mixed with water,     it was the drink of the soldiers, and that, thanks to this     beverage, the veterans of the Roman army braved, by its use, the     inclemency and variety of all the different seasons and climates     of Europe, Asia, and Africa.
10136-8{_}6237{_}It is said, the Spanish peasantry,     and other inhabitants of the southern parts of Europe, still     follow this practice, and add to a gallon of water about a gill     of wine vinegar, with a little salt; and that this drink, with a     little bread, enables them, under the heat of their burning sun,     to sustain the labours of the field.
10136-8{_}6238{_}INDIAN CHETNEY SAUCE.
10136-8{_}6239{_}452.
10136-8{_}6240{_}INGREDIENTS.--8 oz.
10136-8{_}6241{_}of sharp, sour apples, pared and cored; 8 oz.
10136-8{_}6242{_}of tomatoes, 8 oz.
10136-8{_}6243{_}of salt, 8 oz.
10136-8{_}6244{_}of brown, sugar, 8 oz.
10136-8{_}6245{_}of stoned raisins, 4 oz.
10136-8{_}6246{_}of cayenne, 4 oz.
10136-8{_}6247{_}of powdered ginger, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}6248{_}of garlic, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}6249{_}of shalots, 3 quarts of vinegar, 1 quart of lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}6250{_}_Mode_.--Chop the apples in small square pieces, and add to them the other ingredients.
10136-8{_}6251{_}Mix the whole well together, and put in a well-covered jar.
10136-8{_}6252{_}Keep this in a warm place, and stir every day for a month, taking care to put on the lid after this operation; strain, but do not squeeze it dry; store it away in clean jars or bottles for use, and the liquor will serve as an excellent sauce for meat or fish.
10136-8{_}6253{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this sauce when tomatoes are in full season, that is, from the beginning of September to the end of October.
10136-8{_}6254{_}PICKLES.--The ancient Greeks and Romans held their pickles in     high estimation.
10136-8{_}6255{_}They consisted of flowers, herbs, roots, and     vegetables, preserved in vinegar, and which were kept, for a     long time, in cylindrical vases with wide mouths.
10136-8{_}6256{_}Their cooks     prepared pickles with the greatest care, and the various     ingredients were macerated in oil, brine, and vinegar, with     which they were often impregnated drop by drop.
10136-8{_}6257{_}Meat, also,     after having been cut into very small pieces, was treated in the     same manner.
10136-8{_}6258{_}ITALIAN SAUCE (Brown).
10136-8{_}6259{_}453.
10136-8{_}6260{_}INGREDIENTS.--A few chopped mushrooms and shalots, 1/2 pint of stock, No.
10136-8{_}6261{_}105, 1/2 glass of Madeira, the juice of 1/2 lemon, 1/2 teaspoonful of pounded sugar, 1 teaspoonful of chopped parsley.
10136-8{_}6262{_}_Mode_.--Put the stock into a stewpan with the mushrooms, shalots, and Madeira, and stew gently for 1/4 hour, then add the remaining ingredients, and let them just boil.
10136-8{_}6263{_}When the sauce is done enough, put it in another stewpan, and warm it in a _bain marie_.
10136-8{_}6264{_}(_See_ No.
10136-8{_}6265{_}430.)
10136-8{_}6266{_}The mushrooms should not be chopped long before they are wanted, as they will then become black.
10136-8{_}6267{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}6268{_}_Average cost_, for this quantity, 7d.
10136-8{_}6269{_}_Sufficient_ for a small dish.
10136-8{_}6270{_}ITALIAN SAUCE (White).
10136-8{_}6271{_}454.
10136-8{_}6272{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of white stock, No.
10136-8{_}6273{_}107; 2 tablespoonfuls of chopped mushrooms, 1 dessertspoonful of chopped shalots, 1 slice of ham, minced very fine; 1/4 pint of Béchamel, No.
10136-8{_}6274{_}367; salt to taste, a few drops of garlic vinegar, 1/2 teaspoonful of pounded sugar, a squeeze of lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}6275{_}_Mode_.--Put the shalots and mushrooms into a stewpan with the stock and ham, and simmer very gently for 1/2 hour, when add the Béchamel.
10136-8{_}6276{_}Let it just boil up, and then strain it through a tammy; season with the above ingredients, and serve very hot.
10136-8{_}6277{_}If this sauce should not have retained a nice white colour, a little cream may be added.
10136-8{_}6278{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}6279{_}_Average cost_, for this quantity, 10d.
10136-8{_}6280{_}_Sufficient_ for a moderate-sized dish.
10136-8{_}6281{_}_Note_.--To preserve the colour of the mushrooms after pickling, throw them into water to which a little lemon-juice has been added.
10136-8{_}6282{_}TO PICKLE LEMONS WITH THE PEEL ON.
10136-8{_}6283{_}455.
10136-8{_}6284{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 lemons, 2 quarts of boiling water; to each quart of vinegar allow 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}6285{_}of cloves, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}6286{_}of white pepper, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}6287{_}of bruised ginger, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}6288{_}of mace and chilies, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}6289{_}of mustard-seed, 1/2 stick of sliced horseradish, a few cloves of garlic.
10136-8{_}6290{_}_Mode_.--Put the lemons into a brine that will bear an egg; let them remain in it 6 days, stirring them every day; have ready 2 quarts of boiling water, put in the lemons, and allow them to boil for 1/4 hour; take them out, and let them lie in a cloth until perfectly dry and cold.
10136-8{_}6291{_}Boil up sufficient vinegar to cover the lemons, with all the above ingredients, allowing the same proportion as stated to each quart of vinegar.
10136-8{_}6292{_}Pack the lemons in a jar, pour over the vinegar, &c. boiling hot, and tie down with a bladder.
10136-8{_}6293{_}They will be fit for use in about 12 months, or rather sooner.
10136-8{_}6294{_}_Seasonable_.--This should be made from November to April.
10136-8{_}6295{_}THE LEMON.--In the earlier ages of the world, the lemon does not     appear to have been at all known, and the Romans only became     acquainted with it at a very late period, and then only used it     to keep moths from their garments.
10136-8{_}6296{_}Its acidity would seem to     have been unpleasant to them; and in Pliny's time, at the     commencement of the Christian era, this fruit was hardly     accepted, otherwise than as an excellent antidote against the     effects of poison.
10136-8{_}6297{_}Many anecdotes have been related concerning     the anti-venomous properties of the lemon; Athenaeus, a Latin     writer, telling us, that on one occasion, two men felt no     effects from the bites of dangerous serpents, because they had     previously eaten of this fruit.
10136-8{_}6298{_}TO PICKLE LEMONS WITHOUT THE PEEL.
10136-8{_}6299{_}456.
10136-8{_}6300{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 lemons, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}6301{_}of fine salt; to each quart of vinegar, the same ingredients as No.
10136-8{_}6302{_}455.
10136-8{_}6303{_}_Mode_.--Peel the lemons, slit each one down 3 times, so as not to divide them, and rub the salt well into the divisions; place them in a pan, where they must remain for a week, turning them every other day; then put them in a Dutch oven before a clear fire until the salt has become perfectly dry; then arrange them in a jar.
10136-8{_}6304{_}Pour over sufficient boiling vinegar to cover them, to which have been added the ingredients mentioned in the foregoing recipe; tie down closely, and in about 9 months they will be fit for use.
10136-8{_}6305{_}_Seasonable_.--The best time to make this is from November to April.
10136-8{_}6306{_}_Note_.--After this pickle has been made from 4 to 5 months, the liquor may be strained and bottled, and will be found an excellent lemon ketchup.
10136-8{_}6307{_}LEMON-JUICE.--Citric acid is the principal component part of     lemon-juice, which, in addition to the agreeableness of its     flavour, is also particularly cooling and grateful.
10136-8{_}6308{_}It is     likewise an antiscorbutic; and this quality enhances its value.
10136-8{_}6309{_}In order to combat the fatal effects of scurvy amongst the crews     of ships at sea, a regular allowance of lemon-juice is served     out to the men; and by this practice, the disease has almost     entirely disappeared.
10136-8{_}6310{_}By putting the juice into bottles, and     pouring on the top sufficient oil to cover it, it may be     preserved for a considerable time.
10136-8{_}6311{_}Italy and Turkey export great     quantities of it in this manner.
10136-8{_}6312{_}LEMON SAUCE FOR BOILED FOWLS.
10136-8{_}6313{_}457.
10136-8{_}6314{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 small lemon, 3/4 pint of melted butter, No.
10136-8{_}6315{_}380.
10136-8{_}6316{_}_Mode_.--Cut the lemon into very thin slices, and these again into very small dice.
10136-8{_}6317{_}Have ready 3/4 pint of melted butter, made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}6318{_}380; put in the lemon; let it just simmer, but not boil, and pour it over the fowls.
10136-8{_}6319{_}_Time_.--1 minute to simmer.
10136-8{_}6320{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}6321{_}_Sufficient_ for a pair of large fowls.
10136-8{_}6322{_}LEMON WHITE SAUCE, FOR FOWLS, FRICASSEES, &c.  458.
10136-8{_}6323{_}INGREDIENTS.--3/4 pint of cream, the rind and juice of 1 lemon, 1/2 teaspoonful of whole white pepper, 1 sprig of lemon thyme, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}6324{_}of butter, 1 dessertspoonful of flour, 1 teacupful of white stock; salt to taste.
10136-8{_}6325{_}_Mode_.--Put the cream into a very clean saucepan (a lined one is best), with the lemon-peel, pepper, and thyme, and let these infuse for 1/2 hour, when simmer gently for a few minutes, or until there is a nice flavour of lemon.
10136-8{_}6326{_}Strain it, and add a thickening of butter and flour in the above proportions; stir this well in, and put in the lemon-juice at the moment of serving; mix the stock with the cream, and add a little salt.
10136-8{_}6327{_}This sauce should not boil after the cream and stock are mixed together.
10136-8{_}6328{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}6329{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}6330{_}6d.
10136-8{_}6331{_}_Sufficient_, this quantity, for a pair of large boiled fowls.
10136-8{_}6332{_}_Note_.--Where the expense of the cream is objected to, milk may be substituted for it.
10136-8{_}6333{_}In this case, an additional dessertspoonful, or rather more, of flour must be added.
10136-8{_}6334{_}[Illustration: LEMON THYME.]
10136-8{_}6335{_}LEMON THYME.--Two or three tufts of this species of thyme,     _Thymus citriodorus_, usually find a place in the herb     compartment of the kitchen-garden.
10136-8{_}6336{_}It is a trailing evergreen,     is of smaller growth than the common kind (_see_ No.
10136-8{_}6337{_}166), and     is remarkable for its smell, which closely resembles that of the     rind of a lemon.
10136-8{_}6338{_}Hence its distinctive name.
10136-8{_}6339{_}It is used for some     particular dishes, in which the fragrance of the lemon is     desired to slightly predominate.
10136-8{_}6340{_}LEAMINGTON SAUCE (an Excellent Sauce for Flavouring Gravies, Hashes, Soups, &c.).
10136-8{_}6341{_}_(Author's Recipe.
10136-8{_}6342{_})_  459.
10136-8{_}6343{_}INGREDIENTS.--Walnuts.
10136-8{_}6344{_}To each quart of walnut-juice allow 3 quarts of vinegar, 1 pint of Indian soy, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}6345{_}of cayenne, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}6346{_}of shalots, 3/4 oz.
10136-8{_}6347{_}of garlic, 1/2 pint of port wine.
10136-8{_}6348{_}_Mode_.--Be very particular in choosing the walnuts as soon as they appear in the market; for they are more easily bruised before they become hard and shelled.
10136-8{_}6349{_}Pound them in a mortar to a pulp, strew some salt over them, and let them remain thus for two or three days, occasionally stirring and moving them about.
10136-8{_}6350{_}Press out the juice, and to _each quart_ of walnut-liquor allow the above proportion of vinegar, soy, cayenne, shalots, garlic, and port wine.
10136-8{_}6351{_}Pound each ingredient separately in a mortar, then mix them well together, and store away for use in small bottles.
10136-8{_}6352{_}The corks should be well sealed.
10136-8{_}6353{_}_Seasonable_.--This sauce should be made as soon as walnuts are obtainable, from the beginning to the middle of July.
10136-8{_}6354{_}LEMON BRANDY.
10136-8{_}6355{_}460.
10136-8{_}6356{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint of brandy, the rind of two small lemons, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}6357{_}of loaf-sugar, 1/4 pint of water.
10136-8{_}6358{_}_Mode_.--Peel the lemons rather thin, taking care to have none of the white pith.
10136-8{_}6359{_}Put the rinds into a bottle with the brandy, and let them infuse for 24 hours, when they should be strained.
10136-8{_}6360{_}Now boil the sugar with the water for a few minutes, skim it, and, when cold, add it to the brandy.
10136-8{_}6361{_}A dessertspoonful of this will be found an excellent flavouring for boiled custards.
10136-8{_}6362{_}LEMON RIND OR PEEL.--This contains an essential oil of a very     high flavour and fragrance, and is consequently esteemed both a     wholesome and agreeable stomachic.
10136-8{_}6363{_}It is used, as will be seen     by many recipes in this book, as an ingredient for flavouring a     number of various dishes.
10136-8{_}6364{_}Under the name of CANDIED LEMON-PEEL,     it is cleared of the pulp and preserved by sugar, when it     becomes an excellent sweetmeat.
10136-8{_}6365{_}By the ancient medical     philosopher Galen, and others, it may be added, that dried     lemon-peel was considered as one of the best digestives, and     recommended to weak and delicate persons.
10136-8{_}6366{_}LIAISON OF EGGS FOR THICKENING SAUCES.
10136-8{_}6367{_}461.
10136-8{_}6368{_}INGREDIENTS.--The yolks of 3 eggs, 8 tablespoonfuls of milk or cream.
10136-8{_}6369{_}_Mode_.--Beat up the yolks of the eggs, to which add the milk, and strain the whole through a hair-sieve.
10136-8{_}6370{_}When the liaison is being added to the sauce it is intended to thicken, care must be exercised to keep stirring it during the whole time, or, otherwise, the eggs will curdle.
10136-8{_}6371{_}It should only just simmer, but not boil.
10136-8{_}6372{_}LIVER AND LEMON SAUCE FOR POULTRY.
10136-8{_}6373{_}462.
10136-8{_}6374{_}INGREDIENTS.--The liver of a fowl, one lemon, salt to taste, 1/2 pint of melted butter.
10136-8{_}6375{_}No.
10136-8{_}6376{_}376.
10136-8{_}6377{_}_Mode_.--Wash the liver, and let it boil for a few minutes; peel the lemon very thin, remove the white part and pips, and cut it into very small dice; mince the liver and a small quantity of the lemon rind very fine; add these ingredients to 1/2 pint of smoothly-made melted butter; season with a little salt, put in the cut lemon, heat it gradually, but do not allow it to boil, lest the butter should oil.
10136-8{_}6378{_}_Time_.--1 minute to simmer.
10136-8{_}6379{_}_Sufficient_ to serve with a pair of small fowls.
10136-8{_}6380{_}LIVER AND PARSLEY SAUCE FOR POULTRY.
