10136-8{_}6383{_}376.
10136-8{_}6384{_}_Mode_.--Wash and score the liver, boil it for a few minutes, and mince it very fine; blanch or scald a small bunch of parsley, of which there should be sufficient when chopped to fill a tablespoon; add this, with the minced liver, to 1/2 pint of smoothly-made melted butter; let it just boil; when serve.
10136-8{_}6385{_}_Time_.--1 minute to simmer.
10136-8{_}6386{_}_Sufficient_ for a pair of small fowls.
10136-8{_}6387{_}LOBSTER SAUCE, to serve with Turbot, Salmon, Brill, &c.  (_Very Good_.)
10136-8{_}6388{_}464.
10136-8{_}6389{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 middling-sized hen lobster, 3/4 pint of melted butter, No.
10136-8{_}6390{_}376; 1 tablespoonful of anchovy sauce, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}6391{_}of butter, salt and cayenne to taste, a little pounded mace when liked, 2 or 3 tablespoonfuls of cream.
10136-8{_}6392{_}_Mode_.--Choose a hen lobster, as this is indispensable, in order to render this sauce as good as it ought to be.
10136-8{_}6393{_}Pick the meat from the shells, and cut it into small square pieces; put the spawn, which will be found under the tail of the lobster, into a mortar with 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}6394{_}of butter, and pound it quite smooth; rub it through a hair-sieve, and cover up till wanted.
10136-8{_}6395{_}Make 3/4 pint of melted butter by recipe No.
10136-8{_}6396{_}376; put in all the ingredients except the lobster-meat, and well mix the sauce before the lobster is added to it, as it should retain its square form, and not come to table shredded and ragged.
10136-8{_}6397{_}Put in the meat, let it get thoroughly hot, but do not allow it to boil, as the colour would immediately be spoiled; for it should be remembered that this sauce should always have a bright red appearance.
10136-8{_}6398{_}If it is intended to be served with turbot or brill, a little of the spawn (dried and rubbed through a sieve without butter) should be saved to garnish with; but as the goodness, flavour, and appearance of the sauce so much depend on having a proper quantity of spawn, the less used for garnishing the better.
10136-8{_}6399{_}_Time_.--1 minute to simmer.
10136-8{_}6400{_}_Average cost_, for this quantity, 2s.
10136-8{_}6401{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}6402{_}_Sufficient_ to serve with a small turbot, a brill, or salmon for 6 persons.
10136-8{_}6403{_}_Note_.--Melted butter made with milk, No.
10136-8{_}6404{_}380, will be found to answer very well for lobster sauce, as by employing it a nice white colour will be obtained.
10136-8{_}6405{_}Less quantity than the above may be made by using a very small lobster, to which add only 1/2 pint of melted butter, and season as above.
10136-8{_}6406{_}Where economy is desired, the cream may be dispensed with, and the remains of a cold lobster left from table, may, with a little care, be converted into a very good sauce.
10136-8{_}6407{_}MAITRE D'HOTEL BUTTER, for putting into Broiled Fish just before it is sent to Table.
10136-8{_}6408{_}465.
10136-8{_}6409{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}6410{_}of butter, 2 dessertspoonfuls of minced parsley, salt and pepper to taste, the juice of 1 large lemon.
10136-8{_}6411{_}_Mode_.--Work the above ingredients well together, and let them be thoroughly mixed with a wooden spoon.
10136-8{_}6412{_}If this is used as a sauce, it may be poured either under or over the meat or fish it is intended to be served with.
10136-8{_}6413{_}_Average cost_, for this quantity, 5d.
10136-8{_}6414{_}Note.--4 tablespoonfuls of Béchamel, No.
10136-8{_}6415{_}367, 2 do.
10136-8{_}6416{_}of white stock, No.
10136-8{_}6417{_}107, with 2 oz.
10136-8{_}6418{_}of the above maître d'hôtel butter stirred into it, and just allowed to simmer for 1 minute, will be found an excellent hot maître d'hôtel sauce.
10136-8{_}6419{_}THE MAÎTRE D'HÔTEL.--The house-steward of England is synonymous     with the maître d'hôtel of France; and, in ancient times,     amongst the Latins, he was called procurator, or major-domo.
10136-8{_}6420{_}In     Rome, the slaves, after they had procured the various articles     necessary for the repasts of the day, would return to the     spacious kitchen laden with meat, game, sea-fish, vegetables,     fruit, &c. Each one would then lay his basket at the feet of the     major-domo, who would examine its contents and register them on     his tablets, placing in the pantry contiguous to the     dining-room, those of the provisions which need no preparation,     and consigning the others to the more immediate care of the     cooks.
10136-8{_}6421{_}MAITRE D'HOTEL SAUCE (HOT), to serve with Calf's Head, Boiled Eels, and different Fish.
10136-8{_}6422{_}466.
10136-8{_}6423{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 slice of minced ham, a few poultry-trimmings, 2 shalots, 1 clove of garlic, 1 bay-leaf, 3/4 pint of water, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}6424{_}of butter, 1 dessertspoonful of flour, 1 heaped tablespoonful of chopped parsley; salt, pepper, and cayenne to taste; the juice of 1/2 large lemon, 1/4 teaspoonful of pounded sugar.
10136-8{_}6425{_}_Mode_.--Put at the bottom of a stewpan the minced ham, and over it the poultry-trimmings (if these are not at hand, veal should be substituted), with the shalots, garlic, and bay-leaf.
10136-8{_}6426{_}Pour in the water, and let the whole simmer gently for 1 hour, or until the liquor is reduced to a full 1/2 pint.
10136-8{_}6427{_}Then strain this gravy, put it in another saucepan, make a thickening of butter and flour in the above proportions, and stir it to the gravy over a nice clear fire, until it is perfectly smooth and rather thick, care being taken that the butter does not float on the surface.
10136-8{_}6428{_}Skim well, add the remaining ingredients, let the sauce gradually heat, but do not allow it to boil.
10136-8{_}6429{_}If this sauce is intended for an entrée, it is necessary to make it of a sufficient thickness, so that it may adhere to what it is meant to cover.
10136-8{_}6430{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}6431{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}6432{_}2d.
10136-8{_}6433{_}per pint.
10136-8{_}6434{_}_Sufficient_ for re-warming the remains of 1/2 calf's head, or a small dish of cold flaked turbot, cod, &c.   MAIGRE MAITRE D'HOTEL SAUCE (HOT).
10136-8{_}6435{_}(Made without Meat.)
10136-8{_}6436{_}467.
10136-8{_}6437{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of melted butter, No.
10136-8{_}6438{_}376; 1 heaped tablespoonful of chopped parsley, salt and pepper to taste, the juice of 1/2 large lemon; when liked, 2 minced shalots.
10136-8{_}6439{_}_Mode_.--Make 1/2 pint of melted butter, by recipe No.
10136-8{_}6440{_}376; stir in the above ingredients, and let them just boil; when it is ready to serve.
10136-8{_}6441{_}_Time_.--1 minute to simmer.
10136-8{_}6442{_}_Average cost_, 9d.
10136-8{_}6443{_}per pint.
10136-8{_}6444{_}MAYONNAISE, a Sauce or Salad-Dressing for cold Chicken, Meat, and other cold Dishes.
10136-8{_}6445{_}468.
10136-8{_}6446{_}INGREDIENTS.--The yolks of 2 eggs, 6 tablespoonfuls of salad-oil, 4 tablespoonfuls of vinegar, salt and white pepper to taste, 1 tablespoonful of white stock, No.
10136-8{_}6447{_}107, 2 tablespoonfuls of cream.
10136-8{_}6448{_}_Mode_.--Put the yolks of the eggs into a basin, with a seasoning of pepper and salt; have ready the above quantities of oil and vinegar, in separate vessels; add them _very gradually_ to the eggs; continue stirring and rubbing the mixture with a wooden spoon, as herein consists the secret of having a nice smooth sauce.
10136-8{_}6449{_}It cannot be stirred too frequently, and it should be made in a very cool place, or, if ice is at hand, it should be mixed over it.
10136-8{_}6450{_}When the vinegar and oil are well incorporated with the eggs, add the stock and cream, stirring all the time, and it will then be ready for use.
10136-8{_}6451{_}For a fish Mayonnaise, this sauce may be coloured with lobster-spawn, pounded; and for poultry or meat, where variety is desired, a little parsley-juice may be used to add to its appearance.
10136-8{_}6452{_}Cucumber, Tarragon, or any other flavoured vinegar, may be substituted for plain, where they are liked.
10136-8{_}6453{_}_Average cost_, for this quantity, 7d.
10136-8{_}6454{_}_Sufficient_ for a small salad.
10136-8{_}6455{_}_Note_.--In mixing the oil and vinegar with the eggs, put in first a few drops of oil, and then a few drops of vinegar, never adding a large quantity of either at one time.
10136-8{_}6456{_}By this means, you can be more certain of the sauce not curdling.
10136-8{_}6457{_}Patience and practice, let us add, are two essentials for making this sauce good.
10136-8{_}6458{_}MINT SAUCE, to serve with Roast Lamb.
10136-8{_}6459{_}469.
10136-8{_}6460{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 dessertspoonfuls of chopped mint, 2 dessertspoonfuls of pounded white sugar, 1/4 pint of vinegar.
10136-8{_}6461{_}_Mode_.--Wash the mint, which should be young and fresh-gathered, free from grit; pick the leaves from the stalks, mince them very fine, and put them into a tureen; add the sugar and vinegar, and stir till the former is dissolved.
10136-8{_}6462{_}This sauce is better by being made 2 or 3 hours before wanted for table, as the vinegar then becomes impregnated with the flavour of the mint.
10136-8{_}6463{_}By many persons, the above proportion of sugar would not be considered sufficient; but as tastes vary, we have given the quantity which we have found to suit the general palate.
10136-8{_}6464{_}_Average cost_, 3d.
10136-8{_}6465{_}_Sufficient_ to serve with a middling-sized joint of lamb.
10136-8{_}6466{_}_Note_.--Where green mint is scarce and not obtainable, mint vinegar may be substituted for it, and will be found very acceptable in early spring.
10136-8{_}6467{_}[Illustration: MINT.]
10136-8{_}6468{_}MINT.--The common mint cultivated in our gardens is known as the     _Mentha viridis_, and is employed in different culinary     processes, being sometimes boiled with certain dishes, and     afterwards withdrawn.
10136-8{_}6469{_}It has an agreeable aromatic flavour, and     forms an ingredient in soups, and sometimes is used in spring     salads.
10136-8{_}6470{_}It is valuable as a stomachic and antispasmodic; on     which account it is generally served at table with pea-soup.
10136-8{_}6471{_}Several of its species grow wild in low situations in the     country.
10136-8{_}6472{_}MINT VINEGAR.
10136-8{_}6473{_}470.
10136-8{_}6474{_}INGREDIENTS.--Vinegar, mint.
10136-8{_}6475{_}_Mode_.--Procure some nice fresh mint, pick the leaves from the stalks, and fill a bottle or jar with them.
10136-8{_}6476{_}Add vinegar to them until the bottle is full; _cover closely_ to exclude the air, and let it infuse for a fortnight.
10136-8{_}6477{_}Then strain the liquor, and put it into small bottles for use, of which the corks should be sealed.
10136-8{_}6478{_}_Seasonable_.--This should be made in June, July, or August.
10136-8{_}6479{_}MIXED PICKLE.
10136-8{_}6480{_}(_Very Good_.)
10136-8{_}6481{_}471.
10136-8{_}6482{_}INGREDIENTS.--To each gallon of vinegar allow 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}6483{_}of bruised ginger, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}6484{_}of mustard, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}6485{_}of salt, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}6486{_}of mustard-seed, 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}6487{_}of turmeric, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}6488{_}of ground black pepper, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}6489{_}of cayenne, cauliflowers, onions, celery, sliced cucumbers, gherkins, French beans, nasturtiums, capsicums.
10136-8{_}6490{_}_Mode_.--Have a large jar, with a tightly-fitting lid, in which put as much vinegar as required, reserving a little to mix the various powders to a smooth paste.
10136-8{_}6491{_}Put into a basin the mustard, turmeric, pepper, and cayenne; mix them with vinegar, and stir well until no lumps remain; add all the ingredients to the vinegar, and mix well.
10136-8{_}6492{_}Keep this liquor in a warm place, and thoroughly stir every morning for a month with a wooden spoon, when it will be ready for the different vegetables to be added to it.
10136-8{_}6493{_}As these come into season, have them gathered on a dry day, and, after merely wiping them with a cloth, to free them from moisture, put them into the pickle.
10136-8{_}6494{_}The cauliflowers, it may be said, must be divided into small bunches.
10136-8{_}6495{_}Put all these into the pickle raw, and at the end of the season, when there have been added as many of the vegetables as could be procured, store it away in jars, and tie over with bladder.
10136-8{_}6496{_}As none of the ingredients are boiled, this pickle will not be fit to eat till 12 months have elapsed.
10136-8{_}6497{_}Whilst the pickle is being made, keep a wooden spoon tied to the jar; and its contents, it may be repeated, must be stirred every morning.
10136-8{_}6498{_}_Seasonable_.--Make the pickle-liquor in May or June, as the season arrives for the various vegetables to be picked.
10136-8{_}6499{_}MUSHROOM KETCHUP.
10136-8{_}6500{_}472.
10136-8{_}6501{_}INGREDIENTS.--To each peck of mushrooms 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}6502{_}of salt; to each quart of mushroom-liquor 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}6503{_}of cayenne, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}6504{_}of allspice, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}6505{_}of ginger, 2 blades of pounded mace.
10136-8{_}6506{_}_Mode_.--Choose full-grown mushroom-flaps, and take care they are perfectly _fresh-gathered_ when the weather is tolerably dry; for, if they are picked during very heavy rain, the ketchup from which they are made is liable to get musty, and will not keep long.
10136-8{_}6507{_}Put a layer of them in a deep pan, sprinkle salt over them, and then another layer of mushrooms, and so on alternately.
10136-8{_}6508{_}Let them remain for a few hours, when break them up with the hand; put them in a nice cool place for 3 days, occasionally stirring and mashing them well, to extract from them as much juice as possible.
10136-8{_}6509{_}Now measure the quantity of liquor without straining, and to each quart allow the above proportion of spices, &c. Put all into a stone jar, cover it up very closely, put it in a saucepan of boiling water, set it over the fire, and let it boil for 3 hours.
10136-8{_}6510{_}Have ready a nice clean stewpan; turn into it the contents of the jar, and let the whole simmer very gently for 1/2 hour; pour it into a jug, where it should stand in a cool place till the next day; then pour it off into another jug, and strain it into very dry clean bottles, and do not squeeze the mushrooms.
10136-8{_}6511{_}To each pint of ketchup add a few drops of brandy.
10136-8{_}6512{_}Be careful not to shake the contents, but leave all the sediment behind in the jug; cork well, and either seal or rosin the cork, so as perfectly to exclude the air.
10136-8{_}6513{_}When a very clear bright ketchup is wanted, the liquor must be strained through a very fine hair-sieve, or flannel bag, _after_ it has been very gently poured off; if the operation is not successful, it must be repeated until you have quite a clear liquor.
10136-8{_}6514{_}It should be examined occasionally, and if it is spoiling, should be reboiled with a few peppercorns.
10136-8{_}6515{_}_Seasonable_ from the beginning of September to the middle of October, when this ketchup should be made.
10136-8{_}6516{_}_Note_.--This flavouring ingredient, if genuine and well prepared, is one of the most useful store sauces to the experienced cook, and no trouble should be spared in its preparation.
10136-8{_}6517{_}Double ketchup is made by reducing the liquor to half the quantity; for example, 1 quart must be boiled down to 1 pint.
10136-8{_}6518{_}This goes farther than ordinary ketchup, as so little is required to flavour a good quantity of gravy.
10136-8{_}6519{_}The sediment may also be bottled for immediate use, and will be found to answer for flavouring thick soups or gravies.
10136-8{_}6520{_}HOW TO DISTINGUISH MUSHROOMS FROM TOADSTOOLS.--The cultivated     mushroom, known as _Agaricus campestris_, may be distinguished     from other poisonous kinds of fungi by its having pink or     flesh-coloured gills, or under-side, and by its invariably     having an agreeable smell, which the toadstool has not.
10136-8{_}6521{_}When     young, mushrooms are like a small round button, both the stalk     and head being white.
10136-8{_}6522{_}As they grow larger, they expand their     heads by degrees into a flat form, the gills underneath being at     first of a pale flesh-colour, but becoming, as they stand     longer, dark brown or blackish.
10136-8{_}6523{_}Nearly all the poisonous kinds     are brown, and have in general a rank and putrid smell.
10136-8{_}6524{_}Edible     mushrooms are found in closely-fed pastures, but seldom grow in     woods, where most of the poisonous sorts are to be found.
10136-8{_}6525{_}TO DRY MUSHROOMS.
10136-8{_}6526{_}473.
10136-8{_}6527{_}_Mode_.--Wipe them clean, take away the brown part, and peel off the skin; lay them on sheets of paper to dry, in a cool oven, when they will shrivel considerably.
10136-8{_}6528{_}Keep them in paper bags, which hang in a dry place.
10136-8{_}6529{_}When wanted for use, put them into cold gravy, bring them gradually to simmer, and it will be found that they will regain nearly their usual size.
10136-8{_}6530{_}[Illustration: THE MUSHROOM.]
10136-8{_}6531{_}THE MUSHROOM.--The cultivated or garden mushroom is a species of     fungus, which, in England, is considered the best, and is there     usually eaten.
10136-8{_}6532{_}The tribe, however, is numerous, and a large     proportion of them are poisonous; hence it is always dangerous     to make use of mushrooms gathered in their wild state.
10136-8{_}6533{_}In some     parts of Europe, as in Germany, Russia, and Poland, many species     grow wild, and are used as food; but in Britain, two only are     generally eaten.
10136-8{_}6534{_}These are mostly employed for the flavouring of     dishes, and are also dried and pickled.
10136-8{_}6535{_}CATSUP, or KETCHUP, is     made from them by mixing spices and salt with their juice.
10136-8{_}6536{_}The     young, called buttons, are the best for pickling when in the     globular form.
10136-8{_}6537{_}BROWN MUSHROOM SAUCE, to serve with Roast Meat, &c.  474.
10136-8{_}6538{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of button mushrooms, 1/2 pint of good beef gravy, No.
10136-8{_}6539{_}435, 1 tablespoonful of mushroom ketchup (if at hand), thickening of butter and flour.
10136-8{_}6540{_}_Mode_.--Put the gravy into a saucepan, thicken it, and stir over the fire until it boils.
10136-8{_}6541{_}Prepare the mushrooms by cutting off the stalks and wiping them free from grit and dirt; the large flap mushrooms cut into small pieces will answer for a brown sauce, when the buttons are not obtainable; put them into the gravy, and let them simmer very gently for about 10 minutes; then add the ketchup, and serve.
10136-8{_}6542{_}_Time_.--Rather more than 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}6543{_}_Seasonable_ from August to October.
10136-8{_}6544{_}_Note_.--When fresh mushrooms are not obtainable, the powder No.
10136-8{_}6545{_}477 may be used as a substitute for brown sauce.
10136-8{_}6546{_}WHITE MUSHROOM SAUCE, to serve with Boiled Fowls, Cutlets, &c.  I.
10136-8{_}6547{_}475.
10136-8{_}6548{_}INGREDIENTS.--Rather more than 1/2 pint of button mushrooms, lemon-juice and water, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}6549{_}of butter, 1/2 pint of Béchamel, No.
10136-8{_}6550{_}367, 1/4 teaspoonful of pounded sugar.
10136-8{_}6551{_}_Mode_.--Turn the mushrooms white by putting them into lemon-juice and water, having previously cut off the stalks and wiped them perfectly free from grit.
10136-8{_}6552{_}Chop them, and put them in a stewpan with the butter.
10136-8{_}6553{_}When the mushrooms are softened, add the Béchamel, and simmer for about 5 minutes; should they, however, not be done enough, allow rather more time.
10136-8{_}6554{_}They should not boil longer than necessary, as they would then lose their colour and flavour.
10136-8{_}6555{_}Rub the whole through a tammy, and serve very hot.
10136-8{_}6556{_}After this, it should be warmed in a bain marie.
10136-8{_}6557{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}6558{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}6559{_}_Seasonable_ from August to October.
10136-8{_}6560{_}II.
10136-8{_}6561{_}_A More Simple Method_.
10136-8{_}6562{_}476.
10136-8{_}6563{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of melted butter, made with milk, No.
10136-8{_}6564{_}380; 1/2 pint of button mushrooms, 1 dessertspoonful of mushroom ketchup, if at hand; cayenne and salt to taste.
10136-8{_}6565{_}_Mode_.--Make the melted butter by recipe No.
10136-8{_}6566{_}380, and add to it the mushrooms, which must be nicely cleaned, and free from grit, and the stalks cut off.
10136-8{_}6567{_}Let them simmer gently for about 10 minutes, or until they are quite tender.
10136-8{_}6568{_}Put in the seasoning and ketchup; let it just boil, when serve.
10136-8{_}6569{_}_Time_.--Rather more than 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}6570{_}_Average cost_, 8d.
10136-8{_}6571{_}_Seasonable_ from August to October.
10136-8{_}6572{_}GROWTH OF THE MUSHROOM AND OTHER FUNGI.--The quick growth of the     mushroom and other fungi is no less wonderful than the length of     time they live, and the numerous dangers they resist while they     continue in the dormant state.
10136-8{_}6573{_}To spring up "like a mushroom in     a night" is a scriptural mode of expressing celerity; and this     completely accords with all the observations which have been     made concerning this curious class of plants.
10136-8{_}6574{_}Mr. Sowerby     remarks--"I have often placed specimens of the _Phallus caninus_     by a window over-night, while in the egg-form, and they have     been fully grown by the morning."
10136-8{_}6575{_}MUSHROOM POWDER (a valuable addition to Sauces and Gravies, when fresh Mushrooms are not obtainable).
10136-8{_}6576{_}477.
10136-8{_}6577{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 peck of large mushrooms, 2 onions, 12 cloves, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}6578{_}of pounded mace, 2 teaspoonfuls of white pepper.
10136-8{_}6579{_}_Mode_.--Peel the mushrooms, wipe them perfectly free from grit and dirt, remove the black fur, and reject all those that are at all worm-eaten; put them into a stewpan with the above ingredients, but without water; shake them over a clear fire, till all the liquor is dried up, and be careful not to let them burn; arrange them on tins, and dry them in a slow oven; pound them to a fine powder, which put into small _dry_ bottles; cork well, seal the corks, and keep it in a dry place.
10136-8{_}6580{_}In using this powder, add it to the gravy just before serving, when it will merely require one boil-up.
10136-8{_}6581{_}The flavour imparted by this means to the gravy, ought to be exceedingly good.
10136-8{_}6582{_}_Seasonable_.--This should be made in September, or at the beginning of October.
10136-8{_}6583{_}_Note_.--If the bottles in which it is stored away are not perfectly dry, as, also the mushroom powder, it will keep good but a very short time.
10136-8{_}6584{_}PICKLED MUSHROOMS.
10136-8{_}6585{_}478.
10136-8{_}6586{_}INGREDIENTS.--Sufficient vinegar to cover the mushrooms; to each quart of mushrooms, 2 blades of pounded mace, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}6587{_}of ground pepper, salt to taste.
10136-8{_}6588{_}_Mode_.--Choose some nice young button mushrooms for pickling, and rub off the skin with a piece of flannel and salt, and cut off the stalks; if very large, take out the red inside, and reject the black ones, as they are too old.
10136-8{_}6589{_}Put them in a stewpan, sprinkle salt over them, with pounded mace and pepper in the above proportion; shake them well over a clear fire until the liquor flows, and keep them there until it is all dried up again; then add as much vinegar as will cover them; just let it simmer for 1 minute, and store it away in stone jars for use.
10136-8{_}6590{_}When cold, tie down with bladder and keep in a dry place; they will remain good for a length of time, and are generally considered delicious.
10136-8{_}6591{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this the same time as ketchup, from the beginning of September to the middle of October.
10136-8{_}6592{_}NATURE OF THE MUSHROOM.--Locality has evidently a considerable     influence on the nature of the juices of the mushroom; for it     has been discovered, after fatal experience, that some species,     which are perfectly harmless when raised in open meadows and     pasturelands, become virulently poisonous when they happen to     grow in contact with stagnant water or putrescent animal and     vegetable substances.
10136-8{_}6593{_}What the precise nature of the poison in     fungi may be, has not been accurately ascertained.
10136-8{_}6594{_}A VERY RICH AND GOOD MUSHROOM SAUCE, to serve with Fowls or Rabbits.
10136-8{_}6595{_}479.
10136-8{_}6596{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint of mushroom-buttons, salt to taste, a little grated nutmeg, 1 blade of pounded mace, 1 pint of cream, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}6597{_}of butter, flour to thicken.
10136-8{_}6598{_}_Mode_.--Rub the buttons with a piece of flannel and salt, to take off the skin; cut off the stalks, and put them in a stewpan with the above ingredients, previously kneading together the butter and flour; boil the whole for about ten minutes, stirring all the time.
10136-8{_}6599{_}Pour some of the sauce over the fowls, and the remainder serve in a tureen.
10136-8{_}6600{_}_Time_.--10 minutes.
10136-8{_}6601{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}6602{_}_Sufficient_ to serve with a pair of fowls.
10136-8{_}6603{_}_Seasonable_ from August to October.
10136-8{_}6604{_}HOW TO MIX MUSTARD.
10136-8{_}6605{_}480.
10136-8{_}6606{_}INGREDIENTS.--Mustard, salt, and water.
10136-8{_}6607{_}_Mode_.--Mustard should be mixed with water that has been boiled and allowed to cool; hot water destroys its essential properties, and raw cold water might cause it to ferment.
10136-8{_}6608{_}Put the mustard in a cup, with a small pinch of salt, and mix with it very gradually sufficient boiled water to make it drop from the spoon without being watery.
10136-8{_}6609{_}Stir and mix well, and rub the lumps well down with the back of a spoon, as well-mixed mustard should be perfectly free from these.
10136-8{_}6610{_}The mustard-pot should not be more than half full, or rather less if it will not be used in a day or two, as it is so much better when freshly mixed.
10136-8{_}6611{_}TARTAR MUSTARD.
10136-8{_}6612{_}481.
10136-8{_}6613{_}INGREDIENTS.--Horseradish vinegar, cayenne, 1/2 a teacupful of mustard.
10136-8{_}6614{_}_Mode_.--Have ready sufficient horseradish vinegar to mix with the above proportion of mustard; put the mustard in a cup, with a slight seasoning of cayenne; mix it perfectly smooth with the vinegar, adding this a little at a time; rub down with the back of a spoon any lumps that may appear, and do not let it be too thin.
10136-8{_}6615{_}Mustard may be flavoured in various ways, with Tarragon, shalot, celery, and many other vinegars, herbs, spices, &c.; but this is more customary in France than in England, as there it is merely considered a "vehicle of flavours," as it has been termed.
10136-8{_}6616{_}PICKLED NASTURTIUMS (a very good Substitute for Capers)  482.
10136-8{_}6617{_}INGREDIENTS.--To each pint of vinegar, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}6618{_}of salt, 6 peppercorns, nasturtiums.
10136-8{_}6619{_}_Mode_.--Gather the nasturtium-pods on a dry day, and wipe them clean with a cloth; put them in a dry glass bottle, with vinegar, salt, and pepper in the above proportion.
10136-8{_}6620{_}If you cannot find enough ripe to fill a bottle, cork up what you have got until you have some more fit: they may be added from day to day.
10136-8{_}6621{_}Bung up the bottles, and seal or rosin the tops.
10136-8{_}6622{_}They will be fit for use in 10 or 12 months; and the best way is to make them one season for the next.
10136-8{_}6623{_}_Seasonable_.--Look for nasturtium-pods from the end of July to the end of August.
10136-8{_}6624{_}[Illustration: NASTURTIUMS.]
10136-8{_}6625{_}NASTURTIUMS.--The elegant nasturtium-plant, called by     naturalists _Tropoeolum_, and which sometimes goes by the name     of Indian cress, came originally from Peru, but was easily made     to grow in these islands.
10136-8{_}6626{_}Its young leaves and flowers are of a     slightly hot nature, and many consider them a good adjunct to     salads, to which they certainly add a pretty appearance.
10136-8{_}6627{_}When     the beautiful blossoms, which may be employed with great effect     in garnishing dishes, are off, then the fruit is used as     described in the above recipe.
10136-8{_}6628{_}FRENCH ONION SAUCE, or SOUBISE.
10136-8{_}6629{_}483.
10136-8{_}6630{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of Béchamel, No.
10136-8{_}6631{_}367, 1 bay-leaf, seasoning to taste of pounded mace and cayenne, 6 onions, a small piece of ham.
10136-8{_}6632{_}_Mode_.--Peel the onions and cut them in halves; put them in a stewpan, with just sufficient water to cover them, and add the bay-leaf, ham, cayenne, and mace; be careful to keep the lid closely shut, and simmer them until tender.
10136-8{_}6633{_}Take them out and drain thoroughly; rub them through a tammy or sieve (an old one does for the purpose) with a wooden spoon, and put them to 1/2 pint of Béchamel; keep stirring over the fire until it boils, when serve.
10136-8{_}6634{_}If it should require any more seasoning, add it to taste.
10136-8{_}6635{_}_Time_.--3/4 hour to boil the onions.
10136-8{_}6636{_}_Average cost_, 10d.
10136-8{_}6637{_}for this quantity.
10136-8{_}6638{_}_Sufficient_ for a moderate-sized dish.
10136-8{_}6639{_}WHITE ONION SAUCE, for Boiled Rabbits, Roast Shoulder of Mutton, &c.  484.
10136-8{_}6640{_}INGREDIENTS.--9 large onions, or 12 middling-sized ones, 1 pint of melted butter made with milk (No.
10136-8{_}6641{_}380), 1/2 teaspoonful of salt, or rather more.
10136-8{_}6642{_}_Mode_.--Peel the onions and put them into water to which a little salt has been added, to preserve their whiteness, and let them remain for 1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}6643{_}Then put them in a stewpan, cover them with water, and let them boil until tender, and, if the onions should be very strong, change the water after they have been boiling for 1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}6644{_}Drain them thoroughly, chop them, and rub them through a tammy or sieve.
10136-8{_}6645{_}Make 1 pint of melted butter, by recipe No.
10136-8{_}6646{_}380, and when that boils, put in the onions, with a seasoning of salt; stir it till it simmers, when it will be ready to serve.
10136-8{_}6647{_}If these directions are carefully attended to, this onion sauce will be delicious.
10136-8{_}6648{_}_Time_.--From 3/4 to 1 hour, to boil the onions.
10136-8{_}6649{_}_Average cost_, 9d.
10136-8{_}6650{_}per pint.
10136-8{_}6651{_}_Sufficient_ to serve with a roast shoulder of mutton, or boiled rabbit.
10136-8{_}6652{_}_Seasonable_ from August to March.
10136-8{_}6653{_}_Note_.--To make this sauce very mild and delicate, use Spanish onions, which can be procured from the beginning of September to Christmas.
10136-8{_}6654{_}2 or 3 tablespoonfuls of cream added just before serving, will be found to improve its appearance very much.
10136-8{_}6655{_}Small onions, when very young, may be cooked whole, and served in melted butter.
10136-8{_}6656{_}A sieve or tammy should be kept expressly for onions: an old one answers the purpose, as it is liable to retain the flavour and smell, which of course would be excessively disagreeable in delicate preparations.
10136-8{_}6657{_}BROWN ONION SAUCE.
10136-8{_}6658{_}485.
10136-8{_}6659{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 large onions, rather more than 1/2 pint of good gravy, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}6660{_}of butter, salt and pepper to taste.
10136-8{_}6661{_}_Mode_.--Slice and fry the onions of a pale brown in a stewpan, with the above quantity of butter, keeping them well stirred, that they do not get black.
10136-8{_}6662{_}When a nice colour, pour over the gravy, and let them simmer gently until tender.
10136-8{_}6663{_}Now skim off every particle of fat, add the seasoning, and rub the whole through a tammy or sieve; put it back in the saucepan to warm, and when it boils, serve.
10136-8{_}6664{_}_Time_.--Altogether 1 hour.
10136-8{_}6665{_}_Seasonable_ from August to March.
10136-8{_}6666{_}_Note_.--Where a very high flavouring is liked, add 1 tablespoonful of mushroom ketchup, or a small quantity of port wine.
10136-8{_}6667{_}HISTORY OF THE ONION.--It is not supposed that any variety of     the onion is indigenous to Britain, as when the large and mild     roots imported from warmer climates, have been cultivated in     these islands a few years, they deteriorate both in size and     sweetness.
10136-8{_}6668{_}It is therefore most likely that this plant was first     introduced into England from continental Europe, and that it     originally was produced in a southern climate, and has gradually     become acclimatized to a colder atmosphere.
10136-8{_}6669{_}(_See_ No.
10136-8{_}6670{_}139.)
10136-8{_}6671{_}PICKLED ONIONS (a very Simple Method, and exceedingly Good).
10136-8{_}6672{_}486.
10136-8{_}6673{_}INGREDIENTS.--Pickling onions; to each quart of vinegar, 2 teaspoonfuls of allspice, 2 teaspoonfuls of whole black pepper.
10136-8{_}6674{_}_Mode_.--Have the onions gathered when quite dry and ripe, and, with the fingers, take off the thin outside skin; then, with a silver knife (steel should not be used, as it spoils the colour of the onions), remove one more skin, when the onion will look quite clear.
10136-8{_}6675{_}Have ready some very dry bottles or jars, and as fast as they are peeled, put them in.
10136-8{_}6676{_}Pour over sufficient cold vinegar to cover them, with pepper and allspice in the above proportions, taking care that each jar has its share of the latter ingredients.
10136-8{_}6677{_}Tie down with bladder, and put them in a dry place, and in a fortnight they will be fit for use.
10136-8{_}6678{_}This is a most simple recipe and very delicious, the onions being nice and crisp.
10136-8{_}6679{_}They should be eaten within 6 or 8 months after being done, as the onions are liable to become soft.
10136-8{_}6680{_}_Seasonable_ from the middle of July to the end of August.
10136-8{_}6681{_}PICKLED ONIONS.
10136-8{_}6682{_}487.
10136-8{_}6683{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 gallon of pickling onions, salt and water, milk; to each 1/2 gallon of vinegar, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}6684{_}of bruised ginger, 1/4 teaspoonful of cayenne, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}6685{_}of allspice, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}6686{_}of whole black pepper, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}6687{_}of whole nutmeg bruised, 8 cloves, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}6688{_}of mace.
10136-8{_}6689{_}_Mode_.--Gather the onions, which should not be too small, when they are quite dry and ripe; wipe off the dirt, but do not pare them; make a strong solution of salt and water, into which put the onions, and change this, morning and night, for 3 days, and save the _last_ brine they were put in.
10136-8{_}6690{_}Then take the outside skin off, and put them into a tin saucepan capable of holding them all, as they are always better done together.
10136-8{_}6691{_}Now take equal quantities of milk and the last salt and water the onions were in, and pour this to them; to this add 2 large spoonfuls of salt, put them over the fire, and watch them very attentively.
10136-8{_}6692{_}Keep constantly turning the onions about with a wooden skimmer, those at the bottom to the top, and _vice versâ_; and let the milk and water run through the holes of the skimmer.
10136-8{_}6693{_}Remember, the onions must never boil, or, if they do, they will be good for nothing; and they should be quite transparent.
10136-8{_}6694{_}Keep the onions stirred for a few minutes, and, in stirring them, be particular not to break them.
10136-8{_}6695{_}Then have ready a pan with a colander, into which turn the onions to drain, covering them with a cloth to keep in the steam.
10136-8{_}6696{_}Place on a table an old cloth, 2 or 3 times double; put the onions on it when quite hot, and over them an old piece of blanket; cover this closely over them, to keep in the steam.
10136-8{_}6697{_}Let them remain till the next day, when they will be quite cold, and look yellow and shrivelled; take off the shrivelled skins, when they should be as white as snow.
10136-8{_}6698{_}Put them in a pan, make a pickle of vinegar and the remaining ingredients, boil all these up, and pour hot over the onions in the pan.
10136-8{_}6699{_}Cover very closely to keep in all the steam, and let them stand till the following day, when they will be quite cold.
10136-8{_}6700{_}Put them into jars or bottles well bunged, and a tablespoonful of the best olive-oil on the top of each jar or bottle.
10136-8{_}6701{_}Tie them down with bladder, and let them stand in a cool place for a month or six weeks, when they will be fit for use.
10136-8{_}6702{_}They should be beautifully white, and eat crisp, without the least softness, and will keep good many months.
10136-8{_}6703{_}_Seasonable_ from the middle of July to the end of August.
10136-8{_}6704{_}ORANGE GRAVY, for Wildfowl, Widgeon, Teal, &c.  488.
10136-8{_}6705{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of white stock, No.
10136-8{_}6706{_}107, 1 small onion, 3 or 4 strips of lemon or orange peel, a few leaves of basil, if at hand, the juice of a Seville orange or lemon, salt and pepper to taste, 1 glass of port wine.
10136-8{_}6707{_}_Mode_.--Put the onion, cut in slices, into a stewpan with the stock, orange-peel, and basil, and let them simmer very gently for 1/4 hour or rather longer, should the gravy not taste sufficiently of the peel.
10136-8{_}6708{_}Strain it off, and add to the gravy the remaining ingredients; let the whole heat through, and, when on the point of boiling, serve very hot in a tureen which should have a cover to it.
10136-8{_}6709{_}_Time_.--Altogether 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}6710{_}_Sufficient_ for a small tureen.
10136-8{_}6711{_}OYSTER FORCEMEAT, for Roast or Boiled Turkey.
10136-8{_}6712{_}489.
10136-8{_}6713{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of bread crumbs, 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}6714{_}of chopped suet or butter, 1 faggot of savoury herbs, 1/4 saltspoonful of grated nutmeg, salt and pepper to taste, 2 eggs, 18 oysters.
10136-8{_}6715{_}_Mode_.--Grate the bread very fine, and be careful that no large lumps remain; put it into a basin with the suet, which must be very finely minced, or, when butter is used, that must be cut up into small pieces.
10136-8{_}6716{_}Add the herbs, also chopped as small as possible, and seasoning; mix all these well together, until the ingredients are thoroughly mingled.
10136-8{_}6717{_}Open and beard the oysters, chop them, but not too small, and add them to the other ingredients.
10136-8{_}6718{_}Beat up the eggs, and, with the hand, work altogether, until it is smoothly mixed.
10136-8{_}6719{_}The turkey should not be stuffed too full: if there should be too much forcemeat, roll it into balls, fry them, and use them as a garnish.
10136-8{_}6720{_}_Sufficient_ for 1 turkey.
10136-8{_}6721{_}OYSTER KETCHUP.
10136-8{_}6722{_}490.
10136-8{_}6723{_}INGREDIENTS.--Sufficient oysters to fill a pint measure, 1 pint of sherry, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}6724{_}of salt, 1 drachm of cayenne, 2 drachms of pounded mace.
10136-8{_}6725{_}_Mode_.--Procure the oysters very fresh, and open sufficient to fill a pint measure; save the liquor, and scald the oysters in it with the sherry; strain the oysters, and put them in a mortar with the salt, cayenne, and mace; pound the whole until reduced to a pulp, then add it to the liquor in which they were scalded; boil it again five minutes, and skim well; rub the whole through a sieve, and, when cold, bottle and cork closely.
10136-8{_}6726{_}The corks should be sealed.
10136-8{_}6727{_}_Seasonable_ from September to April.
10136-8{_}6728{_}_Note_.--Cider may be substituted for the sherry.
10136-8{_}6729{_}PICKLED OYSTERS.
10136-8{_}6730{_}491.
10136-8{_}6731{_}INGREDIENTS.--100 oysters; to each 1/2 pint of vinegar, 1 blade of pounded mace, 1 strip of lemon-peel, 12 black peppercorns.
10136-8{_}6732{_}_Mode_.--Get the oysters in good condition, open them, place them in a saucepan, and let them simmer in their own liquor for about 10 minutes, very gently; then take them out, one by one, and place them in a jar, and cover them, when cold, with a pickle made as follows:--Measure the oyster-liquor; add to it the same quantity of vinegar, with mace, lemon-peel, and pepper in the above proportion, and boil it for 5 minutes; when cold, pour over the oysters, and tie them down very closely, as contact with the air spoils them.
10136-8{_}6733{_}_Seasonable_ from September to April.
10136-8{_}6734{_}_Note_.--Put this pickle away in small jars; because directly one is opened, its contents should immediately be eaten, as they soon spoil.
10136-8{_}6735{_}The pickle should not be kept more than 2 or 3 months.
10136-8{_}6736{_}OYSTER SAUCE, to serve with Fish, Boiled Poultry, &c.  492.
10136-8{_}6737{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 dozen oysters, 1/2 pint of melted butter, made with milk, No.
10136-8{_}6738{_}380.
10136-8{_}6739{_}_Mode_.--Open the oysters carefully, and save their liquor; strain it into a clean saucepan (a lined one is best), put in the oysters, and let them just come to the boiling-point, when they should look plump.
10136-8{_}6740{_}Take them off the fire immediately, and put the whole into a basin.
10136-8{_}6741{_}Strain the liquor from them, mix with it sufficient milk to make 1/2 pint altogether, and follow the directions of No.
10136-8{_}6742{_}380.
10136-8{_}6743{_}When the melted butter is ready and very smooth, put in the oysters, which should be previously bearded, if you wish the sauce to be really nice.
10136-8{_}6744{_}Set it by the side of the fire to get thoroughly hot, _but do not allow it to boil_, or the oysters will immediately harden.
10136-8{_}6745{_}Using cream instead of milk makes this sauce extremely delicious.
10136-8{_}6746{_}When liked, add a seasoning of cayenne, or anchovy sauce; but, as we have before stated, a plain sauce _should_ be plain, and not be overpowered by highly-flavoured essences; therefore we recommend that the above directions be implicitly followed, and no seasoning added.
10136-8{_}6747{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 2s.
10136-8{_}6748{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 persons.
10136-8{_}6749{_}Never allow fewer than 6 oysters to 1 person, unless the party is very large.
10136-8{_}6750{_}_Seasonable_ from September to April.
10136-8{_}6751{_}A more economical sauce may be made by using a smaller quantity of oysters, and not bearding them before they are added to the sauce: this may answer the purpose, but we cannot undertake to recommend it as a mode of making this delicious adjunct to fish, &c.   PARSLEY AND BUTTER, to serve with Calf's Head.
10136-8{_}6752{_}Boiled Fowls, &c.  493.
10136-8{_}6753{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 tablespoonfuls of minced parsley, 1/2 pint of melted butter, No.
10136-8{_}6754{_}376.
10136-8{_}6755{_}_Mode_.--Put into a saucepan a small quantity of water, slightly salted, and when it boils, throw in a good bunch of parsley which has been previously washed and tied together in a bunch; let it boil for 5 minutes, drain it, mince the leaves very fine, and put the above quantity in a tureen; pour over it 1/2 pint of smoothly-made melted butter; stir once, that the ingredients may be thoroughly mixed, and serve.
10136-8{_}6756{_}_Time_.--5 minutes to boil the parsley.
10136-8{_}6757{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}6758{_}_Sufficient_ for 1 large fowl; allow rather more for a pair.
10136-8{_}6759{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}6760{_}_Note_.--Sometimes, in the middle of winter, parsley-leaves are not to be had, when the following will be found an excellent substitute:--Tie up a little parsley-seed in a small piece of muslin, and boil it for 10 minutes in a small quantity of water; use this water to make the melted butter with, and throw into it a little boiled spinach, minced rather fine, which will have an appearance similar to that of parsley.
10136-8{_}6761{_}[Illustration: PARSLEY.]
10136-8{_}6762{_}PARSLEY.--If there be nothing new under the sun, there are, at     any rate, different uses found for the same thing; for this     pretty aromatic herb was used in ancient times, as we learn from     mythological narrative, to adorn the head of a hero, no less     than Hercules; and now--was ever fall so great?--we moderns use     it in connection with the head of--a calf.
10136-8{_}6763{_}According to Homer's     "Iliad," warriors fed their chariot-steeds on parsley; and Pliny     acquaints us with the fact that, as a symbol of mourning, it was     admitted to furnish the funeral tables of the Romans.
10136-8{_}6764{_}Egypt,     some say, first produced this herb; thence it was introduced, by     some unknown voyager, into Sardinia, where the Carthaginians     found it, and made it known to the inhabitants of Marseilles.
10136-8{_}6765{_}(See No.
10136-8{_}6766{_}123.)
10136-8{_}6767{_}FRIED PARSLEY, for Garnishing.
10136-8{_}6768{_}494.
10136-8{_}6769{_}INGREDIENTS.--Parsley, hot lard or clarified dripping.
10136-8{_}6770{_}_Mode_.--Gather some young parsley; wash, pick, and dry it thoroughly in a cloth; put it into the wire basket of which we have given an engraving, and hold it in boiling lard or dripping for a minute or two.
10136-8{_}6771{_}Directly it is done, lift out the basket, and let it stand before the fire, that the parsley may become thoroughly crisp; and the quicker it is fried the better.
10136-8{_}6772{_}Should the kitchen not be furnished with the above article, throw the parsley into the frying-pan, and when crisp, lift it out with a slice, dry it before the fire, and when thoroughly crisp, it will be ready for use.
10136-8{_}6773{_}[Illustration: WIRE BASKET.]
10136-8{_}6774{_}WIRE BASKET.--For this recipe, a wire basket, as shown in the     annexed engraving, will be found very useful.
10136-8{_}6775{_}It is very light     and handy, and may be used for other similar purposes besides     that described above.
10136-8{_}6776{_}PARSLEY JUICE, for Colouring various Dishes.
10136-8{_}6777{_}495.
10136-8{_}6778{_}Procure some nice young parsley; wash it and dry it thoroughly in a cloth; pound the leaves in a mortar till all the juice is extracted, and put the juice in a teacup or small jar; place this in a saucepan of boiling water, and warm it on the _bain marie_ principle just long enough to take off its rawness; let it drain, and it will be ready for colouring.
10136-8{_}6779{_}TO PRESERVE PARSLEY THROUGH THE WINTER.
10136-8{_}6780{_}496.
10136-8{_}6781{_}Use freshly-gathered parsley for keeping, and wash it perfectly free from grit and dirt; put it into boiling water which has been slightly salted and well skimmed, and then let it boil for 2 or 3 minutes; take it out, let it drain, and lay it on a sieve in front of the fire, when it should be dried as expeditiously as possible.
10136-8{_}6782{_}Store it away in a very dry place in bottles, and when wanted for use, pour over it a little warm water, and let it stand for about 5 minutes.
10136-8{_}6783{_}_Seasonable_.--This may be done at any time between June and October.
10136-8{_}6784{_}AN EXCELLENT PICKLE.
10136-8{_}6785{_}497.
10136-8{_}6786{_}INGREDIENTS.--Equal quantities of medium-sized onions, cucumbers, and sauce-apples; 1-1/2 teaspoonful of salt, 3/4 teaspoonful of cayenne, 1 wineglassful of soy, 1 wineglassful of sherry; vinegar.
10136-8{_}6787{_}_Mode_.--Slice sufficient cucumbers, onions, and apples to fill a pint stone jar, taking care to cut the slices very thin; arrange them in alternate layers, shaking in as you proceed salt and cayenne in the above proportion; pour in the soy and wine, and fill up with vinegar.
10136-8{_}6788{_}It will be fit for use the day it is made.
10136-8{_}6789{_}_Seasonable_ in August and September.
10136-8{_}6790{_}[This recipe was forwarded to the editress of this work by a subscriber to the "Englishwoman's Domestic Magazine."
10136-8{_}6791{_}Mrs. Beeton, not having tested it, cannot vouch for its excellence; but the contributor spoke very highly in its favour.]
10136-8{_}6792{_}SOY.--This is a sauce frequently made use of for fish, and comes     from Japan, where it is prepared from the seeds of a plant     called _Dolichos Soja_.
10136-8{_}6793{_}The Chinese also manufacture it; but     that made by the Japanese is said to be the best.
10136-8{_}6794{_}All sorts of     statements have been made respecting the very general     adulteration of this article in England, and we fear that many     of them are too true.
10136-8{_}6795{_}When genuine, it is of an agreeable     flavour, thick, and of a clear brown colour.
10136-8{_}6796{_}PICKLED RED CABBAGE.
10136-8{_}6797{_}498.
10136-8{_}6798{_}INGREDIENTS.--Red cabbages, salt and water; to each quart of vinegar, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}6799{_}of ginger well bruised, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}6800{_}of whole black pepper, and, when liked, a little cayenne.
10136-8{_}6801{_}_Mode_.--Take off the outside decayed leaves of a nice red cabbage, cut it in quarters, remove the stalks, and cut it across in very thin slices.
10136-8{_}6802{_}Lay these on a dish, and strew them plentifully with salt, covering them with another dish.
10136-8{_}6803{_}Let them remain for 24 hours, turn into a colander to drain, and, if necessary, wipe lightly with a clean soft cloth.
10136-8{_}6804{_}Put them in a jar; boil up the vinegar with spices in the above proportion, and, when cold, pour it over the cabbage.
10136-8{_}6805{_}It will be fit for use in a week or two, and, if kept for a very long time, the cabbage is liable get soft and to discolour.
10136-8{_}6806{_}To be really nice and crisp, and of a good red colour, it should be eaten almost immediately after it is made.
10136-8{_}6807{_}A little bruised cochineal boiled with the vinegar adds much to the appearance of this pickle.
10136-8{_}6808{_}Tie down with bladder, and keep in a dry place.
10136-8{_}6809{_}_Seasonable_ in July and August, but the pickle will be much more crisp if the frost has just touched the leaves.
10136-8{_}6810{_}RED CABBAGE.--This plant, in its growth, is similar in form to     that of the white, but is of a bluish-purple colour, which,     however, turns red on the application of acid, as is the case     with all vegetable blues.
10136-8{_}6811{_}It is principally from the white     vegetable that the Germans make their _sauer kraut_; a dish held     in such high estimation with the inhabitants of Vaderland, but     which requires, generally speaking, with strangers, a long     acquaintance in order to become sufficiently impressed with its     numerous merits.
10136-8{_}6812{_}The large red Dutch is the kind generally     recommended for pickling.
10136-8{_}6813{_}PLUM-PUDDING SAUCE.
10136-8{_}6814{_}499.
10136-8{_}6815{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 wineglassful of brandy, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}6816{_}of very fresh butter, 1 glass of Madeira, pounded sugar to taste.
10136-8{_}6817{_}_Mode_.--Put the pounded sugar in a basin, with part of the brandy and the butter; let it stand by the side of the fire until it is warm and the sugar and butter are dissolved; then add the rest of the brandy, with the Madeira.
10136-8{_}6818{_}Either pour it over the pudding, or serve in a tureen.
10136-8{_}6819{_}This is a very rich and excellent sauce.
10136-8{_}6820{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}6821{_}3d.
10136-8{_}6822{_}for this quantity.
10136-8{_}6823{_}_Sufficient_ for a pudding made for 6 persons.
10136-8{_}6824{_}QUIN'S SAUCE, an excellent Fish Sauce.
10136-8{_}6825{_}500.
10136-8{_}6826{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of walnut pickle, 1/2 pint of port wine, 1 pint of mushroom ketchup, 1 dozen anchovies, 1 dozen shalots, 1/4 pint of soy, 1/2 teaspoonful of cayenne.
10136-8{_}6827{_}_Mode_.--Put all the ingredients into a saucepan, having previously chopped the shalots and anchovies very small; simmer for 15 minutes, strain, and, when cold, bottle off for use: the corks should be well sealed to exclude the air.
10136-8{_}6828{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}6829{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}6830{_}RAVIGOTTE, a French Salad Sauce.
10136-8{_}6831{_}_Mons.
10136-8{_}6832{_}Ude's Recipe_.
10136-8{_}6833{_}501.
10136-8{_}6834{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 teaspoonful of mushroom ketchup, 1 teaspoonful of cavice, 1 teaspoonful of Chili vinegar, 1 teaspoonful of Reading sauce, a piece of butter the size of an egg, 3 tablespoonfuls of thick Béchamel, No.
10136-8{_}6835{_}367, 1 tablespoonful of minced parsley, 3 tablespoonfuls of cream; salt and pepper to taste.
10136-8{_}6836{_}_Mode_.--Scald the parsley, mince the leaves very fine, and add it to all the other ingredients; after mixing the whole together thoroughly, the sauce will be ready for use.
10136-8{_}6837{_}_Average cost_, for this quantity, 10d.
10136-8{_}6838{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}6839{_}READING SAUCE.
10136-8{_}6840{_}502.
10136-8{_}6841{_}INGREDIENTS.--2-1/2 pints of walnut pickle, 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}6842{_}of shalots, 1 quart of spring water, 3/4 pint of Indian soy, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}6843{_}of bruised ginger, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}6844{_}of long pepper, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}6845{_}of mustard-seed, 1 anchovy, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}6846{_}of cayenne, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}6847{_}of dried sweet bay-leaves.
10136-8{_}6848{_}_Mode_.--Bruise the shalots in a mortar, and put them in a stone jar with the walnut-liquor; place it before the fire, and let it boil until reduced to 2 pints.
10136-8{_}6849{_}Then, into another jar, put all the ingredients except the bay-leaves, taking care that they are well bruised, so that the flavour may be thoroughly extracted; put this also before the fire, and let it boil for 1 hour, or rather more.
10136-8{_}6850{_}When the contents of both jars are sufficiently cooked, mix them together, stirring them well as you mix them, and submit them to a slow boiling for 1/2 hour; cover closely, and let them stand 24 hours in a cool place; then open the jar and add the bay-leaves; let it stand a week longer closed down, when strain through a flannel bag, and it will be ready for use.
10136-8{_}6851{_}The above quantities will make 1/2 gallon.
10136-8{_}6852{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 3 hours.
10136-8{_}6853{_}_Seasonable_.--This sauce may be made at any time.
10136-8{_}6854{_}REMOULADE, or FRENCH SALAD-DRESSING.
10136-8{_}6855{_}503.
10136-8{_}6856{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 eggs, 1/2 tablespoonful of made mustard, salt and cayenne to taste, 3 tablespoonfuls of olive-oil, 1 tablespoonful of tarragon or plain vinegar.
10136-8{_}6857{_}_Mode_.--Boil 3 eggs quite hard for about 1/4 hour, put them into cold water, and let them remain in it for a few minutes; strip off the shells, put the yolks in a mortar, and pound them very smoothly; add to them, very gradually, the mustard, seasoning, and vinegar, keeping all well stirred and rubbed down with the back of a wooden spoon.
10136-8{_}6858{_}Put in the oil drop by drop, and when this is thoroughly mixed with the other ingredients, add the yolk of a raw egg, and stir well, when it will be ready for use.
10136-8{_}6859{_}This sauce should not be curdled; and to prevent this, the only way is to mix a little of everything at a time, and not to cease stirring.
10136-8{_}6860{_}The quantities of oil and vinegar may be increased or diminished according to taste, as many persons would prefer a smaller proportion of the former ingredient.
10136-8{_}6861{_}GREEN REMOULADE is made by using tarragon vinegar instead of plain, and colouring with a little parsley-juice, No.
10136-8{_}6862{_}495.
10136-8{_}6863{_}Harvey's sauce, or Chili vinegar, may be added at pleasure.
10136-8{_}6864{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour to boil the eggs.
10136-8{_}6865{_}_Average cost_, for this quantity, 7d.
10136-8{_}6866{_}_Sufficient_ for a salad made for 4 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}6867{_}[Illustration: TARRAGON.]
10136-8{_}6868{_}TARRAGON.--The leaves of this plant, known to naturalists as     _Artemisia dracunculus_, are much used in France as a flavouring     ingredient for salads.
10136-8{_}6869{_}From it also is made the vinegar known as     tarragon vinegar, which is employed by the French in mixing     their mustard.
10136-8{_}6870{_}It originally comes from Tartary, and does not     seed in France.
10136-8{_}6871{_}SAGE-AND-ONION STUFFING, for Geese, Ducks, and Pork.
10136-8{_}6872{_}504.
10136-8{_}6873{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 large onions, 10 sage-leaves, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}6874{_}of bread crumbs, 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}6875{_}of butter, salt and pepper to taste, 1 egg.
10136-8{_}6876{_}_Mode_.--Peel the onions, put them into boiling water, let them simmer for 5 minutes or rather longer, and, just before they are taken out, put in the sage-leaves for a minute or two to take off their rawness.
10136-8{_}6877{_}Chop both these very fine, add the bread, seasoning, and butter, and work the whole together with the yolk of an egg, when the stuffing will be ready for use.
10136-8{_}6878{_}It should be rather highly seasoned, and the sage-leaves should be very finely chopped.
10136-8{_}6879{_}Many cooks do not parboil the onions in the manner just stated, but merely use them raw.
10136-8{_}6880{_}The stuffing then, however, is not nearly so mild, and, to many tastes, its strong flavour would be very objectionable.
10136-8{_}6881{_}When made for goose, a portion of the liver of the bird, simmered for a few minutes and very finely minced, is frequently added to this stuffing; and where economy is studied, the egg may be dispensed with.
10136-8{_}6882{_}_Time_.--Rather more than 5 minutes to simmer the onions.
10136-8{_}6883{_}_Average cost_, for this quantity, 4d.
10136-8{_}6884{_}_Sufficient_ for 1 goose, or a pair of ducks.
10136-8{_}6885{_}505.
10136-8{_}6886{_}SOYER'S RECIPE FOR GOOSE STUFFING.--Take 4 apples, peeled and cored, 4 onions, 4 leaves of sage, and 4 leaves of lemon thyme not broken, and boil them in a stewpan with sufficient water to cover them; when done, pulp them through a sieve, removing the sage and thyme; then add sufficient pulp of mealy potatoes to cause it to be sufficiently dry without sticking to the hand; add pepper and salt, and stuff the bird.
10136-8{_}6887{_}SALAD DRESSING (Excellent).
10136-8{_}6888{_}I.
10136-8{_}6889{_}506.
10136-8{_}6890{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 teaspoonful of mixed mustard, 1 teaspoonful of pounded sugar, 2 tablespoonfuls of salad oil, 4 tablespoonfuls of milk, 2 tablespoonfuls of vinegar, cayenne and salt to taste.
10136-8{_}6891{_}_Mode_.--Put the mixed mustard into a salad-bowl with the sugar, and add the oil drop by drop, carefully stirring and mixing all these ingredients well together.
10136-8{_}6892{_}Proceed in this manner with the milk and vinegar, which must be added very _gradually_, or the sauce will curdle.
10136-8{_}6893{_}Put in the seasoning, when the mixture will be ready for use.
10136-8{_}6894{_}If this dressing is properly made, it will have a soft creamy appearance, and will be found very delicious with crab, or cold fried fish (the latter cut into dice), as well as with salads.
10136-8{_}6895{_}In mixing salad dressings, the ingredients cannot be added _too gradually_, or _stirred too much_.
10136-8{_}6896{_}_Average cost_, for this quantity, 3d.
10136-8{_}6897{_}_Sufficient_ for a small salad.
10136-8{_}6898{_}This recipe can be confidently recommended by the editress, to whom it was given by an intimate friend noted for her salads.
10136-8{_}6899{_}SCARCITY OF SALADS IN ENGLAND.--Three centuries ago, very few     vegetables were cultivated in England, and an author writing of     the period of Henry VIII.
10136-8{_}6900{_}'s reign, tells us that neither salad,     nor carrots, nor cabbages, nor radishes, nor any other     comestibles of a like nature, were grown in any part of the     kingdom: they came from Holland and Flanders.
10136-8{_}6901{_}We further learn,     that Queen Catharine herself, with all her royalty, could not     procure a salad of English growth for her dinner.
10136-8{_}6902{_}The king was     obliged to mend this sad state of affairs, and send to Holland     for a gardener in order to cultivate those pot-herbs, in the     growth of which England is now, perhaps, not behind any other     country in Europe.
10136-8{_}6903{_}[Illustration: THE OLIVE.]
10136-8{_}6904{_}THE OLIVE AND OLIVE OIL.--This tree assumes a high degree of     interest from the historical circumstances with which it is     connected.
10136-8{_}6905{_}A leaf of it was brought into the ark by the dove,     when that vessel was still floating on the waters of the great     deep, and gave the first token that the deluge was subsiding.
10136-8{_}6906{_}Among the Greeks, the prize of the victor in the Olympic games     was a wreath of wild olive; and the "Mount of Olives" is     rendered familiar to our ears by its being mentioned in the     Scriptures as near to Jerusalem.
10136-8{_}6907{_}The tree is indigenous in the     north of Africa, Syria, and Greece; and the Romans introduced it     to Italy.
10136-8{_}6908{_}In Spain and the south of France it is now cultivated;     and although it grows in England, its fruit does not ripen in     the open air.
10136-8{_}6909{_}Both in Greece and Portugal the fruit is eaten in     its ripe state; but its taste is not agreeable to many palates.
10136-8{_}6910{_}To the Italian shepherd, bread and olives, with a little wine,     form a nourishing diet; but in England, olives are usually only     introduced by way of dessert, to destroy the taste of the viands     which have been previously eaten, that the flavour of the wine     may be the better enjoyed.
10136-8{_}6911{_}There are three kinds of olives     imported to London,--the French, Spanish, and Italian: the first     are from Provence, and are generally accounted excellent; the     second are larger, but more bitter; and the last are from Lucca,     and are esteemed the best.
10136-8{_}6912{_}The oil extracted from olives, called     olive oil, or salad oil, is, with the continentals, in continual     request, more dishes being prepared with than without it, we     should imagine.
10136-8{_}6913{_}With us, it is principally used in mixing a     salad, and when thus employed, it tends to prevent fermentation,     and is an antidote against flatulency.
10136-8{_}6914{_}II.
10136-8{_}6915{_}507.
10136-8{_}6916{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 eggs, 1 teaspoonful of mixed mustard, 1/4 teaspoonful of white pepper, half that quantity of cayenne, salt to taste, 4 tablespoonfuls of cream, vinegar.
10136-8{_}6917{_}_Mode_.--Boil the eggs until hard, which will be in about 1/4 hour or 20 minutes; put them into cold water, take off the shells, and pound the yolks in a mortar to a smooth paste.
10136-8{_}6918{_}Then add all the other ingredients, except the vinegar, and stir them well until the whole are thoroughly incorporated one with the other.
10136-8{_}6919{_}Pour in sufficient vinegar to make it of the consistency of cream, taking care to add but little at a time.
10136-8{_}6920{_}The mixture will then be ready for use.
10136-8{_}6921{_}_Average cost_, for this quantity, 7d.
10136-8{_}6922{_}_Sufficient_ for a moderate-sized salad.
10136-8{_}6923{_}_Note_.--The whites of the eggs, cut into rings, will serve very well as a garnishing to the salad.
10136-8{_}6924{_}III.
10136-8{_}6925{_}508.
10136-8{_}6926{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 egg, 1 teaspoonful of salad oil, 1 teaspoonful of mixed mustard, 1/4 teaspoonful of salt, 1/2 teaspoonful of pounded sugar, 2 tablespoonfuls of vinegar, 6 tablespoonfuls of cream.
10136-8{_}6927{_}_Mode_.--Prepare and mix the ingredients by the preceding recipe, and be very particular that the whole is well stirred.
10136-8{_}6928{_}_Note_.--In making salads, the vegetables, &c., should never be added to the sauce very long before they are wanted for table; the dressing, however, may always be prepared some hours before required.
10136-8{_}6929{_}Where salads are much in request, it is a good plan to bottle off sufficient dressing for a few days' consumption, as, thereby, much time and trouble are saved.
10136-8{_}6930{_}If kept in a cool place, it will remain good for 4 or 5 days.
10136-8{_}6931{_}POETIC RECIPE FOR SALAD.--The Rev.
10136-8{_}6932{_}Sydney Smith, the witty canon     of St. Paul's, who thought that an enjoyment of the good things     of this earth was compatible with aspirations for things higher,     wrote the following excellent recipe for salad, which we should     advise our readers not to pass by without a trial, when the hot     weather invites to a dish of cold lamb.
10136-8{_}6933{_}May they find the     flavour equal to the rhyme.--        "Two large potatoes, pass'd through kitchen sieve,       Smoothness and softness to the salad give:       Of mordent mustard add a single spoon,       Distrust the condiment that bites too soon;       But deem it not, thou man of herbs, a fault.
10136-8{_}6934{_}To add a double quantity of salt:       Four times the spoon with oil of Lucca crown,       And twice with vinegar procured from 'town;       True flavour needs it, and your poet begs,       The pounded yellow of two well-boil'd eggs.
10136-8{_}6935{_}Let onion's atoms lurk within the bowl,       And, scarce suspected, animate the whole;       And, lastly, in the flavour'd compound toss       A magic spoonful of anchovy sauce.
10136-8{_}6936{_}Oh!
10136-8{_}6937{_}great and glorious, and herbaceous treat,       'Twould tempt the dying anchorite to eat.
10136-8{_}6938{_}Back to the world he'd turn his weary soul,       And plunge his fingers in the salad-bowl."
10136-8{_}6939{_}SAUCE ALLEMANDE, or GERMAN SAUCE.
10136-8{_}6940{_}509.
10136-8{_}6941{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of sauce tournée (No.
10136-8{_}6942{_}517), the yolks of 2 eggs.
10136-8{_}6943{_}_Mode_.--Put the sauce into a stewpan, heat it, and stir to it the beaten yolks of 2 eggs, which have been previously strained.
10136-8{_}6944{_}Let it just simmer, but not boil, or the eggs will curdle; and after they are added to the sauce, it must be stirred without ceasing.
10136-8{_}6945{_}This sauce is a general favourite, and is used for many made dishes.
10136-8{_}6946{_}_Time_.--1 minute to simmer.
10136-8{_}6947{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}6948{_}SAUCE ARISTOCRATIQUE (a Store Sauce).
10136-8{_}6949{_}510.
10136-8{_}6950{_}INGREDIENTS.--Green walnuts.
10136-8{_}6951{_}To every pint of juice, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}6952{_}of anchovies, 1 drachm of cloves, 1 drachm of mace, 1 drachm of Jamaica ginger bruised, 8 shalots.
10136-8{_}6953{_}To every pint of the boiled liquor, 1/2 pint of vinegar, 1/4 pint of port wine, 2 tablespoonfuls of soy.
10136-8{_}6954{_}_Mode_.--Pound the walnuts in a mortar, squeeze out the juice through a strainer, and let it stand to settle.
10136-8{_}6955{_}Pour off the clear juice, and to every pint of it, add anchovies, spices, and cloves in the above proportion.
10136-8{_}6956{_}Boil all these together till the anchovies are dissolved, then strain the juice again, put in the shalots (8 to every pint), and boil again.
10136-8{_}6957{_}To every pint of the boiled liquor add vinegar, wine, and soy, in the above quantities, and bottle off for use.
10136-8{_}6958{_}Cork well, and seal the corks.
10136-8{_}6959{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this sauce from the beginning to the middle of July, when walnuts are in perfection for sauces and pickling.
10136-8{_}6960{_}_Average cost_, 3s.
10136-8{_}6961{_}6d.
10136-8{_}6962{_}for a quart.
10136-8{_}6963{_}MANUFACTURE OF SAUCES.--In France, during the reign of Louis     XII., at the latter end of the 14th century, there was formed a     company of sauce-manufacturers, who obtained, in those days of     monopolies, the exclusive privilege of making sauces.
10136-8{_}6964{_}The     statutes drawn up by this company inform us that the famous     sauce à la cameline, sold by them, was to be composed or "good     cinnamon, good ginger, good cloves, good grains of paradise,     good bread, and good vinegar."
10136-8{_}6965{_}The sauce Tence, was to be made     of "good sound almonds, good ginger, good wine, and good     verjuice."
10136-8{_}6966{_}May we respectfully express a hope--not that we     desire to doubt it in the least--that the English     sauce-manufacturers of the 19th century are equally considerate     and careful in choosing their ingredients for their various     well-known preparations.
10136-8{_}6967{_}SAUCE A L'AURORE, for Trout, Soles, &c.  511.
10136-8{_}6968{_}INGREDIENTS.--The spawn of 1 lobster, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}6969{_}of butter, 1/2 pint of Béchamel (No.
10136-8{_}6970{_}367), the juice of 1/2 lemon, a high seasoning of salt and cayenne.
10136-8{_}6971{_}_Mode_.--Take the spawn and pound it in a mortar with the butter, until quite smooth, and work it through a hair sieve.
10136-8{_}6972{_}Put the Béchamel into a stewpan, add the pounded spawn, the lemon-juice, which must be strained, and a plentiful seasoning of cayenne and salt; let it just simmer, but do not allow it to boil, or the beautiful red colour of the sauce will be spoiled.
10136-8{_}6973{_}A small spoonful of anchovy essence may be added at pleasure.
10136-8{_}6974{_}_Time_.--1 minute to simmer.
10136-8{_}6975{_}_Average cost_, for this quantity, 1s.
10136-8{_}6976{_}_Sufficient_ for a pair of large soles.
10136-8{_}6977{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}6978{_}SAUCE A LA MATELOTE, for Fish.
10136-8{_}6979{_}512.
10136-8{_}6980{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of Espagnole (No.
10136-8{_}6981{_}411), 3 onions, 2 tablespoonfuls of mushroom ketchup, 1/2 glass of port wine, a bunch of sweet herbs, 1/2 bay-leaf, salt and pepper to taste, 1 clove, 2 berries of allspice, a little liquor in which the fish has been boiled, lemon-juice, and anchovy sauce.
10136-8{_}6982{_}_Mode_.--Slice and fry the onions of a nice brown colour, and put them into a stewpan with the Espagnole, ketchup, wine, and a little liquor in which the fish has been boiled.
10136-8{_}6983{_}Add the seasoning, herbs, and spices, and simmer gently for 10 minutes, stirring well the whole time; strain it through a fine hair sieve, put in the lemon-juice and anchovy sauce, and pour it over the fish.
10136-8{_}6984{_}This sauce may be very much enriched by adding a few small quenelles, or forcemeat balls made of fish, and also glazed onions or mushrooms.
10136-8{_}6985{_}These, however, should not be added to the matelote till it is dished.
10136-8{_}6986{_}_Time_.--10 minutes.
10136-8{_}6987{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}6988{_}6d.
10136-8{_}6989{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}6990{_}_Note_.--This sauce originally took its name as being similar to that which the French sailor (_matelot_) employed as a relish to the fish he caught and ate.
10136-8{_}6991{_}In some cases, cider and perry were substituted for the wine.
10136-8{_}6992{_}The Norman _matelotes_ were very celebrated.
10136-8{_}6993{_}[Illustration: THE BAY.]
10136-8{_}6994{_}THE BAY.--We have already described (see No.
10136-8{_}6995{_}180) the difference     between the cherry-laurel (_Prunus Laurus cerasus_) and the     classic laurel (_Laurus nobilis_), the former only being used     for culinary purposes.
10136-8{_}6996{_}The latter beautiful evergreen was     consecrated by the ancients to priests and heroes, and used in     their sacrifices.
10136-8{_}6997{_}"A crown of bay" was the earnestly-desired     reward for great enterprises, and for the display of uncommon     genius in oratory or writing.
10136-8{_}6998{_}It was more particularly sacred to     Apollo, because, according to the fable, the nymph Daphne was     changed into a laurel-tree.
10136-8{_}6999{_}The ancients believed, too, that the     laurel had the power of communicating the gift of prophecy, as     well as poetic genius; and, when they wished to procure pleasant     dreams, would place a sprig under the pillow of their bed.
10136-8{_}7000{_}It     was the symbol, too, of victory, and it was thought that the     laurel could never be struck by lightning.
10136-8{_}7001{_}From this word comes     that of "laureate;" Alfred Tennyson being the present poet     laureate, crowned with laurel as the first of living bards.
10136-8{_}7002{_}SAUCE PIQUANTE, for Cutlets, Roast Meat, &c.  513.
10136-8{_}7003{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 oz.
10136-8{_}7004{_}of butter, 1 small carrot, 6 shalots, 1 small bunch of savoury herbs, including parsley, 1/2 a bay-leaf, 2 slices of lean ham, 2 cloves, 6 peppercorns, 1 blade of mace, 3 whole allspice, 4 tablespoonfuls of vinegar, 1/2 pint of stock (No.
10136-8{_}7005{_}104 or 105), 1 small lump of sugar, 1/4 saltspoonful of cayenne, salt to taste.
10136-8{_}7006{_}_Mode_.--Put into a stewpan the butter, with the carrot and shalots, both of which must be cut into small slices; add the herbs, bay-leaf, spices, and ham (which must be minced rather finely), and let these ingredients simmer over a slow fire, until the bottom of the stewpan is covered with a brown glaze.
10136-8{_}7007{_}Keep stirring with a wooden spoon, and put in the remaining ingredients.
10136-8{_}7008{_}Simmer very gently for 1/4 hour, skim off every particle of fat, strain the sauce through a sieve, and serve very hot.
10136-8{_}7009{_}Care must be taken that this sauce be not made too acid, although it should possess a sharpness indicated by its name.
10136-8{_}7010{_}Of course the above quantity of vinegar may be increased or diminished at pleasure, according to taste.
10136-8{_}7011{_}_Time_.--Altogether 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}7012{_}_Average cost_, 10d.
10136-8{_}7013{_}_Sufficient_ for a medium-sized dish of cutlets.
10136-8{_}7014{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}7015{_}A GOOD SAUCE FOR VARIOUS BOILED PUDDINGS.
10136-8{_}7016{_}514.
10136-8{_}7017{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}7018{_}of butter, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}7019{_}of pounded sugar, a wineglassful of brandy or rum.
10136-8{_}7020{_}_Mode_.--Beat the butter to a cream, until no lumps remain; add the pounded sugar, and brandy or rum; stir once or twice until the whole is thoroughly mixed, and serve.
10136-8{_}7021{_}This sauce may either be poured round the pudding or served in a tureen, according to the taste or fancy of the cook or mistress.
10136-8{_}7022{_}_Average cost_, 8d.
10136-8{_}7023{_}for this quantity.
10136-8{_}7024{_}_Sufficient_ for a pudding.
10136-8{_}7025{_}SAUCE ROBERT, for Steaks, &c.  515.
10136-8{_}7026{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 oz.
10136-8{_}7027{_}of butter, 3 onions, 1 teaspoonful of flour, 4 tablespoonfuls of gravy, or stock No.
10136-8{_}7028{_}105, salt and pepper to taste, 1 teaspoonful of made mustard, 1 teaspoonful of vinegar, the juice of 1/2 lemon.
10136-8{_}7029{_}_Mode_.--Put the butter into a stewpan, set it on the fire, and, when browning, throw in the onions, which must be cut into small slices.
10136-8{_}7030{_}Fry them brown, but do not burn them; add the flour, shake the onions in it, and give the whole another fry.
10136-8{_}7031{_}Put in the gravy and seasoning, and boil it gently for 10 minutes; skim off the fat, add the mustard, vinegar, and lemon-juice; give it one boil, and pour round the steaks, or whatever dish the sauce has been prepared for.
10136-8{_}7032{_}_Time_.---Altogether 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}7033{_}_Average cost_, for this quantity, 6d.
10136-8{_}7034{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}7035{_}_Sufficient_ for about 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}7036{_}of steak.
10136-8{_}7037{_}_Note_.--This sauce will be found an excellent accompaniment to roast goose, pork, mutton cutlets, and various other dishes.
10136-8{_}7038{_}A GOOD SAUCE FOR STEAKS.
10136-8{_}7039{_}516.
10136-8{_}7040{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 oz.
10136-8{_}7041{_}of whole black pepper, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}7042{_}of allspice, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}7043{_}of salt, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}7044{_}grated horseradish, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}7045{_}of pickled shalots, 1 pint of mushroom ketchup or walnut pickle.
10136-8{_}7046{_}_Mode_.--Pound all the ingredients finely in a mortar, and put them into the ketchup or walnut-liquor.
10136-8{_}7047{_}Let them stand for a fortnight, when strain off the liquor and bottle for use.
10136-8{_}7048{_}Either pour a little of the sauce over the steaks or mix it in the gravy.
10136-8{_}7049{_}_Seasonable_.--This can be made at any time.
10136-8{_}7050{_}_Note_.--In using a jar of pickled walnuts, there is frequently left a large quantity of liquor; this should be converted into a sauce like the above, and will be found a very useful relish.
10136-8{_}7051{_}THE GROWTH OF THE PEPPER-PLANT.--Our readers will see at Nos.
10136-8{_}7052{_}369 and 399, a description, with engravings, of the qualities of     black and long pepper, and an account of where these spices are     found.
10136-8{_}7053{_}We will here say something of the manner of the growth of     the pepper-plant.
10136-8{_}7054{_}Like the vine, it requires support, and it is     usual to plant a thorny tree by its side, to which it may cling.
10136-8{_}7055{_}In Malabar, the chief pepper district of India, the jacca-tree     (_Artocarpus integrifolia_) is made thus to yield its     assistance, the same soil being adapted to the growth of both     plants.
10136-8{_}7056{_}The stem of the pepper-plant entwines round its support     to a considerable height; the flexile branches then droop     downwards, bearing at their extremities, as well as at other     parts, spikes of green flowers, which are followed by the     pungent berries.
10136-8{_}7057{_}These hang in large bunches, resembling in     shape those of grapes; but the fruit grows distinct, each on a     little stalk, like currants.
10136-8{_}7058{_}Each berry contains a single seed,     of a globular form and brownish colour, but which changes to a     nearly black when dried; and this is the pepper of commerce.
10136-8{_}7059{_}The     leaves are not unlike those of the ivy, but are larger and of     rather lighter colour; they partake strongly of the peculiar     smell and pungent taste of the berry.
10136-8{_}7060{_}SAUCE TOURNEE.
10136-8{_}7061{_}517.
10136-8{_}7062{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint of white stock (No.
10136-8{_}7063{_}107), thickening of flour and butter, or white roux (No.
10136-8{_}7064{_}526), a faggot of savoury herbs, including parsley, 6 chopped mushrooms, 6 green onions.
10136-8{_}7065{_}_Mode_.--Put the stock into a stewpan with the herbs, onions, and mushrooms, and let it simmer very gently for about 1/2 hour; stir in sufficient thickening to make it of a proper consistency; let it boil for a few minutes, then skim off all the fat, strain and serve.
10136-8{_}7066{_}This sauce, with the addition of a little cream, is now frequently called velouté.
10136-8{_}7067{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}7068{_}_Average cost_, for this quantity, 6d.
10136-8{_}7069{_}_Note_.--If poultry trimmings are at hand, the stock should be made of these; and the above sauce should not be made too thick, as it does not then admit of the fat being nicely removed.

10136-8{_}7089{_}of bread crumbs, 1 small tablespoonful of minced sage, 1 blade of pounded mace, salt and pepper to taste, 1 egg.
10136-8{_}7090{_}_Mode_.--Chop the meat and fat very finely, mix with them the other ingredients, taking care that the whole is thoroughly incorporated.
