10136-8{_}7097{_}SAVOURY JELLY FOR MEAT PIES.
10136-8{_}7098{_}521.
10136-8{_}7099{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 lbs.
10136-8{_}7100{_}of shin of beef, 1 calf's-foot, 3 lbs.
10136-8{_}7101{_}of knuckle of veal, poultry trimmings (if for game pies, any game trimmings), 2 onions stuck with cloves, 2 carrots, 4 shalots, a bunch of savoury herbs, 2 bay-leaves; when liked, 2 blades of mace and a little spice; 2 slices of lean ham, rather more than 2 quarts of water.
10136-8{_}7102{_}_Mode_.--Cut up the meat and put it into a stewpan with all the ingredients except the water; set it over a slow fire to draw down, and, when the gravy ceases to flow from the meat, pour in the water.
10136-8{_}7103{_}Let it boil up, then carefully take away all scum from the top.
10136-8{_}7104{_}Cover the stewpan closely, and let the stock simmer very gently for 4 hours: if rapidly boiled, the jelly will not be clear.
10136-8{_}7105{_}When done, strain it through a fine sieve or flannel bag; and when cold, the jelly should be quite transparent.
10136-8{_}7106{_}If this is not the case, clarify it with the whites of eggs, as described in recipe No.
10136-8{_}7107{_}109.
10136-8{_}7108{_}_Time_.--4 hours.
10136-8{_}7109{_}_Average cost_, for this quantity, 5s.

10136-8{_}7120{_}SPINACH GREEN FOR COLOURING VARIOUS DISHES.
10136-8{_}7121{_}523.
10136-8{_}7122{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 handfuls of spinach.
10136-8{_}7123{_}_Mode_.--Pick and wash the spinach free from dirt, and pound the leaves in a mortar to extract the juice; then press it through a hair sieve, and put the juice into a small stewpan or jar.
10136-8{_}7124{_}Place this in a bain marie, or saucepan of boiling water, and let it set.
10136-8{_}7125{_}Watch it closely, as it should not boil; and, as soon as it is done, lay it in a sieve, so that all the water may drain from it, and the green will then be ready for colouring.
10136-8{_}7126{_}If made according to this recipe, the spinach-green will be found far superior to that boiled in the ordinary way.
10136-8{_}7127{_}HOT SPICE, a Delicious Adjunct to Chops, Steaks, Gravies, &c.  524.
10136-8{_}7128{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 drachms each of ginger, black pepper, and cinnamon, 7 cloves, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}7129{_}mace, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}7130{_}of cayenne, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}7131{_}grated nutmeg, 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}7132{_}white pepper.
10136-8{_}7133{_}_Mode_.--Pound the ingredients, and mix them thoroughly together, taking care that everything is well blended.

10136-8{_}7136{_}[Illustration: CINNAMON.]
10136-8{_}7137{_}CINNAMON.--The cinnamon-tree (_Laurus Cinnamomum_) is a valuable     and beautiful species of the laurel family, and grows to the     height of 20 or 30 feet.
10136-8{_}7138{_}The trunk is short and straight, with     wide-spreading branches, and it has a smooth ash-like bark.
10136-8{_}7139{_}The     leaves are upon short stalks, and are of an oval shape, and 3 to     5 inches long.
10136-8{_}7140{_}The flowers are in panicles, with six small     petals, and the fruit is about the size of an olive, soft,     insipid, and of a deep blue.
10136-8{_}7141{_}This incloses a nut, the kernel of     which germinates soon after it falls.
10136-8{_}7142{_}The wood of the tree is     white and not very solid, and its root is thick and branching,     exuding a great quantity of camphor.
10136-8{_}7143{_}The inner bark of the tree     forms the cinnamon of commerce.
10136-8{_}7144{_}Ceylon was thought to be its     native island; but it has been found in Malabar, Cochin-China,     Sumatra, and the Eastern Islands; also in the Brazils, the     Mauritius, Jamaica, and other tropical localities.
10136-8{_}7145{_}BROWN ROUX, a French Thickening for Gravies and Sauces.
10136-8{_}7146{_}525.
10136-8{_}7147{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 oz.
10136-8{_}7148{_}of butter, 9 oz.
10136-8{_}7149{_}of flour.
10136-8{_}7150{_}_Mode_.--Melt the butter in a stewpan over a slow fire, and dredge in, very gradually, the flour; stir it till of a light-brown colour--to obtain this do it very slowly, otherwise the flour will burn and impart a bitter taste to the sauce it is mixed with.
10136-8{_}7151{_}Pour it in a jar, and keep it for use: it will remain good some time.
10136-8{_}7152{_}_Time_.--About 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}7153{_}_Average cost_, 7d.
10136-8{_}7154{_}WHITE ROUX, for thickening White Sauces.
10136-8{_}7155{_}526.
10136-8{_}7156{_}Allow the same proportions of butter and flour as in the preceding recipe, and proceed in the same manner as for brown roux, but do not keep it on the fire too long, and take care not to let it colour.
10136-8{_}7157{_}This is used for thickening white sauce.
10136-8{_}7158{_}Pour it into a jar to use when wanted.
10136-8{_}7159{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}7160{_}_Average cost_, 7d.
10136-8{_}7161{_}_Sufficient_,--A dessertspoonful will thicken a pint of gravy.
10136-8{_}7162{_}_Note_.--Besides the above, sauces may be thickened with potato flour, ground rice, baked flour, arrowroot, &c.: the latter will be found far preferable to the ordinary flour for white sauces.
10136-8{_}7163{_}A slice of bread, toasted and added to gravies, answers the two purposes of thickening and colouring them.
10136-8{_}7164{_}SPANISH ONIONS--PICKLED.
10136-8{_}7165{_}527.
10136-8{_}7166{_}INGREDIENTS.--Onions, vinegar; salt and cayenne to taste.
10136-8{_}7167{_}_Mode_.--Cut the onions in thin slices; put a layer of them in the bottom of a jar; sprinkle with salt and cayenne; then add another layer of onions, and season as before.
10136-8{_}7168{_}Proceeding in this manner till the jar is full, pour in sufficient vinegar to cover the whole, and the pickle will be fit for use in a month.
10136-8{_}7169{_}_Seasonable_.--May be had in England from September to February.

10136-8{_}7177{_}TOMATO SAUCE--HOT, to serve with Cutlets, Roast Meats, &c.  529.
10136-8{_}7178{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 tomatoes, 2 shalots, 1 clove, 1 blade of mace, salt and cayenne to taste, 1/4 pint of gravy, No.
10136-8{_}7179{_}436, or stock No.
10136-8{_}7180{_}104.
10136-8{_}7181{_}_Mode_.--Cut the tomatoes in two, and squeeze the juice and seeds out; put them in a stewpan with all the ingredients, and let them simmer _gently_ until the tomatoes are tender enough to pulp; rub the whole through a sieve, boil it for a few minutes, and serve.
10136-8{_}7182{_}The shalots and spices may be omitted when their flavour is objected to.
10136-8{_}7183{_}_Time_.--1 hour, or rather more, to simmer the tomatoes.
10136-8{_}7184{_}_Average cost_, for this quantity, 1s.
10136-8{_}7185{_}_In full season_ in September and October.
10136-8{_}7186{_}[Illustration: THE TOMATO.]
10136-8{_}7187{_}TOMATO, OR LOVE-APPLE.--The plant which bears this fruit is a     native of South America, and takes its name from a Portuguese     word.
10136-8{_}7188{_}The tomato fruit is about the size of a small potato, and     is chiefly used in soups, sauces, and gravies.
10136-8{_}7189{_}It is sometimes     served to table roasted or boiled, and when green, makes a good     ketchup or pickle.
10136-8{_}7190{_}In its unripe state, it is esteemed as     excellent sauce for roast goose or pork, and when quite ripe, a     good store sauce may be prepared from it.
10136-8{_}7191{_}TOMATO SAUCE FOR KEEPING (Excellent).
10136-8{_}7192{_}I.
10136-8{_}7193{_}530.
10136-8{_}7194{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every quart of tomato-pulp allow 1 pint of cayenne vinegar (No.
10136-8{_}7195{_}386), 3/4 oz.
10136-8{_}7196{_}of shalots, 3/4 oz.
10136-8{_}7197{_}of garlic, peeled and cut in slices; salt to taste.
10136-8{_}7198{_}To every six quarts of liquor, 1 pint of soy, 1 pint of anchovy sauce.
10136-8{_}7199{_}_Mode_.--Gather the tomatoes quite ripe; bake them in a slow oven till tender; rub them through a sieve, and to every quart of pulp add cayenne vinegar, shalots, garlic, and salt, in the above proportion; boil the whole together till the garlic and shalots are quite soft; then rub it through a sieve, put it again into a saucepan, and, to every six quarts of the liquor, add 1 pint of soy and the same quantity of anchovy sauce, and boil altogether for about 20 minutes; bottle off for use, and carefully seal or rosin the corks.
10136-8{_}7200{_}This will keep good for 2 or 3 years, but will be fit for use in a week.
10136-8{_}7201{_}A useful and less expensive sauce may be made by omitting the anchovy and soy.
10136-8{_}7202{_}_Time_.--Altogether 1 hour.
10136-8{_}7203{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this from the middle of September to the end of October.
10136-8{_}7204{_}II.
10136-8{_}7205{_}531.
10136-8{_}7206{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 dozen tomatoes, 2 teaspoonfuls of the best powdered ginger, 1 dessertspoonful of salt, 1 head of garlic chopped fine, 2 tablespoonfuls of vinegar, 1 dessertspoonful of Chili vinegar (a small quantity of cayenne may be substituted for this).
10136-8{_}7207{_}_Mode_.--Choose ripe tomatoes, put them into a stone jar, and stand them in a cool oven until quite tender; when cold, take the skins and stalks from them, mix the pulp with the liquor which is in the jar, but do not strain it; add all the other ingredients, mix well together, and put it into well-sealed bottles.
10136-8{_}7208{_}Stored away in a cool dry place, it will keep good for years.
10136-8{_}7209{_}It is ready for use as soon as made, but the flavour is better after a week or two.
10136-8{_}7210{_}Should it not appear to keep, turn it out, and boil it up with a little additional ginger and cayenne.
10136-8{_}7211{_}For immediate use, the skins should be put into a wide-mouthed bottle with a little of the different ingredients, and they will be found very nice for hashes or stews.
10136-8{_}7212{_}_Time_.--4 or 5 hours in a cool oven.
10136-8{_}7213{_}_Seasonable_ from the middle of September to the end of October.
10136-8{_}7214{_}III.
10136-8{_}7215{_}532.
10136-8{_}7216{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 dozen tomatoes; to every pound of tomato-pulp allow 1 pint of Chili vinegar, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}7217{_}of garlic, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}7218{_}of shalot, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}7219{_}of salt, 1 large green capsicum, 1/2 teaspoonful of cayenne, 2 pickled gherkins, 6 pickled onions, 1 pint of common vinegar, and the juice of 6 lemons.
10136-8{_}7220{_}_Mode_.--Choose the tomatoes when quite ripe and red; put them in a jar with a cover to it, and bake them till tender.
10136-8{_}7221{_}The better way is to put them in the oven overnight, when it will not be too hot, and examine them in the morning to see if they are tender.
10136-8{_}7222{_}Do not allow them to remain in the oven long enough to break them; but they should be sufficiently soft to skin nicely and rub through the sieve.
10136-8{_}7223{_}Measure the pulp, and to each pound of pulp, add the above proportion of vinegar and other ingredients, taking care to chop very fine the garlic, shalot, capsicum, onion, and gherkins.
10136-8{_}7224{_}Boil the whole together till everything is tender; then again rub it through a sieve, and add the lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}7225{_}Now boil the whole again till it becomes as thick as cream, and keep continually stirring; bottle it when quite cold, cork well, and seal the corks.
10136-8{_}7226{_}If the flavour of garlic and shalot is very much disliked, diminish the quantities.
10136-8{_}7227{_}_Time_.--Bake the tomatoes in a cool oven all night.
10136-8{_}7228{_}_Seasonable_ from the middle of September to the end of October.
10136-8{_}7229{_}_Note_.--A quantity of liquor will flow from the tomatoes, which must be put through the sieve with the rest.
10136-8{_}7230{_}Keep it well stirred while on the fire, and use a wooden spoon.
10136-8{_}7231{_}UNIVERSAL PICKLE.
10136-8{_}7232{_}533.
10136-8{_}7233{_}INGREDIENTS.--To 6 quarts of vinegar allow 1 lb.
10136-8{_}7234{_}of salt, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}7235{_}of ginger, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}7236{_}of mace, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}7237{_}of shalots, 1 tablespoonful of cayenne, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}7238{_}of mustard-seed, 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}7239{_}of turmeric.
10136-8{_}7240{_}_Mode_.--Boil all the ingredients together for about 20 minutes; when cold, put them into a jar with whatever vegetables you choose, such as radish-pods, French beans, cauliflowers, gherkins, &c. &c., as these come into season; put them in fresh as you gather them, having previously wiped them perfectly free from moisture and grit.
10136-8{_}7241{_}This pickle will be fit for use in about 8 or 9 months.
10136-8{_}7242{_}_Time_.--20 minutes.
10136-8{_}7243{_}_Seasonable_.--Make the pickle in May or June, to be ready for the various vegetables.
10136-8{_}7244{_}_Note_.--As this pickle takes 2 or 3 months to make,--that is to say, nearly that time will elapse before all the different vegetables are added,--care must be taken to keep the jar which contains the pickle well covered, either with a closely-fitting lid, or a piece of bladder securely tied over, so as perfectly to exclude the air.
10136-8{_}7245{_}PICKLED WALNUTS (Very Good).
10136-8{_}7246{_}534.
10136-8{_}7247{_}INGREDIENTS.--100 walnuts, salt and water.
10136-8{_}7248{_}To each quart of vinegar allow 2 oz.
10136-8{_}7249{_}of whole black pepper, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}7250{_}of allspice, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}7251{_}of bruised ginger.
10136-8{_}7252{_}_Mode_.--Procure the walnuts while young; be careful they are not woody, and prick them well with a fork; prepare a strong brine of salt and water (4 lbs.
10136-8{_}7253{_}of salt to each gallon of water), into which put the walnuts, letting them remain 9 days, and changing the brine every third day; drain them off, put them on a dish, place it in the sun until they become perfectly black, which will be in 2 or 3 days; have ready dry jars, into which place the walnuts, and do not quite fill the jars.
10136-8{_}7254{_}Boil sufficient vinegar to cover them, for 10 minutes, with spices in the above proportion, and pour it hot over the walnuts, which must be quite covered with the pickle; tie down with bladder, and keep in a dry place.
10136-8{_}7255{_}They will be fit for use in a month, and will keep good 2 or 3 years.
10136-8{_}7256{_}_Time_.--10 minutes.
10136-8{_}7257{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this from the beginning to the middle of July, before the walnuts harden.
10136-8{_}7258{_}_Note_.--When liked, a few shalots may be added to the vinegar, and boiled with it.
10136-8{_}7259{_}WALNUT KETCHUP.
10136-8{_}7260{_}I.
10136-8{_}7261{_}535.
10136-8{_}7262{_}INGREDIENTS.--100 walnuts, 1 handful of salt, 1 quart of vinegar, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}7263{_}of mace, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}7264{_}of nutmeg, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}7265{_}of cloves, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}7266{_}of ginger, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}7267{_}of whole black pepper, a small piece of horseradish, 20 shalots, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}7268{_}of anchovies, 1 pint of port wine.
10136-8{_}7269{_}_Mode_.--Procure the walnuts at the time you can run a pin through them, slightly bruise, and put them into a jar with the salt and vinegar, let them stand 8 days, stirring every day; then drain the liquor from them, and boil it, with the above ingredients, for about 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}7270{_}It may be strained or not, as preferred, and, if required, a little more vinegar or wine can be added, according to taste.
10136-8{_}7271{_}When bottled well, seal the corks.
10136-8{_}7272{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}7273{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this from the beginning to the middle of July, when walnuts are in perfection for pickling purposes.
10136-8{_}7274{_}II.
10136-8{_}7275{_}536.
10136-8{_}7276{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 sieve of walnut-shells, 2 quarts of water, salt, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}7277{_}of shalots, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}7278{_}of cloves, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}7279{_}of mace, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}7280{_}of whole pepper, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}7281{_}of garlic.
10136-8{_}7282{_}_Mode_.--Put the walnut-shells into a pan, with the water, and a large quantity of salt; let them stand for 10 days, then break the shells up in the water, and let it drain through a sieve, putting a heavy weight on the top to express the juice; place it on the fire, and remove all scum that may arise.
10136-8{_}7283{_}Now boil the liquor with the shalots, cloves, mace, pepper, and garlic, and let all simmer till the shalots sink; then put the liquor into a pan, and, when cold, bottle, and cork closely.
10136-8{_}7284{_}It should stand 6 months before using: should it ferment during that time, it must be again boiled and skimmed.
10136-8{_}7285{_}_Time_.--About 3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}7286{_}_Seasonable_ in September, when the walnut-shells are obtainable.
10136-8{_}7287{_}[Illustration: THE WALNUT.]
10136-8{_}7288{_}THE WALNUT.--This nut is a native of Persia, and was introduced     into England from France.
10136-8{_}7289{_}As a pickle, it is much used in the     green state; and grated walnuts in Spain are much employed, both     in tarts and other dishes.
10136-8{_}7290{_}On the continent it is occasionally     employed as a substitute for olive oil in cooking; but it is     apt, under such circumstances, to become rancid.
10136-8{_}7291{_}The matter     which remains after the oil is extracted is considered highly     nutritious for poultry.
10136-8{_}7292{_}It is called _mare_, and in Switzerland     is eaten under the name of _pain amer_ by the poor.
10136-8{_}7293{_}The oil is     frequently manufactured into a kind of soap, and the leaves and     green husks yield an extract, which, as a brown dye, is used to     stain hair, wool, and wood.
10136-8{_}7294{_}WHITE SAUCE (Good).
10136-8{_}7295{_}537.
10136-8{_}7296{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of white stock (No.
10136-8{_}7297{_}107), 1/2 pint of cream, 1 dessertspoonful of flour, salt to taste.
10136-8{_}7298{_}_Mode_.--Have ready a delicately-clean saucepan, into which put the stock, which should be well flavoured with vegetables, and rather savoury; mix the flour smoothly with the cream, add it to the stock, season with a little salt, and boil all these ingredients very gently for about 10 minutes, keeping them well stirred the whole time, as this sauce is very liable to burn.
10136-8{_}7299{_}_Time_.--10 minutes.
10136-8{_}7300{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}7301{_}_Sufficient_ for a pair of fowls.
10136-8{_}7302{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}7303{_}WHITE SAUCE, made without Meat.
10136-8{_}7304{_}538.
10136-8{_}7305{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 oz.
10136-8{_}7306{_}of butter, 2 small onions, 1 carrot, 1/2 a small teacupful of flour, 1 pint of new milk, salt and cayenne to taste.
10136-8{_}7307{_}_Mode_.--Cut up the onions and carrot very small, and put them into a stewpan with the butter; simmer them till the butter is nearly dried up; then stir in the flour, and add the milk; boil the whole gently until it thickens, strain it, season with salt and cayenne, and it will be ready to serve.
10136-8{_}7308{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}7309{_}_Average cost_, 5d.
10136-8{_}7310{_}_Sufficient_ for a pair of fowls.
10136-8{_}7311{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}7312{_}WHITE SAUCE (a very Simple and Inexpensive Method).
10136-8{_}7313{_}539.
10136-8{_}7314{_}INGREDIENTS.--1-1/2 pint of milk, 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}7315{_}of rice, 1 strip of lemon-peel, 1 small blade of pounded mace, salt and cayenne to taste.
10136-8{_}7316{_}_Mode_.--Boil the milk with the lemon-peel and rice until the latter is perfectly tender, then take out the lemon-peel and pound the milk and rice together; put it back into the stewpan to warm, add the mace and seasoning, give it one boil, and serve.
10136-8{_}7317{_}This sauce should be of the consistency of thick cream.
10136-8{_}7318{_}_Time_.--About 1-1/2 hour to boil the rice.
10136-8{_}7319{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}7320{_}_Sufficient_ for a pair of fowls.
10136-8{_}7321{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}7322{_}[Illustration: THE LEAMINGTON STOVE, OR KITCHENER.]
10136-8{_}7323{_}VARIOUS MODES OF COOKING MEAT.
10136-8{_}7324{_}CHAPTER XI.
10136-8{_}7325{_}GENERAL REMARKS.
10136-8{_}7326{_}540.
10136-8{_}7327{_}In Our "INTRODUCTION TO COOKERY" (_see_ No.
10136-8{_}7328{_}76) we have described the gradual progress of mankind in the art of cookery, the probability being, that the human race, for a long period, lived wholly on fruits.
10136-8{_}7329{_}Man's means of attacking animals, even if he had the desire of slaughtering them, were very limited, until he acquired the use of arms.
10136-8{_}7330{_}He, however, made weapons for himself, and, impelled by a carnivorous instinct, made prey of the animals that surrounded him.
10136-8{_}7331{_}It is natural that man should seek to feed on flesh; he has too small a stomach to be supported alone by fruit, which has not sufficient nourishment to renovate him.
10136-8{_}7332{_}It is possible he might subsist on vegetables; but their preparation needs the knowledge of art, only to be obtained after the lapse of many centuries.
10136-8{_}7333{_}Man's first weapons were the branches of trees, which were succeeded by bows and arrows, and it is worthy of remark, that these latter weapons have been found with the natives of all climates and latitudes.
10136-8{_}7334{_}It is singular how this idea presented itself to individuals so differently placed.
10136-8{_}7335{_}541.
10136-8{_}7336{_}BRILLAT SAVARIN says, that raw flesh has but one inconvenience,--from its viscousness it attaches itself to the teeth.
10136-8{_}7337{_}He goes on to say, that it is not, however, disagreeable; but, when seasoned with salt, that it is easily digested.
10136-8{_}7338{_}He tells a story of a Croat captain, whom he invited to dinner in 1815, during the occupation of Paris by the allied troops.
10136-8{_}7339{_}This officer was amazed at his host's preparations, and said, "When we are campaigning, and get hungry, we knock over the first animal we find, cut off a steak, powder it with salt, which we always have in the sabretasche, put it under the saddle, gallop over it for half a mile, and then dine like princes."
10136-8{_}7340{_}Again, of the huntsmen of Dauphiny it is said, that when they are out shooting in September, they take with them both pepper and salt.
10136-8{_}7341{_}If they kill a very fat bird, they pluck and season it, and, after carrying it some time in their caps, eat it.
10136-8{_}7342{_}This, they declare, is the best way of serving it up.
10136-8{_}7343{_}542.
10136-8{_}7344{_}SUBSEQUENTLY TO THE CROAT MODE, which, doubtless, was in fashion in the earlier ages of the world, fire was discovered.
10136-8{_}7345{_}This was an accident; for fire is not, although we are accustomed to call it so, an element, or spontaneous.
10136-8{_}7346{_}Many savage nations have been found utterly ignorant of it, and many races had no other way of dressing their food than by exposing it to the rays of the sun.
10136-8{_}7347{_}543.
10136-8{_}7348{_}THE INHABITANTS OF THE MARIAN ISLANDS, which were discovered in 1521, had no idea of fire.
10136-8{_}7349{_}Never was astonishment greater than theirs when they first saw it, on the descent of Magellan, the navigator, on one of their isles.
10136-8{_}7350{_}At first they thought it a kind of animal, that fixed itself to and fed upon wood.
10136-8{_}7351{_}Some of them, who approached too near, being burnt, the rest were terrified, and durst only look upon it at a distance.
10136-8{_}7352{_}They were afraid, they said, of being bit, or lest that dreadful animal should wound with his violent respiration and dreadful breath; for these were the first notions they formed of the heat and flame.
10136-8{_}7353{_}Such, too, probably, were the notions the Greeks originally formed of them.
10136-8{_}7354{_}544.
10136-8{_}7355{_}FIRE HAVING BEEN DISCOVERED, mankind endeavoured to make use of it for drying, and afterwards for cooking their meat; but they were a considerable time before they hit upon proper and commodious methods of employing it in the preparation of their food.
10136-8{_}7356{_}545.
10136-8{_}7357{_}MEAT, THEN, PLACED ON BURNING FUEL was found better than when raw: it had more firmness, was eaten with less difficulty, and the ozmazome being condensed by the carbonization, gave it a pleasing perfume and flavour.
10136-8{_}7358{_}Still, however, the meat cooked on the coal would become somewhat befouled, certain portions of the fuel adhering to it.
10136-8{_}7359{_}This disadvantage was remedied by passing spits through it, and placing it at a suitable height above the burning fuel.
10136-8{_}7360{_}Thus grilling was invented; and it is well known that, simple as is this mode of cookery, yet all meat cooked in this way is richly and pleasantly flavoured.
10136-8{_}7361{_}In Homer's time, the, art of cookery had not advanced much beyond this; for we read in the "Iliad," how the great Achilles and his friend Patroclus regaled the three Grecian leaders on bread, wine, and broiled meat.
10136-8{_}7362{_}It is noticeable, too, that Homer does not speak of boiled meat anywhere in his poems.
10136-8{_}7363{_}Later, however, the Jews, coming out of their captivity in Egypt, had made much greater progress.
10136-8{_}7364{_}They undoubtedly possessed kettles; and in one of these, Esau's mess of pottage, for which he sold his birthright, must have been prepared.
10136-8{_}7365{_}546.
10136-8{_}7366{_}HAVING THUS BRIEFLY TRACED A HISTORY OF GASTRONOMICAL PROGRESSES, we will now proceed to describe the various methods of cooking meat, and make a few observations on the chemical changes which occur in each of the operations.
10136-8{_}7367{_}547.
10136-8{_}7368{_}IN THIS COUNTRY, plain boiling, roasting, and baking are the usual methods of cooking animal food.
10136-8{_}7369{_}To explain the philosophy of these simple culinary operations, we must advert to the effects that are produced by heat on the principal constituents of flesh.
10136-8{_}7370{_}When finely-chopped mutton or beef is steeped for some time in a small quantity of clean water, and then subjected to slight pressure, the juice of the meat is extracted, and there is left a white tasteless residue, consisting chiefly of muscular fibres.
10136-8{_}7371{_}When this residue is heated to between 158° and 177° Fahrenheit, the fibres shrink together, and become hard and horny.
10136-8{_}7372{_}The influence of an elevated temperature on the soluble extract of flesh is not less remarkable.
10136-8{_}7373{_}When the watery infusion, which contains all the savoury constituents of the meat, is gradually heated, it soon becomes turbid; and, when the temperature reaches 133°, flakes of whitish matter separate.
10136-8{_}7374{_}These flakes are _albumen_, a substance precisely similar, in all its properties, to the white of egg (see No.
10136-8{_}7375{_}101).
10136-8{_}7376{_}When the temperature of the watery extract is raised to 158°, the colouring matter of the blood coagulates, and the liquid, which was originally tinged red by this substance, is left perfectly clear, and almost colourless.
10136-8{_}7377{_}When evaporated, even at a gentle heat, this residual liquid gradually becomes brown, and acquires the flavour of roast meat.
10136-8{_}7378{_}548.
10136-8{_}7379{_}THESE INTERESTING FACTS, discovered in the laboratory, throw a flood of light upon the mysteries of the kitchen.
10136-8{_}7380{_}The fibres of meat are surrounded by a liquid which contains albumen in its soluble state, just as it exists in the unboiled egg.
10136-8{_}7381{_}During the operation of boiling or roasting, this substance coagulates, and thereby prevents the contraction and hardening of the fibres.
10136-8{_}7382{_}The tenderness of well-cooked meat is consequently proportioned to the amount of albumen deposited in its substance.
10136-8{_}7383{_}Meat is underdone when it has been heated throughout only to the temperature of coagulating albumen: it is thoroughly done when it has been heated through its whole mass to the temperature at which the colouring matter of the blood coagulates: it is overdone when the heat has been continued long enough to harden the fibres.
10136-8{_}7384{_}549.
10136-8{_}7385{_}THE JUICE OF FLESH IS WATER, holding in solution many substances besides albumen, which are of the highest possible value as articles of food.
10136-8{_}7386{_}In preparing meat for the table, great care should be taken to prevent the escape of this precious juice, as the succulence and sapidity of the meat depend on its retention.
10136-8{_}7387{_}The meat to be cooked should be exposed at first to a quick heat, which immediately coagulates the albumen on and near the surface.
10136-8{_}7388{_}A kind of shell is thus formed, which effectually retains the whole of the juice within the meat.
10136-8{_}7389{_}550.
10136-8{_}7390{_}DURING THE OPERATIONS OF BOILING, BOASTING, AND BAKING, fresh beef and mutton, when moderately fat, lose, according to Johnston, on an average about--                        In boiling.
10136-8{_}7391{_}In baking.
10136-8{_}7392{_}In roasting.
10136-8{_}7393{_}4 lbs.
10136-8{_}7394{_}of beef lose    1 lb.
10136-8{_}7395{_}1 lb.
10136-8{_}7396{_}3 oz.
10136-8{_}7397{_}1 lb.
10136-8{_}7398{_}5 oz.
10136-8{_}7399{_}4 lbs.
10136-8{_}7400{_}of mutton lose  14 oz.
10136-8{_}7401{_}1 lb.
10136-8{_}7402{_}4 oz.
10136-8{_}7403{_}1 lb.
10136-8{_}7404{_}6 oz.
10136-8{_}7405{_}BAKING.
10136-8{_}7406{_}[Illustration: BAKING DISH.]
10136-8{_}7407{_}551.
10136-8{_}7408{_}THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN ROASTING MEAT AND BAKING IT, may be generally described as consisting in the fact, that, in baking it, the fumes caused by the operation are not carried off in the same way as occurs in roasting.
10136-8{_}7409{_}Much, however, of this disadvantage is obviated by the improved construction of modern ovens, and of especially those in connection with the Leamington kitchener, of which we give an engraving here, and a full description of which will be seen at paragraph No.
10136-8{_}7410{_}65, with the prices at which they can be purchased of Messrs. R. and J.
10136-8{_}7411{_}Slack, of the Strand.
10136-8{_}7412{_}With meat baked in the generality of ovens, however, which do not possess ventilators on the principle of this kitchener, there is undoubtedly a peculiar taste, which does not at all equal the flavour developed by roasting meat.
10136-8{_}7413{_}The chemistry of baking may be said to be the same as that described in roasting.
10136-8{_}7414{_}552.
10136-8{_}7415{_}SHOULD THE OVEN BE VERY BRISK, it will be found necessary to cover the joint with a piece of white paper, to prevent the meat from being scorched and blackened outside, before the heat can penetrate into the inside.
10136-8{_}7416{_}This paper should be removed half an hour before the time of serving dinner, so that the joint may take a good colour.
10136-8{_}7417{_}553.
10136-8{_}7418{_}BY MEANS OF A JAR, many dishes, which will be enumerated under their special heads, may be economically prepared in the oven.
10136-8{_}7419{_}The principal of these are soup, gravies, jugged hare, beef tea; and this mode of cooking may be advantageously adopted with a ham, which has previously been covered with a common crust of flour and water.
10136-8{_}7420{_}554.
10136-8{_}7421{_}ALL DISHES PREPARED FOR BAKING should be more highly seasoned than when intended to be roasted.
10136-8{_}7422{_}There are some dishes which, it may be said, are at least equally well cooked in the oven as by the roaster; thus, a shoulder of mutton and baked potatoes, a fillet or breast of veal, a sucking pig, a hare, well basted, will be received by connoisseurs as well, when baked, as if they had been roasted.
10136-8{_}7423{_}Indeed, the baker's oven, or the family oven, may often, as has been said, be substituted for the cook and the spit with greater economy and convenience.
10136-8{_}7424{_}555.
10136-8{_}7425{_}A BAKING-DISH, of which we give an engraving, should not be less than 6 or 7 inches deep; so that the meat, which of course cannot be basted, can stew in its own juices.
10136-8{_}7426{_}In the recipe for each dish, full explanations concerning any special points in relation to it will be given.
10136-8{_}7427{_}BOILING.
10136-8{_}7428{_}556.
10136-8{_}7429{_}BOILING, or the preparation of meat by hot water, though one of the easiest processes in cookery, requires skilful management.
10136-8{_}7430{_}Boiled meat should be tender, savoury, and full of its own juice, or natural gravy; but, through the carelessness and ignorance of cooks, it is too often sent to table hard, tasteless, and innutritious.
10136-8{_}7431{_}To insure a successful result in boiling flesh, the heat of the fire must be judiciously regulated, the proper quantity of water must be kept up in the pot, and the scum which rises to the surface must be carefully removed.
10136-8{_}7432{_}557.
10136-8{_}7433{_}MANY WRITERS ON COOKERY assert that the meat to be boiled should be put into cold water, and that the pot should be heated gradually; but Liebig, the highest authority on all matters connected with the chemistry of food, has shown that meat so treated loses some of its most nutritious constituents.
10136-8{_}7434{_}"If the flesh," says the great chemist, "be introduced into the boiler when the water is in a state of brisk ebullition, and if the boiling be kept up for a few minutes, and the pot then placed in a warm place, so that the temperature of the water is kept at 158° to 165°, we have the united conditions for giving to the flesh the qualities which best fit it for being eaten."
10136-8{_}7435{_}When a piece of meat is plunged into boiling water, the albumen which is near the surface immediately coagulates, forming an envelope, which prevents the escape of the internal juice, and most effectually excludes the water, which, by mixing with this juice, would render the meat insipid.
10136-8{_}7436{_}Meat treated thus is juicy and well-flavoured, when cooked, as it retains most of its savoury constituents.
10136-8{_}7437{_}On the other hand, if the piece of meat be set on the fire with cold water, and this slowly heated to boiling, the flesh undergoes a loss of soluble and nutritious substances, while, as a matter of course, the soup becomes richer in these matters.
10136-8{_}7438{_}The albumen is gradually dissolved from the surface to the centre; the fibre loses, more or less, its quality of shortness or tenderness, and becomes hard and tough: the thinner the piece of meat is, the greater is its loss of savoury constituents.
10136-8{_}7439{_}In order to obtain well-flavoured and eatable meat, we must relinquish the idea of making good soup from it, as that mode of boiling which yields the best soup gives the driest, toughest, and most vapid meat.
10136-8{_}7440{_}Slow boiling whitens the meat; and, we suspect, that it is on this account that it is in such favour with the cooks.
10136-8{_}7441{_}The wholesomeness of food is, however, a matter of much greater moment than the appearance it presents on the table.
10136-8{_}7442{_}It should be borne in mind, that the whiteness of meat that has been boiled slowly, is produced by the loss of some important alimentary properties.
10136-8{_}7443{_}558.
10136-8{_}7444{_}THE OBJECTIONS WE HAVE RAISED to the practice of putting meat on the fire in cold water, apply with equal force to the practice of soaking meat before cooking it, which is so strongly recommended by some cooks.
10136-8{_}7445{_}Fresh meat ought never to be soaked, as all its most nutritive constituents are soluble in water.
10136-8{_}7446{_}Soaking, however, is an operation that cannot be entirely dispensed with in the preparation of animal food.
10136-8{_}7447{_}Salted and dried meats require to be soaked for some time in water before they are cooked.
10136-8{_}7448{_}559.
10136-8{_}7449{_}FOR BOILING MEAT, the softer the water is, the better.
10136-8{_}7450{_}When spring water is boiled, the chalk which gives to it the quality of hardness, is precipitated.
10136-8{_}7451{_}This chalk stains the meat, and communicates to it an unpleasant earthy taste.
10136-8{_}7452{_}When nothing but hard water can be procured, it should be softened by boiling it for an hour or two before it is used for culinary purposes.
10136-8{_}7453{_}560.
10136-8{_}7454{_}THE FIRE MUST BE WATCHED with great attention during the operation of boiling, so that its heat may be properly regulated.
10136-8{_}7455{_}As a rule, the pot should be kept in a simmering state; a result which cannot be attained without vigilance.
10136-8{_}7456{_}561.
10136-8{_}7457{_}THE TEMPERATURE AT WHICH WATER BOILS, under usual circumstances, is 212° Fahr.
10136-8{_}7458{_}Water does not become hotter after it has begun to boil, however long or with whatever violence the boiling is continued.
10136-8{_}7459{_}This fact is of great importance in cookery, and attention to it will save much fuel.
10136-8{_}7460{_}Water made to boil in a gentle way by the application of a moderate heat is just as hot as when it is made to boil on a strong fire with the greatest possible violence.
10136-8{_}7461{_}When once water has been brought to the boiling point, the fire may be considerably reduced, as a very gentle heat will suffice to keep the water at its highest temperature.
10136-8{_}7462{_}562.
10136-8{_}7463{_}THE SCUM WHICH RISES to the surface of the pot during the operation of boiling must be carefully removed, otherwise it will attach itself to the meat, and thereby spoil its appearance.
10136-8{_}7464{_}The cook must not neglect to skim during the whole process, though by far the greater part of the scum rises at first.
10136-8{_}7465{_}The practice of wrapping meat in a cloth may be dispensed with if the skimming be skillfully managed.
10136-8{_}7466{_}If the scum be removed as fast as it rises, the meat will be cooked clean and pure, and come out of the vessel in which it was boiled, much more delicate and firm than when cooked in a cloth.
10136-8{_}7467{_}563.
10136-8{_}7468{_}WHEN TAKEN FROM THE POT, the meat must be wiped with a clean cloth, or, what will be found more convenient, a sponge previously dipped in water and wrung dry.
10136-8{_}7469{_}The meat should not be allowed to stand a moment longer than necessary, as boiled meat, as well as roasted, cannot be eaten too hot.
10136-8{_}7470{_}564.
10136-8{_}7471{_}THE TIME ALLOWED FOR THE OPERATION OF BOILING must be regulated according to the size and quality of the meat.
10136-8{_}7472{_}As a general rule, twenty minutes, reckoning from the moment when the boiling commences, may be allowed for every pound of meat.
10136-8{_}7473{_}All the best authorities, however, agree in this, that the longer the boiling the more perfect the operation.
10136-8{_}7474{_}565.
10136-8{_}7475{_}A FEW OBSERVATIONS ON THE NUTRITIVE VALUE OF SALTED MEAT may be properly introduced in this place.
10136-8{_}7476{_}Every housewife knows that dry salt in contact with fresh meat gradually becomes fluid brine.
10136-8{_}7477{_}The application of salt causes the fibres of the meat to contract, and the juice to flow out from its pores: as much as one-third of the juice of the meat is often forced out in this manner.
10136-8{_}7478{_}Now, as this juice is pure extract of meat, containing albumen, osmazome, and other valuable principles, it follows that meat which has been preserved by the action of salt can never have the nutritive properties of fresh meat.
10136-8{_}7479{_}566.
10136-8{_}7480{_}THE VESSELS USED FOR BOILING should be made of cast-iron, well tinned within, and provided with closely-fitting lids.
10136-8{_}7481{_}They must be kept scrupulously clean, otherwise they will render the meat cooked in them unsightly and unwholesome.
10136-8{_}7482{_}Copper pans, if used at all, should be reserved for operations that are performed with rapidity; as, by long contact with copper, food may become dangerously contaminated.
10136-8{_}7483{_}The kettle in which a joint is dressed should be large enough to allow room for a good supply of water; if the meat be cramped and be surrounded with but little water, it will be stewed, not boiled.
10136-8{_}7484{_}567.
10136-8{_}7485{_}IN STEWING, IT IS NOT REQUISITE to have so great a heat as in boiling.
10136-8{_}7486{_}A gentle simmering in a small quantity of water, so that the meat is stewed almost in its own juices, is all that is necessary.
10136-8{_}7487{_}It is a method much used on the continent, and is wholesome and economical.
10136-8{_}7488{_}[Illustration: BOILING-POT.]
10136-8{_}7489{_}[Illustration: STEWPAN.]
10136-8{_}7490{_}Two useful culinary vessels are represented above.
10136-8{_}7491{_}One is a     boiling-pot, in which large joints may be boiled; the other is a     stewpan, with a closely-fitting lid, to which is attached a long     handle; so that the cover can be removed without scalding the     fingers.
10136-8{_}7492{_}[Illustration: HOT-PLATE.]
10136-8{_}7493{_}568.
10136-8{_}7494{_}THE HOT-PLATE is a modern improvement on the old kitchen ranges, being used for boiling and stewing.
10136-8{_}7495{_}It is a plate of cast iron, having a closed fire burning beneath it, by which it is thoroughly well heated.
10136-8{_}7496{_}On this plate are set the various saucepans, stewpans, &c.; and, by this convenient and economical method, a number of dishes may be prepared at one time.
10136-8{_}7497{_}The culinary processes of braising and stewing are, in this manner, rendered more gradual, and consequently the substance acted on becomes more tender, and the gravy is not so much reduced.
10136-8{_}7498{_}BROILING.
10136-8{_}7499{_}[Illustration: REVOLVING GRIDIRON.]
10136-8{_}7500{_}569.
10136-8{_}7501{_}GENERALLY SPEAKING, small dishes only are prepared by this mode of cooking; amongst these, the beef-steak and mutton chop of the solitary English diner may be mentioned as celebrated all the world over.
10136-8{_}7502{_}Our beef-steak, indeed, has long crossed the Channel; and, with a view of pleasing the Britons, there is in every _carte_ at every French restaurant, by the side of _à la Marengo_, and _à la Mayonnaise,--bifteck d'Angleterre_.
10136-8{_}7503{_}In order to succeed in a broil, the cook must have a bright, clear fire; so that the surface of the meat may be quickly heated.
10136-8{_}7504{_}The result of this is the same as that obtained in roasting; namely, that a crust, so to speak, is formed outside, and thus the juices of the meat are retained.
10136-8{_}7505{_}The appetite of an invalid, so difficult to minister to, is often pleased with a broiled dish, as the flavour and sapidity of the meat are so well preserved.
10136-8{_}7506{_}570.
10136-8{_}7507{_}THE UTENSILS USED FOR BROILING need but little description.
10136-8{_}7508{_}The common gridiron, for which see engraving at No.
10136-8{_}7509{_}68, is the same as it has been for ages past, although some little variety has been introduced into its manufacture, by the addition of grooves to the bars, by means of which the liquid fat is carried into a small trough.
10136-8{_}7510{_}One point it is well to bear in mind, viz., that the gridiron should be kept in a direction slanting towards the cook, so that as little fat as possible may fall into the fire.
10136-8{_}7511{_}It has been observed, that broiling is the most difficult manual office the general cook has to perform, and one that requires the most unremitting attention; for she may turn her back upon the stewpan or the spit, but the gridiron can never be left with impunity.
10136-8{_}7512{_}The revolving gridiron, shown in the engraving, possesses some advantages of convenience, which will be at once apparent.
10136-8{_}7513{_}FRYING.
10136-8{_}7514{_}[Illustration: SAUTÉ PAN.]
10136-8{_}7515{_}571.
10136-8{_}7516{_}THIS VERY FAVOURITE MODE OF COOKING may be accurately described as boiling in fat or oil.
10136-8{_}7517{_}Substances dressed in this way are generally well received, for they introduce an agreeable variety, possessing, as they do, a peculiar flavour.
10136-8{_}7518{_}By means of frying, cooks can soon satisfy many requisitions made on them, it being a very expeditious mode of preparing dishes for the table, and one which can be employed when the fire is not sufficiently large for the purposes of roasting and boiling.
10136-8{_}7519{_}The great point to be borne in mind in frying, is that the liquid must be hot enough to act instantaneously, as all the merit of this culinary operation lies in the invasion of the boiling liquid, which carbonizes or burns, at the very instant of the immersion of the body placed in it.
10136-8{_}7520{_}It may be ascertained if the fat is heated to the proper degree, by cutting a piece of bread and dipping it in the frying-pan for five or six seconds; and if it be firm and of a dark brown when taken out, put in immediately what you wish to prepare; if it be not, let the fat be heated until of the right temperature.
10136-8{_}7521{_}This having been effected, moderate the fire, so that the action may not be too hurried, and that by a continuous heat the juices of the substance may be preserved, and its flavour enhanced.
10136-8{_}7522{_}572.
10136-8{_}7523{_}THE PHILOSOPHY OF FRYING consists in this, that liquids subjected to the action of fire do not all receive the same quantity of heat.
10136-8{_}7524{_}Being differently constituted in their nature, they possess different "capacities for caloric."
10136-8{_}7525{_}Thus, you may, with impunity, dip your finger in boiling spirits of wine; you would take it very quickly from boiling brandy, yet more rapidly from water; whilst the effects of the most rapid immersion in boiling oil need not be told.
10136-8{_}7526{_}As a consequence of this, heated fluids act differently on the sapid bodies presented to them.
10136-8{_}7527{_}Those put in water, dissolve, and are reduced to a soft mass; the result being _bouillon_, stock, &c. (_see_ No.
10136-8{_}7528{_}103).
10136-8{_}7529{_}Those substances, on the contrary, treated with oil, harden, assume a more or less deep colour, and are finally carbonized.
10136-8{_}7530{_}The reason of these different results is, that, in the first instance, water dissolves and extracts the interior juices of the alimentary substances placed in it; whilst, in the second, the juices are preserved; for they are insoluble in oil.
10136-8{_}7531{_}573.
10136-8{_}7532{_}IT IS TO BE ESPECIALLY REMEMBERED, in connection with frying, that all dishes fried in fat should be placed before the fire on a piece of blotting-paper, or sieve reversed, and there left for a few minutes, so that any superfluous greasy moisture may be removed.
10136-8{_}7533{_}574.
10136-8{_}7534{_}THE UTENSILS USED FOR THE PURPOSES OF FRYING are confined to frying-pans, although these are of various sizes; and, for small and delicate dishes, such as collops, fritters, pancakes, &c., the _sauté_ pan, of which we give an engraving, is used.
10136-8{_}7535{_}COOKING BY GAS.
10136-8{_}7536{_}[Illustration: GAS STOVE.]
10136-8{_}7537{_}575.
10136-8{_}7538{_}GAS-COOKING can scarcely now be considered a novelty,--many establishments, both small and large, have been fitted with apparatus for cooking by this mode, which undoubtedly exhibits some advantages.
10136-8{_}7539{_}Thus the heat may be more regularly supplied to the substance cooking, and the operation is essentially a clean one, because there can be no cinders or other dirt to be provided for.
10136-8{_}7540{_}Some labour and attention necessary, too, with a coal fire or close stove, may be saved; and, besides this, it may, perhaps, be said that culinary operations are reduced, by this means, to something like a certainty.
10136-8{_}7541{_}576.
10136-8{_}7542{_}THERE ARE, HOWEVER, WE THINK, MANY OBJECTIONS to this mode of cooking, more especially when applied to small domestic establishments.
10136-8{_}7543{_}For instance, the ingenious machinery necessary for carrying it out, requires cooks perfectly conversant with its use; and if the gas, when the cooking operations are finished, be not turned off, there will be a large increase in the cost of cooking, instead of the economy which it has been supposed to bring.
10136-8{_}7544{_}For large establishments, such as some of the immense London warehouses, where a large number of young men have to be catered for daily, it may be well adapted, as it is just possible that a slight increase in the supply of gas necessary for a couple of joints, may serve equally to cook a dozen dishes.
10136-8{_}7545{_}ROASTING.
10136-8{_}7546{_}577.
10136-8{_}7547{_}OF THE VARIOUS METHODS OF PREPARING MEAT, ROASTING is that which most effectually preserves its nutritive qualities.
10136-8{_}7548{_}Meat is roasted by being exposed to the direct influence of the fire.
10136-8{_}7549{_}This is done by placing the meat before an open grate, and keeping it in motion to prevent the scorching on any particular part.
10136-8{_}7550{_}When meat is properly roasted, the outer layer of its albumen is coagulated, and thus presents a barrier to the exit of the juice.
10136-8{_}7551{_}In roasting meat, the heat must be strongest at first, and it should then be much reduced.
10136-8{_}7552{_}To have a good juicy roast, therefore, the fire must be red and vigorous at the very commencement of the operation.
10136-8{_}7553{_}In the most careful roasting, some of the juice is squeezed out of the meat: this evaporates on the surface of the meat, and gives it a dark brown colour, a rich lustre, and a strong aromatic taste.
10136-8{_}7554{_}Besides these effects on the albumen and the expelled juice, roasting converts the cellular tissue of the meat into gelatine, and melts the fat out of the fat-cells.
10136-8{_}7555{_}578.
10136-8{_}7556{_}IF A SPIT is used to support the meat before the fire, it should be kept quite bright.
10136-8{_}7557{_}Sand and water ought to be used to scour it with, for brickdust and oil may give a disagreeable taste to the meat.
10136-8{_}7558{_}When well scoured, it must be wiped quite dry with a clean cloth; and, in spitting the meat, the prime parts should be left untouched, so as to avoid any great escape of its juices.
10136-8{_}7559{_}579.
10136-8{_}7560{_}KITCHENS IN LARGE ESTABLISHMENTS are usually fitted with what are termed "smoke-jacks."
10136-8{_}7561{_}By means of these, several spits, if required, may be turned at the same time.
10136-8{_}7562{_}This not being, of course, necessary in smaller establishments, a roasting apparatus, more economical in its consumption of coal, is more frequently in use.
10136-8{_}7563{_}[Illustration: BOTTLE-JACK, WITH WHEEL AND HOOK.]
10136-8{_}7564{_}580.
10136-8{_}7565{_}THE BOTTLE-JACK, of which we here give an illustration, with the wheel and hook, and showing the precise manner of using it, is now commonly used in many kitchens.
10136-8{_}7566{_}This consists of a spring inclosed in a brass cylinder, and requires winding up before it is used, and sometimes, also, during the operation of roasting.
10136-8{_}7567{_}The joint is fixed to an iron hook, which is suspended by a chain connected with a wheel, and which, in its turn, is connected with the bottle-jack.
10136-8{_}7568{_}Beneath it stands the dripping-pan, which we have also engraved, together with the basting-ladle, the use of which latter should not be spared; as there can be no good roast without good basting.
10136-8{_}7569{_}"Spare the rod, and spoil the child," might easily be paraphrased into "Spare the basting, and spoil the meat."
10136-8{_}7570{_}If the joint is small and light, and so turns unsteadily, this may be remedied by fixing to the wheel one of the kitchen weights.
10136-8{_}7571{_}Sometimes this jack is fixed inside a screen; but there is this objection to this apparatus,--that the meat cooked in it resembles the flavour of baked meat.
10136-8{_}7572{_}This is derived from its being so completely surrounded with the tin, that no sufficient current of air gets to it.
10136-8{_}7573{_}It will be found preferable to make use of a common meat-screen, such as is shown in the woodcut.
10136-8{_}7574{_}This contains shelves for warming plates and dishes; and with this, the reflection not being so powerful, and more air being admitted to the joint, the roast may be very excellently cooked.
10136-8{_}7575{_}[Illustration: DRIPPING-PAN AND BASTING-LADLE.]
10136-8{_}7576{_}581.
10136-8{_}7577{_}IN STIRRING THE FIRE, or putting fresh coals on it, the dripping-pan should always be drawn back, so that there may be no danger of the coal, cinders, or ashes falling down into it.
10136-8{_}7578{_}582.
10136-8{_}7579{_}UNDER EACH PARTICULAR RECIPE there is stated the time required for roasting each joint; but, as a general rule, it may be here given, that for every pound of meat, in ordinary-sized joints, a quarter of an hour may be allotted.
10136-8{_}7580{_}[Illustration: HEAT-SCREEN.]
10136-8{_}7581{_}583.
10136-8{_}7582{_}WHITE MEATS, AND THE MEAT OF YOUNG ANIMALS, require to be very well roasted, both to be pleasant to the palate and easy of digestion.
10136-8{_}7583{_}Thus veal, pork, and lamb, should be thoroughly done to the centre.
10136-8{_}7584{_}584.
10136-8{_}7585{_}MUTTON AND BEEF, on the other hand, do not, generally speaking, require to be so thoroughly done, and they should be dressed to the point, that, in carving them, the gravy should just run, but not too freely.
10136-8{_}7586{_}Of course in this, as in most other dishes, the tastes of individuals vary; and there are many who cannot partake, with satisfaction, of any joint unless it is what others would call overdressed.
10136-8{_}7587{_}[Illustration]     [Illustration]  QUADRUPEDS.
10136-8{_}7588{_}CHAPTER XII.
10136-8{_}7589{_}GENERAL OBSERVATIONS ON QUADRUPEDS.
10136-8{_}7590{_}585.
10136-8{_}7591{_}BY THE GENERAL ASSENT OF MANKIND, THE EMPIRE OF NATURE has been divided into three kingdoms; the first consisting of minerals, the second of vegetables, and the third of animals.
10136-8{_}7592{_}The Mineral Kingdom comprises all substances which are without those organs necessary to locomotion, and the due performance of the functions of life.
10136-8{_}7593{_}They are composed of the accidental aggregation of particles, which, under certain circumstances, take a constant and regular figure, but which are more frequently found without any definite conformation.
10136-8{_}7594{_}They also occupy the interior parts of the earth, as well as compose those huge masses by which we see the land in some parts guarded against the encroachments of the sea.
10136-8{_}7595{_}The Vegetable Kingdom covers and beautifies the earth with an endless variety of form and colour.
10136-8{_}7596{_}It consists of organized bodies, but destitute of the power of locomotion.
10136-8{_}7597{_}They are nourished by means of roots; they breathe by means of leaves; and propagate by means of seed, dispersed within certain limits.
10136-8{_}7598{_}The Animal Kingdom consists of sentient beings, that enliven the external parts of the earth.
10136-8{_}7599{_}They possess the powers of voluntary motion, respire air, and are forced into action by the cravings of hunger or the parching of thirst, by the instincts of animal passion, or by pain.
10136-8{_}7600{_}Like the vegetable kingdom, they are limited within the boundaries of certain countries by the conditions of climate and soil; and some of the species prey upon each other.
10136-8{_}7601{_}Linnaeus has divided them into six classes;--Mammalia, Birds, Fishes, Amphibious Animals, Insects, and Worms.
10136-8{_}7602{_}The three latter do not come within the limits of our domain; of fishes we have already treated, of birds we shall treat, and of mammalia we will now treat.
10136-8{_}7603{_}586.
10136-8{_}7604{_}THIS CLASS OF ANIMALS embraces all those that nourish their young by means of lacteal glands, or teats, and are so constituted as to have a warm or red blood.
10136-8{_}7605{_}In it the whale is placed,--an order which, from external habits, has usually been classed with the fishes; but, although this animal exclusively inhabits the water, and is supplied with fins, it nevertheless exhibits a striking alliance to quadrupeds.
10136-8{_}7606{_}It has warm blood, and produces its young alive; it nourishes them with milk, and, for that purpose, is furnished with teats.
10136-8{_}7607{_}It is also supplied with lungs, and two auricles and two ventricles to the heart; all of which bring it still closer into an alliance with the quadrupedal species of the animal kingdom.
10136-8{_}7608{_}587.
10136-8{_}7609{_}THE GENERAL CHARACTERISTICS OF THE MAMMALIA have been frequently noticed.
10136-8{_}7610{_}The bodies of nearly the whole species are covered with hair, a kind of clothing which is both soft and warm, little liable to injury, and bestowed in proportion to the necessities of the animal and the nature of the climate it inhabits.
10136-8{_}7611{_}In all the higher orders of animals, the head is the principal seat of the organs of sense.
10136-8{_}7612{_}It is there that the eyes, the ears, the nose, and the mouth are placed.
10136-8{_}7613{_}Through the last they receive their nourishment.
10136-8{_}7614{_}In it are the _teeth_, which, in most of the mammalia, are used not only for the mastication of food, but as weapons of offence.
10136-8{_}7615{_}They are inserted into two movable bones called jaws, and the front teeth are so placed that their sharp edges may easily be brought in contact with their food, in order that its fibres may readily be separated.
10136-8{_}7616{_}Next to these, on each side, are situated the canine teeth, or tusks, which are longer than the other teeth, and, being pointed, are used to tear the food.
10136-8{_}7617{_}In the back jaws are placed another form of teeth, called grinders.
10136-8{_}7618{_}These are for masticating the food; and in those animals that live on vegetables, they are flattened at the top; but, in carnivora, their upper surfaces are furnished with sharp-pointed protuberances.
10136-8{_}7619{_}From the numbers, form, and disposition of the teeth, the various genera of quadrupeds have been arranged.
10136-8{_}7620{_}The _nose_ is a cartilaginous body, pierced with two holes, which are called nostrils.
10136-8{_}7621{_}Through these the animal is affected by the sense of smell; and in some it is prominent, whilst in others it is flat, compressed, turned upwards, or bent downwards.
10136-8{_}7622{_}In beasts of prey, it is frequently longer than the lips; and in some other animals it is elongated into a movable trunk or proboscis, whilst, in the rhinoceros tribe, it is armed with a horn.
10136-8{_}7623{_}The _eyes_ of quadrupeds are generally defended by movable lids, on the outer margins of which are fringes of hair, called eyelashes.
10136-8{_}7624{_}The opening of the pupil is in general circular; but to some species, as in those of the Cat and Hare, it is contracted into a perpendicular line, whilst in the Horse, the Ox, and a few others, it forms a transverse bar.
10136-8{_}7625{_}The _ears_ are openings, generally accompanied with a cartilage which defends and covers them, called the external ears.
10136-8{_}7626{_}In water-animals the latter are wanting; sound, in them, being transmitted merely through orifices in the head, which have the name of auditory-holes.
10136-8{_}7627{_}The most defenceless animals are extremely delicate in the sense of hearing, as are likewise most beasts of prey.
10136-8{_}7628{_}Most of the mammiferous animals _walk_ on four feet, which, at the extremities, are usually divided into toes or fingers.
10136-8{_}7629{_}In some, however, the feet end in a single corneous substance called a hoof.
10136-8{_}7630{_}The toes of a few end in broad, flat nails, and of most others, in pointed claws.
10136-8{_}7631{_}Some, again, have the toes connected by a membrane, which is adapted to those that are destined to pass a considerable portion of their lives in water.
10136-8{_}7632{_}Others, again, as in the Bat, have the digitations of the anterior feet greatly elongated, the intervening space being filled by a membrane, which extends round the hinder legs and tail, and by means of which they are enabled to rise into the air.
10136-8{_}7633{_}In Man, the hand alone comprises fingers, separate, free, and flexible; but Apes, and some other kinds of animals, have fingers both to the hands and feet.
10136-8{_}7634{_}These, therefore, are the only animals that can hold movable objects in a single hand.
10136-8{_}7635{_}Others, such as Rats and Squirrels, have the fingers sufficiently small and flexible to enable them to pick up objects; but they are compelled to hold them in both hands.
10136-8{_}7636{_}Others, again, have the toes shorter, and must rest on the fore-feet, as is the case with dogs and cats when they wish to hold a substance firmly on the ground with their paws.
10136-8{_}7637{_}There are still others that have their toes united and drawn under the skin, or enveloped in corneous hoofs, and are thereby enabled to exercise no prehensile power whatever.
10136-8{_}7638{_}588.
10136-8{_}7639{_}ACCORDING TO THE DESIGN AND END OF NATURE, mammiferous animals are calculated, when arrived at maturity, to subsist on various kinds of food,--some to live wholly upon flesh, others upon grain, herbs, or fruits; but in their infant state, milk is the appropriate food of the whole.
10136-8{_}7640{_}That this food may never fail them, it is universally ordained, that the young should no sooner come into the world, than the milk should flow in abundance into the members with which the mother is supplied for the secretion of that nutritious fluid.
10136-8{_}7641{_}By a wonderful instinct of Nature, too, the young animal, almost as soon as it has come into life, searches for the teat, and knows perfectly, at the first, how, by the process of suction, it will be able to extract the fluid necessary to its existence.
10136-8{_}7642{_}589.
10136-8{_}7643{_}IN THE GENERAL ECONOMY OF NATURE, this class of animals seems destined to preserve a constant equilibrium in the number of animated beings that hold their existence on the surface of the earth.
10136-8{_}7644{_}To man they are immediately useful in various ways.
10136-8{_}7645{_}Some of their bodies afford him food, their skin shoes, and their fleece clothes.
10136-8{_}7646{_}Some of them unite with him in participating the dangers of combat with an enemy, and others assist him in the chase, in exterminating wilder sorts, or banishing them from the haunts of civilization.
10136-8{_}7647{_}Many, indeed, are injurious to him; but most of them, in some shape or other, he turns to his service.
10136-8{_}7648{_}Of these there is none he has made more subservient to his purposes than the common ox, of which there is scarcely a part that he has not been able to convert into some useful purpose.
10136-8{_}7649{_}Of the horns he makes drinking-vessels, knife-handles, combs, and boxes; and when they are softened by means of boiling water, he fashions them into transparent plates for lanterns.
10136-8{_}7650{_}This invention is ascribed to King Alfred, who is said to have been the first to use them to preserve his candle time-measures from the wind.
10136-8{_}7651{_}Glue is made of the cartilages, gristles, and the finer pieces of the parings and cuttings of the hides.
10136-8{_}7652{_}Their bone is a cheap substitute for ivory.
10136-8{_}7653{_}The thinnest of the calf-skins are manufactured into vellum.
10136-8{_}7654{_}Their blood is made the basis of Prussian blue, and saddlers use a fine sort of thread prepared from their sinews.
10136-8{_}7655{_}The hair is used in various valuable manufactures; the suet, fat, and tallow, are moulded into candles; and the milk and cream of the cow yield butter and cheese.
10136-8{_}7656{_}Thus is every part of this animal valuable to man, who has spared no pains to bring it to the highest state of perfection.
10136-8{_}7657{_}[Illustration: SHORT-HORN COW.]
10136-8{_}7658{_}[Illustration: SHORT-HORN BULL.]
10136-8{_}7659{_}590.
10136-8{_}7660{_}AMONG THE VARIOUS BREEDS OF THE OX, upon which man has bestowed his highest powers of culture, there is now none takes a higher place than that known by the name of Short-Horns.
10136-8{_}7661{_}From the earliest ages, Great Britain has been distinguished for the excellence of her native breeds of cattle, and there are none in England that have obtained greater celebrity than those which have this name, and which originated, about seventy years ago, on the banks of the Tees.
10136-8{_}7662{_}Thence they have spread into the valleys of the Tweed; thence to the Lothians, in Scotland; and southward, into the fine pastures of England.
10136-8{_}7663{_}They are now esteemed the most profitable breed of cattle, as there is no animal which attains sooner to maturity, and none that supplies meat of a superior quality.
10136-8{_}7664{_}The value of some of the improved breeds is something enormous.
10136-8{_}7665{_}At the sale of Mr. Charles Colling, a breeder in Yorkshire, in 1810, his bull "Comet" sold for 1,000 guineas.
10136-8{_}7666{_}At the sale of Earl Spencer's herd in 1846, 104 cows, heifers, and calves, with nineteen bulls, fetched £8,468.
10136-8{_}7667{_}5s.
10136-8{_}7668{_}; being an average of £68.
10136-8{_}7669{_}17s.
10136-8{_}7670{_}apiece.
10136-8{_}7671{_}The value of such animals is scarcely to be estimated by those who are unacquainted with the care with which they are tended, and with the anxious attention which is paid to the purity of their breed.
10136-8{_}7672{_}A modern writer, well acquainted with this subject, says, "There are now, at least, five hundred herds, large and small, in this kingdom, and from six to seven thousand head registered every alternate year in the herd-book."
10136-8{_}7673{_}The necessity for thus recording the breeds is greater than might, at first sight, be imagined, as it tends directly to preserve the character of the cattle, while it sometimes adds to the value and reputation of the animal thus entered.
10136-8{_}7674{_}Besides, many of the Americans, and large purchasers for the foreign market, will not look at an animal without the breeder has taken care to qualify him for such reference.
10136-8{_}7675{_}Of short-horned stock, there is annually sold from £40,000 to £50,000 worth by public auction, independent of the vast numbers disposed of by private contract.
10136-8{_}7676{_}The brood is highly prized in Belgium, Prussia, France, Italy, and Russia; it is imported into most of the British colonies, and is greatly esteemed both for its meat and its dairy produce, wherever it is known.
10136-8{_}7677{_}The quickness with which it takes on flesh, and the weight which it frequently makes, are well known; but we may mention that it is not uncommon to tee steers of from four to five years old realize a weight of from 800 to 1,000 lbs.
10136-8{_}7678{_}Such animals command from the butcher from £30 to £40 per head, according to the quality; whilst others, of two or three years old, and, of course, of less Weight, bring as much as £20 apiece.
10136-8{_}7679{_}[Illustration: LONG-HORN BULL.]
10136-8{_}7680{_}[Illustration: LONG-HORN COW.]
10136-8{_}7681{_}591.
10136-8{_}7682{_}LONG-HORNS.--This is the prevailing breed in our midland counties and in Ireland; but they are greatly inferior to the short-horns, and are fast being supplanted by them.
10136-8{_}7683{_}Even where they have been cultivated with the nicest care and brought to the greatest perfection, they are inferior to the others, and must ultimately be driven from the farm.
10136-8{_}7684{_}[Illustration: ALDERNEY COW.]
10136-8{_}7685{_}[Illustration: ALDERNEY BULL.]
10136-8{_}7686{_}592.
10136-8{_}7687{_}THE ALDERNEY.--Among the dairy breeds of England, the Alderney takes a prominent place, not on account of the quantity of milk which it yields, but on account of the excellent quality of the cream and butter which are produced from it.
10136-8{_}7688{_}Its docility is marvellous, and in appearance it greatly resembles the Ayrshire breed of Scotland, the excellence of which is supposed to be, in some degree, derived from a mixture of the Alderney blood with that breed.
10136-8{_}7689{_}The distinction between them, however, lies both in the quantity and quality of the milk which they severally produce; that of the Alderney being rich in quality, and that of the Ayrshire abundant in quantity.
10136-8{_}7690{_}The merit of the former, however, ends with its milk, for as a grazer it is worthless.
10136-8{_}7691{_}[Illustration: GALLOWAY BULL.]
10136-8{_}7692{_}[Illustration: GALLOWAY COW.]
10136-8{_}7693{_}593.
10136-8{_}7694{_}SCOTTISH BREEDS.--Of these the Kyloe, which belongs to the Highlands of Scotland; the Galloway, which has been called the Kyloe without horns; and the Ayrshire, are the breeds most celebrated.
10136-8{_}7695{_}The first has kept his place, and on account of the compactness of his form, and the excellent quality of his flesh, he is a great favourite with butchers who have a select family trade.
10136-8{_}7696{_}It is alike unsuitable for the dairy and the arable farm; but in its native Highlands it attains to great perfection, thriving upon the scanty and coarse herbage which it gathers on the sides of the mountains.
10136-8{_}7697{_}The Galloway has a larger frame, and when fattened makes excellent beef.
10136-8{_}7698{_}But it has given place to the short-horns in its native district, where turnip-husbandry is pursued with advantage.
10136-8{_}7699{_}The Ayrshire is peculiarly adapted for the dairy, and for the abundance of its milk cannot be surpassed in its native district.
10136-8{_}7700{_}In this it stands unrivalled, and there is no other breed capable of converting the produce of a poor soil into such fine butter and cheese.
10136-8{_}7701{_}It is difficult to fatten, however, and its beef is of a coarse quality.
10136-8{_}7702{_}We have chosen these as among the principal representative breeds of the ox species; but there are other breeds which, at all events, have a local if not a general celebrity.
10136-8{_}7703{_}[Illustration: SIDE OF BEEF, SHOWING THE SEVERAL JOINTS.]
10136-8{_}7704{_}594.
10136-8{_}7705{_}The general Mode of Slaughtering Oxen in this country is by striking them a smart blow with a hammer or poleaxe on the head, a little above the eyes.
10136-8{_}7706{_}By this means, when the blow is skilfully given, the beast is brought down at one blow, and, to prevent recovery, a cane is generally inserted, by which the spinal cord is perforated, which instantly deprives the ox of all sensation of pain.
10136-8{_}7707{_}In Spain, and some other countries on the continent, it is also usual to deprive oxen of life by the operation of pithing or dividing the spinal cord in the neck, close to the back part of the head.
10136-8{_}7708{_}This is, in effect, the same mode as is practised in the celebrated Spanish bull-fights by the matador, and it is instantaneous in depriving the animal of sensation, if the operator be skilful.
10136-8{_}7709{_}We hope and believe that those men whose disagreeable duty it is to slaughter the "beasts of the field" to provide meat for mankind, inflict as little punishment and cause as little suffering as possible.
10136-8{_}7710{_}595.
10136-8{_}7711{_}THE MANNER IN WHICH A SIDE OF BEEF is cut up in London, is shown in the engraving on this page.
10136-8{_}7712{_}In the metropolis, on account of the large number of its population possessing the means to indulge in the "best of everything," the demand for the most delicate joints of meat is great, the price, at the same time, being much higher for these than for the other parts.
10136-8{_}7713{_}The consequence is, that in London the carcass is there divided so as to obtain the greatest quantity of meat on the most esteemed joints.
10136-8{_}7714{_}In many places, however, where, from a greater equality in the social condition and habits of the inhabitants, the demand and prices for the different parts of the carcasses are more equalized, there is not the same reason for the butcher to cut the best joints so large.
10136-8{_}7715{_}596.
10136-8{_}7716{_}THE MEAT ON THOSE PARTS OF THE ANIMAL in which the muscles are least called into action, is most tender and succulent; as, for instance, along the back, from the rump to the hinder part of the shoulder; whilst the limbs, shoulder, and neck, are the toughest, driest, and least-esteemed.
10136-8{_}7717{_}597.
10136-8{_}7718{_}THE NAMES OF THE SEVERAL JOINTS in the hind and fore quarters of a side of beef, and the purposes for which they are used, are as follows:--  HIND QUARTER.
10136-8{_}7719{_}1.
10136-8{_}7720{_}Sirloin.--The two sirloins, cut together in one joint, form a baron; this, when roasted, is the famous national dish of Englishmen, at entertainments, on occasion of rejoicing.
10136-8{_}7721{_}2.
10136-8{_}7722{_}Rump,--the finest part for steaks.
10136-8{_}7723{_}3.
10136-8{_}7724{_}Aitch-bone,--boiling piece.
10136-8{_}7725{_}4.
10136-8{_}7726{_}Buttock,--prime boiling piece.
10136-8{_}7727{_}5.
10136-8{_}7728{_}Mouse-round,--boiling or stewing.
10136-8{_}7729{_}6.
10136-8{_}7730{_}Hock,--stewing.
10136-8{_}7731{_}7.
10136-8{_}7732{_}Thick flank, cut with the udder-fat,--primest boiling piece.
10136-8{_}7733{_}8.
10136-8{_}7734{_}Thin flank,--boiling.
10136-8{_}7735{_}FORE QUARTER.
10136-8{_}7736{_}9.
10136-8{_}7737{_}Five ribs, called the fore-rib.--This is considered the primest roasting piece.
10136-8{_}7738{_}10.
10136-8{_}7739{_}Four ribs, called the middle-rib,--greatly esteemed by housekeepers as the most economical joint for roasting.
10136-8{_}7740{_}11.
10136-8{_}7741{_}Two ribs, called the chuck-rib,--used for second quality of steaks.
10136-8{_}7742{_}12.
10136-8{_}7743{_}Leg-of-mutton piece,--the muscles of the shoulder dissected from the breast.
10136-8{_}7744{_}13.
10136-8{_}7745{_}Brisket, or breast,--used for boiling, after being salted.
10136-8{_}7746{_}14.
10136-8{_}7747{_}Neck, clod, and sticking-piece,--used for soups, gravies, stocks, pies, and mincing for sausages.
10136-8{_}7748{_}15.
10136-8{_}7749{_}Shin,--stewing.
10136-8{_}7750{_}The following is a classification of the qualities of meat, according to the several joints of beef, when cut up in the London manner.
10136-8{_}7751{_}_First class_.--includes the sirloin, with the kidney suet (1), the rump-steak piece (2), the fore-rib (9).
10136-8{_}7752{_}_Second class_.--The buttock (4), the thick flank (7), the middle-rib (10).
10136-8{_}7753{_}_Third class_.--The aitch-bone (3), the mouse-round (5), the thin flank (8), the chuck (11), the leg-of-mutton piece (12), the brisket (13).
10136-8{_}7754{_}_Fourth class_.--The neck, clod, and sticking-piece (14).
10136-8{_}7755{_}_Fifth class_.--The hock (6), the shin (15).
10136-8{_}7756{_}RECIPES.
10136-8{_}7757{_}CHAPTER XIII.
10136-8{_}7758{_}BAKED BEEF (Cold Meat Cookery).
10136-8{_}7759{_}I.
10136-8{_}7760{_}598.
10136-8{_}7761{_}INGREDIENTS.--About 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}7762{_}of cold roast beef, 2 small onions, 1 large carrot or two small ones, 1 turnip, a small bunch of savoury herbs, salt and pepper to taste, 4 tablespoonfuls of gravy, 3 tablespoonfuls of ale, crust or mashed potatoes.
10136-8{_}7763{_}_Mode_.--Cut the beef in slices, allowing a small amount of fat to each slice; place a layer of this in the bottom of a pie-dish, with a portion of the onions, carrots, and turnips, which must be sliced; mince the herbs, strew them over the meat, and season with pepper and salt.
10136-8{_}7764{_}Then put another layer of meat, vegetables, and seasoning; and proceed in this manner until all the ingredients are used.
10136-8{_}7765{_}Pour in the gravy and ale (water may be substituted for the former, but it is not so nice), cover with a crust or mashed potatoes, and bake for 1/2 hour, or rather longer.
10136-8{_}7766{_}_Time_.--Rather more than 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}7767{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the meat, 6d.
10136-8{_}7768{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}7769{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}7770{_}_Note_.--It is as well to parboil the carrots and turnips before adding them to the meat, and to use some of the liquor in which they were boiled as a substitute for gravy; that is to say, when there is no gravy at hand.
10136-8{_}7771{_}Be particular to cut the onions in very _thin_ slices.
10136-8{_}7772{_}II.
10136-8{_}7773{_}599.
10136-8{_}7774{_}INGREDIENTS.--Slices of cold roast beef, salt and pepper to taste, 1 sliced onion, 1 teaspoonful of minced savoury herbs, 5 or 6 tablespoonfuls of gravy or sauce of any kind, mashed potatoes.
10136-8{_}7775{_}_Mode_.--Butter the sides of a deep dish, and spread mashed potatoes over the bottom of it; on this place layers of beef in thin slices (this may be minced if there is not sufficient beef to cut into slices), well seasoned with pepper and salt, and a very little onion end herbs, which should be previously fried of a nice brown; then put another layer of mashed potatoes, and beef, and other ingredients, as before; pour in the gravy or sauce, cover the whole with another layer of potatoes, and bake for 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}7776{_}This may be served in the dish, or turned out.
10136-8{_}7777{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}7778{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the cold beef, 6d.
10136-8{_}7779{_}_Sufficient_.--A large pie-dish full for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}7780{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}7781{_}BEEF.--The quality of beef depends on various circumstances;     such as the age, the sex, the breed of the animal, and also on     the food upon which it has been raised.
10136-8{_}7782{_}Bull beef is, in     general, dry and tough, and by no means possessed of an     agreeable flavour; whilst the flesh of the ox is not only highly     nourishing and digestible, but, if not too old, extremely     agreeable.
10136-8{_}7783{_}The flesh of the cow is, also, nourishing, but it is     not so agreeable as that of the ox, although that of a heifer is     held in high estimation.
10136-8{_}7784{_}The flesh of the smaller breeds is much     sweeter than that of the larger, which is best when the animal     is about seven years old.
10136-8{_}7785{_}That of the smaller breeds is best at     about five years, and that of the cow can hardly be eaten too     young.
10136-8{_}7786{_}BAKED BEEF-STEAK PUDDING.
10136-8{_}7787{_}600.
10136-8{_}7788{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 oz.
10136-8{_}7789{_}of flour, 2 eggs, not quite 1 pint of milk, salt to taste, 1-1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}7790{_}of rump-steaks, 1 kidney, pepper and salt.
10136-8{_}7791{_}_Mode_.--Cut the steaks into nice square pieces, with a small quantity of fat, and the kidney divide into small pieces.
10136-8{_}7792{_}Make a batter of flour, eggs, and milk in the above proportion; lay a little of it at the bottom of a pie-dish; then put in the steaks and kidney, which should be well seasoned with pepper and salt, and pour over the remainder of the batter, and bake for 1-1/2 hour in a brisk but not fierce oven.
10136-8{_}7793{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}7794{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}7795{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}7796{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}7797{_}BEEF A LA MODE.
10136-8{_}7798{_}(_Economical_.)
10136-8{_}7799{_}601.
10136-8{_}7800{_}INGREDIENTS.--About 3 lbs.
10136-8{_}7801{_}of clod or sticking of beef, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}7802{_}of clarified dripping, 1 large onion, flour, 2 quarts of water, 12 berries of allspice, 2 bay-leaves, 1/2 teaspoonful of whole black pepper, salt to taste.
10136-8{_}7803{_}_Mode_.--Cut the beef into small pieces, and roll them in flour; put the dripping into a stewpan with the onion, which should be sliced thin.
10136-8{_}7804{_}Let it get quite hot; lay in the pieces of beef, and stir them well about.
10136-8{_}7805{_}When nicely browned all over, add _by degrees_ boiling water in the above proportion, and, as the water is added, keep the whole well stirred.
10136-8{_}7806{_}Put in the spice, bay-leaves, and seasoning, cover the stewpan closely, and set it by the side of the fire to stew very _gently_, till the meat becomes quite tender, which will be in about 3 hours, when it will be ready to serve.
