10136-8{_}7807{_}Remove the bay-leaves before it is sent to table.
10136-8{_}7808{_}_Time_.--3 hours.
10136-8{_}7809{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}7810{_}3d.
10136-8{_}7811{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 persons.
10136-8{_}7812{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}7813{_}BEEF A LA MODE.
10136-8{_}7814{_}602.
10136-8{_}7815{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 or 7 lbs.
10136-8{_}7816{_}of the thick flank of beef, a few slices of fat bacon, 1 teacupful of vinegar, black pepper, allspice, 2 cloves well mixed and finely pounded, making altogether 1 heaped teaspoonful; salt to taste, 1 bunch of savoury herbs, including parsley, all finely minced and well mixed; 3 onions, 2 large carrots, 1 turnip, 1 head of celery, 1-1/2 pint of water, 1 glass of port wine.
10136-8{_}7817{_}_Mode_.--Slice and fry the onions of a pale brown, and cut up the other vegetables in small pieces, and prepare the beef for stewing in the following manner:--Choose a fine piece of beef, cut the bacon into long slices, about an inch in thickness, dip them into vinegar, and then into a little of the above seasoning of spice, &c., mixed with the same quantity of minced herbs.
10136-8{_}7818{_}With a sharp knife make holes deep enough to let in the bacon; then rub the beef over with the remainder of the seasoning and herbs, and bind it up in a nice shape with tape.
10136-8{_}7819{_}Have ready a well-tinned stewpan (it should not be much larger than the piece of meat you are cooking), into which put the beef, with the vegetables, vinegar, and water.
10136-8{_}7820{_}Let it simmer _very gently_ for 5 hours, or rather longer, should the meat not be extremely tender, and turn it once or twice.
10136-8{_}7821{_}When ready to serve, take out the beef, remove the tape, and put it on a hot dish.
10136-8{_}7822{_}Skim off every particle of fat from the gravy, add the port wine, just let it boil, pour it over the beef, and it is ready to serve.
10136-8{_}7823{_}Great care must be taken that this does not boil fast, or the meat will be tough and tasteless; it should only just bubble.
10136-8{_}7824{_}When convenient, all kinds of stews, &c., should be cooked on a hot-plate, as the process is so much more gradual than on an open fire.
10136-8{_}7825{_}_Time_.--5 hours, or rather more.
10136-8{_}7826{_}_Average cost_, 7d.
10136-8{_}7827{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}7828{_}_Sufficient_ for 7 or 8 persons.
10136-8{_}7829{_}_Seasonable_ all the year, but more suitable for a winter dish.
10136-8{_}7830{_}GOOD MEAT.--The lyer of meat when freshly killed, and the     animal, when slaughtered, being in a state of perfect health,     adheres firmly to the bones.
10136-8{_}7831{_}Beef of the best quality is of a     deep-red colour; and when the animal has approached maturity,     and been well fed, the lean is intermixed with fat, giving it     the mottled appearance which is so much esteemed.
10136-8{_}7832{_}It is also     full of juice, which resembles in colour claret wine.
10136-8{_}7833{_}The fat of     the best beef is of a firm and waxy consistency, of a colour     resembling that of the finest grass butter; bright in     appearance, neither greasy nor friable to the touch, but     moderately unctuous, in a medium degree between the     last-mentioned properties.
10136-8{_}7834{_}BEEF-STEAKS AND OYSTER SAUCE.
10136-8{_}7835{_}603.
10136-8{_}7836{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 dozen oysters, ingredients for oyster sauce (see No.
10136-8{_}7837{_}492), 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}7838{_}of rump-steak, seasoning to taste of pepper and salt.
10136-8{_}7839{_}_Mode_.--Make the oyster sauce by recipe No.
10136-8{_}7840{_}492, and when that is ready, put it by the side of the fire, but do not let it keep boiling.
10136-8{_}7841{_}Have the steaks cut of an equal thickness, broil them over a very clear fire, turning them often, that the gravy may not escape.
10136-8{_}7842{_}In about 8 minutes they will be done, then put them on a very hot dish; smother with the oyster sauce, and the remainder send to table in a tureen.
10136-8{_}7843{_}Serve quickly.
10136-8{_}7844{_}_Time_.--About 8 to 10 minutes, according to the thickness of the steak.
10136-8{_}7845{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}7846{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}7847{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}7848{_}_Seasonable_ from September to April.
10136-8{_}7849{_}BEEF-STEAK PIE.
10136-8{_}7850{_}604.
10136-8{_}7851{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 lbs.
10136-8{_}7852{_}of rump-steak, seasoning to taste of salt, cayenne, and black pepper, crust, water, the yolk of an egg.
10136-8{_}7853{_}_Mode_.--Have the steaks cut from a rump that has hung a few days, that they may be tender, and be particular that every portion is perfectly sweet.
10136-8{_}7854{_}Cut the steaks into pieces about 3 inches long and 2 wide, allowing a _small_ piece of fat to each piece of lean, and arrange the meat in layers in a pie-dish.
10136-8{_}7855{_}Between each layer sprinkle a seasoning of salt, pepper, and, when liked, a few grains of cayenne.
10136-8{_}7856{_}Fill the dish sufficiently with meat to support the crust, and to give it a nice raised appearance when baked, and not to look flat and hollow.
10136-8{_}7857{_}Pour in sufficient water to half fill the dish, and border it with paste (see Pastry); brush it over with a little water, and put on the cover; slightly press down the edges with the thumb, and trim off close to the dish.
10136-8{_}7858{_}Ornament the pie with leaves, or pieces of paste cut in any shape that fancy may direct, brush it over with the beaten yolk of an egg; make a hole in the top of the crust, and bake in a hot oven for about 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}7859{_}_Time_.--In a hot oven, 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}7860{_}_Average cost_, for this size, 3s 6d.
10136-8{_}7861{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 or 8 persons.
10136-8{_}7862{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}7863{_}Note.--Beef-steak pies may be flavoured in various ways, with oysters and their liquor, mushrooms, minced onions, &c. For family pies, suet may be used instead of butter or lard for the crust, and clarified beef-dripping answers very well where economy is an object.
10136-8{_}7864{_}Pieces of underdone roast or boiled meat may in pies be used very advantageously; but always remove the bone from pie-meat, unless it be chicken or game.
10136-8{_}7865{_}We have directed that the meat shall be cut smaller than is usually the case; for on trial we have found it much more tender, more easily helped, and with more gravy, than when put into the dish in one or two large steaks.
10136-8{_}7866{_}[Illustration: SHERRY PUDDING DISH.]
10136-8{_}7867{_}BEEF-STEAK AND KIDNEY PUDDING.
10136-8{_}7868{_}605.
10136-8{_}7869{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 lbs.
10136-8{_}7870{_}of rump-steak, 2 kidneys, seasoning to taste of salt and black pepper, suet crust made with milk (see Pastry), in the proportion of 6 oz.
10136-8{_}7871{_}of suet to each 1 lb.
10136-8{_}7872{_}of flour.
10136-8{_}7873{_}_Mode_.--Procure some tender rump steak (that which has been hung a little time), and divide it into pieces about an inch square, and cut each kidney into 8 pieces.
10136-8{_}7874{_}Line the dish (of which we have given an engraving) with crust made with suet and flour in the above proportion, leaving a small piece of crust to overlap the edge.
10136-8{_}7875{_}Then cover the bottom with a portion of the steak and a few pieces of kidney; season with salt and pepper (some add a little flour to thicken the gravy, but it is not necessary), and then add another layer of steak, kidney, and seasoning.
10136-8{_}7876{_}Proceed in this manner till the dish is full, when pour in sufficient water to come within 2 inches of the top of the basin.
10136-8{_}7877{_}Moisten the edges of the crust, cover the pudding over, press the two crusts together, that the gravy may not escape, and turn up the overhanging paste.
10136-8{_}7878{_}Wring out a cloth in hot water, flour it, and tie up the pudding; put it into boiling water, and let it boil for at least 4 hours.
10136-8{_}7879{_}If the water diminishes, always replenish with some, hot in a jug, as the pudding should be kept covered all the time, and not allowed to stop boiling.
10136-8{_}7880{_}When the cloth is removed, cut out a round piece in the top of the crust, to prevent the pudding bursting, and send it to table in the basin, either in an ornamental dish, or with a napkin pinned round it.
10136-8{_}7881{_}Serve quickly.
10136-8{_}7882{_}_Time_.--For a pudding with 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}7883{_}of steak and 2 kidneys allow 4 hours.
10136-8{_}7884{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}7885{_}8d.
10136-8{_}7886{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 persons.
10136-8{_}7887{_}_Seasonable_ all the year, but more suitable in winter.
10136-8{_}7888{_}Note.--Beef-steak pudding may be very much enriched by adding a few oysters or mushrooms.
10136-8{_}7889{_}The above recipe was contributed to this work by a Sussex lady, in which county the inhabitants are noted for their savoury puddings.
10136-8{_}7890{_}It differs from the general way of making them, as the meat is cut up into very small pieces and the basin is differently shaped: on trial, this pudding will be found far nicer, and more full of gravy, than when laid in large pieces in the dish.
10136-8{_}7891{_}BAD MEAT.
10136-8{_}7892{_}In the flesh of animals slaughtered whilst suffering     acute inflammation or fever, the hollow fibres, or capillaries,     as they are called, which form the substance of the lyer, are     filled with congested and unassimilated animal fluid, which,     from its impurity, gives the lyer a dark colour, and produces a     tendency to rapid putrefaction.
10136-8{_}7893{_}In a more advanced stage of such     disease, serous, and sometimes purulent matter, is formed in the     cellular tissues between the muscles of the flesh; and when such     is the case, nothing can be more poisonous than such abominable     carrion.
10136-8{_}7894{_}In the flesh of animals killed whilst under the     influence of any disease of an emaciating effect, the lyer     adheres but slightly to the bones, with its fibres contracted     and dry; and the little fat that there may be is friable, and     shrunk within its integuments.
10136-8{_}7895{_}The flesh of animals slaughtered     whilst under considerable depression of vital energy (as from     previous bleeding) has a diminished tendency to stiffen after     death, the feebleness of this tendency being in proportion to     the degree of depression.
10136-8{_}7896{_}It presents, also, an unnatural blue     or pallid appearance, has a faint and slightly sour smell, and     soon becomes putrid.
10136-8{_}7897{_}When an animal has died otherwise than by     slaughtering, its flesh is flaccid and clammy, emits a peculiar     faint and disagreeable smell, and, it need scarcely be added,     spontaneous decomposition proceeds very rapidly.
10136-8{_}7898{_}BEEF-STEAKS WITH FRIED POTATOES, or BIFTEK AUX POMMES-DE-TERRE (a la mode Francaise).
10136-8{_}7899{_}606.
10136-8{_}7900{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 lbs.
10136-8{_}7901{_}of steak, 8 potatoes, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}7902{_}of butter, salt and pepper to taste, 1 teaspoonful of minced herbs.
10136-8{_}7903{_}_Mode_.--Put the butter into a frying or _sauté_ pan, set it over the fire, and let it get very hot; peel, and cut the potatoes into long thin slices; put them into the hot butter, and fry them till of a nice brown colour.
10136-8{_}7904{_}Now broil the steaks over a bright clear fire, turning them frequently, that every part may be equally done: as they should not be thick, 5 minutes will broil them.
10136-8{_}7905{_}Put the herbs and seasoning in the butter the potatoes were fried in, pour it under the steak, and place the fried potatoes round, as a garnish.
10136-8{_}7906{_}To have this dish in perfection, a portion of the fillet of the sirloin should be used, as the meat is generally so much more tender than that of the rump, and the steaks should be cut about 1/3 of an inch in thickness.
10136-8{_}7907{_}_Time_.--5 minutes to broil the steaks, and about the same time to fry the potatoes.
10136-8{_}7908{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}7909{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}7910{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}7911{_}_Seasonable_ all the year; but not so good in warm weather, as the meat cannot hang to get tender.
10136-8{_}7912{_}[Illustration: AITCH-BONE OF BEEF.]
10136-8{_}7913{_}BOILED AITCH-BONE OF BEEF.
10136-8{_}7914{_}607.
10136-8{_}7915{_}INGREDIENTS.--Beef, water.
10136-8{_}7916{_}_Mode_.--After this joint has been in salt 5 or 6 days, it will be ready for use, and will not take so long boiling: as a round, for it is not so solid.
10136-8{_}7917{_}Wash the meat, and, if too salt, soak it for a few hours, changing the water once or twice, till the required freshness is obtained.
10136-8{_}7918{_}Put into a saucepan, or boiling-pot, sufficient water to cover the meat; set it over the fire, and when it boils, plunge in the joint (see No.
10136-8{_}7919{_}557), and let it boil up quickly.
10136-8{_}7920{_}Now draw the pot to the side of the fire, and let the process be very gradual, as the water must only simmer, or the meat will be hard and tough.
10136-8{_}7921{_}Carefully remove the scum from the surface of the water, and continue doing this for a few minutes after it first boils.
10136-8{_}7922{_}Carrots and turnips are served with this dish, and sometimes suet dumplings, which may be boiled with the beef.
10136-8{_}7923{_}Garnish with a few of the carrots and turnips, and serve the remainder in a vegetable-dish.
10136-8{_}7924{_}_Time_.--An aitch-bone of 10 lbs., 2-1/2 hours after the water boils; one of 20 lbs., 4 hours.
10136-8{_}7925{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}7926{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}7927{_}_Sufficient_.--10 lbs.
10136-8{_}7928{_}for 7 or 8 persons.
10136-8{_}7929{_}_Seasonable_ all the year, but best from September to March.
10136-8{_}7930{_}_Note_.--The liquor in which the meat has been boiled may be easily converted into a very excellent pea-soup.
10136-8{_}7931{_}It will require very few vegetables, as it will be impregnated with the flavour of those boiled with the meat.
10136-8{_}7932{_}THE ACTION OF SALT ON MEAT.--The manner in which salt acts in     preserving meat is not difficult to understand.
10136-8{_}7933{_}By its strong     affinity, it, in the first place, extracts the juices from the     substance of meat in sufficient quantity to form a saturated     solution with the water contained in the juice, and the meat     then absorbs the saturated brine in place of the juice extracted     by the salt.
10136-8{_}7934{_}In this way, matter incapable of putrefaction takes     the places of that portion in the meat which is most perishable.
10136-8{_}7935{_}Such, however, is not the only office of salt as a means of     preserving meat; it acts also by its astringency in contracting     the fibres of the muscles, and so excludes the action of air on     the interior of the substance of the meat.
10136-8{_}7936{_}The last-mentioned     operation of salt as an antiseptic is evinced by the diminution     of the volume of meat to which it is applied.
10136-8{_}7937{_}The astringent     action of _saltpetre_ on meat is much greater than that of salt,     and thereby renders meat to which it is applied very hard; but,     in small quantities, it considerably assists the antiseptic     action of salt, and also prevents the destruction of the florid     colour of meat, which is caused by the application of salt.
10136-8{_}7938{_}Thus, it will be perceived, from the foregoing statement, that     the application of salt and saltpetre diminishes, in a     considerable degree, the nutritive, and, to some extent, the     wholesome qualities of meat; and, therefore, in their use, the     quantity applied should be as small as possible, consistent with     the perfect preservation of the meat.
10136-8{_}7939{_}BOILED ROUND OF BEEF.
10136-8{_}7940{_}608.
10136-8{_}7941{_}INGREDIENTS.--Beef, water.
10136-8{_}7942{_}_Mode_.--As a whole round of beef, generally speaking, is too large for small families, and very seldom required, we here give the recipe for dressing a portion of the silver side of the round.
10136-8{_}7943{_}Take from 12 to 16 lbs., after it has been in salt about 10 days; just wash off the salt, skewer it up in a nice round-looking form, and bind it with tape to keep the skewers in their places.
10136-8{_}7944{_}Put it in a saucepan of boiling water, as in the preceding recipe, set it upon a good fire, and when it begins to boil, carefully remove all scum from the surface, as, if this is not attended to, it sinks on to the meat, and when brought to table, presents a very unsightly appearance.
10136-8{_}7945{_}When it is well skimmed, draw the pot to the corner of the fire, and let it simmer very gently until done.
10136-8{_}7946{_}Remove the tape and skewers, which should be replaced by a silver one; pour over a little of the pot-liquor, and garnish with carrots.
10136-8{_}7947{_}(_See_ coloured plate 2.)
10136-8{_}7948{_}Carrots, turnips, parsnips, and sometimes suet dumplings, accompany this dish; and these may all be boiled with the beef.
10136-8{_}7949{_}The pot-liquor should be saved, and converted into pea-soup; and the outside slices, which are generally hard, and of an uninviting appearance, may be out off before being sent to table, and potted.
10136-8{_}7950{_}These make an excellent relish for the breakfast or luncheon table.
10136-8{_}7951{_}_Time_.--Part of a round of beef weighing 12 lbs., about 3 hours after the water boils.
10136-8{_}7952{_}_Average cost_, 8d.
10136-8{_}7953{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}7954{_}_Sufficient_ for 10 persons.
10136-8{_}7955{_}_Seasonable_ all the year, but more suitable for winter.
10136-8{_}7956{_}609.
10136-8{_}7957{_}SOYER'S RECIPE FOR PRESERVING THE GRAVY IN SALT MEAT, WHEN IT IS TO BE SERVED COLD.--Fill two tubs with cold water, into which throw a few pounds of rough ice; and when the meat is done, put it into one of the tubs of ice-water; let it remain 1 minute, when take out, and put it into the other tub.
10136-8{_}7958{_}Fill the first tub again with water, and continue this process for about 20 minutes; then set it upon a dish, and let it remain until quite cold.
10136-8{_}7959{_}When cut, the fat will be as white as possible, besides having saved the whole, of the gravy.
10136-8{_}7960{_}If there is no ice, spring water will answer the same purpose, but will require to be more frequently changed.
10136-8{_}7961{_}_Note_.--The BRISKET and RUMP may be boiled by the above recipe; of course allowing more or less time, according to the size of the joint.
10136-8{_}7962{_}BEEF CAKE.
10136-8{_}7963{_}610.
10136-8{_}7964{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast beef; to each pound of cold meat allow 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}7965{_}of bacon or ham; seasoning to taste of pepper and salt, 1 small bunch of minced savoury herbs, 1 or 2 eggs.
10136-8{_}7966{_}_Mode_.--Mince the beef very finely (if underdone it will be better), add to it the bacon, which must also be chopped very small, and mix well together.
10136-8{_}7967{_}Season, stir in the herbs, and bind with an egg, or 2 should 1 not be sufficient.
10136-8{_}7968{_}Make it into small square cakes, about 1/2 inch thick, fry them in hot dripping, and serve in a dish with good gravy poured round them.
10136-8{_}7969{_}_Time_.--10 minutes.
10136-8{_}7970{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the cold meat, 6d.
10136-8{_}7971{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}7972{_}BROILED BEEF-STEAKS or RUMP-STEAKS.
10136-8{_}7973{_}611.
10136-8{_}7974{_}INGREDIENTS.--Steaks, a piece of butter the size of a walnut, salt to taste, 1 tablespoonful of good mushroom ketchup or Harvey's sauce.
10136-8{_}7975{_}_Mode_.--As the success of a good broil so much depends on the state of the fire, see that it is bright and clear, and perfectly free from smoke, and do not add any fresh fuel just before you require to use the gridiron.
10136-8{_}7976{_}Sprinkle a little salt over the fire, put on the gridiron for a few minutes, to get thoroughly hot through; rub it with a piece of fresh, suet, to prevent the meat from sticking, and lay on the steaks, which should be cut of an equal thickness, about 3/4 of an inch, or rather thinner, and level them by beating them as _little_ as possible with a rolling-pin.
10136-8{_}7977{_}Turn them frequently with steak-tongs (if these are not at hand, stick a fork in the edge of the fat, that no gravy escapes), and in from 8 to 10 minutes they will be done.
10136-8{_}7978{_}Have ready a very hot dish, into which put the ketchup, and, when liked, a little minced shalot; dish up the steaks, rub them over with butter, and season with pepper and salt.
10136-8{_}7979{_}The exact time for broiling steaks must be determined by taste, whether they are liked underdone or well done; more than from 8 to 10 minutes for a steak 3/4 inch in thickness, we think, would spoil and dry up the juices of the meat.
10136-8{_}7980{_}Great expedition is necessary in sending broiled steaks to table; and, to have them in perfection, they should not be cooked till everything else prepared for dinner has been dished up, as their excellence entirely depends on their being served very hot.
10136-8{_}7981{_}Garnish with scraped horseradish, or slices of cucumber.
10136-8{_}7982{_}Oyster, tomato, onion, and many other sauces, are frequent accompaniments to rump-steak, but true lovers of this English dish generally reject all additions but pepper and salt.
10136-8{_}7983{_}_Time_.--8 to 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}7984{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}7985{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}7986{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}7987{_}to each person; if the party consist entirely of gentlemen, 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}7988{_}will not be too much.
10136-8{_}7989{_}_Seasonable_ all the year, but not good in the height of summer, as the meat cannot hang long enough to be tender.
10136-8{_}7990{_}DIFFERENT SEASONS FOR BEEF.--We have already stated (see No.
10136-8{_}7991{_}593) that the Scots breed of oxen, like the South-down in     mutton, stands first in excellence.
10136-8{_}7992{_}It should be borne in mind,     however, that each county has its particular season, and that     the London and other large markets are always supplied by those     counties whose meat, from local circumstances, is in the best     condition at the time.
10136-8{_}7993{_}Thus, the season in Norfolk, from which     the Scots come (these being the principal oxen bred by the     Norfolk and Suffolk graziers), commences about Christmas and     terminates about June, when this breed begins to fall off, their     place being taken by grass-fed oxen.
10136-8{_}7994{_}A large quantity of most     excellent meat is sent to the "dead markets" from Scotland, and     some of the best London butchers are supplied from this source.
10136-8{_}7995{_}BROILED BEEF AND MUSHROOM SAUCE.
10136-8{_}7996{_}(Cold Meat Cookery).
10136-8{_}7997{_}612.
10136-8{_}7998{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 or 3 dozen small button mushrooms, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}7999{_}of butter, salt and cayenne to taste, 1 tablespoonful of mushroom ketchup, mashed potatoes, slices of cold roast beef.
10136-8{_}8000{_}_Mode_.--Wipe the mushrooms free from grit with a piece of flannel, and salt; put them in a stewpan with the butter, seasoning, and ketchup; stir over the fire until the mushrooms are quite done, when pour it in the middle of mashed potatoes, browned.
10136-8{_}8001{_}Then place round the potatoes slices of cold roast beef, nicely broiled, over a clear fire.
10136-8{_}8002{_}In making the mushroom sauce, the ketchup may be dispensed with, if there is sufficient gravy.
10136-8{_}8003{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}8004{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the meat, 8d.
10136-8{_}8005{_}_Seasonable_ from August to October.
10136-8{_}8006{_}BROILED BEEF AND OYSTER SAUCE (Cold Meat Cookery).
10136-8{_}8007{_}613.
10136-8{_}8008{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 dozen oysters, 3 cloves, 1 blade of mace, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}8009{_}of butter, 1/2 teaspoonful of flour, cayenne and salt to taste, mashed potatoes, a few slices of cold roast beef.
10136-8{_}8010{_}_Mode_.--Put the oysters in a stewpan, with their liquor strained; add the cloves, mace, butter, flour, and seasoning, and let them simmer gently for 5 minutes.
10136-8{_}8011{_}Have ready in the centre of a dish round walls of mashed potatoes, browned; into the middle pour the oyster sauce, quite hot, and round the potatoes place, in layers, slices of the beef, which should be previously broiled over a nice clear fire.
10136-8{_}8012{_}_Time_.--5 minutes.
10136-8{_}8013{_}_Average cost_, 1s, 6d., exclusive of the cold meat.
10136-8{_}8014{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}8015{_}_Seasonable_ from September to April.
10136-8{_}8016{_}BROILED BEEF-BONES.
10136-8{_}8017{_}614.
10136-8{_}8018{_}INGREDIENTS.--The bones of ribs or sirloin; salt, pepper, and cayenne.
10136-8{_}8019{_}_Mode_.--Separate the bones, taking care that the meat on them is not too thick in any part; sprinkle them well with the above seasoning, and broil over a very clear fire.
10136-8{_}8020{_}When nicely browned they are done; but do not allow them to blacken.
10136-8{_}8021{_}TO DRESS A BULLOCK'S HEART.
10136-8{_}8022{_}615.
10136-8{_}8023{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 heart, stuffing of veal forcemeat, No.
10136-8{_}8024{_}417.
10136-8{_}8025{_}_Mode_.--Put the heart into warm water to soak for 2 hours; then wipe it well with a cloth, and, after cutting off the lobes, stuff the inside with a highly-seasoned forcemeat (No.
10136-8{_}8026{_}417).
10136-8{_}8027{_}Fasten it in, by means of a needle and coarse thread; tie the heart up in paper, and set it before a good fire, being very particular to keep it well basted, or it will eat dry, there being very little of its own fat.
10136-8{_}8028{_}Two or three minutes before serving, remove the paper, baste well, and serve with good gravy and red-currant jelly or melted butter.
10136-8{_}8029{_}If the heart is very large, it will require 2 hours, and, covered with a caul, may be baked as well as roasted.
10136-8{_}8030{_}_Time_.--Large heart, 2 hours.
10136-8{_}8031{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}8032{_}6d.
10136-8{_}8033{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 or 8 persons.
10136-8{_}8034{_}_Seasonable_ all the year.
10136-8{_}8035{_}_Note_.--This is an excellent family dish, is very savoury, and, though not seen at many good tables, may be recommended for its cheapness and economy.
10136-8{_}8036{_}BUBBLE-AND-SQUEAK (Cold Meat Cookery).
10136-8{_}8037{_}616.
10136-8{_}8038{_}INGREDIENTS.--A few thin slices of cold boiled beef; butter, cabbage, 1 sliced onion, pepper and salt to taste.
10136-8{_}8039{_}_Mode_.--Fry the slices of beef gently in a little butter, taking care not to dry them up.
10136-8{_}8040{_}Lay them on a flat dish, and cover with fried greens.
10136-8{_}8041{_}The greens may be prepared from cabbage sprouts or green savoys.
10136-8{_}8042{_}They should be boiled till tender, well drained, minced, and placed, till quite hot, in a frying-pan, with butter, a sliced onion, and seasoning of pepper and salt.
10136-8{_}8043{_}When the onion is done, it is ready to serve.
10136-8{_}8044{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}8045{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the cold beef, 3d.
10136-8{_}8046{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}8047{_}[Illustration: COLLARED BEEF.]
10136-8{_}8048{_}COLLARED BEEF.
10136-8{_}8049{_}617.
10136-8{_}8050{_}INGREDIENTS.--7 lbs.
10136-8{_}8051{_}of the thin end of the flank of beef, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}8052{_}of coarse sugar, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}8053{_}of salt, 1 oz, of saltpetre, 1 large handful of parsley minced, 1 dessertspoonful of minced sage, a bunch of savoury herbs, 1/2 teaspoonful of pounded allspice; salt and pepper to taste.
10136-8{_}8054{_}_Mode_.--Choose fine tender beef, but not too fat; lay it in a dish; rub in the sugar, salt, and saltpetre, and let it remain in the pickle for a week or ten days, turning and rubbing it every day.
10136-8{_}8055{_}Then bone it, remove all the gristle and the coarse skin of the inside part, and sprinkle it thickly with parsley, herbs, spice, and seasoning in the above proportion, taking care that the former are finely minced, and the latter well pounded.
10136-8{_}8056{_}Roll the meat up in a cloth as tightly as possible, in the same shape as shown in the engraving; bind it firmly with broad tape, and boil it gently for 6 hours.
10136-8{_}8057{_}Immediately on taking it out of the pot, put it under a good weight, without undoing it, and let it remain until cold.
10136-8{_}8058{_}This dish is a very nice addition to the breakfast-table.
10136-8{_}8059{_}_Time_.--6 hours.
10136-8{_}8060{_}_Average cost_, for this quantity, 4s.
10136-8{_}8061{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}8062{_}_Note_.--During the time the beef is in pickle, it should be kept cool, and regularly rubbed and turned every day.
10136-8{_}8063{_}BEEF-COLLOPS.
10136-8{_}8064{_}618.
10136-8{_}8065{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 lbs.
10136-8{_}8066{_}of rump-steak, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}8067{_}of butter, 1 pint of gravy (water may be substituted for this), salt and pepper to taste, 1 shalot finely minced, 1/2 pickled walnut, 1 teaspoonful of capers.
10136-8{_}8068{_}_Mode_.--Have the steak cut thin, and divide it in pieces about 3 inches long; beat these with the blade of a knife, and dredge with flour.
10136-8{_}8069{_}Put them in a frying-pan with the butter, and let them fry for about 3 minutes; then lay them in a small stewpan, and pour over them the gravy.
10136-8{_}8070{_}Add a piece of butter, kneaded with a little flour, put in the seasoning and all the other ingredients, and let the whole simmer, but not boil, for 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}8071{_}Serve in a hot covered dish.
10136-8{_}8072{_}_Time_.--10 minutes.
10136-8{_}8073{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}8074{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}8075{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}8076{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}8077{_}MINCED COLLOPS (an Entree).
10136-8{_}8078{_}619.
10136-8{_}8079{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}8080{_}of rump-steak, salt and pepper to taste, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}8081{_}of butter, 1 onion minced, 1/4 pint of water, 1 tablespoonful of Harvey's sauce, or lemon-juice, or mushroom ketchup; 1 small bunch of savoury herbs.
10136-8{_}8082{_}_Mode_.--Mince the beef and onion very small, and fry the latter in butter until of a pale brown.
10136-8{_}8083{_}Put all the ingredients together in a stewpan, and boil gently for about 10 minutes; garnish with sippets of toasted bread, and serve very hot.
10136-8{_}8084{_}_Time_.--10 minutes.
10136-8{_}8085{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}8086{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}8087{_}_Sufficient_ for 2 or 3 persons.
10136-8{_}8088{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}8089{_}CURRIED BEEF (Cold Meat Cookery).
10136-8{_}8090{_}620.
10136-8{_}8091{_}INGREDIENTS.--A few slices of tolerably lean cold roast or boiled beef, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}8092{_}of butter, 2 onions, 1 wineglassful of beer, 1 dessertspoonful of curry powder.
10136-8{_}8093{_}_Mode_.--Cut up the beef into pieces about 1 inch square, put the butter into a stewpan with the onions sliced, and fry them of a lightly-brown colour.
10136-8{_}8094{_}Add all the other ingredients, and stir gently over a brisk fire for about 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}8095{_}Should this be thought too dry, more beer, or a spoonful or two of gravy or water, may be added; but a good curry should not be very thin.
10136-8{_}8096{_}Place it in a deep dish, with an edging of dry boiled rice, in the same manner as for other curries.
10136-8{_}8097{_}_Time_.--10 minutes.
10136-8{_}8098{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the meat, 4d.
10136-8{_}8099{_}_Seasonable_ in winter.
10136-8{_}8100{_}TO CLARIFY BEEF DRIPPING.
10136-8{_}8101{_}I.
10136-8{_}8102{_}621.
10136-8{_}8103{_}Good and fresh dripping answers very well for basting everything except game and poultry, and, when well clarified, serves for frying nearly as well as lard; it should be kept in a cool place, and will remain good some time.
10136-8{_}8104{_}To clarify it, put the dripping into a basin, pour over it boiling water, and keep stirring the whole to wash away the impurities.
10136-8{_}8105{_}Let it stand to cool, when the water and dirty sediment will settle at the bottom of the basin.
10136-8{_}8106{_}Remove the dripping, and put it away in jars or basins for use.
10136-8{_}8107{_}ANOTHER WAY.
10136-8{_}8108{_}622.
10136-8{_}8109{_}Put the dripping into a clean saucepan, and let it boil for a few minutes over a slow fire, and be careful to skim it well.
10136-8{_}8110{_}Let it stand to cool a little, then strain it through a piece of muslin into jars for use.
10136-8{_}8111{_}Beef dripping is preferable to any other for cooking purposes, as, with mutton dripping, there is liable to be a tallowy taste and smell.
10136-8{_}8112{_}ROAST FILLET OF BEEF (Larded).
10136-8{_}8113{_}623.
10136-8{_}8114{_}INGREDIENTS.--About 4 lbs.
10136-8{_}8115{_}of the inside fillet of the sirloin, 1 onion, a small bunch of parsley, salt and pepper to taste, sufficient vinegar to cover the meat, glaze, Spanish sauce, No.
10136-8{_}8116{_}411.
10136-8{_}8117{_}_Mode_.--Lard the beef with bacon, and put it into a pan with sufficient vinegar to cover it, with an onion sliced, parsley, and seasoning, and let it remain in this pickle for 12 hours.
10136-8{_}8118{_}Roast it before a nice clear fire for about 1-1/4 hour, and, when done, glaze it.
10136-8{_}8119{_}Pour some Spanish sauce round the beef, and the remainder serve in a tureen.
10136-8{_}8120{_}It may be garnished with Spanish onions boiled and glazed.
10136-8{_}8121{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}8122{_}Average cost, exclusive of the sauce, 4s.
10136-8{_}8123{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 or 8 persons.
10136-8{_}8124{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}8125{_}FRICANDEAU OF BEEF.
10136-8{_}8126{_}624.
10136-8{_}8127{_}INGREDIENTS.--About 3 lbs.
10136-8{_}8128{_}of the inside fillet of the sirloin (a piece of the rump may be substituted for this), pepper and salt to taste, 3 cloves, 2 blades of mace, 6 whole allspice, 1 pint of stock No.
10136-8{_}8129{_}105, or water, 1 glass of sherry, 1 bunch of savoury herbs, 2 shalots, bacon.
10136-8{_}8130{_}_Mode_.--Cut some bacon into thin strips, and sprinkle over them a seasoning of pepper and salt, mixed with cloves, mace, and allspice, well pounded.
10136-8{_}8131{_}Lard the beef with these, put it into a stewpan with the stock or water, sherry, herbs, shalots, 2 cloves, and more pepper and salt.
10136-8{_}8132{_}Stew the meat gently until tender, when take it out, cover it closely, skim off all the fat from the gravy, and strain it.
10136-8{_}8133{_}Set it on the fire, and boil, till it becomes a glaze.
10136-8{_}8134{_}Glaze the larded side of the beef with this, and serve on sorrel sauce, which is made as follows:--Wash and pick some sorrel, and put it into a stewpan with only the water that hangs about it.
10136-8{_}8135{_}Keep stirring, to prevent its burning, and when done, lay it in a sieve to drain.
10136-8{_}8136{_}Chop it, and stew it with a small piece of butter and 4 or 6 tablespoonfuls of good gravy, for an hour, and rub it through a tammy.
10136-8{_}8137{_}If too acid, add a little sugar; and a little cabbage-lettuce boiled with the sorrel will be found an improvement.
10136-8{_}8138{_}_Time_.--2 hours to gently stew the meat.
10136-8{_}8139{_}_Average cost_, for this quantity, 4s.
10136-8{_}8140{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 persons.
10136-8{_}8141{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}8142{_}FRIED SALT BEEF (Cold Meat Cookery).
10136-8{_}8143{_}625.
10136-8{_}8144{_}INGREDIENTS.--A few slices of cold salt beef, pepper to taste, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}8145{_}of butter, mashed potatoes.
10136-8{_}8146{_}_Mode_.--Cut any part of cold salt beef into thin slices, fry them gently in butter, and season with a little pepper.
10136-8{_}8147{_}Have ready some very hot mashed potatoes, lay the slices of beef on them, and garnish with 3 or 4 pickled gherkins.
10136-8{_}8148{_}Cold salt beef, warmed in a little liquor from mixed pickle, drained, and served as above, will be found good.
10136-8{_}8149{_}_Time_.--About 5 minutes.
10136-8{_}8150{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the meat, 4d.
10136-8{_}8151{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}8152{_}FRIED RUMP-STEAK.
10136-8{_}8153{_}626.
10136-8{_}8154{_}INGREDIENTS.--Steaks, butter or clarified dripping.
10136-8{_}8155{_}_Mode_.
10136-8{_}8156{_}Although broiling is a far superior method of cooking steaks to frying them, yet, when the cook is not very expert, the latter mode may be adopted; and, when properly done, the dish may really look very inviting, and the flavour be good.
10136-8{_}8157{_}The steaks should be cut rather thinner than for broiling, and with a small quantity of fat to each.
10136-8{_}8158{_}Put some butter or clarified dripping into a frying-pan; let it get quite hot, then lay in the steaks.
10136-8{_}8159{_}Turn them frequently until done, which will be in about 8 minutes, or rather more, should the steaks be very thick.
10136-8{_}8160{_}Serve on a very hot dish, in which put a small piece of butter and a tablespoonful of ketchup, and season with pepper and salt.
10136-8{_}8161{_}They should be sent to table quickly, as, when cold, the steaks are entirely spoiled.
10136-8{_}8162{_}_Time_.--8 minutes for a medium-sized steak, rather longer for a very thick one.
10136-8{_}8163{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}8164{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}8165{_}_Seasonable all the year, but not good in summer, as the meat cannot hang to get tender._  _Note_.--Where much gravy is liked, make it in the following manner:--As soon as the steaks are done, dish them, pour a little boiling water into the frying-pan, add a seasoning of pepper and salt, a small piece of butter, and a tablespoonful of Harvey's sauce or mushroom ketchup.
10136-8{_}8166{_}Hold the pan over the fire for a minute or two, just let the gravy simmer, then pour on the steak, and serve.
10136-8{_}8167{_}A FRENCHMAN'S OPINION OF BEEF.
10136-8{_}8168{_}The following is translated from     a celebrated modern French work, the production of one who in     Paris enjoys a great reputation as cook and chemist:--The flesh     of the ox, to be in the best condition, should be taken from an     animal of from four to six years old, and neither too fat nor     too lean.
10136-8{_}8169{_}This meat, which possesses in the highest degree the     most nutritive qualities, is generally easily digested; stock is     made from it, and it is eaten boiled, broiled, roasted, stewed,     braised, and in a hundred other different ways.
10136-8{_}8170{_}Beef is the     foundation of stock, gravies, braises, &c.; its nutritious and     succulent gravy gives body and flavour to numberless ragoûts.
10136-8{_}8171{_}It     is an exhaustless mine in the hands of a skilful artist, and is     truly the king of the kitchen.
10136-8{_}8172{_}Without it, no soup, no gravy;     and its absence would produce almost a famine in the civilized     world!
10136-8{_}8173{_}BEEF FRITTERS (Cold Meat Cookery).
10136-8{_}8174{_}627.
10136-8{_}8175{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast beef, pepper and salt to taste, 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}8176{_}of flour, 1/2 pint of water, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}8177{_}of butter, the whites of 2 eggs.
10136-8{_}8178{_}_Mode_.--Mix very smoothly, and by degrees, the flour with the above proportion of water; stir in 2 oz.
10136-8{_}8179{_}of butter, which must be melted, but not oiled, and, just before it is to be used, add the whites of two well-whisked eggs.
10136-8{_}8180{_}Should the batter be too thick, more water must be added.
10136-8{_}8181{_}Pare down the cold beef into thin shreds, season with pepper and salt, and mix it with the batter.
10136-8{_}8182{_}Drop a small quantity at a time into a pan of boiling lard, and fry from 7 to 10 minutes, according to the size.
10136-8{_}8183{_}When done on one side, turn and brown them on the other.
10136-8{_}8184{_}Let them dry for a minute or two before the fire, and serve on a folded napkin.
10136-8{_}8185{_}A small quantity of finely-minced onions, mixed with the batter, is an improvement.
10136-8{_}8186{_}_Time_.--From 7 to 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}8187{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the meat, 6d.
10136-8{_}8188{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}8189{_}HASHED BEEF (Cold Meat Cookery).
10136-8{_}8190{_}I.
10136-8{_}8191{_}628.
10136-8{_}8192{_}INGREDIENTS.--Gravy saved from the meat, 1 teaspoonful of tomato sauce, 1 teaspoonful of Harvey's sauce, 1 teaspoonful of good mushroom ketchup, 1/2 glass of port wine or strong ale, pepper and salt to taste, a little flour to thicken, 1 onion finely minced, a few slices of cold roast beef.
10136-8{_}8193{_}_Mode_.--Put all the ingredients but the beef into a stewpan with whatever gravy may have been saved from the meat the day it was roasted; let these simmer gently for 10 minutes, then take the stewpan off the fire; let the gravy cool, and skim off the fat.
10136-8{_}8194{_}Cut the beef into thin slices, dredge them with flour, and lay them in the gravy; let the whole simmer gently for 5 minutes, but not boil, or the meat will be tough and hard.
10136-8{_}8195{_}Serve very hot, and garnish with sippets of toasted bread.
10136-8{_}8196{_}_Time_.--20 minutes.
10136-8{_}8197{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the cold meat, 4d.
10136-8{_}8198{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}8199{_}II.
10136-8{_}8200{_}629.
10136-8{_}8201{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of ribs or sirloin of beef, 2 onions, 1 carrot, 1 bunch of savoury herbs, pepper and salt to taste, 1/2 blade of pounded mace, thickening of flour, rather more than 1 pint of water.
10136-8{_}8202{_}_Mode_.--Take off all the meat from the bones of ribs or sirloin of beef; remove the outside brown and gristle; place the meat on one side, and well stew the bones and pieces, with the above ingredients, for about 2 hours, till it becomes a strong gravy, and is reduced to rather more than 1/2 pint; strain this, thicken with a teaspoonful of flour, and let the gravy cool; skim off all the fat; lay in the meat, let it get hot through, but do not allow it to boil, and garnish with sippets of toasted bread.
10136-8{_}8203{_}The gravy may be flavoured as in the preceding recipe.
10136-8{_}8204{_}_Time_.--Rather more than 2 hours.
10136-8{_}8205{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the cold meat, 2d.
10136-8{_}8206{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}8207{_}_Note_.--Either of the above recipes may be served in walls of mashed potatoes browned; in which case the sippets should be omitted.
10136-8{_}8208{_}Be careful that hashed meat does not boil, or it will become tough.
10136-8{_}8209{_}TO PREPARE HUNG BEEF.
10136-8{_}8210{_}630.
10136-8{_}8211{_}This is preserved by salting and drying, either with or without smoke.
10136-8{_}8212{_}Hang up the beef 3 or 4 days, till it becomes tender, but take care it does not begin to spoil; then salt it in the usual way, either by dry-salting or by brine, with bay-salt, brown sugar, saltpetre, and a little pepper and allspice; afterwards roll it tight in a cloth, and hang it up in a warm, but not hot place, for a fortnight or more, till it is sufficiently hard.
10136-8{_}8213{_}If required to have a little of the smoky flavour, it may be hung for some time in a chimney-corner, or smoked in any other way: it will keep a long time.
10136-8{_}8214{_}HUNTER'S BEEF.
10136-8{_}8215{_}631.
10136-8{_}8216{_}INGREDIENTS.--For a round of beef weighing 25 lbs.
10136-8{_}8217{_}allow 3 oz.
10136-8{_}8218{_}of saltpetre, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}8219{_}of coarse sugar, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}8220{_}of cloves, 1 grated nutmeg, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}8221{_}of allspice, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}8222{_}of salt, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}8223{_}bay-salt.
10136-8{_}8224{_}_Mode_.--Let the beef hang for 2 or 3 days, and remove the bone.
10136-8{_}8225{_}Pound spices, salt, &c. in the above proportion, and let them be reduced to the finest powder.
10136-8{_}8226{_}Put the beef into a pan, rub all the ingredients well into it, and turn and rub it every day for rather more than a fortnight.
10136-8{_}8227{_}When it has been sufficiently long in pickle, wash the meat, bind it up securely with tape, and put it into a pan with 1/2 pint of water at the bottom; mince some suet, cover the top of the meat with it, and over the pan put a common crust of flour and water; bake for 6 hours, and, when cold, remove the paste.
10136-8{_}8228{_}Save the gravy that flows from it, as it adds greatly to the flavour of hashes, stews, &c. The beef may be glazed and garnished with meat jelly.
10136-8{_}8229{_}_Time_.--6 hours.
10136-8{_}8230{_}_Seasonable_ all the year.
10136-8{_}8231{_}_Note_.--In salting or pickling beef or pork for family consumption, it not being generally required to be kept for a great length of time, a less quantity of salt and a larger quantity of other matters more adapted to retain mellowness in meat, may be employed, which could not be adopted by the curer of the immense quantities of meat required to be preserved for victualling the shipping of this maritime country.
10136-8{_}8232{_}Sugar, which is well known to possess the preserving principle in a very great degree, without the pungency and astringency of salt, may be, and is, very generally used in the preserving of meat for family consumption.
10136-8{_}8233{_}Although it acts without corrugating or contracting the fibres of meat, as is the case in the action of salt, and, therefore, does not impair its mellowness, yet its use in sufficient quantities for preservative effect, without the addition of other antiseptics, would impart a flavour not agreeable to the taste of many persons.
10136-8{_}8234{_}It may be used, however, together with salt, with the greatest advantage in imparting mildness and mellowness to cured meat, in a proportion of about one part by weight to four of the mixture; and, perhaps, now that sugar is so much lower in price than it was in former years, one of the obstructions to its more frequent use is removed.
10136-8{_}8235{_}TO DRESS BEEF KIDNEY.
10136-8{_}8236{_}I.
10136-8{_}8237{_}632.
10136-8{_}8238{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 kidney, clarified butter, pepper and salt to taste, a small quantity of highly-seasoned gravy, 1 tablespoonful of lemon-juice, 1/4 teaspoonful of powdered sugar.
10136-8{_}8239{_}_Mode_.--Cut the kidneys into neat slices, put them into warm water to soak for 2 hours, and change the water 2 or 3 times; then put them on a clean cloth to dry the water from them, and lay them in a frying-pan with some clarified butter, and fry them of a nice brown; season each side with pepper and salt, put them round the dish, and the gravy in the middle.
10136-8{_}8240{_}Before pouring the gravy in the dish, add the lemon-juice and sugar.
10136-8{_}8241{_}_Time_.--From 5 to 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}8242{_}_Average cost_, 9d.
10136-8{_}8243{_}each.
10136-8{_}8244{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}8245{_}II.
10136-8{_}8246{_}633.
10136-8{_}8247{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 kidney, 1 dessertspoonful of minced parsley, 1 teaspoonful of minced shalot, salt and pepper to taste, 1/4 pint of gravy, No.
10136-8{_}8248{_}438, 3 tablespoonfuls of sherry.
10136-8{_}8249{_}_Mode_.--Take off a little of the kidney fat, mince it very fine, and put it in a frying-pan; slice the kidney, sprinkle over it parsley and shalots in the above proportion, add a seasoning of pepper and salt, and fry it of a nice brown.
10136-8{_}8250{_}When it is done enough, dredge over a little flour, and pour in the gravy and sherry.
10136-8{_}8251{_}Let it just simmer, but not boil any more, or the kidney would harden; serve very hot, and garnish with croûtons.
10136-8{_}8252{_}Where the flavour of the shalot is disliked, it may be omitted, and a small quantity of savoury herbs substituted for it.
10136-8{_}8253{_}_Time_.--From 5 to 10 minutes, according to the thickness of the slices.
10136-8{_}8254{_}_Average cost_, 9d.
10136-8{_}8255{_}each.
10136-8{_}8256{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 persons.
10136-8{_}8257{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}8258{_}III.
10136-8{_}8259{_}_A more Simple Method_.
10136-8{_}8260{_}634.
10136-8{_}8261{_}Cut the kidney into thin slices, flour them, and fry of a nice brown.
10136-8{_}8262{_}When done, make a gravy in the pan by pouring away the fat, putting in a small piece of butter, 1/4 pint of boiling water, pepper and salt, and a tablespoonful of mushroom ketchup.
10136-8{_}8263{_}Let the gravy just boil up, pour over the kidney, and serve.
10136-8{_}8264{_}BOILED MARROW-BONES.
10136-8{_}8265{_}635.
10136-8{_}8266{_}INGREDIENTS.--Bones, a small piece of common paste, a floured cloth.
10136-8{_}8267{_}_Mode_.--Have the bones neatly sawed into convenient sizes, and cover the ends with a small piece of common crust, made with flour and water.
10136-8{_}8268{_}Over this tie a floured cloth, and place them upright in a saucepan of boiling water, taking care there is sufficient to cover the bones.
10136-8{_}8269{_}Boil them for 2 hours, remove the cloth and paste, and serve them upright on a napkin with dry toast.
10136-8{_}8270{_}Many persons clear the marrow from the bones after they are cooked, spread it over a slice of toast and add a seasoning of pepper; when served in this manner, it must be very expeditiously sent to table, as it so soon gets cold.
10136-8{_}8271{_}_Time_.--2 hours.
10136-8{_}8272{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}8273{_}_Note_.--Marrow-bones may be baked after preparing them as in the preceding recipe; they should be laid in a deep dish, and baked for 2 hours.
10136-8{_}8274{_}[Illustration: MARROW-BONES.]
10136-8{_}8275{_}MARROW-BONES.--Bones are formed of a dense cellular tissue of     membranous matter, made stiff and rigid by insoluble earthy     salts; of which, phosphate of lime is the most abundant.
10136-8{_}8276{_}In a     large bone, the insoluble matter is generally deposited in such     a manner as to leave a cavity, into which a fatty substance,     distinguished by the name of marrow, is thrown.
10136-8{_}8277{_}Hollow     cylindrical bones possess the qualities of strength and     lightness in a remarkable degree.
10136-8{_}8278{_}If bones were entirely solid,     they would be unnecessarily heavy; and if their materials were     brought into smaller compass, they would be weaker, because the     strength of a bone is in proportion to the distance at which its     fibres are from the centre.
10136-8{_}8279{_}Some animals, it must, however, be     observed, have no cavities in the centre of their bones; such as     the whale tribe, skate, and turtles.
10136-8{_}8280{_}MINCED BEEF (Cold Meat Cookery).
10136-8{_}8281{_}636.
10136-8{_}8282{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 oz.
10136-8{_}8283{_}of butter, 1 small onion, 2 tablespoonfuls of gravy left from the meat, 1 tablespoonful of strong ale, 1/2 a teaspoonful of flour, salt and pepper to taste, a few slices of lean roast beef.
10136-8{_}8284{_}_Mode_.--Put into a stewpan the butter with an onion chopped fine; add the gravy, ale, and 1/2 a teaspoonful of flour to thicken; season with pepper and salt, and stir these ingredients over the fire until the onion is a rich brown.
10136-8{_}8285{_}Cut, but do not chop the meat _very fine_, add it to the gravy, stir till quite hot, and serve.
10136-8{_}8286{_}Garnish with sippets of toasted bread.
10136-8{_}8287{_}Be careful in not allowing the gravy to boil after the meat is added, as it would render it hard and tough.
10136-8{_}8288{_}_Time_.--About 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}8289{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the meat, 3d.
10136-8{_}8290{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}8291{_}MIROTON OF BEEF.
10136-8{_}8292{_}637.
10136-8{_}8293{_}INGREDIENTS.--A few slices of cold roast beef, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}8294{_}of butter, salt and pepper to taste, 3 onions, 1/2 pint of gravy.
10136-8{_}8295{_}_Mode_.--Slice the onions and put them into a frying-pan with the cold beef and butter; place it over the fire, and keep turning and stirring the ingredients to prevent them burning.
10136-8{_}8296{_}When of a pale brown, add the gravy and seasoning; let it simmer for a few minutes, and serve very hot.
10136-8{_}8297{_}This dish is excellent and economical.
10136-8{_}8298{_}_Time_.--5 minutes.
10136-8{_}8299{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the meat, 6d.
10136-8{_}8300{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}8301{_}STEWED OX-CHEEK.
10136-8{_}8302{_}638.
10136-8{_}8303{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 cheek, salt and water, 4 or 5 onions, butter and flour, 6 cloves, 3 turnips, 2 carrots, 1 bay-leaf, 1 head of celery, 1 bunch of savoury herbs, cayenne, black pepper and salt to taste, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}8304{_}of butter, 2 dessertspoonfuls of flour, 2 tablespoonfuls of Chili vinegar, 2 tablespoonfuls of mushroom ketchup, 2 tablespoonfuls of port wine, 2 tablespoonfuls of Harvey's sauce.
10136-8{_}8305{_}_Mode_.--Have the cheek boned, and prepare it the day before it is to be eaten, by cleaning and putting it to soak all night in salt and water.
10136-8{_}8306{_}The next day, wipe it dry and clean, and put it into a stewpan.
10136-8{_}8307{_}Just cover it with water, skim well when it boils, and let it gently simmer till the meat is quite tender.
10136-8{_}8308{_}Slice and fry 3 onions in a little butter and flour, and put them into the gravy; add 2 whole onions, each stuck with 3 cloves, 3 turnips quartered, 2 carrots sliced, a bay-leaf, 1 head of celery, a bunch of herbs, and seasoning to taste of cayenne, black pepper, and salt.
10136-8{_}8309{_}Let these stew till perfectly tender; then take out the cheek, divide into pieces fit to help at table, skim and strain the gravy, and thicken 1-1/2 pint of it with butter and flour in the above proportions.
10136-8{_}8310{_}Add the vinegar, ketchup, and port wine; put in the pieces of cheek; let the whole boil up, and serve quite hot.
10136-8{_}8311{_}Send it to table in a ragout-dish.
10136-8{_}8312{_}If the colour of the gravy should not be very good, add a tablespoonful of the browning, No.
10136-8{_}8313{_}108.
10136-8{_}8314{_}_Time_.--4 hours.
10136-8{_}8315{_}_Average cost_, 3d.
10136-8{_}8316{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}8317{_}_Sufficient_ for 8 persons.
10136-8{_}8318{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}8319{_}FRIED OX-FEET, or COW-HEEL.
10136-8{_}8320{_}639.
10136-8{_}8321{_}INGREDIENTS.--Ox-feet, the yolk of 1 egg, bread crumbs, parsley, salt and cayenne to taste, boiling butter.
10136-8{_}8322{_}_Mode_.--Wash, scald, and thoroughly clean the feet, and cut them into pieces about 2 inches long; have ready some fine bread crumbs mixed with a little minced parsley, cayenne, and salt; dip the pieces of heel into the yolk of egg, sprinkle them with the bread crumbs, and fry them until of a nice brown in boiling butter.
10136-8{_}8323{_}_Time_.-1 hour.
10136-8{_}8324{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}8325{_}each.
10136-8{_}8326{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}8327{_}Note.--Ox-feet may be dressed in various ways, stowed in gravy or plainly boiled and served with melted butter.
10136-8{_}8328{_}When plainly boiled, the liquor will answer for making sweet or relishing jellies, and also to give richness to soups or gravies.
10136-8{_}8329{_}STEWED OX-TAILS.
10136-8{_}8330{_}640.
10136-8{_}8331{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 ox-tails, 1 onion, 3 cloves, 1 blade of mace, 1 teaspoonful of whole black pepper, 1 teaspoonful of allspice, 1/2 a teaspoonful of salt, a small bunch of savoury herbs, thickening of butter and flour, 1 tablespoonful of lemon-juice, 1 tablespoonful of mushroom ketchup.
10136-8{_}8332{_}_Mode_.--Divide the tails at the joints, wash, and put them into a stewpan with sufficient water to cover them, and set them on the fire; when the water boils, remove the scum, and add the onion cut into rings, the spice, seasoning, and herbs.
10136-8{_}8333{_}Cover the stewpan closely, and let the tails simmer very gently until tender, which will be in about 2-1/2 hours.
10136-8{_}8334{_}Take them out, make a thickening of butter and flour, add it to the gravy, and let it boil for 1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}8335{_}Strain it through a sieve into a saucepan, put back the tails, add the lemon-juice and ketchup; let the whole just boil up, and serve.
10136-8{_}8336{_}Garnish with croûtons or sippets of toasted bread.
10136-8{_}8337{_}_Time_.--2-1/2 hours to stew the tails.
10136-8{_}8338{_}_Average cost_, 9d.
10136-8{_}8339{_}to 1s.
10136-8{_}8340{_}6d., according to the season.
10136-8{_}8341{_}_Sufficient_ for 8 persons.
10136-8{_}8342{_}_Seasonable_ all the year.
10136-8{_}8343{_}THE TAILS OF ANIMALS.--In the class Mammalia, the vertebral     column or backbone presents only slight modifications, and     everywhere shows the same characteristics as in man, who stands     at the head of this division of the animal kingdom.
10136-8{_}8344{_}The length     of this column, however, varies much, and the number of     vertebrae of which it is composed is far from being uniform.
10136-8{_}8345{_}These numerical differences principally depend on the unequal     development of the caudal portion, or tail-end, of the column.
10136-8{_}8346{_}Thus, the tail-forming vertebrae sometimes do not exist at     all,--amongst certain bats for example; in other instances we     reckon forty, fifty, and even upwards of sixty of these bones.
10136-8{_}8347{_}Among the greater number of mammals, the tail is of little use     for locomotion, except that it acts in many cases as does the     rudder of a ship, steadying the animal in his rapid movements,     and enabling him to turn more easily and quickly.
10136-8{_}8348{_}Among some     animals, it becomes a very powerful instrument of progression.
10136-8{_}8349{_}Thus, in the kangaroos and jerboas, the tail forms, with the     hind feet, a kind of tripod from which the animal makes its     spring.
10136-8{_}8350{_}With most of the American monkeys it is prehensile, and     serves the animal as a fifth hand to suspend itself from the     branches of trees; and, lastly, among the whales, it grows to an     enormous size, and becomes the principal instrument for     swimming.
10136-8{_}8351{_}A PICKLE FOR TONGUES OR BEEF (Newmarket Recipe).
10136-8{_}8352{_}641.
10136-8{_}8353{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 gallon of soft water, 3 lbs.
10136-8{_}8354{_}of coarse salt, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}8355{_}of coarse brown sugar, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}8356{_}of saltpetre.
10136-8{_}8357{_}_Mode_.--Put all the ingredients into a saucepan, and let them boil for 1/2 hour, clear off the scum as it rises, and when done pour the pickle into a pickling-pan.
10136-8{_}8358{_}Let it get cold, then put in the meat, and allow it to remain in the pickle from 8 to 14 days, according to the size.
10136-8{_}8359{_}It will keep good for 6 months if well boiled once a fortnight.
10136-8{_}8360{_}Tongues will take 1 month or 6 weeks to be properly cured; and, in salting meat, beef and tongues should always be put in separate vessels.
10136-8{_}8361{_}_Time_.--A moderate-sized tongue should remain in the pickle about a month, and be turned every day.
10136-8{_}8362{_}[Illustration: POTTING-JAR.]
10136-8{_}8363{_}POTTED BEEF.
10136-8{_}8364{_}I.
10136-8{_}8365{_}642.
10136-8{_}8366{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 lbs.
10136-8{_}8367{_}of lean beef, 1 tablespoonful of water, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}8368{_}of butter, a seasoning to taste of salt, cayenne, pounded mace, and black pepper.
10136-8{_}8369{_}_Mode_.--Procure a nice piece of lean beef, as free as possible from gristle, skin, &c., and put it into a jar (if at hand, one with a lid) with 1 tablespoonful of water.
10136-8{_}8370{_}Cover it _closely_, and put the jar into a saucepan of boiling water, letting the water come within 2 inches of the top of the jar.
10136-8{_}8371{_}Boil gently for 3-1/2 hours, then take the beef, chop it very small with a chopping-knife, and pound it thoroughly in a mortar.
10136-8{_}8372{_}Mix with it by degrees all, or a portion, of the gravy that will have run from it, and a little clarified butter; add the seasoning, put it in small pots for use, and cover with a little butter just warmed and poured over.
10136-8{_}8373{_}If much gravy is added to it, it will keep but a short time; on the contrary, if a large proportion of butter is used, it may be preserved for some time.
10136-8{_}8374{_}_Time_.--3-1/2 hours.
10136-8{_}8375{_}_Average cost_, for this quantity, 1s.
10136-8{_}8376{_}8d.
10136-8{_}8377{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}8378{_}POTTED BEEF (Cold Meat Cookery).
10136-8{_}8379{_}II.
10136-8{_}8380{_}643.
10136-8{_}8381{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast or boiled beef, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}8382{_}of butter, cayenne to taste, 2 blades of pounded mace.
10136-8{_}8383{_}_Mode_.--As we have stated in recipe No.
10136-8{_}8384{_}608, the outside slices of boiled beef may, with a little trouble, be converted into a very nice addition to the breakfast-table.
10136-8{_}8385{_}Cut up the meat into small pieces and pound it well, with a little butter, in a mortar; add a seasoning of cayenne and mace, and be very particular that the latter ingredient is reduced to the finest powder.
10136-8{_}8386{_}When all the ingredients are thoroughly mixed, put it into glass or earthen potting-pots, and pour on the top a coating of clarified butter.
10136-8{_}8387{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}8388{_}_Note_.--If cold roast beef is used, remove all pieces of gristle and dry outside pieces, as these do not pound well.
10136-8{_}8389{_}PRESERVED MEATS.--When an organic substance, like the flesh of     animals, is heated to the boiling-point, it loses the property     of passing into a state of fermentation and decay.
10136-8{_}8390{_}Fresh animal     milk, as is well known, coagulates, after having been kept for     two or three days, into a gelatinous mass; but it may be     preserved for an indefinite period, as a perfectly sweet liquid,     if it be heated daily to the boiling-point.
10136-8{_}8391{_}The knowledge of     this effect of an elevated temperature has given rise to a most     important branch of industry,--namely, the preparation of     preserved meats for the use of the navy and merchant service.
10136-8{_}8392{_}At     Leith, in the neighbourhood of Edinburgh, at Aberdeen, at     Bordeaux, at Marseilles, and in many parts of Germany,     establishments of enormous magnitude exist, in which soup,     vegetables, and viands of every description are prepared, in     such a manner that they retain their freshness for years.
10136-8{_}8393{_}The     prepared aliments are inclosed in canisters of tinned iron     plate, the covers are soldered air-tight, and the canisters     exposed to the temperature of boiling water for three or four     hours.
10136-8{_}8394{_}The aliments thus acquire a stability, which one may     almost say is eternal; and when a canister is opened, after the     lapse of several years, its contents are found to be unaltered     in taste, colour, and smell.
10136-8{_}8395{_}We are indebted to the French     philosopher Gay-Lussac for this beautiful practical application     of the discovery that boiling checks fermentation.
10136-8{_}8396{_}An exclusive     salt-meat diet is extremely injurious to the health; and, in     former times, thousands of mariners lost their lives for the     want of fresh aliments during long voyages.
10136-8{_}8397{_}We are sorry to say     that the preserved meats are sometimes carelessly prepared, and,     though the statement seems incredible, sometimes adulterated.
10136-8{_}8398{_}Dr. Lankester, who has done so much to expose the frauds of     trade, that he ought to be regarded as a public benefactor, says     that he has seen things which were utterly unfit for food,     shipped as preserved meats.
10136-8{_}8399{_}Surely, as he observes, there ought     to be some superintendent to examine the so-called articles of     food that are taken on board ship, so that the poor men who have     been fighting our battles abroad may run no risk of being     starved or poisoned on their way home.
10136-8{_}8400{_}RIB OF BEEF BONES.

10136-8{_}8404{_}_Mode_.--The bones for this dish should have left on them a slight covering of meat; saw them into pieces 3 inches long; season them with pepper and salt, and put them into a stewpan with the remaining ingredients.

10136-8{_}8409{_}BEEF RISSOLES (Cold Meat Cookery).
10136-8{_}8410{_}645.
10136-8{_}8411{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast beef; to each pound of meat allow 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}8412{_}of bread crumbs, salt and pepper to taste, a few chopped savoury herbs, 1/2 a teaspoonful of minced lemon-peel, 1 or 2 eggs, according to the quantity of meat.
10136-8{_}8413{_}_Mode_.--Mince the beef very fine, which should be rather lean, and mix with this bread crumbs, herbs, seasoning, and lemon-peel, in the above proportion, to each pound of meat.
10136-8{_}8414{_}Make all into a thick paste with 1 or 2 eggs; divide into balls or cones, and fry a rich brown.
10136-8{_}8415{_}Garnish the dish with fried parsley, and send with them to table some good brown gravy in a tureen.
10136-8{_}8416{_}Instead of garnishing with fried parsley, gravy may be poured in the dish, round the rissoles: in this case, it will not be necessary to send any in a tureen.
10136-8{_}8417{_}_Time_.--From 5 to 10 minutes, according to size.
10136-8{_}8418{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the meat, 5d.
10136-8{_}8419{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.

10136-8{_}8427{_}417, lay it on the meat, and bind it up securely.

10136-8{_}8429{_}Serve, with a good gravy in the dish, and send red-currant jelly to table with it.

10136-8{_}8440{_}Beef patties may be made of cold meat, by mincing and seasoning beef as directed above, and baking in a rich puff paste in patty-tins.

10136-8{_}8443{_}MINIATURE ROUND OF BEEF.

10136-8{_}8458{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}8459{_}_Note_.--Should the joint be very small, 4 or 5 days will be sufficient time to salt it.
10136-8{_}8460{_}BRISKET OF BEEF, a la Flamande.
10136-8{_}8461{_}649.
10136-8{_}8462{_}INGREDIENTS.--About 6 or 8 lbs.
10136-8{_}8463{_}of the brisket of beef, 4 or 5 slices of bacon, 2 carrots, 1 onion, a bunch of savoury herbs, salt and pepper to taste, 4 cloves, 4 whole allspice, 2 blades of mace.
10136-8{_}8464{_}_Mode_.--Choose that portion of the brisket which contains the gristle, trim it, and put it into a stewpan with the slices of bacon, which should be put under and over the meat.
10136-8{_}8465{_}Add the vegetables, herbs, spices, and seasoning, and cover with a little weak stock or water; close the stewpan as hermetically as possible, and simmer very gently for 4 hours.
10136-8{_}8466{_}Strain the liquor, reserve a portion of it for sauce, and the remainder boil quickly over a sharp fire until reduced to a glaze, with which glaze the meat.
10136-8{_}8467{_}Garnish the dish with scooped carrots and turnips, and when liked, a little cabbage; all of which must be cooked separately.
10136-8{_}8468{_}Thicken and flavour the liquor that was saved for sauce, pour it round the meat, and serve.
10136-8{_}8469{_}The beef may also be garnished with glazed onions, artichoke-bottoms, &c.
10136-8{_}8470{_}_Time_.--4 hours.
10136-8{_}8471{_}_Average cost_, 7d.
10136-8{_}8472{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}8473{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 or 8 persons.
10136-8{_}8474{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}8475{_}FRENCH BEEF.--It has been all but universally admitted, that the     beef of France is greatly inferior in quality to that of     England, owing to inferiority of pasturage.
10136-8{_}8476{_}M. Curmer, however,     one of the latest writers on the culinary art, tells us that     this is a vulgar error, and that French beef is far superior to     that of England.
10136-8{_}8477{_}This is mere vaunting on the part of our     neighbours, who seem to want _la gloire_ in everything; and we     should not deign to notice it, if it had occurred in a work of     small pretensions; but M. Curmer's book professes to be a     complete exposition of the scientific principles of cookery, and     holds a high rank in the didactic literature of France.
10136-8{_}8478{_}We half     suspect that M. Curmer obtained his knowledge of English beef in     the same way as did the poor Frenchman, whom the late Mr.     Mathews, the comedian, so humorously described.
10136-8{_}8479{_}Mr. Lewis, in     his "Physiology of Common Life," has thus revived the story of     the beef-eating son of France:--"A Frenchman was one day blandly     remonstrating against the supercilious scorn expressed by     Englishmen for the beef of France, which he, for his part, did     not find so inferior to that of England.
10136-8{_}8480{_}'I have been two times     in England,' he remarked, but I nevère find the bif so supérieur     to ours.
10136-8{_}8481{_}I find it vary conveenient that they bring it you on     leetle pieces of stick, for one penny: but I do not find the bif     supérieur.'
10136-8{_}8482{_}On hearing this, the Englishman, red with     astonishment, exclaimed, 'Good heavens, sir!
10136-8{_}8483{_}you have been     eating cat's meat.'"
10136-8{_}8484{_}No, M. Curmer, we are ready to acknowledge     the superiority of your cookery, but we have long since made up     our minds as to the inferiority of your raw material.

10136-8{_}8490{_}105, 2 or 3 slices of bacon, 2 tablespoonfuls of any store sauce, a slight thickening of butter and flour.
10136-8{_}8491{_}_Mode_.--Have the steaks cut rather thin, slightly beat them to make them level, cut them into 6 or 7 pieces, brush over with egg, and sprinkle with herbs, which should be very finely minced; season with pepper and salt, and roll up the pieces tightly, and fasten with a small skewer.
10136-8{_}8492{_}Put the stock in a stewpan that will exactly hold them, for by being pressed together, they will keep their shape better; lay in the rolls of meat, cover them with the bacon, cut in thin slices, and over that put a piece of paper.
10136-8{_}8493{_}Stew them very _gently_ for full 2 hours; for the slower they are done the better.
10136-8{_}8494{_}Take them out, remove the skewers, thicken the gravy with butter and flour, and flavour with any store sauce that may be preferred.
10136-8{_}8495{_}Give one boil, pour over the meat, and serve.

10136-8{_}8497{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}8498{_}per pound.
10136-8{_}8499{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}8500{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.

10136-8{_}8507{_}Arrange the meat in a dish, thicken and flavour the gravy, and pour it over the meat, when it is ready to serve.

10136-8{_}8511{_}BROILED OX-TAIL (an Entree).
