10136-8{_}11636{_}_Mode_.--Bone the joint by carefully detaching the meat from the blade-bone on one side, and then on the other, being particular not to pierce the skin; then cut the bone from the knuckle, and take it out.
10136-8{_}11637{_}Fill the cavity whence the bone was taken with a forcemeat made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}11638{_}417.
10136-8{_}11639{_}Roll and bind the veal up tightly; put it into a stew-pan with the carrots, onions, seasoning, herbs, and mace; pour in just sufficient water to cover it, and let it stew _very gently_ for about 5 hours.
10136-8{_}11640{_}Before taking it up, try if it is properly done by thrusting a larding-needle in it: if it penetrates easily, it is sufficiently cooked.
10136-8{_}11641{_}Strain and skim the gravy, thicken with butter and flour, give one boil, and pour it round the meat.
10136-8{_}11642{_}A few young carrots may be boiled and placed round the dish as a garnish, and, when in season, green peas should always be served with this dish.
10136-8{_}11643{_}_Time_.--5 hours.
10136-8{_}11644{_}_Average cost_, 7d.
10136-8{_}11645{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}11646{_}_Sufficient_ for 8 or 9 persons.
10136-8{_}11647{_}_Seasonable_ from March to October.
10136-8{_}11648{_}THE FATTENING OF CALVES.--The fattening of calves for the market     is an important business in Lanarkshire or Clydesdale, and     numbers of newly-dropped calves are regularly carried there from     the farmers of the adjacent districts, in order to be prepared     for the butcher.
10136-8{_}11649{_}The mode of feeding them is very simple; milk     is the chief article of their diet, and of this the calves     require a sufficient supply from first to last.
10136-8{_}11650{_}Added to this,     they must be kept in a well-aired place, neither too hot nor too     cold, and freely supplied with dry litter.
10136-8{_}11651{_}It is usual to     exclude the light,--at all events to a great degree, and to put     within their reach a lump of chalk, which they are very fond of     licking.
10136-8{_}11652{_}Thus fed, calves, at the end of 8 or 9 weeks, often     attain a very large size; viz., 18 to 20 stone, exclusive of the     offal.
10136-8{_}11653{_}Far heavier weights have occurred, and without any     deterioration in the delicacy and richness of the flesh.
10136-8{_}11654{_}This     mode of feeding upon milk alone at first appears to be very     expensive, but it is not so, when all things are taken into     consideration; for at the age of 9 or 10 weeks a calf,     originally purchased for 8 shillings, will realize nearly the     same number of pounds.
10136-8{_}11655{_}For 4, or even 6 weeks, the milk of one     cow is sufficient,--indeed half that quantity is enough for the     first fortnight; but after the 5th or 6th week it will consume     the greater portion of the milk of two moderate cows; but then     it requires neither oil-cake nor linseed, nor any other food.
10136-8{_}11656{_}Usually, however, the calves are not kept beyond the age of 6     weeks, and will then sell for 5 or 6 pounds each: the milk of     the cow is then ready for a successor.
10136-8{_}11657{_}In this manner a relay of     calves may be prepared for the markets from early spring to the     end of summer, a plan more advantageous than that of overfeeding     one to a useless degree of corpulency.
10136-8{_}11658{_}VEAL SAUSAGES.
10136-8{_}11659{_}904.
10136-8{_}11660{_}INGREDIENTS.--Equal quantities of fat bacon and lean veal; to every lb.
10136-8{_}11661{_}of meat, allow 1 teaspoonful of minced sage, salt and pepper to taste.
10136-8{_}11662{_}_Mode_.--Chop the meat and bacon finely, and to every lb.
10136-8{_}11663{_}allow the above proportion of very finely-minced sage; add a seasoning of pepper and salt, mix the whole well together, make it into flat cakes, and fry a nice brown.
10136-8{_}11664{_}_Seasonable_ from March to October.
10136-8{_}11665{_}STEWED VEAL, with Peas, young Carrots, and new Potatoes.
10136-8{_}11666{_}905.
10136-8{_}11667{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 or 4 lbs.
10136-8{_}11668{_}of the loin or neck of veal, 15 young carrots, a few green onions, 1 pint of green peas, 12 new potatoes, a bunch of savoury herbs, pepper and salt to taste, 1 tablespoonful of lemon-juice, 2 tablespoonfuls of tomato sauce, 2 tablespoonfuls of mushroom ketchup.
10136-8{_}11669{_}_Mode_.--Dredge the meat with flour, and roast or bake it for about 3/4 hour: it should acquire a nice brown colour.
10136-8{_}11670{_}Put the meat into a stewpan with the carrots, onions, potatoes, herbs, pepper, and salt; pour over it sufficient boiling water to cover it, and stew gently for 2 hours.
10136-8{_}11671{_}Take out the meat and herbs, put it in a deep dish, skim off all the fat from the gravy, and flavour it with lemon-juice, tomato sauce, and mushroom ketchup in the above proportion.
10136-8{_}11672{_}Have ready a pint of green peas boiled; put these with the meat, pour over it the gravy, and serve.
10136-8{_}11673{_}The dish may be garnished with a few forcemeat balls.
10136-8{_}11674{_}The meat, when preferred, may be cut into chops, and floured and fried instead of being roasted; and any part of veal dressed in this way will be found extremely savoury and good.
10136-8{_}11675{_}_Time_.--3 hours.
10136-8{_}11676{_}_Average cost_, 9d.
10136-8{_}11677{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}11678{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 or 7 persons.
10136-8{_}11679{_}_Seasonable_, with peas, from June to August.
10136-8{_}11680{_}BAKED SWEETBREADS (an Entree).
10136-8{_}11681{_}906.
10136-8{_}11682{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 sweetbreads, egg and bread crumbs, oiled butter, 3 slices of toast, brown gravy.
10136-8{_}11683{_}[Illustration: SWEETBREADS.]
10136-8{_}11684{_}_Mode_.--Choose large white sweetbreads; put them into warm water to draw out the blood, and to improve their colour; let them remain for rather more than 1 hour; then put them into boiling water, and allow them to simmer for about 10 minutes, which renders them firm.
10136-8{_}11685{_}Take them up, drain them, brush over with egg, sprinkle with bread crumbs; dip them in egg again, and then into more bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}11686{_}Drop on them a little oiled butter, and put the sweetbreads into a moderately-heated oven, and let them bake for nearly 3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}11687{_}Make 3 pieces of toast; place the sweetbreads on the toast, and pour round, but not over them, a good brown gravy.
10136-8{_}11688{_}_Time_.--To soak 1 hour, to be boiled 10 minutes, baked 40 minutes.
10136-8{_}11689{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}11690{_}to 5s.
10136-8{_}11691{_}_Sufficient_ for an entrée.
10136-8{_}11692{_}_Seasonable_.--In full season from May to August.
10136-8{_}11693{_}FRIED SWEETBREADS a la Maitre d'Hotel (an Entree).
10136-8{_}11694{_}907.
10136-8{_}11695{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 sweetbreads, egg and bread crumbs, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}11696{_}of butter, salt and pepper to taste, rather more than 1/2 pint of Maître d'hôtel sauce No.
10136-8{_}11697{_}466.
10136-8{_}11698{_}_Mode_.--Soak the sweetbreads in warm water for an hour; then boil them for 10 minutes; cut them in slices, egg and bread crumb them, season with pepper and salt, and put them into a frying-pan, with the above proportion of butter.
10136-8{_}11699{_}Keep turning them until done, which will be in about 10 minutes; dish them, and pour over them a Maître d'hôtel sauce, made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}11700{_}466.
10136-8{_}11701{_}The dish may be garnished with slices of cut lemon.
10136-8{_}11702{_}_Time_.--To soak 1 hour, to be broiled 10 minutes, to be fried about 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}11703{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}11704{_}to 5s., according to the season.
10136-8{_}11705{_}_Sufficient_ for an entrée.
10136-8{_}11706{_}_Seasonable_.--In full season from May to August.
10136-8{_}11707{_}_Note_.--The egg and bread crumb may be omitted, and the slices of sweetbread dredged with a little flour instead, and a good gravy may be substituted for the _maitre d'hôtel_ sauce.
10136-8{_}11708{_}This is a very simple method of dressing them.
10136-8{_}11709{_}STEWED SWEETBREADS (an Entree).
10136-8{_}11710{_}908.
10136-8{_}11711{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 sweetbreads, 1 pint of white stock No.
10136-8{_}11712{_}107, thickening of butter and flour, 6 tablespoonfuls of cream, 1 tablespoonful of lemon-juice, 1 blade of pounded mace, white pepper and salt to taste.
10136-8{_}11713{_}_Mode_.--Soak the sweetbreads in warm water for 1 hour, and boil them for 10 minutes; take them out, put them into cold water for a few minutes; lay them in a stewpan with the stock, and simmer them gently for rather more than 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}11714{_}Dish them; thicken the gravy with a little butter and flour; let it boil up, add the remaining ingredients, allow the sauce to get quite _hot_, but _not boil_, and pour it over the sweetbreads.
10136-8{_}11715{_}_Time_.--To soak 1 hour, to be boiled 10 minutes, stewed rather more than 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}11716{_}_Average cost_, from 1s.
10136-8{_}11717{_}to 5s., according to the season.
10136-8{_}11718{_}_Sufficient_ for an entrée.
10136-8{_}11719{_}_Seasonable_.--In full season from May to August.
10136-8{_}11720{_}_Note_.--A few mushrooms added to this dish, and stewed with the sweetbreads, will be found an improvement.
10136-8{_}11721{_}SEASON AND CHOICE OF VEAL.--Veal, like all other meats, has its     season of plenty.
10136-8{_}11722{_}The best veal, and the largest supply, are to     be had from March to the end of July.
10136-8{_}11723{_}It comes principally from     the western counties, and is generally of the Alderney breed.
10136-8{_}11724{_}In     purchasing veal, its whiteness and fineness of grain should be     considered, the colour being especially of the utmost     consequence.
10136-8{_}11725{_}Veal may be bought at all times of the year and of     excellent quality, but is generally very dear, except in the     months of plenty.
10136-8{_}11726{_}STEWED TENDRONS DE VEAU (an Entree).
10136-8{_}11727{_}909.
10136-8{_}11728{_}INGREDIENTS.--The gristles from 2 breasts of veal, stock No.
10136-8{_}11729{_}107, 1 faggot of savoury herbs, 2 blades of pounded mace, 4 cloves, 2 carrots, 2 onions, a strip of lemon-peel.
10136-8{_}11730{_}_Mode_.--The _tendrons_ or gristles, which are found round the front of a breast of veal, are now very frequently served as an entrée, and when well dressed, make a nice and favourite dish.
10136-8{_}11731{_}Detach the gristles from the bone, and cut them neatly out, so as not to spoil the joint for roasting or stewing.
10136-8{_}11732{_}Put them into a stewpan, with sufficient stock, No.
10136-8{_}11733{_}107, to cover them; add the herbs, mace, cloves, carrots, onions, and lemon, and simmer these for nearly, or quite, 4 hours.
10136-8{_}11734{_}They should be stewed until a fork will enter the meat easily.
10136-8{_}11735{_}Take them up, drain them, strain the gravy, boil it down to a glaze, with which glaze the meat.
10136-8{_}11736{_}Dish the _tendrons_ in a circle, with croûtons fried of a nice colour placed between each; and put mushroom sauce, or a purée of green peas or tomatoes, in the middle.
10136-8{_}11737{_}_Time_.--4 hours.
10136-8{_}11738{_}_Sufficient_ for one entrée.
10136-8{_}11739{_}_Seasonable_.--With peas, from June to August.
10136-8{_}11740{_}COW-POX, OR VARIOLA.--It is to Dr. Jenner, of Berkeley,     Gloucestershire, who died in 1823, that we owe the practice of     vaccination, as a preservative from the attack of that     destructive scourge of the human race, the small-pox.
10136-8{_}11741{_}The     experiments of this philosophic man were begun in 1797, and     published the next year.
10136-8{_}11742{_}He had observed that cows were subject     to a certain infectious eruption of the teats, and that those     persons who became affected by it, while milking the cattle,     escaped the small-pox raging around them.
10136-8{_}11743{_}This fact, known to     farmers from time immemorial, led him to a course of     experiments, the result of which all are acquainted with.
10136-8{_}11744{_}TENDRONS DE VEAU (an Entree).
10136-8{_}11745{_}910.
10136-8{_}11746{_}INGREDIENTS.--The gristles from 2 breasts of veal, stock No.
10136-8{_}11747{_}107, 1 faggot of savoury herbs, 1 blade of pounded mace, 4 cloves, 2 carrots, 2 onions, a strip of lemon-peel, egg and bread crumbs, 2 tablespoonfuls of chopped mushrooms, salt and pepper to taste, 2 tablespoonfuls of sherry, the yolk of 1 egg, 3 tablespoonfuls of cream.
10136-8{_}11748{_}_Mode_.--After removing the gristles from a breast of veal, stew them for 4 hours, as in the preceding recipe, with stock, herbs, mace, cloves, carrots, onions, and lemon-peel.
10136-8{_}11749{_}When perfectly tender, lift them out and remove any bones or hard parts remaining.
10136-8{_}11750{_}Put them between two dishes, with a weight on the top, and when cold, cut them into slices.
10136-8{_}11751{_}Brush these over with egg, sprinkle with bread crumbs, and fry a pale brown.
10136-8{_}11752{_}Take 1/2 pint of the gravy they were boiled in, add 2 tablespoonfuls of chopped mushrooms, a seasoning of salt and pepper, the sherry, and the yolk of an egg beaten with 3 tablespoonfuls of cream.
10136-8{_}11753{_}Stir the sauce over the fire until it thickens; when it is on the _point of boiling_, dish the tendrons in a circle, and pour the sauce in the middle.
10136-8{_}11754{_}Tendrons are dressed in a variety of ways,--with sauce à l'Espagnole, vegetables of all kinds: when they are served with a purée, they should always be glazed.
10136-8{_}11755{_}_Time_.--4-1/2 hours.
10136-8{_}11756{_}_Average cost_.--Usually bought with breast of veal.
10136-8{_}11757{_}_Sufficient_ for an entrée.
10136-8{_}11758{_}_Seasonable_ from March to October.
10136-8{_}11759{_}TETE DE VEAU EN TORTUE (an Entree).
10136-8{_}11760{_}911.
10136-8{_}11761{_}INGREDIENTS.--Half a calf's head, or the remains of a cold boiled one; rather more than 1 pint of good white stock, No.
10136-8{_}11762{_}107, 1 glass of sherry or Madeira, cayenne and salt to taste, about 12 mushroom-buttons (when obtainable), 6 hard-boiled eggs, 4 gherkins, 8 quenelles or forcemeat balls, No.
10136-8{_}11763{_}422 or 423, 12 crayfish, 12 croûtons.
10136-8{_}11764{_}_Mode_.--Half a calf's head is sufficient to make a good entrée, and if there are any remains of a cold one left from the preceding day, it will answer very well for this dish.
10136-8{_}11765{_}After boiling the head until tender, remove the bones, and cut the meat into neat pieces; put the stock into a stewpan, add the wine, and a seasoning of salt and cayenne; fry the mushrooms in butter for 2 or 3 minutes, and add these to the gravy.
10136-8{_}11766{_}Boil this quickly until somewhat reduced; then put in the yolks of the hard-boiled eggs _whole_, the whites cut in small pieces, and the gherkins chopped.
10136-8{_}11767{_}Have ready a few veal quenelles, made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}11768{_}422 or 423; add these, with the slices of head, to the other ingredients, and let the whole get thoroughly hot, _without boiling_.
10136-8{_}11769{_}Arrange the pieces of head as high in the centre of the dish as possible; pour over them the ragout, and garnish with the crayfish and croûtons placed alternately.
10136-8{_}11770{_}A little of the gravy should also be served in a tureen.
10136-8{_}11771{_}_Time_.--About 1/2 hour to reduce the stock.
10136-8{_}11772{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 or 7 persons.
10136-8{_}11773{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the calf's head, 2s.
10136-8{_}11774{_}9d.
10136-8{_}11775{_}_Seasonable_ from March to October.
10136-8{_}11776{_}A FRENCHMAN'S OPINION OF VEAL.--A great authority in his native     Paris tells us, that veal, as a meat, is but little nourishing,     is relaxing, and sufficiently difficult of digestion.
10136-8{_}11777{_}Lending     itself, as it does, he says, in all the flowery imagery of the     French tongue and manner, "to so many metamorphoses, it may be     called, without exaggeration, the chameleon of the kitchen.
10136-8{_}11778{_}Who     has not eaten calf's head _au naturel_, simply boiled with the     skin on, its flavour heightened by sauce just a little sharp?
10136-8{_}11779{_}It     is a dish as wholesome as it is agreeable, and one that the most     inexperienced cook may serve with success.
10136-8{_}11780{_}Calf's feet _à la     poulette_, _au gratin_, fried, &c.; _les cervelles_, served in     the same manner, and under the same names; sweetbreads _en     fricandeau_, _piqués en fin_,--all these offer most satisfactory     entrées, which the art of the cook, more or less, varies for the     gratification of his glory and the well-being of our appetites.
10136-8{_}11781{_}We have not spoken, in the above catalogue, either of the liver,     or of the _fraise_, or of the ears, which also share the honour     of appearing at our tables.
10136-8{_}11782{_}Where is the man not acquainted with     calf's liver _à la bourgeoise_, the most frequent and convenient     dish at unpretentious tables?
10136-8{_}11783{_}The _fraise_, cooked in water, and     eaten with vinegar, is a wholesome and agreeable dish, and     contains a mucilage well adapted for delicate persons.
10136-8{_}11784{_}Calf's     ears have, in common with the feet and _cervelles_, the     advantage of being able to be eaten either fried or _à la     poulette_; and besides, can be made into a _farce_, with the     addition of peas, onions, cheese, &c. Neither is it confined to     the calf's tongue, or even the eyes, that these shall dispute     alone the glory of awakening the taste of man; thus, the     _fressure_ (which, as is known, comprises the heart, the _mou_,     and the _rate_), although not a very recherché dish, lends     itself to all the caprices of an expert artist, and may, under     various marvellous disguises, deceive, and please, and even     awaken our appetite."
10136-8{_}11785{_}--Verily, we might say, after this rhapsody     of our neighbour, that his country's weal will not suffer in him     as an able and eloquent exponent and admirer.
10136-8{_}11786{_}VEAL CARVING.
10136-8{_}11787{_}BREAST OF VEAL.
10136-8{_}11788{_}[Illustration: BREAST OF VEAL.]
10136-8{_}11789{_}912.
10136-8{_}11790{_}The carving of a breast of veal is not dissimilar to that of a fore-quarter of lamb, when the shoulder has been taken off.
10136-8{_}11791{_}The breast of veal consists of two parts,--the rib-bones and the gristly brisket.
10136-8{_}11792{_}These two parts should first be separated by sharply passing the knife in the direction of the lines 1, 2; when they are entirely divided, the rib-bones should be carved in the direction of the lines 5 to 6; and the brisket can be helped by cutting pieces in the direction 3 to 4.
10136-8{_}11793{_}The carver should ask the guests whether they have a preference for the brisket or ribs; and if there be a sweetbread served with the dish, as it often is with roast breast of veal, each person should receive a piece.
10136-8{_}11794{_}CALF'S HEAD.
10136-8{_}11795{_}[Illustration: CALF'S HEAD.]
10136-8{_}11796{_}913.
10136-8{_}11797{_}This is not altogether the most easy-looking dish to cut when it is put before a carver for the first time; there is not much real difficulty in the operation, however, when the head has been attentively examined, and, after the manner of a phrenologist, you get to know its bumps, good and bad.
10136-8{_}11798{_}In the first place, inserting the knife quite down to the bone, cut slices in the direction of the line 1 to 2; with each of these should be helped a piece of what is called the throat sweetbread, cut in the direction of from 3 to 4.
10136-8{_}11799{_}The eye, and the flesh round, are favourite morsels with many, and should be given to those at the table who are known to be the greatest connoisseurs.
10136-8{_}11800{_}The jawbone being removed, there will then be found some nice lean; and the palate, which is reckoned by some a tit-bit, lies under the head.
10136-8{_}11801{_}On a separate dish there is always served the tongue and brains, and each guest should be asked to take some of these.
10136-8{_}11802{_}FILLET OF VEAL.
10136-8{_}11803{_}[Illustration: FILLET OF VEAL.]
10136-8{_}11804{_}914.
10136-8{_}11805{_}The carving of this joint is similar to that of a round of beef.
10136-8{_}11806{_}Slices, not too thick, in the direction of the line 1 to 2 are cut; and the only point to be careful about is, that the veal be _evenly_ carved.
10136-8{_}11807{_}Between the flap and the meat the stuffing is inserted, and a small portion of this should be served to every guest.
10136-8{_}11808{_}The persons whom the host wishes most to honour should be asked if they like the delicious brown outside slice, as this, by many, is exceedingly relished.
10136-8{_}11809{_}KNUCKLE OF VEAL.
10136-8{_}11810{_}[Illustration: KNUCKLE OF VEAL.]
10136-8{_}11811{_}915.
10136-8{_}11812{_}The engraving, showing the dotted line from 1 to 2, sufficiently indicates the direction which should be given to the knife in carving this dish.
10136-8{_}11813{_}The best slices are those from the thickest part of the knuckle, that is, outside the line 1 to 2.
10136-8{_}11814{_}LOIN OF VEAL.
10136-8{_}11815{_}[Illustration: LOIN OF VEAL.]
10136-8{_}11816{_}916.
10136-8{_}11817{_}As is the case with a loin of mutton, the careful jointing of a loin of veal is more than half the battle in carving it.
10136-8{_}11818{_}If the butcher be negligent in this matter, he should be admonished; for there is nothing more annoying or irritating to an inexperienced carver than to be obliged to turn his knife in all directions to find the exact place where it should be inserted in order to divide the bones.
10136-8{_}11819{_}When the jointing is properly performed, there is little difficulty in carrying the knife down in the direction of the line 1 to 2.
10136-8{_}11820{_}To each guest should be given a piece of the kidney and kidney fat, which lie underneath, and are considered great delicacies.
10136-8{_}11821{_}[Illustration]     [Illustration]  CHAPTER XX.
10136-8{_}11822{_}GENERAL OBSERVATIONS ON BIRDS.
10136-8{_}11823{_}"Birds, the free tenants of land, air, and ocean,   Their forms all symmetry, their motions grace;   In plumage delicate and beautiful;   Thick without burthen, close as fishes' scales,   Or loose as full-blown poppies to the breeze."
10136-8{_}11824{_}_The Pelican Island_.
10136-8{_}11825{_}917.
10136-8{_}11826{_}THE DIVISIONS OF BIRDS are founded principally on their habits of life, and the natural resemblance which their external parts, especially their bills, bear to each other.
10136-8{_}11827{_}According to Mr. Vigors, there are five orders, each of which occupies its peculiar place on the surface of the globe; so that the air, the forest, the land, the marsh, and the water, has each its appropriate kind of inhabitants.
10136-8{_}11828{_}These are respectively designated as BIRDS OF PREY, PERCHERS, WALKERS, WADERS, and SWIMMERS; and, in contemplating their variety, lightness, beauty, and wonderful adaptation to the regions they severally inhabit, and the functions they are destined to perform in the grand scheme of creation, our hearts are lifted with admiration at the exhaustless ingenuity, power, and wisdom of HIM who has, in producing them, so strikingly "manifested His handiwork."
10136-8{_}11829{_}Not only these, however, but all classes of animals, have their peculiar ends to fulfil; and, in order that this may be effectually performed, they are constructed in such a manner as will enable them to carry out their conditions.
10136-8{_}11830{_}Thus the quadrupeds, that are formed to tread the earth in common with man, are muscular and vigorous; and, whether they have passed into the servitude of man, or are permitted to range the forest or the field, they still retain, in a high degree, the energies with which they were originally endowed.
10136-8{_}11831{_}Birds, on the contrary, are generally feeble, and, therefore, timid.
10136-8{_}11832{_}Accordingly, wings have been given them to enable them to fly through the air, and thus elude the force which, by nature, they are unable to resist.
10136-8{_}11833{_}Notwithstanding the natural tendency of all bodies towards the centre of the earth, birds, when raised in the atmosphere, glide through it with the greatest ease, rapidity, and vigour.
10136-8{_}11834{_}There, they are in their natural element, and can vary their course with the greatest promptitude--can mount or descend with the utmost facility, and can light on any spot with the most perfect exactness, and without the slightest injury to themselves.
10136-8{_}11835{_}918.
10136-8{_}11836{_}THE MECHANISM WHICH ENABLES BIRDS to wing their course through the air, is both singular and instructive.
10136-8{_}11837{_}Their bodies are covered with feathers, which are much lighter than coverings of hair, with which quadrupeds are usually clothed.
10136-8{_}11838{_}The feathers are so placed as to overlap each other, like the slates or the tiles on the roof of a house.
10136-8{_}11839{_}They are also arranged from the fore-part backwards; by which the animals are enabled the more conveniently to cut their way through the air.
10136-8{_}11840{_}Their bones are tubular or hollow, and extremely light compared with those of terrestrial animals.
10136-8{_}11841{_}This greatly facilitates their rising from the earth, whilst their heads, being comparatively small, their bills shaped like a wedge, their bodies slender, sharp below, and round above,--all these present a union of conditions, favourable, in the last degree, to cutting their way through the aërial element to which they are considered as more peculiarly to belong.
10136-8{_}11842{_}With all these conditions, however, birds could not fly without wings.
10136-8{_}11843{_}These, therefore, are the instruments by which they have the power of rapid locomotion, and are constructed in such a manner as to be capable of great expansion when struck in a downward direction.
10136-8{_}11844{_}If we except, in this action, the slight hollow which takes place on the under-side, they become almost two planes.
10136-8{_}11845{_}In order that the downward action may be accomplished to the necessary extent, the muscles which move the wings have been made exceedingly large; so large, indeed, that, in some instances, they have been estimated at not less than a sixth of the weight of the whole body.
10136-8{_}11846{_}Therefore, when a bird is on the ground and intends to fly, it takes a leap, and immediately stretching its wings, strikes them out with great force.
10136-8{_}11847{_}By this act these are brought into an oblique direction, being turned partly upwards and partly horizontally forwards.
10136-8{_}11848{_}That part of the force which has the upward tendency is neutralized by the weight of the bird, whilst the horizontal force serves to carry it forward.
10136-8{_}11849{_}The stroke being completed, it moves upon its wings, which, being contracted and having their edges turned upwards, obviate, in a great measure, the resistance of the air.
10136-8{_}11850{_}When it is sufficiently elevated, it makes a second stroke downwards, and the impulse of the air again moves it forward.
10136-8{_}11851{_}These successive strokes may be regarded as so many leaps taken in the air.
10136-8{_}11852{_}When the bird desires to direct its course to the right or the left, it strikes strongly with the opposite wing, which impels it to the proper side.
10136-8{_}11853{_}In the motions of the animal, too, the tail takes a prominent part, and acts like the rudder of a ship, except that, instead of sideways, it moves upwards and downwards.
10136-8{_}11854{_}If the bird wishes to rise, it raises its tail; and if to fall, it depresses it; and, whilst in a horizontal position, it keeps it steady.
10136-8{_}11855{_}There are few who have not observed a pigeon or a crow preserve, for some time, a horizontal flight without any apparent motion of the wings.
10136-8{_}11856{_}This is accomplished by the bird having already acquired sufficient velocity, and its wings being parallel to the horizon, meeting with but small resistance from the atmosphere.
10136-8{_}11857{_}If it begins to fall, it can easily steer itself upward by means of its tail, till the motion it had acquired is nearly spent, when it must be renewed by a few more strokes of the wings.
10136-8{_}11858{_}On alighting, a bird expands its wings and tail fully against the air, as a ship, in tacking round, backs her sails, in order that they may meet with all the resistance possible.
10136-8{_}11859{_}919.
10136-8{_}11860{_}IN THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE EYES of birds, there is a peculiarity necessary to their condition.
10136-8{_}11861{_}As they pass a great portion of their lives among thickets and hedges, they are provided for the defence of their eyes from external injuries, as well as from the effects of the light, when flying in opposition to the rays of the sun, with a nictating or winking membrane, which can, at pleasure, be drawn over the whole eye like a curtain.
10136-8{_}11862{_}This covering is neither opaque nor wholly pellucid, but is somewhat transparent; and it is by its means that the eagle is said to be able to gaze at the sun.
10136-8{_}11863{_}"In birds," says a writer on this subject, "we find that the sight is much more piercing, extensive, and exact, than in the other orders of animals.
10136-8{_}11864{_}The eye is much larger in proportion to the bulk of the head, than in any of these.
10136-8{_}11865{_}This is a superiority conferred upon them not without a corresponding utility: it seems even indispensable to their safety and subsistence.
10136-8{_}11866{_}Were this organ in birds dull, or in the least degree opaque, they would be in danger, from the rapidity of their motion, of striking against various objects in their flight.
10136-8{_}11867{_}In this case their celerity, instead of being an advantage, would become an evil, and their flight be restrained by the danger resulting from it.
10136-8{_}11868{_}Indeed we may consider the velocity with which an animal moves, as a sure indication of the perfection of its vision.
10136-8{_}11869{_}Among the quadrupeds, the sloth has its sight greatly limited; whilst the hawk, as it hovers in the air, can espy a lark sitting on a clod, perhaps at twenty times the distance at which a man or a dog could perceive it."
10136-8{_}11870{_}920.
10136-8{_}11871{_}AMONGST THE MANY PECULIARITIES IN THE CONSTRUCTION OF BIRDS, not the least is the mode by which their respiration is accomplished.
10136-8{_}11872{_}This is effected by means of air-vessels, which extend throughout the body, and adhere to the under-surface of the bones.
10136-8{_}11873{_}These, by their motion, force the air through the true lungs, which are very small, and placed in the uppermost part of the chest, and closely braced down to the back and ribs.
10136-8{_}11874{_}The lungs, which are never expanded by air, are destined to the sole purpose of oxidizing the blood.
10136-8{_}11875{_}In the experiments made by Mr. John Hunter, to discover the use of this general diffusion of air through the bodies of birds, he found that it prevents their respiration from being stopped or interrupted by the rapidity of their motion through a resisting medium.
10136-8{_}11876{_}It is well known that, in proportion to celerity of motion, the air becomes resistive; and were it possible for a man to move with the swiftness of a swallow, as he is not provided with an internal construction similar to that of birds, the resistance of the air would soon suffocate him.
10136-8{_}11877{_}921.
10136-8{_}11878{_}BIRDS ARE DISTRIBUTED OVER EVERY PART OF THE GLOBE, being found in the coldest as well as the hottest regions, although some species are restricted to particular countries, whilst others are widely dispersed.
10136-8{_}11879{_}At certain seasons of the year, many of them change their abodes, and migrate to climates better adapted to their temperaments or modes of life, for a time, than those which they leave.
10136-8{_}11880{_}Many of the birds of Britain, directed by an unerring instinct, take their departure from the island before the commencement of winter, and proceed to the more congenial warmth of Africa, to return with the next spring.
10136-8{_}11881{_}The causes assigned by naturalists for this peculiarity are, either a deficiency of food, or the want of a secure asylum for the incubation and nourishment of their young.
10136-8{_}11882{_}Their migrations are generally performed in large companies, and, in the day, they follow a leader, which is occasionally changed.
10136-8{_}11883{_}During the night, many of the tribes send forth a continual cry, to keep themselves together; although one would think that the noise which must accompany their flight would be sufficient for that purpose.
10136-8{_}11884{_}The flight of birds across the Mediterranean was noticed three thousand years ago, as we find it said in the book of Numbers, in the Scriptures, that "There went forth a wind from the Lord, and brought quails from the sea, and let them fall upon the camp, and a day's journey round about it, to the height of two cubits above the earth."
10136-8{_}11885{_}922.
10136-8{_}11886{_}IF THE BEAUTY OF BIRDS were not a recommendation to their being universally admired, their general liveliness, gaiety, and song would endear them to mankind.
10136-8{_}11887{_}It appears, however, from accurate observations founded upon experiment, that the notes peculiar to different kinds of birds are altogether acquired, and that they are not innate, any more than language is to man.
10136-8{_}11888{_}The attempt of a nestling bird to sing has been compared to the endeavour of a child to talk.
10136-8{_}11889{_}The first attempts do not seem to possess the slightest rudiments of the future song; but, as the bird grows older and becomes stronger, it is easily perceived to be aiming at acquiring the art of giving utterance to song.
10136-8{_}11890{_}Whilst the scholar is thus endeavouring to form his notes, when he is once sure of a passage, he usually raises his tone, but drops it again when he finds himself unequal to the voluntary task he has undertaken.
10136-8{_}11891{_}"Many well-authenticated facts," says an ingenious writer, "seem decisively to prove that birds have no innate notes, but that, like mankind, the language of those to whose care they have been committed at their birth, will be their language in after-life."
10136-8{_}11892{_}It would appear, however, somewhat unaccountable why, in a wild state, they adhere so steadily to the song of their own species only, when the notes of so many others are to be heard around them.
10136-8{_}11893{_}This is said to arise from the attention paid by the nestling bird to the instructions of its own parent only, generally disregarding the notes of all the rest.
10136-8{_}11894{_}Persons; however, who have an accurate ear, and who have given their attention to the songs of birds, can frequently distinguish some which have their notes mixed with those of another species; but this is in general so trifling, that it can hardly be considered as more than the mere varieties of provincial dialects.
10136-8{_}11895{_}923.
10136-8{_}11896{_}IN REFERENCE TO THE FOOD OF BIRDS, we find that it varies, as it does in quadrupeds, according to the species.
10136-8{_}11897{_}Some are altogether carnivorous; others, as so many of the web-footed tribes, subsist on fish; others, again, on insects and worms; and others on grain and fruit.
10136-8{_}11898{_}The extraordinary powers of the gizzard of the granivorous tribes, in comminuting their food so as to prepare it for digestion, would, were they not supported by incontrovertible facts founded on experiment, appear to exceed all credibility.
10136-8{_}11899{_}Tin tubes, full of grain, have been forced into the stomachs of turkeys, and in twenty-four hours have been found broken, compressed, and distorted into every shape.
10136-8{_}11900{_}Twelve small lancets, very sharp both at the point and edges, have been fixed in a ball of lead, covered with a case of paper, and given to a turkey-cock, and left in its stomach for eight hours.
10136-8{_}11901{_}After that time the stomach was opened, when nothing appeared except the naked ball.
10136-8{_}11902{_}The twelve lancets were broken to pieces, whilst the stomach remained perfectly sound and entire.
10136-8{_}11903{_}From these facts, it is concluded that the stones, so frequently found in the stomachs of the feathered tribes, are highly useful in assisting the gastric juices to grind down the grain and other hard substances which constitute their food.
10136-8{_}11904{_}The stones, themselves, being also ground down and separated by the powerful action of the gizzard, are mixed with the food, and, no doubt, contribute very greatly to the health, as well as to the nourishment of the animals.
10136-8{_}11905{_}924.
10136-8{_}11906{_}ALL BIRDS BEING OVIPAROUS, the eggs which they produce after the process of incubation, or sitting for a certain length of time, are, in the various species, different both in figure and colour, as well as in point of number.
10136-8{_}11907{_}They contain the elements of the future young, for the perfecting of which in the incubation a bubble of air is always placed at the large end, between the shell and the inside skin.
10136-8{_}11908{_}It is supposed that from the heat communicated by the sitting bird to this confined air, its spring is increased beyond its natural tenor, and, at the same time, its parts are put into motion by the gentle rarefaction.
10136-8{_}11909{_}By this means, pressure and motion are communicated to the parts of the egg, which, in some inscrutable way, gradually promote the formation and growth of the young, till the time comes for its escaping from the shell.
10136-8{_}11910{_}To preserve an egg perfectly fresh, and even fit for incubation, for 5 or 6 months after it has been laid, Réaumur, the French naturalist, has shown that it is only necessary to stop up its pores with a slight coating of varnish or mutton-suet.
10136-8{_}11911{_}925.
10136-8{_}11912{_}BIRDS HOWEVER, DO NOT LAY EGGS before they have some place to put them; accordingly, they construct nests for themselves with astonishing art.
10136-8{_}11913{_}As builders, they exhibit a degree of architectural skill, niceness, and propriety, that would seem even to mock the imitative talents of man, however greatly these are marked by his own high intelligence and ingenuity.
10136-8{_}11914{_}"Each circumstance   Most artfully contrived to favour warmth.
10136-8{_}11915{_}Here read the reason of the vaulted roof;   How Providence compensates, ever kind,   The enormous disproportion that subsists   Between the mother and the numerous brood   Which her small bulk must quicken into life."
10136-8{_}11916{_}In building their nests, the male and female generally assist each other, and they contrive to make the outside of their tenement bear as great a resemblance as possible to the surrounding foliage or branches; so that it cannot very easily be discovered even by those who are in search of it.
10136-8{_}11917{_}This art of nidification is one of the most wonderful contrivances which the wide field of Nature can show, and which, of itself, ought to be sufficient to compel mankind to the belief, that they and every other part of the creation, are constantly under the protecting power of a superintending Being, whose benign dispensations seem as exhaustless as they are unlimited.
10136-8{_}11918{_}[Illustration]     RECIPES.
10136-8{_}11919{_}CHAPTER XXI.
10136-8{_}11920{_}CHICKEN CUTLETS (an Entree).
10136-8{_}11921{_}926.
10136-8{_}11922{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 chickens; seasoning to taste of salt, white pepper, and cayenne; 2 blades of pounded mace, egg and bread crumbs, clarified butter, 1 strip of lemon-rind, 2 carrots, 1 onion, 2 tablespoonfuls of mushroom ketchup, thickening of butter and flour, 1 egg.
10136-8{_}11923{_}_Mode_.--Remove the breast and leg bones of the chickens; cut the meat into neat pieces after having skinned it, and season the cutlets with pepper, salt, pounded mace, and cayenne.
10136-8{_}11924{_}Put the bones, trimmings, &c., into a stewpan with 1 pint of water, adding carrots, onions, and lemon-peel in the above proportion; stew gently for 1-1/2 hour, and strain the gravy.
10136-8{_}11925{_}Thicken it with butter and flour, add the ketchup and 1 egg well beaten; stir it over the fire, and bring it to the simmering-point, but do not allow it to boil.
10136-8{_}11926{_}In the mean time, egg and bread-crumb the cutlets, and give them a few drops of clarified butter; fry them a delicate brown, occasionally turning them; arrange them pyramidically on the dish, and pour over them the sauce.
10136-8{_}11927{_}_Time_.--10 minutes to fry the cutlets.
10136-8{_}11928{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}11929{_}each.
10136-8{_}11930{_}_Sufficient_ for an entrée.
10136-8{_}11931{_}_Seasonable_ from April to July.
10136-8{_}11932{_}FOWLS AS FOOD.--Brillat Savarin, pre-eminent in gastronomic     taste, says that he believes the whole gallinaceous family was     made to enrich our larders and furnish our tables; for, from the     quail to the turkey, he avers their flesh is a light aliment,     full of flavour, and fitted equally well for the invalid as for     the man of robust health.
10136-8{_}11933{_}The fine flavour, however, which     Nature has given to all birds coming under the definition of     poultry, man has not been satisfied with, and has used many     means--such as keeping them in solitude and darkness, and     forcing them to eat--to give them an unnatural state of fatness     or fat.
10136-8{_}11934{_}This fat, thus artificially produced, is doubtless     delicious, and the taste and succulence of the boiled and     roasted bird draw forth the praise of the guests around the     table.
10136-8{_}11935{_}Well-fattened and tender, a fowl is to the cook what the     canvas is to the painter; for do we not see it served boiled,     roasted, fried, fricasseed, hashed, hot, cold, whole,     dismembered, boned, broiled, stuffed, on dishes, and in     pies,--always handy and ever acceptable?
10136-8{_}11936{_}THE COMMON OR DOMESTIC FOWL.--From time immemorial, the common     or domestic fowl has been domesticated in England, and is     supposed to be originally the offspring of some wild species     which abound in the forests of India.
10136-8{_}11937{_}It is divided into a     variety of breeds, but the most esteemed are, the Poland or     Black, the Dorking, the Bantam, the Game Fowl, and the Malay or     Chittagong.
10136-8{_}11938{_}The common, or barn-door fowl, is one of the most     delicate of the varieties; and at Dorking, in Surrey, the breed     is brought to great perfection.
10136-8{_}11939{_}Till they are four months old,     the term chicken is applied to the young female; after that age     they are called pullets, till they begin to lay, when they are     called hens.
10136-8{_}11940{_}The English counties most productive in poultry are     Surrey, Sussex, Norfolk, Herts, Devon, and Somerset.
10136-8{_}11941{_}FRENCH CHICKEN CUTLETS (Cold Meat Cookery).
10136-8{_}11942{_}927.
10136-8{_}11943{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast or boiled fowl, fried bread, clarified butter, the yolk of 1 egg, bread crumbs, 1/2 teaspoonful of finely-minced lemon-peel; salt, cayenne, and mace to taste.
10136-8{_}11944{_}For sauce,--1 oz.
10136-8{_}11945{_}of butter, 2 minced shalots, a few slices of carrot, a small bunch of savoury herbs, including parsley, 1 blade of pounded mace, 6 peppercorns, 1/4 pint of gravy.
10136-8{_}11946{_}_Mode_.--Cut the fowls into as many nice cutlets as possible; take a corresponding number of sippets about the same size, all cut one shape; fry them a pale brown, put them before the fire, then dip the cutlets into clarified butter mixed with the yolk of an egg, cover with bread crumbs seasoned in the above proportion, with lemon-peel, mace, salt, and cayenne; fry them for about 5 minutes, put each piece on one of the sippets, pile them high in the dish, and serve with the following sauce, which should be made ready for the cutlets.
10136-8{_}11947{_}Put the butter into a stewpan, add the shalots, carrot, herbs, mace, and peppercorns; fry for 10 minutes or rather longer; pour in 1/2 pint of good gravy, made of the chicken bones, stew gently for 20 minutes, strain it, and serve.
10136-8{_}11948{_}_Time_.--5 minutes to fry the cutlets; 35 minutes to make the gravy.
10136-8{_}11949{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the chicken, 9d.
10136-8{_}11950{_}_Seasonable_ from April to July.
10136-8{_}11951{_}EGGS FOR HATCHING.--Eggs intended for hatching should be removed     as soon as laid, and placed in bran in a dry, cool place.
10136-8{_}11952{_}Choose     those that are near of a size; and, as a rule, avoid those that     are equally thick at both ends,--such, probably, contain a     double yolk, and will come to no good.
10136-8{_}11953{_}Eggs intended for     hatching should never be stored longer than a month, as much     less the better.
10136-8{_}11954{_}Nine eggs may be placed under a Bantam hen, and     as many as fifteen under a Dorking.
10136-8{_}11955{_}The odd number is considered     preferable, as more easily packed.
10136-8{_}11956{_}It will be as well to mark     the eggs you give the hen to sit on, so that you may know if she     lays any more: if she does, you must remove them; for, if     hatched at all, they would be too late for the brood.
10136-8{_}11957{_}If during     incubation an egg should be broken, remove it, and take out the     remainder, and cleanse them in luke-warm water, or it is     probable the sticky nature of the contents of the broken egg     will make the others cling to the hen's feathers; and they, too,     may be fractured.
10136-8{_}11958{_}HENS SITTING.--Some hens are very capricious as regards sitting;     they will make a great fuss, and keep pining for the nest, and,     when they are permitted to take to it, they will sit just long     enough to addle the eggs, and then they're off again.
10136-8{_}11959{_}The safest     way to guard against such annoyance, is to supply the hen with     some hard-boiled eggs; if she sits on them a reasonable time,     and seems steadily inclined, like a good matron, you may then     give her proper eggs, and let her set about the business in     earnest.
10136-8{_}11960{_}CHICKEN OR FOWL PATTIES.
10136-8{_}11961{_}928.
10136-8{_}11962{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast chicken or fowl; to every 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}11963{_}of meat allow 2 oz.
10136-8{_}11964{_}of ham, 3 tablespoonfuls of cream, 2 tablespoonfuls of veal gravy, 1/2 teaspoonful of minced lemon-peel; cayenne, salt, and pepper to taste; 1 tablespoonful of lemon-juice, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}11965{_}of butter rolled in flour; puff paste.
10136-8{_}11966{_}_Mode_.--Mince very small the white meat from a cold roast fowl, after removing all the skin; weigh it, and to every 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}11967{_}of meat allow the above proportion of minced ham.
10136-8{_}11968{_}Put these into a stewpan with the remaining ingredients, stir over the fire for 10 minutes or 1/4 hour, taking care that the mixture does not burn.
10136-8{_}11969{_}Roll out some puff paste about 1/4 inch in thickness; line the patty-pans with this, put upon each a small piece of bread, and cover with another layer of paste; brush over with the yolk of an egg, and bake in a brisk oven for about 1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}11970{_}When done, cut a round piece out of the top, and, with a small spoon, take out the bread (be particular in not breaking the outside border of the crust), and fill the patties with the mixture.
10136-8{_}11971{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour to prepare the meat; not quite 1/4 hour to bake the crust.
10136-8{_}11972{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}11973{_}HATCHING.--Sometimes the chick within the shell is unable to     break away from its prison; for the white of the egg will     occasionally harden in the air to the consistence of joiners'     clue, when the poor chick is in a terrible fix.
10136-8{_}11974{_}An able writer     says, "Assistance in hatching must not be rendered prematurely,     and thence unnecessarily, but only in the case of the chick     being plainly unable to release itself; then, indeed, an     addition may probably be made to the brood, as great numbers are     always lost in this way.
10136-8{_}11975{_}The chick makes a circular fracture at     the big end of the egg, and a section of about one-third of the     length of the shell being separated, delivers the prisoner,     provided there is no obstruction from adhesion of the body to     the membrane which lines the shell.
10136-8{_}11976{_}Between the body of the     chick and the membrane of the shell there exists a viscous     fluid, the white of the egg thickened with the intense heat of     incubation, until it becomes a positive glue.
10136-8{_}11977{_}When this happens,     the feathers stick fast to the shell, and the chicks remain     confined, and must perish, if not released."
10136-8{_}11978{_}The method of assistance to be rendered to chicks which have a     difficulty in releasing themselves from the shell, is to take     the egg in the hand, and dipping the finger or a piece of linen     rag in warm water, to apply it to the fastened parts until they     are loosened by the gluey substance becoming dissolved and     separated from the feathers.
10136-8{_}11979{_}The chick, then, being returned to     the nest, will extricate itself,--a mode generally to be     observed, since, if violence were used, it would prove fatal.
10136-8{_}11980{_}Nevertheless, breaking the shell may sometimes be necessary; and     separating with the fingers, as gently as may be, the membrane     from the feathers, which are still to be moistened as mentioned     above, to facilitate the operation.
10136-8{_}11981{_}The points of small scissors     may be useful, and when there is much resistance, as also     apparent pain to the bird, the process must be conducted in the     gentlest manner, and the shell separated into a number of small     pieces.
10136-8{_}11982{_}The signs of a need of assistance are the egg being     partly pecked and chipped, and the cluck discontinuing its     efforts for five of six hours.
10136-8{_}11983{_}Weakness from cold may disable     the chicken from commencing the operation of pecking the shell,     which must then be artificially performed with a circular     fracture, such as is made by the bird itself.
10136-8{_}11984{_}CHICKEN OR FOWL PIE.
10136-8{_}11985{_}929.
10136-8{_}11986{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 small fowls or 1 large one, white pepper and salt to taste, 1/2 teaspoonful of grated nutmeg, 1/2 teaspoonful of pounded mace, forcemeat No.
10136-8{_}11987{_}417, a few slices of ham, 3 hard-boiled eggs, 1/2 pint of water, puff crust.
10136-8{_}11988{_}_Mode_.--Skin and cut up the fowls into joints, and put the neck, leg, and backbones in a stewpan, with a little water, an onion, a bunch of savoury herbs, and a blade of mace; let these stew for about an hour, and, when done, strain off the liquor: this is for gravy.
10136-8{_}11989{_}Put a layer of fowl at the bottom of a pie-dish, then a layer of ham, then one of forcemeat and hard-boiled eggs cut in rings; between the layers put a seasoning of pounded mace, nutmeg, pepper, and salt.
10136-8{_}11990{_}Proceed in this manner until the dish is full, and pour in about 1/2 pint of water; border the edge of the dish with puff crust, put on the cover, ornament the top, and glaze it by brushing over it the yolk of an egg.
10136-8{_}11991{_}Bake from 1-1/4 to 1-1/2 hour, should the pie be very large, and, when done, pour in, at the top, the gravy made from the bones.
10136-8{_}11992{_}If to be eaten cold, and wished particularly nice, the joints of the fowls should be boned, and placed in the dish with alternate layers of forcemeat; sausage-meat may also be substituted for the forcemeat, and is now very much used.
10136-8{_}11993{_}When the chickens are boned, and mixed with sausage-meat, the pie will take about 2 hours to bake.
10136-8{_}11994{_}It should be covered with a piece of paper when about half-done, to prevent the paste from being dried up or scorched.
10136-8{_}11995{_}_Time_.--For a pie with unboned meat, 1-1/4 to 1-1/2 hour; with boned meat and sausage or forcemeat, 1-1/2 to 2 hours.
10136-8{_}11996{_}_Average cost_, with 2 fowls, 6s.
10136-8{_}11997{_}6d.
10136-8{_}11998{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 or 7 persons.
10136-8{_}11999{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}12000{_}THE YOUNG CHICKS.--The chicks that are hatched first should be     taken from underneath the hen, lest she might think her task at     an end, and leave the remaining eggs to spoil.
10136-8{_}12001{_}As soon as the     young birds are taken from the mother, they must be placed in a     basket lined with soft wool, flannel, or hay, and stood in the     sunlight if it be summer time, or by the fire if the weather be     cold.
10136-8{_}12002{_}It is a common practice to cram young chicks with food as     soon as they are born.
10136-8{_}12003{_}This is quite unnecessary.
10136-8{_}12004{_}They will, so     long as they are kept warm, come to no harm if they take no food     for twenty-four hours following their birth.
10136-8{_}12005{_}Should the whole of     the brood not be hatched by that time, those that are born may     be fed with bread soaked in milk, and the yolk of a hard-boiled     egg.
10136-8{_}12006{_}POTTED CHICKEN OR FOWL (a Luncheon or Breakfast Dish).
10136-8{_}12007{_}930.
10136-8{_}12008{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast chicken; to every lb.
10136-8{_}12009{_}of meat allow 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}12010{_}of fresh butter, salt and cayenne to taste, 1 teaspoonful of pounded mace, 1/4 small nutmeg.
10136-8{_}12011{_}_Mode_.--Strip the meat from the bones of cold roast fowl; when it is freed from gristle and skin, weigh it, and, to every lb.
10136-8{_}12012{_}of meat, allow the above proportion of butter, seasoning, and spices.
10136-8{_}12013{_}Cut the meat into small pieces, pound it well with the fresh butter, sprinkle in the spices gradually, and keep pounding until reduced to a perfectly smooth paste.
10136-8{_}12014{_}Put it into potting-pots for use, and cover it with clarified butter, about 1/4 inch in thickness, and, if to be kept for some time, tie over a bladder: 2 or 3 slices of ham, minced and pounded with the above ingredients, will be found an improvement.
10136-8{_}12015{_}It should be kept in a dry place.
10136-8{_}12016{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}12017{_}FEEDING AND COOPING THE CHICKS.--When all the chicks are     hatched, they should be placed along with the mother under a     coop in a warm dry spot.
10136-8{_}12018{_}If two hens happen to have their broods     at the same time, their respective chicks should be carefully     kept separate; as, if they get mixed, and so go under the wrong     coop, the hens will probably maim and destroy those who have     mistaken their dwelling.
10136-8{_}12019{_}After being kept snug beneath the coop     for a week (the coop should be placed under cover at nightfall),     the chicks may be turned loose for an hour or so in the warmest     part of the day.
10136-8{_}12020{_}They should be gradually weaned from the soaked     bread and chopped egg, instead of which grits or boiled barley     should be given; in 8 or 10 days their stomachs will be strong     enough to receive bruised barley, and at the end of 3 weeks, if     your chicks be healthy, they will be able to take care of     themselves.
10136-8{_}12021{_}It will be well, however, to keep your eye on them a     week or so longer, as the elder chickens may drive them from     their food.
10136-8{_}12022{_}Great care should be taken that the very young     chicks do not run about the wet ground or on damp grass, as this     is the most prominent and fatal cause of disease.
10136-8{_}12023{_}While under     the coop with their mother, a shallow pan or plate of water     should be supplied to the chicks, as in a deeper vessel they are     liable to drench themselves and take cold, or possibly to get     drowned.
10136-8{_}12024{_}CHICKEN OR FOWL SALAD.
10136-8{_}12025{_}931.
10136-8{_}12026{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast or boiled chicken, 2 lettuces, a little endive, 1 cucumber, a few slices of boiled beetroot, salad-dressing No.
10136-8{_}12027{_}506.
10136-8{_}12028{_}_Mode_.--Trim neatly the remains of the chicken; wash, dry, and slice the lettuces, and place in the middle of a dish; put the pieces of fowl on the top, and pour the salad-dressing over them.
10136-8{_}12029{_}Garnish the edge of the salad with hard-boiled eggs cut in rings, sliced cucumber, and boiled beetroot cut in slices.
10136-8{_}12030{_}Instead of cutting the eggs in rings, the yolks may be rubbed through a hair sieve, and the whites chopped very finely, and arranged on the salad in small bunches, yellow and white alternately.
10136-8{_}12031{_}This should not be made long before it is wanted for table.
10136-8{_}12032{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the cold chicken, 8d.
10136-8{_}12033{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}12034{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}12035{_}AGE AND FLAVOUR OF CHICKENS.--It has been the opinion of the     medical faculty of all ages and all countries, that the flesh of     the young chicken is the must delicate and easy to digest of all     animal food.
10136-8{_}12036{_}It is less alkalescent than the flesh of any other     animal, and its entire freedom from any irritating quality     renders it a fit dish for the ailing, or those whose stomachs     are naturally weak.
10136-8{_}12037{_}In no animal, however, does age work such a     change, in regard to the quality of its flesh, as it does in     domestic fowls.
10136-8{_}12038{_}In their infancy, cocks and hens are equally     tender and toothsome; but as time overtakes them it is the cock     whose flesh toughens first.
10136-8{_}12039{_}A year-old cock, indeed, is fit for     little else than to be converted into soup, while a hen at the     same age, although sufficiently substantial, is not callous to     the insinuations of a carving-knife.
10136-8{_}12040{_}As regards capons, however,     the rule respecting age does not hold good.
10136-8{_}12041{_}There is scarcely to     be found a more delicious animal than a well-fed, well-dressed     capon.
10136-8{_}12042{_}Age does not dry up his juices; indeed, like wine, he     seems but to mellow.
10136-8{_}12043{_}At three years old, even, he is as tender     as a chick, with the additional advantage of his proper chicken     flavour being fully developed.
10136-8{_}12044{_}The above remarks, however,     concerning the capon, only apply to such as are _naturally_ fed,     and not crammed.
10136-8{_}12045{_}The latter process may produce a     handsome-looking bird, and it may weigh enough to satisfy the     whim or avarice of its stuffer; but, when before the fire, it     will reveal the cruel treatment to which it has been subjected,     and will weep a drippingpan-ful of fat tears.
10136-8{_}12046{_}You will never     find heart enough to place such a grief-worn guest at the head     of your table.
10136-8{_}12047{_}It should be borne in mind as a rule, that     small-boned and short-legged poultry are likely to excel the     contrary sort in delicacy of colour, flavour, and fineness of     flesh.
10136-8{_}12048{_}HASHED DUCK (Cold Meat Cookery).
10136-8{_}12049{_}932.
10136-8{_}12050{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast duck, rather more than 1 pint of weak stock or water, 1 onion, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}12051{_}of butter, thickening of butter and flour, salt and cayenne to taste, 1/2 teaspoonful of minced lemon-peel, 1 dessertspoonful of lemon-juice, 1/2 glass of port wine.
10136-8{_}12052{_}_Mode_.--Cut the duck into nice joints, and put the trimmings into a stewpan; slice and fry the onion in a little butter; add these to the trimmings, pour in the above proportion of weak stock or water, and stew gently for 1 hour.
10136-8{_}12053{_}Strain the liquor, thicken it with butter and flour, season with salt and cayenne, and add the remaining ingredients; boil it up and skim well; lay in the pieces of duck, and let them get thoroughly hot through by the side of the fire, but do not allow them to boil: they should soak in the gravy for about 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}12054{_}Garnish with sippets of toasted bread.
10136-8{_}12055{_}The hash may be made richer by using a stronger and more highly-flavoured gravy; a little spice or pounded mace may also be added, when their flavour is liked.
10136-8{_}12056{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}12057{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the cold duck, 4d.
10136-8{_}12058{_}_Seasonable_ from November to February; ducklings from May to August.
10136-8{_}12059{_}THE DUCK.--This bird belongs to the order of _Natatores_, or     Swimmers; the most familiar tribes of which are ducks, swans,     geese, auks, penguins, petrels, pelicans, guillemots, gulls, and     terns.
10136-8{_}12060{_}They mostly live in the water, feeding on fish, worms,     and aquatic plants.
10136-8{_}12061{_}They are generally polygamous, and make     their nests among reeds, or in moist places.
10136-8{_}12062{_}The flesh of many     of the species is eatable, but that of some is extremely rank     and oily.
10136-8{_}12063{_}The duck is a native of Britain, but is found on the     margins of most of the European lakes.
10136-8{_}12064{_}It is excessively greedy,     and by no means a nice feeder.
10136-8{_}12065{_}It requires a mixture of     vegetable and animal food; but aquatic insects, corn, and     vegetables, are its proper food.
10136-8{_}12066{_}Its flesh, however, is savoury,     being not so gross as that of the goose, and of easier     digestion.
10136-8{_}12067{_}In the green-pea season it is usually found on an     English table; but, according to Ude, "November is its proper     season, when it is plump and fat."
10136-8{_}12068{_}TO RAGOUT A DUCK WHOLE.
10136-8{_}12069{_}933.
10136-8{_}12070{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 large duck, pepper and salt to taste, good beef gravy, 2 onions sliced, 4 sage-leaves, a few leaves of lemon thyme, thickening of butter and flour.
10136-8{_}12071{_}_Mode_.--After having emptied and singed the duck, season it inside with pepper and salt, and truss it.
10136-8{_}12072{_}Roast it before a clear fire for about 20 minutes, and let it acquire a nice brown colour.
10136-8{_}12073{_}Put it into a stewpan with sufficient well-seasoned beef gravy to cover it; slice and fry the onions, and add these, with the sage-leaves and lemon thyme, both of which should be finely minced, to the stock.
10136-8{_}12074{_}Simmer gently until the duck is tender; strain, skim, and thicken the gravy with a little butter and flour; boil it up, pour over the duck, and serve.
10136-8{_}12075{_}When in season, about, 1-1/2 pint of young green peas, boiled separately, and put in the ragoût, very much improve this dish.
10136-8{_}12076{_}_Time_.--20 minutes to roast the duck; 20 minutes to stew it.
10136-8{_}12077{_}_Average cost_, from 2s.
10136-8{_}12078{_}3d.
10136-8{_}12079{_}to 2s.
10136-8{_}12080{_}6d.
10136-8{_}12081{_}each.
10136-8{_}12082{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}12083{_}_Seasonable_ from November to February; ducklings from April to August.
10136-8{_}12084{_}[Illustration: BUENOS AYRES DUCKS.]
10136-8{_}12085{_}THE BUENOS AYRES DUCK.--The Buenos Ayres duck is of East-Indian     birth, and is chiefly valuable as an ornament; for we suppose     one would as soon think of picking a Chinese teal for luncheon,     or a gold fish for breakfast, as to consign the handsome Buenos     Ayres to the spit.
10136-8{_}12086{_}The prevailing colour of this bird is black,     with a metallic lustre, and a gleaming of blue steel about its     breast and wings.
10136-8{_}12087{_}VARIETIES OF DUCKS.--Naturalists count nearly a hundred     different species of ducks; and there is no doubt that the     intending keeper of these harmless and profitable birds may     easily take his choice from amongst twenty different sorts.
10136-8{_}12088{_}There is, however, so little difference in the various members     of the family, either as regards hardiness, laying, or hatching,     that the most incompetent fancier or breeder may indulge his     taste without danger of making a bad bargain.
10136-8{_}12089{_}In connection with     their value for table, light-coloured ducks are always of milder     flavour than those that are dark-coloured, the white Aylesbury's     being general favourites.
10136-8{_}12090{_}Ducks reared exclusively on vegetable     diet will have a whiter and more delicate flesh than those     allowed to feed on animal offal; while the flesh of birds     fattened on the latter food, will be firmer than that of those     which have only partaken of food of a vegetable nature.
10136-8{_}12091{_}ROAST DUCKS.
10136-8{_}12092{_}934.
10136-8{_}12093{_}INGREDIENTS.--A couple of ducks; sage-and-onion stuffing No.
10136-8{_}12094{_}504; a little flour.
10136-8{_}12095{_}_Choosing and Trussing_.--Choose ducks with plump bellies, and with thick and yellowish feet.
10136-8{_}12096{_}They should be trussed with the feet on, which should be scalded, and the skin peeled off, and then turned up close to the legs.
10136-8{_}12097{_}Run a skewer through the middle of each leg, after having drawn them as close as possible to the body, to plump up the breast, passing the same quite through the body.
10136-8{_}12098{_}Cut off the heads and necks, and the pinions at the first joint; bring these close to the sides, twist the feet round, and truss them at the back of the bird.
10136-8{_}12099{_}After the duck is stuffed, both ends should be secured with string, so as to keep in the seasoning.
10136-8{_}12100{_}[Illustration: ROAST DUCK.]
10136-8{_}12101{_}_Mode_.--To insure ducks being tender, never dress them the same day they are killed; and if the weather permits, they should hang a day or two.
10136-8{_}12102{_}Make a stuffing of sage and onion sufficient for one duck, and leave the other unseasoned, as the flavour is not liked by everybody.
10136-8{_}12103{_}Put them down to a brisk clear fire, and keep them well basted the whole of the time they are cooking.
10136-8{_}12104{_}A few minutes before serving, dredge them lightly with flour, to make them froth and look plump; and when the steam draws towards the fire, send them to table hot and quickly, with a good brown gravy poured _round_, but not _over_ the ducks, and a little of the same in a tureen.
10136-8{_}12105{_}When in season, green peas should invariably accompany this dish.
10136-8{_}12106{_}_Time_.--Full-grown ducks from 3/4 to 1 hour; ducklings from 25 to 35 minutes.
10136-8{_}12107{_}_Average cost_, from 2s.
10136-8{_}12108{_}3d.
10136-8{_}12109{_}to 2s.
10136-8{_}12110{_}6d.
10136-8{_}12111{_}each.
10136-8{_}12112{_}_Sufficient_.--A.
10136-8{_}12113{_}couple of ducks for 6 or 7 persons.
10136-8{_}12114{_}_Seasonable_.--Ducklings from April to August; ducks from November to February.
10136-8{_}12115{_}_Note_.--Ducklings are trussed and roasted in the same manner, and served with the same sauces and accompaniments.
10136-8{_}12116{_}When in season, serve apple sauce.
10136-8{_}12117{_}[Illustration: ROUEN DUCKS.]
10136-8{_}12118{_}THE ROUEN DUCK.--The Rouen, or Rhone duck, is a large and     handsome variety, of French extraction.
10136-8{_}12119{_}The plumage of the Rouen     duck is somewhat sombre; its flesh is also much darker, and,     though of higher flavour, not near so delicate as that of our     own Aylesbury.
10136-8{_}12120{_}It is with this latter breed that the Rouen duck     is generally mated; and the result is said to be increase of     size and strength.
10136-8{_}12121{_}In Normandy and Brittany these ducks, as well     as other sorts, greatly abound; and the "duck-liver _pâtés_" are     there almost as popular as the _pâté de foie gras_ of Strasburg.
10136-8{_}12122{_}In order to bring the livers of the wretched duck to the     fashionable and unnatural size, the same diabolical cruelty is     resorted to as in the case of the Strasburg goose.
10136-8{_}12123{_}The poor     birds are _nailed_ by the feet to a board placed close to a     fire, and, in that position, plentifully supplied with food and     water.
10136-8{_}12124{_}In a few days, the carcase is reduced to a mere shadow,     while the liver has grown monstrously.
10136-8{_}12125{_}We would rather abstain     from the acquaintance of a man who ate _pâté de foie gras_,     knowing its component parts.
10136-8{_}12126{_}DUCK'S EGGS.--The ancient notion that ducks whose beaks have a     tendency to curve upwards, are better layers than those whose     beaks do not thus point, is, we need hardly say, simply absurd:     all ducks are good layers, if they are carefully fed and tended.
10136-8{_}12127{_}Ducks generally lay at night, or early in the morning.
10136-8{_}12128{_}While     they are in perfect health, they will do this; and one of the     surest signs of indisposition, among birds of this class, is     irregularity in laying.
10136-8{_}12129{_}The eggs laid will approach nearly the     colour of the layer,--light-coloured ducks laying white eggs,     and brown ducks greenish-blue eggs; dark-coloured birds laying     the largest eggs.
10136-8{_}12130{_}One time of day the notion was prevalent that     a duck would hatch no other eggs than her own; and although this     is not true, it will be, nevertheless, as well to match the     duck's own eggs as closely as possible; for we have known     instances wherein the duck has turned out of the nest and     destroyed eggs differing from her own in size and colour.
10136-8{_}12131{_}DUCKS.--The Mallard, or Wild Duck, from which is derived the     domestic species, is prevalent throughout Europe, Asia, and     America.
10136-8{_}12132{_}The mallard's most remarkable characteristic is one     which sets at defiance the speculations of the most profound     ornithologist.
10136-8{_}12133{_}The female bird is extremely plain, but the     male's plumage is a splendour of greens and browns, and browns     and blues.
10136-8{_}12134{_}In the spring, however, the plumage of the male     begins to fade, and in two months, every vestige of his finery     has departed, and he is not to be distinguished from his     soberly-garbed wife.
10136-8{_}12135{_}Then the greens, and the blues, and the     browns begin to bud out again, and by October he is once more a     gorgeous drake.
10136-8{_}12136{_}It is to be regretted that domestication has     seriously deteriorated the moral character of the duck.
10136-8{_}12137{_}In a     wild state, he is a faithful husband, desiring but one wife, and     devoting himself to her; but no sooner is he domesticated than     he becomes polygamous, and makes nothing of owning ten or a     dozen wives at a time.
10136-8{_}12138{_}As regards the females, they are much     more solicitous for the welfare of their progeny in a wild state     than a tame.
10136-8{_}12139{_}Should a tame duck's duckling get into mortal     trouble, its mother will just signify her sorrow by an extra     "quack," or so, and a flapping of her wings; but touch a wild     duck's little one if you dare!
10136-8{_}12140{_}she will buffet you with her     broad wings, and dash boldly at your face with her stout beak.
10136-8{_}12141{_}If you search for her nest amongst the long grass, she will try     no end of manoeuvres to lure you from it, her favourite _ruse_     being to pretend lameness, to delude you into the notion that     you have only to pursue _her_ vigorously, and her capture is     certain; so you persevere for half a mile or so, and then she is     up and away, leaving you to find your way back to the nest if     you can.
10136-8{_}12142{_}Among the ancients, opinion was at variance respecting     the wholesomeness and digestibility of goose flesh, but     concerning the excellence of the duck all parties were agreed;     indeed, they not only assigned to duck-meat the palm for     exquisite flavour and delicacy, they even attributed to it     medicinal powers of the highest order.
10136-8{_}12143{_}Not only the Roman     medical writers of the time make mention of it, but likewise the     philosophers of the period.
10136-8{_}12144{_}Plutarch assures us that Cato     preserved his whole household in health, in a season when plague     and disease were rife, through dieting them on roast duck.
10136-8{_}12145{_}STEWED DUCK AND PEAS (Cold Meat Cookery).
10136-8{_}12146{_}935.
10136-8{_}12147{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast duck, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}12148{_}of butter, 3 or 4 slices of lean ham or bacon, 1 tablespoonful of flour, 2 pints of thin gravy, 1, or a small bunch of green onions, 3 sprigs of parsley, 3 cloves, 1 pint of young green peas, cayenne and salt to taste, 1 teaspoonful of pounded sugar.
10136-8{_}12149{_}_Mode_.--Put the butter into a stewpan; cut up the duck into joints, lay them in with the slices of lean ham or bacon; make it brown, then dredge in a tablespoonful of flour, and stir this well in before adding the gravy.
10136-8{_}12150{_}Put in the onion, parsley, cloves, and gravy, and when it has simmered for 1/4 hour, add a pint of young green peas, and stew gently for about 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}12151{_}Season with cayenne, salt, and sugar; take out the duck, place it round the dish, and the peas in the middle.
10136-8{_}12152{_}_Time_.--3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}12153{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the cold duck, 1s.
10136-8{_}12154{_}_Seasonable_ from June to August.
10136-8{_}12155{_}DUCKS HATCHING.--Concerning incubation by ducks, a practised     writer says, "The duck requires a secret and safe place, rather     than any attendance, and will, at nature's call, cover her eggs     and seek her food.
10136-8{_}12156{_}On hatching, there is not often a necessity     for taking away any of the brood; and, having hatched, let the     mother retain her young ones upon the nest her own time.
10136-8{_}12157{_}On her     moving with her brood, let a coop be prepared upon the short     grass, if the weather be fine, and under shelter, if otherwise."
10136-8{_}12158{_}COOPING AND FEEDING DUCKLINGS.--Brood ducks should be cooped at     some distance from any other.
10136-8{_}12159{_}A wide and flat dish of water, to     be often renewed, should stand just outside the coop, and     barley, or any other meal, be the first food of the ducklings.
10136-8{_}12160{_}It will be needful, if it be wet weather, to clip their tails,     lest these draggle, and so weaken the bird.
10136-8{_}12161{_}The period of the     duck's confinement to the coop will depend on the weather, and     on the strength of the ducklings.
10136-8{_}12162{_}A fortnight is usually the     extent of time necessary, and they may even be sometimes     permitted to enjoy the luxury of a swim at the end of a week.
10136-8{_}12163{_}They should not, however, be allowed to stay too long in the     water at first; for they will then become ill, their feathers     get rough, and looseness of the bowels ensue.
10136-8{_}12164{_}In the latter     case, let them be closely cooped for a few days, and bean-meal     or oatmeal be mixed with their ordinary food.
10136-8{_}12165{_}[Illustration: AYLESBURY DUCKS.]
10136-8{_}12166{_}THE AYLESBURY DUCK.--The white Aylesbury duck is, and     deservedly, a universal favourite.
10136-8{_}12167{_}Its snowy plumage and     comfortable comportment make it a credit to the poultry-yard,     while its broad and deep breast, and its ample back, convey the     assurance that your satisfaction will not cease at its death.
10136-8{_}12168{_}In     parts of Buckinghamshire, this member of the duck family is bred     on an extensive scale; not on plains and commons, however, as     might be naturally imagined, but in the abodes of the cottagers.
10136-8{_}12169{_}Round the walls of the living-rooms, and of the bedroom even,     are fixed rows of wooden boxes, lined with hay; and it is the     business of the wife and children to nurse and comfort the     feathered lodgers, to feed the little ducklings, and to take the     old ones out for an airing.
10136-8{_}12170{_}Sometimes the "stock" ducks are the     cottager's own property, but it more frequently happens that     they are intrusted to his care by a wholesale breeder, who pays     him so much _per_ score for all ducklings properly raised.
10136-8{_}12171{_}To be     perfect, the Aylesbury duck should be plump, pure white, with     yellow feet, and a flesh-coloured beak.
10136-8{_}12172{_}STEWED DUCK AND PEAS (Cold Meat Cookery).
10136-8{_}12173{_}936.
10136-8{_}12174{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast duck, 1/2 pint of good gravy, cayenne and salt to taste, 1/2 teaspoonful of minced lemon-peel, 1 teaspoonful of pounded sugar, 2 oz, of butter rolled in flour, 1-1/2 pint of green peas.
10136-8{_}12175{_}_Mode_.--Cut up the duck into joints, lay it in the gravy, and add a seasoning of cayenne, salt, and minced lemon-peel; let tins gradually warm through, but not boil.
10136-8{_}12176{_}Throw the peas into boiling water slightly salted, and boil them rapidly until tender.
10136-8{_}12177{_}Drain them, stir in the pounded sugar, and the butter rolled in flour; shake them over the fire for two or three minutes, and serve in the centre of the dish, with the duck laid round.
10136-8{_}12178{_}_Time_.--15 minutes to boil the peas, when they are full grown.
10136-8{_}12179{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the cold duck, 10d.
10136-8{_}12180{_}_Seasonable_ from June to August.
10136-8{_}12181{_}FATTENING DUCKS.--Many duck-keepers give their birds nothing in     the shape of food, letting them wander about and pick up a     living for themselves; and they will seem to get fat even upon     this precarious feeding.
10136-8{_}12182{_}Unless, however, ducks are supplied     with, besides chance food, a liberal feed of solid corn, or     grain, morning and evening, their flesh will become flabby and     insipid.
10136-8{_}12183{_}The simple way to fatten ducks is to let them have as     much, substantial food as they will eat, bruised oats and     pea-meal being the standard fattening food for them.
10136-8{_}12184{_}No cramming     is required, as with the turkey and some other poultry: they     will cram themselves to the very verge of suffocation.
10136-8{_}12185{_}At the     same time, plenty of exercise and clean water should be at their     service.
10136-8{_}12186{_}AMERICAN MODE OF CAPTURING DUCKS.--On the American rivers, the     modes of capture are various.
10136-8{_}12187{_}Sometimes half a dozen artificial     birds are fastened to a little raft, and which is so weighted     that the sham birds squat naturally on the water.
10136-8{_}12188{_}This is quite     sufficient to attract the notice of a passing flock, who descend     to cultivate the acquaintance of the isolated few when the     concealed hunter, with his fowling-piece, scatters a deadly     leaden shower amongst them.
10136-8{_}12189{_}In the winter, when the water is     covered with rubble ice, the fowler of the Delaware paints his     canoe entirely white, lies flat in the bottom of it, and floats     with the broken ice; from which the aquatic inhabitants fail to     distinguish it.
10136-8{_}12190{_}So floats the canoe till he within it     understands, by the quacking, and fluttering, and whirring of     wings, that he is in the midst of a flock, when he is up in a     moment with the murderous piece, and dying quacks and     lamentations rend the still air.
