10136-8{_}12191{_}[Illustration: BOW-BILL DUCKS.]
10136-8{_}12192{_}Bow-BILL DUCKS, &c.--Every one knows how awkward are the     _Anatidae_, waddling along on their unelastic webbed toes, and     their short legs, which, being placed considerably backward,     make the fore part of the body preponderate.
10136-8{_}12193{_}Some, however, are     formed more adapted to terrestrial habits than others, and     notably amongst these may be named _Dendronessa sponsa_, the     summer duck of America.
10136-8{_}12194{_}This beautiful bird rears her young in     the holes of trees, generally overhanging the water.
10136-8{_}12195{_}When strong     enough, the young scramble to the mouth of the hole, launch into     the air with their little wings and feet spread out, and drop     into their favourite element.
10136-8{_}12196{_}Whenever their birthplace is at     some distance from the water, the mother carries them to it, one     by one, in her bill, holding them so as not to injure their yet     tender frame.
10136-8{_}12197{_}On several occasions, however, when the hole was     30, 40, or more yards from a piece of water, Audubon observed     that the mother suffered the young to fall on the grass and     dried leaves beneath the tree, and afterwards led them directly     to the nearest edge of the next pool or creek.
10136-8{_}12198{_}There are some     curious varieties of the domestic duck, which only appear     interesting from their singularity, for there does not seem to     be anything of use or value in the unusual characteristics which     distinguish them; thus, the bow-bill duck, as shown in the     engraving, called by some writers the hook-bill, is remarkable     for the peculiarly strange distortion of its beak, and the tuft     on the top of its head.
10136-8{_}12199{_}The penguin duck, again, waddles in an     upright position, like the penguin, on account of the unnatural     situation of its legs.
10136-8{_}12200{_}These odd peculiarities add nothing of     value to the various breeds, and may be set down as only the     result of accidental malformation, transmitted from generation     to generation.
10136-8{_}12201{_}STEWED DUCK AND TURNIPS (Cold Meat Cookery).
10136-8{_}12202{_}937.
10136-8{_}12203{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast duck, 1/2 pint of good gravy, 4 shalots, a few slices of carrot, a small bunch of savoury herbs, 1 blade of pounded mace, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}12204{_}of turnips, weighed after being peeled, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}12205{_}of butter, pepper and salt to taste.
10136-8{_}12206{_}_Mode_.--Cut up the duck into joints, fry the shalots, carrots, and herbs, and put them, with the duck, into the gravy; add the pounded mace, and stew gently for 20 minutes or 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}12207{_}Cut about 1 lb.
10136-8{_}12208{_}of turnips, weighed after being peeled, into 1/2-inch squares, put the butter into a stewpan, and stew them till quite tender, which will be in about 1/2 hour, or rather more; season with pepper and salt, and serve in the centre of the dish, with the duck, &c. laid round.
10136-8{_}12209{_}_Time_.--Rather more than 1/2 hour to stew the turnips.
10136-8{_}12210{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the cold duck, 1s.
10136-8{_}12211{_}_Seasonable_ from November to February.
10136-8{_}12212{_}THE WILD DUCK.--In many parts of England the wild duck is to be     found, especially in those desolate fenny parts where water     abounds.
10136-8{_}12213{_}In Lincolnshire they are plentiful, and are annually     taken in the decoys, which consist of ponds situate in the     marshes, and surrounded with wood or reeds to prevent the birds     which frequent them from, being disturbed.
10136-8{_}12214{_}In these the birds     sleep during the day; and as soon as evening sets in, the _decoy     rises_, and the wild fowl feed during the night.
10136-8{_}12215{_}Now is the time     for the decoy ducks to entrap the others.
10136-8{_}12216{_}From the ponds     diverge, in different directions, certain canals, at the end of     which funnel nets are placed; along these the _decoy ducks_,     trained for the purpose, lead the others in search of food.
10136-8{_}12217{_}After they have got a certain length, a decoy-man appears, and     drives them further on, until they are finally taken in the     nets.
10136-8{_}12218{_}It is from these decoys, in Lincolnshire, that the London     market is mostly supplied.
10136-8{_}12219{_}The Chinese have a singular mode of     catching these ducks.
10136-8{_}12220{_}A person wades in the water up to the     chin, and, having his head covered with an empty calabash,     approaches the place where the ducks are.
10136-8{_}12221{_}As the birds have no     suspicion of the nature of the object which is concealed under     the calabash, they suffer its approach, and allow it to move at     will among their flock.
10136-8{_}12222{_}The man, accordingly, walks about in the     midst of his game, and, whenever he pleases, pulls them by the     legs under the water, and fixes them to his belt, until he has     secured as many as he requires, and then moves off as he went     amongst them, without exciting the slightest suspicion of the     trick he has been playing them.
10136-8{_}12223{_}This singular mode of     duck-hunting is also practised on the Ganges, the earthen     vessels of the Hindoos being used instead of calabashes.
10136-8{_}12224{_}These     vessels, being those in which the inhabitants boil their rice,     are considered, after once being used, as defiled, and are     accordingly thrown into the river.
10136-8{_}12225{_}The duck-takers, finding them     suitable for their purpose, put them on their heads; and as the     ducks, from seeing them constantly floating down the stream, are     familiar with their appearance, they regard them as objects from     which no danger is to be expected.
10136-8{_}12226{_}[Illustration: CALL-DUCKS.]
10136-8{_}12227{_}DUCK-SNARES IN THE LINCOLNSHIRE FENS.--The following interesting     account of how duck-snaring used to be managed in the     Lincolnshire fens, was published some years ago, in a work     entitled the "Feathered Tribes."
10136-8{_}12228{_}--"In the lakes to which they     resorted, their favourite haunts were observed, and in the most     sequestered part of a haunt, a pipe or ditch was cut across the     entrance, decreasing gradually in width from the entrance to the     further end, which was not more than two feet wide.
10136-8{_}12229{_}The ditch     was of a circular form, but did not bend much for the first ten     yards.
10136-8{_}12230{_}The banks of the lake on each side of the ditch were kept     clear of weeds and close herbage, in order that the ducks might     get on them to sit and dress themselves.
10136-8{_}12231{_}Along the ditch, poles     were driven into the ground close to the edge on each side, and     the tops were bent over across the ditch and tied together.
10136-8{_}12232{_}The     poles then bent forward at the entrance to the ditch, and formed     an arch, the top of which was tea feet distant from the surface     of the water; the arch was made to decrease in height as the     ditch decreased in width, so that the remote end was not more     than eighteen inches in height.
10136-8{_}12233{_}The poles were placed about six     feet from each other, and connected by poles laid lengthwise     across the arch, and tied together.
10136-8{_}12234{_}Over the whole was thrown a     net, which was made fast to a reed fence at the entrance and     nine or ten yards up the ditch, and afterwards strongly pegged     to the ground.
10136-8{_}12235{_}At the end of the ditch furthest from the     entrance, was fixed what was called a tunnel-net, of about four     yards in length, of a round form, and kept open by a number of     hoops about eighteen inches in diameter, placed at a small     distance from each other to keep it distended.
10136-8{_}12236{_}Supposing the     circular bend of the ditch to be to the right, when one stands     with his back to the lake, then on the left-hand side, a number     of reed fences were constructed, called shootings, for the     purpose of screening the decoy-man from observation, and, in     such a manner, that the fowl in the decoy would not be alarmed     while he was driving those that were in the pipe.
10136-8{_}12237{_}These     shootings, which were ten in number, were about four yards in     length and about six feet high.
10136-8{_}12238{_}From the end of the last     shooting a person could not see the lake, owing to the bend of     the ditch; and there was then no further occasion for shelter.
10136-8{_}12239{_}Were it not for these shootings, the fowl that remained about     the mouth of the ditch would have been alarmed, if the person     driving the fowl already under the net should have been exposed,     and would have become so shy as entirely to forsake the place."
10136-8{_}12240{_}THE DECOY MAN, DOG, AND DUCKS.--"The first thing the decoy-man     did, on approaching the ditch, was to take a piece of lighted     peat or turf, and to hold it near his mouth, to prevent the     birds from smelling him.
10136-8{_}12241{_}He was attended by a dog trained to     render him assistance.
10136-8{_}12242{_}He walked very silently about halfway up     the shootings, where a small piece of wood was thrust through     the reed fence, which made an aperture just large enough to     enable him to see if there were any fowl within; if not, he     walked to see if any were about the entrance to the ditch.
10136-8{_}12243{_}If     there were, he stopped, made a motion to his dog, and gave him a     piece of cheese to eat, when the dog went directly to a hole     through the reed fence, and the birds immediately flew off the     back into the water.
10136-8{_}12244{_}The dog returned along the bank between the     reed fences, and came out to his master at another hole.
10136-8{_}12245{_}The man     then gave the dog something more to encourage him, and the dog     repeated his rounds, till the birds were attracted by his     motions, and followed him into the mouth of the ditch--an     operation which was called 'working them.'
10136-8{_}12246{_}The man now retreated     further back, working the dog at different holes, until the     ducks were sufficiently under the net.
10136-8{_}12247{_}He then commanded his dog     to lie down under the fence, and going himself forward to the     end of the ditch next the lake, he took off his hat, and gave it     a wave between the shootings.
10136-8{_}12248{_}All the birds that were under the     net could then see him, but none that were in the lake could.
10136-8{_}12249{_}The former flew forward, and the man then ran to the next     shooting, and waved his hat, and so on, driving them along until     they came into the tunnel-net, into which they crept.
10136-8{_}12250{_}When they     were all in, the man gave the net a twist, so as to prevent them     getting back.
10136-8{_}12251{_}He then took the net off from the end of the     ditch, and taking out, one by one, the ducks that were in it,     dislocated their necks."
10136-8{_}12252{_}BOILED FOWLS OR CHICKENS.
10136-8{_}12253{_}[Illustration: BOILED FOWL.]
10136-8{_}12254{_}938.
10136-8{_}12255{_}INGREDIENTS.--A pair of fowls; water.
10136-8{_}12256{_}_Choosing and Trussing_.--In choosing fowls for boiling, it should be borne in mind that those that are not black-legged are generally much whiter when dressed.
10136-8{_}12257{_}Pick, draw, singe, wash, and truss them in the following manner, without the livers in the wings; and, in drawing, be careful not to break the gall-bladder:--Cut off the neck, leaving sufficient skin to skewer back.
10136-8{_}12258{_}Cut the feet off to the first joint, tuck the stumps into a slit made on each side of the belly, twist the wings over the back of the fowl, and secure the top of the leg and the bottom of the wing together by running a skewer through them and the body.
10136-8{_}12259{_}The other side must be done in the same manner.
10136-8{_}12260{_}Should the fowl be very large and old, draw the sinews of the legs before tucking them in.
10136-8{_}12261{_}Make a slit in the apron of the fowl, large enough to admit the parson's nose, and tie a string on the tops of the legs to keep them in their proper place.
10136-8{_}12262{_}_Mode_.--When, they are firmly trussed, put them into a stewpan with plenty of hot water; bring it to boil, and carefully remove all the scum as it rises.
10136-8{_}12263{_}_Simmer very gently_ until the fowl is tender, and bear in mind that the slower it boils, the plumper and whiter will the fowl be.
10136-8{_}12264{_}Many cooks wrap them in a floured cloth to preserve the colour, and to prevent the scum from clinging to them; in this case, a few slices of lemon should be placed on the breasts; over these a sheet of buttered paper, and then the cloth; cooking them in this manner renders the flesh very white.
10136-8{_}12265{_}Boiled ham, bacon, boiled tongue, or pickled pork, are the usual accompaniments to boiled fowls, and they may be served with Béchamel, white sauce, parsley and butter, oyster, lemon, liver, celery, or mushroom sauce.
10136-8{_}12266{_}A little should be poured over the fowls, after the skewers are removed, and the remainder sent in a tureen to table.
10136-8{_}12267{_}_Time_.--Large fowl, 1 hour; moderate-sized one, 3/4 hour; chicken, from 20 minutes to 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}12268{_}_Average cost_, in full season, 5s.
10136-8{_}12269{_}the pair.
10136-8{_}12270{_}_Sufficient_ for 7 or 8 persons.
10136-8{_}12271{_}_Seasonable_ all the year, but scarce in early spring.
10136-8{_}12272{_}[Illustration: GAME-FOWLS.]
10136-8{_}12273{_}THE GAME FOWL.--Respecting the period at which this well-known     member of the _Gallus_ family became domesticated, history is     silent.
10136-8{_}12274{_}There is little doubt, however, that, like the dog, it     has been attached to mankind ever since mankind were attached to     civilization.
10136-8{_}12275{_}Although the social position of this bird is, at     the present time, highly respectable, it is nothing to what it     was when Rome was mistress of the world.
10136-8{_}12276{_}Writing at that period,     Pliny says, respecting the domestic cock, "The gait of the cock     is proud and commanding; he walks with head erect and elevated     crest; alone, of all birds, he habitually looks up to the sky,     raising, at the same time, his curved and scythe-formed tail,     and inspiring terror in the lion himself, that most intrepid of     animals.----They regulate the conduct of our magistrates, and     open or close to them their own houses.
10136-8{_}12277{_}They prescribe rest or     movement to the Roman fasces: they command or prohibit battles.
10136-8{_}12278{_}In a word, they lord it over the masters of the world."
10136-8{_}12279{_}As well     among the ancient Greeks as the Romans, was the cock regarded     with respect, and even awe.
10136-8{_}12280{_}The former people practised     divinations by means of this bird.
10136-8{_}12281{_}Supposing there to be a doubt     in the camp as to the fittest day to fight a battle, the letter     of every day in the week would be placed face downwards, and a     grain of corn placed on each; then the sacred cock would be let     loose, and, according to the letters he pecked his corn from, so     would the battle-time be regulated.
10136-8{_}12282{_}On one momentous occasion,     however, a person inimical to priestly interest officiously     examined the grain, and found that those lying on the letters     not wanted were made of wax, and the birds, preferring the true     grain, left these untouched.
10136-8{_}12283{_}It is needless to add that, after     this, divination through the medium of cocks and grain fell out     of fashion.
10136-8{_}12284{_}Whether or no the learned fowl above alluded to were     of the "game" breed, is unknown; but that the birds were bred     for the inhuman sport of fighting many hundred years before the     Christian era, there can be no doubt.
10136-8{_}12285{_}Themistocles, the Athenian     king, who flourished more than two thousand years ago, took     advantage of the sight of a pitched battle between two cocks to     harangue his soldiers on courage.
10136-8{_}12286{_}"Observe," said he, "with what     intrepid valour they fight, inspired by no other motive than     lore of victory; whereas you have to contend for your religion     and your liberty, for your wives and children, and for the tombs     of your ancestors."
10136-8{_}12287{_}And to this day his courage has not     degenerated.
10136-8{_}12288{_}He still preserves his bold and elegant gait, his     sparkling eye, while his wedge-shaped beak and cruel spurs are     ever ready to support his defiant crow.
10136-8{_}12289{_}It is no wonder that the     breed is not plentiful--first, on account of the few eggs laid     by the hen; and, secondly, from the incurable pugnacity of the     chicks.
10136-8{_}12290{_}Half fledged broods may be found blind as bats from     fighting, and only waiting for the least glimmer of sight to be     at it again.
10136-8{_}12291{_}Without doubt, the flesh of game fowls is every way     superior to that of every chicken of the family.
10136-8{_}12292{_}BROILED FOWL AND MUSHROOM SAUCE.
10136-8{_}12293{_}939.
10136-8{_}12294{_}INGREDIENTS.--A large fowl, seasoning, to taste, of pepper and salt, 2 handfuls of button mushrooms, 1 slice of lean ham, 3/4 pint of thickened gravy, 1 teaspoonful of lemon-juice, 1/2 teaspoonful of pounded sugar.
10136-8{_}12295{_}_Mode_.--Cut the fowl into quarters, roast it until three-parts done, and keep it well basted whilst at the fire.
10136-8{_}12296{_}Take the fowl up, broil it for a few minutes over a clear fire, and season it with pepper and salt.
10136-8{_}12297{_}Have ready some mushroom sauce made in the following manner.
10136-8{_}12298{_}Put the mushrooms into a stewpan with a small piece of butter, the ham, a seasoning of pepper and salt, and the gravy; simmer these gently for 1/2 hour, add the lemon-juice and sugar, dish the fowl, and pour the sauce round them.
10136-8{_}12299{_}_Time_.--To roast the fowl, 35 minutes; to broil it, 10 to 15 minutes.
10136-8{_}12300{_}_Average cost_, in full season, 2s.
10136-8{_}12301{_}6d.
10136-8{_}12302{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}12303{_}_Seasonable_.--In full season from May to January.
10136-8{_}12304{_}[Illustration: BLACK BANTAMS.]
10136-8{_}12305{_}THE BANTAM.--No one will dispute that for beauty, animation,     plumage, and courage the Bantam is entitled to rank next to the     game fowl.
10136-8{_}12306{_}As its name undoubtedly implies, the bird is of     Asiatic origin.
10136-8{_}12307{_}The choicest sorts are the buff-coloured, and     those that are entirely black.
10136-8{_}12308{_}A year-old Bantam cock of pure     breed will not weigh more than sixteen ounces.
10136-8{_}12309{_}Despite its small     size, however, it is marvellously bold, especially in defence of     its progeny.
10136-8{_}12310{_}A friend of the writer's, residing at Kensington,     possessed a pair of thorough-bred Bantams, that were allowed the     range of a yard where a fierce bull-terrier was kennelled.
10136-8{_}12311{_}The     hen had chicks; and, when about three weeks old, one of them     strayed into the dog-kennel.
10136-8{_}12312{_}The grim beast within took no     notice of the tiny fledgling; but, when the anxious mother     ventured in to fetch out the truant, with a growl the dog woke,     and nearly snapped her asunder in his great jaws.
10136-8{_}12313{_}The cock bird     saw the tragic fate of its partner; but, nothing daunted, flew     at the dog with a fierce cry, and pecked savagely at its face.
10136-8{_}12314{_}The odds, however, were too great; and, when the terrier had     sufficiently recovered from the astonishment caused by the     sudden and unexpected attack, he seized the audacious Bantam,     and shook him to death; and, in five minutes, the devoted couple     were entombed in _Pincher's_ capacious maw.
10136-8{_}12315{_}BOILED FOWL AND RICE.
10136-8{_}12316{_}940.
10136-8{_}12317{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 fowl, mutton broth, 2 onions, 2 small blades of pounded mace, pepper and salt to taste, 1/4 pint of rice, parsley and butter.
10136-8{_}12318{_}_Mode_.--Truss the fowl as for boiling, and put it into a stewpan with sufficient clear well-skimmed mutton broth to cover it; add the onion, mace, and a seasoning of pepper and salt; stew very gently for about 1 hour, should the fowl be large, and about 1/2 hour before it is ready put in the rice, which should be well washed and soaked.
10136-8{_}12319{_}When the latter is tender, strain it from the liquor, and put it on a sieve reversed to dry before the fire, and, in the mean time, keep the fowl hot.
10136-8{_}12320{_}Dish it, put the rice round as a border, pour a little parsley and butter over the fowl, and the remainder send to table in a tureen.
10136-8{_}12321{_}_Time_.--A large fowl, 1 hour.
10136-8{_}12322{_}_Average cost_, in full season, 2s.
10136-8{_}12323{_}6d.
10136-8{_}12324{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 or 4 persons.
10136-8{_}12325{_}_Seasonable_ all the year, but scarce in early spring.
10136-8{_}12326{_}[Illustration: DORKINGS.]
10136-8{_}12327{_}THE DORKING.--This bird takes its name from that of a town in     Surrey, where the breed is to be found in greater numbers, and     certainly in greater perfection, than elsewhere.
10136-8{_}12328{_}It is generally     believed that this particular branch of poultry was found in the     town above mentioned as long ago as the Roman era.
10136-8{_}12329{_}The Dorking's     chief characteristic is that he has five claws on each foot; the     extra claw, however, is never of sufficient length to encumber     the foot, or to cause it to "drag" its nest, or scratch out the     eggs.
10136-8{_}12330{_}The colour of the true Dorking is pure white; long in the     body, short in the legs, and a prolific layer.
10136-8{_}12331{_}Thirty years ago,     there was much controversy respecting the origin of the Dorking.
10136-8{_}12332{_}The men of Sussex declared that the bird belonged to them, and     brought birds indigenous to their weald, and possessing all the     Dorking fine points and peculiarities, in proof of the     declaration.
10136-8{_}12333{_}Others inclined to the belief that the Poland bird     was the father of the Dorking, and not without at least a show     of reason, as the former bird much resembles the latter in     shape; and, despite its sombre hue, it is well known that the     Poland cock will occasionally beget thorough white stock from     white English hens.
10136-8{_}12334{_}The commotion has, however, long ago     subsided, and Dorking still retains its fair reputation for     fowl.
10136-8{_}12335{_}CURRIED FOWL.
10136-8{_}12336{_}941.
10136-8{_}12337{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 fowl, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}12338{_}of butter, 3 onions sliced, 1 pint of white veal gravy, 1 tablespoonful of curry-powder, 1 tablespoonful of flour, 1 apple, 4 tablespoonfuls of cream, 1 tablespoonful of lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}12339{_}_Mode_.--Put the butter into a stewpan, with the onions sliced, the fowl cut into small joints, and the apple peeled, cored, and minced.
10136-8{_}12340{_}Fry of a pale brown, add the stock, and stew gently for 20 minutes; rub down the curry-powder and flour with a little of the gravy, quite smoothly, and stir this to the other ingredients; simmer for rather more than 1/2 hour, and just before serving, add the above proportion of hot cream and lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}12341{_}Serve with boiled rice, which may either be heaped lightly on a dish by itself, or put round the curry as a border.
10136-8{_}12342{_}_Time_.--50 minutes.
10136-8{_}12343{_}_Average cost_, 3s.
10136-8{_}12344{_}3d.
10136-8{_}12345{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 or 4 persons.
10136-8{_}12346{_}_Seasonable_ in the winter.
10136-8{_}12347{_}_Note_.--This curry may be made of cold chicken, but undressed meat will be found far superior.
10136-8{_}12348{_}THE POLAND.--This bird, a native of Holland, is a great     favourite with fowl-keepers, especially those who have on eye to     profit rather than to amusement.
10136-8{_}12349{_}Those varieties known as the     "silver spangled" and the "gold spangled" are handsome enough to     please the most fastidious; but the common black breed, with the     bushy crown of white feathers, is but a plain bird.
10136-8{_}12350{_}The chief     value of the common Poland lies in the great number of eggs they     produce; indeed, in many parts, they are as well known as     "everlasting layers" as by their proper name.
10136-8{_}12351{_}However, the     experienced breeder would take good care to send the eggs of his     everlasting layers to market, and not use them for home     consumption, as, although they may be as large as those laid by     other hens, the amount of nutriment contained in them is not     nearly so great.
10136-8{_}12352{_}Mr. Mowbray once kept an account of the number     of eggs produced by this prolific bird, with the following     result:--From the 25th of October to the 25th of the following     September five hens laid 503 eggs; the average weight of each     egg was one ounce five drachms, and the total weight of the     whole, exclusive of the shells, 50-1/4 pounds.
10136-8{_}12353{_}Taking the weight     of the birds at the fair average of five pounds each, we thus     see them producing within a year double their weight of egg     alone; and, supposing every egg to contain a chick, and allowing     the chick to, grow, in less than eighteen months from the laying     of the first egg, _two thousand five hundred pounds_ of     chicken-meat would be the result.
10136-8{_}12354{_}The Poland is easily fattened,     and its flesh is generally considered juicier and of richer     flavour than most others.
10136-8{_}12355{_}[Illustration: SPANGLED POLANDS.]
10136-8{_}12356{_}CURRIED FOWL OR CHICKEN (Cold Meat Cookery).
10136-8{_}12357{_}942.
10136-8{_}12358{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast fowls, 2 large onions, 1 apple, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}12359{_}of butter, 1 dessertspoonful of curry-powder, 1 teaspoonful of flour, 1/2 pint of gravy, 1 tablespoonful of lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}12360{_}_Mode_.--Slice the onions, peel, core, and chop the apple, and cut the fowl into neat joints; fry these in the butter of a nice brown; then add the curry-powder, flour, and gravy, and stew for about 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}12361{_}Put in the lemon-juice, and serve with boiled rice, either placed in a ridge round the dish or separately.
10136-8{_}12362{_}Two or three shallots or a little garlic may be added, if approved.
10136-8{_}12363{_}_Time_.--Altogether 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}12364{_}_Av.
10136-8{_}12365{_}cost_, exclusive of the cold fowl, 6d.
10136-8{_}12366{_}_Seasonable_ in the winter.
10136-8{_}12367{_}[Illustration: COCHIN-CHINAS.]
10136-8{_}12368{_}THE COCHIN-CHINA.--About fifteen years ago, the arrival of this     distinguished Asiatic created in England as great a sensation as     might be expected from the landing of an invading host.
10136-8{_}12369{_}The     first pair that ever made their appearance here were natives of     Shanghai, and were presented to the queen, who exhibited them at     the Dublin poultry-show of 1818.
10136-8{_}12370{_}Then began the "Cochin"     _furor_.
10136-8{_}12371{_}As soon as it was discovered, despite the most     strenuous endeavours to keep the tremendous secret, that a     certain dealer was possessed of a pair of these birds,     straightway the avenues to that dealer's shop were blocked by     broughams, and chariots, and hack cabs, until the shy poulterer     had been tempted by a sufficiently high sum to part with his     treasure.
10136-8{_}12372{_}Bank-notes were exchanged for Cochin chicks, and     Cochin eggs were in as great demand as though they had been laid     by the fabled golden goose.
10136-8{_}12373{_}The reign of the Cochin China was,     however, of inconsiderable duration.
10136-8{_}12374{_}The bird that, in 1847,     would fetch thirty guineas, is now counted but ordinary     chicken-meat, and its price is regulated according to its weight     when ready for the spit.
10136-8{_}12375{_}As for the precious buff eggs, against     which, one time of day, guineas were weighed,--send for     sixpenn'orth at the cheesemonger's, and you will get at least     five; which is just as it should be.
10136-8{_}12376{_}For elegance of shape or     quality of flesh, the Cochin cannot for a moment stand     comparison with our handsome dunghill; neither can the     indescribable mixture of growling and braying, peculiar to the     former, vie with the musical trumpeting of our own morning     herald: yet our poultry-breeders have been immense gainers by     the introduction of the ungainly celestial, inasmuch as _new     blood_ has been infused into the English chicken family.
10136-8{_}12377{_}Of this     incalculable advantage we may be sure; while, as to the Cochin's     defects, they are certain to be lost in the process of "cross     and cross" breeding.
10136-8{_}12378{_}BOILED FOWLS A LA BECHAMEL.
10136-8{_}12379{_}943.
10136-8{_}12380{_}INGREDIENTS.--A pair of fowls, 1 pint of Béchamel, No, 367, a few bunches of boiled brocoli or cauliflower.
10136-8{_}12381{_}_Mode_.--Truss and boil the fowls by recipe No.
10136-8{_}12382{_}938; make a pint of Béchamel sauce by recipe No.
10136-8{_}12383{_}367; pour some of this over the fowls, and the remainder send to table in a tureen.
10136-8{_}12384{_}Garnish the dish with bunches of boiled cauliflowers or brocoli, and serve very hot.
10136-8{_}12385{_}The sauce should be made sufficiently thick to adhere to the fowls; that for the tureen should be thinned by adding a spoonful or two of stock.
10136-8{_}12386{_}_Time_.--From 1/2 to 1 hour, according to size.
10136-8{_}12387{_}_Average cost_, in full season, 5s.
10136-8{_}12388{_}a pair.
10136-8{_}12389{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 or 7 persons.
10136-8{_}12390{_}_Seasonable_ all the year, but scarce in early spring.
10136-8{_}12391{_}SPACE FOR FOWLS.--We are no advocates for converting the     domestic fowl into a cage-bird.
10136-8{_}12392{_}We have known amateur     fowl-keepers--worthy souls, who would butter the very barley     they gave their pets, if they thought they would the more enjoy     it--coop up a male bird and three or four hens in an ordinary     egg-chest placed on its side, and with the front closely barred     with iron hooping!
10136-8{_}12393{_}This system will not do.
10136-8{_}12394{_}Every animal, from     man himself to the guinea-pig, must have what is vulgarly, but     truly, known as "elbow-room;" and it must be self-evident how     emphatically this rule applies to winged animals.
10136-8{_}12395{_}It may be     urged, in the case of domestic fowls, that from constant disuse,     and from clipping and plucking, and other sorts of maltreatment,     their wings can hardly be regarded as instruments of flight; we     maintain, however, that you may pluck a fowl's wing-joints as     bare as a pumpkin, but you will not erase from his memory that     he is a fowl, and that his proper sphere is the open air.
10136-8{_}12396{_}If he     likewise reflects that he is an ill-used fowl--a prison-bird--he     will then come to the conclusion, that there is not the least     use, under such circumstances, for his existence; and you must     admit that the decision is only logical and natural.
10136-8{_}12397{_}BOILED FOWL, with Oysters.
10136-8{_}12398{_}(_Excellent_.)
10136-8{_}12399{_}944.
10136-8{_}12400{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 young fowl, 3 dozen oysters, the yolks of 2 eggs, 1/4 pint of cream.
10136-8{_}12401{_}_Mode_.--Truss a young fowl as for boiling; fill the inside with oysters which have been bearded and washed in their own liquor; secure the ends of the fowl, put it into a jar, and plunge the jar into a saucepan of boiling water.
10136-8{_}12402{_}Keep it boiling for 1-1/2 hour, or rather longer; then take the gravy that has flowed from the oysters and fowl, of which there will be a good quantity; stir in the cream and yolks of eggs, add a few oysters scalded in their liquor; let the sauce get quite _hot_, but do not allow it to _boil;_ pour some of it over the fowl, and the remainder send to table in a tureen.
10136-8{_}12403{_}A blade of pounded mace added to the sauce, with the cream and eggs, will be found an improvement.
10136-8{_}12404{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}12405{_}Average cost, 4s.
10136-8{_}12406{_}6d.
10136-8{_}12407{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 or 4 persons.
10136-8{_}12408{_}_Seasonable_ from September to April.
10136-8{_}12409{_}THE FOWL-HOUSE.--In building a fowl-house, take care that it be,     if possible, built against a wall or fence that faces the     _south_, and thus insure its inmates against many cold winds,     driving rains, and sleets they will otherwise suffer.
10136-8{_}12410{_}Let the     floor of the house slope half an inch to the foot from back to     front, so as to insure drainage; let it also be close, hard, and     perfectly smooth; so that it may be cleanly swept out.
10136-8{_}12411{_}A capital     plan is to mix a few bushels of chalk and dry earth, spread it     over the floor, and pay a paviour's labourer a trifle to hammer     it level with his rammer.
10136-8{_}12412{_}The fowl-house should be seven feet     high, and furnished with perches at least two feet apart.
10136-8{_}12413{_}The     perches must be level, and not one above the other, or     unpleasant consequences may ensue to the undermost row.
10136-8{_}12414{_}The     perches should be ledged (not fixed--just dropped into sockets,     that they may be easily taken out and cleaned) not lower than     five feet from the ground, convenient slips of wood being driven     into the wall, to render the ascent as easy as possible.
10136-8{_}12415{_}The     front of the fowl-house should be latticed, taking care that the     interstices be not wide enough even to tempt a chick to crawl     through.
10136-8{_}12416{_}Nesting-boxes, containing soft hay, and fitted against     the walls, so as to be easily reached by the perch-ladder,     should be supplied.
10136-8{_}12417{_}It will be as well to keep by you a few     portable doors, so that you may hang one before the entrance to     a nesting-box, when the hen goes in to sit.
10136-8{_}12418{_}This will prevent     other hens from intruding, a habit to which some are much     addicted.
10136-8{_}12419{_}FRICASSEED FOWL OR CHICKEN (an Entree).
10136-8{_}12420{_}945.
10136-8{_}12421{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 small fowls or 1 large one, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}12422{_}of butter, a bunch of parsley and green onions, 1 clove, 2 blades of mace, 1 shalot, 1 bay-leaf, salt and white pepper to taste, 1/4 pint of cream, the yolks of 3 eggs.
10136-8{_}12423{_}_Mode_.--Choose a couple of fat plump chickens, and, after drawing, singeing, and washing them, skin, and carve them into joints; blanch these in boiling water for 2 or 3 minutes; take them out, and immerse them in cold water to render them white.
10136-8{_}12424{_}Put the trimmings, with the necks and legs, into a stewpan; add the parsley, onions, clove, mace, shalot, bay-leaf, and a seasoning of pepper and salt; pour to these the water that the chickens were blanched in, and simmer gently for rather more than 1 hour.
10136-8{_}12425{_}Have ready another stewpan; put in the joints of fowl, with the above proportion of butter; dredge them with flour, let them get hot, but do not brown them much; then moisten the fricassee with the gravy made from the trimmings, &c., and stew very gently for 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}12426{_}Lift the fowl into another stewpan, skim the sauce, reduce it quickly over the fire, by letting it boil fast, and strain it over them.
10136-8{_}12427{_}Add the cream, and a seasoning of pounded mace and cayenne; let it boil up, and when ready to serve, stir to it the well-beaten yolks of 3 eggs: these should not be put in till the last moment, and the sauce should be made _hot_, but must _not boil_, or it will instantly curdle.
10136-8{_}12428{_}A few button-mushrooms stewed with the fowl are by many persons considered an improvement.
10136-8{_}12429{_}_Time_.--1 hour to make the gravy, 1/2 hour to simmer the fowl.
10136-8{_}12430{_}_Average cost_, 5s.
10136-8{_}12431{_}the pair.
10136-8{_}12432{_}_Sufficient_.--1 large fowl for one entrée.
10136-8{_}12433{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}12434{_}STOCKING THE FOWL-HOUSE.--Take care that the birds with which     you stock your house are _young_.
10136-8{_}12435{_}The surest indications of old     age are fading of the comb and gills from brilliant red to a     dingy brick-colour, general paleness of plumage, brittleness of     the feathers, length and size of the claws, and the scales of     the legs and feet assuming a ragged and _corny_ appearance.
10136-8{_}12436{_}Your     cock and hens should be as near two years old as possible.
10136-8{_}12437{_}Hens     will lay at a year old, but the eggs are always insignificant in     size, and the layers giddy and unsteady sitters.
10136-8{_}12438{_}The hen-bird is     in her prime for breeding at three years old, and will continue     so, under favourable circumstances, for two years longer; after     which she will decline.
10136-8{_}12439{_}Crowing hens, and those that have large     combs, are generally looked on with mistrust; but this is mere     silliness and superstition--though it is possible that a spruce     young cock would as much object to a spouse with such peculiar     addictions, as a young fellow of our own species would to a     damsel who whistled and who wore whiskers.
10136-8{_}12440{_}Fowls with yellow     legs should be avoided; they are generally of a tender     constitution, loose-fleshed, and of indifferent flavour.
10136-8{_}12441{_}FRICASSEED FOWL (Cold Meat Cookery).
10136-8{_}12442{_}946.
10136-8{_}12443{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast fowl, 1 strip of lemon-peel, 1 blade of pounded mace, 1 bunch of savoury herbs, 1 onion, popper and salt to taste, 1 pint of water, 1 teaspoonful of flour, 1/4 pint of cream, the yolks of 2 eggs.
10136-8{_}12444{_}_Mode_.--Carve the fowls into nice joints; make gravy of the trimmings and legs, by stewing them with the lemon-peel, mace, herbs, onion, seasoning, and water, until reduced to 1/2 pint; then strain, and put in the fowl.
10136-8{_}12445{_}Warm it through, and thicken with a teaspoonful of flour; stir the yolks of the eggs into the cream; add these to the sauce, let it get thoroughly hot, but do not allow it to boil, or it will curdle.
10136-8{_}12446{_}_Time_.--1 hour to make the gravy, 1/4 hour to warm the fowl.
10136-8{_}12447{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the cold chicken, 8d.
10136-8{_}12448{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}12449{_}CHARACTERISTICS OF HEALTH AND POWER.--The chief characteristics     of health in a fowl are brightness and dryness of eye and     nostrils, the comb and wattles firm and ruddy, the feathers     elastic and glossy.
10136-8{_}12450{_}The most useful cock is generally the     greatest tyrant, who struts among his hens despotically, with     his head erect and his eyes ever watchful.
10136-8{_}12451{_}There is likely to be     handsomer and stronger chicks in a house where a bold,     active--even savage--bird reigns, than where the lord of the     hen-house is a weak, meek creature, who bears the abuse and     peckings of his wives without a remonstrance.
10136-8{_}12452{_}I much prefer     dark-coloured cock-birds to those of light plumage.
10136-8{_}12453{_}A cock, to     be handsome, should be of middling size; his bill should be     short, comb bright-red, wattles large, breast broad, and wings     strong.
10136-8{_}12454{_}His head should be rather small than otherwise, his legs     short and sturdy, and his spurs well-formed; his feathers should     be short and close, and the more frequently and heartily he     crows, the better father he is likely to become.
10136-8{_}12455{_}The common     error of choosing hens _above_ the ordinary stature of their     respective varieties should be avoided, as the best     breeding-hens are those of medium size.
10136-8{_}12456{_}FRIED FOWLS (Cold Meat Cookery).
10136-8{_}12457{_}I.
10136-8{_}12458{_}947.
10136-8{_}12459{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast fowls, vinegar, salt and cayenne to taste, 3 or 4 minced shalots.
10136-8{_}12460{_}For the batter,--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}12461{_}of flour, 1/2 pint of hot water, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}12462{_}of butter, the whites of 2 eggs.
10136-8{_}12463{_}_Mode_.--Cut the fowl into nice joints; steep them for an hour in a little vinegar, with salt, cayenne, and minced shalots.
10136-8{_}12464{_}Make the batter by mixing the flour and water smoothly together; melt in it the butter, and add the whites of egg beaten to a froth; take out the pieces of fowl, dip them in the batter, and fry, in boiling lard, a nice brown.
10136-8{_}12465{_}Pile them high in the dish, and garnish with fried parsley or rolled bacon.
10136-8{_}12466{_}When approved, a sauce or gravy may be served with them.
10136-8{_}12467{_}_Time_.--10 minutes to fry the fowl.
10136-8{_}12468{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the cold fowl, 8d.
10136-8{_}12469{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}12470{_}CHANTICLEER AND HIS COMPANIONS.--On bringing the male and female     birds together for the first time, it will be necessary to watch     the former closely, as it is a very common occurrence with him     to conceive a sudden and violent dislike for one or more of his     wives, and not allow the obnoxious ones to approach within some     distance of the others; indeed, I know many cases where the     capricious tyrant has set upon the innocent cause of his     resentment and killed her outright.
10136-8{_}12471{_}In all such cases, the hen     objected to should be removed and replaced by another.
10136-8{_}12472{_}If the     cock should, by any accident, get killed, considerable delicacy     is required in introducing a new one.
10136-8{_}12473{_}The hens may mope, and     refuse to associate with their new husband, clustering in     corners, and making odious comparisons between him and the     departed; or the cock may have his own peculiar notions as to     what a wife should be, and be by no means satisfied with those     you have provided him.
10136-8{_}12474{_}The plan is, to keep him by himself     nearly the whole day, supplying him plentifully with     exhilarating food, then to turn him loose among the hens, and to     continue this practice, allowing him more of the society of his     wives each day, until you suffer him to abide with them     altogether.
10136-8{_}12475{_}II.
10136-8{_}12476{_}948.
10136-8{_}12477{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast fowl, vinegar, salt and cayenne to taste, 4 minced shalots, yolk of egg; to every teacupful of bread crumbs allow 1 blade of pounded mace, 5 teaspoonful of minced lemon-peel, 1 saltspoonful of salt, a few grains of cayenne.
10136-8{_}12478{_}_Mode_.--Steep the pieces of fowl as in the preceding recipe, then dip them into the yolk of an egg or clarified butter; sprinkle over bread crumbs with which have been mixed salt, mace, cayenne, and lemon-peel in the above proportion.
10136-8{_}12479{_}Fry a light brown, and serve with or without gravy, as may be preferred.
10136-8{_}12480{_}_Time_.--10 minutes to fry the fowl.
10136-8{_}12481{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the cold fowl, 6d.
10136-8{_}12482{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}12483{_}VARIOUS MODES OF FATTENING FOWLS.--It would, I think, be a     difficult matter to find, among the entire fraternity of     fowl-keepers, a dozen whose mode of fattening "stock" is the     same.
10136-8{_}12484{_}Some say that the grand f secret is to give them abundance     of saccharine food; others say nothing beats heavy corn steeped     in milk; while another breeder, celebrated in his day, and the     recipient of a gold medal from a learned society, says, "The     best method is as follows:-The chickens are to be taken from the     hen the night after they are hatched, and fed with eggs     hard-boiled, chopped, and mixed with crumbs of bread, as larks     and other small birds are fed, for the first fortnight; after     which give them oatmeal and treacle mixed so as to crumble, of     which the chickens are very fond, and thrive so fast that, at     the end of two months, they will be as large as full-grown     fowls."
10136-8{_}12485{_}Others there are who insist that nothing beats     oleaginous diet, and cram their birds with ground oats and suet.
10136-8{_}12486{_}But, whatever the course of diet favoured, on one point they     seem agreed; and that is, that, while fattening, the fowls     _should be kept in the dark_.
10136-8{_}12487{_}Supposing the reader to be a     dealer--a breeder of gross chicken meat for the market (against     which supposition the chances are 10,000 to 1), and beset with     as few scruples as generally trouble the huckster, the advice is     valuable.
10136-8{_}12488{_}"Laugh and grow fat" is a good maxim enough; but     "Sleep and grow fat" is, as is well known to folks of porcine     attributes, a better.
10136-8{_}12489{_}The poor birds, immured in their dark     dungeons, ignorant that there is life and sunshine abroad, tuck     their heads under their wings and make a long night of it; while     their digestive organs, having no harder work than to pile up     fat, have an easy time enough.
10136-8{_}12490{_}But, unless we are mistaken, he     who breeds poultry for his own eating, bargains for a more     substantial reward than the questionable pleasure of burying his     carving-knife in chicken grease.
10136-8{_}12491{_}Tender, delicate, and     nutritious flesh is the great aim; and these qualities, I can     affirm without fear of contradiction, were never attained by a     dungeon-fatted chicken: perpetual gloom and darkness is as     incompatible with chicken life as it is with human.
10136-8{_}12492{_}If you wish     to be convinced of the absurdity of endeavouring to thwart     nature's laws, plant a tuft of grass, or a cabbage-plant, in the     darkest corner of your coal-cellar.
10136-8{_}12493{_}The plant or the tuft may     increase in length and breadth, but its colour will be as wan     and pale, almost, as would be your own face under the     circumstances.
10136-8{_}12494{_}POULET A LA MARENGO.
10136-8{_}12495{_}949.
10136-8{_}12496{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 large fowl, 4 tablespoonfuls of salad oil, 1 tablespoonful of flour, 1 pint of stock No.
10136-8{_}12497{_}105, or water, about 20 mushroom-buttons, salt and pepper to taste, 1 teaspoonful of powdered sugar, a very small piece of garlic.
10136-8{_}12498{_}_Mode_.--Cut the fowl into 8 or 10 pieces; put them with the oil into a stewpan, and brown them over a moderate fire; dredge in the above proportion of flour; when that is browned, pour in the stock or water; let it simmer very slowly for rather more than 1/2 hour, and skim off the fat as it rises to the top; add the mushrooms; season with salt, pepper, garlic, and sugar; take out the fowl, which arrange pyramidically on the dish, with the inferior joints at the bottom.
10136-8{_}12499{_}Reduce the sauce by boiling it quickly over the fire, keeping it stirred until sufficiently thick to adhere to the back of a spoon; pour over the fowl, and serve.
10136-8{_}12500{_}_Time_.--Altogether 50 minutes.
10136-8{_}12501{_}_Average cost_, 3s.
10136-8{_}12502{_}6d.
10136-8{_}12503{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 or 4 persons.
10136-8{_}12504{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}12505{_}A FOWL À LA MARENGO.--The following is the origin of the     well-known dish Poulet à la Marengo:--On the evening of the     battle the first consul was very hungry after the agitation of     the day, and a fowl was ordered with all expedition.
10136-8{_}12506{_}The fowl     was procured, but there was no butter at hand, and unluckily     none could be found in the neighbourhood.
10136-8{_}12507{_}There was oil in     abundance, however; and the cook having poured a certain     quantity into his skillet, put in the fowl, with a clove of     garlic and other seasoning, with a little white wine, the best     the country afforded; he then garnished it with mushrooms, and     served it up hot.
10136-8{_}12508{_}This dish proved the second conquest of the     day, as the first consul found it most agreeable to his palate,     and expressed his satisfaction.
10136-8{_}12509{_}Ever since, a fowl à la Marengo     is a favourite dish with all lovers of good cheer.
10136-8{_}12510{_}MINCED FOWL A LA BECHAMEL.
10136-8{_}12511{_}950.
10136-8{_}12512{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast fowl, 6 tablespoonfuls of Béchamel sauce No.
10136-8{_}12513{_}367, 6 tablespoonfuls of white stock No.
10136-8{_}12514{_}107, the white of 1 egg, bread crumbs, clarified butter.
10136-8{_}12515{_}_Mode_.--Take the remains of roast fowls, mince the white meat very small, and put it into a stewpan with the Béchamel and stock; stir it well over the fire, and just let it boil up.
10136-8{_}12516{_}Pour the mince into a dish, beat up the white of egg, spread it over, and strew on it a few grated bread crumbs; pour a very little clarified butter on the whole, and brown either before the fire or with a salamander.
10136-8{_}12517{_}This should be served in a silver dish, if at hand.
10136-8{_}12518{_}_Time_.--2 or 3 minutes to simmer in the sauce.
10136-8{_}12519{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}12520{_}THE BEST WAY TO FATTEN FOWLS.--The barn-door fowl is in itself a     complete refutation of the cramming and dungeon policy of     feeding practised by some.
10136-8{_}12521{_}This fowl, which has the common run     of the farm-yard, living on dairy-scraps and offal from the     stable, begins to grow fat at threshing-time.
10136-8{_}12522{_}He has his fill of     the finest corn; he has his fill of fresh air and natural     exercise, and at last he comes smoking to the table,--a dish     for the gods.
10136-8{_}12523{_}In the matter of unnaturally stuffing and     confining fowls, Mowbray is exactly of our opinion.
10136-8{_}12524{_}He says:     "The London chicken-butchers, as they are termed, are said to     be, of all others, the most expeditious and dexterous feeders,     putting up a coop of fowls, and making them thoroughly fat     within the space of a fortnight, using much grease, and that     perhaps not of the most delicate kind, in the food.
10136-8{_}12525{_}In this way     I have no boasts to make, having always found it necessary to     allow a considerable number of weeks for the purpose of making     fowls fat in coops.
10136-8{_}12526{_}In the common way this business is often     badly managed, fowls being huddled together in a small coop,     tearing each other to pieces, instead of enjoying that repose     which alone can insure, the wished-for object--irregularly fed     and cleaned, until they become so stenched and poisoned in their     own excrement, that their flesh actually smells and tastes when     smoking upon the table."
10136-8{_}12527{_}Sussex produces the fattest and largest     poultry of any county in England, and the fatting process there     most common is to give them a gruel made of pot-liquor and     bruised oats, with which are mixed hog's grease, sugar, and     milk.
10136-8{_}12528{_}The fowls are kept very warm, and crammed morning and     night.
10136-8{_}12529{_}They are put into the coop, and kept there two or three     days before the cramming begins, and then it is continued for a     fortnight, and the birds are sent to market.
10136-8{_}12530{_}RAGOUT OF FOWL.
10136-8{_}12531{_}951.
10136-8{_}12532{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast fowls, 3 shalots, 2 blades of mace, a faggot of savoury herbs, 2 or three slices of lean ham, 1 pint of stock or water, pepper and salt to taste, 1 onion, 1 dessertspoonful of flour, 1 tablespoonful of lemon-juice, 1/2 teaspoonful of pounded sugar, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}12533{_}of butter.
10136-8{_}12534{_}_Mode_.--Cut the fowls up into neat pieces, the same as for a fricassee; put the trimmings into a stewpan with the shalots, mace, herbs, ham, onion, and stock (water may be substituted for this).
10136-8{_}12535{_}Boil it slowly for 1 hour, strain the liquor, and put a small piece of butter into a stewpan; when melted, dredge in sufficient flour to dry up the butter, and stir it over the fire.
10136-8{_}12536{_}Put in the strained liquor, boil for a few minutes, and strain it again over the pieces of fowl.
10136-8{_}12537{_}Squeeze in the lemon-juice, add the sugar and a seasoning of pepper and salt, make it hot, but do not allow it to boil; lay the fowl neatly on the dish, and garnish with croûtons.
10136-8{_}12538{_}_Time_.--Altogether 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}12539{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the cold fowl, 9d.
10136-8{_}12540{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}12541{_}THE BEST FOWLS TO FATTEN, &c.--The chicks most likely to fatten     well are those first hatched in the brood, and those with the     shortest legs.
10136-8{_}12542{_}Long-legged fowls, as a rule, are by far the most     difficult to fatten.
10136-8{_}12543{_}The most delicate sort are those which are     put up to fatten as soon as the hen forsakes them; for, as says     an old writer, "then they will be in fine condition, and full of     flesh, which flesh is afterwards expended in the exercise of     foraging for food, and in the increase of stature; and it may be     a work of some weeks to recover it,--especially with young     cocks."
10136-8{_}12544{_}But whether you take them in hand as chicks, or not till     they are older, the three prime rules to be observed are, sound     and various food, warmth, and cleanliness.
10136-8{_}12545{_}There is nothing that     a fatting fowl grows so fastidious about as his water.
10136-8{_}12546{_}If water     any way foul be offered him, he will not drink it, but sulk with     his food, and pine, and you all the while wondering the reason     why.
10136-8{_}12547{_}Keep them separate, allowing to each bird as much space as     you can spare.
10136-8{_}12548{_}Spread the ground with sharp sandy gravel; take     care that they are not disturbed.
10136-8{_}12549{_}In addition to their regular     diet of good corn, make them a cake of ground oats or beans,     brown sugar, milk, and mutton suet.
10136-8{_}12550{_}Let the cake lie till it is     stale, then crumble it, and give each bird a gill-measureful     morning and evening.
10136-8{_}12551{_}No entire grain should be given to fowls     during the time they are fattening; indeed, the secret of     success lies in supplying them with the most nutritious food     without stint, and in such a form that their digestive mills     shall find no difficulty in grinding it.
10136-8{_}12552{_}[Illustration: ROAST FOWL.]
10136-8{_}12553{_}ROAST FOWLS.
10136-8{_}12554{_}952.
10136-8{_}12555{_}INGREDIENTS.--A pair of fowls; a little flour.
10136-8{_}12556{_}_Mode_.--Fowls to be tender should be killed a couple of days before they are dressed; when the feathers come out easily, then let them be picked and cooked.
10136-8{_}12557{_}In drawing them, be careful not to break the gall-bag, as, wherever it touches, it would impart a very bitter taste; the liver and gizzard should also be preserved.
10136-8{_}12558{_}Truss them in the following manner:--After having carefully picked them, cut off the head, and skewer the skin of the neck down over the back.
10136-8{_}12559{_}Cut off the claws; dip the legs in boiling water, and scrape them; turn the pinions under, run a skewer through them and the middle of the legs, which should be passed through the body to the pinion and leg on the other side, one skewer securing the limbs on both sides.
10136-8{_}12560{_}The liver and gizzard should be placed in the wings, the liver on one side and the gizzard on the other.
10136-8{_}12561{_}Tie the legs together by passing a trussing-needle, threaded with twine, through the backbone, and secure it on the other side.
10136-8{_}12562{_}If trussed like a capon, the legs are placed more apart.
10136-8{_}12563{_}When firmly trussed, singe them all over; put them down to a bright clear fire, paper the breasts with a sheet of buttered paper, and keep the fowls well basted.
10136-8{_}12564{_}Roast them for 3/4 hour, more or less, according to the size, and 10 minutes before serving, remove the paper, dredge the fowls with a little fine flour, put a piece of butter into the basting-ladle, and as it melts, baste the fowls with it; when nicely frothed and of a rich colour, serve with good brown gravy, a little of which should be poured over the fowls, and a tureen of well-made bread sauce, No.
10136-8{_}12565{_}371.
10136-8{_}12566{_}Mushroom, oyster, or egg sauce are very suitable accompaniments to roast fowl.--Chicken is roasted in the same manner.
10136-8{_}12567{_}_Time_.--A very large fowl, quite 1 hour, medium-sized one 3/4 hour, chicken 1/2 hour, or rather longer.
10136-8{_}12568{_}_Average cost_, in full season, 5s.
10136-8{_}12569{_}a pair; when scarce, 7s.
10136-8{_}12570{_}6d.
10136-8{_}12571{_}the pair.
10136-8{_}12572{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 or 7 persons.
10136-8{_}12573{_}_Seasonable_ all the year, but scarce in early spring.
10136-8{_}12574{_}THE DISEASES OF FOWLS, AND HOW TO CURE THEM.--The diseases to     which _Gallus domesticus_ is chiefly liable, are roup, pip,     scouring, and chip.
10136-8{_}12575{_}The first-mentioned is the most common of     all, and results from cold.
10136-8{_}12576{_}The ordinary symptoms,--swollen     eyes, running at the nostrils, and the purple colour of the     wattles.
10136-8{_}12577{_}Part birds so affected from the healthy ones, as, when     the disease is at its height it is as contagious as glanders     among horses.
10136-8{_}12578{_}Wash out the nostrils with warm water, give daily     a peppercorn inclosed in dough; bathe the eyes and nostrils with     warm milk and water.
10136-8{_}12579{_}If the head is much swollen, bathe with     warm brandy and water.
10136-8{_}12580{_}When the bird is getting well, put half a     spoonful of sulphur in his drinking-water.
10136-8{_}12581{_}Some fanciers     prescribe for this disease half a spoonful of table salt,     dissolved in half a gill of water, in which rue has been     steeped; others, pills composed of ground rice and fresh butter:     but the remedy first mentioned will be found far the best.
10136-8{_}12582{_}As     there is a doubt respecting the wholesomeness of the eggs laid     by roupy hens, it will be as well to throw them away.
10136-8{_}12583{_}The pip is     a white horny skin growing on the tip of the bird's tongue.
10136-8{_}12584{_}It     should be removed with the point of a penknife, and the place     rubbed with salt.
10136-8{_}12585{_}FOWL AND RICE CROQUETTES (an Entree).
10136-8{_}12586{_}953.
10136-8{_}12587{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}12588{_}of rice, 1 quart of stock or broth, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}12589{_}of butter, minced fowl, egg, and bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}12590{_}_Mode_.--Put the rice into the above proportion of cold stock or broth, and let it boil very gently for 1/2 hour; then add the butter, and simmer it till quite dry and soft When cold, make it into balls, hollow out the inside, and fill with minced fowl made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}12591{_}956.
10136-8{_}12592{_}The mince should be rather thick.
10136-8{_}12593{_}Cover over with rice, dip the balls into egg, sprinkle them with bread crumbs, and fry a nice brown.
10136-8{_}12594{_}Dish them, and garnish with fried parsley.
10136-8{_}12595{_}Oysters, white sauce, or a little cream, may be stirred into the rice before it cools.
10136-8{_}12596{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour to boil the rice, 10 minutes to fry the croquettes.
10136-8{_}12597{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the fowl, 8d.
10136-8{_}12598{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}12599{_}CHIP.--If the birds are allowed to puddle about on wet soil, or     to be much out in the rain, they will get "chip."
10136-8{_}12600{_}Young chicks     are especially liable to this complaint.
10136-8{_}12601{_}They will sit shivering     in out-of-the-way corners, perpetually uttering a dolorous     "chip, chip;" seemingly frozen with cold, though, on handling     them, they are found to be in high fever.
10136-8{_}12602{_}A wholesale breeder     would take no pains to attempt the cure of fowls so afflicted;     but they who keep chickens for the pleasure, and not for the     profit they yield, will be inclined to recover them if possible.
10136-8{_}12603{_}Give them none but warm food, half a peppercorn rolled in a     morsel of dough every night, and a little nitre in their water.
10136-8{_}12604{_}Above all, keep them warm; a corner in the kitchen fender, for a     day or two, will do more to effect a cure than the run of a     druggist's warehouse.
10136-8{_}12605{_}CROQUETTES OF FOWL (an Entree).
10136-8{_}12606{_}954.
10136-8{_}12607{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 or 4 shalots, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}12608{_}of butter, 1 teaspoonful of flour, white sauce; pepper, salt, and pounded mace to taste; 1/2 teaspoonful of pounded sugar, the remains of cold roast fowls, the yolks of 2 eggs, egg, and bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}12609{_}_Mode_.--Mince the fowl, carefully removing all skin and bone, and fry the shalots in the butter; add the minced fowl, dredge in the flour, put in the pepper, salt, mace, pounded sugar, and sufficient white sauce to moisten it; stir to it the yolks of 2 well-beaten eggs, and set it by to cool.
10136-8{_}12610{_}Then make the mixture up into balls, egg and bread-crumb them, and fry a nice brown.
10136-8{_}12611{_}They may be served on a border of mashed potatoes, with gravy or sauce in the centre.
10136-8{_}12612{_}_Time_.--10 minutes to fry the balls.
10136-8{_}12613{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}12614{_}THE TURN.--What is termed "turrling" with song-birds, is known,     as regard fowls, as the "turn."
10136-8{_}12615{_}Its origin is the same in both     cases,--over-feeing and want of exercise.
10136-8{_}12616{_}Without a moment's     warning, a fowl so afflicted will totter and fall from its     perch, and unless assistance be at hand, speedily give up the     ghost.
10136-8{_}12617{_}The veins of the palate should be opened, and a few drops     of mixture composed of six parts of sweet nitre and one of     ammonia, poured down its throat.
10136-8{_}12618{_}I have seen ignorant keepers     plunge a bird, stricken with the "turn," into cold water; but I     never saw it taken out again alive; and for a good reason: the     sudden chill has the effect of driving the blood to the     head,--of aggravating the disease indeed, instead of relieving     it.
10136-8{_}12619{_}HASHED FOWL--an Entree (Cold Meat Cookery).
10136-8{_}12620{_}955.
10136-8{_}12621{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast fowl, 1 pint of water, 1 onion, 2 or three small carrots, 1 blade of pounded mace, pepper and salt to taste, 1 small bunch of savoury herbs, thickening of butter and flour, 1-1/2 tablespoonful of mushroom ketchup.
10136-8{_}12622{_}_Mode_.--Cut off the best joints from the fowl, and the remainder make into gravy, by adding to the bones and trimmings a pint of water, an onion sliced and fried of a nice brown, the carrots, mace, seasoning, and herbs.
10136-8{_}12623{_}Let these stew gently for 1-1/2 hour, strain the liquor, and thicken with a little flour and butter.
10136-8{_}12624{_}Lay in the fowl, thoroughly warm it through, add the ketchup, and garnish with sippets of toasted bread.
10136-8{_}12625{_}_Time_.--Altogether 1-3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}12626{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the cold fowl, 4d.
10136-8{_}12627{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}12628{_}SKIN-DISEASE IN FOWLS.--Skin-disease is, nine times out of ten,     caused by the feathers being swarmed by parasites.
10136-8{_}12629{_}Poor feeding     will induce this, even if cleanliness be observed;     uncleanliness, however liberal the bill of fare, will be taken     as an invitation by the little biting pests, and heartily     responded to.
10136-8{_}12630{_}Mix half a teaspoonful of hydro-oxalic acid with     twelve teaspoonfuls of water,--apply to the itching parts with     an old shaving-brush.
10136-8{_}12631{_}OBSTRUCTION OF THE CROP.--Obstruction of the crop is occasioned     by weakness or greediness.
10136-8{_}12632{_}You may know when a bird is so     afflicted by his crop being distended almost to bursting.
10136-8{_}12633{_}Mowbray tells of a hen of his in this predicament; when the crop     was opened, a quantity of new beans were discovered in a state     of vegetation.
10136-8{_}12634{_}The crop should be slit from the _bottom_ to the     _top_ with a sharp pair of scissors, the contents taken out, and     the slit sewed up again with line white thread.
10136-8{_}12635{_}MINCED FOWL--an Entree (Cold Meat Cookery).
10136-8{_}12636{_}956.
10136-8{_}12637{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast fowl, 2 hard-boiled eggs, salt, cayenne, and pounded mace, 1 onion, 1 faggot of savoury herbs, 6 tablespoonfuls of cream, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}12638{_}of butter, two teaspoonfuls of flour, 1/2 teaspoonful of finely-minced lemon-peel, 1 tablespoonful of lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}12639{_}_Mode_.--Cut out from the fowl all the white meat, and mince it finely without any skin or bone; put the bones, skin, and trimmings into a stewpan with an onion, a bunch of savoury herbs, a blade of mace, and nearly a pint of water; let this stew for an hour, then strain the liquor.
10136-8{_}12640{_}Chop the eggs small; mix them with the fowl; add salt, cayenne, and pounded mace, put in the gravy and remaining ingredients; let the whole just boil, and serve with sippets of toasted bread.
10136-8{_}12641{_}_Time_.--Rather more than 1 hour.
10136-8{_}12642{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the fowl, 8d.
10136-8{_}12643{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}12644{_}_Note_.--Another way to make this is to mince the fowl, and warm it in white sauce or Béchamel.
10136-8{_}12645{_}When dressed like this, 3 or 4 poached eggs may be placed on the top: oysters, or chopped mushrooms, or balls of oyster forcemeat, may be laid round the dish.
10136-8{_}12646{_}THE MOULTING SEASON.--During the moulting season beginning     properly at the end of September, the fowls will require a     little extra attention.
10136-8{_}12647{_}Keep them dry and warm, and feed them     liberally on warm and satisfying food.
10136-8{_}12648{_}If in any fowl the moult     should seem protracted, examine it for broken feather-stumps     still beaded in the skin: if you find any, extract them     carefully with a pair of tweezers.
10136-8{_}12649{_}If a fowl is hearty and     strong, six weeks will see him out of his trouble; if he is     weakly, or should take cold during the time, he will not     thoroughly recover in less than three months.
10136-8{_}12650{_}It is seldom or     ever that hens will lay during the moult; while the cock, during     the same period, will give so little of his consideration to the     frivolities of love, that you may as well, nay, much better,     keep him by himself till he perfectly recovers.
10136-8{_}12651{_}A moulting     chicken makes but a sorry dish.
10136-8{_}12652{_}HASHED FOWL, Indian Fashion (an Entree).
10136-8{_}12653{_}957.--INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast fowl, 3 or 4 sliced onions, 1 apple, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}12654{_}of butter, pounded mace, pepper and salt to taste, 1 tablespoonful of curry-powder, 2 tablespoonfuls of vinegar, 1 tablespoonful of flour, 1 teaspoonful of pounded sugar, 1 pint of gravy.
10136-8{_}12655{_}_Mode_.--Cut the onions into slices, mince the apple, and fry these in the butter; add pounded mace, pepper, salt, curry-powder, vinegar, flour, and sugar in the above proportions; when the onion is brown, put it the gravy, which should be previously made from the bones and trimmings of the fowls, and stew for 3/4 hour; add the fowl cut into nice-sized joints, let it warm through, and when quite tender, serve.
10136-8{_}12656{_}The dish should be garnished with au edging of boiled rice.
10136-8{_}12657{_}_Time_.--1 hour.
10136-8{_}12658{_}Average cost, exclusive of the fowl, 8d.
10136-8{_}12659{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}12660{_}THE SCOUR OR DYSENTERY.--The scour, or dysentery, or diarrhoea,     is induced variously.
10136-8{_}12661{_}A sudden alteration in diet will cause it,     as will a superabundance of green food.
10136-8{_}12662{_}The best remedy is a     piece of toasted biscuit sopped in ale.
10136-8{_}12663{_}If the disease has too     tight a hold on the bird to be quelled by this, give six drops     of syrup of white poppies and six drops of castor-oil, mixed     with a little oatmeal or ground rice.
10136-8{_}12664{_}Restrict the bird's diet,     for a few days, to dry food,--crushed beans or oats, stale     bread-crumbs, &c.      FOWL SCOLLOPS (Cold Meat Cookery).
10136-8{_}12665{_}958.
10136-8{_}12666{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast or boiled fowl, 1/2     pint of Béchamel, No.
10136-8{_}12667{_}367, or white sauce, No.
10136-8{_}12668{_}537 or 539.
10136-8{_}12669{_}_Mode_.--Strip off the skin from the fowl; cut the meat into     thin slices, and warm them in about 1/2 pint, or rather more, of     Béchamel, or white sauce.
10136-8{_}12670{_}When quite hot, serve, and garnish the     dish with rolled ham or bacon toasted.
10136-8{_}12671{_}_Time_.--1 minute to simmer the slices of fowl.
10136-8{_}12672{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}12673{_}[Illustration: THE FEATHER LEGGED BANTAM.]
10136-8{_}12674{_}THE FEATHER LEGGED BANTAM.--Since the introduction of the Bantam     into Europe, it has ramified into many varieties, none of which     are destitute of elegance, and some, indeed, remarkable for     their beauty.
10136-8{_}12675{_}All are, or ought to be, of small size, but lively     and vigorous, exhibiting in their movements both grace and     stateliness.
10136-8{_}12676{_}The variety shown in the engraving is remarkable     for the _tarsi_, or beams of the legs, being plumed to the toes,     with stiff, long feathers, which brush the ground.
10136-8{_}12677{_}Owing,     possibly, to the little care taken to preserve this variety from     admixture, it is now not frequently seen.
10136-8{_}12678{_}Another variety is     often red, with a black breast and single dentated comb.
10136-8{_}12679{_}The     _tarsi_ are smooth, and of a dusky blue.
10136-8{_}12680{_}When this sort of     Bantam is pure, it yields in courage and spirit to none, and is,     in fact, a game-fowl in miniature, being as beautiful and     graceful as it is spirited.
10136-8{_}12681{_}A pure white Bantam, possessing all     the qualifications just named, is also bred in the royal aviary     at Windsor.
10136-8{_}12682{_}AN INDIAN DISH OF FOWL (an Entree).
10136-8{_}12683{_}959.
10136-8{_}12684{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast fowl, 3 or 4 sliced onions, 1 tablespoonful of curry-powder, salt to taste.
10136-8{_}12685{_}_Mode_.--Divide the fowl into joints; slice and fry the onions in a little butter, taking care not to burn them; sprinkle over the fowl a little curry-powder and salt; fry these nicely, pile them high in the centre of the dish, cover with the onion, and serve with a cut lemon on a plate.
10136-8{_}12686{_}Care must be taken that the onions are not greasy: they should be quite dry, but not burnt.
10136-8{_}12687{_}_Time_.--5 minutes to fry the onions, 10 minutes to fry the fowl.
10136-8{_}12688{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the fowl, 4d.
10136-8{_}12689{_}_Seasonable_ during the winter month.
10136-8{_}12690{_}[Illustration: SPECKLED HAMBURGS.]
10136-8{_}12691{_}THE SPECKLED HAMBURG.--Of the speckled, or spangled Hamburg     which is a favourite breed with many persons, there are two     varieties,--the golden-speckled and the silver-speckled.
10136-8{_}12692{_}The     general colour of the former is golden, or orange-yellow, each     feather having a glossy dark brown or black tip, particularly     remarkable on the hackles of the cock and the wing-coverts, and     also on the darker feathers of the breast.
10136-8{_}12693{_}The female is yellow,     or orange-brown, the feathers in like manner being margined with     black.
10136-8{_}12694{_}The silver-speckled variety is distinguished by the     ground-colour of the plumage being of a silver-white, with     perhaps a tinge of straw-yellow, every leather being margined     with a semi-lunar mark of glossy black.
10136-8{_}12695{_}Both of these varieties     are extremely beautiful, the hens laying freely.
10136-8{_}12696{_}First-rate     birds command a high price.
10136-8{_}12697{_}FOWL SAUTE WITH PEAS (an Entree).
10136-8{_}12698{_}960.
10136-8{_}12699{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast fowl, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}12700{_}of butter, pepper, salt, and pounded mace to taste, 1 dessertspoonful of flour, 1/2 pint of weak stock, 1 pint of green peas, 1 teaspoonful of pounded sugar.
10136-8{_}12701{_}_Mode_.--Cut the fowl into nice pieces; put the butter into a stew-pan; sautez or fry the fowl a nice brown colour, previously sprinkling it with pepper, salt, and pounded mace.
10136-8{_}12702{_}Dredge in the flour, shake the ingredients well round, then add the stock and peas, and stew till the latter are tender, which will be in about 20 minutes; put in the pounded sugar, and serve, placing the chicken round, and the peas in the middle of the dish.
10136-8{_}12703{_}When liked, mushrooms may be substituted for the peas.
10136-8{_}12704{_}_Time_.--Altogether 40 minutes.
10136-8{_}12705{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the fowl, 7d.
10136-8{_}12706{_}_Seasonable_ from June to August.
10136-8{_}12707{_}BOUDIN A LA REINE (an Entree).
10136-8{_}12708{_}(M. Ude's Recipe.)
10136-8{_}12709{_}961.
10136-8{_}12710{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast fowls, 1 pint of Béchamel No.
10136-8{_}12711{_}367, salt and cayenne to taste, egg and bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}12712{_}_Mode_.--Take the breasts and nice white meat from the fowls; cut it into small dice of an equal size, and throw them into some good Béchamel, made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}12713{_}367; season with salt and cayenne, and put the mixture into a dish to cool.
10136-8{_}12714{_}When this preparation is quite cold, cut it into 2 equal parts, which should be made into _boudins_ of a long shape, the size of the dish they are intended to be served on; roll them in flour, egg and bread-crumb them, and be careful that the ends are well covered with the crumbs, otherwise they would break in the frying-pan; fry them a nice colour, put them before the fire to drain the greasy moisture from them, and serve with the remainder of the Béchamel poured round: this should be thinned with a little stock.
10136-8{_}12715{_}_Time_.--10 minutes to fry the boudins.
10136-8{_}12716{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the fowl, 1s.
10136-8{_}12717{_}3d.
10136-8{_}12718{_}_Sufficient_ for 1 entrée.
10136-8{_}12719{_}[Illustration: SEBRIGHT BANTAMS.]
10136-8{_}12720{_}SIR JOHN SEBRIGHT'S BANTAMS.--Above all Bantams is placed, the     celebrated and beautiful breed called Sir John Sebright's Silver     Bantams.
10136-8{_}12721{_}This breed, which Sir John brought to perfection after     years of careful trials, is very small, with un-feathered legs,     and a rose comb and short hackles.
10136-8{_}12722{_}The plumage is gold or     silver, spangled, every feather being of a golden orange, or of     a silver white, with a glossy jet-black margin; the cocks have     the tail folded like that of a hen, with the sickle feathers     shortened straight, or nearly so, and broader than usual.
10136-8{_}12723{_}The     term _hen-cocks_ is, in consequence, often applied to them; but     although the sickle feathers are thus modified, no bird     possesses higher courage, or a more gallant carriage.
10136-8{_}12724{_}The     attitude of the cock is, indeed, singularly proud; and he is     often seen to bear himself so haughtily, that his head, thrown     back as if in disdain, nearly touches the two upper     feathers--sickles they can scarcely be called--of his tail.
10136-8{_}12725{_}Half-bred birds of this kind are not uncommon, but birds of the     pure breed are not to be obtained without trouble and expense;     indeed, some time ago, it was almost impossible to procure     either a fowl or an egg.
10136-8{_}12726{_}"The finest," says the writer whom we     have consulted as to this breed, "we have ever seen, were in Sir     John's poultry-yard, adjacent to Turnham-Green Common, in the     byroad leading to Acton."
10136-8{_}12727{_}FOWL A LA MAYONNAISE.
10136-8{_}12728{_}962.
10136-8{_}12729{_}INGREDIENTS.--A cold roast fowl, Mayonnaise sauce No.
10136-8{_}12730{_}468, 4 or 5 young lettuces, 4 hard-boiled eggs, a few water-cresses, endive.
10136-8{_}12731{_}_Mode_.--Cut the fowl into neat joints, lay them in a deep dish, piling them high in the centre, sauce the fowl with Mayonnaise made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}12732{_}468, and garnish the dish with young lettuces cut in halves, water-cresses, endive, and hard-boiled eggs: these may be sliced in rings, or laid on the dish whole, cutting off at the bottom a piece of the white, to make the egg stand.
10136-8{_}12733{_}All kinds of cold meat and solid fish may be dressed à la Mayonnaise, and make excellent luncheon or supper dishes.
10136-8{_}12734{_}The sauce should not be poured over the fowls until the moment of serving.
10136-8{_}12735{_}Should a very large Mayonnaise be required, use 2 fowls instead of 1, with an equal proportion of the remaining ingredients.
10136-8{_}12736{_}_Average cost_, with one fowl, 3s.
10136-8{_}12737{_}6d.
10136-8{_}12738{_}_Sufficient_ for a moderate-sized dish.
10136-8{_}12739{_}_Seasonable_ from April to September.
10136-8{_}12740{_}[Illustration: BLACK SPANISH.]
10136-8{_}12741{_}BLACK SPANISH.--The real Spanish fowl is recognized by its     uniformly black colour burnished with tints of green; its     peculiar white face, and the large development of its comb and     wattle.
10136-8{_}12742{_}The hens are excellent layers, and their eggs are of a     very large size.
10136-8{_}12743{_}They are, however, bad nurses; consequently,     their eggs should be laid in the nest of other varieties to be     hatched.
10136-8{_}12744{_}"In purchasing Spanish," says an authority, "blue legs,     the entire absence of white or coloured feathers in the plumage,     and a large, white face, with a very large high comb, which     should be erect in the cock, though pendent in the hens, should     be insisted on."
10136-8{_}12745{_}The flesh of this fowl is esteemed; but, from     the smallness of its body when compared with that of the     Dorking, it is not placed on an equality with it for the table.
10136-8{_}12746{_}Otherwise, however, they are profitable birds, and their     handsome carriage, and striking contrast of colour in the comb,     face, and plumage, are a high recommendation to them as kept     fowls.
10136-8{_}12747{_}For a town fowl, they are perhaps better adapted than any     other variety.
10136-8{_}12748{_}FOWL PILLAU, based on M. Soyer's Recipe (an Indian Dish).
10136-8{_}12749{_}963.
10136-8{_}12750{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}12751{_}of rice, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}12752{_}of butter, a fowl, 2 quarts of stock or good broth, 40 cardamum-seeds, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}12753{_}of coriander-seed, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}12754{_}of cloves, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}12755{_}of allspice, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}12756{_}of mace, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}12757{_}of cinnamon, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}12758{_}of peppercorns, 4 onions, 6 thin slices of bacon, 2 hard-boiled eggs.
10136-8{_}12759{_}_Mode_.--Well wash 1 lb.
