10136-8{_}12760{_}of the best Patna rice, put it into a frying-pan with the butter, which keep moving over a slow fire until the rice is lightly browned.
10136-8{_}12761{_}Truss the fowl as for boiling, put it into a stewpan with the stock or broth; pound the spices and seeds thoroughly in a mortar, tie them in a piece of muslin, and put them in with the fowl.
10136-8{_}12762{_}Let it boil slowly until it is nearly done; then add the rice, which should stew until quite tender and almost dry; cut the onions into slices, sprinkle them with flour, and fry, without breaking them, of a nice brown colour.
10136-8{_}12763{_}Have ready the slices of bacon curled and grilled, and the eggs boiled hard.
10136-8{_}12764{_}Lay the fowl in the form of a pyramid upon a dish, smother with the rice, garnish with the bacon, fried onions, and the hard-boiled eggs cut into quarters, and serve very hot.
10136-8{_}12765{_}Before taking the rice out, remove the spices.
10136-8{_}12766{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour to stew the fowl without the rice; 1/2 hour with it.
10136-8{_}12767{_}_Average cost_, 4s.
10136-8{_}12768{_}3d.
10136-8{_}12769{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}12770{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}12771{_}[Illustration: SULTANS.]
10136-8{_}12772{_}THE SERAI TA-OOK, OR FOWLS OF THE SULTAN.--This fowl is the size     of our English Polands, and is the latest species introduced to     England.
10136-8{_}12773{_}They have a white and flowing plumage, a full-sized,     compact Poland tuft on the head, are muffed, have a full flowing     tail, short legs well feathered, and five toes upon each foot.
10136-8{_}12774{_}Their comb consists merely of two little points, and their     wattles are very small: their colour is that of a pure white.
10136-8{_}12775{_}In     January, 1854, they arrived in this country from Constantinople;     and they take their name from _sarai_, the Turkish word for     sultan's palace, and _ta-ook_, the Turkish for fowl.
10136-8{_}12776{_}They are     thus called the "fowls of the sultan," a name which has the     twofold advantage of being the nearest to be found to that by     which they have been known in their own country, and of     designating the country whence they come.
10136-8{_}12777{_}Their habits are     described as being generally brisk and happy-tempered, but not     so easily kept in as Cochin-Chinas.
10136-8{_}12778{_}They are excellent layers;     but they are non-sitters and small eaters: their eggs are large     and white.
10136-8{_}12779{_}Brahmas or Cochins will clear the crop of a grass-run     long before they will, and, with scattered food, they soon     satisfy themselves and walk away.
10136-8{_}12780{_}POULET AUX CRESSONS.
10136-8{_}12781{_}964.
10136-8{_}12782{_}INGREDIENTS.--A fowl, a large bunch of water-cresses, 3 tablespoonfuls of vinegar, 1/4 pint of gravy.
10136-8{_}12783{_}_Mode_.--Truss and roast a fowl by recipe No.
10136-8{_}12784{_}952, taking care that it is nicely frothed and brown.
10136-8{_}12785{_}Wash and dry the water-cresses, pick them nicely, and arrange them in a flat layer on a dish.
10136-8{_}12786{_}Sprinkle over a little salt and the above proportion of vinegar; place over these the fowl, and pour over it the gravy.
10136-8{_}12787{_}A little gravy should be served in a tureen.
10136-8{_}12788{_}When not liked, the vinegar may be omitted.
10136-8{_}12789{_}_Time_.--From 1/2 to 1 hour, according to size.
10136-8{_}12790{_}_Average cost_, in full season, 2s.
10136-8{_}12791{_}6d.
10136-8{_}12792{_}each.

10136-8{_}12795{_}ROAST FOWL, Stuffed.
10136-8{_}12796{_}965.
10136-8{_}12797{_}INGREDIENTS.--A large fowl, forcemeat No.
10136-8{_}12798{_}417, a little flour.
10136-8{_}12799{_}_Mode_.--Select a large plump fowl, fill the breast with forcemeat, made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}12800{_}417, truss it firmly, the same as for a plain roast fowl, dredge it with flour, and put it down to a bright fire.
10136-8{_}12801{_}Roast it for nearly or quite an hour, should it be very large; remove the skewers, and serve with a good brown gravy and a tureen of bread sauce.
10136-8{_}12802{_}_Time_.--Large fowl, nearly or quite 1 hour.
10136-8{_}12803{_}_Average cost_, in full season, 2s.
10136-8{_}12804{_}6d.
10136-8{_}12805{_}each.
10136-8{_}12806{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}12807{_}_Seasonable_ all the year, but scarce in early spring.
10136-8{_}12808{_}_Note_.--Sausage-meat stuffing may be substituted for the above: this is now a very general mode of serving fowl.
10136-8{_}12809{_}[Illustration: PENCILLED HAMBURG.]
10136-8{_}12810{_}PENCILLED HAMBURG.--This variety of the Hamburg fowl is of two     colours, golden and silver, and is very minutely marked.
10136-8{_}12811{_}The     hens of both should have the body clearly pencilled across with     several bars of black, and the hackle in both, sexes should be     perfectly free from dark marks.
10136-8{_}12812{_}The cocks do not exhibit the     pencillings, but are white or brown in the golden or silver     birds respectively.
10136-8{_}12813{_}Their form is compact, and their attitudes     graceful and sprightly.
10136-8{_}12814{_}The hens do not sit, but lay extremely     well; hence one of their common names, that of Dutch every-day     layers.
10136-8{_}12815{_}They are also known in different parts of the country,     as Chitteprats, Creoles, or Corals, Bolton bays and grays, and,     in some parts of Yorkshire, by the wrong name of Corsican fowls.
10136-8{_}12816{_}They are imported in large numbers from Holland, but those bred     in this country are greatly superior in size.
10136-8{_}12817{_}GIBLET PIE.
10136-8{_}12818{_}966.
10136-8{_}12819{_}INGREDIENTS.--A set of duck or goose giblets, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}12820{_}of rump-steak, 1 onion, 1/2 teaspoonful of whole black pepper, a bunch of savoury herbs, plain crust.
10136-8{_}12821{_}_Mode_.--Clean, and put the giblets into a stewpan with an onion, whole pepper, and a bunch of savoury herbs; add rather more than a pint of water, and simmer gently for about 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}12822{_}Take them out, let them cool, and cut them into pieces; line the bottom of a pie-dish with a few pieces of rump-steak; add a layer of giblets and a few more pieces of steak; season with pepper and salt, and pour in the gravy (which should be strained), that the giblets were stewed in; cover with a plain crust, and bake for rather more than 1-1/2 hour in a brisk oven.
10136-8{_}12823{_}Cover a piece of paper over the pie, to prevent the crust taking too much colour.
10136-8{_}12824{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 hour to stew the giblets, about 1 hour to bake the pie.
10136-8{_}12825{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the giblets, 1s.
10136-8{_}12826{_}4d.
10136-8{_}12827{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}12828{_}THE BRENT GOOSE.--This is the smallest and most numerous species     of the geese which visit the British islands.
10136-8{_}12829{_}It makes its     appearance in winter, and ranges over the whole of the coasts     and estuaries frequented by other migrant geese.
10136-8{_}12830{_}Mr. Selby     states that a very large body of these birds annually resort to     the extensive sandy and muddy flats which lie between the     mainland and Holy Island, on the Northumbrian coast, and which     are covered by every flow of the tide.
10136-8{_}12831{_}This part of the coast     appears to have been a favourite resort of these birds from time     immemorial, where they have always received the name of Ware     geese, no doubt from their continually feeding on marine     vegetables.
10136-8{_}12832{_}Their flesh is very agreeable.
10136-8{_}12833{_}HASHED GOOSE.
10136-8{_}12834{_}967.
10136-8{_}12835{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast goose, 2 onions, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}12836{_}of butter, 1 pint of boiling water, 1 dessertspoonful of flour, pepper and salt to taste, 1 tablespoonful of port wine, 2 tablespoonfuls of mushroom ketchup.
10136-8{_}12837{_}_Mode_.--Cut up the goose into pieces of the size required; the inferior joints, trimmings, &c., put into a stewpan to make the gravy; slice and fry the onions in the butter of a very pale brown; add these to the trimmings, and pour over about a pint of boiling water; stew these gently for 3/4 hour, then skim and strain the liquor.
10136-8{_}12838{_}Thicken it with flour, and flavour with port wine and ketchup, in the above proportion; add a seasoning of pepper and salt, and put in the pieces of goose; let these get thoroughly hot through, but do not allow them to boil, and serve with sippets of toasted bread.
10136-8{_}12839{_}_Time_.--Altogether, rather more than 1 hour.
10136-8{_}12840{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the cold goose, 4d.
10136-8{_}12841{_}_Seasonable_ from September to March.
10136-8{_}12842{_}THE WILD GOOSE.--This bird is sometimes called the "Gray-lag"     and is the original of the domestic goose.
10136-8{_}12843{_}It is, according to     Pennant, the only species which the Britons could take young,     and familiarize.
10136-8{_}12844{_}"The Gray-lag," says Mr. Gould, "is known to     Persia, and we believe it is generally dispersed over Asia     Minor."
10136-8{_}12845{_}It is the bird that saved the Capitol by its vigilance,     and by the Romans was cherished accordingly.
10136-8{_}12846{_}ROAST GOOSE.
10136-8{_}12847{_}968.
10136-8{_}12848{_}INGREDIENTS.--Goose, 4 large onions, 10 sage-leaves, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}12849{_}of bread crumbs, 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}12850{_}of butter, salt and pepper to taste, 1 egg.
10136-8{_}12851{_}_Choosing and Trussing_.--Select a goose with a clean white skin, plump breast, and yellow feet: if these latter are red, the bird is old.
10136-8{_}12852{_}Should the weather permit, let it hang for a few days: by so doing, the flavour will be very much improved.
10136-8{_}12853{_}Pluck, singe, draw, and carefully wash and wipe the goose; cut off the neck close to the back, leaving the skin long enough to turn over; cut off the feet at the first joint, and separate the pinions at the first joint.
10136-8{_}12854{_}Beat the breast-bone flat with a rolling-pin, put a skewer through the under part of each wing, and having drawn up the legs closely, put a skewer into the middle of each, and pass the same quite through the body.
10136-8{_}12855{_}Insert another skewer into the small of the leg, bring it close down to the side bone, run it through, and do the same to the other side.
10136-8{_}12856{_}Now cut off the end of the vent, and make a hole in the skin sufficiently large for the passage of the rump, in order to keep in the seasoning.
10136-8{_}12857{_}[Illustration: ROAST GOOSE.]
10136-8{_}12858{_}_Mode_.--Make a sage-and-onion stuffing of the above ingredients, by recipe No.
10136-8{_}12859{_}504; put it into the body of the goose, and secure it firmly at both ends, by passing the rump through the hole made in the skin, and the other end by tying the skin of the neck to the back; by this means the seasoning will not escape.
10136-8{_}12860{_}Put it down to a brisk fire, keep it well basted, and roast from 1-1/2 to 2 hours, according to the size.
10136-8{_}12861{_}Remove the skewers, and serve with a tureen of good gravy, and one of well-made apple-sauce.
10136-8{_}12862{_}Should a very highly-flavoured seasoning be preferred, the onions should not be parboiled, but minced raw: of the two methods, the mild seasoning is far superior.
10136-8{_}12863{_}A ragoût, or pie, should be made of the giblets, or they may be stewed down to make gravy.
10136-8{_}12864{_}Be careful to serve the goose before the breast falls, or its appearance will be spoiled by coming flattened to table.
10136-8{_}12865{_}As this is rather a troublesome joint to carve, a _large_ quantity of gravy should not be poured round the goose, but sent in a tureen.
10136-8{_}12866{_}_Time_.--A large goose, 1-3/4 hour; a moderate-sized one, 1-1/4 to 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}12867{_}_Seasonable_ from September to March; but in perfection from Michaelmas to Christmas.
10136-8{_}12868{_}_Average cost_, 5s.
10136-8{_}12869{_}6d.
10136-8{_}12870{_}each.
10136-8{_}12871{_}_Sufficient_ for 8 or 9 persons.
10136-8{_}12872{_}_Note_.--A teaspoonful of made mustard, a saltspoonful of salt, a few grains of cayenne, mixed with a glass of port wine, are sometimes poured into the goose by a slit made in the apron.
10136-8{_}12873{_}This sauce is, by many persons, considered an improvement.
10136-8{_}12874{_}[Illustration: EMDEN GOOSE.]
10136-8{_}12875{_}THE GOOSE.--This bird is pretty generally distributed over the     face of the globe, being met with in North America, Lapland,     Iceland, Arabia, and Persia.
10136-8{_}12876{_}Its varieties are numerous; but in     England there is only one species, which is supposed to be a     native breed.
10136-8{_}12877{_}The best geese are found on the borders of     Suffolk, and in Norfolk and Berkshire; but the largest flocks     are reared in the fens of Lincolnshire and Cambridge.
10136-8{_}12878{_}They     thrive best where they have an easy access to water, and large     herds of them are sent every year to London, to be fattened by     the metropolitan poulterers.
10136-8{_}12879{_}"A Michaelmas goose," says Dr.     Kitchener, "is as famous in the mouths of the million as the     minced-pie at Christmas; yet for those who eat with delicacy, it     is, at that time, too full-grown.
10136-8{_}12880{_}The true period when the goose     is in the highest perfection is when it has just acquired its     full growth, and not begun to harden; if the March goose is     insipid, the Michaelmas goose is rank.
10136-8{_}12881{_}The fine time is between     both; from the second week in June to the first in September."
10136-8{_}12882{_}It is said that the Michaelmas goose is indebted to Queen     Elizabeth for its origin on the table at that season.
10136-8{_}12883{_}Her     majesty happened to dine on one at the table of an English     baronet, when she received the news of the discomfiture of the     Spanish Armada.
10136-8{_}12884{_}In commemoration of this event, she commanded     the goose to make its appearance at table on every Michaelmas.
10136-8{_}12885{_}We here give an engraving of the Emden goose.
10136-8{_}12886{_}TO DRESS A GREEN GOOSE.
10136-8{_}12887{_}969.
10136-8{_}12888{_}INGREDIENTS.--Goose, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}12889{_}of butter, pepper and salt to taste.
10136-8{_}12890{_}_Mode_.--Geese are called green till they are about four months old, and should not be stuffed.
10136-8{_}12891{_}After it has been singed and trussed, the same as in the preceding recipe, put into the body a seasoning of pepper and salt, and the butter to moisten it inside.
10136-8{_}12892{_}Roast before a clear fire for about 3/4 hour, froth and brown it nicely, and serve with a brown gravy, and, when liked, gooseberry-sauce.
10136-8{_}12893{_}This dish should be garnished with water-cresses.
10136-8{_}12894{_}_Time_.--About 3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}12895{_}_Average cost_, 4s.
10136-8{_}12896{_}6d.
10136-8{_}12897{_}each.
10136-8{_}12898{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}12899{_}_Seasonable_ in June, July, and August.
10136-8{_}12900{_}[Illustration: TOULOUSE GOOSE.]
10136-8{_}12901{_}THE EGYPTIAN GOOSE.--Especial attention has been directed to     this bird by Herodotus, who says it was held sacred by the     ancient Egyptians, which has been partially confirmed by modern     travellers.
10136-8{_}12902{_}Mr. Salt remarks, "Horus Apollo says the old geese     stay with their young in the most imminent danger, at the risk     of their own lives, which I have myself frequently witnessed.
10136-8{_}12903{_}Vielpanser is the goose of the Nile, and wherever this goose is     represented on the walls of the temples in colours, the     resemblance may be clearly traced."
10136-8{_}12904{_}The goose is also said to     have been a bird under the care of Isis.
10136-8{_}12905{_}It has been placed by     Mr. Gould amongst the birds of Europe; not from the number of     half-reclaimed individuals which are annually shot in Britain,     but from the circumstance of its occasionally visiting the     southern parts of the continent from its native country, Africa.
10136-8{_}12906{_}The Toulouse goose, of which we give an engraving, is a     well-known bird.
10136-8{_}12907{_}ROAST GUINEA-FOWL, Larded.
10136-8{_}12908{_}970.
10136-8{_}12909{_}INGREDIENTS.--A Guinea-fowl, lardoons, flour, and salt.
10136-8{_}12910{_}_Mode_.--When this bird is larded, it should be trussed the same as a pheasant; if plainly roasted, truss it like a turkey.
10136-8{_}12911{_}After larding and trussing it, put it down to roast at a brisk fire; keep it well basted, and a short time before serving, dredge it with a little flour, and let it froth nicely.
10136-8{_}12912{_}Serve with a little gravy in the dish, and a tureen of the same, and one of well-made bread-sauce.
10136-8{_}12913{_}_Time_.--Guinea-fowl, larded, 1-1/4 hour; plainly roasted, about 1 hour.
10136-8{_}12914{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 persons.
10136-8{_}12915{_}_Seasonable_ in winter.
10136-8{_}12916{_}_Note_.--The breast, if larded, should be covered with a piece of paper, and removed about 10 minutes before serving.
10136-8{_}12917{_}[Illustration: GUINEA-FOWLS.]
10136-8{_}12918{_}THE GUINEA-FOWL.--The bird takes its name from Guinea, in     Africa, where it is found--wild, and in great abundance.
10136-8{_}12919{_}It is     gregarious in its habits, associating in flocks of two or three     hundred, delighting in marshy grounds, and at night perching     upon trees, or on high situations.
10136-8{_}12920{_}Its size is about the same as     that of a common hen, but it stands higher on its legs.
10136-8{_}12921{_}Though     domesticated, it retains much of its wild nature, and is apt to     wander.
10136-8{_}12922{_}The hens lay abundantly, and the eggs are excellent.
10136-8{_}12923{_}In     their flesh, however, they are not so white as the common fowl,     but more inclined to the colour of the pheasant, for which it     frequently makes a good substitute at table.
10136-8{_}12924{_}The flesh is both     savoury and easy of digestion, and is in season when game is out     of season.
10136-8{_}12925{_}LARK PIE (an Entree).
10136-8{_}12926{_}971.
10136-8{_}12927{_}INGREDIENTS.--A few thin slices of beef, the same of bacon, 9 larks, flour; for stuffing, 1 teacupful of bread crumbs, 1/2 teaspoonful of minced lemon-peel, 1 teaspoonful of minced parsley, 1 egg, salt and pepper to taste, 1 teaspoonful of chopped shalot, 1/2 pint of weak stock or water, puff-paste.
10136-8{_}12928{_}_Mode_.--Make a stuffing of bread crumbs, minced lemon-peel, parsley, and the yolk of an egg, all of which should be well mixed together; roll the larks in flour, and stuff them.
10136-8{_}12929{_}Line the bottom of a pie-dish with a few slices of beef and bacon; over these place the larks, and season with salt, pepper, minced parsley, and chopped shalot, in the above proportion.
10136-8{_}12930{_}Pour in the stock or water, cover with crust, and bake for an hour in a moderate oven.
10136-8{_}12931{_}During the time the pie is baking, shake it 2 or 3 times, to assist in thickening the gravy, and serve very hot.
10136-8{_}12932{_}_Time_.--1 hour.
10136-8{_}12933{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}12934{_}6d.
10136-8{_}12935{_}a dozen.
10136-8{_}12936{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}12937{_}_Seasonable_.--In full season in November.
10136-8{_}12938{_}ROAST LARKS.
10136-8{_}12939{_}972.
10136-8{_}12940{_}INGREDIENTS.--Larks, egg and bread crumbs, fresh butter.
10136-8{_}12941{_}_Mode_.--These birds are by many persons esteemed a great delicacy, and may be either roasted or broiled.
10136-8{_}12942{_}Pick, gut, and clean them; when they are trussed, brush them over with the yolk of an egg; sprinkle with bread crumbs, and roast them before a quick fire; baste them continually with fresh butter, and keep sprinkling with the bread crumbs until the birds are well covered.
10136-8{_}12943{_}Dish them on bread crumbs fried in clarified butter, and garnish the dish with slices of lemon.
10136-8{_}12944{_}Broiled larks are also very excellent: they should be cooked over a clear fire, and would take about 10 minutes or 1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}12945{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour to roast; 10 minutes to broil.
10136-8{_}12946{_}_Seasonable_.--In full season in November.
10136-8{_}12947{_}_Note_.--Larks may also be plainly roasted, without covering them with egg and bread crumbs; they should be dished on fried crumbs.
10136-8{_}12948{_}BROILED PIGEONS.
10136-8{_}12949{_}973.
10136-8{_}12950{_}INGREDIENTS.--Pigeons, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}12951{_}of butter, pepper and salt to taste.
10136-8{_}12952{_}_Mode_.--Take care that the pigeons are quite fresh, and carefully pluck, draw, and wash them; split the backs, rub the birds over with butter, season them with pepper and salt, and broil them over a moderate fire for 1/4 hour or 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}12953{_}Serve very hot, with either mushroom-sauce or a good gravy.
10136-8{_}12954{_}Pigeons may also be plainly boiled, and served with parsley and butter; they should be trussed like boiled fowls, and take from 1/4 hour to 20 minutes to boil.
10136-8{_}12955{_}_Time_.--To broil a pigeon, from 1/4 hour to 20 minutes; to boil one, the same time.
10136-8{_}12956{_}_Average cost_, from 6d.
10136-8{_}12957{_}to 9d.
10136-8{_}12958{_}each.
10136-8{_}12959{_}_Seasonable_ from April to September, but in the greatest perfection from midsummer to Michaelmas.
10136-8{_}12960{_}THE POUTER PIGEON.--This is a very favourite pigeon, and,     without doubt, the most curious of his species.
10136-8{_}12961{_}He is a tail     strong bird, as he had need be to carry about his great inflated     crop, frequently as large and as round as a middling-sized     turnip.
10136-8{_}12962{_}A perfect pouter, seen on a windy day, is certainly a     ludicrous sight: his feathered legs have the appearance of white     trousers; his tapering tail looks like a swallow-tailed coat;     his head is entirely concealed by his immense windy     protuberance; and, altogether, he reminds you of a little     "swell" of a past century, staggering under a bale of linen.
10136-8{_}12963{_}The     most common pouters are the blues, buffs, and whites, or an     intermixture of all these various colours.
10136-8{_}12964{_}The pouter is not a     prolific breeder, is a bad nurse, and more likely to degenerate,     if not repeatedly crossed and re-crossed with Irish stock, than     any other pigeon: nevertheless, it is a useful bird to keep if     you are founding a new colony, as it is much attached to its     home, and little apt to stray; consequently it is calculated to     induce more restless birds to fettle down and make themselves     comfortable.
10136-8{_}12965{_}If you wish to breed pouters, you cannot do worse     than intrust them with the care of their own eggs.
10136-8{_}12966{_}ROAST PIGEONS.
10136-8{_}12967{_}974.
10136-8{_}12968{_}INGREDIENTS.--Pigeons, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}12969{_}of butter, pepper and salt to taste.
10136-8{_}12970{_}_Trussing_.--Pigeons, to be good, should be eaten fresh (if kept a little, the flavour goes off), and they should be drawn as soon as killed.
10136-8{_}12971{_}Cut off the heads and necks, truss the wings over the backs, and cut off the toes at the first joint: previous to trussing, they should be carefully cleaned, as no bird requires so much washing.
10136-8{_}12972{_}[Illustration: ROAST PIGEON.]
10136-8{_}12973{_}_Mode_.--Wipe the birds very dry, season them inside with pepper and salt, and put about 3/4 oz.
10136-8{_}12974{_}of butter into the body of each: this makes them moist.
10136-8{_}12975{_}Put them down to a bright fire, and baste them well the whole of the time they are cooking (they will be done enough in from 20 to 30 minutes); garnish with fried parsley, and serve with a tureen of parsley and butter.
10136-8{_}12976{_}Bread-sauce and gravy, the same as for roast fowl, are exceedingly nice accompaniments to roast pigeons, as also egg-sauce.
10136-8{_}12977{_}_Time_.--From 20 minutes to 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}12978{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}12979{_}to 9d.
10136-8{_}12980{_}each.
10136-8{_}12981{_}_Seasonable_ from April to September; but in the greatest perfection from Midsummer to Michaelmas.
10136-8{_}12982{_}THE PIGEON--The pigeon tribe forms a connecting ling between the     passerine birds and poultry.
10136-8{_}12983{_}They are widely distributed over     the world, some of the species being found even in the arctic     regions.
10136-8{_}12984{_}Their chief food is grain, and they drink much; not at     intervals, like other birds, but by a continuous draught, like     quadrupeds.
10136-8{_}12985{_}The wild pigeon, or stockdove, is the parent whence     all the varieties of the domestic pigeon are derived.
10136-8{_}12986{_}In the     wild state it is still found in many parts of this island,     making its nest in the holes of rocks, in the hollows of trees,     or in old towers, but never, like the ringdove, on branches.
10136-8{_}12987{_}The     blue house-pigeon is the variety principally reared for the     table in this country, and is produced from our farmyards in     great numbers.
10136-8{_}12988{_}When young, and still fed by their parents, they     are most preferable for the table, and are called _squabs_;     under six months they are denominated _squeakers_, and at six     months they begin to breed.
10136-8{_}12989{_}Their flesh is accounted savoury,     delicate, and stimulating, and the dark-coloured birds are     considered to have the highest flavour, whilst the light are     esteemed to have the more delicate flesh.
10136-8{_}12990{_}THE PIGEON-HOUSE, OR DOVECOT.--The first thing to be done     towards keeping pigeons is to provide a commodious place for     their reception; and the next is, to provide the pigeons     themselves.
10136-8{_}12991{_}The situation or size of the dovecot will     necessarily depend on convenience; but there is one point which     must invariably be observed, and that is, that every pair of     pigeons has two holes or rooms to nest in.
10136-8{_}12992{_}This is     indispensable, as, without it, there will be no security, but     the constant prospect of confusion, breaking of eggs, and the     destruction of young.
10136-8{_}12993{_}The proper place for the pigeon-house is     the poultry-yard; but it does very well near dwellings, stables,     brewhouses, bakehouses, or such offices.
10136-8{_}12994{_}Some persons keep     pigeons in rooms, and have them making their nests on the floor.
10136-8{_}12995{_}The object is to escape the danger of the young falling out; but     in such cases, there is a great risk of rats or other vermin     getting at the pigeons.
10136-8{_}12996{_}ASPECT OF THE PIGEON-HOUSE.--The front of the pigeon-house     should have a southwest aspect, and, if a room be selected for     the purpose, it is usual to break a hole in the roof of the     building for the passage of the pigeons, but which can be closed     at convenience.
10136-8{_}12997{_}A platform ought to be laid at the entrance for     the pigeons to perch upon, with some kind of defence against     strange cats, which will frequently depopulate a whole dovecot.
10136-8{_}12998{_}Yet, although cats are dangerous neighbours for the birds, they     are necessary to defend them from the approach of rats and mice,     which will not only suck the eggs, but destroy the birds.
10136-8{_}12999{_}The     platform should be painted white, and renewed as the paint wears     off, white being a favourite colour with pigeons, and also most     conspicuous as a mark to enable them to find their house.
10136-8{_}13000{_}The     boxes ought also to be similarly painted, and renewed when     necessary, for which purpose lime and water will do very well.
10136-8{_}13001{_}THE NECESSITY OF CLEANLINESS.--As cleanliness in human     habitations is of the first importance, so is it in the     pigeon-house.
10136-8{_}13002{_}There the want of it will soon render the place a     nuisance not to be approached, and the birds, both young and     old, will be so covered with vermin and filth, that they will     neither enjoy health nor comforts, whilst early mortality     amongst them will be almost certain.
10136-8{_}13003{_}In some cases, the     pigeon-house is cleaned daily; but it should always be done, at     any rate, once a week, and the floor covered with sifted gravel,     frequently renewed.
10136-8{_}13004{_}Pigeons being exceedingly fond of water, and     having a prescience of the coming of rain, they may be seen upon     the house-tops waiting upon it until late in the evening, and     then spreading their wings to receive the luxury of the     refreshing shower.
10136-8{_}13005{_}When they are confined in a room, therefore,     they should be allowed a wide pan of water, to be often renewed.
10136-8{_}13006{_}This serves them for a bath, which cools, refreshes, and assists     them to keep their bodies clear of vermin.
10136-8{_}13007{_}BREEDING PIGEONS.--In breeding pigeons, it is necessary to match     a cock and hen, and shut them up together, or place them near to     each other, and in the course of a day or two there is little     doubt of their mating.
10136-8{_}13008{_}Various rules have been laid down for the     purpose of assisting to distinguish the cock from the hen     pigeon; but the masculine forwardness and action of the cock is     generally so remarkable, that he is easily ascertained.
10136-8{_}13009{_}The     pigeon being monogamous, the male attaches and confines himself     to one female, and the attachment is reciprocal, and the     fidelity of the dove to its mate is proverbial.
10136-8{_}13010{_}At the age of     six months, young pigeons are termed squeakers, and then begin     to breed, when properly managed.
10136-8{_}13011{_}Their courtship, and the     well-known tone of voice in the cock, just then acquired and     commencing, are indications of their approaching union.
10136-8{_}13012{_}Nestlings, while fed by cock and hen, are termed squabs, and     are, at that age, sold and used for the table.
10136-8{_}13013{_}The dove-house     pigeon is said to breed monthly, when well supplied with food.
10136-8{_}13014{_}At all events, it may be depended on, that pigeons of almost any     healthy and well-established variety will breed eight or nine     times in the year; whence it may readily be conceived how vast     are the numbers that may be raised.
10136-8{_}13015{_}[Illustration: CARRIER PIGEONS.]
10136-8{_}13016{_}THE CARRIER PIGEON.--Without doubt the carrier is entitled to     rank first in the pigeon family, with the exception, perhaps, of     the blue-rock pigeons.
10136-8{_}13017{_}No domestic fowl can be traced to so     remote an antiquity.
10136-8{_}13018{_}When Greece was in its glory, carrier     pigeons were used to convey to distant parts the names of the     victors at the Olympian games.
10136-8{_}13019{_}During the holy war, when Acre     was besieged by King Richard, Saladin habitually corresponded     with the besieged by means of carrier pigeons.
10136-8{_}13020{_}A shaft from an     English crossbow, however, happened to bring one of those     feathered messengers to the ground, and the stratagem was     discovered, the design of the Saracens revealed, and so turned     against the designers, that Acre was in the hands of the     Christians before the wily Saladin dreamt of such a thing.
10136-8{_}13021{_}PIGEON PIE (Epsom Grand-Stand Recipe).
10136-8{_}13022{_}975.
10136-8{_}13023{_}INGREDIENTS.--1-1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}13024{_}of rump-steak, 2 or 3 pigeons, 3 slices of ham, pepper and salt to taste, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}13025{_}of butter, 4 eggs, puff crust.
10136-8{_}13026{_}_Mode_.--Cut the steak into pieces about 3 inches square, and with it line the bottom of a pie-dish, seasoning it well with pepper and salt.
10136-8{_}13027{_}Clean the pigeons, rub them with pepper and salt inside and out, and put into the body of each rather more than 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}13028{_}of butter; lay them on the steak, and a piece of ham on each pigeon.
10136-8{_}13029{_}Add the yolks of 4 eggs, and half fill the dish with stock; place a border of puff paste round the edge of the dish, put on the cover, and ornament it in any way that may be preferred.
10136-8{_}13030{_}Clean three of the feet, and place them in a hole made in the crust at the top: this shows what kind of pie it is.
10136-8{_}13031{_}Glaze the crust,--that is to say, brush it over with the yolk of an egg,--and bake it in a well-heated oven for about 1-1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}13032{_}When liked, a seasoning of pounded mace may be added.
10136-8{_}13033{_}_Time_.--1-1/4 hour, or rather less.
10136-8{_}13034{_}_Average cost_, 5s.
10136-8{_}13035{_}3d.
10136-8{_}13036{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}13037{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}13038{_}[Illustration: TUMBLER PIGEONS.]
10136-8{_}13039{_}TUMBLER PIGEONS.--The smaller the size of this variety, the     greater its value.
10136-8{_}13040{_}The head should be round and smooth, the neck     thin, and the tail similar to that of the turbit.
10136-8{_}13041{_}Highly-bred     birds of this variety will attain an elevation in their flight     beyond that of any other pigeons; and it is in seeing these     little birds wing themselves so far into the skies that the     fanciers take such delight.
10136-8{_}13042{_}For four or five hours tumblers have     been known to keep on the wing; and it is when they are almost     lost to the power of human vision that they exhibit those     pantomimic feats which give them their name, and which are     marked by a tumbling over-and-over process, which suggests the     idea of their having suddenly become giddy, been deprived of     their self-control, or overtaken by some calamity.
10136-8{_}13043{_}This     acrobatic propensity in these pigeons has been ascribed by some     to the absence of a proper power in the tail; but is nothing     more than a natural habit, for which no adequate reason can be     assigned.
10136-8{_}13044{_}Of this variety, the Almond Tumbler is the most     beautiful; and the greater the variation of the colour in the     flight and tail, the greater their value.
10136-8{_}13045{_}[Illustration: RUNT PIGEONS.]
10136-8{_}13046{_}THE RUNT PIGEON.--This is generally esteemed among the largest     of the pigeon varieties, and being possessed of proportionate     strength, with a strong propensity to exercise it, they keep the     dovecot in a state of almost continual commotion by domineering     over the weaker inmates.
10136-8{_}13047{_}They breed tolerably well, however, and     are valuable for the table.
10136-8{_}13048{_}There is both the Leghorn and the     Spanish Runt, variously plumaged; but when red, white, or black     mottled, are most highly esteemed.
10136-8{_}13049{_}One of the great advantages     connected with the Runt is, that he is not likely to fly away     from home.
10136-8{_}13050{_}Being heavy birds, they find it difficult, when well     fed, to mount even to a low housetop.
10136-8{_}13051{_}Again, they require no     loft, or special dwelling-place, but, if properly tended, will     be perfectly satisfied, and thrive as well, in a rabbit-hutch as     any where.
10136-8{_}13052{_}Their flavour is very good; and it is not an uncommon     thing for a squeaker Runt to exceed a pound and a quarter in     weight.
10136-8{_}13053{_}[Illustration: NUN PIGEONS.]
10136-8{_}13054{_}THE NUN PIGEON.--The Tumbler bears a strong resemblance to this     variety, which is characterized by a tuft of feathers rising     from the back of the head, and which, on the whole, is an     extremely pretty little bird.
10136-8{_}13055{_}According to the colour of the     head, it is called the red, black, or yellow-headed Nun.
10136-8{_}13056{_}To be a     perfect bird, it should have a small head and beak; and the     larger the tuft at the back of his head, the handsomer the bird     is esteemed, and proportionately valuable in the eyes of     pigeon-fanciers.
10136-8{_}13057{_}[Illustration: TRUMPETER PIGEONS.]
10136-8{_}13058{_}THE TRUMPETER PIGEON.--From the circumstance of this bird     imitating the sound of a trumpet, instead of cooing, like other     pigeons, it has received its designation.
10136-8{_}13059{_}It is of the middle     size, having its legs and feet covered with feathers, and its     plumage generally of a mottled black-and-white.
10136-8{_}13060{_}It has a tuft     springing from the root of its beak, and the larger this topknot     is, the higher the estimation in which the breed is held.
10136-8{_}13061{_}In     their powers of trumpeting some are more expert than others; and     whether this has any effect in influencing their own estimate of     themselves, we cannot say; but they are rather select in the     choice of their company.
10136-8{_}13062{_}If two of them are put in a     pigeon-house with other doves, it will be found that they     confine their association almost entirely to each other.
10136-8{_}13063{_}As much     as two guineas have been paid for a well-trained docile bird of     this kind.
10136-8{_}13064{_}[Illustration: WOOD-PIGEON.]
10136-8{_}13065{_}THE WOOD, OR WILD PIGEON.--Buffon enumerates upwards of thirty     varieties of the pigeon, which he derives from one root,--viz.
10136-8{_}13066{_}the stockdove, or common wild pigeon.
10136-8{_}13067{_}All the varieties of     colour and form which we witness, he attributes to human     contrivance and fancy.
10136-8{_}13068{_}Nevertheless, there exist essentially     specific differences in these birds, which would appear to be     attributable rather to the nature of the region, soil, and     climate to which they are indigenous, than to the art and     ingenuity of man.
10136-8{_}13069{_}The stockdove, in its wild state, is still     found in some parts of Britain, forming its nest in the holes of     rocks, old towers, and in the hollows of trees; it never,     however, like the ringdove, nestles in the branches.
10136-8{_}13070{_}Multitudes     of wild pigeons still visit our shores in the winter, coming     from their more northerly retreats, making their appearance     about November, and retiring again in the spring.
10136-8{_}13071{_}When forests     of beechwood covered large tracts of the ground of this country,     these birds used to haunt them in myriads, frequently covering a     mile of ground in extent when they went out in the morning to     feed.
10136-8{_}13072{_}STEWED PIGEONS.
10136-8{_}13073{_}976.
10136-8{_}13074{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 pigeons, a few slices of bacon, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}13075{_}of butter, 2 tablespoonfuls of minced parsley, sufficient stock No.
10136-8{_}13076{_}104 to cover the pigeons, thickening of butter and flour, 1 tablespoonful of mushroom ketchup, 1 tablespoonful of port wine.
10136-8{_}13077{_}_Mode_.--Empty and clean the pigeons thoroughly, mince the livers, add to these the parsley and butter, and put it into the insides of the birds.
10136-8{_}13078{_}Truss them with the legs inward, and put them into a stewpan, with a few slices of bacon placed under and over them; add the stock, and stew gently for rather more than 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}13079{_}Dish the pigeons, strain the gravy, thicken it with butter and flour, add the ketchup and port wine, give one boil, pour over the pigeons, and serve.
10136-8{_}13080{_}_Time_.--Rather more than 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}13081{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}13082{_}to 9d.
10136-8{_}13083{_}each.
10136-8{_}13084{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}13085{_}_Seasonable_ from April to September.
10136-8{_}13086{_}[Illustration: FANTAIL PIGEONS.]
10136-8{_}13087{_}THE FANTAIL PIGEON.--This curious variety is inferior in point     of size to most of the other varieties, and is characterized by     having a short, slender bill, pendent wings, and naked legs and     feet.
10136-8{_}13088{_}It has the power of erecting its tail in the manner of a     turkey-cock; during which action, especially when paying court     to it's mate, it trembles or shakes, like the peacock when     moving about with his train expanded and in full display.
10136-8{_}13089{_}This     power of erecting and spreading the tail is not confined to the     male bird alone: the female possesses the same power to an equal     extent, and otherwise resembles the male in every respect.
10136-8{_}13090{_}It is     not very prolific, and seldom succeeds so well in the aviary or     pigeon-house as most of the other kinds.
10136-8{_}13091{_}[Illustration: JACOBIN PIGEONS.]
10136-8{_}13092{_}THE JACOBIN PIGEON.--This variety, having the power to transmit     to posterity a form precisely similar, with all its peculiar     characters undiminished, is, among pigeon-fanciers, designated     as of a pure or permanent race.
10136-8{_}13093{_}It is distinguished by a     remarkable ruff or frill of raised feathers, which, commencing     behind the head and proceeding down the neck and breast, forms a     kind of hood, not unlike that worn by a monk.
10136-8{_}13094{_}From this     circumstance, it has obtained its Gallic name of _nonnain     capuchin_.
10136-8{_}13095{_}In size it is one of the smallest of the domestic     pigeons, and its form is light and elegant.
10136-8{_}13096{_}It is a very     productive species, and, having its flight considerably impeded     by the size and form of its hooded frill, keeps much at home,     and is well adapted for the aviary or other buildings where     pigeons are confined.
10136-8{_}13097{_}[Illustration: TURBIT PIGEONS.]
10136-8{_}13098{_}THE TURBIT PIGEON.--This variety bears a strong resemblance to     the Jacobin, having a kind of frill in the fore part of its     neck, occasioned by the breast-feathers lying contrariwise and     standing straight out.
10136-8{_}13099{_}The species is classed in accordance with     the colour of the shoulders, similarly as the Nuns are by the     colour of their heads.
10136-8{_}13100{_}Their characteristics of excellence are a     full frill, short bill, and small round head.
10136-8{_}13101{_}In Germany it is     called the ruffle pigeon, in allusion to the feathers on its     breast; and it has rarely any feathers on its feet.
10136-8{_}13102{_}There is a     peculiarity connected with this bird, which somewhat lowers it     in the estimation of fanciers: it seldom rears more than one at     a time, which, therefore, marks it as a bird rather for     amusement than profit.
10136-8{_}13103{_}[Illustration: BARB PIGEONS.]
10136-8{_}13104{_}THE BARB PIGEON.--The name of this variety is a contraction of     Barbary, from which country it originally comes.
10136-8{_}13105{_}It is both     prolific and has excellent qualities as a nurse.
10136-8{_}13106{_}The kind most     esteemed is that of one uniform colour, that of blue-black being     preferable to any other.
10136-8{_}13107{_}Speckled or mottled Barbs are esteemed     the most common of all pigeons.
10136-8{_}13108{_}It is not unlike the Carrier     pigeon, and, at a small distance, might easily be mistaken for     the latter.
10136-8{_}13109{_}It has a short beak and a small wattle.
10136-8{_}13110{_}A spongy,     pinky skin round the eyes is its chief characteristic, however,     and this increases in size till the bird is three or four years     old.
10136-8{_}13111{_}This peculiarity is hardly distinguishable in very young     birds.
10136-8{_}13112{_}[Illustration: BLUE ROCK-PIGEON.]
10136-8{_}13113{_}THE ROCK PIGEON.--This variety, in its wild state, is found upon     the rocky parts of the west of Scotland, and the bold shores of     the Western Isles, more abundant than in any other parts of the     British islands.
10136-8{_}13114{_}As the shores of the mainland are exposed to     the muds of the Atlantic, and the comparatively small islands     are surrounded by that ocean, the low grounds exposed to the     west are seldom covered with snow for any length of time, and     thus the birds easily find a supply of food.
10136-8{_}13115{_}The numbers which     there congregate are often very great, and the din of their     united cry is sometimes very loud and even alarming.
10136-8{_}13116{_}The love of     home and the certainty of returning to it is very conspicuous in     the rock-pigeon or _biset_, as it is called by the French.
10136-8{_}13117{_}Flocks from different parts of the coasts often meet on the     feeding-grounds; but when the time of returning to rest comes     round, each one keeps to its own party.
10136-8{_}13118{_}[Illustration: OWL PIGEONS.]
10136-8{_}13119{_}THE OWL PIGEON.--This pigeon does not seem to be so well known     as it formerly was, if we may judge from the fact that few     modern writers mention it.
10136-8{_}13120{_}Like the Turbit pigeon, the Owl has a     remarkable tuft of feathers on the breast, it having been     compared by some to the frill of a shirt, and by others to a     full-blown white rose.
10136-8{_}13121{_}In size, it is not quite so large a     pigeon as the Jacobin.
10136-8{_}13122{_}It is said to be preferred in France,     above other varieties, as a bird to rear and kill for the table.
10136-8{_}13123{_}In England it is very far from being common; indeed, we have     applied to several keepers of pigeons, who have fancied     themselves acquainted with all the varieties of this bird, and     they have been able to tell us nothing of it.
10136-8{_}13124{_}Mr. Harrison Weir,     our artist, however, has made his portrait from the life.
10136-8{_}13125{_}BOILED RABBIT.
10136-8{_}13126{_}[Illustration: BOILED RABBIT.]
10136-8{_}13127{_}977.
10136-8{_}13128{_}INGREDIENTS.--Rabbit; water.
10136-8{_}13129{_}_Mode_.--For boiling, choose rabbits with smooth and sharp claws, as that denotes they are young: should these be blunt and rugged, the ears dry and tough, the animal is old.
10136-8{_}13130{_}After emptying and skinning it, wash it well in cold water, and let it soak for about 1/4 hour in warm water, to draw out the blood.
10136-8{_}13131{_}Bring the head round to the side, and fasten it there by means of a skewer run through that and the body.
10136-8{_}13132{_}Put the rabbit into sufficient hot water to cover it, let it boil very gently until tender, which will be in from 1/2 to 3/4 hour, according to its size and age.
10136-8{_}13133{_}Dish it, and smother it either with onion, mushroom, or liver sauce, or parsley-and-butter; the former is, however, generally preferred to any of the last-named sauces.
10136-8{_}13134{_}When liver-sauce is preferred, the liver should be boiled for a few minutes, and minced very finely, or rubbed through a sieve before it is added to the sauce.
10136-8{_}13135{_}_Time_.--A very young rabbit, 1/2 hour; a large one, 3/4 hour; an old one, 1 hour or longer.
10136-8{_}13136{_}_Average cost_, from 1s.
10136-8{_}13137{_}to 1s.
10136-8{_}13138{_}6d.
10136-8{_}13139{_}each.
10136-8{_}13140{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}13141{_}_Seasonable_ from September to February.
10136-8{_}13142{_}THE RABBIT.--Though this animal is an inhabitant of most     temperate climates, it does not reach so far north as the hare.
10136-8{_}13143{_}The wild rabbit is a native of Great Britain, and is found in     large numbers in the sandy districts of Norfolk and     Cambridgeshire.
10136-8{_}13144{_}Its flesh is, by some, considered to have a     higher flavour than that of the tame rabbit, although it is     neither so white nor so delicate.
10136-8{_}13145{_}The animal, however, becomes     larger and fatter in the tame than in the wild state; but it is     not desirable to have it so fat as it can be made.
10136-8{_}13146{_}CURRIED RABBIT.
10136-8{_}13147{_}978.
10136-8{_}13148{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 rabbit, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}13149{_}of butter, 3 onions, 1 pint of stock No.
10136-8{_}13150{_}104, 1 tablespoonful of curry powder, 1 tablespoonful of flour, 1 teaspoonful of mushroom powder, the juice of 1/2 lemon, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}13151{_}of rice.
10136-8{_}13152{_}_Mode_.--Empty, skin, and wash the rabbit thoroughly, and cut it neatly into joints.
10136-8{_}13153{_}Put it into a stewpan with the butter and sliced onions, and let them acquire a nice brown colour, but do not allow them to blacken.
10136-8{_}13154{_}Pour in the stock, which should be boiling; mix the curry powder and flour smoothly with a little water, add it to the stock, with the mushroom powder, and simmer gently for rather more than 1/2 hour; squeeze in the lemon-juice, and serve in the centre of a dish, with an edging of boiled rice all round.
10136-8{_}13155{_}Where economy is studied, water may be substituted for the stock; in this case, the meat and onions must be very nicely browned.
10136-8{_}13156{_}A little sour apple and rasped cocoa-nut stewed with the curry will be found a great improvement.
10136-8{_}13157{_}_Time_.--Altogether 3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}13158{_}_Average cost_, from 1s.
10136-8{_}13159{_}to 1s.
10136-8{_}13160{_}6d.
10136-8{_}13161{_}each.
10136-8{_}13162{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}13163{_}_Seasonable_ in winter.
10136-8{_}13164{_}[Illustration: WILD RABBITS.]
10136-8{_}13165{_}THE COMMON OR WILD RABBIT.--Warrens, or inclosures, are     frequently made in favourable localities, and some of them are     so large as to comprise 2,000 acres.
10136-8{_}13166{_}The common wild rabbit is     of a grey colour, and is esteemed the best for the purposes of     food.
10136-8{_}13167{_}Its skin is valuable as an article of commerce, being used     for the making of hats.
10136-8{_}13168{_}Another variety of the rabbit, however,     called the "silver-grey," has been lately introduced to this     country, and is still more valuable.
10136-8{_}13169{_}Its colour is a black     ground, thickly interspersed with grey hairs; and its powers as     a destroyer and consumer of vegetable food are well known to be     enormous, especially by those who have gardens in the vicinity     of a rabbit-warren.
10136-8{_}13170{_}FRIED RABBIT.
10136-8{_}13171{_}979.
10136-8{_}13172{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 rabbit, flour, dripping, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}13173{_}of butter, 1 teaspoonful of minced shalot, 2 tablespoonfuls of mushroom ketchup.
10136-8{_}13174{_}_Mode_.--Cut the rabbit into neat joints, and flour them well; make the dripping boiling in a fryingpan, put in the rabbit, and fry it a nice brown.
10136-8{_}13175{_}Have ready a very hot dish, put in the butter, shalot, and ketchup; arrange the rabbit pyramidically on this, and serve as quickly as possible.
10136-8{_}13176{_}_Time_.--10 minutes.
10136-8{_}13177{_}_Average cost_, from 1s.
10136-8{_}13178{_}to 1s.
10136-8{_}13179{_}6d.
10136-8{_}13180{_}each.
10136-8{_}13181{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}13182{_}_Seasonable_ from September to February.
10136-8{_}13183{_}_Note_.--The rabbit may be brushed over with egg, and sprinkled with bread crumbs, and fried as above.
10136-8{_}13184{_}When cooked in this manner, make a gravy in the pan by recipe No.
10136-8{_}13185{_}866, and pour it round, but not over, the pieces of rabbit.
10136-8{_}13186{_}VARIETIES IN RABBITS.--Almost everybody knows that a rabbit is a     furry animal, that lives on plants, and burrows in the ground;     that it has its varieties as well as other animals, and that it     is frequently an especial favourite with boys.
10136-8{_}13187{_}Among its     varieties, the short-legged, with width and substance of loin,     is the most hardy, and fattens the most expeditiously.
10136-8{_}13188{_}It has,     besides, the soundest liver, rabbits generally being subject to     defects of that part.
10136-8{_}13189{_}It is also the smallest variety.
10136-8{_}13190{_}There is     a very large species of the hare-colour, having much bone,     length and depth of carcase, large and long ears, with full     eyes, resembling those of the hare: it might readily be taken     for a hybrid or mule, but for the objection to its breeding.
10136-8{_}13191{_}Its     flesh is high-coloured, substantial, and more savoury than that     of the common rabbit; and, cooked like the hare, it makes a good     dish.
10136-8{_}13192{_}The large white, and yellow and white species, have whiter     and more delicate flesh, and, cooked in the same way, will rival     the turkey.
10136-8{_}13193{_}Rabbits are divided into four kinds, distinguished     as warreners, parkers, hedgehogs, and sweethearts.
10136-8{_}13194{_}The warrener,     as his name implies, is a member of a subterranean community,     and is less effeminate than his kindred who dwell _upon_ the     earth and have "the world at their will," and his fur is the     most esteemed.
10136-8{_}13195{_}After him, comes the parker, whose favourite     resort is a gentleman's pleasure-ground, where he usually breeds     in great numbers, and from which he frequently drives away the     hares.
10136-8{_}13196{_}The hedgehog is a sort of vagabond rabbit, that, tinker     like, roams about the country, and would have a much better coat     on his back if he was more settled in his habits, and remained     more at home.
10136-8{_}13197{_}The sweetheart is a tame rabbit, with its fur so     sleek, soft, and silky, that it is also used to some extent in     the important branch of hat-making.
10136-8{_}13198{_}RABBIT A LA MINUTE.
10136-8{_}13199{_}980.
10136-8{_}13200{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 rabbit, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}13201{_}of butter, salt and pepper to taste, 2 blades of pounded mace, 3 dried mushrooms, 2 tablespoonfuls of minced parsley, 2 teaspoonfuls of flour, 2 glasses of sherry, 1 pint of water.
10136-8{_}13202{_}_Mode_.--Empty, skin, and wash the rabbit thoroughly, and cut it into joints.
10136-8{_}13203{_}Put the butter into a stewpan with the pieces of rabbit; add salt, pepper, and pounded mace, and let it cook until three parts done; then put in the remaining ingredients, and boil for about 10 minutes: it will then be ready to serve.
10136-8{_}13204{_}Fowls or hare may be dressed in the same manner.
10136-8{_}13205{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 35 minutes.
10136-8{_}13206{_}_Average cost_, from 1s.
10136-8{_}13207{_}to 1s.
10136-8{_}13208{_}6d.
10136-8{_}13209{_}each.
10136-8{_}13210{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}13211{_}_Seasonable_ from September to February.
10136-8{_}13212{_}RABBIT PIE.
10136-8{_}13213{_}981.
10136-8{_}13214{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 rabbit, a few slices of ham, salt and white pepper to taste, 2 blades of pounded mace, 1/2 teaspoonful of grated nutmeg, a few forcemeat balls, 3 hard-boiled eggs, 1/2 pint of gravy, puff crust.
10136-8{_}13215{_}_Mode_.--Cut up the rabbit (which should be young), remove the breastbone, and bone the legs.
10136-8{_}13216{_}Put the rabbit, slices of ham, forcemeat balls, and hard eggs, by turns, in layers, and season each layer with pepper, salt, pounded mace, and grated nutmeg.
10136-8{_}13217{_}Pour in about 1/2 pint of water, cover with crust, and bake in a well-heated oven for about 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}13218{_}Should the crust acquire too much colour, place a piece of paper over it to prevent its burning.
10136-8{_}13219{_}When done, pour in at the top, by means of the hole in the middle of the crust, a little good gravy, which may be made of the breast- and leg-bones of the rabbit and 2 or 3 shank-bones, flavoured with onion, herbs, and spices.
10136-8{_}13220{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}13221{_}_Average cost_, from 1s.
10136-8{_}13222{_}to 1s.
10136-8{_}13223{_}6d.
10136-8{_}13224{_}each.
10136-8{_}13225{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}13226{_}_Seasonable_ from September to February.
10136-8{_}13227{_}Note.--The liver of the rabbit may be boiled, minced, and mixed with the forcemeat balls, when the flavour is liked.
10136-8{_}13228{_}FECUNDITY OF THE RABBIT.--The fruitfulness of this animal has     been the subject of wonder to all naturalists.
10136-8{_}13229{_}It breeds seven     times in the year, and generally begets seven or eight young     ones at a time.
10136-8{_}13230{_}If we suppose this to happen regularly for a     period of four years, the progeny that would spring from a     single pair would amount to more than a million.
10136-8{_}13231{_}As the rabbit,     however, has many enemies, it can never be permitted to increase     in numbers to such an extent as to prove injurious to mankind;     for it not only furnishes man with an article of food, but is,     by carnivorous animals of every description, mercilessly     sacrificed.
10136-8{_}13232{_}Notwithstanding this, however, in the time of the     Roman power, they once infested the Balearic islands to such an     extent, that the inhabitants were obliged to implore the     assistance of a military force from Augustus to exterminate     them.
10136-8{_}13233{_}RAGOUT OF RABBIT OR HARE.
10136-8{_}13234{_}982.
10136-8{_}13235{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 rabbit, 3 teaspoonfuls of flour, 3 sliced onions, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}13236{_}of butter, a few thin slices of bacon, pepper and salt to taste, 2 slices of lemon, 1 bay-leaf, 1 glass of port wine.
10136-8{_}13237{_}_Mode_.--Slice the onions, and put them into a stewpan with the flour and butter; place the pan near the fire, stir well as the butter melts, till the onions become a rich brown colour, and add, by degrees, a little water or gravy till the mixture is of the consistency of cream.
10136-8{_}13238{_}Cut some thin slices of bacon; lay in these with the rabbit, cut into neat joints; add a seasoning of pepper and salt, the lemon and bay-leaf, and let the whole simmer until tender.
10136-8{_}13239{_}Pour in the port wine, give one boil, and serve.
10136-8{_}13240{_}_Time_.--About 1/2 hour to simmer the rabbit.
10136-8{_}13241{_}_Average cost_, from 1s.
10136-8{_}13242{_}to 1s.
10136-8{_}13243{_}6d.
10136-8{_}13244{_}each.
10136-8{_}13245{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}13246{_}_Seasonable_ from September to February.
10136-8{_}13247{_}THE RABBIT-HOUSE.--Rabbit-keeping is generally practised by a     few individuals in almost every town, and by a few in almost     every part of the country.
10136-8{_}13248{_}Forty years ago, there were in the     metropolis one or two considerable feeders, who, according to     report, kept from 1,600 to 2,000 breeding does.
10136-8{_}13249{_}These large     establishments, however, have ceased to exist, and London     receives the supply of tame as well as wild rabbits chiefly from     the country.
10136-8{_}13250{_}Where they are kept, however, the rabbit-house     should be placed upon a dry foundation, and be well ventilated.
10136-8{_}13251{_}Exposure to rain, whether externally or internally, is fatal to     rabbits, which, like sheep, are liable to the rot, springing     from the same causes.
10136-8{_}13252{_}Thorough ventilation and good air are     indispensable where many rabbits are kept, or they will neither     prosper nor remain healthy for any length of time.
10136-8{_}13253{_}A thorough     draught or passage for the air is, therefore, absolutely     necessary, and should be so contrived as to be checked in cold     or wet weather by the closing or shutting of opposite doors or     windows.
10136-8{_}13254{_}ROAST OR BAKED RABBIT.
10136-8{_}13255{_}983.
10136-8{_}13256{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 rabbit, forcemeat No.
10136-8{_}13257{_}417, buttered paper, sausage-meat.
10136-8{_}13258{_}[Illustration: ROAST RABBIT.]
10136-8{_}13259{_}_Mode_.--Empty, skin, and thoroughly wash the rabbit; wipe it dry, line the inside with sausage-meat and forcemeat made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}13260{_}417, and to which has been added the minced liver.
10136-8{_}13261{_}Sew the stuffing inside, skewer back the head between the shoulders, cut off the fore-joints of the shoulders and legs, bring: them close to the body, and secure them by means of a skewer.
10136-8{_}13262{_}Wrap the rabbit in buttered paper, and put it down to a bright clear fire; keep it well basted, and a few minutes before it is done remove the paper, flour and froth it, and let it acquire a nice brown colour.
10136-8{_}13263{_}Take out the skewers, and serve with brown gravy and red-currant jelly.
10136-8{_}13264{_}To bake the rabbit, proceed in the same manner as above; in a good oven, it will take about the same time as roasting.
10136-8{_}13265{_}_Time_.--A young rabbit, 35 minutes; a large one, about 3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}13266{_}_Average cost_, from 1s.
10136-8{_}13267{_}to 1s.
10136-8{_}13268{_}6d.
10136-8{_}13269{_}each.
10136-8{_}13270{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}13271{_}_Seasonable_ from September to February.
10136-8{_}13272{_}THE HUTCH.--Hutches are generally placed one above another to     the height required by the number of rabbits and the extent of     the room.
10136-8{_}13273{_}Where a large stock is kept, to make the most of room,     the hutches may be placed in rows, with a sufficient interval     between for feeding and cleaning, instead of being, in the usual     way, joined to the wall.
10136-8{_}13274{_}It is preferable to rest the hutches     upon stands, about a foot above the ground, for the convenience     of cleaning under them.
10136-8{_}13275{_}Each of the hutches intended for     breeding should have two rooms,--a feeding and a bed-room.
10136-8{_}13276{_}Those     are single for the use of the weaned rabbits, or for the bucks,     which are always kept separate.
10136-8{_}13277{_}The floors should be planed     smooth, that wet may run off, and a common hoe, with a short     handle, and a short broom, are most convenient implements for     cleaning these houses.
10136-8{_}13278{_}STEWED RABBIT.
10136-8{_}13279{_}984.
10136-8{_}13280{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 rabbit, 2 large onions, 6 cloves, 1 small teaspoonful of chopped lemon-peel, a few forcemeat balls, thickening of butter and flour, 1 large tablespoonful of mushroom ketchup.
10136-8{_}13281{_}_Mode_.--Cut the rabbit into small joints; put them into a stewpan, add the onions sliced, the cloves, and minced lemon-peel.
10136-8{_}13282{_}Pour in sufficient water to cover the meat, and, when the rabbit is nearly done, drop in a few forcemeat balls, to which has been added the liver, finely chopped.
10136-8{_}13283{_}Thicken the gravy with flour and butter, put in the ketchup, give one boil, and serve.
10136-8{_}13284{_}_Time_.--Rather more than 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}13285{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}13286{_}to 1s.
10136-8{_}13287{_}6d each.
10136-8{_}13288{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}13289{_}_Seasonable_ from September to February.
10136-8{_}13290{_}[Illustration: LOP-EARED RABBIT.]
10136-8{_}13291{_}FANCY RABBITS.--The graceful fall of the ears is the first thing     that is looked to by the fancier; next, the dewlap, if the     animal is in its prime; then the colours and marked points, and,     lastly, the shape and general appearance.
10136-8{_}13292{_}The ears of a fine     rabbit should extend not less than seven inches, measured from     tip to tip in a line across the skull; but even should they     exceed this length, they are admitted with reluctance into a     fancy stock, unless they have a uniform and graceful droop.
10136-8{_}13293{_}The     dewlap, which is a fold of skin under the neck and throat, is     only seen in fancy rabbits, after they have attained their full     growth: it commences immediately under the jaw, and adds greatly     to the beauty of their appearance.
10136-8{_}13294{_}It goes down the throat and     between the fore legs, and is so broad that it projects beyond     the chin.
10136-8{_}13295{_}The difference between the fancy and common rabbit in the back,     independent of the ears, is sufficient to strike the common     observer.
10136-8{_}13296{_}Fancy rabbits fetch a very high price; so much as five     and ten guineas, and even more, is sometimes given for a     first-rate doe.
10136-8{_}13297{_}If young ones are first procured from a good     family, the foundation of an excellent stock can be procured for     a much smaller sum.
10136-8{_}13298{_}Sometimes the ears, instead of drooping     down, slope backwards: a rabbit with this characteristic is     scarcely admitted into a fancy lot, and is not considered worth     more than the common variety.
10136-8{_}13299{_}The next position is when one ear     lops outwards, and the other stands erect: rabbits of this kind     possess but little value, however fine the shape and beautiful     the colour, although they sometimes breed as good specimens as     finer ones.
10136-8{_}13300{_}The forward or horn-lop is one degree nearer perfection than the     half-lop: the ears, in this case, slope forward and down over     the forehead.
10136-8{_}13301{_}Rabbits with this peculiarity are often perfect in     other respects, with the exception of the droop of the ears, and     often become the parents of perfect young ones: does of this     kind often have the power of lifting an ear erect.
10136-8{_}13302{_}In the     ear-lop, the ears spread out in an horizontal position, like the     wings of a bird in flight, or the arms of a man swimming.
10136-8{_}13303{_}A     great many excellent does have this characteristic, and some of     the best-bred bucks in the fancy are entirely so.
10136-8{_}13304{_}Sometimes a     rabbit drops one ear completely, but raises the other so neatly     horizontally as to constitute an ear-lop: this is superior to     all others, except the perfect fall, which is so rarely to be     met with, that those which are merely ear-lopped are considered     as valuable rabbits, if well bred and with other good qualities.
10136-8{_}13305{_}"The real lop has ears that hang down by the side of the cheek,     slanting somewhat outward in their descent, with the open part     of the ear inward, and sometimes either backwards or forwards     instead of perpendicular: when the animals stand in an easy     position, the tips of the ears touch the ground.
10136-8{_}13306{_}The hollows of     the ears, in a fancy rabbit of a first-rate kind, should be     turned so completely backwards that only the outer part of them     should remain in front: they should match exactly in their     descent, and should slant outwards as little as possible."
10136-8{_}13307{_}The same authority asserts that perfect lops are so rare, that a     breeder possessing twenty of the handsomest and most perfect     does would consider himself lucky if, in the course of a year,     he managed to raise twelve full-lopped rabbits out of them all.
10136-8{_}13308{_}As regards variety and purity of colour an experienced breeder     says:--      "The fur of fancy rabbits may be blue, or rather lead-colour,     and white, or black and white, or tawny and white, that is,     tortoiseshell-coloured.
10136-8{_}13309{_}But it is not of so much importance what     colours the coat of a rabbit displays, as it is that those     colours shall be arranged in a particular manner, forming     imaginary figures or fancied resemblances to certain objects.
10136-8{_}13310{_}Hence the peculiarities of their markings have been denoted by     distinctive designations.
10136-8{_}13311{_}What is termed 'the blue butterfly     smut' was, for some time, considered the most valuable of fancy     rabbits.
10136-8{_}13312{_}It is thus named on account of having bluish or     lead-coloured spots on either side of the nose, having some     resemblance to the spread wings of a butterfly, what may be     termed the groundwork of the rabbit's face being white.
10136-8{_}13313{_}A black     and white rabbit may also have the face marked in a similar     manner, constituting a 'black butterfly smut.'
10136-8{_}13314{_}"But A good fancy rabbit must likewise have other marks, without     which it cannot be considered a perfect model of its kind.
10136-8{_}13315{_}There     should be a black or blue patch on its back, called the saddle;     the tail must be of the same colour with the back and snout;     while the legs should be all white; and there ought to be dark     stripes on both sides of the body in front, passing backwards to     meet the saddle, and uniting on the top of the shoulders at the     part called the withers in a horse.
10136-8{_}13316{_}These stripes form what is     termed the 'chain' having somewhat the appearance of a chain or     collar hanging round the neck."
10136-8{_}13317{_}"Among thorough-bred fancy rabbits, perhaps not one in a hundred     will have all these markings clearly and exactly displayed on     the coat; but the more nearly the figures on the coat of a     rabbit approach to the pattern described, the greater will be     its value, so far, at least, as relates to colour.
10136-8{_}13318{_}The beauty     and consequent worth of a fancy rabbit, however, depends a good     deal on its shape, or what is styled its carriage.
10136-8{_}13319{_}A rabbit is     said to have a good carriage when its back is finely arched,     rising full two inches above the top of its head, which must be     held so low as for the muzzle and the points of the ears to     reach almost to the ground."
10136-8{_}13320{_}STEWED RABBIT, Larded.
10136-8{_}13321{_}985.
10136-8{_}13322{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 rabbit, a few strips of bacon, rather more than 1 pint of good broth or stock, a bunch of savoury herbs, salt and pepper to taste, thickening of butter and flour, 1 glass of sherry.
10136-8{_}13323{_}_Mode_.--Well wash the rabbit, cut it into quarters, lard them with Blips of bacon, and fry them; then put them into a stewpan with the broth, herbs, and a seasoning of pepper and salt; simmer gently until the rabbit is tender, then strain the gravy, thicken it with butter and flour, add the sherry, give one boil, pour it over the rabbit, and serve.
10136-8{_}13324{_}Garnish with slices of cut lemon.
10136-8{_}13325{_}_Time_.--Rather more than 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}13326{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}13327{_}to 1s.
10136-8{_}13328{_}6d.
10136-8{_}13329{_}each.
10136-8{_}13330{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}13331{_}_Seasonable_ from September to February.
10136-8{_}13332{_}[Illustration: THE HARE-RABBIT.]
10136-8{_}13333{_}THE HARE-RABBIT.--There has been lately introduced to French     tables an animal called the "Hare-rabbit," partaking of the     nature, characteristics, and qualifications of both the hare and     the rabbit.
10136-8{_}13334{_}It is highly spoken of, both as regards flesh and     flavour; and it is said to be the only hybrid which is able to     perpetuate its race.
10136-8{_}13335{_}We hope that some enterprising individual     will soon secure for English, tables what would seem to be a     really valuable addition to our other game and poultry dishes;     although it will be rather difficult to exactly assign its     proper position, as within or without the meaning of "game," as     by law established.
10136-8{_}13336{_}Only a few specimens have been seen in     England at present, but there is no reason to doubt that our     rabbit-fanciers will prove equal to the occasion, and cope     successfully with our neighbours across the Channel in     introducing a new animal serviceable in the kitchen.
10136-8{_}13337{_}[Illustration: ANGORA RABBIT.]
10136-8{_}13338{_}THE ANGORA RABBIT.--This is one of the handsomest of all     rabbits.
10136-8{_}13339{_}It takes its name from being an inhabitant of Angora, a     city and district of Asia Minor.
10136-8{_}13340{_}Like the well-known Angora goat     and cat, both of which are valuable on account of the fineness     of their wool and fur, this rabbit is prized for its long,     waved, silky fur, which, as an article of commerce is highly     esteemed.
10136-8{_}13341{_}We are not aware whether it is eaten by the     inhabitants, and but few specimens have been introduced into     England, where, doubtless, the beauty of its coat would     materially suffer from the more humid and less genial character     of the climate.
10136-8{_}13342{_}To the rabbits of the ancient and mountainous     district of Angora the words of the wise man would seem most to     apply, "The conies are but feeble folk, yet make they their     houses in the rocks."
10136-8{_}13343{_}[Illustration: HIMALAYA RABBITS.]
10136-8{_}13344{_}THE HIMALAYA RABBIT.--Amidst the mighty Himalaya mountains,     whose peaks are the highest on the globe, the pretty rabbit here     portrayed is found; and his colour seems to be like the snow,     which, above the altitude of from 13,000 to 16,000 feet,     perpetually crowns the summits of these monarchs of the world.
10136-8{_}13345{_}It is, at present, a very rare animal in England, but will,     doubtless, be more extensively known in the course of a few     years.
10136-8{_}13346{_}From the earth-tunnelling powers of this little animal,     Martial declares that mankind learned the art of fortification,     mining, and covered roads.
10136-8{_}13347{_}BOILED TURKEY.
10136-8{_}13348{_}986.
10136-8{_}13349{_}INGREDIENTS.--Turkey; forcemeat No.
10136-8{_}13350{_}417.
10136-8{_}13351{_}_Choosing and Trussing_.--Hen turkeys are preferable for boiling, on account of their whiteness and tenderness, and one of moderate size should be selected, as a large one is not suitable for this mode of cooking.
10136-8{_}13352{_}They should not be dressed until they have been killed 3 or 4 days, as they will neither look white, nor will they be tender.
10136-8{_}13353{_}Pluck the bird, carefully draw, and singe it with a piece of white paper, wash it inside and out, and wipe it thoroughly dry with a cloth.
10136-8{_}13354{_}Cut off the head and neck, draw the strings or sinews of the thighs, and cut off the legs at the first joint; draw the legs into the body, fill the breast with forcemeat made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}13355{_}417; run a skewer through the wing and the middle joint of the leg, quite into the leg and wing on the opposite side; break the breastbone, and make the bird look as round and as compact as possible.
10136-8{_}13356{_}[Illustration: BOILED TURKEY.]
10136-8{_}13357{_}_Mode_.--Put the turkey into sufficient _hot_ water to cover it; let it come to a boil, then carefully remove all the scum: if this is attended to, there is no occasion to boil the bird in a floured cloth; but it should be well covered with the water.
10136-8{_}13358{_}Let it simmer very gently for about 1-1/2 hour to 1-3/4 hour, according to the size, and serve with either white, celery, oyster, or mushroom sauce, or parsley-and-butter, a little of which should be poured over the turkey.
10136-8{_}13359{_}Boiled ham, bacon, tongue, or pickled pork, should always accompany this dish; and when oyster sauce is served, the turkey should be stuffed with oyster forcemeat.
10136-8{_}13360{_}_Time_.--A small turkey, 1-1/2 hour; a large one, 1-3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}13361{_}_Average cost_, 5s.
10136-8{_}13362{_}6d.
10136-8{_}13363{_}to 7s.
10136-8{_}13364{_}6d.
10136-8{_}13365{_}each, but more expensive at Christmas, on account of the great demand.
10136-8{_}13366{_}_Sufficient_ for 7 or 8 persons.
10136-8{_}13367{_}_Seasonable_ from December to February.
10136-8{_}13368{_}THE TURKEY.--The turkey, for which fine bird we are indebted to     America, is certainly one of the most glorious presents made by     the New World to the Old.
10136-8{_}13369{_}Some, indeed, assert that this bird     was known to the ancients, and that it was served at the     wedding-feast of Charlemagne.
10136-8{_}13370{_}This opinion, however, has been     controverted by first-rate authorities, who declare that the     French name of the bird, _dindon_, proves its origin; that the     form of the bird is altogether foreign, and that it is found in     America alone in a wild state.
10136-8{_}13371{_}There is but little doubt, from     the information which has been gained at considerable trouble,     that it appeared, generally, in Europe about the end of the 17th     century; that it was first imported into France by Jesuits, who     had been sent out missionaries to the West; and that from France     it spread over Europe.
10136-8{_}13372{_}To this day, in many localities in     France, a turkey is called a Jesuit.
10136-8{_}13373{_}On the farms of N. America,     where turkeys are very common, they are raised either from eggs     which have been found, or from young ones caught in the woods:     they thus preserve almost entirely their original plumage.
10136-8{_}13374{_}The     turkey only became gradually acclimated, both on the continent     and in England: in the middle of the 18th century, scarcely 10     out of 20 young turkeys lived; now, generally speaking, 15 out     of the same number arrive at maturity.
10136-8{_}13375{_}CROQUETTES OF TURKEY (Cold Meat Cookery).
10136-8{_}13376{_}987.
10136-8{_}13377{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold turkey; to every 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}13378{_}of meat allow 2 oz.
10136-8{_}13379{_}of ham or bacon, 2 shalots, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}13380{_}of butter, 1 tablespoonful of flour, the yolks of 2 eggs, egg and bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}13381{_}_Mode_.--The smaller pieces, that will not do for a fricassée or hash, answer very well for this dish.
10136-8{_}13382{_}Mince the meat finely with ham or bacon in the above proportion; make a gravy of the bones and trimmings, well seasoning it; mince the shalots, put them into a stewpan with the butter, add the flour; mix well, then put in the mince, and about 1/2 pint of the gravy made from the bones.
10136-8{_}13383{_}(The proportion of the butter must be increased or diminished according to the quantity of mince.)
10136-8{_}13384{_}When just boiled, add the yolks of 2 eggs; put the mixture out to cool, and then shape it in a wineglass.
10136-8{_}13385{_}Cover the croquettes with egg and bread crumbs, and fry them a delicate brown.
10136-8{_}13386{_}Put small pieces of parsley-stems for stalks, and serve with, rolled bacon cut very thin.
10136-8{_}13387{_}_Time_.--8 minutes to fry the croquettes.
10136-8{_}13388{_}_Seasonable_ from December to February.
10136-8{_}13389{_}THE WILD TURKEY.--In its wild state, the turkey is gregarious,     going together in extensive flocks, numbering as many as five     hundred.
10136-8{_}13390{_}These frequent the great swamps of America, where they     roost; but, at sunrise, leave these situations to repair to the     dry woods, in search of berries and acorns.
10136-8{_}13391{_}They perch on the     boughs of trees, and, by rising from branch to branch, attain     the height they desire.
10136-8{_}13392{_}They usually mount to the highest tops,     apparently from an instinctive conception that the loftier they     are the further they are out of danger.
10136-8{_}13393{_}They fly awkwardly, but     run with great swiftness, and, about the month of March become     so fat as not to be able to take a flight beyond three or four     hundred yards, and are then, also, easily run down by a     horseman.
10136-8{_}13394{_}Now, however, it rarely happens that wild turkeys are     seen in the inhabited parts of America.
10136-8{_}13395{_}It is only in the     distant and more unfrequented parts that they are found in great     numbers.
10136-8{_}13396{_}FRICASSEED TURKEY (Cold Meat Cookery).
10136-8{_}13397{_}988.
10136-8{_}13398{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold roast or boiled turkey; a strip of lemon-peel, a bunch of savoury herbs, 1 onion, pepper and salt to taste, 1 pint of water, 4 tablespoonfuls of cream, the yolk of an egg.
10136-8{_}13399{_}_Mode_.--Cut some nice slices from the remains of a cold turkey, and put the bones and trimmings into a stewpan, with the lemon-peel, herbs, onion, pepper, salt, add the water; stew for an hour, strain the gravy, and lay in the pieces of turkey.
10136-8{_}13400{_}When warm through, add the cream and the yolk of an egg; stir it well round, and, when getting thick, take out the pieces, lay them on a hot dish, and pour the sauce over.
10136-8{_}13401{_}Garnish the fricassée with sippets of toasted bread.
