10136-8{_}13946{_}_Seasonable_ from September to the end of February.
10136-8{_}13947{_}JUGGED HARE.
10136-8{_}13948{_}(_Very Good_.)
10136-8{_}13949{_}1031.
10136-8{_}13950{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 hare, 1-1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}13951{_}of gravy beef, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}13952{_}of butter, 1 onion, 1 lemon, 6 cloves; pepper, cayenne, and salt to taste; 1/2 pint of port wine.
10136-8{_}13953{_}_Mode_.--Skin, paunch, and wash the hare, cut it into pieces, dredge them with flour, and fry in boiling butter.
10136-8{_}13954{_}Have ready 1-1/2 pint of gravy, made from the above proportion of beef, and thickened with a little flour.
10136-8{_}13955{_}Put this into a jar; add the pieces of fried hare, an onion stuck with six cloves, a lemon peeled and cut in half, and a good seasoning of pepper, cayenne, and salt; cover the jar down tightly, put it up to the neck into a stewpan of boiling water, and let it stew until the hare is quite tender, taking care to keep the water boiling.
10136-8{_}13956{_}When nearly done, pour in the wine, and add a few forcemeat balls, made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}13957{_}417: these must be fried or baked in the oven for a few minutes before they are put to the gravy.
10136-8{_}13958{_}Serve with red-currant jelly.
10136-8{_}13959{_}_Time_,--3-1/2 to 4 hours.
10136-8{_}13960{_}If the hare is very old, allow 4-1/2 hours.
10136-8{_}13961{_}_Average cost_, 7s.
10136-8{_}13962{_}_Sufficient_ for 7 or 8 persons.
10136-8{_}13963{_}_Seasonable_ from September to the end of February.
10136-8{_}13964{_}II.
10136-8{_}13965{_}(_A Quicker and more Economical Way_.)
10136-8{_}13966{_}1032.
10136-8{_}13967{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 hare, a bunch of sweet herbs, 2 onions, each stuck with 3 cloves, 6 whole allspice, 1/2 teaspoonful of black pepper, a strip of lemon-peel, thickening of butter and flour, 2 tablespoonfuls of mushroom ketchup, 1/4 pint of port wine.
10136-8{_}13968{_}_Mode._--Wash the hare nicely, cut it up into joints (not too large), and flour and brown them as in the preceding recipe; then put them into a stewpan with the herbs, onions, cloves, allspice, pepper, and lemon-peel; cover with hot water, and when it boils, carefully remove all the scum, and let it simmer gently till tender, which will be in about 1-3/4 hour, or longer, should the hare be very old.
10136-8{_}13969{_}Take out the pieces of hare, thicken the gravy with flour and butter, add the ketchup and port wine, let it boil for about 10 minutes, strain it through a sieve over the hare, and serve.
10136-8{_}13970{_}A few fried forcemeat balls should be added at the moment of serving, or instead of frying them, they may be stewed in the gravy, about 10 minutes before the hare is wanted for table.
10136-8{_}13971{_}Do not omit to serve red-currant jelly with it.
10136-8{_}13972{_}_Time_.--Altogether 2 hours.
10136-8{_}13973{_}_Average cost_, 5s.
10136-8{_}13974{_}6d.
10136-8{_}13975{_}_Sufficient_ for 7 or 8 persons.
10136-8{_}13976{_}_Seasonable_ from September to the end of February.
10136-8{_}13977{_}_Note_.--Should there be any left, rewarm it the next day by putting the hare, &c. into a covered jar, and placing this jar in a saucepan of boiling water: this method prevents a great deal of waste.
10136-8{_}13978{_}ROAST LANDRAIL, OR CORN-CRAKE.
10136-8{_}13979{_}1033.
10136-8{_}13980{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 or 4 birds, butter, fried bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}13981{_}[Illustration: LANDRAILS.]
10136-8{_}13982{_}_Mode_.--Pluck and draw the birds, wipe them inside and out with damp cloths, and truss them in the following manner:--Bring the head round under the wing, and the thighs close to the sides; pass a skewer through them and the body, and keep the legs straight.
10136-8{_}13983{_}Roast them before a clear fire, keep them well basted, and serve on fried bread crumbs, with a tureen of brown gravy.
10136-8{_}13984{_}When liked, bread-sauce may also be sent to table with them.
10136-8{_}13985{_}_Time_.--12 to 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}13986{_}_Average cost_,--Seldom bought.
10136-8{_}13987{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow--1 for a dish.
10136-8{_}13988{_}_Seasonable_ from August 12th to the middle of September.
10136-8{_}13989{_}[Illustration: THE LANDRAIL.]
10136-8{_}13990{_}THE LANDRAIL, OR CORN-CRAKE.--This bird is migratory in its     habits, yet from its formation, it seems ill adapted for long     aërial passages, its wings being short, and placed so forward     out of the centre of gravity, that it flies in an extremely     heavy and embarrassed manner, and with its legs hanging down.
10136-8{_}13991{_}When it alights, it can hardly be sprung a second time, as it     runs very fast, and seems to depend for its safety more on the     swiftness of its feet than the celerity of its wings.
10136-8{_}13992{_}It makes     its appearance in England about the same time as the quail, that     is, in the months of April and May, and frequents the same     places.
10136-8{_}13993{_}Its singular cry is first heard when the grass becomes     long enough to shelter it, and it continues to be heard until     the grass is cut.
10136-8{_}13994{_}The bird, however, is seldom seen, for it     constantly skulks among the thickest portions of the herbage,     and runs so nimbly through it, doubling and winding in every     direction, that it is difficult to get near it.
10136-8{_}13995{_}It leaves this     island before the winter, and repairs to other countries in     search of its food, which principally consists of slugs, large     numbers of which it destroys.
10136-8{_}13996{_}It is very common in Ireland, and,     whilst migrating to this country, is seen in great numbers in     the island of Anglesea.
10136-8{_}13997{_}On its first arrival in England, it is     so lean as scarcely to weigh above five or six ounces; before     its departure, however, it has been known to exceed eight     ounces, and is then most delicious eating.
10136-8{_}13998{_}TO DRESS A LEVERET.
10136-8{_}13999{_}1034.
10136-8{_}14000{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 leverets, butter, flour.
10136-8{_}14001{_}_Mode_.--Leverets should be trussed in the same manner as a hare, but they do not require stuffing.
10136-8{_}14002{_}Roast them before a clear fire, and keep them well basted all the time they are cooking.
10136-8{_}14003{_}A few minutes before serving, dredge them lightly with flour, and froth them nicely.
10136-8{_}14004{_}Serve with plain gravy in the dish, and send to table red-currant jelly with them.
10136-8{_}14005{_}_Time_.--1/2 to 3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}14006{_}_Average cost_, in full season, 4s.
10136-8{_}14007{_}each.
10136-8{_}14008{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}14009{_}_Seasonable_ from May to August, but cheapest in July and August.
10136-8{_}14010{_}BROILED PARTRIDGE (a Luncheon, Breakfast, or Supper Dish).
10136-8{_}14011{_}1035.
10136-8{_}14012{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 partridges, salt and cayenne to taste, a small piece of butter, brown gravy or mushroom sauce.
10136-8{_}14013{_}_Mode_.--Pluck, draw, and cut the partridges in half, and wipe the inside thoroughly with a damp cloth.
10136-8{_}14014{_}Season them with salt and cayenne, broil them over a very clear fire, and dish them on a hot dish; rub a small piece of butter over each half, and send them to table with brown gravy or mushroom sauce.
10136-8{_}14015{_}_Time_.--About 1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}14016{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}14017{_}6d.
10136-8{_}14018{_}to 2s.
10136-8{_}14019{_}a brace.
10136-8{_}14020{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 or 4 persons.
10136-8{_}14021{_}_Seasonable_ from the 1st of September to the beginning of February.
10136-8{_}14022{_}PARTRIDGE PIE.
10136-8{_}14023{_}1036.
10136-8{_}14024{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 partridges, pepper and salt to taste, 1 teaspoonful of minced parsley (when obtainable, a few mushrooms), 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}14025{_}of veal cutlet, a slice of ham, 1/2 pint of stock, puff paste.
10136-8{_}14026{_}_Mode_.--Line a pie-dish with a veal cutlet; over that place a slice of ham and a seasoning of pepper and salt.
10136-8{_}14027{_}Pluck, draw, and wipe the partridges; cut off the legs at the first joint, and season them inside with pepper, salt, minced parsley, and a small piece of butter; place them in the dish, and pour over the stock; line the edges of the dish with puff paste, cover with the same, brush it over with the yolk of an egg, and bake for 3/4 to 1 hour.
10136-8{_}14028{_}_Time_.--3/4 to 1 hour.
10136-8{_}14029{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}14030{_}6d.
10136-8{_}14031{_}to 2s.
10136-8{_}14032{_}a brace.
10136-8{_}14033{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}14034{_}_Seasonable_ from the 1st of September to the beginning of February.
10136-8{_}14035{_}Note.--Should the partridges be very large, split them in half; they will then lie in the dish more compactly.
10136-8{_}14036{_}When at hand, a few mushrooms should always be added.
10136-8{_}14037{_}POTTED PARTRIDGE.
10136-8{_}14038{_}1037.
10136-8{_}14039{_}INGREDIENTS.--Partridges; seasoning to taste of mace, allspice white pepper, and salt; butter, coarse paste.
10136-8{_}14040{_}_Mode_.--Pluck and draw the birds, and wipe them inside with a damp cloth.
10136-8{_}14041{_}Pound well some mace, allspice, white pepper, and salt; mix together, and rub every part of the partridges with this.
10136-8{_}14042{_}Pack the birds as closely as possible in a baking-pan, with plenty of butter over them, and cover with a coarse flour and water crust.
10136-8{_}14043{_}Tie a paper over this, and bake for rather more than 1-1/2 hour; let the birds get cold, then cut them into pieces for keeping, pack them closely into a large potting-pot, and cover with clarified butter.
10136-8{_}14044{_}This should be kept in a cool dry place.
10136-8{_}14045{_}The butter used for potted things will answer for basting, or for paste for meat pies.--See coloured plate, D1.
10136-8{_}14046{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}14047{_}_Seasonable_ from the 1st of September to the beginning of February.
10136-8{_}14048{_}SALMI DE PERDRIX, or HASHED PARTRIDGES.
10136-8{_}14049{_}1038.
10136-8{_}14050{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 young partridges, 3 shalots, a slice of lean ham, 1 carrot, 3 or 4 mushrooms, a bunch of savoury herbs, 2 cloves, 6 whole peppers, 3/4 pint of stock, 1 glass of sherry or Madeira, a small lump of sugar.
10136-8{_}14051{_}_Mode_.--After the partridges are plucked and drawn, roast them rather underdone, and cover them with paper, as they should not be browned; cut them into joints, take off the skin from the wings, legs, and breasts; put these into a stewpan, cover them up, and set by until the gravy is ready.
10136-8{_}14052{_}Cut a slice of ham into small pieces, and put them, with the carrots sliced, the shalots, mushrooms, herbs, cloves, and pepper, into a stewpan; fry them lightly in a little butter, pour in the stock, add the bones and trimming from the partridges, and simmer for 1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}14053{_}Strain the gravy, let it cool, and skim off every particle of fat; put it to the legs, wings, and breasts, add a glass of sherry or Madeira and a small lump of sugar, let all gradually warm through by the side of the fire, and when on the point of boiling, serve, and garnish the dish with croûtons.
10136-8{_}14054{_}The remains of roast partridge answer very well dressed in this way, although not so good as when the birds are in the first instance only half-roasted.
10136-8{_}14055{_}This recipe is equally suitable for pheasants, moor-game, &c.; but care must be taken always to skin the joints.
10136-8{_}14056{_}_Time_.--Altogether 1 hour.
10136-8{_}14057{_}_Sufficient_.--2 or 3 partridges for an entrée.
10136-8{_}14058{_}_Seasonable_ from the 1st of September to the beginning of February.
10136-8{_}14059{_}ROAST PARTRIDGE.
10136-8{_}14060{_}1039.
10136-8{_}14061{_}INGREDIENTS.--Partridge; butter.
10136-8{_}14062{_}_Choosing and Trussing_.--Choose young birds, with dark-coloured bills and yellowish legs, and let them hang a few days, or there will be no flavour to the flesh, nor will it be tender.
10136-8{_}14063{_}The time they should be kept, entirely depends on the taste of those for whom they are intended, as what some persons would consider delicious, would be to others disgusting and offensive.
10136-8{_}14064{_}They may be trussed with or without the head, the latter mode being now considered the most fashionable.
10136-8{_}14065{_}Pluck, draw, and wipe the partridge carefully inside and out; cut off the head, leaving sufficient skin on the neck to skewer back; bring the legs close to the breast, between it and the side-bones, and pass a skewer through the pinions and the thick part of the thighs.
10136-8{_}14066{_}When the head is left on, it should be brought round and fixed on to the point of the skewer.
10136-8{_}14067{_}[Illustration: ROAST PARTRIDGE.]
10136-8{_}14068{_}_Mode_.--When the bird is firmly and plumply trussed, roast it before a nice bright fire; keep it well basted, and a few minutes before serving, flour and froth it well.
10136-8{_}14069{_}Dish it, and serve with gravy and bread sauce, and send to table hot and quickly.
10136-8{_}14070{_}A little of the gravy should be poured over the bird.--See coloured plate, D1.
10136-8{_}14071{_}_Time_.--25 to 35 minutes.
10136-8{_}14072{_}_Average cost_, is 1s.
10136-8{_}14073{_}6d.
10136-8{_}14074{_}to 2s.
10136-8{_}14075{_}a brace.
10136-8{_}14076{_}_Sufficient_,--2 for a dish.
10136-8{_}14077{_}_Seasonable_ from the 1st of September to the beginning of February.
10136-8{_}14078{_}[Illustration: PARTRIDGES.]
10136-8{_}14079{_}THE PARTRIDGE.--This bird is to be found in nearly all the     temperate countries of Europe, but is most abundant in the     Ukraine, although it is unable to bear the extremes of climate,     whether hot or cold.
10136-8{_}14080{_}It was formerly very common in France, and     is considered a table luxury in England.
10136-8{_}14081{_}The instinct of this     bird is frequently exemplified in a remarkable manner, for the     preservation of its young.
10136-8{_}14082{_}"I have seen it often," says a very     celebrated writer, and an accurate observer of nature, "and once     in particular, I saw an extraordinary instance of an old bird's     solicitude to save its brood.
10136-8{_}14083{_}As I was hunting with a young     pointer, the dog ran on a brood of very small partridges; the     old bird cried, fluttered, and ran tumbling along just before     the dog's nose, till she had drawn him to a considerable     distance, when she took wing, and flew still further off, but     not out of the field; on this the dog returned to me, near the     place where the young ones lay concealed in the grass, which the     old bird no sooner perceived than she flew back to us, settled     just before the dog's nose again, and by rolling and tumbling     about, drew off his attention from her young, and thus preserved     her brood a second time.
10136-8{_}14084{_}I have also seen, when a kite has been     hovering over a covey of young partridges, the old birds fly up     at the bird of prey, screaming and fighting with all their might     to preserve their brood."
10136-8{_}14085{_}Partridges should be chosen young; if     old, they are valueless.
10136-8{_}14086{_}The young ones are generally known by     their yellow legs and dark-coloured bills.
10136-8{_}14087{_}PHEASANT CUTLETS.
10136-8{_}14088{_}1040.
10136-8{_}14089{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 or 3 pheasants, egg and bread crumbs, cayenne and salt to taste, brown gravy.
10136-8{_}14090{_}_Mode_.--Procure 3 young pheasants that have been hung a few days; pluck, draw, and wipe them inside; cut them into joints; remove the bones from the best of these; and the backbones, trimmings, &c., put into a stewpan, with a little stock, herbs, vegetables, seasoning, &c., to make the gravy.
10136-8{_}14091{_}Flatten and trim the cutlets of a good shape, egg and bread crumb them, broil them over a clear fire, pile them high in the dish, and pour under them the gravy made from the bones, which should be strained, flavoured, and thickened.
10136-8{_}14092{_}One of the small bones should be stuck on the point of each cutlet.
10136-8{_}14093{_}_Time_.--10 minutes.
10136-8{_}14094{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}14095{_}6d.
10136-8{_}14096{_}to 3s.
10136-8{_}14097{_}each.
10136-8{_}14098{_}_Sufficient_ for 2 entrées.
10136-8{_}14099{_}_Seasonable_ from the 1st of October to the beginning of February.
10136-8{_}14100{_}ROAST PHEASANT.
10136-8{_}14101{_}1041.
10136-8{_}14102{_}INGREDIENTS.--Pheasant, flour, butter.
10136-8{_}14103{_}_Choosing and Trussing_.--Old pheasants may be known by the length and sharpness of their spurs; in young ones they are short and blunt.
10136-8{_}14104{_}The cock bird is generally reckoned the best, except when the hen is with egg.
10136-8{_}14105{_}They should hang some time before they are dressed, as, if they are cooked fresh, the flesh will be exceedingly dry and tasteless.
10136-8{_}14106{_}After the bird is plucked and drawn, wipe the inside with a damp cloth, and truss it in the same manner as partridge, No.
10136-8{_}14107{_}1039.
10136-8{_}14108{_}If the head is left on, as shown in the engraving, bring it round under the wing, and fix it on to the point of the skewer.
10136-8{_}14109{_}[Illustration: ROAST PHEASANT.]
10136-8{_}14110{_}_Mode_.--Roast it before a brisk fire, keep it well basted, and flour and froth it nicely.
10136-8{_}14111{_}Serve with brown gravy, a little of which should be poured round the bird, and a tureen of bread sauce.
10136-8{_}14112{_}2 or 3 of the pheasant's best tail-feathers are sometimes stuck in the tail as an ornament; but the fashion is not much to be commended.--See coloured plate, F1.
10136-8{_}14113{_}_Time_.--1/2 to 1 hour, according to the size.
10136-8{_}14114{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}14115{_}6d.
10136-8{_}14116{_}to 3s.
10136-8{_}14117{_}each.
10136-8{_}14118{_}_Sufficient_,--1 for a dish.
10136-8{_}14119{_}_Seasonable_ from the 1st of October to the beginning of February.
10136-8{_}14120{_}[Illustration: THE PHEASANT.]
10136-8{_}14121{_}THE PHEASANT.--This beautiful bird is said to have been     discovered by the Argonauts on the banks of the Phasis, near     Mount Ararat, in their expedition to Colchis.
10136-8{_}14122{_}It is common,     however, in almost all the southern parts of the European     continent, and has been long naturalized in the warmest and most     woody counties of England.
10136-8{_}14123{_}It is very common in France; indeed,     so common as to be esteemed a nuisance by the farmers.
10136-8{_}14124{_}Although     it has been domesticated, this is not easily accomplished, nor     is its flesh so palatable then as it is in the wild state.
10136-8{_}14125{_}Mr.     Ude says--"It is not often that pheasants are met with     possessing that exquisite taste which is acquired only by long     keeping, as the damp of this climate prevents their being kept     as long as they are in other countries.
10136-8{_}14126{_}The hens, in general,     are the most delicate.
10136-8{_}14127{_}The cocks show their age by their spurs.
10136-8{_}14128{_}They are only fit to be eaten when the blood begins to run from     the bill, which is commonly six days or a week after they have     been killed.
10136-8{_}14129{_}The flesh is white, tender, and has a good flavour,     if you keep it long enough; if not, it is not much different     from that of a common fowl or hen."
10136-8{_}14130{_}BRILLAT SAVARIN'S RECIPE FOR ROAST PHEASANT, a la Sainte Alliance.
10136-8{_}14131{_}1042.
10136-8{_}14132{_}When the pheasant is in good condition to be cooked (_see_ No.
10136-8{_}14133{_}1041), it should be plucked, and not before.
10136-8{_}14134{_}The bird should then be stuffed in the following manner:--Take two snipes, and draw them, putting the bodies on one plate, and the livers, &c., on another.
10136-8{_}14135{_}Take off the flesh, and mince it finely with a little beef, lard, a few truffles, pepper and salt to taste, and stuff the pheasant carefully with this.
10136-8{_}14136{_}Cut a slice of bread, larger considerably than the bird, and cover it with the liver, &c., and a few truffles: an anchovy and a little fresh butter added to these will do no harm.
10136-8{_}14137{_}Put the bread, &c., into the dripping-pan, and, when the bird is roasted, place it on the preparation, and surround it with Florida oranges.
10136-8{_}14138{_}Do not be uneasy, Savarin adds, about your dinner; for a pheasant served in this way is fit for beings better than men.
10136-8{_}14139{_}The pheasant itself is a very good bird; and, imbibing the dressing and the flavour of the truffle and snipe, it becomes thrice better.
10136-8{_}14140{_}BROILED PHEASANT (a Breakfast or Luncheon Dish).
10136-8{_}14141{_}1043.
10136-8{_}14142{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pheasant, a little lard, egg and bread crumbs, salt and cayenne to taste.
10136-8{_}14143{_}_Mode_.--Cut the legs off at the first joint, and the remainder of the bird into neat pieces; put them into a fryingpan with a little lard, and when browned on both sides, and about half done, take them out and drain them; brush the pieces over with egg, and sprinkle with bread crumbs with which has been mixed a good seasoning of cayenne and salt.
10136-8{_}14144{_}Broil them over a moderate fire for about 10 minutes, or rather longer, and serve with mushroom-sauce, sauce piquante, or brown gravy, in which a few game-bones and trimmings have been stewed.
10136-8{_}14145{_}_Time_.--Altogether 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}14146{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}14147{_}_Seasonable_ from the 1st of October to the beginning of February.
10136-8{_}14148{_}THE HEIGHT OF EXCELLENCE IN A PHEASANT.--Things edible have     their degrees of excellence under various circumstances: thus,     asparagus, capers, peas, and partridges are best when young.
10136-8{_}14149{_}Perfection in others is only reached when they attain maturity:     let us say, for example, melons and nearly all fruits (we must     except, perhaps, the medlar), with the majority of those animals     whose flesh we eat.
10136-8{_}14150{_}But others, again, are not good until     decomposition is about to set in; and here we may mention     particularly the snipe and the pheasant.
10136-8{_}14151{_}If the latter bird be     eaten so soon as three days after it has been killed, it then     has no peculiarity of flavour; a pullet would be more relished,     and a quail would surpass it in aroma.
10136-8{_}14152{_}Kept, however, a proper     length of time,--and this can be ascertained by a slight smell     and change of colour,--then it becomes a highly, flavoured dish,     occupying, so to speak, the middle distance between chicken and     venison.
10136-8{_}14153{_}It is difficult to define any exact time to "hang" a     pheasant; but any one possessed of the instincts of     gastronomical science, can at once detect the right moment when     a pheasant should be taken down, in the same way as a good cook     knows whether a bird should be removed from the spit, or have a     turn or two more.
10136-8{_}14154{_}TO DRESS PLOVERS.
10136-8{_}14155{_}1044.
10136-8{_}14156{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 plovers, butter, flour, toasted bread.
10136-8{_}14157{_}_Choosing and Trussing_.--Choose those that feel hard at the vent, as that shows their fatness.
10136-8{_}14158{_}There are three sorts,--the grey, green, and bastard plover, or lapwing.
10136-8{_}14159{_}They will keep good for some time, but if very stale, the feet will be very dry.
10136-8{_}14160{_}Plovers are scarcely fit for anything but roasting; they are, however, sometimes stewed, or made into a ragoût, but this mode of cooking is not to be recommended.
10136-8{_}14161{_}_Mode_.--Pluck off the feathers, wipe the outside of the birds with a damp cloth, and do not draw them; truss with the head under the wing, put them down to a clear fire, and lay slices of moistened toast in the dripping-pan, to catch the trail.
10136-8{_}14162{_}Keep them _well basted_, dredge them lightly with flour a few minutes before they are done, and let them be nicely frothed.
10136-8{_}14163{_}Dish them on the toasts, over which the _trail_ should be equally spread.
10136-8{_}14164{_}Pour round the toast a little good gravy, and send some to table in a tureen.
10136-8{_}14165{_}_Time_.--10 minutes to 1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}14166{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}14167{_}6d.
10136-8{_}14168{_}the brace, if plentiful.
10136-8{_}14169{_}_Sufficient_ for 2 persons.
10136-8{_}14170{_}_Seasonable_.--In perfection from the beginning of September to the end of January.
10136-8{_}14171{_}THE PLOVER.--There are two species of this bird, the grey and     the green, the former being larger than the other, and somewhat     less than the woodcock.
10136-8{_}14172{_}It has generally been classed with those     birds which chiefly live in the water; but it would seem only to     seek its food there, for many of the species breed upon the     loftiest mountains.
10136-8{_}14173{_}Immense flights of these birds are to be     seen in the Hebrides, and other parts of Scotland; and, in the     winter, large numbers are sent to the London market, which is     sometimes so much glutted with them that they are sold very     cheap.
10136-8{_}14174{_}Previous to dressing, they are kept till they have a game     flavour; and although their flesh is a favourite with many, it     is not universally relished.
10136-8{_}14175{_}The green is preferred to the grey,     but both are inferior to the woodcock.
10136-8{_}14176{_}Their eggs are esteemed     as a great delicacy.
10136-8{_}14177{_}Birds of this kind are migratory.
10136-8{_}14178{_}They     arrive in England in April, live with us all the spring and     summer, and at the beginning of autumn prepare to take leave by     getting together in flocks.
10136-8{_}14179{_}It is supposed that they then retire     to Spain, and frequent the sheep-walks with which that country     abounds.
10136-8{_}14180{_}[Illustration: THE PLOVER.]
10136-8{_}14181{_}TO DRESS THE PTARMIGAN.
10136-8{_}14182{_}1045.
10136-8{_}14183{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 or 3 birds; butter, flour, fried bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}14184{_}_Mode_.--The ptarmigan, or white grouse, when young and tender, are exceedingly fine eating, and should be kept as long as possible, to be good.
10136-8{_}14185{_}Pluck, draw, and truss them in the same manner as grouse, No.
10136-8{_}14186{_}1025, and roast them before a brisk fire.
10136-8{_}14187{_}Flour and froth them nicely, and serve on buttered toast, with a tureen of brown gravy.
10136-8{_}14188{_}Bread sauce, when liked, may be sent to table with them, and fried bread crumbs substituted for the toasted bread.
10136-8{_}14189{_}_Time_.--About 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}14190{_}_Sufficient_,--2 for a dish.
10136-8{_}14191{_}_Seasonable_ from the beginning of February to the end of April.
10136-8{_}14192{_}THE PTARMIGAN, OR WHITE GROUSE.--This bird is nearly the same     size as red grouse, and is fond of lofty situations, where it     braves the severest weather, and is found in most parts of     Europe, as well as in Greenland.
10136-8{_}14193{_}At Hudson's Bay they appear in     such multitudes that so many as sixty or seventy are frequently     taken at once in a net.
10136-8{_}14194{_}As they are as tame as chickens, this is     done without difficulty.
10136-8{_}14195{_}Buffon says that the Ptarmigan avoids     the solar heat, and prefers the frosts of the summits of the     mountains; for, as the snow melts on the sides of the mountains,     it ascends till it gains the top, where it makes a hole, and     burrows in the snow.
10136-8{_}14196{_}In winter, it flies in flocks, and feeds on     the wild vegetation of the hills, which imparts to its flesh a     bitter, but not altogether an unpalatable taste.
10136-8{_}14197{_}It is     dark-coloured, and has something of the flavour of the hare, and     is greatly relished, and much sought after by some sportsmen.
10136-8{_}14198{_}[Illustration: THE PTARMIGAN.]
10136-8{_}14199{_}TO DRESS QUAILS.
10136-8{_}14200{_}1046.
10136-8{_}14201{_}INGREDIENTS.--Quails, butter, toast.
10136-8{_}14202{_}_Mode_.--These birds keep good several days, and should be roasted without drawing.
10136-8{_}14203{_}Truss them in the same manner as woodcocks, No.
10136-8{_}14204{_}1062; roast them before a clear fire, keep them well basted, and serve on toast.
10136-8{_}14205{_}_Time_.--About 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}14206{_}_Average cost_.--Seldom bought.
10136-8{_}14207{_}_Sufficient_ 2 for a dish.
10136-8{_}14208{_}_Seasonable_ from October to December.
10136-8{_}14209{_}[Illustration: THE QUAIL.]
10136-8{_}14210{_}THE QUAIL.--Quails are almost universally diffused over Europe,     Asia, and Africa.
10136-8{_}14211{_}Being birds of passage, they are seen in     immense flocks, traversing the Mediterranean Sea from Europe to     Africa, in the autumn, and returning again in the spring,     frequently alighting in their passage on many of the islands of     the Archipelago, which, with their vast numbers, they almost     completely cover.
10136-8{_}14212{_}On the western coasts of the kingdom of     Naples, they have appeared in such prodigious numbers, that,     within the compass of four or five miles, as many as a hundred     thousand have been taken in a day.
10136-8{_}14213{_}"From these circumstances,"     says a writer on natural history, "it appears highly probable     that the quails which supplied the Israelites with food during     their journey through the wilderness, were sent thither, on     their passage to the north, by a wind from the south-west,     sweeping over Egypt and Ethiopia towards the shores of the Red     Sea."
10136-8{_}14214{_}In England they are not very numerous, although they breed     in it; and many of them are said to remain throughout the year,     changing their quarters from the interior parts of the country     for the seacoast.
10136-8{_}14215{_}TO DRESS SNIPES.
10136-8{_}14216{_}1047.
10136-8{_}14217{_}INGREDIENTS.--Snipes, butter, flour, toast.
10136-8{_}14218{_}_Mode_.--These, like woodcocks, should be dressed without being drawn.
10136-8{_}14219{_}Pluck, and wipe them outside, and truss them with the head under the wing, having previously skinned that and the neck.
10136-8{_}14220{_}Twist the legs at the first joint, press the feet upon the thighs, and pass a skewer through these and the body.
10136-8{_}14221{_}Place four on a skewer, tie them on to the jack or spit, and roast before a clear fire for about 1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}14222{_}Put some pieces of buttered toast into the dripping-pan to catch the trails; flour and froth the birds nicely, dish the pieces of toast with the snipes on them, and pour round, but not over them, a little good brown gravy.
10136-8{_}14223{_}They should be sent to table very hot and expeditiously, or they will not be worth eating.--See coloured plate M1.
10136-8{_}14224{_}[Illustration: ROAST SNIPE.]
10136-8{_}14225{_}_Time_.--About 1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}14226{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}14227{_}6d.
10136-8{_}14228{_}to 2s.
10136-8{_}14229{_}the brace.
10136-8{_}14230{_}_Sufficient_,--4 for a dish.
10136-8{_}14231{_}_Seasonable_ from November to February.
10136-8{_}14232{_}_Note_.--Ortolans are trussed and dressed in the same manner.
10136-8{_}14233{_}[Illustration: THE SNIPE.]
10136-8{_}14234{_}THE SNIPE.--This is a migratory bird, and is generally     distributed over Europe.
10136-8{_}14235{_}It is found in most parts of England,     in the high as well as the low lands, depending much on the     weather.
10136-8{_}14236{_}In very wet seasons it resorts to the hills, but at     other times frequents marshes, where it can penetrate the earth     with its bill, hunting for worms, which form its principal food.
10136-8{_}14237{_}In the Hebrides and the Orkneys snipes are plentiful, and they     are fattest in frosty weather.
10136-8{_}14238{_}In the breeding season the snipe     changes its note entirely from that which it has in the winter.
10136-8{_}14239{_}The male will keep on wing for an hour together, mounting like a     lark, and uttering a shrill piping noise; then, with a bleating     sound, not unlike that made by an old goat, it will descend with     great velocity, especially if the female be sitting in her nest,     from which it will not wander far.
10136-8{_}14240{_}ROAST TEAL.
10136-8{_}14241{_}1048.
10136-8{_}14242{_}INGREDIENTS.--Teal, butter, a little flour.
10136-8{_}14243{_}_Mode_.--Choose fat plump birds, after the frost has set in, as they are generally better flavoured; truss them in the same manner as wild duck, No.
10136-8{_}14244{_}1022; roast them before a brisk fire, and keep them well basted.
10136-8{_}14245{_}Serve with brown or orange gravy, water-cresses, and a cut lemon.
10136-8{_}14246{_}The remains of teal make excellent hash.
10136-8{_}14247{_}_Time_.--From 9 to 15 minutes.
10136-8{_}14248{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}14249{_}each; but seldom bought.
10136-8{_}14250{_}_Sufficient_,--2 for a dish.
10136-8{_}14251{_}_Seasonable_ from October to February.
10136-8{_}14252{_}ROAST HAUNCH OF VENISON.
10136-8{_}14253{_}1049.
10136-8{_}14254{_}INGREDIENTS.--Venison, coarse flour-and-water paste, a little flour.
10136-8{_}14255{_}_Mode_.--Choose a haunch with clear, bright, and thick fat, and the cleft of the hoof smooth and close; the greater quantity of fat there is, the better quality will the meat be.
10136-8{_}14256{_}As many people object to venison when it has too much _haut goût_, ascertain how long it has been kept, by running a sharp skewer into the meat close to the bone; when this is withdrawn, its sweetness can be judged of.
10136-8{_}14257{_}With care and attention, it will keep good a fortnight, unless the weather is very mild.
10136-8{_}14258{_}Keep it perfectly dry by wiping it with clean cloths till not the least damp remains, and sprinkle over powdered ginger or pepper, as a preventative against the fly.
10136-8{_}14259{_}When required for use, wash it in warm water, and _dry_ it _well_ with a cloth; butter a sheet of white paper, put it over the fat, lay a coarse paste, about 1/2 inch in thickness, over this, and then a sheet or two of strong paper.
10136-8{_}14260{_}Tie the whole firmly on to the haunch with twine, and put the joint down to a strong close fire; baste the venison immediately, to prevent the paper and string from burning, and continue this operation, without intermission, the whole of the time it is cooking.
10136-8{_}14261{_}About 20 minutes before it is done, carefully remove the paste and paper, dredge the joint with flour, and baste well with _butter_ until it is nicely frothed, and of a nice pale-brown colour; garnish the knuckle-bone with a frill of white paper, and serve with a good, strong, but unflavoured gravy, in a tureen, and currant jelly; or melt the jelly with a little port wine, and serve that also in a tureen.
10136-8{_}14262{_}As the principal object in roasting venison is to preserve the fat, the above is the best mode of doing so where expense is not objected to; but, in ordinary cases, the paste may be dispensed with, and a double paper placed over the roast instead: it will not require so long cooking without the paste.
10136-8{_}14263{_}Do not omit to send very hot plates to table, as the venison fat so soon freezes: to be thoroughly enjoyed by epicures, it should be eaten on hot-water plates.
10136-8{_}14264{_}The neck and shoulder may be roasted in the same manner.
10136-8{_}14265{_}[Illustration: ROAST HAUNCH OF VENISON.]
10136-8{_}14266{_}_Time_.--A large haunch of buck venison, with the paste, 4 to 5 hours; haunch of doe venison, 3-1/4 to 3-3/4 hours.
10136-8{_}14267{_}Allow less time without the paste.
10136-8{_}14268{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}14269{_}4d.
10136-8{_}14270{_}to 1s.
10136-8{_}14271{_}6d.
10136-8{_}14272{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}14273{_}_Sufficient_ for 18 persons.
10136-8{_}14274{_}_Seasonable_.--Buck venison in greatest perfection from June to Michaelmas; doe venison from November to the end of January.
10136-8{_}14275{_}THE DEER.--This active tribe of animals principally inhabit wild     and woody regions.
10136-8{_}14276{_}In their contentions, both with each other     and the rest of the brute creation, these animals not only use     their horns, but strike very furiously with their fore feet.
10136-8{_}14277{_}Some of the species are employed as beasts of draught, whilst     the flesh of the whole is wholesome, and that of some of the     kinds, under the name of "venison," is considered very     delicious.
10136-8{_}14278{_}Persons fond of hunting have invented peculiar terms     by which the objects of their pursuit are characterized: thus     the stag is called, the first year, a _calf_, or _hind-calf_;     the second, a _knobber_; the third, a _brock_; the fourth, a     _staggard_; the fifth, a _stag_; and the sixth, a _hart_.
10136-8{_}14279{_}The     female is, the first year, called a _calf_; the second, a     _hearse_; and the third, a _hind_.
10136-8{_}14280{_}In Britain, the stag has     become scarcer than it formerly was; but, in the Highlands of     Scotland, herds of four or five hundred may still be seen,     ranging over the vast mountains of the north; and some of the     stags of a great size.
10136-8{_}14281{_}In former times, the great feudal     chieftains used to hunt with all the pomp of eastern sovereigns,     assembling some thousands of their clans, who drove the deer     into the toils, or to such stations as were occupied by their     chiefs.
10136-8{_}14282{_}As this sport, however, was occasionally used as a means     for collecting their vassals together for the purpose of     concocting rebellion, an act was passed prohibitory of such     assemblages.
10136-8{_}14283{_}In the "Waverley" of Sir Walter Scott, a     deer-hunting scene of this kind is admirably described.
10136-8{_}14284{_}VENISON.--This is the name given to the flesh of some kinds of     deer, and is esteemed as very delicious.
10136-8{_}14285{_}Different species of     deer are found in warm as well as cold climates, and are in     several instances invaluable to man.
10136-8{_}14286{_}This is especially the case     with the Laplander, whose reindeer constitutes a large     proportion of his wealth.
10136-8{_}14287{_}There--        "The reindeer unharness'd in freedom can play,       And safely o'er Odin's steep precipice stray,       Whilst the wolf to the forest recesses may fly,       And howl to the moon as she glides through the sky."
10136-8{_}14288{_}In that country it is the substitute for the horse, the cow, the     goat, and the sheep.
10136-8{_}14289{_}From its milk is produced cheese; from its     skin, clothing; from its tendons, bowstrings and thread; from     its horns, glue; from its bones, spoons; and its flesh furnishes     food.
10136-8{_}14290{_}In England we have the stag, an animal of great beauty,     and much admired.
10136-8{_}14291{_}He is a native of many parts of Europe, and is     supposed to have been originally introduced into this country     from France.
10136-8{_}14292{_}About a century back he was to be found wild in     some of the rough and mountainous parts of Wales, as well as in     the forests of Exmoor, in Devonshire, and the woods on the banks     of the Tamar.
10136-8{_}14293{_}In the middle ages the deer formed food for the     not over abstemious monks, as represented by Friar Tuck's     larder, in the admirable fiction of "Ivanhoe;" and at a later     period it was a deer-stealing adventure that drove the     "ingenious" William Shakspeare to London, to become a common     player, and the greatest dramatist that ever lived.
10136-8{_}14294{_}HASHED VENISON.
10136-8{_}14295{_}1050.
10136-8{_}14296{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of roast venison, its own or mutton gravy, thickening of butter and flour.
10136-8{_}14297{_}_Mode_.--Cut the meat from the bones in neat slices, and, if there is sufficient of its own gravy left, put the meat into this, as it is preferable to any other.
10136-8{_}14298{_}Should there not be enough, put the bones and trimmings into a stewpan, with about a pint of mutton gravy; let them stew gently for an hour, and strain the gravy.
10136-8{_}14299{_}Put a little flour and butter into the stewpan, keep stirring until brown, then add the strained gravy, and give it a boil up; skim and strain again, and, when a little cool, put in the slices of venison.
10136-8{_}14300{_}Place the stewpan by the side of the fire, and, when on the point of simmering, serve: do not allow it to boil, or the meat will be hard.
10136-8{_}14301{_}Send red-currant jelly to table with it.
10136-8{_}14302{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}14303{_}_Seasonable_.--Buck venison, from June to Michaelmas; doe venison, from November to the end of January.
10136-8{_}14304{_}_Note_.--A small quantity of Harvey's sauce, ketchup, or port wine, may be added to enrich the gravy: these ingredients must, however, be used very sparingly, or they will overpower the flavour of the venison.
10136-8{_}14305{_}[Illustration: FALLOW-DEER (BUCK).
10136-8{_}14306{_}FALLOW-DEER (DOE).]
10136-8{_}14307{_}THE FALLOW-DEER.--This is the domestic or park deer; and no two     animals can make a nearer approach to each other than the stag     and it, and yet no two animals keep more distinct, or avoid each     other with a more inveterate animosity.
10136-8{_}14308{_}They never herd or     intermix together, and consequently never give rise to an     intermediate race; it is even rare, unless they have been     transported thither, to find fellow-deer in a country where     stags are numerous.
10136-8{_}14309{_}He is very easily tamed, and feeds upon many     things which the stag refuses: he also browzes closer than the     stag, and preserves his venison better.
10136-8{_}14310{_}The doe produces one     fawn, sometimes two, but rarely three.
10136-8{_}14311{_}In short, they resemble     the stag in all his natural habits, and the greatest difference     between them is the duration of their lives: the stag, it is     said, lives to the age of thirty-five or forty years, and the     fallow-deer does not live more than twenty.
10136-8{_}14312{_}As they are smaller     than the stag, it is probable that their growth is sooner     completed.
10136-8{_}14313{_}STEWED VENISON.
10136-8{_}14314{_}1051.
10136-8{_}14315{_}INGREDIENTS.--A shoulder of venison, a few slices of mutton fat, 2 glasses of port wine, pepper and allspice to taste, 1-1/2 pint of weak stock or gravy, 1/2 teaspoonful of whole pepper, 1/2 teaspoonful of whole allspice.
10136-8{_}14316{_}_Mode_.--Hang the venison till tender; take out the bone, flatten the meat with a rolling-pin, and place over it a few slices of mutton fat, which have been previously soaked for 2 or 3 hours in port wine; sprinkle these with a little fine allspice and pepper, roll the meat up, and bind and tie it securely.
10136-8{_}14317{_}Put it into a stewpan with the bone and the above proportion of weak stock or gravy, whole allspice, black pepper, and port wine; cover the lid down closely, and simmer, very gently, from 3-1/2 to 4 hours.
10136-8{_}14318{_}When quite tender, take off the tape, and dish the meat; strain the gravy over it, and send it to table with red-currant jelly.
10136-8{_}14319{_}Unless the joint is very fat, the above is the best mode of cooking it.
10136-8{_}14320{_}_Time_.--3-1/2 to 4 hours.
10136-8{_}14321{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}14322{_}4d.
10136-8{_}14323{_}to 1s.
10136-8{_}14324{_}6d.
10136-8{_}14325{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}14326{_}_Sufficient_ for 10 or 12 persons.
10136-8{_}14327{_}_Seasonable_.--Buck venison, from June to Michaelmas; doe venison, from November to the end of January.
10136-8{_}14328{_}[Illustration: THE ROEBUCK.]
10136-8{_}14329{_}THE ROEBUCK.--This is the _Certuscapreolus_, or common roe, and     is of a reddish-brown colour.
10136-8{_}14330{_}It is an inhabitant of Asia, as     well as of Europe.
10136-8{_}14331{_}It has great grace in its movements, and     stands about two feet seven inches high, and has a length of     about three feet nine.
10136-8{_}14332{_}The extent of its horns is from six to     eight inches.
10136-8{_}14333{_}[Illustration: THE STAG.
10136-8{_}14334{_}THE HIND.]
10136-8{_}14335{_}THE STAG.--The stag, or hart, is the male of the red deer, and     the hind is the female.
10136-8{_}14336{_}He is much larger than the fallow-deer,     and his age is indicated by his horns, which are round instead     of being palmated, like those of the fallow-deer.
10136-8{_}14337{_}During the     first year he has no horns, but a horny excrescence, which is     short and rough, and covered with a thin hairy skin.
10136-8{_}14338{_}The next     year, the horns are single and straight; and in the third they     have two antlers, three the fourth, four the fifth, and five the     sixth year; although this number is not always certain, for     sometimes they are more, and often less.
10136-8{_}14339{_}After the sixth year,     the antlers do not always increase; and, although in number they     may amount to six or seven on each side, yet the animal's age is     then estimated rather by the size of the antlers and the     thickness of the branch which sustains them, than by their     variety.
10136-8{_}14340{_}Large as these horns seem, however, they are shed every     year, and their place supplied by new ones.
10136-8{_}14341{_}This usually takes     place in the spring.
10136-8{_}14342{_}When the old horns have fallen off, the new     ones do not make their appearance immediately; but the bones of     the skull ore seen covered with a transparent periosteum, or     skin, which enwraps the bones of all animals.
10136-8{_}14343{_}After a short     time, however, the skin begins to swell, and to form a sort of     tumour.
10136-8{_}14344{_}From this, by-and-by, rising from the head, shoot forth     the antlers from each side; and, in a short time, in proportion     as the animal is in condition, the entire horns are completed.
10136-8{_}14345{_}The solidity of the extremities, however, is not perfect until     the horns have arrived at their full growth.
10136-8{_}14346{_}Old stags usually     shed their horns first, which generally happens towards the     latter end of February or the beginning of March.
10136-8{_}14347{_}Such as are     between five and six years old shed them about the middle or     latter end of March; those still younger in the month of April;     and the youngest of all not till the middle or latter end of     May.
10136-8{_}14348{_}These rules, though generally true, are subject to     variations; for a severe winter will retard the shedding of the     horns.--The HIND has no horns, and is less fitted for being     hunted than the male.
10136-8{_}14349{_}She takes the greatest care of her young,     and secretes them in the most obscure thickets, lest they become     a prey to their numerous enemies.
10136-8{_}14350{_}All the rapacious family of     the cat kind, with the wolf, the dog, the eagle, and the falcon,     are continually endeavouring to find her retreat, whilst the     stag himself is the foe of his own offspring.
10136-8{_}14351{_}When she has     young, therefore, it would seem that the courage of the male is     transferred to the female, for she defends them with the most     resolute bravery.
10136-8{_}14352{_}If pursued by the hunter, she will fly before     the hounds for half the day, and then return to her young, whose     life she has thus preserved at the hazard of her own.
10136-8{_}14353{_}[Illustration: ELAND (BULL).
10136-8{_}14354{_}ELAND (COW).]
10136-8{_}14355{_}THE NEW VENISON.--The deer population of our splendid English     parks was, until a few years since, limited to two species, the     fallow and the red.
10136-8{_}14356{_}But as the fallow-deer itself was an     acclimated animal, of comparatively recent introduction, it came     to be a question why might not the proprietor of any deer-park     in England have the luxury of at least half a dozen species of     deer and antelopes, to adorn the hills, dales, ferny brakes, and     rich pastures of his domain?
10136-8{_}14357{_}The temperate regions of the whole     world might be made to yield specimens of the noble ruminant,     valuable either for their individual beauty, or for their     availability to gastronomic purposes.
10136-8{_}14358{_}During the last four or live years a few spirited English     noblemen have made the experiment of breeding foreign deer in     their parks, and have obtained such a decided success, that it     may be hoped their example will induce others to follow in a     course which will eventually give to England's rural scenery a     new element of beauty, and to English tables a fresh viand of     the choicest character.
10136-8{_}14359{_}A practical solution of this interesting question was made by     Viscount Hill, at Hawkestone Park, Salop, in January, 1809.
10136-8{_}14360{_}On     that occasion a magnificent eland, an acclimated scion of the     species whose native home is the South African wilderness, was     killed for the table.
10136-8{_}14361{_}The noble beast was thus described:--"He     weighed 1,176 lbs.
10136-8{_}14362{_}as he dropped; huge as a short-horn, but with     bone not half the size; active as a deer, stately in all his     paces, perfect in form, bright in colour, with a vast dewlap,     and strong sculptured horn.
10136-8{_}14363{_}This eland in his lifetime strode     majestic on the hill-side, where he dwelt with his mates and     their progeny, all English-born, like himself."
10136-8{_}14364{_}Three pairs of     the same species of deer were left to roam at large on the     picturesque elopes throughout the day, and to return to their     home at pleasure.
10136-8{_}14365{_}"Here, during winter, they are assisted with     roots and hay, but in summer they have nothing but the pasture     of the park; so that, in point of expense, they cost no more     than cattle of the best description."
10136-8{_}14366{_}Travellers and sportsmen     say that the male eland is unapproached in the quality of his     flesh by any ruminant in South Africa; that it grows to an     enormous size, and lays on fat with as great facility as a true     short-horn; while in texture and flavour it is infinitely     superior.
10136-8{_}14367{_}The lean is remarkably fine, the fat firm and     delicate.
10136-8{_}14368{_}It was tried in every fashion,--braised brisket,     roasted ribs, broiled steaks, filet sauté, boiled aitchbone,     &c.,--and in all, gave evidence of the fact, that a new meat of     surpassing value had been added to the products of the English     park.
10136-8{_}14369{_}When we hear such a gratifying account of the eland, it is     pleasing to record that Lord Hastings has a herd of the Canadian     wapiti, a herd of Indian nylghaus, and another of the small     Indian hog-deer; that the Earl of Ducie has been successful in     breeding the magnificent Persian deer.
10136-8{_}14370{_}The eland was first     acclimated in England by the late Earl of Derby, between the     years 1835-1851, at his menagerie at Knowsley.
10136-8{_}14371{_}On his death, in     1851, he bequeathed to the Zoological Society his breed of     elands, consisting of two males and three females.
10136-8{_}14372{_}Here the     animals have been treated with the greatest success, and from     the year 1853 to the present time, the females have regularly     reproduced, without the loss of a single calf.
10136-8{_}14373{_}ROAST WIDGEON.
10136-8{_}14374{_}1052.
10136-8{_}14375{_}INGREDIENTS.--Widgeons, a little flour, butter.
10136-8{_}14376{_}_Mode_.--These are trussed in the same manner as wild duck, No.
10136-8{_}14377{_}1022, but must not be kept so long before they are dressed.
10136-8{_}14378{_}Put them down to a brisk fire; flour, and baste them continually with butter, and, when browned and nicely frothed, send them to table hot and quickly.
10136-8{_}14379{_}Serve with brown gravy, or orange gravy, No.
10136-8{_}14380{_}488, and a cut lemon.
10136-8{_}14381{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour; if liked well done, 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}14382{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}14383{_}each; but seldom bought.
10136-8{_}14384{_}_Sufficient_,--2 for a dish.
10136-8{_}14385{_}_Seasonable_ from October to February.
10136-8{_}14386{_}[Illustration: ROAST WOODCOCK.]
10136-8{_}14387{_}ROAST WOODCOCK.
10136-8{_}14388{_}1053.
10136-8{_}14389{_}INGREDIENTS.--Woodcocks; butter, flour, toast.
10136-8{_}14390{_}_Mode_.--Woodcocks should not be drawn, as the trails are, by epicures, considered a great delicacy.
10136-8{_}14391{_}Pluck, and wipe them well outside; truss them with the legs close to the body, and the feet pressing upon the thighs; skin the neck and head, and bring the beak round under the wing.
10136-8{_}14392{_}Place some slices of toast in the dripping-pan to catch the trails, allowing a piece of toast for each bird.
10136-8{_}14393{_}Roast before a clear fire from 15 to 25 minutes; keep them well basted, and flour and froth them nicely.
10136-8{_}14394{_}When done, dish the pieces of toast with the birds upon them, and pour round a very little gravy; send some more to table in a tureen.
10136-8{_}14395{_}These are most delicious birds when well cooked, but they should not be kept too long: when the feathers drop, or easily come out, they are fit for table.--See coloured plate, I 1.
10136-8{_}14396{_}_Time_.---When liked underdone, 15 to 20 minutes; if liked well done, allow an extra 5 minutes.
10136-8{_}14397{_}_Average cost_.--Seldom bought.
10136-8{_}14398{_}_Sufficient_,--2 for a dish.
10136-8{_}14399{_}_Seasonable_ from November to February.
10136-8{_}14400{_}[Illustration: THE WOODCOCK.]
10136-8{_}14401{_}THE WOODCOCK.--This bird being migratory in its habits, has,     consequently, no settled habitation; it cannot be considered as     the property of any one, and is, therefore, not game by law.
10136-8{_}14402{_}It     breeds in high northern latitudes, and the time of its     appearance and disappearance in Sweden coincides exactly with     that of its arrival in and return from Great Britain.
10136-8{_}14403{_}On the     coast of Suffolk its vernal and autumnal visits have been     accurately observed.
10136-8{_}14404{_}In the first week of October it makes its     appearance in small numbers, but in November and December it     appears in larger numbers, and always after sunset, and most     gregariously.
10136-8{_}14405{_}In the same manner as woodcocks take their leave     of us, they quit France, Germany, and Italy, making the northern     and colder climates their summer rendezvous.
10136-8{_}14406{_}They visit Burgundy     in the latter part of October, but continue there only a few     weeks, the country being hard, and unable to supply them with     such sustenance as they require.
10136-8{_}14407{_}In the winter, they are found     as far south as Smyrna and Aleppo, and, during the same season,     in Barbary, where the Africans name them "the ass of the     partridge."
10136-8{_}14408{_}It has been asserted that they have been seen as far     south as Egypt, which is the most remote region to which they     can be traced on that side of the eastern world; on the other     side, they are common in Japan.
10136-8{_}14409{_}Those which resort to the     countries of the Levant are supposed to come from the mountains     of Armenia, or the deserts of Tartary or Siberia.
10136-8{_}14410{_}The flesh of     the woodcock is held in high estimation; hence the bird is     eagerly sought after by the sportsman.
10136-8{_}14411{_}GAME CARVING.
10136-8{_}14412{_}BLACKCOCK.
10136-8{_}14413{_}[Illustration: BLACKCOCK.]
10136-8{_}14414{_}1054.
10136-8{_}14415{_}Skilful carving of game undoubtedly adds to the pleasure of the guests at a dinner-table; for game seems pre-eminently to be composed of such delicate limbs and tender flesh that an inapt practitioner appears to more disadvantage when mauling these pretty and favourite dishes, than larger and more robust _pièces de résistance_.
10136-8{_}14416{_}As described at recipe No.
10136-8{_}14417{_}1019, this bird is variously served with or without the head on; and although we do not personally object to the appearance of the head as shown in the woodcut, yet it seems to be more in vogue to serve it without.
10136-8{_}14418{_}The carving is not difficult, but should be elegantly and deftly done.
10136-8{_}14419{_}Slices from the breast, cut in the direction of the dotted line from 2 to 1, should be taken off, the merrythought displaced and the leg and wing removed by running the knife along from 3 to 4, and following the directions given under the head of boiled fowl, No.
10136-8{_}14420{_}1000, reserving the thigh, which is considered a great delicacy, for the most honoured guests, some of whom may also esteem the brains of this bird.
10136-8{_}14421{_}WILD DUCK.
10136-8{_}14422{_}[Illustration: WILD DUCK.]
10136-8{_}14423{_}1055.
10136-8{_}14424{_}As game is almost universally served as a dainty, and not as a dish to stand the assaults of an altogether fresh appetite, these dishes are not usually cut up entirely, but only those parts are served of each, which are considered the best-flavoured and the primest.
10136-8{_}14425{_}Of wild-fowl, the breast alone is considered by epicures worth eating, and slices are cut from this, in the direction indicated by the lines, from 1 to 2; if necessary, the leg and wing can be taken off by passing the knife from 3 to 4, and by generally following the directions described for carving boiled fowl, No.
10136-8{_}14426{_}1000.
10136-8{_}14427{_}ROAST HARE.
10136-8{_}14428{_}[Illustration: ROAST HARE.]
10136-8{_}14429{_}1056.
10136-8{_}14430{_}The "Grand Carver" of olden times, a functionary of no ordinary dignity, was pleased when he had a hare to manipulate, for his skill and grace had an opportunity of display.
10136-8{_}14431{_}_Diners à la Russe_ may possibly, erewhile, save modern gentlemen the necessity of learning the art which was in auld lang syne one of the necessary accomplishments of the youthful squire; but, until side-tables become universal, or till we see the office of "grand carver" once more instituted, it will be well for all to learn how to assist at the carving of this dish, which, if not the most elegant in appearance, is a very general favourite.
10136-8{_}14432{_}The hare, having its head to the left, as shown in the woodcut, should be first served by cutting slices from each side of the backbone, in the direction of the lines from 3 to 4.
10136-8{_}14433{_}After these prime parts are disposed of, the leg should next be disengaged by cutting round the line indicated by the figures 5 to 6.
10136-8{_}14434{_}The shoulders will then be taken off by passing the knife round from 7 to 8.
10136-8{_}14435{_}The back of the hare should now be divided by cutting quite through its spine, as shown by the line 1 to 2, taking care to feel with the point of the knife for a joint where the back may be readily penetrated.
10136-8{_}14436{_}It is the usual plan not to serve any bone in helping hare; and thus the flesh should be sliced from the legs and placed alone on the plate.
10136-8{_}14437{_}In large establishments, and where men-cooks are kept, it is often the case that the backbone of the hare, especially in old animals, is taken out, and then the process of carving is, of course, considerably facilitated.
10136-8{_}14438{_}A great point to be remembered in connection with carving hare is, that plenty of gravy should accompany each helping; otherwise this dish, which is naturally dry, will lose half its flavour, and so become a failure.
10136-8{_}14439{_}Stuffing is also served with it; and the ears, which should be nicely crisp, and the brains of the hare, are esteemed as delicacies by many connoisseurs.
10136-8{_}14440{_}PARTRIDGES.
10136-8{_}14441{_}[Illustration: ROAST PARTRIDGES.]
10136-8{_}14442{_}1057.
10136-8{_}14443{_}There are several ways of carving this most familiar game bird.
10136-8{_}14444{_}The more usual and summary mode is to carry the knife sharply along the top of the breastbone of the bird, and cut it quite through, thus dividing it into two precisely equal and similar parts, in the same manner as carving a pigeon, No.
10136-8{_}14445{_}1003.
10136-8{_}14446{_}Another plan is to cut it into three pieces; viz., by severing a small wing and leg on either side from the body, by following the line 1 to 2 in the upper woodcut; thus making 2 helpings, when the breast will remain for a third plate.
10136-8{_}14447{_}The most elegant manner is that of thrusting back the body from the legs, and then cutting through the breast in the direction shown by the line 1 to 2: this plan will give 4 or more small helpings.
10136-8{_}14448{_}A little bread-sauce should be served to each guest.
10136-8{_}14449{_}GROUSE.
10136-8{_}14450{_}[Illustration]  1058.
10136-8{_}14451{_}GROUSE may be carved in the way first described in carving partridge.
10136-8{_}14452{_}The backbone of the grouse is highly esteemed by many, and this part of many game birds is considered the finest flavoured.
10136-8{_}14453{_}PHEASANT.
10136-8{_}14454{_}[Illustration: ROAST PHEASANT.]
10136-8{_}14455{_}1059.
10136-8{_}14456{_}Fixing the fork in the breast, let the carver cut slices from it in the direction of the lines from 2 to 1: these are the prime pieces.
10136-8{_}14457{_}If there be more guests to satisfy than these slices will serve, then let the legs and wings be disengaged in the same manner as described in carving boiled fowl, No.
10136-8{_}14458{_}1000, the point where the wing joins the neckbone being carefully found.
10136-8{_}14459{_}The merrythought will come off in the same way as that of a fowl.
10136-8{_}14460{_}The most valued parts are the same as those which are most considered in a fowl.
10136-8{_}14461{_}SNIPE.
10136-8{_}14462{_}[Illustration: SNIPE.]
10136-8{_}14463{_}1060.
10136-8{_}14464{_}One of these small but delicious birds may be given, whole, to a gentleman; but, in helping a lady, it will be better to cut them quite through the centre, from 1 to 2, completely dividing them into equal and like portions, and put only one half on the plate.
10136-8{_}14465{_}HAUNCH OF VENISON.
10136-8{_}14466{_}[Illustration: HAUNCH OF VENISON.]
10136-8{_}14467{_}1061.
10136-8{_}14468{_}Here is a grand dish for a knight of the carving-knife to exercise his skill upon, and, what will be pleasant for many to know, there is but little difficulty in the performance.
10136-8{_}14469{_}An incision being made completely down to the bone, in the direction of the line 1 to 2, the gravy will then be able easily to flow; when slices, not too thick, should be cut along the haunch, as indicated by the line 4 to 3; that end of the joint marked 3 having been turned towards the carver, so that he may have a more complete command over the joint.
10136-8{_}14470{_}Although some epicures affect to believe that some parts of the haunch are superior to others, yet we doubt if there is any difference between the slices cut above and below the line.
10136-8{_}14471{_}It should be borne in mind to serve each guest with a portion of fat; and the most expeditious carver will be the best carver, as, like mutton, venison soon begins to chill, when it loses much of its charm.
10136-8{_}14472{_}WOODCOCK.
10136-8{_}14473{_}[Illustration: WOODCOCK.]
10136-8{_}14474{_}1062.
10136-8{_}14475{_}This bird, like a partridge, may be carved by cutting it exactly into two like portions, or made into three helpings, as described in carving partridge (No.
10136-8{_}14476{_}1057).
10136-8{_}14477{_}The backbone is considered the tit-bit of a woodcock, and by many the thigh is also thought a great delicacy.
10136-8{_}14478{_}This bird is served in the manner advised by Brillat Savarin, in connection with the pheasant, viz., on toast which has received its drippings whilst roasting; and a piece of this toast should invariably accompany each plate.
10136-8{_}14479{_}LANDRAIL.
10136-8{_}14480{_}1063.
10136-8{_}14481{_}LANDRAIL, being trussed like Snipe, with the exception of its being drawn, may be carved in the same manner.--See No.
10136-8{_}14482{_}1060.
10136-8{_}14483{_}PTARMIGAN.
10136-8{_}14484{_}1064.
10136-8{_}14485{_}PTARMIGAN, being of much the same size, and trussed in the same manner, as the red-bird, may be carved in the manner described in Partridge and Grouse carving, Nos.
10136-8{_}14486{_}1057 and 1058.
10136-8{_}14487{_}QUAILS.
10136-8{_}14488{_}1065.
10136-8{_}14489{_}QUAILS, being trussed and served like Woodcock, may be similarly carved.--See No.
10136-8{_}14490{_}1062.
10136-8{_}14491{_}PLOVERS.
10136-8{_}14492{_}1066.
10136-8{_}14493{_}PLOVERS may be carved like Quails or Woodcock, being trussed and served in the same way as those birds.--See No.
10136-8{_}14494{_}1055.
10136-8{_}14495{_}TEAL.
10136-8{_}14496{_}1067.
10136-8{_}14497{_}TEAL, being of the same character as Widgeon and Wild Duck, may be treated, in carving, in the same style.
10136-8{_}14498{_}WIDGEON.
10136-8{_}14499{_}1068.
10136-8{_}14500{_}WIDGEON may be carved in the same way as described in regard to Wild Duck, at No.
10136-8{_}14501{_}1055.
10136-8{_}14502{_}[Illustration]     [Illustration]  CHAPTER XXIV.
10136-8{_}14503{_}GENERAL OBSERVATIONS ON VEGETABLES.
10136-8{_}14504{_}"Strange there should be found   Who, self-imprison'd in their proud saloons,   Renounce the odours of the open field   For the unscented fictions of the loom;   Who, satisfied with only pencilled scenes,   Prefer to the performance of a God,   Th' inferior wonders of an artist's hand!
10136-8{_}14505{_}Lovely, indeed, the mimic works of art,   But Nature's works far lovelier."--COWPER.
10136-8{_}14506{_}1069.
10136-8{_}14507{_}"THE ANIMAL AND VEGETABLE KINGDOMS," says Hogg, in his Natural History of the Vegetable Kingdom, "may be aptly compared to the primary colours of the prismatic spectrum, which are so gradually and intimately blended, that we fail to discover where the one terminates and where the other begins.
10136-8{_}14508{_}If we had to deal with yellow and blue only, the eye would easily distinguish the one from the other; but when the two are blended, and form green, we cannot tell where the blue ends and the yellow begins.
10136-8{_}14509{_}And so it is in the animal and vegetable kingdoms.
10136-8{_}14510{_}If our powers of observation were limited to the highest orders of animals and plants, if there were only mammals, birds, reptiles, fishes, and insects in the one, and trees, shrubs, and herbs in the other, we should then be able with facility to define the bounds of the two kingdoms; but as we descend the scale of each, and arrive at the lowest forms of animals and plants, we there meet with bodies of the simplest structure, sometimes a mere cell, whose organization, modes of development and reproduction, are so anomalous, and partake so much of the character of both, that we cannot distinguish whether they are plants or whether they are animals."
10136-8{_}14511{_}1070.
10136-8{_}14512{_}WHILST IT IS DIFFICULT TO DETERMINE where the animal begins and the vegetable ends, it is as difficult to account for many of the singularities by which numbers of plants are characterized.
10136-8{_}14513{_}This, however, can hardly be regarded as a matter of surprise, when we recollect that, so far as it is at present known, the vegetable kingdom is composed of upwards of 92,000 species of plants.
10136-8{_}14514{_}Of this amazing number the lichens and the mosses are of the simplest and hardiest kinds.
10136-8{_}14515{_}These, indeed, may be considered as the very creators of the soil: they thrive in the coldest and most sterile regions, many of them commencing the operations of nature in the growth of vegetables on the barest rocks, and receiving no other nourishment than such as may be supplied to them by the simple elements of air and rain.
10136-8{_}14516{_}When they have exhausted their period in such situations as have been assigned them, they pass into a state of decay, and become changed into a very fine mould, which, in the active spontaneity of nature, immediately begins to produce other species, which in their turn become food for various mosses, and also rot.
10136-8{_}14517{_}This process of growth and decay, being, from time to time, continued, by-and-by forms a soil sufficient for the maintenance of larger plants, which also die and decay, and so increase the soil, until it becomes deep enough to sustain an oak, or even the weight of a tropical forest.
10136-8{_}14518{_}To create soil amongst rocks, however, must not be considered as the only end of the lichen; different kinds of it minister to the elegant arts, in the form of beautiful dyes; thus the _lichen rocella_ is used to communicate to silk and wool, various shades of purple and crimson, which greatly enhance the value of these materials.
10136-8{_}14519{_}This species is chiefly imported from the Canary Islands, and, when scarce, as an article of commerce has brought as much as £1000 per ton.
10136-8{_}14520{_}1071.
10136-8{_}14521{_}IN THE VICINITY OF LICHENS, THE MUSCI, OR MOSSES, are generally to be found.
10136-8{_}14522{_}Indeed, wherever vegetation can be sustained, there they are, affording protection to the roots and seeds of more delicate vegetables, and, by their spongy texture, retaining a moisture which preserves other plants from the withering drought of summer.
10136-8{_}14523{_}But even in winter we find them enlivening, by their verdure, the cold bosom of Nature.
10136-8{_}14524{_}We see them abounding in our pastures and our woods, attaching themselves to the living, and still more abundantly to the dead, trunks and branches of trees.
10136-8{_}14525{_}In marshy places they also abound, and become the medium of their conversion into fruitful fields.
10136-8{_}14526{_}This is exemplified by the manner in which peat-mosses are formed: on the surface of these we find them in a state of great life and vigour; immediately below we discover them, more or less, in a state of decomposition; and, still deeper, we find their stems and branches consolidated into a light brown peat.
10136-8{_}14527{_}Thus are extensive tracts formed, ultimately to be brought into a state of cultivation, and rendered subservient to the wants of man.
10136-8{_}14528{_}1072.
10136-8{_}14529{_}WHEN NATURE HAS FOUND A SOIL, her next care is to perfect the growth of her seeds, and then to disperse them.
10136-8{_}14530{_}Whilst the seed remains confined in its capsule, it cannot answer its purpose; hence, when it is sufficiently ripe, the pericardium opens, and lets it out.
10136-8{_}14531{_}What must strike every observer with surprise is, how nuts and shells, which we can hardly crack with our teeth, or even with a hammer, will divide of themselves, and make way for the little tender sprout which proceeds from the kernel.
10136-8{_}14532{_}There are instances, it is said, such as in the Touch-me-not (_impatiens_), and the Cuckoo-flower (_cardamine_), in which the seed-vessels, by an elastic jerk at the moment of their explosion, cast the seeds to a distance.
10136-8{_}14533{_}We are all aware, however, that many seeds--those of the most composite flowers, as of the thistle and dandelion--are endowed with, what have not been inappropriately called, wings.
10136-8{_}14534{_}These consist of a beautiful silk-looking down, by which they are enabled to float in the air, and to be transported, sometimes, to considerable distances from the parent plant that produced them.
10136-8{_}14535{_}The swelling of this downy tuft within the seed-vessel is the means by which the seed is enabled to overcome the resistance of its coats, and to force for itself a passage by which it escapes from its little prison-house.
10136-8{_}14536{_}[Illustration: BEETON'S Book of HOUSEHOLD MANAGEMENT EDITED BY MRS. ISABELLA BEETON]  [Illustration: "THE FREE, FAIR HOMES OF ENGLAND."]
10136-8{_}14537{_}1073.
10136-8{_}14538{_}BIRDS, AS WELL AS QUADRUPEDS, are likewise the means of dispersing the seeds of plants, and placing them in situations where they ultimately grow.
10136-8{_}14539{_}Amongst the latter is the squirrel, which is an extensive planter of oaks; nay, it may be regarded as having, in some measure, been one of the creators of the British navy.
10136-8{_}14540{_}We have read of a gentleman who was walking one day in some woods belonging to the Duke of Beaufort, near Troy House, in Monmouthshire, when his attention was arrested by a squirrel, sitting very composedly upon the ground.
10136-8{_}14541{_}He stopped to observe its motions, when, in a short time, the little animal suddenly quitted its position, and darted to the top of the tree beneath which it had been sitting.
10136-8{_}14542{_}In an instant it returned with an acorn in its mouth, and with its paws began to burrow in the earth.
10136-8{_}14543{_}After digging a small hole, it therein deposited an acorn, which it hastily covered, and then darted up the tree again.
10136-8{_}14544{_}In a moment it was down with another, which it buried in the same manner; and so continued its labour, gathering and burying, as long as the gentleman had patience to watch it.
10136-8{_}14545{_}This industry in the squirrel is an instinct which directs it to lay up a store of provision for the winter; and as it is probable that its memory is not sufficiently retentive to enable it to recollect all the spots in which it deposits its acorns, it no doubt makes some slips in the course of the season, and loses some of them.
10136-8{_}14546{_}These few spring up, and are, in time, destined to supply the place of the parent tree.
10136-8{_}14547{_}Thus may the sons of Britain, in some degree, consider themselves to be indebted to the industry and defective memory of this little animal for the production of some of those "wooden walls" which have, for centuries, been the national pride, and which have so long "braved the battle and the breeze" on the broad bosom of the great deep, in every quarter of the civilized globe.
10136-8{_}14548{_}As with the squirrel, so with jays and pies, which plant among the grass and moss, horse-beans, and probably forget where they have secreted them.
10136-8{_}14549{_}Mr. White, the naturalist, says, that both horse-beans and peas sprang up in his field-walks in the autumn; and he attributes the sowing of them to birds.
10136-8{_}14550{_}Bees, he also observes, are much the best setters of cucumbers.
10136-8{_}14551{_}If they do not happen to take kindly to the frames, the best way is to tempt them by a little honey put on the male and female bloom.
10136-8{_}14552{_}When they are once induced to haunt the frames, they set all the fruit, and will hover with impatience round the lights in a morning till the glasses are opened.
10136-8{_}14553{_}1074.
10136-8{_}14554{_}Some of the acorns planted by the squirrel of Monmouthshire may be now in a fair way to become, at the end of some centuries, venerable trees; for not the least remarkable quality of oaks is the strong principle of life with which they are endued.
10136-8{_}14555{_}In Major Rooke's "Sketch of the forest of Sherwood" we find it stated that, on some timber cut down in Berkland and Bilhaugh, letters were found stamped in the bodies of the trees, denoting the king's reign in which they were marked.
10136-8{_}14556{_}The bark appears to have been cut off, and then the letters to have been cut in, and the next year's wood to have grown over them without adhering to where the bark had been cut out.
10136-8{_}14557{_}The ciphers were found to be of James I., William and Mary, and one of King John.
10136-8{_}14558{_}One of the ciphers of James was about one foot within the tree, and one foot from the centre.
10136-8{_}14559{_}It was cut down in 1786.
10136-8{_}14560{_}The tree must have been two feet in diameter, or two yards in circumference, when the mark was cut.
10136-8{_}14561{_}A tree of this size is generally estimated at 120 years' growth; which number being subtracted from the middle year of the reign of James, would carry the year back to 1492, which would be about the period of its being planted.
10136-8{_}14562{_}The tree with the cipher of William and Mary displayed its mark about nine inches within the tree, and three feet three inches from the centre.
10136-8{_}14563{_}This tree was felled in 1786.
10136-8{_}14564{_}The cipher of John was eighteen inches within the tree, and rather more than a foot from the centre.
10136-8{_}14565{_}The middle year of the reign of that monarch was 1207.
10136-8{_}14566{_}By subtracting from this 120, the number of years requisite for a tree's growth to arrive at the diameter of two feet, the date of its being planted would seem to have been 1085, or about twenty years after the Conquest.
10136-8{_}14567{_}[Illustration: CELLULAR DEVELOPMENT.]
10136-8{_}14568{_}1075.
10136-8{_}14569{_}Considering the great endurance of these trees, we are necessarily led to inquire into the means by which they are enabled to arrive at such strength and maturity; and whether it may be considered as a humiliation we will not determine, but, with all the ingenious mechanical contrivances of man, we are still unable to define the limits of the animal and vegetable kingdoms.
10136-8{_}14570{_}"Plants have been described by naturalists, who would determine the limits of the two kingdoms, as organized living bodies, without volition or locomotion, destitute of a mouth or intestinal cavity, which, when detached from their place of growth, die, and, in decay, ferment, but do not putrefy, and which, on being subjected to analysis, furnish an excess of carbon and no nitrogen.
10136-8{_}14571{_}The powers of chemistry, and of the microscope, however, instead of confirming these views, tend more and more to show that a still closer affinity exists between plants and animals; for it is now ascertained that nitrogen, which was believed to be present only in animals, enters largely into the composition of plants also.
10136-8{_}14572{_}When the microscope is brought to aid our powers of observation, we find that there are organized bodies belonging to the vegetable kingdom which possess very evident powers of locomotion, and which change about in so very remarkable a manner, that no other cause than that of volition can be assigned to it."
10136-8{_}14573{_}Thus it would seem that, in this particular at least, some vegetables bear a very close resemblance to animal life; and when we consider the manner in which they are supplied with nourishment, and perform the functions of their existence, the resemblance would seem still closer.
10136-8{_}14574{_}If, for example, we take a thin transverse slice of the stem of any plant, or a slice cut across its stem, and immerse it in a little pure water, and place it under a microscope, we will find that it consists principally of cells, more or less regular, and resembling those of a honeycomb or a network of cobweb.
10136-8{_}14575{_}The size of these varies in different plants, as it does in different parts of the same plant, and they are sometimes so minute as to require a million to cover a square inch of surface.
10136-8{_}14576{_}This singular structure, besides containing water and air, is the repository or storehouse of various secretions.
10136-8{_}14577{_}Through it, the sap, when produced, is diffused sideways through the plant, and by it numerous changes are effected in the juices which fill its cells.
10136-8{_}14578{_}The forms of the cells are various; they are also subject to various transformations.
