10136-8{_}14579{_}Sometimes a number of cylindrical cells are laid end to end, and, by the absorption of the transverse partitions, form a continuous tube, as in the sap-vessels of plants, or in muscular and nervous fibre; and when cells are thus woven together, they are called cellular tissue, which, in the human body, forms a fine net-like membrane, enveloping or connecting most of its structures.
10136-8{_}14580{_}In pulpy fruits, the cells may be easily separated one from the other; and within the cells are smaller cells, commonly known as pulp.
10136-8{_}14581{_}Among the cell-contents of some plants are beautiful crystals, called _raphides_.
10136-8{_}14582{_}The term is derived from [Greek: rhaphis] a _needle_, on account of the resemblance of the crystal to a needle.
10136-8{_}14583{_}They are composed of the phosphate and oxalate of lime; but there is great difference of opinion as to their use in the economy of the plant, and one of the French philosophers endeavoured to prove that crystals are the possible transition of the inorganic to organic matter.
10136-8{_}14584{_}The differences, however, between the highest form of crystal and the lowest form of organic life known, viz., a simple reproductive cell, are so manifold and striking, that the attempt to make crystals the bridge over which inorganic matter passes into organic, is almost totally regarded as futile.
10136-8{_}14585{_}In a layer of an onion, a fig, a section of garden rhubarb, in some species of aloe, in the bark of many trees, and in portions of the cuticle of the medicinal squill, bundles of these needle-shaped crystals are to be found.
10136-8{_}14586{_}Some of them are as large as 1-40th of an inch, others are as small as the 1-1000th.
10136-8{_}14587{_}They are found in all parts of the plant,--in the stem, bark, leaves, stipules, petals, fruit, roots, and even in the pollen, with some few exceptions, and they are always situated in the interior of cells.
10136-8{_}14588{_}Some plants, as many of the _cactus_ tribe, are made up almost entirely of these needle-crystals; in some instances, every cell of the cuticle contains a stellate mass of crystals; in others, the whole interior is full of them, rendering the plant so exceedingly brittle, that the least touch will occasion a fracture; so much so, that some specimens of _Cactus senilis_, said to be a thousand years old, which were sent a few years since to Kew, from South America, were obliged to be packed in cotton, with all the care of the most delicate jewellery, to preserve them during transport.
10136-8{_}14589{_}[Illustration: SILICEOUS CUTICLE FROM UNDER-SIDE OF LEAF OF DEUTZIA SCABRA.]
10136-8{_}14590{_}[Illustration: SILICEOUS CUTICLE OF GRASS.]
10136-8{_}14591{_}1076.
10136-8{_}14592{_}Besides the cellular tissue, there is what is called a vascular system, which consists of another set of small vessels.
10136-8{_}14593{_}If, for example, we, early in the spring, cut a branch transversely, we will perceive the sap oozing out from numerous points over the whole of the divided surface, except on that part occupied by the pith and the bark; and if a twig, on which the leaves are already unfolded, be cut from the tree, and placed with its cut end in a watery solution of Brazil-wood, the colouring matter will be found to ascend into the leaves and to the top of the twig.
10136-8{_}14594{_}In both these cases, a close examination with a powerful microscope, will discover the sap perspiring from the divided portion of the stem, and the colouring matter rising through real tubes to the top of the twig: these are the sap or conducting vessels of the plant.
10136-8{_}14595{_}If, however, we examine a transverse section of the vine, or of any other tree, at a later period of the season, we find that the wood is apparently dry, whilst the bark, particularly that part next the wood, is swelled with fluid.
10136-8{_}14596{_}This is contained in vessels of a different kind from those in which the sap rises.
10136-8{_}14597{_}They are found in the _bark_ only in trees, and may be called returning vessels, from their carrying the sap downwards after its preparation in the leaf.
10136-8{_}14598{_}It is believed that the passage of the sap in plants is conducted in a manner precisely similar to that of the blood in man, from the regular contraction and expansion of the vessels; but, on account of their extreme minuteness, it is almost an impossibility to be certain upon this point.
10136-8{_}14599{_}Numerous observations made with the microscope show that their diameter seldom exceeds a 290th part of a line, or a 3,000th part of an inch.
10136-8{_}14600{_}Leuwenhoeck reckoned 20,000 vessels in a morsel of oak about one nineteenth of an inch square.
10136-8{_}14601{_}1077.
10136-8{_}14602{_}In the vascular system of a plant, we at once see the great analogy which it bears to the veins and arteries in the human system; but neither it, nor the cellular tissue combined, is all that is required to perfect the production of a vegetable.
10136-8{_}14603{_}There is, besides, a tracheal system, which is composed of very minute elastic spiral tubes, designed for the purpose of conveying air both to and from the plant.
10136-8{_}14604{_}There are also fibres, which consist of collections of these cells and vessels closely united together.
10136-8{_}14605{_}These form the root and the stem.
10136-8{_}14606{_}If we attempt to cut them transversely, we meet with difficulty, because we have to force our way across the tubes, and break them; but if we slit the wood lengthwise, the vessels are separated without breaking.
10136-8{_}14607{_}The layers of wood, which appear in the stem or branch of a tree cut transversely, consist of different zones of fibres, each the produce of one year's growth, and separated by a coat of cellular tissue, without which they could not be well distinguished.
10136-8{_}14608{_}Besides all these, there is the cuticle, which extends over every part of the plant, and covers the bark with three distinct coats.
10136-8{_}14609{_}The _liber_, or inner bark, is said to be formed of hollow tubes, which convey the sap downwards to increase the solid diameter of the tree.
10136-8{_}14610{_}1078.
10136-8{_}14611{_}THE ROOT AND THE STEM NOW DEMAND A SLIGHT NOTICE.
10136-8{_}14612{_}The former is designed, not only to support the plant by fixing it in the soil, but also to fulfil the functions of a channel for the conveyance of nourishment: it is therefore furnished with pores, or spongioles, as they are called, from their resemblance to a sponge, to suck up whatever comes within its reach.
10136-8{_}14613{_}It is found in a variety of forms, and hence its adaptation to a great diversity of soils and circumstances.
10136-8{_}14614{_}We have heard of a willow-tree being dug up and its head planted where its roots were, and these suffered to spread out in the air like naked branches.
10136-8{_}14615{_}In course of time, the roots became branches, and the branches roots, or rather, roots rose from the branches beneath the ground, and branches shot from the roots above.
10136-8{_}14616{_}Some roots last one year, others two, and others, like the shrubs and trees which they produce, have an indefinite period of existence; but they all consist of a collection of fibres, composed of vascular and cellular tissue, without tracheae, or breathing-vessels.
10136-8{_}14617{_}The stem is the grand distributor of the nourishment taken up by the roots, to the several parts of the plant.
10136-8{_}14618{_}The seat of its vitality is said to be in the point or spot called the neck, which separates the stem from the root.
10136-8{_}14619{_}If the root of a young plant be cut off, it will shoot out afresh; if even the stem be taken away, it will be renewed; but if this part be injured, the plant will assuredly die.
10136-8{_}14620{_}1079.
10136-8{_}14621{_}IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE PLAN OF THIS WORK, special notices of culinary vegetables will accompany the various recipes in which they are spoken of; but here we cannot resist the opportunity of declaring it as our conviction, that he or she who introduces a useful or an ornamental plant into our island, ought justly to be considered, to a large extent, a benefactor to the country.
10136-8{_}14622{_}No one can calculate the benefits which may spring from this very vegetable, after its qualities have become thoroughly known.
10136-8{_}14623{_}If viewed in no other light, it is pleasing to consider it as bestowing upon us a share of the blessings of other climates, and enabling us to participate in the luxury which a more genial sun has produced.
10136-8{_}14624{_}RECIPES.
10136-8{_}14625{_}CHAPTER XXV.
10136-8{_}14626{_}BOILED ARTICHOKES.
10136-8{_}14627{_}1080.
10136-8{_}14628{_}INGREDIENTS.--To each 1/2 gallon of water, allow 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt, a piece of soda the size of a shilling; artichokes.
10136-8{_}14629{_}[Illustration: ARTICHOKES.]
10136-8{_}14630{_}_Mode_.--Wash the artichokes well in several waters; see that no insects remain about them, and trim away the leaves at the bottom.
10136-8{_}14631{_}Cut off the stems and put them into _boiling_ water, to which have been added salt and soda in the above proportion.
10136-8{_}14632{_}Keep the saucepan uncovered, and let them boil quickly until tender; ascertain when they are done by thrusting a fork in them, or by trying if the leaves can be easily removed.
10136-8{_}14633{_}Take them out, let them drain for a minute or two, and serve in a napkin, or with a little white sauce poured over.
10136-8{_}14634{_}A tureen of melted butter should accompany them.
10136-8{_}14635{_}This vegetable, unlike any other, is considered better for being gathered two or three days; but they must be well soaked and washed previous to dressing.
10136-8{_}14636{_}_Time_.--20 to 25 minutes, after the water boils.
10136-8{_}14637{_}_Sufficient_,--a dish of 5 or 6 for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}14638{_}_Seasonable_ from July to the beginning of September.
10136-8{_}14639{_}[Illustration: CARDOON ARTICHOKE.]
10136-8{_}14640{_}THE COMPOSITAE, OR COMPOSITE FLOWERS.--This family is so     extensive, as to contain nearly a twelfth part of the whole of     the vegetable kingdom.
10136-8{_}14641{_}It embraces about 9,000 species,     distributed over almost every country; and new discoveries are     constantly being made and added to the number.
10136-8{_}14642{_}Towards the poles     their numbers diminish, and slightly, also, towards the equator;     but they abound in the tropical and sub-tropical islands, and in     the tracts of continent not far from the sea-shore.
10136-8{_}14643{_}Among     esculent vegetables, the Lettuce, Salsify, Scorzonera, Cardoon,     and Artichoke belong to the family.
10136-8{_}14644{_}FRIED ARTICHOKES.
10136-8{_}14645{_}(Entremets, or Small Dish, to be served with the Second Course.)
10136-8{_}14646{_}1081.
10136-8{_}14647{_}INGREDIENTS.--5 or 6 artichokes, salt and water: for the batter,--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}14648{_}of flour, a little salt, the yolk of 1 egg, milk.
10136-8{_}14649{_}_Mode_.--Trim and boil the artichokes by recipe No.
10136-8{_}14650{_}1080, and rub them over with lemon-juice, to keep them white.
10136-8{_}14651{_}When they are quite tender, take them up, remove the chokes, and divide the bottoms; dip each piece into batter, fry them in hot lard or dripping, and garnish the dish with crisped parsley.
10136-8{_}14652{_}Serve with plain melted butter.
10136-8{_}14653{_}_Time_.--20 minutes to boil the artichokes, 5 to 7 minutes to fry them.
10136-8{_}14654{_}_Sufficient_,--5 or 6 for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}14655{_}_Seasonable_ from July to the beginning of September.
10136-8{_}14656{_}A FRENCH MODE OF COOKING ARTICHOKES.
10136-8{_}14657{_}1082.
10136-8{_}14658{_}INGREDIENTS.--5 or 6 artichokes; to each 1/2 gallon of water allow 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt, 1/2 teaspoonful of pepper, 1 bunch of savoury herbs, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}14659{_}of butter.
10136-8{_}14660{_}_Mode_.--Cut the ends of the leaves, as also the stems; put the artichokes into boiling water, with the above proportion of salt, pepper, herbs, and butter; let them boil quickly until tender, keeping the lid of the saucepan off, and when the leaves come out easily, they are cooked enough.
10136-8{_}14661{_}To keep them a beautiful green, put a large piece of cinder into a muslin bag, and let it boil with them.
10136-8{_}14662{_}Serve with plain melted butter.
10136-8{_}14663{_}_Time_.--20 to 25 minutes.
10136-8{_}14664{_}_Sufficient_,--5 or 6 sufficient for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}14665{_}_Seasonable_ from July to the beginning of September.
10136-8{_}14666{_}ARTICHOKES A L'ITALIENNE.
10136-8{_}14667{_}1083.
10136-8{_}14668{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 or 6 artichokes, salt and butter, about 1/2 pint of good gravy.
10136-8{_}14669{_}_Mode_.--Trim and cut the artichokes into quarters, and boil them until tender in water mixed with a little salt and butter.
10136-8{_}14670{_}When done, drain them well, and lay them all round the dish, with the leaves outside.
10136-8{_}14671{_}Have ready some good gravy, highly flavoured with mushrooms; reduce it until quite thick, and pour it round the artichokes, and serve.
10136-8{_}14672{_}_Time_.--20 to 25 minutes to boil the artichokes.
10136-8{_}14673{_}_Sufficient_ for one side-dish.
10136-8{_}14674{_}_Seasonable_ from July to the beginning of September.
10136-8{_}14675{_}CONSTITUENT PROPERTIES OF THE ARTICHOKE.--According to the     analysis of Braconnet, the constituent elements of an artichoke     are,--starch 30, albumen 10, uncrystallizable sugar 148, gum 12,     fixed oil 1, woody fibre 12, inorganic matter 27, and water 770.
10136-8{_}14676{_}BOILED JERUSALEM ARTICHOKES.
10136-8{_}14677{_}1084.
10136-8{_}14678{_}INGREDIENTS.--To each 1 gallon of water allow 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt; artichokes.
10136-8{_}14679{_}_Mode_.--Wash, peel, and shape the artichokes in a round or oval form, and put them into a saucepan with sufficient cold water to cover them, salted in the above proportion.
10136-8{_}14680{_}Let them boil gently until tender; take them up, drain them, and serve them in a napkin, or plain, whichever mode is preferred; send to table with them a tureen of melted butter or cream sauce, a little of which may be poured over the artichokes when they are _not_ served in a napkin.
10136-8{_}14681{_}[Illustration: JERUSALEM ARTICHOKES.]
10136-8{_}14682{_}_Time_.--About 20 minutes after the water boils.
10136-8{_}14683{_}_Average cost_, 2d.
10136-8{_}14684{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}14685{_}_Sufficient_,--10 for a dish for 6 persons.
10136-8{_}14686{_}_Seasonable_ from September to June.
10136-8{_}14687{_}USES OF THE JERUSALEM ARTICHOKE.--This being a tuberous-rooted     plant, with leafy stems from four to six feet high, it is     alleged that its tops will afford as much fodder per acre as a     crop of oats, or more, and its roots half as many tubers as an     ordinary crop of potatoes.
10136-8{_}14688{_}The tubers, being abundant in the     market-gardens, are to be had at little more than the price of     potatoes.
10136-8{_}14689{_}The fibres of the stems may be separated by     maceration, and manufactured into cordage or cloth; and this is     said to be done in some parts of the north and west of France,     as about Hagenau, where this plant, on the poor sandy soils, is     an object of field culture.
10136-8{_}14690{_}MASHED JERUSALEM ARTICHOKES.
10136-8{_}14691{_}1085.
10136-8{_}14692{_}INGREDIENTS.--To each 1 gallon of water allow 1 oz.
10136-8{_}14693{_}of salt; 15 or 16 artichokes, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}14694{_}butter, pepper and salt to taste.
10136-8{_}14695{_}_Mode_.--Boil the artichokes as in the preceding recipe until tender; drain and press the water from them, and beat them up with a fork.
10136-8{_}14696{_}When thoroughly mashed and free from lumps, put them into a saucepan with the butter and a seasoning of white pepper and salt; keep stirring over the fire until the artichokes are quite hot, and serve.
10136-8{_}14697{_}_Time_.--About 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}14698{_}_Average cost_, 2d.
10136-8{_}14699{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}14700{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 or 7 persons.
10136-8{_}14701{_}_Seasonable_ from September to June.
10136-8{_}14702{_}JERUSALEM ARTICHOKES WITH WHITE SAUCE.
10136-8{_}14703{_}(Entremets, or to be served with the Second Course as a Side-dish.)
10136-8{_}14704{_}1086.
10136-8{_}14705{_}INGREDIENTS.--12 to 15 artichokes, 12 to 15 Brussels sprouts, 1/2 pint of white sauce, No.
10136-8{_}14706{_}538.
10136-8{_}14707{_}_Mode_.--Peel and cut the artichokes in the shape of a pear; cut a piece off the bottom of each, that they may stand upright in the dish, and boil them in salt and water until tender.
10136-8{_}14708{_}Have ready 1/2 pint of white sauce, made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}14709{_}538; dish the artichokes, pour over them the sauce, and place between each a fine Brussels sprout: these should be boiled separately, and not with the artichokes.
10136-8{_}14710{_}_Time_.--About 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}14711{_}_Average cost_, 2d.
10136-8{_}14712{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}14713{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 or 7 persons.
10136-8{_}14714{_}_Seasonable_ from September to June.
10136-8{_}14715{_}THE JERUSALEM ARTICHOKE.--This plant is well known, being, for     its tubers, cultivated not only as a garden vegetable, but also     as an agricultural crop.
10136-8{_}14716{_}By many it is much esteemed as an     esculent, when cooked in various ways; and the domesticated     animals eat both the fresh foliage, and the tubers with great     relish.
10136-8{_}14717{_}By some, they are not only considered nourishing, but     even fattening.
10136-8{_}14718{_}BOILED ASPARAGUS.
10136-8{_}14719{_}1087.
10136-8{_}14720{_}INGREDIENTS.--To each 1/2 gallon of water allow 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt; asparagus.
10136-8{_}14721{_}[Illustration: ASPARAGUS ON TOAST.
10136-8{_}14722{_}ASPARAGUS TONGS.]
10136-8{_}14723{_}_Mode_.--Asparagus should be dressed as soon as possible after it is cut, although it may be kept for a day or two by putting the stalks into cold water; yet, to be good, like every other vegetable, it cannot be cooked too fresh.
10136-8{_}14724{_}Scrape the white part of the stems, _beginning_ from the _head_, and throw them into cold water; then tie them into bundles of about 20 each, keeping the heads all one way, and cut the stalks evenly, that they may all be the same length; put them into _boiling_ water, with salt in the above proportion; keep them boiling quickly until tender, with the saucepan uncovered.
10136-8{_}14725{_}When the asparagus is done, dish it upon toast, which should be dipped in the water it was cooked in, and leave the white ends outwards each war, with the points meeting in the middle.
10136-8{_}14726{_}Serve with a tureen of melted butter.
10136-8{_}14727{_}_Time_.--15 to 18 minutes after the water boils.
10136-8{_}14728{_}_Average cost_, in full season, 2s.
10136-8{_}14729{_}6d.
10136-8{_}14730{_}the 100 heads.
10136-8{_}14731{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow about 50 heads for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}14732{_}_Seasonable_.--May be had, forced, from January but cheapest in May, June, and July.
10136-8{_}14733{_}[Illustration: ASPARAGUS.]
10136-8{_}14734{_}ASPARAGUS.--This plant belongs to the variously-featured family     of the order _Liliaceae_, which, in the temperate regions of     both hemispheres, are most abundant, and, between the tropics,     gigantic in size and arborescent in form.
10136-8{_}14735{_}Asparagus is a native     of Great Britain, and is found on various parts of the seacoast,     and in the fens of Lincolnshire.
10136-8{_}14736{_}At Kynarve Cove, in Cornwall,     there is an island called "Asparagus Island," from the abundance     in which it is there found.
10136-8{_}14737{_}The uses to which the young shoots     are applied, and the manure in which they are cultivated in     order to bring them to the highest state of excellence, have     been a study with many kitchen-gardeners.
10136-8{_}14738{_}ASPARAGUS PEAS.
10136-8{_}14739{_}(Entremets, or to be served as a Side-dish with the Second Course.)
10136-8{_}14740{_}1088.
10136-8{_}14741{_}INGREDIENTS.--100 heads of asparagus, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}14742{_}of butter, a small bunch of parsley, 2 or 3 green onions, flour, 1 lump of sugar, the yolks of 2 eggs, 4 tablespoonfuls of cream, salt.
10136-8{_}14743{_}_Mode_.--Carefully scrape the asparagus, cut it into pieces of an equal size, avoiding that which is in the least hard or tough, and throw them into cold water.
10136-8{_}14744{_}Then boil the asparagus in salt and water until three-parts done; take it out, drain, and place it on a cloth to dry the moisture away from it.
10136-8{_}14745{_}Put it into a stewpan with the butter, parsley, and onions, and shake over a brisk fire for 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}14746{_}Dredge in a little flour, add the sugar, and moisten with boiling water.
10136-8{_}14747{_}When boiled a short time and reduced, take out the parsley and onions, thicken with the yolks of 2 eggs beaten with the cream; add a seasoning of salt, and, when the whole is on the point of simmering, serve.
10136-8{_}14748{_}Make the sauce sufficiently thick to adhere to the vegetable.
10136-8{_}14749{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}14750{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}14751{_}6d.
10136-8{_}14752{_}a pint.
10136-8{_}14753{_}_Seasonable_ in May, June, and July.
10136-8{_}14754{_}MEDICINAL USES OF ASPARAGUS.--This plant not only acts as a     wholesome and nutritious vegetable, but also as a diuretic,     aperient, and deobstruent.
10136-8{_}14755{_}The chemical analysis of its juice     discovers its composition to be a peculiar crystallizable     principle, called asparagin, albumen, mannite, malic acid, and     some salts.
10136-8{_}14756{_}Thours says, the cellular tissue contains a     substance similar to sage.
10136-8{_}14757{_}The berries are capable of undergoing     vinous fermentation, and affording alcohol by distillation.
10136-8{_}14758{_}In     their unripe state they possess the same properties as the     roots, and probably in a much higher degree.
10136-8{_}14759{_}ASPARAGUS PUDDING.
10136-8{_}14760{_}(A delicious Dish, to be served with the Second Course.)
10136-8{_}14761{_}1089.
10136-8{_}14762{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of asparagus peas, 4 eggs, 2 tablespoonfuls of flour, 1 tablespoonful of _very finely_ minced ham, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}14763{_}of butter, pepper and salt to taste, milk.
10136-8{_}14764{_}_Mode_.--Cut up the nice green tender parts of asparagus, about the size of peas; put them into a basin with the eggs, which should be well beaten, and the flour, ham, butter, pepper, and salt.
10136-8{_}14765{_}Mix all these ingredients well together, and moisten with sufficient milk to make the pudding of the consistency of thick batter; put it into a pint buttered mould, tie it down tightly with a floured cloth, place it in _boiling water_, and let it boil for 2 hours; turn it out of the mould on to a hot dish, and pour plain melted butter _round_, but not over, the pudding.
10136-8{_}14766{_}Green peas pudding may be made in exactly the same manner, substituting peas for the asparagus.
10136-8{_}14767{_}_Time_.--2 hours.
10136-8{_}14768{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}14769{_}6d.
10136-8{_}14770{_}per pint.
10136-8{_}14771{_}_Seasonable_ in May, June, and July.
10136-8{_}14772{_}BOILED FRENCH BEANS.
10136-8{_}14773{_}1090.
10136-8{_}14774{_}INGREDIENTS.--To each 1/2 gallon of water allow 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt, a very small piece of soda.
10136-8{_}14775{_}[Illustration: Scarlet Runner.]
10136-8{_}14776{_}_Mode_.--This vegetable should always be eaten young, as, when allowed to grow too long, it tastes stringy and tough when cooked.
10136-8{_}14777{_}Cut off the heads and tails, and a thin strip on each side of the beans, to remove the strings.
10136-8{_}14778{_}Then divide each bean into 4 or 6 pieces, according to size, cutting them lengthways in a slanting direction, and, as they are cut, put them into cold water, with a small quantity of salt dissolved in it.
10136-8{_}14779{_}Have ready a saucepan of boiling water, with salt and soda in the above proportion; put in the beans, keep them boiling quickly, with the lid uncovered, and be careful that they do not get smoked.
10136-8{_}14780{_}When tender, which may be ascertained by their sinking to the bottom of the saucepan, take them up, throw them into a colander; and when drained, dish and serve with plain melted butter.
10136-8{_}14781{_}When very young, beans are sometimes served whole: when they are thus dressed, their colour and flavour are much better preserved; but the more general way of dressing them is to cut them into thin strips.
10136-8{_}14782{_}_Time_.--Very young beans, 10 to 12 minutes; moderate size, 15 to 20 minutes, after the water boils.
10136-8{_}14783{_}_Average cost_, in full season, 1s.
10136-8{_}14784{_}4d.
10136-8{_}14785{_}a peck; but, when forced, very expensive.
10136-8{_}14786{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 1/2 peck for 6 or 7 persons.
10136-8{_}14787{_}_Seasonable_ from the middle of July to the end of September; but may be had, forced, from February to the beginning of June.
10136-8{_}14788{_}FRENCH MODE OF COOKING FRENCH BEANS.
10136-8{_}14789{_}1091.
10136-8{_}14790{_}INGREDIENTS.--A quart of French beans, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}14791{_}of fresh butter, pepper and salt to taste, the juice of 1/2 lemon.
10136-8{_}14792{_}_Mode_.--Cut and boil the beans by the preceding recipe, and when tender, put them into a stewpan, and shake over the fire, to dry away the moisture from the beans.
10136-8{_}14793{_}When quite dry and hot, add the butter, pepper, salt, and lemon-juice; keep moving the stewpan, without using a spoon, as that would break the beans; and when the butter is melted, and all is thoroughly hot, serve.
10136-8{_}14794{_}If the butter should not mix well, add a tablespoonful of gravy, and serve very quickly.
10136-8{_}14795{_}_Time_.--About 1/4 hour to boil the beans; 10 minutes to shake them over the fire.
10136-8{_}14796{_}_Average cost_, in full season, about 1s.
10136-8{_}14797{_}4d.
10136-8{_}14798{_}a peck.
10136-8{_}14799{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}14800{_}_Seasonable_ from the middle of July to the end of September.
10136-8{_}14801{_}BOILED BROAD OR WINDSOR BEANS.
10136-8{_}14802{_}1092.
10136-8{_}14803{_}INGREDIENTS.--To each 1/2 gallon of water, allow 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt; beans.
10136-8{_}14804{_}[Illustration: BROAD BEAN.]
10136-8{_}14805{_}_Mode_.--This is a favourite vegetable with many persons, but to be nice, should be young and freshly gathered.
10136-8{_}14806{_}After shelling the beans, put them into _boiling_ water, salted in the above proportion, and let them boil rapidly until tender.
10136-8{_}14807{_}Drain them well in a colander; dish, and serve with them separately a tureen of parsley and butter.
10136-8{_}14808{_}Boiled bacon should always accompany this vegetable, but the beans should be cooked separately.
10136-8{_}14809{_}It is usually served with the beans laid round, and the parsley and butter in a tureen.
10136-8{_}14810{_}Beans also make an excellent garnish to a ham, and when used for this purpose, if very old, should have their skins removed.
10136-8{_}14811{_}_Time_.--Very young beans, 15 minutes; when of a moderate size, 20 to 25 minutes, or longer.
10136-8{_}14812{_}_Average cost_, unshelled, 6d.
10136-8{_}14813{_}per peck.
10136-8{_}14814{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow one peck for 6 or 7 persons.
10136-8{_}14815{_}_Seasonable_ in July and August.
10136-8{_}14816{_}NUTRITIVE PROPERTIES OF THE BEAN.--The produce of beans in meal     is, like that of peas, more in proportion to the grain than in     any of the cereal grasses.
10136-8{_}14817{_}A bushel of beans is supposed to     yield fourteen pounds more of flour than a bushel of oats; and a     bushel of peas eighteen pounds more, or, according to some,     twenty pounds.
10136-8{_}14818{_}A thousand parts of bean flour were found by Sir     II.
10136-8{_}14819{_}Davy to yield 570 parts of nutritive matter, of which 426     were mucilage or starch, 103 gluten, and 41 extract, or matter     rendered insoluble during the process.
10136-8{_}14820{_}BROAD BEANS A LA POULETTE.
10136-8{_}14821{_}1093.
10136-8{_}14822{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 pints of broad beans, 1/2 pint of stock or broth, a small bunch of savoury herbs, including parsley, a small lump of sugar, the yolk of 1 egg, 1/4 pint of cream, pepper and salt to taste.
10136-8{_}14823{_}_Mode_.--Procure some young and freshly-gathered beans, and shell sufficient to make 2 pints; boil them, as in the preceding recipe, until nearly done; then drain them and put them into a stewpan, with the stock, finely-minced herbs, and sugar.
10136-8{_}14824{_}Stew the beans until perfectly tender, and the liquor has dried away a little; then beat up the yolk of an egg with the cream, add this to the beans, let the whole get thoroughly hot, and when on the point of simmering, serve.
10136-8{_}14825{_}Should the beans be very large, the skin should be removed previously to boiling them.
10136-8{_}14826{_}_Time_.--10 minutes to boil the beans, 15 minutes to stew them in the stock.
10136-8{_}14827{_}_Average cost_, unshelled, 6d.
10136-8{_}14828{_}per peck.
10136-8{_}14829{_}_Seasonable_ in July and August.
10136-8{_}14830{_}ORIGIN AND VARIETIES OF THE BEAN.--This valuable plant is said     to be a native of Egypt, but, like other plants which have been     domesticated, its origin is uncertain.
10136-8{_}14831{_}It has been cultivated in     Europe and Asia from time immemorial, and has been long known in     Britain.
10136-8{_}14832{_}Its varieties may be included under two general     heads,--the white, or garden beans, and the grey, or field     beans, of the former, sown in the fields, the mazagan and     long-pod are almost the only sorts; of the latter, those known     as the horse-bean, the small or ticks, and the prolific of     Heligoland, are the principal sorts.
10136-8{_}14833{_}New varieties are procured     in the same manner as in other plants.
10136-8{_}14834{_}BOILED BEETROOT.
10136-8{_}14835{_}1094.
10136-8{_}14836{_}INGREDIENTS,--Beetroot; boiling water.
10136-8{_}14837{_}_Mode_.--When large, young, and juicy, this vegetable makes a very excellent addition to winter salads, and may easily be converted into an economical and quickly-made pickle.
10136-8{_}14838{_}(_See_ No.
10136-8{_}14839{_}369.)
10136-8{_}14840{_}Beetroot is more frequently served cold than hot: when the latter mode is preferred, melted butter should be sent to table with it.
10136-8{_}14841{_}It may also be stewed with button onions, or boiled and served with roasted onions.
10136-8{_}14842{_}Wash the beets thoroughly; but do not prick or break the skin before they are cooked, or they would lose their beautiful colour in boiling.
10136-8{_}14843{_}Put them into boiling water, and let them boil until tender, keeping them well covered.
10136-8{_}14844{_}If to be served hot, remove the peel quickly, cut the beetroot into thick slices, and send to table melted butter.
10136-8{_}14845{_}For salads, pickle, &c., let the root cool, then peel, and cut it into slices.
10136-8{_}14846{_}_Time_.--Small beetroot, 1-1/2 to 2 hours; large, 2-1/2 to 3 hours.
10136-8{_}14847{_}_Average cost_, in full season, 2d.
10136-8{_}14848{_}each.
10136-8{_}14849{_}_Seasonable_.--May be had at any time.
10136-8{_}14850{_}[Illustration: BEETROOT.]
10136-8{_}14851{_}BEETROOT.--The geographical distribution of the order Saltworts     (_Salxolaceae_), to which beetroot belongs, is most common in     extra-tropical and temperate regions, where they are common     weeds, frequenting waste places, among rubbish, and on marshes     by the seashore.
10136-8{_}14852{_}In the tropics they are rare.
10136-8{_}14853{_}They are     characterized by the large quantities of mucilage, sugar,     starch, and alkaline salts which are found in them.
10136-8{_}14854{_}Many of them     are used as potherbs, and some are emetic and vermifuge in their     medicinal properties.
10136-8{_}14855{_}The _root_ of _garden_ or red beet is     exceedingly wholesome and nutritious, and Dr. Lyon Playfair has     recommended that a good brown bread may be made by rasping down     this root with an equal quantity of flour.
10136-8{_}14856{_}He says that the     average quality of flour contains about 12 per cent.
10136-8{_}14857{_}of azotized     principles adapted for the formation of flesh, and the average     quality of beet contains about 2 per cent.
10136-8{_}14858{_}of the same     materials.
10136-8{_}14859{_}BOILED BROCOLI.
10136-8{_}14860{_}1095.
10136-8{_}14861{_}INGREDIENTS.--To each 1/2 gallon of water allow 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt; brocoli.
10136-8{_}14862{_}[Illustration: BOILED BROCOLI.]
10136-8{_}14863{_}_Mode_.--Strip off the dead outside leaves, and the inside ones cut off level with the flower; cut off the stalk close at the bottom, and put the brocoli into cold salt and water, with the heads downwards.
10136-8{_}14864{_}When they have remained in this for about 3/4 hour, and they are _perfectly_ free from insects, put them into a saucepan of _boiling_ water, salted in the above proportion, and keep them boiling quickly over a brisk fire, with the saucepan uncovered.
10136-8{_}14865{_}Take them up with a slice the moment they are done; drain them well, and serve with a tureen of melted butter, a _little_ of which should be poured over the brocoli.
10136-8{_}14866{_}If left in the water after it is done, it will break, its colour will be spoiled, and its crispness gone.
10136-8{_}14867{_}_Time_.--Small brocoli, 10 to 15 minutes; large one, 20 to 25 minutes.
10136-8{_}14868{_}_Average cost_, 2d.
10136-8{_}14869{_}each.
10136-8{_}14870{_}_Sufficient_,--2 for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}14871{_}_Seasonable_ from October to March; plentiful in February and March.
10136-8{_}14872{_}[Illustration: BROCOLI.]
10136-8{_}14873{_}THE KOHL-RABI, OR TURNIP-CABBAGE.--This variety presents a     singular development, inasmuch as the stem swells out like a     large turnip on the surface of the ground, the leaves shooting     from it all round, and the top being surmounted by a cluster of     leaves issuing from it.
10136-8{_}14874{_}Although not generally grown as a garden     vegetable, if used when young and tender, it is wholesome,     nutritious, and very palatable.
10136-8{_}14875{_}BOILED BRUSSELS SPROUTS.
10136-8{_}14876{_}1096.
10136-8{_}14877{_}INGREDIENTS.--To each 1/2 gallon of water allow 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt; a _very small_ piece of soda.
10136-8{_}14878{_}_Mode_.--Clean the sprouts from insects, nicely wash them, and pick off any dead or discoloured leaves from the outsides; put them into a saucepan of _boiling_ water, with salt and soda in the above proportion; keep the pan uncovered, and let them boil quickly over a brisk fire until tender; drain, dish, and serve with a tureen of melted butter, or with a maître d'hôtel sauce poured over them.
10136-8{_}14879{_}Another mode of serving is, when they are dished, to stir in about 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}14880{_}of butter and a seasoning of pepper and salt.
10136-8{_}14881{_}They must, however, be sent to table very quickly, as, being so very small, this vegetable soon cools.
10136-8{_}14882{_}Where the cook is very expeditious, this vegetable, when cooked, may be arranged on the dish in the form of a pineapple, and, so served, has a very pretty appearance.
10136-8{_}14883{_}_Time_.--From 9 to 12 minutes after the water boils.
10136-8{_}14884{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}14885{_}4d.
10136-8{_}14886{_}per peck.
10136-8{_}14887{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow between 40 and 50 for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}14888{_}_Seasonable_ from November to March.
10136-8{_}14889{_}SAVOYS AND BRUSSELS SPROUTS.--When the Green Kale, or Borecole,     has been advanced a step further in the path of improvement, it     assumes the headed or hearting character, with blistered leaves;     it is then known by the name of Savoys and Brussels Sprouts.
10136-8{_}14890{_}Another of its headed forms, but with smooth glaucous leaves, is     the cultivated Cabbage of our gardens (the _Borecole oleracea     capitula_ of science); and all its varieties of green, red,     dwarf, tall, early, late, round, conical, flat, and all the     forms into which it is possible to put it.
10136-8{_}14891{_}TO BOIL YOUNG GREENS OR SPROUTS.
10136-8{_}14892{_}1097.
10136-8{_}14893{_}INGREDIENTS.--To each 1/2 gallon of water allow 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt; a _very small_ piece of soda.
10136-8{_}14894{_}[Illustration: BRUSSELS SPROUTS.]
10136-8{_}14895{_}_Mode_.--Pick away all the dead leaves, and wash the greens well in cold water; drain them in a colander, and put them into fast-boiling water, with salt and soda in the above proportion.
10136-8{_}14896{_}Keep them boiling quickly, with the lid uncovered, until tender; and the moment they are done, take them up, or their colour will be spoiled; when well drained, serve.
10136-8{_}14897{_}The great art in cooking greens properly, and to have them a good colour, is to put them into _plenty_ of _fast-boiling_ water, to let them boil very quickly, and to take them up the moment they become tender.
10136-8{_}14898{_}_Time_.--Brocoli sprouts, 10 to 12 minutes; young greens, 10 to 12 minutes; sprouts, 12 minutes, after the water boils.
10136-8{_}14899{_}_Seasonable_.--Sprouts of various kinds may be had all the year.
10136-8{_}14900{_}GREEN KALE, OR BORECOLE.--When Colewort, or Wild Cabbage, is     brought into a state of cultivation, its character becomes     greatly improved, although it still retains the loose open     leaves, and in this form it is called Green Kale, or Borecole.
10136-8{_}14901{_}The scientific name is _Borecole oleracea acephala_, and of it     there are many varieties, both as regards the form and colour of     the leaves, as well as the height which the plants attain.
10136-8{_}14902{_}We     may observe, that among them, are included the Thousand-headed,     and the Cow or Tree Cabbage.
10136-8{_}14903{_}BOILED CABBAGE.
10136-8{_}14904{_}1098.
10136-8{_}14905{_}INGREDIENTS.--To each 1/2 gallon of water allow 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt; a _very small_ piece of soda.
10136-8{_}14906{_}_Mode_.--Pick off all the dead outside leaves, cut off as much of the stalk as possible, and cut the cabbages across twice, at the stalk end; if they should be very large, quarter them.
10136-8{_}14907{_}Wash them well in cold water, place them in a colander, and drain; then put them into _plenty_ of _fast-boiling_ water, to which have been added salt and soda in the above proportions.
10136-8{_}14908{_}Stir them down once or twice in the water, keep the pan uncovered, and let them boil quickly until tender.
10136-8{_}14909{_}The instant they are done, take them up into a colander, place a plate over them, let them thoroughly drain, dish, and serve.
10136-8{_}14910{_}_Time_.--Large cabbages, or savoys, 1/3 to 3/4 hour, young summer cabbage, 10 to 12 minutes, after the water boils.
10136-8{_}14911{_}_Average cost_, 2d.
10136-8{_}14912{_}each in full season.
10136-8{_}14913{_}_Sufficient_,--2 large ones for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}14914{_}_Seasonable_.--Cabbages and sprouts of various kinds at any time.
10136-8{_}14915{_}THE CABBAGE TRIBE: THEIR ORIGIN.--Of all the tribes of the     _Cruciferae_ this is by far the most important.
10136-8{_}14916{_}Its scientific     name is _Brassiceae_, and it contains a collection of plants     which, both in themselves and their products, occupy a prominent     position in agriculture, commerce, and domestic economy.
10136-8{_}14917{_}On the     cliffs of Dover, and in many places on the coasts of     Dorsetshire, Cornwall, and Yorkshire, there grows a wild plant,     with variously-indented, much-waved, and loose spreading leaves,     of a sea-green colour, and large yellow flowers.
10136-8{_}14918{_}In spring, the     leaves of this plant are collected by the inhabitants, who,     after boiling them in two waters, to remove the saltness, use     them as a vegetable along with their meat.
10136-8{_}14919{_}This is the _Brassica     oleracea_ of science, the Wild Cabbage, or Colewort, from which     have originated all the varieties of Cabbage, Cauliflower,     Greens, and Brocoli.
10136-8{_}14920{_}STEWED RED CABBAGE.
10136-8{_}14921{_}1099.
10136-8{_}14922{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 red cabbage, a small slice of ham, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}14923{_}of fresh butter, 1 pint of weak stock or broth, 1 gill of vinegar, salt and pepper to taste, 1 tablespoonful of pounded sugar.
10136-8{_}14924{_}_Mode_.--Cut the cabbage into very thin slices, put it into a stewpan, with the ham cut in dice, the butter, 1/2 pint of stock, and the vinegar; cover the pan closely, and let it stew for 1 hour.
10136-8{_}14925{_}When it is very tender, add the remainder of the stock, a seasoning of salt and pepper, and the pounded sugar; mix all well together, stir over the fire until nearly all the liquor is dried away, and serve.
10136-8{_}14926{_}Fried sausages are usually sent to table with this dish: they should be laid round and on the cabbage, as a garnish.
10136-8{_}14927{_}_Time_.--Rather more than 1 hour.
10136-8{_}14928{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}14929{_}each.
10136-8{_}14930{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}14931{_}_Seasonable_ from September to January.
10136-8{_}14932{_}THE WILD CABBAGE, OR COLEWORT.--This plant, as it is found on     the sea-cliffs of England, presents us with the origin of the     cabbage tribe in its simplest and normal form.
10136-8{_}14933{_}In this state it     is the true Collet, or Colewort, although the name is now     applied to any young cabbage which has a loose and open heart.
10136-8{_}14934{_}BOILED CARROTS.
10136-8{_}14935{_}1100.
10136-8{_}14936{_}INGREDIENTS.--To each 1/2 gallon of water, allow 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt; carrots.
10136-8{_}14937{_}_Mode_.--Cut off the green tops, wash and scrape the carrots, and should there be any black specks, remove them.
10136-8{_}14938{_}If very large, cut them in halves, divide them lengthwise into four pieces, and put them into boiling water, salted in the above proportion; let them boil until tender, which may be ascertained by thrusting a fork into them: dish, and serve very hot.
10136-8{_}14939{_}This vegetable is an indispensable accompaniment to boiled beef.
10136-8{_}14940{_}When thus served, it is usually boiled with the beef; a few carrots are placed round the dish as a garnish, and the remainder sent to table in a vegetable-dish.
10136-8{_}14941{_}Young carrots do not require nearly so much boiling, nor should they be divided: these make a nice addition to stewed veal, &c.
10136-8{_}14942{_}_Time_.--Large carrots, 1-3/4 to 2-1/4 hours; young ones, about 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}14943{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}14944{_}to 8d, per bunch of 18.
10136-8{_}14945{_}_Sufficient_,--4 large carrots for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}14946{_}_Seasonable_.--Young carrots from April to June, old ones at any time.
10136-8{_}14947{_}[Illustration: CARROTS.]
10136-8{_}14948{_}ORIGIN OF THE CARROT.--In its wild state, this vegetable is     found plentifully in Britain, both in cultivated lands and by     waysides, and is known by the name of birds-nest, from its     umbels of fruit becoming incurved from a hollow cup, like a     birds-nest.
10136-8{_}14949{_}In this state its root is whitish, slender, and     hard, with an acrid, disagreeable taste, and a strong aromatic     smell, and was formerly used as an aperient.
10136-8{_}14950{_}When cultivated, it     is reddish, thick, fleshy, with a pleasant odour, and a     peculiar, sweet, mucilaginous taste.
10136-8{_}14951{_}The carrot is said by     naturalists not to contain much nourishing matter, and,     generally speaking, is somewhat difficult of digestion.
10136-8{_}14952{_}TO DRESS CARROTS IN THE GERMAN WAY.
10136-8{_}14953{_}1101.
10136-8{_}14954{_}INGREDIENTS.--8 large carrots, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}14955{_}of butter, salt to taste, a very little grated nutmeg, 1 tablespoonful of finely-minced parsley, 1 dessertspoonful of minced onion, rather more than 1 pint of weak stock or broth, 1 tablespoonful of flour.
10136-8{_}14956{_}_Mode_.--Wash and scrape the carrots, and cut them into rings of about 1/4 inch in thickness.
10136-8{_}14957{_}Put the butter into a stewpan; when it is melted, lay in the carrots, with salt, nutmeg, parsley, and onion in the above proportions.
10136-8{_}14958{_}Toss the stewpan over the fire for a few minutes, and when the carrots are well saturated with the butter, pour in the stock, and simmer gently until they are nearly tender.
10136-8{_}14959{_}Then put into another stewpan a small piece of butter; dredge in about a tablespoonful of flour; stir this over the fire, and when of a nice brown colour, add the liquor that the carrots have been boiling in; let this just boil up, pour it over the carrots in the other stewpan, and let them finish simmering until quite tender.
10136-8{_}14960{_}Serve very hot.
10136-8{_}14961{_}This vegetable, dressed as above, is a favourite accompaniment of roast pork, sausages, &c. &c.
10136-8{_}14962{_}_Time_.--About 3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}14963{_}Average cost, 6d.
10136-8{_}14964{_}to 8d.
10136-8{_}14965{_}per bunch of 18.
10136-8{_}14966{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 or 7 persons.
10136-8{_}14967{_}_Seasonable_.--Young carrots from April to June, old ones at any time.
10136-8{_}14968{_}CONSTITUENTS OF THE CARROT.--These are crystallizable and     uncrystallizable sugar, a little starch, extractive, gluten,     albumen, volatile oil, vegetable jelly, or pectin, saline     matter, malic acid, and a peculiar crystallizable ruby-red     neuter principle, without odour or taste, called carotin.
10136-8{_}14969{_}This     vegetable jelly, or pectin, so named from its singular property     of gelatinizing, is considered by some as another form of gum or     mucilage, combined with vegetable acid.
10136-8{_}14970{_}It exists more or less     in all vegetables, and is especially abundant in those roots and     fruits from which jellies are prepared.
10136-8{_}14971{_}STEWED CARROTS.
10136-8{_}14972{_}1102.
10136-8{_}14973{_}INGREDIENTS.--7 or 8 large carrots, 1 teacupful of broth, pepper and salt to taste, 1/2 teacupful of cream, thickening of butter and flour.
10136-8{_}14974{_}_Mode_.--Scrape the carrots nicely; half-boil, and slice them into a stewpan; add the broth, pepper and salt, and cream; simmer till tender, and be careful the carrots are not broken.
10136-8{_}14975{_}A few minutes before serving, mix a little flour with about 1 oz.
10136-8{_}14976{_}of butter; thicken the gravy with this; let it just boil up, and serve.
10136-8{_}14977{_}_Time_.--About 3/4 hour to parboil the carrots, about 20 minutes to cook them after they are sliced.
10136-8{_}14978{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}14979{_}to 8d.
10136-8{_}14980{_}per bunch of 18.
10136-8{_}14981{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}14982{_}_Seasonable_.--Young carrots from April to June, old ones at any time.
10136-8{_}14983{_}NUTRITIVE PROPERTIES OF THE CARROT.--Sir H. Davy ascertained the     nutritive matter of the carrot to amount to ninety-eight parts     in one thousand; of which ninety-five are sugar and three are     starch.
10136-8{_}14984{_}It is used in winter and spring in the dairy to give     colour and flavour to butter; and it is excellent in stews,     haricots, soups, and, when boiled whole, with salt beef.
10136-8{_}14985{_}In the     distillery, owing to the great proportion of sugar in its     composition, it yields more spirit than the potato.
10136-8{_}14986{_}The usual     quantity is twelve gallons per ton.
10136-8{_}14987{_}SLICED CARROTS.
10136-8{_}14988{_}(Entremets, or to be served with the Second Course, as a Side-dish.)
10136-8{_}14989{_}1103.
10136-8{_}14990{_}INGREDIENTS.--5 or 6 large carrots, a large lump of sugar, 1 pint of weak stock, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}14991{_}of fresh butter, salt to taste.
10136-8{_}14992{_}_Mode_.--Scrape and wash the carrots, cut them into slices of an equal size, and boil them in salt and water, until half done; drain them well, put them into a stewpan with the sugar and stock, and let them boil over a brisk fire.
10136-8{_}14993{_}When reduced to a glaze, add the fresh butter and a seasoning of salt; shake the stewpan about well, and when the butter is well mixed with the carrots, serve.
10136-8{_}14994{_}There should be no sauce in the dish when it comes to table, but it should all adhere to the carrots.
10136-8{_}14995{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}14996{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}14997{_}to 8d.
10136-8{_}14998{_}per bunch of 18.
10136-8{_}14999{_}_Sufficient_ for 1 dish.
10136-8{_}15000{_}_Seasonable_.--Young carrots from April to June, old ones at any time.
10136-8{_}15001{_}THE SEED OF THE CARROT.--In order to save the seed of carrots,     the plan is, to select annually the most perfect and best-shaped     roots in the taking-up season, and either preserve them in sand     in a cellar till spring, or plant them immediately in an open     airy part of the garden, protecting them with litter during     severe frost, or earthing them over, and uncovering them in     March following.
10136-8{_}15002{_}The seed is in no danger from being injured by     any other plant.
10136-8{_}15003{_}In August it is fit to gather, and is best     preserved on the stalks till wanted.
10136-8{_}15004{_}BOILED CAULIFLOWERS.
10136-8{_}15005{_}[Illustration: BOILED CAULIFLOWER.]
10136-8{_}15006{_}[Illustration: CAULIFLOWER.]
10136-8{_}15007{_}1104.
10136-8{_}15008{_}INGREDIENTS.--To each 1/2 gallon of water allow 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt.
10136-8{_}15009{_}_Mode_.--Choose cauliflowers that are close and white; trim off the decayed outside leaves, and cut the stalk off flat at the bottom.
10136-8{_}15010{_}Open the flower a little in places to remove the insects, which generally are found about the stalk, and let the cauliflowers lie in salt and water for an hour previous to dressing them, with their heads downwards: this will effectually draw out all the vermin.
10136-8{_}15011{_}Then put them into fast-boiling water, with the addition of salt in the above proportion, and let them boil briskly over a good fire, keeping the saucepan uncovered.
10136-8{_}15012{_}The water should be well skimmed; and, when the cauliflowers are tender, take them up with a slice; let them drain, and, if large enough, place them upright in the dish.
10136-8{_}15013{_}Serve with plain melted butter, a little of which may be poured over the flower.
10136-8{_}15014{_}_Time_.--Small cauliflower, 12 to 15 minutes, large one, 20 to 25 minutes, after the water boils.
10136-8{_}15015{_}_Average cost_, for large cauliflowers, 6d.
10136-8{_}15016{_}each.
10136-8{_}15017{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 1 large cauliflower for 3 persons.
10136-8{_}15018{_}_Seasonable_ from the beginning of June to the end of September.
10136-8{_}15019{_}CAULIFLOWERS A LA SAUCE BLANCHE.
10136-8{_}15020{_}(Entremets, or Side-dish, to be served with the Second Course.)
10136-8{_}15021{_}1105.
10136-8{_}15022{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 cauliflowers, 1/2 pint of sauce blanche, or French melted butter, No.
10136-8{_}15023{_}378; 3 oz.
10136-8{_}15024{_}of butter; salt and water.
10136-8{_}15025{_}_Mode_.--Cleanse the cauliflowers as in the preceding recipe, and cut the stalks off flat at the bottom; boil them until tender in salt and water, to which the above proportion of butter has been added, and be careful to take them up the moment they are done, or they will break, and the appearance of the dish will be spoiled.
10136-8{_}15026{_}Drain them well, and dish them in the shape of a large cauliflower.
10136-8{_}15027{_}Have ready 1/2 pint of sauce, made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}15028{_}378, pour it over the flowers, and serve hot and quickly.
10136-8{_}15029{_}_Time_.--Small cauliflowers, 12 to 15 minutes, large ones, 20 to 25 minutes, after the water boils.
10136-8{_}15030{_}_Average cost_,--large cauliflowers, in full season, 6d.
10136-8{_}15031{_}each.
10136-8{_}15032{_}_Sufficient_,--1 large cauliflower for 3 or 4 persons.
10136-8{_}15033{_}_Seasonable_ from the beginning of June to the end of September.
10136-8{_}15034{_}CAULIFLOWER AND BROCOLI.--These are only forms of the wild     Cabbage in its cultivated state.
10136-8{_}15035{_}They are both well known; but     we may observe, that the purple and white Brocoli are only     varieties of the Cauliflower.
10136-8{_}15036{_}CAULIFLOWERS WITH PARMESAN CHEESE.
10136-8{_}15037{_}(Entremets, or Side-dish, to be served with the Second Course.)
10136-8{_}15038{_}1106.
10136-8{_}15039{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 or 3 cauliflowers, rather more than 1/2 pint of white sauce No.
10136-8{_}15040{_}378, 2 tablespoonfuls of grated Parmesan cheese, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}15041{_}of fresh butter, 3 tablespoonfuls of bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}15042{_}_Mode_.--Cleanse and boil the cauliflowers by recipe No.
10136-8{_}15043{_}1104, and drain them and dish them with the flowers standing upright.
10136-8{_}15044{_}Have ready the above proportion of white sauce; pour sufficient of it over the cauliflowers just to cover the top; sprinkle over this some rasped Parmesan cheese and bread crumbs, and drop on these the butter, which should be melted, but not oiled.
10136-8{_}15045{_}Brown with a salamander, or before the fire, and pour round, but not over, the flowers the remainder of the sauce, with which should be mixed a small quantity of grated Parmesan cheese.
10136-8{_}15046{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}15047{_}_Average cost_, for large cauliflowers, 6d.
10136-8{_}15048{_}each.
10136-8{_}15049{_}_Sufficient_,--3 small cauliflowers for 1 dish.
10136-8{_}15050{_}_Seasonable_ from the beginning of June to the end of September.
10136-8{_}15051{_}CELERY.
10136-8{_}15052{_}[Illustration: CELERY IN GLASS.]
10136-8{_}15053{_}1107.
10136-8{_}15054{_}With a good heart, and nicely blanched, this vegetable is generally eaten raw, and is usually served with the cheese.
10136-8{_}15055{_}Let the roots be washed free from dirt, all the decayed and outside leaves being cut off, preserving as much of the stalk as possible, and all specks or blemishes being carefully removed.
10136-8{_}15056{_}Should the celery be large, divide it lengthwise into quarters, and place it, root downwards, in a celery-glass, which should be rather more than half filled with water.
10136-8{_}15057{_}The top leaves may be curled, by shredding them in narrow strips with the point of a clean skewer, at a distance of about 4 inches from the top.
10136-8{_}15058{_}_Average cost_, 2d.
10136-8{_}15059{_}per head.
10136-8{_}15060{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 2 heads for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}15061{_}_Seasonable_ from October to April.
10136-8{_}15062{_}_Note_.--This vegetable is exceedingly useful for flavouring soups, sauces, &c., and makes a very nice addition to winter salad.
10136-8{_}15063{_}STEWED CELERY A LA CREME.
10136-8{_}15064{_}1108.
10136-8{_}15065{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 heads of celery; to each 1/2 gallon of water allow 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt, 1 blade of pounded mace, 1/3 pint of cream.
10136-8{_}15066{_}_Mode_.--Wash the celery thoroughly; trim, and boil it in salt and water until tender.
10136-8{_}15067{_}Put the cream and pounded mace into a stewpan; shake it over the fire until the cream thickens, dish the celery, pour over the sauce, and serve.
10136-8{_}15068{_}_Time_.--Large heads of celery, 25 minutes; small ones, 15 to 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}15069{_}_Average cost_.
10136-8{_}15070{_}2d.
10136-8{_}15071{_}per head.
10136-8{_}15072{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}15073{_}_Seasonable_ from October to April.
10136-8{_}15074{_}ALEXANDERS.--This plant is the _Smyrnium olustratum_ of science, and is used in this country in the same way in which celery is.
10136-8{_}15075{_}It is a native of Great Britain, and is found in its wild state near the seacoast.
10136-8{_}15076{_}It received its name from the Italian "herba Alexandrina," and is supposed to have been originally brought from Alexandria; but, be this as it may, its cultivation is now almost entirely abandoned.
10136-8{_}15077{_}STEWED CELERY (with White Sauce).
10136-8{_}15078{_}I.
10136-8{_}15079{_}1109.
10136-8{_}15080{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 heads of celery, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}15081{_}of butter; to each 1/2 gallon of water allow 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt, 1/2 pint of white sauce, No.
10136-8{_}15082{_}537 or 538.
10136-8{_}15083{_}_Mode_.--Have ready sufficient boiling water just to cover the celery, with salt and butter in the above proportion.
10136-8{_}15084{_}Wash the celery well; cut off the decayed outside leaves, trim away the green tops, and shape the root into a point; put it into the boiling water; let it boil rapidly until tender; then take it out, drain well, place it upon a dish, and pour over about 1/2 pint of white sauce, made by either of the recipes No.
10136-8{_}15085{_}537 or 538.
10136-8{_}15086{_}It may also be plainly boiled as above, placed on toast, and melted butter poured over, the same as asparagus is dished.
10136-8{_}15087{_}_Time_.--Large heads of celery, 25 minutes, small ones, 15 to 20 minutes, after the water boils.
10136-8{_}15088{_}_Average cost_, 2d.
10136-8{_}15089{_}per head.
10136-8{_}15090{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}15091{_}_Seasonable_ from October to April.
10136-8{_}15092{_}ORIGIN OF CELERY.--In the marshes and ditches of this country     there is to be found a very common plant, known by the name of     Smallage.
10136-8{_}15093{_}This is the wild form of celery; but, by being     subjected to cultivation, it loses its acrid nature, and becomes     mild and sweet.
10136-8{_}15094{_}In its natural state, it has a peculiar rank,     coarse taste and smell, and its root was reckoned by the     ancients as one of the "five greater aperient roots."
10136-8{_}15095{_}There is a     variety of this in which the root becomes turnip-shaped and     large.
10136-8{_}15096{_}It is called _Celeriae_, and is extensively used by the     Germans, and preferred by them to celery.
10136-8{_}15097{_}In a raw state, this     plant does not suit weak stomachs; cooked, it is less difficult     of digestion, although a large quantity should not he taken.
10136-8{_}15098{_}[Illustration: CELERY.].
10136-8{_}15099{_}II.
10136-8{_}15100{_}1110.
10136-8{_}15101{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 heads of celery, 1/2 pint of white stock or weak broth, 4 tablespoonfuls of cream, thickening of butter and flour, 1 blade of pounded mace, a _very little_ grated nutmeg; pepper and salt to taste.
10136-8{_}15102{_}_Mode_.--Wash the celery, strip off the outer leaves, and cut it into lengths of about 4 inches.
10136-8{_}15103{_}Put these into a saucepan, with the broth, and stew till tender, which will be in from 20 to 25 minutes; then add the remaining ingredients, simmer altogether for 4 or 5 minutes, pour into a dish, and serve.
10136-8{_}15104{_}It may be garnished with sippets of toasted bread.
10136-8{_}15105{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}15106{_}_Average cost_, 2d.
10136-8{_}15107{_}per head.
10136-8{_}15108{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}15109{_}_Seasonable_ from October to April.
10136-8{_}15110{_}_Note_.--By cutting the celery into smaller pieces, by stewing it a little longer, and, when done, by pressing it through a sieve, the above stew may be converted into a puree of celery.
10136-8{_}15111{_}TO DRESS CUCUMBERS.
10136-8{_}15112{_}1111.
10136-8{_}15113{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 tablespoonfuls of salad-oil, 4 tablespoonfuls of vinegar, salt and pepper to taste; cucumber.
10136-8{_}15114{_}_Mode_.--Pare the cucumber, cut it equally into _very thin_ slices, and _commence_ cutting from the _thick end_; if commenced at the stalk, the cucumber will most likely have an exceedingly bitter taste, far from agreeable.
10136-8{_}15115{_}Put the slices into a dish, sprinkle over salt and pepper, and pour over oil and vinegar in the above proportion; turn the cucumber about, and it is ready to serve.
10136-8{_}15116{_}This is a favourite accompaniment to boiled salmon, is a nice addition to all descriptions of salads, and makes a pretty garnish to lobster salad.
10136-8{_}15117{_}[Illustration: SLICED CUCUMBERS.]
10136-8{_}15118{_}[Illustration: CUCUMBER.]
10136-8{_}15119{_}_Average cost_, when scarce, 1s.
10136-8{_}15120{_}to 2s.
10136-8{_}15121{_}6d.
10136-8{_}15122{_}; when cheapest, may be had for 4d.
10136-8{_}15123{_}each.
10136-8{_}15124{_}_Seasonable_.--Forced from the beginning of March to the end of June; in full season in July, August, and September.
10136-8{_}15125{_}GEOGRAPHICAL DISTRIBUTION OF THE CUCUMBERS.--This family is not     known in the frigid zone, is somewhat rare in the temperate, but     in the tropical and warmer regions throughout the world they are     abundant.
10136-8{_}15126{_}They are most plentiful in the continent of Hindostan;     but in America are not near so plentiful.
10136-8{_}15127{_}Many of the kinds     supply useful articles of consumption for food, and others are     actively medicinal in their virtues.
10136-8{_}15128{_}Generally speaking,     delicate stomachs should avoid this plant, for it is cold and     indigestible.
10136-8{_}15129{_}CUCUMBERS A LA POULETTE.
10136-8{_}15130{_}1112.
10136-8{_}15131{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 or 3 cucumbers, salt and vinegar, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}15132{_}of butter, flour, 1/2 pint of broth, 1 teaspoonful of minced parsley, a lump of sugar, the yolks of 2 eggs, salt and pepper to taste.
10136-8{_}15133{_}_Mode_.--Pare and cut the cucumbers into slices of an equal thickness, and let them remain in a pickle of salt and vinegar for 1/2 hour; then drain them in a cloth, and put them into a stewpan with the butter.
10136-8{_}15134{_}Fry them over a brisk fire, but do not brown them, and then dredge over them a little flour; add the broth, skim off all the fat, which will rise to the surface, and boil gently until the gravy is somewhat reduced; but the cucumber should not be broken.
10136-8{_}15135{_}Stir in the yolks of the eggs, add the parsley, sugar, and a seasoning of pepper and salt; bring the whole to the point of boiling, and serve.
10136-8{_}15136{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 1 hour.
10136-8{_}15137{_}_Average cost_, when cheapest, 4d.
10136-8{_}15138{_}each.
10136-8{_}15139{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}15140{_}_Seasonable_ in July, August, and September; but may be had, forced, from the beginning of March.
10136-8{_}15141{_}FRIED CUCUMBERS.
10136-8{_}15142{_}1113.
10136-8{_}15143{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 or 3 cucumbers, pepper and salt to taste, flour, oil or butter.
10136-8{_}15144{_}_Mode_.--Pare the cucumbers and cut them into slices of an equal thickness, commencing to slice from the thick, and not the stalk end of the cucumber.
10136-8{_}15145{_}Wipe the slices dry with a cloth, dredge them with flour, and put them into a pan of boiling oil or butter; Keep turning them about until brown; lift them out of the pan, let them drain, and serve, piled lightly in a dish.
10136-8{_}15146{_}These will be found a great improvement to rump-steak: they should be placed on a dish with the steak on the top.
10136-8{_}15147{_}_Time_.--5 minutes.
10136-8{_}15148{_}_Average cost_, when cheapest, 4d.
10136-8{_}15149{_}each.
10136-8{_}15150{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}15151{_}_Seasonable_.--Forced from the beginning of March to the end of June; in full season in July and August.
10136-8{_}15152{_}PROPERTIES AND USES OF THE CUCURBITS.--The common cucumber is     the C. sativus of science, and although the whole of the family     have a similar action in the animal economy, yet there are some     which present us with great anomalies.
10136-8{_}15153{_}The roots of those which     are perennial contain, besides fecula, which is their base, a     resinous, acrid, and bitter principle.
10136-8{_}15154{_}The fruits of this     family, however, have in general a sugary taste, and are more or     less dissolving and perfumed, as we find in the melons, gourds,     cucumbers, vegetable-marrows, and squashes.
10136-8{_}15155{_}But these are     slightly laxative if partaken of largely.
10136-8{_}15156{_}In tropical countries,     this order furnishes the inhabitants with a large portion of     their food, which, even in the most arid deserts and most barren     islands, is of the finest quality.
10136-8{_}15157{_}In China, Cashmere, and     Persia, they are cultivated on the lakes on the floating     collections of weeds common in these localities.
10136-8{_}15158{_}In India they     are everywhere abundant, either in a cultivated or wild state,     and the seeds of all the family are sweet and mucilaginous.
10136-8{_}15159{_}STEWED CUCUMBERS.
10136-8{_}15160{_}1114.
10136-8{_}15161{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 large cucumbers, flour, butter, rather more than 1/2 pint of good brown gravy.
10136-8{_}15162{_}_Mode_.--Cut the cucumbers lengthwise the size of the dish they are intended to be served in; empty them of the seeds, and put them into boiling water with a little salt, and let them simmer for 5 minutes; then take them out, place them in another stewpan, with the gravy, and let them boil over a brisk fire until the cucumbers are tender.
10136-8{_}15163{_}Should these be bitter, add a lump of sugar; carefully dish them, skim the sauce, pour over the cucumbers, and serve.
10136-8{_}15164{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}15165{_}_Average cost_, when cheapest, 1d.
10136-8{_}15166{_}each.
10136-8{_}15167{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 or 4 persons.
10136-8{_}15168{_}_Seasonable_ in June, July, and August; but may be had, forced, from the beginning of March.
10136-8{_}15169{_}THE CHATE.--This cucumber is a native of Egypt and Arabia, and     produces a fruit of almost the same substance as that of the     Melon.
10136-8{_}15170{_}In Egypt it is esteemed by the upper class natives, as     well as by Europeans, as the most pleasant fruit they have.
10136-8{_}15171{_}STEWED CUCUMBERS WITH ONIONS.
10136-8{_}15172{_}1115.
10136-8{_}15173{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 cucumbers, 3 moderate-sized onions, not quite 1 pint of white stock, cayenne and salt to taste, the yolks of 2 eggs, a very little grated nutmeg.
10136-8{_}15174{_}_Mode_.--Pare and slice the cucumbers, take out the seeds, and cut the onions into thin slices; put these both into a stewpan, with the stock, and let them boil for 1/4 hour or longer, should the cucumbers be very large.
10136-8{_}15175{_}Beat up the yolks of 2 eggs; stir these into the sauce; add the cayenne, salt, and grated nutmeg; bring it to the point of boiling, and serve.
10136-8{_}15176{_}Do not allow the sauce to boil, or it will curdle.
10136-8{_}15177{_}This is a favourite dish with lamb or mutton chops, rump-steaks, &c.
10136-8{_}15178{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}15179{_}_Average cost_, when cheapest, 4d.
10136-8{_}15180{_}each.
10136-8{_}15181{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 or 7 persons.
10136-8{_}15182{_}_Seasonable_ in July, August, and September; but may be had, forced, from the beginning of March.
10136-8{_}15183{_}THE MELON.--This is another species of the cucumber, and is     highly esteemed for its rich and delicious fruit.
10136-8{_}15184{_}It was     introduced to this country from Jamaica, in 1570; since which     period it has continued to be cultivated.
10136-8{_}15185{_}It was formerly called     the Musk Melon.
10136-8{_}15186{_}ENDIVE.
10136-8{_}15187{_}[Illustration: ENDIVE.]
10136-8{_}15188{_}1116.
10136-8{_}15189{_}This vegetable, so beautiful in appearance, makes an excellent addition to winter salad, when lettuces and other salad herbs are not obtainable.
10136-8{_}15190{_}It is usually placed in the centre of the dish, and looks remarkably pretty with slices of beetroot, hard-boiled eggs, and curled celery placed round it, so that the colours contrast nicely.
10136-8{_}15191{_}In preparing it, carefully wash and cleanse it free from insects, which are generally found near the heart; remove any decayed or dead leaves, and dry it thoroughly by shaking in a cloth.
10136-8{_}15192{_}This vegetable may also be served hot, stewed in cream, brown gravy, or butter; but when dressed thus, the sauce it is stewed in should not be very highly seasoned, as that would destroy and overpower the flavour of the vegetable.
10136-8{_}15193{_}_Average cost_, 1d.
10136-8{_}15194{_}per head.
10136-8{_}15195{_}_Sufficient_,--1 head for a salad for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}15196{_}_Seasonable_ from November to March.
10136-8{_}15197{_}ENDIVE.--This is the _C.
10136-8{_}15198{_}endivium_ of science, and is much used     as a salad.
10136-8{_}15199{_}It belongs to the family of the _Compositae_, with     Chicory, common Goats-beard, and others of the same genus.
10136-8{_}15200{_}Withering states, that before the stems of the common     Goats-beard shoot up the roots, boiled like asparagus, have the     same flavour, and are nearly as nutritious.
10136-8{_}15201{_}We are also informed     by Villars that the children in Dauphiné universally eat the     stems and leaves of the young plant before the flowers appear,     with great avidity.
10136-8{_}15202{_}The fresh juice of these tender herbs is     said to be the best solvent of bile.
10136-8{_}15203{_}STEWED ENDIVE.
10136-8{_}15204{_}1117.
10136-8{_}15205{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 heads of endive, salt and water, 1 pint of broth, thickening of butter and flour, 1 tablespoonful of lemon-juice, a small lump of sugar.
10136-8{_}15206{_}_Mode_.--Wash and free the endive thoroughly from insects, remove the green part of the leaves, and put it into boiling water, slightly salted.
10136-8{_}15207{_}Let it remain for 10 minutes; then take it out, drain it till there is no water remaining, and chop it very fine.
10136-8{_}15208{_}Put it into a stewpan with the broth; add a little salt and a lump of sugar, and boil until the endive is perfectly tender.
10136-8{_}15209{_}When done, which may be ascertained by squeezing a piece between the thumb and finger, add a thickening of butter and flour and the lemon-juice: let the sauce boil up, and serve.
10136-8{_}15210{_}_Time_.--10 minutes to boil, 5 minutes to simmer in the broth.
10136-8{_}15211{_}_Average cost_, 1d.
10136-8{_}15212{_}per head.
10136-8{_}15213{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 or 4 persons.
10136-8{_}15214{_}_Seasonable_ from November to March.
10136-8{_}15215{_}ENDIVE A LA FRANCAISE.
10136-8{_}15216{_}1118.
10136-8{_}15217{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 heads of endive, 1 pint of broth, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}15218{_}of fresh butter; salt, pepper, and grated nutmeg to taste.
10136-8{_}15219{_}_Mode_.--Wash and boil the endive as in the preceding recipe; chop it rather fine, and put into a stewpan with the broth; boil over a brisk fire until the sauce is all reduced; then put in the butter, pepper, salt, and grated nutmeg (the latter must be very sparingly used); mix all well together, bring it to the boiling point, and serve very hot.
10136-8{_}15220{_}_Time_,--10 minutes to boil, 5 minutes to simmer in the broth.
10136-8{_}15221{_}_Average cost_, 1d.
10136-8{_}15222{_}per head.
10136-8{_}15223{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 or 4 persons.
10136-8{_}15224{_}_Seasonable_ from November to March.
10136-8{_}15225{_}TO BOIL HARICOTS BLANCS, or WHITE HARICOT BEANS.
10136-8{_}15226{_}1119.
10136-8{_}15227{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 quart of white haricot beans, 2 quarts of soft water, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}15228{_}of butter, 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt.
10136-8{_}15229{_}_Mode_.--Put the beans into cold water, and let them soak from 2 to 4 hours, according to their age; then put them into cold water, salted in the above proportion, bring them to boil, and let them simmer very slowly until tender; pour the water away from them, let them stand by the side of the fire, with the lid of the saucepan partially off, to allow the beans to dry; then add 1 oz.
10136-8{_}15230{_}of butter and a seasoning of pepper and salt.
10136-8{_}15231{_}Shake the beans about for a minute or two, and serve: do not stir them with a spoon, for fear of breaking them to pieces.
10136-8{_}15232{_}_Time_.--After the water boils, from 2 to 2-1/2 hours.
10136-8{_}15233{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}15234{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}15235{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}15236{_}_Seasonable_ in winter, when other vegetables are scarce.
10136-8{_}15237{_}_Note_.--Haricots blancs, when new and fresh, should be put into boiling water, and do not require any soaking previous to dressing.
10136-8{_}15238{_}HARICOTS AND LENTILS.--Although these vegetables are not much     used in this country, yet in France, and other Catholic     countries, from their peculiar constituent properties, they form     an excellent substitute for animal food during Lent and _maigre_     days.
10136-8{_}15239{_}At the time of the prevalence of the Roman religion in     this country, they were probably much more generally used than     at present.
10136-8{_}15240{_}As reformations are often carried beyond necessity,     possibly lentils may have fallen into disuse, as an article of     diet amongst Protestants, for fear the use of them might be     considered a sign of popery.
10136-8{_}15241{_}HARICOTS BLANCS A LA MAITRE D'HOTEL.
10136-8{_}15242{_}1120.
10136-8{_}15243{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 quart of white haricot beans, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}15244{_}of fresh butter, 1 tablespoonful of minced parsley, pepper and salt to taste, the juice of 1/2 lemon.
10136-8{_}15245{_}[Illustration: HARICOT BEANS.]
10136-8{_}15246{_}_Mode_.--Should the beans be very dry, soak them for an hour or two in cold water, and boil them until perfectly tender, as in the preceding recipe.
10136-8{_}15247{_}If the water should boil away, replenish it with a little more cold, which makes the skin of the beans tender.
10136-8{_}15248{_}Let them be very thoroughly done; drain them well; then add to them the butter, minced parsley, and a seasoning of pepper and salt.
10136-8{_}15249{_}Keep moving the stewpan over the fire without using a spoon, as this would break the beans; and, when the various ingredients are well mixed with them, squeeze in the lemon-juice, and serve very hot.
10136-8{_}15250{_}_Time_.--From 2 to 2-1/2 hours to boil the beans.
10136-8{_}15251{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}15252{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}15253{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}15254{_}_Seasonable_ in winter.
10136-8{_}15255{_}HARICOT BEANS.--This is the _haricot blanc_ of the French, and     is a native of India.
10136-8{_}15256{_}It ripens readily, in dry summers, in most     parts of Britain, but its culture has hitherto been confined to     gardens in England; but in Germany and Switzerland it is grown     in fields.
10136-8{_}15257{_}It is usually harvested by pulling up the plants,     which, being dried, are stacked and thrashed.
10136-8{_}15258{_}The haulm is both     of little bulk and little use, but the seed is used in making     the esteemed French dish called haricot, with which it were well     if the working classes of this country were acquainted.
10136-8{_}15259{_}There     is, perhaps, no other vegetable dish so cheap and easily cooked,     and, at the same time, so agreeable and nourishing.
10136-8{_}15260{_}The beans     are boiled, and then mixed with a little fat or salt butter, and     a little milk or water and flour.
10136-8{_}15261{_}From 3,840 parts of     kidney-bean Einholff obtained 1,805 parts of matter analogous to     starch, 351 of vegeto-animal matter, and 799 parts of mucilage.
10136-8{_}15262{_}HARICOT BEANS AND MINCED ONIONS.
10136-8{_}15263{_}1121.
10136-8{_}15264{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 quart of white haricot beans, 4 middling-sized onions, 1/4 pint of good brown gravy, pepper and salt to taste, a little flour.
10136-8{_}15265{_}_Mode_.--Peel and mince the onions not too finely, and fry them in butter of a light brown colour; dredge over them a little flour, and add the gravy and a seasoning of pepper and salt.
10136-8{_}15266{_}Have ready a pint of haricot beans well boiled and drained; put them with the onions and gravy, mix all well together, and serve very hot.
10136-8{_}15267{_}_Time_.--From 2 to 2-1/2 hours to boil the beans; 5 minutes to fry the onions.
10136-8{_}15268{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}15269{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}15270{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}15271{_}_Seasonable_ in winter.
10136-8{_}15272{_}HORSERADISH.
10136-8{_}15273{_}1122.
10136-8{_}15274{_}This root, scraped, is always served with hot roast beef, and is used for garnishing many kinds of boiled fish.
10136-8{_}15275{_}Let the horseradish remain in cold water for an hour; wash it well, and with a sharp knife scrape it into very thin shreds, commencing from the thick end of the root.
10136-8{_}15276{_}Arrange some of it lightly in a small glass dish, and the remainder use for garnishing the joint: it should be placed in tufts round the border of the dish, with 1 or 2 bunches on the meat.
10136-8{_}15277{_}_Average cost_, 2d.
10136-8{_}15278{_}per stick.
10136-8{_}15279{_}_Seasonable_ from October to June.
10136-8{_}15280{_}[Illustration: HORSERADISH.]
10136-8{_}15281{_}THE HORSERADISH.--This belongs to the tribe _Alyssidae_, and is     highly stimulant and exciting to the stomach.
10136-8{_}15282{_}It has been     recommended in chronic rheumatism, palsy, dropsical complaints,     and in cases of enfeebled digestion.
10136-8{_}15283{_}Its principal use, however,     is as a condiment to promote appetite and excite the digestive     organs.
10136-8{_}15284{_}The horseradish contains sulphur to the extent of thirty     per cent, in the number of its elements; and it is to the     presence of this quality that the metal vessels in which the     radish is sometimes distilled, are turned into a black colour.
10136-8{_}15285{_}It is one of the most powerful excitants and antiscorbutics we     have, and forms the basis of several medical preparations, in     the form of wines, tinctures, and syrups.
10136-8{_}15286{_}LETTUCES.
10136-8{_}15287{_}1123.
10136-8{_}15288{_}These form one of the principal ingredients to summer salads; should be nicely blanched, and be eaten young.
10136-8{_}15289{_}They are seldom served in any other way, but may be stewed and sent to table in a good brown gravy flavoured with lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}15290{_}In preparing them for a salad, carefully wash them free from dirt, pick off all the decayed and outer leaves, and dry them thoroughly by shaking them in a cloth.
10136-8{_}15291{_}Cut off the stalks, and either halve or cut the lettuces into small pieces.
10136-8{_}15292{_}The manner of cutting them up entirely depends on the salad for which they are intended.
10136-8{_}15293{_}In France the lettuces are sometimes merely wiped with a cloth and not washed, the cooks there declaring that the act of washing them injuriously affects the pleasant crispness of the plant: in this case scrupulous attention must be paid to each leaf, and the grit thoroughly wiped away.
10136-8{_}15294{_}_Average cost_, when cheapest, 1d.
10136-8{_}15295{_}each.
10136-8{_}15296{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 2 lettuces for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}15297{_}_Seasonable_ from March to the end of August, but may be had all the year.
10136-8{_}15298{_}[Illustration: LETTUCE.]
10136-8{_}15299{_}THE LETTUCE.--All the varieties of the garden lettuce have     originated from the _Lactuca sativa_ of science, which has never     yet been found in a wild state.
10136-8{_}15300{_}Hence it may be concluded that     it is merely another form of some species, changed through the     effects of cultivation.
10136-8{_}15301{_}In its young state, the lettuce forms a     well-known and wholesome salad, containing a bland pellucid     juice, with little taste or smell, and having a cooling and     soothing influence on the system.
