10136-8{_}15302{_}This arises from the large     quantities of water and mucilage it contains, and not from any     narcotic principle which it is supposed to possess.
10136-8{_}15303{_}During the     period of flowering, it abounds in a peculiar milky juice, which     flows from the stem when wounded, and which has been found to be     possessed of decided medicinal properties.
10136-8{_}15304{_}BAKED MUSHROOMS.
10136-8{_}15305{_}(A Breakfast, Luncheon, or Supper Dish.)
10136-8{_}15306{_}1124.
10136-8{_}15307{_}INGREDIENTS.--16 to 20 mushroom-flaps, butter, pepper to taste.
10136-8{_}15308{_}_Mode_.--For this mode of cooking, the mushroom flaps are better than the buttons, and should not be too large.
10136-8{_}15309{_}Cut off a portion of the stalk, peel the top, and wipe the mushrooms carefully with a piece of flannel and a little fine salt.
10136-8{_}15310{_}Put them into a tin baking-dish, with a very small piece of butter placed on each mushroom; sprinkle over a little pepper, and let them bake for about 20 minutes, or longer should the mushrooms be very large.
10136-8{_}15311{_}Have ready a _very hot_ dish, pile the mushrooms high in the centre, pour the gravy round, and send them to table quickly, with very _hot_ plates.
10136-8{_}15312{_}_Time_.--20 minutes; large mushrooms, 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}15313{_}_Average cost_, 1d.
10136-8{_}15314{_}each for large mushroom-flaps.
10136-8{_}15315{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}15316{_}_Seasonable_.--Meadow mushrooms in September and October; cultivated mushrooms may be had at any time.
10136-8{_}15317{_}FUNGI.--These are common parasitical plants, originating in the     production of copious filamentous threads, called the mycelium,     or spawn.
10136-8{_}15318{_}Rounded tubers appear on the mycelium; some of these     enlarge rapidly, burst an outer covering, which is left at the     base, and protrude a thick stalk, bearing at its summit a     rounded body, which in a short time expands into the pileus or     cap.
10136-8{_}15319{_}The gills, which occupy its lower surface, consist of     parallel plates, bearing naked sporules over their whole     surface.
10136-8{_}15320{_}Some of the cells, which are visible by the microscope,     produce four small cells at their free summit, apparently by     germination and constriction.
10136-8{_}15321{_}These are the sporules, and this     is the development of the Agarics.
10136-8{_}15322{_}BROILED MUSHROOMS.
10136-8{_}15323{_}(A Breakfast, Luncheon, or Supper Dish.)
10136-8{_}15324{_}1125.
10136-8{_}15325{_}INGREDIENTS.--Mushroom-flaps, pepper and salt to taste, butter, lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}15326{_}[Illustration: BROILED MUSHROOMS.]
10136-8{_}15327{_}_Mode_.--Cleanse the mushrooms by wiping them with a piece of flannel and a little salt; cut off a portion of the stalk, and peel the tops: broil them over a clear fire, turning them once, and arrange them on a very hot dish.
10136-8{_}15328{_}Put a small piece of butter on each mushroom, season with pepper and salt, and squeeze over them a few drops of lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}15329{_}Place the dish before the fire, and when the butter is melted, serve very hot and quickly.
10136-8{_}15330{_}Moderate-sized flaps are better suited to this mode of cooking than the buttons: the latter are better in stews.
10136-8{_}15331{_}_Time_.--10 minutes for medium-sized mushrooms.
10136-8{_}15332{_}_Average cost_, 1d.
10136-8{_}15333{_}each for large mushrooms.
10136-8{_}15334{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 3 or 4 mushrooms to each person.
10136-8{_}15335{_}_Seasonable_.--Meadow mushrooms in September and October; cultivated mushrooms may be had at any time.
10136-8{_}15336{_}[Illustration: MUSHROOMS.]
10136-8{_}15337{_}VARIETIES OF THE MUSHROOM.--The common mushroom found in our     pastures is the _Agaricus campestris_ of science, and another     edible British species is _A.
10136-8{_}15338{_}Georgii;_ but _A.
10136-8{_}15339{_}primulus_ is     affirmed to be the most delicious mushroom.
10136-8{_}15340{_}The morel is     _Morchella esculenta_, and _Tuber cibarium_ is the common     truffle.
10136-8{_}15341{_}There is in New Zealand a long fungus, which grows from     the head of a caterpillar, and which forms a horn, as it were,     and is called _Sphaeria Robertsii_.
10136-8{_}15342{_}TO PRESERVE MUSHROOMS.
10136-8{_}15343{_}1126.
10136-8{_}15344{_}INGREDIENTS.--To each quart of mushrooms, allow 3 oz.
10136-8{_}15345{_}of butter, pepper and salt to taste, the juice of 1 lemon, clarified butter.
10136-8{_}15346{_}_Mode_.--Peel the mushrooms, put them into cold water, with a little lemon-juice; take them out and _dry_ them very carefully in a cloth.
10136-8{_}15347{_}Put the butter into a stewpan capable of holding the mushrooms; when it is melted, add the mushrooms, lemon-juice, and a seasoning of pepper and salt; draw them down over a slow fire, and let them remain until their liquor is boiled away, and they have become quite dry, but be careful in not allowing them to stick to the bottom of the stewpan.
10136-8{_}15348{_}When done, put them into pots, and pour over the top clarified butter.
10136-8{_}15349{_}If wanted for immediate use, they will keep good a few days without being covered over.
10136-8{_}15350{_}To re-warm them, put the mushrooms into a stewpan, strain the butter from them, and they will be ready for use.
10136-8{_}15351{_}_Average cost_, 1d.
10136-8{_}15352{_}each.
10136-8{_}15353{_}_Seasonable_.--Meadow mushrooms in September and October; cultivated mushrooms may be had at any time.
10136-8{_}15354{_}LOCALITIES OF THE MUSHROOM.--Mushrooms are to be met with in     pastures, woods, and marshes, but are very capricious and     uncertain in their places of growth, multitudes being obtained     in one season where few or none were to be found in the     preceding.
10136-8{_}15355{_}They sometimes grow solitary, but more frequently     they are gregarious, and rise in a regular circular form.
10136-8{_}15356{_}Many     species are employed by man as food; but, generally speaking,     they are difficult of digestion, and by no means very     nourishing.
10136-8{_}15357{_}Many of them are also of suspicious qualities.
10136-8{_}15358{_}Little reliance can be placed either on their taste, smell, or     colour, as much depends on the situation in which they vegetate;     and even the same plant, it is affirmed, may be innocent when     young, but become noxious when advanced in age.
10136-8{_}15359{_}STEWED MUSHROOMS.
10136-8{_}15360{_}1127.
10136-8{_}15361{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint mushroom-buttons, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}15362{_}of fresh butter, white pepper and salt to taste, lemon-juice, 1 teaspoonful of flour, cream or milk, 1 teaspoonful of grated nutmeg.
10136-8{_}15363{_}_Mode_.--Cut off the ends of the stalks, and pare neatly a pint of mushroom-buttons; put them into a basin of water, with a little lemon-juice, as they are done.
10136-8{_}15364{_}When all are prepared, take them from the water with the hands, to avoid the sediment, and put them into a stewpan with the fresh butter, white pepper, salt, and the juice of 1/2 lemon; cover the pan closely, and let the mushrooms stew gently from 20 to 25 minutes; then thicken the butter with the above proportion of flour, add gradually sufficient cream, or cream and milk, to make the sauce of a proper consistency, and put in the grated nutmeg.
10136-8{_}15365{_}If the mushrooms are not perfectly tender, stew them for 5 minutes longer, remove every particle of butter which may be floating on the top, and serve.
10136-8{_}15366{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}15367{_}_Average cost_, from 9d.
10136-8{_}15368{_}to 2s.
10136-8{_}15369{_}per pint.
10136-8{_}15370{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}15371{_}_Seasonable_.--Meadow mushrooms in September and October.
10136-8{_}15372{_}TO PROCURE MUSHROOMS.--In order to obtain mushrooms at all     seasons, several methods of propagation have been had recourse     to.
10136-8{_}15373{_}It is said that, in some parts of Italy, a species of stone     is used for this purpose, which is described as being of two     different kinds; the one is found in the chalk hills near     Naples, and has a white, porous, stalactical appearance; the     other is a hardened turf from some volcanic mountains near     Florence.
10136-8{_}15374{_}These stones are kept in cellars, and occasionally     moistened with water which has been used in the washing of     mushrooms, and are thus supplied with their minute seeds.
10136-8{_}15375{_}In     this country, gardeners provide themselves with what is called     _spawn_, either from the old manure of cucumber-beds, or     purchase it from those whose business it is to propagate it.
10136-8{_}15376{_}When thus procured, it is usually made up for sale in quadrils,     consisting of numerous white fibrous roots, having a strong     smell of mushrooms.
10136-8{_}15377{_}This is planted in rows, in a dry situation,     and carefully attended to for five or six weeks, when the bed     begins to produce, and continues to do so for several months.
10136-8{_}15378{_}STEWED MUSHROOMS IN GRAVY.
10136-8{_}15379{_}1128.
10136-8{_}15380{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint of mushroom-buttons, 1 pint of brown gravy No.
10136-8{_}15381{_}436, 1/4 teaspoonful of grated nutmeg, cayenne and salt to taste.
10136-8{_}15382{_}_Mode_.--Make a pint of brown gravy by recipe 436; cut nearly all the stalks away from the mushrooms and peel the tops; put them into a stewpan, with the gravy, and simmer them gently from 20 minutes to 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}15383{_}Add the nutmeg and a seasoning of cayenne and salt, and serve very hot.
10136-8{_}15384{_}_Time_.--20 minutes to 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}15385{_}_Average cost_, 9d.
10136-8{_}15386{_}to 2s.
10136-8{_}15387{_}per pint.
10136-8{_}15388{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}15389{_}_Seasonable_.--Meadow mushrooms in September and October.
10136-8{_}15390{_}ANALYSIS OF FUNGI.--The fungi have been examined chemically with     much care, both by MM.
10136-8{_}15391{_}Bracannot and Vauquelin, who designate     the insoluble spongy matter by the name of fungin, and the     soluble portion is found to contain the bolotic and the fungic     acids.
10136-8{_}15392{_}BAKED SPANISH ONIONS.
10136-8{_}15393{_}1129.
10136-8{_}15394{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 or 5 Spanish onions, salt, and water.
10136-8{_}15395{_}_Mode_.--Put the onions, with their skins on, into a saucepan of boiling water slightly salted, and let them boil quickly for an hour.
10136-8{_}15396{_}Then take them out, wipe them thoroughly, wrap each one in a piece of paper separately, and bake them in a moderate oven for 2 hours, or longer, should the onions be very large.
10136-8{_}15397{_}They may be served in their skins, and eaten with a piece of cold butter and a seasoning of pepper and salt; or they may be peeled, and a good brown gravy poured over them.
10136-8{_}15398{_}_Time_.--1 hour to boil, 2 hours to bake.
10136-8{_}15399{_}_Average cost_, medium-sized, 2d.
10136-8{_}15400{_}each.
10136-8{_}15401{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}15402{_}_Seasonable_ from September to January.
10136-8{_}15403{_}[Illustration: ONION.]
10136-8{_}15404{_}THE GENUS ALLIUM.--The Onion, like the Leek, Garlic, and Shalot,     belongs to the genus _Allium_, which is a numerous species of     vegetable; and every one of them possesses, more or less, a     volatile and acrid penetrating principle, pricking the thin     transparent membrane of the eyelids; and all are very similar in     their properties.
10136-8{_}15405{_}In the whole of them the bulb is the most     active part, and any one of them may supply the place of the     other; for they are all irritant, excitant, and vesicant.
10136-8{_}15406{_}With     many, the onion is a very great favourite, and is considered an     extremely nutritive vegetable.
10136-8{_}15407{_}The Spanish kind is frequently     taken for supper, it being simply boiled, and then seasoned with     salt, pepper, and butter.
10136-8{_}15408{_}Some dredge on a little flour, but     many prefer it without this.
10136-8{_}15409{_}BURNT ONIONS FOR GRAVIES.
10136-8{_}15410{_}1130.
10136-8{_}15411{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}15412{_}of onions, 1/3 pint of water, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}15413{_}of moist sugar, 1/3 pint of vinegar.
10136-8{_}15414{_}_Mode_.--Peel and chop the onions fine, and put them into a stewpan (not tinned), with the water; let them boil for 5 minutes, then add the sugar, and simmer gently until the mixture becomes nearly black and throws out bubbles of smoke.
10136-8{_}15415{_}Have ready the above proportion of boiling vinegar, strain the liquor gradually to it, and keep stirring with a wooden spoon until it is well incorporated.
10136-8{_}15416{_}When cold, bottle for use.
10136-8{_}15417{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 1 hour.
10136-8{_}15418{_}PROPERTIES OF THE ONION.--The onion is possessed of a white,     acrid, volatile oil, holding sulphur in solution, albumen, a     good deal of uncrystallizable sugar and mucilage; phosphoric     acid, both free and combined with lime; acetic acid, citrate of     lime, and lignine.
10136-8{_}15419{_}Of all the species of allium, the onion has     the volatile principle in the greatest degree; and hence it is     impossible to separate the scales of the root without the eyes     being affected.
10136-8{_}15420{_}The juice is sensibly acid, and is capable of     being, by fermentation, converted into vinegar, and, mixed with     water or the dregs of beer, yields, by distillation, an     alcoholic liquor.
10136-8{_}15421{_}Although used as a common esculent, onions are     not suited to all stomachs; there are some who cannot eat them     either fried or roasted, whilst others prefer them boiled, which     is the best way of using them, as, by the process they then     undergo, they are deprived of their essential oil.
10136-8{_}15422{_}The pulp of     roasted onions, with oil, forms an excellent anodyne and     emollient poultice to suppurating tumours.
10136-8{_}15423{_}STEWED SPANISH ONIONS.
10136-8{_}15424{_}1131--INGREDIENTS.--5 or 6 Spanish onions, 1 pint of good broth or gravy.
10136-8{_}15425{_}_Mode_.--Peel the onions, taking care not to cut away too much of the tops or tails, or they would then fall to pieces; put them into a stewpan capable of holding them at the bottom without piling them one on the top of another; add the broth or gravy, and simmer _very gently_ until the onions are perfectly tender.
10136-8{_}15426{_}Dish them, pour the gravy round, and serve.
10136-8{_}15427{_}Instead of using broth, Spanish onions may be stewed with a large piece of butter: they must be done very gradually over a slow fire or hot-plate, and will produce plenty of gravy.
10136-8{_}15428{_}_Time_.--To stew in gravy, 2 hours, or longer if very large.
10136-8{_}15429{_}_Average cost_.--medium-sized, 2d.
10136-8{_}15430{_}each.
10136-8{_}15431{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 or 7 persons.
10136-8{_}15432{_}_Seasonable_ from September to January.
10136-8{_}15433{_}_Note_.--Stewed Spanish onions are a favourite accompaniment to roast shoulder of mutton.
10136-8{_}15434{_}ORIGIN OF THE ONION.--This vegetable is thought to have     originally come from India, through Egypt, where it became an     object of worship.
10136-8{_}15435{_}Thence it was transmitted to Greece, thence     to Italy, and ultimately it was distributed throughout Europe,     in almost every part of which it has, from time immemorial, been     cultivated.
10136-8{_}15436{_}In warm climates it is found to be less acrid and     much sweeter than in colder latitudes; and in Spain it is not at     all unusual to see a peasant munching an onion, as an Englishman     would an apple.
10136-8{_}15437{_}Spanish onions, which are imported to this     country during the winter months, are, when properly roasted,     perfectly sweet, and equal to many preserves.
10136-8{_}15438{_}BOILED PARSNIPS.
10136-8{_}15439{_}1132.
10136-8{_}15440{_}INGREDIENTS.--Parsnips; to each gallon of water allow 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt.
10136-8{_}15441{_}_Mode_.--Wash the parsnips, scrape them thoroughly, and, with the point of the knife, remove any black specks about them, and, should they be very large, cut the thick part into quarters.
10136-8{_}15442{_}Put them into a saucepan of boiling water salted in the above proportion, boil them rapidly until tender, which may be ascertained by thrusting a fork in them; take them up, drain them, and serve in a vegetable-dish.
10136-8{_}15443{_}This vegetable is usually served with salt fish, boiled pork, or boiled beef: when sent to table with the latter, a few should be placed alternately with carrots round the dish, as a garnish.
10136-8{_}15444{_}_Time_.--Large parsnips, 1 to 1-1/2 hour; small ones, 1/2 to 1 hour.
10136-8{_}15445{_}_Average cost_, 1d.
10136-8{_}15446{_}each.
10136-8{_}15447{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 1 for each person.
10136-8{_}15448{_}_Seasonable_ from October to May.
10136-8{_}15449{_}[Illustration: THE PARSNIP.]
10136-8{_}15450{_}THE PARSNIP.--This vegetable is found wild in meadows all over     Europe, and, in England, is met with very frequently on dry     banks in a chalky soil.
10136-8{_}15451{_}In its wild state, the root is white,     mucilaginous, aromatic, and sweet, with some degree of acrimony:     when old, it has been known to cause vertigo.
10136-8{_}15452{_}Willis relates     that a whole family fell into delirium from having eaten of its     roots, and cattle never touch it in its wild state.
10136-8{_}15453{_}In domestic     economy the parsnip is much used, and is found to be a highly     nutritious vegetable.
10136-8{_}15454{_}In times of scarcity, an excellent bread     has been made from the roots, and they also furnish an excellent     wine, resembling the malmsey of Madeira and the Canaries: a     spirit is also obtained from them in as great quantities as from     carrots.
10136-8{_}15455{_}The composition of the parsnip-root has been found to     be 79.4 of water, 0.9 starch and fibre, 6.1 gum, 5.5 sugar, and     2.1 of albumen.
10136-8{_}15456{_}BOILED GREEN PEAS.
10136-8{_}15457{_}1133.
10136-8{_}15458{_}INGREDIENTS.--Green peas; to each 1/2 gallon of water allow 1 _small_ teaspoonful of moist sugar, 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt.
10136-8{_}15459{_}_Mode_.--This delicious vegetable, to be eaten in perfection, should be young, and not _gathered_ or _shelled_ long before it is dressed.
10136-8{_}15460{_}Shell the peas, wash them well in cold water, and drain them; then put them into a saucepan with plenty of _fast-boiling_ water, to which salt and _moist sugar_ have been added in the above proportion; let them boil quickly over a brisk fire, with the lid of the saucepan uncovered, and be careful that the smoke does not draw in.
10136-8{_}15461{_}When tender, pour them into a colander; put them into a hot vegetable-dish, and quite in the centre of the peas place a piece of butter, the size of a walnut.
10136-8{_}15462{_}Many cooks boil a small bunch of mint _with_ the _peas_, or garnish them with it, by boiling a few sprigs in a saucepan by themselves.
10136-8{_}15463{_}Should the peas be very old, and difficult to boil a good colour, a very tiny piece of soda may be thrown in the water previous to putting them in; but this must be very sparingly used, as it causes the peas, when boiled, to have a smashed and broken appearance.
10136-8{_}15464{_}With young peas, there is not the slightest occasion to use it.
10136-8{_}15465{_}_Time_.--Young peas, 10 to 15 minutes; the large sorts, such as marrowfats, &c., 18 to 24 minutes; old peas, 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}15466{_}_Average cost_, when cheapest, 6d.
10136-8{_}15467{_}per peck; when first in season, 1s.
10136-8{_}15468{_}to 1s.
10136-8{_}15469{_}6d.
10136-8{_}15470{_}per peck.
10136-8{_}15471{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 1 peck of unshelled peas for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}15472{_}_Seasonable_ from June to the end of August.
10136-8{_}15473{_}ORIGIN OF THE PEA.--All the varieties of garden peas which are     cultivated have originated from the _Pisum sativum_, a native of     the south of Europe; and field peas are varieties of _Pisum     arvense_.
10136-8{_}15474{_}The Everlasting Pea is _Lathyrus latifolius_, an old     favourite in flower-gardens.
10136-8{_}15475{_}It is said to yield an abundance of     honey to bees, which are remarkably fond of it.
10136-8{_}15476{_}In this country     the pea has been grown from time immemorial; but its culture     seems to have diminished since the more general introduction of     herbage, plants, and roots.
10136-8{_}15477{_}GREEN PEAS A LA FRANCAISE.
10136-8{_}15478{_}1134.
10136-8{_}15479{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 quarts of green peas, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}15480{_}of fresh butter, a bunch of parsley, 6 green onions, flour, a small lump of sugar, 1/2 teaspoonful of salt, a teaspoonful of flour.
10136-8{_}15481{_}_Mode_.--Shell sufficient fresh-gathered peas to fill 2 quarts; put them into cold water, with the above proportion of butter, and stir them about until they are well covered with the butter; drain them in a colander, and put them in a stewpan, with the parsley and onions; dredge over them a little flour, stir the peas well, and moisten them with boiling water; boil them quickly over a large fire for 20 minutes, or until there is no liquor remaining.
10136-8{_}15482{_}Dip a small lump of sugar into some water, that it may soon melt; put it with the peas, to which add 1/2 teaspoonful of salt.
10136-8{_}15483{_}Take a piece of butter the size of a walnut, work it together with a teaspoonful of flour; and add this to the peas, which should be boiling when it is put in.
10136-8{_}15484{_}Keep shaking the stewpan, and, when the peas are nicely thickened, dress them high in the dish, and serve.
10136-8{_}15485{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}15486{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}15487{_}per peck.
10136-8{_}15488{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}15489{_}_Seasonable_ from June to the end of August.
10136-8{_}15490{_}VARIETIES OF THE PEA.--The varieties of the Pea are numerous;     but they may be divided into two classes--those grown for the     ripened seed, and those grown for gathering in a green state.
10136-8{_}15491{_}The culture of the latter is chiefly confined to the     neighbourhoods of large towns, and may be considered as in part     rather to belong to the operations of the gardener than to those     of the agriculturist.
10136-8{_}15492{_}The grey varieties are the early grey, the     late grey, and the purple grey; to which some add the     Marlborough grey and the horn grey.
10136-8{_}15493{_}The white varieties grown in     fields are the pearl, early Charlton, golden hotspur, the common     white, or Suffolk, and other Suffolk varieties.
10136-8{_}15494{_}STEWED GREEN PEAS.
10136-8{_}15495{_}1135.
10136-8{_}15496{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 quart of peas, 1 Lettuce, 1 onion, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}15497{_}of butter, pepper and salt to taste, 1 egg, 1/2 teaspoonful of powdered sugar.
10136-8{_}15498{_}_Mode_.--Shell the peas, and cut the onion and lettuce into slices; put these into a stewpan, with the butter, pepper, and salt, but with no more water than that which hangs round the lettuce from washing.
10136-8{_}15499{_}Stew the whole very gently for rather more than 1 hour; then stir to it a well-beaten egg, and about 1/2 teaspoonful of powdered sugar.
10136-8{_}15500{_}When the peas, &c., are nicely thickened, serve but, after the egg is added, do not allow them to boil.
10136-8{_}15501{_}_Time_.--1-1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}15502{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}15503{_}per peck.
10136-8{_}15504{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 or 4 persons.
10136-8{_}15505{_}_Seasonable_ from June to the end of August.
10136-8{_}15506{_}[Illustration: GREEN PEA.]
10136-8{_}15507{_}THE SWEET-PEA AND THE HEATH OR WOOD-PEA.--The well-known     sweet-pea forms a fine covering to a trellis, or lattice-work in     a flower-garden.
10136-8{_}15508{_}Its gay and fragrant flowers, with its rambling     habit, render it peculiarly adapted for such a purpose.
10136-8{_}15509{_}The     wood-pea, or heath-pea, is found in the heaths of Scotland, and     the Highlanders of that country are extremely partial to them,     and dry and chew them to give a greater relish to their whiskey.
10136-8{_}15510{_}They also regard them as good against chest complaints, and say     that by the use of them they are enabled to withstand hunger and     thirst for a long time.
10136-8{_}15511{_}The peas have a sweet taste, somewhat     like the root of liquorice, and, when boiled, have an agreeable     flavour, and are nutritive.
10136-8{_}15512{_}In times of scarcity they have     served as an article of food.
10136-8{_}15513{_}When well boiled, a fork will pass     through them; and, slightly dried, they are roasted, and in     Holland and Flanders served up like chestnuts.
10136-8{_}15514{_}BAKED POTATOES.
10136-8{_}15515{_}1136.
10136-8{_}15516{_}INGREDIENTS.--Potatoes.
10136-8{_}15517{_}[Illustration: BAKED POTATOES SERVED IN NAPKIN.]
10136-8{_}15518{_}_Mode_.--Choose large potatoes, as much of a size as possible; wash them in lukewarm water, and scrub them well, for the browned skin of a baked potato is by many persons considered the better part of it.
10136-8{_}15519{_}Put them into a moderate oven, and bake them for about 2 hours, turning them three or four times whilst they are cooking.
10136-8{_}15520{_}Serve them in a napkin immediately they are done, as, if kept a long time in the oven, they have a shrivelled appearance.
10136-8{_}15521{_}Potatoes may also be roasted before the fire, in an American oven; but when thus cooked, they must be done very slowly.
10136-8{_}15522{_}Do not forget to send to table with them a piece of cold butter.
10136-8{_}15523{_}_Time_.--Large potatoes, in a hot oven 1-1/2 hour to 2 hours; in a cool oven, 2 to 2-1/2 hours.
10136-8{_}15524{_}_Average cost_, 4s.
10136-8{_}15525{_}per bushel.
10136-8{_}15526{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 2 to each person.
10136-8{_}15527{_}_Seasonable_ all the year, but not good just before and whilst new potatoes are in season.
10136-8{_}15528{_}POTATO-SUGAR.--This sugary substance, found in the tubers of     potatoes, is obtained in the form of syrup or treacle, and has     not yet been crystallized.
10136-8{_}15529{_}It resembles the sugar of grapes,     has a very sweet taste, and may be used for making sweetmeats,     and as a substitute for honey.
10136-8{_}15530{_}Sixty pounds of potatoes,     yielding eight pounds of dry starch, will produce seven and a     half pounds of sugar.
10136-8{_}15531{_}In Russia it is extensively made, as     good, though of less consistency than the treacle obtained from     cane-sugar.
10136-8{_}15532{_}A spirit is also distilled from the tubers, which     resembles brandy, but is milder, and has a flavour as if it were     charged with the odour of violets or raspberries.
10136-8{_}15533{_}In France     this manufacture is carried on pretty extensively, and five     hundred pounds of the tubers will produce twelve quarts of     spirit, the pulp being given to cattle.
10136-8{_}15534{_}TO BOIL POTATOES.
10136-8{_}15535{_}1137.
10136-8{_}15536{_}INGREDIENTS.--10 or 12 potatoes; to each 1/2 gallon of water allow 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt.
10136-8{_}15537{_}_Mode_.--Choose potatoes of an equal size, pare them, take out all the eyes and specks, and as they are peeled, throw them into cold water.
10136-8{_}15538{_}Put them into a saucepan, with sufficient cold water to cover them, with salt in the above proportion, and let them boil gently until tender.
10136-8{_}15539{_}Ascertain when they are done by thrusting a fork in them, and take them up the moment they feel soft through; for if they are left in the water afterwards, they become waxy or watery.
10136-8{_}15540{_}Drain away the water, put the saucepan by the side of the fire, with the lid partially uncovered, to allow the steam to escape, and let the potatoes get thoroughly dry, and do not allow them to get burnt.
10136-8{_}15541{_}Their superfluous moisture will evaporate, and the potatoes, if a good sort, should be perfectly mealy and dry.
10136-8{_}15542{_}Potatoes vary so much in quality and size, that it is difficult to give the exact time for boiling; they should be attentively watched, and probed with a fork, to ascertain when they are cooked.
10136-8{_}15543{_}Send them to table quickly, and very hot, and with an opening in the cover of the dish, that a portion of the steam may evaporate, and not fall back on the potatoes.
10136-8{_}15544{_}_Time_.--Moderate-sized old potatoes, 15 to 20 minutes after the water boils; large ones, 1/2 hour to 35 minutes.
10136-8{_}15545{_}_Average cost_, 4s.
10136-8{_}15546{_}per bushel.
10136-8{_}15547{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 persons.
10136-8{_}15548{_}_Seasonable_ all the year, but not good just before and whilst new potatoes are in season.
10136-8{_}15549{_}_Note_.--To keep potatoes hot, after draining the water from them, put a folded cloth or flannel (kept for the purpose) on the top of them, keeping the saucepan-lid partially uncovered.
10136-8{_}15550{_}This will absorb the moisture, and keep them hot some time without spoiling.
10136-8{_}15551{_}THE POTATO.--The potato belongs to the family of the     _Solanaceae_, the greater number of which inhabit the tropics,     and the remainder are distributed over the temperate regions of     both hemispheres, but do not extend to the arctic and antarctic     zones.
10136-8{_}15552{_}The whole of the family are suspicious; a great number     are narcotic, and many are deleterious.
10136-8{_}15553{_}The roots partake of the     properties of the plants, and are sometimes even more active.
10136-8{_}15554{_}The tubercles of such as produce them, are amylaceous and     nutritive, as in those of the potato.
10136-8{_}15555{_}The leaves are generally     narcotic; but they lose this principle in boiling, as is the     case with the _Solanum nigrum_, which are used as a vegetable     when cooked.
10136-8{_}15556{_}TO BOIL POTATOES IN THEIR JACKETS.
10136-8{_}15557{_}1138.
10136-8{_}15558{_}INGREDIENTS.--10 or 12 potatoes; to each 1/2 gallon of water, allow 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt.
10136-8{_}15559{_}_Mode_.--To obtain this wholesome and delicious vegetable cooked in perfection, it should be boiled and sent to table with the skin on.
10136-8{_}15560{_}In Ireland, where, perhaps, the cooking of potatoes is better understood than in any country, they are always served so.
10136-8{_}15561{_}Wash the potatoes well, and if necessary, use a clean scrubbing-brush to remove the dirt from them; and if possible, choose the potatoes so that they may all be as nearly the same size as possible.
10136-8{_}15562{_}When thoroughly cleansed, fill the saucepan half full with them, and just cover the potatoes with cold water, salted in the above proportion: they are more quickly boiled with a small quantity of water, and, besides, are more savoury than when drowned in it.
10136-8{_}15563{_}Bring them to boil, then draw the pan to the side of the fire, and let them simmer gently until tender.
10136-8{_}15564{_}Ascertain when they are done by probing them with a fork; then pour off the water, uncover the saucepan, and let the potatoes dry by the side of the fire, taking care not to let them burn.
10136-8{_}15565{_}Peel them quickly, put them in a very hot vegetable-dish, either with or without a napkin, and serve very quickly.
10136-8{_}15566{_}After potatoes are cooked, they should never be entirely covered up, as the steam, instead of escaping, falls down on them, and makes them watery and insipid.
10136-8{_}15567{_}In Ireland they are usually served up with the skins on, and a small plate is placed by the side of each guest.
10136-8{_}15568{_}_Time_.--Moderate-sized potatoes, with their skins on, 20 to 25 minutes after the water boils; large potatoes, 25 minutes to 3/4 hour, or longer; 5 minutes to dry them.
10136-8{_}15569{_}_Average cost_, 4s.
10136-8{_}15570{_}per bushel.
10136-8{_}15571{_}Sufficient for 6 persons.
10136-8{_}15572{_}_Seasonable_ all the year, but not good just before and whilst new potatoes are in season.
10136-8{_}15573{_}ANALYSIS OF THE POTATO.--Next to the cereals, the potato is the     most valuable plant for the production of human food.
10136-8{_}15574{_}Its     tubers, according to analysis conducted by Mr. Fromberg, in the     laboratory of the Agricultural Chemical Association in Scotland,     contain the following ingredients:--75.52 per cent.
10136-8{_}15575{_}of water,     15.72 starch, O.55 dextrine, 3.3 of impure saccharine matter,     and 3.25 of fibre with coagulated albumen.
10136-8{_}15576{_}In a dried state the     tuber contains 64.2 per cent, of starch, 2.25 of dextrine, 13.47     of impure saccharine matter, 5.77 of caseine, gluten, and     albumen, 1 of fatty matter, and 13.31 of fibre with coagulated     albumen.
10136-8{_}15577{_}TO BOIL NEW POTATOES.
10136-8{_}15578{_}1139.
10136-8{_}15579{_}INGREDIENTS.--Potatoes; to each 1/2 gallon of water allow 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt.
10136-8{_}15580{_}_Mode_.--Do not have the potatoes dug long before they are dressed, as they are never good when they have been out of the ground some time.
10136-8{_}15581{_}Well wash them, rub off the skins with a coarse cloth, and put them into _boiling_ water salted in the above proportion.
10136-8{_}15582{_}Let them boil until tender; try them with a fork, and when done, pour the water away from them; let them stand by the side of the fire with the lid of the saucepan partially uncovered, and when the potatoes are thoroughly dry, put them into a hot vegetable-dish, with a piece of butter the size of a walnut; pile the potatoes over this, and serve.
10136-8{_}15583{_}If the potatoes are too old to have the skins rubbed off, boil them in their jackets; drain, peel, and serve them as above, with a piece of butter placed in the midst of them.
10136-8{_}15584{_}_Time_.--1/4 to 1/2 hour, according to the size.
10136-8{_}15585{_}_Average cost_, in full season, 1d.
10136-8{_}15586{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}15587{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 3 lbs.
10136-8{_}15588{_}for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}15589{_}_Seasonable_ in May and June, but may be had, forced, in March.
10136-8{_}15590{_}POTATO STARCH.--This fecula has a beautiful white crystalline     appearance, and is inodorous, soft to the touch, insoluble in     cold, but readily soluble in boiling water.
10136-8{_}15591{_}It is on this starch     that the nutritive properties of the tubers depend.
10136-8{_}15592{_}As an     aliment, it is well adapted for invalids and persons of delicate     constitution.
10136-8{_}15593{_}It may be used in the form of arrow-root, and     eaten with milk or sugar.
10136-8{_}15594{_}For pastry of all kinds it is more     light and easier of digestion than that made with flour of     wheat.
10136-8{_}15595{_}In confectionery it serves to form creams and jellies,     and in cookery may be used to thicken soups and sauces.
10136-8{_}15596{_}It     accommodates itself to the chest and stomach of children, for     whom it is well adapted; and it is an aliment that cannot be too     generally used, as much on account of its wholesomeness as its     cheapness, and the ease with which it is kept, which are equal,     if not superior, to all the much-vaunted exotic feculae; as,     salep, tapioca, sago, and arrow-root.
10136-8{_}15597{_}TO STEAM POTATOES.
10136-8{_}15598{_}1140.
10136-8{_}15599{_}INGREDIENTS.--Potatoes; boiling water.
10136-8{_}15600{_}_Mode_.--This mode of cooking potatoes is now much in vogue, particularly where they are wanted on a large scale, it being so very convenient.
10136-8{_}15601{_}Pare the potatoes, throw them into cold water as they are peeled, then put them into a steamer.
10136-8{_}15602{_}Place the steamer over a saucepan of boiling water, and steam the potatoes from 20 to 40 minutes, according to the size and sort.
10136-8{_}15603{_}When a fork goes easily through them, they are done; then take them up, dish, and serve very quickly.
10136-8{_}15604{_}_Time_.--20 to 40 minutes.
10136-8{_}15605{_}_Average cost_, 4s.
10136-8{_}15606{_}per bushel.
10136-8{_}15607{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 2 large potatoes to each person.
10136-8{_}15608{_}_Seasonable_ all the year, but not so good whilst new potatoes are in season.
10136-8{_}15609{_}USES OF THE POTATO.--Potatoes boiled and beaten along with sour     milk form a sort of cheese, which is made in Saxony; and, when     kept in close vessels, may be preserved for several years.
10136-8{_}15610{_}It is     generally supposed that the water in which potatoes are boiled     is injurious; and as instances are recorded where cattle having     drunk it were seriously affected, it may be well to err on the     safe side, and avoid its use for any alimentary purpose.
10136-8{_}15611{_}Potatoes which have been exposed to the air and become green,     are very unwholesome.
10136-8{_}15612{_}Cadet de Vaux asserts that potatoes will     clean linen as well as soap; and it is well known that the     berries of the _S.
10136-8{_}15613{_}saponaceum_ are used in Peru for the same     purpose.
10136-8{_}15614{_}HOW TO USE COLD POTATOES.
10136-8{_}15615{_}1141.
10136-8{_}15616{_}INGREDIENTS.--The remains of cold potatoes; to every lb.
10136-8{_}15617{_}allow 2 tablespoonfuls of flour, 2 ditto of minced onions, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}15618{_}of butter, milk.
10136-8{_}15619{_}_Mode_.--Mash the potatoes with a fork until perfectly free from lumps; stir in the other ingredients, and add sufficient milk to moisten them well; press the potatoes into a mould, and bake in a moderate oven until nicely brown, which will be in from 20 minutes to 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}15620{_}Turn them out of the mould, and serve.
10136-8{_}15621{_}_Time_.--20 minutes to 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}15622{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}15623{_}POTATO BREAD.--The manner in which this is made is very simple.
10136-8{_}15624{_}The adhesive tendency of the flour of the potato acts against     its being baked or kneaded without being mixed with wheaten     flour or meal; it may, however, be made into cakes in the     following manner:--A small wooden frame, nearly square, is laid     on a pan like a frying-pan and is grooved, and so constructed     that, by means of a presser or lid introduced into the groove,     the cake is at once fashioned, according to the dimensions of     the mould.
10136-8{_}15625{_}The frame containing the farina may be almost     immediately withdrawn after the mould is formed upon the pan;     because, from the consistency imparted to the incipient cake by     the heat, it will speedily admit of being safely handled: it     must not, however, be fried too hastily.
10136-8{_}15626{_}It will then eat very     palatably, and might from time to time be soaked for puddings,     like tapioca, or might be used like the cassada-cake, for, when     well buttered and toasted, it will be found an excellent     accompaniment to breakfast.
10136-8{_}15627{_}In Scotland, cold boiled potatoes     are frequently squeezed up and mixed with flour or oatmeal, and     an excellent cake, or _scon_, obtained.
10136-8{_}15628{_}FRIED POTATOES (French Fashion).
10136-8{_}15629{_}1142.
10136-8{_}15630{_}INGREDIENTS.--Potatoes, hot butter or clarified dripping, salt.
10136-8{_}15631{_}_Mode_.--Peel and cut the potatoes into thin slices, as nearly the same size as possible; make some butter or dripping quite hot in a frying-pan; put in the potatoes, and fry them on both sides of a nice brown.
10136-8{_}15632{_}When they are crisp and done, take them up, place them on a cloth before the fire to drain the grease from them, and serve very hot, after sprinkling them with salt.
10136-8{_}15633{_}These are delicious with rump-steak, and, in France, are frequently served thus as a breakfast dish.
10136-8{_}15634{_}The remains of cold potatoes may also be sliced and fried by the above recipe, but the slices must be cut a little thicker.
10136-8{_}15635{_}_Time_.--Sliced raw potatoes, 5 minutes; cooked potatoes, 5 minutes.
10136-8{_}15636{_}_Average cost_, 4s.
10136-8{_}15637{_}per bushel.
10136-8{_}15638{_}_Sufficient_,--6 sliced potatoes for 3 persons.
10136-8{_}15639{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}15640{_}A GERMAN METHOD OF COOKING POTATOES.
10136-8{_}15641{_}1143.
10136-8{_}15642{_}INGREDIENTS.--8 to 10 middling-sized potatoes, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}15643{_}of butter, 2 tablespoonfuls of flour, 1/2 pint of broth, 2 tablespoonfuls of vinegar.
10136-8{_}15644{_}_Mode_.--Put the butter and flour into a stewpan; stir over the fire until the butter is of a nice brown colour, and add the broth and vinegar; peel and cut the potatoes into long thin slices, lay them in the gravy, and let them simmer gently until tender, which will be in from 10 to 15 minutes, and serve very hot.
10136-8{_}15645{_}A laurel-leaf simmered with the potatoes is an improvement.
10136-8{_}15646{_}_Time_.--10 to 15 minutes.
10136-8{_}15647{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}15648{_}PRESERVING POTATOES.--In general, potatoes are stored or     preserved in pits, cellars, pies, or camps; but, whatever mode     is adopted, it is essential that the tubers be perfectly dry;     otherwise, they will surely rot; and a few rotten potatoes will     contaminate a whole mass.
10136-8{_}15649{_}The pie, as it is called, consists of     a trench, lined and covered with straw; the potatoes in it being     piled in the shape of a house roof, to the height of about three     feet.
10136-8{_}15650{_}The camps are shallow pits, filled and ridged up in a     similar manner, covered up with the excavated mould of the pit.
10136-8{_}15651{_}In Russia and Canada, the potato is preserved in boxes, in     houses or cellars, heated, when necessary, to a temperature one     or two degrees above the freezing-point, by stoves.
10136-8{_}15652{_}To keep     potatoes for a considerable time, the best way is to place them     in thin layers on a platform suspended in an ice-cellar: there,     the temperature being always below that of active vegetation,     they will not sprout; while, not being above one or two degrees     below the freezing-point, the tubers will not be frostbitten.
10136-8{_}15653{_}Another mode is to scoop out the eyes with a very small scoop,     and keep the roots buried in earth; a third mode is to destroy     the vital principle, by kiln-drying, steaming, or scalding; a     fourth is to bury them so deep in dry soil, that no change of     temperature will reach them; and thus, being without air, they     will remain upwards of a year without vegetating.
10136-8{_}15654{_}POTATOES A LA MAITRE D'HOTEL.
10136-8{_}15655{_}1144.
10136-8{_}15656{_}INGREDIENTS.--Potatoes, salt and water; to every 6 potatoes allow 1 tablespoonful of minced parsley, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}15657{_}of butter, pepper and salt to taste, 4 tablespoonfuls of gravy, 2 tablespoonfuls of lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}15658{_}_Mode_.--Wash the potatoes clean, and boil them in salt and water by recipe No.
10136-8{_}15659{_}1138; when they are done, drain them, let them cool; then peel and cut the potatoes into thick slices: if these are too thin, they would break in the sauce.
10136-8{_}15660{_}Put the butter into a stewpan with the pepper, salt, gravy, and parsley; mix these ingredients well together, put in the potatoes, shake them two or three times, that they may be well covered with the sauce, and, when quite hot through, squeeze in the lemon-juice, and serve.
10136-8{_}15661{_}_Time_.--1/2 to 3/4 hour to boil the potatoes; 10 minutes for them to heat in the sauce.
10136-8{_}15662{_}_Average cost_, 4s.
10136-8{_}15663{_}per bushel.
10136-8{_}15664{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 persons.
10136-8{_}15665{_}_Seasonable_ all the year.
10136-8{_}15666{_}MASHED POTATOES.
10136-8{_}15667{_}1145.
10136-8{_}15668{_}INGREDIENTS.--Potatoes; to every lb.
10136-8{_}15669{_}of mashed potatoes allow 1 oz.
10136-8{_}15670{_}of butter, 2 tablespoonfuls of milk, salt to taste.
10136-8{_}15671{_}_Mode_.--Boil the potatoes in their skins; when done, drain them, and let them get thoroughly dry by the side of the fire; then peel them, and, as they are peeled, put them into a clean saucepan, and with a large fork beat them to a light paste; add butter, milk, and salt in the above proportion, and stir all the ingredients well over the fire.
10136-8{_}15672{_}When thoroughly hot, dish them lightly, and draw the fork backwards over the potatoes to make the surface rough, and serve.
10136-8{_}15673{_}When dressed in this manner, they may be browned at the top with a salamander, or before the fire.
10136-8{_}15674{_}Some cooks press the potatoes into moulds, then turn them out, and brown them in the oven: this is a pretty mode of serving, but it makes them heavy.
10136-8{_}15675{_}In whatever way they are sent to table, care must be taken to have them quite free from lumps.
10136-8{_}15676{_}_Time_.--From 1/2 to 3/4 hour to boil the potatoes.
10136-8{_}15677{_}_Average cost_, 4s.
10136-8{_}15678{_}per bushel.
10136-8{_}15679{_}_Sufficient_,--1 lb.
10136-8{_}15680{_}of mashed potatoes for 3 persons.
10136-8{_}15681{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}15682{_}PUREE DE POMMES DE TERRE, or, Very Thin-mashed Potatoes.
10136-8{_}15683{_}1146.
10136-8{_}15684{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}15685{_}of mashed potatoes allow 1/4 pint of good broth or stock, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}15686{_}of butter.
10136-8{_}15687{_}_Mode_.--Boil the potatoes, well drain them, and pound them smoothly in a mortar, or beat them up with a fork; add the stock or broth, and rub the potatoes through a sieve.
10136-8{_}15688{_}Put the puree into a very clean saucepan with the butter; stir it well over the fire until thoroughly hot, and it will then be ready to serve.
10136-8{_}15689{_}A puree should be rather thinner than mashed potatoes, and is a delicious accompaniment to delicately broiled mutton cutlets.
10136-8{_}15690{_}Cream or milk may be substituted for the broth when the latter is not at hand.
10136-8{_}15691{_}A casserole of potatoes, which is often used for ragoûts instead of rice, is made by mashing potatoes rather thickly, placing them on a dish, and making an opening in the centre.
10136-8{_}15692{_}After having browned the potatoes in the oven, the dish should be wiped clean, and the ragout or fricassée poured in.
10136-8{_}15693{_}_Time_.--About 1/2 hour to boil the potatoes; 6 or 7 minutes to warm the purée.
10136-8{_}15694{_}_Average cost_, 4s.
10136-8{_}15695{_}per bushel.
10136-8{_}15696{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 1 lb.
10136-8{_}15697{_}of cooked potatoes for 3 persons.
10136-8{_}15698{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}15699{_}[Illustration: SWEET POTATO.]
10136-8{_}15700{_}VARIETIES OF THE POTATO.--These are very numerous.
10136-8{_}15701{_}"They     differ," says an authority, "in their leaves and bulk of haulm;     in the colour of the skin of the tubers; in the colour of the     interior, compared with that of the skin; in the time of     ripening; in being farinaceous, glutinous, or watery; in tasting     agreeably or disagreeably; in cooking readily or tediously; in     the length of the subterraneous _stolones_ to which the tubers     are attached; in blossoming or not blossoming; and finally, in     the soil which they prefer."
10136-8{_}15702{_}The earliest varieties grown in     fields are,--the Early Kidney, the Nonsuch, the Early Shaw, and     the Early Champion.
10136-8{_}15703{_}This last is the most generally cultivated     round London: it is both mealy and hardy.
10136-8{_}15704{_}The sweet potato is     but rarely eaten in Britain; but in America it is often served     at table, and is there very highly esteemed.
10136-8{_}15705{_}POTATO RISSOLES.
10136-8{_}15706{_}1147.
10136-8{_}15707{_}INGREDIENTS.--Mashed potatoes, salt and pepper to taste; when liked, a very little minced parsley, egg, and bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}15708{_}[Illustration: POTATO RISSOLES.]
10136-8{_}15709{_}_Mode_.--Boil and mash the potatoes by recipe No.
10136-8{_}15710{_}1145; add a seasoning of pepper and salt, and, when liked, a little minced parsley.
10136-8{_}15711{_}Roll the potatoes into small balls, cover them with egg and bread crumbs, and fry in hot lard for about 10 minutes; let them drain before the fire, dish them on a napkin, and serve.
10136-8{_}15712{_}_Time_,--10 minutes to fry the rissoles.
10136-8{_}15713{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}15714{_}_Note_.--The flavour of these rissoles may be very much increased by adding finely-minced tongue or ham, or even chopped onions, when these are liked.
10136-8{_}15715{_}QUALITIES OF POTATOES.--In making a choice from the many     varieties of potatoes which are everywhere found, the best way     is to get a sample and taste them, and then fix upon the kind     which best pleases your palate.
10136-8{_}15716{_}The Shaw is one of the most     esteemed of the early potatoes for field culture; and the Kidney     and Bread-fruit are also good sorts.
10136-8{_}15717{_}The Lancashire Pink is also     a good potato, and is much cultivated in the neighbourhood of     Liverpool.
10136-8{_}15718{_}As late or long-keeping potatoes, the Tartan or     Red-apple stands very high in favour.
10136-8{_}15719{_}POTATO SNOW.
10136-8{_}15720{_}1148.
10136-8{_}15721{_}INGREDIENTS.--Potatoes, salt, and water.
10136-8{_}15722{_}_Mode_.--Choose large white potatoes, as free from spots as possible; boil them in their skins in salt and water until perfectly tender; drain and _dry them thoroughly_ by the side of the fire, and peel them.
10136-8{_}15723{_}Put a hot dish before the fire, rub the potatoes through a coarse sieve on to this dish; do not touch them afterwards, or the flakes will fall, and serve as hot as possible.
10136-8{_}15724{_}_Time_.--1/2 to 3/4 hour to boil the potatoes.
10136-8{_}15725{_}_Average cost_, 4s.
10136-8{_}15726{_}per bushel.
10136-8{_}15727{_}_Sufficient_,--6 potatoes for 3 persons.
10136-8{_}15728{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}15729{_}THE POTATO AS AN ARTICLE OF HUMAN FOOD.--This valuable esculent,     next to wheat, is of the greatest importance in the eye of the     political economist.
10136-8{_}15730{_}From no other crop that can be cultivated     does the public derive so much benefit; and it has been     demonstrated that an acre of potatoes will feed double the     number of people that can be fed from an acre of wheat.
10136-8{_}15731{_}TO DRESS SALSIFY.
10136-8{_}15732{_}1149.
10136-8{_}15733{_}INGREDIENTS.--Salsify; to each 1/2 gallon of water allow 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}15734{_}of butter, 2 tablespoonfuls of lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}15735{_}_Mode_.--Scrape the roots gently, so as to strip them only of their outside peel; cut them into pieces about 4 inches long, and, as they are peeled, throw them into water with which has been mixed a little lemon-juice, to prevent their discolouring.
10136-8{_}15736{_}Put them into boiling water, with salt, butter, and lemon-juice in the above proportion, and let them boil rapidly until tender; try them with a fork; and, when it penetrates easily, they are done.
10136-8{_}15737{_}Drain the salsify, and serve with a good white sauce or French melted butter.
10136-8{_}15738{_}_Time_.--30 to 50 minutes.
10136-8{_}15739{_}_Seasonable_ in winter.
10136-8{_}15740{_}_Note_.--This vegetable may be also boiled, sliced, and fried in batter of a nice brown.
10136-8{_}15741{_}When crisp and a good colour, they should be served with fried parsley in the centre of the dish, and a little fine salt sprinkled over the salsify.
10136-8{_}15742{_}SALSIFY.--This esculent is, for the sake of its roots,     cultivated in gardens.
10136-8{_}15743{_}It belongs to the Composite class of     flowers, which is the most extensive family in the vegetable     kingdom.
10136-8{_}15744{_}This family is not only one of the most natural and     most uniform in structure, but there is also a great similarity     existing in the properties of the plants of which it is     composed.
10136-8{_}15745{_}Generally speaking, all composite flowers are tonic or     stimulant in their medical virtues.
10136-8{_}15746{_}BOILED SEA-KALE.
10136-8{_}15747{_}1150.
10136-8{_}15748{_}INGREDIENTS.--To each 1/2 gallon of water allow 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt.
10136-8{_}15749{_}[Illustration: BOILED SEA-KALE.]
10136-8{_}15750{_}_Mode_.--Well wash the kale, cut away any wormeaten pieces, and tie it into small bunches; put it into _boiling_ water, salted in the above proportion, and let it boil quickly until tender.
10136-8{_}15751{_}Take it out, drain, untie the bunches, and serve with plain melted butter or white sauce, a little of which may be poured over the kale.
10136-8{_}15752{_}Sea-kale may also be parboiled and stewed in good brown gravy: it will then take about 1/2 hour altogether.
10136-8{_}15753{_}_Time_.--15 minutes; when liked very thoroughly done, allow an extra 5 minutes.
10136-8{_}15754{_}_Average cost_, in full season, 9d.
10136-8{_}15755{_}per basket.
10136-8{_}15756{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 12 heads for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}15757{_}_Seasonable_ from February to June.
10136-8{_}15758{_}[Illustration: SEA-KALE.]
10136-8{_}15759{_}SEA-KALE.--This plant belongs to the Asparagus tribe, and grows     on seashores, especially in the West of England, and in the     neighbourhood of Dublin.
10136-8{_}15760{_}Although it is now in very general use,     it did not come into repute till 1794.
10136-8{_}15761{_}It is easily cultivated,     and is esteemed as one of the most valuable esculents indigenous     to Britain.
10136-8{_}15762{_}As a vegetable, it is stimulating to the appetite,     easily digestible, and nutritious.
10136-8{_}15763{_}It is so light that the most     delicate organizations may readily eat it.
10136-8{_}15764{_}The flowers form a     favourite resort for bees, as their petals contain a great     amount of saccharine matter.
10136-8{_}15765{_}BOILED SALAD.
10136-8{_}15766{_}1151.
10136-8{_}15767{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 heads of celery, 1 pint of French beans, lettuce, and endive.
10136-8{_}15768{_}[Illustration: FRENCH BEANS.]
10136-8{_}15769{_}[Illustration: CHERVIL.]
10136-8{_}15770{_}_Mode_.--Boil the celery and beans separately until tender, and cut the celery into pieces about 2 inches long.
10136-8{_}15771{_}Put these into a salad-bowl or dish; pour over either of the sauces No.
10136-8{_}15772{_}506, 507, or 508, and garnish the dish with a little lettuce finely chopped, blanched endive, or a few tufts of boiled cauliflower.
10136-8{_}15773{_}This composition, if less agreeable than vegetables in their raw state, is more wholesome; for salads, however they may be compounded, when eaten uncooked, prove to some people indigestible.
10136-8{_}15774{_}Tarragon, chervil, burnet, and boiled onion, may be added to the above salad with advantage, as also slices of cold meat, poultry, or fish.
10136-8{_}15775{_}_Seasonable_ from July to October.
10136-8{_}15776{_}ACETARIOUS VEGETABLES.--By the term Acetarious vegetables, is     expressed a numerous class of plants, of various culture and     habit, which are principally used as salads, pickles, and     condiments.
10136-8{_}15777{_}They are to be considered rather as articles of     comparative luxury than as ordinary food, and are more desirable     for their coolness, or their agreeable flavour, than for their     nutritive powers.
10136-8{_}15778{_}CAULIFLOWER.--The cauliflower is less indigestible than the     cabbage; it possesses a most agreeable flavour, and is     sufficiently delicate to be served at the tables of the wealthy.
10136-8{_}15779{_}It is a wholesome vegetable, but should be eaten moderately, as     it induces flatulence.
10136-8{_}15780{_}Persons of weak constitutions and     delicate stomachs should abstain from cauliflower as much as     possible.
10136-8{_}15781{_}They may be prepared in a variety of ways; and, in     selecting them, the whitest should be chosen; those tinged with     green or yellow being of indifferent quality.
10136-8{_}15782{_}SUMMER SALAD.
10136-8{_}15783{_}1152.
10136-8{_}15784{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 lettuces, 2 handfuls of mustard-and-cress, 10 young radishes, a few slices of cucumber.
10136-8{_}15785{_}[Illustration: SALAD IN BOWL.]
10136-8{_}15786{_}_Mode_.--Let the herbs be as fresh as possible for a salad, and, if at all stale or dead-looking, let them lie in water for an hour or two, which will very much refresh them.
10136-8{_}15787{_}Wash and carefully pick them over, remove any decayed or wormeaten leaves, and drain them thoroughly by swinging them gently in a clean cloth.
10136-8{_}15788{_}With a silver knife, cut the lettuces into small pieces, and the radishes and cucumbers into thin slices; arrange all these ingredients lightly on a dish, with the mustard-and-cress, and pour under, but not over the salad, either of the sauces No.
10136-8{_}15789{_}506, 507, or 508, and do not stir it up until it is to be eaten.
10136-8{_}15790{_}It may be garnished with hard-boiled eggs, cut in slices, sliced cucumbers, nasturtiums, cut vegetable-flowers, and many other things that taste will always suggest to make a pretty and elegant dish.
10136-8{_}15791{_}In making a good salad, care must be taken to have the herbs freshly gathered, and _thoroughly drained_ before the sauce is added to them, or it will be watery and thin.
10136-8{_}15792{_}Young spring onions, cut small, are by many persons considered an improvement to salads; but, before these are added, the cook should always consult the taste of her employer.
10136-8{_}15793{_}Slices of cold meat or poultry added to a salad make a convenient and quickly-made summer luncheon-dish; or cold fish, flaked, will also be found exceedingly nice, mixed with it.
10136-8{_}15794{_}_Average cost_, 9d.
10136-8{_}15795{_}for a salad for 5 or 6 persons; but more expensive when the herbs are forced.
10136-8{_}15796{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}15797{_}_Seasonable_ from May to September.
10136-8{_}15798{_}CUCUMBERS.--The cucumber is refreshing, but neither nutritious     nor digestible, and should be excluded from the regimen of the     delicate.
10136-8{_}15799{_}There are various modes of preparing cucumbers.
10136-8{_}15800{_}When     gathered young, they are called gherkins: these, pickled, are     much used in seasonings.
10136-8{_}15801{_}[Illustration: CUCUMBER-SLICE.]
10136-8{_}15802{_}RADISHES.--This is the common name given to the root of the     _Raphanus satious_, one of the varieties of the cultivated     horseradish.
10136-8{_}15803{_}There are red and white radishes; and the French     have also what they call violet and black ones, of which the     black are the larger.
10136-8{_}15804{_}Radishes are composed of nearly the same     constituents as turnips, that is to say, mostly fibre and     nitrogen; and, being generally eaten raw, it is on the last of     these that their flavour depends.
10136-8{_}15805{_}They do not agree with people,     except those who are in good health, and have active digestive     powers; for they are difficult of digestion, and cause     flatulency and wind, and are the cause of headaches when eaten     to excess.
10136-8{_}15806{_}Besides being eaten raw, they are sometimes, but     rarely, boiled; and they also serve as a pretty garnish for     salads.
10136-8{_}15807{_}In China, the radish may be found growing naturally,     without cultivation; and may be occasionally met with in England     as a weed, in similar places to where the wild turnip grows; it,     however, thrives best in the garden, and the ground it likes     best is a deep open loam, or a well-manured sandy soil.
10136-8{_}15808{_}[Illustration: TURNIP RADISHES.]
10136-8{_}15809{_}[Illustration: LONG RADISHES.]
10136-8{_}15810{_}WINTER SALAD.
10136-8{_}15811{_}1153.
10136-8{_}15812{_}INGREDIENTS.--Endive, mustard-and-cress, boiled beetroot, 3 or 4 hard-boiled eggs, celery.
10136-8{_}15813{_}_Mode_.--The above ingredients form the principal constituents of a winter salad, and may be converted into a very pretty dish, by nicely contrasting the various colours, and by tastefully garnishing it.
10136-8{_}15814{_}Shred the celery into thin pieces, after having carefully washed and cut away all wormeaten pieces; cleanse the endive and mustard-and-cress free from grit, and arrange these high in the centre of a salad-bowl or dish; garnish with the hard-boiled eggs and beetroot, both of which should be cut in slices; and pour into the dish, but not over the salad, either of the sauces No.
10136-8{_}15815{_}506, 507, or 508.
10136-8{_}15816{_}Never dress a salad long before it is required for table, as, by standing, it loses its freshness and pretty crisp and light appearance; the sauce, however, may always be prepared a few hours beforehand, and when required for use, the herbs laid lightly over it.
10136-8{_}15817{_}_Average cost_, 9d.
10136-8{_}15818{_}for a salad for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}15819{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}15820{_}_Seasonable_ from the end of September to March.
10136-8{_}15821{_}SALADS.--Salads are raw vegetables, of which, among us, the     lettuce is the most generally used; several others, however,     such as cresses, celery, onions, beetroot, &c., are occasionally     employed.
10136-8{_}15822{_}As vegetables eaten in a raw state are apt to ferment     on the stomach, and as they have very little stimulative power     upon that organ, they are usually dressed with some condiments,     such as pepper, vinegar, salt, mustard, and oil.
10136-8{_}15823{_}Respecting the     use of these, medical men disagree, especially in reference to     oil, which is condemned by some and recommended by others.
10136-8{_}15824{_}POTATO SALAD.
10136-8{_}15825{_}1154.
10136-8{_}15826{_}INGREDIENTS.--10 or 12 cold boiled potatoes, 4 tablespoonfuls of tarragon or plain vinegar, 6 tablespoonfuls of salad-oil, pepper and salt to taste, 1 teaspoonful of minced parsley.
10136-8{_}15827{_}_Mode_.--Cut the potatoes into slices about 1/2 inch in thickness; put these into a salad-bowl with oil and vinegar in the above proportion; season with pepper, salt, and a teaspoonful of minced parsley; stir the salad well, that all the ingredients may be thoroughly incorporated, and it is ready to serve.
10136-8{_}15828{_}This should be made two or three hours before it is wanted for table.
10136-8{_}15829{_}Anchovies, olives, or pickles may be added to this salad, as also slices of cold beef, fowl, or turkey.
10136-8{_}15830{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}15831{_}CHICKEN SALAD.--(See No.
10136-8{_}15832{_}931.)
10136-8{_}15833{_}GROUSE SALAD.--(See No.
10136-8{_}15834{_}1020.)
10136-8{_}15835{_}LOBSTER SALAD.--(See No.
10136-8{_}15836{_}272.)
10136-8{_}15837{_}TO BOIL SPINACH (English Mode).
10136-8{_}15838{_}1155.
10136-8{_}15839{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 pailfuls of spinach, 2 heaped tablespoonfuls of salt, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}15840{_}of butter, pepper to taste.
10136-8{_}15841{_}[Illustration: SPINACH GARNISHED WITH CROÛTONS.]
10136-8{_}15842{_}_Mode_.--Pick the spinach carefully, and see that no stalks or weeds are left amongst it; wash it in several waters, and, to prevent it being gritty, act in the following manner:--Have ready two large pans or tubs filled with water; put the spinach into one of these, and thoroughly wash it; then, _with the hands_, take out the spinach, and put it into the _other tub_ of water (by this means all the grit will be left at the bottom of the tub); wash it again, and, should it not be perfectly free from dirt, repeat the process.
10136-8{_}15843{_}Put it into a very large saucepan, with about 1/2 pint of water, just sufficient to keep the spinach from burning, and the above proportion of salt.
10136-8{_}15844{_}Press it down frequently with a wooden spoon, that it may be done equally; and when it has boiled for rather more than 10 minutes, or until it is perfectly tender, drain it in a colander, squeeze it quite dry, and chop it finely.
10136-8{_}15845{_}Put the spinach into a clean stewpan, with the butter and a seasoning of pepper; stir the whole over the fire until quite hot; then put it on a hot dish, and garnish with sippets of toasted bread.
10136-8{_}15846{_}_Time_.--10 to 15 minutes to boil the spinach, 5 minutes to warm with the butter.
10136-8{_}15847{_}_Average cost_ for the above quantity, 8d.
10136-8{_}15848{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}15849{_}_Seasonable_.--Spring spinach from March to July; winter spinach from November to March.
10136-8{_}15850{_}_Note_.--Grated nutmeg, pounded mace, or lemon-juice may also be added to enrich the flavour; and poached eggs are also frequently served with spinach: they should be placed on the top of it, and it should be garnished with sippets of toasted bread.--See coloured plate U.
10136-8{_}15851{_}VARIETIES OF SPINACH.--These comprise the Strawberry spinach,     which, under that name, was wont to be grown in our     flower-gardens; the Good King Harry, the Garden Oracle, the     Prickly, and the Round, are the varieties commonly used.
10136-8{_}15852{_}The     Oracle is a hardy sort, much esteemed in France, and is a native     of Tartary, introduced in 1548.
10136-8{_}15853{_}The common spinach has its     leaves round, and is softer and more succulent than any of the     Brassica tribe.
10136-8{_}15854{_}SPINACH DRESSED WITH CREAM, a la Francaise.
10136-8{_}15855{_}1156.
10136-8{_}15856{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 pailfuls of spinach, 2 tablespoonfuls of salt, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}15857{_}of butter, 8 tablespoonfuls of cream, 1 small teaspoonful of pounded sugar, a very little grated nutmeg.
10136-8{_}15858{_}_Mode_.--Boil and drain the spinach as in recipe No.
10136-8{_}15859{_}1155; chop it finely, and put it into a stewpan with the butter; stir over a gentle fire, and, when the butter has dried away, add the remaining ingredients, and simmer for about 5 minutes.
10136-8{_}15860{_}Previously to adding the cream, boil it first, in case it should curdle.
10136-8{_}15861{_}Serve on a hot dish, and garnish either with sippets of toasted bread or leaves of puff-paste.
10136-8{_}15862{_}_Time_.--10 to 15 minutes to boil the spinach; 10 minutes to stew with the cream.
10136-8{_}15863{_}_Average cost_ for the above quantity, 8d.
10136-8{_}15864{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}15865{_}_Seasonable_.--Spring spinach from March to July; winter spinach from November to March.
10136-8{_}15866{_}[Illustration: SPINACH.]
10136-8{_}15867{_}SPINACH.--This is a Persian plant.
10136-8{_}15868{_}It has been cultivated in our     gardens about two hundred years, and is the most wholesome of     vegetables.
10136-8{_}15869{_}It is not very nutritious, but is very easily     digested.
10136-8{_}15870{_}It is very light and laxative.
10136-8{_}15871{_}Wonderful properties     have been ascribed to spinach.
10136-8{_}15872{_}It is an excellent vegetable, and     very beneficial to health.
10136-8{_}15873{_}Plainly dressed, it is a resource for     the poor; prepared luxuriantly, it is a choice dish for the     rich.
10136-8{_}15874{_}SPINACH.--This vegetable belongs to a sub-order of the     _Salsolaceae_, or saltworts, and is classified under the head of     _Spirolobeae_, with leaves shaped like worms, and of a succulent     kind.
10136-8{_}15875{_}In its geographical distribution it is commonly found in     extratropical and temperate regions, where they grow as weeds in     waste places, and among rubbish, and in marshes by the seashore.
10136-8{_}15876{_}In the tropics the order is rarely found.
10136-8{_}15877{_}Many of them are used     as potherbs, and some of them are emetic and vermifuge in their     medicinal properties.
10136-8{_}15878{_}FRENCH MODE OF DRESSING SPINACH.
10136-8{_}15879{_}1157.
10136-8{_}15880{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 pailfuls of spinach, 2 tablespoonfuls of salt, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}15881{_}of butter, 1 teaspoonful of flour, 8 tablespoonfuls of good gravy; when liked, a very little grated nutmeg.
10136-8{_}15882{_}_Mode_.--Pick, wash, and boil the spinach, as in recipe No.
10136-8{_}15883{_}1155, and when quite tender, drain and squeeze it perfectly dry from the water that hangs about it.
10136-8{_}15884{_}Chop it very fine, put the butter into a stewpan, and lay the spinach over that; stir it over a gentle fire, and dredge in the flour.
10136-8{_}15885{_}Add the gravy, and let it boil _quickly_ for a few minutes, that it may not discolour.
10136-8{_}15886{_}When the flavour of nutmeg is liked, grate some to the spinach, and when thoroughly hot, and the gravy has dried away a little, serve.
10136-8{_}15887{_}Garnish the dish with sippets of toasted bread.
10136-8{_}15888{_}_Time_.--10 to 15 minutes to boil the spinach; 10 minutes to simmer in the gravy.
10136-8{_}15889{_}_Average cost_ for the above quantity, 8d.
10136-8{_}15890{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}15891{_}_Seasonable_.--Spring spinach from March to July; winter spinach from October to February.
10136-8{_}15892{_}_Note_.--For an entremets or second-course dish, spinach, dressed by the above recipe may be pressed into a hot mould; it should then be turned out quickly, and served very hot.
10136-8{_}15893{_}BAKED TOMATOES.
10136-8{_}15894{_}(_Excellent_.)
10136-8{_}15895{_}1158.
10136-8{_}15896{_}INGREDIENTS.--8 or 10 tomatoes, pepper and salt to taste, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}15897{_}of butter, bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}15898{_}_Mode_.--Take off the stalks from the tomatoes; cut them into thick slices, and put them into a deep baking-dish; add a plentiful seasoning of pepper and salt, and butter in the above proportion; cover the whole with bread crumbs; drop over these a little clarified butter; bake in a moderate oven from 20 minutes to 1/2 hour, and serve very hot.
10136-8{_}15899{_}This vegetable, dressed as above, is an exceedingly nice accompaniment to all kinds of roast meat.
10136-8{_}15900{_}The tomatoes, instead of being cut in slices, may be baked whole; but they will take rather longer time to cook.
10136-8{_}15901{_}_Time_.--20 minutes to 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}15902{_}_Average cost_, in full season, 9d.
10136-8{_}15903{_}per basket.
10136-8{_}15904{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}15905{_}_Seasonable_ in August, September, and October; but may be had, forced, much earlier.
10136-8{_}15906{_}[Illustration: THE TOMATO.]
10136-8{_}15907{_}TOMATOES.--The Tomato is a native of tropical countries, but is     now cultivated considerably both in France and England.
10136-8{_}15908{_}Its skin     is of a brilliant red, and its flavour, which is somewhat sour,     has become of immense importance in the culinary art.
10136-8{_}15909{_}It is used     both fresh and preserved.
10136-8{_}15910{_}When eaten fresh, it is served as an     _entremets_; but its principal use is in sauce and gravy; its     flavour stimulates the appetite, and is almost universally     approved.
10136-8{_}15911{_}The Tomato is a wholesome fruit, and digests easily.
10136-8{_}15912{_}From July to September, they gather the tomatoes green in     France, not breaking them away from the stalk; they are then     hung, head downwards, in a dry and not too cold place; and there     they ripen.
10136-8{_}15913{_}HOT TOMATO SAUCE, or PUREE OF TOMATOES.
10136-8{_}15914{_}(See No.
10136-8{_}15915{_}529.)
10136-8{_}15916{_}[Illustration: STEWED TOMATOES.]
10136-8{_}15917{_}STEWED TOMATOES.
10136-8{_}15918{_}I.
10136-8{_}15919{_}1159.
10136-8{_}15920{_}INGREDIENTS.--8 tomatoes, pepper and salt to taste, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}15921{_}of butter, 2 tablespoonfuls of vinegar.
10136-8{_}15922{_}_Mode_.--Slice the tomatoes into a _lined_ saucepan; season them with pepper and salt, and place small pieces of butter on them.
10136-8{_}15923{_}Cover the lid down closely, and stew from 20 to 25 minutes, or until the tomatoes are perfectly tender; add the vinegar, stir two or three times, and serve with any kind of roast meat, with which they will be found a delicious accompaniment.
10136-8{_}15924{_}_Time_.--20 to 25 minutes.
10136-8{_}15925{_}_Average cost_, in full season, 9d.
10136-8{_}15926{_}per basket.
10136-8{_}15927{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}15928{_}_Seasonable_ from August to October; but may be had, forced, much earlier.
10136-8{_}15929{_}ANALYSIS OF THE TOMATO.--The fruit of the love-apple is the only     part used as an esculent, and it has been found to contain a     particular acid, a volatile oil, a brown, very fragrant     extracto-resinous matter, a vegeto-mineral matter,     muco-saccharine, some salts, and, in all probability, an     alkaloid.
10136-8{_}15930{_}The whole plant has a disagreeable odour, and its     juice, subjected to the action of the fire, emits a vapour so     powerful as to cause vertigo and vomiting.
10136-8{_}15931{_}II.
10136-8{_}15932{_}1160.
10136-8{_}15933{_}INGREDIENTS.--8 tomatoes, about 1/2 pint of good gravy, thickening of butter and flour, cayenne and salt to taste.
10136-8{_}15934{_}_Mode_.--Take out the stalks of the tomatoes; put them into a wide stewpan, pour over them the above proportion of good brown gravy, and stew gently until they are tender, occasionally _carefully_ turning them, that they may be equally done.
10136-8{_}15935{_}Thicken the gravy with a little butter and flour worked together on a plate; let it just boil up after the thickening is added, and serve.
10136-8{_}15936{_}If it be at hand, these should be served on a silver or plated vegetable-dish.
10136-8{_}15937{_}_Time_.--20 to 25 minutes, very gentle stewing.
10136-8{_}15938{_}_Average cost_, in full season, 9d.
10136-8{_}15939{_}per basket.
10136-8{_}15940{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}15941{_}_Seasonable_ in August, September, and October; but maybe had, forced, much earlier.
10136-8{_}15942{_}THE TOMATO, OR LOVE-APPLE.--This vegetable is a native of Mexico     and South America, but is also found in the East Indies, where     it is supposed to have been introduced by the Spaniards.
10136-8{_}15943{_}In this     country it is much more cultivated than it formerly was; and the     more the community becomes acquainted with the many agreeable     forms in which the fruit can be prepared, the more widely will     its cultivation be extended.
10136-8{_}15944{_}For ketchup, soups, and sauces, it     is equally applicable, and the unripe fruit makes one of the     best pickles.
10136-8{_}15945{_}TRUFFLES AU NATUREL.
10136-8{_}15946{_}1161.
10136-8{_}15947{_}INGREDIENTS.--Truffles, buttered paper.
10136-8{_}15948{_}_Mode_.--Select some fine truffles; cleanse them, by washing them in several waters with a brush, until not a particle of sand or grit remains on them; wrap each truffle in buttered paper, and bake in a hot oven for quite an hour; take off the paper, wipe the truffles, and serve them in a hot napkin.
10136-8{_}15949{_}_Time_.--1 hour.
10136-8{_}15950{_}_Average cost_.--Not often bought in this country.
10136-8{_}15951{_}_Seasonable_ from November to March.
10136-8{_}15952{_}[Illustration: TRUFFLES.]
10136-8{_}15953{_}THE COMMON TRUFFLE.--This is the _Tuber cibarium_ of science,     and belongs to that numerous class of esculent fungi     distinguished from other vegetables not only by the singularity     of their forms, but by their chemical composition.
10136-8{_}15954{_}Upon     analysis, they are found not only to contain the usual     components of the vegetable kingdom, such as carbon, oxygen, and     hydrogen, but likewise a large proportion of nitrogen; from     which they approach more nearly to the nature of animal flesh.
10136-8{_}15955{_}It was long ago observed by Dr. Darwin, that all the mushrooms     cooked at our tables, as well as those used for ketchup,     possessed an animal flavour; and soup enriched by mushrooms only     has sometimes been supposed to contain meat.
10136-8{_}15956{_}TO DRESS TRUFFLES WITH CHAMPAGNE.
10136-8{_}15957{_}1162.
10136-8{_}15958{_}INGREDIENTS.--12 fine black truffles, a few slices of fat bacon, 1 carrot, 1 turnip, 2 onions, a bunch of savoury herbs, including parsley, 1 bay-leaf, 2 cloves, 1 blade of pounded mace, 2 glasses of champagne, 1/2 pint of stock.
10136-8{_}15959{_}_Mode_.--Carefully select the truffles, reject those that have a musty smell, and wash them well with a brush, in cold water only, until perfectly clean.
10136-8{_}15960{_}Put the bacon into a stewpan, with the truffles and the remaining ingredients; simmer these gently for an hour, and let the whole cool in the stewpan.
10136-8{_}15961{_}When to be served, rewarm them, and drain them on a clean cloth; then arrange them on a delicately white napkin, that it may contrast as strongly as possible with the truffles, and serve.
10136-8{_}15962{_}The trimmings of truffles are used to flavour gravies, stock, sauces, &c.; and are an excellent addition to ragouts, made dishes of fowl, &c.
10136-8{_}15963{_}_Time_.--1 hour.
10136-8{_}15964{_}_Average cost_.--Not often bought in this country.
10136-8{_}15965{_}_Seasonable_ from November to March.
10136-8{_}15966{_}THE TRUFFLE.--The Truffle belongs to the family of the Mushroom.
10136-8{_}15967{_}It is certain that the truffle must possess, equally with other     plants, organs of reproduction; yet, notwithstanding all the     efforts of art and science, it has been impossible to subject it     to a regular culture.
10136-8{_}15968{_}Truffles grow at a considerable depth     under the earth, never appearing on the surface.
10136-8{_}15969{_}They are found     in many parts of France: those of Périgord Magny are the most     esteemed for their odour.
10136-8{_}15970{_}There are three varieties of the     species,--the black, the red, and the white: the latter are of     little value.
10136-8{_}15971{_}The red are very rare, and their use is     restricted.
10136-8{_}15972{_}The black has the highest repute, and its     consumption is enormous.
10136-8{_}15973{_}When the peasantry go to gather     truffles, they take a pig with them to scent out the spot where     they grow.
10136-8{_}15974{_}When that is found, the pig turns up the surface with     his snout, and the men then dig until they find the truffles.
10136-8{_}15975{_}Good truffles are easily distinguished by their agreeable     perfume; they should be light in proportion to their size, and     elastic when pressed by the finger.
10136-8{_}15976{_}To have them in perfection,     they should be quite fresh, as their aroma is considerably     diminished by any conserving process.
10136-8{_}15977{_}Truffles are stimulating     and beating.
10136-8{_}15978{_}Weak stomachs digest them with difficulty.
10136-8{_}15979{_}Some of     the culinary uses to which they are subjected render them more     digestible; but they should always be eaten sparingly.
10136-8{_}15980{_}Their     chief use is in seasoning and garnitures.
10136-8{_}15981{_}In short, a professor     has said, "Meats with truffles are the most distinguished dishes     that opulence can offer to the epicure."
10136-8{_}15982{_}The Truffle grows in     clusters, some inches below the surface of the soil, and is of     an irregular globular form.
10136-8{_}15983{_}Those which grow wild in England are     about the size of a hen's egg, and have no roots.
10136-8{_}15984{_}As there is     nothing to indicate the places where they are, dogs have been     trained to discriminate their scent, by which they are     discovered.
10136-8{_}15985{_}Hogs are very fond of them, and frequently lead to     their being found, from their rutting up the ground in search of     them.
10136-8{_}15986{_}ITALIAN MODE OF DRESSING TRUFFLES.
10136-8{_}15987{_}1163.
10136-8{_}15988{_}INGREDIENTS.--10 truffles, 1/4 pint of salad-oil, pepper and salt to taste, 1 tablespoonful of minced parsley, a very little finely-minced garlic, 2 blades of pounded mace, 1 tablespoonful of lemon-juice.
