10136-8{_}15989{_}_Mode_.--After cleansing and brushing the truffles, cut them into thin slices, and put them in a baking-dish, on a seasoning of oil, pepper, salt, parsley, garlic, and mace in the above proportion.
10136-8{_}15990{_}Bake them for nearly an hour, and, just before serving, add the lemon-juice, and send them to table very hot.
10136-8{_}15991{_}_Time_.--Nearly 1 hour.
10136-8{_}15992{_}_Average cost_.--Not often bought in this country.
10136-8{_}15993{_}_Seasonable_ from November to March.
10136-8{_}15994{_}WHERE TRUFFLES ARE FOUND.--In this country, the common truffle     is found on the downs of Hampshire, Wiltshire, and Kent; and     they abound in dry light soils, and more especially in oak and     chestnut forests.
10136-8{_}15995{_}In France they are plentiful, and many are     imported from the south of that country and Italy, where they     are much larger and in greater perfection: they lose, however,     much of their flavour by drying.
10136-8{_}15996{_}Truffles have in England been     tried to be propagated artificially, but without success.
10136-8{_}15997{_}TRUFFLES A L'ITALIENNE.
10136-8{_}15998{_}1164.
10136-8{_}15999{_}INGREDIENTS.--10 truffles, 1 tablespoonful of minced parsley, 1 minced shalot, salt and pepper to taste, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}16000{_}of butter, 2 tablespoonfuls of good brown gravy, the juice of 1/2 lemon, cayenne to taste.
10136-8{_}16001{_}_Mode_.--Wash the truffles and cut them into slices about the size of a penny-piece; put them into a sauté pan, with the parsley, shalot, salt, pepper, and 1 oz.
10136-8{_}16002{_}of butter; stir them over the fire, that they may all be equally done, which will be in about 10 minutes, and drain off some of the butter; then add a little more fresh butter, 2 tablespoonfuls of good gravy, the juice of 1/2 lemon, and a little cayenne; stir over the fire until the whole is on the point of boiling, when serve.
10136-8{_}16003{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}16004{_}_Average cost_.--Not often bought in this country.
10136-8{_}16005{_}_Seasonable_ from November to March.
10136-8{_}16006{_}USES OF THE TRUFFLE.--Like the Morel, truffles are seldom eaten     alone, but are much used in gravies, soups, and ragoûts.
10136-8{_}16007{_}They     are likewise dried for the winter months, and, when reduced to     powder, form a useful culinary ingredient; they, however, have     many virtues attributed to them which they do not possess.
10136-8{_}16008{_}Their     wholesomeness is, perhaps, questionable, and they should be     eaten with moderation.
10136-8{_}16009{_}BOILED TURNIPS.
10136-8{_}16010{_}1165.
10136-8{_}16011{_}INGREDIENTS.--Turnips; to each 1/2 gallon of water allow 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt.
10136-8{_}16012{_}_Mode_.--Pare the turnips, and, should they be very large, divide them into quarters; but, unless this is the case, let them be cooked whole.
10136-8{_}16013{_}Put them into a saucepan of boiling water, salted in the above proportion, and let them boil gently until tender.
10136-8{_}16014{_}Try them with a fork, and, when done, take them up in a colander; let them thoroughly drain, and serve.
10136-8{_}16015{_}Boiled turnips are usually sent to table with boiled mutton, but are infinitely nicer when mashed than served whole: unless nice and young, they are scarcely worth the trouble of dressing plainly as above.
10136-8{_}16016{_}_Time_.--Old turnips, 3/4 to 1-1/4 hour; young ones, about 18 to 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}16017{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}16018{_}per bunch.
10136-8{_}16019{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow a bunch of 12 turnips for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}16020{_}_Seasonable_.--May be had all the year; but in spring only useful for flavouring gravies, &c.  [Illustration: TURNIPS.]
10136-8{_}16021{_}THE TURNIP.--This vegetable is the _Brassica Rapa_ of science,     and grows wild in England, but cannot be brought exactly to     resemble what it becomes in a cultivated state.
10136-8{_}16022{_}It is said to     have been originally introduced from Hanover, and forms an     excellent culinary vegetable, much used all over Europe, where     it is either eaten alone or mashed and cooked in soups and     stews.
10136-8{_}16023{_}They do not thrive in a hot climate; for in India they,     and many more of our garden vegetables, lose their flavour and     become comparatively tasteless.
10136-8{_}16024{_}The Swede is the largest     variety, but it is too coarse for the table.
10136-8{_}16025{_}MASHED TURNIPS.
10136-8{_}16026{_}1166.
10136-8{_}16027{_}INGREDIENTS.--10 or 12 large turnips; to each 1/2 gallon of water allow 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}16028{_}of butter, cayenne or white pepper to taste.
10136-8{_}16029{_}_Mode_.--Pare the turnips, quarter them, and put them into boiling water, salted in the above proportion; boil them until tender; then drain them in a colander, and squeeze them as dry as possible by pressing them with the back of a large plate.
10136-8{_}16030{_}When quite free from water, rub the turnips with a wooden spoon through the colander, and put them into a very clean saucepan; add the butter, white pepper, or cayenne, and, if necessary, a little salt.
10136-8{_}16031{_}Keep stirring them over the fire until the butter is well mixed with them, and the turnips are thoroughly hot; dish, and serve.
10136-8{_}16032{_}A little cream or milk added after the turnips are pressed through the colander, is an improvement to both the colour and flavour of this vegetable.
10136-8{_}16033{_}_Time_.--From 1/2 to 3/4 hour to boil the turnips; 10 minutes to warm them through.
10136-8{_}16034{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}16035{_}per bunch.
10136-8{_}16036{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}16037{_}_Seasonable_.--May be had all the year; but in spring only good for flavouring gravies.
10136-8{_}16038{_}VEGETABLES REDUCED TO PURÉE.--Persons in the flower of youth,     having healthy stomachs, and leading active lives, may eat all     sorts of vegetables, without inconvenience, save, of course, in     excess.
10136-8{_}16039{_}The digestive functions possess great energy during the     period of youth: the body, to develop itself, needs nourishment.
10136-8{_}16040{_}Physical exercise gives an appetite, which it is necessary to     satisfy, and vegetables cannot resist the vigorous action of the     gastric organs.
10136-8{_}16041{_}As old proverb says, "At twenty one can digest     iron."
10136-8{_}16042{_}But for aged persons, the sedentary, or the delicate, it     is quite otherwise.
10136-8{_}16043{_}Then the gastric power has considerably     diminished, the digestive organs have lost their energy, the     process of digestion is consequently slower, and the least     excess at table is followed by derangement of the stomach for     several days.
10136-8{_}16044{_}Those who generally digest vegetables with     difficulty, should eat them reduced to a pulp or purée, that is     to say, with their skins and tough fibres removed.
10136-8{_}16045{_}Subjected to     this process, vegetables which, when entire, would create     flatulence and wind, are then comparatively harmless.
10136-8{_}16046{_}Experience     has established the rule, that nourishment is not complete     without the alliance of meat with vegetables.
10136-8{_}16047{_}We would also add,     that the regime most favourable to health is found in variety:     variety pleases the senses, monotony is disagreeable.
10136-8{_}16048{_}The eye is     fatigued by looking always on one object, the ear by listening     to one sound, and the palate by tasting one flavour.
10136-8{_}16049{_}It is the     same with the stomach: consequently, variety of food is one of     the essentials for securing good digestion.
10136-8{_}16050{_}GERMAN MODE OF COOKING TURNIPS.
10136-8{_}16051{_}1167.
10136-8{_}16052{_}INGREDIENTS.--8 large turnips, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}16053{_}of butter, pepper and salt to taste, rather more than 1/2 pint of weak stock or broth, 1 tablespoonful of flour.
10136-8{_}16054{_}_Mode_.--Make the butter hot in a stewpan, lay in the turnips, after having pared and cut them into dice, and season them with pepper and salt.
10136-8{_}16055{_}Toss them over the fire for a few minutes, then add the broth, and simmer the whole gently till the turnips are tender.
10136-8{_}16056{_}Brown the above proportion of flour with a little butter; add this to the turnips, let them simmer another 5 minutes, and serve.
10136-8{_}16057{_}Boiled mutton is usually sent to table with this vegetable, and may be cooked with the turnips by placing it in the midst of them: the meat would then be very delicious, as, there being so little liquid with the turnips, it would almost be steamed, and consequently very tender.
10136-8{_}16058{_}_Time_.--20 minutes.
10136-8{_}16059{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}16060{_}per bunch.
10136-8{_}16061{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}16062{_}_Seasonable_.--May be had all the year.
10136-8{_}16063{_}TURNIPS.--Good turnips are delicate in texture, firm, and sweet.
10136-8{_}16064{_}The best sorts contain a sweet juicy mucilage, uniting with the     aroma a slightly acid quality, which is completely neutralized     in cooking.
10136-8{_}16065{_}The turnip is prepared in a variety of ways.
10136-8{_}16066{_}Ducks     stuffed with turnips have been highly appreciated.
10136-8{_}16067{_}It is useful     in the regimen of persons afflicted with chronic visceral     irritations.
10136-8{_}16068{_}The turnip only creates flatulency when it is soft,     porous, and stringy.
10136-8{_}16069{_}It is then, consequently, bad.
10136-8{_}16070{_}TURNIPS IN WHITE SAUCE.
10136-8{_}16071{_}(An Entremets, or to be served with the Second Course as a Side-dish.)
10136-8{_}16072{_}1168.
10136-8{_}16073{_}INGREDIENTS.--7 or 8 turnips, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}16074{_}of butter, 1/2 pint of white sauce, No.
10136-8{_}16075{_}538 or 539.
10136-8{_}16076{_}_Mode_.--Peel and cut the turnips in the shape of pears or marbles; boil them in salt and water, to which has been added a little butter, until tender; then take them out, drain, arrange them on a dish, and pour over the white sauce made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}16077{_}538 or 539, and to which has been added a small lump of sugar.
10136-8{_}16078{_}In winter, when other vegetables are scarce, this will be found a very good and pretty-looking dish: when approved, a little mustard may be added to the sauce.
10136-8{_}16079{_}_Time_.--About 3/4 hour to boil the turnips.
10136-8{_}16080{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}16081{_}per bunch.
10136-8{_}16082{_}_Sufficient_ for 1 side-dish.
10136-8{_}16083{_}_Seasonable_ in winter.
10136-8{_}16084{_}THE FRENCH NAVET.--This is a variety of the turnip; but, instead     of being globular, has more the shape of the carrot.
10136-8{_}16085{_}Its flavour     being excellent, it is much esteemed on the Continent for soups     and made dishes.
10136-8{_}16086{_}Two or three of them will impart as much     flavour as a dozen of the common turnips will.
10136-8{_}16087{_}Accordingly, when     stewed in gravy, they are greatly relished.
10136-8{_}16088{_}This flavour resides     in the rind, which is not cut off, but scraped.
10136-8{_}16089{_}This variety was     once grown in England, but now it is rarely found in our     gardens, though highly deserving of a place there.
10136-8{_}16090{_}It is of a     yellowish-white colour, and is sometimes imported to the London     market.
10136-8{_}16091{_}BOILED TURNIP GREENS.
10136-8{_}16092{_}1169.
10136-8{_}16093{_}INGREDIENTS.--To each 1/2 gallon of water, allow 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt; turnip-greens.
10136-8{_}16094{_}_Mode_.--Wash the greens well in two or three waters, and pick off all the decayed and dead leaves; tie them in small bunches, and put them into plenty of boiling water, salted in the above proportion.
10136-8{_}16095{_}Keep them boiling quickly, with the lid of the saucepan uncovered, and when tender, pour them into a colander; let them drain, arrange them in a vegetable-dish, remove the string that the greens were tied with, and serve.
10136-8{_}16096{_}_Time_.--15 to 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}16097{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}16098{_}for a dish for 3 persons.
10136-8{_}16099{_}_Seasonable_ in March, April, and May.
10136-8{_}16100{_}CABBAGE, TURNIP-TOPS, AND GREENS.--All the cabbage tribe, which     comprises coleworts, brocoli, cauliflower, sprouts, and     turnip-tops, in order to be delicate, should be dressed young,     when they have a rapid growth; but, if they have stood the     summer, in order to be tender, they should be allowed to have a     touch of frost.
10136-8{_}16101{_}The cabbage contains much vegetable albumen, and     several parts sulphur and nitrate of potass.
10136-8{_}16102{_}Cabbage is heavy,     and a long time digesting, which has led to a belief that it is     very nourishing.
10136-8{_}16103{_}It is only fit food for robust and active     persons; the sedentary or delicate should carefully avoid it.
10136-8{_}16104{_}Cabbage may be prepared in a variety of ways: it serves as a     garniture to several recherché dishes,--partridge and cabbage     for example.
10136-8{_}16105{_}Bacon and cabbage is a very favourite dish; but     only a good stomach can digest it.
10136-8{_}16106{_}BOILED VEGETABLE MARROW.
10136-8{_}16107{_}1170.
10136-8{_}16108{_}INGREDIENTS.--To each 1/2 gallon of water, allow 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt; vegetable marrows.
10136-8{_}16109{_}[Illustration: VEGETABLE MARROW ON TOAST.]
10136-8{_}16110{_}_Mode_.--Have ready a saucepan of boiling water, salted in the above proportion; put in the marrows after peeling them, and boil them until quite tender.
10136-8{_}16111{_}Take them up with a slice, halve, and, should they be very large, quarter them.
10136-8{_}16112{_}Dish them on toast, and send to table with them a tureen of melted butter, or, in lieu of this, a small pat of salt butter.
10136-8{_}16113{_}Large vegetable marrows may be preserved throughout the winter by storing them in a dry place; when wanted for use, a few slices should be cut and boiled in the same manner as above; but, when once begun, the marrow must be eaten quickly, as it keeps but a short time after it is cut.
10136-8{_}16114{_}Vegetable marrows are also very delicious mashed: they should be boiled, then drained, and mashed smoothly with a wooden spoon.
10136-8{_}16115{_}Heat them in a saucepan, add a seasoning of salt and pepper, and a small piece of butter, and dish with a few sippets of toasted bread placed round as a garnish.
10136-8{_}16116{_}_Time_.--Young vegetable marrows 10 to 20 minutes; old ones, 1/2 to 3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}16117{_}_Average cost_, in full season, 1s.
10136-8{_}16118{_}per dozen.
10136-8{_}16119{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 1 moderate-sized marrow for each person.
10136-8{_}16120{_}_Seasonable_ in July, August, and September; but may be preserved all the winter.
10136-8{_}16121{_}FRIED VEGETABLE MARROW.
10136-8{_}16122{_}1171.
10136-8{_}16123{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 medium-sized vegetable marrows, egg and bread crumbs, hot lard.
10136-8{_}16124{_}_Mode_.--Peel, and boil the marrows until tender in salt and water; then drain them and cut them in quarters, and take out the seeds.
10136-8{_}16125{_}When thoroughly drained, brush the marrows over with egg, and sprinkle with bread crumbs; have ready some hot lard, fry the marrow in this, and, when of a nice brown, dish; sprinkle over a little salt and pepper, and serve.
10136-8{_}16126{_}_Time_.--About 1/2 hour to boil the marrow, 7 minutes to fry it.
10136-8{_}16127{_}_Average cost_, in full season, 1s.
10136-8{_}16128{_}per dozen.
10136-8{_}16129{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}16130{_}_Seasonable_ in July, August, and September.
10136-8{_}16131{_}[Illustration: VEGETABLE MARROW.]
10136-8{_}16132{_}THE VEGETABLE MARROW.--This vegetable is now extensively used,     and belongs to the Cucurbits.
10136-8{_}16133{_}It is the _C.
10136-8{_}16134{_}ovifera_ of science,     and, like the melon, gourd, cucumber, and squash, is widely     diffused in the tropical or warmer regions of the globe.
10136-8{_}16135{_}Of the     nature of this family we have already spoken when treating of     the cucumber.
10136-8{_}16136{_}CUT VEGETABLES FOR SOUPS, &c.  [Illustration: VEGETABLE-CUTTER.]
10136-8{_}16137{_}1172.
10136-8{_}16138{_}The annexed engraving represents a cutter for shaping vegetables for soups, ragouts, stews, &c.; carrots and turnips being the usual vegetables for which this utensil is used.
10136-8{_}16139{_}Cut the vegetables into slices about 1/4 inch in thickness, stamp them out with the cutter, and boil them for a few minutes in salt and water, until tender.
10136-8{_}16140{_}Turnips should be cut in rather thicker slices than carrots, on account of the former boiling more quickly to a pulp than the latter.
10136-8{_}16141{_}CARROTS.--Several species of carrots are cultivated,--the red,     the yellow, and the which.
10136-8{_}16142{_}Those known as the Crecy carrots are     considered the best, and are very sweet.
10136-8{_}16143{_}The carrot has been     classed by hygienists among flatulent vegetables, and as     difficult of digestion.
10136-8{_}16144{_}When the root becomes old, it is almost     as hard as wood; but the young carrot, which has not reached its     full growth, is tender, relishing, nutritious, and digests well     when properly cooked.
10136-8{_}16145{_}VEGETABLE MARROWS IN WHITE SAUCE.
10136-8{_}16146{_}1173.
10136-8{_}16147{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 or 5 moderate-sized marrows, 1/2 pint of white sauce, No.
10136-8{_}16148{_}539.
10136-8{_}16149{_}[Illustration: VEGETABLE MARROW IN WHITE SAUCE.]
10136-8{_}16150{_}_Mode_.--Pare the marrows; cut them in halves, and shape each half at the top in a point, leaving the bottom end flat for it to stand upright in the dish.
10136-8{_}16151{_}Boil the marrows in salt and water until tender; take them up very carefully, and arrange them on a hot dish.
10136-8{_}16152{_}Have ready 1/2 pint of white sauce, made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}16153{_}539; pour this over the marrows, and serve.
10136-8{_}16154{_}_Time_.--From 15 to 20 minutes to boil the marrows.
10136-8{_}16155{_}_Average cost_, in full season, 1s.
10136-8{_}16156{_}per dozen.
10136-8{_}16157{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}16158{_}_Seasonable_ in July, August, and September.
10136-8{_}16159{_}BOILED INDIAN WHEAT or MAIZE.
10136-8{_}16160{_}1174.
10136-8{_}16161{_}INGREDIENTS.--The ears of young and green Indian wheat; to every 1/2 gallon of water allow 1 heaped tablespoonful of salt.
10136-8{_}16162{_}_Mode_.--This vegetable, which makes one of the most delicious dishes brought to table, is unfortunately very rarely seen in Britain; and we wonder that, in the gardens of the wealthy, it is not invariably cultivated.
10136-8{_}16163{_}Our sun, it is true, possesses hardly power sufficient to ripen maize; but, with well-prepared ground, and in a favourable position, it might be sufficiently advanced by the beginning of autumn to serve as a vegetable.
10136-8{_}16164{_}The outside sheath being taken off and the waving fibres removed, let the ears be placed in boiling water, where they should remain for about 25 minutes (a longer time may be necessary for larger ears than ordinary); and, when sufficiently boiled and well drained, they may be sent to table whole, and with a piece of toast underneath them.
10136-8{_}16165{_}Melted butter should be served with them.
10136-8{_}16166{_}_Time_.--25 to 35 minutes.
10136-8{_}16167{_}_Average cost_.--Seldom bought.
10136-8{_}16168{_}_Sufficient_,--1 ear for each person.
10136-8{_}16169{_}_Seasonable_ in autumn.
10136-8{_}16170{_}_Note_.--William Cobbett, the English radical writer and politician, was a great cultivator and admirer of maize, and constantly ate it as a vegetable, boiled.
10136-8{_}16171{_}We believe he printed a special recipe for it, but we have been unable to lay our hands on it.
10136-8{_}16172{_}Mr. Buchanan, the present president of the United States, was in the habit, when ambassador here, of receiving a supply of Indian corn from America in hermetically-sealed cases; and the publisher of this work remembers, with considerable satisfaction, his introduction to a dish of this vegetable, when in America.
10136-8{_}16173{_}He found it to combine the excellences of the young green pea and the finest asparagus; but he felt at first slightly awkward in holding the large ear with one hand, whilst the other had to be employed in cutting off with a knife the delicate green grains.
10136-8{_}16174{_}[Illustration]     [Illustration]  CHAPTER XXVI.
10136-8{_}16175{_}GENERAL OBSERVATIONS ON PUDDINGS AND PASTRY.
10136-8{_}16176{_}1175.
10136-8{_}16177{_}PUDDINGS AND PASTRY, familiar as they may be, and unimportant as they may be held in the estimation of some, are yet intimately connected with the development of agricultural resources in reference to the cereal grasses.
10136-8{_}16178{_}When they began to be made is uncertain; but we may safely presume, that a simple form of pudding was amongst the first dishes made after discovering a mode of grinding wheat into flour.
10136-8{_}16179{_}Traditional history enables us to trace man back to the time of the Deluge.
10136-8{_}16180{_}After that event he seems to have recovered himself in the central parts of Asia, and to have first risen to eminence in the arts of civilization on the banks of the Nile.
10136-8{_}16181{_}From this region, Greece, Carthage, and some other parts along the shores of the Mediterranean Sea, were colonized.
10136-8{_}16182{_}In process of time, Greece gave to the Romans the arts which she had thus received from Egypt, and these subsequently diffused them over Europe.
10136-8{_}16183{_}How these were carried to or developed in India and China, is not so well ascertained; and in America their ancient existence rests only on very indistinct traditions.
10136-8{_}16184{_}As to who was the real discoverer of the use of corn, we have no authentic knowledge.
10136-8{_}16185{_}The traditions of different countries ascribe it to various fabulous personages, whose names it is here unnecessary to introduce.
10136-8{_}16186{_}In Egypt, however, corn must have grown abundantly; for Abraham, and after him Jacob, had recourse to that country for supplies during times of famine.
10136-8{_}16187{_}1176.
10136-8{_}16188{_}THE HABITS OF A PEOPLE, to a great extent, are formed by the climate in which they live, and by the native or cultivated productions in which their country abounds.
10136-8{_}16189{_}Thus we find that the agricultural produce of the ancient Egyptians is pretty much the same as that of the present day, and the habits of the people are not materially altered.
10136-8{_}16190{_}In Greece, the products cultivated in antiquity were the same kinds of grains and legumes as are cultivated at present, with the vine, the fig, the olive, the apple, and other fruits.
10136-8{_}16191{_}So with the Romans, and so with other nations.
10136-8{_}16192{_}As to the different modes of artificially preparing those to please the taste, it is only necessary to say that they arise from the universal desire of novelty, characteristic of man in the development of his social conditions.
10136-8{_}16193{_}Thus has arisen the whole science of cookery, and thus arose the art of making puddings.
10136-8{_}16194{_}The porridge of the Scotch is nothing more than a species of hasty pudding, composed of oatmeal, salt, and water; and the "red pottage" for which Esau sold his birthright, must have been something similar.
10136-8{_}16195{_}The barley-gruel of the Lacedaemonians, of the Athenian gladiators and common people, was the same, with the exception of the slight seasoning it had beyond the simplicity of Scottish fare.
10136-8{_}16196{_}Here is the ancient recipe for the Athenian national dish:--"Dry near the fire, in the oven, twenty pounds of barley-flour; then parch it; add three pounds of linseed-meal, half a pound of coriander-seed, two ounces of salt, and the quantity of water necessary."
10136-8{_}16197{_}To this sometimes a little millet was added, in order to give the paste greater cohesion and delicacy.
10136-8{_}16198{_}1177.
10136-8{_}16199{_}OATMEAL AMONGST THE GREEKS AND ROMANS was highly esteemed, as was also rice, which they considered as beneficial to the chest.
10136-8{_}16200{_}They also held in high repute the Irion, or Indian wheat of the moderns.
10136-8{_}16201{_}The flour of this cereal was made into a kind of hasty pudding, and, parched or roasted, as eaten with a little salt.
10136-8{_}16202{_}The Spelt, or Red wheat, was likewise esteemed, and its flour formed the basis of the Carthaginian pudding, for which we here give the scientific recipe:--"Put a pound of red-wheat flour into water, and when it has steeped some time, transfer it to a wooden bowl.
10136-8{_}16203{_}Add three pounds of cream cheese, half a pound of honey, and one egg.
10136-8{_}16204{_}Beat the whole together, and cook it on a slow fire in a stewpan."
10136-8{_}16205{_}Should this be considered unpalatable, another form has been recommended.
10136-8{_}16206{_}"Sift the flour, and, with some water, put it into a wooden vessel, and, for ten days, renew the water twice each day.
10136-8{_}16207{_}At the end of that period, press out the water and place the paste in another vessel.
10136-8{_}16208{_}It is now to be reduced to the consistence of thick lees, and passed through a piece of new linen.
10136-8{_}16209{_}Repeat this last operation, then dry the mass in the sun and boil it in milk.
10136-8{_}16210{_}Season according to taste."
10136-8{_}16211{_}These are specimens of the puddings of antiquity, and this last recipe was held in especial favour by the Romans.
10136-8{_}16212{_}1178.
10136-8{_}16213{_}HOWEVER GREAT MAY HAVE BEEN THE QUALIFICATIONS of the ancients, however, in the art of pudding-making, we apprehend that such preparations as gave gratification to their palates, would have generally found little favour amongst the insulated inhabitants of Great Britain.
10136-8{_}16214{_}Here, from the simple suet dumpling up to the most complicated Christmas production, the grand feature of substantiality is primarily attended to.
10136-8{_}16215{_}Variety in the ingredients, we think, is held only of secondary consideration with the great body of the people, provided that the whole is agreeable and of sufficient abundance.
10136-8{_}16216{_}1179.
10136-8{_}16217{_}ALTHOUGH FROM PUDDINGS TO PASTRY is but a step, it requires a higher degree of art to make the one than to make the other.
10136-8{_}16218{_}Indeed, pastry is one of the most important branches of the culinary science.
10136-8{_}16219{_}It unceasingly occupies itself with ministering pleasure to the sight as well as to the taste; with erecting graceful monuments, miniature fortresses, and all kinds of architectural imitations, composed of the sweetest and most agreeable products of all climates and countries.
10136-8{_}16220{_}At a very early period, the Orientals were acquainted with the art of manipulating in pastry; but they by no means attained to the taste, variety, and splendour of design, by which it is characterized amongst the moderns.
10136-8{_}16221{_}At first it generally consisted of certain mixtures of flour, oil, and honey, to which it was confined for centuries, even among the southern nations of the European continent.
10136-8{_}16222{_}At the commencement of the middle ages, a change began to take place in the art of mixing it.
10136-8{_}16223{_}Eggs, butter, and salt came into repute in the making of paste, which was forthwith used as an inclosure for meat, seasoned with spices.
10136-8{_}16224{_}This advance attained, the next step was to inclose cream, fruit, and marmalades; and the next, to build pyramids and castles; when the summit of the art of the pastry-cook may be supposed to have been achieved.
10136-8{_}16225{_}DIRECTIONS IN CONNECTION WITH THE MAKING OF PUDDINGS AND PASTRY.
10136-8{_}16226{_}1180.
10136-8{_}16227{_}A few general remarks respecting the various ingredients of which puddings and pastry are composed, may be acceptable as preliminary to the recipes in this department of Household Management.
10136-8{_}16228{_}1181.
10136-8{_}16229{_}_Flour_ should be of the best quality, and perfectly dry, and sifted before being used; if in the least damp, the paste made from it will certainly be heavy.
10136-8{_}16230{_}1182.
10136-8{_}16231{_}_Butter_, unless fresh is used, should be washed from the salt, and well squeezed and wrung in a cloth, to get out all the water and buttermilk, which, if left in, assists to make the paste heavy.
10136-8{_}16232{_}1183.
10136-8{_}16233{_}_Lard_ should be perfectly sweet, which may be ascertained by cutting the bladder through, and, if the knife smells sweet, the lard is good.
10136-8{_}16234{_}1184.
10136-8{_}16235{_}_Suet_ should be finely chopped, perfectly free from skin, and quite sweet; during the process of chopping, it should be lightly dredged with flour, which prevents the pieces from sticking together.
10136-8{_}16236{_}Beef suet is considered the best; but veal suet, or the outside fat of a loin or neck of mutton, makes good crusts; as also the skimmings in which a joint of mutton has been boiled, but _without_ vegetables.
10136-8{_}16237{_}1185.
10136-8{_}16238{_}_Clarified Beef Dripping_, directions for which will be found in recipes Nos.
10136-8{_}16239{_}621 and 622, answers very well for kitchen pies, puddings, cakes, or for family use.
10136-8{_}16240{_}A very good short crust may be made by mixing with it a small quantity of moist sugar; but care must be taken to use the dripping sparingly, or a very disagreeable flavour will be imparted to the paste.
10136-8{_}16241{_}1186.
10136-8{_}16242{_}Strict cleanliness must be observed in pastry-making; all the utensils used should be perfectly free from dust and dirt, and the things required for pastry, kept entirely for that purpose.
10136-8{_}16243{_}[Illustration: PASTE-BOARD AND ROLLING-PIN.]
10136-8{_}16244{_}1187.
10136-8{_}16245{_}In mixing paste, add the water very gradually, work the whole together with the knife-blade, and knead it until perfectly smooth.
10136-8{_}16246{_}Those who are inexperienced in pastry-making, should work the butter in by breaking it in small pieces and covering the paste rolled out.
10136-8{_}16247{_}It should then be dredged with flour, and the ends folded over and rolled out very thin again: this process must be repeated until all the butter is used.
10136-8{_}16248{_}[Illustration: PASTE-PINCERS AND JAGGER, FOR ORNAMENTING THE EDGES OF PIE-CRUSTS.]
10136-8{_}16249{_}1188.
10136-8{_}16250{_}The art of making paste requires much practice, dexterity, and skill: it should be touched as lightly as possible, made with cool hands and in a cool place (a marble slab is better than a board for the purpose), and the coolest part of the house should be selected for the process during warm weather.
10136-8{_}16251{_}1189.
10136-8{_}16252{_}To insure rich paste being light, great expedition must be used in the making and baking; for if it stand long before it is put in the oven, it becomes flat and heavy.
10136-8{_}16253{_}[Illustration: PASTE-CUTTER AND CORNER-CUTTER.]
10136-8{_}16254{_}[Illustration: ORNAMENTAL-PASTE CUTTER.]
10136-8{_}16255{_}1190.
10136-8{_}16256{_}_Puff-paste_ requires a brisk oven, but not too hot, or it would blacken the crust; on the other hand, if the oven be too slack, the paste will be soddened, and will not rise, nor will it have any colour.
10136-8{_}16257{_}Tart-tins, cake-moulds, dishes for baked puddings, pattypans, &c., should all be buttered before the article intended to be baked is put in them: things to be baked on sheets should be placed on buttered paper.
10136-8{_}16258{_}Raised-pie paste should have a soaking heat, and paste glazed must have rather a slack oven, that the icing be not scorched.
10136-8{_}16259{_}It is better to ice tarts, &c. when they are three-parts baked.
10136-8{_}16260{_}[Illustration: PATTY-PANS, PLAIN AND FLUTED.]
10136-8{_}16261{_}[Illustration: PIE-DISH.]
10136-8{_}16262{_}[Illustration: RAISED-PIE MOULD.]
10136-8{_}16263{_}[Illustration: RAISED-PIE MOULD, OPEN.]
10136-8{_}16264{_}1191.
10136-8{_}16265{_}To ascertain when the oven is heated to the proper degree for puff-paste, put a small piece of the paste in previous to baking the whole, and then the heat can thus be judged of.
10136-8{_}16266{_}1192.
10136-8{_}16267{_}The freshness of all pudding ingredients is of much importance, as one bad article will taint the whole mixture.
10136-8{_}16268{_}1193.
10136-8{_}16269{_}When the _freshness_ of eggs is _doubtful_, break each one separately in a cup, before mixing them altogether.
10136-8{_}16270{_}Should there be a bad one amongst them, it can be thrown away; whereas, if mixed with the good ones, the entire quantity would be spoiled.
10136-8{_}16271{_}The yolks and whites beaten separately make the articles they are put into much lighter.
10136-8{_}16272{_}1194.
10136-8{_}16273{_}Raisins and dried fruits for puddings should be carefully picked, and, in many cases, stoned.
10136-8{_}16274{_}Currants should be well washed, pressed in a cloth, and placed on a dish before the fire to get thoroughly dry; they should then be picked carefully over, and _every piece of grit or stone_ removed from amongst them.
10136-8{_}16275{_}To plump them, some cooks pour boiling water over them, and then dry them before the fire.
10136-8{_}16276{_}1195.
10136-8{_}16277{_}Batter pudding should be smoothly mixed and free from lumps.
10136-8{_}16278{_}To insure this, first mix the flour with a very small proportion of milk, and add the remainder by degrees.
10136-8{_}16279{_}Should the pudding be very lumpy, it may be strained through a hair sieve.
10136-8{_}16280{_}1196.
10136-8{_}16281{_}_All boiled puddings_ should be put on in _boiling water_, which must not be allowed to stop simmering, and the pudding must always be covered with the water; if requisite, the saucepan should be kept filled up.
10136-8{_}16282{_}[Illustration: BOILED-PUDDING MOULD.]
10136-8{_}16283{_}1197.
10136-8{_}16284{_}To prevent a pudding boiled in a cloth from sticking to the bottom of the saucepan, place a small plate or saucer underneath it, and set the pan _on a trivet_ over the fire.
10136-8{_}16285{_}If a mould is used, this precaution is not necessary; but care must be taken to keep the pudding well covered with water.
10136-8{_}16286{_}1198.
10136-8{_}16287{_}For dishing a boiled pudding as soon as it comes out of the pot, dip it into a basin of cold water, and the cloth will then not adhere to it.
10136-8{_}16288{_}Great expedition is necessary in sending puddings to table, as, by standing, they quickly become heavy, batter puddings particularly.
10136-8{_}16289{_}[Illustration: BOILED-PUDDING MOULD.]
10136-8{_}16290{_}1199.
10136-8{_}16291{_}For baked or boiled puddings, the moulds, cups, or basins, should be always buttered before the mixture is put in them, and they should be put into the saucepan directly they are filled.
10136-8{_}16292{_}1200.
10136-8{_}16293{_}Scrupulous attention should be paid to the cleanliness of pudding-cloths, as, from neglect in this particular, the outsides of boiled puddings frequently taste very disagreeably.
10136-8{_}16294{_}As soon as possible after it is taken off the pudding, it should be soaked in water, and then well washed, without soap, unless it be very greasy.
10136-8{_}16295{_}It should be dried out of doors, then folded up and kept in a dry place.
10136-8{_}16296{_}When wanted for use, dip it in boiling water, and dredge it slightly with flour.
10136-8{_}16297{_}[Illustration: PUDDING-BASIN.]
10136-8{_}16298{_}1201.
10136-8{_}16299{_}The _dry ingredients_ for puddings are better for being mixed some time before they are wanted; the liquid portion should only be added just before the pudding is put into the saucepan.
10136-8{_}16300{_}1202.
10136-8{_}16301{_}A pinch of salt is an improvement to the generality of puddings; but this ingredient should be added very sparingly, as the flavour should not be detected.
10136-8{_}16302{_}1203.
10136-8{_}16303{_}When baked puddings are sufficiently solid, turn them out of the dish they were baked in, bottom uppermost, and strew over them fine sifted sugar.
10136-8{_}16304{_}1204.
10136-8{_}16305{_}When pastry or baked puddings are not done through, and yet the outside is sufficiently brown, cover them over with a piece of white paper until thoroughly cooked: this prevents them from getting burnt.
10136-8{_}16306{_}[Illustration]     RECIPES.
10136-8{_}16307{_}CHAPTER XXVII.
10136-8{_}16308{_}VERY GOOD PUFF-PASTE.
10136-8{_}16309{_}1205.
10136-8{_}16310{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}16311{_}of flour allow 1 lb.
10136-8{_}16312{_}of butter, and not quite 1/2 pint of water.
10136-8{_}16313{_}_Mode_.--Carefully weigh the flour and butter, and have the exact proportion; squeeze the butter well, to extract the water from it, and afterwards wring it in a clean cloth, that no moisture may remain.
10136-8{_}16314{_}Sift the flour; see that it is perfectly dry, and proceed in the following manner to make the paste, using a very _clean_ paste-board and rolling-pin:--Supposing the quantity to be 1 lb.
10136-8{_}16315{_}of flour, work the whole into a smooth paste, with not quite 1/2 pint of water, using a knife to mix it with: the proportion of this latter ingredient must be regulated by the discretion of the cook; if too much be added, the paste, when baked, will be tough.
10136-8{_}16316{_}Roll it out until it is of an equal thickness of about an inch; break 4 oz.
10136-8{_}16317{_}of the butter into small pieces; place these on the paste, sift over it a little flour, fold it over, roll out again, and put another 4 oz.
10136-8{_}16318{_}of butter.
10136-8{_}16319{_}Repeat the rolling and buttering until the paste has been rolled out 4 times, or equal quantities of flour and butter have been used.
10136-8{_}16320{_}Do not omit, every time the paste is rolled out, to dredge a little flour over that and the rolling-pin, to prevent both from sticking.
10136-8{_}16321{_}Handle the paste as lightly as possible, and do not press heavily upon it with the rolling-pin.
10136-8{_}16322{_}The next thing to be considered is the oven, as the baking of pastry requires particular attention.
10136-8{_}16323{_}Do not put it into the oven until it is sufficiently hot to raise the paste; for the best-prepared paste, if not properly baked, will be good for nothing.
10136-8{_}16324{_}Brushing the paste as often as rolled out, and the pieces of butter placed thereon, with the white of an egg, assists it to rise in _leaves_ or _flakes_.
10136-8{_}16325{_}As this is the great beauty of puff-paste, it is as well to try this method.
10136-8{_}16326{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}16327{_}4d.
10136-8{_}16328{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}16329{_}BUTTER.--About the second century of the Christian era, butter     was placed by Galen amongst the useful medical agents; and about     a century before him, Dioscorides mentioned that he had noticed     that fresh butter, made of ewes' and goats' milk, was served at     meals instead of oil, and that it took the place of fat in     making pastry.
10136-8{_}16330{_}Thus we have undoubted authority that, eighteen     hundred years ago, there existed a knowledge of the useful     qualities of butter.
10136-8{_}16331{_}The Romans seem to have set about making it     much as we do; for Pliny tells us, "Butter is made from milk;     and the use of this element, so much sought after by barbarous     nations, distinguished the rich from the common people.
10136-8{_}16332{_}It is     obtained principally from cows' milk; that from ewes is the     fattest; goats also supply some.
10136-8{_}16333{_}It is produced by agitating the     milk in long vessels with narrow openings: a little water is     added."
10136-8{_}16334{_}MEDIUM PUFF-PASTE.
10136-8{_}16335{_}1206.
10136-8{_}16336{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}16337{_}of flour allow 8 oz.
10136-8{_}16338{_}of butter, 4 oz.
10136-8{_}16339{_}of lard, not quite 1/2 pint of water.
10136-8{_}16340{_}_Mode_.--This paste may be made by the directions in the preceding recipe, only using less butter and substituting lard for a portion of it.
10136-8{_}16341{_}Mix the flour to a smooth paste with not quite 1/2 pint of water; then roll it out 3 times, the first time covering the paste with butter, the second with lard, and the third with butter.
10136-8{_}16342{_}Keep the rolling-pin and paste slightly dredged with flour, to prevent them from sticking, and it will be ready for use.
10136-8{_}16343{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}16344{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}16345{_}BUTTER IN HASTE.--In his "History of Food," Soyer says that to     obtain butter instantly, it is only necessary, in summer, to put     new milk into a bottle, some hours after it has been taken from     the cow, and shake it briskly.
10136-8{_}16346{_}The clots which are thus formed     should be thrown into a sieve, washed and pressed together, and     they constitute the finest and most delicate butter that can     possibly be made.
10136-8{_}16347{_}COMMON PASTE, for Family Pies.
10136-8{_}16348{_}1207.
10136-8{_}16349{_}INGREDIENTS.--1-1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}16350{_}of flour, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}16351{_}of butter, rather more than 1/2 pint of water.
10136-8{_}16352{_}_Mode_.--Rub the butter lightly into the flour, and mix it to a smooth paste with the water; roll it out 2 or 3 times, and it will be ready for use.
10136-8{_}16353{_}This paste may be converted into an excellent short crust for sweet tart, by adding to the flour, after the butter is rubbed in, 2 tablespoonfuls of fine-sifted sugar.
10136-8{_}16354{_}_Average cost_, 8d.
10136-8{_}16355{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}16356{_}TO KEEP BUTTER FRESH.--One of the best means to preserve butter     fresh is, first to completely press out all the buttermilk, then     to keep it under water, renewing the water frequently, and to     remove it from the influence of heat and air, by wrapping it in     a wet cloth.
10136-8{_}16357{_}FRENCH PUFF-PASTE, or FEUILLETAGE.
10136-8{_}16358{_}(Founded on M. Ude's Recipe.)
10136-8{_}16359{_}1208.
10136-8{_}16360{_}INGREDIENTS.--Equal quantities of flour and butter--say 1 lb.
10136-8{_}16361{_}of each; 1/2 saltspoonful of salt, the yolks of 2 eggs, rather more than 1/4 pint of water.
10136-8{_}16362{_}_Mode_.--Weigh the flour; ascertain that it is perfectly _dry_, and sift it; squeeze all the water from the butter, and wring it in a clean cloth till there is no moisture remaining.
10136-8{_}16363{_}Put the flour on the paste-board, work lightly into it 2 oz.
10136-8{_}16364{_}of the butter, and then make a hole in the centre; into this well put the yolks of 2 eggs, the salt, and about 1/4 pint of water (the quantity of this latter ingredient must be regulated by the cook, as it is impossible to give the exact proportion of it); knead up the paste quickly and lightly, and, when quite smooth, roll it out square to the thickness of about 1/2 inch.
10136-8{_}16365{_}Presuming that the butter is perfectly free from moisture, and _as cool_ as possible, roll it into a ball, and place this ball of butter on the paste; fold the paste over the butter all round, and secure it by wrapping it well all over.
10136-8{_}16366{_}Flatten the paste by rolling it lightly with the rolling-pin until it is quite thin, but not thin enough to allow the butter to break through, and keep the board and paste dredged lightly with flour during the process of making it.
10136-8{_}16367{_}This rolling gives it the _first_ turn.
10136-8{_}16368{_}Now fold the paste in three, and roll out again, and, should the weather be very warm, put it in a cold place on the ground to cool between the several turns; for, unless this is particularly attended to, the paste will be spoiled.
10136-8{_}16369{_}Roll out the paste again _twice_, put it by to cool, then roll it out _twice_ more, which will make 6 _turnings_ in all.
10136-8{_}16370{_}Now fold the paste in two, and it will be ready for use.
10136-8{_}16371{_}If properly baked and well made, this crust will be delicious, and should rise in the oven about 5 or 6 inches.
10136-8{_}16372{_}The paste should be made rather firm in the first instance, as the ball of butter is liable to break through.
10136-8{_}16373{_}Great attention must also be paid to keeping the butter very cool, as, if this is in a liquid and soft state, the paste will not answer at all.
10136-8{_}16374{_}Should the cook be dexterous enough to succeed in making this, the paste will have a much better appearance than that made by the process of dividing the butter into 4 parts, and placing it over the rolled-out paste; but, until experience has been acquired, we recommend puff-paste made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}16375{_}1205.
10136-8{_}16376{_}The above paste is used for vols-au-vent, small articles of pastry, and, in fact, everything that requires very light crust.
10136-8{_}16377{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}16378{_}6d.
10136-8{_}16379{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}16380{_}WHAT TO DO WITH RANCID BUTTER.--When butter has become very     rancid, it should be melted several times by a moderate heat,     with or without the addition of water, and as soon as it has     been well kneaded, after the cooling, in order to extract any     water it may have retained, it should be put into brown     freestone pots, sheltered from the contact of the air.
10136-8{_}16381{_}The     French often add to it, after it has been melted, a piece of     toasted bread, which helps to destroy the tendency of the batter     to rancidity.
10136-8{_}16382{_}SOYER'S RECIPE FOR PUFF-PASTE.
10136-8{_}16383{_}1209.
10136-8{_}16384{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}16385{_}of flour allow the yolk of 1 egg, the juice of 1 lemon, 1/2 saltspoonful of salt, cold water, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}16386{_}of fresh butter.
10136-8{_}16387{_}_Mode_.--Put the flour on to the paste-board; make a hole in the centre, into which put the yolk of the egg, the lemon-juice, and salt; mix the whole with cold water (this should be iced in summer, if convenient) into a soft flexible paste, with the right hand, and handle it as little as possible; then squeeze all the buttermilk from the butter, wring it in a cloth, and roll out the paste; place the butter on this, and fold the edges of the paste over, so as to hide it; roll it out again to the thickness of 1/4 inch; fold over one third, over which again pass the rolling-pin; then fold over the other third, thus forming a square; place it with the ends, top, and bottom before you, shaking a little flour both under and over, and repeat the rolls and turns twice again, as before.
10136-8{_}16388{_}Flour a baking-sheet, put the paste on this, and let it remain on ice or in some cool place for 1/2 hour; then roll twice more, turning it as before; place it again upon the ice for 1/4 hour, give it 2 more rolls, making 7 in all, and it is ready for use when required.
10136-8{_}16389{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}16390{_}6d.
10136-8{_}16391{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}16392{_}VERY GOOD SHORT CRUST FOR FRUIT TARTS.
10136-8{_}16393{_}1210.
10136-8{_}16394{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}16395{_}of flour allow 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}16396{_}of butter, 1 tablespoonful of sifted sugar, 1/3 pint of water.
10136-8{_}16397{_}_Mode_.--Rub the butter into the flour, after having ascertained that the latter is perfectly dry; add the sugar, and mix the whole into a stiff paste, with about 1/3 pint of water.
10136-8{_}16398{_}Roll it out two or three times, folding the paste over each time, and it will be ready for use.
10136-8{_}16399{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}16400{_}1d.
10136-8{_}16401{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}16402{_}ANOTHER GOOD SHORT CRUST.
10136-8{_}16403{_}1211.
10136-8{_}16404{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}16405{_}of flour allow 8 oz.
10136-8{_}16406{_}of butter, the yolks of 2 eggs, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}16407{_}of sifted sugar, about 1/4 pint of milk.
10136-8{_}16408{_}_Mode_.--Rub the butter into the flour, add the sugar, and mix the whole as lightly as possible to a smooth paste, with the yolks of eggs well beaten, and the milk.
10136-8{_}16409{_}The proportion of the latter ingredient must be judged of by the size of the eggs: if these are large, so much will not be required, and more if the eggs are smaller.
10136-8{_}16410{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}16411{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}16412{_}SUGAR AND BEETROOT.--There are two sorts of Beet,--white and     red; occasionally, in the south, a yellow variety is met with.
10136-8{_}16413{_}Beetroot contains twenty parts sugar.
10136-8{_}16414{_}Everybody knows that the     beet has competed with the sugar-cane, and a great part of the     French sugar is manufactured from beet.
10136-8{_}16415{_}Beetroot has a     refreshing, composing, and slightly purgative quality.
10136-8{_}16416{_}The young     leaves, when cooked, are a substitute for spinach; they are also     useful for mixing with sorrel, to lessen its acidity.
10136-8{_}16417{_}The large     ribs of the leaves are serviceable in various culinary     preparations; the root also may be prepared in several ways, but     its most general use is in salad.
10136-8{_}16418{_}Some writers upon the subject     have expressed their opinion that beetroot is easily digested,     but those who have taken pains to carefully analyze its     qualities make quite a contrary statement.
10136-8{_}16419{_}Youth, of course, can     digest it; but to persons of a certain age beet is very     indigestible, or rather, it does not digest at all.
10136-8{_}16420{_}It is not     the sugary pulp which is indigestible, but its fibrous network     that resists the action of the gastric organs.
10136-8{_}16421{_}Thus, when the     root is reduced to a puree, almost any person may eat it.
10136-8{_}16422{_}FRENCH SUGAR.--It had long been thought that tropical heat was     not necessary to form sugar, and, about 1740, it was discovered     that many plants of the temperate zone, and amongst others the     beet, contained it.
10136-8{_}16423{_}Towards the beginning of the 19th century,     circumstances having, in France, made sugar scarce, and     consequently dear, the government caused inquiries to be     instituted as to the possibility of finding a substitute for it.
10136-8{_}16424{_}Accordingly, it was ascertained that sugar exists in the whole     vegetable kingdom; that it is to be found in the grape,     chestnut, potato; but that, far above all, the beet contains it     in a large proportion.
10136-8{_}16425{_}Thus the beet became an object of the     most careful culture; and many experiments went to prove that in     this respect the old world was independent of the new.
10136-8{_}16426{_}Many     manufactories came into existence in all parts of France, and     the making of sugar became naturalized in that country.
10136-8{_}16427{_}COMMON SHORT CRUST.
10136-8{_}16428{_}1212.
10136-8{_}16429{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every pound of flour allow 2 oz.
10136-8{_}16430{_}of sifted sugar, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}16431{_}of butter, about 1/2 pint of boiling milk.
10136-8{_}16432{_}_Mode_.--Crumble the butter into the flour as finely as possible, add the sugar, and work the whole up to a smooth paste with the boiling milk.
10136-8{_}16433{_}Roll it out thin, and bake in a moderate oven.
10136-8{_}16434{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}16435{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}16436{_}QUALITIES OF SUGAR.--Sugars obtained from various plants are in     fact, of the same nature, and have no intrinsic difference when     they have become equally purified by the same processes.
10136-8{_}16437{_}Taste,     crystallization, colour, weight, are absolutely identical; and     the most accurate observer cannot distinguish the one from the     other.
10136-8{_}16438{_}BUTTER CRUST, for Boiled Puddings.
10136-8{_}16439{_}1213.
10136-8{_}16440{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.

10136-8{_}16442{_}of butter, 1/2 pint of water.
10136-8{_}16443{_}_Mode_.--With a knife, work the flour to a smooth paste with 1/2 pint of water; roll the crust out rather thin; place the butter over it in small pieces; dredge lightly over it some flour, and fold the paste over; repeat the rolling once more, and the crust will be ready for use.
10136-8{_}16444{_}It may be enriched by adding another 2 oz.
10136-8{_}16445{_}of butter; but, for ordinary purposes, the above quantity will be found quite sufficient.
10136-8{_}16446{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}16447{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}16448{_}DRIPPING CRUST, for Kitchen Puddings, Pies, &c.  1214.
10136-8{_}16449{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}16450{_}of flour allow 6 oz.
10136-8{_}16451{_}of clarified beef dripping, 1/2 pint of water.
10136-8{_}16452{_}_Mode_.--After having clarified the dripping, by either of the recipes No.
10136-8{_}16453{_}621 or 622, weigh it, and to every lb.
10136-8{_}16454{_}of flour allow the above proportion of dripping.
10136-8{_}16455{_}With a knife, work the flour into a smooth paste with the water, rolling it out 3 times, each time placing on the crust 2 oz.
10136-8{_}16456{_}of the dripping, broken into small pieces.
10136-8{_}16457{_}If this paste is lightly made, if good dripping is used, and _not too much_ of it, it will be found good; and by the addition of two tablespoonfuls of fine moist sugar, it may be converted into a common short crust for fruit pies.

10136-8{_}16460{_}WATER:--WHAT THE ANCIENTS THOUGHT OF IT.--All the nations of     antiquity possessed great veneration for water: thus, the     Egyptians offered prayers and homage to water, and the Nile was     an especial object of their adoration; the Persians would not     wash their hands; the Scythians honoured the Danube; the Greeks     and Romans erected altars to the fountains and rivers; and some     of the architectural embellishments executed for fountains in     Greece were remarkable for their beauty and delicacy.
10136-8{_}16461{_}The purity     of the water was a great object of the care of the ancients; and     we learn that the Athenians appointed four officers to keep     watch and ward over the water in their city.
10136-8{_}16462{_}These men had to     keep the fountains in order and clean the reservoirs, so that     the water might be preserved pure and limpid.
10136-8{_}16463{_}Like officers were     appointed in other Greek cities.
10136-8{_}16464{_}SUET CRUST, for Pies or Puddings.
10136-8{_}16465{_}1215.
10136-8{_}16466{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}16467{_}of flour allow 5 or 6 oz.
10136-8{_}16468{_}of beef suet, 1/2 pint of water.
10136-8{_}16469{_}_Mode_.--Free the suet from skin and shreds; chop it extremely fine, and rub it well into the flour; work the whole to a smooth paste with the above proportion of water; roll it out, and it is ready for use.
10136-8{_}16470{_}This crust is quite rich enough for ordinary purposes, but when a better one is desired, use from 1/2 to 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}16471{_}of suet to every lb.
10136-8{_}16472{_}of flour.
10136-8{_}16473{_}Some cooks, for rich crusts, pound the suet in a mortar, with a small quantity of butter.
10136-8{_}16474{_}It should then be laid on the paste in small pieces, the same as for puff-crust, and will be found exceedingly nice for hot tarts.
10136-8{_}16475{_}5 oz.
10136-8{_}16476{_}of suet to every lb.
10136-8{_}16477{_}of flour will make a very good crust; and even 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}16478{_}will answer very well for children, or where the crust is wanted very plain.
10136-8{_}16479{_}_Average cost_, 5d.
10136-8{_}16480{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}16481{_}PATE BRISEE, or FRENCH CRUST, for Raised Pies.
10136-8{_}16482{_}1216.
10136-8{_}16483{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}16484{_}of flour allow 1/2 saltspoonful of salt, 2 eggs, 1/3 pint of water, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}16485{_}of butter.
10136-8{_}16486{_}_Mode_.--Spread the flour, which should be sifted and thoroughly dry, on the paste-board; make a hole in the centre, into which put the butter; work it lightly into the flour, and when quite fine, add the salt; work the whole into a smooth paste with the eggs (yolks and whites) and water, and make it very firm.
10136-8{_}16487{_}Knead the paste well, and let it be rather stiff, that the sides of the pie may be easily raised, and that they do not afterwards tumble or shrink.
10136-8{_}16488{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}16489{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}16490{_}_Note_.--This paste may be very much enriched by making it with equal quantities of flour and butter; but then it is not so easily raised as when made plainer.
10136-8{_}16491{_}WATER SUPPLY IN ROME.--Nothing in Italy is more extraordinary     than the remains of the ancient aqueducts.
10136-8{_}16492{_}At first, the Romans     were contented with the water from the Tiber.
10136-8{_}16493{_}Ancus Martius was     the first to commence the building of aqueducts destined to     convey the water of the fountain of Piconia from Tibur to Rome,     a distance of some 33,000 paces.
10136-8{_}16494{_}Appius Claudius continued the     good work, and to him is due the completion of the celebrated     Appian Way.
10136-8{_}16495{_}In time, the gigantic waterways greatly multiplied,     and, by the reign of Nero, there were constructed nine principal     aqueducts, the pipes of which were of bricks, baked tiles,     stone, lead, or wood.
10136-8{_}16496{_}According to the calculation of Vigenerus,     half a million hogsheads of water were conveyed into Rome every     day, by upwards of 10,000 small pipes not one-third of an inch     in diameter.
10136-8{_}16497{_}The water was received in large closed basins,     above which rose splendid monuments: these basins supplied other     subterranean conduits, connected with various quarters of the     city, and these conveyed water to small reservoirs furnished     with taps for the exclusive use of certain streets.
10136-8{_}16498{_}The water     which was not drinkable ran out, by means of large pipes, into     extensive inclosures, where it served to water cattle.
10136-8{_}16499{_}At these     places the people wished their linen; and here, too, was a     supply of the necessary element in case of fire.
10136-8{_}16500{_}COMMON CRUST FOR RAISED PIES.
10136-8{_}16501{_}1217.
10136-8{_}16502{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}16503{_}of flour allow 1/2 pint of water, 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}16504{_}of butter, 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}16505{_}of lard, 1/2 saltspoonful of salt.
10136-8{_}16506{_}_Mode_.--Put into a saucepan the water; when it boils, add the butter and lard; and when these are melted, make a hole in the middle of the flour; pour in the water gradually; beat it well with a wooden spoon, and be particular in not making the paste too soft.
10136-8{_}16507{_}When it is well mixed, knead it with the hands until quite stiff, dredging a little flour over the paste and board, to prevent them from sticking.
10136-8{_}16508{_}When it is well kneaded, place it before the fire, with a cloth covered over it, for a few minutes; it will then be more easily worked into shape.
10136-8{_}16509{_}This paste does not taste so nicely as the preceding one, but is worked with greater facility, and answers just as well for raised pies, for the crust is seldom eaten.
10136-8{_}16510{_}_Average cost_, 5d, per lb.
10136-8{_}16511{_}LARD OR FLEAD CRUST.
10136-8{_}16512{_}1218.
10136-8{_}16513{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}16514{_}of flour allow 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}16515{_}of lard or flead, 1/2 pint of water, 1/2 saltspoonful of salt.
10136-8{_}16516{_}_Mode_.--Clear the flead free from skin, and slice it into thin flakes; rub it into the flour, add the salt, and work the whole into a smooth paste, with the above proportion of water; fold the paste over two or three times, beat it well with the rolling-pin, roll it out, and it will be ready for use.
10136-8{_}16517{_}The crust made from this will be found extremely light, and may be made into cakes or tarts; it may also be very much enriched by adding more flead to the same proportion of flour.
10136-8{_}16518{_}_Average cost_, 8d.
10136-8{_}16519{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}16520{_}NUTRITIOUS QUALITIES OF FLOUR.--The gluten of grain and the     albumen of vegetable juices are identical in composition with     the albumen of blood.
10136-8{_}16521{_}Vegetable caseine has also the composition     of animal caseine.
10136-8{_}16522{_}The finest wheat flour contains more starch     than the coarser; the bran of wheat is proportionably richer in     gluten.
10136-8{_}16523{_}Rye and rye-bread contain a substance resembling     starch-gum (or dextrine, as it is called) in its properties,     which is very easily converted into sugar.
10136-8{_}16524{_}The starch of barley     approaches in many properties to cellulose, and is, therefore,     less digestible.
10136-8{_}16525{_}Oats are particularly rich in plastic     substances; Scotch oats are richer than those grown in England     or in Germany.
10136-8{_}16526{_}This kind of grain contains in its ashes, after     deduction of the silica of the husks, very nearly the same     ingredients as are found in the ashes of the juice of flesh.
10136-8{_}16527{_}Fine American flour is one of the varieties which is richest in     gluten, and is consequently one of the most nutritious.
10136-8{_}16528{_}ALMOND CHEESECAKES.
10136-8{_}16529{_}1219.
10136-8{_}16530{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}16531{_}of sweet almonds, 4 bitter ones, 3 eggs, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}16532{_}of butter, the rind of 1/4 lemon, 1 tablespoonful of lemon-juice, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}16533{_}of sugar.
10136-8{_}16534{_}_Mode_.--Blanch and pound the almonds smoothly in a mortar, with a little rose- or spring-water; stir in the eggs, which should be well beaten, and the butter, which should be warmed; add the grated lemon-peel and -juice, sweeten, and stir well until the whole is thoroughly mixed.
10136-8{_}16535{_}Line some pattypans with puff-paste, put in the mixture, and bake for 20 minutes, or rather less in a quick oven.
10136-8{_}16536{_}_Time_.--20 minutes, or rather less.
10136-8{_}16537{_}_Average cost_, 10d.
10136-8{_}16538{_}_Sufficient_ for about 12 cheesecakes.
10136-8{_}16539{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}16540{_}[Illustration: ALMOND AND BLOSSOM.]
10136-8{_}16541{_}ALMONDS.--Almonds are the fruit of the _Amygdalus commenis_, and     are cultivated throughout the whole of the south of Europe,     Syria, Persia, and Northern Africa; but England is mostly     supplied with those which are grown in Spain and the south of     France.
10136-8{_}16542{_}They are distinguished into Sweet and Bitter, the     produce of different varieties.
10136-8{_}16543{_}Of the sweet, there are two     varieties, distinguished in commerce by the names of Jordan and     Valentia almonds.
10136-8{_}16544{_}The former are imported from Malaga, and are     longer, narrower, more pointed, and more highly esteemed than     the latter, which are imported from Valentia.
10136-8{_}16545{_}Bitter almonds are     principally obtained from Morocco, and are exported from     Mogador.
10136-8{_}16546{_}ALMOND PASTE, for Second-Course Dishes.
10136-8{_}16547{_}1220.
10136-8{_}16548{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}16549{_}of sweet almonds, 6 bitter ones, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}16550{_}of very finely sifted sugar, the whites of 2 eggs.
10136-8{_}16551{_}_Mode_.--Blanch the almonds, and dry them thoroughly; put them into a mortar, and pound them well, wetting them gradually with the whites of 2 eggs.
10136-8{_}16552{_}When well pounded, put them into a small preserving-pan, add the sugar, and place the pan on a small but clear fire (a hot-plate is better); keep stirring until the paste is dry, then take it out of the pan, put it between two dishes, and, when cold, make it into any shape that fancy may dictate.
10136-8{_}16553{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}16554{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}16555{_}for the above quantity.
10136-8{_}16556{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 small dishes of pastry.
10136-8{_}16557{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}16558{_}BITTER ALMONDS.--The Bitter Almond is a variety of the common     almond, and is injurious to animal life, on account of the great     quantity of hydrocyanic acid it contains, and is consequently     seldom used in domestic economy, unless it be to give flavour to     confectionery; and even then it should he used with great     caution.
10136-8{_}16559{_}A single drop of the essential oil of bitter almonds is     sufficient to destroy a bird, and four drops have caused the     death of a middle-sized dog.
10136-8{_}16560{_}BAKED ALMOND PUDDING.
10136-8{_}16561{_}(_Very rich_.)
10136-8{_}16562{_}1221.
10136-8{_}16563{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}16564{_}of almonds, 4 bitter ditto, 1 glass of sherry, 4 eggs, the rind and juice of 1/2 lemon, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}16565{_}of butter, 1 pint of cream, 2 tablespoonfuls of sugar.
10136-8{_}16566{_}_Mode_.--Blanch and pound the almonds to a smooth paste with the water; mix these with the butter, which should be melted; beat up the eggs, grate the lemon-rind, and strain the juice; add these, with the cream, sugar, and wine, to the other ingredients, and stir them well together.
10136-8{_}16567{_}When well mixed, put it into a pie-dish lined with puff-paste, and bake for 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}16568{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}16569{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}16570{_}3d.
10136-8{_}16571{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}16572{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}16573{_}_Note_.--To make this pudding more economically, substitute milk for the cream; but then add rather more than 1 oz.
10136-8{_}16574{_}of finely grated bread.
10136-8{_}16575{_}USES OF THE SWEET ALMOND.--The kernels of the sweet almond are     used either in a green or ripe state, and as an article in the     dessert.
10136-8{_}16576{_}Into cookery, confectionery, perfumery, and medicine,     they largely enter, and in domestic economy, should always be     used in preference to bitter almonds.
10136-8{_}16577{_}The reason for advising     this, is because the kernels do not contain any hydrocyanic or     prussic acid, although it is found in the leaves, flowers, and     bark of the tree.
10136-8{_}16578{_}When young and green, they are preserved in     sugar, like green apricots.
10136-8{_}16579{_}They furnish the almond-oil; and the     farinaceous matter which is left after the oil is expressed,     forms the _pâte d'amandes_ of perfumers.
10136-8{_}16580{_}In the arts, the oil is     employed for the same purposes as the olive-oil, and forms the     basis of kalydor, macassar oil, Gowland's lotion, and many other     articles of that kind vended by perfumers.
10136-8{_}16581{_}In medicine, it is     considered a nutritive, laxative, and an emollient.
10136-8{_}16582{_}SMALL ALMOND PUDDINGS.
10136-8{_}16583{_}1222.
10136-8{_}16584{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}16585{_}of sweet almonds, 6 bitter ones, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}16586{_}of butter, 4 eggs, 2 tablespoonfuls of sifted sugar, 2 tablespoonfuls of cream, 1 tablespoonful of brandy.
10136-8{_}16587{_}[Illustration: ALMOND PUDDINGS.]
10136-8{_}16588{_}_Mode_.--Blanch and pound the almonds to a smooth paste with a spoonful of water; warm the butter, mix the almonds with this, and add the other ingredients, leaving out the whites of 2 eggs, and be particular that these are well beaten.
10136-8{_}16589{_}Mix well, butter some cups, half fill them, and bake the puddings from 20 minutes to 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}16590{_}Turn them out on a dish, and serve with sweet sauce.
10136-8{_}16591{_}_Time_.--20 minutes to 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}16592{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}16593{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}16594{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}16595{_}THE HUSKS OF ALMONDS.--In the environs of Alicante, the husks of     almonds are ground to a powder, and enter into the composition     of common soap, the large quantity of alkaline principle they     contain rendering them suitable for this purpose.
10136-8{_}16596{_}It is said     that in some parts of the south of France, where they are     extensively grown, horses and mules are fed on the green and dry     husks; but, to prevent any evil consequences arising from this     practice, they are mixed with chopped straw or oats.
10136-8{_}16597{_}ALMOND PUFFS.
10136-8{_}16598{_}1223.
10136-8{_}16599{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 tablespoonfuls of flour, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}16600{_}of butter, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}16601{_}of pounded sugar, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}16602{_}of sweet almonds, 4 bitter almonds.
10136-8{_}16603{_}_Mode_.--Blanch and pound the almonds in a mortar to a smooth paste; melt the butter, dredge in the flour, and add the sugar and pounded almonds.
10136-8{_}16604{_}Beat the mixture well, and put it into cups or very tiny jelly-pots, which should be well buttered, and bake in a moderate oven for about 20 minutes, or longer should the puffs be large.
10136-8{_}16605{_}Turn them out on a dish, the bottom of the puff upper-most, and serve.
10136-8{_}16606{_}_Time_.--20 minutes.
10136-8{_}16607{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}16608{_}_Sufficient_ for 2 or 3 persons.
10136-8{_}16609{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}16610{_}AUNT NELLY'S PUDDING.
10136-8{_}16611{_}1224.
10136-8{_}16612{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}16613{_}of flour, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}16614{_}of treacle, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}16615{_}of suet, the rind and juice of 1 lemon, a few strips of candied lemon-peel, 3 tablespoonfuls of cream, 2 eggs.
10136-8{_}16616{_}_Mode_.--Chop the suet finely; mix with it the flour, treacle, lemon-peel minced, and candied lemon-peel; add the cream, lemon-juice, and 2 well-beaten eggs; beat the pudding well, put it into a buttered basin, tie it down with a cloth, and boil from 3-1/2 to 4 hours.
10136-8{_}16617{_}_Time_.--3-1/2 to 4 hours.
10136-8{_}16618{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}16619{_}2d.
10136-8{_}16620{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}16621{_}_Seasonable_ at any time, but more suitable for a winter pudding.
10136-8{_}16622{_}TREACLE, OR MOLASSES.--Treacle is the uncrystallizable part of     the saccharine juice drained from the Muscovado sugar, and is     either naturally so or rendered uncrystallizable through some     defect in the process of boiling.
10136-8{_}16623{_}As it contains a large     quantity of sweet or saccharine principle and is cheap, it is of     great use as an article of domestic economy.
10136-8{_}16624{_}Children are     especially fond of it; and it is accounted wholesome.
10136-8{_}16625{_}It is also     useful for making beer, rum, and the very dark syrups.
10136-8{_}16626{_}BAKED APPLE DUMPLINGS (a Plain Family Dish).
10136-8{_}16627{_}1225.
10136-8{_}16628{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 apples, 3/4 lb.. of suet-crust No.
10136-8{_}16629{_}1215, sugar to taste.
10136-8{_}16630{_}_Mode_.--Pare and take out the cores of the apples without dividing them, and make 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}16631{_}of suet-crust by recipe No.
10136-8{_}16632{_}1215; roll the apples in the crust, previously sweetening them with moist sugar, and taking care to join the paste nicely.
10136-8{_}16633{_}When they are formed into round balls, put them on a tin, and bake them for about 1/2 hour, or longer should the apples be very large; arrange them pyramidically on a dish, and sift over them some pounded white sugar.
10136-8{_}16634{_}These may be made richer by using one of the puff-pastes instead of suet.
10136-8{_}16635{_}_Time_.--From 1/2 to 3/4 hour, or longer.
10136-8{_}16636{_}_Average cost_, 1-1/2d.
10136-8{_}16637{_}each.
10136-8{_}16638{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}16639{_}_Seasonable_ from August to March, but flavourless after the end of January.
10136-8{_}16640{_}USES OF THE APPLE.--It is well known that this fruit forms a     very important article of food, in the form of pies and     puddings, and furnishes several delicacies, such as sauces,     marmalades, and jellies, and is much esteemed as a dessert     fruit.
10136-8{_}16641{_}When flattened in the form of round cakes, and baked in     ovens, they are called beefings; and large quantities are     annually dried in the sun in America, as well as in Normandy,     and stored for use during winter, when they may be stewed or     made into pies.
10136-8{_}16642{_}In a roasted state they are remarkably     wholesome, and, it is said, strengthening to a weak stomach.
10136-8{_}16643{_}In     putrid and malignant fevers, when used with the juice of lemons     and currants, they are considered highly efficacious.
10136-8{_}16644{_}APPLE CHEESECAKES.
10136-8{_}16645{_}1226.
10136-8{_}16646{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}16647{_}of apple pulp, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}16648{_}of sifted sugar, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}16649{_}of butter, 4 eggs, the rind and juice of 1 lemon.
10136-8{_}16650{_}_Mode_.--Pare, core, and boil sufficient apples to make 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}16651{_}when cooked; add to these the sugar, the butter, which should be melted; the eggs, leaving out 2 of the whites, and take grated rind and juice of 1 lemon; stir the mixture well; line some patty-pans with puff-paste, put in the mixture, and bake about 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}16652{_}_Time_.--About 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}16653{_}_Average cost_, for the above quantity, with the paste, 1s.
10136-8{_}16654{_}2d.
10136-8{_}16655{_}_Sufficient_ for about 18 or 20 cheesecakes.
10136-8{_}16656{_}_Seasonable_ from August to March.
10136-8{_}16657{_}[Illustration: APPLE AND BLOSSOM.]
10136-8{_}16658{_}THE APPLE.--The most useful of all the British fruits is the     apple, which is a native of Britain, and may be found in woods     and hedges, in the form of the common wild crab, of which all     our best apples are merely seminal varieties, produced by     culture or particular circumstances.
10136-8{_}16659{_}In most temperate climates     it is very extensively cultivated, and in England, both as     regards variety and quantity, it is excellent and abundant.
10136-8{_}16660{_}Immense supplies are also imported from the United States and     from France.
10136-8{_}16661{_}The apples grown in the vicinity of New York are     universally admitted to be the finest of any; but unless     selected and packed with great care, they are apt to spoil     before reaching England.
10136-8{_}16662{_}BOILED APPLE DUMPLINGS.
10136-8{_}16663{_}1227.
10136-8{_}16664{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 apples, 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}16665{_}of suet-crust No.
10136-8{_}16666{_}1215, sugar to taste.
10136-8{_}16667{_}_Mode_.--Pare and take out the cores of the apples without dividing them; sweeten, and roll each apple in a piece of crust, made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}16668{_}1211; be particular that the paste is nicely joined; put the dumplings into floured cloths, tie them securely, and put them into boiling water.
10136-8{_}16669{_}Keep them boiling from 1/2 to 3/4 hour; remove the cloths, and send them hot and quickly to table.
10136-8{_}16670{_}Dumplings boiled in knitted cloths have a very pretty appearance when they come to table.
10136-8{_}16671{_}The cloths should be made square, just large enough to hold one dumpling, and should be knitted in plain knitting, with _very coarse_ cotton.
10136-8{_}16672{_}_Time_.--3/4 to 1 hour, or longer should the dumplings be very large.
10136-8{_}16673{_}_Average cost_, 11/2d.
10136-8{_}16674{_}each.
10136-8{_}16675{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}16676{_}_Seasonable_ from August to March, but flavourless after the end of January.
10136-8{_}16677{_}LAMBSWOOL, or LAMASOOL.--This old English beverage is composed     of apples mixed with ale, and seasoned with sugar and spice.
10136-8{_}16678{_}It     takes its name from _Lamaes abhal_, which, in ancient British,     signifies the day of apple fruit, from being drunk on the apple     feast in autumn.
10136-8{_}16679{_}In France, a beverage, called by the Parisians     _raisinée_, is made by boiling any given quantity of new wine,     skimming it as often as fresh scum rises, and, when it is boiled     to half its bulk, straining it.
10136-8{_}16680{_}To this apples, pared and cut     into quarters, are added; the whole is then allowed to simmer     gently, stirring it all the time with a long wooden spoon, till     the apples are thoroughly mixed with the liquor, and the whole     forms a species of marmalade, which is extremely agreeable to     the taste, having a slight flavour of acidity, like lemon mixed     with honey.
10136-8{_}16681{_}RICH BAKED APPLE PUDDING.
10136-8{_}16682{_}I.
10136-8{_}16683{_}1228.
10136-8{_}16684{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}16685{_}of the pulp of apples, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}16686{_}of loaf sugar, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}16687{_}of butter, the rind of 1 lemon, 6 eggs, puff-paste.
10136-8{_}16688{_}_Mode_.--Peel, core, and cut the apples, as for sauce; put them into a stewpan, with only just sufficient water to prevent them from burning, and let them stew until reduced to a pulp.
10136-8{_}16689{_}Weigh the pulp, and to every 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}16690{_}add sifted sugar, grated lemon-rind, and 6 well-beaten eggs.
10136-8{_}16691{_}Beat these ingredients well together; then melt the butter, stir it to the other things, put a border of puff-paste round the dish, and bake for rather more than 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}16692{_}The butter should not be added until the pudding is ready for the oven.
10136-8{_}16693{_}_Time_.--1/2 to 3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}16694{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}16695{_}10d.
10136-8{_}16696{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}16697{_}_Seasonable_ from August to March.
10136-8{_}16698{_}II.
10136-8{_}16699{_}(_More Economical_.)
10136-8{_}16700{_}1229.
10136-8{_}16701{_}INGREDIENTS.--12 large apples, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}16702{_}of moist sugar, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}16703{_}of butter, 4 eggs, 1 pint of bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}16704{_}_Mode_.--Pare, core, and cut the apples, as for sauce, and boil them until reduced to a pulp; then add the butter, melted, and the eggs, which should be well whisked.
10136-8{_}16705{_}Beat up the pudding for 2 or 3 minutes; butter a pie-dish; put in a layer of bread crumbs, then the apple, and then another layer of bread crumbs; flake over these a few tiny pieces of butter, and bake for about 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}16706{_}_Time_.--About 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}16707{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}16708{_}3d.
10136-8{_}16709{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}16710{_}_Seasonable_ from August to March.
10136-8{_}16711{_}_Note_.--A very good economical pudding may be made merely with apples, boiled and sweetened, with the addition of a few strips of lemon-peel.
10136-8{_}16712{_}A layer of bread crumbs should be placed above and below the apples, and the pudding baked for 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}16713{_}CONSTITUENTS OF THE APPLE.--All apples contain sugar, malic     acid, or the acid of apples; mucilage, or gum; woody fibre, and     water; together with some aroma, on which their peculiar flavour     depends.
10136-8{_}16714{_}The hard acid kinds are unwholesome if eaten raw; but     by the process of cooking, a great deal of this acid is     decomposed and converted into sugar.
10136-8{_}16715{_}The sweet and mellow kinds     form a valuable addition to the dessert.
10136-8{_}16716{_}A great part of the     acid juice is converted into sugar as the fruit ripens, and even     after it is gathered, by natural process, termed maturation;     but, when apples decay, the sugar is changed into a bitter     principle, and the mucilage becomes mouldy and offensive.
10136-8{_}16717{_}Old     cheese has a remarkable effect in meliorating the apple when     eaten; probably from the volatile alkali or ammonia of the     cheese neutralizing its acid.
10136-8{_}16718{_}RICH SWEET APPLE PUDDING.
10136-8{_}16719{_}1230.
10136-8{_}16720{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}16721{_}of bread crumbs, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}16722{_}of suet, 1/2 lb.
