10136-8{_}19243{_}APPLE SOUFFLE.
10136-8{_}19244{_}1402.
10136-8{_}19245{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 oz.
10136-8{_}19246{_}of rice, 1 quart of milk, the rind of 1/2 lemon, sugar to taste, the yolks of 4 eggs, the whites of 6, 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}19247{_}of butter, 4 tablespoonfuls of apple marmalade No.
10136-8{_}19248{_}1395.
10136-8{_}19249{_}_Mode_.--Boil the milk with the lemon-peel until the former is well flavoured; then strain it, put in the rice, and let it gradually swell over a slow fire, adding sufficient sugar to sweeten it nicely.
10136-8{_}19250{_}Then crush the rice to a smooth pulp with the back of a wooden spoon; line the bottom and sides of a round cake-tin with it, and put it into the oven to set; turn it out of the tin carefully, and be careful that the border of rice is firm in every part.
10136-8{_}19251{_}Mix with the marmalade the beaten yolks of eggs and the butter, and stir these over the fire until the mixture thickens.
10136-8{_}19252{_}Take it off the fire; to this add the whites of the eggs, which should be previously beaten to a strong froth; stir all together, and put it into the rice border.
10136-8{_}19253{_}Bake in a moderate oven for about 1/2 hour, or until the soufflé rises very light.
10136-8{_}19254{_}It should be watched, and served instantly, or it will immediately fall after it is taken from the oven.
10136-8{_}19255{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}19256{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}19257{_}6d.
10136-8{_}19258{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}19259{_}_Seasonable_ from July to March.
10136-8{_}19260{_}STEWED APPLES AND CUSTARD.

10136-8{_}19262{_}1403.
10136-8{_}19263{_}INGREDIENTS.--7 good-sized apples, the rind of 1/2 lemon or 4 cloves, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}19264{_}of sugar, 3/4 pint of water, 1/2 pint of custard No.
10136-8{_}19265{_}1423.
10136-8{_}19266{_}_Mode_.--Pare and take out the cores of the apples, without dividing them, and, if possible, leave the stalks on; boil the sugar and water together for 10 minutes; then put in the apples with the lemon-rind or cloves, whichever flavour may be preferred, and simmer gently until they are tender, taking care not to let them break.
10136-8{_}19267{_}Dish them neatly on a glass dish, reduce the syrup by boiling it quickly for a few minutes, let it cool a little; then pour it over the apples.
10136-8{_}19268{_}Have ready quite 1/2 pint of custard made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}19269{_}1423; pour it round, but not over, the apples when they are quite cold, and the dish is ready for table.
10136-8{_}19270{_}A few almonds blanched and cut into strips, and stuck in the apples, would improve their appearance.--See coloured plate Q1.
10136-8{_}19271{_}_Time_.--From 20 to 30 minutes to stew the apples.
10136-8{_}19272{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}19273{_}_Sufficient_ to fill a large glass dish.
10136-8{_}19274{_}_Seasonable_ from July to March.
10136-8{_}19275{_}APPLE TRIFLE.
10136-8{_}19276{_}(_A Supper Dish_.)
10136-8{_}19277{_}1404.
10136-8{_}19278{_}INGREDIENTS.--10 good-sized apples, the rind of 1/2 lemon, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}19279{_}of pounded sugar, 1/2 pint of milk, 1/2 pint of cream, 2 eggs, whipped cream.
10136-8{_}19280{_}_Mode_.--Peel, core, and cut the apples into thin slices, and put them into a saucepan with 2 tablespoonfuls of water, the sugar, and minced lemon-rind.
10136-8{_}19281{_}Boil all together until quite tender, and pulp the apples through a sieve; if they should not be quite sweet enough, add a little more sugar, and put them at the bottom of the dish to form a thick layer.
10136-8{_}19282{_}Stir together the milk, cream, and eggs, with a little sugar, over the fire, and let the mixture thicken, but do not allow it to reach the boiling-point.
10136-8{_}19283{_}When thick, take it off the fire; let it cool a little, then pour it over the apples.
10136-8{_}19284{_}Whip some cream with sugar, lemon-peel, &c., the same as for other trifles; heap it high over the custard, and the dish is ready for table.
10136-8{_}19285{_}It may be garnished as fancy dictates, with strips of bright apple jelly, slices of citron, &c.
10136-8{_}19286{_}_Time_.--From 30 to 40 minutes to stew the apples; 10 minutes to stir the custard over the fire.
10136-8{_}19287{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}19288{_}6d.
10136-8{_}19289{_}_Sufficient_ for a moderate-sized trifle.
10136-8{_}19290{_}_Seasonable_ from July to March.
10136-8{_}19291{_}APRICOT CREAM.
10136-8{_}19292{_}1405.
10136-8{_}19293{_}INGREDIENTS.--12 to 16 ripe apricots, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}19294{_}of sugar, 1-1/2 pint of milk, the yolks of 8 eggs, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}19295{_}of isinglass.
10136-8{_}19296{_}_Mode_.--Divide the apricots, take out the stones, and boil them in a syrup made with 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}19297{_}of sugar and 1/4 pint of water, until they form a thin marmalade, which rub through a sieve.
10136-8{_}19298{_}Boil the milk with the other 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}19299{_}of sugar, let it cool a little, then mix with it the yolks of eggs which have been previously well beaten; put this mixture into a jug, place this jug in boiling water, and stir it one way over the fire until it thickens; but on no account let it boil.
10136-8{_}19300{_}Strain through a sieve, add the isinglass, previously boiled with a small quantity of water, and keep stirring it till nearly cold; then mix the cream with the apricots; stir well, put it into an oiled mould, and, if convenient, set it on ice; at any rate, in a very cool place.
10136-8{_}19301{_}It should turn out on the dish without any difficulty.
10136-8{_}19302{_}_Time_.--From 20 to 30 minutes to boil the apricots.
10136-8{_}19303{_}_Average cost_, 3s.
10136-8{_}19304{_}6d.
10136-8{_}19305{_}_Sufficient_ to fill a quart mould.
10136-8{_}19306{_}_Seasonable_ in August, September, and October.
10136-8{_}19307{_}_Note_.--In winter-time, when fresh apricots are not obtainable, a little jam may be substituted for them.
10136-8{_}19308{_}FLANC OF APRICOTS, or Compote of Apricots in a Raised Crust.

10136-8{_}19312{_}of short crust No.

10136-8{_}19314{_}of sugar.
10136-8{_}19315{_}_Mode_.--Make a short crust by recipe No.
10136-8{_}19316{_}1212, and line a mould with it as directed in recipe No.
10136-8{_}19317{_}1391.
10136-8{_}19318{_}Boil the sugar and water together for 10 minutes; halve the apricots, take out the stones, and simmer them in the syrup until tender; watch them carefully, and take them up the moment they are done, for fear they break.
10136-8{_}19319{_}Arrange them neatly in the flanc or case; boil the syrup until reduced to a jelly, pour it over the fruit, and serve either hot or cold.
10136-8{_}19320{_}Greengages, plums of all kinds, peaches, &c., may be done in the same manner, as also currants, raspberries, gooseberries, strawberries, &c.; but with the last-named fruits, a little currant-juice added to them will be found an improvement.

10136-8{_}19326{_}ARROWROOT BLANC-MANGE.
10136-8{_}19327{_}(_An inexpensive Supper Dish_.)
10136-8{_}19328{_}1407.
10136-8{_}19329{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 heaped tablespoonfuls of arrowroot, 1-1/2 pint of milk, 3 laurel-leaves or the rind of 1/2 lemon, sugar to taste.
10136-8{_}19330{_}_Mode_.--Mix to a smooth batter the arrowroot with 1/2 pint of the milk; put the other pint on the fire, with laurel-leaves or lemon-peel, whichever may be preferred, and let the milk steep until it is well flavoured.
10136-8{_}19331{_}Then strain the milk, and add it, boiling, to the mixed arrowroot; sweeten it with sifted sugar, and let it boil, stirring it all the time, till it thickens sufficiently to come from the saucepan.
10136-8{_}19332{_}Grease a mould with pure salad-oil, pour in the blanc-mange, and when quite set, turn it out on a dish, and pour round it a compôte of any kind of fruit, or garnish it with jam.
10136-8{_}19333{_}A tablespoonful of brandy, stirred in just before the blanc-mange is moulded, very much improves the flavour of this sweet dish.
10136-8{_}19334{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}19335{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}19336{_}without the garnishing.
10136-8{_}19337{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}19338{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19339{_}BLANC-MANGE.
10136-8{_}19340{_}(_A Supper Dish_.)
10136-8{_}19341{_}1408.
10136-8{_}19342{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint of new milk, 1-1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}19343{_}of isinglass, the rind of 1/2 lemon, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}19344{_}of loaf sugar, 10 bitter almonds, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}19345{_}of sweet almonds, 1 pint of cream.
10136-8{_}19346{_}[Illustration: BLANC-MANGE MOULD.]
10136-8{_}19347{_}_Mode_.--Put the milk into a saucepan, with the isinglass, lemon-rind, and sugar, and let these ingredients stand by the side of the fire until the milk is well flavoured; add the almonds, which should be blanched and pounded in a mortar to a paste, and let the milk just boil up; strain it through a fine sieve or muslin into a jug, add the cream, and stir the mixture occasionally until nearly cold.
10136-8{_}19348{_}Let it stand for a few minutes, then pour it into the mould, which should be previously oiled with the purest salad-oil, or dipped in cold water.
10136-8{_}19349{_}There will be a sediment at the bottom of the jug, which must not be poured into the mould, as, when turned out, it would very much disfigure the appearance of the blanc-mange.
10136-8{_}19350{_}This blanc-mange may be made very much richer by using 1-1/2 pint of cream, and melting the isinglass in 1/2 pint of boiling water.
10136-8{_}19351{_}The flavour may also be very much varied by adding bay-leaves, laurel-leaves, or essence of vanilla, instead of the lemon-rind and almonds.
10136-8{_}19352{_}Noyeau, Maraschino, Curaçoa, or any favourite liqueur, added in small proportions, very much enhances the flavour of this always favourite dish.
10136-8{_}19353{_}In turning it out, just loosen the edges of the blanc-mange from the mould, place a dish on it, and turn it quickly over; it should come out easily, and the blanc-mange have a smooth glossy appearance when the mould is oiled, which it frequently has not when it is only dipped in water.
10136-8{_}19354{_}It may be garnished as fancy dictates.
10136-8{_}19355{_}_Time_.--About 1-1/2 hour to steep the lemon-rind and almonds in the milk.
10136-8{_}19356{_}_Average cost_, with cream at 1s.
10136-8{_}19357{_}per pint, 3s.
10136-8{_}19358{_}3d.
10136-8{_}19359{_}_Sufficient_ to fill a quart mould.
10136-8{_}19360{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19361{_}CHEAP BLANC-MANGE.
10136-8{_}19362{_}1409.
10136-8{_}19363{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}19364{_}of sugar, 1 quart of milk, 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}19365{_}of isinglass, the rind of 1/2 lemon, 4 laurel-leaves.
10136-8{_}19366{_}[Illustration: BLANC-MANGE.]
10136-8{_}19367{_}_Mode_.--Put all the ingredients into a lined saucepan, and boil gently until the isinglass is dissolved; taste it occasionally, to ascertain when it is sufficiently flavoured with the laurel-leaves; then take them out, and keep stirring the mixture over the fire for about 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}19368{_}Strain it through a fine sieve into a jug, and, when nearly cold, pour it into a well-oiled mould, omitting the sediment at the bottom.
10136-8{_}19369{_}Turn it out carefully on a dish, and garnish with preserves, bright jelly, or a compote of fruit.
10136-8{_}19370{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}19371{_}_Average cost_, 8d.
10136-8{_}19372{_}_Sufficient_ to fill a quart mould.
10136-8{_}19373{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19374{_}BREAD-AND-BUTTER FRITTERS.
10136-8{_}19375{_}1410.
10136-8{_}19376{_}INGREDIENTS.--Batter, 8 slices of bread and butter, 3 or 4 tablespoonfuls of jam.
10136-8{_}19377{_}_Mode_.--Make a batter, the same as for apple fritters No.
10136-8{_}19378{_}1393; cut some slices of bread and butter, not very thick; spread half of them with any jam that may he preferred, and cover with the other slices; slightly press them together, and cut them out in square, long, or round pieces.
10136-8{_}19379{_}Dip them in the batter, and fry in boiling lard for about 10 minutes; drain them before the fire on a piece of blotting-paper or cloth.
10136-8{_}19380{_}Dish them, sprinkle over sifted sugar, and serve.
10136-8{_}19381{_}_Time_.--About 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}19382{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}19383{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}19384{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19385{_}TO MAKE THE STOCK FOR JELLY, AND TO CLARIFY IT.
10136-8{_}19386{_}1411.
10136-8{_}19387{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 calf's feet, 6 pints of water.
10136-8{_}19388{_}[Illustration: JELLY-MOULD.]
10136-8{_}19389{_}[Illustration: JELLY-BAG.]
10136-8{_}19390{_}_Mode_.--The stock for jellies should always be made the day before it is required for use, as the liquor has time to cool, and the fat can be so much more easily and effectually removed when thoroughly set.
10136-8{_}19391{_}Procure from the butcher's 2 nice calf's feet: scald them, to take off the hair; slit them in two, remove the fat from between the claws, and wash the feet well in warm water; put them into a stewpan, with the above proportion of cold water, bring it gradually to boil, and remove every particle of scum as it rises.
10136-8{_}19392{_}When it is well skimmed, boil it very gently for 6 or 7 hours, or until the liquor is reduced rather more than half; then strain it through a sieve into a basin, and put it in a cool place to set.
10136-8{_}19393{_}As the liquor is strained, measure it, to ascertain the proportion for the jelly, allowing something for the sediment and fat at the top.
10136-8{_}19394{_}To clarify it, carefully remove all the fat from the top, pour over a little warm water, to wash away any that may remain, and wipe the jelly with a clean cloth; remove the jelly from the sediment, put it into a saucepan, and, supposing the quantity to be a quart, add to it 6 oz.
10136-8{_}19395{_}of loaf sugar, the shells and well-whisked whites of 5 eggs, and stir these ingredients together cold; set the saucepan on the fire, but _do not stir the jelly after it begins to warm_.
10136-8{_}19396{_}Let it boil about 10 minutes after it rises to a head, then throw in a teacupful of cold water; let it boil 5 minutes longer, then take the saucepan off, cover it closely, and let it remain 1/2 hour near the fire.
10136-8{_}19397{_}Dip the jelly-bag into hot water, wring it out quite dry, and fasten it on to a stand or the back of a chair, which must be placed near the fire, to prevent the jelly from setting before it has run through the bag.
10136-8{_}19398{_}Place a basin underneath to receive the jelly; then pour it into the bag, and should it not be clear the first time, run it through the bag again.
10136-8{_}19399{_}This stock is the foundation of all _really good_ jellies, which may be varied in innumerable ways, by colouring and flavouring with liqueurs, and by moulding it with fresh and preserved fruits.
10136-8{_}19400{_}To insure the jelly being firm when turned out, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}19401{_}of isinglass clarified might be added to the above proportion of stock.
10136-8{_}19402{_}Substitutes for calf's feet are now frequently used in making jellies, which lessen the expense and trouble in preparing this favourite dish; isinglass and gelatine being two of the principal materials employed; but, although they may _look_ as nicely as jellies made from good stock, they are never so delicate, having very often an unpleasant flavour, somewhat resembling glue, particularly when made with gelatine.
10136-8{_}19403{_}_Time_.--About 6 hours to boil the feet for the stock; to clarify it,--1/4 hour to boil, 1/2 hour to stand in the saucepan covered.
10136-8{_}19404{_}_Average cost_.--Calf's feet may be purchased for 6d.
10136-8{_}19405{_}each when veal is in full season, but more expensive when it is scarce.
10136-8{_}19406{_}_Sufficient_.--2 calf's feet should make 1 quart of stock.
10136-8{_}19407{_}_Seasonable_ from March to October, but may be had all the year.
10136-8{_}19408{_}HOW TO MAKE A JELLY-BAG.--The very stout flannel called     double-mill, used for ironing-blankets, is the best material for     a jelly-bag: those of home manufacture are the only ones to be     relied on for thoroughly clearing the jelly.
10136-8{_}19409{_}Care should be     taken that the seam of the bag be stitched twice, to secure it     against unequal filtration.
10136-8{_}19410{_}The most convenient mode of using     the big is to tie it upon a hoop the exact size of the outside     of its mouth; and, to do this, strings should be sewn round it     at equal distances.
10136-8{_}19411{_}The jelly-bag may, of coarse, be made any     size; but one of twelve or fourteen inches deep, and seven or     eight across the mouth, will be sufficient for ordinary use.
10136-8{_}19412{_}The     form of a jelly-bag is the fool's cap.
10136-8{_}19413{_}COW-HEEL STOCK FOR JELLIES.
10136-8{_}19414{_}(More Economical than Calf's Feet.)
10136-8{_}19415{_}1412.
10136-8{_}19416{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 cow-heels, 3 quarts of water.
10136-8{_}19417{_}_Mode_.--Procure 2 heels that have only been scalded, and not boiled; split them in two, and remove the fat between the claws; wash them well in warm water, and put them into a saucepan with the above proportion of cold water; bring it gradually to boil, remove all the scum as it rises, and simmer the heels gently from 7 to 8 hours, or until the liquor is reduced one-half; then strain it into a basin, measuring the quantity, and put it in a cool place.
10136-8{_}19418{_}Clarify it in the same manner as calf's-feet stock No.
10136-8{_}19419{_}1411, using, with the other ingredients, about 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}19420{_}of isinglass to each quart.
10136-8{_}19421{_}This stock should be made the day before it is required for use.
10136-8{_}19422{_}Two dozen shank-bones of mutton, boiled for 6 or 7 hours, yield a quart of strong firm stock.
10136-8{_}19423{_}They should be put on in 2 quarts of water, which should be reduced one-half.
10136-8{_}19424{_}Make this also the day before it is required.
10136-8{_}19425{_}_Time_.--7 to 8 hours to boil the cow-heels, 6 to 7 hours to boil the shank-bones.
10136-8{_}19426{_}_Average cost_, from 4d.
10136-8{_}19427{_}to 6d.
10136-8{_}19428{_}each.
10136-8{_}19429{_}_Sufficient_.--2 cow-heels should make 3 pints of stock.
10136-8{_}19430{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19431{_}ISINGLASS OR GELATINE JELLY.
10136-8{_}19432{_}(_Substitutes for Calf's Feet_.)
10136-8{_}19433{_}1413.
10136-8{_}19434{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 oz.
10136-8{_}19435{_}of isinglass or gelatine, 2 quarts of water.
10136-8{_}19436{_}_Mode_.--Put the isinglass or gelatine into a saucepan with the above proportion of cold water; bring it quickly to boil, and let it boil very fast, until the liquor is reduced one-half.
10136-8{_}19437{_}Carefully remove the scum as it rises, then strain it through a jelly-bag, and it will be ready for use.
10136-8{_}19438{_}If not required very clear, it may be merely strained through a fine sieve, instead of being run through a bag.
10136-8{_}19439{_}Rather more than 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}19440{_}of isinglass is about the proper quantity to use for a quart of strong calf's-feet stock, and rather more than 2 oz.
10136-8{_}19441{_}for the same quantity of fruit juice.
10136-8{_}19442{_}As isinglass varies so much in quality and strength, it is difficult to give the exact proportions.
10136-8{_}19443{_}The larger the mould, the stiffer should be the jelly; and where there is no ice, more isinglass must be used than if the mixture were frozen.
10136-8{_}19444{_}This forms a stock for all kinds of jellies, which may be flavoured in many ways.
10136-8{_}19445{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}19446{_}_Sufficient_, with wine, syrup, fruit, &c., to fill two moderate-sized moulds.
10136-8{_}19447{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19448{_}_Note_.--The above, when boiled, should be perfectly clear, and may be mixed warm with wine, flavourings, fruits, &c., and then run through the bag.
10136-8{_}19449{_}ISINGLASS.--The best isinglass is brought from Russia; some of     an inferior kind is brought from North and South America and the     East Indies: the several varieties may be had from the wholesale     dealers in isinglass in London.
10136-8{_}19450{_}In choosing isinglass for     domestic use, select that which is whitest, has no unpleasant     odour, and which dissolves most readily in water.
10136-8{_}19451{_}The inferior     kinds are used for fining beer, and similar purposes.
10136-8{_}19452{_}Isinglass     is much adulterated: to test its purity, take a few threads of     the substance, drop some into boiling water, some into cold     water, and some into vinegar.
10136-8{_}19453{_}In the boiling water the isinglass     will dissolve, in cold water it will become white and "cloudy,"     and in vinegar it will swell and become jelly-like.
10136-8{_}19454{_}If the     isinglass is adulterated with gelatine (that is to say, the     commoner sorts of gelatine,--for isinglass is classed amongst     gelatines, of all which varieties it is the very purest and     best), in boiling water the gelatine will not so completely     dissolve as the isinglass; in cold water it becomes clear and     jelly-like; and in vinegar it will harden.
10136-8{_}19455{_}HOW TO MOULD BOTTLED JELLIES.
10136-8{_}19456{_}1414.
10136-8{_}19457{_}Uncork the bottle; place it in a saucepan of hot water until the jelly is reduced to a liquid state; taste it, to ascertain whether it is sufficiently flavoured, and if not, add a little wine.
10136-8{_}19458{_}Pour the jelly into moulds which have been soaked in water; let it set, and turn it out by placing the mould in hot water for a minute; then wipe the outside, put a dish on the top, and turn it over quickly.
10136-8{_}19459{_}The jelly should then slip easily away from the mould, and be quite firm.
10136-8{_}19460{_}It may be garnished as taste dictates.
10136-8{_}19461{_}TO CLARIFY SYRUP FOR JELLIES.
10136-8{_}19462{_}1415.
10136-8{_}19463{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every quart of water allow 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}19464{_}of loaf sugar; the white of 1 egg.
10136-8{_}19465{_}_Mode_.--Put the sugar and water into a stewpan; set it on the fire, and, when the sugar is dissolved, add the white of the egg, whipped up with a little water.
10136-8{_}19466{_}Whisk the whole well together, and simmer very gently until it has thrown up all the scum.
10136-8{_}19467{_}Take this off as it rises, strain the syrup through a fine sieve or cloth into a basin, and keep it for use.
10136-8{_}19468{_}CALF'S-FEET JELLY.
10136-8{_}19469{_}1416.
10136-8{_}19470{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 quart of calf's-feet stock No.
10136-8{_}19471{_}1411, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}19472{_}of sugar, 1/2 pint of sherry, 1 glass of brandy, the shells and whites of 5 eggs, the rind and juice of 2 lemons, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}19473{_}of isinglass.
10136-8{_}19474{_}_Mode_.--Prepare the stock as directed in recipe No.
10136-8{_}19475{_}1411, taking care to leave the sediment, and to remove all the fat from the surface.
10136-8{_}19476{_}Put it into a saucepan, cold, without clarifying it; add the remaining ingredients, and stir them well together before the saucepan is placed on the fire.
10136-8{_}19477{_}Then simmer the mixture gently for 1/4 hour, _but do not stir it after it begins to warm_.
10136-8{_}19478{_}Throw in a teacupful of cold water, boil for another 5 minutes, and keep the saucepan covered by the side of the fire for about 1/2 hour, but do not let it boil again.
10136-8{_}19479{_}In simmering, the head or scum may be carefully removed as it rises; but particular attention must be given to the jelly, that it be not stirred in the slightest degree after it is heated.
10136-8{_}19480{_}The isinglass should be added when the jelly begins to boil: this assists to clear it, and makes it firmer for turning out.
10136-8{_}19481{_}Wring out a jelly-bag in hot water; fasten it on to a stand, or the back of a chair; place it near the fire with a basin underneath it, and run the jelly through it.
10136-8{_}19482{_}Should it not be perfectly clear the first time, repeat the process until the desired brilliancy is obtained.
10136-8{_}19483{_}Soak the moulds in water, drain them for half a second, pour in the jelly, and put it in a cool place to set.
10136-8{_}19484{_}If ice is at hand, surround the moulds with it, and the jelly will set sooner, and be firmer when turned out.
10136-8{_}19485{_}In summer it is necessary to have ice in which to put the moulds, or the cook will be, very likely, disappointed, by her jellies being in too liquid a state to turn out properly, unless a great deal of isinglass is used.
10136-8{_}19486{_}When wanted for table, dip the moulds in hot water for a minute, wipe the outside with a cloth, lay a dish on the top of the mould, turn it quickly over, and the jelly should slip out easily.
10136-8{_}19487{_}It is sometimes served broken into square lumps, and piled high in glasses.
10136-8{_}19488{_}Earthenware moulds are preferable to those of pewter or tin, for red jellies, the colour and transparency of the composition being often spoiled by using the latter.
10136-8{_}19489{_}[Illustration: JELLY-MOULD.]
10136-8{_}19490{_}To make this jelly more economically, raisin wine may be substituted for the sherry and brandy, and the stock made from cow-heels, instead of calf's feet.
10136-8{_}19491{_}_Time_.--20 minutes to simmer the jelly, 1/2 hour to stand covered.
10136-8{_}19492{_}_Average cost_, reckoning the feet at 6d.
10136-8{_}19493{_}each, 3s.
10136-8{_}19494{_}6d.
10136-8{_}19495{_}_Sufficient_ to fill two 1-1/2-pint moulds.
10136-8{_}19496{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19497{_}_Note_.--As lemon-juice, unless carefully strained, is liable to make the jelly muddy, see that it is clear before it is added to the other ingredients.
10136-8{_}19498{_}Omit the brandy when the flavour is objected to.
10136-8{_}19499{_}SHERRY.--There are several kinds of sherry, as pale and brown, and there are various degrees of each.
10136-8{_}19500{_}Sherry is, in general, of an amber-colour, and, when good, has a fine aromatic odour, with something of the agreeable bitterness of the peach kernel.
10136-8{_}19501{_}When new, it is harsh and fiery, and requires to be mellowed in the wood for four or five years.
10136-8{_}19502{_}Sherry has of late got much into fashion in England, from the idea that it is more free from acid than other wines; but some careful experiments on wines do not fully confirm this opinion.
10136-8{_}19503{_}CANNELONS, or FRIED PUFFS.
10136-8{_}19504{_}(_Sweet Entremets_.)
10136-8{_}19505{_}1417.
10136-8{_}19506{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}19507{_}of puff-paste No.
10136-8{_}19508{_}1205; apricot, or any kind of preserve that may be preferred; hot lard.
10136-8{_}19509{_}_Mode_.--Cannelons which are made of puff-paste rolled very thin, with jam inclosed, and cut out in long narrow rolls or puffs, make a very pretty and elegant dish.
10136-8{_}19510{_}Make some good puff-paste, by recipe No.
10136-8{_}19511{_}1205; roll it out very thin, and cut it into pieces of an equal size, about 2 inches wide and 8 inches long; place upon each piece a spoonful of jam, wet the edges with the white of egg, and fold the paste over _twice;_ slightly press the edges together, that the jam may not escape in the frying; and when all are prepared, fry them in boiling lard until of a nice brown, letting them remain by the side of the fire after they are coloured, that the paste may be thoroughly done.
10136-8{_}19512{_}Drain them before the fire, dish on a d'oyley, sprinkle over them sifted sugar, and serve.
10136-8{_}19513{_}These cannelons are very delicious made with fresh instead of preserved fruit, such as strawberries, raspberries, or currants: it should be laid in the paste, plenty of pounded sugar sprinkled over, and folded and fried in the same manner as stated above.
10136-8{_}19514{_}_Time_.--About 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}19515{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}19516{_}_Sufficient_,--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}19517{_}of paste for a moderate-sized dish of cannelons.
10136-8{_}19518{_}_Seasonable_, with jam, at any time.
10136-8{_}19519{_}CHARLOTTE-AUX-POMMES.
10136-8{_}19520{_}1418.
10136-8{_}19521{_}INGREDIENTS.--A few slices of rather stale bread 1/2 inch thick, clarified butter, apple marmalade made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}19522{_}1395, with about 2 dozen apples, 1/2 glass of sherry.
10136-8{_}19523{_}[Illustration: CHARLOTTE-AUX-POMMES.]
10136-8{_}19524{_}_Mode_.--Cut a slice of bread the same shape as the bottom of a plain round mould, which has been well buttered, and a few strips the height of the mould, and about 1-1/2 inch wide; dip the bread in clarified butter (or spread it with cold butter, if not wanted quite so rich); place the round piece at the bottom of the mould, and set the narrow strips up the sides of it, overlapping each other a little, that no juice from the apples may escape, and that they may hold firmly to the mould.
10136-8{_}19525{_}Brush the _interior_ over with white of egg (this will assist to make the case firmer); fill it with apple marmalade made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}19526{_}1395, with the addition of a little sherry, and cover them with a round piece of bread, also brushed over with egg, the same as the bottom; slightly press the bread down, to make it adhere to the other pieces; put a plate on the top, and bake the _charlotte_ in a brisk oven, of a light colour.
10136-8{_}19527{_}Turn it out on the dish, strew sifted sugar over the top, and pour round it a little melted apricot jam.
10136-8{_}19528{_}_Time_.--40 to 50 minutes.
10136-8{_}19529{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}19530{_}9d.
10136-8{_}19531{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}19532{_}_Seasonable_ from July to March.
10136-8{_}19533{_}AN EASY METHOD OF MAKING A CHARLOTTE-AUX-POMMES.
10136-8{_}19534{_}1419.
10136-8{_}19535{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}19536{_}of flour, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}19537{_}of butter, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}19538{_}of powdered sugar, 1/2 teaspoonful of baking-powder, 1 egg, milk, 1 glass of raisin-wine, apple marmalade No.
10136-8{_}19539{_}1395, 1/4 pint of cream, 2 dessertspoonfuls of pounded sugar, 2 tablespoonfuls of lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}19540{_}_Mode_.--Make a cake with the flour, butter, sugar, and baking-powder; moisten with the egg and sufficient milk to make it the proper consistency, and bake it in a round tin.
10136-8{_}19541{_}When cold, scoop out the middle, leaving a good thickness all round the sides, to prevent them breaking; take some of the scooped-out pieces, which should be trimmed into neat slices; lay them in the cake, and pour over sufficient raisin-wine, with the addition of a little brandy, if approved, to soak them well.
10136-8{_}19542{_}Have ready some apple marmalade, made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}19543{_}1395; place a layer of this over the soaked cake, then a layer of cake and a layer of apples; whip the cream to a froth, mixing with it the sugar and lemon-juice; pile it on the top of the _charlotte_, and garnish it with pieces of clear apple jelly.
10136-8{_}19544{_}This dish is served cold, but may be eaten hot, by omitting the cream, and merely garnishing the top with bright jelly just before it is sent to table.
10136-8{_}19545{_}_Time_.--1 hour to bake the cake.
10136-8{_}19546{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}19547{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}19548{_}_Seasonable_ from July to March.
10136-8{_}19549{_}A VERY SIMPLE APPLE CHARLOTTE.
10136-8{_}19550{_}1420.
10136-8{_}19551{_}INGREDIENTS.--9 slices of bread and butter, about 6 good-sized apples, 1 tablespoonful of minced lemon-peel, 2 tablespoonfuls of juice, moist sugar to taste.
10136-8{_}19552{_}_Mode_.--Butter a pie-dish; place a layer of bread and butter, without the crust, at the bottom; then a layer of apples, pared, cored, and cut into thin slices; sprinkle over these a portion of the lemon-peel and juice, and sweeten with moist sugar.
10136-8{_}19553{_}Place another layer of bread and butter, and then one of apples, proceeding in this manner until the dish is full; then cover it up with the peel of the apples, to preserve the top from browning or burning; bake in a brisk oven for rather more than 3/4 hour; torn the charlotte on a dish, sprinkle sifted sugar over, and serve.
10136-8{_}19554{_}_Time_.--3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}19555{_}_Average cost_, 9d.
10136-8{_}19556{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}19557{_}_Seasonable_ from July to March.
10136-8{_}19558{_}CHARLOTTE RUSSE.
10136-8{_}19559{_}(_An Elegant Sweet Entremets_.)
10136-8{_}19560{_}1421.
10136-8{_}19561{_}INGREDIENTS.--About 18 Savoy biscuits, 3/4 pint of cream, flavouring of vanilla, liqueurs, or wine, 1 tablespoonful of pounded sugar, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}19562{_}of isinglass.
10136-8{_}19563{_}_Mode_.--Procure about 18 Savoy biscuits, or ladies'-fingers, as they are sometimes called; brush the edges of them with the white of an egg, and line the bottom of a plain round mould, placing them like a star or rosette.
10136-8{_}19564{_}Stand them upright all round the edge; carefully put them so closely together that the white of the egg connects them firmly, and place this case in the oven for about 5 minutes, just to dry the egg.
10136-8{_}19565{_}Whisk the cream to a stiff froth, with the sugar, flavouring, and melted isinglass; fill the charlotte with it, cover with a slice of sponge-cake cut in the shape of the mould; place it in ice, where let it remain till ready for table; then turn it on a dish, remove the mould, and serve.
10136-8{_}19566{_}1 tablespoonful of liqueur of any kind, or 4 tablespoonfuls of wine, would nicely flavour the above proportion of cream.
10136-8{_}19567{_}For arranging the biscuits in the mould, cut them to the shape required, so that they fit in nicely, and level them with the mould at the top, that, when turned out, there may be something firm to rest upon.
10136-8{_}19568{_}Great care and attention is required in the turning out of this dish, that the cream does not burst the case; and the edges of the biscuits must have the smallest quantity of egg brushed over them, or it would stick to the mould, and so prevent the charlotte from coming away properly.
10136-8{_}19569{_}_Time_.--5 minutes in the oven.
10136-8{_}19570{_}_Average cost_, with cream at 1s.
10136-8{_}19571{_}per pint, 2s.
10136-8{_}19572{_}_Sufficient_ for 1 charlotte.
10136-8{_}19573{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19574{_}CREAM A LA VALOIS.
10136-8{_}19575{_}1422.
10136-8{_}19576{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 sponge-cakes, jam, 3/4 pint of cream, sugar to taste, the juice of 1/2 lemon, 1/4 glass of sherry, 1-1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}19577{_}of isinglass.
10136-8{_}19578{_}_Mode_.--Cut the sponge-cakes into thin slices; place two together, with preserve between them, and pour over them a small quantity of sherry mixed with a little brandy.
10136-8{_}19579{_}Sweeten and flavour the cream with the lemon-juice and sherry; add the isinglass, which should be dissolved in a little water, and beat up the cream well.
10136-8{_}19580{_}Place a little in an oiled mould; arrange the pieces of cake in the cream; then fill the mould with the remainder; let it cool, and turn it out on a dish.
10136-8{_}19581{_}By oiling the mould, the cream will have a much smoother appearance, and will turn out more easily than when merely dipped in cold water.
10136-8{_}19582{_}_Average cost_, 3s.
10136-8{_}19583{_}6d.
10136-8{_}19584{_}_Sufficient_ to fill a 1-1/2 pint mould.
10136-8{_}19585{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19586{_}BOILED CUSTARDS.
10136-8{_}19587{_}1423.
10136-8{_}19588{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint of milk, 5 eggs, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}19589{_}of loaf sugar, 3 laurel-leaves, or the rind of 4 lemon, or a few drops of essence of vanilla, 1 tablespoonful of brandy.
10136-8{_}19590{_}[Illustration: CUSTARDS IN GLASSES.]
10136-8{_}19591{_}_Mode_.--Put the milk into a lined saucepan, with the sugar, and whichever of the above flavourings may be preferred (the lemon-rind flavours custards most deliciously), and let the milk steep by the side of the fire until it is well flavoured.
10136-8{_}19592{_}Bring it to the point of boiling, then strain it into a basin; whisk the eggs well, and, when the milk has cooled a little, stir in the eggs, and _strain_ this mixture into a jug.
10136-8{_}19593{_}Place this jug in a saucepan of boiling water over the fire; keep stirring the custard _one way_ until it thickens; but on no account allow it to reach the boiling-point, as it will instantly curdle and be full of lumps.
10136-8{_}19594{_}Take it off the fire, stir in the brandy, and, when this is well mixed with the custard, pour it into glasses, which should be rather more than three-parts full; grate a little nutmeg over the top, and the dish is ready for table.
10136-8{_}19595{_}To make custards look and eat better, ducks' eggs should be used, when obtainable; they add very much to the flavour and richness, and so many are not required as of the ordinary eggs, 4 ducks' eggs to the pint of milk making a delicious custard.
10136-8{_}19596{_}When desired extremely rich and good, cream should be substituted for the milk, and double the quantity of eggs used, to those mentioned, omitting the whites.
10136-8{_}19597{_}_Time_.
10136-8{_}19598{_}1/2 hour to infuse the lemon-rind, about 10 minutes to stir the custard.
10136-8{_}19599{_}_Average cost_, 8d.
10136-8{_}19600{_}_Sufficient_ to fill 8 custard-glasses.
10136-8{_}19601{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19602{_}GINGER APPLES.
10136-8{_}19603{_}(_A pretty Supper or Dessert Dish_.)
10136-8{_}19604{_}1424.
10136-8{_}19605{_}INGREDIENTS.--1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}19606{_}of whole ginger, 1/4 pint of whiskey, 3 lbs.
10136-8{_}19607{_}of apples, 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}19608{_}of white sugar, the juice of 2 lemons.
10136-8{_}19609{_}_Mode_.--Bruise the ginger, put it into a small jar, pour over sufficient whiskey to cover it, and let it remain for 3 days; then cut the apples into thin slices, after paring and coring them; add the sugar and the lemon-juice, which should he strained; and simmer all together _very gently_ until the apples are transparent, but not broken.
10136-8{_}19610{_}Serve cold, and garnish the dish with slices of candied lemon-peel or preserved ginger.
10136-8{_}19611{_}_Time_.--3 days to soak the ginger; about 3/4 hour to simmer the apples very gently.
10136-8{_}19612{_}_Average cost_, 2s, 6d.
10136-8{_}19613{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 dishes.
10136-8{_}19614{_}_Seasonable_ from July to March.
10136-8{_}19615{_}FRENCH PANCAKES.
10136-8{_}19616{_}1425.
10136-8{_}19617{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 eggs, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}19618{_}of butter, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}19619{_}of sifted sugar, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}19620{_}of flour, 1/2 pint of new milk.
10136-8{_}19621{_}_Mode_.--Beat the eggs thoroughly, and put them into a basin with the butter, which should be beaten to a cream; stir in the sugar and flour, and when these ingredients are well mixed, add the milk; keep stirring and beating the mixture for a few minutes; put it on buttered plates, and bake in a quick oven for 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}19622{_}Serve with a cut lemon and sifted sugar, or pile the pancakes high on a dish, with a layer of preserve or marmalade between each.
10136-8{_}19623{_}_Time_.--20 minutes.
10136-8{_}19624{_}_Average cost_, 7d.
10136-8{_}19625{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 or 4 persons.
10136-8{_}19626{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19627{_}DUTCH FLUMMERY.
10136-8{_}19628{_}1426.
10136-8{_}19629{_}INGREDIENTS.--1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}19630{_}of isinglass, the rind and juice of 1 lemon, 1 pint of water, 4 eggs, 1 pint of sherry, Madeira, or raisin-wine; sifted sugar to taste.
10136-8{_}19631{_}_Mode_.--Put the water, isinglass, and lemon-rind into a lined saucepan, and simmer gently until the isinglass is dissolved; strain this into a basin, stir in the eggs, which should be well beaten, the lemon-juice, which should be strained, and the wine; sweeten to taste with pounded sugar, mix all well together, pour it into a jug, set this jug in a saucepan of boiling water over the fire, and keep stirring it one way until it thickens; but _take care that it does not boil_.
10136-8{_}19632{_}Strain it into a mould that has been oiled or laid in water for a short time, and put it in a cool place to set.
10136-8{_}19633{_}A tablespoonful of brandy stirred in just before it is poured into the mould, improves the flavour of this dish: it is better if made the day before it is required for table.
10136-8{_}19634{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour to simmer the isinglass; about 1/4 hour to stir the mixture over the fire.
10136-8{_}19635{_}_Average cost_, 4s.
10136-8{_}19636{_}6d., if made with sherry; less with raisin-wine.
10136-8{_}19637{_}_Sufficient_ to fill a quart mould.
10136-8{_}19638{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19639{_}PALE SHERRIES are made from the same grapes as brown.
10136-8{_}19640{_}The latter     are coloured by an addition of some cheap must, or wine which     has been boiled till it has acquired a deep-brown tint.
10136-8{_}19641{_}Pale     sherries were, some time ago, preferred in England, being     supposed most pure; but the brown are preferred by many people.
10136-8{_}19642{_}The inferior sherries exported to England are often mixed with a     cheap and light wine called Moguer, and are strengthened in the     making by brandy; but too frequently they are adulterated by the     London dealers.
10136-8{_}19643{_}CHOCOLATE SOUFFLE.
10136-8{_}19644{_}1427.
10136-8{_}19645{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 eggs, 3 teaspoonfuls of pounded sugar, 1 teaspoonful of flour, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}19646{_}of the best chocolate.
10136-8{_}19647{_}_Mode_.--Break the eggs, separating the whites from the yolks, and put them into different basins; add to the yolks the sugar, flour, and chocolate, which should be very finely grated, and stir these ingredients for 5 minutes.
10136-8{_}19648{_}Then well whisk the whites of the eggs in the other basin, until they are stiff, and, when firm, mix lightly with the yolks, till the whole forms a smooth and light substance; butter a round cake-tin, put in the mixture, and bake in a moderate oven from 15 to 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}19649{_}Pin a white napkin round the tin, strew sifted sugar over the top of the soufflé, and send it immediately to table.
10136-8{_}19650{_}The proper appearance of this dish depends entirely on the expedition with which it is served, and some cooks, to preserve its lightness, hold a salamander over the soufflé until it is placed on the table.
10136-8{_}19651{_}If allowed to stand after it comes from the oven, it will be entirely spoiled, as it falls almost immediately.
10136-8{_}19652{_}_Time_.--15 to 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}19653{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}19654{_}_Sufficient_ for a moderate-sized soufflé.
10136-8{_}19655{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19656{_}DARIOLES A LA VANILLE.
10136-8{_}19657{_}(_Sweet Entremets_.)
10136-8{_}19658{_}1428.
10136-8{_}19659{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of milk, 1/2 pint of cream, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}19660{_}of flour, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}19661{_}of pounded sugar, 6 eggs, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}19662{_}of butter, puff-paste, flavouring of essence of vanilla.
10136-8{_}19663{_}_Mode_.--Mix the flour to a smooth batter, with the milk; stir in the cream, sugar, the eggs, which should be well whisked, and the butter, which should be beaten to a cream.
10136-8{_}19664{_}Put in some essence of vanilla, drop by drop, until the mixture is well flavoured; line some dariole-moulds with puff-paste, three-parts fill them with the batter, and bake in a good oven from 25 to 35 minutes.
10136-8{_}19665{_}Turn them out of the moulds on a dish, without breaking them; strew over sifted sugar, and serve.
10136-8{_}19666{_}The flavouring of the darioles may be varied by substituting lemon, cinnamon, or almonds, for the vanilla.
10136-8{_}19667{_}_Time_.--25 to 35 minutes.
10136-8{_}19668{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}19669{_}8d.
10136-8{_}19670{_}_Sufficient_ to fill 6 or 7 dariole-moulds.
10136-8{_}19671{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19672{_}CURRANT FRITTERS.
10136-8{_}19673{_}1429.
10136-8{_}19674{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of milk, 2 tablespoonfuls of flour, 4 eggs, 3 tablespoonfuls of boiled rice, 3 tablespoonfuls of currants, sugar to taste, a very little grated nutmeg, hot lard or clarified dripping.
10136-8{_}19675{_}_Mode_.--Put the milk into a basin with the flour, which should previously be rubbed to a smooth batter with a little cold milk; stir these ingredients together; add the well-whisked eggs, the rice, currants, sugar, and nutmeg.
10136-8{_}19676{_}Beat the mixture for a few minutes, and, if not sufficiently thick, add a little more boiled rice; drop it, in small quantities, into a pan of boiling lard or clarified dripping; fry the fritters a nice brown, and, when done, drain them on a piece of blotting-paper, before the fire.
10136-8{_}19677{_}Pile them on a white d'oyley, strew over sifted sugar, and serve them very hot.
10136-8{_}19678{_}Send a cut lemon to table with them.
10136-8{_}19679{_}_Time_.--From 8 to 10 minutes to fry the fritters.
10136-8{_}19680{_}_Average cost_, 9d.
10136-8{_}19681{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 or 4 persons.
10136-8{_}19682{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19683{_}CHOCOLATE CREAM.
10136-8{_}19684{_}1430.
10136-8{_}19685{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 oz.
10136-8{_}19686{_}of grated chocolate, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}19687{_}of sugar, 1-1/2 pint of cream, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}19688{_}of clarified isinglass, the yolks of 6 eggs.
10136-8{_}19689{_}[Illustration: CREAM-MOULD.]
10136-8{_}19690{_}_Mode_.--Beat the yolks of the eggs well; put them into a basin with the grated chocolate, the sugar, and 1 pint of the cream; stir these ingredients well together, pour them into a jug, and set this jug in a saucepan of boiling water; stir it one way until the mixture thickens, but _do not allow it to boil_, or it will curdle.
10136-8{_}19691{_}Strain the cream through a sieve into a basin; stir in the isinglass and the other 1/2 pint of cream, which should be well whipped; mix all well together, and pour it into a mould which has been previously oiled with the purest salad-oil, and, if at hand, set it in ice until wanted for table.
10136-8{_}19692{_}_Time_.--About 10 minutes to stir the mixture over the fire.
10136-8{_}19693{_}_Average cost_, 4s.
10136-8{_}19694{_}6d, with cream at 1s.
10136-8{_}19695{_}per pint.
10136-8{_}19696{_}_Sufficient_ to fill a quart mould.
10136-8{_}19697{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19698{_}GENEVA WAFERS.
10136-8{_}19699{_}1431.
10136-8{_}19700{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 eggs, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}19701{_}of butter, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}19702{_}of flour, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}19703{_}of pounded sugar.
10136-8{_}19704{_}_Mode_.--Well whisk the eggs; put them into a basin, and stir to them the butter, which should be beaten to a cream; add the flour and sifted sugar gradually, and then mix all well together.
10136-8{_}19705{_}Butter a baking-sheet, and drop on it a teaspoonful of the mixture at a time, leaving a space between each.
10136-8{_}19706{_}Bake in a cool oven; watch the pieces of paste, and, when half done, roll them up like wafers, and put in a small wedge of bread or piece of wood, to keep them in shape.
10136-8{_}19707{_}Return them to the oven until crisp.
10136-8{_}19708{_}Before serving, remove the bread, put a spoonful of preserve in the widest end, and fill up with whipped cream.
10136-8{_}19709{_}This is a very pretty and ornamental dish for the supper-table, and is very nice and very easily made.
10136-8{_}19710{_}_Time_.--Altogether 20 to 25 minutes.
10136-8{_}19711{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the preserve and cream, 7d.
10136-8{_}19712{_}_Sufficient_ for a nice-sized dish.
10136-8{_}19713{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19714{_}GINGER CREAM.
10136-8{_}19715{_}1432.
10136-8{_}19716{_}INGREDIENTS.--The yolks of 4 eggs, 1 pint of cream, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}19717{_}of preserved ginger, 2 dessertspoonfuls of syrup, sifted sugar to taste, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}19718{_}of isinglass.
10136-8{_}19719{_}_Mode_.--Slice the ginger finely; put it into a basin with the syrup, the well-beaten yolks of eggs, and the cream; mix these ingredients well together, and stir them over the fire for about 10 minutes, or until the mixture thickens; then take it off the fire, whisk till nearly cold, sweeten to taste, add the isinglass, which should be melted and strained, and serve the cream in a glass dish.
10136-8{_}19720{_}It may be garnished with slices of preserved ginger or candied citron.
10136-8{_}19721{_}_Time_.--About 10 minutes to stir the cream over the fire.
10136-8{_}19722{_}_Average cost_, with cream at 1s.
10136-8{_}19723{_}per pint, 3s.
10136-8{_}19724{_}6d.
10136-8{_}19725{_}_Sufficient_ for a good-sized dish.
10136-8{_}19726{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19727{_}PRESERVED GINGER comes to us from the West Indies.
10136-8{_}19728{_}It is made by     scalding the roots when they are green and full of sap, then     peeling them in cold water, and putting them into jars, with a     rich syrup; in which state we receive them.
10136-8{_}19729{_}It should be chosen     of a bright-yellow colour, with a little transparency: what is     dark-coloured, fibrous, and stringy, is not good.
10136-8{_}19730{_}Ginger roots,     fit for preserving, and in size equal to West Indian, have been     produced in the Royal Agricultural Garden in Edinburgh.
10136-8{_}19731{_}TO MAKE GOOSEBERRY FOOL.
10136-8{_}19732{_}1433.
10136-8{_}19733{_}INGREDIENTS.--Green gooseberries; to every pint of pulp add 1 pint of milk, or 1/2 pint of cream and 1/2 pint of milk; sugar to taste.
10136-8{_}19734{_}_Mode_.--Cut the tops and tails off the gooseberries; put them into a jar, with 2 tablespoonfuls of water and a little good moist sugar; set this jar in a saucepan of boiling water, and let it boil until the fruit is soft enough to mash.
10136-8{_}19735{_}When done enough, beat it to a pulp, work this pulp through a colander, and stir to every pint the above proportion of milk, or equal quantities of milk and cream.
10136-8{_}19736{_}Ascertain if the mixture is sweet enough, and put in plenty of sugar, or it will not be eatable; and in mixing the milk and gooseberries, add the former very gradually to these: serve in a glass dish, or in small glasses.
10136-8{_}19737{_}This, although a very old-fashioned and homely dish, is, when well made, very delicious, and, if properly sweetened, a very suitable preparation for children.
10136-8{_}19738{_}_Time_.--From 3/4 to 1 hour.
10136-8{_}19739{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}19740{_}per pint, with milk.
10136-8{_}19741{_}_Sufficient_.--A pint of milk and a pint of gooseberry pulp for 5 or 6 children.
10136-8{_}19742{_}_Seasonable_ in May and June.
10136-8{_}19743{_}GOOSEBERRY TRIFLE.
10136-8{_}19744{_}1434.
10136-8{_}19745{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 quart of gooseberries, sugar to taste, 1 pint of custard No.
10136-8{_}19746{_}1423, a plateful of whipped cream.
10136-8{_}19747{_}_Mode_.--Put the gooseberries into a jar, with sufficient moist sugar to sweeten them, and boil them until reduced to a pulp.
10136-8{_}19748{_}Put this pulp at the bottom of a trifle-dish; pour over it a pint of custard made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}19749{_}1423, and, when cold, cover with whipped cream.
10136-8{_}19750{_}The cream should be whipped the day before it is wanted for table, as it will then be so much firmer and more solid.
10136-8{_}19751{_}The dish may be garnished as fancy dictates.
10136-8{_}19752{_}_Time_.--About 3/4 hour to boil the gooseberries.
10136-8{_}19753{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}19754{_}6d.
10136-8{_}19755{_}_Sufficient_ for 1 trifle.
10136-8{_}19756{_}_Seasonable_ in May and June.
10136-8{_}19757{_}INDIAN FRITTERS.
10136-8{_}19758{_}1435.
10136-8{_}19759{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 tablespoonfuls of flour, boiling water, the yolks of 4 eggs, the whites of 2, hot lard or clarified dripping, jam.
10136-8{_}19760{_}_Mode_.--Put the flour into a basin, and pour over it sufficient _boiling_ water to make it into a stiff paste, taking care to stir and beat it well, to prevent it getting lumpy.
10136-8{_}19761{_}Leave it a little time to cool, and then break into it (_without beating them at first_) the yolks of 4 eggs and the whites of 2, and stir and beat all well together.
10136-8{_}19762{_}Have ready some boiling lard or butter; drop a dessertspoonful of batter in at a time, and fry the fritters of a light brown.
10136-8{_}19763{_}They should rise so much as to be almost like balls.
10136-8{_}19764{_}Serve on a dish, with a spoonful of preserve or marmalade dropped in between each fritter.
10136-8{_}19765{_}This is an excellent dish for a hasty addition to dinner, if a guest unexpectedly arrives, it being so easily and quickly made, and it is always a great favourite.
10136-8{_}19766{_}_Time_.--From 5 to 8 minutes to fry the fritters.
10136-8{_}19767{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the jam, 5d.
10136-8{_}19768{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}19769{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19770{_}INDIAN TRIFLE.
10136-8{_}19771{_}1436.
10136-8{_}19772{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 quart of milk, the rind of 1/2 large lemon, sugar to taste, 5 heaped tablespoonfuls of rice-flour, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}19773{_}of sweet almonds, 1/2 pint of custard.
10136-8{_}19774{_}_Mode_.--Boil the milk and lemon-rind together until the former is well flavoured; take out the lemon-rind and stir in the rice-flour, which should first be moistened with cold milk, and add sufficient loaf sugar to sweeten it nicely.
10136-8{_}19775{_}Boil gently for about 5 minutes, and keep the mixture stirred; take it off the fire, let it cool _a little_, and pour it into a glass dish.
10136-8{_}19776{_}When cold, cut the rice out in the form of a star, or any other shape that may be preferred; take out the spare rice, and fill the space with boiled custard.
10136-8{_}19777{_}Blanch and cut the almonds into strips; stick them over the trifle, and garnish it with pieces of brightly-coloured jelly, or preserved fruits, or candied citron.
10136-8{_}19778{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour to simmer the milk, 5 minutes after the rice is added.
10136-8{_}19779{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}19780{_}_Sufficient_ for 1 trifle.
10136-8{_}19781{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19782{_}[Illustration: THE CITRON.]
10136-8{_}19783{_}THE CITRON.--The citron belongs to the same species as the     lemon, being considered only as a variety, the distinction     between them not being very great.
10136-8{_}19784{_}It is larger, and is less     succulent, but more acid: with a little artificial heat, the     citron comes to as great perfection in England as in Spain and     Italy.
10136-8{_}19785{_}The fruit is oblong and about five or six inches in     length.
10136-8{_}19786{_}The tree is thorny.
10136-8{_}19787{_}The juice forms an excellent     lemonade with sugar and water; its uses in punch, negus, and in     medicine, are well known.
10136-8{_}19788{_}The rind is very thick, and, when     candied with sugar, forms an excellent sweetmeat.
10136-8{_}19789{_}There are     several varieties cultivated in England, one of which is termed     the Forbidden Fruit.
10136-8{_}19790{_}ITALIAN CREAM.
10136-8{_}19791{_}1437.
10136-8{_}19792{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint of milk, 4 pint of cream, sugar to taste, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}19793{_}of isinglass, 1 lemon, the yolks of 4 eggs.
10136-8{_}19794{_}_Mode_.--Put the cream and milk into a saucepan, with sugar to sweeten, and the lemon-rind.
10136-8{_}19795{_}Boil until the milk is well flavoured then strain it into a basin, and add the beaten yolks of eggs.
10136-8{_}19796{_}Put this mixture into a jug; place the jug in a saucepan of boiling water over the fire, and stir the contents until they thicken, but do not allow them to boil.
10136-8{_}19797{_}Take the cream off the fire, stir in the lemon-juice and isinglass, which should be melted, and whip well; fill a mould, place it in ice if at hand, and, when set, turn it out on a dish, and garnish as taste may dictate.
10136-8{_}19798{_}The mixture may be whipped and drained, and then put into small glasses, when this mode of serving is preferred.
10136-8{_}19799{_}_Time_.--From 5 to 8 minutes to stir the mixture in the jug.
10136-8{_}19800{_}_Average cost_, with the best isinglass, 2s.
10136-8{_}19801{_}6d.
10136-8{_}19802{_}_Sufficient_ to fill 1-1/2-pint mould.
10136-8{_}19803{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19804{_}THE HIDDEN MOUNTAIN.
10136-8{_}19805{_}(_A pretty Supper Dish_.)
10136-8{_}19806{_}1438.
10136-8{_}19807{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 eggs, a few slices of citron, sugar to taste, 1/4 pint of cream, a layer of any kind of jam.
10136-8{_}19808{_}_Mode_.--Beat the whites and yolks of the eggs separately; then mix them and beat well again, adding a few thin slices of citron, the cream, and sufficient pounded sugar to sweeten it nicely.
10136-8{_}19809{_}When the mixture is well beaten, put it into a buttered pan, and fry the same as a pancake; but it should be three times the thickness of an ordinary pancake.
10136-8{_}19810{_}Cover it with jam, and garnish with slices of citron and holly-leaves.
10136-8{_}19811{_}This dish is served cold.
10136-8{_}19812{_}_Time_.--About 10 minutes to fry the mixture.
10136-8{_}19813{_}_Average cost_, with the jam, 1s.
10136-8{_}19814{_}4d.
10136-8{_}19815{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 or 4 persons.
10136-8{_}19816{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19817{_}JAUNEMANGE.
10136-8{_}19818{_}1439.
10136-8{_}19819{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 oz.
10136-8{_}19820{_}of isinglass, 1 pint of water, 1/2 pint of white wine, the rind and juice of 1 large lemon, sugar to taste, the yolks of 6 eggs.
10136-8{_}19821{_}_Mode_.--Put the isinglass, water, and lemon-rind into a saucepan, and boil gently until the former is dissolved; then add the strained lemon-juice, the wine, and sufficient white sugar to sweeten the whole nicely.
10136-8{_}19822{_}Boil for 2 or 3 minutes, strain the mixture into a jug, and add the yolks of the eggs, which should be well beaten; place the jug in a saucepan of boiling water; keep stirring the mixture _one way_ until it thickens, _but do not allow it to boil_; then take it off the fire, and keep stirring until nearly cold.
10136-8{_}19823{_}Pour it into a mould, omitting the sediment at the bottom of the jug, and let it remain until quite firm.
10136-8{_}19824{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour to boil the isinglass and water; about 10 minutes to stir the mixture in the jug.
10136-8{_}19825{_}_Average cost_, with the best isinglass, 2s.
10136-8{_}19826{_}9d.
10136-8{_}19827{_}_Sufficient_ to fill a quart mould.
10136-8{_}19828{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19829{_}JELLY MOULDED WITH FRESH FRUIT, or MACEDOINE DE FRUITS.
10136-8{_}19830{_}1440.
10136-8{_}19831{_}INGREDIENTS.--Rather more than 1-1/2 pint of jelly, a few nice strawberries, or red or white currants, or raspberries, or any fresh fruit that may be in season.
10136-8{_}19832{_}_Mode_.--Have ready the above proportion of jelly, which must be very clear and rather sweet, the raw fruit requiring an additional quantity of sugar.
10136-8{_}19833{_}Select ripe, nice-looking fruit; pick off the stalks, unless currants are used, when they are laid in the jelly as they come from the tree.
10136-8{_}19834{_}Begin by putting a little jelly at the bottom of the mould, which must harden; then arrange the fruit round the sides of the mould, recollecting; that _it will be reversed when turned out;_ then pour in some more jelly to make the fruit adhere, and, when that layer is set, put another row of fruit and jelly until the mould is full.
10136-8{_}19835{_}If convenient, put it in ice until required for table, then wring a cloth in boiling water, wrap it round the mould for a minute, and turn the jelly carefully out.
10136-8{_}19836{_}Peaches, apricots, plums, apples, &c., are better for being boiled in a little clear syrup before they are laid in the jelly; strawberries, raspberries, grapes, cherries, and currants are put in raw.
10136-8{_}19837{_}In winter, when fresh fruits are not obtainable, a very pretty jelly may be made with preserved fruits or brandy cherries: these, in a bright and clear jelly, have a very pretty effect; of course, unless the jelly be _very clear_, the beauty of the dish will be spoiled.
10136-8{_}19838{_}It may be garnished with the same fruit as is laid in the jelly; for instance, an open jelly with strawberries might have, piled in the centre, a few of the same fruit prettily arranged, or a little whipped cream might be substituted for the fruit.
10136-8{_}19839{_}[Illustration: JELLY MOULDED WITH CHERRIES.]
10136-8{_}19840{_}_Time_.--One layer of jelly should remain 2 hours in a very cool place, before another layer is added.
10136-8{_}19841{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}19842{_}6d.
10136-8{_}19843{_}_Sufficient_, with fruit, to fill a quart mould.
10136-8{_}19844{_}_Seasonable_, with fresh fruit, from June to October; with dried, at any time.
10136-8{_}19845{_}JELLY OF TWO COLOURS.
10136-8{_}19846{_}1441.
10136-8{_}19847{_}INGREDIENTS.--1-1/2 pint of calf's-feet jelly No.
10136-8{_}19848{_}1416, a few drops of prepared cochineal.
10136-8{_}19849{_}[Illustration: JELLY OF TWO COLOURS.]
10136-8{_}19850{_}_Mode_.--Make 1-1/2 pint of jelly by recipe No.
10136-8{_}19851{_}1416, or, if wished more economical, of clarified syrup and gelatine, flavouring it in any way that may be preferred.
10136-8{_}19852{_}Colour one-half of the jelly with a few drops of prepared cochineal, and the other half leave as pale as possible.
10136-8{_}19853{_}Have ready a mould well wetted in every part; pour in a small quantity of the red jelly, and let this set; when quite firm, pour on it the same quantity of the pale jelly, and let this set; then proceed in this manner until the mould is full, always taking care to let one jelly set before the other is poured in, or the colours would run one into the other.
10136-8{_}19854{_}When turned out, the jelly should have a striped appearance.
10136-8{_}19855{_}For variety, half the mould may be filled at once with one of the jellies, and, when firm, filled up with the other: this, also, has a very pretty effect, and is more expeditiously prepared than when the jelly is poured in small quantities into the mould.
10136-8{_}19856{_}Blancmange and red jelly, or blancmange and raspberry cream, moulded in the above manner, look very well.
10136-8{_}19857{_}The layers of blancmange and jelly should be about an inch in depth, and each layer should be perfectly hardened before another is added.
10136-8{_}19858{_}Half a mould of blancmange and half a mould of jelly are frequently served in the same manner.
10136-8{_}19859{_}A few pretty dishes may be made, in this way, of jellies or blancmanges left from the preceding day, by melting them separately in a jug placed in a saucepan of boiling water, and then moulding them by the foregoing directions.
10136-8{_}19860{_}(See coloured plate S1.)
10136-8{_}19861{_}_Time_.--3/4 hour to make the jelly.
10136-8{_}19862{_}_Average cost_, with calf's-feet jelly, 2s.
10136-8{_}19863{_}; with gelatine and syrup, more economical.
10136-8{_}19864{_}_Sufficient_ to fill 1-1/2 pint mould.
10136-8{_}19865{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19866{_}_Note_.--In making the jelly, use for flavouring a very pale sherry, or the colour will be too dark to contrast nicely with the red jelly.
10136-8{_}19867{_}LEMON BLANCMANGE.
10136-8{_}19868{_}1442.
10136-8{_}19869{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 quart of milk, the yolks of 4 eggs, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}19870{_}of ground rice, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}19871{_}of pounded sugar, 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}19872{_}of fresh butter, the rind of 1 lemon, the juice of 2, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}19873{_}of gelatine.
10136-8{_}19874{_}[Illustration: BLANCMANGE MOULD.]
10136-8{_}19875{_}_Mode_.--Make a custard with the yolks of the eggs and 1/2 pint of the milk, and, when done, put it into a basin: put half the remainder of the milk into a saucepan with the ground rice, fresh butter, lemon-rind, and 3 oz.
10136-8{_}19876{_}of the sugar, and let these ingredients boil until the mixture is stiff, stirring them continually; when done, pour it into the bowl where the custard is, mixing both well together.
10136-8{_}19877{_}Put the gelatine with the rest of the milk into a saucepan, and let it stand by the side of the fire to dissolve; boil for a minute or two, stir carefully into the basin, adding 3 oz.
10136-8{_}19878{_}more of pounded sugar.
10136-8{_}19879{_}When cold, stir in the lemon-juice, which should be carefully strained, and pour the mixture into a well-oiled mould, leaving out the lemon-peel, and set the mould in a pan of cold water until wanted for table.
10136-8{_}19880{_}Use eggs that have rich-looking yolks; and, should the weather be very warm, rather a larger proportion of gelatine must be allowed.
10136-8{_}19881{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 1 hour.
10136-8{_}19882{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}19883{_}6d.
10136-8{_}19884{_}_Sufficient_ to fill 2 small moulds.
10136-8{_}19885{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19886{_}LEMON CREAM.
10136-8{_}19887{_}1443.
10136-8{_}19888{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint of cream, the yolks of 2 eggs, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}19889{_}of white sugar, 1 large lemon, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}19890{_}of isinglass.
10136-8{_}19891{_}[Illustration: LEMON-CREAM MOULD.]
10136-8{_}19892{_}_Mode_.--Put the cream into a _lined_ saucepan with the sugar, lemon-peel, and isinglass, and simmer these over a gentle fire for about 10 minutes, stirring them all the time.
10136-8{_}19893{_}Strain the cream into a jug, add the yolks of eggs, which should be well beaten, and put the jug into a saucepan of boiling water; stir the mixture one way until it thickens, _but do not allow it to boil_; take it off the fire, and keep stirring it until nearly cold.
10136-8{_}19894{_}Strain the lemon-juice into a basin, gradually pour on it the cream, and _stir it well_ until the juice is well mixed with it.
10136-8{_}19895{_}Have ready a well-oiled mould, pour the cream into it, and let it remain until perfectly set.
10136-8{_}19896{_}When required for table, loosen the edges with a small blunt knife, put a dish on the top of the mould, turn it over quickly, and the cream should easily slip away.
10136-8{_}19897{_}_Time_.--10 minutes to boil the cream; about 10 minutes to stir it over the fire in the jug.
10136-8{_}19898{_}_Average cost_, with cream at 1s.
10136-8{_}19899{_}per pint, and the best isinglass, 2s.
10136-8{_}19900{_}6d.
10136-8{_}19901{_}_Sufficient_ to fill 1-1/2-pint mould.
10136-8{_}19902{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19903{_}ECONOMICAL LEMON CREAM.
10136-8{_}19904{_}1444.
10136-8{_}19905{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 quart of milk, 8 bitter almonds, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}19906{_}of gelatine, 2 large lemons, 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}19907{_}of lump sugar, the yolks of 6 eggs.
10136-8{_}19908{_}_Mode_.--Put the milk into a lined saucepan with the almonds, which should be well pounded in a mortar, the gelatine, lemon-rind, and lump sugar, and boil these ingredients for about 5 minutes.
10136-8{_}19909{_}Beat up the yolks of the eggs, strain the milk into a jug, add the eggs, and pour the mixture backwards and forwards a few times, until nearly cold; then stir briskly to it the lemon-juice, which should be strained, and keep stirring until the cream is almost cold: put it into an oiled mould, and let it remain until perfectly set.
10136-8{_}19910{_}The lemon-juice must not be added to the cream when it is warm, and should be well stirred after it is put in.
10136-8{_}19911{_}_Time_.--5 minutes to boil the milk.
10136-8{_}19912{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}19913{_}5d.
10136-8{_}19914{_}_Sufficient_ to fill two 1-1/2-pint moulds.
10136-8{_}19915{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19916{_}LEMON CREAMS.
10136-8{_}19917{_}(_Very good_.)
10136-8{_}19918{_}1445.
10136-8{_}19919{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint of cream, 2 dozen sweet almonds, 3 glasses of sherry, the rind and juice of 2 lemons, sugar to taste.
10136-8{_}19920{_}_Mode_.--Blanch and chop the almonds, and put them into a jug with the cream; in another jug put the sherry, lemon-rind, strained juice, and sufficient pounded sugar to sweeten the whole nicely.
10136-8{_}19921{_}Pour rapidly from one jug to the other till the mixture is well frothed; then, pour it into jelly-glasses, omitting the lemon-rind.
10136-8{_}19922{_}This is a very cool and delicious sweet for summer, and may be made less rich by omitting the almonds and substituting orange or raisin wine for the sherry.
10136-8{_}19923{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}19924{_}_Average cost_, with cream at 1s.
10136-8{_}19925{_}per pint, 3s.
10136-8{_}19926{_}_Sufficient_ to fill 12 glasses.
10136-8{_}19927{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19928{_}LEMON CREAMS OF CUSTARDS.
10136-8{_}19929{_}1446.
10136-8{_}19930{_}INGREDIENTS.--5 oz.
10136-8{_}19931{_}of loaf sugar, 2 pints of boiling water, the rind of 1 lemon and the juice of 3, the yolks of 8 eggs.
10136-8{_}19932{_}_Mode_.--Make a quart of lemonade in the following manner:--Dissolve the sugar in the boiling water, having previously, with part of the sugar, rubbed off the lemon-rind, and add the strained juice.
10136-8{_}19933{_}Strain the lemonade into a saucepan, and add the yolks of the eggs, which should be well beaten; stir this _one way_ over the fire until the mixture thickens, but do not allow it to boil, and serve in custard-glasses, or on a glass dish.
10136-8{_}19934{_}After the boiling water is poured on the sugar and lemon, it should stand covered for about 1/2 hour before the eggs are added to it, that the flavour of the rind may be extracted.
10136-8{_}19935{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour to make the lemonade; about 10 minutes to stir the custard over the fire.
10136-8{_}19936{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}19937{_}_Sufficient_ to fill 12 to 14 custard-glasses.
10136-8{_}19938{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19939{_}LEMON JELLY.
10136-8{_}19940{_}1447.
10136-8{_}19941{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 lemons, 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}19942{_}of lump sugar, 1 pint of water, 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}19943{_}of isinglass, 1/4 pint of sherry.
10136-8{_}19944{_}_Mode_.--Peel 3 of the lemons, pour 1/2 pint of boiling water on the rind, and let it infuse for 1/2 hour; put the sugar, isinglass, and 1/2 pint of water into a lined saucepan, and boil these ingredients for 20 minutes; then put in the strained lemon-juice, the strained infusion of the rind, and bring the whole to the point of boiling; skim well, add the wine, and run the jelly through a bag; pour it into a mould that has been wetted or soaked in water; put it in ice, if convenient, where let it remain until required for table.
10136-8{_}19945{_}Previously to adding the lemon-juice to the other ingredients, ascertain that it is very nicely strained, as, if this is not properly attended to, it is liable to make the jelly thick and muddy.
10136-8{_}19946{_}As this jelly is very pale, and almost colourless, it answers very well for moulding with a jelly of any bright hue; for instance, half a jelly bright red, and the other half made of the above, would have a very good effect.
10136-8{_}19947{_}Lemon jelly may also be made with calf's-feet stock, allowing the juice of 3 lemons to every pint of stock.
10136-8{_}19948{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 1 hour.
10136-8{_}19949{_}_Average cost_, with the best isinglass, 2s.
10136-8{_}19950{_}9d.
10136-8{_}19951{_}_Sufficient_ to fill 1-1/2-pint mould.
10136-8{_}19952{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19953{_}LEMON SPONGE.
10136-8{_}19954{_}1448.
10136-8{_}19955{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 oz.
10136-8{_}19956{_}of isinglass, 1-3/4 pint of water, 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}19957{_}of pounded sugar, the juice of 5 lemons, the rind of 1, the whites of 3 eggs.
10136-8{_}19958{_}_Mode_.--Dissolve the isinglass in the water, strain it into a saucepan, and add the sugar, lemon-rind, and juice.
10136-8{_}19959{_}Boil the whole from 10 to 15 minutes; strain it again, and let it stand till it is cold and begins to stiffen.
10136-8{_}19960{_}Beat the whites of the eggs, put them to it, and whisk the mixture till it is quite white; put it into a mould which has been previously wetted, and let it remain until perfectly set; then turn it out, and garnish it according to taste.
10136-8{_}19961{_}_Time_.--10 to 15 minutes.
10136-8{_}19962{_}_Average cost_, with the best isinglass, 3s.
10136-8{_}19963{_}6d.
10136-8{_}19964{_}_Sufficient_ to fill a quart mould.
10136-8{_}19965{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19966{_}LIQUEUR JELLY.
10136-8{_}19967{_}1449.
10136-8{_}19968{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}19969{_}of lump sugar, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}19970{_}of isinglass, 1-1/2 pint of water, the juice of 2 lemons, 1/4 pint of liqueur.
10136-8{_}19971{_}[Illustration: OVAL JELLY-MOULD.]
10136-8{_}19972{_}_Mode_.--Put the sugar, with 1 pint of the water, into a stewpan, and boil them gently by the side of the fire until there is no scum remaining, which must be carefully removed as fast as it rises.
10136-8{_}19973{_}Boil the isinglass with the other 1/2 pint of water, and skim it carefully in the same manner.
10136-8{_}19974{_}Strain the lemon-juice, and add it, with the clarified isinglass, to the syrup; put in the liqueur, and bring the whole to the boiling-point.
10136-8{_}19975{_}Let the saucepan remain covered by the side of the fire for a few minutes; then pour the jelly through a bag, put it into a mould, and set the mould in ice until required for table.
10136-8{_}19976{_}Dip the mould in hot water, wipe the outside, loosen the jelly by passing a knife round the edges, and turn it out carefully on a dish.
10136-8{_}19977{_}Noyeau, Maraschino, Curaçoa, brandy, or any kind of liqueur, answers for this jelly; and, when made with isinglass, liqueur jellies are usually prepared as directed above.
10136-8{_}19978{_}_Time_.--10 minutes to boil the sugar and water.
10136-8{_}19979{_}_Average cost_, with the best isinglass, 3s.
10136-8{_}19980{_}6d.
10136-8{_}19981{_}_Sufficient_ to fill a quart mould.
10136-8{_}19982{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19983{_}A SWEET DISH OF MACARONI.
10136-8{_}19984{_}1450.
10136-8{_}19985{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}19986{_}of macaroni, 1-1/2 pint of milk, the rind of 1/2 lemon, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}19987{_}of lump sugar, 3/4 pint of custard No.
10136-8{_}19988{_}1423.
10136-8{_}19989{_}_Mode_.--Put the milk into a saucepan, with the lemon-peel and sugar; bring it to the boiling-point, drop in the macaroni, and let it gradually swell over a gentle fire, but do not allow the pipes to break.
10136-8{_}19990{_}The form should be entirely preserved; and, though tender, should be firm, and not soft, with no part beginning to melt.
10136-8{_}19991{_}Should the milk dry away before the macaroni is sufficiently swelled, add a little more.
10136-8{_}19992{_}Make a custard by recipe No.
10136-8{_}19993{_}1423; place the macaroni on a dish, and pour the custard over the hot macaroni; grate over it a little nutmeg, and, when cold, garnish the dish with slices of candied citron.
10136-8{_}19994{_}_Time_.--From 40 to 50 minutes to swell the macaroni.
10136-8{_}19995{_}_Average cost_, with the custard, 1s.
10136-8{_}19996{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}19997{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}19998{_}MERINGUES.
10136-8{_}19999{_}1451.
10136-8{_}20000{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}20001{_}of pounded sugar, the whites of 4 eggs.
10136-8{_}20002{_}[Illustration: MERINGUES.]
10136-8{_}20003{_}_Mode_.--Whisk the whites of the eggs to a stiff froth, and, with a wooden spoon, stir in _quickly_ the pounded sugar; and have some boards thick enough to put in the oven to prevent the bottom of the meringues from acquiring too much colour.
10136-8{_}20004{_}Cut some strips of paper about 2 inches wide; place this paper on the board, and drop a tablespoonful at a time of the mixture on the paper, taking care to let all the meringues be the same size.
10136-8{_}20005{_}In dropping it from the spoon, give the mixture the form of an egg, and keep the meringues about 2 inches apart from each other on the paper.
10136-8{_}20006{_}Strew over them some sifted sugar, and bake in a moderate oven for 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}20007{_}As soon as they begin to colour, remove them from the oven; take each slip of paper by the two ends, and turn it gently on the table, and, with a small spoon, take out the soft part of each meringue.
10136-8{_}20008{_}Spread some clean paper on the board, turn the meringues upside down, and put them into the oven to harden and brown on the other side.
10136-8{_}20009{_}When required for table, fill them with whipped cream, flavoured with liqueur or vanilla, and sweetened with pounded sugar.
10136-8{_}20010{_}Join two of the meringues together, and pile them high in the dish, as shown in the annexed drawing.
10136-8{_}20011{_}To vary their appearance, finely-chopped almonds or currants may be strewn over them before the sugar is sprinkled over; and they may be garnished with any bright-coloured preserve.
10136-8{_}20012{_}Great expedition is necessary in making this sweet dish; as, if the meringues are not put into the oven as soon as the sugar and eggs are mixed, the former melts, and the mixture would run on the paper, instead of keeping its egg-shape.
10136-8{_}20013{_}The sweeter the meringues are made, the crisper will they be; but, if there is not sufficient sugar mixed with them, they will most likely be tough.
10136-8{_}20014{_}They are sometimes coloured with cochineal; and, if kept well covered in a dry place, will remain good for a month or six weeks.
10136-8{_}20015{_}_Time_.--Altogether, about 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}20016{_}_Average cost_, with the cream and flavouring, 1s.
10136-8{_}20017{_}_Sufficient_ to make 2 dozen meringues.
10136-8{_}20018{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20019{_}NOYEAU CREAM.
10136-8{_}20020{_}1452.
10136-8{_}20021{_}INGREDIENTS.--1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}20022{_}of isinglass, the juice of 2 lemons, noyeau and pounded sugar to taste, 1-1/2 pint of cream.
10136-8{_}20023{_}_Mode_.--Dissolve the isinglass in a little boiling water, add the lemon-juice, and strain this to the cream, putting in sufficient noyeau and sugar to flavour and sweeten the mixture nicely; whisk the cream well, put it into an oiled mould, and set the mould in ice or in a cool place; turn it out, and garnish the dish to taste.
10136-8{_}20024{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}20025{_}_Average cost_, with cream at 1s.
10136-8{_}20026{_}per pint and the best isinglass, 4s.
10136-8{_}20027{_}_Sufficient_ to fill a quart mould.
10136-8{_}20028{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20029{_}OPEN JELLY WITH WHIPPED CREAM.
10136-8{_}20030{_}(_A very pretty dish_.)
10136-8{_}20031{_}1453.
10136-8{_}20032{_}INGREDIENTS.--1-1/2 pint of jelly, 1/2 pint of cream, 1 glass of sherry, sugar to taste.
10136-8{_}20033{_}[Illustration: OPEN JELLY WITH WHIPPED CREAM.]
10136-8{_}20034{_}_Mode_.--Make the above proportion of calf's-feet or isinglass jelly, colouring and flavouring it in any way that may be preferred; soak a mould, open in the centre, for about 1/2 hour in cold water; fill it with the jelly, and let it remain in a cool place until perfectly set; then turn it out on a dish; fill the centre with whipped cream, flavoured with sherry and sweetened with pounded sugar; pile this cream high in the centre, and serve.
10136-8{_}20035{_}The jelly should be made of rather a dark colour, to contrast nicely with the cream.
10136-8{_}20036{_}_Time_.--3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}20037{_}_Average cost_, 3s.
10136-8{_}20038{_}6d.
10136-8{_}20039{_}_Sufficient_ to fill 1-1/2-pint mould.
10136-8{_}20040{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20041{_}ORANGE JELLY.
10136-8{_}20042{_}1454.
10136-8{_}20043{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint of water, 1-1/2 to 2 oz.
10136-8{_}20044{_}of isinglass, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}20045{_}of loaf sugar, 1 Seville orange, 1 lemon, about 9 China oranges.
10136-8{_}20046{_}[Illustration: OPEN MOULD.]
