10136-8{_}20047{_}_Mode_.--Put the water into a saucepan, with the isinglass, sugar, and the rind of 1 orange, and the same of 1/2 lemon, and stir these over the fire until the isinglass is dissolved, and remove the scum; then add to this the juice of the Seville orange, the juice of the lemon, and sufficient juice of China oranges to make in all 1 pint; from 8 to 10 oranges will yield the desired quantity.
10136-8{_}20048{_}Stir all together over the fire until it is just on the point of boiling; skim well; then strain the jelly through a very fine sieve or jelly-bag, and when nearly cold, put it into a mould previously wetted, and, when quite set, turn it out on a dish, and garnish it to taste.
10136-8{_}20049{_}To insure this jelly being clear, the orange-and lemon-juice should be well strained, and the isinglass clarified, before they are added to the other ingredients, and, to heighten the colour, a few drops of prepared cochineal may be added.
10136-8{_}20050{_}_Time_.--5 minutes to boil without the juice; 1 minute after it is added.
10136-8{_}20051{_}_Average cost_, with the best isinglass, 3s.
10136-8{_}20052{_}6d.
10136-8{_}20053{_}_Sufficient_ to fill a quart mould.
10136-8{_}20054{_}_Seasonable_ from November to May.
10136-8{_}20055{_}ORANGE JELLY MOULDED WITH SLICES OF ORANGE.
10136-8{_}20056{_}1455.
10136-8{_}20057{_}INGREDIENTS.--1-1/2 pint of orange jelly No.
10136-8{_}20058{_}1454, 4 oranges, 1 pint of clarified syrup.
10136-8{_}20059{_}_Mode_.--Boil 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}20060{_}of loaf sugar with 1/2 pint of water until there is no scum left (which must be carefully removed as fast as it rises), and carefully peel the oranges; divide them into thin slices, without breaking the thin skin, and put these pieces of orange into the syrup, where let them remain for about 5 minutes; then take them out, and use the syrup for the jelly, which should be made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}20061{_}1454.
10136-8{_}20062{_}When the oranges are well drained, and the jelly is nearly cold, pour a little of the latter into the bottom of the mould; then lay in a few pieces of orange; over these pour a little jelly, and when this is set, place another layer of oranges, proceeding in this manner until the mould is full.
10136-8{_}20063{_}Put it in ice, or in a cool place, and, before turning it out, wrap a cloth round the mould for a minute or two, which has been wrung out in boiling water.
10136-8{_}20064{_}_Time_.--5 minutes to simmer the oranges.
10136-8{_}20065{_}_Average cost_, 3s.
10136-8{_}20066{_}6d.
10136-8{_}20067{_}_Sufficient_, with the slices of orange, to fill a quart mould.
10136-8{_}20068{_}_Seasonable_ from November to May.
10136-8{_}20069{_}TO MAKE A PLAIN OMELET.
10136-8{_}20070{_}1456.
10136-8{_}20071{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 eggs, 1 saltspoonful of salt, 1/3 saltspoonful of pepper, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}20072{_}of butter.
10136-8{_}20073{_}[Illustration: OMELET.]
10136-8{_}20074{_}_Mode_.--Break the eggs into a basin, omitting the whites of 3, and beat them up with the salt and pepper until extremely light; then add 2 oz.
10136-8{_}20075{_}of the butter broken into small pieces, and stir this into the mixture.
10136-8{_}20076{_}Put the other 2 oz.
10136-8{_}20077{_}of butter into a frying-pan, make it quite hot, and, as soon as it begins to bubble, whisk the eggs, &c. very briskly for a minute or two, and pour them into the pan; stir the omelet with a spoon one way until the mixture thickens and becomes firm, and when the whole is set, fold the edges over, so that the omelet assumes an oval form; and when it is nicely brown on one side, and quite firm, it is done.
10136-8{_}20078{_}To take off the rawness on the upper side, hold the pan before the fire for a minute or two, and brown it with a salamander or hot shovel.
10136-8{_}20079{_}Serve very expeditiously on a very hot dish, and never cook it until it is just wanted.
10136-8{_}20080{_}The flavour of this omelet may be very much enhanced by adding minced parsley, minced onion or eschalot, or grated cheese, allowing 1 tablespoonful of the former, and half the quantity of the latter, to the above proportion of eggs.
10136-8{_}20081{_}Shrimps or oysters may also be added: the latter should be scalded in their liquor, and then bearded and cut into small pieces.
10136-8{_}20082{_}In making an omelet, be particularly careful that it is not too thin, and, to avoid this, do not make it in too large a frying-pan, as the mixture would then spread too much, and taste of the outside.
10136-8{_}20083{_}It should also not be greasy, burnt, or too much done, and should be cooked over a gentle fire, that the whole of the substance may be heated without drying up the outside.
10136-8{_}20084{_}Omelets are sometimes served with gravy; but _this should never be poured over them_, but served in a tureen, as the liquid causes the omelet to become heavy and flat, instead of eating light and soft.
10136-8{_}20085{_}In making the gravy, the flavour should not overpower that of the omelet, and should be thickened with arrowroot or rice flour.
10136-8{_}20086{_}_Time_.--With 6 eggs, in a frying-pan 18 or 20 inches round, 4 to 6 minutes.
10136-8{_}20087{_}_Average cost_, 9d.
10136-8{_}20088{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}20089{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20090{_}HAM OMELET (_A delicious Breakfast Dish_.)
10136-8{_}20091{_}1457.
10136-8{_}20092{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 eggs, 4 oz.
10136-8{_}20093{_}of butter, 1/2 saltspoonful of pepper, 2 tablespoonfuls of minced ham.
10136-8{_}20094{_}_Mode_.--Mince the ham very finely, without any fat, and fry it for 2 minutes in a little butter; then make the batter for the omelet, stir in the ham, and proceed as directed in recipe No.
10136-8{_}20095{_}1456.
10136-8{_}20096{_}Do not add any salt to the batter, as the ham is usually sufficiently salt to impart a flavour to the omelet.
10136-8{_}20097{_}Good lean bacon, or tongue, answers equally well for this dish; but they must also be slightly cooked previously to mixing them with the batter.
10136-8{_}20098{_}Serve very hot and quickly, without gravy.
10136-8{_}20099{_}_Time_.--From 4 to 6 minutes.
10136-8{_}20100{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}20101{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}20102{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20103{_}KIDNEY OMELET (_A favourite French dish_.)
10136-8{_}20104{_}1458.
10136-8{_}20105{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 eggs, 1 saltspoonful of salt, 1/2 saltspoonful of pepper, 2 sheep's kidneys, or 2 tablespoonfuls of minced veal kidney, 5 oz.
10136-8{_}20106{_}of butter.
10136-8{_}20107{_}_Mode_.--Skin the kidneys, cut them into small dice, and toss them in a frying-pan, in 1 oz.
10136-8{_}20108{_}of butter, over the fire for 2 or 3 minutes.
10136-8{_}20109{_}Mix the ingredients for the omelet the same as in recipe No.
10136-8{_}20110{_}1456, and when the eggs are well whisked, stir in the pieces of kidney.
10136-8{_}20111{_}Make the butter hot in the frying-pan, and when it bubbles, pour in the omelet, and fry it over a gentle fire from 4 to 6 minutes.
10136-8{_}20112{_}When the eggs are set, fold the edges over, so that the omelet assumes an oval form, and be careful that it is not too much done: to brown the top, hold the pan before the fire for a minute or two, or use a salamander until the desired colour is obtained, but never turn an omelet in the pan.
10136-8{_}20113{_}Slip it carefully on to a _very hot_ dish, or, what is a much safer method, put a dish on the omelet, and turn the pan quickly over.
10136-8{_}20114{_}It should be served the instant it comes from the fire.
10136-8{_}20115{_}_Time_.--4 to 6 minutes.
10136-8{_}20116{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}20117{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}20118{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20119{_}TO MAKE A PLAIN SWEET OMELET.
10136-8{_}20120{_}1459.
10136-8{_}20121{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 eggs, 4 oz.
10136-8{_}20122{_}of butter, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}20123{_}of sifted sugar.
10136-8{_}20124{_}_Mode_.--Break the eggs into a basin, omitting the whites of 3; whisk them well, adding the sugar and 2 oz.
10136-8{_}20125{_}of the butter, which should be broken into small pieces, and stir all these ingredients well together.
10136-8{_}20126{_}Make the remainder of the butter quite hot in a small frying-pan, and when it commences to bubble, pour in the eggs, &c. Keep stirring them until they begin to set; then turn the edges of the omelet over, to make it an oval shape, and finish cooking it.
10136-8{_}20127{_}To brown the top, hold the pan before the fire, or use a salamander, and turn it carefully on to a _very hot_ dish: sprinkle sifted sugar over, and serve.
10136-8{_}20128{_}_Time_.--From 4 to 6 minutes.
10136-8{_}20129{_}_Average cost_, 10d.
10136-8{_}20130{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}20131{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20132{_}OMELETTE AUX CONFITURES, or JAM OMELET.
10136-8{_}20133{_}1460.
10136-8{_}20134{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 eggs, 4 oz.
10136-8{_}20135{_}of butter, 3 tablespoonfuls of apricot, strawberry, or any jam that may be preferred.
10136-8{_}20136{_}_Mode_.--Make the omelet by recipe No.
10136-8{_}20137{_}1459, only instead of doubling it over, leave it flat in the pan.
10136-8{_}20138{_}When quite firm, and nicely brown on one side, turn it carefully on to a hot dish, spread over the middle of it the jam, and fold the omelet over on each side; sprinkle sifted sugar over, and serve very quickly.
10136-8{_}20139{_}A pretty dish of small omelets may be made by dividing the batter into 3 or 4 portions, and frying them separately; they should then be spread each one with a different kind of preserve, and the omelets rolled over.
10136-8{_}20140{_}Always sprinkle sweet omelets with sifted sugar before being sent to table.
10136-8{_}20141{_}_Time_.--4 to 6 minutes.
10136-8{_}20142{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}20143{_}2d.
10136-8{_}20144{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 persons.
10136-8{_}20145{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20146{_}OMELETTE SOUFFLÉ.
10136-8{_}20147{_}1461.
10136-8{_}20148{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 eggs, 5 oz.
10136-8{_}20149{_}of pounded sugar, flavouring of vanilla, orange-flower water, or lemon-rind, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}20150{_}of butter, 1 dessert-spoonful of rice-flour.
10136-8{_}20151{_}_Mode_.--Separate the yolks from the whites of the eggs, add to the former the sugar, the rice-flour, and either of the above flavourings that may be preferred, and stir these ingredients well together.
10136-8{_}20152{_}Whip the whites of the eggs, mix them lightly with the batter, and put the butter into a small frying-pan.
10136-8{_}20153{_}As soon as it begins to bubble, pour the batter into it, and set the pan over a bright but gentle fire; and when the omelet is set, turn the edges over to make it an oval shape, and slip it on to a silver dish, which has been previously well buttered.
10136-8{_}20154{_}Put it in the oven, and bake from 12 to 15 minutes; sprinkle finely-powdered sugar over the soufflé, and _serve it immediately_.
10136-8{_}20155{_}_Time_.--About 4 minutes in the pan; to bake, from 12 to 15 minutes.
10136-8{_}20156{_}_Average cost_.
10136-8{_}20157{_}1s.
10136-8{_}20158{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 or 4 persons.
10136-8{_}20159{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20160{_}BACHELOR'S OMELET.
10136-8{_}20161{_}1462.
10136-8{_}20162{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 or 3 eggs, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}20163{_}of butter, 1 teaspoonful of flour, 1/2 teacupful of milk.
10136-8{_}20164{_}_Mode_.--Make a thin cream of the flour and milk; then beat up the eggs, mix all together, and add a pinch of salt and a few grains of cayenne.
10136-8{_}20165{_}Melt the butter in a small frying-pan, and, when very hot, pour in the batter.
10136-8{_}20166{_}Let the pan remain for a few minutes over a clear fire; then sprinkle upon the omelet some chopped herbs and a few shreds of onion; double the omelet dexterously, and shake it out of the pan on to a hot dish.
10136-8{_}20167{_}A simple sweet omelet can be made by the same process, substituting sugar or preserve for the chopped herbs.
10136-8{_}20168{_}_Time_.--2 minutes.
10136-8{_}20169{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}20170{_}_Sufficient_ for 2 persons.
10136-8{_}20171{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20172{_}ORANGE CREAM.
10136-8{_}20173{_}1463.
10136-8{_}20174{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 oz.
10136-8{_}20175{_}of isinglass, 6 large oranges, 1 lemon, sugar to taste, water, 1/2 pint of good cream.
10136-8{_}20176{_}[Illustration: OPEN MOULD.]
10136-8{_}20177{_}_Mode_.--Squeeze the juice from the oranges and lemon; strain it, and put it into a saucepan with the isinglass, and sufficient water to make in all 1-1/2 pint.
10136-8{_}20178{_}Rub the sugar on the orange and lemon-rind, add it to the other ingredients, and boil all together for about 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}20179{_}Strain through a muslin bag, and, when cold, beat up with it 1/2 pint of thick cream.
10136-8{_}20180{_}Wet a mould, or soak it in cold water; pour in the cream, and put it in a cool place to set.
10136-8{_}20181{_}If the weather is very cold, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}20182{_}of isinglass will be found sufficient for the above proportion of ingredients.
10136-8{_}20183{_}_Time_.--10 minutes to boil the juice and water.
10136-8{_}20184{_}_Average cost_, with the best isinglass, 3s.
10136-8{_}20185{_}_Sufficient_ to fill a quart mould.
10136-8{_}20186{_}_Seasonable_ from November to May.
10136-8{_}20187{_}ORANGE CREAMS.
10136-8{_}20188{_}1464.
10136-8{_}20189{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 Seville orange, 1 tablespoonful of brandy, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}20190{_}of loaf sugar, the yolks of 4 eggs, 1 pint of cream.
10136-8{_}20191{_}_Mode_.--Boil the rind of the Seville orange until tender, and beat it in a mortar to a pulp; add to it the brandy, the strained juice of the orange, and the sugar, and beat all together for about 10 minutes, adding the well-beaten yolks of eggs.
10136-8{_}20192{_}Bring the cream to the boiling-point, and pour it very gradually to the other ingredients, and beat the mixture till nearly cold; put it into custard-cups, place the cups in a deep dish of boiling water, where let them remain till quite cold.
10136-8{_}20193{_}Take the cups out of the water, wipe them, and garnish the tops of the creams with candied orange-peel or preserved chips.
10136-8{_}20194{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}20195{_}_Average cost_, with cream at 1s.
10136-8{_}20196{_}per pint, 1s.
10136-8{_}20197{_}7d.
10136-8{_}20198{_}_Sufficient_ to make 7 or 8 creams.
10136-8{_}20199{_}_Seasonable_ from November to May.
10136-8{_}20200{_}_Note_.--To render this dish more economical, substitute milk for the cream, but add a small pinch of isinglass to make the creams firm.
10136-8{_}20201{_}SEVILLE ORANGE (_Citrus vulgaris_).--This variety, called also     _bitter orange_, is of the same species as the sweet orange, and     grows in great abundance on the banks of the Guadalquiver, in     Andalusia, whence this fruit is chiefly obtained.
10136-8{_}20202{_}In that part     of Spain there are very extensive orchards of these oranges,     which form the chief wealth of the monasteries.
10136-8{_}20203{_}The pulp of the     bitter orange is not eaten raw.
10136-8{_}20204{_}In the yellow rind, separated     from the white spongy substance immediately below it, is     contained an essential oil, which is an agreeable warm aromatic,     much superior for many purposes to that of the common orange.
10136-8{_}20205{_}The best marmalade and the richest wine are made from this     orange; and from its flowers the best orange-flower water is     distilled.
10136-8{_}20206{_}Seville oranges are also preserved whole as a     sweetmeat.
10136-8{_}20207{_}ORANGE FRITTERS.
10136-8{_}20208{_}1465.
10136-8{_}20209{_}INGREDIENTS.--For the batter, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}20210{_}of flour, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}20211{_}of butter, 1/2 saltspoonful of salt, 2 eggs, milk, oranges, hot lard or clarified dripping.
10136-8{_}20212{_}_Mode_.--Make a nice light batter with the above proportion of flour, butter, salt, eggs, and sufficient milk to make it the proper consistency; peel the oranges, remove as much of the white skin as possible, and divide each orange into eight pieces, without breaking the thin skin, unless it be to remove the pips; dip each piece of orange in the batter.
10136-8{_}20213{_}Have ready a pan of boiling lard or clarified dripping; drop in the oranges, and fry them a delicate brown from 8 to 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}20214{_}When done, lay them on a piece of blotting-paper before the fire, to drain away the greasy moisture, and dish them on a white d'oyley; sprinkle over them plenty of pounded sugar, and serve quickly.
10136-8{_}20215{_}_Time_.--8 to 10 minutes to fry the fritters; 5 minutes to drain them.
10136-8{_}20216{_}_Average cost_, 9d.
10136-8{_}20217{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}20218{_}_Seasonable_ from November to May.
10136-8{_}20219{_}A PRETTY DISH OF ORANGES.
10136-8{_}20220{_}1466.
10136-8{_}20221{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 large oranges, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}20222{_}of loaf sugar, 1/4 pint of water, 1/2 pint of cream, 2 tablespoonfuls of any kind of liqueur, sugar to taste.
10136-8{_}20223{_}_Mode_.--Put the sugar and water into a saucepan, and boil them until the sugar becomes brittle, which may be ascertained by taking up a small quantity in a spoon, and dipping it in cold water; if the sugar is sufficiently boiled, it will easily snap.
10136-8{_}20224{_}Peel the oranges, remove as much of the white pith as possible, and divide them into nice-sized slices, without breaking the thin white skin which surrounds the juicy pulp.
10136-8{_}20225{_}Place the pieces of orange on small skewers, dip them into the hot sugar, and arrange them in layers round a plain mould, which should be well oiled with the purest salad-oil.
10136-8{_}20226{_}The sides of the mould only should be lined with the oranges, and the centre left open for the cream.
10136-8{_}20227{_}Let the sugar become firm by cooling; turn the oranges carefully out on a dish, and fill the centre with whipped cream, flavoured with any kind of liqueur, and sweetened with pounded sugar.
10136-8{_}20228{_}This is an exceedingly ornamental and nice dish for the supper-table.
10136-8{_}20229{_}_Time_.--10 minutes to boil the sugar.
10136-8{_}20230{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}20231{_}8d.
10136-8{_}20232{_}_Sufficient_ for 1 mould.
10136-8{_}20233{_}_Seasonable_ from November to May.
10136-8{_}20234{_}TO MAKE PANCAKES.
10136-8{_}20235{_}1467.
10136-8{_}20236{_}INGREDIENTS.--Eggs, flour, milk; to every egg allow 1 oz.
10136-8{_}20237{_}of flour, about 1 gill of milk, 1/8 saltspoonful of salt.
10136-8{_}20238{_}[Illustration: PANCAKES.]
10136-8{_}20239{_}_Mode_.--Ascertain that the eggs are fresh; break each one separately in a cup; whisk them well, put them into a basin, with the flour, salt, and a few drops of milk, and beat the whole to a perfectly _smooth_ batter; then add by degrees the remainder of the milk.
10136-8{_}20240{_}The proportion of this latter ingredient must be regulated by the size of the eggs, &c. &c.; but the batter, when ready for frying, should be of the consistency of thick cream.
10136-8{_}20241{_}Place a small frying-pan on the fire to get hot; let it be delicately clean, or the pancakes will stick, and, when quite hot, put into it a small piece of butter, allowing about 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}20242{_}to each pancake.
10136-8{_}20243{_}When it is melted, pour in the batter, about 1/2 teacupful to a pan 5 inches in diameter, and fry it for about 4 minutes, or until it is nicely brown on one side.
10136-8{_}20244{_}By only pouring in a small quantity of batter, and so making the pancakes thin, the necessity of turning them (an operation rather difficult to unskilful cooks) is obviated.
10136-8{_}20245{_}When the pancake is done, sprinkle over it some pounded sugar, roll it up in the pan, and take it out with a large slice, and place it on a dish before the fire.
10136-8{_}20246{_}Proceed in this manner until sufficient are cooked for a dish; then send them quickly to table, and continue to send in a further quantity, as pancakes are never good unless eaten almost immediately they come from the frying-pan.
10136-8{_}20247{_}The batter may be flavoured with a little grated lemon-rind, or the pancakes may have preserve rolled in them instead of sugar.
10136-8{_}20248{_}Send sifted sugar and a cut lemon to table with them.
10136-8{_}20249{_}To render the pancakes very light, the yolks and whites of the eggs should be beaten separately, and the whites added the last thing to the batter before frying.
10136-8{_}20250{_}_Time_.--from 4 to 6 minutes for a pancake that does not require turning; from 6 to 8 minutes for a thicker one.
10136-8{_}20251{_}_Average cost_, for 3 persons, 6d.
10136-8{_}20252{_}_Sufficient._--Allow 3 eggs, with the other ingredients in proportion, for 3 persons.
10136-8{_}20253{_}_Seasonable_ at any time, but specially served on Shrove Tuesday.
10136-8{_}20254{_}RICHER PANCAKES.
10136-8{_}20255{_}1468.
10136-8{_}20256{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 eggs, 1 pint of cream, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}20257{_}of loaf sugar, 1 glass of sherry, 1/2 teaspoonful of grated nutmeg, flour.
10136-8{_}20258{_}_Mode_.--Ascertain that the eggs are extremely fresh, beat them well, strain and mix with them the cream, pounded sugar, wine, nutmeg, and as much flour as will make the batter nearly as thick as that for ordinary pancakes.
10136-8{_}20259{_}Make the frying-pan hot, wipe it with a clean cloth, pour in sufficient batter to make a thin pancake, and fry it for about 5 minutes.
10136-8{_}20260{_}Dish the pancakes piled one above the other, strew sifted sugar between each, and serve.
10136-8{_}20261{_}_Time_.--About 5 minutes.
10136-8{_}20262{_}_Average cost_, with cream at 1s.
10136-8{_}20263{_}per pint, 2s.
10136-8{_}20264{_}3d.
10136-8{_}20265{_}_Sufficient_ to make 8 pancakes.
10136-8{_}20266{_}_Seasonable_ at any time, but specially served on Shrove Tuesday.
10136-8{_}20267{_}PEACH FRITTERS.
10136-8{_}20268{_}1469.
10136-8{_}20269{_}INGREDIENTS.--For the batter: 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}20270{_}of flour, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}20271{_}of butter, 1/2 saltspoonful of salt, 2 eggs, milk;--peaches, hot lard or clarified dripping.
10136-8{_}20272{_}_Mode_.--Make a nice smooth, batter in the same manner as directed in recipe No.
10136-8{_}20273{_}1393, and skin, halve, and stone the peaches, which should be quite ripe; dip them in the batter, and fry the pieces in hot lard or clarified dripping, which should be brought to the boiling-point before the peaches are put in.
10136-8{_}20274{_}From 8 to 10 minutes will be required to fry them, and, when done, drain them before the fire, and dish them on a white d'oyley.
10136-8{_}20275{_}Strew over plenty of pounded sugar, and serve.
10136-8{_}20276{_}_Time_.--From 8 to 10 minutes to fry the fritters, 6 minutes to drain them.
10136-8{_}20277{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}20278{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}20279{_}_Seasonable_ in July, August, and September.
10136-8{_}20280{_}[Illustration: PEACH.]
10136-8{_}20281{_}PEACH.--The peach and nectarine are amongst the most delicious     of our fruits, and are considered as varieties of the same     species produced by cultivation.
10136-8{_}20282{_}The former is characterized by     a very delicate down, while the latter is smooth; but, as a     proof of their identity as to species, trees have borne peaches     in one part and nectarines in another; and even a single fruit     has had down on one side and the other smooth.
10136-8{_}20283{_}The trees are     almost exactly alike, as well as the blossoms.
10136-8{_}20284{_}Pliny states that     the peach was originally brought from Persia, where it grows     naturally, from which the name of Persica was bestowed upon it     by the Romans; and some modern botanists apply this as the     generic name, separating them from _Amygdalus_, or Almond, to     which Linnaeus had united them.
10136-8{_}20285{_}Although they are not tropical,     they require a great deal of warmth to bring them to perfection:     hence they seldom ripen in this country, in ordinary seasons,     without the use of walls or glass; consequently, they bear a     high price.
10136-8{_}20286{_}In a good peach, the flesh is firm, the skin thin,     of a deep bright colour next the sun and of a yellowish green     next to the wall; the pulp is yellowish, full of     highly-flavoured juice, the fleshy part thick, and the stone     small.
10136-8{_}20287{_}Too much down is a sign of inferior quality.
10136-8{_}20288{_}This fruit     is much used at the dessert, and makes a delicious preserve.
10136-8{_}20289{_}PEARS A L'ALLEMANDE.
10136-8{_}20290{_}1470.
10136-8{_}20291{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 to 8 pears, water, sugar, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}20292{_}of butter, the yolk of an egg, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}20293{_}of gelatine.
10136-8{_}20294{_}_Mode_.--Peel and cut the pears into any form that may be preferred, and steep them in cold water to prevent them turning black; put them into a saucepan with sufficient cold water to cover them, and boil them with the butter and enough sugar to sweeten them nicely, until tender; then brush the pears over with the yolk of an egg, sprinkle them with sifted sugar, and arrange them on a dish.
10136-8{_}20295{_}Add the gelatine to the syrup, boil it up quickly for about 5 minutes, strain it over the pears, and let it remain until set.
10136-8{_}20296{_}The syrup may be coloured with a little prepared cochineal, which would very much improve the appearance of the dish.
10136-8{_}20297{_}_Time_.--From 20 minutes to 1/2 hour to stew the pears; 5 minutes to boil the syrup.
10136-8{_}20298{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}20299{_}3d.
10136-8{_}20300{_}_Sufficient_ for a large dish.
10136-8{_}20301{_}_Seasonable_ from August to February.
10136-8{_}20302{_}MOULDED PEARS.
10136-8{_}20303{_}1471.
10136-8{_}20304{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 large pears or 6 small ones, 8 cloves, sugar to taste, water, a small piece of cinnamon, 1/4 pint of raisin wine, a strip of lemon-peel, the juice of 1/2 lemon, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}20305{_}of gelatine.
10136-8{_}20306{_}_Mode_.--Peel and cut the pears into quarters; put them into a jar with 3/4 pint of water, cloves, cinnamon, and sufficient sugar to sweeten the whole nicely; cover down the top of the jar, and bake the pears in a gentle oven until perfectly tender, but do not allow them to break.
10136-8{_}20307{_}When done, lay the pears in a plain mould, which should be well wetted, and boil 1/2 pint of the liquor the pears were baked in with the wine, lemon-peel, strained juice, and gelatine.
10136-8{_}20308{_}Let these ingredients boil quickly for 5 minutes, then strain the liquid warm over the pears; put the mould in a cool place, and when the jelly is firm, turn it out on a glass dish.
10136-8{_}20309{_}_Time_.--2 hours to bake the pears in a cool oven.
10136-8{_}20310{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}20311{_}3d.
10136-8{_}20312{_}_Sufficient_ for a quart mould.
10136-8{_}20313{_}_Seasonable_ from August to February   PINEAPPLE FRITTERS.
10136-8{_}20314{_}(_An elegant Dish_.)
10136-8{_}20315{_}1472.
10136-8{_}20316{_}INGREDIENTS.--A small pineapple, a small wineglassful of brandy or liqueur, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}20317{_}of sifted sugar; batter as for apple fritters No.
10136-8{_}20318{_}1393.
10136-8{_}20319{_}_Mode_.--This elegant dish, although it may appear extravagant, is really not so if made when pineapples are plentiful.
10136-8{_}20320{_}We receive them now in such large quantities from the West Indies, that at times they may be purchased at an exceedingly low rate: it would not, of course, be economical to use the pines which are grown in our English pineries for the purposes of fritters.
10136-8{_}20321{_}Pare the pine with as little waste as possible, cut it into rather thin slices, and soak these slices in the above proportion of brandy or liqueur and pounded sugar for 4 hours; then make a batter the same as for apple fritters, substituting cream for the milk, and using a smaller quantity of flour; and, when this is ready, dip in the pieces of pine, and fry them in boiling lard from 5 to 8 minutes; turn them when sufficiently brown on one side, and, when done, drain them from the lard before the fire, dish them on a white d'oyley, strew over them sifted sugar, and serve quickly.
10136-8{_}20322{_}_Time_.--5 to 8 minutes.
10136-8{_}20323{_}_Average cost_, when cheap and plentiful, 1s.
10136-8{_}20324{_}6d.
10136-8{_}20325{_}for the pine.
10136-8{_}20326{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 or 4 persons.
10136-8{_}20327{_}_Seasonable_ in July and August.
10136-8{_}20328{_}PINEAPPLE.--The pineapple has not been known in Europe above two     hundred years, and has not been cultivated in England much above     a century.
10136-8{_}20329{_}It is stated that the first pineapples raised in     Europe were by M. La Cour, of Leyden, about the middle of the     17th century; and it is said to have been first cultivated in     England by Sir Matthew Decker, of Richmond.
10136-8{_}20330{_}In Kensington     Palace, there is a picture in which Charles II.
10136-8{_}20331{_}is represented     as receiving a pineapple from his gardener Rose, who is     presenting it on his knees.
10136-8{_}20332{_}PLAIN FRITTERS.
10136-8{_}20333{_}1473.
10136-8{_}20334{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 oz.
10136-8{_}20335{_}of flour, 3 eggs, 1/3 pint of milk.
10136-8{_}20336{_}[Illustration: STAR FRITTER-MOULD.]
10136-8{_}20337{_}_Mode_.--Mix the flour to a smooth batter with a small quantity of the milk; stir in the eggs, which should be well whisked, and then the remainder of the milk; boat the whole to a perfectly smooth batter, and should it be found not quite thin enough, add two or three tablespoonfuls more milk.
10136-8{_}20338{_}Have ready a frying-pan, with plenty of boiling lard in it; drop in rather more than a tablespoonful at a time of the batter, and fry the fritters a nice brown, turning them when sufficiently cooked on one side.
10136-8{_}20339{_}Drain them well from the greasy moisture by placing them upon a piece of blotting-paper before the fire; dish them on a white d'oyley, sprinkle over them sifted sugar, and send to table with them a cut lemon and plenty of pounded sugar.
10136-8{_}20340{_}_Time_.--From 6 to 8 minutes.
10136-8{_}20341{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}20342{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 or 4 persons.
10136-8{_}20343{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20344{_}POTATO FRITTERS.
10136-8{_}20345{_}1474.
10136-8{_}20346{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 large potatoes, 4 eggs, 2 tablespoonfuls of cream, 2 ditto of raisin or sweet wine, 1 dessertspoonful of lemon-juice, 4 teaspoonful of grated nutmeg, hot lard.
10136-8{_}20347{_}[Illustration: SCROLL FRITTER-MOULD.]
10136-8{_}20348{_}_Mode_.--Boil the potatoes, and beat them up lightly with a fork, but do not use a spoon, as that would make them heavy.
10136-8{_}20349{_}Beat the eggs well, leaving out one of the whites; add the other ingredients, and beat all together for at least 20 minutes, or until the batter is extremely light.
10136-8{_}20350{_}Put plenty of good lard into a frying-pan, and drop a tablespoonful of the batter at a time into it, and fry the fritters a nice brown.
10136-8{_}20351{_}Serve them with the following sauce:--A glass of sherry mixed with the strained juice of a lemon, and sufficient white sugar to sweeten the whole nicely.
10136-8{_}20352{_}Warm these ingredients, and serve the sauce separately in a tureen.
10136-8{_}20353{_}The fritters should be neatly dished on a white d'oyley, and pounded sugar sprinkled over them; and they should be well drained on a piece of blotting-paper before the fire previously to being dished.
10136-8{_}20354{_}_Time_.--From 6 to 8 minutes.
10136-8{_}20355{_}_Average cost_, 9d.
10136-8{_}20356{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 or 4 persons.
10136-8{_}20357{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20358{_}RASPBERRY CREAM.
10136-8{_}20359{_}1475.
10136-8{_}20360{_}INGREDIENTS.--3/4 pint of milk, 3/4 pint of cream, 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}20361{_}of isinglass, raspberry jelly, sugar to taste, 2 tablespoonfuls of brandy.
10136-8{_}20362{_}[Illustration: RASPBERRY CREAM MOULD.]
10136-8{_}20363{_}_Mode_.--Boil the milk, cream, and isinglass together for 1/4 hour, or until the latter is melted, and strain it through a hair sieve into a basin.
10136-8{_}20364{_}Let it cool a little; then add to it sufficient raspberry jelly, which, when melted, would make 1/3 pint, and stir well till the ingredients are thoroughly mixed.
10136-8{_}20365{_}If not sufficiently sweet, add a little pounded sugar with the brandy; whisk the mixture well until nearly cold, put it into a well-oiled mould, and set it in a cool place till perfectly set.
10136-8{_}20366{_}Raspberry jam may be substituted for the jelly, but must be melted, and rubbed through a sieve, to free it from seeds: in summer, the juice of the fresh fruit may be used, by slightly mashing it with a wooden spoon, and sprinkling sugar over it; the juice that flows from the fruit should then be used for mixing with the cream.
10136-8{_}20367{_}If the colour should not be very good, a few drops of prepared cochineal may be added to improve its appearance.
10136-8{_}20368{_}(_See_ coloured plate T1.)
10136-8{_}20369{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour to boil the cream and isinglass.
10136-8{_}20370{_}_Average cost_, with cream at 1s.
10136-8{_}20371{_}per pint, and the best isinglass, 3s.
10136-8{_}20372{_}_Sufficient_ to fill a quart mould.
10136-8{_}20373{_}_Seasonable_, with jelly, at any time.
10136-8{_}20374{_}_Note_.--Strawberry cream may be made in precisely the same manner, substituting strawberry jam or jelly for the raspberry.
10136-8{_}20375{_}RICE BLANCMANGE.
10136-8{_}20376{_}1476.
10136-8{_}20377{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}20378{_}of ground rice, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}20379{_}of loaf sugar, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}20380{_}of fresh butter, 1 quart of milk, flavouring of lemon-peel, essence of almonds or vanilla, or laurel-leaves.
10136-8{_}20381{_}_Mode_.--Mix the rice to a smooth batter with about 1/2 pint of the milk, and the remainder put into a saucepan, with the sugar, butter, and whichever of the above flavourings may be preferred; bring the milk to the boiling-point, quickly stir in the rice, and let it boil for about 10 minutes, or until it comes easily away from the saucepan, keeping it well stirred the whole time.
10136-8{_}20382{_}Grease a mould with pure salad-oil; pour in the rice, and let it get perfectly set, when it should turn out quite easily; garnish it with jam, or pour round a compôte of any kind of fruit, just before it is sent to table.
10136-8{_}20383{_}This blancmange is better for being made the day before it is wanted, as it then has time to become firm.
10136-8{_}20384{_}If laurel-leaves are used for flavouring, steep 3 of them in the milk, and take them out before the rice is added: about 8 drops of essence of almonds, or from 12 to 16 drops of essence of vanilla, would be required to flavour the above proportion of milk.
10136-8{_}20385{_}_Time_.--From 10 to 15 minutes to boil the rice.
10136-8{_}20386{_}_Average cost_, 9d.
10136-8{_}20387{_}_Sufficient_ to fill a quart mould.
10136-8{_}20388{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20389{_}RICE CROQUETTES.
10136-8{_}20390{_}1477.
10136-8{_}20391{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}20392{_}of rice, 1 quart of milk, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}20393{_}of pounded sugar, flavouring of vanilla, lemon-peel, or bitter almonds, egg and bread crumbs, hot lard.
10136-8{_}20394{_}_Mode_.--Put the rice, milk, and sugar into a saucepan, and let the former gradually swell over a gentle fire until all the milk is dried up; and just before the rice is done, stir in a few drops of essence of any of the above flavourings.
10136-8{_}20395{_}Let the rice get cold; then form it into small round balls, dip them into yolk of egg, sprinkle them with bread crumbs, and fry them in boiling lard for about 10 minutes, turning them about, that they may get equally browned.
10136-8{_}20396{_}Drain the greasy moisture from them, by placing them on a cloth in front of the fire for a minute or two; pile them on a white d'oyley, and send them quickly to table.
10136-8{_}20397{_}A small piece of jam is sometimes introduced into the middle of each croquette, which adds very much to the flavour of this favourite dish.
10136-8{_}20398{_}_Time_.--From 3/4 to 1 hour to swell the rice; about 10 minutes to fry the croquettes.
10136-8{_}20399{_}_Average cost_, 10d.
10136-8{_}20400{_}_Sufficient_ to make 7 or 8 croquettes.
10136-8{_}20401{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20402{_}RICE FRITTERS.
10136-8{_}20403{_}1478.
10136-8{_}20404{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 oz.
10136-8{_}20405{_}of rice, 1 quart of milk, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}20406{_}of sugar, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}20407{_}of fresh butter 6 oz.
10136-8{_}20408{_}of orange marmalade, 4 eggs.
10136-8{_}20409{_}_Mode_.--Swell the rice in the milk, with the sugar and butter, over a slow fire until it is perfectly tender, which will be in about 3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}20410{_}When the rice is done, strain away the milk, should there be any left, and mix with it the marmalade and well-beaten eggs; stir the whole over the fire until the eggs are set; then spread the mixture on a dish to the thickness of about 1/2 inch, or rather thicker.
10136-8{_}20411{_}When it is perfectly cold, cut it into long strips, dip them in a batter the same as for apple fritters, and fry them a nice brown.
10136-8{_}20412{_}Dish them on a white d'oyley, strew sifted sugar over, and serve quickly.
10136-8{_}20413{_}_Time_.--About 3/4 hour to swell the rice; from 7 to 10 minutes to fry the fritters.
10136-8{_}20414{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}20415{_}6d.
10136-8{_}20416{_}_Sufficient_ to make 7 or 8 fritters.
10136-8{_}20417{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20418{_}RICE SNOWBALLS.
10136-8{_}20419{_}(_A pretty dish for Juvenile Suppers_.)
10136-8{_}20420{_}1479.
10136-8{_}20421{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 oz.
10136-8{_}20422{_}of rice, 1 quart of milk, flavouring of essence of almonds, sugar to taste, 1 pint of custard made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}20423{_}1423.
10136-8{_}20424{_}_Mode_.--Boil the rice in the milk, with sugar and a flavouring of essence of almonds, until the former is tender, adding, if necessary, a little more milk, should it dry away too much.
10136-8{_}20425{_}When the rice is quite soft, put it into teacups, or _small_ round jars, and let it remain until cold; then turn the rice out on a deep glass dish, pour over a custard made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}20426{_}1423, and, on the top of each ball place a small piece of bright-coloured preserve or jelly.
10136-8{_}20427{_}Lemon-peel or vanilla may be boiled with the rice instead of the essence of almonds, when either of these is preferred; but the flavouring of the custard must correspond with that of the rice.
10136-8{_}20428{_}_Time_.--About 3/4 hour to swell the rice in the milk.
10136-8{_}20429{_}_Average cost_, with the custard, 1s.
10136-8{_}20430{_}6d.
10136-8{_}20431{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 children.
10136-8{_}20432{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20433{_}RICE SOUFFLE.
10136-8{_}20434{_}1480.
10136-8{_}20435{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 tablespoonfuls of ground rice, 1 pint of milk, 5 eggs, pounded sugar to taste, flavouring of lemon-rind, vanilla, coffee, chocolate, or anything that may be preferred, a piece of butter the size of a walnut.
10136-8{_}20436{_}_Mode_.--Mix the ground rice with 6 tablespoonfuls of the milk quite smoothly, and put it into a saucepan with the remainder of the milk and butter, and keep stirring it over the fire for about 1/4 hour, or until the mixture thickens.
10136-8{_}20437{_}Separate the yolks from the whites of the eggs, beat the former in a basin, and stir to them the rice and sufficient pounded sugar to sweeten the soufflé; but add this latter ingredient as sparingly as possible, as, the less sugar there is used, the lighter will be the soufflé.
10136-8{_}20438{_}Now whisk the whites of the eggs to a stiff froth or snow; mix them with the other preparation, and pour the whole into a soufflé-dish, and put it instantly into the oven; bake it about 1/2 hour in a moderate oven; take it out, hold a salamander or hot shovel over the top, sprinkle sifted sugar over it, and send the soufflé to table in the dish it was baked in, either with a napkin pinned round, or inclosed in a more ornamental dish.
10136-8{_}20439{_}The excellence of this fashionable dish entirely depends on the proper whisking of the whites of the eggs, the manner of baking, and the expedition with which it is sent to table.
10136-8{_}20440{_}Soufflés should be served _instantly_ from the oven, or they will sink, and be nothing more than an ordinary pudding.
10136-8{_}20441{_}_Time_.--About 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}20442{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}20443{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 or 4 persons.
10136-8{_}20444{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20445{_}TO MAKE A SOUFFLE.
10136-8{_}20446{_}1481.
10136-8{_}20447{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 heaped tablespoonfuls of potato-flour, rice-flour, arrowroot, or tapioca, 1 pint of milk, 5 eggs, a piece of butter the size of a walnut, sifted sugar to taste, 1/4 saltspoonful of salt flavouring.
10136-8{_}20448{_}_Mode_.--Mix the potato-flour, or whichever one of the above ingredients is used, with a little of the milk; put it into a saucepan, with the remainder of the milk, the butter, salt, and sufficient pounded sugar to sweeten the whole nicely.
10136-8{_}20449{_}Stir these ingredients over the fire until the mixture thickens; then take it off the fire, and let it cool a little.
10136-8{_}20450{_}Separate the whites from the yolks of the eggs, beat the latter, and stir them into the soufflé batter.
10136-8{_}20451{_}Now whisk the whites of the eggs to the firmest possible froth, for on this depends the excellence of the dish; stir them to the other ingredients, and add a few drops of essence of any flavouring that may be preferred; such as vanilla, lemon, orange, ginger, &c. &c. Pour the batter into a soufflé-dish, put it immediately into the oven, and bake for about 1/2 hour; then take it out, put the dish into another more ornamental one, such as is made for the purpose; hold a salamander or hot shovel over the soufflé, strew it with sifted sugar, and send it instantly to table.
10136-8{_}20452{_}The secret of making a soufflé well, is to have the eggs well whisked, but particularly the whites, the oven not too hot, and to send it to table the moment it comes from the oven.
10136-8{_}20453{_}If the soufflé be ever so well made, and it is allowed to stand before being sent to table, its appearance and goodness will be entirely spoiled.
10136-8{_}20454{_}Soufflés may be flavoured in various ways, but must be named accordingly.
10136-8{_}20455{_}Vanilla is one of the most delicate and recherché flavourings that can be used for this very fashionable dish.
10136-8{_}20456{_}_Time_.--About 1/2 hour in the oven; 2 or 3 minutes to hold the salamander over.
10136-8{_}20457{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}20458{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 or 4 persons.
10136-8{_}20459{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20460{_}SNOW EGGS, or OEUFS A LA NEIGE.
10136-8{_}20461{_}(_A very pretty Supper Dish_.)
10136-8{_}20462{_}1482.
10136-8{_}20463{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 eggs, 3/4 pint of milk, pounded sugar to taste, flavouring of vanilla, lemon-rind, or orange-flower water.
10136-8{_}20464{_}_Mode_.--Put the milk into a saucepan with sufficient sugar to sweeten it nicely, and the rind of 1/2 lemon.
10136-8{_}20465{_}Let this steep by the side of the fire for 1/2 hour, when take out the peel; separate the whites from the yolks of the eggs, and whisk the former to a perfectly stiff froth, or until there is no liquid remaining; bring the milk to the boiling-point, and drop in the snow a tablespoonful at a time, and keep turning the eggs until sufficiently cooked.
10136-8{_}20466{_}Then place them on a glass dish, beat up the yolks of the eggs, stir to them the milk, add a little more sugar, and strain this mixture into a jug; place the jug in a saucepan of boiling water, and stir it one way until the mixture thickens, but do not allow it to boil, or it will curdle.
10136-8{_}20467{_}Pour this custard over the eggs, when they should rise to the surface.
10136-8{_}20468{_}They make an exceedingly pretty addition to a supper, and should be put in a cold place after being made.
10136-8{_}20469{_}When they are flavoured with vanilla or orange-flower water, it is not necessary to steep the milk.
10136-8{_}20470{_}A few drops of the essence of either may be poured in the milk just before the whites are poached.
10136-8{_}20471{_}In making the custard, a little more flavouring and sugar should always be added.
10136-8{_}20472{_}_Time_.--About 2 minutes to poach the whites; 8 minutes to stir the custard.
10136-8{_}20473{_}_Average cost_, 8d.
10136-8{_}20474{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}20475{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20476{_}STONE CREAM OF TOUS LES MOIS.
10136-8{_}20477{_}1483.
10136-8{_}20478{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}20479{_}of preserve, 1 pint of milk, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}20480{_}of lump sugar, 1 heaped tablespoonful of tous les mois, 3 drops of essence of cloves, 3 drops of almond-flavouring.
10136-8{_}20481{_}_Mode_.--Place the preserve at the bottom of a glass dish; put the milk into a lined saucepan, with the sugar, and make it boil.
10136-8{_}20482{_}Mix to a smooth batter the tous les mois, with a very little cold milk; stir it briskly into the boiling milk, add the flavouring, and simmer for 2 minutes.
10136-8{_}20483{_}When rather cool, but before turning solid, pour the cream over the jam, and ornament it with strips of red-currant jelly or preserved fruit.
10136-8{_}20484{_}_Time_.--2 minutes.
10136-8{_}20485{_}_Average cost_, 10d.
10136-8{_}20486{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}20487{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20488{_}STRAWBERRY JELLY.
10136-8{_}20489{_}1484.
10136-8{_}20490{_}INGREDIENTS.--Strawberries, pounded sugar; to every pint of juice allow 1-1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}20491{_}of isinglass.
10136-8{_}20492{_}_Mode_.--Pick the strawberries, put them into a pan, squeeze them well with a wooden spoon, add sufficient pounded sugar to sweeten them nicely, and let them remain for 1 hour, that the juice may be extracted; then add 1/2 pint of water to every pint of juice.
10136-8{_}20493{_}Strain the strawberry-juice and water through a bag; measure it, and to every pint allow 1-1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}20494{_}of isinglass, melted and clarified in 1/4 pint of water.
10136-8{_}20495{_}Mix this with the juice; put the jelly into a mould, and set the mould in ice.
10136-8{_}20496{_}A little lemon-juice added to the strawberry-juice improves the flavour of the jelly, if the fruit is very ripe; but it must be well strained before it is put to the other ingredients, or it will make the jelly muddy.
10136-8{_}20497{_}_Time_.--1 hour to draw the juice.
10136-8{_}20498{_}_Average cost_, with the best isinglass, 3s.
10136-8{_}20499{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 1-1/2 pint of jelly for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}20500{_}_Seasonable_ in June, July, and August.
10136-8{_}20501{_}SWISS CREAM.
10136-8{_}20502{_}1485.
10136-8{_}20503{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}20504{_}of macaroons or 6 small sponge-cakes, sherry, 1 pint of cream, 5 oz.
10136-8{_}20505{_}of lump sugar, 2 large tablespoonfuls of arrowroot, the rind of 1 lemon, the juice of 1/2 lemon, 3 tablespoonfuls of milk.
10136-8{_}20506{_}_Mode_.--Lay the macaroons or sponge-cakes in a glass dish, and pour over them as much sherry as will cover them, or sufficient to soak them well.
10136-8{_}20507{_}Put the cream into a lined saucepan, with the sugar and lemon-rind, and let it remain by the side of the fire until the cream is well flavoured, when take out the lemon-rind.
10136-8{_}20508{_}Mix the arrowroot smoothly with the cold milk; add this to the cream, and let it boil gently for about 3 minutes, keeping it well stirred.
10136-8{_}20509{_}Take it off the fire, stir till nearly cold, when add the lemon-juice, and pour the whole over the cakes.
10136-8{_}20510{_}Garnish the cream with strips of angelica, or candied citron cut thin, or bright-coloured jelly or preserve.
10136-8{_}20511{_}This cream is exceedingly delicious, flavoured with vanilla instead of lemon: when this flavouring is used, the sherry may be omitted, and the mixture poured over the _dry_ cakes.
10136-8{_}20512{_}_Time_.--About 1/2 hour to infuse the lemon-rind; 5 minutes to boil the cream.
10136-8{_}20513{_}_Average cost_, with cream at 1s.
10136-8{_}20514{_}per pint, 3s.
10136-8{_}20515{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}20516{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20517{_}TO MAKE SYLLABUB.
10136-8{_}20518{_}1486.
10136-8{_}20519{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint of sherry or white wine, 1/2 grated nutmeg, sugar to taste, 1-1/2 pint of milk.
10136-8{_}20520{_}_Mode_.--Put the wine into a bowl, with the grated nutmeg and plenty of pounded sugar, and milk into it the above proportion of milk frothed up.
10136-8{_}20521{_}Clouted cream may be laid on the top, with pounded cinnamon or nutmeg and sugar; and a little brandy may be added to the wine before the milk is put in.
10136-8{_}20522{_}In some counties, cider is substituted for the wine: when this is used, brandy must always be added.
10136-8{_}20523{_}Warm milk may be poured on from a spouted jug or teapot; but it must be held very high.
10136-8{_}20524{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}20525{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}20526{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20527{_}TIPSY CAKE.
10136-8{_}20528{_}1487.
10136-8{_}20529{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 moulded sponge-or Savoy-cake, sufficient sweet wine or sherry to soak it, 6 tablespoonfuls of brandy, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}20530{_}of sweet almonds, 1 pint of rich custard.
10136-8{_}20531{_}[Illustration: TIPSY CAKE.]
10136-8{_}20532{_}_Mode_.--Procure a cake that is three or four days old,--either sponge, Savoy, or rice answering for the purpose of a tipsy cake.
10136-8{_}20533{_}Cut the bottom of the cake level, to make it stand firm in the dish; make a small hole in the centre, and pour in and over the cake sufficient sweet wine or sherry, mixed with the above proportion of brandy, to soak it nicely.
10136-8{_}20534{_}When the cake is well soaked, blanch and cut the almonds into strips, stick them all over the cake, and pour round it a good custard, made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}20535{_}1423, allowing 8 eggs instead of 5 to the pint of milk.
10136-8{_}20536{_}The cakes are sometimes crumbled and soaked, and a whipped cream heaped over them, the same as for trifles.
10136-8{_}20537{_}_Time_.--About 2 hours to soak the cake.
10136-8{_}20538{_}_Average cost_, 4s.
10136-8{_}20539{_}6d.
10136-8{_}20540{_}_Sufficient_ for 1 dish.
10136-8{_}20541{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20542{_}ALMOND.--The almond-tree is a native of warmer climates than     Britain, and is indigenous to the northern parts of Africa and     Asia; but it is now commonly cultivated in Italy, Spain, and the     south of France.
10136-8{_}20543{_}It is not usually grown in Britain, and the     fruit seldom ripens in this country: it is much admired for the     beauty of its blossoms.
10136-8{_}20544{_}In the form of its leaves and blossoms     it strongly resembles the peach-tree, and is included in the     same genus by botanists; but the fruit, instead of presenting a     delicious pulp like the peach, shrivels up as it ripens, and     becomes only a tough coriaceous covering to the stone inclosing     the eatable kernel, which is surrounded by a thin bitter skin.
10136-8{_}20545{_}It flowers early in the spring, and produces fruit in August.
10136-8{_}20546{_}There are two sorts of almonds,--sweet and bitter; but they are     considered to be only varieties of the species; and though the     qualities of the kernels are very different, they are not     distinguishable by their appearance.
10136-8{_}20547{_}AN EASY WAY OF MAKING A TIPSY CAKE.
10136-8{_}20548{_}1488.
10136-8{_}20549{_}INGREDIENTS.--12 stale small sponge-cakes, raisin wine, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}20550{_}of jam, 1 pint of custard No.
10136-8{_}20551{_}1423.
10136-8{_}20552{_}_Mode_.--Soak the sponge-cakes, which should be stale (on this account they should be cheaper), in a little raisin wine; arrange them on a deep glass dish in four layers, putting a layer of jam between each, and pour round them a pint of custard, made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}20553{_}1423, decorating the top with cut preserved fruit.
10136-8{_}20554{_}_Time_.--2 hours to soak the cakes.
10136-8{_}20555{_}Average cost, 2s.
10136-8{_}20556{_}6d.
10136-8{_}20557{_}_Sufficient_ for 1 dish.
10136-8{_}20558{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20559{_}TO MAKE A TRIFLE.
10136-8{_}20560{_}1489.
10136-8{_}20561{_}INGREDIENTS.--For the whip, 1 pint of cream, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}20562{_}of pounded sugar, the whites of 2 eggs, a small glass of sherry or raisin wine.
10136-8{_}20563{_}For the trifle, 1 pint of custard, made with 8 eggs to a pint of milk; 6 small sponge-cakes, or 6 slices of sponge-cake; 12 macaroons, 2 dozen ratafias, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}20564{_}of sweet almonds, the grated rind of 1 lemon, a layer of raspberry or strawberry jam, 1/2 pint of sherry or sweet wine, 6 tablespoonfuls of brandy.
10136-8{_}20565{_}[Illustration: TRIFLE.]
10136-8{_}20566{_}_Mode_.--The whip to lay over the top of the trifle should be made the day before it is required for table, as the flavour is better, and it is much more solid than when prepared the same day.
10136-8{_}20567{_}Put into a large bowl the pounded sugar, the whites of the eggs, which should be beaten to a stiff froth, a glass of sherry or sweet wine, and the cream.
10136-8{_}20568{_}Whisk these ingredients well in a cool place, and take off the froth with a skimmer as fast as it rises, and put it on a sieve to drain; continue the whisking till there is sufficient of the whip, which must be put away in a cool place to drain.
10136-8{_}20569{_}The next day, place the sponge-cakes, macaroons, and ratafias at the bottom of a trifle-dish; pour over them 1/2 pint of sherry or sweet wine, mixed with 6 tablespoonfuls of brandy, and, should this proportion of wine not be found quite sufficient, add a little more, as the cakes should be well soaked.
10136-8{_}20570{_}Over the cakes put the grated lemon-rind, the sweet almonds, blanched and cut into strips, and a layer of raspberry or strawberry jam.
10136-8{_}20571{_}Make a good custard by recipe No.
10136-8{_}20572{_}1423, using 8 instead of 5 eggs to the pint of milk, and let this cool a little; then pour it over the cakes, &c. The whip being made the day previously, and the trifle prepared, there remains nothing to do now but heap the whip lightly over the top: this should stand as high as possible, and it may be garnished with strips of bright currant jelly, crystallized sweetmeats, or flowers; the small coloured comfits are sometimes used for the purpose of garnishing a trifle, but they are now considered rather old-fashioned.
10136-8{_}20573{_}(See coloured plate, V1.)
10136-8{_}20574{_}_Average cost_, with cream at 1s.
10136-8{_}20575{_}per pint, 5s.
10136-8{_}20576{_}6d.
10136-8{_}20577{_}_Sufficient_ for 1 trifle.
10136-8{_}20578{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20579{_}VANILLA CREAM.
10136-8{_}20580{_}1490.
10136-8{_}20581{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint of milk, the yolks of 8 eggs, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}20582{_}of sugar, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}20583{_}of isinglass, flavouring to taste of essence of vanilla.
10136-8{_}20584{_}[Illustration: VANILLA-CREAM MOULD.]
10136-8{_}20585{_}_Mode_.--Put the milk and sugar into a saucepan, and let it get hot over a slow fire; beat up the yolks of the eggs, to which add gradually the sweetened milk; flavour the whole with essence of vanilla, put the mixture into a jug, and place this jug in a saucepan of boiling water.
10136-8{_}20586{_}Stir the contents with a wooden spoon one way until the mixture thickens, but do not allow it to boil, or it will be full of lumps.
10136-8{_}20587{_}Take it off the fire; stir in the isinglass, which should be previously dissolved in about 1/4 pint of water, and boiled for 2 or 3 minutes; pour the cream into an oiled mould, put it in a cool place to set, and turn it out carefully on a dish.
10136-8{_}20588{_}Instead of using the essence of vanilla, a pod may be boiled in the milk instead, until the flavour is well extracted.
10136-8{_}20589{_}A pod, or a pod and a half, will be found sufficient for the above proportion of ingredients.
10136-8{_}20590{_}_Time_.--About 10 minutes to stir the mixture.
10136-8{_}20591{_}_Average cost_, with the best isinglass, 2s.
10136-8{_}20592{_}6d.
10136-8{_}20593{_}_Sufficient_ to fill a quart mould.
10136-8{_}20594{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20595{_}VANILLE or VANILLA, is the fruit of the vanillier, a parasitical     herbaceous plant, which flourishes in Brazil, Mexico, and Peru.
10136-8{_}20596{_}The fruit is a long capsule, thick and fleshy.
10136-8{_}20597{_}Certain species     of this fruit contain a pulp with a delicious perfume and     flavour.
10136-8{_}20598{_}Vanilla is principally imported from Mexico.
10136-8{_}20599{_}The     capsules for export are always picked at perfect maturity.
10136-8{_}20600{_}The     essence is the form in which it is used generally and most     conveniently.
10136-8{_}20601{_}Its properties are stimulating and exciting.
10136-8{_}20602{_}It is     in daily use for ices, chocolates, and flavouring confections     generally.
10136-8{_}20603{_}VICTORIA SANDWICHES.
10136-8{_}20604{_}1491.
10136-8{_}20605{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 eggs; their weight in pounded sugar, butter, and flour; 1/4 saltspoonful of salt, a layer of any kind of jam or marmalade.
10136-8{_}20606{_}_Mode_.--Beat the butter to a cream; dredge in the flour and pounded sugar; stir these ingredients well together, and add the eggs, which should be previously thoroughly whisked.
10136-8{_}20607{_}When the mixture has been well beaten for about 10 minutes, butter a Yorkshire-pudding tin, pour in the batter, and bake it in a moderate oven for 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}20608{_}Let it cool, spread one half of the cake with a layer of nice preserve, place over it the other half of the cake, press the pieces slightly together, and then cut it into long finger-pieces; pile them in crossbars on a glass dish, and serve.
10136-8{_}20609{_}_Time_.--20 minutes.
10136-8{_}20610{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}20611{_}3d.
10136-8{_}20612{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}20613{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20614{_}WHIPPED CREAM, for putting on Trifles, serving in Glasses, &c.  1492.
10136-8{_}20615{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every pint of cream allow 3 oz.
10136-8{_}20616{_}of pounded sugar, 1 glass of sherry or any kind of sweet white wine, the rind of 1/2 lemon, the white of 1 egg.
10136-8{_}20617{_}[Illustration: PASTRY LEAF.]
10136-8{_}20618{_}_Mode_.--Rub the sugar on the lemon-rind, and pound it in a mortar until quite fine, and beat up the white of the egg until quite stiff; put the cream into a large bowl, with the sugar, wine, and beaten egg, and whip it to a froth; as fast as the froth rises, take it off with a skimmer, and put it on a sieve to drain, in a cool place.
10136-8{_}20619{_}This should be made the day before it is wanted, as the whip is then so much firmer.
10136-8{_}20620{_}The cream should be whipped in a cool place, and in summer, over ice, if it is obtainable.
10136-8{_}20621{_}A plain whipped cream may be served on a glass dish, and garnished with strips of angelica, or pastry leaves, or pieces of bright-coloured jelly: it makes a very pretty addition to the supper-table.
10136-8{_}20622{_}_Time_.--About 1 hour to whip the cream.
10136-8{_}20623{_}_Average cost_, with cream at 1s.
10136-8{_}20624{_}per pint, 1s.
10136-8{_}20625{_}9d.
10136-8{_}20626{_}_Sufficient_ for 1 dish or 1 trifle.
10136-8{_}20627{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20628{_}WHIPPED SYLLABUBS.
10136-8{_}20629{_}1493.
10136-8{_}20630{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of cream, 1/4 pint of sherry, half that quantity of brandy, the juice of 1/2 lemon, a little grated nutmeg, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}20631{_}of pounded sugar, whipped cream the same as for trifle No.
10136-8{_}20632{_}1489.
10136-8{_}20633{_}_Mode_.--Mix all the ingredients together, put the syllabub into glasses, and over the top of them heap a little whipped cream, made in the same manner as for trifle No.
10136-8{_}20634{_}1489.
10136-8{_}20635{_}Solid syllabub is made by whisking or milling the mixture to a stiff froth, and putting it in the glasses, without the whipped cream at the top.
10136-8{_}20636{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}20637{_}8d.
10136-8{_}20638{_}_Sufficient_ to fill 8 or 9 glasses.
10136-8{_}20639{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}20640{_}THE CURE'S OMELET.
10136-8{_}20641{_}"Every one knows," says Brillat Savarin, in his "Physiology of Taste," "that for twenty years Madame Récamier was the most beautiful woman in Paris.
10136-8{_}20642{_}It is also well known that she was exceedingly charitable, and took a great interest in every benevolent work.
10136-8{_}20643{_}Wishing to consult the Curé of ---- respecting the working of an institution, she went to his house at five o'clock in the afternoon, and was much astonished at finding him already at his dinner-table.
10136-8{_}20644{_}"Madame Récamier wished to retire, but the Curé would not hear of it.
10136-8{_}20645{_}A neat white cloth covered the table; some good old wine sparkled in a crystal decanter; the porcelain was of the best; the plates had heaters of boiling water beneath them; a neatly-costumed maid-servant was in attendance.
10136-8{_}20646{_}The repast was a compromise between frugality and luxury.
10136-8{_}20647{_}The crawfish-soup had just been removed, and there was on the table a salmon-trout, an omelet, and a salad.
10136-8{_}20648{_}"'My dinner will tell you,' said the worthy Curé, with a smile, 'that it is fast-day, according to our Church's regulations.'
10136-8{_}20649{_}Madame Récamier and her host attacked the trout, the sauce served with which betrayed a skilful hand, the countenance of the Curé the while showing satisfaction.
10136-8{_}20650{_}"And now they fell upon the omelet, which was round, sufficiently thick, and cooked, so to speak, to a hair's-breadth.
10136-8{_}20651{_}"As the spoon entered the omelet, a thick rich juice issued from it, pleasant to the eye as well as to the smell; the dish became full of it; and our fair friend owns that, between the perfume and the sight, it made her mouth water.
10136-8{_}20652{_}"'It is an _omelette au thon_' (that is to say, a tunny omelet), said the Curé, noticing, with the greatest delight, the emotion of Madame Récamier, 'and few people taste it without lavishing praises on it.'
10136-8{_}20653{_}"'It surprises me not at all,' returned the beauty; 'never has so enticing an omelet met my gaze at any of our lay tables.'
10136-8{_}20654{_}"'My cook understands them well, I think.'
10136-8{_}20655{_}"'Yes,' added Madame, 'I never ate anything so delightful.'"
10136-8{_}20656{_}Then came the salad, which Savarin recommends to all who place confidence in him.
10136-8{_}20657{_}It refreshes without exciting; and he has a theory that it makes people younger.
10136-8{_}20658{_}Amidst pleasant converse the dessert arrived.
10136-8{_}20659{_}It consisted of three apples, cheese, and a plate of preserves; and then upon a little round table was served the Mocha coffee, for which France has been, and is, so justly famous.
10136-8{_}20660{_}"'I never,' said the Curé, 'take spirits; I always offer liqueurs to my guests but reserve the use of them, myself, to my old age, if it should please Providence to grant me that.'
10136-8{_}20661{_}"Finally, the charming Madame Récamier took her leave, and told all her friends of the delicious omelet which she had seen and partaken of."
10136-8{_}20662{_}And Brillat Savarin, in his capacity as the Layard of the concealed treasures of Gastronomia, has succeeded in withdrawing from obscurity the details of the preparation of which so much had been said, and which he imagines to be as wholesome as it was agreeable.
10136-8{_}20663{_}Here follows the recipe:--  OMELETTE AU THON.
10136-8{_}20664{_}1494.
10136-8{_}20665{_}Take, for 6 persons, the roes of 2 carp; [Footnote: An American writer says he has followed this recipe, substituting pike, shad, &c., in the place of carp, and can recommend all these also, with a quiet conscience.
10136-8{_}20666{_}Any fish, indeed, may be used with success.]
10136-8{_}20667{_}bleach them, by putting them, for 5 minutes, in boiling water slightly salted.
10136-8{_}20668{_}Take a piece of fresh tunny about the size of a hen's egg, to which add a small shalot already chopped; hash up together the roe and the tunny, so as to mix them well, and throw the whole into a saucepan, with a sufficient quantity of very good butter: whip it up until the butter is melted!
10136-8{_}20669{_}This constitutes the specialty of the omelet.
10136-8{_}20670{_}Take a second piece of butter, _à discrétion_, mix it with parsley and herbs, place it in a long-shaped dish destined to receive the omelet; squeeze the juice of a lemon over it, and place it on hot embers.
10136-8{_}20671{_}Beat up 12 eggs (the fresher the better); throw up the sauté of roe and tunny, stirring it so as to mix all well together; then make your omelet in the usual manner, endeavouring to turn it out long, thick, and soft.
10136-8{_}20672{_}Spread it carefully on the dish prepared for it, and serve at once.
10136-8{_}20673{_}This dish ought to be reserved for recherché déjeûners, or for assemblies where amateurs meet who know how to eat well; washed down with a good old wine, it will work wonders.
10136-8{_}20674{_}_Note_.--The roe and the tunny must be beaten up (sauté) without allowing them to boil, to prevent their hardening, which would prevent them mixing well with the eggs.
10136-8{_}20675{_}Your dish should be hollowed towards the centre, to allow the gravy to concentrate, that it may be helped with a spoon.
10136-8{_}20676{_}The dish ought to be slightly heated, otherwise the cold china will extract all the heat from the omelet.
10136-8{_}20677{_}[Illustration]     [Illustration]  CHAPTER XXX.
10136-8{_}20678{_}GENERAL OBSERVATIONS ON PRESERVES, CONFECTIONARY, ICES, AND DESSERT DISHES.
10136-8{_}20679{_}PRESERVES.
10136-8{_}20680{_}1495.
10136-8{_}20681{_}From the nature of vegetable substances, and chiefly from their not passing so rapidly into the putrescent state as animal bodies, the mode of preserving them is somewhat different, although the general principles are the same.
10136-8{_}20682{_}All the means of preservation are put in practice occasionally for fruits and the various parts of vegetables, according to the nature of the species, the climate, the uses to which they are applied, &c. Some are dried, as nuts, raisins, sweet herbs, &c.; others are preserved by means of sugar, such as many fruits whose delicate juices would be lost by drying; some are preserved by means of vinegar, and chiefly used as condiments or pickles; a few also by salting, as French beans; while others are preserved in spirits.
10136-8{_}20683{_}We have, however, in this place to treat of the best methods of preserving fruits.
10136-8{_}20684{_}Fruit is a most important item in the economy of health; the epicurean can scarcely be said to have any luxuries without it; therefore, as it is so invaluable, when we cannot have it fresh, we must have it preserved.
10136-8{_}20685{_}It has long been a desideratum to preserve fruits by some cheap method, yet by such as would keep them fit for the various culinary purposes, as making tarts and other similar dishes.
10136-8{_}20686{_}The expense of preserving them with sugar is a serious objection; for, except the sugar is used in considerable quantities, the success is very uncertain.
10136-8{_}20687{_}Sugar also overpowers and destroys the sub-acid taste so desirable in many fruits: these which are preserved in this manner are chiefly intended for the dessert.
10136-8{_}20688{_}Fruits intended for preservation should be gathered in the morning, in dry weather, with the morning sun upon them, if possible; they will then have their fullest flavour, and keep in good condition longer than when gathered at any other time.
10136-8{_}20689{_}Until fruit can be used, it should be placed in the dairy, an ice-house, or a refrigerator.
10136-8{_}20690{_}In an icehouse it will remain fresh and plump for several days.
10136-8{_}20691{_}Fruit gathered in wet or foggy weather will soon be mildewed, and be of no service for preserves.
10136-8{_}20692{_}1496.
10136-8{_}20693{_}Having secured the first and most important contribution to the manufacture of preserves,--the fruit, the next consideration is the preparation of the syrup in which the fruit is to be suspended; and this requires much care.
10136-8{_}20694{_}In the confectioner's art there is a great nicety in proportioning the degree of concentration of the syrup very exactly to each particular case; and they know this by signs, and express it by certain technical terms.
10136-8{_}20695{_}But to distinguish these properly requires very great attention and considerable experience.
10136-8{_}20696{_}The principal thing to be acquainted with is the fact, that, in proportion as the syrup is longer boiled, its water will become evaporated, and its consistency will be thicker.
10136-8{_}20697{_}Great care must be taken in the management of the fire, that the syrup does not boil over, and that the boiling is not carried to such an extent as to burn the sugar.
10136-8{_}20698{_}1497.
10136-8{_}20699{_}The first degree of consistency is called _the thread_, which is subdivided into the little and great thread.
10136-8{_}20700{_}If you dip the finger into the syrup and apply it to the thumb, the tenacity of the syrup will, on separating the finger and thumb, afford a thread, which shortly breaks: this is the little thread.
10136-8{_}20701{_}If the thread, from the greater tenacity, and, consequently, greater strength of the syrup, admits of a greater extension of the finger and thumb, it is called the great thread.
10136-8{_}20702{_}There are half a dozen other terms and experiments for testing the various thickness of the boiling sugar towards the consistency called _caramel_; but that degree of sugar-boiling belongs to the confectioner.
10136-8{_}20703{_}A solution of sugar prepared by dissolving two parts of double-refined sugar (the best sugar is the most economical for preserves) in one of water, and boiling this a little, affords a syrup of the right degree of strength, and which neither ferments nor crystallizes.
10136-8{_}20704{_}This appears to be the degree called _smooth_ by the confectioners, and is proper to be used for the purposes of preserves.
10136-8{_}20705{_}The syrup employed should sometimes be clarified, which is done in the following manner:--Dissolve 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}20706{_}of loaf sugar in a pint of water; add to this solution the white of an egg, and beat it well.
10136-8{_}20707{_}Put the preserving-pan upon the fire with the solution; stir it with a wooden spatula, and, when it begins to swell and boil up, throw in some cold water or a little oil, to damp the boiling; for, as it rises suddenly, if it should boil over, it would take fire, being of a very inflammable nature.
10136-8{_}20708{_}Let it boil up again; then take it off, and remove carefully the scum that has risen.
10136-8{_}20709{_}Boil the solution again, throw in a little more cold water, remove the scum, and so on for three or four times successively; then strain it.
10136-8{_}20710{_}It is considered to be sufficiently boiled when some taken up in a spoon pours out like oil.
10136-8{_}20711{_}1498.
10136-8{_}20712{_}Although sugar passes so easily into the state of fermentation, and is, in fact, the only substance capable of undergoing the vinous stage of that process, yet it will not ferment at all if the quantity be sufficient to constitute a very strong syrup: hence, syrups are used to preserve fruits and other vegetable substances from the changes they would undergo if left to themselves.
10136-8{_}20713{_}Before sugar was in use, honey was employed to preserve many vegetable productions, though this substance has now given way to the juice of the sugar-cane.
10136-8{_}20714{_}1499.
10136-8{_}20715{_}The fruits that are the most fit for preservation in syrup are, apricots, peaches, nectarines, apples, greengages, plums of all kinds, and pears.
10136-8{_}20716{_}As an example, take some apricots not too ripe, make a small slit at the stem end, and push out the stone; simmer them in water till they are softened and about half done, and afterwards throw them into cold water.
10136-8{_}20717{_}When they have cooled, take them out and drain them.
10136-8{_}20718{_}Put the apricots into the pie-serving-pan with sufficient syrup to cover them; let them boil up three or four times, and then skim them; remove them from the fire, pour them into an earthen pan, and let them cool till next day.
10136-8{_}20719{_}Boil them up three days successively, skimming each time, and they will then be finished and in a state fit to be put into pots for use.
10136-8{_}20720{_}After each bailing, it is proper to examine into the state of the syrup when cold; if too thin, it will bear additional boiling; if too thick, it may be lowered with more syrup of the usual standard.
10136-8{_}20721{_}The reason why the fruit is emptied out of the preserving-pan into an earthen pan is, that the acid of the fruit acts upon the copper, of which the preserving-pans are usually made.
10136-8{_}20722{_}From this example the process of preserving fruits by syrup will be easily comprehended.
10136-8{_}20723{_}The first object is to soften the fruit by blanching or boiling it in water, in order that the syrup by which it is preserved may penetrate through its substance.
10136-8{_}20724{_}1500.
10136-8{_}20725{_}Many fruits, when preserved by boiling, lose much of their peculiar and delicate flavour, as, for instance, pine-apples; and this inconvenience may, in some instances, be remedied by preserving them without heat.
10136-8{_}20726{_}Cut the fruit in slices about one fifth of an inch thick, strew powdered loaf sugar an eighth of an inch thick on the bottom of a jar, and put the slices on it.
10136-8{_}20727{_}Put more sugar on this, and then another layer of the slices, and so on till the jar is full.
10136-8{_}20728{_}Place the jar with the fruit up to the neck in boiling water, and keep it there till the sugar is completely dissolved, which may take half an hour, removing the scum as it rises.
10136-8{_}20729{_}Lastly, tie a wet bladder over the mouth of the jar, or cork and wax it.
10136-8{_}20730{_}1501.
10136-8{_}20731{_}Any of the fruits that have been preserved in syrup may be converted into dry preserves, by first draining them from the syrup, and then drying them in a stove or very moderate oven, adding to them a quantity of powdered loaf sugar, which will gradually penetrate the fruit, while the fluid parts of the syrup gently evaporate.
10136-8{_}20732{_}They should be dried in the stove or oven on a sieve, and turned every six or eight hours, fresh powdered sugar being sifted over them every time they are turned.
10136-8{_}20733{_}Afterwards, they are to be kept in a dry situation, in drawers or boxes.
10136-8{_}20734{_}Currants and cherries preserved whole in this manner, in bunches, are extremely elegant, and have a fine flavour.
10136-8{_}20735{_}In this way it is, also, that orange and lemon chips are preserved.
10136-8{_}20736{_}1502.
10136-8{_}20737{_}Marmalades, jams, and fruit pastes are of the same nature, and are now in very general request.
10136-8{_}20738{_}They are prepared without difficulty, by attending to a very few directions; they are somewhat expensive, but may be kept without spoiling for a considerable time.
10136-8{_}20739{_}Marmalades and jams differ little from each other: they are preserves of a half-liquid consistency, made by boiling the pulp of fruits, and sometimes part of the rinds, with sugar.
10136-8{_}20740{_}The appellation of marmalade is applied to those confitures which are composed of the firmer fruits, as pineapples or the rinds of oranges; whereas jams are made of the more juicy berries, such as strawberries, raspberries, currants, mulberries, &c. Fruit pastes are a kind of marmalades, consisting of the pulp of fruits, first evaporated to a proper consistency, and afterwards boiled with sugar.
10136-8{_}20741{_}The mixture is then poured into a mould, or spread on sheets of tin, and subsequently dried in the oven or stove till it has acquired the state of a paste.
10136-8{_}20742{_}From a sheet of this paste, strips may be cut and formed into any shape that may be desired, as knots, rings, &c. Jams require the same care and attention in the boiling as marmalade; the slightest degree of burning communicates a disagreeable empyreumatic taste, and if they are not boiled sufficiently, they will not keep.
10136-8{_}20743{_}That they may keep, it is necessary not to be sparing of sugar.
10136-8{_}20744{_}1503.
10136-8{_}20745{_}In all the operations for preserve-making, when the preserving-pan is used, it should not be placed on the fire, but on a trivet, unless the jam is made on a hot plate, when this is not necessary.
10136-8{_}20746{_}If the pan is placed close on to the fire, the preserve is very liable to burn, and the colour and flavour be consequently spoiled.
10136-8{_}20747{_}1504.
10136-8{_}20748{_}Fruit jellies are compounds of the juices of fruits combined with sugar, concentrated, by boiling, to such a consistency that the liquid, upon cooling, assumes the form of a tremulous jelly.
10136-8{_}20749{_}1505.
10136-8{_}20750{_}Before fruits are candied, they must first be boiled in syrup, after which they are taken out and dried on a stove, or before the fire; the syrup is then to be concentrated, or boiled to a candy height, and the fruit dipped in it, and again laid on the stove to dry and candy: they are then to be put into boxes, and kept dry.
10136-8{_}20751{_}1506.
10136-8{_}20752{_}Conserves consist of fresh vegetable matters beat into a uniform mass with refined sugar, and they are intended to preserve the virtues and properties of recent flowers, leaves, roots, peels, or fruits, unaltered, and as near as possible to what they were when fresh gathered, and to give them an agreeable taste.
10136-8{_}20753{_}1507.
10136-8{_}20754{_}The last-mentioned, but not the least-important preparation of fruit, is the _compôte,_ a confiture made at the moment of need, and with much less sugar than would be ordinarily put to preserves.
10136-8{_}20755{_}They are most wholesome things, suitable to most stomachs which cannot accommodate themselves to raw fruit or a large portion of sugar: they are the happy medium, and far better than ordinary stewed fruit.
10136-8{_}20756{_}CONFECTIONARY.
10136-8{_}20757{_}1508.
10136-8{_}20758{_}In speaking of confectionary, it should be remarked that all the various preparations above named come, strictly speaking, under that head; for the various fruits, flowers, herbs, roots, and juices, which, when boiled with sugar, were formerly employed in pharmacy as well as for sweetmeats, were called _confections_, from the Latin word _conficere_, 'to make up;' but the term confectionary embraces a very large class indeed of sweet food, many kinds of which should not be attempted in the ordinary cuisine.
10136-8{_}20759{_}The thousand and one ornamental dishes that adorn the tables of the wealthy should be purchased from the confectioner: they cannot profitably be made at home.
10136-8{_}20760{_}Apart from these, cakes, biscuits, and tarts, &c., the class of sweetmeats called confections may be thus classified:--1.
