10136-8{_}20761{_}Liquid confects, or fruits either whole or in pieces, preserved by being immersed in a fluid transparent syrup; as the liquid confects of apricots, green citrons, and many foreign fruits.
10136-8{_}20762{_}2.
10136-8{_}20763{_}Dry confects are those which, after having been boiled in the syrup, are taken out and put to dry in an oven, as citron and orange-peel, &c. 3.
10136-8{_}20764{_}Marmalade, jams, and pastes, a kind of soft compounds made of the pulp of fruits or other vegetable substances, beat up with sugar or honey; such as oranges, apricots, pears, &c. 4.
10136-8{_}20765{_}Jellies are the juices of fruits boiled with sugar to a pretty thick consistency, so as, upon cooling, to form a trembling jelly; as currant, gooseberry, apple jelly, &c. 5.
10136-8{_}20766{_}Conserves are a kind of dry confects, made by beating up flowers, fruits, &c., with sugar, not dissolved.
10136-8{_}20767{_}6.
10136-8{_}20768{_}Candies are fruits candied over with sugar after having been boiled in the syrup.
10136-8{_}20769{_}DESSERT DISHES.
10136-8{_}20770{_}1509.
10136-8{_}20771{_}With moderns the dessert is not so profuse, nor does it hold the same relationship to the dinner that it held with the ancients,--the Romans more especially.
10136-8{_}20772{_}On ivory tables they would spread hundreds of different kinds of raw, cooked, and preserved fruits, tarts and cakes, as substitutes for the more substantial comestibles with which the guests were satiated.
10136-8{_}20773{_}However, as late as the reigns of our two last Georges, fabulous sums were often expended upon fanciful desserts.
10136-8{_}20774{_}The dessert certainly repays, in its general effect, the expenditure upon it of much pains; and it may be said, that if there be any poetry at all in meals, or the process of feeding, there is poetry in the dessert, the materials for which should be selected with taste, and, of course, must depend, in a great measure, upon the season.
10136-8{_}20775{_}Pines, melons, grapes, peaches, nectarines, plums, strawberries, apples, pears, oranges, almonds, raisins, figs, walnuts, filberts, medlars, cherries, &c. &c., all kinds of dried fruits, and choice and delicately-flavoured cakes and biscuits, make up the dessert, together with the most costly and _recherché_ wines.
10136-8{_}20776{_}The shape of the dishes varies at different periods, the prevailing fashion at present being oval and circular dishes on stems.
10136-8{_}20777{_}The patterns and colours are also subject to changes of fashion; some persons selecting china, chaste in pattern and colour; others, elegantly-shaped glass dishes on stems, with gilt edges.
10136-8{_}20778{_}The beauty of the dessert services at the tables of the wealthy tends to enhance the splendour of the plate.
10136-8{_}20779{_}The general mode of putting a dessert on table, now the elegant tazzas are fashionable, is, to place them down the middle of the table, a tall and short dish alternately; the fresh fruits being arranged on the tall dishes, and dried fruits, bon-bons, &c., on small round or oval glass plates.
10136-8{_}20780{_}The garnishing needs especial attention, as the contrast of the brilliant-coloured fruits with nicely-arranged foliage is very charming.
10136-8{_}20781{_}The garnish _par excellence_ for dessert is the ice-plant; its crystallized dewdrops producing a marvellous effect in the height of summer, giving a most inviting sense of coolness to the fruit it encircles.
10136-8{_}20782{_}The double-edged mallow, strawberry, and vine leaves have a pleasing effect; and for winter desserts, the bay, cuba, and laurel are sometimes used.
10136-8{_}20783{_}In town, the expense and difficulty of obtaining natural foliage is great, but paper and composite leaves are to be purchased at an almost nominal price.
10136-8{_}20784{_}Mixed fruits of the larger sort are now frequently served on one dish.
10136-8{_}20785{_}This mode admits of the display of much taste in the arrangement of the fruit: for instance, a pine in the centre of the dish, surrounded with large plums of various sorts and colours, mixed with pears, rosy-cheeked apples, all arranged with a due regard to colour, have a very good effect.
10136-8{_}20786{_}Again, apples and pears look well mingled with plums and grapes, hanging from the border of the dish in a _négligé_ sort of manner, with a large bunch of the same fruit lying on the top of the apples.
10136-8{_}20787{_}A dessert would not now be considered complete without candied and preserved fruits and confections.
10136-8{_}20788{_}The candied fruits may be purchased at a less cost than they can be manufactured at home.
10136-8{_}20789{_}They are preserved abroad in most ornamental and elegant forms.
10136-8{_}20790{_}And since, from the facilities of travel, we have become so familiar with the tables of the French, chocolate in different forms is indispensable to our desserts.
10136-8{_}20791{_}ICES.
10136-8{_}20792{_}510.
10136-8{_}20793{_}Ices are composed, it is scarcely necessary to say, of congealed cream or water, combined sometimes with liqueurs or other flavouring ingredients, or more generally with the juices of fruits.
10136-8{_}20794{_}At desserts, or at some evening parties, ices are scarcely to be dispensed with.
10136-8{_}20795{_}The principal utensils required for making ice-creams are ice-tubs, freezing-pots, spaddles, and a cellaret.
10136-8{_}20796{_}The tub must be large enough to contain about a bushel of ice, pounded small, when brought out of the ice-house, and mixed very carefully with either _salt, nitre,_ or _soda._ The freezing-pot is best made of pewter.
10136-8{_}20797{_}If it be of tin, as is sometimes the case, the congelation goes on too rapidly in it for the thorough intermingling of its contents, on which the excellence of the ice greatly depends.
10136-8{_}20798{_}The spaddle is generally made of copper, kept bright and clean.
10136-8{_}20799{_}The cellaret is a tin vessel, in which ices are kept for a short time from dissolving.
10136-8{_}20800{_}The method to be pursued in the freezing process must be attended to.
10136-8{_}20801{_}When the ice-tub is prepared with fresh-pounded ice and salt, the freezing-pot is put into it up to its cover.
10136-8{_}20802{_}The articles to be congealed are then poured into it and covered over; but to prevent the ingredients from separating and the heaviest of them from falling to the bottom of the mould, it is requisite to turn the freezing-pot round and round by the handle, so as to keep its contents moving until the congelation commences.
10136-8{_}20803{_}As soon as this is perceived (the cover of the pot being occasionally taken off for the purpose of noticing when freezing takes place), the cover is immediately closed over it, ice is put upon it, and it is left in this state till it is served.
10136-8{_}20804{_}The use of the spaddle is to stir up and remove from the sides of the freezing pot the cream, which in the shaking may have washed against it, and by stirring it in with the rest, to prevent waste of it occurring.
10136-8{_}20805{_}Any negligence in stirring the contents of the freezing-pot before congelation takes place, will destroy the whole: either the sugar sinks to the bottom and leaves the ice insufficiently sweetened, or lumps are formed, which disfigure and discolour it.
10136-8{_}20806{_}1511.
10136-8{_}20807{_}The aged, the delicate, and children should abstain from ices or iced beverages; even the strong and healthy should partake of them in moderation.
10136-8{_}20808{_}They should be taken immediately after the repast, or some hours after, because the taking these substances _during_ the process of digestion is apt to provoke indisposition.
10136-8{_}20809{_}It is necessary, then, that this function should have scarcely commenced, or that it should be completely finished, before partaking of ices.
10136-8{_}20810{_}It is also necessary to abstain from them when persons are very warm, or immediately after taking violent exercise, as in some cases they have produced illnesses which have ended fatally.
10136-8{_}20811{_}[Do ladies know to whom they are indebted for the introduction of ices, which all the fair sex are passionately fond of?--To Catherine de' Medici.
10136-8{_}20812{_}Will not this fact cover a multitude of sins committed by the instigator of St. Bartholomew ?]
10136-8{_}20813{_}RECIPES.
10136-8{_}20814{_}CHAPTER XXXI.
10136-8{_}20815{_}TO MAKE SYRUP FOR COMPOTES, &c.  1512.
10136-8{_}20816{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}20817{_}of sugar allow 1-1/2 pint of water.
10136-8{_}20818{_}_Mode_.--Boil the sugar and water together for 1/4 hour, carefully removing the scum as it rises: the syrup is then ready for the fruit.
10136-8{_}20819{_}The articles boiled in this syrup will not keep for any length of time, it being suitable only for dishes intended to be eaten immediately.
10136-8{_}20820{_}A larger proportion of sugar must be added for a syrup intended to keep.
10136-8{_}20821{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}20822{_}TO CLARIFY SUGAR OR SYRUP.
10136-8{_}20823{_}1513.
10136-8{_}20824{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}20825{_}of sugar allow 1/2 pint of water and 1/2 the white of an egg.
10136-8{_}20826{_}_Mode_.--Put the sugar, water, and the white of the egg, which should, be well beaten, into a preserving-pan or lined saucepan; and do not put it on the fire till the sugar is dissolved.
10136-8{_}20827{_}Then place it on the fire, and when it boils, throw in a teacupful of cold water, and do not stir the sugar after this is added.
10136-8{_}20828{_}Bring it to the boiling-point again, and then place the pan by the side of the fire, for the preparation to settle.
10136-8{_}20829{_}Remove all the scum, and the sugar will be ready for use.
10136-8{_}20830{_}The scum should be placed on a sieve, so that what syrup runs from it may be boiled up again: this must also be well skimmed.
10136-8{_}20831{_}_Time_.--20 minutes for the sugar to dissolve; 5 minutes to boil.
10136-8{_}20832{_}_Note_.--The above two recipes are those used in the preparation of dishes usually made at home.
10136-8{_}20833{_}There are many degrees of boiling sugar, which process requires great care, attention, and experience.
10136-8{_}20834{_}Caramel sugar, which makes an elegant cover for sweetmeats, is difficult to prepare, and is best left to an experienced confectioner.
10136-8{_}20835{_}We give the recipe, for those of our readers who care to attempt the operation.
10136-8{_}20836{_}TO BOIL SUGAR TO CARAMEL.
10136-8{_}20837{_}1514.
10136-8{_}20838{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}20839{_}of lump sugar allow 1 gill of spring water.
10136-8{_}20840{_}_Mode_.--Boil the sugar and water together very quickly over a clear fire, skimming it very carefully as soon as it boils.
10136-8{_}20841{_}Keep it boiling until the sugar snaps when a little of it is dropped in a pan of cold water.
10136-8{_}20842{_}If it remains hard, the sugar has attained the right degree; then squeeze in a little lemon-juice, and let it remain an instant on the fire.
10136-8{_}20843{_}Set the pan into another of cold water, and the caramel is then ready for use.
10136-8{_}20844{_}The insides of well-oiled moulds are often ornamented with this sugar, which with a fork should be spread over them in fine threads or network.
10136-8{_}20845{_}A dish of light pastry, tastefully arranged, looks very prettily with this sugar spun lightly over it.
10136-8{_}20846{_}The sugar must be carefully watched, and taken up the instant it is done.
10136-8{_}20847{_}Unless the cook is very experienced and thoroughly understands her business, it is scarcely worth while to attempt to make this elaborate ornament, as it may be purchased quite as economically at a confectioner's, if the failures in the preparation are taken into consideration.
10136-8{_}20848{_}COMPOTE OF APPLES.
10136-8{_}20849{_}_(Soyer's Recipe,--a Dessert Dish.
10136-8{_}20850{_})_  1515.
10136-8{_}20851{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 ripe apples, 1 lemon, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}20852{_}of lump sugar, 1/2 pint of water.
10136-8{_}20853{_}[Illustration: COMPÔTE OF APPLES.]
10136-8{_}20854{_}_Mode_.--Select the apples of a moderate size, peel them, cut them in halves, remove the cores, and rub each piece over with a little lemon.
10136-8{_}20855{_}Put the sugar and water together into a lined saucepan, and let them boil until forming a thickish syrup, when lay in the apples with the rind of the lemon cut thin, and the juice of the same.
10136-8{_}20856{_}Let the apples simmer till tender; then take them out very carefully, drain them on a sieve, and reduce the syrup by boiling it quickly for a few minutes.
10136-8{_}20857{_}When both are cold, arrange the apples neatly on a glass dish, pour over the syrup, and garnish with strips of green angelica or candied citron.
10136-8{_}20858{_}Smaller apples may be dressed in the same manner: they should not be divided in half, but peeled and the cores pushed out with a vegetable-cutter.
10136-8{_}20859{_}_Time_.--10 minutes to boil the sugar and water together; from 15 to 25 minutes to simmer the apples.
10136-8{_}20860{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}20861{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}20862{_}_Seasonable_ from July to March.
10136-8{_}20863{_}APPLE GINGER.
10136-8{_}20864{_}(_A Dessert Dish_.)
10136-8{_}20865{_}1516 INGREDIENTS.--2 lbs.
10136-8{_}20866{_}of any kind of hard apples, 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}20867{_}of loaf sugar, 1-1/2 pint of water, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}20868{_}of tincture of ginger.
10136-8{_}20869{_}_Mode_.--Boil the sugar and water until they form a rich syrup, adding the ginger when it boils up.
10136-8{_}20870{_}Pare, core, and cut the apples into pieces; dip them in cold water to preserve the colour, and boil them in the syrup until transparent; but be careful not to let them break.
10136-8{_}20871{_}Put the pieces of apple into jars, pour over the syrup, and carefully exclude the air, by well covering them.
10136-8{_}20872{_}It will remain good some time, if kept in a dry place.
10136-8{_}20873{_}_Time_.--From 5 to 10 minutes to boil the syrup; about 1/2 hour to simmer the apples.
10136-8{_}20874{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}20875{_}_Sufficient_ for 7 or 8 persons.
10136-8{_}20876{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in September, October, or November.
10136-8{_}20877{_}APPLE JAM.
10136-8{_}20878{_}1517.
10136-8{_}20879{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}20880{_}of fruit weighed after being pared, cored, and sliced, allow 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}20881{_}of preserving-sugar, the grated rind of 1 lemon, the juice of 1/2 lemon.
10136-8{_}20882{_}_Mode_.--Peel the apples, core and slice them very thin, and be particular that they are all the same sort.
10136-8{_}20883{_}Put them into a jar, stand this in a saucepan of boiling water, and let the apples stew until quite tender.
10136-8{_}20884{_}Previously to putting the fruit into the jar, weigh it, to ascertain the proportion of sugar that may be required.
10136-8{_}20885{_}Put the apples into a preserving-pan, crush the sugar to small lumps, and add it, with the grated lemon-rind and juice, to the apples.
10136-8{_}20886{_}Simmer these over the fire for 1/2 hour, reckoning from the time the jam begins to simmer properly; remove the scum as it rises, and when the jam is done, put it into pots for use.
10136-8{_}20887{_}Place a piece of oiled paper over the jam, and to exclude the air, cover the pots with tissue-paper dipped in the white of an egg, and stretched over the top.
10136-8{_}20888{_}This jam will keep good for a long time.
10136-8{_}20889{_}_Time_.--About 2 hours to stew in the jar; 1/2 hour to boil after the jam begins to simmer.
10136-8{_}20890{_}_Average cost_, for this quantity, 6s.
10136-8{_}20891{_}_Sufficient._--7 or 8 lbs.
10136-8{_}20892{_}of apples for 6 pots of jam.
10136-8{_}20893{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in September, October, or November.
10136-8{_}20894{_}APPLE JELLY.
10136-8{_}20895{_}I.
10136-8{_}20896{_}1518.
10136-8{_}20897{_}INGREDIENTS.--To 6 lbs.
10136-8{_}20898{_}of apples allow 3 pints of water; to every quart of juice allow 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}20899{_}of loaf sugar;--the juice of 1/2 lemon.
10136-8{_}20900{_}_Mode_.--Pare, core, and cut the apples into slices, and put them into a jar, with water in the above proportion.
10136-8{_}20901{_}Place them in a cool oven, with the jar well covered, and when the juice is thoroughly drawn and the apples are quite soft, strain them through a jelly-bag.
10136-8{_}20902{_}To every quart of juice allow 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}20903{_}of loaf sugar, which should be crushed to small lumps, and put into a preserving-pan with the juice.
10136-8{_}20904{_}Boil these together for rather more than 1/2 hour, remove the scum as it rises, add the lemon-juice just before it is done, and put the jelly into pots for use.
10136-8{_}20905{_}This preparation is useful for garnishing sweet dishes, and may be turned out for dessert.
10136-8{_}20906{_}_Time_.--The apples to be put in the oven over-night, and left till morning; rather more than 1/2 hour to boil the jelly.
10136-8{_}20907{_}_Average cost_, for this quantity, 3s.
10136-8{_}20908{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 small pots of jelly.
10136-8{_}20909{_}_Seasonable_,--This should be made in September, October, or November.
10136-8{_}20910{_}II.
10136-8{_}20911{_}1519.
10136-8{_}20912{_}INGREDIENTS.--Apples, water: to every pint of syrup allow 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}20913{_}of loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}20914{_}_Mode_.--Pare and cut the apples into pieces, remove the cores, and put them in a preserving-pan with sufficient cold water to cover them.
10136-8{_}20915{_}Let them boil for an hour; then drain the syrup from them through a hair sieve or jelly-bag, and measure the juice; to every pint allow 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}20916{_}of loaf sugar, and boil these together for 3/4 hour, removing every particle of scum as it rises, and keeping the jelly well stirred, that it may not burn.
10136-8{_}20917{_}A little lemon-rind may be boiled with the apples, and a small quantity of strained lemon-juice may be put in the jelly just before it is done, when the flavour is liked.
10136-8{_}20918{_}This jelly may be ornamented with preserved greengages, or any other preserved fruit, and will turn out very prettily for dessert.
10136-8{_}20919{_}It should be stored away in small pots.
10136-8{_}20920{_}_Time_.--1 hour to boil the fruit and water; 3/4 hour to boil the juice with the sugar.
10136-8{_}20921{_}_Average cost_, for 6 lbs.
10136-8{_}20922{_}of apples, with the other ingredients in proportion, 3s.
10136-8{_}20923{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 small pots of jelly.
10136-8{_}20924{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in September, October, or November.
10136-8{_}20925{_}TO PRESERVE APPLES IN QUARTERS, in imitation of Ginger.
10136-8{_}20926{_}1520.
10136-8{_}20927{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}20928{_}of apples allow 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}20929{_}of sugar, 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}20930{_}of the best white ginger; 1 oz.
10136-8{_}20931{_}of ginger to every 1/2 pint of water.
10136-8{_}20932{_}_Mode_.--Peel, core, and quarter the apples, and put the fruit, sugar, and ginger in layers into a wide-mouthed jar, and let them remain for 2 days; then infuse 1 oz.
10136-8{_}20933{_}of ginger in 1/2 pint of boiling water, and cover it closely, and let it remain for 1 day: this quantity of ginger and water is for 3 lbs.
10136-8{_}20934{_}of apples, with the other ingredients in proportion.
10136-8{_}20935{_}Put the apples, &c., into a preserving-pan with the water strained from the ginger, and boil till the apples look clear and the syrup is rich, which will be in about an hour.
10136-8{_}20936{_}The rind of a lemon may be added just before the apples have finished boiling; and great care must be taken not to break the pieces of apple in putting them into the jars.
10136-8{_}20937{_}Serve on glass dishes for dessert.
10136-8{_}20938{_}_Time_.--2 days for the apples to remain in the jar with sugar, &c.; 1 day to infuse the ginger; about 1 hour to boil the apples.
10136-8{_}20939{_}_Average cost_, for 3 lbs.
10136-8{_}20940{_}of apples, with the other ingredients in proportion, 2s.
10136-8{_}20941{_}3d.
10136-8{_}20942{_}_Sufficient._--3 lbs.
10136-8{_}20943{_}should fill 3 moderate-sized jars.
10136-8{_}20944{_}_Seasonable_.--This should be made in September, October, or November.
10136-8{_}20945{_}COMPOTE OF APRICOTS.
10136-8{_}20946{_}(_An elegant Dish_.)
10136-8{_}20947{_}1521.
10136-8{_}20948{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of syrup No.
10136-8{_}20949{_}1512, 12 green apricots.
10136-8{_}20950{_}_Mode_.--Make the syrup by recipe No.
10136-8{_}20951{_}1512, and when it is ready, put in the apricots whilst the syrup is boiling.
10136-8{_}20952{_}Simmer them very gently until tender, taking care not to let them break; take them out carefully, arrange them on a glass dish, let the syrup cool a little, pour it over the apricots, and, when cold, serve.
10136-8{_}20953{_}_Time_.--From 15 to 20 minutes to simmer the apricots.
10136-8{_}20954{_}_Average cost_, 9d.
10136-8{_}20955{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}20956{_}_Seasonable_ in June and July, with green apricots.
10136-8{_}20957{_}APRICOT JAM or MARMALADE.
10136-8{_}20958{_}1522.
10136-8{_}20959{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}20960{_}of ripe apricots, weighed after being skinned and stoned, allow 1 lb.
10136-8{_}20961{_}of sugar.
10136-8{_}20962{_}_Mode_.--Pare the apricots, which should be ripe, as thinly as possible, break them in half, and remove the stones.
10136-8{_}20963{_}Weigh the fruit, and to every lb.
10136-8{_}20964{_}allow the same proportion of loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}20965{_}Pound the sugar very finely in a mortar, strew it over the apricots, which should be placed on dishes, and let them remain for 12 hours.
10136-8{_}20966{_}Break the stones, blanch the kernels, and put them with the sugar and fruit into a preserving-pan.
10136-8{_}20967{_}Let these simmer very gently until clear; take out the pieces of apricot singly as they become so, and, as fast as the scum rises, carefully remove it.
10136-8{_}20968{_}Put the apricots into small jars, pour over them the syrup and kernels, cover the jam with pieces of paper dipped in the purest salad-oil, and stretch over the top of the jars tissue-paper, cut about 2 inches larger and brushed over with the white of an egg: when dry, it will be perfectly hard and air-tight.
10136-8{_}20969{_}_Time_.--12 hours sprinkled with sugar; about 3/4 hour to boil the jam.
10136-8{_}20970{_}_Average cost_.--When cheap, apricots may be purchased for preserving at about 1s.
10136-8{_}20971{_}6d.
10136-8{_}20972{_}per gallon.
10136-8{_}20973{_}_Sufficient_,--10 lbs.
10136-8{_}20974{_}of fruit for 12 pots of jam.
10136-8{_}20975{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in August or September.
10136-8{_}20976{_}BARBERRIES IN BUNCHES.
10136-8{_}20977{_}1523.
10136-8{_}20978{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint of syrup No.
10136-8{_}20979{_}1513, barberries.
10136-8{_}20980{_}_Mode_.--Prepare some small pieces of clean white wood, 3 inches long and 1/4 inch wide, and tie the fruit on to these in nice bunches.
10136-8{_}20981{_}Have ready some clear syrup, made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}20982{_}1513; put in the barberries, and simmer them in it for 2 successive days, boiling them for nearly 1/2 hour each day, and covering them each time with the syrup when cold.
10136-8{_}20983{_}When the fruit looks perfectly clear, it is sufficiently done, and should be stored away in pots, with the syrup poured over, or the fruit may be candied.
10136-8{_}20984{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour to simmer each day.
10136-8{_}20985{_}_Seasonable_ in autumn.
10136-8{_}20986{_}_Note_.--The berries in their natural state make a very pretty garnishing for dishes, and may even be used for the same purpose, preserved as above, and look exceedingly nice on sweet dishes.
10136-8{_}20987{_}TO MAKE BARLEY-SUGAR.
10136-8{_}20988{_}1524.
10136-8{_}20989{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}20990{_}of sugar allow 1/2 pint of water, 1/2 the white of an egg.
10136-8{_}20991{_}_Mode_.--Put the sugar into a well-tinned saucepan, with the water, and, when the former is dissolved, set it over a moderate fire, adding the well-beaten egg before the mixture gets warm, and stir it well together.
10136-8{_}20992{_}When it boils, remove the scum as it rises, and keep it boiling until no more appears, and the syrup looks perfectly clear; then strain it through a fine sieve or muslin bag, and put it back into the saucepan.
10136-8{_}20993{_}Boil it again like caramel, until it is brittle, when a little is dropped in a basin of cold water: it is then sufficiently boiled.
10136-8{_}20994{_}Add a little lemon-juice and a few drops of essence of lemon, and let it stand for a minute or two.
10136-8{_}20995{_}Have ready a marble slab or large dish, rubbed over with salad-oil; pour on it the sugar, and cut it into strips with a pair of scissors: these strips should then be twisted, and the barley-sugar stored away in a very dry place.
10136-8{_}20996{_}It may be formed into lozenges or drops, by dropping the sugar in a very small quantity at a time on to the oiled slab or dish.
10136-8{_}20997{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}20998{_}_Average cost_, 7d.
10136-8{_}20999{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 sticks.
10136-8{_}21000{_}CARROT JAM TO IMITATE APRICOT PRESERVE.
10136-8{_}21001{_}1525.
10136-8{_}21002{_}INGREDIENTS.--Carrots; to every lb.
10136-8{_}21003{_}of carrot pulp allow 1 lb.
10136-8{_}21004{_}of pounded sugar, the grated rind of 1 lemon, the strained juice of 2, 6 chopped bitter almonds, 2 tablespoonfuls of brandy.
10136-8{_}21005{_}_Mode_.--Select young carrots; wash and scrape them clean, cut them into round pieces, put them into a saucepan with sufficient water to cover them, and let them simmer until perfectly soft; then beat them through a sieve.
10136-8{_}21006{_}Weigh the pulp, and to every lb.
10136-8{_}21007{_}allow the above ingredients.
10136-8{_}21008{_}Put the pulp into a preserving-pan with the sugar, and let this boil for 5 minutes, stirring and skimming all the time.
10136-8{_}21009{_}When cold, add the lemon-rind and juice, almonds and brandy; mix these well with the jam; then put it into pots, which must be well covered and kept in a dry place.
10136-8{_}21010{_}The brandy may be omitted, but the preserve will then not keep: with the brandy it will remain good for months.
10136-8{_}21011{_}_Time_.--About 3/4 hour to boil the carrots; 5 minutes to simmer the pulp.
10136-8{_}21012{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}21013{_}2d.
10136-8{_}21014{_}for 1 lb.
10136-8{_}21015{_}of pulp, with the other ingredients in proportion.
10136-8{_}21016{_}_Sufficient_ to fill 3 pots.
10136-8{_}21017{_}_Seasonable_ from July to December.
10136-8{_}21018{_}TO MAKE CHERRY BRANDY.
10136-8{_}21019{_}1536.
10136-8{_}21020{_}INGREDIENTS.--Morella cherries, good brandy; to every lb.
10136-8{_}21021{_}of cherries allow 3 oz.
10136-8{_}21022{_}of pounded sugar.
10136-8{_}21023{_}_Mode_.--Have ready some glass bottles, which must be perfectly dry.
10136-8{_}21024{_}Ascertain that the cherries are not too ripe and are freshly gathered, and cut off about half of the stalks.
10136-8{_}21025{_}Put them into the bottles, with the above proportion of sugar to every lb.
10136-8{_}21026{_}of fruit; strew this in between the cherries, and, when the bottles are nearly full, pour in sufficient brandy to reach just below the cork.
10136-8{_}21027{_}A few peach or apricot kernels will add much to their flavour, or a few blanched bitter almonds.
10136-8{_}21028{_}Put corks or bungs into the bottles, tie over them a piece of bladder, and store away in a dry place.
10136-8{_}21029{_}The cherries will be fit to eat in 2 or 3 months, and will remain good for years.
10136-8{_}21030{_}They are liable to shrivel and become tough if too much sugar be added to them.
10136-8{_}21031{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}21032{_}to 1s.
10136-8{_}21033{_}6d.
10136-8{_}21034{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}21035{_}_Sufficient_.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}21036{_}of cherries and about 1/4 pint of brandy for a quart bottle.
10136-8{_}21037{_}_Seasonable_ in August and September.
10136-8{_}21038{_}DRIED CHERRIES.
10136-8{_}21039{_}1527.
10136-8{_}21040{_}CHERRIES may be put in a slow oven and thoroughly dried before they begin to change colour.
10136-8{_}21041{_}They should then be taken out of the oven, tied in bunches, and stored away in a dry place.
10136-8{_}21042{_}In the winter, they may be cooked with sugar for dessert, the same as Normandy pippins.
10136-8{_}21043{_}Particular care must be taken that the oven be not too hot.
10136-8{_}21044{_}Another method of drying cherries is to stone them, and to put them into a preserving-pan, with plenty of loaf sugar strewed amongst them.
10136-8{_}21045{_}They should be simmered till the fruit shrivels, when they should be strained from the juice.
10136-8{_}21046{_}The cherries should then be placed in an oven, cool enough to dry without baking them.
10136-8{_}21047{_}About 5 oz.
10136-8{_}21048{_}of sugar would be required for 1 lb.
10136-8{_}21049{_}of cherries, and the same syrup may be used again to do another quantity of fruit.
10136-8{_}21050{_}CHERRY JAM.
10136-8{_}21051{_}1528.
10136-8{_}21052{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}21053{_}of fruit, weighed before stoning, allow 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}21054{_}of sugar; to every 6 lbs.
10136-8{_}21055{_}of fruit allow 1 pint of red-currant juice, and to every pint of juice 1 lb.
10136-8{_}21056{_}of sugar.
10136-8{_}21057{_}_Mode_.--Weigh the fruit before stoning, and allow half the weight of sugar; stone the cherries, and boil them in a preserving-pan until nearly all the juice is dried up; then add the sugar, which should be crushed to powder, and the currant-juice, allowing 1 pint to every 6 lbs.
10136-8{_}21058{_}of cherries (original weight), and 1 lb.
10136-8{_}21059{_}of sugar to every pint of juice.
10136-8{_}21060{_}Boil all together until it jellies, which will be in from 20 minutes to 1/2 hour; skim the jam well, keep it well stirred, and, a few minutes before it is done, crack some of the stones, and add the kernels: these impart a very delicious flavour to the jam.
10136-8{_}21061{_}_Time_.--According to the quality of the cherries, from 3/4 to 1 hour to boil them; 20 minutes to 1/2 hour with the sugar.
10136-8{_}21062{_}_Average cost_, from 7d.
10136-8{_}21063{_}to 8d.
10136-8{_}21064{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}21065{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21066{_}_Sufficient_.--1 pint of fruit for a lb.
10136-8{_}21067{_}pot of jam.
10136-8{_}21068{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in July or August.
10136-8{_}21069{_}TO PRESERVE CHERRIES IN SYRUP.
10136-8{_}21070{_}(_Very delicious_.)
10136-8{_}21071{_}1529.
10136-8{_}21072{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 lbs.
10136-8{_}21073{_}of cherries, 3 lbs.
10136-8{_}21074{_}of sugar, 1 pint of white-currant juice.
10136-8{_}21075{_}_Mode_.--Let the cherries be as clear and as transparent as possible, and perfectly ripe; pick off the stalks, and remove the stones, damaging the fruit as little as you can.
10136-8{_}21076{_}Make a syrup with the above proportion of sugar, by recipe No.
10136-8{_}21077{_}1512; mix the cherries with it, and boil them for about 15 minutes, carefully skimming them; turn them gently into a pan, and let them remain till the next day; then drain the cherries on a sieve, and put the syrup and white-currant juice into the preserving-pan again.
10136-8{_}21078{_}Boil these together until the syrup is somewhat reduced and rather thick; then put in the cherries, and let them boil for about 5 minutes; take them off the fire, skim the syrup, put the cherries into small pots or wide-mouthed bottles; pour the syrup over, and when quite cold, tie them down carefully, so that the air is quite excluded.
10136-8{_}21079{_}_Time_.--15 minutes to boil the cherries in the syrup; 10 minutes to boil the syrup and currant-juice; 6 minutes to boil the cherries the second time.
10136-8{_}21080{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 3s.
10136-8{_}21081{_}6d.
10136-8{_}21082{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in July or August.
10136-8{_}21083{_}BLACK-CURRANT JAM.
10136-8{_}21084{_}1530.
10136-8{_}21085{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}21086{_}of fruit, weighed before being stripped from the stalks, allow 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}21087{_}of loaf sugar, 1 gill of water.
10136-8{_}21088{_}_Mode_.--Let the fruit be very ripe, and gathered on a dry day.
10136-8{_}21089{_}Strip it from the stalks, and put it into a preserving-pan, with a gill of water to each lb.
10136-8{_}21090{_}of fruit; boil these together for 10 minutes; then add the sugar, and boil the jam again for 30 minutes, reckoning from the time when the jam simmers equally all over, or longer, should it not appear to set nicely when a little is poured on to a plate.
10136-8{_}21091{_}Keep stirring it to prevent it from burning, carefully remove all the scum, and when done, pour it into pots.
10136-8{_}21092{_}Let it cool, cover the top of the jam with oiled paper, and the top of the jars with a piece of tissue-paper brushed over on both sides with the white of an egg: this, when cold, forms a hard stiff cover, and perfectly excludes the air.
10136-8{_}21093{_}Great attention must be paid to the stirring of this jam, as it is very liable to burn, on account of the thickness of the juice.
10136-8{_}21094{_}_Time_.--10 minutes to boil the fruit and water; 30 minutes with the sugar, or longer.
10136-8{_}21095{_}_Average cost_, from 6d.
10136-8{_}21096{_}to 8d.
10136-8{_}21097{_}for a pot capable of holding 1 lb.
10136-8{_}21098{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow from 6 to 7 quarts of currants to make 1 dozen pots of jam, each pot to hold 1 lb.
10136-8{_}21099{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in July.
10136-8{_}21100{_}BLACK-CURRANT JELLY.
10136-8{_}21101{_}1531.
10136-8{_}21102{_}INGREDIENTS.--Black currants; to every pint of juice allow 1/4 pint of water, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}21103{_}of loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}21104{_}_Mode_.--Strip the currants from the stalks, which may be done in an expeditious manner, by holding the bunch in one hand, and passing a small silver fork down the currants: they will then readily fall from the stalks.
10136-8{_}21105{_}Put them into a jar, place this jar in a saucepan of boiling water, and simmer them until their juice is extracted; then strain them, and to every pint of juice allow the above proportion of sugar and water; stir these ingredients together cold until the sugar is dissolved; place the preserving-pan on the fire, and boil the jelly for about 1/2 hour, reckoning from the time it commences to boil all over, and carefully remove the scum as it rises.
10136-8{_}21106{_}If the jelly becomes firm when a little is put on a plate, it is done; it should then be put into _small_ pots, and covered the same as the jam in the preceding recipe.
10136-8{_}21107{_}If the jelly is wanted very clear, the fruit should not be squeezed dry; but, of course, so much juice will not be obtained.
10136-8{_}21108{_}If the fruit is not much squeezed, it may be converted into a jam for immediate eating, by boiling it with a little common sugar: this answers very well for a nursery preserve.
10136-8{_}21109{_}_Time_.--About 3/4 hour to extract the juice; 1/2 hour to boil the jelly.
10136-8{_}21110{_}_Average cost_, from 8d.
10136-8{_}21111{_}to 10d.
10136-8{_}21112{_}per 1/2-lb.
10136-8{_}21113{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21114{_}_Sufficient_.--From 3 pints to 2 quarts of fruit should yield a pint of juice.
10136-8{_}21115{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in July.
10136-8{_}21116{_}RED-CURRANT JAM.
10136-8{_}21117{_}1532.
10136-8{_}21118{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}21119{_}of fruit allow 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}21120{_}of loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}21121{_}[Illustration: JAM-POT.]
10136-8{_}21122{_}_Mode_.--Let the fruit be gathered on a fine day; weigh it, and then strip the currants from the stalks; put them into a preserving-pan with sugar in the above proportion; stir them, and boil them for about 3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}21123{_}Carefully remove the scum as it rises.
10136-8{_}21124{_}Put the jam into pots, and, when cold, cover with oiled papers; over these put a piece of tissue-paper brushed over on both sides with the white of an egg; press the paper round the top of the pot, and, when dry, the covering will be quite hard and air-tight.
10136-8{_}21125{_}_Time_.--1/2 to 3/4 hour, reckoning from the time the jam boils all over.
10136-8{_}21126{_}_Average cost_, for a lb.
10136-8{_}21127{_}pot, from 6d.
10136-8{_}21128{_}to 8d.
10136-8{_}21129{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow from 6 to 7 quarts of currants to make 12 1-lb, pots of jam.
10136-8{_}21130{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in July.
10136-8{_}21131{_}RED-CURRANT JELLY.
10136-8{_}21132{_}1533.
10136-8{_}21133{_}INGREDIENTS.--Red currants; to every pint of juice allow 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}21134{_}of loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}21135{_}_Mode_.--Have the fruit gathered in fine weather; pick it from the stalks, put it into a jar, and place this jar in a saucepan of boiling water over the fire, and let it simmer gently until the juice is well drawn from the currants; then strain them through a jelly-bag or fine cloth, and, if the jelly is wished very clear, do not squeeze them _too much_, as the skin and pulp from the fruit will be pressed through with the juice, and so make the jelly muddy.
10136-8{_}21136{_}Measure the juice, and to each pint allow 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}21137{_}of loaf sugar; put these into a preserving-pan, set it over the fire, and keep stirring the jelly until it is done, carefully removing every particle of scum as it rises, using a wooden or silver spoon for the purpose, as metal or iron ones would spoil the colour of the jelly when it has boiled from 20 minutes to 1/2 hour, put a little of the jelly on a plate, and if firm when cool, it is done.
10136-8{_}21138{_}Take it off the fire, pour it into small gallipots, cover each of the pots with an oiled paper, and then with a piece of tissue-paper brushed over on both sides with the white of an egg.
10136-8{_}21139{_}Label the pots, adding the year when the jelly was made, and store it away in a dry place.
10136-8{_}21140{_}A jam may be made with the currants, if they are not squeezed too dry, by adding a few fresh raspberries, and boiling all together, with sufficient sugar to sweeten it nicely.
10136-8{_}21141{_}As this preserve is not worth storing away, but is only for immediate eating, a smaller proportion of sugar than usual will be found enough: it answers very well for children's puddings, or for a nursery preserve.
10136-8{_}21142{_}_Time_.--From 3/4 to 1 hour to extract the juice; 20 minutes to 1/2 hour to boil the jelly.
10136-8{_}21143{_}_Average cost_, from 8d.
10136-8{_}21144{_}to 10d.
10136-8{_}21145{_}per 1/2-lb.
10136-8{_}21146{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21147{_}_Sufficient_.--8 quarts of currants will make from 10 to 12 pots of jelly.
10136-8{_}21148{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in July.
10136-8{_}21149{_}_Note_.--Should the above proportion of sugar not be found sufficient for some tastes, add an extra 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}21150{_}to every pint of juice, making altogether 1 lb.
10136-8{_}21151{_}WHITE-CURRANT JELLY.
10136-8{_}21152{_}1534.
10136-8{_}21153{_}INGREDIENTS.--White currants; to every pint of juice allow 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}21154{_}of good loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}21155{_}_Mode_.--Pick the currants from the stalks, and put them into a jar; place this jar in a saucepan of boiling water, and simmer until the juice is well drawn from the fruit, which will be in from 3/4 to 1 hour.
10136-8{_}21156{_}Then strain the currants through a fine cloth or jelly-bag; do not squeeze them too much, or the jelly will not be clear, and put the juice into a very clean preserving-pan, with the sugar.
10136-8{_}21157{_}Let this simmer gently over a clear fire until it is firm, and keep stirring and skimming until it is done; then pour it into small pots, cover them, and store away in a dry place.
10136-8{_}21158{_}_Time_.--3/4 hour to draw the juice; 1/2 hour to boil the jelly.
10136-8{_}21159{_}_Average cost_, from 8d.
10136-8{_}21160{_}to 10d.
10136-8{_}21161{_}per 1/2-lb.
10136-8{_}21162{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21163{_}_Sufficient._--From 3 pints to 2 quarts of fruit should yield 1 pint of juice.
10136-8{_}21164{_}_Seasonable_ in July and August.
10136-8{_}21165{_}BAKED DAMSONS FOR WINTER USE.
10136-8{_}21166{_}1535.
10136-8{_}21167{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}21168{_}of fruit allow 6 oz.
10136-8{_}21169{_}of pounded sugar; melted mutton suet.
10136-8{_}21170{_}_Mode_.--Choose sound fruit, not too ripe; pick off the stalks, weigh it, and to every lb.
10136-8{_}21171{_}allow the above proportion of pounded sugar.
10136-8{_}21172{_}Put the fruit into large dry stone jars, sprinkling the sugar amongst it; cover the jars with saucers, place them in a rather cool oven, and bake the fruit until it is quite tender.
10136-8{_}21173{_}When cold, cover the top of the fruit with a piece of white paper cut to the size of the jar; pour over this melted mutton suet about an inch thick, and cover the tops of the jars with thick brown paper, well tied down.
10136-8{_}21174{_}Keep the jars in a cool dry place, and the fruit will remain good till the following Christmas, but not much longer.
10136-8{_}21175{_}_Time_.--From 5 to 6 hours to bake the damsons, in a very cool oven.
10136-8{_}21176{_}_Seasonable_ in September and October.
10136-8{_}21177{_}DAMSON CHEESE.
10136-8{_}21178{_}1536.
10136-8{_}21179{_}INGREDIENTS.--Damsons; to every lb.
10136-8{_}21180{_}of fruit pulp allow 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}21181{_}of loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}21182{_}_Mode_.--Pick the stalks from the damsons, and put them into a preserving-pan; simmer them over the fire until they are soft, occasionally stirring them; then beat them through a coarse sieve, and put the pulp and juice into the preserving-pan, with sugar in the above proportion, having previously carefully weighed them.
10136-8{_}21183{_}Stir the sugar well in, and simmer the damsons slowly for 2 hours.
10136-8{_}21184{_}Skim well; then boil the preserve quickly for 1/2 hour, or until it looks firm and hard in the spoon; put it quickly into shallow pots, or very tiny earthenware moulds, and, when cold, cover it with oiled papers, and the jars with tissue-paper brushed over on both sides with the white of an egg.
10136-8{_}21185{_}A few of the stones may be cracked, and the kernels boiled with the damsons, which very much improves the flavour of the cheese.
10136-8{_}21186{_}_Time_.--1 hour to boil the damsons without the sugar; 2 hours to simmer them slowly, 1/2 hour quickly.
10136-8{_}21187{_}_Average cost_, from 8d.
10136-8{_}21188{_}to 10d.
10136-8{_}21189{_}per 1/3 lb.
10136-8{_}21190{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21191{_}_Sufficient_.--1 pint of damsons to make a _very small_ pot of cheese.
10136-8{_}21192{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in September or October.
10136-8{_}21193{_}COMPOTE OF DAMSONS.
10136-8{_}21194{_}1537.
10136-8{_}21195{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 quart of damsons, 1 pint of syrup No.
10136-8{_}21196{_}1512.
10136-8{_}21197{_}_Mode_.--Procure sound ripe damsons; pick the stalks from them, and put them into boiling syrup, made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}21198{_}1512.
10136-8{_}21199{_}Simmer them gently until the fruit is tender, but not sufficiently soft to break; take them up, boil the syrup for 5 minutes; pour it over the damsons, and serve.
10136-8{_}21200{_}This should be sent to table in a glass dish.
10136-8{_}21201{_}_Time_.--About 1/4 hour to simmer the damsons; 5 minutes to boil the syrup.
10136-8{_}21202{_}_Average cost_, 9d.
10136-8{_}21203{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}21204{_}_Seasonable_ in September and October.
10136-8{_}21205{_}DAMSON JAM.
10136-8{_}21206{_}1538.
10136-8{_}21207{_}INGREDIENTS.--Damsons; to every lb.
10136-8{_}21208{_}of fruit allow 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}21209{_}of loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}21210{_}_Mode_.--Have the fruit gathered in dry weather; pick it over, and reject any that is at all blemished.
10136-8{_}21211{_}Stone the damsons, weigh them, and to every lb.
10136-8{_}21212{_}allow 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}21213{_}of loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}21214{_}Put the fruit and sugar into a preserving-pan; keep stirring them gently until the sugar is dissolved, and carefully remove the scum as it rises.
10136-8{_}21215{_}Boil the jam for about an hour, reckoning from the time it commences to simmer all over alike: it must be well stirred all the time, or it will be liable to burn and stick to the pan, which will cause the jam to have a very disagreeable flavour.
10136-8{_}21216{_}When the jam looks firm, and the juice appears to set, it is done.
10136-8{_}21217{_}Then take it off the fire, put into pots, cover it down, when quite cold, with oiled and egged papers, the same as in recipe No.
10136-8{_}21218{_}1530, and store it away in a dry place.
10136-8{_}21219{_}_Time_.--1 hour after the jam simmers all over.
10136-8{_}21220{_}_Average cost_, from 6d.
10136-8{_}21221{_}to 8d.
10136-8{_}21222{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}21223{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21224{_}_Sufficient_.--1-1/2 pint of damsons for a lb.
10136-8{_}21225{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21226{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in September or October.
10136-8{_}21227{_}A VERY NICE PRESERVE OF DAMSONS.
10136-8{_}21228{_}1539.
10136-8{_}21229{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every quart of damsons allow 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}21230{_}of loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}21231{_}_Mode_.--Put the damsons (which should be picked from the stalks and quite free from blemishes) into a jar, with pounded sugar sprinkled amongst them in the above proportion; tie the jar closely down, set it in a saucepan of cold water; bring it gradually to boil, and simmer gently until the damsons are soft, without being broken.
10136-8{_}21232{_}Let them stand till cold; then strain the juice from them, boil it up well, strain it through a jelly-bag, and pour it over the fruit.
10136-8{_}21233{_}Let it cool, cover with oiled papers, and the jars with tissue-paper brushed over on both sides with the white of an egg, and store away in a dry cool place.
10136-8{_}21234{_}_Time_.--About 3/4 hour to simmer the fruit after the water boils; 1/4 hour to boil the juice.
10136-8{_}21235{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in September or October.
10136-8{_}21236{_}TO PRESERVE DAMSONS, OR ANY KIND OF PLUMS.
10136-8{_}21237{_}(_Useful in Winter_.)
10136-8{_}21238{_}1540.
10136-8{_}21239{_}INGREDIENTS.--Damsons or plums; boiling water.
10136-8{_}21240{_}_Mode_.--Pick the fruit into clean dry stone jars, taking care to leave out all that are broken or blemished.
10136-8{_}21241{_}When full, pour boiling water on the plums, until it stands one inch above the fruit; cut a piece of paper to fit the inside of the jar, over which pour melted mutton-suet; cover down with brown paper, and keep the jars in a dry cool place.
10136-8{_}21242{_}When used, the suet should be removed, the water poured off, and the jelly at the bottom of the jar used and mixed with the fruit.
10136-8{_}21243{_}_Seasonable_ in September and October.
10136-8{_}21244{_}COMPOTE OF GREEN FIGS.
10136-8{_}21245{_}[Illustration: COMPÔTE OF FIGS.]
10136-8{_}21246{_}1541.
10136-8{_}21247{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint of syrup No.
10136-8{_}21248{_}1512, 1-1/2 pint of green figs, the rind of 1/2 lemon.
10136-8{_}21249{_}_Mode_.--Make a syrup by recipe No.
10136-8{_}21250{_}1512, boiling with it the lemon-rind, and carefully remove all the scum as it rises.
10136-8{_}21251{_}Put in the figs, and simmer them very slowly until tender; dish them on a glass dish; reduce the syrup by boiling it quickly for 5 minutes; take out the lemon-peel, pour the syrup over the figs, and the compote, when cold, will be ready for table.
10136-8{_}21252{_}A little port wine, or lemon-juice, added just before the figs are done, will be found an improvement.
10136-8{_}21253{_}_Time_.--2 to 3 hours to stew the figs.
10136-8{_}21254{_}_Average cost_, figs, 2s.
10136-8{_}21255{_}to 3s.
10136-8{_}21256{_}per dozen.
10136-8{_}21257{_}_Seasonable_ in August and September.
10136-8{_}21258{_}TO BOTTLE FRESH FRUIT.
10136-8{_}21259{_}(_Very useful in Winter_.)
10136-8{_}21260{_}I.
10136-8{_}21261{_}1542.
10136-8{_}21262{_}INGREDIENTS.--Fresh fruits, such as currants, raspberries, cherries, gooseberries, plums of all kinds, damsons, &c.; wide-mouthed glass bottles, new corks to fit them tightly.
10136-8{_}21263{_}_Mode_.--Let the fruit be full grown, but not too ripe, and gathered in dry weather.
10136-8{_}21264{_}Pick it off the stalks without bruising or breaking the skin, and reject any that is at all blemished: if gathered in the damp, or if the skins are cut at all, the fruit will mould.
10136-8{_}21265{_}Have ready some _perfectly dry_ glass bottles, and some nice new soft corks or bungs; burn a match in each bottle, to exhaust the air, and quickly place the fruit in to be preserved; gently cork the bottles, and put them into a very cool oven, where let them remain until the fruit has shrunk away a fourth part.
10136-8{_}21266{_}Then take the bottles out; _do not open them,_ but immediately beat the corks in tight, cut off the tops, and cover them with melted resin.
10136-8{_}21267{_}If kept in a dry place, the fruit will remain good for months; and on this principally depends the success of the preparation; for if stored away in a place that is in the least damp, the fruit will soon spoil.
10136-8{_}21268{_}_Time_.--From 5 to 6 hours in a very slow oven.
10136-8{_}21269{_}II.
10136-8{_}21270{_}1543.
10136-8{_}21271{_}INGREDIENTS.--Any kind of fresh fruit, such as currants, cherries, gooseberries, all kinds of plums, &c.; wide-mouthed glass bottles, new corks to fit them tightly.
10136-8{_}21272{_}_Mode_.--The fruit must be full-grown, not too ripe, and gathered on a fine day.
10136-8{_}21273{_}Let it be carefully picked and put into the bottles, which must be clean and perfectly dry.
10136-8{_}21274{_}Tie over the tops of the bottles pieces of bladder; stand the bottles in a large pot, copper, or boiler, with cold water to reach to their necks; kindle a fire under, let the water boil, and as the bladders begin to rise and puff, prick them.
10136-8{_}21275{_}As soon as the water boils, extinguish the fire, and let the bottles remain where they are, to become cold.
10136-8{_}21276{_}The next day remove the bladders, and strew over the fruit a thick layer of pounded sugar; fit the bottles with corks, and let each cork lie close at hand to its own bottle.
10136-8{_}21277{_}Hold for a few moments, in the neck of the bottle, two or three lighted matches, and when they have filled the bottle neck with gas, and before they go out, remove them very quickly; instantly cork the bottle closely, and dip it in bottle cement.
10136-8{_}21278{_}_Time_.--Altogether about 8 hours.
10136-8{_}21279{_}TO BOTTLE FRESH FRUIT WITH SUGAR.
10136-8{_}21280{_}(_Very useful in Winter_.)
10136-8{_}21281{_}1544.
10136-8{_}21282{_}INGREDIENTS.--Any kind of fresh fruit; to each quart bottle allow 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}21283{_}of pounded sugar.
10136-8{_}21284{_}_Mode_.--Let the fruit be gathered in dry weather.
10136-8{_}21285{_}Pick it carefully, and drop it into _clean_ and _very dry_ quart glass bottles, sprinkling over it the above proportion of pounded sugar to each quart.
10136-8{_}21286{_}Put the corks in the bottles, and place them in a copper of cold water up to their necks, with small hay-wisps round them, to prevent the bottles from knocking together.
10136-8{_}21287{_}Light the fire under, bring the water gradually to boil, and let it simmer gently until the fruit in the bottles is reduced nearly one third.
10136-8{_}21288{_}Extinguish the fire, _and let the bottles remain in the water until it is perfectly cold;_ then take them out, make the corks secure, and cover them with melted resin or wax.
10136-8{_}21289{_}_Time_.--About 1 hour from the time the water commences to boil.
10136-8{_}21290{_}TO FROST HOLLY-LEAVES, for garnishing and decorating Dessert and Supper Dishes.
10136-8{_}21291{_}1545.--INGREDIENTS.--Sprigs of holly, oiled butter, coarsely-powdered sugar.
10136-8{_}21292{_}_Mode_.--Procure some nice sprigs of holly; pick the leaves from the stalks, and wipe them with a clean cloth free from all moisture; then place them on a dish near the fire, to get thoroughly dry, but not too near to shrivel the leaves; dip them into oiled butter, sprinkle over them some coarsely-powdered sugar, and dry them before the fire.
10136-8{_}21293{_}They should be kept in a dry place, as the least damp would spoil their appearance.
10136-8{_}21294{_}_Time_.--About 10 minutes to dry before the fire.
10136-8{_}21295{_}_Seasonable_.--These may be made at any time; but are more suitable for winter garnishes, when fresh flowers are not easily obtained.
10136-8{_}21296{_}COMPOTE OF GOOSEBERRIES.
10136-8{_}21297{_}1546.
10136-8{_}21298{_}INGREDIENTS.--Syrup made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}21299{_}1512; to 1 pint of syrup allow nearly a quart of gooseberries.
10136-8{_}21300{_}_Mode_.--Top and tail the gooseberries, which should not be very ripe, and pour over them some boiling water; then take them out, and plunge them into cold water, with which has been mixed a tablespoonful of vinegar, which will assist to keep the fruit a good colour.
10136-8{_}21301{_}Make a pint of syrup by recipe No.
10136-8{_}21302{_}1512, and when it boils, drain the gooseberries and put them in; simmer them gently until the fruit is nicely pulped and tender, without being broken; then dish the gooseberries on a glass dish, boil the syrup for 2 or 3 minutes, pour over the gooseberries, and serve cold.
10136-8{_}21303{_}_Time_.--About 5 minutes to boil the gooseberries in the syrup; 3 minutes to reduce the syrup.
10136-8{_}21304{_}_Average cost_, 9d.
10136-8{_}21305{_}_Sufficient_,--a quart of gooseberries for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}21306{_}_Seasonable_ in June.
10136-8{_}21307{_}GOOSEBERRY JAM.
10136-8{_}21308{_}I.
10136-8{_}21309{_}1547.
10136-8{_}21310{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}21311{_}of fruit allow 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}21312{_}of loaf sugar; currant-juice.
10136-8{_}21313{_}_Mode_.--Select red hairy gooseberries; have them gathered in dry weather, when quite ripe, without being too soft.
10136-8{_}21314{_}Weigh them; with a pair of scissors, cut off the tops and tails, and to every 6 lbs.
10136-8{_}21315{_}of fruit have ready 1/2 pint of red-currant juice, drawn as for jelly.
10136-8{_}21316{_}Put the gooseberries and currant-juice into a preserving-pan; let them boil tolerably quickly, keeping them well stirred; when they begin to break, add to them the sugar, and keep simmering until the jam becomes firm, carefully skimming: and stirring it, that it does not burn at the bottom.
10136-8{_}21317{_}It should be boiled rather a long time, or it will not keep.
10136-8{_}21318{_}Put it into pots (not too large); let it get perfectly cold; then cover the pots down with oiled and egged papers, as directed for red-currant jelly No.
10136-8{_}21319{_}1533.
10136-8{_}21320{_}_Time_.--About 1 hour to boil the gooseberries in the currant-juice; from 1/2 to 3/4 hour with the sugar.
10136-8{_}21321{_}_Average cost_, per lb.
10136-8{_}21322{_}pot, from 6d.
10136-8{_}21323{_}to 8d.
10136-8{_}21324{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 1-1/2 pint of fruit for a lb.
10136-8{_}21325{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21326{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in June or July.
10136-8{_}21327{_}II.
10136-8{_}21328{_}1548.
10136-8{_}21329{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every 8 lbs.
10136-8{_}21330{_}of red, rough, ripe gooseberries allow 1 quart of red-currant juice, 5 lbs.
10136-8{_}21331{_}of loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}21332{_}_Mode_.--Have the fruit gathered in dry weather, and cut off the tops and tails.
10136-8{_}21333{_}Prepare 1 quart of red-currant juice, the same as for red-currant jelly No.
10136-8{_}21334{_}1533; put it into a preserving-pan with the sugar, and keep stirring until the latter is dissolved.
10136-8{_}21335{_}Keep it boiling for about 5 minutes; skim well; then put in the gooseberries, and let them boil from 1/2 to 3/4 hour; then turn the whole into an earthen pan, and let it remain for 2 days.
10136-8{_}21336{_}Boil the jam up again until it looks clear; put it into pots, and when cold, cover with oiled paper, and over the jars put tissue-paper brushed over on both sides with the white of an egg, and store away in a dry place.
10136-8{_}21337{_}Care must be taken, in making this, to keep the jam well stirred and well skimmed, to prevent it burning at the bottom of the pan, and to have it very clear.
10136-8{_}21338{_}_Time_.--5 minutes to boil the currant-juice and sugar after the latter is dissolved; from 1/2 to 3/4 hour to simmer the gooseberries the first time, 1/4 hour the second time of boiling.
10136-8{_}21339{_}_Average cost_, from 8d.
10136-8{_}21340{_}to 10d.
10136-8{_}21341{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}21342{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21343{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 1-1/2 pint of fruit for a lb.
10136-8{_}21344{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21345{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in June or July.
10136-8{_}21346{_}WHITE OR GREEN GOOSEBERRY JAM.
10136-8{_}21347{_}1549.

10136-8{_}21376{_}COMPOTE OF GREENGAGES.
10136-8{_}21377{_}1551.
10136-8{_}21378{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint of syrup made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}21379{_}1512, 1 quart of greengages.
10136-8{_}21380{_}_Mode_.--Make a syrup by recipe No.
10136-8{_}21381{_}1512, skim it well, and put in the greengages when the syrup is boiling, having previously removed the stalks and stones from the fruit.
10136-8{_}21382{_}Boil gently for 1/4 hour, or until the fruit is tender; but take care not to let it break, as the appearance of the dish would be spoiled were the fruit reduced to a pulp.
10136-8{_}21383{_}Take the greengages carefully out, place them on a glass dish, boil the syrup for another 5 minutes, let it cool a little, pour over the fruit, and, when cold, it will be ready for use.
10136-8{_}21384{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour to simmer the fruit, 5 minutes the syrup.
10136-8{_}21385{_}_Average cost_, in full season, 10d.
10136-8{_}21386{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}21387{_}_Seasonable_ in July, August, and September.
10136-8{_}21388{_}GREENGAGE JAM.
10136-8{_}21389{_}1552.
10136-8{_}21390{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}21391{_}of fruit, weighed before being stoned, allow 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}21392{_}of lump sugar.
10136-8{_}21393{_}_Mode_.--Divide the greengages, take out the stones, and put them into a preserving-pan.
10136-8{_}21394{_}Bring the fruit to a boil, then add the sugar, and keep stirring it over a gentle fire until it is melted.
10136-8{_}21395{_}Remove all the scum as it rises, and, just before the jam is done, boil it rapidly for 5 minutes.
10136-8{_}21396{_}To ascertain when it is sufficiently boiled, pour a little on a plate, and if the syrup thickens and appears firm, it is done.
10136-8{_}21397{_}Have ready half the kernels blanched; put them into the jam, give them one boil, and pour the preserve into pots.
10136-8{_}21398{_}When cold, cover down with oiled papers, and, over these, tissue-paper brushed over on both sides with the white of an egg.
10136-8{_}21399{_}_Time_.--3/4 hour after the sugar is added.
10136-8{_}21400{_}_Average cost_, from 6d.
10136-8{_}21401{_}to 8d.
10136-8{_}21402{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}21403{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21404{_}_Sufficient._--Allow about 1-1/2 pint of fruit for every lb.
10136-8{_}21405{_}pot of jam.
10136-8{_}21406{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in August or September.
10136-8{_}21407{_}TO PRESERVE AND DRY GREENGAGES.
10136-8{_}21408{_}1553.
10136-8{_}21409{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}21410{_}of sugar allow 1 lb.
10136-8{_}21411{_}of fruit, 1/4 pint of water.
10136-8{_}21412{_}_Mode_.--For this purpose, the fruit must be used before it is quite ripe, and part of the stalk must be left on.
10136-8{_}21413{_}Weigh the fruit, rejecting all that is in the least degree blemished, and put it into a lined saucepan with the sugar and water, which should have been previously boiled together to a rich syrup.
10136-8{_}21414{_}Boil the fruit in this for 10 minutes, remove it from the fire, and drain the greengages.
10136-8{_}21415{_}The next day, boil up the syrup and put in the fruit again, and let it simmer for 3 minutes, and drain the syrup away.
10136-8{_}21416{_}Continue this process for 5 or 6 days, and the last time place the greengages, when drained, on a hair sieve, and put them in an oven or warm spot to dry; keep them in a box, with paper between each layer, in a place free from damp.
10136-8{_}21417{_}_Time_.--10 minutes the first time of boiling.
10136-8{_}21418{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in August or September.
10136-8{_}21419{_}PRESERVED GREENGAGES IN SYRUP.
10136-8{_}21420{_}1554.
10136-8{_}21421{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}21422{_}of fruit allow 1 lb.
10136-8{_}21423{_}of loaf sugar 1/4 pint of water.
10136-8{_}21424{_}_Mode_.--Boil the sugar and water together for about 10 minutes; divide the greengages, take out the stones, put the fruit into the syrup, and let it simmer gently until nearly tender.
10136-8{_}21425{_}Take it off the fire, put it into a large pan, and, the next day, boil it up again for about 10 minutes with the kernels from the stones, which should be blanched.
10136-8{_}21426{_}Put the fruit carefully into jars, pour over it the syrup, and, when cold, cover down, so that the air is quite excluded.
10136-8{_}21427{_}Let the syrup be well skimmed both the first and second day of boiling, otherwise it will not be clear.
10136-8{_}21428{_}_Time_.--10 minutes to boil the syrup; 1/4 hour to simmer the fruit the first day, 10 minutes the second day.
10136-8{_}21429{_}_Average cost_, from 6d.
10136-8{_}21430{_}to 8d.
10136-8{_}21431{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}21432{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21433{_}_Sufficient._--Allow about 1 pint of fruit to fill a 1-lb.
10136-8{_}21434{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21435{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in August or September.
10136-8{_}21436{_}TO MAKE FRUIT ICE-CREAMS.
10136-8{_}21437{_}1555.
10136-8{_}21438{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every pint of fruit-juice allow 1 pint of cream; sugar to taste.
10136-8{_}21439{_}_Mode_.--Let the fruit be well ripened; pick it off the stalks, and put it into a large earthen pan.
10136-8{_}21440{_}Stir it about with a wooden spoon, breaking it until it is well mashed; then, with the back of the spoon, rub it through a hair sieve.
10136-8{_}21441{_}Sweeten it nicely with pounded sugar; whip the cream for a few minutes, add it to the fruit, and whisk the whole again for another 5 minutes.
10136-8{_}21442{_}Put the mixture into the freezing-pot, and freeze in the same manner as directed for Ice Pudding, No.
10136-8{_}21443{_}1290, taking care to stir the cream, &c., two or three times, and to remove it from the sides of the vessel, that the mixture may be equally frozen and smooth.
10136-8{_}21444{_}Ices are usually served in glasses, but if moulded, as they sometimes are for dessert, must have a small quantity of melted isinglass added to them, to enable them to keep their shape.
10136-8{_}21445{_}Raspberry, strawberry, currant, and all fruit ice-creams, are made in the same manner.
10136-8{_}21446{_}A little pounded sugar sprinkled over the fruit before it is mashed assists to extract the juice.
10136-8{_}21447{_}In winter, when fresh fruit is not obtainable, a little jam may be substituted for it: it should be melted and worked through a sieve before being added to the whipped cream; and if the colour should not be good, a little prepared cochineal or beetroot may be put in to improve its appearance.
10136-8{_}21448{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour to freeze the mixture.
10136-8{_}21449{_}_Average cost_, with cream at 1s.
10136-8{_}21450{_}per pint, 4d.
10136-8{_}21451{_}each ice.
10136-8{_}21452{_}_Seasonable_, with fresh fruit, in June, July, and August.
10136-8{_}21453{_}TO MAKE FRUIT-WATER ICES.
10136-8{_}21454{_}1556.
10136-8{_}21455{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every pint of fruit-juice allow 1 pint of syrup made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}21456{_}1513.
10136-8{_}21457{_}[Illustration: DISH OF ICES.]
10136-8{_}21458{_}_Mode_.--Select nice ripe fruit; pick off the stalks, and put it into a large earthen pan, with a little pounded sugar strewed over; stir it about with a wooden spoon until it is well broken, then rub it through a hair sieve.
10136-8{_}21459{_}Make the syrup by recipe No.
10136-8{_}21460{_}1513, omitting the white of the egg; let it cool, add the fruit-juice, mix well together, and put the mixture into the freezing-pot.
10136-8{_}21461{_}Proceed as directed for Ice Puddings, No.
10136-8{_}21462{_}1290, and when the mixture is equally frozen, put it into small glasses.
10136-8{_}21463{_}Raspberry, strawberry, currant, and other fresh-fruit-water ices, are made in the same manner.
10136-8{_}21464{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour to freeze the mixture.
10136-8{_}21465{_}_Average cost_, 3d.
10136-8{_}21466{_}to 4d.
10136-8{_}21467{_}each.
10136-8{_}21468{_}_Seasonable_, with fresh fruit, in June, July, and August.
10136-8{_}21469{_}LEMON-WATER ICE.
10136-8{_}21470{_}1557.
10136-8{_}21471{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every pint of syrup, made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}21472{_}1513, allow 1/3 pint of lemon-juice; the rind of 4 lemons.
10136-8{_}21473{_}_Mode_.--Rub the sugar on the rinds of the lemons, and with it make the syrup by recipe No.
10136-8{_}21474{_}1513, omitting the white of egg.
10136-8{_}21475{_}Strain the lemon-juice, add it to the other ingredients, stir well, and put the mixture into a freezing-pot.
10136-8{_}21476{_}Freeze as directed for Ice Pudding, No.
10136-8{_}21477{_}1290, and, when the mixture is thoroughly and equally frozen, put it into ice-glasses.
10136-8{_}21478{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour to freeze the mixture.
10136-8{_}21479{_}_Average cost_, 3d.
10136-8{_}21480{_}to 4d.
10136-8{_}21481{_}each.

10136-8{_}21483{_}ICED CURRANTS, for Dessert.
10136-8{_}21484{_}1558.
10136-8{_}21485{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 pint of water, the whites of 2 eggs, currants, pounded sugar.
10136-8{_}21486{_}_Mode_.--Select very fine bunches of red or white currants, and well beat the whites of the eggs.
10136-8{_}21487{_}Mix these with the water; then take the currants, a bunch at a time, and dip them in; let them drain for a minute or two, and roll them in very fine pounded sugar.
10136-8{_}21488{_}Lay them to dry on paper, when the sugar will crystallize round each currant, and have a very pretty effect.
10136-8{_}21489{_}All fresh fruit may be prepared in the same manner; and a mixture of various fruits iced in this manner, and arranged on one dish, looks very well for a summer dessert.
10136-8{_}21490{_}_Time_.--1/4 day to dry the fruit.
10136-8{_}21491{_}_Average cost_, 8d.
10136-8{_}21492{_}for a pint of iced currants.
10136-8{_}21493{_}_Seasonable_ in summer.
10136-8{_}21494{_}MELONS.
10136-8{_}21495{_}1559.--This fruit is rarely preserved or cooked in any way, and should be sent to table on a dish garnished with leaves or flowers, as fancy dictates.
10136-8{_}21496{_}A border of any other kind of small fruit, arranged round the melon, has a pretty effect, the colour the former contrasting nicely with the melon.
10136-8{_}21497{_}Plenty of pounded sugar should be served with it; and the fruit should be cut lengthwise, in moderate-sized slices.
10136-8{_}21498{_}In America, it is frequently eaten with pepper and salt.
10136-8{_}21499{_}_Average cost_,--English, in full season, 3s.
10136-8{_}21500{_}6d.
10136-8{_}21501{_}to 5s.
10136-8{_}21502{_}each; when scarce, 10s.
10136-8{_}21503{_}to 15s.
10136-8{_}21504{_}; _seasonable_, June to August.
10136-8{_}21505{_}French, 2s.
10136-8{_}21506{_}to 3s.
10136-8{_}21507{_}6d.
10136-8{_}21508{_}each; _seasonable_, June and July.
10136-8{_}21509{_}Dutch, 9d.
10136-8{_}21510{_}to 2s.
10136-8{_}21511{_}each; _seasonable_, July and August.
10136-8{_}21512{_}MELON.--The melon is a most delicious fruit, succulent, cool,     and high-flavoured.
10136-8{_}21513{_}With us, it is used only at the dessert, and     is generally eaten with sugar, ginger, or pepper; but, in     France, it is likewise served up at dinner as a sauce for boiled     meats.
10136-8{_}21514{_}It grows wild in Tartary, and has been lately found in     abundance on the sandy plains of Jeypoor.
10136-8{_}21515{_}It was brought     originally from Asia by the Romans, and is said to have been     common in England in the time of Edward III., though it is     supposed that it was lost again, as well as the cucumber, during     the wars of York and Lancaster.
10136-8{_}21516{_}The best kind, called the     _Cantaloupe_, from the name of a place near Rome where it was     first cultivated in Europe, is a native of Armenia, where it     grows so plentifully that a horse-load may be bought for a     crown.
10136-8{_}21517{_}PRESERVED MULBERRIES.
10136-8{_}21518{_}1560.
10136-8{_}21519{_}INGREDIENTS.--To 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}21520{_}of fruit and 1 pint of juice allow 2-1/2 lbs.
10136-8{_}21521{_}of loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}21522{_}_Mode_.--Put some of the fruit into a preserving-pan, and simmer it gently until the juice is well drawn.
10136-8{_}21523{_}Strain it through a bag, measure it, and to every pint allow the above proportion of sugar and fruit.
10136-8{_}21524{_}Put the sugar into the preserving-pan, moisten it with the juice, boil it up, skim well, and then add the mulberries, which should be ripe, but not soft enough to break to a pulp.
10136-8{_}21525{_}Let them stand in the syrup till warm through, then set them on the fire to boil gently; when half done, turn them carefully into an earthen pan, and let them remain till the next day; then boil them as before, and when the syrup is thick, and becomes firm when cold, put the preserve into pots.
10136-8{_}21526{_}In making this, care should be taken not to break the mulberries: this may be avoided by very gentle stirring, and by simmering the fruit very slowly.
10136-8{_}21527{_}_Time_.--3/4 hour to extract the juice;  1/4 hour to boil the mulberries the first time, 1/4 hour the second time.
10136-8{_}21528{_}_Seasonable_ in August and September.
10136-8{_}21529{_}[Illustration: MULBERRY.]
10136-8{_}21530{_}MULBERRY.--Mulberries are esteemed for their highly aromatic flavour, and their sub-acid nature.
10136-8{_}21531{_}They are considered as cooling, laxative, and generally wholesome.
10136-8{_}21532{_}This fruit was very highly esteemed by the Romans, who appear to have preferred it to every other.
10136-8{_}21533{_}The mulberry-tree is stated to have been introduced into this country in 1548, being first planted at Sion House, where the original trees still thrive.
10136-8{_}21534{_}The planting of them was much encouraged by King James I. about 1605; and considerable attempts were made at that time to rear silkworms on a large scale for the purpose of making silk; but these endeavours have always failed, the climate being scarcely warm enough.
10136-8{_}21535{_}TO PRESERVE MORELLO CHERRIES.
10136-8{_}21536{_}1561.
10136-8{_}21537{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}21538{_}of cherries allow 1-1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}21539{_}of sugar, 1 gill of water.
10136-8{_}21540{_}_Mode_.--Select ripe cherries; pick off the stalks, and reject all that have any blemishes.
10136-8{_}21541{_}Boil the sugar and water together for 5 minutes; put in the cherries, and boil them for 10 minutes, removing the scum as it rises.
10136-8{_}21542{_}Then turn the fruit, &c. into a pan, and let it remain until the next day, when boil it all again for another 10 minutes, and, if necessary, skim well.
10136-8{_}21543{_}Put the cherries into small pots; pour over them the syrup, and, when cold, cover down with oiled papers, and the tops of the jars with tissue-paper brushed over on both sides with the white of an egg, and keep in a dry place.
10136-8{_}21544{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 25 minutes to boil.
10136-8{_}21545{_}_Average cost_, from 8d.
10136-8{_}21546{_}to 10d.
10136-8{_}21547{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}21548{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21549{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in July or August.
10136-8{_}21550{_}THE CHERRY-TREE IN ROME.--The Cherry-tree was introduced into Rome by Lucullus about seventy years before the Christian era; but the capital of the world knew not at first how to appreciate this present as it deserved; for the cherry-tree was propagated so slowly in Italy, that more than a century after its introduction it was far from being generally cultivated.
10136-8{_}21551{_}The Romans distinguished three principal species of cherries--the _Apronian_, of a bright red, with a firm and delicate pulp; the _Lutatian_, very black and sweet; the _Caecilian_, round and stubby, and much esteemed.
10136-8{_}21552{_}The cherry embellished the third course in Rome and the second at Athens.
10136-8{_}21553{_}PRESERVED NECTARINES.
10136-8{_}21554{_}1562.
10136-8{_}21555{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}21556{_}of sugar allow 1/4 pint of water; nectarines.
10136-8{_}21557{_}_Mode_.--Divide the nectarines in two, take out the stones, and make a strong syrup with sugar and water in the above proportion.
10136-8{_}21558{_}Put in the nectarines, and boil them until they have thoroughly imbibed the sugar.
10136-8{_}21559{_}Keep the fruit as whole as possible, and turn it carefully into a pan.
10136-8{_}21560{_}The next day boil it again for a few minutes, take out the nectarines, put them into jars, boil the syrup quickly for 5 minutes, pour it over the fruit, and, when cold, cover the preserve down.
10136-8{_}21561{_}The syrup and preserve must be carefully skimmed, or it will not be clear.
10136-8{_}21562{_}_Time_.--10 minutes to boil the sugar and water; 20 minutes to boil the fruit the first time, 10 minutes the second time; 5 minutes to boil the syrup.
10136-8{_}21563{_}_Seasonable_ in August and September, but cheapest in September.
10136-8{_}21564{_}STEWED NORMANDY PIPPINS.
10136-8{_}21565{_}1563.
10136-8{_}21566{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}21567{_}of Normandy pippins, 1 quart of water, 1/2 teaspoonful of powdered cinnamon, 1/2 teaspoonful of ground ginger, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}21568{_}of moist sugar, 1 lemon.
10136-8{_}21569{_}_Mode_.--Well wash the pippins, and put them into 1 quart of water with the above proportion of cinnamon and ginger, and let them stand 12 hours; then put these all together into a stewpan, with the lemon sliced thinly, and half the moist sugar.
10136-8{_}21570{_}Let them boil slowly until the pippins are half done; then add the remainder of the sugar, and simmer until they are quite tender.
10136-8{_}21571{_}Serve on glass dishes for dessert.
10136-8{_}21572{_}_Time_.--2 to 3 hours.
10136-8{_}21573{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}21574{_}6d.
10136-8{_}21575{_}_Seasonable_.--Suitable for a winter dish.
10136-8{_}21576{_}ICED ORANGES.
10136-8{_}21577{_}1564.
10136-8{_}21578{_}INGREDIENTS.--Oranges; to every lb.
10136-8{_}21579{_}of pounded loaf sugar allow the whites of 2 eggs.
10136-8{_}21580{_}_Mode_.--Whisk the whites of the eggs well, stir in the sugar, and beat this mixture for 1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}21581{_}Skin the oranges, remove as much of the white pith as possible without injuring the pulp of the fruit; pass a thread through the centre of each orange, dip them into the sugar, and tie them to a stick.
10136-8{_}21582{_}Place this stick across the oven, and let the oranges remain until dry, when they will have the appearance of balls of ice.
10136-8{_}21583{_}They make a pretty dessert or supper dish.
10136-8{_}21584{_}Care must be taken not to have the oven too fierce, or the oranges would scorch and acquire a brown colour, which would entirely spoil their appearance.
10136-8{_}21585{_}_Time_.--From 1/2 to 1 hour to dry in a moderate oven.
10136-8{_}21586{_}_Average cost_, 1-1/2d.
10136-8{_}21587{_}each.
10136-8{_}21588{_}_Sufficient_.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}21589{_}of sugar to ice 12 oranges.
10136-8{_}21590{_}_Seasonable_ from November to May.
10136-8{_}21591{_}THE FIRST ORANGE-TREE IN FRANCE.--The first Orange-tree cultivated in the centre of France was to be seen a few years ago at Fontainebleau.
10136-8{_}21592{_}It was called _Le Connétable_ (the Constable), because it had belonged to the Connétable de Bourbon, and had been confiscated, together with all property belonging to that prince, after his revolt against his sovereign.
10136-8{_}21593{_}COMPOTE OF ORANGES.
10136-8{_}21594{_}1565.
10136-8{_}21595{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint of syrup No.
10136-8{_}21596{_}1512, 6 oranges.
10136-8{_}21597{_}_Mode_.--Peel the oranges, remove as much of the white pith as possible, and divide them into small pieces without breaking the thin skin with which they are surrounded.
10136-8{_}21598{_}Make the syrup by recipe No.
10136-8{_}21599{_}1512, adding the rind of the orange cut into thin narrow strips.
10136-8{_}21600{_}When the syrup has been well skimmed, and is quite clear, put in the pieces of orange, and simmer them for 5 minutes.
10136-8{_}21601{_}Take them out carefully with a spoon without breaking them, and arrange them on a glass dish.
10136-8{_}21602{_}Reduce the syrup by boiling it quickly until thick; let it cool a little, pour it over the oranges, and, when cold, they will be ready for table.
10136-8{_}21603{_}[Illustration: COMPÔTE OF ORANGES.]
10136-8{_}21604{_}_Time_.--10 minutes to boil the syrup; 5 minutes to simmer the oranges; 5 minutes to reduce the syrup.
10136-8{_}21605{_}_Average cost_, 9d.
10136-8{_}21606{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}21607{_}_Seasonable_ from November to May.
10136-8{_}21608{_}THE ORANGE IN PORTUGAL.--The Orange known under the name of "Portugal Orange" comes originally from China.
10136-8{_}21609{_}Not more than two centuries ago, the Portuguese brought thence the first scion, which has multiplied so prodigiously that we now see entire forests of orange-trees in Portugal.
10136-8{_}21610{_}ORANGE AND CLOVES.--It appears to have been the custom formerly, in England, to make new year's presents with oranges stuck full with cloves.
10136-8{_}21611{_}We read in one of Ben Jonson's pieces,--the "Christmas Masque,"--"He has an orange and rosemary, but not a clove to stick in it."
10136-8{_}21612{_}ORANGE MARMALADE.
10136-8{_}21613{_}I.
10136-8{_}21614{_}1566.
10136-8{_}21615{_}INGREDIENTS.--Equal weight of fine loaf sugar and Seville oranges; to 12 oranges allow 1 pint of water.
10136-8{_}21616{_}_Mode_.--Let there be an equal weight of loaf sugar and Seville oranges, and allow the above proportion of water to every dozen oranges.
10136-8{_}21617{_}Peel them carefully, remove a little of the white pith, and boil the rinds in water 2 hours, changing the water three times to take off a little of the bitter taste.
10136-8{_}21618{_}Break the pulp into small pieces, take out all the pips, and cut the boiled rind into chips.
10136-8{_}21619{_}Make a syrup with the sugar and water; boil this well, skim it, and, when clear, put in the pulp and chips.
10136-8{_}21620{_}Boil all together from 20 minutes to 1/2 hour; pour it into pots, and, when cold, cover down with bladders or tissue-paper brushed over on both sides with the white of an egg.
10136-8{_}21621{_}The juice and grated rind of 2 lemons to every dozen of oranges, added with the pulp and chips to the syrup, are a very great improvement to this marmalade.
10136-8{_}21622{_}_Time_.--2 hours to boil the orange-rinds; 10 minutes to boil the syrup; 20 minutes to 1/2 hour to boil the marmalade.
10136-8{_}21623{_}_Average cost_, from 6d.
10136-8{_}21624{_}to 8d.
10136-8{_}21625{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}21626{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21627{_}_Seasonable_.--This should be made in March or April, as Seville oranges are then in perfection.
10136-8{_}21628{_}II.
10136-8{_}21629{_}1567.
10136-8{_}21630{_}INGREDIENTS.--Equal weight of Seville oranges and sugar; to every lb.
10136-8{_}21631{_}of sugar allow 1/2 pint of water.
10136-8{_}21632{_}_Mode_.--Weigh the sugar and oranges, score the skin across, and take it off in quarters.
10136-8{_}21633{_}Boil these quarters in a muslin bag in water until they are quite soft, and they can be pierced easily with the head of a pin; then cut them into chips about 1 inch long, and as thin as possible.
