10136-8{_}21634{_}Should there be a great deal of white stringy pulp, remove it before cutting the rind into chips.
10136-8{_}21635{_}Split open the oranges, scrape out the best part of the pulp, with the juice, rejecting the white pith and pips.
10136-8{_}21636{_}Make a syrup with the sugar and water; boil it until clear; then put in the chips, pulp, and juice, and boil the marmalade from 20 minutes to 1/2 hour, removing all the scum as it rises.
10136-8{_}21637{_}In boiling the syrup, clear it carefully from scum before the oranges are added to it.
10136-8{_}21638{_}_Time_.--2 hours to boil the rinds, 10 minutes the syrup, 20 minutes to 1/2 hour the marmalade.
10136-8{_}21639{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}21640{_}to 8d.
10136-8{_}21641{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}21642{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21643{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in March or April, when Seville oranges are in perfection.
10136-8{_}21644{_}AN EASY WAY OF MAKING ORANGE MARMALADE.
10136-8{_}21645{_}1568.
10136-8{_}21646{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}21647{_}of pulp allow 1-1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}21648{_}of loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}21649{_}_Mode_.--Choose some fine Seville oranges; put them whole into a stewpan with sufficient water to cover them, and stew them until they become perfectly tender, changing the water 2 or 3 times; drain them, take off the rind, remove the pips from the pulp, weigh it, and to every lb.
10136-8{_}21650{_}allow 1-1/2 of loaf sugar and 1/2 pint of the water the oranges were last boiled in.
10136-8{_}21651{_}Boil the sugar and water together for 10 minutes; put in the pulp, boil for another 10 minutes; then add the peel cut into strips, and boil the marmalade for another 10 minutes, which completes the process.
10136-8{_}21652{_}Pour it into jars; let it cool; then cover down with bladders, or tissue-paper brushed over on both sides with the white of an egg.
10136-8{_}21653{_}_Time_.--2 hours to boil the oranges; altogether 1/2 hour to boil the marmalade.
10136-8{_}21654{_}_Average cost_, from 6d.
10136-8{_}21655{_}to 8d.
10136-8{_}21656{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}21657{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21658{_}_Seasonable_--Make this in March or April.
10136-8{_}21659{_}ORANGE MARMALADE MADE WITH HONEY.
10136-8{_}21660{_}1569.
10136-8{_}21661{_}INGREDIENTS.--To 1 quart of the juice and pulp of Seville oranges allow 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}21662{_}of honey, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}21663{_}of the rind.
10136-8{_}21664{_}_Mode_.--Peel the oranges and boil the rind in water until tender, and cut it into strips.
10136-8{_}21665{_}Take away the pips from the juice and pulp, and put it with the honey and chips into a preserving-pan; boil all together for about 1/2 hour, or until the marmalade is of the proper consistency; put it into pots, and, when cold, cover down with bladders.
10136-8{_}21666{_}_Time_.--2 hours to boil the rind, 1/2 hour the marmalade.
10136-8{_}21667{_}_Average cost_, from 7d.
10136-8{_}21668{_}to 9d.
10136-8{_}21669{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}21670{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21671{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in March or April.
10136-8{_}21672{_}TO PRESERVE ORANGES.
10136-8{_}21673{_}1570.
10136-8{_}21674{_}INGREDIENTS.--Oranges; to every lb.
10136-8{_}21675{_}of juice and pulp allow 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}21676{_}of loaf sugar; to every pint of water 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}21677{_}of loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}21678{_}_Mode_.--Wholly grate or peel the oranges, taking off only the thin outside portion of the rind.
10136-8{_}21679{_}Make a small incision where the stalk is taken out, squeeze out as much of the juice as can be obtained, and preserve it in a basin with the pulp that accompanies it.
10136-8{_}21680{_}Put the oranges into cold water; let them stand for 3 days, changing the water twice; then boil them in fresh water till they are very tender, and put them to drain.
10136-8{_}21681{_}Make a syrup with the above proportion of sugar and water, sufficient to cover the oranges; let them stand in it for 2 or 3 days; then drain them well.
10136-8{_}21682{_}Weigh the juice and pulp, allow double their weight of sugar, and boil them together until the scum ceases to rise, which must all be carefully removed; put in the oranges, boil them for 10 minutes, place them in jars, pour over them the syrup, and, when cold, cover down.
10136-8{_}21683{_}They will be fit for use in a week.
10136-8{_}21684{_}_Time_.--3 days for the oranges to remain in water, 3 days in the syrup; 1/2 hour to boil the pulp, 10 minutes the oranges.
10136-8{_}21685{_}_Seasonable_.--This preserve should be made in February or March, when oranges are plentiful.
10136-8{_}21686{_}ORANGE SALAD.
10136-8{_}21687{_}1571.
10136-8{_}21688{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 oranges, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}21689{_}of muscatel raisins, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}21690{_}of pounded sugar, 4 tablespoonfuls of brandy.
10136-8{_}21691{_}_Mode_.--Peel 5 of the oranges; divide them into slices without breaking the pulp, and arrange them on a glass dish.
10136-8{_}21692{_}Stone the raisins, mix them with the sugar and brandy, and mingle them with the oranges.
10136-8{_}21693{_}Squeeze the juice of the other orange over the whole, and the dish is ready for table.
10136-8{_}21694{_}A little pounded spice may be put in when the flavour is liked; but this ingredient must be added very sparingly.
10136-8{_}21695{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}21696{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}21697{_}_Seasonable_ from November to May.
10136-8{_}21698{_}COMPOTE OF PEACHES.
10136-8{_}21699{_}1572.
10136-8{_}21700{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint of syrup No.
10136-8{_}21701{_}1512, about 15 small peaches.
10136-8{_}21702{_}_Mode_.--Peaches that are not very large, and that would not look well for dessert, answer very nicely for a compôte.
10136-8{_}21703{_}Divide the peaches, take out the stones, and pare the fruit; make a syrup by recipe No.
10136-8{_}21704{_}1512, put in the peaches, and stew them gently for about 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}21705{_}Take them out without breaking, arrange them on a glass dish, boil the syrup for 2 or 3 minutes, let it cool, pour it over the fruit, and, when cold, it will be ready for table.
10136-8{_}21706{_}_Time_.--10 minutes.
10136-8{_}21707{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}21708{_}2d.
10136-8{_}21709{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}21710{_}_Seasonable_ in August and September.
10136-8{_}21711{_}PEACH AND NECTARINE.--The peach and nectarine, which are among     the most delicious of our fruits, are considered as varieties of     the same species, produced by cultivation.
10136-8{_}21712{_}The former is     characterized by a very delicate down, while the latter is     smooth; but, as a proof of their identity as to species, trees     have borne peaches on one part and nectarines on another; and     even a single fruit has had down on one side, and on the other     none; the trees are almost exactly alike, as well as the     blossoms.
10136-8{_}21713{_}Pliny states that the peach was originally brought     from Persia, where it grows naturally.
10136-8{_}21714{_}At Montreuil, a village     near Paris, almost the whole population is employed in the     cultivation of peaches; and this occupation has maintained the     inhabitants for ages, and, in consequence, they raise better     peaches than anywhere else in France.
10136-8{_}21715{_}In Maryland and Virginia,     peaches grow nearly wild in orchards resembling forests; but the     fruit is of little value for the table, being employed only in     fattening hogs and for the distillation of peach brandy.
10136-8{_}21716{_}On the     east side of the Andes, peaches grow wild among the cornfields     and in the mountains, and are dried as an article of food.
10136-8{_}21717{_}The     young leaves of the peach are sometimes used in cookery, from     their agreeable flavour; and a liqueur resembling the fine     noyeau of Martinique may be made by steeping them in brandy     sweetened with sugar and fined with milk: gin may also be     flavoured in the same manner.
10136-8{_}21718{_}The kernels of the fruit have the     same flavour.
10136-8{_}21719{_}The nectarine is said to have received its name     from nectar, the particular drink of the gods.
10136-8{_}21720{_}Though it is     considered as the same species as the peach, it is not known     which of the varieties come from the other; the nectarine, is by     some considered as the superior fruit.
10136-8{_}21721{_}PEACHES PRESERVED IN BRANDY.
10136-8{_}21722{_}1573.
10136-8{_}21723{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}21724{_}of fruit weighed before being stoned, allow 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}21725{_}of finely-pounded loaf sugar; brandy.
10136-8{_}21726{_}_Mode_.--Let the fruit be gathered in dry weather; wipe and weigh it, and remove the stones as carefully as possible, without injuring the peaches much.
10136-8{_}21727{_}Put them into a jar, sprinkle amongst them pounded loaf sugar in the above proportion, and pour brandy over the fruit.
10136-8{_}21728{_}Cover the jar down closely, place it in a saucepan of boiling water over the fire, and bring the brandy to the simmering-point, but do not allow it to boil.
10136-8{_}21729{_}Take the fruit out carefully, without breaking it; put it into small jars, pour over it the brandy, and, when cold, exclude the air by covering the jars with bladders, or tissue-paper brushed over on both sides with the white of an egg.
10136-8{_}21730{_}Apricots may be done in the same manner, and, if properly prepared, will be found delicious.
10136-8{_}21731{_}_Time_.--From 10 to 20 minutes to bring the brandy to the simmering-point.
10136-8{_}21732{_}_Seasonable_ in August and September.
10136-8{_}21733{_}BAKED PEARS.
10136-8{_}21734{_}1574.
10136-8{_}21735{_}INGREDIENTS.--12 pears, the rind of 1 lemon, 6 cloves, 10 whole allspice; to every pint of water allow 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}21736{_}of loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}21737{_}_Mode_.--Pare and cut the pears into halves, and, should they be very large, into quarters; leave the stalks on, and carefully remove the cores.
10136-8{_}21738{_}Place them in a clean baking-jar, with a closely-fitting lid; add to them the lemon-rind cut in strips, the juice of 1/2 lemon, the cloves, pounded allspice, and sufficient water just to cover the whole, with sugar in the above proportion.
10136-8{_}21739{_}Cover the jar down closely, put it into a very cool oven, and bake the pears from 5 to 6 hours, but be very careful that the oven is not too hot.
10136-8{_}21740{_}To improve the colour of the fruit, a few drops of prepared cochineal may be added; but this will not be found necessary if the pears are very gently baked.
10136-8{_}21741{_}_Time_.--Large pears, 5 to 6 hours, in a very slow oven.
10136-8{_}21742{_}_Average cost_, 1d.
10136-8{_}21743{_}to 2d.
10136-8{_}21744{_}each.
10136-8{_}21745{_}_Sufficient_ for 7 or 8 persons.
10136-8{_}21746{_}_Seasonable_ from September to January.
10136-8{_}21747{_}PEAR.--The pear, like the apple, is indigenous to this country;     but the wild pear is a very unsatisfactory fruit.
10136-8{_}21748{_}The best     varieties were brought from the East by the Romans, who     cultivated them with care, and probably introduced some of their     best sorts into this island, to which others were added by the     inhabitants of the monasteries.
10136-8{_}21749{_}The Dutch and Flemings, as well     as the French, have excelled in the cultivation of the pear, and     most of the late varieties introduced are from France and     Flanders.
10136-8{_}21750{_}The pear is a hardy tree, and a longer liver than the     apple: it has been known to exist for centuries.
10136-8{_}21751{_}There are now     about 150 varieties of this fruit.
10136-8{_}21752{_}Though perfectly wholesome     when ripe, the pear is not so when green; but in this state it     is fit for stewing.
10136-8{_}21753{_}An agreeable beverage, called perry, is made     from pears, and the varieties which are least fit for eating     make the best perry.
10136-8{_}21754{_}PRESERVED PEARS.
10136-8{_}21755{_}1575.
10136-8{_}21756{_}INGREDIENTS.--Jargonelle pears; to every lb.
10136-8{_}21757{_}of sugar allow 1/2 pint of water.
10136-8{_}21758{_}_Mode_.--Procure some Jargonelle pears, not too ripe; put them into a stewpan with sufficient water to cover them, and simmer them till rather tender, but do not allow them to break; then put them into cold water.
10136-8{_}21759{_}Boil the sugar and water together for 5 minutes, skim well, put in the pears, and simmer them gently for 5 minutes.
10136-8{_}21760{_}Repeat the simmering for 3 successive days, taking care not to let the fruit break.
10136-8{_}21761{_}The last time of boiling, the syrup should be made rather richer, and the fruit boiled for 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}21762{_}When the pears are done, drain them from the syrup, and dry them in the sun, or in a cool oven; or they may be kept in the syrup, and dried as they are wanted.
10136-8{_}21763{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour to simmer the pears in water, 20 minutes in the syrup.
10136-8{_}21764{_}_Average cost_, 1d.
10136-8{_}21765{_}to 2d.
10136-8{_}21766{_}each.
10136-8{_}21767{_}_Seasonable_.--Most plentiful in September and October.
10136-8{_}21768{_}STEWED PEARS.
10136-8{_}21769{_}[Illustration: STEWED PEARS.]
10136-8{_}21770{_}1576.
10136-8{_}21771{_}INGREDIENTS.--8 large pears, 5 oz.
10136-8{_}21772{_}of loaf sugar, 6 cloves, 6 whole allspice, 1/2 pint of water, 1/4 pint of port wine, a few drops of prepared cochineal.
10136-8{_}21773{_}_Mode_.--Pare the pears, halve them, remove the cores, and leave the stalks on; put them into a _lined_ saucepan with the above ingredients, and let them simmer very gently until tender, which will be in from 3 to 4 hours, according to the quality of the pears.
10136-8{_}21774{_}They should be watched, and, when done, carefully lifted out on to a glass dish without breaking them.
10136-8{_}21775{_}Boil up the syrup quickly for 2 or 3 minutes; allow it to cool a little, pour it over the pears, and let them get perfectly cold.
10136-8{_}21776{_}To improve the colour of the fruit, a few drops of prepared cochineal may be added, which rather enhances the beauty of this dish.
10136-8{_}21777{_}The fruit must not be boiled fast, but only simmered, and watched that it be not too much done.
10136-8{_}21778{_}_Time_.--3 to 4 hours.
10136-8{_}21779{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}21780{_}6d.
10136-8{_}21781{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}21782{_}_Seasonable_ from September to January.
10136-8{_}21783{_}THE BON CHRETIEN PEAR.--The valuable variety of pear called _Bon     Chrétien_, which comes to our tables in winter, either raw or     cooked, received its name through the following incident:--Louis     XI., king of France, had sent for Saint Francois de Paule from     the lower part of Calabria, in the hopes of recovering his     health through his intercession.
10136-8{_}21784{_}The saint brought with him the     seeds of this pear; and, as he was called at court Le Bon     Chrétien, this fruit obtained the name of him to whom France     owed its introduction.
10136-8{_}21785{_}PINEAPPLE CHIPS.
10136-8{_}21786{_}1577.
10136-8{_}21787{_}INGREDIENTS.--Pineapples; sugar to taste.
10136-8{_}21788{_}_Mode_.--Pare and slice the fruit thinly, put it on dishes, and strew over it plenty of pounded sugar.
10136-8{_}21789{_}Keep it in a hot closet, or very slow oven, 8 or 10 days, and turn the fruit every day until dry; then put the pieces of pine on tins, and place them in a quick oven for 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}21790{_}Let them cool, and store them away in dry boxes, with paper between each layer.
10136-8{_}21791{_}_Time_.--8 to 10 days.
10136-8{_}21792{_}_Seasonable_.--Foreign pines, in July and August.
10136-8{_}21793{_}PRESERVED PINEAPPLE.
10136-8{_}21794{_}1578.
10136-8{_}21795{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}21796{_}of fruit, weighed after being pared, allow 1 lb.
10136-8{_}21797{_}of loaf sugar; 1/4 pint of water.
10136-8{_}21798{_}_Mode_.--The pines for making this preserve should be perfectly sound but ripe.
10136-8{_}21799{_}Cut them into rather thick slices, as the fruit shrinks very much in the boiling.
10136-8{_}21800{_}Pare off the rind carefully, that none of the pine be wasted; and, in doing so, notch it in and out, as the edge cannot be smoothly cut without great waste.
10136-8{_}21801{_}Dissolve a portion of the sugar in a preserving-pan with 1/4 pint of water; when this is melted, gradually add the remainder of the sugar, and boil it until it forms a clear syrup, skimming well.
10136-8{_}21802{_}As soon as this is the case, put in the pieces of pine, and boil well for at least 1/2 hour, or until it looks nearly transparent.
10136-8{_}21803{_}Put it into pots, cover down when cold, and store away in a dry place.
10136-8{_}21804{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour to boil the fruit.
10136-8{_}21805{_}_Average cost_, 10d.
10136-8{_}21806{_}to 1s.
10136-8{_}21807{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}21808{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21809{_}_Seasonable_.--Foreign pines, in July and August.
10136-8{_}21810{_}THE PINEAPPLE IN HEATHENDOM.--Heathen nations invented     protective divinities for their orchards (such as Pomona,     Vertumnus, Priapus, &c.), and benevolent patrons for their     fruits: thus, the olive-tree grew under the auspices of Minerva;     the Muses cherished the palm-tree, Bacchus the fig and grape,     _and the pine and its cone were consecrated to the great Cyble_.
10136-8{_}21811{_}PRESERVED PINEAPPLE, for Present Use.
10136-8{_}21812{_}1579.
10136-8{_}21813{_}INGREDIENTS.--Pineapple, sugar, water.
10136-8{_}21814{_}_Mode_.--Cut the pine into slices 1/4 inch in thickness; peel them, and remove the hard part from the middle.
10136-8{_}21815{_}Put the parings and hard pieces into a stewpan with sufficient water to cover them, and boil for 1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}21816{_}Strain the liquor, and put in the slices of pine.
10136-8{_}21817{_}Stew them for 10 minutes, add sufficient sugar to sweeten the whole nicely, and boil again for another 1/4 hour; skim well, and the preserve will be ready for use.
10136-8{_}21818{_}It must be eaten soon, as it will keep but a very short time.
10136-8{_}21819{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour to boil the parings in water; 10 minutes to boil the pine without sugar, 1/4 hour with sugar.
10136-8{_}21820{_}_Average cost_.--Foreign pines, 1s.
10136-8{_}21821{_}to 3s.
10136-8{_}21822{_}each; English, from 2s.
10136-8{_}21823{_}to 12s.
10136-8{_}21824{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}21825{_}_Seasonable_.--Foreign, in July and August; English, all the year.
10136-8{_}21826{_}PLUM JAM.
10136-8{_}21827{_}1580.
10136-8{_}21828{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}21829{_}of plums, weighed before being stoned, allow 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}21830{_}of loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}21831{_}_Mode_.--In making plum jam, the quantity of sugar for each lb.
10136-8{_}21832{_}of fruit must be regulated by the quality and size of the fruit, some plums requiring much more sugar than others.
10136-8{_}21833{_}Divide the plums, take out the stones, and put them on to large dishes, with roughly-pounded sugar sprinkled over them in the above proportion, and let them remain for one day; then put them into a preserving-pan, stand them by the side of the fire to simmer gently for about 1/2 hour, and then boil them rapidly for another 15 minutes.
10136-8{_}21834{_}The scum must be carefully removed as it rises, and the jam must be well stirred all the time, or it will burn at the bottom of the pan, and so spoil the colour and flavour of the preserve.
10136-8{_}21835{_}Some of the stones may be cracked, and a few kernels added to the jam just before it is done: these impart a very delicious flavour to the plums.
10136-8{_}21836{_}The above proportion of sugar would answer for Orleans plums; the Impératrice Magnum-bonum, and Winesour would not require quite so much.
10136-8{_}21837{_}_Time_.--1/2 hour to simmer gently, 1/4 hour to boil rapidly.
10136-8{_}21838{_}_Best plums for preserving_.--Violets, Mussels, Orleans, Impératrice Magnum-bonum, and Winesour.
10136-8{_}21839{_}_Seasonable_ from the end of July to the beginning of October.
10136-8{_}21840{_}PLUMS.--The Damson, or Damascene plum, takes its name from     Damascus, where it grows in great quantities, and whence it was     brought into Italy about 114 B.C.
10136-8{_}21841{_}The Orleans plum is from     France.
10136-8{_}21842{_}The Greengage is called after the Gage family, who first     brought it into England from the monastery of the Chartreuse, at     Paris, where it still bears the name of Reine Claude.
10136-8{_}21843{_}The     Magnum-bonum is our largest plum, and greatly esteemed for     preserves and culinary purposes.
10136-8{_}21844{_}The best sorts of plums are     agreeable at the dessert, and, when perfectly ripe, are     wholesome; but some are too astringent.
10136-8{_}21845{_}They lose much of their     bad qualities by baking, and are extensively used, from their     cheapness, when in full season, in tarts and preserves; but they     are not a very wholesome fruit, and should be eaten in     moderation.
10136-8{_}21846{_}PRESERVED PLUMS.
10136-8{_}21847{_}1581.
10136-8{_}21848{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}21849{_}of fruit allow 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}21850{_}of loaf sugar; for the thin syrup, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}21851{_}of sugar to each pint of water.
10136-8{_}21852{_}_Mode_.--Select large ripe plums; slightly prick them, to prevent them from bursting, and simmer them very gently in a syrup made with the above proportion of sugar and water.
10136-8{_}21853{_}Put them carefully into a pan, let the syrup cool, pour it over the plums, and allow them to remain for two days.
10136-8{_}21854{_}Having previously weighed the other sugar, dip the lumps quickly into water, and put them into a preserving-pan with no more water than hangs about them; and boil the sugar to a syrup, carefully skimming it.
10136-8{_}21855{_}Drain the plums from the first syrup; put them into the fresh syrup, and simmer them very gently until they are clear; lift them out singly into pots, pour the syrup over, and when cold, cover down to exclude the air.
10136-8{_}21856{_}This preserve will remain good some time, if kept in a dry place, and makes a very nice addition to a dessert.
10136-8{_}21857{_}The magnum-bonum plums answer for this preserve better than any other kind of plum.
10136-8{_}21858{_}Greengages are also very delicious done in this manner.
10136-8{_}21859{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour to 20 minutes to simmer the plums in the first syrup; 20 minutes to 1/2 hour very gentle simmering in the second.
10136-8{_}21860{_}_Seasonable_ from August to October.
10136-8{_}21861{_}TO PRESERVE PLUMS DRY.
10136-8{_}21862{_}1582.
10136-8{_}21863{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}21864{_}of sugar allow 1/4 pint of water.
10136-8{_}21865{_}_Mode_.--Gather the plums when they are full-grown and just turning colour; prick them, put them into a saucepan of cold water, and set them on the fire until the water is on the point of boiling.
10136-8{_}21866{_}Then take them out, drain them, and boil them gently in syrup made with the above proportion of sugar and water; and if the plums shrink, and will not take the sugar, prick them as they lie in the pan; give them another boil, skim, and set them by.
10136-8{_}21867{_}The next day add some more sugar, boiled almost to candy, to the fruit and syrup; put all together into a wide-mouthed jar, and place them in a cool oven for 2 nights; then drain the plums from the syrup, sprinkle a little powdered sugar over, and dry them in a cool oven.
10136-8{_}21868{_}_Time_.--15 to 20 minutes to boil the plums in the syrup.
10136-8{_}21869{_}_Seasonable_ from August to October.
10136-8{_}21870{_}PLUMS.--The wild sloe is the parent of the plum, but the     acclimated kinds come from the East.
10136-8{_}21871{_}The cultivation of this     fruit was probably attended to very early in England, as Gerrard     informs us that, in 1597, he had in his garden, in Holborn,     threescore sorts.
10136-8{_}21872{_}The sloe is a shrub common in our hedgerows,     and belongs to the natural order _Amygdaleae_; the fruit is     about the size of a large pea, of a black colour, and covered     with a bloom of a bright blue.
10136-8{_}21873{_}It is one of the few indigenous     to our island.
10136-8{_}21874{_}The juice is extremely sharp and astringent, and     was formerly employed as a medicine, where astringents were     necessary.
10136-8{_}21875{_}It now assists in the manufacture of a red wine made     to imitate port, and also for adulteration.
10136-8{_}21876{_}The leaves have been     used to adulterate tea; the fruit, when ripe, makes a good     preserve.
10136-8{_}21877{_}STEWED FRENCH PLUMS.
10136-8{_}21878{_}(_A Dessert Dish_.)
10136-8{_}21879{_}1583.
10136-8{_}21880{_}INGREDIENTS.--1-1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}21881{_}of French plums, 3/4 pint of syrup No.
10136-8{_}21882{_}1512, 1 glass of port wine, the rind and juice of 1 lemon.
10136-8{_}21883{_}_Mode_.--Stew the plums gently in water for 1 hour; strain the water, and with it make the syrup.
10136-8{_}21884{_}When it is clear, put in the plums with the port wine, lemon-juice, and rind, and simmer very gently for 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}21885{_}Arrange the plums on a glass dish, take out the lemon-rind, pour the syrup over the plums, and, when cold, they will be ready for table.
10136-8{_}21886{_}A little allspice stewed with the fruit is by many persons considered an improvement.
10136-8{_}21887{_}_Time_.--1 hour to stew the plums in water, 1-1/2 hour in the syrup.
10136-8{_}21888{_}_Average cost_,--plums sufficiently good for stewing, 1s.
10136-8{_}21889{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}21890{_}_Sufficient_ for 7 or 8 persons.
10136-8{_}21891{_}_Seasonable_ in winter.
10136-8{_}21892{_}PRESERVED PUMPKIN.
10136-8{_}21893{_}1584.
10136-8{_}21894{_}INGREDIENTS.--To each lb.
10136-8{_}21895{_}of pumpkin allow 1 lb.
10136-8{_}21896{_}of roughly pounded loaf sugar, 1 gill of lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}21897{_}_Mode_.--Obtain a good sweet pumpkin; halve it, take out the seeds, and pare off the rind; cut it into neat slices, or into pieces about the size of a five-shilling piece.
10136-8{_}21898{_}Weigh the pumpkin, put the slices in a pan or deep dish in layers, with the sugar sprinkled between them; pour the lemon-juice over the top, and let the whole remain for 2 or 3 days.
10136-8{_}21899{_}Boil altogether, adding 1/4 pint of water to every 3 lbs.
10136-8{_}21900{_}of sugar used until the pumpkin becomes tender; then turn the whole into a pan, where let it remain for a week; then drain off the syrup, boil it until it is quite thick; skim, and pour it, boiling, over the pumpkin.
10136-8{_}21901{_}A little bruised ginger and lemon-rind, thinly pared, may be boiled in the syrup to flavour the pumpkin.
10136-8{_}21902{_}_Time_.--From 1/2 to 3/4 hour to boil the pumpkin tender.
10136-8{_}21903{_}_Average cost_, 5d.
10136-8{_}21904{_}to 7d.
10136-8{_}21905{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}21906{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21907{_}_Seasonable_ in September and October; but better when made in the latter month, as the pumpkin is then quite ripe.
10136-8{_}21908{_}_Note_.--Vegetable marrows are very good prepared in the same manner, but are not quite so rich.
10136-8{_}21909{_}QUINCE JELLY.
10136-8{_}21910{_}1585.
10136-8{_}21911{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every pint of juice allow 1 lb.
10136-8{_}21912{_}of loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}21913{_}_Mode_.--Pare and slice the quinces, and put them into a preserving-pan with sufficient water to float them.
10136-8{_}21914{_}Boil them until tender, and the fruit is reduced to a pulp; strain off the clear juice, and to each pint allow the above proportion of loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}21915{_}Boil the juice and sugar together for about 3/4 hour; remove all the scum as it rises, and, when the jelly appears firm when a little is poured on a plate, it is done.
10136-8{_}21916{_}The residue left on the sieve will answer to make a common marmalade, for immediate use, by boiling it with 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}21917{_}of common sugar to every lb.
10136-8{_}21918{_}of pulp.
10136-8{_}21919{_}_Time_.--3 hours to boil the quinces in water; 3/4 hour to boil the jelly.
10136-8{_}21920{_}_Average cost_, from 8d.
10136-8{_}21921{_}to 10d.
10136-8{_}21922{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}21923{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21924{_}_Seasonable_ from August to October.
10136-8{_}21925{_}QUINCE MARMALADE.
10136-8{_}21926{_}1586.
10136-8{_}21927{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}21928{_}of quince pulp allow 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}21929{_}of loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}21930{_}_Mode_.--Slice the quinces into a preserving-pan, adding sufficient water for them to float; place them on the fire to stew, until reduced to a pulp, keeping them stirred occasionally from the bottom, to prevent their burning; then pass the pulp through a hair sieve, to keep back the skin and seeds.
10136-8{_}21931{_}Weigh the pulp, and to each lb.
10136-8{_}21932{_}add lump sugar in the above proportion, broken very small.
10136-8{_}21933{_}Place the whole on the fire, and keep it well stirred from the bottom of the pan with a wooden spoon, until reduced to a marmalade, which may be known by dropping a little on a cold plate, when, if it jellies, it is done.
10136-8{_}21934{_}Put it into jars whilst hot; let it cool, and cover with pieces of oiled paper cut to the size of the mouths of the jars.
10136-8{_}21935{_}The tops of them may be afterwards covered with pieces of bladder, or tissue-paper brushed over on both sides with the white of an egg.
10136-8{_}21936{_}_Time_.--3 hours to boil the quinces without the sugar; 3/4 hour to boil the pulp with the sugar.
10136-8{_}21937{_}_Average cost_, from 8d.
10136-8{_}21938{_}to 9d.
10136-8{_}21939{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}21940{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21941{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 1 pint of sliced quinces for a lb.
10136-8{_}21942{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21943{_}_Seasonable_ in August, September, and October.
10136-8{_}21944{_}RAISIN CHEESE.
10136-8{_}21945{_}1587.
10136-8{_}21946{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}21947{_}of raisins allow a lb.
10136-8{_}21948{_}of loaf sugar; pounded cinnamon and cloves to taste.
10136-8{_}21949{_}_Mode_.--Stone the raisins; put them into a stewpan with the sugar, cinnamon, and cloves, and let them boil for 1-1/2 hour, stirring all the time.
10136-8{_}21950{_}Let the preparation cool a little, pour it into a glass dish, and garnish with strips of candied lemon-peel and citron.
10136-8{_}21951{_}This will remain good some time, if kept in a dry place.
10136-8{_}21952{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}21953{_}_Average cost_, 9d.
10136-8{_}21954{_}_Sufficient_.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}21955{_}for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}21956{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}21957{_}RASPBERRY JAM.
10136-8{_}21958{_}1588.
10136-8{_}21959{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}21960{_}of raspberries allow 1 lb.
10136-8{_}21961{_}of sugar, 1/4 pint of red-currant juice.
10136-8{_}21962{_}_Mode_.--Let the fruit for this preserve be gathered in fine weather, and used as soon after it is picked as possible.
10136-8{_}21963{_}Take off the stalks, put the raspberries into a preserving-pan, break them well with a wooden spoon, and let them boil for 1/4 hour, keeping them well stirred.
10136-8{_}21964{_}Then add the currant-juice and sugar, and boil again for 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}21965{_}Skim the jam well after the sugar is added, or the preserve will not be clear.
10136-8{_}21966{_}The addition of the currant juice is a very great improvement to this preserve, as it gives it a piquant taste, which the flavour of the raspberries seems to require.
10136-8{_}21967{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour to simmer the fruit without the sugar; 1/4 hour after it is added.
10136-8{_}21968{_}_Average cost_, from 6d.
10136-8{_}21969{_}to 8d.
10136-8{_}21970{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}21971{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21972{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow about 1 pint of fruit to fill a 1-lb.
10136-8{_}21973{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21974{_}_Seasonable_ in July and August.
10136-8{_}21975{_}RASPBERRY JELLY.
10136-8{_}21976{_}1589.
10136-8{_}21977{_}INGREDIENTS.--To each pint of juice allow 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}21978{_}of loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}21979{_}_Mode_.--Let the raspberries be freshly gathered, quite ripe, and picked from the stalks; put them into a large jar, after breaking the fruit a little with a wooden spoon, and place this jar, covered, in a saucepan of boiling water.
10136-8{_}21980{_}When the juice is well drawn, which will be in from 3/4 to 1 hour, strain the fruit through a fine hair sieve or cloth; measure the juice, and to every pint allow the above proportion of loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}21981{_}Put the juice and sugar into a preserving-pan, place it over the fire, and boil gently until the jelly thickens when a little is poured on a plate; carefully remove all the scum as it rises, pour the jelly into small pots, cover down, and keep in a dry place.
10136-8{_}21982{_}This jelly answers for making raspberry cream, and for flavouring various sweet dishes, when, in winter, the fresh fruit is not obtainable.
10136-8{_}21983{_}_Time_.--3/4 to 1 hour to draw the juice.
10136-8{_}21984{_}_Average cost_, from 9d.
10136-8{_}21985{_}to 1s.
10136-8{_}21986{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}21987{_}pot.
10136-8{_}21988{_}_Sufficient._--From 3 pints to 2 quarts of fruit should yield 1 pint of juice.
10136-8{_}21989{_}_Seasonable_.--This should be made in July or August.
10136-8{_}21990{_}RHUBARB JAM.
10136-8{_}21991{_}1590.
10136-8{_}21992{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}21993{_}of rhubarb allow 1 lb.
10136-8{_}21994{_}of loaf sugar, the rind of 1/2 lemon.
10136-8{_}21995{_}_Mode_.--Wipe the rhubarb perfectly dry, take off the string or peel, and weigh it; put it into a preserving-pan, with sugar in the above proportion; mince the lemon-rind very finely, add it to the other ingredients, and place the preserving-pan by the side of the fire; keep stirring to prevent the rhubarb from burning, and when the sugar is well dissolved, put the pan more over the fire, and let the jam boil until it is done, taking care to keep it well skimmed and stirred with a wooden or silver spoon.
10136-8{_}21996{_}Pour it into pots, and cover down with oiled and egged papers.
10136-8{_}21997{_}_Time_.--If the rhubarb is young and tender, 3/4 hour, reckoning from the time it simmers equally; old rhubarb, 1-1/4 to 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}21998{_}_Average cost_, 5d.
10136-8{_}21999{_}to 7d.
10136-8{_}22000{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}22001{_}pot.
10136-8{_}22002{_}_Sufficient_.--About 1 pint of sliced rhubarb to fill a lb.
10136-8{_}22003{_}pot.
10136-8{_}22004{_}_Seasonable_ from February to April.
10136-8{_}22005{_}RHUBARB AND ORANGE JAM, to resemble Scotch Marmalade.
10136-8{_}22006{_}1591.
10136-8{_}22007{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 quart of finely-cut rhubarb, 6 oranges, 1-1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}22008{_}of loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}22009{_}_Mode_.--Peel the oranges; remove as much of the white pith as possible, divide them, and take out the pips; slice the pulp into a preserving-pan, add the rind of half the oranges cut into thin strips, and the loaf sugar, which should be broken small.
10136-8{_}22010{_}Peel the rhubarb, cut it into thin pieces, put it to the oranges, and stir altogether over a gentle fire until the jam is done.
10136-8{_}22011{_}Remove all the scum as it rises, put the preserve into pots, and, when cold, cover down.
10136-8{_}22012{_}Should the rhubarb be very old, stew it alone for 1/4 hour before the other ingredients are added.
10136-8{_}22013{_}_Time_.--3/4 to 1 hour.
10136-8{_}22014{_}_Average cost_, from 6d.
10136-8{_}22015{_}to 8d.
10136-8{_}22016{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}22017{_}pot.
10136-8{_}22018{_}_Seasonable_ from February to April.
10136-8{_}22019{_}RASPBERRY AND CURRANT, or any Fresh Fruit Salad.
10136-8{_}22020{_}(_A Dessert Dish_.)
10136-8{_}22021{_}1592.
10136-8{_}22022{_}_Mode_.--Fruit salads are made by stripping the fruit from the stalks, piling it on a dish, and sprinkling over it finely-pounded sugar.
10136-8{_}22023{_}They may be made of strawberries, raspberries, currants, or any of these fruits mixed; peaches also make a very good salad.
10136-8{_}22024{_}After the sugar is sprinkled over, about 6 large tablespoonfuls of wine or brandy, or 3 tablespoonfuls of liqueur, should be poured in the middle of the fruit; and, when the flavour is liked, a little pounded cinnamon may be added.
10136-8{_}22025{_}In helping the fruit, it should be lightly stirred, that the wine and sugar may be equally distributed.
10136-8{_}22026{_}_Sufficient._--1-1/2 pint of fruit, with 3 oz.
10136-8{_}22027{_}of pounded sugar, for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}22028{_}_Seasonable_ in summer.
10136-8{_}22029{_}STRAWBERRIES AND CREAM.
10136-8{_}22030{_}1593.
10136-8{_}22031{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every pint of picked strawberries allow 1/3 pint of cream, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}22032{_}of finely-pounded sugar.
10136-8{_}22033{_}_Mode_.--Pick the stalks from the fruit, place it on a glass dish, sprinkle over it pounded sugar, and slightly stir the strawberries, that they may all be equally sweetened; pour the cream over the top, and serve.
10136-8{_}22034{_}Devonshire cream, when it can be obtained, is exceedingly delicious for this dish; and, if very thick indeed, may be diluted with a little thin cream or milk.
10136-8{_}22035{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, with cream at 1s.
10136-8{_}22036{_}per pint, 1s.
10136-8{_}22037{_}_Sufficient_ for 2 persons.
10136-8{_}22038{_}_Seasonable_ in June and July.
10136-8{_}22039{_}STRAWBERRY JAM.
10136-8{_}22040{_}1594.
10136-8{_}22041{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}22042{_}of fruit allow 1/2 pint of red-currant juice, 1-1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}22043{_}of loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}22044{_}_Mode_.--Strip the currants from the stalks, put them into a jar; place this jar in a saucepan of boiling water, and simmer until the juice is well drawn from the fruit; strain the currants, measure the juice, put it into a preserving-pan, and add the sugar.
10136-8{_}22045{_}Select well-ripened but sound strawberries; pick them from the stalks, and when the sugar is dissolved in the currant juice, put in the fruit.
10136-8{_}22046{_}Simmer the whole over a moderate fire, from 1/2 to 3/4 hour, carefully removing the scum as it rises.
10136-8{_}22047{_}Stir the jam only enough to prevent it from burning at the bottom of the pan, as the fruit should be preserved as whole as possible.
10136-8{_}22048{_}Put the jam into jars, and when cold, cover down.
10136-8{_}22049{_}_Time_.--1/2 to 3/4 hour, reckoning from the time the jam simmers all over.
10136-8{_}22050{_}_Average cost_, from 7d.
10136-8{_}22051{_}to 8d.
10136-8{_}22052{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}22053{_}pot.
10136-8{_}22054{_}_Sufficient._--12 pints of strawberries will make 12 lb.
10136-8{_}22055{_}pots of jam.
10136-8{_}22056{_}_Seasonable_ in June and July.
10136-8{_}22057{_}PRESERVED STRAWBERRIES IN WINE.
10136-8{_}22058{_}1595.
10136-8{_}22059{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every quart bottle allow 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}22060{_}of finely-pounded loaf sugar; sherry or Madeira.
10136-8{_}22061{_}_Mode_.--Let the fruit be gathered in fine weather, and used as soon as picked.
10136-8{_}22062{_}Have ready some perfectly dry glass bottles, and some nice soft corks or bungs.
10136-8{_}22063{_}Pick the stalks from the strawberries, drop them into the bottles, sprinkling amongst them pounded sugar in the above proportion, and when the fruit reaches to the neck of the bottle, fill up with sherry or Madeira.
10136-8{_}22064{_}Cork the bottles down with new corks, and dip them into melted resin.
10136-8{_}22065{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in June or July.
10136-8{_}22066{_}TO PRESERVE STRAWBERRIES WHOLE.
10136-8{_}22067{_}1596.
10136-8{_}22068{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}22069{_}of fruit allow 1-1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}22070{_}of good loaf sugar, 1 pint of red-currant juice.
10136-8{_}22071{_}_Mode_.--Choose the strawberries not too ripe, of a fine large sort and of a good colour.
10136-8{_}22072{_}Pick off the stalks, lay the strawberries in a dish, and sprinkle over them half the quantity of sugar, which must be finely pounded.
10136-8{_}22073{_}Shake the dish gently, that the sugar may be equally distributed and touch the under-side of the fruit, and let it remain for 1 day.
10136-8{_}22074{_}Then have ready the currant-juice, drawn as for red-currant jelly No.
10136-8{_}22075{_}1533; boil it with the remainder of the sugar until it forms a thin syrup, and in this simmer the strawberries and sugar, until the whole is sufficiently jellied.
10136-8{_}22076{_}Great care must be taken not to stir the fruit roughly, as it should be preserved as whole as possible.
10136-8{_}22077{_}Strawberries prepared in this manner are very good served in glasses and mixed with thin cream.
10136-8{_}22078{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour to 20 minutes to simmer the strawberries in the syrup.
10136-8{_}22079{_}_Seasonable_ in June and July.
10136-8{_}22080{_}TO MAKE EVERTON TOFFEE.
10136-8{_}22081{_}1597.
10136-8{_}22082{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}22083{_}of powdered loaf sugar, 1 teacupful of water, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}22084{_}of butter, 6 drops of essence of lemon.
10136-8{_}22085{_}_Mode_.--Put the water and sugar into a brass pan, and beat the butter to a cream.
10136-8{_}22086{_}When the sugar is dissolved, add the butter, and keep stirring the mixture over the fire until it sets, when a little is poured on to a buttered dish; and just before the toffee is done, add the essence of lemon.
10136-8{_}22087{_}Butter a dish or tin, pour on it the mixture, and when cool, it will easily separate from the dish.
10136-8{_}22088{_}Butter-Scotch, an excellent thing for coughs, is made with brown, instead of white sugar, omitting the water, and flavoured with 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}22089{_}of powdered ginger.
10136-8{_}22090{_}It is made in the same manner as toffee.
10136-8{_}22091{_}_Time_.--18 to 35 minutes.
10136-8{_}22092{_}_Average cost_, 10d.
10136-8{_}22093{_}_Sufficient_ to make a lb.
10136-8{_}22094{_}of toffee.
10136-8{_}22095{_}DESSERT DISHES.
10136-8{_}22096{_}[Illustration: DISH OF NUTS.]
10136-8{_}22097{_}[Illustration: BOX OF FRENCH PLUMS.]
10136-8{_}22098{_}[Illustration: DISH OF MIXED FRUIT.]
10136-8{_}22099{_}1598.
10136-8{_}22100{_}The tazza, or dish with stem, the same as that shown in our illustrations, is now the favourite shape for dessert-dishes.
10136-8{_}22101{_}The fruit can be arranged and shown to better advantage on these tall high dishes than on the short flat ones.
10136-8{_}22102{_}All the dishes are now usually placed down the centre of the table, dried and fresh fruit alternately, the former being arranged on small round or oval glass plates, and the latter on the dishes with stems.
10136-8{_}22103{_}The fruit should always be gathered on the same day that it is required for table, and should be tastefully arranged on the dishes, with leaves between and round it.
10136-8{_}22104{_}By purchasing fruits that are in season, a dessert can be supplied at a very moderate cost.
10136-8{_}22105{_}These, with a few fancy biscuits, crystallized fruit, bon-bons, &c., are sufficient for an ordinary dessert.
10136-8{_}22106{_}When fresh fruit cannot be obtained, dried and foreign fruits, compotes, baked pears, stewed Normandy pippins, &c. &c., must supply its place, with the addition of preserves, bon-bons, cakes, biscuits, &c. At fashionable tables, forced fruit is served growing in pots, these pots being hidden in more ornamental ones, and arranged with the other dishes.--(See coloured plate W1.)
10136-8{_}22107{_}A few vases of fresh flowers, tastefully arranged, add very much to the appearance of the dessert; and, when these are not obtainable, a few paper ones, mixed with green leaves, answer very well as a substitute.
10136-8{_}22108{_}In decorating a table, whether for luncheon, dessert, or supper, a vase or two of flowers should never be forgotten, as they add so much to the elegance of the _tout ensemble_.
10136-8{_}22109{_}In summer and autumn, ladies residing in the country can always manage to have a few freshly-gathered flowers on their tables, and should never be without this inexpensive luxury.
10136-8{_}22110{_}On the continent, vases or epergnes filled with flowers are invariably placed down the centre of the dinner-table at regular distances.
10136-8{_}22111{_}Ices for dessert are usually moulded: when this is not the case, they are handed round in glasses with wafers to accompany them.
10136-8{_}22112{_}Preserved ginger is frequently handed round after ices, to prepare the palate for the delicious dessert wines.
10136-8{_}22113{_}A basin or glass of finely-pounded lump sugar must never be omitted at a dessert, as also a glass jug of fresh cold water (iced, if possible), and two goblets by its side.
10136-8{_}22114{_}Grape-scissors, a melon-knife and fork, and nutcrackers, should always be put on table, if there are dishes of fruit requiring them.
10136-8{_}22115{_}Zests are sometimes served at the close of the dessert; such as anchovy toasts or biscuits.
10136-8{_}22116{_}The French often serve plain or grated cheese with a dessert of fresh or dried fruit.
10136-8{_}22117{_}At some tables, finger-glasses are placed at the right of each person, nearly half filled with cold spring water, and in winter with tepid water.
10136-8{_}22118{_}These precede the dessert.
10136-8{_}22119{_}At other tables, a glass or vase is simply handed round, filled with perfumed water, into which each guest dips the corner of his napkin, and, when needful, refreshes his lips and the tips of his fingers.
10136-8{_}22120{_}[Illustration: BOX OF CHOCOLATE.]
10136-8{_}22121{_}[Illustration: DISH OF APPLES.]
10136-8{_}22122{_}[Illustration: ALMONDS AND RAISINS.]
10136-8{_}22123{_}[Illustration: DISH OF STRAWBERRIES.]
10136-8{_}22124{_}After the dishes are placed, and every one is provided with plates, glasses, spoons, &c., the wine should be put at each end of the table, cooled or otherwise, according to the season.
10136-8{_}22125{_}If the party be small, the wine may be placed only at the top of the table, near the host.
10136-8{_}22126{_}DISH OF NUTS.
10136-8{_}22127{_}1599.
10136-8{_}22128{_}These are merely arranged piled high in the centre of the dish, as shown in the engraving, with or without leaves round the edge.
10136-8{_}22129{_}Filberts should always be served with the outer skin or husk on them; and walnuts should be well wiped with a damp cloth, and then--with a dry one, to remove the unpleasant sticky feeling the shells frequently have.
10136-8{_}22130{_}_Seasonable_.--Filberts from September to March, good; may be had after that time, but are generally shrivelled and dry.
10136-8{_}22131{_}Walnuts from September to January.
10136-8{_}22132{_}HAZEL NUT AND FILBERT.--The common Hazel is the wild, and the     Filbert the cultivated state of the same tree.
10136-8{_}22133{_}The hazel is     found wild, not only in forests and hedges, in dingles and     ravines, but occurs in extensive tracts in the more northern and     mountainous parts of the country.
10136-8{_}22134{_}It was formerly one of the     most abundant of those trees which are indigenous in this     island.
10136-8{_}22135{_}It is seldom cultivated as a fruit-tree, though perhaps     its nuts are superior in flavour to the others.
10136-8{_}22136{_}The Spanish nuts     imported are a superior kind, but they are somewhat oily and     rather indigestible.
10136-8{_}22137{_}Filberts, both the red and the white, and     the cob-nut, are supposed to be merely varieties of the common     hazel, which have been produced, partly by the superiority of     soil and climate, and partly by culture.
10136-8{_}22138{_}They were originally     brought out of Greece to Italy, whence they have found their way     to Holland, and from that country to England.
10136-8{_}22139{_}It is supposed     that, within a few miles of Maidstone, in Kent, there are more     filberts grown than in all England besides; and it is from that     place that the London market is supplied.
10136-8{_}22140{_}The filbert is longer     than the common nut, though of the same thickness, and has a     larger kernel.
10136-8{_}22141{_}The cob-nut is a still larger variety, and is     roundish.
10136-8{_}22142{_}Filberts are more esteemed at the dessert than common     nuts, and are generally eaten with salt.
10136-8{_}22143{_}They are very free from     oil, and disagree with few persons.
10136-8{_}22144{_}WALNUTS.--The Walnut is a native of Persia, the Caucasus, and     China, but was introduced to this kingdom from France.
10136-8{_}22145{_}The ripe     kernel is brought to the dessert on account of its agreeable     flavour; and the fruit is also much used in the green state, but     before the stone hardens, as a pickle.
10136-8{_}22146{_}In Spain, grated walnuts     are employed in tarts and other dishes.
10136-8{_}22147{_}The Walnut abounds in     oil which is expressed and which, being of a highly drying     nature, and very limpid, is much employed for delicate painting.
10136-8{_}22148{_}This, on the continent, is sometimes used as a substitute for     olive-oil in cooking, but is very apt to turn rancid.
10136-8{_}22149{_}It is also     manufactured into a kind of soap.
10136-8{_}22150{_}The mare, or refuse matter     after the oil is extracted, proves very nutritious for poultry     or other domestic animals.
10136-8{_}22151{_}In Switzerland, this is eaten by poor     people under the name of _pain amer._  BOX OF FRENCH PLUMS.
10136-8{_}22152{_}1600.
10136-8{_}22153{_}If the box which contains them is exceedingly ornamental, it may be placed on the table; if small, on a glass dish; if large, without one, French plums may also be arranged on a glass plate, and garnished with bright-coloured sweetmeats, which make a very good effect.
10136-8{_}22154{_}All fancy boxes of preserved and crystallized fruit may be put on the table or not, at pleasure.
10136-8{_}22155{_}These little matters of detail must, of course, be left to individual taste.
10136-8{_}22156{_}_Seasonable_.--May be purchased all the year; but are in greater perfection in the winter, and are more suitable for that season, as fresh fruit cannot be obtained.
10136-8{_}22157{_}DISH OF MIXED FRUIT.
10136-8{_}22158{_}1601.
10136-8{_}22159{_}For a centre dish, a mixture of various fresh fruits has a remarkably good effect, particularly if a pine be added to the list.
10136-8{_}22160{_}A high raised appearance should be given to the fruit, which is done in the following manner.
10136-8{_}22161{_}Place a tumbler in the centre of the dish, and, in this tumbler, the pine, crown uppermost; round the tumbler put a thick layer of moss, and, over this, apples, pears, plums, peaches, and such fruit as is simultaneously in season.
10136-8{_}22162{_}By putting a layer of moss underneath, so much fruit is not required, besides giving a better shape to the dish.
10136-8{_}22163{_}Grapes should be placed on the top of the fruit, a portion of some of the bunches hanging over the sides of the dish in a négligé kind of manner, which takes off the formal look of the dish.
10136-8{_}22164{_}In arranging the plums, apples, &c., let the colours contrast well.
10136-8{_}22165{_}_Seasonable_.--Suitable for a dessert in September or October.
10136-8{_}22166{_}GRAPES.--France produces about a thousand varieties of the     grape, which is cultivated more extensively in that country than     in any other.
10136-8{_}22167{_}Hygienists agree in pronouncing grapes as among     the best of fruits.
10136-8{_}22168{_}The grape possesses several rare qualities:     it is nourishing and fattening, and its prolonged use has often     overcome the most obstinate cases of constipation.
10136-8{_}22169{_}The skins and     pips of grapes should not be eaten.
10136-8{_}22170{_}BOX OF CHOCOLATE.
10136-8{_}22171{_}1602.
10136-8{_}22172{_}This is served in an ornamental box, placed on a glass plate or dish.
10136-8{_}22173{_}_Seasonable_.--May be purchased at any time.
10136-8{_}22174{_}DISH OF APPLES.
10136-8{_}22175{_}1603.
10136-8{_}22176{_}The apples should be nicely wiped with a dry cloth, and arranged on a dish, piled high in the centre, with evergreen leaves between each layer.
10136-8{_}22177{_}The inferior apples should form the bottom layer, with the bright-coloured large ones at the top.
10136-8{_}22178{_}The leaves of the laurel, bay, holly, or any shrub green in winter, are suitable for garnishing dessert dishes.
10136-8{_}22179{_}Oranges may be arranged in the same manner; they should also be wiped with a dry cloth before being sent to table.
10136-8{_}22180{_}DISH OF MIXED SUMMER FRUIT.
10136-8{_}22181{_}1604.
10136-8{_}22182{_}This dish consists of cherries, raspberries, currants, and strawberries, piled in different layers, with plenty of leaves between each layer; so that each fruit is well separated.
10136-8{_}22183{_}The fruit should be arranged with a due regard to colour, so that they contrast nicely one with the other.
10136-8{_}22184{_}Our engraving shows a layer of white cherries at the bottom, then one of red raspberries; over that a layer of white currants, and at the top some fine scarlet strawberries.
10136-8{_}22185{_}_Seasonable_ in June, July, and August.
10136-8{_}22186{_}ALMONDS AND RAISINS.
10136-8{_}22187{_}1605.
10136-8{_}22188{_}These are usually served on glass dishes, the fruit piled high in the centre, and the almonds blanched, and strewn over.
10136-8{_}22189{_}To blanch the almonds, put them into a small mug or teacup, pour over them boiling water, let them remain for 2 or 3 minutes, and the skins may then be easily removed.
10136-8{_}22190{_}Figs, dates, French plums, &c., are all served on small glass plates or oval dishes, but without the almonds.
10136-8{_}22191{_}_Seasonable_ at any time, but more suitable in winter, when fresh fruit is not obtainable.
10136-8{_}22192{_}DATES.--Dates are imported into Britain, in a dried state, from     Barbary and Egypt, and, when in good condition, they are much     esteemed.
10136-8{_}22193{_}An inferior kind has lately become common, which are     dried hard, and have little or no flavour.
10136-8{_}22194{_}They should be chosen     large, softish, not much wrinkled, of a reddish-yellow colour on     the outside, with a whitish membrane between the fruit and the     stone.
10136-8{_}22195{_}DISH OF STRAWBERRIES.
10136-8{_}22196{_}1606.
10136-8{_}22197{_}Fine strawberries, arranged in the manner shown in the engraving, look exceedingly well.
10136-8{_}22198{_}The inferior ones should be placed at the bottom of the dish, and the others put in rows pyramidically, with the stalks downwards; so that when the whole is completed, nothing but the red part of the fruit is visible.
10136-8{_}22199{_}The fruit should be gathered with rather long stalks, as there is then something to support it, and it can be placed more upright in each layer.
10136-8{_}22200{_}A few of the finest should be reserved to crown the top.
10136-8{_}22201{_}TO HAVE WALNUTS FRESH THROUGHOUT THE SEASON.
10136-8{_}22202{_}1607.
10136-8{_}22203{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every pint of water allow 1 teaspoonful of salt.
10136-8{_}22204{_}_Mode_.--Place the walnuts in the salt and water for 24 hours at least; then take them out, and rub them dry.
10136-8{_}22205{_}Old nuts may be freshened in this manner; or walnuts, when first picked, may be put into an earthen pan with salt sprinkled amongst them, and with damped hay placed on the top of them, and then covered down with a lid.
10136-8{_}22206{_}They must be well wiped before they are put on table.
10136-8{_}22207{_}_Seasonable_.--Should be stored away in September or October.
10136-8{_}22208{_}[Illustration]     [Illustration]  CHAPTER XXXII.
10136-8{_}22209{_}GENERAL OBSERVATIONS ON MILK, BUTTER, CHEESE, AND EGGS.
10136-8{_}22210{_}MILK.
10136-8{_}22211{_}1608.
10136-8{_}22212{_}Milk is obtained only from the class of animals called Mammalia, and is intended by Nature for the nourishment of their young.
10136-8{_}22213{_}The milk of each animal is distinguished by some peculiarities; but as that of the cow is by far the most useful to us in this part of the world, our observations will be confined to that variety.
10136-8{_}22214{_}1609.
10136-8{_}22215{_}Milk, when drawn from the cow, is of a yellowish-white colour, and is the most yellow at the beginning of the period of lactation.
10136-8{_}22216{_}Its taste is agreeable, and rather saccharine.
10136-8{_}22217{_}The viscidity and specific gravity of milk are somewhat greater than that of water; but these properties vary somewhat in the milk procured from different individuals.
10136-8{_}22218{_}On an average, the specific gravity of milk is 1.035, water being 1.
10136-8{_}22219{_}The small cows of the Alderney breed afford the richest milk.
10136-8{_}22220{_}1610.
10136-8{_}22221{_}Milk which is carried to a considerable distance, so as to be much agitated, and cooled before it is put into pans to settle for cream, never throws up so much, nor such rich cream, as if the same milk had been put into pans directly after it was milked.
10136-8{_}22222{_}1611.
10136-8{_}22223{_}Milk, considered as an aliment, is of such importance in domestic economy as to render all the improvements in its production extremely valuable.
10136-8{_}22224{_}To enlarge upon the antiquity of its use is unnecessary; it has always been a favourite food in Britain.
10136-8{_}22225{_}"Lacte et carno vivunt," says Caesar, in his Commentaries; the English of which is, "the inhabitants subsist upon flesh and milk."
10136-8{_}22226{_}The breed of the cow has received great improvement in modern times, as regards the quantity and quality of the milk which she affords; the form of milch-cows, their mode of nourishment, and progress, are also manifest in the management of the dairy.
10136-8{_}22227{_}1612.
10136-8{_}22228{_}Although milk in its natural state be a fluid, yet, considered as an aliment, it is both solid and fluid: for no sooner does it enter the stomach, than it is coagulated by the gastric juice, and separated into curd and whey, the first of these being extremely nutritive.
10136-8{_}22229{_}1613.
10136-8{_}22230{_}Milk of the _human subject_ is much thinner than cow's milk; _Ass's milk_ comes the nearest to human milk of any other; _Goat's milk_ is something thicker and richer than cow's milk; _Ewe's milk_ has the appearance of cow's milk, and affords a larger quantity of cream; _Mare's milk_ contains more sugar than that of the ewe; _Camel's milk_ is used only in Africa; _Buffalo's milk_ is employed in India.
10136-8{_}22231{_}1614.
10136-8{_}22232{_}From no other substance, solid or fluid, can so great a number of distinct kinds of aliment be prepared as from milk; some forming food, others drink; some of them delicious, and deserving the name of luxuries; all of them wholesome, and some medicinal: indeed, the variety of aliments that seems capable of being produced from milk, appears to be quite endless.
10136-8{_}22233{_}In every age this must have been a subject for experiment, and every nation has added to the number by the invention of some peculiarity of its own.
10136-8{_}22234{_}BUTTER.
10136-8{_}22235{_}1615.
10136-8{_}22236{_}BECKMAN, in his "History of Inventions," states that butter was not used either by the Greeks or Romans in cooking, nor was it brought upon their tables at certain meals, as is the custom at present.
10136-8{_}22237{_}In England it has been made from time immemorial, though the art of making cheese is said not to have been known to the ancient Britons, and to have been learned from their conquerors.
10136-8{_}22238{_}1616.
10136-8{_}22239{_}The taste of butter is peculiar, and very unlike any other fatty substance.
10136-8{_}22240{_}It is extremely agreeable when of the best quality; but its flavour depends much upon the food given to the cows: to be good, it should not adhere to the knife.
10136-8{_}22241{_}1617.
10136-8{_}22242{_}Butter, with regard to its dietetic properties, may be regarded nearly in the light of vegetable oils and animal fats; but it becomes sooner rancid than most other fat oils.
10136-8{_}22243{_}When fresh, it cannot but be considered as very wholesome; but it should be quite free from rancidity.
10136-8{_}22244{_}If slightly salted when it is fresh, its wholesomeness is probably not at all impaired; but should it begin to turn rancid, salting will not correct its unwholesomeness.
10136-8{_}22245{_}When salt butter is put into casks, the upper part next the air is very apt to become rancid, and this rancidity is also liable to affect the whole cask.
10136-8{_}22246{_}1618.
10136-8{_}22247{_}_Epping butter_ is the kind most esteemed in London.
10136-8{_}22248{_}_Fresh butter_ comes to London from Buckinghamshire, Suffolk, Oxfordshire, Yorkshire, Devonshire, &c. _Cambridge butter_ is esteemed next to fresh; _Devonshire butter_ is nearly similar in quality to the latter; _Irish butter_ sold in London is all salted, but is generally good.
10136-8{_}22249{_}The number of firkins exported annually from Ireland amounts to 420,000, equal to a million of money.
10136-8{_}22250{_}_Dutch butter_ is in good repute all over Europe, America, and even India; and no country in the world is so successful in the manufacture of this article, Holland supplying more butter to the rest of the world than any country whatever.
10136-8{_}22251{_}1619.
10136-8{_}22252{_}There are two methods pursued in the manufacture of butter.
10136-8{_}22253{_}In one, the cream is separated from the milk, and in that state it is converted into butter by churning, as is the practice about Epping; in the other, milk is subjected to the same process, which is the method usually followed in Cheshire.
10136-8{_}22254{_}The first method is generally said to give the richest butter, and the latter the largest quantity, though some are of opinion that there is little difference either in quality or quantity.
10136-8{_}22255{_}CHEESE.
10136-8{_}22256{_}1620.
10136-8{_}22257{_}CHEESE is the curd formed from milk by artificial coagulation, pressed and dried for use.
10136-8{_}22258{_}Curd, called also casein and caseous matter, or the basis of cheese, exists in the milk, and not in the cream, and requires only to be separated by coagulation.
10136-8{_}22259{_}The coagulation, however, supposes some alteration of the curd.
10136-8{_}22260{_}By means of the substance employed to coagulate it, it is rendered insoluble in water.
10136-8{_}22261{_}When the curd is freed from the whey, kneaded and pressed to expel it entirely, it becomes cheese.
10136-8{_}22262{_}This assumes a degree of transparency, and possesses many of the properties of coagulated albumen.
10136-8{_}22263{_}If it be well dried, it does not change by exposure to the air; but if it contain moisture, it soon putrefies.
10136-8{_}22264{_}It therefore requires some salt to preserve it, and this acts likewise as a kind of seasoning.
10136-8{_}22265{_}All our cheese is coloured more or less, except that made from skim milk.
10136-8{_}22266{_}The colouring substances employed are arnatto, turmeric, or marigold, all perfectly harmless unless they are adulterated; and it is said that arnatto sometimes contains red lead.
10136-8{_}22267{_}1621.
10136-8{_}22268{_}Cheese varies in quality and richness according to the materials of which it is composed.
10136-8{_}22269{_}It is made--1.
10136-8{_}22270{_}Of entire milk, as in Cheshire; 2. of milk and cream, as at Stilton; 3. of new milk mixed with skimmed milk, as in Gloucestershire; 4. of skimmed milk only, as in Suffolk, Holland, and Italy.
10136-8{_}22271{_}1622.
10136-8{_}22272{_}The principal varieties of cheese used in England are the following:--_Cheshire cheese_, famed all over Europe for its rich quality and fine piquant flavour.
10136-8{_}22273{_}It is made of entire new milk, the cream not being taken off.
10136-8{_}22274{_}_Gloucester cheese_ is much milder in its taste than the Cheshire.
10136-8{_}22275{_}There are two kinds of Gloucester cheese,--single and double.
10136-8{_}22276{_}_Single Gloucester_ is made of skimmed milk, or of the milk deprived of half the cream; _Double Gloucester_ is a cheese that pleases almost every palate: it is made of the whole milk and cream.
10136-8{_}22277{_}_Stilton cheese_ is made by adding the cream of one day to the entire milk of the next: it was first made at Stilton, in Leicestershire.
10136-8{_}22278{_}_Sage cheese_ is so called from the practice of colouring some curd with bruised sage, marigold-leaves, and parsley, and mixing this with some uncoloured curd.
10136-8{_}22279{_}With the Romans, and during the middle ages, this practice was extensively adopted.
10136-8{_}22280{_}_Cheddar cheese_ much resembles Parmesan.
10136-8{_}22281{_}It has a very agreeable taste and flavour, and has a spongy appearance.
10136-8{_}22282{_}_Brickbat cheese_ has nothing remarkable except its form.
10136-8{_}22283{_}It is made by turning with rennet a mixture of cream and new milk.
10136-8{_}22284{_}The curd is put into a wooden vessel the shape of a brick, and is then pressed and dried in the usual way.
10136-8{_}22285{_}_Dunlop cheese_ has a peculiarly mild and rich taste: the best is made entirely from new milk.
10136-8{_}22286{_}_New cheese_ (as it is called in London) is made chiefly in Lincolnshire, and is either made of all cream, or, like Stilton.
10136-8{_}22287{_}by adding the cream of one day's milking to the milk that comes immediately from the cow: they are extremely thin, and are compressed gently two or three times, turned for a few days, and then eaten new with radishes, salad, &c. _Skimmed Milk cheese_ is made for sea voyages principally.
10136-8{_}22288{_}_Parmesan cheese_ is made in Parma and Piacenza.
10136-8{_}22289{_}It is the most celebrated of all cheese: it is made entirely of skimmed cow's milk.
10136-8{_}22290{_}The high flavour which it has, is supposed to be owing to the rich herbage of the meadows of the Po, where the cows are pastured.
10136-8{_}22291{_}The best Parmesan is kept for three or four years, and none is carried to market till it is at least six months old.
10136-8{_}22292{_}_Dutch cheese_ derives its peculiar pungent taste from the practice adopted in Holland of coagulating the milk with muriatic acid instead of rennet.
10136-8{_}22293{_}_Swiss cheeses_ in their several varieties are all remarkable for their fine flavour.
10136-8{_}22294{_}That from _Gruyère_, a bailiwick in the canton of Fribourg, is best known in England.
10136-8{_}22295{_}It is flavoured by the dried herb of _Melilotos officinalis_ in powder.
10136-8{_}22296{_}Cheese from milk and potatoes is manufactured in Thuringia and Saxony.
10136-8{_}22297{_}_Cream cheese_, although so called, is not properly cheese, but is nothing more than cream dried sufficiently to be cut with a knife.
10136-8{_}22298{_}EGGS.
10136-8{_}22299{_}1623.
10136-8{_}22300{_}There is only one opinion as to the nutritive properties of eggs, although the qualities of those belonging to different birds vary somewhat.
10136-8{_}22301{_}Those of the common hen are most esteemed as delicate food, particularly when "new-laid."
10136-8{_}22302{_}The quality of eggs depends much upon the food given to the hen.
10136-8{_}22303{_}Eggs in general are considered most easily digestible when little subjected to the art of cookery.
10136-8{_}22304{_}The lightest way of dressing them is by poaching, which is effected by putting them for a minute or two into brisk boiling water: this coagulates the external white, without doing the inner part too much.
10136-8{_}22305{_}Eggs are much better when new-laid than a day or two afterwards.
10136-8{_}22306{_}The usual time allotted for boiling eggs in the shell is 3 to 3-3/4 minutes: less time than that in boiling water will not be sufficient to solidify the white, and more will make the yolk hard and less digestible: it is very difficult to _guess_ accurately as to the time.
10136-8{_}22307{_}Great care should be employed in putting them into the water, to prevent cracking the shell, which inevitably causes a portion of the white to exude, and lets water into the egg.
10136-8{_}22308{_}Eggs are often beaten up raw in nutritive beverages.
10136-8{_}22309{_}1624.
10136-8{_}22310{_}Eggs are employed in a very great many articles of cookery, entrées, and entremets, and they form an essential ingredient in pastry, creams, flip, &c. It is particularly necessary that they should be quite fresh, as nothing is worse than stale eggs.
10136-8{_}22311{_}Cobbett justly says, stale, or even preserved eggs, are things to be run from, not after.
10136-8{_}22312{_}1625.
10136-8{_}22313{_}The Metropolis is supplied with eggs from all parts of the kingdom, and they are likewise largely imported from various places on the continent; as France, Holland, Belgium, Guernsey, and Jersey.
10136-8{_}22314{_}It appears from official statements mentioned in McCulloch's "Commercial Dictionary," that the number imported from France alone amounts to about 60,000,000 a year; and supposing them on an average to cost fourpence a dozen, it follows that we pay our continental neighbours above £83,000 a year for eggs.
10136-8{_}22315{_}1626.
10136-8{_}22316{_}The eggs of different birds vary much in size and colour.
10136-8{_}22317{_}Those of the ostrich are the largest: one laid in the menagerie in Paris weighed 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}22318{_}14 oz., held a pint, and was six inches deep: this is about the usual size of those brought from Africa.
10136-8{_}22319{_}Travellers describe _ostrich eggs_ as of an agreeable taste: they keep longer than hen's eggs.
10136-8{_}22320{_}Drinking-cups are often made of the shell, which is very strong.
10136-8{_}22321{_}The eggs of the _turkey_ are almost as mild as those of the hen; the egg of the _goose_ is large, but well-tasted.
10136-8{_}22322{_}_Duck's eggs_ have a rich flavour; the albumen is slightly transparent, or bluish, when set or coagulated by boiling, which requires less time than hen's eggs.
10136-8{_}22323{_}_Guinea-fowl eggs_ are smaller and more delicate than those of the hen.
10136-8{_}22324{_}Eggs of _wild fowl_ are generally coloured, often spotted; and the taste generally partakes somewhat of the flavour of the bird they belong to.
10136-8{_}22325{_}Those of land birds that are eaten, as the _plover, lapwing, ruff_, &c., are in general much esteemed; but those of _sea-fowl_ have, more or less, a strong fishy taste.
10136-8{_}22326{_}The eggs of the _turtle_ are very numerous: they consist of yolk only, without shell, and are delicious.
10136-8{_}22327{_}RECIPES.
10136-8{_}22328{_}CHAPTER XXXIII.
10136-8{_}22329{_}SEPARATION OF MILK AND CREAM.
10136-8{_}22330{_}1627.
10136-8{_}22331{_}If it be desired that the milk should be freed entirely from cream, it should be poured into a very shallow broad pan or dish, not more than 1-1/2 inch deep, as cream cannot rise through a great depth of milk.
10136-8{_}22332{_}In cold and wet weather, milk is not so rich as it is in summer and warm weather, and the morning's milk is always richer than the evening's.
10136-8{_}22333{_}The last-drawn milk of each milking, at all times and seasons, is richer than the first-drawn, and on that account should be set apart for cream.
10136-8{_}22334{_}Milk should be shaken as little as possible when carried from the cow to the dairy, and should be poured into the pans very gently.
10136-8{_}22335{_}Persons not keeping cows, may always have a little cream, provided the milk they purchase be pure and unadulterated.
10136-8{_}22336{_}As soon as it comes in, it should be poured into very shallow open pie-dishes, and set by in a very cool place, and in 7 or 8 hours a nice cream should have risen to the surface.
10136-8{_}22337{_}MILK is one of the most complete of all articles of food: that     is to say, it contains a very large number of the elements which     enter into the composition of the human body.
10136-8{_}22338{_}It "disagrees"     with fat, heavy, languid people, of slow circulation; and, at     first, with many people of sedentary habits, and stomachs     weakened by stimulants of different kinds.
10136-8{_}22339{_}But, if exercise can     be taken and a little patience shown, while the system     accommodates itself to a new regimen, this bland and soothing     article of diet is excellent for the majority of thin, nervous     people; especially for those who have suffered much from     emotional disturbances, or have relaxed their stomachs by too     much tea or coffee, taken too hot.
10136-8{_}22340{_}Milk is, in fact, a nutrient     and a sedative at once.
10136-8{_}22341{_}Stomachs, however, have their     idiosyncrasies, and it sometimes proves an unwelcome and     ill-digested article of food.
10136-8{_}22342{_}As milk, when good, contains a     good deal of respiratory material (fat),--material which _must_     either be burnt off, or derange the liver, and be rejected in     other ways, it may disagree because the lungs are not     sufficiently used in the open air.
10136-8{_}22343{_}But it is very probable that     there are really "constitutions" which cannot take to it; and     _they_ should not be forced.
10136-8{_}22344{_}TO KEEP MILK AND CREAM IN HOT WEATHER.
10136-8{_}22345{_}1628.
10136-8{_}22346{_}When the weather is very warm, and it is very difficult to prevent milk from turning sour and spoiling the cream, it should be scalded, and it will then remain good for a few hours.
10136-8{_}22347{_}It must on no account be allowed to boil, or there will be a skin instead of a cream upon the milk; and the slower the process, the safer will it be.
10136-8{_}22348{_}A very good plan to scald milk, is to put the pan that contains it into a saucepan or wide kettle of boiling water.
10136-8{_}22349{_}When the surface looks thick, the milk is sufficiently scalded, and it should then be put away in a cool place in the same vessel that it was scalded in.
10136-8{_}22350{_}Cream may be kept for 24 hours, if scalded without sugar; and by the addition of the latter ingredient, it will remain good double the time, if kept in a cool place.
10136-8{_}22351{_}All pans, jugs, and vessels intended for milk, should be kept beautifully clean, and well scalded before the milk is put in, as any negligence in this respect may cause large quantities of it to be spoiled; and milk should never be kept in vessels of zinc or copper.
10136-8{_}22352{_}Milk may be preserved good in hot weather, for a few hours, by placing the jug which contains it in ice, or very cold water; or a pinch of bicarbonate of soda may be introduced into the liquid.
10136-8{_}22353{_}MILK, when of good quality, is of an opaque white colour: the     cream always comes to the top; the well-known milky odour is     strong; it will boil without altering its appearance, in these     respects; the little bladders which arise on the surface will     renew themselves if broken by the spoon.
10136-8{_}22354{_}To boil milk is, in     fact, the simplest way of testing its quality.
10136-8{_}22355{_}The commonest     adulterations of milk are not of a hurtful character.
10136-8{_}22356{_}It is a     good deal thinned with water, and sometimes thickened with a     little starch, or colored with yolk of egg, or even saffron; but     these processes have nothing murderous in them.
10136-8{_}22357{_}CURDS AND WHEY.
10136-8{_}22358{_}1629.
10136-8{_}22359{_}INGREDIENTS.--A very small piece of rennet, 1/2 gallon of milk.
10136-8{_}22360{_}_Mode_.--Procure from the butcher's a small piece of rennet, which is the stomach of the calf, taken as soon as it is killed, scoured, and well rubbed with salt, and stretched on sticks to dry.
10136-8{_}22361{_}Pour some boiling water on the rennet, and let it remain for 6 hours; then use the liquor to turn the milk.
10136-8{_}22362{_}The milk should be warm and fresh from the cow: if allowed to cool, it must be heated till it is of a degree quite equal to new milk; but do not let it be too hot.
10136-8{_}22363{_}About a tablespoonful or rather more, would be sufficient to turn the above proportion of milk into curds and whey; and whilst the milk is turning, let it be kept in rather a warm place.
10136-8{_}22364{_}_Time_.--From 2 to 3 hours to turn the milk.
10136-8{_}22365{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}22366{_}DEVONSHIRE CREAM.
10136-8{_}22367{_}1630.
10136-8{_}22368{_}The milk should stand 24 hours in the winter, half that time when the weather is very warm.
10136-8{_}22369{_}The milkpan is then set on a stove, and should there remain until the milk is quite hot; but it must not boil, or there will be a thick skin on the surface.
10136-8{_}22370{_}When it is sufficiently done, the undulations on the surface look thick, and small rings appear.
10136-8{_}22371{_}The time required for scalding cream depends on the size of the pan and the heat of the fire; but the slower it is done, the better.
10136-8{_}22372{_}The pan should be placed in the dairy when the cream is sufficiently scalded, and skimmed the following day.
10136-8{_}22373{_}This cream is so much esteemed that it is sent to the London markets in small square tins, and is exceedingly delicious eaten with fresh fruit.
10136-8{_}22374{_}In Devonshire, butter is made from this cream, and is usually very firm.
10136-8{_}22375{_}DEVONSHIRE JUNKET.
10136-8{_}22376{_}1631.
10136-8{_}22377{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every pint of new milk allow 2 dessertspoonfuls of brandy, 1 dessertspoonful of sugar, and 1-1/2 dessertspoonful of prepared rennet; thick cream, pounded cinnamon, or grated nutmeg.
10136-8{_}22378{_}_Mode_.--Make the milk blood-warm; put it into a deep dish with the brandy, sugar, and rennet; stir it altogether, and cover it over until it is set.
10136-8{_}22379{_}Then spread some thick or clotted cream over the top, grate some nutmeg, and strew some sugar over, and the dish will be ready to serve.
10136-8{_}22380{_}_Time_.--About 2 hours to set the milk.
10136-8{_}22381{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}22382{_}TO KEEP AND CHOOSE FRESH BUTTER.
10136-8{_}22383{_}1632.
10136-8{_}22384{_}Fresh butter should be kept in a dark, cool place, and in as large a mass as possible.
10136-8{_}22385{_}Mould as much only as is required, as the more surface is exposed, the more liability there will be to spoil; and the outside very soon becomes rancid.
10136-8{_}22386{_}Fresh butter should be kept covered with white paper.
10136-8{_}22387{_}For small larders, butter-coolers of red brick are now very much used for keeping fresh butter in warm weather.
10136-8{_}22388{_}These coolers are made with a large bell-shaped cover, into the top of which a little cold water should be poured, and in summer time very frequently changed; and the butter must be kept covered.
10136-8{_}22389{_}These coolers keep butter remarkably firm in hot weather, and are extremely convenient for those whose larder accommodation is limited.
10136-8{_}22390{_}[Illustration: BUTTER-DISH.]
10136-8{_}22391{_}In choosing fresh butter, remember it should smell deliciously, and be of an equal colour all through: if it smells sour, it has not been sufficiently washed from the buttermilk; and if veiny and open, it has probably been worked with a staler or an inferior sort.
10136-8{_}22392{_}TO PRESERVE AND TO CHOOSE SALT BUTTER.
10136-8{_}22393{_}1633.
10136-8{_}22394{_}In large families, where salt butter is purchased a tub at a time, the first thing to be done is to turn the whole of the butter out, and, with a clean knife, to scrape the outside; the tub should then be wiped with a clean cloth, and sprinkled all round with salt, the butter replaced, and the lid kept on to exclude the air.
10136-8{_}22395{_}It is necessary to take these precautions, as sometimes a want of proper cleanliness in the dairymaid causes the outside of the butter to become rancid, and if the scraping be neglected, the whole mass would soon become spoiled.
10136-8{_}22396{_}To choose salt butter, plunge a knife into it, and if, when drawn out, the blade smells rancid or unpleasant, the butter is bad.
