10136-8{_}22397{_}The layers in tubs will vary greatly, the butter being made at different times; so, to try if the whole tub be good, the cask should be unhooped, and the butter tried between the staves.
10136-8{_}22398{_}It is not necessary to state that butter is extracted from cream, or from unskimmed milk, by the churn.
10136-8{_}22399{_}Of course it partakes of the qualities of the milk, and winter butter is said not to be so good as spring butter.
10136-8{_}22400{_}A word of caution is necessary about _rancid_ butter.
10136-8{_}22401{_}Nobody eats it on bread, but it is sometimes used in cooking, in forms in which the acidity can be more or less disguised.
10136-8{_}22402{_}So much the worse; it is almost poisonous, disguise it as you may.
10136-8{_}22403{_}Never, under any exigency whatever, be tempted into allowing butter with even a _soupçon_ of "turning" to enter into the composition of any dish that appears on your table.
10136-8{_}22404{_}And, in general, the more you can do without the employment of butter that has been subjected to the influence of heat, the better.
10136-8{_}22405{_}The woman of modern times is not a "leech;" but she might often keep the "leech" from the door, if she would give herself the trouble to invent _innocent_ sauces.
10136-8{_}22406{_}BUTTER-MOULDS, for Moulding Fresh Butter.
10136-8{_}22407{_}[Illustration: DISH OF ROLLED BUTTER.]
10136-8{_}22408{_}1634.
10136-8{_}22409{_}Butter-moulds, or wooden stamps for moulding fresh butter, are much used, and are made in a variety of forms and shapes.
10136-8{_}22410{_}In using them, let them be kept scrupulously clean, and before the butter is pressed in, the interior should be well wetted with cold water; the butter must then be pressed in, the mould opened, and the perfect shape taken out.
10136-8{_}22411{_}The butter may be then dished, and garnished with a wreath of parsley, if for a cheese course; if for breakfast, put it into an ornamental butter-dish, with a little water at the bottom, should the weather be very warm.
10136-8{_}22412{_}CURLED BUTTER.
10136-8{_}22413{_}1635.
10136-8{_}22414{_}Tie a strong cloth by two of the corners to an iron hook in the wall; make a knot with the other two ends, so that a stick might pass through.
10136-8{_}22415{_}Put the butter into the cloth; twist it tightly over a dish, into which the butter will fall through the knot, so forming small and pretty little strings.
10136-8{_}22416{_}The butter may then be garnished with parsley, if to serve with a cheese course; or it may be sent to table plain for breakfast, in an ornamental dish.
10136-8{_}22417{_}Squirted butter for garnishing hams, salads, eggs, &c., is made by forming a piece of stiff paper in the shape of a cornet, and squeezing the butter in fine strings from the hole at the bottom.
10136-8{_}22418{_}Scooped butter is made by dipping a teaspoon or scooper in warm water, and then scooping the butter quickly and thin.
10136-8{_}22419{_}In warm weather, it would not be necessary to heat the spoon.
10136-8{_}22420{_}BUTTER may be kept fresh for ten or twelve days by a very simple     process.
10136-8{_}22421{_}Knead it well in cold water till the buttermilk is     extracted; then put it in a glazed jar, which invert in another,     putting into the latter a sufficient quantity of water to     exclude the air.
10136-8{_}22422{_}Renew the water every day.
10136-8{_}22423{_}FAIRY BUTTER.
10136-8{_}22424{_}1636.
10136-8{_}22425{_}INGREDIENTS.--The yolks of 2 hard-boiled eggs, 1 tablespoonful of orange-flower water, 2 tablespoonfuls of pounded sugar, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}22426{_}of good fresh butter.
10136-8{_}22427{_}_Mode_.--Beat the yolks of the eggs smoothly in a mortar, with the orange-flower water and the sugar, until the whole is reduced to a fine paste; add the butter, and force all through an old but clean cloth by wringing the cloth and squeezing the butter very hard.
10136-8{_}22428{_}The butter will then drop on the plate in large and small pieces, according to the holes in the cloth.
10136-8{_}22429{_}Plain butter may be done in the same manner, and is very quickly prepared, besides having a very good effect.
10136-8{_}22430{_}BUTTER.--White-coloured butter is said not to be so good as the     yellow; but the yellow colour is often artificially produced, by     the introduction of colouring matter into the churn.
10136-8{_}22431{_}ANCHOVY BUTTER.
10136-8{_}22432{_}1637.
10136-8{_}22433{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}22434{_}of butter allow 6 anchovies, 1 small bunch of parsley.
10136-8{_}22435{_}_Mode_.--Wash, bone, and pound the anchovies well in a mortar; scald the parsley, chop it, and rub through a sieve; then pound all the ingredients together, mix well, and make the butter into pats immediately.
10136-8{_}22436{_}This makes a pretty dish, if fancifully moulded, for breakfast or supper, and should be garnished with parsley.
10136-8{_}22437{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}22438{_}8d.
10136-8{_}22439{_}_Sufficient_ to make 2 dishes, with 4 pats each.
10136-8{_}22440{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}22441{_}CHEESE.
10136-8{_}22442{_}1638.
10136-8{_}22443{_}In families where much cheese is consumed, and it is bought in large quantities, a piece from the whole cheese should be cut, the larger quantity spread with a thickly-buttered sheet of white paper, and the outside occasionally wiped.
10136-8{_}22444{_}To keep cheeses moist that are in daily use, when they come from table a damp cloth should be wrapped round them, and the cheese put into a pan with a cover to it, in a cool but not very dry place.
10136-8{_}22445{_}To ripen cheeses, and bring them forward, put them into a damp cellar; and, to check too large a production of mites, spirits may be poured into the parts affected.
10136-8{_}22446{_}Pieces of cheese which are too near the rind, or too dry to put on table, may be made into Welsh rare-bits, or grated down and mixed with macaroni.
10136-8{_}22447{_}Cheeses may be preserved in a perfect state for years, by covering them with parchment made pliable by soaking in water, or by rubbing them over with a coating of melted fat.
10136-8{_}22448{_}The cheeses selected should be free from cracks or bruises of any kind.
10136-8{_}22449{_}CHEESE.--It is well known that some persons like cheese in a     state of decay, and even "alive."
10136-8{_}22450{_}There is no accounting for     tastes, and it maybe hard to show why mould, which is     vegetation, should not be eaten as well as salad, or maggots as     well as eels.
10136-8{_}22451{_}But, generally speaking, decomposing bodies are     not wholesome eating, and the line must be drawn somewhere.
10136-8{_}22452{_}STILTON CHEESE.
10136-8{_}22453{_}[Illustration: STILTON CHEESE.]
10136-8{_}22454{_}1639.
10136-8{_}22455{_}Stilton cheese, or British Parmesan, as it is sometimes called, is generally preferred to all other cheeses by those whose authority few will dispute.
10136-8{_}22456{_}Those made in May or June are usually served at Christmas; or, to be in prime order, should be kept from 10 to 12 months, or even longer.
10136-8{_}22457{_}An artificial ripeness in Stilton cheese is sometimes produced by inserting a small piece of decayed Cheshire into an aperture at the top.
10136-8{_}22458{_}From 3 weeks to a month is sufficient time to ripen the cheese.
10136-8{_}22459{_}An additional flavour may also be obtained by scooping out a piece from the top, and pouring therein port, sherry, Madeira, or old ale, and letting the cheese absorb these for 2 or 3 weeks.
10136-8{_}22460{_}But that cheese is the finest which is ripened without any artificial aid, is the opinion of those who are judges in these matters.
10136-8{_}22461{_}In serving a Stilton cheese, the top of it should be cut off to form a lid, and a napkin or piece of white paper, with a frill at the top, pinned round.
10136-8{_}22462{_}When the cheese goes from table, the lid should be replaced.
10136-8{_}22463{_}MODE OF SERVING CHEESE.
10136-8{_}22464{_}[Illustration: CHEESE-GLASS.]
10136-8{_}22465{_}1640.
10136-8{_}22466{_}The usual mode of serving cheese at good tables is to cut a small quantity of it into neat square pieces, and to put them into a glass cheese-dish, this dish being handed round.
10136-8{_}22467{_}Should the cheese crumble much, of course this method is rather wasteful, and it may then be put on the table in the piece, and the host may cut from it.
10136-8{_}22468{_}When served thus, the cheese must always be carefully scraped, and laid on a white d'oyley or napkin, neatly folded.
10136-8{_}22469{_}Cream cheese is often served in a cheese course, and, sometimes, grated Parmesan: the latter should he put into a covered glass dish.
10136-8{_}22470{_}Rusks, cheese-biscuits, pats or slices of butter, and salad, cucumber, or water-cresses, should always form part of a cheese course.
10136-8{_}22471{_}SMOKING CHEESES.--The Romans smoked their cheeses, to give them     a sharp taste.
10136-8{_}22472{_}They possessed public places expressly for this     use, and subject to police regulations which no one could evade.
10136-8{_}22473{_}A celebrated gourmand remarked that a dinner without cheese is     like a woman with one eye.
10136-8{_}22474{_}CHEESE SANDWICHES.
10136-8{_}22475{_}1641.
10136-8{_}22476{_}INGREDIENTS.--Slices of brown bread-and-butter, thin slices of cheese.
10136-8{_}22477{_}_Mode_.--Cut from a nice fat Cheshire, or any good rich cheese, some slices about 1/2 inch thick, and place them between some slices of brown bread-and-butter, like sandwiches.
10136-8{_}22478{_}Place them on a plate in the oven, and, when the bread is toasted, serve on a napkin very hot and very quickly.
10136-8{_}22479{_}_Time_.--10 minutes in a brisk oven.
10136-8{_}22480{_}_Average cost_, 1-1/2d.
10136-8{_}22481{_}each sandwich.
10136-8{_}22482{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow a sandwich for each person.
10136-8{_}22483{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}22484{_}CHEESE.--One of the most important products of coagulated milk     is cheese.
10136-8{_}22485{_}Unfermented, or cream-cheese, when quite fresh, is     good for subjects with whom milk does not disagree; but cheese,     in its commonest shape, is only fit for sedentary people as an     after-dinner stimulant, and in very small quantity.
10136-8{_}22486{_}Bread and     cheese, as a meal, is only fit for soldiers on march or     labourers in the open air, who like it because it "holds the     stomach a long time."
10136-8{_}22487{_}CAYENNE CHEESES.
10136-8{_}22488{_}1642.
10136-8{_}22489{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}22490{_}of butter, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}22491{_}of flour, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}22492{_}of grated cheese, 1/3 teaspoonful of cayenne, 1/3 teaspoonful of salt; water.
10136-8{_}22493{_}_Mode_.--Rub the butter in the flour; add the grated cheese, cayenne.
10136-8{_}22494{_}and salt; and mix these ingredients well together.
10136-8{_}22495{_}Moisten with sufficient water to make the whole into a paste; roll out, and cut into fingers about 4 inches in length.
10136-8{_}22496{_}Bake them in a moderate oven a very light colour, and serve very hot.
10136-8{_}22497{_}_Time_.--15 to 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}22498{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}22499{_}4d.
10136-8{_}22500{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 or 7 persons.
10136-8{_}22501{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}22502{_}TO MAKE A FONDUE.
10136-8{_}22503{_}1643.
10136-8{_}22504{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 eggs, the weight of 2 in Parmesan or good Cheshire cheese, the weight of 2 in butter; pepper and salt to taste.
10136-8{_}22505{_}_Mode_.--Separate the yolks from the whites of the eggs; beat the former in a basin, and grate the cheese, or cut it into _very thin_ flakes.
10136-8{_}22506{_}Parmesan or Cheshire cheese may be used, whichever is the most convenient, although the former is considered more suitable for this dish; or an equal quantity of each may be used.
10136-8{_}22507{_}Break the butter into small pieces, add it to the other ingredients, with sufficient pepper and salt to season nicely, and beat the mixture thoroughly.
10136-8{_}22508{_}Well whisk the whites of the eggs, stir them lightly in, and either bake the fondue in a soufflé-dish or small round cake-tin.
10136-8{_}22509{_}Fill the dish only half full, as the fondue should rise very much.
10136-8{_}22510{_}Pin a napkin round the tin or dish, and serve very hot and very quickly.
10136-8{_}22511{_}If allowed to stand after it is withdrawn from the oven, the beauty and lightness of this preparation will be entirely spoiled.
10136-8{_}22512{_}_Time_.--From 15 to 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}22513{_}_Average cost_, 10d.
10136-8{_}22514{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}22515{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}22516{_}BRILLAT SAVARIN'S FONDUE.
10136-8{_}22517{_}(_An excellent Recipe_.)
10136-8{_}22518{_}1644.
10136-8{_}22519{_}INGREDIENTS.--Eggs, cheese, butter, pepper and salt.
10136-8{_}22520{_}_Mode_.--Take the same number of eggs as there are guests; weigh the eggs in the shell, allow a third of their weight in Gruyère cheese, and a piece of butter one-sixth of the weight of the cheese.
10136-8{_}22521{_}Break the eggs into a basin, beat them well; add the cheese, which should be grated, and the butter, which should be broken into small pieces.
10136-8{_}22522{_}Stir these ingredients together with a wooden spoon; put the mixture into a lined saucepan, place it over the fire, and stir until the substance is thick and soft.
10136-8{_}22523{_}Put in a little salt, according to the age of the cheese, and a good sprinkling of pepper, and serve the fondue on a very hot silver or metal plate.
10136-8{_}22524{_}Do not allow the fondue to remain on the fire after the mixture is set, as, if it boils, it will be entirely spoiled.
10136-8{_}22525{_}Brillat Savarin recommends that some choice Burgundy should he handed round with this dish.
10136-8{_}22526{_}We have given this recipe exactly as he recommends it to be made; but we have tried it with good Cheshire cheese, and found it answer remarkably well.
10136-8{_}22527{_}_Time_.--About 4 minutes to set the mixture.
10136-8{_}22528{_}_Average cost_ for 4 persons, 10d.
10136-8{_}22529{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 1 egg, with the other ingredients in proportion, for one person.
10136-8{_}22530{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}22531{_}MACARONI, as usually served with the CHEESE COURSE.
10136-8{_}22532{_}I.
10136-8{_}22533{_}1645.
10136-8{_}22534{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}22535{_}of pipe macaroni, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}22536{_}of butter, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}22537{_}of Parmesan or Cheshire cheese, pepper and salt to taste, 1 pint of milk, 2 pints of water, bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}22538{_}_Mode_.--Put the milk and water into a saucepan with sufficient salt to flavour it; place it on the fire, and, when it boils quickly, drop in the macaroni.
10136-8{_}22539{_}Keep the water boiling until it is quite tender; drain the macaroni, and put it into a deep dish.
10136-8{_}22540{_}Have ready the grated cheese, either Parmesan or Cheshire; sprinkle it amongst the macaroni and some of the butter cut into small pieces, reserving some of the cheese for the top layer.
10136-8{_}22541{_}Season with a little pepper, and cover the top layer of cheese with some very fine bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}22542{_}Warm, without oiling, the remainder of the butter, and pour it gently over the bread crumbs.
10136-8{_}22543{_}Place the dish before a bright fire to brown the crumbs; turn it once or twice, that it may be equally coloured, and serve very hot.
10136-8{_}22544{_}The top of the macaroni may be browned with a salamander, which is even better than placing it before the fire, as the process is more expeditious; but it should never be browned in the oven, as the butter would oil, and so impart a very disagreeable flavour to the dish.
10136-8{_}22545{_}In boiling the macaroni, let it be perfectly tender but firm, no part beginning to melt, and the form entirely preserved.
10136-8{_}22546{_}It may be boiled in plain water, with a little salt instead of using milk, but should then have a small piece of butter mixed with it.
10136-8{_}22547{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 to 1-3/4 hour to boil the macaroni, 5 minutes to brown it before the fire.
10136-8{_}22548{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}22549{_}6d.
10136-8{_}22550{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 or 7 persons.
10136-8{_}22551{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}22552{_}_Note_.--Riband macaroni may be dressed in the same manner, but does not require boiling so long a time.
10136-8{_}22553{_}II.
10136-8{_}22554{_}1646.
10136-8{_}22555{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}22556{_}of pipe or riband macaroni, 1/2 pint of milk, 1/2 pint of veal or beef gravy, the yolks of 2 eggs, 4 tablespoonfuls of cream, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}22557{_}of grated Parmesan or Cheshire cheese, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}22558{_}of butter.
10136-8{_}22559{_}_Mode_.--Wash the macaroni, and boil it in the gravy and milk until quite tender, without being broken.
10136-8{_}22560{_}Drain it, and put it into rather a deep dish.
10136-8{_}22561{_}Beat the yolks of the eggs with the cream and 2 tablespoonfuls of the liquor the macaroni was boiled in; make this sufficiently hot to thicken, but do not allow it to boil; pour it over the macaroni, over which sprinkle the grated cheese and the butter broken into small pieces; brown with a salamander, or before the fire, and serve.
10136-8{_}22562{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 to 1-3/4 hour to boil the macaroni, 5 minutes to thicken the eggs and cream, 5 minutes to brown.
10136-8{_}22563{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}22564{_}2d.
10136-8{_}22565{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 or 4 persons.
10136-8{_}22566{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}22567{_}III.
10136-8{_}22568{_}1647.
10136-8{_}22569{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}22570{_}of pipe macaroni, 1/2 pint of brown gravy No.
10136-8{_}22571{_}436, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}22572{_}of grated Parmesan cheese.
10136-8{_}22573{_}_Mode_.--Wash the macaroni, and boil it in salt and water until quite tender; drain it, and put it into rather a deep dish.
10136-8{_}22574{_}Have ready a pint of good brown gravy, pour it hot over the macaroni, and send it to table with grated Parmesan served on a separate dish.
10136-8{_}22575{_}When the flavour is liked, a little pounded mace may be added to the water in which the macaroni is boiled; but this must always be sparingly added, as it will impart a very strong flavour.
10136-8{_}22576{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 to 1-3/4 hour to boil the macaroni.
10136-8{_}22577{_}_Average cost_, with the gravy and cheese, 1s.
10136-8{_}22578{_}3d.
10136-8{_}22579{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 or 4 persons.
10136-8{_}22580{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}22581{_}POUNDED CHEESE.
10136-8{_}22582{_}1648.
10136-8{_}22583{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}22584{_}of cheese allow 3 oz.
10136-8{_}22585{_}of fresh butter.
10136-8{_}22586{_}_Mode_.--To pound cheese is an economical way of using it, if it has become dry; it is exceedingly good spread on bread, and is the best way of eating it for those whose digestion is weak.
10136-8{_}22587{_}Cut up the cheese into small pieces, and pound it smoothly in a mortar, adding butter in the above proportion.
10136-8{_}22588{_}Press it down into a jar, cover with clarified butter, and it will keep for several days.
10136-8{_}22589{_}The flavour may be very much increased by adding mixed mustard (about a teaspoonful to every lb.
10136-8{_}22590{_}), or cayenne, or pounded mace.
10136-8{_}22591{_}Curry-powder is also not unfrequently mixed with it.
10136-8{_}22592{_}RAMAKINS, to serve with the CHEESE COURSE.
10136-8{_}22593{_}1649.
10136-8{_}22594{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}22595{_}of Cheshire cheese, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}22596{_}of Parmesan cheese, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}22597{_}of fresh butter, 4 eggs, the crumb of a small roll; pepper, salt, and pounded mace to taste.
10136-8{_}22598{_}_Mode_.--Boil the crumb of the roll in milk for 5 minutes; strain, and put it into a mortar; add the cheese, which should be finely scraped, the butter, the yolks of the eggs, and seasoning, and pound these ingredients well together.
10136-8{_}22599{_}Whisk the whites of the eggs, mix them with the paste, and put it into small pans or saucers, which should not be more than half filled.
10136-8{_}22600{_}Bake them from 10 to 12 minutes, and serve them very hot and very quickly.
10136-8{_}22601{_}This batter answers equally well for macaroni after it is boiled tender.
10136-8{_}22602{_}_Time_--10 to 12 minutes.
10136-8{_}22603{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}22604{_}4d.
10136-8{_}22605{_}_Sufficient_ for 7 or 8 persons.
10136-8{_}22606{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}22607{_}PASTRY RAMAKINS, to serve with the CHEESE COURSE.
10136-8{_}22608{_}1650.
10136-8{_}22609{_}INGREDIENTS.--Any pieces of very good light puff-paste Cheshire, Parmesan, or Stilton cheese.
10136-8{_}22610{_}_Mode_.--The remains or odd pieces of paste left from large tarts, &c. answer for making these little dishes.
10136-8{_}22611{_}Gather up the pieces of paste, roll it out evenly, and sprinkle it with grated cheese of a nice flavour.
10136-8{_}22612{_}Fold the paste in three, roll it out again, and sprinkle more cheese over; fold the paste, roll it out, and with a paste-cutter shape it in any way that may be desired.
10136-8{_}22613{_}Bake the ramakins in a brisk oven from 10 to 15 minutes, dish them on a hot napkin, and serve quickly.
10136-8{_}22614{_}The appearance of this dish may be very much improved by brushing the ramakins over with yolk of egg before they are placed in the oven.
10136-8{_}22615{_}Where expense is not objected to, Parmesan is the best kind of cheese to use for making this dish.
10136-8{_}22616{_}_Time_.--10 to 15 minutes.
10136-8{_}22617{_}_Average cost_, with 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}22618{_}of paste, 10d.
10136-8{_}22619{_}_Sufficient_ for 6 or 7 persons.
10136-8{_}22620{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}22621{_}TOASTED CHEESE, or SCOTCH RARE-BIT.
10136-8{_}22622{_}1651.
10136-8{_}22623{_}INGREDIENTS.--A few slices of rich cheese, toast, mustard, and pepper.
10136-8{_}22624{_}[Illustration: HOT-WATER CHEESE-DISH.]
10136-8{_}22625{_}_Mode_.--Cut some nice rich sound cheese into rather thin slices; melt it in a cheese-toaster on a hot plate, or over steam, and, when melted, add a small quantity of mixed mustard and a seasoning of pepper; stir the cheese until it is completely dissolved, then brown it before the fire, or with a salamander.
10136-8{_}22626{_}Fill the bottom of the cheese-toaster with hot water, and serve with dry or buttered toasts, whichever may be preferred.
10136-8{_}22627{_}Our engraving illustrates a cheese-toaster with hot-water reservoir: the cheese is melted in the upper tin, which is placed in another vessel of boiling water, so keeping the preparation beautifully hot.
10136-8{_}22628{_}A small quantity of porter, or port wine, is sometimes mixed with the cheese; and, if it be not very rich, a few pieces of butter may be mixed with it to great advantage.
10136-8{_}22629{_}Sometimes the melted cheese is spread on the toasts, and then laid in the cheese-dish at the top of the hot water.
10136-8{_}22630{_}Whichever way it is served, it is highly necessary that the mixture be very hot, and very quickly sent to table, or it will be worthless.
10136-8{_}22631{_}_Time_.--About 5 minutes to melt the cheese.
10136-8{_}22632{_}_Average cost_, 1-1/2d.
10136-8{_}22633{_}per slice.
10136-8{_}22634{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow a slice to each person.
10136-8{_}22635{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}22636{_}TOASTED CHEESE, or WELSH RARE-BIT.
10136-8{_}22637{_}1652.
10136-8{_}22638{_}INGREDIENTS.--Slices of bread, butter, Cheshire or Gloucester cheese, mustard, and pepper.
10136-8{_}22639{_}_Mode_.--Cut the bread into slices about 1/2 inch in thickness; pare off the crust, toast the bread slightly without hardening or burning it, and spread it with butter.
10136-8{_}22640{_}Cut some slices, not quite so large as the bread, from a good rich fat cheese; lay them on the toasted bread in a cheese-toaster; be careful that the cheese does not burn, and let it be equally melted.
10136-8{_}22641{_}Spread over the top a little made mustard and a seasoning of pepper, and serve very hot, with very hot plates.
10136-8{_}22642{_}To facilitate the melting of the cheese, it may be cut into thin flakes or toasted on one side before it is laid on the bread.
10136-8{_}22643{_}As it is so essential to send this dish hot to table, it is a good plan to melt the cheese in small round silver or metal pans, and to send these pans to table, allowing one for each guest.
10136-8{_}22644{_}Slices of dry or buttered toast should always accompany them, with mustard, pepper, and salt.
10136-8{_}22645{_}_Time_.--About 5 minutes to melt the cheese.
10136-8{_}22646{_}_Average cost_, 1-1/2d.
10136-8{_}22647{_}each slice.
10136-8{_}22648{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow a slice to each person.
10136-8{_}22649{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}22650{_}_Note_.--Should the cheese be dry, a little butter mixed with it will be an improvement.
10136-8{_}22651{_}"COW CHEESE."
10136-8{_}22652{_}--It was only fifty years after Aristotle--the     fourth century before Christ--that butter began to be noticed as     an aliment.
10136-8{_}22653{_}The Greeks, in imitation of the Parthians and     Scythians, who used to send it to them, had it served upon their     tables, and called it at first "oil of milk," and later,     _bouturos_, "cow cheese."
10136-8{_}22654{_}SCOTCH WOODCOCK.
10136-8{_}22655{_}1653.
10136-8{_}22656{_}INGREDIENTS.--A few slices of hot buttered toast; allow 1 anchovy to each slice.
10136-8{_}22657{_}For the sauce,--1/4 pint of cream, the yolks of 3 eggs.
10136-8{_}22658{_}_Mode_.--Separate the yolks from the whites of the eggs; beat the former, stir to them the cream, and bring the sauce to the boiling-point, but do not allow it to boil, or it will curdle.
10136-8{_}22659{_}Have ready some hot buttered toast, spread with anchovies pounded to a paste; pour a little of the hot sauce on the top, and serve very hot and very quickly.
10136-8{_}22660{_}_Time_.--5 minutes to make the sauce hot.
10136-8{_}22661{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 1/2 slice to each person.
10136-8{_}22662{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}22663{_}TO CHOOSE EGGS.
10136-8{_}22664{_}1654.
10136-8{_}22665{_}In choosing eggs, apply the tongue to the large end of the egg, and, if it feels warm, it is new, and may be relied on as a fresh egg.
10136-8{_}22666{_}Another mode of ascertaining their freshness is to hold them before a lighted candle, or to the light, and if the egg looks clear, it will be tolerably good; if thick, it is stale; and if there is a black spot attached to the shell, it is worthless.
10136-8{_}22667{_}No egg should be used for culinary purposes with the slightest taint in it, as it will render perfectly useless those with which it has been mixed.
10136-8{_}22668{_}Eggs that are purchased, and that cannot be relied on, should always be broken in a cup, and then put into a basin: by this means stale or bad eggs may be easily rejected, without wasting the others.
10136-8{_}22669{_}EGGS contain, for their volume, a greater quantity of nutriment     than any other article of food.
10136-8{_}22670{_}But it does not follow that they     are always good for weak stomachs; quite the contrary; for it is     often a great object to give the stomach a large surface to work     upon, a considerable volume of _ingesta_, over which the     nutritive matter is diffused, and so exposed to the action of     the gastric juice at many points.
10136-8{_}22671{_}There are many persons who     cannot digest eggs, however cooked.
10136-8{_}22672{_}It is said, however, that     their digestibility decreases in proportion to the degree in     which they are hardened by boiling.
10136-8{_}22673{_}TO KEEP EGGS FRESH FOR SEVERAL WEEKS.
10136-8{_}22674{_}1655.
10136-8{_}22675{_}Have ready a large saucepan, capable of holding 3 or 4 quarts, full of boiling water.
10136-8{_}22676{_}Put the eggs into a cabbage-net, say 20 at a time, and hold them in the water (which must be kept boiling) _for_ 20 _seconds_.
10136-8{_}22677{_}Proceed in this manner till you have done as many eggs as you wish to preserve; then pack them away in sawdust.
10136-8{_}22678{_}We have tried this method of preserving eggs, and can vouch for its excellence: they will be found, at the end of 2 or 3 months, quite good enough for culinary purposes; and although the white may be a little tougher than that of a new-laid egg, the yolk will be nearly the same.
10136-8{_}22679{_}Many persons keep eggs for a long time by smearing the shells with butter or sweet oil: they should then be packed in plenty of bran or sawdust, and the eggs not allowed to touch each other.
10136-8{_}22680{_}Eggs for storing should be collected in fine weather, and should not be more than 24 hours old when they are packed away, or their flavour, when used, cannot be relied on.
10136-8{_}22681{_}Another simple way of preserving eggs is to immerse them in lime-water soon after they have been laid, and then to put the vessel containing the lime-water in a cellar or cool outhouse.
10136-8{_}22682{_}_Seasonable_.--The best time for preserving eggs is from July to September.
10136-8{_}22683{_}EGGS.--The quality of eggs is said to be very much affected by     the food of the fowls who lay them.
10136-8{_}22684{_}Herbs and grain together     make a better food than grain only.
10136-8{_}22685{_}When the hens eat too many     insects, the eggs have a disagreeable flavour.
10136-8{_}22686{_}TO BOIL EGGS FOR BREAKFAST, SALADS, &c.  [Illustration: EGG-STAND FOR THE BREAKFAST-TABLE.]
10136-8{_}22687{_}1656.
10136-8{_}22688{_}Eggs for boiling cannot be too fresh, or boiled too soon after they are laid; but rather a longer time should be allowed for boiling a new-laid egg than for one that is three or four days old.
10136-8{_}22689{_}Have ready a saucepan of boiling water; put the eggs into it gently with a spoon, letting the spoon touch the bottom of the saucepan before it is withdrawn, that the egg may not fall, and consequently crack.
10136-8{_}22690{_}For those who like eggs lightly boiled, 3 minutes will be found sufficient; 3-3/4 to 4 minutes will be ample time to set the white nicely; and, if liked hard, 6 to 7 minutes will not be found too long.
10136-8{_}22691{_}Should the eggs be unusually large, as those of black Spanish fowls sometimes are, allow an extra 1/2 minute for them.
10136-8{_}22692{_}Eggs for salads should be boiled from 10 minutes to 1/4 hour, and should be placed in a basin of cold water for a few minutes; they should then be rolled on the table with the hand, and the shell will peel off easily.
10136-8{_}22693{_}_Time_.--To boil eggs lightly, for invalids or children, 3 minutes; to boil eggs to suit the generality of tastes, 3-3/4 to 4 minutes; to boil eggs hard, 6 to 7 minutes; for salads, 10 to 15 minutes.
10136-8{_}22694{_}_Note_.--Silver or plated egg-dishes, like that shown in our engraving, are now very much used.
10136-8{_}22695{_}The price of the one illustrated is £2.
10136-8{_}22696{_}2s., and may be purchased of Messrs. R. & J.
10136-8{_}22697{_}Slack, 336, Strand.
10136-8{_}22698{_}EGGS.--When fresh eggs are dropped into a vessel _full_ of     boiling water, they crack, because the eggs being well filled,     the shells give way to the efforts of the interior fluids,     dilated by heat.
10136-8{_}22699{_}If the volume of hot water be small, the shells     do not crack, because its temperature is reduced by the eggs     before the interior dilation can take place.
10136-8{_}22700{_}Stale eggs, again,     do not crack, because the air inside is easily compressed.
10136-8{_}22701{_}BUTTERED EGGS.
10136-8{_}22702{_}1657.
10136-8{_}22703{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 new-laid eggs, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}22704{_}of butter.
10136-8{_}22705{_}_Mode_.--Procure the eggs new-laid if possible; break them into a basin, and beat them well; put the butter into another basin, which place in boiling water, and stir till the butter is melted.
10136-8{_}22706{_}Pour that and the eggs into a lined saucepan; hold it over a gentle fire, and, as the mixture begins to warm, pour it two or three times into the basin, and back again, that the two ingredients may be well incorporated.
10136-8{_}22707{_}Keep stirring the eggs and butter one way until they are hot, _without boiling_, and serve on hot buttered toast.
10136-8{_}22708{_}If the mixture is allowed to boil, it will curdle, and so be entirely spoiled.
10136-8{_}22709{_}_Time_.--About 5 minutes to make the eggs hot.
10136-8{_}22710{_}_Average cost_, 7d.
10136-8{_}22711{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow a slice to each person.
10136-8{_}22712{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}22713{_}DUCKS' EGGS.
10136-8{_}22714{_}1658.
10136-8{_}22715{_}Ducks' eggs are usually so strongly flavoured that, plainly boiled, they are not good for eating; they answer, however, very well for various culinary preparations where eggs are required; such as custards, &c. &c. Being so large and highly-flavoured, 1 duck's egg will go as far as 2 small hen's eggs; besides making whatever they are mixed with exceedingly rich.
10136-8{_}22716{_}They also are admirable when used in puddings.
10136-8{_}22717{_}PRIMITIVE METHOD OF COOKING EGGS.--The shepherds of Egypt had a     singular manner of cooking eggs without the aid of fire.
10136-8{_}22718{_}They     placed them in a sling, which they turned so rapidly that the     friction of the air heated them to the exact point required for     use.
10136-8{_}22719{_}FRIED EGGS.
10136-8{_}22720{_}1659.
10136-8{_}22721{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 eggs, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}22722{_}of lard, butter or clarified dripping.
10136-8{_}22723{_}[Illustration: FRIED EGGS ON BACON.]
10136-8{_}22724{_}_Mode_.--Place a delicately-clean frying-pan over a gentle fire; put in the fat, and allow it to come to the boiling-point.
10136-8{_}22725{_}Break the eggs into cups, slip them into the boiling fat, and let them remain until the whites are delicately set; and, whilst they are frying, ladle a little of the fat over them.
10136-8{_}22726{_}Take them up with a slice, drain them for a minute from their greasy moisture, trim them neatly, and serve on slices of fried bacon or ham; or the eggs may be placed in the middle of the dish, with the bacon put round as a garnish.
10136-8{_}22727{_}_Time_.--2 to 3 minutes.
10136-8{_}22728{_}Average cost, 1d.
10136-8{_}22729{_}each; 2d.
10136-8{_}22730{_}when scarce.
10136-8{_}22731{_}_Sufficient_ for 2 persons.
10136-8{_}22732{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}22733{_}VENERATION FOR EGGS.--Many of the most learned philosophers held     eggs in a kind of respect, approaching to veneration, because     they saw in them the emblem of the world and the four elements.
10136-8{_}22734{_}The shell, they said, represented the earth; the white, water;     the yolk, fire; and air was found under the shell at one end of     the egg.
10136-8{_}22735{_}EGGS A LA MAITRE D'HOTEL.
10136-8{_}22736{_}1660.
10136-8{_}22737{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}22738{_}of fresh butter, 1 tablespoonful of flour, 1/2 pint of milk, pepper and salt to taste, 1 tablespoonful of minced parsley, the juice of 1/2 lemon, 6 eggs.
10136-8{_}22739{_}_Mode_.--Put the flour and half the butter into a stewpan; stir them over the fire until the mixture thickens; pour in the milk, which should be boiling; add a seasoning of pepper and salt, and simmer the whole for 5 minutes.
10136-8{_}22740{_}Put the remainder of the butter into the sauce, and add the minced parsley; then boil the eggs hard, strip off the shells, cut the eggs into quarters, and put them on a dish.
10136-8{_}22741{_}Bring the sauce to the boiling-point, add the lemon-juice, pour over the eggs, and serve.
10136-8{_}22742{_}_Time_.--5 minutes to boil the sauce; the eggs, 10 to 15 minutes.
10136-8{_}22743{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}22744{_}_Sufficient_ for 4 or 5 persons.
10136-8{_}22745{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}22746{_}OEUFS AU PLAT, or AU MIROIR, served on the Dish in which they are Cooked.
10136-8{_}22747{_}1661.
10136-8{_}22748{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 eggs, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}22749{_}of butter, pepper and salt to taste.
10136-8{_}22750{_}_Mode_.--Butter a dish rather thickly with good fresh butter; melt it, break the eggs into it the same as for poaching, sprinkle them with white pepper and fine salt, and put the remainder of the butter, cut into very small pieces, on the top of them.
10136-8{_}22751{_}Put the dish on a hot plate, or in the oven, or before the fire, and let it remain until the whites become set, but not hard, when serve immediately, placing the dish they were cooked in on another.
10136-8{_}22752{_}To hasten the cooking of the eggs, a salamander may be held over them for a minute; but great care must be taken that they are not too much done.
10136-8{_}22753{_}This is an exceedingly nice dish, and one very easily prepared for breakfast.
10136-8{_}22754{_}_Time_.--3 minutes.
10136-8{_}22755{_}_Average cost_, 5d.
10136-8{_}22756{_}_Sufficient_ for 2 persons.
10136-8{_}22757{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}22758{_}PLOVERS' EGGS.
10136-8{_}22759{_}1662.
10136-8{_}22760{_}Plovers' eggs are usually served boiled hard, and sent to table in a napkin, either hot or cold.
10136-8{_}22761{_}They may also be shelled, and served the same as eggs à la Tripe, with a good Béchamel sauce, or brown gravy, poured over them.
10136-8{_}22762{_}They are also used for decorating salads, the beautiful colour of the white being generally so much admired.
10136-8{_}22763{_}POACHED EGGS.
10136-8{_}22764{_}[Illustration: EGGS POACHED ON TOAST.]
10136-8{_}22765{_}[Illustration: TIN EGG-POACHER.]
10136-8{_}22766{_}1663.
10136-8{_}22767{_}INGREDIENTS.--Eggs, water.
10136-8{_}22768{_}To every pint of water allow 1 tablespoonful of vinegar.
10136-8{_}22769{_}_Mode_.--Eggs for poaching should be perfectly fresh, but not quite new-laid; those that are about 36 hours old are the best for the purpose.
10136-8{_}22770{_}If quite new-laid, the white is so milky it is almost impossible to set it; and, on the other hand, if the egg be at all stale, it is equally difficult to poach it nicely.
10136-8{_}22771{_}Strain some boiling water into a deep clean frying-pan; break the egg into a cup without damaging the yolk, and, when the water boils, remove the pan to the side of the fire, and gently slip the egg into it.
10136-8{_}22772{_}Place the pan over a gentle fire, and keep the water simmering until the white looks nicely set, when the egg is ready.
10136-8{_}22773{_}Take it up gently with a slice, cut away the ragged edges of the white, and serve either on toasted bread or on slices of ham or bacon, or on spinach, &c. A poached egg should not be overdone, as its appearance and taste will be quite spoiled if the yolk be allowed to harden.
10136-8{_}22774{_}When the egg is slipped into the water, the white should be gathered together, to keep it a little in form, or the cup should be turned over it for 1 minute.
10136-8{_}22775{_}To poach an egg to perfection is rather a difficult operation; so, for inexperienced cooks, a tin egg-poacher may be purchased, which greatly facilitates this manner of dressing ecgs.
10136-8{_}22776{_}Our illustration clearly shows what it is: it consists of a tin plate with a handle, with a space for three perforated cups.
10136-8{_}22777{_}An egg should be broken into each cup, and the machine then placed in a stewpan of boiling water, which has been previously strained.
10136-8{_}22778{_}When the whites of the eggs appear set, they are done, and should then be carefully slipped on to the toast or spinach, or with whatever they are served.
10136-8{_}22779{_}In poaching eggs in a frying-pan, never do more than four at a time; and, when a little vinegar is liked mixed with the water in which the eggs are done, use the above proportion.
10136-8{_}22780{_}_Time_.--2-1/2 to 3-1/2 minutes, according to the size of the egg.
10136-8{_}22781{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 2 eggs to each person.
10136-8{_}22782{_}_Seasonable_ at any time, but less plentiful in winter.
10136-8{_}22783{_}POACHED EGGS, WITH CREAM.
10136-8{_}22784{_}1664.
10136-8{_}22785{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 pint of water, 1 teaspoonful of salt, 4 teaspoonfuls of vinegar, 4 fresh eggs, 1/2 gill of cream, salt, pepper, and pounded sugar to taste, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}22786{_}of butter.
10136-8{_}22787{_}_Mode_.--Put the water, vinegar, and salt into a frying-pan, and break each egg into a separate cup; bring the water, &c. to boil, and slip the eggs gently into it without breaking the yolks.
10136-8{_}22788{_}Simmer them from 3 to 4 minutes, but not longer, and, with a slice, lift them out on to a hot dish, and trim the edges.
10136-8{_}22789{_}Empty the pan of its contents, put in the cream, add a seasoning to taste of pepper, salt, and pounded sugar; bring the whole to the boiling-point; then add the butter, broken into small pieces; toss the pan round and round till the butter is melted; pour it over the eggs, and serve.
10136-8{_}22790{_}To insure the eggs not being spoiled whilst the cream, &c., is preparing, it is a good plan to warm the cream with the butter, &c., before the eggs are poached, so that it may be poured over them immediately after they are dished.
10136-8{_}22791{_}_Time_.--3 to 4 minutes to poach the eggs, 5 minutes to warm the cream.
10136-8{_}22792{_}_Average cost_ for the above quantity, 9d.
10136-8{_}22793{_}_Sufficient_ for 2 persons.
10136-8{_}22794{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}22795{_}1665.
10136-8{_}22796{_}COMPARATIVE SIZES OF EGGS.
10136-8{_}22797{_}[Illustration: 1 SWAN'S EGG.
10136-8{_}22798{_}2 TURKEY'S EGG.
10136-8{_}22799{_}3 DUCK'S EGG.
10136-8{_}22800{_}4 PLOVER'S EGG.]
10136-8{_}22801{_}SCOTCH EGGS.
10136-8{_}22802{_}1666.
10136-8{_}22803{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 eggs, 6 tablespoonfuls of forcemeat No.
10136-8{_}22804{_}417, hot lard, 1/2 pint of good brown gravy.
10136-8{_}22805{_}_Mode_.--Boil the eggs for 10 minutes; strip them from the shells, and cover them with forcemeat made by recipe No.
10136-8{_}22806{_}417; or substitute pounded anchovies for the ham.
10136-8{_}22807{_}Fry the eggs a nice brown in boiling lard, drain them before the fire from their greasy moisture, dish them, and pour round from 1/4 to 1/2 pint of good brown gravy.
10136-8{_}22808{_}To enhance the appearance of the eggs, they may be rolled in beaten egg and sprinkled with bread crumbs; but this is scarcely necessary if they are carefully fried.
10136-8{_}22809{_}The flavour of the ham or anchovy in the forcemeat must preponderate, as it should be very relishing.
10136-8{_}22810{_}_Time_.--10 minutes to boil the eggs, 5 to 7 minutes to fry them.
10136-8{_}22811{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}22812{_}4d.
10136-8{_}22813{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 or 4 persons.
10136-8{_}22814{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}22815{_}EGGS A LA TRIPE.
10136-8{_}22816{_}1667.
10136-8{_}22817{_}INGREDIENTS.--8 eggs, 3/4 pint of Béchamel sauce No.
10136-8{_}22818{_}368, dessertspoonful of finely-minced parsley.
10136-8{_}22819{_}_Mode_.--Boil the eggs hard; put them into cold water, peel them, take out the yolks whole, and shred the whites.
10136-8{_}22820{_}Make 3/4 pint of Béchamel sauce by recipe No.
10136-8{_}22821{_}368; add the parsley, and, when the sauce is quite hot, put the yolks of the eggs into the middle of the dish, and the shred whites round them; pour over the sauce, and garnish with leaves of puff-paste or fried croûtons.
10136-8{_}22822{_}There is no necessity for putting the eggs into the saucepan with the Béchamel; the sauce, being quite hot, will warm the eggs sufficiently.
10136-8{_}22823{_}_Time_.--10 minutes to boil the eggs.
10136-8{_}22824{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}22825{_}_Sufficient_ for 5 or 6 persons.
10136-8{_}22826{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}22827{_}[Illustration]     [Illustration]  CHAPTER XXXIV.
10136-8{_}22828{_}GENERAL OBSERVATIONS ON BREAD, BISCUITS, AND CAKES.
10136-8{_}22829{_}BREAD AND BREAD-MAKING.
10136-8{_}22830{_}1668.
10136-8{_}22831{_}AMONG the numerous vegetable products yielding articles of food for man, the Cereals hold the first place.
10136-8{_}22832{_}By means of skilful cultivation, mankind have transformed the original forms of these growths, poor and ill-flavoured as they perhaps were, into various fruitful and agreeable species, which yield an abundant and pleasant supply.
10136-8{_}22833{_}Classified according to their respective richness in alimentary elements, the Cereals stand thus:--Wheat, and its varieties, Rye, Barley, Oats, Rice, Indian Corn.
10136-8{_}22834{_}Everybody knows it is wheat flour which yields the best bread.
10136-8{_}22835{_}Rye-bread is viscous, hard, less easily soluble by the gastric juice, and not so rich in nutritive power.
10136-8{_}22836{_}Flour produced from barley, Indian corn, or rice, is not so readily made into bread; and the article, when made, is heavy and indigestible.
10136-8{_}22837{_}1669.
10136-8{_}22838{_}On examining a grain of corn from any of the numerous cereals [Footnote: _Cereal,_ a corn-producing plant; from Ceres, the goddess of agriculture.]
10136-8{_}22839{_}used in the preparation of flour, such as wheat, maize, rye, barley, &c., it will be found to consist of two parts,--the husk, or exterior covering, which is generally of a dark colour, and the inner, or albuminous part, which is more or less white.
10136-8{_}22840{_}In grinding, these two portions are separated, and the husk being blown away in the process of winnowing, the flour remains in the form of a light brown powder, consisting principally of starch and gluten.
10136-8{_}22841{_}In order to render it white, it undergoes a process called "bolting."
10136-8{_}22842{_}It is passed through a series of fine sieves, which separate the coarser parts, leaving behind fine white flour,--the "fine firsts" of the corn-dealer.
10136-8{_}22843{_}The process of bolting, as just described, tends to deprive flour of its gluten, the coarser and darker portion containing much of that substance; while the lighter part is peculiarly rich in starch.
10136-8{_}22844{_}Bran contains a large proportion of gluten; hence it will be seen why brown broad is so much more nutritious than white; in fact, we may lay it down as a general rule, that the whiter the bread the less nourishment it contains.
10136-8{_}22845{_}Majendie proved this by feeding a dog for forty days with white wheaten bread, at the end of which time he died; while another dog, fed on brown bread made with flour mixed with bran, lived without any disturbance of his health.
10136-8{_}22846{_}The "bolting" process, then, is rather injurious than beneficial in its result; and is one of the numerous instances where fashion has chosen a wrong standard to go by.
10136-8{_}22847{_}In ancient times, down to the Emperors, no bolted flour was known.
10136-8{_}22848{_}In many parts of Germany the entire meal is used; and in no part of the world are the digestive organs of the people in a better condition.
10136-8{_}22849{_}In years of famine, when corn is scarce, the use of bolted flour is most culpable, for from 18 to 20 per cent, is lost in bran.
10136-8{_}22850{_}Brown bread has, of late years, become very popular; and many physicians have recommended it to invalids with weak digestions with great success.
10136-8{_}22851{_}This rage for white bread has introduced adulterations of a very serious character, affecting the health of the whole community.
10136-8{_}22852{_}Potatoes are added for this purpose; but this is a comparatively harmless cheat, only reducing the nutritive property of the bread; but bone-dust and alum are also put in, which are far from harmless.
10136-8{_}22853{_}1670.
10136-8{_}22854{_}Bread-making is a very ancient art indeed.
10136-8{_}22855{_}The Assyrians, Egyptians, and Greeks, used to make bread, in which oil, with aniseed and other spices, was an element; but this was unleavened.
10136-8{_}22856{_}Every family used to prepare the bread for its own consumption, the _trade_ of baking not having yet taken shape.
10136-8{_}22857{_}It is said, that somewhere about the beginning of the thirtieth Olympiad, the slave of an archon, at Athens, made leavened bread by accident.
10136-8{_}22858{_}He had left some wheaten dough in an earthen pan, and forgotten it; some days afterwards, he lighted upon it again, and found it turning sour.
10136-8{_}22859{_}His first thought was to throw it away; but, his master coming up, he mixed this now acescent dough with some fresh dough, which he was working at.
10136-8{_}22860{_}The bread thus produced, by the introduction of dough in which alcoholic fermentation had begun, was found delicious by the archon and his friends; and the slave, being summoned and catechised, told the secret.
10136-8{_}22861{_}It spread all over Athens; and everybody wanting leavened bread at once, certain persons set up as bread-makers, or bakers.
10136-8{_}22862{_}In a short time bread-baking became quite an art, and "Athenian bread" was quoted all over Greece as the best bread, just as the honey of Hyamettus was celebrated as the best honey.
10136-8{_}22863{_}1671.
10136-8{_}22864{_}In our own times, and among civilized peoples, bread has become an article of food of the first necessity; and properly so, for it constitutes of itself a complete life-sustainer, the gluten, starch, and sugar, which it contains, representing azotized and hydro-carbonated nutrients, and combining the sustaining powers of the animal and vegetable kingdoms in one product.
10136-8{_}22865{_}1672.
10136-8{_}22866{_}WHEATEN BREAD.--The finest, wholesomest, and most savoury bread is made from wheaten flour.
10136-8{_}22867{_}There are, of wheat, three leading qualities,-- the soft, the medium, and the hard wheat; the last of which yields a kind of bread that is not so white as that made from soft wheat, but is richer in gluten, and, consequently, more nutritive.
10136-8{_}22868{_}1673.
10136-8{_}22869{_}RYE BREAD.--This comes next to wheaten bread: it is not so rich in gluten, but is said to keep fresh longer, and to have some laxative qualities.
10136-8{_}22870{_}1674.
10136-8{_}22871{_}BARLEY BREAD, INDIAN-CORN BREAD, &c.--Bread made from barley, maize, oats, rice, potatoes, &c. "rises" badly, because the grains in question contain but little gluten, which makes the bread heavy, close in texture, and difficult of digestion; in fact, corn-flour has to be added before panification can take place.
10136-8{_}22872{_}In countries where wheat is scarce and maize abundant, the people make the latter a chief article of sustenance, when prepared in different forms.
10136-8{_}22873{_}BREAD-MAKING.
10136-8{_}22874{_}1675.
10136-8{_}22875{_}PANIFICATION, or bread-making, consists of the following processes, in the case of Wheaten Flour.
10136-8{_}22876{_}Fifty or sixty per cent.
10136-8{_}22877{_}of water is added to the flour, with the addition of some leavening matter, and, preferably, of yeast from malt and hops.
10136-8{_}22878{_}All kinds of leavening matter have, however, been, and are still used in different parts of the world: in the East Indies, "toddy," which is a liquor that flows from the wounded cocoa-nut tree; and, in the West Indies, "dunder," or the refuse of the distillation of rum.
10136-8{_}22879{_}The dough then undergoes the well-known process called _kneading_.
10136-8{_}22880{_}The yeast produces fermentation, a process which may be thus described:--The dough reacting upon the leavening matter introduced, the starch of the flour is transformed into saccharine matter, the saccharine matter being afterwards changed into alcohol and carbonic acid.
10136-8{_}22881{_}The dough must be well "bound," and yet allow the escape of the little bubbles of carbonic acid which accompany the fermentation, and which, in their passage, cause the numerous little holes which are seen in light bread.
10136-8{_}22882{_}1676.
10136-8{_}22883{_}The yeast must be good and fresh, if the bread is to be digestible and nice.
10136-8{_}22884{_}Stale yeast produces, instead of vinous fermentation, an acetous fermentation, which flavours the bread and makes it disagreeable.
10136-8{_}22885{_}A poor thin yeast produces an imperfect fermentation, the result being a heavy unwholesome loaf.
10136-8{_}22886{_}1677.
10136-8{_}22887{_}When the dough is well kneaded, it is left to stand for some time, and then, as soon as it begins to swell, it is divided into loaves; after which it is again left to stand, when it once more swells up, and manifests, for the last time, the symptoms of fermentation.
10136-8{_}22888{_}It is then put into the oven, where the water contained in the dough is partly evaporated, and the loaves swell up again, while a yellow crust begins to form upon the surface.
10136-8{_}22889{_}When the bread is sufficiently baked, the bottom crust is hard and resonant if struck with the finger, while the crumb is elastic, and rises again after being pressed down with the finger.
10136-8{_}22890{_}The bread is, in all probability, baked sufficiently if, on opening the door of the oven, you are met by a cloud of steam which quickly passes away.
10136-8{_}22891{_}1678.
10136-8{_}22892{_}One word as to the unwholesomeness of new bread and hot rolls.
10136-8{_}22893{_}When bread is taken out of the oven, it is full of moisture; the starch is held together in masses, and the bread, instead of being crusted so as to expose each grain of starch to the saliva, actually prevents their digestion by being formed by the teeth into leathery poreless masses, which lie on the stomach like so many bullets.
10136-8{_}22894{_}Bread should always be at least a day old before it is eaten; and, if properly made, and kept in a _cool dry_ place, ought to be perfectly soft and palatable at the end of three or four days.
10136-8{_}22895{_}Hot rolls, swimming in melted butter, and new bread, ought to be carefully shunned by everybody who has the slightest respect for that much-injured individual--the Stomach.
10136-8{_}22896{_}1679.
10136-8{_}22897{_}AERATED BREAD.--It is not unknown to some of our readers that Dr. Dauglish, of Malvern, has recently patented a process for making bread "light" without the use of leaven.
10136-8{_}22898{_}The ordinary process of bread-making by fermentation is tedious, and much labour of human hands is requisite in the kneading, in order that the dough may be thoroughly interpenetrated with the leaven.
10136-8{_}22899{_}The new process impregnates the bread, by the application of machinery, with carbonic acid gas, or fixed air.
10136-8{_}22900{_}Different opinions are expressed about the bread; but it is curious to note, that, as corn is now reaped by machinery, and dough is baked by machinery, the whole process of bread-making is probably in course of undergoing changes which will emancipate both the housewife and the professional baker from a large amount of labour.
10136-8{_}22901{_}1680.
10136-8{_}22902{_}In the production of Aërated Bread, wheaten flour, water, salt, and carbonic acid gas (generated by proper machinery), are the only materials employed.
10136-8{_}22903{_}We need not inform our readers that carbonic acid gas is the source of the effervescence, whether in common water coming from a depth, or in lemonade, or any aërated drink.
10136-8{_}22904{_}Its action, in the new bread, takes the place of fermentation in the old.
10136-8{_}22905{_}1681.
10136-8{_}22906{_}In the patent process, the dough is mixed in a great iron ball, inside which is a system of paddles, perpetually turning, and doing the kneading part of the business.
10136-8{_}22907{_}Into this globe the flour is dropped till it is full, and then the common atmospheric air is pumped out, and the pure gas turned on.
10136-8{_}22908{_}The gas is followed by the water, which has been aërated for the purpose, and then begins the churning or kneading part of the business.
10136-8{_}22909{_}1682.
10136-8{_}22910{_}Of course, it is not long before we have the dough, and very "light" and nice it looks.
10136-8{_}22911{_}This is caught in tins, and passed on to the floor of the oven, which is an endless floor, moving slowly through the fire.
10136-8{_}22912{_}Done to a turn, the loaves emerge at the other end of the apartment,--and the Aërated Bread is made.
10136-8{_}22913{_}1683.
10136-8{_}22914{_}It may be added, that it is a good plan to change one's baker from time to time, and so secure a change in the quality of the bread that is eaten.
10136-8{_}22915{_}1684.
10136-8{_}22916{_}MIXED BREADS.--Rye bread is hard of digestion, and requires longer and slower baking than wheaten bread.
10136-8{_}22917{_}It is better when made with leaven of wheaten flour rather than yeast, and turns out lighter.
10136-8{_}22918{_}It should not be eaten till two days old.
10136-8{_}22919{_}It will keep a long time.
10136-8{_}22920{_}1685.
10136-8{_}22921{_}A good bread may be made by mixing rye-flour, wheat-flour, and rice-paste in equal proportions; also by mixing rye, wheat, and barley.
10136-8{_}22922{_}In Norway, it is said that they only bake their barley broad once a year, such is its "keeping" quality.
10136-8{_}22923{_}1686.
10136-8{_}22924{_}Indian-corn flour mixed with wheat-flour (half with half) makes a nice bread; but it is not considered very digestible, though it keeps well.
10136-8{_}22925{_}1687.
10136-8{_}22926{_}Rice cannot be made into bread, nor can potatoes; but one-third potato flour to three-fourths wheaten flour makes a tolerably good loaf.
10136-8{_}22927{_}1688.
10136-8{_}22928{_}A very good bread, better than the ordinary sort, and of a delicious flavour, is said to be produced by adopting the following recipe:--Take ten parts of wheat-flour, five parts of potato-flour, one part of rice-paste; knead together, add the yeast, and bake as usual.
10136-8{_}22929{_}This is, of course, cheaper than wheaten bread.
10136-8{_}22930{_}1689.
10136-8{_}22931{_}Flour, when freshly ground, is too glutinous to make good bread, and should therefore not be used immediately, but should be kept dry for a few weeks, and stirred occasionally, until it becomes dry, and crumbles easily between the fingers.
10136-8{_}22932{_}1690.
10136-8{_}22933{_}Flour should be perfectly dry before being used for bread or cakes; if at all damp, the preparation is sure to be heavy.
10136-8{_}22934{_}Before mixing it with the other ingredients, it is a good plan to place it for an hour or two before the fire, until it feels warm and dry.
10136-8{_}22935{_}1691.
10136-8{_}22936{_}Yeast from home-brewed beer is generally preferred to any other: it is very bitter, and, on that account, should be well washed, and put away until the thick mass settles.
10136-8{_}22937{_}If it still continues bitter, the process should be repeated; and, before being used, all the water floating at the top must be poured off.
10136-8{_}22938{_}German yeast is now very much used, and should be moistened, and thoroughly mixed with the milk or water with which the bread is to be made.
10136-8{_}22939{_}1692.
10136-8{_}22940{_}The following observations are extracted from a valuable work on Bread-making, [Footnote: "The English Bread-Book."
10136-8{_}22941{_}By Eliza Acton.
10136-8{_}22942{_}London: Longman.]
10136-8{_}22943{_}and will be found very useful to our readers:--  1693.
10136-8{_}22944{_}The first thing required for making wholesome bread is the utmost cleanliness; the next is the soundness and sweetness of all the ingredients used for it; and, in addition to these, there must be attention and care through the whole process.
10136-8{_}22945{_}1694.
10136-8{_}22946{_}An almost certain way of spoiling dough is to leave it half-made, and to allow it to become cold before it is finished.
10136-8{_}22947{_}The other most common causes of failure are using yeast which is no longer sweet, or which has been frozen, or has had hot liquid poured over it.
10136-8{_}22948{_}1695.
10136-8{_}22949{_}Too small a proportion of yeast, or insufficient time allowed for the dough to rise, will cause the bread to be heavy.
10136-8{_}22950{_}1696.
10136-8{_}22951{_}Heavy bread will also most likely be the result of making the dough very hard, and letting it become quite, cold, particularly in winter.
10136-8{_}22952{_}1697.
10136-8{_}22953{_}If either the sponge or the dough be permitted to overwork itself, that is to say, if the mixing and kneading be neglected when it has reached the proper point for either, sour bread will probably be the consequence in warm weather, and bad bread in any.
10136-8{_}22954{_}The goodness will also be endangered by placing it so near a fire as to make any part of it hot, instead of maintaining the gentle and equal degree of heat required for its due fermentation.
10136-8{_}22955{_}1698.
10136-8{_}22956{_}MILK OR BUTTER.--Milk which is not perfectly sweet will not only injure the flavour of the bread, but, in sultry weather, will often cause it to be quite uneatable; yet either of them, if fresh and good, will materially improve its quality.
10136-8{_}22957{_}1699.
10136-8{_}22958{_}To keep bread sweet and fresh, as soon as it is cold it should be put into a clean earthen pan, with a cover to it: this pan should be placed at a little distance from the ground, to allow a current of air to pass underneath.
10136-8{_}22959{_}Some persons prefer keeping bread on clean wooden shelves, without being covered, that the crust may not soften.
10136-8{_}22960{_}Stale bread may be freshened by warming it through in a gentle oven.
10136-8{_}22961{_}Stale pastry, cakes, &c., may also be improved by this method.
10136-8{_}22962{_}1700.
10136-8{_}22963{_}The utensils required for making bread, on a moderate scale, are a kneading-trough or pan, sufficiently large that the dough may be kneaded freely without throwing the flour over the edges, and also to allow for its rising; a hair sieve for straining yeast, and one or two strong spoons.
10136-8{_}22964{_}1701.
10136-8{_}22965{_}Yeast must always be good of its kind, and in a fitting state to produce ready and proper fermentation.
10136-8{_}22966{_}Yeast of strong beer or ale produces more effect than that of milder kinds; and the fresher the yeast, the smaller the quantity will be required to raise the dough.
10136-8{_}22967{_}1702.
10136-8{_}22968{_}As a general rule, the oven for baking bread should be rather quick, and the heat so regulated as to penetrate the dough without hardening the outside.
10136-8{_}22969{_}The oven door should not be opened after the bread is put in until the dough is set, or has become firm, as the cool air admitted will have an unfavourable effect on it.
10136-8{_}22970{_}1703.
10136-8{_}22971{_}Brick ovens are generally considered the best adapted for baking bread: these should be heated with wood faggots, and then swept and mopped out, to cleanse them for the reception of the bread.
10136-8{_}22972{_}Iron ovens are more difficult to manage, being apt to burn the surface of the bread before the middle is baked.
10136-8{_}22973{_}To remedy this, a few clean bricks should be set at the bottom of the oven, close together, to receive the tins of bread.
10136-8{_}22974{_}In many modern stoves the ovens are so much improved that they bake admirably; and they can always be brought to the required temperature, when it is higher than is needed, by leaving the door open for a time.
10136-8{_}22975{_}A FEW HINTS respecting the Making and Baking of CAKES.
10136-8{_}22976{_}1704.
10136-8{_}22977{_}_Eggs_ should always be broken into a cup, the whites and yolks separated, and they should always be strained.
10136-8{_}22978{_}Breaking the eggs thus, the bad ones may be easily rejected without spoiling the others, and so cause no waste.
10136-8{_}22979{_}As eggs are used instead of yeast, they should be very thoroughly whisked; they are generally sufficiently beaten when thick enough to carry the drop that falls from the whisk.
10136-8{_}22980{_}1705.
10136-8{_}22981{_}_Loaf Sugar_ should be well pounded, and then sifted through a fine sieve.
10136-8{_}22982{_}1706.
10136-8{_}22983{_}_Currants_ should be nicely washed, picked, dried in a cloth, and then carefully examined, that no pieces of grit or stone may be left amongst them.
10136-8{_}22984{_}They should then be laid on a dish before the fire, to become thoroughly dry; as, if added damp to the other ingredients, cakes will be liable to be heavy.
10136-8{_}22985{_}1707.
10136-8{_}22986{_}_Good Butter_ should always be used in the manufacture of cakes; and if beaten to a cream, it saves much time and labour to warm, but not melt, it before beating.
10136-8{_}22987{_}1708.
10136-8{_}22988{_}Less butter and eggs are required for cakes when yeast is mixed with the other ingredients.
10136-8{_}22989{_}1709.
10136-8{_}22990{_}The heat of the oven is of great importance, especially for large cakes.
10136-8{_}22991{_}If the heat be not tolerably fierce, the batter will not rise.
10136-8{_}22992{_}If the oven is too quick, and there is any danger of the cake burning or catching, put a sheet of clean paper over the top.
10136-8{_}22993{_}Newspaper, or paper that has been printed on, should never be used for this purpose.
10136-8{_}22994{_}1710.
10136-8{_}22995{_}To know when a cake is sufficiently baked, plunge a clean knife into the middle of it; draw it quickly out, and if it looks in the least sticky, put the cake back, and close the oven door until the cake is done.
10136-8{_}22996{_}1711.
10136-8{_}22997{_}Cakes should be kept in closed tin canisters or jars, and in a dry place.
10136-8{_}22998{_}Those made with yeast do not keep so long as those made without it.
10136-8{_}22999{_}BISCUITS.
10136-8{_}23000{_}1712.
10136-8{_}23001{_}Since the establishment of the large modern biscuit manufactories, biscuits have been produced both cheap and wholesome, in, comparatively speaking, endless variety.
10136-8{_}23002{_}Their actual component parts are, perhaps, known only to the various makers; but there are several kinds of biscuits which have long been in use, that may here be advantageously described.
10136-8{_}23003{_}1713.
10136-8{_}23004{_}Biscuits belong to the class of unfermented bread, and are, perhaps, the most wholesome of that class.
10136-8{_}23005{_}In cases where fermented bread does not agree with the human stomach, they may be recommended: in many instances they are considered lighter, and less liable to create acidity and flatulence.
10136-8{_}23006{_}The name is derived from the French _bis cuit_, "twice-baked," because, originally, that was the mode of entirely depriving them of all moisture, to insure their keeping; but, although that process is no longer employed, the name is retained.
10136-8{_}23007{_}The use of this kind of bread on land is pretty general, and some varieties are luxuries; but, at sea, biscuits are articles of the first necessity.
10136-8{_}23008{_}1714.
10136-8{_}23009{_}SEA, or SHIP BISCUITS, are made of wheat-flour from which only the coarsest bran has been separated.
10136-8{_}23010{_}The dough is made up as stiff as it can be worked, and is then formed into shapes, and baked in an oven; after which, the biscuits are exposed in lofts over the oven until perfectly dry, to prevent them from becoming mouldy when stored.
10136-8{_}23011{_}1715.
10136-8{_}23012{_}CAPTAINS' BISCUITS are made in a similar manner, only of fine flour.
10136-8{_}23013{_}RECIPES.
10136-8{_}23014{_}CHAPTER XXXV.
10136-8{_}23015{_}TO MAKE YEAST FOR BREAD.
10136-8{_}23016{_}1716.
10136-8{_}23017{_}INGREDIENTS.--1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}23018{_}of hops, 3 quarts of water, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}23019{_}of bruised malt, 1/2 pint of yeast.
10136-8{_}23020{_}_Mode_.--Boil the hops in the water for 20 minutes; let it stand for about 5 minutes, then add it to 1 lb.
10136-8{_}23021{_}of bruised malt prepared as for brewing.
10136-8{_}23022{_}Let the mixture stand covered till about lukewarm; then put in not quite 1/2 pint of yeast; keep it warm, and let it work 3 or 4 hours; then put it into small 1/2-pint bottles (ginger-beer bottles are the best for the purpose), cork them well, and tie them down.
10136-8{_}23023{_}The yeast is now ready for use; it will keep good for a few weeks, and 1 bottle will be found sufficient for 18 lbs.
10136-8{_}23024{_}of flour.
10136-8{_}23025{_}When required for use, boil 3 lbs.
10136-8{_}23026{_}of potatoes without salt, mash them in the same water in which they were boiled, and rub them through a colander.
10136-8{_}23027{_}Stir in about 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23028{_}of flour; then put in the yeast, pour it in the middle of the flour, and let it stand warm on the hearth all night, and in the morning let it be quite warm when it is kneaded.
10136-8{_}23029{_}The bottles of yeast require very careful opening, as it is generally exceedingly ripe.
10136-8{_}23030{_}_Time_.--20 minutes to boil the hops and water, the yeast to work 3 or 4 hours.
10136-8{_}23031{_}_Sufficient._--1/2 pint sufficient for 18 lbs.
10136-8{_}23032{_}of flour.
10136-8{_}23033{_}KIRKLEATHAM YEAST.
10136-8{_}23034{_}1717.
10136-8{_}23035{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 oz.
10136-8{_}23036{_}of hops, 4 quarts of water, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23037{_}of flour, 1/2 pint of yeast.
10136-8{_}23038{_}_Mode_.--Boil the hops and water for 20 minutes; strain, and mix with the liquid 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23039{_}of flour and not quite 1/2 pint of yeast.
10136-8{_}23040{_}Bottle it up, and tie the corks down.
10136-8{_}23041{_}When wanted for use, boil potatoes according to the quantity of bread to be made (about 3 lbs.
10136-8{_}23042{_}are sufficient for about a peck of flour); mash them, add to them 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23043{_}of flour, and mix about 1/2 pint of the yeast with them; let this mixture stand all day, and lay the bread to rise the night before it is wanted.
10136-8{_}23044{_}_Time_.--20 minutes to boil the hops and water.
10136-8{_}23045{_}_Sufficient_.--1/2 pint of this yeast sufficient for a peck of flour, or rather more.
10136-8{_}23046{_}TO MAKE GOOD HOME-MADE BREAD.
10136-8{_}23047{_}(_Miss Acton's Recipe_.)
10136-8{_}23048{_}1718.
10136-8{_}23049{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 quartern of flour, 1 large tablespoonful of solid brewer's yeast, or nearly 1 oz.
10136-8{_}23050{_}of fresh German yeast, 1-1/4 to 1-1/2 pint of warm milk-and-water.
10136-8{_}23051{_}[Illustration: COTTAGE LOAF.]
10136-8{_}23052{_}[Illustration: TIN BREAD.]
10136-8{_}23053{_}_Mode_.--Put the flour into a large earthenware bowl or deep pan; then, with a strong metal or wooden spoon, hollow out the middle; but do not clear it entirely away from the bottom of the pan, as, in that case, the sponge (or leaven, as it was formerly termed) would stick to it, which it ought not to do.
10136-8{_}23054{_}Next take either a large tablespoonful of brewer's yeast which has been rendered solid by mixing it with plenty of cold water, and letting it afterwards stand to settle for a day and night; or nearly an ounce of German yeast; put it into a large basin, and proceed to mix it, so that it shall be as smooth as cream, with 3/4 pint of warm milk-and-water, or with water only; though even a very little milk will much improve the bread.
10136-8{_}23055{_}Pour the yeast into the hole made in the flour, and stir into it as much of that which lies round it as will make a thick batter, in which there must be no lumps.
10136-8{_}23056{_}Strew plenty of flour on the top; throw a thick clean cloth over, and set it where the air is warm; but do not place it upon the kitchen fender, for it will become too much heated there.
10136-8{_}23057{_}Look at it from time to time: when it has been laid for nearly an hour, and when the yeast has risen and broken through the flour, so that bubbles appear in it, you will know that it is ready to be made up into dough.
10136-8{_}23058{_}Then place the pan on a strong chair, or dresser, or table, of convenient height; pour into the sponge the remainder of the warm milk-and-water; stir into it as much of the flour as you can with the spoon; then wipe it out clean with your fingers, and lay it aside.
10136-8{_}23059{_}Next take plenty of the remaining flour, throw it on the top of the leaven, and begin, with the knuckles of both hands, to knead it well.
10136-8{_}23060{_}When the flour is nearly all kneaded in, begin to draw the edges of the dough towards the middle, in order to mix the whole thoroughly; and when it is free from flour and lumps and crumbs, and does not stick to the hands when touched, it will be done, and may again be covered with the cloth, and left to rise a second time.
10136-8{_}23061{_}In 3/4 hour look at it, and should it have swollen very much, and begin to crack, it will be light enough to bake.
10136-8{_}23062{_}Turn it then on to a paste-board or very clean dresser, and with a large sharp knife divide it in two; make it up quickly into loaves, and dispatch it to the oven: make one or two incisions across the tops of the loaves, as they will rise more easily if this be done.
10136-8{_}23063{_}If baked in tins or pans, rub them with a tiny piece of butter laid on a piece of clean paper, to prevent the dough from sticking to them.
10136-8{_}23064{_}All bread should be turned upside down, or on its side, as soon as it is drawn from the oven: if this be neglected, the under part of the loaves will become wet and blistered from the steam, which cannot then escape from them.
10136-8{_}23065{_}_To make the dough without setting a sponge_, merely mix the yeast with the greater part of the warm milk-and-water, and wet up the whole of the flour at once after a little salt has been stirred in, proceeding exactly, in every other respect, as in the directions just given.
10136-8{_}23066{_}As the dough will _soften_ in the rising, it should be made quite firm at first, or it will be too lithe by the time it is ready for the oven.
10136-8{_}23067{_}[Illustration: ITALIAN MILLET.]
10136-8{_}23068{_}_Time_.--To be left to rise an hour the first time, 3/4 hour the second time; to be baked from 1 to 1-1/4 hour, or baked in one loaf from 1-1/2 to 2 hours.
10136-8{_}23069{_}ITALIAN MILLET, or Great Indian Millet, is cultivated in Egypt     and Nubia, where it is called _dhourra_, and is used as human     food, as well as for the fermentation of beer.
10136-8{_}23070{_}It will grow on     poor soils, and is extremely productive.
10136-8{_}23071{_}It has been introduced     into Italy, where they make a coarse bread from it; and it is     also employed in pastry and puddings: they also use it for     feeding horses and domestic fowls.
10136-8{_}23072{_}It is the largest variety,     growing to the height of six feet; but it requires a warm     climate, and will not ripen in this country.
10136-8{_}23073{_}A yellow variety,     called Golden Millet, is sold in the grocers' shops, for making     puddings, and is very delicate and wholesome.
10136-8{_}23074{_}TO MAKE A PECK OF GOOD BREAD.
10136-8{_}23075{_}1719.
10136-8{_}23076{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 lbs.
10136-8{_}23077{_}of potatoes, 6 pints of cold water, 1/2 pint of good yeast, a peck of flour, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}23078{_}of salt.
10136-8{_}23079{_}_Mode_.--Peel and boil the potatoes; beat them to a cream while warm; then add 1 pint of cold water, strain through a colander, and add to it 1/2 pint of good yeast, which should have been put in water over-night, to take off its bitterness.
10136-8{_}23080{_}Stir all well together with a wooden spoon, and pour the mixture into the centre of the flour; mix it to the substance of cream, cover it over closely, and let it remain near the fire for an hour; then add the 5 pints of water, milk-warm, with 2 oz.
10136-8{_}23081{_}of salt; pour this in, and mix the whole to a nice light dough.
10136-8{_}23082{_}Let it remain for about 2 hours; then make it into 7 loaves, and bake for about 1-1/2 hour in a good oven.
10136-8{_}23083{_}When baked, the bread should weigh nearly 20 lbs.
10136-8{_}23084{_}_Time_.--About 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}23085{_}THE RED VARIETIES OF WHEAT are generally hardier and more easily     grown than the white sorts, and, although of less value to the     miller, they are fully more profitable to the grower, in     consequence of the better crops which they produce.
10136-8{_}23086{_}Another     advantage the red wheats possess is their comparative immunity     from the attacks of mildew and fly.
10136-8{_}23087{_}The best English wheat comes     from the counties of Kent and Essex; the qualities under these     heads always bearing a higher price than others, as will be seen     by the periodical lists in the journals.
10136-8{_}23088{_}RICE BREAD.
10136-8{_}23089{_}1720.
10136-8{_}23090{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}23091{_}of rice allow 4 lbs.
10136-8{_}23092{_}of wheat flour, nearly 3 tablespoonfuls of yeast, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}23093{_}of salt.
10136-8{_}23094{_}_Mode_.--Boil the rice in water until it is quite tender; pour off the water, and put the rice, before it is cold, to the flour.
10136-8{_}23095{_}Mix these well together with the yeast, salt, and sufficient warm water to make the whole into a smooth dough; let it rise by the side of the fire, then form it into loaves, and bake them from 1-1/2 to 2 hours, according to their size.
10136-8{_}23096{_}If the rice is boiled in milk instead of water, it makes very delicious bread or cakes.
10136-8{_}23097{_}When boiled in this manner, it may be mixed with the flour without straining the liquid from it.
10136-8{_}23098{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 to 2 hours.
10136-8{_}23099{_}INDIAN-CORN-FLOUR BREAD.
10136-8{_}23100{_}1721.
10136-8{_}23101{_}INGREDIENTS.--To 4 lbs.
10136-8{_}23102{_}of flour allow 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}23103{_}of Indian-corn flour, 2 tablespoonfuls of yeast, 3 pints of warm water, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}23104{_}of salt.
10136-8{_}23105{_}_Mode_.--Mix the two flours well together, with the salt; make a hole in the centre, and stir the yeast up well with 1/2 pint of the warm water; put this into the middle of the flour, and mix enough of it with the yeast to make a thin batter; throw a little flour over the surface of this batter, cover the whole with a thick cloth, and set it to rise in a warm place.
10136-8{_}23106{_}When the batter has nicely risen, work the whole to a nice smooth dough, adding the water as required; knead it well, and mould the dough into loaves; let them rise for nearly 1/2 hour, then put them into a well-heated oven.
10136-8{_}23107{_}If made into 2 loaves, they will require from 1-1/2 to 2 hours baking.
10136-8{_}23108{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 to 2 hours.
10136-8{_}23109{_}[Illustration: MAIZE PLANT.]
10136-8{_}23110{_}[Illustration: EAR OF MAIZE.]
10136-8{_}23111{_}MAIZE.--Next to wheat and rice, maize is the grain most used in     the nourishment of man.
10136-8{_}23112{_}In Asia, Africa, and America, it is the     principal daily food of a large portion of the population,     especially of the colonists.
10136-8{_}23113{_}In some of the provinces of France,     too, it is consumed in large quantities.
10136-8{_}23114{_}There are eight     varieties of the maize; the most productive is the maize of     Cusco.
10136-8{_}23115{_}The flour of maize is yellow, and it contains an oily     matter, which, when fresh, gives it an agreeable flavour and     odour; but the action of the air on it soon develops rancidity.
10136-8{_}23116{_}If carried any distance, it should be stored away in air-tight     vessels.
10136-8{_}23117{_}An excellent soup is prepared with meat and     maize-flour.
10136-8{_}23118{_}The inhabitants of some countries, where wheat is     scarce, make, with maize and water, or milk and salt, a kind of     biscuit, which is pleasant in taste, but indigestible.
10136-8{_}23119{_}Some of     the preparations of maize-flour are very good, and, when     partaken in moderation, suitable food for almost everybody.
10136-8{_}23120{_}SODA BREAD.
10136-8{_}23121{_}1722.
10136-8{_}23122{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every 2 lbs.
