10136-8{_}23123{_}of flour allow 1 teaspoonful of tartaric acid, 1 teaspoonful of salt, 1 teaspoonful of carbonate of soda, 2 breakfast-cupfuls of cold milk.
10136-8{_}23124{_}_Mode_.--Let the tartaric acid and salt be reduced to the finest possible powder; then mix them well with the flour.
10136-8{_}23125{_}Dissolve the soda in the milk, and pour it several times from one basin to another, before adding it to the flour.
10136-8{_}23126{_}Work the whole quickly into a light dough, divide it into 2 loaves, and put them into a well-heated oven immediately, and bake for an hour.
10136-8{_}23127{_}Sour milk or buttermilk may be used, but then a little less acid will be needed.
10136-8{_}23128{_}_Time_.--1 hour.
10136-8{_}23129{_}POLISH AND POMERANIAN WHEAT are accounted by authorities most     excellent.
10136-8{_}23130{_}Large raft-like barges convey this grain down the     rivers, from the interior of the country to the seaports.
10136-8{_}23131{_}This     corn is described as being white, hard, and thin-skinned; and it     yields a large quantity of flour, having a small proportion of     bran.
10136-8{_}23132{_}EXCELLENT ROLLS.
10136-8{_}23133{_}1723.
10136-8{_}23134{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}23135{_}of flour allow 1 oz.
10136-8{_}23136{_}of butter, 1/4 pint of milk, 1 large teaspoonful of yeast, a little salt.
10136-8{_}23137{_}[Illustration: ROLLS.]
10136-8{_}23138{_}_Mode_.--Warm the butter in the milk, add to it the yeast and salt, and mix these ingredients well together.
10136-8{_}23139{_}Put the flour into a pan, stir in the above ingredients, and let the dough rise, covered in a warm place.
10136-8{_}23140{_}Knead it well, make it into rolls, let them rise again for a few minutes, and bake in a quick oven.
10136-8{_}23141{_}Richer rolls may be made by adding 1 or 2 eggs and a larger proportion of butter, and their appearance improved by brushing the tops over with yolk of egg or a little milk.
10136-8{_}23142{_}_Time_--1 lb.
10136-8{_}23143{_}of flour, divided into 6 rolls, from 15 to 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}23144{_}HOT ROLLS.
10136-8{_}23145{_}1724.
10136-8{_}23146{_}This dish, although very unwholesome and indigestible, is nevertheless a great favourite, and eaten by many persons.
10136-8{_}23147{_}As soon as the rolls come from the baker's, they should be put into the oven, which, in the early part of the morning, is sure not to be very hot; and the rolls must not be buttered until wanted.
10136-8{_}23148{_}When they are quite hot, divide them lengthwise into three; put some thin flakes of good butter between the slices, press the rolls together, and put them in the oven for a minute or two, but not longer, or the butter would oil; take them out of the oven, spread the butter equally over, divide the rolls in half, and put them on to a very hot clean dish, and send them instantly to table.
10136-8{_}23149{_}TO MAKE DRY TOAST.
10136-8{_}23150{_}1725.
10136-8{_}23151{_}To make dry toast properly, a great deal of attention is required; much more, indeed, than people generally suppose.
10136-8{_}23152{_}Never use new bread for making any kind of toast, as it eats heavy, and, besides, is very extravagant.
10136-8{_}23153{_}Procure a loaf of household bread about two days old; cut off as many slices as may be required, not quite 1/4 inch in thickness; trim off the crusts and ragged edges, put the bread on a toasting-fork, and hold it before a very clear fire.
10136-8{_}23154{_}Move it backwards and forwards until the bread is nicely coloured; then turn it and toast the other side, and do not place it so near the fire that it blackens.
10136-8{_}23155{_}Dry toast should be more gradually made than buttered toast, as its great beauty consists in its crispness, and this cannot be attained unless the process is slow and the bread is allowed gradually to colour.
10136-8{_}23156{_}It should never be made long before it is wanted, as it soon becomes tough, unless placed on the fender in front of the fire.
10136-8{_}23157{_}As soon as each piece is ready, it should be put into a rack, or stood upon its edges, and sent quickly to table.
10136-8{_}23158{_}TO MAKE HOT BUTTERED TOAST.
10136-8{_}23159{_}1726.
10136-8{_}23160{_}A loaf of household bread about two days old answers for making toast better than cottage bread, the latter not being a good shape, and too crusty for the purpose.
10136-8{_}23161{_}Cut as many nice even slices as may be required, rather more than 1/4 inch in thickness, and toast them before a very bright fire, without allowing the bread to blacken, which spoils the appearance and flavour of all toast.
10136-8{_}23162{_}When of a nice colour on both sides, put it on a hot plate; divide some good butter into small pieces, place them on the toast, set this before the fire, and when the butter is just beginning to melt, spread it lightly over the toast.
10136-8{_}23163{_}Trim off the crust and ragged edges, divide each round into 4 pieces, and send the toast quickly to table.
10136-8{_}23164{_}Some persons cut the slices of toast across from corner to corner, so making the pieces of a three-cornered shape.
10136-8{_}23165{_}Soyer recommends that each slice should be cut into pieces as soon as it is buttered, and when all are ready, that they should be piled lightly on the dish they are intended to be served on.
10136-8{_}23166{_}He says that by cutting through 4 or 5 slices at a time, all the butter is squeezed out of the upper ones, while the bottom one is swimming in fat liquid.
10136-8{_}23167{_}It is highly essential to use good butter for making this dish.
10136-8{_}23168{_}MUFFINS.
10136-8{_}23169{_}1727.
10136-8{_}23170{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every quart of milk allow 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}23171{_}of German yeast, a little salt; flour.
10136-8{_}23172{_}[Illustration: MUFFINS.]
10136-8{_}23173{_}_Mode_.--Warm the milk, add to it the yeast, and mix these well together; put them into a pan, and stir in sufficient flour to make the whole into a dough of rather a soft consistence; cover it over with a cloth, and place it in a warm place to rise, and, when light and nicely risen, divide the dough into pieces, and round them to the proper shape with the hands; place them, in a layer of flour about two inches thick, on wooden trays, and let them rise again; when this is effected, they each will exhibit a semi-globular shape.
10136-8{_}23174{_}Then place them carefully on a hot-plate or stove, and bake them until they are slightly browned, turning them when they are done on one side.
10136-8{_}23175{_}Muffins are not easily made, and are more generally purchased than manufactured at home.
10136-8{_}23176{_}_To toast them_, divide the edge of the muffin all round, by pulling it open, to the depth of about an inch, with the fingers.
10136-8{_}23177{_}Put it on a toasting-fork, and hold it before a very clear fire until one side is nicely browned, but not burnt; turn, and toast it on the other.
10136-8{_}23178{_}Do not toast them too quickly, as, if this is done, the middle of the muffin will not be warmed through.
10136-8{_}23179{_}When done, divide them by pulling them open; butter them slightly on both sides, put them together again, and cut them into halves: when sufficient are toasted and buttered, pile them on a very hot dish, and send them very quickly to table.
10136-8{_}23180{_}_Time_.--From 20 minutes to 1/2 hour to bake them.
10136-8{_}23181{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 1 muffin to each person.
10136-8{_}23182{_}CRUMPETS.
10136-8{_}23183{_}[Illustration: CRUMPETS.]
10136-8{_}23184{_}1728.
10136-8{_}23185{_}These are made in the same manner as muffins; only, in making the mixture, let it be more like batter than dough.
10136-8{_}23186{_}Let it rise for about 1/2 hour; pour it into iron rings, which should be ready on a hot-plate; bake them, and when one side appears done, turn them quickly on the other.
10136-8{_}23187{_}_To toast them_, have ready a very _bright clear_ fire; put the crumpet on a toasting-fork, and hold it before the fire, _not too close_, until it is nicely brown on one side, but do not allow it to blacken.
10136-8{_}23188{_}Turn it, and brown the other side; then spread it with good butter, cut it in half, and, when all are done, pile them on a hot dish, and send them quickly to table.
10136-8{_}23189{_}Muffins and crumpets should always be served on separate dishes, and both toasted and served as expeditiously as possible.
10136-8{_}23190{_}_Time_.--From 10 to 15 minutes to bake them.
10136-8{_}23191{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 2 crumpets to each person.
10136-8{_}23192{_}PLAIN BUNS.
10136-8{_}23193{_}1729.
10136-8{_}23194{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}23195{_}of flour allow 6 oz.
10136-8{_}23196{_}of moist sugar, 1/2 gill of yeast, 1/2 pint of milk, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23197{_}of butter, warm milk.
10136-8{_}23198{_}_Mode_.--Put the flour into a basin, mix the sugar well with it, make a hole in the centre, and stir in the yeast and milk (which should be lukewarm), with enough of the flour to make it the thickness of cream.
10136-8{_}23199{_}Cover the basin over with a cloth, and let the sponge rise in a warm place, which will be accomplished in about 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}23200{_}Melt the butter, but do not allow it to oil; stir it into the other ingredients, with enough warm milk to make the whole into a soft dough; then mould it into buns about the size of an egg; lay them in rows quite 3 inches apart; set them again in a warm place, until they have risen to double their size; then put them into a good brisk oven, and just before they are done, wash them over with a little milk.
10136-8{_}23201{_}From 15 to 20 minutes will be required to bake them nicely.
10136-8{_}23202{_}These buns may be varied by adding a few currants, candied peel, or caraway seeds to the other ingredients; and the above mixture answers for hot cross buns, by putting in a little ground allspice; and by pressing a tin mould in the form of a cross in the centre of the bun.
10136-8{_}23203{_}_Time_.--15 to 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}23204{_}_Average cost_, 1d.
10136-8{_}23205{_}each.
10136-8{_}23206{_}_Sufficient_ to make 18 buns.
10136-8{_}23207{_}TO MAKE GOOD PLAIN BUNS.
10136-8{_}23208{_}1730.
10136-8{_}23209{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}23210{_}of flour, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}23211{_}of good butter, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23212{_}of sugar, 1 egg, nearly 1/4 pint of milk, 2 small teaspoonfuls of baking-powder, a few drops of essence of lemon.
10136-8{_}23213{_}_Mode_.--Warm the butter, without oiling it; beat it with a wooden spoon; stir the flour in gradually with the sugar, and mix these ingredients well together.
10136-8{_}23214{_}Make the milk lukewarm, beat up with it the yolk of the egg and the essence of lemon, and stir these to the flour, &c. Add the baking-powder, beat the dough well for about 10 minutes, divide it into 24 pieces, put them into buttered tins or cups, and bake in a brisk oven from 20 to 30 minutes.
10136-8{_}23215{_}_Time_.--20 to 30 minutes.
10136-8{_}23216{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23217{_}_Sufficient_ to make 12 buns.
10136-8{_}23218{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23219{_}LIGHT BUNS.
10136-8{_}23220{_}[Illustration: BUNS.]
10136-8{_}23221{_}1731.
10136-8{_}23222{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 teaspoonful of tartaric acid, 1/2 teaspoonful of bicarbonate of soda, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}23223{_}of flour, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}23224{_}of butter, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}23225{_}of loaf sugar, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23226{_}of currants or raisins,--when liked, a few caraway seeds, 1/2 pint of cold new milk, 1 egg.
10136-8{_}23227{_}_Mode_.--Rub the tartaric acid, soda, and flour all together through a hair sieve; work the butter into the flour; add the sugar, currants, and caraway seeds, when the flavour of them latter is liked.
10136-8{_}23228{_}Mix all these ingredients well together; make a hole in the middle of the flour, and pour in the milk, mixed with the egg, which should be well beaten; mix quickly, and set the dough, with a fork, on baking-tins, and bake the buns for about 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}23229{_}This mixture makes a very good cake, and if put into a tin, should be baked 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}23230{_}The same quantity of flour, soda, and tartaric acid, with 1/2 pint of milk and a little salt, will make either bread or teacakes, if wanted quickly.
10136-8{_}23231{_}_Time_.--20 minutes for the buns; if made into a cake, 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}23232{_}_Sufficient_ to make about 12 buns.
10136-8{_}23233{_}VICTORIA BUNS.
10136-8{_}23234{_}1732.
10136-8{_}23235{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 oz.
10136-8{_}23236{_}of pounded loaf sugar, 1 egg, 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}23237{_}of ground rice, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}23238{_}of butter, 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}23239{_}of currants, a few thin slices of candied peel; flour.
10136-8{_}23240{_}_Mode_.--Whisk the egg, stir in the sugar, and beat these ingredients well together; beat the butter to a cream, stir in the ground rice, currants, and candied peel, and as much flour as will make it of such a consistency that it may be rolled into 7 or 8 balls.
10136-8{_}23241{_}Put these on to a buttered tin, and bake them from 1/2 to 3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}23242{_}They should be put into the oven immediately, or they will become heavy; and the oven should be tolerably brisk.
10136-8{_}23243{_}_Time_.--1/2 to 3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}23244{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}23245{_}_Sufficient_ to make 7 or 8 buns.
10136-8{_}23246{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23247{_}ITALIAN RUSKS.
10136-8{_}23248{_}1733.
10136-8{_}23249{_}A stale Savoy or lemon cake may be converted into very good rusks in the following manner.
10136-8{_}23250{_}Cut the cake into slices, divide each slice in two; put them on a baking-sheet, in a slow oven, and when they are of a nice brown and quite hard, they are done.
10136-8{_}23251{_}They should be kept in a closed tin canister in a dry place, to preserve their crispness.
10136-8{_}23252{_}[Illustration: PANNICLED MILLET.]
10136-8{_}23253{_}PANNICLED MILLET.--This is the smallest-seeded of the     corn-plants, being a true grass; but the number of the seeds in     each ear makes up for their size.
10136-8{_}23254{_}It grows in sandy soils that     will not do for the cultivation of many other kinds of grain,     and forms the chief sustenance in the arid districts of Arabia,     Syria, Nubia, and parts of India.
10136-8{_}23255{_}It is not cultivated in     England, being principally confined to the East.
10136-8{_}23256{_}The nations who     make use of it grind it, in the primitive manner, between two     stones, and make it into a diet which, cannot be properly called     bread, but rather a kind of soft thin cake half-baked.
10136-8{_}23257{_}When we     take into account that the Arabians are fond of lizards and     locusts as articles of food, their _cuisine_, altogether, is     scarcely a tempting one.
10136-8{_}23258{_}TO MAKE RUSKS.
10136-8{_}23259{_}(_Suffolk Recipe_.)
10136-8{_}23260{_}1734.
10136-8{_}23261{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}23262{_}of flour allow 2 oz.
10136-8{_}23263{_}of butter, 1/4 pint of milk, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}23264{_}of loaf sugar, 3 eggs, 1 tablespoonful of yeast.
10136-8{_}23265{_}[Illustration: RUSKS.]
10136-8{_}23266{_}_Mode_.--Put the milk and butter into a saucepan, and keep shaking it round until the latter is melted.
10136-8{_}23267{_}Put the flour into a basin with the sugar, mix these well together, and beat the eggs.
10136-8{_}23268{_}Stir them with the yeast to the milk and butter, and with this liquid work the flour into a smooth dough.
10136-8{_}23269{_}Cover a cloth over the basin, and leave the dough to rise by the side of the fire; then knead it, and divide it into 12 pieces; place them in a brisk oven, and bake for about 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}23270{_}Take the rusks out, break them in half, and then set them in the oven to get crisp on the other side.
10136-8{_}23271{_}When cold, they should be put into tin canisters to keep them dry; and, if intended for the cheese course, the sifted sugar should be omitted.
10136-8{_}23272{_}_Time_.--20 minutes to bake the rusks; 5 minutes to render them crisp after being divided.
10136-8{_}23273{_}_Average cost_, 8d.
10136-8{_}23274{_}_Sufficient_ to make 2 dozen rusks.
10136-8{_}23275{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23276{_}ALMOND ICING FOR CAKES.
10136-8{_}23277{_}1735.
10136-8{_}23278{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}23279{_}of finely-pounded loaf sugar allow 1 lb.
10136-8{_}23280{_}of sweet almonds, the whites of 4 eggs, a little rose-water.
10136-8{_}23281{_}_Mode_.--Blanch the almonds, and pound them (a few at a time) in a mortar to a paste, adding a little rose-water to facilitate the operation.
10136-8{_}23282{_}Whisk the whites of the eggs to a strong froth; mix them with the pounded almonds, stir in the sugar, and beat altogether.
10136-8{_}23283{_}When the cake is sufficiently baked, lay on the almond icing, and put it into the oven to dry.
10136-8{_}23284{_}Before laying this preparation on the cake, great care must be taken that it is nice and smooth, which is easily accomplished by well beating the mixture.
10136-8{_}23285{_}SUGAR ICING FOR CAKES.
10136-8{_}23286{_}1736.
10136-8{_}23287{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}23288{_}of loaf sugar allow the whites of 4 eggs, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}23289{_}of fine starch.
10136-8{_}23290{_}_Mode_.--Beat the eggs to a strong froth, and gradually sift in the sugar, which should be reduced to the finest possible powder, and gradually add the starch, also finely powdered.
10136-8{_}23291{_}Beat the mixture well until the sugar is smooth; then with a spoon or broad knife lay the icing equally over the cakes.
10136-8{_}23292{_}These should then be placed in a very cool oven, and the icing allowed to dry and harden, but not to colour.
10136-8{_}23293{_}The icing may be coloured with strawberry or currant-juice, or with prepared cochineal.
10136-8{_}23294{_}If it be put on the cakes as soon as they are withdrawn from the oven, it will become firm and hard by the time the cakes are cold.
10136-8{_}23295{_}On very rich cakes, such as wedding, christening cakes, &c., a layer of almond icing, No.
10136-8{_}23296{_}1735, is usually spread over the top, and over that the white icing as described.
10136-8{_}23297{_}All iced cakes should be kept in a very dry place.
10136-8{_}23298{_}BISCUIT POWDER, generally used for Infants' Food.
10136-8{_}23299{_}1737.
10136-8{_}23300{_}This powder may be purchased in tin canisters, and may also be prepared at home.
10136-8{_}23301{_}Dry the biscuits well in a slow oven; roll them and grind them with a rolling-pin on a clean board, until they are reduced to powder; sift it through a close hair sieve, and it is fit for use.
10136-8{_}23302{_}It should be kept in well-covered tins, and in a dry place.
10136-8{_}23303{_}ARROWROOT BISCUITS OR DROPS.
10136-8{_}23304{_}1738.
10136-8{_}23305{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23306{_}of butter, 6 eggs, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23307{_}of flour, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}23308{_}of arrowroot, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23309{_}of pounded loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}23310{_}_Mode_.--Beat the butter to a cream; whisk the eggs to a strong froth, add them to the butter, stir in the flour a little at a time, and beat the mixture well.
10136-8{_}23311{_}Break down all the lumps from the arrowroot, and add that with the sugar to the other ingredients.
10136-8{_}23312{_}Mix all well together, drop the dough on a buttered tin, in pieces the size of a shilling, and bake the biscuits about 1/4 hour in a slow oven.
10136-8{_}23313{_}_Time_.--1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}23314{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}23315{_}6d.
10136-8{_}23316{_}_Sufficient_ to make from 3 to 4 dozen biscuits.
10136-8{_}23317{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23318{_}NICE BREAKFAST CAKES.
10136-8{_}23319{_}1739.
10136-8{_}23320{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}23321{_}of flour, 1/2 teaspoonful of tartaric acid, 1/2 teaspoonful of salt, 1/2 teaspoonful of carbonate of soda, 1-1/2 breakfast-cupful of milk, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}23322{_}of sifted loaf sugar, 2 eggs.
10136-8{_}23323{_}_Mode_.--These cakes are made in the same manner as the soda bread No.
10136-8{_}23324{_}1722, with the addition of eggs and sugar.
10136-8{_}23325{_}Mix the flour, tartaric acid, and salt well together, taking care that the two latter ingredients are reduced to the finest powder, and stir in the sifted sugar, which should also be very fine.
10136-8{_}23326{_}Dissolve the soda in the milk, add the eggs, which should be well whisked, and with this liquid work the flour, &c. into a light dough.
10136-8{_}23327{_}Divide it into small cakes, put them into the oven immediately, and bake for about 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}23328{_}_Time_.--20 minutes.
10136-8{_}23329{_}COCOA-NUT BISCUITS OR CAKES.
10136-8{_}23330{_}1740.
10136-8{_}23331{_}INGREDIENTS.--10 oz.
10136-8{_}23332{_}of sifted sugar, 3 eggs, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}23333{_}of grated cocoa-nut.
10136-8{_}23334{_}_Mode_.--Whisk the eggs until they are very light; add the sugar gradually; then stir in the cocoa-nut.
10136-8{_}23335{_}Roll a tablespoonful of the paste at a time in your hands in the form of a pyramid; place the pyramids on paper, put the paper on tins, and bake the biscuits in rather a cool oven until they are just coloured a light brown.
10136-8{_}23336{_}_Time_.--About 1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}23337{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23338{_}CRISP BISCUITS.
10136-8{_}23339{_}1741.
10136-8{_}23340{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}23341{_}of flour, the yolk of 1 egg, milk.
10136-8{_}23342{_}_Mode_.--Mix the flour and the yolk of the egg with sufficient milk to make the whole into a very stiff paste; beat it well, and knead it until it is perfectly smooth.
10136-8{_}23343{_}Roll the paste out very thin; with a round cutter shape it into small biscuits, and bake them a nice brown in a slow oven from 12 to 18 minutes.
10136-8{_}23344{_}_Time_.--12 to 18 minutes.
10136-8{_}23345{_}_Average cost_, 4d.
10136-8{_}23346{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23347{_}DESSERT BISCUITS, which may be flavoured with Ground Ginger, Cinnamon, &c. &c.  1742.
10136-8{_}23348{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}23349{_}of flour, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23350{_}of butter, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23351{_}of sifted sugar, the yolks of 6 eggs, flavouring to taste.
10136-8{_}23352{_}_Mode_.--Put the butter into a basin; warm it, but do not allow it to oil; then with the hand beat it to a cream.
10136-8{_}23353{_}Add the flour by degrees, then the sugar and flavouring, and moisten the whole with the yolks of the eggs, which should previously be well beaten.
10136-8{_}23354{_}When all the ingredients are thoroughly incorporated, drop the mixture from a spoon on to a buttered paper, leaving a distance between each cake, as they spread as soon as they begin to get warm.
10136-8{_}23355{_}Bake in rather a slow oven from 12 to 18 minutes, and do not let the biscuits acquire too much colour.
10136-8{_}23356{_}In making the above quantity, half may be flavoured with ground ginger and the other half with essence of lemon or currants, to make a variety.
10136-8{_}23357{_}With whatever the preparation is flavoured, so are the biscuits called; and an endless variety may be made in this manner.
10136-8{_}23358{_}_Time_.--12 to 18 minutes, or rather longer, in a very slow oven.
10136-8{_}23359{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23360{_}6d.
10136-8{_}23361{_}_Sufficient_ to make from 3 to 4 dozen cakes.
10136-8{_}23362{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23363{_}LEMON BISCUITS.
10136-8{_}23364{_}1743--INGREDIENTS.--1-1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23365{_}of flour, 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23366{_}of loaf sugar, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}23367{_}of fresh butter, 4 eggs, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}23368{_}of lemon-peel, 2 dessertspoonfuls of lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}23369{_}_Mode_.--Rub the flour into the butter; stir in the pounded sugar and very finely-minced lemon-peel, and when these ingredients are thoroughly mixed, add the eggs, which should be previously well whisked, and the lemon-juice.
10136-8{_}23370{_}Beat the mixture well for a minute or two, then drop it from a spoon on to a buttered tin, about 2 inches apart, as the cakes will spread when they get warm; place the tin in the oven, and bake the cakes of a pale brown from 15 to 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}23371{_}_Time_.--15 to 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}23372{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23373{_}6d.
10136-8{_}23374{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23375{_}MACAROONS.
10136-8{_}23376{_}1744.
10136-8{_}23377{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23378{_}of sweet almonds, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23379{_}of sifted loaf sugar, the whites of 3 eggs, wafer-paper.
10136-8{_}23380{_}[Illustration: MACAROONS.]
10136-8{_}23381{_}_Mode_.--Blanch, skin, and dry the almonds, and pound them well with a little orange-flower water or plain water; then add to them the sifted sugar and the whites of the eggs, which should be beaten to a stiff froth, and mix all the ingredients well together.
10136-8{_}23382{_}When the paste looks soft, drop it at equal distances from a biscuit-syringe on to sheets of wafer-paper; put a strip of almond on the top of each; strew some sugar over, and bake the macaroons in rather a slow oven, of a light brown colour when hard and set, they are done, and must not be allowed to get very brown, as that would spoil their appearance.
10136-8{_}23383{_}If the cakes, when baked, appear heavy, add a little more white of egg, but let this always be well whisked before it is added to the other ingredients.
10136-8{_}23384{_}We have given a recipe for making these cakes, but we think it almost or quite as economical to purchase such articles as these at a good confectioner's.
10136-8{_}23385{_}_Time_.--From 15 to 20 minutes, in a slow oven.
10136-8{_}23386{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23387{_}8d.
10136-8{_}23388{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}23389{_}RATAFIAS.
10136-8{_}23390{_}[Illustration: RATAFIAS.]
10136-8{_}23391{_}1745.
10136-8{_}23392{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23393{_}of sweet almonds, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23394{_}of bitter ones, 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23395{_}of sifted loaf sugar, the whites of 4 eggs.
10136-8{_}23396{_}_Mode_.--Blanch, skin, and dry the almonds, and pound them in a mortar with the white of an egg; stir in the sugar, and gradually add the remaining whites of eggs, taking care that they are very thoroughly whisked.
10136-8{_}23397{_}Drop the mixture through a small biscuit-syringe on to cartridge paper, and bake the cakes from 10 to 12 minutes in rather a quicker oven than for macaroons.
10136-8{_}23398{_}A very small quantity should be dropped on the paper to form one cake, as, when baked, the ratafias should be about the size of a large button.
10136-8{_}23399{_}_Time_.--10 to 12 minutes.
10136-8{_}23400{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23401{_}8d.
10136-8{_}23402{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}23403{_}RICE BISCUITS OR CAKES.
10136-8{_}23404{_}1746.
10136-8{_}23405{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23406{_}of rice-flour allow 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23407{_}of pounded lump sugar, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23408{_}of butter, 2 eggs.
10136-8{_}23409{_}_Mode_.--Beat the butter to a cream, stir in the rice-flour and pounded sugar, and moisten the whole with the eggs, which should be previously well beaten.
10136-8{_}23410{_}Roll out the paste, shape it with a round paste-cutter into small cakes, and bake them from 12 to 18 minutes in a very slow oven.
10136-8{_}23411{_}_Time_.--12 to 18 minutes.
10136-8{_}23412{_}_Average cost_, 9d.
10136-8{_}23413{_}_Sufficient_ to make about 18 cakes.
10136-8{_}23414{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23415{_}GROUND RICE, or rice-flour, is used for making several kinds of     cakes, also for thickening soups, and for mixing with wheaten     flour in producing Manna Kroup.
10136-8{_}23416{_}The Americans make rice-bread,     and prepare the flour for it in the following manner:--When the     rice is thoroughly cleansed, the water is drawn off, and the     rice, while damp, bruised in a mortar: it is then dried, and     passed through a hair sieve.
10136-8{_}23417{_}ROCK BISCUITS.
10136-8{_}23418{_}1747.
10136-8{_}23419{_}INGREDIENTS.--6 eggs, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}23420{_}of sifted sugar, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23421{_}of flour, a few currants.
10136-8{_}23422{_}_Mode_.--Break the eggs into a basin, beat them well until very light, add the pounded sugar, and when this is well mixed with the eggs, dredge in the flour gradually, and add the currants.
10136-8{_}23423{_}Mix all well together, and put the dough, with a fork, on the tins, making it look as rough as possible.
10136-8{_}23424{_}Bake the cakes in a moderate oven from 20 minutes to 1/2 hour; when they are done, allow them to get cool, and store them away in a tin canister, in a dry place.
10136-8{_}23425{_}_Time_.--20 minutes to 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}23426{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23427{_}2d.
10136-8{_}23428{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23429{_}SAVOY BISCUITS OR CAKES.
10136-8{_}23430{_}1748.
10136-8{_}23431{_}INGREDIENTS.--4 eggs, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}23432{_}of pounded sugar, the rind of 1 lemon, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}23433{_}of flour.
10136-8{_}23434{_}_Mode_.--Break the eggs into a basin, separating the whites from the yolks; beat the yolks well, mix with them the pounded sugar and grated lemon-rind, and beat these ingredients together for 1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}23435{_}Then dredge in the flour gradually, and when the whites of the eggs have been whisked to a solid froth, stir them to the flour, &c.; beat the mixture well for another 5 minutes, then draw it along in strips upon thick cartridge paper to the proper size of the biscuit, and bake them in rather a hot oven; but let them be carefully watched, as they are soon done, and a few seconds over the proper time will scorch and spoil them.
10136-8{_}23436{_}These biscuits, or ladies'-fingers, as they are called, are used for making Charlotte russes, and for a variety of fancy sweet dishes.
10136-8{_}23437{_}_Time_.--5 to 8 minutes, in a quick oven.
10136-8{_}23438{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23439{_}8d.
10136-8{_}23440{_}per lb., or 1/2d.
10136-8{_}23441{_}each.
10136-8{_}23442{_}SEED BISCUITS.
10136-8{_}23443{_}1749.
10136-8{_}23444{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}23445{_}of flour, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23446{_}of sifted sugar, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23447{_}of butter, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}23448{_}of caraway seeds, 3 eggs.
10136-8{_}23449{_}_Mode_.--Beat the butter to a cream; stir in the flour, sugar, and caraway seeds; and when these ingredients are well mixed, add the eggs, which should be well whisked.
10136-8{_}23450{_}Roll out the paste, with a round cutter shape out the biscuits, and bake them in a moderate oven from 10 to 15 minutes.
10136-8{_}23451{_}The tops of the biscuits may be brushed over with a little milk or the white of an egg, and then a little sugar strewn over.
10136-8{_}23452{_}_Time_.--10 to 15 minutes.
10136-8{_}23453{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23454{_}_Sufficient_ to make 3 dozen biscuits.
10136-8{_}23455{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23456{_}SIMPLE HARD BISCUITS.
10136-8{_}23457{_}1750.
10136-8{_}23458{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every lb.
10136-8{_}23459{_}of flour allow 2 oz.
10136-8{_}23460{_}of butter, about 1/2 pint of skimmed milk.
10136-8{_}23461{_}_Mode_.--Warm the butter in the milk until the former is dissolved, and then mix it with the flour into a very stiff paste; beat it with a rolling-pin until the dough looks perfectly smooth.
10136-8{_}23462{_}Roll it out thin; cut it with the top of a glass into round biscuits; prick them well, and bake them from 6 to 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}23463{_}The above is the proportion of milk which we think would convert the flour into a stiff paste; but should it be found too much, an extra spoonful or two of flour must be put in.
10136-8{_}23464{_}These biscuits are very nice for the cheese course.
10136-8{_}23465{_}_Time_.--6 to 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}23466{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23467{_}SODA BISCUITS.
10136-8{_}23468{_}1751.
10136-8{_}23469{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}23470{_}of flour, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23471{_}of pounded loaf sugar, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23472{_}of fresh butter, 2 eggs, 1 small teaspoonful of carbonate of soda.
10136-8{_}23473{_}_Mode_.--Put the flour (which should be perfectly dry) into a basin; rub in the butter, add the sugar, and mix these ingredients well together.
10136-8{_}23474{_}Whisk the eggs, stir them into the mixture, and beat it well, until everything is well incorporated.
10136-8{_}23475{_}Quickly stir in the soda, roll the paste out until it is about 1/2 inch thick, cut it into small round cakes with a tin cutter, and bake them from 12 to 18 minutes in rather a brisk oven.
10136-8{_}23476{_}After the soda is added, great expedition is necessary in rolling and cutting out the paste, and in putting the biscuits _immediately_ into the oven, or they will be heavy.
10136-8{_}23477{_}_Time_.--12 to 18 minutes.
10136-8{_}23478{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23479{_}_Sufficient_ to make about 3 dozen cakes.
10136-8{_}23480{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23481{_}ALMOND CAKE.
10136-8{_}23482{_}1752.
10136-8{_}23483{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23484{_}of sweet almonds, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}23485{_}of bitter almonds, 6 eggs, 8 tablespoonfuls of sifted sugar, 5 tablespoonfuls of fine flour, the grated rind of 1 lemon, 3 oz.
10136-8{_}23486{_}of butter.
10136-8{_}23487{_}_Mode_.--Blanch and pound the almonds to a paste; separate the whites from the yolks of the eggs; beat the latter, and add them to the almonds.
10136-8{_}23488{_}Stir in the sugar, flour, and lemon-rind; add the butter, which should be beaten to a cream; and when all these ingredients are well mixed, put in the whites of the eggs, which should be whisked to a stiff froth.
10136-8{_}23489{_}Butter a cake-mould, put in the mixture, and bake in a good oven from 1-1/4 to 1-3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}23490{_}_Time_.--1-1/4 to 1-3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}23491{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23492{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23493{_}RICH BRIDE OR CHRISTENING CAKE.
10136-8{_}23494{_}1753.
10136-8{_}23495{_}INGREDIENTS.--5 lbs.
10136-8{_}23496{_}of the finest flour, 3 lbs.
10136-8{_}23497{_}of fresh butter, 5 lbs.
10136-8{_}23498{_}of currants, 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}23499{_}of sifted loaf sugar, 2 nutmegs, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}23500{_}of mace, half 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}23501{_}of cloves, 16 eggs, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}23502{_}of sweet almonds, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23503{_}of candied citron, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23504{_}each of candied orange and lemon peel, 1 gill of wine, 1 gill of brandy.
10136-8{_}23505{_}_Mode_.--Let the flour be as fine as possible, and well dried and sifted; the currants washed, picked, and dried before the fire; the sugar well pounded and sifted; the nutmegs grated, the spices pounded; the eggs thoroughly whisked, whites and yolks separately; the almonds pounded with a little orange-flower water, and the candied peel cut in neat slices.
10136-8{_}23506{_}When all these ingredients are prepared, mix them in the following manner.
10136-8{_}23507{_}Begin working the butter with the hand till it becomes of a cream-like consistency; stir in the sugar, and when the whites of the eggs are whisked to a solid froth, mix them with the butter and sugar; next, well beat up the yolks for 10 minutes, and, adding them to the flour, nutmegs, mace, and cloves, continue beating the whole together for 1/2 hour or longer, till wanted for the oven.
10136-8{_}23508{_}Then mix in lightly the currants, almonds, and candied peel with the wine and brandy; and having lined a hoop with buttered paper, fill it with the mixture, and bake the cake in a tolerably quick oven, taking care, however, not to burn it: to prevent this, the top of it may be covered with a sheet of paper.
10136-8{_}23509{_}To ascertain whether the cake is done, plunge a clean knife into the middle of it, withdraw it directly, and if the blade is not sticky, and looks bright, the cake is sufficiently baked.
10136-8{_}23510{_}These cakes are usually spread with a thick layer of almond icing, and over that another layer of sugar icing, and afterwards ornamented.
10136-8{_}23511{_}In baking a large cake like this, great attention must be paid to the heat of the oven; it should not be too fierce, but have a good soaking heat.
10136-8{_}23512{_}_Time_.--5 to 6 hours.
10136-8{_}23513{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}23514{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}23515{_}CHRISTMAS CAKE.
10136-8{_}23516{_}1754.
10136-8{_}23517{_}INGREDIENTS.--5 teacupfuls of flour, 1 teacupful of melted butter, 1 teacupful of cream, 1 teacupful of treacle, 1 teacupful of moist sugar, 2 eggs, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}23518{_}of powdered ginger, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23519{_}of raisins, 1 teaspoonful of carbonate of soda, 1 tablespoonful of vinegar.
10136-8{_}23520{_}_Mode_.--Make the butter sufficiently warm to melt it, but do not allow it to oil; put the flour into a basin; add to it the sugar, ginger, and raisins, which should be stoned and cut into small pieces.
10136-8{_}23521{_}When these dry ingredients are thoroughly mixed, stir in the butter, cream, treacle, and well-whisked eggs, and beat the mixture for a few minutes.
10136-8{_}23522{_}Dissolve the soda in the vinegar, add it to the dough, and be particular that these latter ingredients are well incorporated with the others; put the cake into a buttered mould or tin, place it in a moderate oven immediately, and bake it from 1-3/4 to 2-1/4 hours.
10136-8{_}23523{_}_Time_.--1-3/4 to 2-1/4 hours.
10136-8{_}23524{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23525{_}6d.
10136-8{_}23526{_}COMMON CAKE, suitable for sending to Children at School.
10136-8{_}23527{_}1755.
10136-8{_}23528{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 lbs.
10136-8{_}23529{_}of flour, 4 oz.
10136-8{_}23530{_}of butter or clarified dripping, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}23531{_}of caraway seeds, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}23532{_}of allspice, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23533{_}of pounded sugar, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}23534{_}of currants, 1 pint of milk, 3 tablespoonfuls of fresh yeast.
10136-8{_}23535{_}_Mode_.--Rub the butter lightly into the flour; add all the dry ingredients, and mix these well together.
10136-8{_}23536{_}Make the milk warm, but not hot; stir in the yeast, and with this liquid make the whole into a light dough; knead it well, and line the cake-tins with strips of buttered paper; this paper should be about 6 inches higher than the top of the tin.
10136-8{_}23537{_}Put in the dough; stand it in a warm place to rise for more than an hour; then bake the cakes in a well-heated oven.
10136-8{_}23538{_}If this quantity be divided in two, they will take from 1-1/2 to 2 hours' baking.
10136-8{_}23539{_}_Time_.--1-3/4 to 2-1/4 hours.
10136-8{_}23540{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23541{_}9d.
10136-8{_}23542{_}_Sufficient_ to make 2 moderate-sized cakes.
10136-8{_}23543{_}ECONOMICAL CAKE.
10136-8{_}23544{_}[Illustration: CAKE-MOULD.]
10136-8{_}23545{_}1756.
10136-8{_}23546{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}23547{_}of flour, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23548{_}of sugar, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23549{_}of butter or lard, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23550{_}of currants, 1 teaspoonful of carbonate of soda, the whites of 4 eggs, 1/2 pint of milk.
10136-8{_}23551{_}_Mode_,--In making many sweet dishes, the whites of eggs are not required, and if well beaten and added to the above ingredients, make an excellent cake, with or without currants.
10136-8{_}23552{_}Beat the butter to a cream, well whisk the whites of the eggs, and stir all the ingredients together but the soda, which must not be added until all is well mixed, and the cake is ready to be put into the oven.
10136-8{_}23553{_}When the mixture has been well beaten, stir in the soda, put the cake into a buttered mould, and bake it in a moderate oven for 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}23554{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}23555{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23556{_}3d.
10136-8{_}23557{_}A NICE USEFUL CAKE.
10136-8{_}23558{_}1757.
10136-8{_}23559{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23560{_}of butter, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}23561{_}of currants, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23562{_}of sugar 1 lb.
10136-8{_}23563{_}of dried flour, 2 teaspoonfuls of baking-powder, 3 eggs, 1 teacupful of milk, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}23564{_}of sweet almonds, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}23565{_}of candied peel.
10136-8{_}23566{_}_Mode_.--Beat the butter to a cream; wash, pick, and dry the currants; whisk the eggs; blanch and chop the almonds, and cut the peel into neat slices.
10136-8{_}23567{_}When all these are ready, mix the dry ingredients together; then add the butter, milk, and eggs, and beat the mixture well for a few minutes.
10136-8{_}23568{_}Put the cake into a buttered mould or tin, and bake it for rather more than 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}23569{_}The currants and candied peel may be omitted, and a little lemon or almond flavouring substituted for them: made in this manner, the cake will be found very good.
10136-8{_}23570{_}_Time_.--Rather more than 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}23571{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23572{_}9d.
10136-8{_}23573{_}HONEY CAKE.
10136-8{_}23574{_}1758.
10136-8{_}23575{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 breakfast-cupful of sugar, 1 breakfast-cupful of rich sour cream, 2 breakfast-cupfuls of flour, 1/2 teaspoonful of carbonate of soda, honey to taste.
10136-8{_}23576{_}_Mode_.--Mix the sugar and cream together; dredge in the flour, with as much honey as will flavour the mixture nicely; stir it well, that all the ingredients may be thoroughly mixed; add the carbonate of soda, and beat the cake well for another 5 minutes; put it into a buttered tin, bake it from 1/2 to 3/4 hour, and let it be eaten warm.
10136-8{_}23577{_}_Time_.--1/2 to 3/4 hour.
10136-8{_}23578{_}_Average cost_, 8d.
10136-8{_}23579{_}_Sufficient_ for 3 or 4 persons.
10136-8{_}23580{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23581{_}RICH SWEETMEAT GINGERBREAD NUTS.
10136-8{_}23582{_}1759.
10136-8{_}23583{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}23584{_}of treacle, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23585{_}of clarified butter, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}23586{_}of coarse brown sugar, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}23587{_}of ground ginger, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}23588{_}of candied orange-peel, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}23589{_}of candied angelica, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}23590{_}of candied lemon-peel, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}23591{_}of coriander seeds, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}23592{_}of caraway seeds, 1 egg; flour.
10136-8{_}23593{_}_Mode_.--Put the treacle into a basin, and pour over it the butter, melted so as not to oil, the sugar, and ginger.
10136-8{_}23594{_}Stir these ingredients well together, and whilst mixing, add the candied peel, which should be cut into very small pieces, but not bruised, and the caraway and coriander seeds, which should be pounded.
10136-8{_}23595{_}Having mixed all thoroughly together, break in an egg, and work the whole up with as much fine flour as may be necessary to form a paste.
10136-8{_}23596{_}Make this into nuts of any size, put them on a tin plate, and bake in a slow oven from 1/4 to 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}23597{_}_Time_.--1/4 to 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}23598{_}_Average cost_, from 1s.
10136-8{_}23599{_}to 1s.
10136-8{_}23600{_}4d.
10136-8{_}23601{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}23602{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23603{_}THICK GINGERBREAD.
10136-8{_}23604{_}1760.
10136-8{_}23605{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}23606{_}of treacle, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23607{_}of butter, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23608{_}of coarse brown sugar, 1-1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23609{_}of flour, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}23610{_}of ginger, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}23611{_}of ground allspice, 1 teaspoonful of carbonate of soda, 1/4 pint of warm milk, 3 eggs.
10136-8{_}23612{_}[Illustration: GINGERBREAD.]
10136-8{_}23613{_}_Mode_.--Put the flour into a basin, with the sugar, ginger, and allspice; mix these together; warm the butter, and add it, with the treacle, to the other ingredients.
10136-8{_}23614{_}Stir well; make the milk just warm, dissolve the carbonate of soda in it, and mix the whole into a nice smooth dough with the eggs, which should be previously well whisked; pour the mixture into a buttered tin, and bake it from 3/4 to 1 hour, or longer, should the gingerbread be very thick.
10136-8{_}23615{_}Just before it is done, brush the top over with the yolk of an egg beaten up with a little milk, and put it back in the oven to finish baking.
10136-8{_}23616{_}_Time_.--3/4 to 1 hour.
10136-8{_}23617{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23618{_}per square.
10136-8{_}23619{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23620{_}SUNDERLAND GINGERBREAD NUTS.
10136-8{_}23621{_}(_An Excellent Recipe_.)
10136-8{_}23622{_}1761.
10136-8{_}23623{_}INGREDIENTS.--1-3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23624{_}treacle, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}23625{_}of moist sugar, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}23626{_}of butter, 2-3/4 lbs.
10136-8{_}23627{_}of flour, 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}23628{_}of ground ginger, 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}23629{_}of allspice, 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}23630{_}of coriander seeds.
10136-8{_}23631{_}_Mode_.--Let the allspice, coriander seeds, and ginger be freshly ground; put them into a basin, with the flour and sugar, and mix these ingredients well together; warm the treacle and butter together; then with a spoon work it into the flour, &c., until the whole forms a nice smooth paste.
10136-8{_}23632{_}Drop the mixture from the spoon on to a piece of buttered paper, and bake in rather a slow oven from 20 minutes to 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}23633{_}A little candied lemon-peel mixed with the above is an improvement, and a great authority in culinary matters suggests the addition of a little cayenne pepper in gingerbread.
10136-8{_}23634{_}Whether it be advisable to use this latter ingredient or not, we leave our readers to decide.
10136-8{_}23635{_}_Time_.--20 minutes to 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}23636{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23637{_}to 1s.
10136-8{_}23638{_}4d.
10136-8{_}23639{_}per lb.
10136-8{_}23640{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23641{_}WHITE GINGERBREAD.
10136-8{_}23642{_}1762.
10136-8{_}23643{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}23644{_}of flour, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23645{_}of butter, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23646{_}of loaf sugar, the rind of 1 lemon, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}23647{_}of ground ginger, 1 nutmeg grated, 1/2 teaspoonful of carbonate of soda, 1 gill of milk.
10136-8{_}23648{_}_Mode_.--Rub the butter into the flour; add the sugar, which should be finely pounded and sifted, and the minced lemon-rind, ginger, and nutmeg.
10136-8{_}23649{_}Mix these well together; make the milk just warm, stir in the soda, and work the whole into a nice smooth paste; roll it out, cut it into cakes, and bake in a moderate oven from 15 to 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}23650{_}_Time_.--15 to 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}23651{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23652{_}3d.
10136-8{_}23653{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23654{_}GOOD HOLIDAY CAKE.
10136-8{_}23655{_}1763.
10136-8{_}23656{_}INGREDIENTS.--1-1/2d.
10136-8{_}23657{_}worth of Borwick's German baking-powder, 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}23658{_}of flour, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}23659{_}of butter, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23660{_}of lard, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}23661{_}of currants, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23662{_}of stoned and cut raisins, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23663{_}of mixed candied peel, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23664{_}of moist sugar, 3 eggs, 3/4 pint of cold milk.
10136-8{_}23665{_}_Mode_.--Mix the baking-powder with the flour; then rub in the butter and lard; have ready the currants, washed, picked, and dried the raisins stoned and cut into small pieces (not chopped), and the peel cut into neat slices.
10136-8{_}23666{_}Add these with the sugar to the flour, &c., and mix all the dry ingredients well together.
10136-8{_}23667{_}Whisk the eggs, stir to them the milk, and with this liquid moisten the cake; beat it up well, that all may be very thoroughly mixed; line a cake-tin with buttered paper, put in the cake, and bake it from 2-1/4 to 2-3/4 hours in a good oven.
10136-8{_}23668{_}To ascertain when it is done, plunge a clean knife into the middle of it, and if, on withdrawing it, the knife looks clean, and not sticky, the cake is done.
10136-8{_}23669{_}To prevent its burning at the top, a piece of clean paper may be put over whilst the cake is soaking, or being thoroughly cooked in the middle.
10136-8{_}23670{_}A steamer, such as is used for steaming potatoes, makes a very good cake-tin, if it be lined at the bottom and sides with buttered paper.
10136-8{_}23671{_}_Time_.--2-1/4 to 2-3/4 hours.
10136-8{_}23672{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}23673{_}6d.
10136-8{_}23674{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23675{_}LEMON CAKE.
10136-8{_}23676{_}1764.
10136-8{_}23677{_}INGREDIENTS.--10 eggs, 3 tablespoonfuls of orange-flower water, 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23678{_}of pounded loaf sugar, 1 lemon, 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23679{_}of flour.
10136-8{_}23680{_}[Illustration: CAKE-MOULD.]
10136-8{_}23681{_}_Mode_.--Separate the whites from the yolks of the eggs whisk the former to a stiff froth; add the orange-flower water, the sugar, grated lemon-rind, and mix these ingredients well together.
10136-8{_}23682{_}Then beat the yolks of the eggs, and add them, with the lemon-juice, to the whites, &c.; dredge in the flour gradually; keep beating the mixture well; put it into a buttered mould, and bake the cake about an hour, or rather longer.
10136-8{_}23683{_}The addition of a little butter, beaten to a cream, we think, would improve this cake.
10136-8{_}23684{_}_Time_.--About 1 hour.
10136-8{_}23685{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23686{_}4d.
10136-8{_}23687{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23688{_}LUNCHEON CAKE.
10136-8{_}23689{_}1765.
10136-8{_}23690{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23691{_}of butter, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}23692{_}of flour, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}23693{_}of caraway seeds, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23694{_}of currants, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}23695{_}of moist sugar, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}23696{_}of candied peel, 3 eggs, 1/2 pint of milk, 1 small teaspoonful of carbonate of soda.
10136-8{_}23697{_}_Mode_.--Rub the butter into the flour until it is quite fine; add the caraway seeds, currants (which should be nicely washed, picked, and dried), sugar, and candied peel cut into thin slices; mix these well together, and moisten with the eggs, which should be well whisked.
10136-8{_}23698{_}Boil the milk, and add to it, whilst boiling, the carbonate of soda, which must be well stirred into it, and, with the milk, mix the other ingredients.
10136-8{_}23699{_}Butter a tin, pour the cake into it, and bake it in a moderate oven from 3/4 to 1 hour.
10136-8{_}23700{_}_Time_.--1 to 14 hour.
10136-8{_}23701{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23702{_}8d.
10136-8{_}23703{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23704{_}CARBONATE OF SODA--Soda was called the mineral alkali, because     it was originally dug up out of the ground in Africa and other     countries: this state of carbonate of soda is called _natron._     But carbonate of soda is likewise procured from the combustion     of marine plants, or such as grow on the sea-shore.
10136-8{_}23705{_}Pure     carbonate of soda is employed for making effervescing draughts,     with lemon-juice, citric acid, or tartaric acid.
10136-8{_}23706{_}The chief     constituent of soda, the alkali, has been used in France from     time immemorial in the manufacture of soap and glass, two     chemical productions which employ and keep in circulation an     immense amount of capital.
10136-8{_}23707{_}A small pinch of carbonate of soda     will give an extraordinary lightness to puff pastes; and,     introduced into the teapot, will extract the full strength of     the tea.
10136-8{_}23708{_}But its qualities have a powerful effect upon delicate     constitutions, and it is not to be used incautiously in any     preparation.
10136-8{_}23709{_}A NICE PLAIN CAKE.
10136-8{_}23710{_}1766.
10136-8{_}23711{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}23712{_}of flour, 1 teaspoonful of Borwick's baking-powder, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23713{_}of good dripping, 1 teacupful of moist sugar, 3 eggs, 1 breakfast-cupful of milk, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}23714{_}of caraway seeds, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23715{_}of currants.
10136-8{_}23716{_}_Mode_.--Put the flour and baking-powder into a basin; stir those together; then rub in the dripping, add the sugar, caraway seeds, and currants; whisk the eggs with the milk, and beat all together very thoroughly until the ingredients are well mixed.
10136-8{_}23717{_}Butter a tin, put in the cake, and bake it from 11/2 to 2 hours.
10136-8{_}23718{_}Let the dripping be quite clean before using: to insure this, it is a good plan to clarify it.
10136-8{_}23719{_}Beef dripping is better than any other for cakes, &c., as mutton dripping frequently has a very unpleasant flavour, which would be imparted to the preparation.
10136-8{_}23720{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 to 2 hours.
10136-8{_}23721{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23722{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23723{_}A NICE PLAIN CAKE FOR CHILDREN.
10136-8{_}23724{_}1767.
10136-8{_}23725{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 quartern of dough, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23726{_}of moist sugar, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23727{_}of butter or good beef dripping, 1/4 pint of warm milk, 1/2 grated nutmeg or 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}23728{_}of caraway seeds.
10136-8{_}23729{_}_Mode_.--If you are not in the habit of making bread at home, procure the dough from the baker's, and, as soon as it comes in, put it into a basin near the fire; cover the basin with a thick cloth, and let the dough remain a little while to rise.
10136-8{_}23730{_}In the mean time, beat the butter to a cream, and make the milk warm; and when the dough has risen, mix with it thoroughly all the above ingredients, and knead the cake well for a few minutes.
10136-8{_}23731{_}Butter some cake-tins, half fill them, and stand them in a warm place, to allow the dough to rise again.
10136-8{_}23732{_}When the tins are three parts full, put the cakes into a good oven, and bake them from 13/4 to 2 hours.
10136-8{_}23733{_}A few currants might be substituted for the caraway seeds when the flavour of the latter is disliked.
10136-8{_}23734{_}_Time_.--1-3/4 to 2 hours.
10136-8{_}23735{_}_Average cost_, _1s.
10136-8{_}23736{_}2d._  _Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23737{_}COMMON PLUM CAKE.
10136-8{_}23738{_}1768.
10136-8{_}23739{_}INGREDIENTS.--3 lbs.
10136-8{_}23740{_}of flour, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}23741{_}of butter or good dripping, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}23742{_}of moist sugar, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}23743{_}of currants, 4 oz.
10136-8{_}23744{_}of pounded allspice, 2 tablespoonfuls of fresh yeast, 1 pint of new milk.
10136-8{_}23745{_}_Mode_.--Rub the butter into the flour; add the sugar, currants, and allspice; warm the milk, stir to it the yeast, and mix the whole into a dough; knead it well, and put it into 6 buttered tins; place them near the fire for nearly an hour for the dough to rise, then bake the cakes in a good oven from 1 to 11/4 hour.
10136-8{_}23746{_}To ascertain when they are done, plunge a clean knife into the middle, and if on withdrawal it comes out clean, the cakes are done.
10136-8{_}23747{_}_Time_.--1 to 1-1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}23748{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23749{_}8d.
10136-8{_}23750{_}_Sufficient_ to make 6 small cakes.
10136-8{_}23751{_}A NICE PLUM CAKE.
10136-8{_}23752{_}1769.
10136-8{_}23753{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}23754{_}of flour, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23755{_}of butter, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23756{_}of sugar, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23757{_}of currants, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}23758{_}of candied lemon-peel, 1/2 pint of milk, 1 teaspoonful of ammonia or carbonate of soda.
10136-8{_}23759{_}_Mode_.--Put the flour into a basin with the sugar, currants, and sliced candied peel; beat the butter to a cream, and mix all these ingredients together with the milk.
10136-8{_}23760{_}Stir the ammonia into 2 tablespoonfuls of milk and add it to the dough, and beat the whole well, until everything is thoroughly mixed.
10136-8{_}23761{_}Put the dough into a buttered tin, and bake the cake from 1-1/2 to 2 hours.
10136-8{_}23762{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 to 2 hours.
10136-8{_}23763{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23764{_}3d.
10136-8{_}23765{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23766{_}POUND CAKE.
10136-8{_}23767{_}[Illustration: POUND CAKE.]
10136-8{_}23768{_}1770.
10136-8{_}23769{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}23770{_}of butter, 1-1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23771{_}of flour, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}23772{_}of pounded loaf sugar, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}23773{_}of currants, 9 eggs, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}23774{_}of candied peel, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}23775{_}of citron, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}23776{_}of sweet almonds; when liked, a little pounded mace.
10136-8{_}23777{_}_Mode_.--Work the butter to a cream; dredge in the flour; add the sugar, currants, candied peel, which should be cut into neat slices, and the almonds, which should be blanched and chopped, and mix all these well together; whisk the eggs, and let them be thoroughly blended with the dry ingredients.
10136-8{_}23778{_}Beat the cake well for 20 minutes, and put it into a round tin, lined at the bottom and sides with a strip of white buttered paper.
10136-8{_}23779{_}Bake it from 1-1/2 to 2 hours, and let the oven be well heated when the cake is first put in, as, if this is not the case, the currants will all sink to the bottom of it.
10136-8{_}23780{_}To make this preparation light, the yolks and whites of the eggs should be beaten separately, and added separately to the other ingredients.
10136-8{_}23781{_}A glass of wine is sometimes added to the mixture; but this is scarcely necessary, as the cake will be found quite rich enough without it.
10136-8{_}23782{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 to 2 hours.
10136-8{_}23783{_}_Average cost_, 3s.
10136-8{_}23784{_}6d.
10136-8{_}23785{_}_Sufficient._--The above quantity divided in two will make two nice-sized cakes.
10136-8{_}23786{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23787{_}A PAVINI CAKE.
10136-8{_}23788{_}1771.
10136-8{_}23789{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23790{_}of flour, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23791{_}of ground rice, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23792{_}of raisins stoned and cut into small pieces, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23793{_}of currants, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23794{_}of butter, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}23795{_}of sweet almonds, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23796{_}of sifted loaf sugar, 1/2 nutmeg grated, 1 pint of milk, 1 teaspoonful of carbonate of soda.
10136-8{_}23797{_}_Mode_.--Stone and cut the raisins into small pieces; wash, pick, and dry the currants; melt the butter to a cream, but without oiling it; blanch and chop the almonds, and grate the nutmeg.
10136-8{_}23798{_}When all these ingredients are thus prepared, mix them well together; make the milk warm, stir in the soda, and with this liquid make the whole into a paste.
10136-8{_}23799{_}Butter a mould, rather more than half fill it with the dough, and bake the cake in a moderate oven from 1-1/2 to 2 hours, or less time should it be made into 2 cakes.
10136-8{_}23800{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 to 2 hours.
10136-8{_}23801{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23802{_}8d.
10136-8{_}23803{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23804{_}[Illustration: CAKE-MOULD.]
10136-8{_}23805{_}RICE CAKE.
10136-8{_}23806{_}1772.
10136-8{_}23807{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23808{_}of ground rice, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23809{_}of flour, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23810{_}of loaf sugar, 9 eggs, 20 drops of essence of lemon, or the rind of 1 lemon, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23811{_}of butter.
10136-8{_}23812{_}_Mode_.--Separate the whites from the yolks of the eggs; whisk them both well, and add to the latter the butter beaten to a cream.
10136-8{_}23813{_}Stir in the flour, rice, and lemon (if the rind is used, it must be very finely minced), and beat the mixture well; then add the whites of the eggs, beat the cake again for some time, put it into a buttered mould or tin, and bake it for nearly 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}23814{_}It may be flavoured with essence of almonds, when this is preferred.
10136-8{_}23815{_}_Time_.--Nearly 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}23816{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23817{_}6d.
10136-8{_}23818{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23819{_}QUEEN-CAKES.
10136-8{_}23820{_}1773.
10136-8{_}23821{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}23822{_}of flour, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23823{_}of butter, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23824{_}of pounded loaf sugar, 3 eggs, 1 teacupful of cream, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23825{_}of currants, 1 teaspoonful of carbonate of soda, essence of lemon, or almonds to taste.
10136-8{_}23826{_}_Mode_.--Work the butter to a cream; dredge in the flour, add the sugar and currants, and mix the ingredients well together.
10136-8{_}23827{_}Whisk the eggs, mix them with the cream and flavouring, and stir these to the flour; add the carbonate of soda, beat the paste well for 10 minutes, put it into small buttered pans, and bake the cake from 1/4 to 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}23828{_}Grated lemon-rind may be substituted for the lemon and almond flavouring, which will make the cakes equally nice.
10136-8{_}23829{_}_Time_.
10136-8{_}23830{_}1/4 to 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}23831{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23832{_}9d.
10136-8{_}23833{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23834{_}SAUCER-CAKE FOR TEA.
10136-8{_}23835{_}1774.
10136-8{_}23836{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23837{_}of flour, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23838{_}of _tous-les-mois_, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23839{_}of pounded white sugar, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23840{_}of butter, 2 eggs, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}23841{_}of candied orange or lemon-peel.
10136-8{_}23842{_}_Mode_.--Mix the flour and _tous-les-mois_ together; add the sugar, the candied peel cut into thin slices, the butter beaten to a cream, and the eggs well whisked.
10136-8{_}23843{_}Beat the mixture for 10 minutes, put it into a buttered cake-tin or mould, or, if this is not obtainable, a soup-plate answers the purpose, lined with a piece of buttered paper.
10136-8{_}23844{_}Bake the cake in a moderate oven from 1 to 1-1/4 hour, and when cold, put it away in a covered canister.
10136-8{_}23845{_}It will remain good some weeks, even if it be cut into slices.
10136-8{_}23846{_}_Time_.--1 to 1-1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}23847{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23848{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23849{_}COMMON SEED-CAKE.
10136-8{_}23850{_}1775.
10136-8{_}23851{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 quartern of dough, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23852{_}of good dripping, 6 oz.
10136-8{_}23853{_}of moist sugar, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}23854{_}of caraway seeds, 1 egg.
10136-8{_}23855{_}_Mode_.--If the dough is sent in from the baker's, put it in a basin covered with a cloth, and set it in a warm place to rise.
10136-8{_}23856{_}Then with a wooden spoon beat the dripping to a liquid; add it, with the other ingredients, to the dough, and beat it until everything is very thoroughly mixed.
10136-8{_}23857{_}Put it into a buttered tin, and bake the cake for rather more than 2 hours.
10136-8{_}23858{_}_Time_.--Rather more than 2 hours.
10136-8{_}23859{_}_Average cost_, 8d.

10136-8{_}23861{_}A VERY GOOD SEED-CAKE.
10136-8{_}23862{_}1776.
10136-8{_}23863{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}23864{_}of butter, 6 eggs, 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23865{_}of sifted sugar, pounded mace and grated nutmeg to taste, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}23866{_}of flour, 3/4 oz.
10136-8{_}23867{_}of caraway seeds, 1 wineglassful of brandy.
10136-8{_}23868{_}_Mode_.--Beat the butter to a cream; dredge in the flour; add the sugar, mace, nutmeg, and caraway seeds, and mix these ingredients well together.
10136-8{_}23869{_}Whisk the eggs, stir to them the brandy, and beat the cake again for 10 minutes.
10136-8{_}23870{_}Put it into a tin lined with buttered paper, and bake it from 1-1/2 to 2 hours.
10136-8{_}23871{_}This cake would be equally nice made with currants, and omitting the caraway seeds.
10136-8{_}23872{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 to 2 hours.
10136-8{_}23873{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}23874{_}6d.
10136-8{_}23875{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23876{_}BREAD-MAKING IN SPAIN.--The bread in the south of Spain is     delicious: it is white as snow, close as cake, and yet very     light; the flavour is most admirable, for the wheat is good and     pure, and the bread well kneaded.
10136-8{_}23877{_}The way they make this bread     is as follows:--From large round panniers filled with wheat they     take out a handful at a time, sorting it most carefully and     expeditiously, and throwing every defective grain into another     basket.
10136-8{_}23878{_}This done, the wheat is ground between two circular     stones, as it was ground in Egypt 2,000 years ago (see No.
10136-8{_}23879{_}117),     the requisite rotary motion being given by a blindfolded mule,     which paces round and round with untiring patience, a bell being     attached to his neck, which, as long as he is in movement,     tinkles on; and when it stops, he is urged to his duty by the     shout of "_Arre, mula_," from some one within hearing.
10136-8{_}23880{_}When     ground, the wheat is sifted through three sieves, the last of     these being so fine that only the pure flour can pass through     it: this is of a pale apricot-colour.
10136-8{_}23881{_}The bread is made in the     evening.
10136-8{_}23882{_}It is mixed with only sufficient water, with a little     salt in it, to make it into dough: a very small quantity of     leaven, or fermenting mixture is added.
10136-8{_}23883{_}The Scripture says, "A     little leaven leaveneth the whole lump;" but in England, to     avoid the trouble of kneading, many put as much leaven or yeast     in one batch of household bread as in Spain would last them a     week for the six or eight donkey-loads of bread they send every     night from their oven.
10136-8{_}23884{_}The dough made, it is put into sacks, and     carried on the donkeys' backs to the oven in the centre of the     village, so as to bake it immediately it is kneaded.
10136-8{_}23885{_}On arriving     there, the dough is divided into portions weighing 3 lbs.
10136-8{_}23886{_}each.
10136-8{_}23887{_}Two long narrow wooden tables on trestles are then placed down     the room; and now a curious sight may be seen.
10136-8{_}23888{_}About twenty men     (bakers) come in and range themselves on one side of the tables.
10136-8{_}23889{_}A lump of dough is handed to the nearest, which he commences     kneading and knocking about with all his might for about 3 or 4     minutes, and then passes it on to his neighbour, who does the     same; and so on successively until all have kneaded it, when it     becomes as soft as new putty, and ready for the oven.
10136-8{_}23890{_}Of course,     as soon as the first baker has handed the first lump to his     neighbour, another is given to him, and so on till the whole     quantity of dough is successively kneaded by them all.
10136-8{_}23891{_}The     bakers' wives and daughters shape the loaves for the oven, and     some of them are very small, and they are baked immediately.
10136-8{_}23892{_}The     ovens are very large, and not heated by fires _under_ them; but     a quantity of twigs of the herbs of sweet marjoram and thyme,     which cover the hills in great profusion, are put in the oven     and ignited.
10136-8{_}23893{_}They heat the oven to any extent required; and, as     the bread gets baked, the oven gets gradually colder; so the     bread is never burned.
10136-8{_}23894{_}They knead the bread in Spain with such     force, that the palm of the hand and the second joints of the     fingers of the bakers are covered with corns; and it so affects     the chest, that they cannot work more than two hours at a time.
10136-8{_}23895{_}SNOW-CAKE.
10136-8{_}23896{_}1777.
10136-8{_}23897{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23898{_}of _tous-les-mois_, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23899{_}of white pounded sugar, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23900{_}of fresh or washed salt butter, 1 egg, the juice of 1 lemon.
10136-8{_}23901{_}_Mode_.--Beat the butter to a cream; then add the egg, previously well beaten, and then the other ingredients; if the mixture is not light, add another egg, and beat for 1/4 hour, until it turns white and light.
10136-8{_}23902{_}Line a flat tin, with raised edges, with a sheet of buttered paper; pour in the cake, and put it into the oven.
10136-8{_}23903{_}It must be rather slow, and the cake not allowed to brown at all.
10136-8{_}23904{_}If the oven is properly heated, 1 to 1-1/4 hour will be found long enough to bake it.
10136-8{_}23905{_}Let it cool a few minutes, then with a clean sharp knife cut it into small square pieces, which should be gently removed to a large flat dish to cool before putting away.
10136-8{_}23906{_}This will keep for several weeks.
10136-8{_}23907{_}_Time_.--1 to 1-1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}23908{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23909{_}3d.
10136-8{_}23910{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23911{_}SNOW-CAKE.
10136-8{_}23912{_}(_A genuine Scotch Recipe_.)
10136-8{_}23913{_}1778.
10136-8{_}23914{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}23915{_}of arrowroot, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23916{_}of pounded white sugar, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23917{_}of butter, the whites of 6 eggs; flavouring to taste, of essence of almonds, or vanilla, or lemon.
10136-8{_}23918{_}_Mode_.--Beat the butter to a cream; stir in the sugar and arrowroot gradually, at the same time beating the mixture.
10136-8{_}23919{_}Whisk the whites of the eggs to a stiff froth, add them to the other ingredients, and beat well for 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}23920{_}Put in whichever of the above flavourings may be preferred; pour the cake into a buttered mould or tin and bake it in a moderate oven from 1 to 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}23921{_}_Time_.--1 to 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}23922{_}_Average cost_, with the best Bermuda arrowroot, 4s.
10136-8{_}23923{_}6d.
10136-8{_}23924{_}; with St. Vincent ditto, 2s.
10136-8{_}23925{_}9d.
10136-8{_}23926{_}_Sufficient_ to make a moderate-sized cake.
10136-8{_}23927{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23928{_}SCRAP-CAKES.
10136-8{_}23929{_}1779.
10136-8{_}23930{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 lbs.
10136-8{_}23931{_}of leaf, or the inside fat of a pig; 1-1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23932{_}of flour, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23933{_}of moist sugar, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23934{_}of currants, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}23935{_}of candied lemon-peel, ground allspice to taste.
10136-8{_}23936{_}_Mode_.--Cut the leaf, or flead, as it is sometimes called, into small pieces; put it into a large dish, which place in a quick oven; be careful that it does not burn, and in a short time it will be reduced to oil, with the small pieces of leaf floating on the surface; and it is of these that the cakes should be made.
10136-8{_}23937{_}Gather all the scraps together, put them into a basin with the flour, and rub them well together.
10136-8{_}23938{_}Add the currants, sugar, candied peel, cut into thin slices, and the ground allspice.
10136-8{_}23939{_}When all these ingredients are well mixed, moisten with sufficient cold water to make the whole into a nice paste; roll it out thin, cut it into shapes, and bake the cakes in a quick oven from 15 to 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}23940{_}These are very economical and wholesome cakes for children, and the lard, melted at home, produced from the flead, is generally better than that you purchase.
10136-8{_}23941{_}To prevent the lard from burning, and to insure its being a good colour, it is better to melt it in a jar placed in a saucepan of boiling water; by doing it in this manner, there will be no chance of its discolouring.
10136-8{_}23942{_}_Time_.--15 to 20 minutes.
10136-8{_}23943{_}_Sufficient_ to make 3 or 4 dozen cakes.
10136-8{_}23944{_}_Seasonable_ from September to March.
10136-8{_}23945{_}[Illustration: WHEAT.]
10136-8{_}23946{_}Wheat is liable to several diseases, which affect the flour made     from it, and render it unfit for good bread.
10136-8{_}23947{_}The principal of     these are the blight, mildew, and smut, which are occasioned by     microscopic fungi, which sow themselves and grow upon the stems     and ears, destroying the nutritive principles, and introducing     matter of a deleterious kind.
10136-8{_}23948{_}The farmer is at the utmost pains     to keep away these intruders.
10136-8{_}23949{_}Wheat, as well as all kinds of     corn, is also very liable to be injured by being stacked before     it is quite dry; in which case it will heat, and become musty in     the ricks.
10136-8{_}23950{_}In wet harvests it is sometimes impossible to get it     sufficiently dried, and a great deal of corn is thus often     spoiled.
10136-8{_}23951{_}It is generally reckoned that the sweetest bread is     made from wheat threshed out before it is stacked; which shows     the importance of studying the best modes of preserving it.
10136-8{_}23952{_}The erudite are not agreed as to the aboriginal country of corn:     some say it is Egypt, others Tartary; and the learned Bailly, as     well as the traveller Pallas, affirms that it grows     spontaneously in Siberia.
10136-8{_}23953{_}Be that as it may, the Phocians     brought it to Marseilles before the Romans had penetrated into     Gaul.
10136-8{_}23954{_}The Gauls ate the corn cooked or bruised in a mortar: they     did not know, for a long time, how to make fermented bread.
10136-8{_}23955{_}SCOTCH SHORTBREAD.
10136-8{_}23956{_}1780.
10136-8{_}23957{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 lbs.
10136-8{_}23958{_}of flour, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}23959{_}of butter, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23960{_}of pounded loaf sugar, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}23961{_}of caraway seeds, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}23962{_}of sweet almonds, a few strips of candied orange-peel.
10136-8{_}23963{_}[Illustration: SHORTBREAD.]
10136-8{_}23964{_}_Mode_.--Beat the butter to a cream, gradually dredge in the flour, and add the sugar, caraway seeds, and sweet almonds, which should be blanched and cut into small pieces.
10136-8{_}23965{_}Work the paste until it is quite smooth, and divide it into six pieces.
10136-8{_}23966{_}Put each cake on a separate piece of paper, roll the paste out square to the thickness of about an inch, and pinch it upon all sides.
10136-8{_}23967{_}Prick it well, and ornament with one or two strips of candied orange-peel.
10136-8{_}23968{_}Put the cakes into a good oven, and bake them from 25 to 30 minutes.
10136-8{_}23969{_}_Time_.--25 to 30 minutes.
10136-8{_}23970{_}_Average cost_, for this quantity, 2s.
10136-8{_}23971{_}_Sufficient_ to make 6 cakes.
10136-8{_}23972{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23973{_}_Note_.--Where the flavour of the caraway seeds is disliked, omit them, and add rather a larger proportion of candied peel.
10136-8{_}23974{_}SODA-CAKE.
10136-8{_}23975{_}1781.
10136-8{_}23976{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}23977{_}of butter, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}23978{_}of flour, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23979{_}of currants, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}23980{_}of moist sugar, 1 teacupful of milk, 3 eggs, 1 teaspoonful of carbonate of soda.
10136-8{_}23981{_}_Mode_.--Rub the butter into the flour, add the currants and sugar, and mix these ingredients well together.
10136-8{_}23982{_}Whisk the eggs well, stir them to the flour, &c., with the milk, in which the soda should be previously dissolved, and beat the whole up together with a wooden spoon or beater.
10136-8{_}23983{_}Divide the dough into two pieces, put them into buttered moulds or cake-tins, and bake in a moderate oven for nearly an hour.
10136-8{_}23984{_}The mixture must be extremely well beaten up, and not allowed to stand after the soda is added to it, but must be placed in the oven immediately.
10136-8{_}23985{_}Great care must also be taken that the cakes are quite done through, which may be ascertained by thrusting a knife into the middle of them: if the blade looks bright when withdrawn, they are done.
10136-8{_}23986{_}If the tops acquire too much colour before the inside is sufficiently baked, cover them over with a piece of clean white paper, to prevent them from burning.
10136-8{_}23987{_}_Time_.--1 hour.
10136-8{_}23988{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}23989{_}6d.
10136-8{_}23990{_}_Sufficient_ to make 2 small cakes.
10136-8{_}23991{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}23992{_}SAVOY CAKE.
10136-8{_}23993{_}1782.
10136-8{_}23994{_}INGREDIENTS.--The weight of 4 eggs in pounded loaf sugar, the weight of 7 in flour, a little grated lemon-rind, or essence of almonds, or orange-flower water.
10136-8{_}23995{_}_Mode_.--Break the 7 eggs, putting the yolks into one basin and the whites into another.
10136-8{_}23996{_}Whisk the former, and mix with them the sugar, the grated lemon-rind, or any other flavouring to taste; beat them well together, and add the whites of the eggs, whisked to a froth.
10136-8{_}23997{_}Put in the flour by degrees, continuing to beat the mixture for 1/4 hour, butter a mould, pour in the cake, and bake it from 1-1/4 to 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}23998{_}This is a very nice cake for dessert, and may be iced for a supper-table, or cut into slices and spread with jam, which converts it into sandwiches.
10136-8{_}23999{_}_Time_.--1-1/4 to 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}24000{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}24001{_}_Sufficient_ for 1 cake.
10136-8{_}24002{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}24003{_}SPONGE-CAKE.
10136-8{_}24004{_}I.
10136-8{_}24005{_}[Illustration: SPONGE-CAKE.]
10136-8{_}24006{_}1783.
10136-8{_}24007{_}INGREDIENTS.--The weight of 8 eggs in pounded loaf sugar, the weight of 5 in flour, the rind of 1 lemon, 1 tablespoonful of brandy.
10136-8{_}24008{_}_Mode_.--Put the eggs into one side of the scale, and take the weight of 8 in pounded loaf sugar, and the weight of 5 in good _dry_ flour.
10136-8{_}24009{_}Separate the yolks from the whites of the eggs; beat the former, put them into a saucepan with the sugar, and let them remain over the fire until _milk-warm,_ keeping them well stirred.
10136-8{_}24010{_}Then put them into a basin, add the grated lemon-rind mixed with the brandy, and stir these well together, dredging in the flour very gradually.
10136-8{_}24011{_}Whisk the whites of the eggs to a very stiff froth, stir them to the flour, &c., and beat the cake well for 1/4 hour.
10136-8{_}24012{_}Put it into a buttered mould strewn with a little fine sifted sugar, and bake the cake in a quick oven for 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}24013{_}Care must be taken that it is put into the oven immediately, or it will not be light.
10136-8{_}24014{_}The flavouring of this cake may be varied by adding a few drops of essence of almonds instead of the grated lemon-rind.
10136-8{_}24015{_}_Time_.--1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}24016{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}24017{_}3d.
10136-8{_}24018{_}_Sufficient_ for 1 cake.
10136-8{_}24019{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}24020{_}[Illustration: EGYPTIAN WHEAT.]
10136-8{_}24021{_}The Egyptian, or Mummy Wheat, is not grown to any great extent,     owing to its inferior quality; but it is notable for its large     produce, and is often cultivated on allotment grounds and on     small farms, where quantity rather than quality is desired.
10136-8{_}24022{_}At     Wix, in Essex, the seed of this wheat has produced, without     artificial assistance, four thousandfold; some of the ears have     had eleven offshoots, and have contained, altogether, eleven     grains in one ear.
10136-8{_}24023{_}II.
10136-8{_}24024{_}1784.
10136-8{_}24025{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}24026{_}of loaf sugar, not quite 1/4 pint of water, 5 eggs, 1 lemon, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}24027{_}of flour, 1/4 teaspoonful of carbonate of soda.
10136-8{_}24028{_}_Mode_.--Boil the sugar and water together until they form a thick syrup; let it cool a little, then pour it to the eggs, which should be previously well whisked; and after the eggs and syrup are mixed together, continue beating them for a few minutes.
10136-8{_}24029{_}Grate the lemon-rind, mix the carbonate of soda with the flour, and stir these lightly to the other ingredients; then add the lemon-juice, and, when the whole is thoroughly mixed, pour it into a buttered mould, and bake in rather a quick oven for rather more than 1 hour.
10136-8{_}24030{_}The remains of sponge or Savoy cakes answer very well for trifles, light puddings, &c.; and a very stale one (if not mouldy) makes an excellent tipsy-cake.
10136-8{_}24031{_}_Time_.--Rather more than 1 hour.
10136-8{_}24032{_}_Average cost_, 10d.
10136-8{_}24033{_}_Sufficient_ to make 1 cake.
10136-8{_}24034{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}24035{_}TO MAKE SMALL SPONGE-CAKES.
10136-8{_}24036{_}1785.
10136-8{_}24037{_}INGREDIENTS.--The weight of 5 eggs in flour, the weight of 8 in pounded loaf sugar; flavouring to taste.
