10136-8{_}24038{_}_Mode_.--Let the flour be perfectly dry, and the sugar well pounded and sifted.
10136-8{_}24039{_}Separate the whites from the yolks of the eggs, and beat the latter up with the sugar; then whisk the whites until they become rather stiff, and mix them with the yolks, but do not stir them more than is just necessary to mingle the ingredients well together.
10136-8{_}24040{_}Dredge in the flour by degrees, add the flavouring; batter the tins well, pour in the batter, sift a little sugar over the cakes, and bake them in rather a quick oven, but do not allow them to take too much colour, as they should be rather pale.
10136-8{_}24041{_}Remove them from the tins before they get cold, and turn them on their faces, where let them remain until quite cold, when store them away in a closed tin canister or wide-mouthed glass bottle.
10136-8{_}24042{_}_Time_.--10 to 15 minutes in a quick oven.
10136-8{_}24043{_}_Average cost_, 1d.
10136-8{_}24044{_}each.
10136-8{_}24045{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}24046{_}TEA-CAKES.
10136-8{_}24047{_}1786.
10136-8{_}24048{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 lbs.
10136-8{_}24049{_}of flour, 1/2 teaspoonful of salt, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}24050{_}of butter or lard, 1 egg, a piece of German yeast the size of a walnut, warm milk.
10136-8{_}24051{_}_Mode_.--Put the flour (which should be perfectly dry) into a basin mix with it the salt, and rub in the butter or lard; then beat the egg well, stir to it the yeast, and add these to the flour with as much warm milk as will make the whole into a smooth paste, and knead it well.
10136-8{_}24052{_}Let it rise near the fire, and, when well risen, form it into cakes; place them on tins, let them rise again for a few minutes before putting them into the oven, and bake from 1/4 to 1/2 hour in a moderate oven.
10136-8{_}24053{_}These are very nice with a few currants and a little sugar added to the other ingredients: they should be put in after the butter is rubbed in.
10136-8{_}24054{_}These cakes should be buttered, and eaten hot as soon as baked; but, when stale, they are very nice split and toasted; or, if dipped in milk, or even water, and covered with a basin in the oven till hot, they will be almost equal to new.
10136-8{_}24055{_}_Time_.--1/4 to 1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}24056{_}_Average cost_, 10d.
10136-8{_}24057{_}_Sufficient_ to make 8 tea-cakes.
10136-8{_}24058{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}24059{_}TO TOAST TEA-CAKES.
10136-8{_}24060{_}[Illustration: TEA-CAKES.]
10136-8{_}24061{_}1787.
10136-8{_}24062{_}Cut each tea-cake into three or four slices, according to its thickness; toast them on both sides before a nice clear fire, and as each slice is done, spread it with butter on both sides.
10136-8{_}24063{_}When a cake is toasted, pile the slices one on the top of the other, cut them into quarters, put them on a very hot plate, and send the cakes immediately to table.
10136-8{_}24064{_}As they are wanted, send them in hot, one or two at a time, as, if allowed to stand, they spoil, unless kept in a muffin-plate over a basin of boiling water.
10136-8{_}24065{_}A NICE YEAST-CAKE.
10136-8{_}24066{_}1788.
10136-8{_}24067{_}INGREDIENTS.--1-1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}24068{_}of flour, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}24069{_}of butter, 1/2 pint of milk, 1-1/2 tablespoonful of good yeast, 3 eggs, 3/4 lb.
10136-8{_}24070{_}of currants, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}24071{_}of white moist sugar, 2 oz.
10136-8{_}24072{_}of candied peel.
10136-8{_}24073{_}_Mode_.--Put the milk and butter into a saucepan, and shake it round over a fire until the butter is melted, but do not allow the milk to get very hot.
10136-8{_}24074{_}Put the flour into a basin, stir to it the milk and butter, the yeast, and eggs, which should be well beaten, and form the whole into a smooth dough.
10136-8{_}24075{_}Let it stand in a warm place, covered with a cloth, to rise, and, when sufficiently risen, add the currants, sugar, and candied peel cut into thin slices.
10136-8{_}24076{_}When all the ingredients are thoroughly mixed, line 2 moderate-sized cake-tins with buttered paper, which should be about six inches higher than the tin; pour in the mixture, let it stand to rise again for another 1/2 hour, and then bake the cakes in a brisk oven for about 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}24077{_}If the tops of them become too brown, cover them with paper until they are done through.
10136-8{_}24078{_}A few drops of essence of lemon, or a little grated nutmeg, may be added when the flavour is liked.
10136-8{_}24079{_}_Time_.--From 1-1/4 to 1-1/2 hour.
10136-8{_}24080{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}24081{_}_Sufficient_ to make 2 moderate-sized cakes.
10136-8{_}24082{_}_Seasonable_ at any time.
10136-8{_}24083{_}[Illustration]     [Illustration]  CHAPTER XXXVI.
10136-8{_}24084{_}GENERAL OBSERVATIONS ON BEVERAGES.
10136-8{_}24085{_}1789.
10136-8{_}24086{_}Beverages are innumerable in their variety; but the ordinary beverages drunk in the British isles, may be divided into three classes:--1.
10136-8{_}24087{_}Beverages of the simplest kind not fermented.
10136-8{_}24088{_}2.
10136-8{_}24089{_}Beverages, consisting of water, containing a considerable quantity of carbonic acid.
10136-8{_}24090{_}3.
10136-8{_}24091{_}Beverages composed partly of fermented liquors.
10136-8{_}24092{_}Of the first class may be mentioned,--water, toast-and-water, barley-water, eau sucré, lait sucré, cheese and milk whey, milk-and-water, lemonade, orangeade, sherbet, apple and pear juice, capillaire, vinegar-and-water, raspberry vinegar and water.
10136-8{_}24093{_}1790.
10136-8{_}24094{_}Of the common class of beverages, consisting of water impregnated with carbonic acid gas, we may name soda-water, single and double, ordinary effervescing draughts, and ginger-beer.
10136-8{_}24095{_}1791.
10136-8{_}24096{_}The beverages composed partly of fermented liquors, are hot spiced wines, bishop, egg-flip, egg-hot, ale posset, sack posset, punch, and spirits-and-water.
10136-8{_}24097{_}1792.
10136-8{_}24098{_}We will, however, forthwith treat on the most popular of our beverages, beginning with the one which makes "the cup that cheers but not inebriates."
10136-8{_}24099{_}1793.
10136-8{_}24100{_}The beverage called tea has now become almost a necessary of life.
10136-8{_}24101{_}Previous to the middle of the 17th century it was not used in England, and it was wholly unknown to the Greeks and Romans.
10136-8{_}24102{_}Pepys says, in his Diary,--"September 25th, 1661.--I sent for a cup of tea (a China drink), of which I had never drunk before."
10136-8{_}24103{_}Two years later it was so rare a commodity in England, that the English East-India Company bought 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}24104{_}2 oz.
10136-8{_}24105{_}of it, as a present for his majesty.
10136-8{_}24106{_}In 1666 it was sold in London for sixty shillings a pound.
10136-8{_}24107{_}From that date the consumption has gone on increasing from 5,000 lbs.
10136-8{_}24108{_}to 50,000,000 lbs.
10136-8{_}24109{_}1794.
10136-8{_}24110{_}Linnaeus was induced to think that there were two species of tea-plant, one of which produced the black, and the other the green teas; but later observations do not confirm this.
10136-8{_}24111{_}When the leaves of black and green tea are expanded by hot water, and examined by the botanist, though a difference of character is perceived, yet this is not sufficient to authorize considering them as distinct species.
10136-8{_}24112{_}The tea-tree flourishes best in temperate regions; in China it is indigenous.
10136-8{_}24113{_}The part of China where the best tea is cultivated, is called by us the "tea country."
10136-8{_}24114{_}The cultivation of the plant requires great care.
10136-8{_}24115{_}It is raised chiefly on the sides of hills; and, in order to increase the quantity and improve the quality of the leaves, the shrub is pruned, so as not to exceed the height of from two to three feet, much in the same manner as the vine is treated in France.
10136-8{_}24116{_}They pluck the leaves, one selecting them according to the kinds of tea required; and, notwithstanding the tediousness of the operation, each labourer is able to gather from four to ten or fifteen pounds a day.
10136-8{_}24117{_}When the trees attain to six or seven years of age, the produce becomes so inferior that they are removed to make room for a fresh succession, or they are cut down to allow of numerous young shoots.
10136-8{_}24118{_}Teas of the finest flavour consist of the youngest leaves; and as these are gathered at four different periods of the year, the younger the leaves the higher flavoured the tea, and the scarcer, and consequently the dearer, the article.
10136-8{_}24119{_}1795.
10136-8{_}24120{_}The various names by which teas are sold in the British market are corruptions of Chinese words.
10136-8{_}24121{_}There are about a dozen different kinds; but the principal are Bohea, Congou, and Souchong, and signify, respectively, inferior, middling, and superior.
10136-8{_}24122{_}Teas are often perfumed and flavoured with the leaves of different kinds of plants grown on purpose.
10136-8{_}24123{_}Different tea-farms in China produce teas of various qualities, raised by skilful cultivation on various soils.
10136-8{_}24124{_}1796.
10136-8{_}24125{_}Tea, when chemically analyzed, is found to contain woody fibre, mucilage, a considerable quantity of the astringent principle, or tannin, a narcotic principle, which is, perhaps, connected with a peculiar aroma.
10136-8{_}24126{_}The tannin is shown by its striking a black colour with sulphate of iron, and is the cause of the dark stain which is always formed when tea is spilt upon buff-coloured cottons dyed with iron.
10136-8{_}24127{_}A constituent called _Theine_ has also been discovered in tea, supposed to be identical with _Caffeine_, one of the constituents of coffee.
10136-8{_}24128{_}Liebig says, "Theine yields, in certain processes of decomposition, a series of most remarkable products, which have much analogy with those derived from uric acid in similar circumstances.
10136-8{_}24129{_}The infusion of tea differs from that of coffee, by containing iron and manganese.
10136-8{_}24130{_}We have in tea, of many kinds, a beverage which contains the active constituents of the most powerful mineral springs, and, however small the amount of iron may be which we daily take in this form, it cannot be destitute of influence on the vital processes."
10136-8{_}24131{_}1797.
10136-8{_}24132{_}Chinese tea has frequently been adulterated in this country, by the admixture of the dried leaves of certain plants.
10136-8{_}24133{_}The leaves of the sloe, white thorn, ash, elder, and some others, have been employed for this purpose; such as the leaves of the speedwell, wild germander, black currants, syringa, purple-spiked willow-herb, sweet-brier, and cherry-tree.
10136-8{_}24134{_}Some of these are harmless, others are to a certain degree poisonous; as, for example, are the leaves of all the varieties of the plum and cherry tribe, to which the sloe belongs.
10136-8{_}24135{_}Adulteration by means of these leaves is by no means a new species of fraud; and several acts of parliament, from the time of George II., have been passed, specifying severe penalties against those guilty of the offence, which, notwithstanding numerous convictions, continues to the present time.
10136-8{_}24136{_}1798.
10136-8{_}24137{_}In the purchase of tea, that should be chosen which possesses an agreeable odour and is as whole as possible, in order that the leaf may be easily examined.
10136-8{_}24138{_}The greatest care should be taken that it has not been exposed to the air, which destroys its flavour.
10136-8{_}24139{_}1799.
10136-8{_}24140{_}It would be impossible, in the space at our command, to enumerate the various modes adopted in different countries for "making coffee;" that is, the phrase commonly understood to mean the complete preparation of this delicious beverage for drinking.
10136-8{_}24141{_}For performing this operation, such recipes or methods as we have found most practical will be inserted in their proper place; but the following facts connected with coffee will be found highly interesting.
10136-8{_}24142{_}1800.
10136-8{_}24143{_}The introduction of coffee into this country is comparatively of recent date.
10136-8{_}24144{_}We are assured by Bruce that the coffee-tree is a native of Abyssinia, and it is said to have been cultivated in that country from time immemorial.
10136-8{_}24145{_}1801.
10136-8{_}24146{_}It appears that coffee was first introduced into England by Daniel Edwards, a Turkey merchant, whose servant, Pasqua, a Greek, understood the manner of roasting it.
10136-8{_}24147{_}This servant, under the patronage of Edwards, established the first coffee-house in London, in George Yard, Lombard Street.
10136-8{_}24148{_}Coffee was then sold at four or five guineas a pound, and a duty was soon afterwards laid upon it of fourpence a gallon, when made into a beverage.
10136-8{_}24149{_}In the course of two centuries, however, this berry, unknown originally as an article of food, except to some savage tribes on the confines of Abyssinia, has made its way through the whole of the civilized world.
10136-8{_}24150{_}Mahommedans of all ranks drink coffee twice a day; it is in universal request in France; and the demand for it throughout the British isles is daily increasing, the more especially since so much attention has been given to mechanical contrivances for roasting and grinding the berry and preparing the beverage.
10136-8{_}24151{_}1802.
10136-8{_}24152{_}Of the various kinds of coffee the Arabian is considered the best.
10136-8{_}24153{_}It is grown chiefly in the districts of Aden and Mocha; whence the name of our Mocha coffee.
10136-8{_}24154{_}Mocha coffee has a smaller and rounder bean than any other, and likewise a more agreeable smell and taste.
10136-8{_}24155{_}The next in reputation and quality is the Java and Ceylon coffee, and then the coffees of Bourbon and Martinique, and that of Berbice, a district of the colony of British Guiana.
10136-8{_}24156{_}The Jamaica and St. Domingo coffees are less esteemed.
10136-8{_}24157{_}1803.
10136-8{_}24158{_}A considerable change takes place in the arrangement of the constituents of coffee by the application of heat in roasting it.
10136-8{_}24159{_}Independently of one of the objects of roasting, namely, that of destroying its toughness and rendering it easily ground, its tannin and other principles are rendered partly soluble in water; and it is to the tannin that the brown colour of the decoction of coffee is owing.
10136-8{_}24160{_}An aromatic flavour is likewise developed during torrefaction, which is not perceived in the raw berry, and which is not produced in the greatest perfection until the heat has arrived at a certain degree of temperature; but, if the heat be increased beyond this, the flavour is again dissipated, and little remains but a bitter and astringent matter with carbon.
10136-8{_}24161{_}1804.
10136-8{_}24162{_}The roasting of coffee in the best manner requires great nicety, and much of the qualities of the beverage depends upon the operation.
10136-8{_}24163{_}The roasting of coffee for the dealers in London and Paris has now become a separate branch of business, and some of the roasters perform the operation on a great scale, with considerable skill.
10136-8{_}24164{_}Roasted coffee loses from 20 to 30 per cent, by sufficient roasting, and the powder suffers much by exposure to the air; but, while raw, it not only does not lose its flavour for a year or two, but improves by keeping.
10136-8{_}24165{_}If a cup of the best coffee be placed upon a table boiling hot, it will fill the room with its fragrance; but the coffee, when warmed again after being cold, will be found to have lost most of its flavour.
10136-8{_}24166{_}1805.
10136-8{_}24167{_}To have coffee in perfection, it should be roasted and ground just before it is used, and more should not be ground at a time than is wanted for immediate use, or, if it be necessary to grind more, it should be kept closed from the air.
10136-8{_}24168{_}Coffee readily imbibes exhalations from other substances, and thus often acquires a bad flavour: brown sugar placed near it will communicate a disagreeable flavour.
10136-8{_}24169{_}It is stated that the coffee in the West Indies has often been injured by being laid in rooms near the sugar-works, or where rum is distilled; and the same effect has been produced by bringing over coffee in the same ships with rum and sugar.
10136-8{_}24170{_}Dr. Moseley mentions that a few bags of pepper, on board a ship from India, spoiled a whole cargo of coffee.
10136-8{_}24171{_}1806.
10136-8{_}24172{_}With respect to the quantity of coffee used in making the decoction, much depends upon the taste of the consumer.
10136-8{_}24173{_}The greatest and most common fault in English coffee is the too small quantity of the ingredient.
10136-8{_}24174{_}Count Rumford says that to make good coffee for drinking after dinner, a pound of good Mocha coffee, which, when roasted and ground, weighs only thirteen ounces, serves to make fifty-six full cups, or a little less than a quarter of an ounce to a coffee-cup of moderate size.
10136-8{_}24175{_}RECIPES.
10136-8{_}24176{_}CHAPTER XXXVII.
10136-8{_}24177{_}TO MAKE CHOCOLATE.
10136-8{_}24178{_}1807.
10136-8{_}24179{_}INGREDIENTS.--Allow 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}24180{_}of chocolate to each person; to every oz.
10136-8{_}24181{_}allow 1/2 pint of water, 1/2 pint of milk.
10136-8{_}24182{_}_Mode_.--Make the milk-and-water hot; scrape the chocolate into it, and stir the mixture constantly and quickly until the chocolate is dissolved; bring it to the boiling-point, stir it well, and serve directly with white sugar.
10136-8{_}24183{_}Chocolate prepared with in a mill, as shown in the engraving, is made by putting in the scraped chocolate, pouring over it the boiling milk-and-water, and milling it over the fire until hot and frothy.
10136-8{_}24184{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}24185{_}of cake chocolate to each person.
10136-8{_}24186{_}[Illustration: MILL.]
10136-8{_}24187{_}CHOCOLATE AND COCOA.--Both these preparations are made from the     seeds or beans of the cacao-tree, which grows in the West Indies     and South America.
10136-8{_}24188{_}The Spanish, and the proper name, is cacao,     not cocoa, as it is generally spelt.
10136-8{_}24189{_}From this mistake, the tree     from which the beverage is procured has been often confounded     with the palm that produces the edible cocoa-nuts, which are the     produce of the cocoa-tree (_Cocos nucifera_), whereas the tree     from which chocolate is procured is very different (the     _Theobroma cacao_).
10136-8{_}24190{_}The cocoa-tree was cultivated by the     aboriginal inhabitants of South America, particularly in Mexico,     where, according to Humboldt, it was reared by Montezuma.
10136-8{_}24191{_}It was     transplanted thence into other dependencies of the Spanish     monarchy in 1520; and it was so highly esteemed by Linnaeus     receive from him the name now conferred upon it, of Theobroma, a     term derived from the Greek, and signifying "_food for gods_."
10136-8{_}24192{_}Chocolate has always been a favourite beverage among the     Spaniards and Creoles, and was considered here as a great luxury     when first introduced, after the discovery of America; but the     high duties laid upon it, confined it long almost entirely to     the wealthier classes.
10136-8{_}24193{_}Before it was subjected to duty, Mr.     Bryan Edwards stated that cocoa plantations were numerous in     Jamaica, but that the duty caused their almost entire ruin.
10136-8{_}24194{_}The     removal of this duty has increased their cultivation.
10136-8{_}24195{_}(For     engraving of cocoa-bean, _see_ No.
10136-8{_}24196{_}1816.)
10136-8{_}24197{_}TO MAKE ESSENCE OF COFFEE.
10136-8{_}24198{_}1808.
10136-8{_}24199{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}24200{_}of ground coffee allow 1 small teaspoonful of powdered chicory, 3 small teacupfuls, or 1 pint, of water.
10136-8{_}24201{_}_Mode_.--Let the coffee be freshly ground, and, if possible, freshly roasted; put it into a percolater, or filter, with the chicory, and pour _slowly_ over it the above proportion of boiling water.
10136-8{_}24202{_}When it has all filtered through, warm the coffee sufficiently to bring it to the simmering-point, but do not allow it to boil; then filter it a second time, put it into a clean and dry bottle, cork it well, and it will remain good for several days.
10136-8{_}24203{_}Two tablespoonfuls of this essence are quite sufficient for a breakfast-cupful of hot milk.
10136-8{_}24204{_}This essence will be found particularly useful to those persons who have to rise extremely early; and having only the milk to make boiling, is very easily and quickly prepared.
10136-8{_}24205{_}When the essence is bottled, pour another 3 tea-cupfuls of _boiling_ water slowly on the grounds, which, when filtered through, will be a very weak coffee.
10136-8{_}24206{_}The next time there is essence to be prepared, make this weak coffee boiling, and pour it on the ground coffee instead of plain water: by this means a better coffee will be obtained.
10136-8{_}24207{_}Never throw away the grounds without having made use of them in this manner; and always cork the bottle well that contains this preparation, until the day that it is wanted for making the fresh essence.
10136-8{_}24208{_}_Time_.--To be filtered once, then brought to the boiling-point, and filtered again.
10136-8{_}24209{_}_Average cost_, with coffee at 1s.
10136-8{_}24210{_}8d.
10136-8{_}24211{_}per lb., 6d.
10136-8{_}24212{_}_Sufficient'_-Allow 2 tablespoonfuls for a breakfast-cupful of hot milk.
10136-8{_}24213{_}TO ROAST COFFEE.
10136-8{_}24214{_}(_A French Recipe_.)
10136-8{_}24215{_}1809.
10136-8{_}24216{_}It being an acknowledged fact that French coffee is decidedly superior to that made in England, and as the roasting of the berry is of great importance to the flavour of the preparation, it will be useful and interesting to know how they manage these things in France.
10136-8{_}24217{_}In Paris, there are two houses justly celebrated for the flavour of their coffee,--_La Maison Corcellet_ and _La Maison Royer de Chartres_; and to obtain this flavour, before roasting they add to every 3 lbs.
10136-8{_}24218{_}of coffee a piece of butter the size of a nut, and a dessert-spoonful of powdered sugar: it is then roasted in the usual manner.
10136-8{_}24219{_}The addition of the butter and sugar develops the flavour and aroma of the berry; but it must be borne in mind, that the quality of the butter must be of the very best description.
10136-8{_}24220{_}TO MAKE COFFEE.
10136-8{_}24221{_}1810.
10136-8{_}24222{_}INGREDIENTS.--Allow 4 oz., or 1 tablespoonful, of ground coffee to each person; to every oz.
10136-8{_}24223{_}of coffee allow 1/3 pint of water.
10136-8{_}24224{_}_Mode_.--To make coffee good, _it should never be boiled_, but the boiling water merely poured on it, the same as for tea.
10136-8{_}24225{_}The coffee should always be purchased in the berry,--if possible, freshly roasted; and it should never be ground long before it is wanted for use.
10136-8{_}24226{_}There are very many new kinds of coffee-pots, but the method of making the coffee is nearly always the same; namely, pouring the boiling water on the powder, and allowing it to filter through.
10136-8{_}24227{_}Our illustration shows one of Loysel's Hydrostatic Urns, which are admirably adapted for making good and clear coffee, which should be made in the following, manner:--Warm the urn with boiling water, remove the lid and movable filter, and place the ground coffee at the bottom of the urn.
10136-8{_}24228{_}Put the movable filter over this, and screw the lid, inverted, tightly on the end of the centre pipe.
10136-8{_}24229{_}Pour into the inverted lid the above proportion of boiling water, and when all the water so poured has disappeared from the funnel, and made its way down the centre pipe and up again through the ground coffee by _hydrostatic pressure_, unscrew screw the lid and cover the urn.
10136-8{_}24230{_}Pour back direct into the urn, _not through the funnel_, one, two, or three cups, according to the size of the percolater, in order to make the infusion of uniform strength; the contents will then be ready for use, and should run from the tap strong, hot, and clear.
10136-8{_}24231{_}The coffee made in these urns generally turns out very good, and there is but one objection to them,--the coffee runs rather slowly from the tap.
10136-8{_}24232{_}This is of no consequence where there is a small party, but tedious where there are many persons to provide for.
10136-8{_}24233{_}A remedy for this objection may be suggested; namely, to make the coffee very strong, so that not more than 1/3 of a cup would be required, as the rest would be filled up with milk.
10136-8{_}24234{_}Making coffee in filters or percolaters does away with the necessity of using isinglass, white of egg, and various other preparations to clear it.
10136-8{_}24235{_}Coffee should always be served very hot, and, if possible, in the same vessel in which it is made, as pouring it from one pot to another cools, and consequently spoils it.
10136-8{_}24236{_}Many persons may think that the proportion of water we have given for each oz.
10136-8{_}24237{_}of coffee is rather small; it is so, and the coffee produced from it will be very strong; 1/3 of a cup will be found quite sufficient, which should be filled with nice hot milk, or milk and cream mixed.
10136-8{_}24238{_}This is the 'cafe au lait' for which our neighbours over the Channel are so justly celebrated.
10136-8{_}24239{_}Should the ordinary method of making coffee be preferred, use double the quantity of water, and, in pouring it into the cups, put in more coffee and less milk.
10136-8{_}24240{_}[Illustration: LOYSEL'S HYDROSTATIC URN.]
10136-8{_}24241{_}_Sufficient_.--For very good coffee, allow 1/2 oz., or 1 tablespoonful, to each person.
10136-8{_}24242{_}A VERY SIMPLE METHOD OF MAKING COFFEE.
10136-8{_}24243{_}1811.
10136-8{_}24244{_}INGREDIENTS.--Allow 1/2 oz., or 1 tablespoonful, of coffee to each person; to every oz.
10136-8{_}24245{_}allow 1 pint of water.
10136-8{_}24246{_}_Mode_.--Have a small iron ring made to fit the top of the coffee-pot inside, and to this ring sew a small muslin bag (the muslin for the purpose must not be too thin).
10136-8{_}24247{_}Fit the bag into the pot, pour some boiling water in it, and, when the pot is well warmed, put the ground coffee into the bag; pour over as much boiling water as is required, close the lid, and, when all the water has filtered through, remove the bag, and send the coffee to table.
10136-8{_}24248{_}Making it in this manner prevents the necessity of pouring the coffee from one vessel to another, which cools and spoils it.
10136-8{_}24249{_}The water should be poured on the coffee gradually, so that the infusion may be stronger; and the bag must be well made, that none of the grounds may escape through the seams, and so make the coffee thick and muddy.
10136-8{_}24250{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 1 tablespoonful, or 1/2 oz., to each person.
10136-8{_}24251{_}[Illustration: COFFEE.]
10136-8{_}24252{_}THE COFFEE PLANT grows to the height of about twelve or fifteen     feet, with leaves not unlike those of the common laurel,     although more pointed, and not so dry and thick.
10136-8{_}24253{_}The blossoms     are white, much like those of jasmine, and issue from the angles     of the leaf-stalks.
10136-8{_}24254{_}When the flowers fade, they are succeeded by     the coffee-bean, or seed, which is inclosed in a berry of a red     colour, when ripe resembling a cherry.
10136-8{_}24255{_}The coffee-beans are     prepared by exposing them to the sun for a few days, that the     pulp may ferment and throw off a strong acidulous moisture.
10136-8{_}24256{_}They     are then gradually dried for about three weeks, and put into a     mill to separate the husk from the seed.
10136-8{_}24257{_}CAFE AU LAIT.
10136-8{_}24258{_}1812.
10136-8{_}24259{_}This is merely very strong coffee added to a large proportion of good hot milk; about 6 tablespoonfuls of strong coffee being quite sufficient for a breakfast-cupful of milk.
10136-8{_}24260{_}Of the essence No.
10136-8{_}24261{_}1808, which answers admirably for 'cafe an lait', so much would not be required.
10136-8{_}24262{_}This preparation is infinitely superior to the weak watery coffee so often served at English tables.
10136-8{_}24263{_}A little cream mixed with the milk, if the latter cannot be depended on for richness, improves the taste of the coffee, as also the richness of the beverage.
10136-8{_}24264{_}_Sufficient_.--6 tablespoonfuls of strong coffee, or 2 tablespoonfuls of the essence, to a breakfast-cupful of milk.
10136-8{_}24265{_}TEA AND COFFEE.--It is true, says Liebig, that thousands have     lived without a knowledge of tea and coffee; and daily     experience teaches us that, under certain circumstances, they     may be dispensed with without disadvantage to the merely animal     functions; but it is an error, certainly, to conclude from this     that they may be altogether dispensed with in reference to their     effects; and it is a question whether, if we had no tea and no     coffee, the popular instinct would not seek for and discover the     means of replacing them.
10136-8{_}24266{_}Science, which accuses us of so much in     these respects, will have, in the first place, to ascertain     whether it depends on sensual and sinful inclinations merely,     that every people of the globe have appropriated some such means     of acting on the nervous life, from the shore of the Pacific,     where the Indian retires from life for days in order to enjoy     the bliss of intoxication with koko, to the Arctic regions,     where Kamtschatdales and Koriakes prepare an intoxicating     beverage from a poisonous mushroom.
10136-8{_}24267{_}We think it, on the     contrary, highly probable, not to say certain, that the instinct     of man, feeling certain blanks, certain wants of the intensified     life of our times, which cannot be satisfied or filled up by     mere quantity, has discovered, in these products of vegetable     life the true means of giving to his food the desired and     necessary quality.
10136-8{_}24268{_}CAFE NOIR.
10136-8{_}24269{_}1813.
10136-8{_}24270{_}This is usually handed round after dinner, and should be drunk well sweetened, with the addition of a little brandy or liqueurs, which may be added or not at pleasure.
10136-8{_}24271{_}The coffee should be made very strong, and served in very small cups, but never mixed with milk or cream.
10136-8{_}24272{_}Cafe noir may be made of the essence of coffee No.
10136-8{_}24273{_}1808, by pouring a tablespoonful into each cup, and filling it up with boiling water.
10136-8{_}24274{_}This is a very simple and expeditious manner of preparing coffee for a large party, but the essence for it must be made very good, and kept well corked until required for use.
10136-8{_}24275{_}TO MAKE TEA.
10136-8{_}24276{_}1814.
10136-8{_}24277{_}There is very little art in making good tea; if the water is boiling, and there is no sparing of the fragrant leaf, the beverage will almost invariably be good.
10136-8{_}24278{_}The old-fashioned plan of allowing a teaspoonful to each person, and one over, is still practised.
10136-8{_}24279{_}Warm the teapot with boiling water; let it remain for two or three minutes for the vessel to become thoroughly hot, then pour it away.
10136-8{_}24280{_}Put in the tea, pour in from 1/2 to 3/4 pint of boiling water, close the lid, and let it stand for the tea to draw from 5 to 10 minutes; then fill up the pot with water.
10136-8{_}24281{_}The tea will be quite spoiled unless made with water that is actually 'boiling', as the leaves will not open, and the flavour not be extracted from them; the beverage will consequently be colourless and tasteless,--in fact, nothing but tepid water.
10136-8{_}24282{_}Where there is a very large party to make tea for, it is a good plan to have two teapots instead of putting a large quantity of tea into one pot; the tea, besides, will go farther.
10136-8{_}24283{_}When the infusion has been once completed, the addition of fresh tea adds very little to the strength; so, when more is required, have the pot emptied of the old leaves, scalded, and fresh tea made in the usual manner.
10136-8{_}24284{_}Economists say that a few grains of carbonate of soda, added before the boiling water is poured on the tea, assist to draw out the goodness: if the water is very hard, perhaps it is a good plan, as the soda softens it; but care must be taken to use this ingredient sparingly, as it is liable to give the tea a soapy taste if added in too large a quantity.
10136-8{_}24285{_}For mixed tea, the usual proportion is four spoonfuls of black to one of green; more of the latter when the flavour is very much liked; but strong green tea is highly pernicious, and should never be partaken of too freely.
10136-8{_}24286{_}_Time_.--2 minutes to warm the teapot, 5 to 10 minutes to draw the strength from the tea.
10136-8{_}24287{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 1 teaspoonful to each person, and one over.
10136-8{_}24288{_}TEA.--The tea-tree or shrub belongs to the class and order of     Monadelphia polyandria in the Linnaean system, and to the     natural order of Aurantiaceae in the system of Jussieu.
10136-8{_}24289{_}Lately     it has been made into a new order, the Theasia, which includes     the Camellia and some other plants.
10136-8{_}24290{_}It commonly grows to the     height of from three to six feet; but it is said, that, in its     wild or native state, it reaches twenty feet or more.
10136-8{_}24291{_}In China     it is cultivated in numerous small plantations.
10136-8{_}24292{_}In its general     appearance, and the form of its leaf, it resembles the myrtle.
10136-8{_}24293{_}The blossoms are white and fragrant, not unlike those of the     wild rose, but smaller; and they are succeeded by soft green     capsules, containing each from one to three white seeds.
10136-8{_}24294{_}These     capsules are crushed for oil, which is in general use in China.
10136-8{_}24295{_}[Illustration: TEA.]
10136-8{_}24296{_}AN EXCELLENT SUBSTITUTE FOR MILK OR CREAM IN TEA OR COFFEE.
10136-8{_}24297{_}1815.
10136-8{_}24298{_}INGREDIENTS.--Allow 1 new-laid egg to every large breakfast-cupful of tea or coffee.
10136-8{_}24299{_}_Mode_.--Beat up the whole of the egg in a basin, put it into a cup (or a portion of it, if the cup be small), and pour over it the tea or coffee very hot.
10136-8{_}24300{_}These should be added very gradually, and stirred all the time, to prevent the egg from curdling.
10136-8{_}24301{_}In point of nourishment, both these beverages are much improved by this addition.
10136-8{_}24302{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow 1 egg to every large breakfast-cupful of tea or coffee.
10136-8{_}24303{_}TO MAKE COCOA.
10136-8{_}24304{_}1816.
10136-8{_}24305{_}INGREDIENTS.--Allow 2 teaspoonfuls of the prepared cocoa to 1 breakfast-cup; boiling milk and boiling water.
10136-8{_}24306{_}[Illustration: COCOA-BEAN.]
10136-8{_}24307{_}_Mode_.--Put the cocoa into a breakfast-cup, pour over it sufficient cold milk to make it into a smooth paste; then add equal quantities of boiling milk and boiling water, and stir all well together.
10136-8{_}24308{_}Care must be taken not to allow the milk to get burnt, as it will entirely spoil the flavour of the preparation.
10136-8{_}24309{_}The above directions are usually given for making the prepared cocoa.
10136-8{_}24310{_}The rock cocoa, or that bought in a solid piece, should be scraped, and made in the same manner, taking care to rub down all the lumps before the boiling liquid is added.
10136-8{_}24311{_}_Sufficient_--2 teaspoonfuls of prepared cocoa for 1 breakfast-cup, or 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}24312{_}of the rock cocoa for the same quantity.
10136-8{_}24313{_}COWSLIP WINE.
10136-8{_}24314{_}1817.
10136-8{_}24315{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every gallon of water allow 3 lbs.
10136-8{_}24316{_}of lump sugar, the rind of 2 lemons, the juice of 1, the rind and juice of 1 Seville orange, 1 gallon of cowslip pips.
10136-8{_}24317{_}To every 4-1/2 gallons of wine allow 1 bottle of brandy.
10136-8{_}24318{_}_Mode_.--Boil the sugar and water together for 1/2 hour, carefully removing all the scum as it rises.
10136-8{_}24319{_}Pour this boiling liquor on the orange and lemon-rinds, and the juice, which should be strained; when milk-warm, add the cowslip pips or flowers, picked from the stalks and seeds; and to 9 gallons of wine 3 tablespoonfuls of good fresh brewers' yeast.
10136-8{_}24320{_}Let it ferment 3 or 4 days; then put all together in a cask with the brandy, and let it remain for 2 months, when bottle it off for use.
10136-8{_}24321{_}_Time_.--To be boiled 1/2 hour; to ferment 3 or 4 days; to remain in the cask 2 months.
10136-8{_}24322{_}_Average cost_, exclusive of the cowslips, which may be picked in the fields, 2s.
10136-8{_}24323{_}9d.
10136-8{_}24324{_}per gallon.
10136-8{_}24325{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in April or May.
10136-8{_}24326{_}ELDER WINE.
10136-8{_}24327{_}1818.
10136-8{_}24328{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every 3 gallons of water allow 1 peck of elderberries; to every gallon of juice allow 3 lbs.
10136-8{_}24329{_}of sugar, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}24330{_}of ground ginger, 6 cloves, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}24331{_}of good Turkey raisins; 1/2 pint of brandy to every gallon of wine.
10136-8{_}24332{_}To every 9 gallons of wine 3 or 4 tablespoonfuls of fresh brewer's yeast.
10136-8{_}24333{_}_Mode_.--Pour the water, quite boiling, on the elderberries, which should be picked from the stalks, and let these stand covered for 24 hours; then strain the whole through a sieve or bag, breaking the fruit to express all the juice from it.
10136-8{_}24334{_}Measure the liquor, and to every gallon allow the above proportion of sugar.
10136-8{_}24335{_}Boil the juice and sugar with the ginger, cloves, and raisins for 1 hour, skimming the liquor the whole time; let it stand until milk-warm, then put it into a clean dry cask, with 3 or 4 tablespoonfuls of good fresh yeast to every 9 gallons of wine.
10136-8{_}24336{_}Let it ferment for about a fortnight; then add the brandy, bung up the cask, and let it stand some months before it is bottled, when it will be found excellent.
10136-8{_}24337{_}A bunch of hops suspended to a string from the bung, some persons say, will preserve the wine good for several years.
10136-8{_}24338{_}Elder wine is usually mulled, and served with sippets of toasted bread and a little grated nutmeg.
10136-8{_}24339{_}_Time_.--To stand covered 24 hours; to be boiled 1 hour.
10136-8{_}24340{_}_Average cost_, when made at home, 3s.
10136-8{_}24341{_}6d.
10136-8{_}24342{_}per gallon.
10136-8{_}24343{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in September.
10136-8{_}24344{_}[Illustration: ELDER-BERRIES.]
10136-8{_}24345{_}ELDER-BERRY WINE.--The elder-berry is well adapted for the     production of wine; its juice contains a considerable portion of     the principle necessary for a vigorous fermentation, and its     beautiful colour communicates a rich tint to the wine made from     it.
10136-8{_}24346{_}It is, however, deficient in sweetness, and therefore     demands an addition of sugar.
10136-8{_}24347{_}It is one of the very best of the     genuine old English wines; and a cup of it mulled, just previous     to retiring to bed on a winter night, is a thing to be "run     for," as Cobbett would say: it is not, however, agreeable to     every taste.
10136-8{_}24348{_}GINGER WINE.
10136-8{_}24349{_}1819.
10136-8{_}24350{_}INGREDIENTS.--To 9 gallons of water allow 27 lbs.
10136-8{_}24351{_}of loaf sugar, 9 lemons, 12 oz.
10136-8{_}24352{_}of bruised ginger, 3 tablespoonfuls of yeast, 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}24353{_}of raisins stoned and chopped, 1 pint of brandy.
10136-8{_}24354{_}_Mode_.--Boil together for 1 hour in a copper (let it previously be well scoured and beautifully clean) the water, sugar, _lemon-rinds_, and bruised ginger; remove every particle of scum as it rises, and when the liquor is sufficiently boiled, put it into a large tub or pan, as it must not remain in the copper.
10136-8{_}24355{_}When nearly cold, add the yeast, which must be thick and very fresh, and, the next day, put all in a dry cask with the strained lemon-juice and chopped raisins.
10136-8{_}24356{_}Stir the wine every day for a fortnight; then add the brandy, stop the cask down by degrees, and in a few weeks it will be fit to bottle.
10136-8{_}24357{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}24358{_}per gallon.
10136-8{_}24359{_}_Sufficient_ to make 9 gallons of wine.
10136-8{_}24360{_}_Seasonable_.--The best time for making this wine is either in March or September.
10136-8{_}24361{_}_Note_.--Wine made early in March will be fit to bottle in June.
10136-8{_}24362{_}GOOSEBERRY VINEGAR.
10136-8{_}24363{_}(_An Excellent Recipe_.)
10136-8{_}24364{_}1820.
10136-8{_}24365{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 pecks of crystal gooseberries, 6 gallons of water, 12 lbs.
10136-8{_}24366{_}of foots sugar of the coarsest brown quality.
10136-8{_}24367{_}_Mode_.--Mash the gooseberries (which should be quite ripe) in a tub with a mallet; put to them the water nearly milk-warm; let this stand 24 hours; then strain it through a sieve, and put the sugar to it; mix it well, and tun it.
10136-8{_}24368{_}These proportions are for a 9-gallon cask; and if it be not quite full, more water must be added.
10136-8{_}24369{_}Let the mixture be stirred from the bottom of the cask two or three times daily for three or four days, to assist the melting of the sugar; then paste a piece of linen cloth over the bunghole, and set the cask in a warm place, _but not in the sun_; any corner of a warm kitchen is the best situation for it.
10136-8{_}24370{_}The following spring it should be drawn off into stone bottles, and the vinegar will be fit for use twelve months after it is made.
10136-8{_}24371{_}This will be found a most excellent preparation, greatly superior to much that is sold under the name of the best white wine vinegar.
10136-8{_}24372{_}Many years' experience has proved that pickle made with this vinegar will keep, when bought vinegar will not preserve the ingredients.
10136-8{_}24373{_}The cost per gallon is merely nominal, especially to those who reside in the country and grow their own gooseberries; the coarse sugar is then the only ingredient to be purchased.
10136-8{_}24374{_}_Time_.--To remain in the cask 9 months.
10136-8{_}24375{_}_Average cost_, when the gooseberries have to be purchased, 1s.
10136-8{_}24376{_}per gallon; when they are grown at home, 6d.
10136-8{_}24377{_}per gallon.
10136-8{_}24378{_}_Seasonable_.--This should be made the end of June or the beginning of July, when gooseberries are ripe and plentiful.
10136-8{_}24379{_}EFFERVESCING GOOSEBERRY WINE.
10136-8{_}24380{_}1821.
10136-8{_}24381{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every gallon of water allow 6 lbs.
10136-8{_}24382{_}of green gooseberries, 3 lbs.
10136-8{_}24383{_}of lump sugar.
10136-8{_}24384{_}_Mode_.--This wine should be prepared from unripe gooseberries, in order to avoid the flavour which the fruit would give to the wine when in a mature state.
10136-8{_}24385{_}Its briskness depends more upon the time of bottling than upon the unripe state of the fruit, for effervescing wine can be made from fruit that is ripe as well as that which is unripe.
10136-8{_}24386{_}The fruit should be selected when it has nearly attained its full growth, and consequently before it shows any tendency to ripen.
10136-8{_}24387{_}Any bruised or decayed berries, and those that are very small, should be rejected.
10136-8{_}24388{_}The blossom and stalk ends should be removed, and the fruit well bruised in a tub or pan, in such quantities as to insure each berry being broken without crushing the seeds.
10136-8{_}24389{_}Pour the water (which should be warm) on the fruit, squeeze and stir it with the hand until all the pulp is removed from the skin and seeds, and cover the whole closely for 24 hours; after which, strain it through a coarse bag, and press it with as much force as can be conveniently applied, to extract the whole of the juice and liquor the fruit may contain.
10136-8{_}24390{_}To every 40 or 50 lbs.
10136-8{_}24391{_}of fruit one gallon more of hot water may be passed through the marc, or husks, in order to obtain any soluble matter that may remain, and be again pressed.
10136-8{_}24392{_}The juice should be put into a tub or pan of sufficient size to contain all of it, and the sugar added to it.
10136-8{_}24393{_}Let it be well stirred until the sugar is dissolved, and place the pan in a warm situation; keep it closely covered, and let it ferment for a day or two.
10136-8{_}24394{_}It must then be drawn off into clean casks, placed a little on one side for the scum that arises to be thrown out, and the casks kept filled with the remaining "must," that should be reserved for that purpose.
10136-8{_}24395{_}When the active fermentation has ceased, the casks should be plugged upright, again filled, if necessary, the bungs be put in loosely, and, after a few days, when the fermentation is a little more languid (which may be known, by the hissing noise ceasing), the bungs should be driven in tight, and a spile-hole made, to give vent if necessary.
10136-8{_}24396{_}About November or December, on a clear fine day, the wine should he racked from its lees into clean casks, which may be rinsed with brandy.
10136-8{_}24397{_}After a month, it should be examined to see if it is sufficiently clear for bottling; if not, it must be fined with isinglass, which may be dissolved in some of the wine: 1 oz.
10136-8{_}24398{_}will be sufficient for 9 gallons.
10136-8{_}24399{_}In March or April, or when the gooseberry bushes begin to blossom, the wine must be bottled, in order to insure its being effervescing.
10136-8{_}24400{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this the end of May or beginning of June, before the berries ripen.
10136-8{_}24401{_}LEMON SYRUP.
10136-8{_}24402{_}1822.
10136-8{_}24403{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 lbs.
10136-8{_}24404{_}of loaf sugar, 2 pints of water, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}24405{_}of citric acid, 12 drachm of essence of lemon.
10136-8{_}24406{_}_Mode_.--Boil the sugar and water together for 1/4 hour, and put it into a basin, where let it remain till cold.
10136-8{_}24407{_}Beat the citric acid to a powder, mix the essence of lemon with it, then add these two ingredients to the syrup; mix well, and bottle for use.
10136-8{_}24408{_}Two tablespoonfuls of the syrup are sufficient for a tumbler of cold water, and will be found a very refreshing summer drink.
10136-8{_}24409{_}_Sufficient_--2 tablespoonfuls of syrup to a tumbler-ful of cold water.
10136-8{_}24410{_}LEMON WINE.
10136-8{_}24411{_}1823.
10136-8{_}24412{_}INGREDIENTS.--To 4-1/2 gallons of water allow the pulp of 50 lemons, the rind of 25, 16 lbs.
10136-8{_}24413{_}of loaf sugar,--1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}24414{_}of isinglass, 1 bottle of brandy.
10136-8{_}24415{_}_Mode_.--Peel and slice the lemons, but use only the rind of 25 of them, and put them into the cold water.
10136-8{_}24416{_}Let it stand 8 or 9 days, squeezing the lemons well every day; then strain the water off and put it into a cask with the sugar.
10136-8{_}24417{_}Let it work some time, and when it has ceased working, put in the isinglass.
10136-8{_}24418{_}Stop the cask down; in about six months put in the brandy and bottle the wine off.
10136-8{_}24419{_}_Seasonable_.--The best time to make this is in January or February, when lemons are best and cheapest.
10136-8{_}24420{_}MALT WINE.
10136-8{_}24421{_}1824.
10136-8{_}24422{_}INGREDIENTS.--5 gallons of water, 28 lbs.
10136-8{_}24423{_}of sugar, 6 quarts of sweet-wort, 6 quarts of tun, 3 lbs.
10136-8{_}24424{_}of raisins, 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}24425{_}of candy, 1 pint of brandy.
10136-8{_}24426{_}_Mode_.--Boil the sugar and water together for 10 minutes; skim it well, and put the liquor into a convenient-sized pan or tub.
10136-8{_}24427{_}Allow it to cool; then mix it with the sweet-wort and tun.
10136-8{_}24428{_}Let it stand for 3 days, then put it into a barrel; here it will work or ferment for another three days or more; then bung up the cask, and keep it undisturbed for 2 or 3 months.
10136-8{_}24429{_}After this, add the raisins (whole), the candy, and brandy, and, in 6 months' time, bottle the wine off.
10136-8{_}24430{_}Those who do not brew, may procure the sweet-wort and tun from any brewer.
10136-8{_}24431{_}Sweet-wort is the liquor that leaves the mash of malt before it is boiled with the hops; tun is the new beer after the whole of the brewing operation has been completed.
10136-8{_}24432{_}_Time_.--To be boiled 10 minutes; to stand 3 days after mixing; to ferment 3 days; to remain in the cask 2 mouths before the raisins are added; bottle 6 months after.
10136-8{_}24433{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in March or October.
10136-8{_}24434{_}HOME-MADE NOYEAU.
10136-8{_}24435{_}1825.
10136-8{_}24436{_}INGREDIENTS.--2 oz.
10136-8{_}24437{_}of bitter almonds, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}24438{_}of sweet ditto, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}24439{_}of loaf sugar, the rinds of 3 lemons, 1 quart of Irish whiskey or gin, 1 tablespoonful of clarified honey, 4 pint of new milk.
10136-8{_}24440{_}_Mode_.--Blanch and pound the almonds, and mix with them the sugar, which should also be pounded.
10136-8{_}24441{_}Boil the milk; let it stand till quite cold; then mix all the ingredients together, and let them remain for 10 days, shaking them every day.
10136-8{_}24442{_}Filter the mixture through blotting-paper, bottle off for use in small bottles, and seal the corks down.
10136-8{_}24443{_}This will be found useful for flavouring many sweet dishes.
10136-8{_}24444{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}24445{_}9d.
10136-8{_}24446{_}_Sufficient_ to make about 24 pints of Noyeau.
10136-8{_}24447{_}_Seasonable_.--May be made at any time.
10136-8{_}24448{_}ORANGE BRANDY.
10136-8{_}24449{_}(_Excellent_.)
10136-8{_}24450{_}1826.
10136-8{_}24451{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every 1 gallon of brandy allow 3/4 pint of Seville orange-juice, 1-1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}24452{_}of loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}24453{_}_Mode_.--To bring out the full flavour of the orange-peel, rub a few lumps of the sugar on 2 or 3 unpared oranges, and put these lumps to the rest.
10136-8{_}24454{_}Mix the brandy with the orange-juice, strained, the rinds of 6 of the oranges pared very thin, and the sugar.
10136-8{_}24455{_}Let all stand in a closely-covered jar for about 3 days, stirring it 3 or 4 times a day.
10136-8{_}24456{_}When clear, it should be bottled and closely corked for a year; it will then be ready for use, but will keep any length of time.
10136-8{_}24457{_}This is a most excellent stomachic when taken pure in small quantities; or, as the strength of the brandy is very little deteriorated by the other ingredients, it may be diluted with water.
10136-8{_}24458{_}_Time_.--To be stirred every day for 3 days.
10136-8{_}24459{_}_Average cost_, 7s.
10136-8{_}24460{_}_Sufficient_ to make 2 quarts.
10136-8{_}24461{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in March.
10136-8{_}24462{_}A VERY SIMPLE AND EASY METHOD OF MAKING A VERY SUPERIOR ORANGE WINE.
10136-8{_}24463{_}1827.
10136-8{_}24464{_}INGREDIENTS.--90 Seville oranges, 32 lbs.
10136-8{_}24465{_}of lump sugar, water.
10136-8{_}24466{_}_Mode_.--Break up the sugar into small pieces, and put it into a dry, sweet 9-gallon cask, placed in a cellar or other storehouse, where it is intended to be kept.
10136-8{_}24467{_}Have ready close to the cask two large pans or wooden keelers, into one of which put the peel of the oranges pared quite thin, and into the other the pulp after the juice has been squeezed from it.
10136-8{_}24468{_}Strain the juice through a piece of double muslin, and put it into the cask with the sugar.
10136-8{_}24469{_}Then pour about 1-1/2 gallon of cold spring water on both the peels and pulp; let it stand for 24 hours, and then strain it into the cask; add more water to the peels and pulp when this is done, and repeat the same process every day for a week: it should take about a week to fill up the cask.
10136-8{_}24470{_}Be careful to apportion the quantity as nearly as possible to the seven days, and to stir the contents of the cask each day.
10136-8{_}24471{_}On the ''third' day after the cask is full,--that is, the 'tenth' day after the commencement of making,--the cask may be securely bunged down.
10136-8{_}24472{_}This is a very simple and easy method, and the wine made according to it will be pronounced to be most excellent.
10136-8{_}24473{_}There is no troublesome boiling, and all fermentation takes place in the cask.
10136-8{_}24474{_}When the above directions are attended to, the wine cannot fail to be good.
10136-8{_}24475{_}It should be bottled in 8 or 9 months, and will be fit for use in a twelve month after the time of making.
10136-8{_}24476{_}Ginger wine may be made in precisely the same manner, only, with the 9-gallon cask for ginger wine, 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}24477{_}of the best whole ginger, 'bruised', must be put with the sugar.
10136-8{_}24478{_}It will be found convenient to tie the ginger loosely in a muslin bag.
10136-8{_}24479{_}_Time_.--Altogether, 10 days to make it.
10136-8{_}24480{_}_Average cost_, 2s.
10136-8{_}24481{_}6d.
10136-8{_}24482{_}per gallon.
10136-8{_}24483{_}_Sufficient_ for 9 gallons.
10136-8{_}24484{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in March, and bottle it the following January.
10136-8{_}24485{_}RASPBERRY VINEGAR.
10136-8{_}24486{_}1828.
10136-8{_}24487{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every 3 pints of the best vinegar allow 4-1/2 pints of freshly-gathered raspberries; to each pint of liquor allow 1 lb.
10136-8{_}24488{_}of pounded loaf sugar, 1 wineglassful of brandy.
10136-8{_}24489{_}_Mode_.--Let the raspberries be freshly gathered; pick them from the stalks, and put 1-1/2 pint of them into a stone jar; pour 3 pints of the best vinegar over them, and let them remain for 24 hours; then strain the liquor over another 1-1/2 pint of fresh raspberries.
10136-8{_}24490{_}Let them remain another 24 hours, and the following day repeat the process for the third time; then drain off the liquor without pressing, and pass it through a jelly-bag (previously wetted with plain vinegar), into a stone jar.
10136-8{_}24491{_}Add to every pint of the liquor 1 lb.
10136-8{_}24492{_}of pounded loaf sugar; stir them together, and, when the sugar is dissolved, cover the jar; set it upon the fire in a saucepan of boiling water, and let it boil for an hour, removing the scum as fast as it rises; add to each pint a glass of brandy, bottle it, and seal the corks.
10136-8{_}24493{_}This is an excellent drink in cases of fevers and colds: it should be diluted with cold water, according to the taste or requirement of the patient.
10136-8{_}24494{_}_Time_.--To be boiled 1 hour.
10136-8{_}24495{_}Average cost, 1s.
10136-8{_}24496{_}per pint.
10136-8{_}24497{_}_Sufficient_ to make 2 quarts.
10136-8{_}24498{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in July or August, when raspberries are most plentiful.
10136-8{_}24499{_}RHUBARB WINE.
10136-8{_}24500{_}1829.
10136-8{_}24501{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every 5 lbs.
10136-8{_}24502{_}of rhubarb pulp allow 1 gallon of cold spring water; to every gallon of liquor allow 3 lbs.
10136-8{_}24503{_}of loaf sugar, 1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}24504{_}of isinglass, the rind of 1 lemon.
10136-8{_}24505{_}_Mode_.--Gather the rhubarb about the middle of May; wipe it with a wet cloth, and, with a mallet, bruise it in a large wooden tub or other convenient means.
10136-8{_}24506{_}When reduced to a pulp, weigh it, and to every 5 lbs.
10136-8{_}24507{_}add 1 gallon of cold spring water; let these remain for 3 days, stirring 3 or 4 times a day; and, on the fourth day, press the pulp through a hair sieve; put the liquor into a tub, and to every gallon put 3 lbs.
10136-8{_}24508{_}of loaf sugar; stir in the sugar until it is quite dissolved, and add the lemon-rind; let the liquor remain, and, in 4, 5, or 6 days, the fermentation will begin to subside, and a crust or head will be formed, which should be skimmed off, or the liquor drawn from it, when the crust begins to crack or separate.
10136-8{_}24509{_}Put the wine into a cask, and if, after that, it ferments, rack it off into another cask, and in a fortnight stop it down.
10136-8{_}24510{_}If the wine should have lost any of its original sweetness, add a little more loaf sugar, taking care that the cask is full.
10136-8{_}24511{_}Bottle it off in February or March, and in the summer it should be fit to drink.
10136-8{_}24512{_}It will improve greatly by keeping; and, should a very brilliant colour be desired, add a little currant-juice.
10136-8{_}24513{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this about the middle of May.
10136-8{_}24514{_}WELSH NECTAR.
10136-8{_}24515{_}1830.
10136-8{_}24516{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}24517{_}of raisins, 3 lemons, 2 lbs.
10136-8{_}24518{_}of loaf sugar, 2 gallons of boiling water.
10136-8{_}24519{_}_Mode_.--Cut the peel of the lemons very thin, pour upon it the boiling water, and, when cool, add the strained juice of the lemons, the sugar, and the raisins, stoned and chopped very fine.
10136-8{_}24520{_}Let it stand 4 or 5 days, stirring it every day; then strain it through a jelly-bag, and bottle it for present use.
10136-8{_}24521{_}_Time_.--4 or 5 days.
10136-8{_}24522{_}_Average cost_, 1s.
10136-8{_}24523{_}9d.
10136-8{_}24524{_}_Sufficient_ to make 2 gallons.
10136-8{_}24525{_}CLARET-CUP.
10136-8{_}24526{_}[Illustration: CLARET CUP.]
10136-8{_}24527{_}1831.
10136-8{_}24528{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 bottle of claret, 1 bottle of soda-water, about 1/2 lb.
10136-8{_}24529{_}of pounded ice, 4 tablespoonfuls of powdered sugar, 1/4 teaspoonful of grated nutmeg, 1 liqueur-glass of Maraschino, a sprig of green borage.
10136-8{_}24530{_}_Mode_.--Put all the ingredients into a silver cup, regulating the proportion of ice by the state of the weather: if very warm, a larger quantity would be necessary.
10136-8{_}24531{_}Hand the cup round with a clean napkin passed through one of the handles, that the edge of the cup may be wiped after each guest has partaken of the contents thereof.
10136-8{_}24532{_}_Seasonable_ in summer.
10136-8{_}24533{_}CLARETS.--All those wines called in England clarets are the     produce of the country round Bordeaux, or the Bordelais; but it     is remarkable that there is no pure wine in France known by the     name of claret, which is a corruption of _clairet_, a term that     is applied there to any red or rose-coloured wine.
10136-8{_}24534{_}Round     Bordeaux are produced a number of wines of the first quality,     which pass under the name simply of _vins de Bordeaux_, or have     the designation of the particular district where they are made;     as Lafitte, Latour, &c. The clarets brought to the English     market are frequently prepared for it by the wine-growers by     mixing together several Bordeaux wines, or by adding to them a     portion of some other wines; but in France the pure wines are     carefully preserved distinct.
10136-8{_}24535{_}The genuine wines of Bordeaux are     of great variety, that part being one of the most distinguished     in France; and the principal vineyards are those of Medoc,     Palus, Graves, and Blanche, the product of each having     characters considerably different.
10136-8{_}24536{_}CHAMPAGNE-CUP.
10136-8{_}24537{_}1832.
10136-8{_}24538{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 quart bottle of champagne, 2 bottles of soda-water, 1 liqueur-glass of brandy or Curaçoa, 2 tablespoonfuls of powdered sugar, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}24539{_}of pounded ice, a sprig of green borage.
10136-8{_}24540{_}_Mode_.--Put all the ingredients into a silver cup; stir them together, and serve the same as claret-cup No.
10136-8{_}24541{_}1831.
10136-8{_}24542{_}Should the above proportion of sugar not be found sufficient to suit some tastes, increase the quantity.
10136-8{_}24543{_}When borage is not easily obtainable, substitute for it a few slices of cucumber-rind.
10136-8{_}24544{_}_Seasonable_.--Suitable for pic-nics, balls, weddings, and other festive occasions.
10136-8{_}24545{_}CHAMPAGNE.--This, the most celebrated of French wines, is the     produce chiefly of the province of that name, and is generally     understood in England to be a brisk, effervescing, or sparkling     white wine, of a very fine flavour; but this is only one of the     varieties of this class.
10136-8{_}24546{_}There is both red and white champagne,     and each of these may be either still or brisk.
10136-8{_}24547{_}There are the     sparkling wines (mousseux), and the still wines (non-mousseux).
10136-8{_}24548{_}The brisk are in general the most highly esteemed, or, at least,     are the most popular in this country, on account of their     delicate flavour and the agreeable pungency which they derive     from the carbonic acid they contain, and to which they owe their     briskness.
10136-8{_}24549{_}GINGER BEER.
10136-8{_}24550{_}1833.
10136-8{_}24551{_}INGREDIENTS.--2-1/2 lbs.
10136-8{_}24552{_}of loaf sugar, 1-1/2 oz.
10136-8{_}24553{_}of bruised ginger, 1 oz.
10136-8{_}24554{_}of cream of tartar, the rind and juice of 2 lemons, 3 gallons of boiling water, 2 large tablespoonfuls of thick and fresh brewer's yeast.
10136-8{_}24555{_}_Mode_.--Peel the lemons, squeeze the juice, strain it, and put the peel and juice into a large earthen pan, with the bruised ginger, cream of tartar, and loaf sugar.
10136-8{_}24556{_}Pour over these ingredients 3 gallons of boiling water; let it stand until just warm, when add the yeast, which should be thick and perfectly fresh.
10136-8{_}24557{_}Stir the contents of the pan well, and let them remain near the fire all night, covering the pan over with a cloth.
10136-8{_}24558{_}The next day skim off the yeast, and pour the liquor carefully into another vessel, leaving the sediment; then bottle immediately, and tie the corks down, and in 3 days the ginger beer will be fit for use.
10136-8{_}24559{_}For some tastes, the above proportion of sugar may be found rather too large, when it may be diminished; but the beer will not keep so long good.
10136-8{_}24560{_}_Average cost_ for this quantity, 2s.
10136-8{_}24561{_}; or 1/2d.
10136-8{_}24562{_}per bottle.
10136-8{_}24563{_}_Sufficient_ to fill 4 dozen ginger-beer bottles.
10136-8{_}24564{_}_Seasonable_.--This should be made during the summer months.
10136-8{_}24565{_}LEMONADE.
10136-8{_}24566{_}1834.
10136-8{_}24567{_}INGREDIENTS--The rind of 2 lemons, the juice of 3 large or 4 small ones, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}24568{_}of loaf sugar, 1 quart of boiling water.
10136-8{_}24569{_}_Mode_.--Rub some of the sugar, in lumps, on 2 of the lemons until they have imbibed all the oil from them, and put it with the remainder of the sugar into a jug; add the lemon-juice (but no pips), and pour over the whole a quart of boiling water.
10136-8{_}24570{_}When the sugar is dissolved, strain the lemonade through a fine sieve or piece of muslin, and, when cool, it will be ready for use.
10136-8{_}24571{_}The lemonade will be much improved by having the white of an egg beaten up in it; a little sherry mixed with it, also, makes this beverage much nicer.
10136-8{_}24572{_}_Average cost_, 6d.
10136-8{_}24573{_}per quart.
10136-8{_}24574{_}LEMONADE--"There is a current opinion among women" says Brillat     Savarin "which every year causes the death of many young     women,--that acids, especially vinegar, are preventives of     obesity.
10136-8{_}24575{_}Beyond all doubt, acids have the effect of destroying     obesity; but they also destroy health and freshness.
10136-8{_}24576{_}Lemonade     is, of all acids, the most harmless; but few stomachs can resist     it long.
10136-8{_}24577{_}I knew, in 1776, at Dijon, a young lady of great     beauty, to whom I was attached by bonds of friendship, great,     almost as those of love.
10136-8{_}24578{_}One day, when she had for some time     gradually grown pale and thin (previously she had a slight     embonpoint), she told me in confidence, that as her young     friends had ridiculed her for being fat, she had, to counteract     the tendency, been in the habit every day of drinking a large     glass of vinaigre.
10136-8{_}24579{_}She died at eighteen years of age, from the     effects of these potions."
10136-8{_}24580{_}TO MAKE NEGUS.
10136-8{_}24581{_}1835.
10136-8{_}24582{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every pint of port wine allow 1 quart of boiling water, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}24583{_}of sugar, 1 lemon, grated nutmeg to taste.
10136-8{_}24584{_}_Mode_.--As this beverage is more usually drunk at children's parties than at any other, the wine need not be very old or expensive for the purpose, a new fruity wine answering very well for it.
10136-8{_}24585{_}Put the wine into a jug, rub some lumps of sugar (equal to 1/4 lb.)
10136-8{_}24586{_}on the lemon-rind until all the yellow part of the skin is absorbed, then squeeze the juice, and strain it.
10136-8{_}24587{_}Add the sugar and lemon-juice to the port wine, with the grated nutmeg; pour over it the boiling water, cover the jug, and, when the beverage has cooled a little, it will be fit for use.
10136-8{_}24588{_}Negus may also be made of sherry, or any other sweet white wine, but is more usually made of port than of any other beverage.
10136-8{_}24589{_}_Sufficient_--Allow 1 pint of wine, with the other ingredients in proportion, for a party of 9 or 10 children.
10136-8{_}24590{_}A PLEASANT DRINK FOR WARM WEATHER.
10136-8{_}24591{_}1836.
10136-8{_}24592{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every 1-1/2 pint of good ale allow 1 bottle of ginger beer.
10136-8{_}24593{_}_Mode_.--For this beverage the ginger beer must be in an effervescing state, and the beer not in the least turned or sour.
10136-8{_}24594{_}Mix them together, and drink immediately.
10136-8{_}24595{_}The draught is refreshing and wholesome, as the ginger corrects the action of the beer.
10136-8{_}24596{_}It does not deteriorate by standing a little, but, of course, is better when taken fresh.
10136-8{_}24597{_}FOR A SUMMER DRAUGHT.
10136-8{_}24598{_}1837.
10136-8{_}24599{_}INGREDIENTS.--The juice of 1 lemon, a tumbler-ful of cold water, pounded sugar to taste, 4 small teaspoonful of carbonate of soda.
10136-8{_}24600{_}_Mode_.--Squeeze the juice from the lemon; strain, and add it to the water, with sufficient pounded sugar to sweeten the whole nicely.
10136-8{_}24601{_}When well mixed, put in the soda, stir well, and drink while the mixture is in an effervescing state.
10136-8{_}24602{_}TO MULL WINE.
10136-8{_}24603{_}1838.
10136-8{_}24604{_}INGREDIENTS.--To every pint of wine allow 1 large cupful of water, sugar and spice to taste.
10136-8{_}24605{_}_Mode_.--In making preparations like the above, it is very difficult to give the exact proportions of ingredients like sugar and spice, as what quantity might suit one person would be to another quite distasteful.
10136-8{_}24606{_}Boil the spice in the water until the flavour is extracted, then add the wine and sugar, and bring the whole to the boiling-point, when serve with strips of crisp dry toast, or with biscuits.
10136-8{_}24607{_}The spices usually used for mulled wine are cloves, grated nutmeg, and cinnamon or mace.
10136-8{_}24608{_}Any kind of wine may be mulled, but port and claret are those usually selected for the purpose; and the latter requires a very large proportion of sugar.
10136-8{_}24609{_}The vessel that the wine is boiled in must be delicately clean, and should be kept exclusively for the purpose.
10136-8{_}24610{_}Small tin warmers may be purchased for a trifle, which are more suitable than saucepans, as, if the latter are not scrupulously clean, they will spoil the wine, by imparting to it a very disagreeable flavour.
10136-8{_}24611{_}These warmers should be used for no other purposes.
10136-8{_}24612{_}TO MAKE HOT PUNCH.
10136-8{_}24613{_}1839.
10136-8{_}24614{_}INGREDIENTS.--1/2 pint of rum, 1/2 pint of brandy, 1/4 lb.
10136-8{_}24615{_}of sugar, 1 large lemon, 1/2 teaspoonful of nutmeg, 1 pint of boiling water.
10136-8{_}24616{_}[Illustration: PUNCH-BOWL AND LADLE.]
10136-8{_}24617{_}_Mode_.--Rub the sugar over the lemon until it has absorbed all the yellow part of the skin, then put the sugar into a punchbowl; add the lemon-juice (free from pips), and mix these two ingredients well together.
10136-8{_}24618{_}Pour over them the boiling water, stir well together, add the rum, brandy, and nutmeg; mix thoroughly, and the punch will be ready to serve.
10136-8{_}24619{_}It is very important in making good punch that all the ingredients are thoroughly incorporated; and, to insure success, the processes of mixing must be diligently attended to.
10136-8{_}24620{_}_Sufficient_.--Allow a quart for 4 persons; but this information must be taken _cum grano salis_; for the capacities of persons for this kind of beverage are generally supposed to vary considerably.
10136-8{_}24621{_}PUNCH is a beverage made of various spirituous liquors or wine,     hot water, the acid juice of fruits, and sugar.
10136-8{_}24622{_}It is considered     to be very intoxicating; but this is probably because the     spirit, being partly sheathed by the mucilaginous juice and the     sugar, its strength does not appear to the taste so great as it     really is.
10136-8{_}24623{_}Punch, which was almost universally drunk among the     middle classes about fifty or sixty years ago, has almost     disappeared from our domestic tables, being superseded by wine.
10136-8{_}24624{_}There are many different varieties of punch.
10136-8{_}24625{_}It is sometimes     kept cold in bottles, and makes a most agreeable summer drink.
10136-8{_}24626{_}In Scotland, instead of the Madeira or sherry generally used in     its manufacture, whiskey is substituted, and then its insidious     properties are more than usually felt.
10136-8{_}24627{_}Where fresh lemons cannot     be had for punch or similar beverages, crystallized citric acid     and a few drops of the essence of lemon will be very nearly the     same thing.
10136-8{_}24628{_}In the composition of "Regent's punch," champagne,     brandy, and _veritable Martinique_ are required; "Norfolk punch"     requires Seville oranges; "Milk punch" may be extemporized by     adding a little hot milk to lemonade, and then straining it     through a jelly-bag.
10136-8{_}24629{_}Then there are "Wine punch," "Tea punch,"     and "French punch," made with lemons, spirits, and wine, in     fantastic proportions.
10136-8{_}24630{_}But of all the compounds of these     materials, perhaps, for a _summer_ drink, the North-American     "mint julep" is the most inviting.
10136-8{_}24631{_}Captain Marryat gives the     following recipe for its preparation:--"Put into a tumbler about     a dozen sprigs of the tender shoots of mint; upon them put a     spoonful of white sugar, and equal proportions of peach and     common brandy, so as to fill up one third, or, perhaps, a little     less; then take rasped or pounded ice, and fill up the tumbler.
10136-8{_}24632{_}Epicures rub the lips of the tumbler with a piece of fresh     pineapple; and the tumbler itself is very often encrusted     outside with stalactites of ice.
10136-8{_}24633{_}As the ice melts, you drink."
10136-8{_}24634{_}The Virginians, say Captain Marryat, claim the merit of having     invented this superb compound; but, from a passage in the     "Comus" of Milton, he claims it for his own country.
10136-8{_}24635{_}WHISKEY CORDIAL.
10136-8{_}24636{_}1840.
10136-8{_}24637{_}INGREDIENTS.--1 lb.
10136-8{_}24638{_}of ripe white currants, the rind of 2 lemons, 1/4 oz.
10136-8{_}24639{_}of grated ginger, 1 quart of whiskey, 1 lb.
10136-8{_}24640{_}of lump sugar.
10136-8{_}24641{_}_Mode_.--Strip the currants from the stalks; put them into a large jug; add the lemon-rind, ginger, and whiskey; cover the jug closely, and let it remain covered for 24 hours.
10136-8{_}24642{_}Strain through a hair sieve, add the lump sugar, and let it stand 12 hours longer; then bottle, and cork well.
10136-8{_}24643{_}_Time_.--To stand 24 hours before being strained; 12 hours after the sugar is added.
10136-8{_}24644{_}_Seasonable_.--Make this in July.
10136-8{_}24645{_}[Illustration]     INVALID COOKERY.
10136-8{_}24646{_}CHAPTER XXXVIII.
10136-8{_}24647{_}A FEW RULES TO BE OBSERVED IN COOKING FOR INVALIDS.
10136-8{_}24648{_}1841.
10136-8{_}24649{_}LET all the kitchen utensils used in the preparation of invalids' cookery be delicately and 'scrupulously clean;' if this is not the case, a disagreeable flavour may be imparted to the preparation, which flavour may disgust, and prevent the patient from partaking of the refreshment when brought to him or her.
10136-8{_}24650{_}1842.
10136-8{_}24651{_}For invalids, never make a large quantity of one thing, as they seldom require much at a time; and it is desirable that variety be provided for them.
10136-8{_}24652{_}1843.
10136-8{_}24653{_}Always have something in readiness; a little beef tea, nicely made and nicely skimmed, a few spoonfuls of jelly, &c. &c., that it may be administered as soon almost as the invalid wishes for it.
10136-8{_}24654{_}If obliged to wait a long time, the patient loses the desire to eat, and often turns against the food when brought to him or her.
10136-8{_}24655{_}1844.
10136-8{_}24656{_}In sending dishes or preparations up to invalids, let everything look as tempting as possible.
10136-8{_}24657{_}Have a clean tray-cloth laid smoothly over the tray; let the spoons, tumblers, cups and saucers, &c., be very clean and bright.
10136-8{_}24658{_}Gruel served in a tumbler is more appetizing than when served in a basin or cup and saucer.
10136-8{_}24659{_}1845.
10136-8{_}24660{_}As milk is an important article of food for the sick, in warm weather let it be kept on ice, to prevent its turning sour.
10136-8{_}24661{_}Many other delicacies may also be preserved good in the same manner for some little time.
10136-8{_}24662{_}1846.
10136-8{_}24663{_}If the patient be allowed to eat vegetables, never send them up undercooked, or half raw; and let a small quantity only be temptingly arranged on a dish.
10136-8{_}24664{_}This rule will apply to every preparation, as an invalid is much more likely to enjoy his food if small delicate pieces are served to him.
10136-8{_}24665{_}1847.
10136-8{_}24666{_}Never leave food about a sick room; if the patient cannot eat it when brought to him, take it away, and bring it to him in an hour or two's time.
10136-8{_}24667{_}Miss Nightingale says, "To leave the patient's untasted food by his side, from meal to meal, in hopes that he will eat it in the interval, is simply to prevent him from taking any food at all."
10136-8{_}24668{_}She says, "I have known patients literally incapacitated from taking one article of food after another by this piece of ignorance.
10136-8{_}24669{_}Let the food come at the right time, and be taken away, eaten or uneaten, at the right time, but never let a patient have 'something always standing' by him, if you don't wish to disgust him of everything."
10136-8{_}24670{_}1848.
10136-8{_}24671{_}Never serve beef tea or broth with the _smallest particle_ of fat or grease on the surface.
10136-8{_}24672{_}It is better, after making either of these, to allow them to get perfectly cold, when _all the fat_ may be easily removed; then warm up as much as may be required.
10136-8{_}24673{_}Two or three pieces of clean whity-brown paper laid on the broth will absorb any greasy particles that may be floating at the top, as the grease will cling to the paper.
10136-8{_}24674{_}1849.
10136-8{_}24675{_}Roast mutton, chickens, rabbits, calves' feet or head, game, fish (simply dressed), and simple puddings, are all light food, and easily digested.
10136-8{_}24676{_}Of course, these things are only partaken of, supposing the patient is recovering.
10136-8{_}24677{_}1850.
10136-8{_}24678{_}A mutton chop, nicely cut, trimmed, and broiled to a turn, is a dish to be recommended for invalids; but it must not be served _with all the fat_ at the end, nor must it be too thickly cut.
10136-8{_}24679{_}Let it be cooked over a fire free from smoke, and sent up with the gravy in it, between two very hot plates.
10136-8{_}24680{_}Nothing is more disagreeable to an invalid than _smoked_ food.
10136-8{_}24681{_}1851.
10136-8{_}24682{_}In making toast-and-water, never blacken the bread, but toast it only a nice brown.
10136-8{_}24683{_}Never leave toast-and-water to make until the moment it is required, as it cannot then be properly prepared,--at least, the patient will be obliged to drink it warm, which is anything but agreeable.
10136-8{_}24684{_}1852.
10136-8{_}24685{_}In boiling eggs for invalids, let the white be just set; if boiled hard, they will be likely to disagree with the patient.
10136-8{_}24686{_}1853.
10136-8{_}24687{_}In Miss Nightingale's admirable "Notes on Nursing," a book that no mother or nurse should be without, she says,--"You cannot be too careful as to quality in sick diet.
10136-8{_}24688{_}A nurse should never put before a patient milk that is sour, meat or soup that is turned, an egg that is bad, or vegetables underdone."
10136-8{_}24689{_}Yet often, she says, she has seen these things brought in to the sick, in a state perfectly perceptible to every nose or eye except the nurse's.
10136-8{_}24690{_}It is here that the clever nurse appears,--she will not bring in the peccant article; but, not to disappoint the patient, she will whip up something else in a few minutes.
10136-8{_}24691{_}Remember, that sick cookery should half do the work of your poor patient's weak digestion.
10136-8{_}24692{_}1854.
10136-8{_}24693{_}She goes on to caution nurses, by saying,--"Take care not to spill into your patient's saucer; in other words, take care that the outside bottom rim of his cup shall be quite dry and clean.
10136-8{_}24694{_}If, every time he lifts his cup to his lips, he has to carry the saucer with it, or else to drop the liquid upon and to soil his sheet, or bedgown, or pillow, or, if he is sitting up, his dress, you have no idea what a difference this minute want of care on your part makes to his comfort, and even to his willingness for food."
10136-8{_}24695{_}RECIPES.
10136-8{_}24696{_}CHAPTER XXXIX.
10136-8{_}24697{_}TO MAKE ARROWROOT.
10136-8{_}24698{_}1855.
10136-8{_}24699{_}INGREDIENTS.--Two teaspoonfuls of arrowroot, 3 tablespoonfuls of cold water, 1/2 pint of boiling water.
10136-8{_}24700{_}_Mode_.--Mix the arrowroot smoothly in a basin with the cold water, then pour on it the _boiling_ water, _stirring_ all the time.
10136-8{_}24701{_}The water must be _boiling_ at the time it is poured on the mixture, or it will not thicken; if mixed with hot water only, it must be put into a clean saucepan, and boiled until it thickens; but this is more trouble, and quite unnecessary if the water is boiling at first.
10136-8{_}24702{_}Put the arrowroot into a tumbler, sweeten it with lump sugar, and flavour it with grated nutmeg or cinnamon, or a piece of lemon-peel, or, when allowed, 3 tablespoonfuls of port or sherry.
10136-8{_}24703{_}As arrowroot is in itself flavourless and insipid, it is almost necessary to add the wine to make it palatable.
10136-8{_}24704{_}Arrowroot made with milk instead of water is far nicer, but is not so easily digested.
10136-8{_}24705{_}It should be mixed in the same manner, with 3 tablespoonfuls of cold water, the boiling milk then poured on it, and well stirred.
10136-8{_}24706{_}When made in this manner, no wine should be added, but merely sugar, and a little grated nutmeg or lemon-peel.
10136-8{_}24707{_}_Time_.--If obliged to be boiled, 2 minutes.
10136-8{_}24708{_}_Average cost_, 2d.
